headline: Bancrofts Agree to Meet with Murdoch
text: Is this the beginning of the end of an independent Dow Jones & Company?

headline: Giambi Gives In to the Pain
text: It’s always interesting to read the comments on this and other Yankees blogs. Many fans make terrific points. But one thing people sometimes say is that the Yankees simply don’t try hard enough, or they’re content to collect their big paychecks and lose.

headline: Topic A, for Abduction
text: I was going to move on this week and write a column about end-of-school-year dyspepsia, but your answers to last week’s post have been so voluminous and so passionate that I don’t feel ready to let that topic – the response to Madeleine McCann’s abduction – go just yet. You will note the phrasing: the topic here (as last week) is “the response to Madeleine McCann’s abduction,” not the abduction itself.

headline: Congress Wants to Define Exactly What Abusive Tax Shelters Are
text: The tax shelter business is under attack.

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: Ruling Favors Developer’s Plan for Vacant East Village School
text: After nine years of battling community activists and the city, a developer has won a round in his effort to redevelop a vacant, crumbling school building on the Lower East Side.

headline: Wie’s Day Ends With Wrong Kind of Buzz
text: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C., May 31 — Michelle Wie winced as she watched her tee shot soar out of bounds on an uncomplicated par 5 at the Ginn Tribute on Thursday morning. She was trying to salvage a disastrous round, her first in a tournament since January. She had already sprayed shots into the woods, fished others out of the tall swooping grass that grows in the swamp here and annoyed her playing partners when her father spoke to her during a previous calamitous hole.

headline: Teacher’s Novel, and Its Aftermath, Stir Up a Bronx School
text: A furor has erupted at a New York City private high school over a history teacher’s satirical novel, his impending departure and, now, accusations that administrators barred the student newspaper from publishing a letter by prominent historians and scholars who had come to the teacher’s defense.

headline: Top Lawyer, Under Fire, May Depart
text: William S. Lerach, one of the most powerful securities class-action lawyers in the nation, is considering plans to leave the law firm he founded three years ago.

headline: Civil War and Civil Ways
text: The Museum of the Confederacy (1201 East Clay Street; 804-649-1861) and the adjacent Confederate White House (joint ticket, $11) are open in summer from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Monday through Saturday and from noon to 5 p.m. Sunday. The American Civil War Center (500 Tredegar Street; 804-780-1865; $8) and the visitors center of the Richmond National Battlefield Park (804-226-1981; admission free), on the same grounds, are open from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. daily. Parking is also available there for Belle Isle.

headline: Genome of DNA Discoverer Is Deciphered
text: The full genome of James D. Watson, who jointly discovered the structure of DNA in 1953, has been deciphered, marking what some scientists believe is the gateway to an impending era of personalized genomic medicine.

headline: One Place Where Obama Goes Elbow to Elbow
text: Last Christmas, Senator Barack Obama flew to Hawaii to contemplate a presidential bid in the peace of his childhood home. But there, on a humid playground near Waikiki Beach, he found himself being roughed up by some of his best friends. It was the third and final game of the group’s annual three-on-three basketball showdown, and with the score nearly tied, things were getting dirty.

headline: Tragedy, Too, Is in the Eye of the Beholder
text: Love is blind, and so too is Linda Pugach, one of the loony-tuners in the somewhat sickening, mildly gonzo documentary “Crazy Love.” In 1959, when she was 22, and known as Linda Riss, Mrs. Pugach opened the door of her Bronx apartment to a thug who claimed to have an engagement present for her and instead threw liquid lye in her face. Screaming tabloid headlines ensued, along with a sensational trial, a suicide attempt, an insanity diagnosis and finally the conviction of a jilted boyfriend, Burton Pugach, a Bronx lawyer turned Bellevue-certified nut job, who after the assault promised to buy Ms. Riss a seeing-eye dog for Christmas. Fifteen years later they were married. Crazy love? Try demented.

headline: Trenton: State Exceeds Insurance Goal
text: New Jersey has surpassed its goal of enrolling an additional 50,000 children in the state’s health insurance program by July, state officials said yesterday. Jennifer Velez, the acting human services commissioner, said 96,000 additional children had enrolled in the program since Gov. Jon S. Corzine announced the goal in February 2006. The program, NJ FamilyCare, provides free or low-cost health insurance to people, depending on their income. Currently, 536,102 children and 163,303 adults are covered.

headline: Ambush Kills 16 Policemen on Highway in Afghanistan
text: JALALABAD, Afghanistan, May 31  Sixteen Afghan policemen were killed and six more wounded in an ambush Thursday morning on the main road that runs from the capital to the southern city of Kandahar.

headline: Columbia Settles Student Loan Case
text: Columbia University will pay $1.1 million to a fund to educate students about loans and has agreed to have its financial aid office monitored by state officials for five years, under a settlement that New York State Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced yesterday.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Revisiting a Composer’s Distinct Experiments in Sound
text: In the years surrounding 1970 Krzysztof Penderecki and George Crumb were very much in the musical news. The first composer was Polish, and the second, American, and each had found something new to say in a classical music world that thrived on the old.

headline: New Hampshire Adopts Same-Sex Unions
text: BOSTON, May 31 — Civil unions for same-sex couples in New Hampshire will be legal starting in January under a bill signed into law Thursday by Gov. John Lynch.

headline: Hard-Won Garbage Plan Runs Into Trouble in Albany
text: It seemed like a political milestone of sorts. After two years of squabbling, the City Council and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg reached an agreement last year to overhaul the way the city disposes of garbage.

headline: Inspired by a Modern Marvel: Insurance
text: THE latest in a long line of New York State insurance superintendents — there were 38 before him, one of whom, Neil D. Levin, went on to run the Port Authority and perished at ground zero — Eric R. Dinallo is blessed with the sustainable energy peculiar to public servants genuinely convinced of their indispensability to the public good.

headline: Wachovia in Deal to Acquire A.G. Edwards
text: When the brokerage business was populated by dozens of small companies, three firms in St. Louis made the city the industry’s biggest center west of Wall Street. Now, only two remain independent.

headline: Estonia: Settlements in S.E.C. Case
text: An investment bank in Estonia, Lohmus Haavel & Viisemann, and a former worker agreed to pay $15 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission allegations that they had made illegal trades based on information from stolen news releases. The former employee, Oliver Peek, will forfeit $13 million in profit and will pay a $1.35 million fine. The bank will pay a $650,000 penalty, the S.E.C. said. They neither admitted nor denied wrongdoing in agreeing to the sanctions. The S.E.C.’s lawsuit accused Lohmus Haavel, which is based in Tallinn, of using a computer program to retrieve information on more than 200 United States companies from Business Wire’s secure Web site before announcements were made public from January to November 2005.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A chart on Sunday about occupations in which illegal immigrants account for a large proportion of all workers misstated the size of the civilian labor force in 2005. It was 148.6 million, not 48.6 million.

headline: Be Our Guests
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Senate Panel Questions C.I.A. Detentions
text: WASHINGTON, May 31 — The Senate Intelligence Committee on Thursday questioned the continuing value of the Central Intelligence Agency’s secret interrogation program for terrorism suspects, suggesting that international condemnation and the obstacles it has created to criminal prosecution may outweigh its worth in gathering information.

headline: India: Expansion at Two-Decade High
text: India’s economy grew at the fastest rate in almost 20 years in its last fiscal year as companies lifted production to meet surging consumer demand. The economy expanded 9.4 percent in the year, which ended March 31, the biggest gain since 1989 and more than the government’s initial estimate of 9.2 percent, the Central Statistical Organization said. India’s economy grew 9.1 percent in the three months to March 31, according to the report, averaging a quarterly pace of 8.8 percent in the last two years compared with 5.7 percent in the 1990s. Manufacturing gained 12.4 percent while mining rose 7.1 percent and electricity output climbed 6.9 percent in the quarter. Agriculture, which accounts for a fifth of the economy, grew 3.8 percent.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A listing on the Calendar page in the Westchester section on Sunday for a tour and program tomorrow, “Afternoon Tea with Mrs. Dyckman,” at the Boscobel Restoration in Garrison, N.Y., misstated the telephone number for information. It is 845-265-3638.

headline: Big, Gritty Chongqing, City of 12 Million, Is China’s Model for Future
text: CHONGQING, China — Stand in the right spot in this gigantic city and hills draped with apartment complexes can remind you of Hong Kong, the density of habitation will recall Tokyo and the river-spanning brawn, replete with an immense new structure over the Yangtze that echoes the Brooklyn Bridge, might recall New York.

headline: Mickelson Drops Out of Memorial With Injured Wrist
text: DUBLIN, Ohio, May 31  Phil Mickelson withdrew from the first round of the Memorial Tournament at Muirfield Village Golf Club on Thursday with an injured left wrist, two weeks before the start of the United States Open.

headline: Sunni Fighters Battle Al Qaeda in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD, June 1 — After several days of fierce skirmishes between Al Qaeda and other Sunni fighters in the insurgent-dominated Amariyah neighborhood of western Baghdad, terrified residents on Friday holed up in their homes and said Iraqi and American forces drove through the streets warning them not to come outside.

headline: In Casting for President, Will Actor Rate a Callback?
text: When the movie mogul Jack Warner heard that Ronald Reagan was running for governor of California in 1966, he was dismayed. “Jimmy Stewart for governor,” he said. “Ronald Reagan for best friend.”

headline: Bush Proposes Goals on Greenhouse Gas Emissions
text: WASHINGTON, May 31 — President Bush, fending off international accusations that he was ignoring climate change, proposed for the first time on Thursday to set “a long-term global goal” for cutting greenhouse gas emissions, and he called on other high-polluting nations to join the United States in negotiations aimed at reaching an agreement by the end of next year.

headline: A Back Door for Terrorists
text: AMID all of the xenophobia and nativism surrounding the immigration debate, there is a real security concern. In the language of the bureaucracy, the problem is referred to as the “O.T.M.’s,” or Other Than Mexicans.

headline: Rockets Fray Nerves in Israeli ‘Bull’s-Eye’ City
text: SDEROT, Israel, May 29 — Kobi Cohen was 2 years old when a Qassam rocket fired by Palestinians from the Gaza Strip exploded 50 yards from him. Now 5, a skinny boy with an impish face, Kobi still shows signs of trauma. He had some therapy at the time, said his mother, Hanna Cohen, but she is not sure how effective it was.

headline: Chief Says G.E. Aims to Match the Growth Pace Set by India
text: NEW DELHI, May 31 — Pressure to slim General Electric’s corporate portfolio at home has not stopped Jeffrey R. Immelt’s aggressive plans for expanding in emerging markets.

headline: Art in Review
text: PICASSO, BRAQUE And Early Film in Cubism PaceWildenstein 32 East 57th Street, Manhattan  Through June 23

headline: Mideast Meeting May Take Place in Palestinian Area
text: JERUSALEM, May 31  The meeting planned for next week between the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, and Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel is expected to take place in the Palestinian territories for the first time, aides said Thursday.

headline: Court Says New Jersey Official Was Wrong to Permit Angioplasties
text: TRENTON, May 31  The New Jersey health commissioner erred in 2005 when he allowed nine hospitals without cardiac surgery units to perform elective angioplasty, the State Supreme Court ruled Thursday.

headline: Iran Seen to Make Concession in Nuclear Talks
text: MADRID, June 1 — Iran’s nuclear negotiator has promised to give the United Nations nuclear monitoring agency answers to longstanding questions about suspicious nuclear activity, a European official said today.

headline: The Real Al Gore (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Dell Reports Better-Than-Expected Profit
text: Dell said yesterday that it would lay off 10 percent of its 88,100 employees over the next 12 months as it tries to increase profit. The computer maker also said that lower component costs and higher selling prices helped it produce stronger-than-expected earnings in its first quarter.

headline: Enough Space for Me and My Sailboard
text: JUST off Oak Street, the main drag of Hood River, Ore., there’s a block of multistory town houses, each with an ordinary-looking garage door at street level. But look close, and you’ll notice something odd. There are no accompanying curb cuts — no breaks in the concrete at the street to allow driving in.

headline: Top Bush Aide Is Leaving White House
text: WASHINGTON, June 1 — Dan Bartlett, counselor to President Bush and his longest-serving aide, is leaving the administration to spend more time with his family, the White House announced today.

headline: Rodriguez Keeps Straddling Baseball’s Foul Line
text: It was clever or childish, cunning gamesmanship or borderline cheating, or maybe something in between. But when Alex Rodriguez of the Yankees shouted something to a Toronto Blue Jays infielder Wednesday night, helping cause a pop-up to drop and leading to three runs, the debate began.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: In Cajun Country, a Fight to the Finish
text: THE two fighters cradle their birds on either side of the dirt pit. The roosters peck sharply at the air, their instincts revved for combat. But before the referee starts the first match of the night, he grabs a microphone and addresses the 200 or so spectators.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Faith, Reason and a G.O.P. Hopeful (8 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Agencies and Networks Ponder Nielsen Ad Ratings
text: THE NIELSEN COMPANY, long the arbiter of television viewership, released standardized ratings of commercials yesterday, giving advertisers more information about how often viewers stay tuned during commercial breaks.

headline: Ancient Aboriginal Tales, Parallel Across Epochs
text: “I came from a water hole,” declares the wise, slyly humorous Storyteller, who narrates “Ten Canoes,” Rolf de Heer’s mesmerizing film of Australian Aboriginal life many centuries ago. As he muses on birth, death and reincarnation in tribal mythology, and goes on to relate an ancient, rambling fable in which a young man learns patience, the cycle of human life is indivisible from the rhythms of the natural world.

headline: Manhattan: Man Denies Raping Student
text: An ex-convict pleaded not guilty yesterday to raping and torturing a Columbia University graduate student in her Hamilton Heights apartment in April. The suspect, Robert A. Williams, 30, was arraigned in State Supreme Court on attempted murder, rape, kidnapping, sexual assault and other charges. Police have said that Mr. Williams, who served eight years in prison for attempted murder, tied the 23-year-old woman to her bed, raped and sodomized her, slit her eyelids and poured bleach and scalding water over her. During his arraignment, Mr. Williams was watched over by about 20 court officers. A prosecutor said he had been found concealing two razor blades on May 21, the day before he was scheduled to be in a lineup.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article last Friday about fund-raising efforts for historic cemeteries, including one where some Titanic passengers are buried, referred incorrectly to the victims of the Titanic. About 1,500 passengers died  not 2,200, which was the approximate number on board.

headline: BHP Billiton Selects a Chief Executive
text: BHP Billiton, the mining company, chose the head of its copper and aluminum division, Marius Kloppers, to succeed its American chief executive, Charles W. Goodyear, when Mr. Goodyear steps down Oct. 1. Mr. Goodyear has overseen a wave of record-setting earnings since taking charge of the company in 2003 as the company benefited from a China-led boom in demand for iron and other metals. But in the last two years, soaring prices for copper have fueled BHP’s results. Mr. Kloppers, a 44-year-old South African, played a crucial role in BHP’s merger with Billiton in 2001 and in the $7.6 billion takeover of WMC Resources in 2005.

headline: Overshadowed Spurs Are Rarely Overmatched
text: SAN ANTONIO, May 31 — In a mildly crowded, modestly happy locker room Wednesday night, R. C. Buford traded smiles and handshakes, soaking in the San Antonio Spurs’ fourth Western Conference title in nine years. Then Buford, the low-profile general manager of the N.B.A.’s low-key dynasty, spotted a reporter for a certain 24-hour sports network.

headline: If Adventure Is the Topic, the Talk Isn’t Cheap
text: THE 19th-century British explorer Richard Burton once said that the reason he tempted death in searching for the source of the Nile or by penetrating the inner reaches of Arabia disguised as a Pathan was because “the devil drives.”

headline: After Crash, No New Speeding Rule for Corzine’s Drivers
text: TRENTON, May 31  Acknowledging that Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s recent near-fatal crash occurred as a trooper drove their S.U.V. at 91 miles per hour in a 65 m.p.h. zone, the New Jersey State Police superintendent said Thursday that the governor’s drivers would still not be prohibited from speeding in non-emergency situations.

headline: Wal-Mart Scales Back Expansion Plans
text: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., June 1 — The world’s biggest retailer is slowing down. Again.

headline: What Mexico Wants
text: Mexico City

headline: William Meredith, 88, Poet Who Wed Depth to Form, Dies
text: William Meredith, a Pulitzer Prize-winning poet who used the rigorous constraints of meter and rhyme to subdue some of the most uncontrollable aspects of the human condition  fear, loneliness, destiny, mortality  died Wednesday in New London, Conn. He was 88 and had homes in Uncasville, Conn., and West Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: Administration Rebukes Putin on His Policies
text: WASHINGTON, May 31 — A top Russia expert at the State Department issued an unusually sharp public criticism on Thursday of Moscow’s behavior under President Vladimir V. Putin, describing the Kremlin as bullying its neighbors while silencing political opponents and suppressing individual rights at home.

headline: What Seller Wants a Low Price?
text: Can you imagine an auction house bragging to sellers about the low prices at its auctions? Perhaps this would be the pitch:

headline: Now Batting for the Yankees, Lindsay Lohan
text: Now Alex Rodriguez knows what is like to be Lindsay Lohan, a serial mainstay of celebrity culture. There he was Wednesday on the front page of The New York Post, pictured in a Toronto hotel with a woman, who, as the tabloid noted, was not his wife. “STRAY-ROD,” read the perfect headline.

headline: Richmond’s Old South Roots Are Never Far Away
text: YOU don't have to go that far south to find the South. Richmond, a mere two hours from Washington, has a magnolia-and-veranda-swing appeal that is worlds apart from anything even a little farther north. And notwithstanding its ties and testimonies to Robert E. Lee and other heroes of a long-lost world, Richmond today competes with Washington, its near neighbor, in up-to-date cultural sophistication.

headline: Trenton: Republicans Demand Corzine’s E-Mail
text: New Jersey Republicans yesterday filed a lawsuit in State Superior Court charging that the Democratic governor, Jon S. Corzine, was violating the state’s Open Records Act by refusing to release e-mail messages he exchanged with his former companion, the president of a state employees union, during recent contract negotiations. Lawyers for the governor say that the e-mail messages between Mr. Corzine and Carla Katz, president of the Communications Workers of America Local 1034, are protected by gubernatorial privilege. Mr. Corzine’s lawyers also point out that a state ethics panel has reviewed the messages and concluded that the governor acted appropriately. But Mark Sheridan, a lawyer for the Republican State Committee, said the law required Mr. Corzine to disclose any correspondence that discusses the contract negotiations because they involve state business.

headline: A Wobbly Quarter for Sears and Costco
text: Sears Holdings reported profit that trailed analysts’ estimates yesterday after it lost customers to J. C. Penney and Kohl’s, while earnings at Costco Wholesale fell 4.9 percent on the cost of a new return policy.

headline: Fighting Resumes at Camp in Lebanon
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, June 1 — Under a hail of gunfire and shelling, Lebanon’s army today moved into a besieged refugee camp in northern Lebanon where a group of militants have been hiding, crossing the boundaries of the camp for the first time since the siege began two weeks ago and shrugging off warnings to stay out.

headline: Out of Africa, Eclectic Visions
text: African art has it all: beauty, brio, inventiveness, moral gravity, emotional depth, practicality, sensuality and humor. It’s hot and cool, high and low, chastening and consoling, endlessly varied, surprising always.

headline: Detour on the Scott Boras Expressway
text: FORT WORTH, May 31  For any young ballplayer who thinks he should have been drafted higher, treated better, offered more, there is a place where he can still go and get the signing bonus of his dreams.

headline: Detroit Finds Agreement on the Need to Be Green
text: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., May 31 — Labor and management in the auto industry are often at odds, but on Thursday they agreed on something critics have been telling them for years: Detroit must act to reduce its vehicles’ impact on the environment.

headline: Bush Accuses Opponents of Immigration Bill of Fear-Mongering
text: WASHINGTON, June 1 — President Bush took on opponents of immigration legislation again today, accusing some of them of fear-mongering and prodding members of Congress to act despite their worries of a backlash at home.

headline: Correction: Museum Row, for Children
text: An article last Friday, about summer weekend destinations in and near New York City, misstated the age of the Garden City Hotel in Garden City, N.Y. The hotel dates to 1983, not 1874. No part of any of the three previous Garden City Hotel buildings was used in the construction of the current building, which is in a different location on the property.

headline: Dow Jones Says It Will Consider Options for Sale
text: The family that controls Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, announced yesterday that it would consider selling the company, ending more than a century of family ownership.

headline: Education Department Issues Rules for Student Loans
text: The federal Education Department released new rules for federal student loan programs today that would require universities to include at least three lenders on any list recommended to students and that would ban many of the incentives loan companies have been offering colleges and university officials to win student business.

headline: Accolades, Some Tearful, for a Preacher in His Twilight Years
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 31 For a man who has welcomed crowds his whole life, the evangelist Billy Graham appeared humbled and a bit embarrassed to be before this one Thursday in a parking lot near the Charlotte airport.

headline: First-Quarter Revision Shows Economy at Slowest Pace Since Late 2002
text: The economy stalled this winter.

headline: The Hot List
text: These are the books mentioned in this article:

headline: A Dad Hunt That Ends in Ohio
text: On the eve of his 23rd birthday, eight years ago, Adrian Grenier, the future star of “Entourage,” set about making a documentary about fathers. Mr. Grenier had grown up in New York, the child of a single mother who had Ali MacGraw looks and flower-child ways. The man with whom he shared his DNA was either someone named John, in Ohio, or a man his mother was about to marry, a guy she had known for more than two decades.

headline: Judge Criticizes Police Dept. for Illegal Loitering Arrests
text: A federal judge sharply criticized the New York Police Department yesterday for failing to follow repeated court orders by arresting hundreds of panhandlers and beggars, but still denied a request to hold the city in contempt of court.

headline: U.S. Economic Growth Weakest in Over 4 Years
text: The government cut in half its estimate of economic growth in the first quarter, reporting the slowest rate of expansion since the end of 2002.

headline: City Considers Bigger Tax Cuts as Property Assessments Soar
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and City Council leaders are considering expanding property tax cuts that the mayor proposed in January to help property owners stave off the effects of soaring assessments, an administration official said yesterday.

headline: Strong Women Don’t Play Hanky-Panky
text: “Fate’s Imagination,” a mix of politics, sex, comedy and drama receiving its world premiere at the Players Theater, lets you know early on that it’s a gratingly uneven piece of work. That ends up being a good thing, because it frees you not to view the play as a serious piece of theater and instead sit back and enjoy its strengths: a couple of tasty plot twists and some very funny lines.

headline: Attorney General Is Called Corzine’s Pick for Top Judge
text: Gov. Jon S. Corzine plans to nominate Attorney General Stuart Rabner to be the next chief justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court, potentially leaving his imprint on the state’s legal landscape for the next two decades, administration officials said yesterday.

headline: A Growing Demand for the Rare American Imam
text: MISSION VIEJO, Calif. — Sheik Yassir Fazaga regularly uses a standard American calendar to provide inspiration for his weekly Friday sermon.

headline: Zambia: Court Says Ex-Leader Is Fit for Trial
text: Former President Frederick Chiluba is well enough to stand trial on corruption charges despite being hospitalized last week after collapsing at his home with an acute heart ailment, a judge ruled in the capital, Lusaka. Mr. Chiluba, 64, was convicted last month by a London court of embezzling $46 million while serving as president from 1991 to 2002. Zambian prosecutors have charged him with stealing nearly $500,000 during his years in office. His trial has been delayed since May 2006 because of health concerns. A Zambian magistrate, Jones Chinyama, said that Mr. Chiluba could be tried either via a video link from his home or by moving court proceedings there.

headline: Bancroft Family Statement
text: Following is the preliminary statement issued Thursday evening by the Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones & Company:

headline: My Father, Jon Corzine (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Lottery Numbers
From Mr. Masterpiece, International Odds and Ends
text: “When I die,” George Balanchine sometimes remarked, “everything masterpiece.” Twenty-four years after the death of this greatest of choreographers, it’s easy to forget that during his lifetime several of his ballets, like many major aspects of his dance style, were thoroughly controversial.

headline: Radioactivity Sensors for Russia
text: MOSCOW, May 31  The United States and Russia have agreed to accelerate a program that detects radioactive materials along Russia’s borders and plan to have automated detection systems installed at all Russian border crossing points by 2011, American energy officials said Thursday.

headline: Man of Steel
text: The Richard Serra retrospective, opening Sunday, arrives at the Museum of Modern Art virtually a foregone matter, in the way that Picasso and Matisse shows arrived in the old days. It’s a landmark, by a titan of sculpture, one of the last great modernists in an age of minor talents, mad money and so much meaningless art. At 67 Mr. Serra is still nudging the language of abstraction, constructing ever more awesome mazes of looming Cor-Ten steel.

headline: Playing to the Crowd: Talk About Warming
text: President Bush has been feeling the heat on global warming. He’s been feeling it from Congress, from state governors, from the business community and, most recently and powerfully, from America’s closest foreign allies, who are fed up with his passivity on the issue and desperate for him to show some real leadership.

headline: The Hockey Rink Is Alive ...
text: WHAT do Brad Pitt, Barack Obama and Garrison Keillor have in common? At some time in their lives, they’ve all sung in choirs. An estimated 23 million American adults are doing so now, according to a survey by Chorus America, an association of vocal ensembles. With numbers like that, it’s not hard to understand why so many people love choral music. Whether experienced from within the chorus or from the audience outside, the unique sound of music made by groups of people using their own voices has a universal appeal.

headline: Canada: Office for Native Claims Urged
text: An inquiry into the shooting death by the police of an aboriginal man during a land claim protest in 1995 called on the government to establish an independent land claims agency to settle a growing number of claims by Native Canadians. The protester, Dudley George, was shot by a police sniper during the protest in Ontario. The inquiry’s report comes as Native leaders are threatening rail blockades and occupations this summer to protest more than 1,100 unsettled claims across the country.

headline: Witchy Girls on a Mission: The Dark Side of Cliques
text: “Hex” is a study of English faces passing as a television series. There is a cruel, beautiful, tawny face with pursed lips and shifty eyes. There is a taut black face with tense temples and a hard jaw. There are many wide, white faces — some nearly livid — with asymmetrical noses and tear-streaked cheeks.

headline: Lawyers in Haditha Case Say Gunshots, Not Grenades, Killed Many Victims
text: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 31  Many of the 24 Iraqi civilians killed by Marine infantrymen in Haditha in 2005 died from close-range gunshot wounds, a military prosecutor said Thursday.

headline: Agent at Border, Aware, Let In Man With TB
text: The man with a dangerous form of tuberculosis who flew to Europe for his wedding and honeymoon was identified yesterday as a 31-year-old Atlanta lawyer. Department of Homeland Security officials said he re-entered the country from Canada when a customs agent let him pass despite knowing that the man was being sought by health authorities.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,457 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: New Jersey High Court Hands Wal-Mart a Setback
text: In a setback for Wal-Mart, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that a lawsuit claiming off-the-clock violations could proceed as a class action on behalf of nearly 80,000 current and former Wal-Mart employees.

headline: Big Investors Jumping Back Into Shaky Home Loans
text: The subprime mortgage business is in tatters: loan volume is plummeting, defaults are rising and some of the biggest lenders have cut back or shut down.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Wednesday about plans by Mike Wallace to have the first interview with Jack Kevorkian, the assisted suicide advocate, after he is released from prison in Michigan today referred incorrectly to the prison. It is a state prison, not a federal one.

headline: Suspect in Ex-Agent’s Poisoning Insists He Was Framed
text: MOSCOW, May 31 — The suspect in the fatal poisoning of Alexander V. Litvinenko, the former K.G.B. officer and Kremlin critic who died last year in Britain, said Thursday that Britain’s foreign intelligence agency and a self-exiled Russian tycoon had organized the killing and framed him to create a political scandal.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article last Friday about the families of two soldiers missing in Iraq, including Pvt. Byron W. Fouty of Waterford, Mich., misstated the timing of a telephone call Private Fouty made from Iraq in March to his former high school. He called during a rehearsal of an extracurricular play, not during class.

headline: Inches Too Tall for Tunnel, Rig Plies It Anyway
text: It was just six inches.

headline: Abuses by the N.Y.P.D. (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Jan. 21 about the presidential prospects of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton referred incorrectly to the results of a Washington Post/ABC News poll on Jan. 19. The poll found that Mrs. Clinton had the support of 41 percent of Democrats questioned, not a favorability rating of 41 percent among all respondents. (Her favorability rating among all of those questioned was 54 percent.) The error was pointed out on Wednesday in a posting on the Web site of Media Matters for America.

headline: Playing to the Crowd: A Real Plan for AIDS
text: An expected less-than-warm welcome at the Group of 8 meeting was also clearly on President Bush’s mind this week when he announced an expanded plan to combat AIDS in foreign lands. Even so, that should not obscure the real good that can be done — both in preventing and treating AIDS and in spurring a wider global fight against H.I.V., the virus that causes it.

headline: Less Circling at the Airport, at Least for Those on the Ground
text: The art of picking up people at the airport rests partly on dodging traffic police and feigning ignorance when caught waiting in no-parking zones.

headline: Search for Abducted Britons Continues Across Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD, May 31 — The search for five British civilians kidnapped from an Iraqi government building intensified Thursday with American troops conducting raids in Sadr City and the Iraqi government pledging its support for an investigation.

headline: Lo Duca Has the Versatility to Hit Anywhere in the Mets’ Lineup
text: The first person Paul Lo Duca thought of after he notched his 1,000th career hit Wednesday night was Pete Rose.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: At a Distance, Famiglietti Sees Skyscrapers, Everything
text: Anthony Famiglietti may be the fastest and most versatile distance runner the New York City area has ever produced. Tomorrow, he will run 5,000 meters at the Reebok Grand Prix on Randalls Island.

headline: U.S. Data Show Rapid Minority Growth in School Rolls
text: Driven mainly by an extraordinary influx of Hispanics, the nation’s population of minority students has surged to 42 percent of public school enrollment, up from 22 percent three decades ago, according to an annual report issued yesterday by the government.

headline: Queens: Man Charged in Fatal Bat Assault
text: A Queens man was charged yesterday with killing an elderly relative with a baseball bat after beating his own companion, prosecutors said. The man, Michael Alexander, 54, was charged with murder, manslaughter and assault, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. The police had been looking for Mr. Alexander since the beating death of Rudolph Campbell, 71, who was married to Mr. Alexander’s aunt, in June 2006 at Mr. Alexander’s Queens Village home, Mr. Brown said. The fatal beating followed an attack on Mr. Alexander’s companion, then 22, during a dispute, Mr. Brown said. Mr. Alexander was found working at a Brooklyn auto body shop after his story was broadcast last month on the television program “America’s Most Wanted,” Mr. Brown said.

headline: No Breakthrough as Iranian Nuclear Talks Recess
text: MADRID, May 31 — Talks between Iran’s nuclear negotiator and a top envoy for the European Union ended late Thursday with few signs they were closer to breaking their deadlock over Iran’s nuclear ambitions.

headline: Legislation Pushed to Require Minimum Wage for Domestic Workers
text: For years, the more than 200,000 nannies, housekeepers and other domestic workers in New York State have been exempt from many basic labor protections.

headline: Defense Team Asks Leniency From Judge in Libby Case
text: WASHINGTON, May 31  Lawyers for I. Lewis Libby Jr. urged a federal judge on Thursday to consider his long record of public service and spare him from prison on his felony conviction for his role in a C.I.A. leak investigation.

headline: Bush's Climate Plan Alters Showdown With Europe
text: FRANKFURT, June 1 — For six years, Europeans have pleaded with President Bush to seize the initiative in the campaign against global warming. Now that he has, many here are even more frustrated.

headline: Lawyer Files Bias Suit Against G.E.
text: Lorene F. Schaefer says she moved steadily up General Electric’s in-house legal ladder for 13 years, getting praise and stock grants each step along the way. She made it as far as general counsel for GE Transportation.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Jan. 21 about the presidential prospects of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton referred incorrectly to the results of a Washington Post/ABC News poll on Jan. 19. The poll found that Mrs. Clinton had the support of 41 percent of Democrats questioned, not a favorability rating of 41 percent among all respondents. (Her favorability rating among all of those questioned was 54 percent.) The error was pointed out on Wednesday in a posting on the Web site of Media Matters for America. (Go to Article)

headline: A Secular Turkish City Feels Islam’s Pulse Beating Stronger, Causing Divisions
text: DENIZLI, Turkey — The little red prayer book was handed out in a public primary school here in western Turkey in early May. It was small enough to fit in a pocket, but it carried a big message: Pray in the Muslim way. Get others to pray, too.

headline: In Opera’s Shrinking World, It Still Helps to Use Your First Language
text: The audience that packed Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night was drawn by the chance to hear two of opera’s most glamorous and charismatic stars: the soprano Anna Netrebko and the baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky, performing arias and duets with the Orchestra of St. Luke’s, Asher Fisch conducting. But the program also offered a lesson in the continuing importance of national singing styles.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on Monday about Indar Jit Rikhye, an Indian general who was a top adviser to United Nations peacekeepers, referred incompletely to the circumstances of the withdrawal overseen by General Rikhye of the United Nations Emergency Force in Gaza and the Sinai in June 1967. While he and some peacekeepers were caught in the path of Israeli forces, the Israelis were not responsible for their expulsion. Egypt had expelled the peacekeepers from Sinai and Gaza in mid-May, which Israel viewed as part of an Egyptian plan for war. General Rikhye  who was trying to appeal that expulsion  and some men remained. When Israel pre-emptively attacked Egypt in early June, starting the Six-Day War, the remaining peacekeepers were in their path.

headline: Wachovia to Buy A.G. Edwards
text: Wachovia said today that it would buy A.G. Edwards for $6.8 billion in cash and stock, forming the second-largest retail stock brokerage firm in the United States after Merrill Lynch.

headline: Minnesota’s ‘Freshwater Ocean’ Attracts a New Generation
text: THE Shore,” for most Minnesotans, is the North Shore of Lake Superior. Before Highway 61 — which is more than just a road in Bob Dylan’s mythology — was extended from Duluth to the Canadian border in the 1920s, local Scandinavian fisherman took in summer guests who traveled from the railhead in Duluth north on the postal boat.

headline: Italian Team Finds Familiar Obstacle
text: VALENCIA, Spain, May 31 — Much has changed for Francesco de Angelis, the skipper of Luna Rossa Challenge, since he made his first attempt at winning an America’s Cup.

headline: James Puts on Scoring Clinic in Overtime
text: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., May 31 — Minute after hypnotic minute, LeBron James lifted into the air, suspended in a stratosphere from where only he could see the basket. Every time his feet hit the ground a split second before his improbable jumpers hit the bottom of the net, despite Detroit Pistons defenders all over him, the Palace of Auburn Hills gasped and fell into stunned silence.

headline: Kevorkian Is Released From Prison
text: COLDWATER, Mich. — Jack Kevorkian, the former doctor and outspoken, flamboyant advocate for assisted suicide, walked out of a prison here this morning after serving eight years for second degree murder for his role in one death.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A sports article on Wednesday about the auction of letters written by the Olympic champion and football player Jim Thorpe to the woman who became his second wife misstated her surname. She was Freeda Kirkpatrick, not Fitzpatrick.

headline: Modern and Safe Play (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (Travel Channel) MOST HAUNTED LIVE USA Night-vision camera. Check. Thermal-imaging device. Check. Courage. Um, check. Karl Beattie, Yvette Fielding and David Wells (from left, above) and the rest of the spirit-sleuthing team from the British show “Most Haunted Live” travel to the United States to investigate paranormal activity at Eastern State Penitentiary, a famously haunted prison in Philadelphia, in this live seven-hour special. Viewers can log onto travelchannel.com to watch supplemental action via Web cams as the team ventures into places off-limits to the public to dredge up things that go bump in the night.

headline: Witness Protection
text: A catalog of cooperating witnesses in criminal cases is probably not what Internet pioneers had in mind when they touted the Web’s potential. But like bomb-making instructional videos on jihadi sites, it is the unfortunate reality.

headline: She Walks in Beauty Amid Elves and Evil
text: The Sleeping Beauty” is considered by many to be the highest, purest achievement of Marius Petipa, the 19th-century choreographer of “Swan Lake,” who shaped what we think of today as ballet classicism. Lincoln Kirstein called “The Sleeping Beauty,” first performed in January 1890 at the Maryinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, “a final definition of czarist spectacle.”

headline: Florida’s Donovan Is Leaving for the N.B.A.
text: After leading Florida to consecutive men’s national basketball titles, Coach Billy Donovan accepted an offer to become head coach of the Orlando Magic.

headline: Hernández Rolls as Mets’ Outfield Shrinks Again
text: Every time Paul Lo Duca catches for Orlando Hernández, he settles into his crouch, puts down two fingers — the sign for a curveball — and prepares for a surprise. The ball may come in slow, fast or somewhere in the middle, and from any of Hernández’s 58 arm angles.

headline: Healthy Abreu Tries to Get Swing Back in Shape
text: It was a subtle but symbolic move at the end of a rout. With the Yankees ahead by five runs in Toronto on Wednesday, Manager Joe Torre removed Johnny Damon from the outfield and inserted Bobby Abreu. It was one 33-year-old outfielder in a hitting slump replacing another in a physical slump.

headline: Man With TB Apologizes for Endangering Others
text: The Atlanta lawyer who flew on crowded airplanes while infected with a dangerous form of tuberculosis said today he did not think he presented a danger when he flew and he apologized to his fellow passengers.

headline: U.S. Not Pushing for Attack on Iran, Rice Says
text: MADRID, June 1 — Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice sought today to minimize any sense of division within the Bush administration over Iran after the head of the United Nations nuclear watchdog agency delivered a pointed new warning against what he called the “new crazies” pushing for military action against Tehran.

headline: Cloistered in the Castle and Dreaming of His Empire
text: With “The Fifth Empire,” a drama about a young Portuguese king hoping to unite his troubled nation by embarking on a foreign adventure, the prolific 98-year-old director Manoel de Oliveira pushes his minimalist style as far as it can go.

headline: Pension Fund in New Jersey Faces Scrutiny From S.E.C.
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an inquiry into New Jersey’s handling of its pension fund for public employees, a move that suggests federal regulators are concerned that the state did not properly disclose its contributions to the fund.

headline: Auction Houses Banking on Buoyant London Market
text: After the record prices at last month’s auctions in New York, Sotheby’s and Christie’s are bracing for an encore in London this month. But what will distinguish these sales, starting on June 18, from any that have taken place there in a generation is the increase of artwork from the United States.

headline: Edward S. Behr, 81, Writer and a War Correspondent, Dies
text: Edward S. Behr, a former war correspondent who covered conflicts around the world for nearly three decades and who wrote books about notable and sometimes notorious figures in 20th-century history, died Saturday in Paris, where he lived. He was 81.

headline: Where the Boats Dance
text: WHO Ann McCullagh, 50, a teacher from Elgin, Ill., and her husband Mark, 49, a medical sales representative, with their children, Bridget, 18, and Luke, 16.

headline: In the 21st Century, the Persistence of Tradition
text: You could say that contemporary art became academic art in the 1960s, when experimental and subversive artists started teaching in art schools. Most of the art now in galleries, biennials and fairs is produced by artists coming out of this educational system. But there is “academic” in this sense, and then there are academicians, professional artists elected by their peers to be members of the National Academy.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Ink feature on Tuesday, about a nonprofit group that collects grease from restaurants at no cost and sells it to a company that converts it into biodiesel fuel, misstated the name of the group. It is RWA Resource Recovery, not RWA Natural Resource Recovery. The article also misstated the reason that the organization does not use biodiesel fuel in the truck that transports the grease. The biodiesel would have to be mixed with the petroleum diesel that the truck now runs on, and the group says it does not yet have the resources to mix the fuels. Vehicles powered by petroleum diesel do not, however, need to be retrofitted to use biodiesel.

headline: Sweep at School Turns Up a Trove of Electronic Contraband
text: When Olivia Lara-Gresty saw the metal detectors at the entrance of Middle School 54 on the Upper West Side, she turned around and ran home to ditch her contraband before joining her sixth-grade class.

headline: Plame Sues C.I.A. for Blocking Her Memoir
text: Valerie Wilson, the former intelligence operative at the heart of an investigation that reached into the White House, sued the Central Intelligence Agency in federal court in New York yesterday over its refusal to allow her to publish a memoir that would discuss how long she had worked for the agency.

headline: Giambi Will Be Out Several Weeks With a Foot Injury
text: Jason Giambi tore the plantar fascia in his left foot while trotting around second base after hitting a home run on Tuesday in Toronto. He had already been hobbled by the injury, and when he felt a pop during his trot, he feared the worst.

headline: Sales Barely Up, Book Trade Yearns for Next Blockbuster
text: In the absence of a new Harry Potter book or a blockbuster by Dan Brown, the publishing industry struggled to sell more copies last year than it did the year before, according to a report to be released today by the Book Industry Study Group, a publishing trade association.

headline: Video of Captive BBC Reporter Emerges
text: JERUSALEM, June 1 — A British reporter kidnapped in Gaza on March 12 was shown today in a video released to an Islamic militant website, providing the first sign that the reporter was alive. And Israeli troops killed two young Palestinians and wounded a third near the Gaza border with Israel.

headline: Bye-Bye, Bong. Hello, Baby.
text: It may be a bit, um, premature to say so, but Judd Apatow’s “Knocked Up” strikes me as an instant classic, a comedy that captures the sexual confusion and moral ambivalence of our moment without straining, pandering or preaching. Like “The 40-Year-Old Virgin,” Mr. Apatow’s earlier film, it attaches dirty humor to a basically upright premise. While this movie’s barrage of gynecology-inspired jokes would have driven the prudes at the old Hays Office mad, its story, about a young man trying to do what used to be the very definition of the Right Thing, might equally have brought a smile of approval to the lips of the starchiest old-Hollywood censor.

headline: Speller Loses Publicity Bid for Parents
text: The words that shaped Kunal Sah’s path to the Scripps National Spelling Bee — “determination,” “hope,” “anguish” — were not enough to spell victory.

headline: India and U.S. Try to Rekindle Stalled Talks on a Nuclear Pact
text: NEW DELHI, May 31  Talks intended to restart stalled negotiations on a landmark nuclear pact between India and the United States began here on Thursday amid disagreement over India’s right to continue testing nuclear weapons and process spent fuel.

headline: A Book the Met Wasn’t Ready for, It Seems
text: Nicholas Fox Weber believed a deal had been struck, but we will get to that in a moment.

headline: British Boycott and Israel (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Aide Says Edwards Misspoke on Reading Classified Iraq Report
text: Former Senator John Edwards, a Democratic presidential candidate, told an interviewer on Wednesday that he had read the classified October 2002 National Intelligence Estimate before voting to authorize force in Iraq, but his campaign retracted the statement yesterday.

headline: Past and Present: Imperfect, Tense
text: After two big, ambitious novels — “Atonement” and “Saturday” — Ian McEwan has inexplicably produced a small, sullen, unsatisfying story that possesses none of those earlier books’ emotional wisdom, narrative scope or lovely specificity of detail.

headline: Jean-Claude Brialy, 74, Actor, Dies
text: Jean-Claude Brialy, a dashing leading man of the French New Wave films of the 1960s and ’70s, died Wednesday in Paris. He was 74.

headline: The Two-Year Solution
text: Washington

headline: From Music’s Persistent Gender Gap, a Festival Arises
text: The composer Joan Tower, 69, her voice lowered a semitone by a cold, poured herself a beer in a Midtown bar and half-championed, half-defended her next project.

headline: New Hampshire Senate Rejects Bill on Mandatory Seat Belting
text: BOSTON, May 31  New Hampshire will remain the only state without a law requiring adults to wear seat belts after the State Senate on Thursday rejected a bill mandating their use.

headline: Manhattan: Man Arrested in Taxi Robberies
text: A man was arrested yesterday in connection with eight robberies of taxi drivers since May 17, the police said, and a realistic-looking toy pistol, which they believe he used to carry them out, was recovered. At a news conference, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly identified the man as Earl Bradley Evans, 36. He was arrested when he returned to the building where he lived, at 231 Vernon Avenue in Brooklyn, Mr. Kelly said, by officers who had been staking it out. Mr. Kelly declined to say what led detectives to Mr. Evans, who was carrying a Tennessee driver’s license, and said the charges against him had not been determined. But Mr. Kelly said he chose to announce the arrest yesterday to allay taxi drivers’ fears that a serial robber armed with a real gun was on the loose.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Accident Halts London ‘Rings’

headline: Needed in Darfur: More Than Words (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Poise in His Performance, Surprises Up His Sleeve
text: Something funny happened during Bobby Hutcherson’s second set at the Blue Note on Wednesday night. He was halfway through a vibraphone solo, just gaining momentum, when he had the impulse to pound furiously at a single note — plonk! plonk! plonk! — as if hammering nails into a board. This intemperate act seemed to take even Mr. Hutcherson by surprise: he staggered a couple of steps back from his instrument, and there was a flicker of mild astonishment on his face before he convulsed with laughter.

headline: Ex-Governor Says Affidavit Shows Politics in Bribe Case
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 31  Alabama has a tradition of savage political warfare, but Don E. Siegelman’s fight to stay out of prison is reverberating all the way back to Washington.

headline: Knowledgeable Furniture
text: When we try to picture Microsoft’s new “interactive virtual concierge” what comes to mind is Sonny — the robot-hero of the movie “I, Robot.” We can almost hear him saying, in a voice practically weeping with patience, that alas the stairway up the Statue of Liberty has been closed to visitors since 9/11 and will remain closed indefinitely. But the concierge Microsoft means is something less anthropomorphic than Sonny. It is, in essence, a 30-inch computer touch screen in coffee-table format — called Surface — and it is likely to be deployed first in Las Vegas casinos for visitors who already believe they can communicate with slot machines.

headline: Albany: Increased Spending for Legal Aid
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer proposed new regulations yesterday that are expected to increase by more than fourfold state spending on civil legal services for the poor. The regulations will require banks to pay a far higher interest rate on funds deposited in special accounts that lawyers use to temporarily hold money deposited by clients. Interest from these accounts has traditionally been used to pay for civil legal services, but banks have been paying an interest rate of 0.5 percent, on average. The new regulations will require banks to pay a more competitive rate of about 2.7 percent. The change, which requires a 45-day comment period but not legislative approval, is expected to increase financing for civil legal services for the poor from more than $13 million to as much as $65 million.

headline: People
text: People

headline: Google Zooms In Too Close for Some
text: OAKLAND, Calif., May 31 — For Mary Kalin-Casey, it was never about her cat.

headline: 2 More Democratic Candidates Decline to Join in Fox News Debate
text: The congressman overseeing plans to stage a debate among Democratic presidential hopefuls on the Fox News Channel said yesterday that the forum would go on as planned, despite the defection of two more candidates, Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut and Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico.

headline: China Says 2 of Its Companies Played a Role in Poisonings
text: BEIJING, May 31 — Chinese regulators acknowledged for the first time Thursday that two Chinese companies had “engaged in some misconduct” in the way they labeled and sold a poisonous ingredient that ended up in cold medicine, killing at least 100 people in Panama last year.

headline: The, Uh, Joy of Digging Ditches
text: MY neighbor in Ulster County, N.Y., is a great gardener who can toss off the Latin name for most everything on his 10-acre spread without a moment’s hesitation. Another friend of mine is a terrific gardener, too — “a guy gave me this,” he’s always saying, “and I just stuck it in the ground and now look at it go.” The carpenter down the road effortlessly coaxes stone into beautiful snaking walls rivaling those that have stood there for 200 years. Tourists stop and take pictures of them.

headline: A Father With Two Careers, in Business and in Murder
text: Who knew that serial killing is an addiction that sufferers hope to overcome by attending A.A. meetings and murmuring the serenity prayer? That, at least, is how the buttoned-up title character of “Mr. Brooks,” a nutty variation of “Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde,” deals with such inconvenient urges. “I’m an addict,” he announces at a 12-step meeting while withholding the true nature of his cravings.

headline: Manhattan: Arbitration for Sotheby’s
text: A State Supreme Court judge has granted Sotheby’s auction house a temporary restraining order that blocks its landlord from selling its longtime home on York Avenue while the two sides wrestle over the property. The developer Aby Rosen bought the 10-story building from Sotheby’s in 2002 for $175 million and leased it back to the company. The two sides had a falling out earlier this year when Mr. Rosen put the building up for sale. Sotheby’s contends that it has the right under the terms of its lease to buy the building for a fraction of the $465 million Mr. Rose has demanded. The injunction, granted on Wednesday, allows the two to proceed with what is known as baseball arbitration, in which an arbitrator declares one side or the other the winner.

headline: Mixed Reaction in Lebanon to U.N. Assassination Tribunal
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, May 31 — After two and a half years of protests, Lebanese who have demanded an international tribunal to try suspects in the 2005 assassination of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri and in several other politically inspired killings finally got what they wished for.

headline: Theater Listings
text: ‘MY TRIP TO AL-QAEDA’ Before heading off on your summer vacation, beach reading in tow, you have another chance to join Lawrence Wright on his disturbing voyage into the netherworld of international terrorism. Mr. Wright brings “My Trip to Al-Qaeda,” his illuminating monologue about the rise of the Islamist movement, to Town Hall for two more performances next week, a follow-up to its popular Off Broadway run at the Culture Project this spring.

headline: Stalled by Conflict, Ukraine’s Democracy Gasps for Air
text: KIEV, Ukraine, May 31 — Two and a half years ago, the “Orange Revolution” promised Ukrainians a freer, more democratic system of government. Instead, the country now finds itself mired in perpetual political crisis, punctuated by confusion, chaos and, at times, comedy.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: Don’t Forget the Border
text: Phoenix

headline: Where Now, for the Wind?
text: WINGATE, Tex. — If he could have ever seen the FPL Group’s new wind farm here, Don Quixote would have certainly fallen off his horse.

headline: Back to Basics
text: This week Fred Thompson gave a speech in Connecticut during which two words did not cross his lips: George Bush. But that’s all right. Thompson recently gave speeches in Virginia and California during which he scarcely mentioned Bush either. In the world Thompson described, the current Washington players are most notable for being trapped in that undifferentiated swamp we call Washington politics.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Where the Beach Books Are
text: If a computer were programmed to create summer reading, it might outdo Hilma Wolitzer’s new novel. Maybe.

headline: Pentagon Files Offer Details on Detainee in Suicide
text: The Guantánamo detainee who apparently committed suicide on Wednesday was a persistent hunger striker, at one point dropping his weight to 88.5 pounds, government documents indicate.

headline: Purple Clay, a Pot of Tea and Thou, O China
text: Teapots of silver and porcelain are undoubtedly luxurious, but Chinese literati traditionally preferred theirs made of a particular type of purple clay, which they valued more than gold. Called Zisha (literally “purple sand”), it is from Yixing, a small town on the west bank of Lake Tai about 120 miles west of Shanghai.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a brief art review in Weekend last Friday about an exhibition of works by Luigi Ontani used an outdated name for the gallery where the works are being shown. It is just Bortolami, not Bortolami Dayan.

headline: Bancroft Family Agrees to Meet With Murdoch
text: The Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones & Company, the owner of The Wall Street Journal, agreed late today to meet with the News Corporation to discuss its $5 billion bid.

headline: Chávez Looks at His Critics in the Media and Sees the Enemy
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 31 — “Sound the alarm in the hills, slums and towns to defend our revolution from this new fascist attack,” President Hugo Chávez said in a nationally televised speech this week as his government was under siege by student protests over his decision to take a dissident television network off the air. “We are waiting for you.”

headline: Street Sense Will Pass Up the Belmont
text: Street Sense, the Kentucky Derby winner, is skipping the 139th running of the Belmont Stakes, leaving Curlin, the Preakness champion, the likely favorite in what now is a compact field of five for the third leg of the Triple Crown.

headline: Mauresmo Rallies and Carries the Flag to the Third Round
text: PARIS, May 31 — In the middle of Amélie Mauresmo’s match here Thursday, a spectator yelled “Vive la France!” and laughter rippled through the packed Court Philippe Chatrier.

headline: Largest Labor Union in Britain May Consider a Boycott of Israel
text: LONDON, May 31 — A movement in Britain to boycott Israel economically and culturally gathered speed on Thursday as the country’s biggest labor union said it would follow the union of university instructors in weighing punitive measures against Israel.

headline: Athletes Acting Cadly
text: On my car radio yesterday morning, a baseball reporter for ESPN was lamenting the disconnect between the news media and celebrity athletes as a result of salacious reporting, such as the latest tabloid frenzy in New York over Alex Rodriguez’s personal life. Contemporary stars, the reporter contended, are more distrustful than ever of mainstream outlets and, given their wealth, increasingly indifferent to the benefits of making themselves available.

headline: Deficit Expected to Be Less Than Predicted
text: This year’s federal budget deficit probably will be about $200 billion, $44 billion less than the Bush administration first forecast, said the White House budget director, Rob Portman. In a briefing on budget negotiations with Congress, Mr. Portman attributed the lower number to a growing economy that is bringing in higher tax revenue combined with efforts to hold down government spending. “There’s no magic to it,” he said. “The point is the deficit is going down, and it has been going down.”

headline: A Disease That’s Difficult to Cure
text: Andrew Speaker’s extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis, or XDR TB, is a rare form of the disease caused by bacteria that are resistant to nearly all the antibiotics normally used for TB.

headline: Pelosi’s Order in the House
text: The differences between House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and her predecessor, J. Dennis Hastert, could not be more striking.

headline: A $56 million view?
text: Is a view ever worth $56 million? The developers of the Plaza Residences in New York City hope so.

headline: Fonts, Louder Than Words
text: M/M (Paris) didn't become the fashion world's go-to graphic design duo by being polite.

headline: Workin’ (More Than) 9 to 5
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Accident Halts London ‘Rings’
text: Performances of the $49.5 million London production of "The Lord of the Rings," with its cast of 50 actors and acrobats, were suspended for two days after the hydraulic stage machinery trapped the leg of Adam Salter, who plays a Ranger, The Times of London reported.

headline: Theater Briefs
text: Kevin Spacey, artistic director of the Old Vic Theater in London, will star in a revival of David Mamet's "Speed-the-Plow" in the coming season, Playbill.com reported.

headline: Feathered Gladiators
text: Cockfighting continues in Louisiana, the last outpost of a tradition in its twilight.

headline: Must a Co-op Provide a List of All Its Shareholders?
text: Q Are shareholders in co-ops entitled to receive a list of all the other shareholders and their addresses, phone numbers, etc.?

headline: AIDS Treatment in Puerto Rico
text: Hundreds of patients are not receiving vital care as a result of what many doctors and patient groups say is the poor management of federal assistance.

headline: Flea market north of the Marais this weekend
text: Rue de Bretagne on Friday, June 1, the first day of the flea market. (James Connell)

headline: Pulse
text: What I'm wearing now, flipping and flopping and toning, shimmers of elegance and more.

headline: Gizmoz Raises $6.3 Million for Do-It-Yourself Avatars
text: Gizmoz, a company that aims to let people make digital avatars of themselves, raised $6.3 million in its first round of venture funding from Benchmark Capital and Columbia Capital.

headline: Do Small-Time Insider Traders Get a Free Pass?
text: Though market watchdogs have brought several insider-trading cases lately, Marketwatch’s David Weidner argues that regulators find the most commonplace cases of insider trading to be “generally irrelevant” as they concentrate on the big, flashy scandals while small-time criminals “fly under the radar.”

headline: Multiverse Takes $4.1 Million in First Round
text: Multiverse, an online game and virtual world developer on Thursday announced the completion of a Series A financing round worth $4.175 million. The funding was led by Sterling Stamos Capital Management and included unnamed angel investors.

headline: Harry Potter and the Marketing Event Horizon
text: It is a truth universally acknowledged that the one thing central Florida most desperately needs is more theme park attractions. Likewise, children these days can never have too many ways to satisfy their craving for all things Hogwartsian. And J.K. Rowling could always do with another few million.

headline: Cardinal Health Settles Shareholders’ Suit
text: Cardinal Health, the medical products and services company, agreed Wednesday to pay $600 million to settle a lawsuit filed by shareholders accusing it of accounting irregularities and inflated earnings. In a regulatory filing, the company denied any wrongdoing and said it settled to eliminate the uncertainties and expense of further litigation. The settlement is subject to approval in Federal District Court.

headline: BHP Billiton Selects a Chief Executive
text: BHP Billiton, the mining company, chose the head of its copper and aluminum division, Marius Kloppers, to succeed its American chief executive, Charles W. Goodyear, when Mr. Goodyear steps down Oct. 1.

headline: Dow Jones Opens Door to Rival Bidders
text: While the Bancroft family’s announcement Thursday that it would consider selling Dow Jones & Company represents a remarkable about-face for both the company and Rupert Murdoch’s $5 billion bid, it does not necessarily mean that Mr. Murdoch will capture Dow Jones, which he has long coveted.

headline: Western Refining Completes Giant Deal in Face of F.T.C. Opposition
text: Western Refining completed its $1.13 billion purchase of rival Giant Industries Thursday after a federal appeals court denied a last-minute effort by the Federal Trade Commission to block the deal.

headline: Navteq Stock Rises Amid Buyout Speculation
text: Navteq shares hit a 10-month high after an analyst said a buyout firm may be interested in acquiring the company, which makes maps used in car navigation systems. William Benton of William Blair & Company wrote in a research note that a private equity fund could be attracted to Navteq’s growth potential, strong cash flow and lack of debt. It has a market capitalization of about $4 billion.

headline: Bioenvision Shareholder Strikes Out at Genzyme Deal
text: Genzyme‘s planned takeover of a cancer drug maker, Bioenvision, has hit a bump: A key Bioenvision shareholder is calling the deal a lowball offer and digging in against it.

headline: C.I.B.C. Profits Up but Shares Head Down
text: Shares of the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce headed lower Thursday after the bank reported second-quarter earnings of 807 million Canadian dollars ($756 million), up 38 percent from the same period a year ago. The results topped analyst forecasts. But “we think [the] quarter missed expectations that have been rising in recent weeks,” UBS Investment Research analyst Jason Bilodeau wrote in a note to clients.

headline: Long lines at Heathrow (set to music)
Jefferies Snaps Up U.K. M&A Adviser
text: Jefferies, the investment bank, has agreed to acquire LongAcre Partners, the British media mergers and acquisitions adviser behind deals such as the sale of “Who Wants To Be A Millionaire?” producer Celador and ITV‘s acquisition of Friends Reunited.

headline: Eton Park Raises Cash for Emerging Markets Fund
text: Eton Park Capital Management, the hedge-fund firm founded by Eric Mindich, a former Goldman Sachs Group partner, raised $518.5 million for a private-equity fund to invest in developing countries.

headline: Northwest Exits Bankruptcy and Begins to Trade Shares
text: Shares of Northwest Airlines, newly emerged from bankruptcy protection, began trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday after the airline’s chief executive, Douglas M. Steenland, and other employees rang the opening bell.

headline: Quebecor Bulks Up With Osprey Media Deal
text: Quebecor is poised to become one of Canada’s biggest newspaper publishers with the acquisition of the Osprey Media Income Fund. Montreal-based Quebecor, which owns the Le Journal papers in Quebec and the Sun Media chain across Canada, bought Osprey’s chain of 54 daily and weekly newspapers for 517 million Canadian dollars ($484 million), in a deal announced Thursday night.

headline: Cerberus Said to Be Eyeing Canadian Sporting-Goods Chain
text: Shares of the Forzani Group continued to climb to record highs on Thursday morning amid talk that the Canadian sporting goods chain is in takeover talks with private equity bidders. Cerberus Capital Management is a prime suitor, according to The Globe and Mail.

headline: Midsize Brokerages Seen as Takeover Targets
text: Wachovia‘s $6.8 billion deal for A.G. Edwards  touched off speculation that more midsize brokers may succumb to potential suitors. Among those being bandied about as possible targets are Stifel Financial, Raymond James Financial and Charles Schwab .

headline: Top Plaintiffs’ Lawyer, Under Fire, May Depart
text: William S. Lerach, one of the most powerful securities class-action lawyers in the nation, is considering plans to leave the law firm he founded three years ago. In a hastily called meeting this week at his San Diego law firm, Lerach Coughlin Stoia Geller Rudman & Robbins, it was disclosed that Mr. Lerach, 61, was weighing his departure, said a lawyer inside the firm who spoke on condition of anonymity.

headline: WellPoint Forces Out Its Financial Chief
text: WellPoint, the biggest American health insurer, ousted its chief financial officer on Thursday after an external investigation found that he violated the company code of conduct. The board named its chief accounting officer, Wayne S. DeVeydt, to succeed the finance chief, David C. Colby, effective immediately. Angela F. Braly is to become chief executive and president on Friday, succeeding Larry C. Glasscock, who is retiring.

headline: Ivy Owner Sells Pizza Chain to Blackstone Firm
text: Richard Caring, the millionaire owner of the British celebrity haunt The Ivy, has sold off his Strada pizza chain for 140 million pounds ($277 million), less than a month after buying a 3 percent stake in the Carluccio‘s restaurant chain, prompting speculation that he could bid for the company.

headline: Lawyer Files Bias Suit Against G.E
text: A lawyer for General Electric, Lorene F. Schaefer, has filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court in Connecticut, accusing G.E. of systematically discriminating against women in both pay and promotions.

headline: Bally Total Fitness to Restructure in Bankruptcy
text: Bally Total Fitness, the health-club chain, said Thursday it would file for bankruptcy protection as part of a plan to reduce its debt. The proposed restructuring would make Phil Anschutz, a Denver financier, a major shareholder. Tennenbaum Capital Partners and Goldman Sachs would also get stock in the reorganized company in exchange for their notes.

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Another Swing at Topps
text: A New York hedge fund, Crescendo Partners, on Thursday alleged that certain Topps board members have conflicts of interest that prevent the trading card and confection company from negotiating in good faith with its rival, Upper Deck, on a potential acquisition.

headline: Congress Wants to Define ‘Abusive Tax Shelters’
text: The tax shelter business is under attack.

headline: Is Buffett Mulling Move on Kraft?
text: Is Warren Buffett waking up and smelling the Maxwell House? Rumors that the chief of Berkshire Hathaway is eyeing Kraft Foods caused a surge in call option activity in the company.

headline: Big Investors Jumping Back Into Shaky Home Loans
text: As the subprime mortgage business finds itself in tatters — loan volume is plummeting, defaults are rising and some of the biggest lenders have cut back or shut down — private equity, hedge funds and investment banks are swooping in and taking over the battered businesses, seeing opportunity amid the wreckage.

headline: Man Group Files for I.P.O. in New York
text: Man Group‘s brokerage unit filed for a $1 billion initial public offering in New York on Thursday, leaving the London-based asset-management company to focus on its hedge fund business, which is one of the largest in the world.

headline: Jazz Pharmaceutical Cuts I.P.O. Price
text: Jazz Pharmaceuticals, a biopharmaceutical company, priced its initial public offering below the forecast range, which had already been reduced. The 6-million-share offering raised $108 million, providing sorely needed cash for the money-losing drugmaker. Since 2003, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and other private equity firms have invested $265 million in Jazz, whose main product, gamma hydroxybutyrate, is used to treat narcolepsy but also has a history of use in date rape and risks of overdose.

headline: Cellphone Raid Roils Manhattan School
text: Few subjects have stirred up New York City public school parents more than the ban on cellphones in schools that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is determined to enforce.

headline: 2008: Obama’s Hoop Dreams
text: “Armchair psychologists and fans of athletic metaphors, take note,” writes The Times’s Jodi Kantor. “Barack Obama is a wily player of pickup basketball, the version of the game with unspoken rules, no referee and lots of elbows.”

headline: Canada’s Stelco Is Said to Be Up for Sale
text: In what may be the end for Canadian-owned steel giants, Stelco has gone up for sale, the Globe and Mail reported Friday citing unnamed sources. A sale of the Hamilton, Ontario-based company would cap a remarkable string of deals for the country’s steel makers, including Dofasco, Algoma Steel and Ipsco, all sold to buyers from Europe or Asia.

headline: No One Knows Who They Were, or What They Were Doing …
text: — Tobin Harshaw

headline: Even in Trivia, Team Goldman Takes the Crown
text: Investment bankers are known for their fierce competitive spirit when it comes to landing deals. Why should winning a trip to stay at the Morocco home of a top model be any different?

headline: The Speaker’s Shift
text: Dennis Hastert was an advocate of governing the House by a “majority of the majority.” Nancy Pelosi has shown she will deviate from that approach.

headline: Dow Jones Shares Surge on Bancroft News
text: Dow Jones & Company‘s stock is off and running.

headline: Owner of Elvis’s Image to Go Private
text: Even Elvis Presley is getting in on the recent run of management-led buyouts.

headline: The Mayor, Taxes and Zero-Sum Games
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg hinted further today that larger property tax cuts could be on the way for New York City residents, but he warned that the City Council would first have to give up some of its spending initiatives.

headline: Dr. Death Is Released
text: Pathologist, angel of mercy, advocate, lightning rod, scofflaw, punchline — to Dr. Jack Kevorkian’s long resume of sobriquets we may now add ex-con.

headline: Controversial Clinton Donor Still a Bundler
text: In the Democratic competition for campaign cash, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton continues to turn to every friend she has – even controversial ones.

headline: In Summer, Dandelion and Soot
text: It’s disconcerting that when you wear a little more makeup than usual and throw a roller or two in your hair you suddenly appear invisible to others. Or, perhaps I should say, newly recognized. “You look so different?” “I didn’t see you!” Or my favorite: “You must be in love.” This was offered once by Helmut Lang outside the Paris Theater in New York, before a screening of “Moulin Rouge,” the Kidman musical. I had my hair up in a twist and, no, love had nothing to do with it. Not then.

headline: What Dunn Learned From the H.P. Scandal
text: Despite the investigation that has ended her career at Hewlett-Packard, Patricia C. Dunn would still tell others to aggressively investigate boardroom leaks.

headline: Yahoo-eBay: The Non-Deal That Won’t Die
text: In May 2006, analyst at J.P. Morgan Chase considered all the possible pairings of the biggest Internet companies and concluded that “a partnership or merger between eBay and Yahoo is the most strategically feasible.”

headline: A Letter to Horace Mann
text: As The Times reported this morning, a furor has erupted at the Horace Mann School over a history teacher’s satirical novel, his impending departure and, now, accusations that administrators barred the student newspaper from publishing a letter by prominent historians and scholars who had come to the teacher’s defense. Here is the letter:

headline: Censorship, Academic Freedom and Private Schools
