text: What prompted prominent historians across the country — including some at Columbia University and the University of Virginia — to come to the defense of Andrew S. Trees, a history teacher at the Horace Mann School?

headline: Bank of America Names Global Markets Head
text: Bank of America said Friday that it promoted Thomas G. White to head of global markets and that Mark Werner, who became chief executive of its investment banking arm less than two years ago, is leaving the company “to pursue other opportunities.” Bloomberg News said three of Mr. Werner’s top executives are leaving with him.

headline: Weekend Video: Pearlstine on Dow Jones
text: The Bancroft family may be warming to the idea of a sale, but it is still far from certain that Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, or any other buyer, will succeed in acquiring Dow Jones. Even less clear, Norman Pearlstine of Carlyle Group said in an interview with Bloomberg News, is what would become of Ottaway Newspapers, the nationwide chain of community papers that Dow Jones has owned since 1970.

headline: A Costume Drama
text: Tony nominee Christine Ebersole discusses her wild and elaborate wardrobe for "Grey Gardens."

headline: Your Summer Rituals
text: Share what makes summer summer for you.

headline: More Weekend Video: Dows of Our Lives
text: You might be tempted to agree with Dow Chemical chief executive Andrew Liveris that the story of two fired executives at his company becoming a “soap opera” — except even soap operas aren’t this confusing.

headline: Parsing NASA Chief’s Warming Comment
text: The chorus of outrage over the NASA chief’s global warming comments were led by a well-known climate scientist within NASA. James E. Hansen, director of NASA’s Goddard Institute for Space Studies. “I almost fell off my chair,” he told NPR’s Morning Edition.

headline: Spoleto Festival U.S.A.: Where the Classical World Parties Hard
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. – Between the 120 events of the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. here over 17 days and the 700 of the concurrent, city-sponsored Piccolo Spoleto Festival, who has time for anything more? Everyone, it seems, has time to party. Although the Spoleto Festival prides itself on not spending its own money on parties, its sponsors, models of Southern hospitality, pick up the slack with pre- or postconcert events in their homes — and how.

headline: Spoleto Festival U.S.A: The Most Famous Face Nobody Knows
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. – The most famous face in the city at the moment is that of the composer Philip Glass. You see him in miniature and writ huge, on a 38-by-26 foot banner at the Gailliard Auditorium. You see him on posters in store windows and restaurants. You see him walking toward you on the street, on the front of a T-shirt, and as likely as not, the wearer is carrying a program book for the Spoleto Festival U.S.A., with – who else? – Philip Glass on the cover.

headline: Nannies and a Minimum Wage
text: Should there be a minimum wage for nannies, housekeepers, cooks and baby sitters, well above the $7.15 statewide minimum? A coalition of immigrant and labor groups and their allies is pushing for a bill that would establish a minimum wage of $14 an hour for domestic workers in New York State.

headline: You Can Have Your Cellphone Back Now
text: Hundreds of cellphones confiscated at Middle School 54 yesterday morning were released to their owners today –- four days earlier than originally ordered.

headline: Hire the Old Folks
text: The household survey of employment shows some odd trends in who is holding down jobs. The number of employed teenagers is falling, but the number of employed people over 55 is soaring.

headline: A Million Little Pieces
text: “He sundered the party that rallied to him, and broke his coalition into pieces. He threw away his inheritance. I do not understand such squandering.” Such is the judgment rendered on President Bush by former Reagan speechwriter Peggy Noonan, whose words means something in Republican circles. So how did those circles respond?

headline: Permira Sweeps up Valentino with €783 Million Stake
text: The worlds of fashion and business are both rough and tumble realms. On Friday the two combined, as Permira Advisers sought to outflank the Carlyle Group by paying 782.6 million euros for a majority stake in Valentino Fashion Group, valuing the clothing company at 2.6 billion euros ($3.5 billion).

headline: The House Plans: Version 3.1
text: The third version of our house plans was heading in the right direction. Paul and I sat down at lunch and made a list of pluses and minuses.

headline: Must-Read Memoir
text: This weekend’s article on must-read car books made me think of mine: “Flat Out, Flat Broke: Formula One the Hard Way” (Haynes Publishing, 2002). It’s a memoir by Perry McCarthy on his desperate attempts to break into Formula One. No, I hadn’t heard of him either.

headline: The New Normal
text: It’s quickly approaching a full year since I returned from Iraq, but it really doesn’t seem that long ago. However, the calendar doesn’t lie, and the end of August will mark the day in 2006 when I reunited with my wife, Christina, on the steps in front of my unit’s barracks in Camp Pendleton, Calif. Of course, we managed to miss each other as I got off the bus, and then we both proceeded to circle the crowd in a clockwise direction, maintaining equal distance and obliviousness of each other until we finally gravitated towards the center and met. After exchanging the required hugs and kisses I thought, “What do I do now?” I thought for a moment and offered the suggestion, “Let’s go home.” And that’s what we did. At T plus four minutes from setting foot in the continental United States it was already as if I was just coming home from another day of work.The feeling actually started on the bus on our way from March Air Reserve Base to Camp Pendleton. I looked out at the Southern California countryside and thought, “It’s so familiar. It’s like I never left.” Then a cell-phone laden motorist in an S.U.V. swung around our bus at a high speed and I thought, “Whoa! I see those didn’t die out while I was gone.”

headline: From the Annals of the Very, Very Unlikely
text: Your blogger rates it a safe bet that many a reader reacted the way he did to the reports about That Guy With TB and the fact that his new father-in-law just happens to be, of all things, a scientist who studies that very disease and has worked for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the agency that isolated him:

headline: Burgers, Pizzas, Opinions
text: For a while there I was on a burger jag. Wrote a little about burgers in the newspaper and a lot about them on this blog. Did the burger at Peter Luger. Went to Burger Joint and Houston’s.

headline: Friends of F. Thompson, Inc.
text: Fred Thompson took his first official step today toward becoming a candidate for president, filing papers in Nashville to set up an preliminary “test-the-waters” committee.

headline: Rangel on a Clinton Apology
text: Apologize — if it makes you feel better. But it’s not necessary.

headline: Realism in the Bush Administration?
text: The Washington Note has an interesting post saying that David Gordon, now the vice chairman of the National Intelligence Council, will be announced as the new head of Policy Planning at the State Department. That’s very interesting, because David Gordon is first rate and not ideological, and because Policy Planning is a key portfolio in any administration in developing long-range policy. Of course, hard-liners in the Office of the Vice President can still out-maneuver the sensible people, as they have for most of the last six years, but it’s nice to see good people appointed to top posts. Steve Clemons, who writes the Note, says that Gordon’s appointment is indicative of better people going into posts more recently, and maybe there’s some truth to that. If the administration had started with Bob Gates and Gordon England at the Pentagon, instead of Rumsfeld and Wolfowitz, with Zoellick at the World Bank — and, best of all, with somebody like Tom Ridge as vice president rather than Cheney — then Bush might have avoided a failed presidency. Bush also might have done better in preserving his reputation if he had just been defeated for reelection, so that his fans could blame today’s problems on John Kerry.

headline: Weekend Reading: Inside Macquarie’s Money Machine
text: Few companies have done more to make toll roads sexy than Macquarie Bank. Though not exactly a household name in the United States, the Australian bank has blazed a trail in infrastructure investments, wringing billions of dollars in profits from buying up bridges, airports and utilities in more than 100 countries, using a model that has inspired much bigger and better-known rivals.

headline: Another Clinches at the Candidates as Carlsen and Polgar Strike Back
text: With a draw against Vladimir Malakhov of Russia, Alexander Grischuk, also of Russia, joined Gata Kamsky of the United States and Peter Leko of Hungary as victors in their preliminary candidates matches. Judit Polgar, another Hungarian, staved off elimination by beating Evgeny Bareev of Russia, although she still trails 3 to 2 with one game to play. (If matches are tied after six games, there will be tie-breaker games to determine who goes through to the next round.) Magnus Carlsen of Norway also won, squaring his match with Levon Aronian of Armenia at 2.5.

headline: A Plea for Finesse
text: Two columns in the June 30 issue of Wine Spectator provide a fascinating counterpoint in one of the most important aesthetic arguments in wine today. The first, by James Laube, one of the Spectator’s senior editors, takes a swipe at those who complain about the high alcohol content in many of today’s wines. “If you taste a wine and it seems to be balanced,’’ Laube writes, “the alcohol content shouldn’t matter.’’

headline: Executive Pursuits
text: Harry Hurt III learns a few tricks of the sideshow trade.

headline: McCain in Iowa on Immigration
text: DES MOINES – Senator John McCain surely has longed for the day when his campaign was not dogged by daily questions and criticisms about his support for the Iraq war.

headline: Penguin Homes
text: The migration of the birds' main food supply is threatening their well-being.

headline: Torre Admonishes A-Rod
text: The Yankees’ manager has weighed in on Alex Rodriguez’s Shout Heard ‘Round The World from Wednesday night’s game in Toronto. And he didn’t like it.

headline: You Got Some Siblings — AND I DON’T LIKE IT
text: I have a lot to say today.

headline: Vows: Jennifer and Randy
text: Jennifer and Randy met by coincidence while on solo vacations in Florence, Italy.

headline: The Re-Education of Kerry Wood
text: The Cubs pitcher Kerry Wood is trying to once again come back from a serious injury and return to Wrigley Field.

headline: Fenway Fan Fun Over A-Rod
text: Alex Rodriguez of the Yankees has drawn great attention this week for his activities on and off the field, and the fans at Fenway Park — informed, opinionated and sophisticated about baseball — are having a good time with him tonight as he faces their first-place team.

headline: Dazzling Display Takes Everything Out of James
text: CLEVELAND, June 1  The electric night faded into a new day and a new month, and LeBron James looked like he had been snapped out of a dream. He was as dazed as the next person inside the Palace of Auburn Hills.

headline: An Import British and Blue
text: If the recent departures of Don Imus and Rosie O’Donnell have you worried that the airwaves are no longer safe for rudeness, you’ll be buoyed by “The Graham Norton Show.” This giggly British import, which makes its United States debut on BBC America tonight, is rude, blue, cruel and often hilarious.

headline: For the Record
text: A sports article on Sunday about late-game decisions by LeBron James of the Cleveland Cavaliers, and about how his development as a star player compares to that of other N.B.A. greats, referred imprecisely to two defining plays involving Michael Jordan’s Chicago Bulls in the 1990s. It was Horace Grant, not Jordan, who passed to John Paxson for the title-clinching 3-pointer in the 1993 N.B.A. finals against Phoenix. And in the 1997 finals, Jordan’s teammate Steve Kerr made a 2-point shot, not a 3-pointer, to lift Chicago over Utah.

headline: A Journey to, and From, the Heart of Radical Islam in Britain
text: LONDON

headline: Number of Unidentified Bodies Found in Baghdad Rose Sharply in May
text: BAGHDAD, June 1 — The number of unidentified corpses discovered in Baghdad soared more than 70 percent during May, according to new statistics from the Iraqi Ministry of Interior, an indication that sectarian killings are rising sharply as militias return to the streets after lying low during the first few months of the troop “surge.”

headline: For Pornographers, Internet’s Virtues Turn to Vices
text: The Internet was supposed to be a tremendous boon for the pornography industry, creating a global market of images and videos accessible from the privacy of a home computer. For a time it worked, with wider distribution and social acceptance driving a steady increase in sales.

headline: 2 American Pilots Are Indicted in Brazilian Airliner Crash
text: WASHINGTON, June 1 — A Brazilian judge on Friday indicted the two American pilots of a corporate jet that collided with an airliner over the Amazon on Sept. 29, along with four Brazilian air traffic controllers.

text: THE government said economic growth was slower in the first quarter than it had initially estimated. Chinese markets swooned, but American investors reached new heights. The World Bank has big money-raising needs for its new leader.

headline: Seeking Trade to Bridge a Political North-South Divide
text: NIZHNY PANJ, Tajikistan — The nearly completed bridge over the Panj River makes an incongruous sight. More than 700 yards long, it is the sort of modern and imposing concrete structure that might carry a rush of traffic over a gorge in the West.

headline: The Salary May Be Low, but How About Those Hours?
text: At a retirement party last fall, the master of ceremonies noted that the guest of honor, a police chief, had served the city for four decades.

headline: Study Finds Police Training Plays Key Role in Shootings
text: In making snap decisions about whether to shoot a potentially armed suspect, police officers are far less influenced by racial bias than students or community members forced to make the same decision, a large study has found.

headline: Spitzer Pushes Paid Leave Plan for Workers
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer is pushing behind the scenes to win legislative backing for a plan that would give workers several weeks of paid leave to care for newborn children or seriously ill family members.

headline: A Nation’s Lost Holocaust History, Now on Display
text: When Israelitische Kultusgemeinde Wien, or Jewish Community Vienna, decided to sell a vacant building in the summer of 2000, two employees were sent to look for any archival material that might have been left behind.

headline: May Jobs Growth Unexpectedly Strong
text: The American economy bounced back in May, as employers added nearly twice the numbers of jobs they had in April, and the manufacturing sector grew at its fastest rate in more than a year.

headline: Making the Minimum Sound Like More
text: Most performers are pleased when people in the crowd stop what they’re doing to watch and applaud. But for a D.J. that kind of tribute might inspire mixed emotions. If a dance party ends up feeling more like a concert, is that success or failure?

headline: For the Record
text: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the possibility that global warming could lead to an increase in hurricanes misstated part of the name of an organization that studies hurricane formation. It is the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, not “Oceanographic.”

headline: Underscoring the Romance of a Romantic Composer
text: The New York Philharmonic’s Brahms the Romantic festival, scattered in chunks throughout the season, offers the perfect measure of how bereft of fresh ideas this orchestra’s artistic management is. Here is the degree to which the works on the two concluding programs would have been neglected if Lorin Maazel hadn’t offered this festival overview of the Brahms orchestral canon: the Third and Fourth Symphonies, heard on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, were last played by the Philharmonic in 2003 and 2005. The Haydn Variations and the German Requiem, to be performed tonight and on Tuesday, were on the orchestra’s programs in 2006 and 2001.

headline: Questions Are Raised About Firing of Soprano
text: In the ego-driven arena of opera, “indisposed” is the main euphemism used when a singer is replaced, whatever the real reason.

headline: Dow Jones Says It Will Consider Options for Sale
text: The family that controls Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, announced yesterday that it would consider selling the company, ending more than a century of family ownership.

headline: Wal-Mart Cuts Back Expansion
text: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., June 1  The world’s largest retailer is slowing down. Again.

headline: Yanks Show Some Fire in Victory at Fenway
text: BOSTON, June 1 — They are far apart in the standings. One team threatening to run away with the American League East, the other still well under .500. But passion is the lifeblood of the rivalry between the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox, and that blood was still boiling Friday.

headline: Poisonous Police Behavior
text: You most likely have no idea of the abusive treatment that students and teachers at many of New York City’s public schools are enduring at the hands of overly aggressive police officers and security aides assigned to the schools.

headline: Vice Chairman of Joint Chiefs Says He’ll Retire in August
text: WASHINGTON, June 1 — Adm. Edmund P. Giambastiani Jr., who as vice chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff has guided Pentagon efforts to rewrite strategy and streamline budgeting and procurement, said Friday that he would retire from the military in August.

headline: Bush’s Greenhouse Gas Plan Throws Europe Off Guard
text: FRANKFURT, June 1 — For six years, Europeans have pleaded with President Bush to seize the initiative in the campaign against global warming. Now that he has, many here are even more frustrated.

headline: Noh, Bollywood and 3-D, With a Dash of Broadway
text: Koosil-ja, a Korean choreographer who grew up in Osaka, Japan, dropped her surname, Hwang, several years ago, and in the manner of Bjork or Madonna, it’s fairly evident that she wants to be a star. As a dancer, her approach is never trivial: as taut as a coiled spring, she is full of tension in her spare, controlled movements, yet never unduly tense. Chalk it up to her presence, which is always something to love in her technologically innovative performances. Unfortunately, it’s nearly always impossible to love the whole production.

headline: Venus’s Exit Means Serena Williams Stands Alone
text: PARIS, June 1 — During a changeover in the middle of her third-round match, Venus Williams whipped out a notebook and flipped through its pages, desperately looking at strategy and inspirational sayings she had compiled for times just like this.

headline: A Runner Taking Each Hurdle as It Comes
text: Liu Xiang approaches life the same way he does the hurdles. He says he takes each day as it comes, instead of letting his focus drift to what lies ahead.

headline: What’s on Saturday Night
text: 8 P.M. (Hallmark Channel) MARCO POLO (2007) Ian Somerhalder (“Lost”), left, plays that 13th-century rambling man who barely survived a trek from Venice to the far side of the world, where he spent 20 years in the court of the Mongol ruler Kublai Khan (Brian Dennehy) and discovered mysteries like timepieces, paper currency, a postal system, pasta and ice cream. B. D. Wong plays Polo’s peripatetic servant and friend, Pedro. Desiree Siahann does double duty as both objects of Polo’s affection, the courtesan Temulun and her younger sister, Kensai.

text: June 1, 2007

headline: U.S. Questions Spain’s Leaders on Cuba Policy
text: MADRID, June 1 — Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice bluntly criticized Spain’s increasingly close contacts with Cuba on Friday and prodded the Spanish government to do more to support dissidents in Cuba as it prepares for what she called a “major transition” — a reference to the health of Fidel Castro.

headline: Hard Questions on War and Terror (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Memories Etched in Motion
text: Hilary Easton takes a wise and witty look at memory in “It’s All True,” which opened on Thursday night at The Duke on 42nd Street. What do we remember? How close are our memories to the events remembered? How do memories weave together to color or construct a life? Ms. Easton manages to suggest the answers in her hourlong piece, creating a bold new life and community onstage as she goes.

headline: Mark Harris, Author of ‘Bang the Drum Slowly,’ Is Dead at 84
text: Mark Harris, who took readers on a literary journey through the life of a mythical baseball player in four well-received novels, including “Bang the Drum Slowly,” which became the basis of a 1973 movie, died Wednesday. He was 84 and lived in Goleta, Calif.

headline: Darfur Advocacy Group Undergoes a Shake-Up
text: Even as advocacy groups attained the seeming triumph of President Bush’s new sanctions against Sudan, the organization that helped bring the conflict in Darfur to the world’s attention is in upheaval, firing its executive director, reorganizing its board and rethinking its strategies.

headline: With Five Starters Out of Lineup, Mets’ Offense Has Little in Reserve
text: The Mets received some good news and some bad news before their game against the Arizona Diamondbacks yesterday. A magnetic resonance imaging test on Carlos Beltrán’s right knee was negative.

headline: Proclaiming Liberalism, and What It Now Means
text: The struggle among conservatives to define their movement in the post-Bush era may be getting more attention these days, but liberal intellectuals and writers are doing some soul-searching of their own. Not only are they trying to figure out what “the L word” now means, but also whether it could become a guiding philosophy in the 2008 presidential campaign by embracing the very ideas that are often seen as its greatest weaknesses: family values and a proactive government.

headline: Several Signs the Economy Is Reviving
text: The American economy appears to have shaken out of its slumber.

headline: From a Long Line of Onlies, a Mother of Two
text: I get plenty of ribbing from my husband about being an only child. His theory, after spending most of his life with a younger sister, goes something like this: The size of the bite one mooches off a cupcake is inversely proportional to the number of siblings one has. Only children never got pinched by anyone for taking more than their share, so they never learn.

headline: Ready to Fly Again
text: Douglas M. Steenland, chief executive of Northwest Airlines, steered his carrier out of bankruptcy protection this week after nearly 20 months of haggling with creditors and workers to reduce annual costs by about $2.4 billion.

headline: Murdoch’s Promises and Desires
text: When I hear Rupert Murdoch talking about all the steps he’s going to take to preserve the editorial integrity of The Wall Street Journal, I can’t help thinking about The New Yorker.

headline: A Troupe Known for Daredevil Choreography Copes With a Casualty
text: Performers in the dance company Streb Extreme Action fling themselves against plexiglass or sail off a trampoline and land facedown on a mat. They yank themselves around on ropes and dodge swinging cinder blocks. Some shows are subtitled “Slam,” and a company motto is “Dance, Danger, Action!”

headline: Dr. John B. Buse Statement
text: Statement released last night by Dr. John B. Buse:

headline: Warren Anderson, Albany G.O.P. Leader, Dies at 91
text: Warren M. Anderson, a longtime Republican leader in the New York State Senate who helped to bail New York City out of its fiscal crisis in the mid-1970s, died yesterday at Wilson Regional Medical Center in Johnson City, N.Y. He was 91 and lived in Dickinson.

headline: Yo, Vermont, What Up? These 3 Dudes, for Starters
text: MONTPELIER, Vt., May 30 — Vermont has long been a muse for poets and painters, but rappers have never been known to draw inspiration from its bucolic landscapes and postcard-perfect small towns.

headline: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about the impact that a Senate proposal to overhaul immigration law could have on New York misstated a provision of the bill. Immigrants who are relatives of United States citizens and have overstayed their temporary visas could indeed qualify for legalization on the same terms as illegal immigrants who crossed the border surreptitiously. Also, the article referred incompletely to another provision of the bill. While it would eliminate the right of citizens to sponsor their parents  a right that is now unlimited  it would create an annual quota of 40,000 visas for which citizens could compete to bring parents into the country.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Skull for Sale,

headline: William Silver, 59, Who Stirred Debate Over Gay Ministers, Dies
text: William Silver, whose 1975 application for ordination in the United Presbyterian Church — the first by an openly gay man — set off a continuing debate in the church over admitting homosexuals into the ministry, died on May 26. He was 59 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: For the Record
text: An article yesterday about Robert B. Zoellick, President Bush’s nominee to be the next president of the World Bank, gave an incorrect figure in some copies for the bank’s total lending to poor countries. It is $23 billion, not $23 million.

headline: Bush’s Longest-Serving Aide Plans to Depart
text: WASHINGTON, June 1  Dan Bartlett, one of President Bush’s longest-serving aides and closest confidants, said Friday that he would leave the administration in the summer. Mr. Bartlett’s is the latest and most significant departure in what has been a shrinking of Mr. Bush’s inner circle.

headline: Strange, Faraway Fantasies of Hell and Paradise
text: CHARLESTON, S.C., June 1 — Two more disparate works could hardly be imagined. And yet they have odd similarities.

headline: Massachusetts Governor Proposes Free Community Colleges
text: BOSTON, June 1  Community colleges in Massachusetts would be free to all students within 10 years under a proposal by Gov. Deval Patrick.

headline: The Halls Are Alive With the Sound of Rest (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Riding a Deceptive Discard to Victory in the Easterns
text: The Reisinger Knockout is the premier team event at the Eastern States Regional, which concluded last weekend in Manhattan. The 10 teams were divided into two groups of five, from which four teams qualified for the semifinals. The final was won by Christal Henner-Welland, Uday Ivatury, Roy Welland and Chris Willenken of New York and Steve Garner of Chicago. They defeated Robert Blanchard, Sam Lev and James Rosenbloom of New York; Grant Baze of San Diego; Gary Cohler of Miami; and Reese Milner of Los Angeles.

headline: Appeals Rejected in Cheating Scandal
text: Fuqua School of Business at Duke University in Durham, N.C., rejected appeals from 24 students who were punished earlier this year in a cheating scandal. The master’s of business administration students were given until June to appeal. In April, 34 students were punished after a professor noticed similarities among their work. Nine students faced expulsion and 15 faced a one-year suspension and a failing grade in the course. Ten others were found guilty of lesser offenses.

headline: Canadian Steel Maker Looks for Buyer
text: OTTAWA, June 1 — Stelco, Canada’s last domestically owned steel maker, said Friday that it was in early talks that might lead to its sale.

headline: Connecticut Takes Up Fight Over Accounting Rules
text: Less than a month after Texas passed a law blocking a new accounting rule, Connecticut has picked a fight with the independent board that tells state and local governments how to report their financial affairs.

headline: U.S. Puts Limits on Lenders’ Ties to Universities
text: The Education Department, criticized for lax oversight of student loans, released proposed rules yesterday that would set new standards for universities and ban lenders’ marketing practices that have resulted, in some cases, in loan company payoffs to university officials.

headline: A Jazzman’s Farewell Album, All Heart and Soul
text: It was a frail Michael Brecker who walked slowly into a Manhattan recording studio last August, clutching a cane and a folder of sheet music.

headline: Field Is Paved, Gloves Are Borrowed, Spirit Is Real
text: Here is a tattered patch of asphalt in the heart of a West Harlem housing project. It is caged in and a world apart, in the shadows of the burnt-orange high-rises. The bases are whatever the players can find: worn-out gloves, T-shirts, their imaginations. The outfield is a basketball court; baseballs take funny bounces on this hard surface.

headline: Mets Try to Cope With Rash of Injuries
text: Before last night’s game between the Mets and the Arizona Diamondbacks, Mets Manager Willie Randolph was asked about the rash of injuries his ball club is trying to fight through.

headline: 4 Men Charged in Plot to Bomb Kennedy Airport
text: By WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM

headline: For the Record
text: An article on May 18 about a contemporary-art auction at Phillips de Pury & Company referred incorrectly to the buyer of one of two Andy Warhol camouflage images that were sold. While one went to a telephone bidder for $1.4 million, the other, which sold for $712,000, was bought by Yung Hee Kim, who was in the auction room, not bidding by telephone.

headline: The Wordy Warriors (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Toxic Toothpaste Made in China Is Found in U.S.
text: Consumers were advised yesterday to discard all toothpaste made in China after federal health officials said they found Chinese-made toothpaste containing a poison used in some antifreeze in three locations: Miami, the Port of Los Angeles and Puerto Rico.

headline: Cars Outsell Light Trucks for First Time Since 2002
text: DETROIT, June 1  The car is officially back.

headline: Playing Games at CNBC
text: IN his 5,000-word apologia in New York magazine this week, the TV stock-picker James Cramer wrote that in the 1990s “people learned the stock market was a game that could make them rich, and they loved it because the pursuit of wealth is our true national pastime.”

headline: Russian Panel Delays Vote on Revoking BP Gas Field License
text: MOSCOW, June 1  A Russian committee delayed a decision on Friday on whether to revoke the license for a major natural gas field held by a BP joint venture, though draft minutes for the meeting are said to have included a recommendation to cancel the license.

headline: Team New Zealand Takes an Early Lead and Protects It
text: VALENCIA, Spain, June 1 — It was the first day of the Louis Vuitton Cup finals between Emirates Team New Zealand and Luna Rossa Challenge, and it must have been close to what America’s Cup officials had in their collective mind’s eye when they decided to take Valencia’s millions and word and bring sailing’s premier regatta here.

headline: Group Sets Sights on Antiwar ‘Camp’
text: A patch of Texas property used as a base camp by the antiwar activist Cindy Sheehan since 2006 became a battleground itself yesterday when an organization that supports the United States’ continued presence in Iraq announced plans to buy the five-acre plot.

headline: Huang Ju, Powerful Chinese Official, Dies at 68
text: BEIJING, Saturday, June 2 — Huang Ju, a Politburo member who rose out of Shanghai’s political elite to become one of the most powerful leaders in China, died Saturday morning after a long illness, state news media reported. Mr. Huang was 68.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on the Street Scene page of Business Day yesterday about Congressional efforts to rein in tax shelters referred incompletely to a tax shelter case involving United Parcel Service. Although a federal court did indeed rule that U.P.S. engaged in sham transactions to avoid hundreds of millions of dollars in corporate income taxes, that ruling was rejected in 2001 by the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit.

headline: Rice Plays Down Hawkish Talk About Iran
text: MADRID, June 1  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice sought Friday to minimize any sense of division within the Bush administration over Iran after the head of the United Nations nuclear watchdog agency delivered a pointed warning against what he called the “new crazies” pushing for military action against Tehran.

headline: Marriage Benefits (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Long Life Span of a Housing Downturn
text: WHAT happens when the American housing industry enters a downturn? It can last a long time.

headline: Clashes Continue at Camp in Lebanon
text: TRIPOLI, Lebanon, June 2 — Heavy shelling and gunfire continued for the second day at the Nahr al Bared refugee camp, as the Lebanese Army intensified its offensive against the Fatah al Islam militia.

headline: Ballet and Headstands, and Other Quirky Contrasts
text: The three pieces on the program presented by Ben Munisteri Dance Projects on Thursday night at Dance New Amsterdam use ballet extensively. So extensively that you start to think that the work might look even better coming from a ballet company. But the extended lines, small beats of the feet and tight, whirling turns are democratically apportioned — some of the dancers look balletic, some don’t — and interspersed with other things: jumping jacks, handstands, ordinary walks and crouches.

headline: Reconsidering, Torre Admonishes Rodriguez
text: BOSTON, June 1  Politically, it would have been easy for Yankees Manager Joe Torre to defend Alex Rodriguez for distracting a Toronto fielder by shouting as he ran past him on the bases Wednesday night. But with two days to think about it, Torre admonished Rodriguez on Friday.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on the Street Scene page of Business Day yesterday about Congressional efforts to rein in tax shelters referred incompletely to a tax shelter case involving United Parcel Service. Although a federal court did indeed rule that U.P.S. engaged in sham transactions to avoid hundreds of millions of dollars in corporate income taxes, that ruling was rejected in 2001 by the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit. (Go to Article)

headline: Getting Away to It All
text: The life-size plastic cows remain frozen in rumination at the old farm fence as weekend drivers wend along the country road. After a double-take, a driver ponders the brindled statues as an answer to the timeless question: Are we there yet? Well, yes, in a certain existential way, we have indeed arrived in the country on our weekend trek from the city. Except — not to get too urban kvetchy about this — the country isn’t what it used to be. Those fake cows stand where actual ones used to graze on the North Fork pastures of eastern Long Island.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,468 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: 18 Dead in Lebanon as Army and Militants Clash
text: TRIPOLI, Lebanon, June 1 — Under a hail of gunfire and mortar shells, Lebanon’s army on Friday moved closer to a Palestinian refugee camp in northern Lebanon where a group of militants has been hiding, seizing new ground in a daylong fight that left 18 dead and dozens wounded.

headline: Kazakh Leader’s Defiant Son-in-Law Is Held in Vienna
text: The son-in-law of President Nursultan Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan, accused in his homeland of kidnapping two leading bankers and running a crime network, was arrested by the Vienna police yesterday, a day after proclaiming his innocence in an interview with an Austrian news weekly.

headline: Breathing in Coney Island, at Just $178 a Bottle
text: Some have left their heart there. Others love it in the springtime. Not a few — maybe most — hold its eating contests, roller coaster and skeeball in high regard.

headline: World View Podcast
text: GREG WINTER. Welcome to the New York Times World View podcast, a weekly conversation with Times correspondents from across the globe.

headline: A Cyberblockade in Estonia
text: The small but technologically adept nation of Estonia has raised an alarm that should be heard around the wired world. Last month it weathered what some describe as the first real war in cyberspace when its government and much of its commerce nearly shut down for days because of an orchestrated Internet assault.

headline: A Miracle-Worker Highway Man Rides the Bonus Train
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 — Bay Area residents are used to growing old waiting for new roads. Construction of the new Bay Bridge has become a generational event: 13 years to plan and an estimated 11 to build. So after a gasoline tanker truck crashed in April, burning a busy ramp in Oakland that linked parts of the East Bay to San Francisco, drivers grumbled and took to surface streets, convinced their slow-motion commutes would last months.

headline: A Hobby That’s Part Party, Part Debate, All Intellect
text: When it comes to worthy recipients of noblesse largesse, a well-meaning multimillionaire in New York has no shortage of gratifying options: the sick and the poor; cultural institutions; universities; the public sector.

headline: Bombing Damages Bridge Linking Baghdad and Kirkuk
text: BAGHDAD, June 2 — Bomb blasts severely damaged a bridge linking a highway from Baghdad with the northern city of Kirkuk today, the police and witnesses said, heightening tensions between Arabs and Kurds and forcing traffic to re-route through some of the most dangerous areas of Diyala province.

headline: Montana, Under Pressure, to Take Bison Back to Yellowstone
text: HELENA, Mont., June 1 — Facing an outcry over plans to slaughter 300 bison that have repeatedly migrated out of Yellowstone National Park, Gov. Brian Schweitzer said Friday that Montana would load the animals onto trucks if they strayed again and haul them deeper into the park.

headline: Hot Enough in Here?
text: Michael Griffin, administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, is renowned for speaking bluntly so it was no surprise when he stuck his foot in his mouth during a recent interview. The disturbing element is that he may have inadvertently revealed one reason the space agency has been cutting back on satellite missions to study global warming.

headline: Wallace Seawell, 90, a Master at Shooting Stars, Is Dead
text: Wallace Seawell, a celebrity photographer whose West Hollywood home was for decades one of the country’s most productive glamour factories, turning out thousands of portraits of movie stars, singers, presidents, kings and Gabor sisters (all three), died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 90.

headline: Budget Tough Talk
text: When it comes to the federal budget, the Bush administration wants to look both prudent and generous. It’s neither.

headline: Beethoven and Friends, Together Once Again
text: On paper a program of three string quartets by Haydn, Mozart and Beethoven may look terribly conventional. But the Emerson String Quartet, which began its performances in the Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night with such a program, had a larger purpose in mind.

headline: Preventing Suicide (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Top Connecticut Republican Is Charged in Threat Conspiracy
text: HARTFORD, June 1 The leading Republican of the Connecticut State Senate, Louis C. DeLuca, was arrested on Friday and charged with conspiring to threaten a man he believed was abusing a young female relative.

headline: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, several words are missing in some copies from an article this weekend on Page 12 of the special Tony Awards section of Arts & Leisure about indelible moments on Broadway. The passage  the first two paragraphs of an item on “The Coast of Utopia”  should read:

headline: Toothpaste Containing Poison Is Found in U.S.
text: Consumers were advised on Friday to discard all toothpaste made in China after federal health officials said they found Chinese-made toothpaste containing a poison related to a chemical used in antifreeze in three locations — Miami, the Port of Los Angeles and Puerto Rico.

headline: For the Record
text: The listing of lottery results on Tuesday misstated two winning numbers for Monday’s New York Take 5 in some copies. The winning numbers were 5, 12, 35, 36 and 37; the numbers 17 and 26 were not drawn.

headline: A Defendant for the Defense, Following His Own Rules
text: An unwritten playbook seems to guide jailhouse lawyers: bring a dramatic flair, rant and rave, put the whole system on trial. Point your fingers. Wave your arms around. Grow a catawampus mane of wild-man hair if at all possible. Call out the police for laziness, the prosecutors for zealousness and the whole establishment for racism, sexism, ageism, xenophobia, catatonia and misanthropy. If all else fails, refuse to appear in the courtroom.

headline: British Reporter’s Abductors Release Video of Him Alive
text: JERUSALEM, June 1  For the first time since his abduction, a British reporter kidnapped in Gaza on March 12 was shown Friday in a video released to an Islamic militant Web site. Later on Friday, Israeli troops killed two young Palestinians and wounded a third near the Gaza border with Israel.

headline: Red Sox Lose Starters Lowell and Drew to Injuries
text: BOSTON, June 1  While losing to the Yankees, 9-5, on Friday night, the Red Sox also lost two starters to injuries, at least temporarily.

headline: Iraqi Bombers Thwart Efforts to Shield G.I.’s
text: WASHINGTON, June 1 — American commanders are expressing frustration at the increasing death toll in Iraq caused by makeshift explosives, which have killed 80 percent of the Americans who died in combat over the last three months, despite the billions of dollars being spent to fight the threat.

headline: Some on Journal Staff Voice Wish That Different Bidder Would Emerge
text: They only work there. But still, a small group of reporters and editors at The Wall Street Journal raised an outcry yesterday against Rupert Murdoch’s plan to buy Dow Jones & Company.

headline: The National Guard, Where It’s Needed (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: General Says Bosses Knew of ’05 Killings in Iraqi Town
text: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., June 1 — The general who was in charge of the Marine division in Iraq when infantrymen in the division killed 24 civilians in Haditha in late 2005, said Friday that all his superiors, including Gen. George W. Casey Jr., the top commander in Iraq, knew of the event within hours.

headline: Memorial Unit at Ground Zero Lists Donors
text: The World Trade Center Memorial Foundation announced a partial list of its major donors yesterday, showing a wide range of contributions from well-known figures and companies.

headline: How the Bancrofts Decided to Talk With Murdoch
text: The Bancrofts, owners of a communications empire, were never very good at communicating with one another.

headline: Split Over the Mormon Church, but Maintaining Some Ties
text: MILLVILLE, Utah — Janet and Lars Bergeson recently held a prewedding lawn party for their son at their home, surrounded by farms on a bluff in sight of Mount Bergeson. The landmark, named for a Swedish Mormon who arrived in 1860, is a reminder of their ancestors’ religion.

headline: Tangle of Conflicting Accounts in TB Patient’s Odyssey
text: As the Atlanta lawyer with a dangerous form of tuberculosis began treatment yesterday in Denver, the patient and government officials here and abroad provided sharply divergent accounts of his 12 days of world travel. The accounts seemed to agree only in the missed opportunities to head off what has become an international public health scandal.

headline: For the Record
text: An article last Saturday about efforts by Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey to promote seat belt safety referred imprecisely to a public service announcement in which he appears. Mr. Corzine, who was not wearing a seat belt when he was badly injured in a crash in April, is standing throughout the ad; he does not rise from a chair before walking off on crutches in the final moments.

headline: The Price of Free Airwaves
text: Washington

headline: Where the School Lunch Menu Includes Fire and Swords
text: I HOBBLED down the Coney Island boardwalk in the footsteps of all the sideshow freaks who had come and gone before. The sun glinted off the Cyclone roller coaster and the carousels. Flags flapped in the wind. Mothers pushed baby carriages. Couples strolled arm in arm past hot-dog stands, piña colada huts and potholes strewn with broken glass.

headline: Doctor Says Drug Maker Tried to Quash His Criticism of Avandia
text: When a Congressional committee holds a hearing next Wednesday, the subject will be the safety of the diabetes drug Avandia and whether federal drug regulators have paid close enough attention to its potential risks.

headline: Kevorkian Freed After Years in Prison for Aiding Suicide
text: CHICAGO, June 1 — Jack Kevorkian, the former pathologist who brought the debate over physician-assisted suicide into the national spotlight a decade ago, saying he had helped 130 terminally ill people in their deaths, stepped out of a Michigan prison on Friday having pledged not to assist anyone else.

headline: Young Siblings From Iowa Learn to Shine
text: It is a universal truth that whenever a child appears in a production by the New York City Ballet, audiences, even those immune to the easy charms of a mop-headed boy or a frisky, budding ballerina, melt like butter.

headline: Bill to Reduce Tuition for Illegal Immigrants Passes in Connecticut
text: HARTFORD, June 1 — Illegal immigrants who graduate from Connecticut high schools will be eligible for the resident tuition rate at the state’s public universities and colleges if the governor signs a bill that the Senate narrowly passed on Friday.

headline: Have Germs, Will Travel
text: San Francisco

headline: Hat-Wearing Bank Robber Strikes Again, in Montclair
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 1  He usually wears baseball caps. But on occasion, there have been a hunting cap and a fisherman’s hat. And this time, there might be a big red splotch.

headline: Principal Goodell Sets a New Tone for the N.F.L.
text: I’ve watched with great curiosity during the past few months as Roger Goodell, the new National Football League commissioner, has made his moves. What I’ve been unable to determine is whether he wants to be a commissioner of the people, or whether he will be the law and order commissioner. Early returns point to law and order, although after speaking with Goodell yesterday, he also seems to see himself as a conductor who uses his pitch pipe to set the proper tone. Indeed, the N.F.L., for all its soaring profits, is out of tune.

headline: City Streamlines Searches for Real Estate Sales Data
text: Once, curious neighbors wanting to find out how much a co-op unit sold for had no choice but to ask. The city made things a bit easier last summer by putting such data online, but few besides wonks and real estate professionals could find it.

headline: Science-Fiction Fan Hopes Jets’ Opportunity Isn’t a Fantasy
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., June 1  Darian Barnes has done some of his best work creating comic-book characters like Paradox, Outback and Ironbound in a series called the “National Triumph League.” He has created the story lines of their lives and has overseen their illustration.

headline: Gates Offers to Work With China’s Military
text: SINGAPORE, Saturday, June 2 — Nearly two years to the day after his predecessor bluntly criticized China’s rapid military buildup, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates struck a conciliatory tone toward Beijing on Saturday, saying the United States and China had the opportunity to “build trust over time.”

headline: California Primary Ballot May Include Iraq Question
text: LOS ANGELES, June 1  California is poised to become the first state to ask voters whether they favor an immediate withdrawal of American troops from Iraq.

headline: Prosecutors Say Insurer Was Billed for Brain Surgery That Never Occurred
text: It may have been the nine brain operations that Stanley Canella claimed that he, his wife and their two sons had from April 2003 to September 2006 that piqued the interest of federal investigators.

headline: More Advice Graduates Don’t Want to Hear
text: Last year at this time, as college graduates walked out into the world, I wrote a column giving advice on how they could save money.

headline: Pistons Will Try to Put Defensive Woes Behind Them
text: CLEVELAND, June 2 — Pistons point guard Chauncey Billups is not known for guarantees. His teammate Rasheed Wallace usually takes care of them.

headline: Council Seeks Sharp Curbs on Financing of Campaigns
text: The City Council is poised to introduce one of the most sweeping campaign finance overhauls in the country, aimed at limiting the influence of contractors, lobbyists, developers and others who do business with the city.

headline: The Proctor Is in … Trouble
text: When catcher Jorge Posada came to the mound before the bottom of the ninth inning tonight, this is what Scott Proctor said he told him: “Listen, you don’t need to do anything here. Just get out of here.”

headline: Changes on Broadway
text: A glance at four seasons over 60 years suggests that the decline of the straight play is real.  Everything else seems to be going up.

headline: Spoleto Festival U.S.A.: ‘Amahl’ Out of Season, in Tribute to Menotti
text: GOOSE CREEK, S.C., June 1 – For anyone caught up in the whirl of 120 events in the 17 days of the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in Charleston, it is daunting to realize that there are 700 more in the concurrent festival Piccolo Spoleto, run by the city’s Office of Cultural Affairs. But one item in particular stood out in this year’s Piccolo schedule, after the death of Gian Carlo Menotti, Spoleto’s patron saint, in February: a series of three semistaged performances of Mr. Menotti’s gloriously tuneful little opera “Amahl and the Night Visitors” around the city.

headline: Go Here to Stoke Your Stroke
text: THE RACE CLUB

headline: Faster Freestyle: the Gospel According to John Olsen
text: 1. Keep your head down. Forget the old idea of keeping your head high enough so that the water hits you in the forehead. You'll move faster and with less resistance by keeping your head on an even plane with your body, as if you were standing and looking straight ahead.

headline: 2008: Eyes on Early States and the South
text: With a pair of debates Sunday (Democrats) and Tuesday (Republicans) putting the focus on New Hampshire, many in the Democratic field are swinging from that critical early primary state where there’s an event this morning, to Iowa tonight for the state party’s annual Hall of Fame Dinner.

headline: Newsy tidbits
text: Spain has witnessed a 7.4 percent drop in the number of properties sold in 2006, with new-builds down 10.11 percent to 389,594 units. Is more trouble on the horizon?

headline: At Book Expo With Khaled Hosseini
text: The author of "The Kite Runner" and the new best seller "A Thousand Splendid Suns" talks with The Times's Motoko Rich.

headline: Correction: Knives on the Streets
text: A picture caption on May 6 with an article about gang violence in Queens referred incorrectly to the significance of the word “Mecca” on a T-shirt that bore the logo of the Mecca USA clothing company. Though the word Mecca has been adopted by some gang members as an acronym standing for “Murder every Crip child alive,” the company and its logo have no link to gang activity.

headline: Correction: Romancing the Stones
text: An article last Sunday about the transfer of Woodlawn Cemetery’s archives to the Avery Architectural and Fine Arts Library of Columbia University misstated the connection between Janet Parks, the library’s curator of drawings, and Charles Warren, an architect and preservationist who suggested a transfer of archives. Ms. Parks met Mr. Warren through one of her students; she is not a former Columbia classmate of Mr. Warren’s. Also, a picture caption with the article referred imprecisely to the occupation of the three women shown with Susan Olsen, executive director of Friends of Woodlawn, who was on the left. The women are members of the library staff, not researchers. In addition, the article and a picture caption referred imprecisely to Isidor and Ida Straus’s ownership of Macy’s. The Strauses, who died when the Titanic sank, shared ownership of Macy’s with Isidor’s brother Nathan; they were not the sole owners.

headline: Correction: Take This Job and Love It
text: A picture caption with an article last Sunday about subway enthusiasts who pursue jobs with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority misidentified a part of a subway train shown. It was a train operator's cab, not a conductor's booth.

headline: Test Your Ethics (or Lack Thereof)
text: If you have high ethical standards, I have two opportunities for you to contribute to the cause of science.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 3
text: This week’s mix of guests and journalists on the Sunday shows is rather eclectic, but it covers some of the ground again on the topics of the day, week, the month, and yes, the year.

headline: Spoleto Festival U.S.A.: Reviewing the Review
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — It is a beauty of an event like the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. that you can have breakfast with a principal in a review you have just published and have him take issue with your opinions. The conversation with Emmanuel Villaume, the festival’s music director and the conductor of the current production of the Weill-Brecht “Aufstieg und Fall der Stadt Mahagonny,” had been arranged to discuss other matters. But Mr. Villaume begged, politely, to differ with my criticism of “Mahagonny” itself — as I fully expected that many others would, too, if not necessarily politely.

headline: Spoleto Festival U.S.A.: The Nerd of the Instruments, Cool at Last
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. – I am old enough to have learned most of what I know about accordion music from “The Lawrence Welk Show” and foolhardy enough to admit that I actually liked some of it. By the tepid standards of the 1950s, the accordion was almost cool. It became distinctly uncool in later decades, at least in the United States, but in recent years it has been making a comeback in the hands of performers like William Schimmel and Guy Klucevsek.

headline: Breaking News: Clemens Will Miss Chicago Series
text: The Yankees will not start Roger Clemens on Monday in Chicago, after all. Clemens hurt his groin during his last minor league start for Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre on Monday and has been unable to shake the discomfort. He will miss the Chicago series and perhaps be lost for two more weeks. Kei Igawa, who has been in the minors for about a month as he revamps his delivery, is expected to start on Monday against the White Sox.

headline: Hong Kong’s Stanley: sun, sea & shopping
text: The dragon boating on June 19 (see link below) is not the only reason to go to Stanley on the south side of Hong Kong Island. Here are a few others:

text: CHARLESTON, S.C. – The city has two truly distinctive concert halls, and it is sprucing up both of them.

headline: Two More Advance at the Candidates, Six Others Must Play on
text: Two Russians, Sergei Rublevsky and Evgeny Bareev clinched their preliminary candidates matches today at the expense of Ruslan Ponomariov of Ukraine and Judit Polgar of Hungary, respectively. Alexei Shirov of Spain avoided elimination when he beat Michael Adams of England to tie the match and force a playoff tomorrow. Joining them in the playoffs are Magnus Carlsen of Norway and Levon Aronian of Armenia and Rustam Kasimdzhanov of Uzbekistan and Boris Gelfand of Isreal.

text: THE YOGA FACELIFT

headline: Broadway by the Numbers: Remember Those $4 Tickets?
text: THE past season has done little to disprove a familiar lament: As far as Broadway is concerned, the straight play is dead.

headline: Concert Hall? How About Music Museum?
text: NOT long ago the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra decided to sell off its recently acquired collection of vintage string instruments, including 13 made by the legendary Antonio Stradivari. The orchestra is losing money partly because it bought the instruments in the first place, hoping — artistic value aside — that their glamour would attract donations. After all, if museums can flourish by housing objects that are old and valuable, why not orchestras? Most of the music the orchestras play is old and valuable too. The match seemed perfect.

headline: Iraq’s Curse: A Thirst for Final, Crushing Victory
text: BAGHDAD

headline: A Corner Once Sunny, Made Dreary by Drugs
text: In an unexpected detour, Cheryl Graham pushed the stroller with her squirmy 3-year-old into the crowded Kennedy Fried Chicken. Her 7-year-old son, Jyair, his dark eyes beaming, chivalrously held open the door for his family.

headline: One Person, One Office
text: The good news is that the New Jersey Legislature finally seems about to end the practice of holding more than one elective office at a time. The bad news is that legislators will do it with the hypocrisy that New Jerseyans have come to expect of them.

headline: Allison Hecht, Grant Held
text: Allison Hecht and Grant Steven Held were married last evening by Rabbi David M. Posner at the Lotos Club in New York.

headline: When in the Netherlands...
text: ARE WE ROME?” is a much-talked-about new book, but if Justin Giunta were to write his own treatise about the glory of the United States, he might use a different title.

text: Jessica Lynn Antonellis, a daughter of Bunny Antonellis of Needham, Mass., and Paul Antonellis of Newton, Mass., was married last evening to Alexis A. Casano, a daughter of Maryanne Casano of Albany and A. Andrew Casano of Loudonville, N.Y. Nancy Gagnon, a Massachusetts justice of the peace, officiated at the Granite Links Golf Club in Quincy, Mass.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: Music and Dance

headline: Postmodern Homegirl
text: Josephine Baker wasn’t the first young woman to shake a scantily clad brown bottom for the music-hall audiences of Paris during the Roaring Twenties. Chorus girls of every make and model had been strutting up and down the stages of Montmartre for more than a decade by the time Baker hit the scene in 1925, and African-American writers and musicians had been arriving by the boatload since the war. Still, no other American entertainer — male or female, black or white — was ever to achieve as phenomenal a stardom as Baker. Her 50-year-long triumph was a sociocultural moment yet to be repeated.

headline: Still Needing, Still Feeding the Muse at 64
text: THE first video from Paul McCartney’s new album, “Memory Almost Full,” is an otherworldly fantasy, directed by the French filmmaker Michel Gondry, in which a postman brings this former Beatle a box with an old mandolin and, it turns out, an assembly of mischievous ghosts. As Mr. McCartney plays “Dance Tonight,” with its simple percussion and bright pop melody, the ghosts — including one played by Natalie Portman — leap around him, throw sparkling fireballs and scare off the postman. Mr. McCartney later follows them into the box, and as the clip ends, he is seen jamming with them, playing the drums.

headline: Aimee Bartol, Jacob Zissu
text: Aimee Elizabeth Bartol, a daughter of Christine Bartol and Ernest T. Bartol of Syosset, N.Y., was married on Monday to Jacob Royal Zissu, the son of Patricia J. Murphy of New York and Michael J. Zissu of Largo, Fla. C. Raymond Radigan, a retired judge of the Surrogate’s Court of Nassau County, in Mineola, N.Y., officiated at the Woodbury Country Club in Woodbury, N.Y.

headline: Teams Are Warned, but Proctor Is Off Hook
text: BOSTON, June 2 — Scott Proctor insisted after Friday’s game that he had not intentionally thrown at the Red Sox’ Kevin Youkilis when he hit him with a pitch in the ninth inning. The benches and bullpens emptied, and Proctor was ejected. But Bob Watson sided with Proctor.

headline: Three Spaces for the Price of One
text: WAS it a live-work space she needed, a smaller work studio or a cheaper apartment? Beck Hickey wasn’t quite sure, but she knew she needed to downsize.

headline: Target: Trash
text: IT was 5 in the afternoon, and the scratched-up green Dodge pickup was stopped at a light at Foster and Remsen Avenues in Canarsie, Brooklyn. A teetering bureau and a load of wooden slats were in back.

headline: At Pan Am Games, Play It Safe and Enjoy
text: THE World Cup ended nearly a year ago, and the next Olympics are both a year off and on the other side of the world. But for sports fans hooked on international competition, an opportunity is coming up in July: the quadrennial Pan-American Games are being held in Rio de Janeiro.

headline: Summer Bummer
text: The gnashing of teeth never stopped the year my 15-year-old son brought home “A Tale of Two Cities” as his summer reading assignment. According to him, the backbreaking obligation to read Charles Dickens blighted June, ravaged July and obliterated August. Thus, at back-to-school night in September, when his teacher informed parents that their children were gifted, a joy to work with and loved Dickens, I knew she was lying. My kid hated “A Tale of Two Cities.” And he wasn’t alone.

headline: Children’s Books
text: The premise of Dale Peck’s middle-grade series, Drift House, could serve as a metaphor for novel-reading: you enter a mysterious and promising house, then find yourself adrift on timeless waters, adventure all around. In the first book, published in 2005, the three Oakenfeld children are exiled from Manhattan by worried parents after the Sept. 11 attacks and sent to their eccentric Uncle Farley’s remote house on the Bay of Eternity in Canada, where delicious food and scrupulous housekeeping are provided by an apparently invisible staff. The morning following their arrival, after a storm, the children discover that the house has broken free of the shore. They are drifting on the Sea of Time, guided only by the changing images in a drawing room mural and the patchy memories of the youngest Oakenfeld, 5-year-old Murray, who has traveled to the future and back during a game of hide-and-seek.

headline: Buenos Aires:  Cowhide Rugs
text: Argentines love their steak, but it is hard to fully fathom the country's fascination with cows until you walk down Avenida Boedo in the working-class Boedo neighborhood of Buenos Aires. This is where you'll find the wholesale leather district, the prime place to pick up that most Argentine of home accessories — a cowhide for use as a rug — for less than $150.

headline: Money or Your Life
text: Chuck Barris, it appears, is not aging gracefully. This is great news, and not just because there’s a kind of pleasure in thinking that the guy who inflicted “The Newlywed Game” on the world is spending his late 70s cranky and unfulfilled. No, the real payoff for us is that Barris has been able to channel his age rage, along with his eclectic résumé, into a shamelessly entertaining, if somewhat late-to-the-party, comic novel, “The Big Question.”

headline: At Town Hall, an Arboreal Tug of War

headline: Imported Doesn’t Always Mean Important
text: THE mania for all things British continued unabated this season on Broadway, and there’s no reason to believe it will subside anytime soon. The slow slide of the dollar versus the pound notwithstanding, American producers embark on shopping trips to snap up rights to hot London productions with the casual air most of us associate with popping into Duane Reade to pick up a new toothbrush.

headline: Stalling for Time on Iraq (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Two Mothers, a Camera and a Look at School Lunch
text: Bedford

headline: Concentrated Talent
text: IN most years, Rick Porcello, the 2007 Gatorade National Baseball Player of the Year, would have no equal as a high school player. He is a big, right-handed pitcher, a senior at Seton Hall Preparatory School in West Orange, N.J., who throws faster than most pros and whose route to the major leagues could be a short one.

headline: New Dramas, New Voices, Below 14th Street
text: SPEND enough time in small New York theaters, and you will see your share of obscene solo shows, onstage violence and confessions of incest. But after reviewing productions for the last year in the margins of Off Broadway and the wilds of Off Off Broadway, I’ve discovered something much more shocking: hope for the American play.

headline: On Paper, the Pistons Have Already Won
text: For years, N.B.A. coaches have tried to achieve optimum productivity from their players, tinkering and toying with various lineups. To find the most effective combinations of players on the court, coaches have played hunches, ridden hot streaks, gone by the book and against it, and searched as high as Yao Ming and as low as Muggsy Bogues for pieces to fit their hardwood puzzles.

headline: Bollywood Fabulous
text: IN the early morning hours, the D.J. blared remixed Indian folk tunes that drew revelers onto the dance floor of the SoHo night club, gyrating their hips and clasping their arms behind their necks.

headline: Dance, Dance, Revolution
text: COMPARED with most of the issues that the venerable civil liberties lawyer Norman Siegel takes up, this one may seem like the ultimate in urban frivolity: Late last month, he joined hundreds of hip-hoppers, salsa dancers, Lindy Hoppers and techno-heads boogying along Fifth Avenue to protest New York City’s 80-year-old restrictions on dancing in bars.

headline: The Novelist and the Curious Cabbie
text: I WAS standing on the curb, uptown, my hand raised for a cab. It was evening, and the sky was clear and the air cool. I had plenty of time, and I was happy: I was on my way to an international literary festival.

headline: Correction: A Rumble Is Heard in Ataturk’s Grave
text: An article on May 20 about the secularist legacy of Ataturk, the founder of the present Turkish republic, misidentified the party in power when Turkey abolished the death penalty in mid-2002. A secularist coalition dominated Parliament — not the Justice and Development Party, which has Islamic roots and was elected later that year.

headline: With Korea as Model, Bush Team Ponders Long Support Role in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, June 2 — For the first time, the Bush administration is beginning publicly to discuss basing American troops in Iraq for years, even decades to come, a subject so fraught with political landmines that officials are tiptoeing around the inevitable questions about what the United States’ long-term mission would be there.

headline: A City’s Championship Dreams Come Into Focus
text: As I walked through the Cleveland Cavaliers’ Quicken Loans Arena on Saturday evening, there was a sense that this city was about to take a major step toward erasing its tortured sports history. Next door at Jacobs Field, the Indians were battling the Tigers while many fans were still reveling in Friday night’s dramatic comeback victory over Detroit.

headline: So, Sweetie, I Quit to Bake Cupcakes
text: Los Angeles

headline: Shut Me In for the Ballgame
text: If you think you have a dorky hobby, imagine spending several hours a week waiting for a Web site to play simulated baseball games. Then imagine that the teams were constructed using the statistics of nearly every player who has ever played pro baseball, going back to 1885, the vast majority of whom you’ve never heard of. The games are simulated three times a day, so that a season takes about two months. You’re now imagining one of my hobbies. Suddenly your own doesn’t seem so dorky anymore, does it?

headline: New York:  London NYC
text: THE BASICS

headline: On a Block of Stables, an Unexpected Restoration
text: THE Marquand stable, on East 73rd Street, was long thought to be irrevocably entombed in stucco, applied after the rich brick surface had been brutally roughened. But now new owners are going to extraordinary lengths to restore the facade, which will revivify an unusual work by Richard Morris Hunt.

headline: Cooking
text: Editor's Note Appended

headline: Overcoming the U.S. Open
text: Once a year, professional golfers are faced with a course that makes them look like mortals. The United States Open is the sport’s four-day stress test, a marathon of frayed nerves, gnashed teeth and shocking scores. (Just ask Phil Mickelson.) Mike Davis of the United States Golf Association is charged with preparing this year’s Open — to be held this month at Oakmont, near Pittsburgh — just as he was last year at Winged Foot. Playing in his 13th Open, Jim Furyk, the 2003 champion, will try to survive the ordeal. Here, the two men discuss some peculiarities of golf’s toughest tournament.

headline: Swimming for Peace in the Middle East, for the Dalai Lama, for Clean Water, for the Rain Forest. We’ll Drink to That.
text: After completing his 67-day, 3,278-mile swim down the Amazon River on April 8, Martin Strel, a 53-year-old Slovene, did not make the same mistake he made after finishing his 2,360-mile swim down the Mississippi in 2002 — this time, instead of going home to Trebnje, he came to Hollywood. “Jay Leno called us 37 times,” says Strel’s son, Borut, who manages his swimming expeditions, “but we had appointments in Slovenia.”

headline: That Household Name May Also Be a Value Stock
text: LIKE truth and beauty, the term “value” may be in the eye of the beholder. But experts say a few simple guideposts can help investors who are hunting for value stocks under most any market conditions.

headline: Dow Jones, Murdoch and an Enticing ‘Kiss’
text: FOR many people, especially shareholders, money often makes the bitterest of medicines easier to swallow. So too for the Bancroft family, it would seem.

headline: Thousands Rally for Changes to Immigration Bill
text: WASHINGTON, June 2  Thousands of immigrants and their supporters gathered on the west lawn of the Capitol on Saturday to urge the Senate to adopt legislation that would make it easier for illegal immigrants to become legal residents of the United States.

headline:
My Borough Is Not a Parking Lot; A High School
on Governors Island; An Exhibition, Unmentioned (3 Letters)

headline: Gregory Camp for Assembly
text: On Tuesday, New York City will hold another almost-invisible election. Most people in the 65th Assembly District (much of the Upper East Side plus Roosevelt Island) probably have no idea that they can vote that day to elect a successor to Assemblyman Alexander Grannis.

headline: The Royal Me
text: It was after midnight, and the crowd of nightclubbers on West 27th Street was thick and antic. Outside Bungalow 8, there was a police barricade at the curb that said “Do Not Cross.” But why should that stop me? It was cold, and I wanted to get home quickly by skirting the sidewalk hordes and walking in the street.

headline: A High Life After Death? The Candy Man Can
text: SAMMY DAVIS JR. never could stay away from the limelight. Seventeen years after he died of throat cancer, Davis — vaudevillian, singer, actor, Rat Packer — is once again getting the entertainment world’s love he always craved. Four Davis projects are in the works, involving the likes of Denzel Washington, and André 3000, of the hip-hop duo OutKast. Hollywood’s interest, piqued by recent biographies and the resurgence of Rat Pack nostalgia, includes two traditional biopics, an account of his romance with the blond actress Kim Novak and a feature documentary.

headline: Five Catalan Stars, With Small Plates and Long Menus
text: AT a glance, Barcelona's Inopia doesn't look like a place where you'd want to spend much time. More a bar than a restaurant, it's impossibly bright, with white walls and bare fluorescent fixtures. The room is small, irregularly shaped, and — save for one table that's reserved for large groups — there is barely any seating. Almost everyone manages with stools, or leans or stands — some outside, having ordered through the window.

headline: Outlaw DNA
text: It was a single line from a longer e-mail message. But when read into the record by prosecutors at the drug trial last year of the German track coach Thomas Springstein, it caused a sensation. “The new Repoxygen is hard to get,” Springstein had written. “Please give me new instructions soon so that I can order the product before Christmas.”

headline: An East Village Haven for Meat Lovers Closes Its Doors
text: There is no more of the best-selling baked ham, which takes two and a half weeks to cure and 24 hours to smoke in the shop’s own smoke pits, and sold for $5.59 a pound. And there is very little left of the second big seller, kielbasa, which takes four hours to smoke, and sold for $4.79 a pound.

headline: Talia Rubin, Yaron Langman
text: Dr. Talia B. Rubin, a daughter of Evelyn C. Rubin-Houpt of Englewood, N.J., and Ronald I. Rubin of Riverdale, the Bronx, is to be married this afternoon to Dr. Yaron D. Langman, the son of Roberta Langman and Samuel Langman of Freehold, N.J. Rabbi Shmuel Goldin is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Keter Torah in Teaneck, N.J.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 2, 2007

headline: 533,000 Miles and It Runs Like a Top
text: THERE is no one secret to getting your car to live to a ripe old odometer reading. Luck could get you there, but it is no surprise that many vehicles that have reached 200,000, 400,000 and even 500,000 miles have received extraordinary care and maintenance, often with the owners doing the routine work themselves.

headline: Up Front
text: John Hodgman may be best known these days for his appearances on “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” and in those ubiquitous Apple Computer ads. (He’s also a contributing writer to The Times Magazine and the author of a book, “The Areas of My Expertise.”) For three years Hodgman has also been, happily for us, the Book Review’s comics critic. Hodgman has been obsessed with the form, he told us in an e-mail interview, since elementary school. “If there is one thing that sums up the cultural mood of a certain niche of non-sports-playing boys in the early ’80s, it is Wolverine fighting ninjas in Japan as drawn by Frank Miller,” he wrote.

headline: Ladies Who Read
text: No country house murder or cockpit cliffhanger can get a cast of characters more efficiently assembled and down to business than a fictional book-discussion group. Karen Joy Fowler brought this device some sparkling exposure a few years ago with “The Jane Austen Book Club.” In more pastel-shaded mode, Hilma Wolitzer’s latest novel uses it to frame a gentle summer triptych of interlinked lives, complete with three happy endings.

headline: Ready to Improve Your Game? The Experts Offer Some Advice
text: With summer (nearly) here, the time is right for improving your game. While some people catch up on reading, chess players can use the longer days to study and train.

headline: Letters
text: The Architecture Issue

headline: The Swimmers
text: Haven’t we all awakened from time to time hoping that perhaps this will be the day a book comes along about swimming pools?

headline: A Fully Grown Adult Baby
text: It was tax time. I owed money this year, and I was on my way to the post office to mail my payments. You can imagine the honey of a mood I was in. Not only did I get to give the government even more money than it had already taken, I also had the pleasure of getting to stand in line at the post office and of being “helped” by a postal employee I will simply refer to as the Biggest Sweetheart in the World (known from here on simply as Sweetheart).

headline: Putting Pay to Play on Notice
text: The City Council is poised to address some of the worst abuses of New York’s otherwise progressive campaign financing system. If the legislation now being shepherded by Speaker Christine Quinn curbs the influence of powerful interests, it could set a new standard for clean local government. That’s an exciting prospect: It is conservatively estimated that in 2005 more than one-fifth of campaign donations came from special interests like city contractors and lobbyists.

headline: Two Mothers, a Camera and a Fresh Take on School Lunches
text: Fairfield

headline: The Law and the Elderly
text: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut do not place any restrictions on elderly drivers. “We don’t say, ‘Hey, you’re 90, you have to take a special test,’ ” says Kevin Cranston, a spokesman for the New Jersey Motor Vehicle Commission.

headline: Correction
text: An entry on the hardcover advice best-seller list on May 20 for “The Dangerous Book for Boys” misstated the given name of one of its co-authors. He is Conn Iggulden, not Gonn.

headline: 36 Hours in Florence
text: WHEN Roman soldiers founded Florence around 60 B.C., its original name was Florentia, meaning “may she flourish.” It may have taken some 1,500 years, but flourish she did — becoming home and inspiration to Dante, Michelangelo and a lot of other really, really talented people. That's a source of pride for a city that clings to its history. Wander around, and you get the sense that Florentines never got the memo that Italy's capital moved south 140 years ago. That may explain its enduring appeal to legions of tourists and art-history majors. But the city's reputation as a tourist trap in Renaissance clothing may be undeserved. Florence still has the ability to surprise, with modern art, specialty shops and trendy bars. And with a half-dozen breathtaking gardens overlooking it all, not only is the city flourishing, it's in full bloom.

headline: Veronica Beke and Christopher Aquilino
text: Veronica Anne Beke and Christopher Thomas Aquilino were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Robert J. Duncan at the United Methodist Church of Southampton in Southampton, N.Y.

headline: Remembering the Royal Wedding of 1947
text: Those impatient for Prince William to wed should instead visit Buckingham Palace this summer, where they can experience Queen Elizabeth’s royal wedding all over again — or for the first time. From July 28 to Sept. 25 an exhibition will celebrate the 60th anniversary of the marriage of Elizabeth, then a princess, to the Duke of Edinburgh in November 1947.

headline: Making Cyberspace Safer
text: MySpace.com, the Internet social networking site, has gained tens of millions of users in the four short years it has been in business. But as users have multiplied, creating their own web pages on the site, rare but troubling incidents have increased, too. Sexual assailants have monitored MySpace Web sites to prey upon minors who ill-advisedly post highly personal information about themselves.
