text: Julia Harris Taft, a daughter of Julia V. Taft and William H. Taft IV of Lorton, Va., was married there yesterday to Christof Blackman Putzel, the son of Ann Blackman and Michael Putzel of Washington. Leora Motley, a civil marriage celebrant in Fairfax County, Va., officiated at the home of the bride’s parents.

headline: America’s Cup: Team New Zealand Widens Its Lead
text: VALENCIA, Spain, June 2 — After outclassing the lone entry from the United States in the semifinals of the Louis Vuitton Cup, Luna Rossa Challenge is searching for answers and for the lead, any lead, after falling behind by 2-0 to Emirates Team New Zealand in the finals.

headline: A Loathing Supreme
text: Surf rivalries are generally rather tame affairs, but consider the opening salvo in the war between Ken Bradshaw and Mark Foo, as told in Andy Martin’s new book, “Stealing the Wave” (Bloomsbury, $24.95). Bradshaw and Foo were the premier big-wave surfers at Hawaii’s Waimea Bay, and one morning in the mid-1980s, Foo “dropped in” on Bradshaw — meaning he co-opted his wave. Bradshaw flew into a De Niro-esque rage — You’re dropping in on me? — and exacted his revenge by clotheslining Foo and taking a bite out of his favorite surfboard. It makes charging the mound seem tame by comparison.

headline: Boy to Man, a Life in Planes
text: GROWING up, I lived behind an airport in Augusta, Ga. All I had to do was climb over a fence. I’d sit in the planes and pretend I was flying, until someone chased me out.

headline: Correction: Grooming a Handwriting Champion
text: The Parenting column last Sunday, about a seventh-grade handwriting champion at a Roman Catholic school, St. Pius V, in Melville, gave an incomplete account of the circumstances surrounding the suspensions of several students last year. While a parent said the suspensions were for remarks about the school’s nuns that students posted on the Internet, the principal, Sister Maria Dolorosa, said the students were suspended because they used the Internet to view movies and listen to music that they knew were prohibited by the school.

headline: A Fly on the Gallery Wall
text: AT a glance, Mia, the self-effacing heroine of “Lulu Meets God and Doubts Him,” Danielle Ganek’s catty vivisection of the New York art world, has little in common with her peers. They are “gallerinas,” formidably icy girl Fridays, imperious behind their steel-and-stone desks at Manhattan galleries.

headline: Not Even Clemens Is Immune to Injury Streak
text: BOSTON, June 2  A season rife with injuries took another discouraging turn for the Yankees on Saturday when they learned that Roger Clemens would miss his start in Chicago on Monday with a right groin injury.

headline: Colette Reiner, Gibson Verkuil
text: Colette A. Reiner, the daughter of Colleen A. Reiner of Ventura, Calif., and the late Robert C. Reiner, was married on Friday to John Gibson Verkuil, the son of Frances Gibson McGlothlin of Austin, Tex., and Paul R. Verkuil of Miami Beach.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article today on Page 12 of the special Tony Awards section of Arts & Leisure about indelible moments on Broadway omits, in some copies, several words in the first two paragraphs of an item on “The Coast of Utopia.” The passage should read:

headline: Term Limits Force an Early Start to ’09 Campaign
text: Melinda R. Katz, a city councilwoman from Queens, has held so many fund-raisers in her campaign for city comptroller in recent months that she cannot remember the precise number — “somewhere between seven and 10.”

headline: Before the Cobblestones Vanish, a Push to Preserve
text: IN 1997, when preservationists and residents of the Dumbo neighborhood of Brooklyn were campaigning to have the area listed on the National Register of Historic Places, they commissioned a series of photographs to depict its industrial grandeur, from its cobblestone streets to its cavernous warehouse buildings, all perched on the waterfront between the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges.

headline: Loosey-Goosey Voice on, Yeah, Public Radio
text: BILL BRADLEY, the former senator, was on public radio earnestly discussing how politicians communicate with Americans when the interviewer, Faith Salie, asked, “If Thomas Jefferson had a blog, what would he be writing about?”

headline: Unearthing the Bad News
text: School officials in the northern New Jersey suburb of Paramus abdicated their responsibility for assuring student safety by waiting more than four months before warning parents about contaminated soil just outside a middle school.

headline: At a 50-Year-Old Art Center, All Things Clay
text: MIDWAY through its yearlong 50th-anniversary celebration, the Clay Art Center, housed in a two-story building at the back of a municipal parking lot in Port Chester, is setting up its next exhibition, “At the Table: Morning, Noon and Night.” The exhibit will feature tableware made by 50 past and present Clay Art Center members — from full place settings to pitchers, trays, serving bowls, platters, candlesticks and even wall sculptures — all laid out on cloth-draped tables. At the opening reception, on Friday, some of those pieces will be filled with food prepared from Potluck, the new cookbook of 250 recipes gathered from and compiled by Clay Art Center members.

headline: Investigator Faults Colonel for Actions During Killings
text: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., June 2  The Marine infantry officer investigating accusations against a former battalion commander in charge of marines who killed 24 Iraqi civilians in 2005 on Saturday implicitly criticized the commander’s decisions to remain miles away during an hours-long battle with insurgents linked to Al Qaeda.

headline: When Should a Kid Start Kindergarten?
text: According to the apple-or-coin test, used in the Middle Ages, children should start school when they are mature enough for the delayed gratification and abstract reasoning involved in choosing money over fruit. In 15th- and 16th-century Germany, parents were told to send their children to school when the children started to act “rational.” And in contemporary America, children are deemed eligible to enter kindergarten according to an arbitrary date on the calendar known as the birthday cutoff — that is, when the state, or in some instances the school district, determines they are old enough. The birthday cutoffs span six months, from Indiana, where a child must turn 5 by July 1 of the year he enters kindergarten, to Connecticut, where he must turn 5 by Jan. 1 of his kindergarten year. Children can start school a year late, but in general they cannot start a year early. As a result, when the 22 kindergartners entered Jane Andersen’s class at the Glen Arden Elementary School near Asheville, N.C., one warm April morning, each brought with her or him a snack and a unique set of gifts and challenges, which included for some what’s referred to in education circles as “the gift of time.”

headline: Hollywood Finds a Match Made in Connecticut
text: STAMFORD

headline: A Detour to Iowa Showcases ’08 Democrats
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, June 2 — On the eve of a presidential debate in New Hampshire, five Democratic candidates made a quick detour to Iowa on Saturday evening to appeal to nearly 1,000 party activists, seeking to distinguish themselves to the voters who will open the 2008 nominating fight.

headline: What You Get for ...$300,000
text: Sheffield, Mass.

headline: Demand for School Chiefs Pushes Salaries Up
text: SALARIES for school superintendents rose at a rate well above inflation on Long Island last year, according to new state figures, as school board officials say it is increasingly difficult to find the leadership needed to meet the high expectations of suburban parents and homeowners.

headline: Grilling, for the Easily Distracted
text: BACKYARD chefs are often judged solely on the succulence of their barbecued meats. As a result, a summer cookout can be a stressful affair; overdone ribs and roasts can mar a grill master’s culinary reputation.

headline: After Injuring Her Groin, Fifth-Seeded Mauresmo Loses
text: PARIS, June 2  During the first set of her third-round match Saturday, Amélie Mauresmo felt a twinge in her right groin, and right then, her chances at winning the French Open vanished.

headline: Fighting in Northern Lebanese Camp Spreads
text: SIDON, Lebanon, Monday, June 4 — The deadly volley of shelling and sniper fire at a refugee camp in northern Lebanon intensified Sunday and fighting broke out between militants and the Lebanese Army in another camp in the south, increasing fears that the two-week battle between the Lebanese Army and Islamist militants could spread to other parts of the country.

headline: On Offense and Defense, Lowell Leaves His Mark
text: BOSTON, June 2 — During the Boston Red Sox’ 11-6 victory against the Yankees on Saturday at Fenway Park, Mike Lowell tormented the Yankees in just about every way possible.

headline: The Best Buildings You’ll Ever Hear
text: COULD it be that we’re entering a golden age in concert hall design?

headline: Jeff Daniels and Alison Pill
text: Shed more than a decade in 90 minutes, without plastic surgery. This miraculous act of rejuvenation is achieved by Jeff Daniels and Alison Pill in “Blackbird” at the Manhattan Theater Club. Their mastery of the art of growing younger is a big factor in making David Harrower’s drama the season’s most compelling — and devastating.

headline: Sex, With Consequences
text: AT least since Ovid, sex has been the theme music in much of Western literature, played at variable volume in all its many keys: sex as fate, as fun, as tedium and emotional torture, as stand-in for religious devotion and, until not that many decades ago, as the fastest way in fiction to lose honor, home and head.

headline: The Whistle-Blower
text: Q: As the male escort who outed Ted Haggard, the celebrity preacher and former head of the New Life Church in Colorado Springs, it was probably inevitable that you would write a memoir about your affair with him. Are you concerned that your new book, “I Had to Say Something,” exploits his sorrows for financial gain? No. I received a very small advance for the book. And when I decided to come out with the story last year, I lost everything. I lost all my massage clients; I lost all my personal-training clients. I got fired from my modeling job at the art school.

text: Doors Open: Chapter 4: The Faker

headline: A Legal Debate in Guantánamo on Boy Fighters
text: The facts of Omar Ahmed Khadr’s case are grim. The shrapnel from the grenade he is accused of throwing ripped through the skull of Sgt. First Class Christopher J. Speer, who was 28 when he died.

text: Simone Mindwell Marean and Daniel Nathan Kasen were married yesterday by the Rev. Arrington Chambliss, an Episcopal priest, at Our Lady of the Evergreens, a chapel in Harborside, Me.

headline: Class-Action Firms Extend Reach to Global Rights Cases
text: The plaintiffs are thousands of boys from South Asia and Africa who say they were abducted, enslaved and forced to ride racing camels to entertain the rich in the Middle East. The defendants live in the United Arab Emirates.

headline: TVR’s Long and Winding Road Leads (for Now) to Florida
text: LIKE the mythical Monty Python castle built on a swamp, which sank three times only to be rebuilt three times, one of Britain’s last sports car makers has risen again after several near-death experiences and ownership changes.

headline: In Silicon Valley, the Crash Seems Like Just Yesterday
text: GRANDPA lived through the Depression, and life thereafter was indelibly shaped by haunting memories of soup kitchens and hobos. Similarly, the digerati of Silicon Valley endured the 1990s dot-com bubble, and since then have lived with the psychic shock of its ignoble end.

headline: Company for an Only Child, and for Parents, Peace of Mind
text: PARSIPPANY, N.J.  It would have been an innocent picture: Katie Hall, age 9, enjoying an outing with her mother and a dozen children like her, playing on the plastic slides of a Fuddruckers restaurant at dinnertime.

headline: For Free Spirit, the Tour Is the Latest Adventure
text: DUBLIN, Ohio, June 2  Will MacKenzie’s hobbies include heliboarding in Alaska and surfing in Hawaii.

headline: The Next Big Thing in Law? The Harsh Jurisprudence of Justice Thomas
text: In the last 100 Supreme Court arguments, Clarence Thomas has not uttered a word. Court watchers have suggested a variety of explanations. Among the least flattering: he is afraid that if he speaks he will reveal his ignorance about the case; he is so ideologically driven that he invariably comes with his mind made up; or he has contempt for the process.

headline: First and Long — Very Long
text: Bill Hambrecht is a rich old Wall Street guy who has made his money tilting at windmills and disrupting the establishment. “That’s what I do,” he says. “It’s fun.” Almost a decade ago, at 62, he founded WR Hambrecht + Company, whose fundamental premise is that companies don’t need to use Wall Street investment bankers — and pay their outrageous fees — to go public. Hambrecht + Company has since become so threatening to traditional underwriters that they often refuse to be involved in any I.P.O. in which his firm takes part.

headline: Jennifer Reid, Luis Andrade
text: Jennifer Jermond Reid and Luis Bolivar Andrade Marquez were married last evening at Preservation Park in Oakland, Calif. Samuel A. Dexter, a friend of the couple who was appointed as a deputy marriage commissioner by Alameda County, officiated.

headline: Cast Off, Characters!
text: If everything proceeds as planned – not that it ever does – late on the afternoon of July 7, in the Mediterranean waters fronting the ancient Spanish city of Valencia, one middle-aged man’s $100 million, four-year-long campaign to win the America’s Cup will explode in his face. Precisely to whom this will occur has yet to be decided. Word along the waterfront identifies several good candidates. Larry Ellison, the billionaire software magnate behind the American entry, BMW Oracle, is a popular choice. Another is Patrizio Bertelli, the head of the Italian effort and the C.E.O. of the design house Prada, his boats’s main sponsor. Then there is Ernesto Bertarelli, an elegant 41-year-old billionaire from Geneva who is the current holder of the Cup, which his team, Alinghi, wrested away from New Zealand in 2003.

headline: Bridge Bombing Increases Tensions in Northern Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, June 2  Bomb blasts severely damaged a bridge linking a highway from Baghdad with the northern city of Kirkuk on Saturday, the police and witnesses said, heightening tensions between Arabs and Kurds and forcing traffic to detour through some of the most dangerous areas of Diyala Province.

headline: Relative Distance
text: Recently, my Indian grandmother visited the United States for a prolonged stay. She has made this journey several times, but she is 79 now, and my mother said that this would be her last trip. Since her last visit I had become a mother, and my grandmother made a point of delaying her return to India so that she could attend Maya’s first birthday celebration at my home in Boston.

text: Boston

text: MORBI, India  Meet the men and women building the new India.

headline: For One Gender, It’s Even Lonelier at the Top
text: If you’re a woman and you aspire to be a C.E.O., you’re better off working in nonprofits or health care. And you may want to avoid the semiconductor and the aerospace industries.

headline: Cameras Were Ready; The Revolution Wasn’t

headline: Shepherding the Suburban Returnees
text: WHEN my parents moved us from a cramped apartment in an aging industrial city out to a raw new development in the suburbs, it seemed like Disney’s Frontierland  without Uncle Walt’s thoughtful amenities. Dad took the Chevy to work, so the rest of us walked everywhere at first. The nearest loaf of bread was about a mile away. My mother adored her new pink ranch with the blue-tiled bathroom, but she missed the corner store and her sisters a short walk away. In a weak moment, as we struggled toward town against a mean November wind with my little brother, she yelled into the gale, “How do people live here?”

headline: Suicide Bomber Misses Somalia’s Premier
text: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 3 — A suicide bomber narrowly missed killing Somalia’s transitional prime minister on Sunday afternoon after he rammed a pickup truck packed with explosives into the gates of the prime minister’s house in Mogadishu, the capital.

headline: A Room With a View? No, but It’s Cheaper

headline: Heartburn and Magic
text: I approached “The Best Place to Be” with suspicion. When a book is called “a novel in stories,” as this one is on its cover, I wonder: Is it a ploy to avoid the heavy lifting of novel writing? Is the writer incapable of connecting the dots — or fresh from an M.F.A. program, armed with a collection of stories that happen to feature the same character?

headline: Laurie Corn, Frank Powell
text: Laurie Beth Corn and Frank Powell were married last evening at the Ritz-Carlton on Amelia Island, Fla. Rabbi Michael Matuson officiated.

headline: Mix, Scratch and Spin: You, Too, Can Become a D.J.
text: AT nightclubs, Bill Blaney long admired the skills and style of hip-hop D.J.’s. He spoke for years about wanting to keep an audience enthralled by scratching records and mixing digital sound to create music.

text: The neon frankfurter on the front window, nestled neatly in a bun, would seem to say all you need to know regarding Capitol Lunch. It’s true, hot dogs are the primary business of this barebones place, which grills thousands of them every week.

text: THE Strathmere Fishing and Environmental Club had its annual opening day flounder tournament last Saturday, a beautiful late-spring day.

headline: A Mountain Laurel by Any Other Name
text: THE mountain laurel, Connecticut’s state flower, was blooming in New England when the earliest settlers arrived. Today, on roadsides in suburban gardens, pink and white clouds of blossoms flourish every June from Florida to Maine.

headline: Surprise Breaks Out of the Box (or Cube)
text: WHEN visitors to the Venice Biennale arrive next week at the Argentine Pavilion to see paintings by Guillermo Kuitca, the Buenos Aires artist known for canvases based on maps, architectural blueprints and seating plans, they may wonder whether they are in the right place. “I can hardly recognize myself,” Mr. Kuitca, 46, said on a recent afternoon at Sperone Westwater, his New York gallery, as he conceded that he found his four new epic-scale works very strange.

headline: For Rivers, Pursuit of a Different Triple Crown
text: Mickey Rivers was too young to enter Tropical Park racetrack in Miami about 50 years ago, so he watched the horses from behind a fence. Rivers spoke to everyone about the horses. Before a race, his mother would go to him for some advice and for his contribution to a $2 bet.

headline: Men Will Be Boys
text: When Alvy Singer and Annie Hall split up, he tells her a relationship is like a shark: “It has to constantly move forward or it dies. And I think what we got on our hands is a dead shark.”

headline: P.S. I Loved You

headline: The Old Devil
text: In the years between the publication of his first novel, “Lucky Jim,” in 1954 and his death in 1995, Kingsley Amis enjoyed, to a degree matched by few of his contemporaries, the career of a Major British Author. Toward the end of it, he harvested some of the traditional honors associated with such status: a CBE, a Booker Prize, six-figure advances, knighthood. These he had earned through decades of clockwork productivity, the kind of brisk, un-neurotic industriousness more often associated with Major British Authors than with their American cousins. There was a new novel every couple of years — more than 20 in all — and in the intervals between them a steady outpouring of stories, reviews, poems, opinion pieces and travelogues. As a biographical note at the front of one of Amis’s later books put it, “he has written ephemerally on politics, education, language, films, television, restaurants and drink.”

headline: Letters
text: How Detroit Can Rebound

headline: Reviving a Birthplace of Civil Rights
text: J. W. ROBINSON, 80, remembers when the Sweet Auburn neighborhood of Atlanta was a mecca for aspiring African-American professionals like himself. Just out of college in the early 1950s, Mr. Robinson, a fledgling architect, used to frequent the stylish establishments along the 1.5-mile-long stretch of Auburn Avenue — among them the Royal Peacock, a nightclub that featured Ray Charles and well-known jazz performers of the day.

headline: Where the World Meets Sweden, and Vice Versa
text: LIKE its big sister Stockholm, Goteborg, Sweden's second city, is as much about boats and water as it is about bricks and mortar. Built on the broad estuary of the Gota River, greater Goteborg stretches for miles before fanning out into the North Sea across an archipelago of some 1,000 islands.

headline: For the Sergeants, a Hip New Boot, Stripes Included
text: Just inside the front door of the Training Camp sneaker store on West 45th Street, rows of Adidas and Converse shoes in dozens of wild color combinations are lined up. But for a small group of shoppers, these flashy items are hard-pressed to compete with the understated wares on display near the back of the store.

headline: Time’s Guardian
text: NEW YORKERS look to the time the way farmers look to the weather. Many have their own idiosyncratic maps of public street clocks they rely on, scurrying to work or late for appointments, but few would imagine that so many of those clocks run thanks to a man named Marvin Schneider.

headline: Shattering Stereotypes About Immigrant Workers
text: AS immigration legislation slowly makes its way through Congress, the debate about illegal immigrants’ role in the economy has intensified. To some people, they represent a black-market work force that is lowering the wages of legal immigrants and native-born Americans. To others, they are an essential part of several big industries. What’s the truth?

headline: A High School Drama Over Artistic Freedom
text: Pleasantville

headline: My Right Arm
text: There are few things in sports more full of promise than a major-league clubhouse before a game, and on this second Monday in April — the home opener for the Chicago Cubs in the frumpish glory that is forever Wrigley Field — the Cubs’ clubhouse is brimming with a hopefulness that seems positively staggering.

headline: Public Detectives
text: Sand Lake, N.Y.

headline: Travel
text: Travel books can generally be divided into two categories. First there are the ones in which all the traveling is done in the journey to an intended destination, at which point the writer stays put. And then there are the books in which the writer never stops — jetting, cycling, cruising or otherwise gamboling about — often at breakneck, TGV speed.

headline: Yet Again, Camping’s Loss Is Land Preservation’s Gain
text: ANOTHER summer camp may soon become publicly owned open space in eastern Suffolk County, where the sale of camps that have become increasingly expensive to operate has helped local governments meet land-preservation goals.

The “Living In” article last Sunday, about Morningside Heights in Upper Manhattan, misstated the destination of the No. 60 bus. It is La Guardia Airport, not Kennedy Airport. In addition, a map with the article mislabeled the neighborhood’s northern boundary. It is 125th Street, not 125th Avenue.

headline: The Iceman Cometh
text: It’s particularly fitting that the title of Damien Hirst’s new headline-grabbing work came from an exasperated exclamation of his mother’s: “For the love of God, what are you going to do next?”

headline: Fairer, Still a Half-Step
text: Public high schools routinely discipline students who use, sell or possess illegal drugs or alcohol. But they frequently single out athletes for extra discipline — barring them from competition, for instance — because of the special status such students have among their peers.

headline: Samantha Bishopp, Ryan Mollett
text: Samantha Noelle Bishopp, a daughter of Claudia Reynaud Bishopp and Malcolm F. Bishopp, both of New York, was married yesterday to Ryan DeForest Mollett, a son of Dorothy Mollett and Richard C. Mollett of Taneytown, Md. The Rev. Dr. William F. R. Gilroy, a Lutheran minister, officiated at Antrim 1844, a Taneytown inn that is owned by the bridegroom’s parents.

headline: Menus and Summer Music
text: The summer-long River to River Festival, which begins this weekend, offers more than 500 free performances and arts events throughout Lower Manhattan. These restaurants, which are among the newer dining spots in the area, are all short walks from many of the festival sites.

headline: Boys Gone Mild
text: I remember we called it “play.” It occurred on weekends and after school, when the grown-ups weren’t around. Sometimes it hurt. It hurt when the ball struck someone in the face. It hurt when the thing we were climbing — the tree, the fire escape, the face of the sandstone cliff beside the river — suddenly grew slippery or broke. But those were mere physical injuries. They healed, often after trips to the emergency room. The injuries that lingered were the emotional ones, incurred when someone came in last in one of the contests we dreamed up. And, being boys (girls were simply not part of our thinking), we made contests out of everything, from walking, balance-beam style, down the railroad tracks to collecting crawfish from the creek.

headline: Correction: A Dot-Com City Comes Back After the Collapse
text: The Next Stop column on May 20 about a cultural revival in San Jose, Calif., misstated the amount and the donor of a gift to help restore the California Theater there. It was $25 million — not $75 million — and it was given by the Packard Humanities Institute, not by David Packard, who is president of the institute.

headline: The Wal-Mart of College Sports
text: In Bentonville, Ark., secret agents inside the world of Wal-Mart have gone so far as to press an ear on a hotel room door to snoop on employees suspected of canoodling against the company code of prim culture.

headline: Correction: At 12,000 Feet, Andean Culture Meets Pop Art
text: The Cultured Traveler column last Sunday about La Paz, Bolivia, misstated the surname in some copies for Roberto Cazorla Guzman, the owner of the Costilla de Adán bar. As the article noted in other references, he is Mr. Cazorla, not Mr. Guzman.

headline: First, Cure Malaria. Next, Global Warming.
text: AMYRIS BIOTECHNOLOGIES has almost finished developing a cheap cure for malaria that could save the lives of millions of the poor. Now, using the same technology, this start-up in Emeryville, Calif., wants to create new biofuels that may help save the planet.

headline: For the Hot Dog Faithful
text: Bill Yuengling, who grew up in Westwood, spent many hours of his childhood, he says, driving around the state with his father in search of the best hot dog they could find. It was all groundwork for Hot Dog Heaven in Emerson, the shop he opened six years ago.
