text: Primary Features Several Contested Races

headline: ‘Four Queens’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Plugged In at Home, but Somehow Left Out
text: I KNEW that there was a problem when I found myself waiting for my telephone to ring. Not, mind you, to talk to the person on the other end, but to listen to my answering machine.

headline: Boho in Boston
text: BOSTON

headline: Children’s Books
text: Even a decade ago, there were very few books in the young adult section of the bookstore that a reasonably sophisticated 16-year-old would enjoy. Back then, “YA” novels were almost always written for (and sold to) middle-school students. Now, books like “The Astonishing Life of Octavian Nothing” and “The Book Thief” are being read not only by teenagers but also by their parents.

headline: Glorious Dissolution: Musicians on Film
text: IN “Last Days,” Gus Van Sant’s meditation on the demise of Kurt Cobain, a record executive confronts the incoherent, drug-addled “Blake” about what he will tell his daughter. “Do you say,” she asks, “ ‘I’m sorry I’m a rock ’n’ roll cliché’?”

headline: Using Wood to Define an Open Space
text: DAVID HOWELL, a Manhattan architect, stood looking at the old brick loft building at 295 Third Avenue, between 22nd and 23rd Streets, his gaze traveling up from the street-level bar to the tall windows above.

headline: 1989: Spinach Roman Style
text: Sometimes I think we don’t feel enough shame for the things we put on our plates in the 1980s — the towers of tuna sprouting chives, the squiggles of mayonnaise. But in the decade’s defense, it did mark the beginning of the love fest for Italian cooking that still continues. Back then, The Times published a spate of stories about Italian dishes like risotto, polenta and biscotti. In an article on antipasti in this magazine, published in 1989, there was a terrific recipe for spinach “Roman style,” or sautéed spinach with raisins and pine nuts.

headline: Senators Try to Rally in Hockey-Bruised Ottawa
text: OTTAWA  At a pep rally May 24 to celebrate the Senators’ advance to the Stanley Cup finals, several thousand people filled the plaza at City Hall and the mayor declared Ottawa “Swaggerville,” trying to wash away its image as the sleepy national capital full of easily bruised hockey fans.

headline: Pirates of the Caribbean
text: On Nov. 22, 1718, Edward Thatch, better known as Blackbeard, was killed in a bloody shipboard battle. His face slashed, his body rent by musket balls, he fought savagely until — and here surviving accounts of the battle diverge — he either succumbed to his many wounds or was felled by a single blow from a sword, which left his head dangling from his shoulder by a ribbon of flesh. Whether Blackbeard was decapitated in the heat of battle or only after death, in the cold administration of 18th-century punishment, justice had prevailed. His vanquishers — American sailors led by a dashing young lieutenant — lashed his head to their bowsprit for the journey home to Virginia, then hung their terrible prize from a pole on the banks of the Hampton River.

headline: A Family Tradition
text: If students of George Bernard Shaw can be called Shavians, a friend of Evelyn Waugh’s named John Sutro argued, then those interested in all things Waugh might be called Wavians. I now realize that, without knowing it, I have been a Wavian for many years. And I opened this book eagerly, anticipating a trove of revelation about the author’s father, Auberon, and grandfather Evelyn. Instead, I was engrossed for almost half the book by an extraordinary depiction of the true paterfamilias, Arthur Waugh, whose position in London publishing helped launch his two sons — the elder brother, Alec, and the younger, Evelyn — on their careers as authors. Here is a sample of the old boy’s prose. He is writing to his favorite, Alec, who has been having a spot of sexual trouble at school:

headline: Allison Babb, Michael Christopher
text: Allison White Babb and Michael Scott Christopher were married yesterday in New Paltz, N.Y. The Rev. Howard B. Major III performed the ceremony at the New Paltz Reformed Church.

headline: Utility Judgment
text: A utility pole behind our garage was rotting and likely to fall, so we notified the utility company. Weeks passed without action. Then my wife, the executive director of a small nonprofit agency, contacted a member of her board, who heads the utility. The pole was replaced within 48 hours. Now my wife feels she did wrong. Did she? — Michael Grimaldi, Kansas City, Mo.

headline: Bagels, Bialys and Raspberries
text: It seemed like a harmless enough name, but when Ravi Aggarwal decided to call his new shop Arena Bagels and Bialys, he learned otherwise.

headline: A Day in the Life of an Interconnected World
text: DANIEL ALTMAN, a well-traveled columnist for this section, earned a Ph.D. in economics from Harvard. In “Connected: 24 Hours in the Global Economy” (Farrar, Straus, Giroux, $24), he promises to use his formidable knowledge and access to take readers beyond stock market indexes and into the inner workings of the global economy.

headline: The Tangled Web
text: In the long history of espionage, spies have routinely used hoaxes to fool their enemies. During World War II, the Allies employed Operation Bodyguard — creating an entire fake army — to keep the Germans guessing about where they would land on D-Day. Since the time of the czars, the Russian security services have been especially fond of deception and disinformation. The Communist K.G.B. (and its predecessor, the N.K.V.D.) routinely used false defectors and phony sources to lure and entrap credulous Western spies, who in the early days of the cold war fell for ruses with embarrassing regularity. During the late 1940s and early ’50s, the British and Americans sent money and parachuted doomed volunteers behind the Iron Curtain to resistance networks that were actually under Communist control.

headline: Jane DiGiacomo, Miles Parker
text: Jane DiGiacomo and Miles Travis Parker were married yesterday at Louse Point Beach in East Hampton, N.Y. Dorothy Dai-en Friedman, a Buddhist priest, officiated, with Michel Engu Dobbs, also a Buddhist priest, taking part.

headline: The Mets’ Fill-In Lineup Brings Down the Diamondbacks
text: Rubén Gotay had an old-fashioned case of ants in his pants before the Mets played the Diamondbacks yesterday. Gotay, a reserve infielder who can also play the outfield in a pinch, knew that several starters were injured. He hoped Manager Willie Randolph would insert him into the starting lineup. Gotay checked and double-checked the lineup board in the Mets’ clubhouse, but it was not set.

headline: We Don’t Need No Stinking Baseball
text: Consider this the next time you’re tweaking your fantasy baseball lineup: you are part of an intellectual revolution. A minor revolution, perhaps, somewhat less ambitious than the call to arms described in “Moneyball,” but a revolution all the same. With every hour you spend “managing” your fantasy team, with every moment spent devouring the literary output of experts like Ron Shandler, the fabled publisher of Baseball Forecaster, or Matthew Berry, a writer otherwise known as “the Talented Mr. Roto,” with every soul fiber you sink into fantasy baseball, you move one step closer to becoming a postmodern baseball fan. Makes you feel better, no?

headline: As Preschoolers Are Shown the Door, Parents Cry Foul Play
text: TWENTY-SIX years ago, a ragtag collection of artists and working-class parents united to transform the decrepit Public School 122 into both a day care center for neighborhood children and a funky refuge for painters and performers.

headline: A Dialogue Between Plays and the World
text: IT seems inevitable that every awards season eventually becomes an occasion to lament the state of the medium receiving the toast. We decry the pandering. We rage against the casting of movie stars onstage; we scream at the thought of a “Mission: Impossible VIII”; we persist in equating reality television with the end of reason. On Broadway, the critics moan, there are too few compelling straight plays and too many dopey musical revivals, a complaint leveled not out of some stuffy commitment to archaic aesthetics but because the countervailing evidence (lately at least) has remained so slim.

headline: Covering the Bases
text: Balk Talk

headline: When Children Know Best
text: WHEN my mother reached her mid-80s, it began to dawn on me that I’d have to start intervening in her life. This was not pleasant. Mom had always been fiercely independent, happily living on her own in suburban Boston for the 20 years after my dad died.

headline: After Sanctions, Doctors Get Drug Company Pay
text: A decade ago the Minnesota Board of Medical Practice accused Dr. Faruk Abuzzahab of a “reckless, if not willful, disregard” for the welfare of 46 patients, 5 of whom died in his care or shortly afterward. The board suspended his license for seven months and restricted it for two years after that.

headline: Combat Rocker
text: Joe Strummer was born John Mellor in 1952, the mostly Scottish, part Armenian, part Jewish son of a self-made diplomat of socialist leanings. After several exotic postings, the family settled in London when John was 7. Scarred slightly by boarding school and immensely by his brother’s suicide in 1970, Mellor slacked through art school, renamed himself Woody Mellor, wandered and squatted and scrounged, renamed himself Joe Strummer, and began his pursuit of stardom by singing in the pub-rock 101’ers. From that rather trad band, he was recruited by the theoretically left-wing schemer-manager Bernie Rhodes to join the punk radicals the Clash in 1976. Other members were the pop-savvy guitarist Mick Jones, the style-setting bassist Paul Simonon and, eventually, the deft power drummer Topper Headon.

headline: The Long and Winding Road
text: Sometime in early July, Roz Savage will climb aboard her boat, the Sedna, in San Francisco harbor and pick up the oars for a long paddle westward. Savage, a 39-year-old former suit from Cheshire, England, decided five years ago that she’d rather die an adventurer than an I.T. project manager. Both she and the Sedna proved their seaworthiness during the 2,550-mile Trans-Atlantic Row in 2006, a race that took her 103 days (she finished 20th out of 26 boats; 6 abandoned the race). This time, the task is even more imposing: she will row 2,600 miles to Hawaii, the first leg of a three-part, 6,700-mile journey across the Pacific that will end in Australia in 2009. Here, a look at Savage’s quest to become the first woman to row across the big ocean:

headline: Shark Cartilage, Not a Cancer Therapy
text: CHICAGO, June 2 — Shark fin soup might taste good. But it will not do much for cancer.

headline: Paying Tribute to the King 30 Years After His Death
text: August marks the 30th anniversary of the death of Elvis Presley, an event that will be anything but ignored by the King’s fans.

headline: Medical Offices Designed for This Century
text: THE new headquarters of the Westchester Medical Group in Rye, N.Y., is a lot like a high-tech yacht. It is compact and streamlined, and every function and tool has a clearly defined place. Space is used as economically as possible, and what isn’t absolutely necessary has been eliminated — even paper files and X-rays, which are now fully computerized. When possible, e-mail messages are substituted for intraoffice phone calls to cut down on distracting nonurgent communication and noise.

headline: Visuals
text: The term “small press” usually refers to independent publishers with limited means and large ambitions. For the creators of an old literary genre, however, the phrase described the machinery on which very, very tiny books were produced. Bound miniature books were common in medieval and Renaissance times as illuminated manuscripts, and in the 18th and 19th centuries as everything from alphabet primers to novels; present-day artists have also used them as a medium. Although some may look like dollhouse props, these miniatures are by no means toys. Rather, they are meant to be read and collected. In MINIATURE BOOKS: 4,000 Years of Tiny Treasures (Abrams/Grolier Club, $40), Anne C. Bromer and Julian I. Edison chronicle this legacy of petite functional volumes, including some of the quirkiest — like “Thoughts From the Cork” (1981), with a cover fashioned from a 1 5/8-by-1-inch wine cork.

headline: Yanks Brightened a Life by Showing They Cared
text: Ray Smith, a spirited Yankees fan, once decided the team’s lineup with Manager Joe Torre, called catcher Joe Girardi one of his best friends and playfully told the announcer Michael Kay that he would one day have Kay’s job on the YES Network. Smith’s life revolved around his faith, his family and baseball.

headline: Idiot Wind
text: Cooperstown, N.Y.

headline: Bugs and Trees, Up Close and Luminous
text: The summer program of the Noyes Museum of Art in Oceanville has gotten into full swing early this year with “Recent Works by Doug and Mike Starn,” an inviting exhibition of more than three dozen photographs by the twin brothers, who work together as a collaborative team. Born in Absecon in 1961, they attended college in Boston, then moved to New York, where they were feted and fawned over in the 1980s. They have kept a low profile since then, and their work has benefited as a result.

headline: Partying Like a Czar: Vodka but No Diet Coke
text: THROUGH whatever mechanism Russian immigrants managed to make the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn their own — be it demographic evolution or intelligent real estate design — things sure worked out well. They landed a prime section of beachfront, right near the subway but far enough away not to be overrun by gentrifying artistes, as happened in Puerto Rican Williamsburg.

headline: You Won It! Now What Do You Do With It?
text: JEFF WHITTY keeps his Tony Award in a display case, among his collection of vintage trophies for cheerleading, raccoon hunting, ballroom dancing and elderly bodybuilding. Philip Bosco isn’t quite sure where his is at the moment. “I guess it’s up in my library somewhere,” he said.

headline: Moondoggie Needs an Intervention
text: To surf, a small verb lacking filigree or urgency, belongs to magical realism as much as to sport. Hawaiians, who were perhaps the first surfers, prayed for good conditions and venerated those who could truly harness a wave. Mark Twain wrote rapturously of his first encounter with surfing, watching a native Hawaiian “face the shore and wait for a particularly prodigious billow to come along; at the right moment he would fling his board upon its foamy crest and himself upon the board, and here he would come whizzing by like a bombshell!” When people started to explore the Internet, which promised endless possibility to anyone with a computer, they called it surfing.

headline: A Requiem for Reading in a Smoldering Pyre of Books
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo.

headline: Demolition Man
text: Not long into “Rant” — 21 pages to be exact, after the car wrecks featuring impaled lungs and “severe internal exsanguination,” after the torn-apart carcasses of mule deer and rabbits, after the black widow bites on human nether parts and the blood-drinking family dogs — the author describes the prairie storms that hit the little burg of Middleton, blowing over trash cans, strewing used condoms and panty liners and sanitary napkins (but nothing else, apparently) along the barbed wire fences on the edge of town. He zooms in — he can’t resist — for a closer look: “Old blood and chunks so black it could be road tar. Blood brown as coffee. Watery pink blood. Sperm died down to almost-clear water.”

headline: Katya Kazakina, Greg Goldberg
text: Katya Kazakina and Greg Allen Goldberg were married last evening by Cantor Boris Kazansky at Blue Hill at Stone Barns in Pocantico Hills, N.Y.

headline: Inside the List
text: BAD SEX POLICE: BBC Radio 4 — our planet’s best radio station — has a lovely program with a snuggly title: “Book at Bedtime,” broadcast on weeknights from 10:45 to 11 p.m. This show is exactly what it sounds like: a series of readings from a book, often a new one, spread over the course of a week. A recent “Book at Bedtime” title was Ian McEwan’s “On Chesil Beach” (see the review this week). Because McEwan’s novel is about a sexually awkward honeymoon, though, the decision to read it out loud made at least one McEwan fan nervous. Writing in The Times of London, the comedian and columnist David Baddiel wasn’t worried he’d “hear descriptions so frank and graphic that they would cause me to swerve off the road in shame.” He simply worried, he wrote, “for any author who attempts any kind of elaborate sex scene, because of the possibility that it may come to the notice of the Bad Sex police.” (Much ado is made in Britain about the Bad Sex in Fiction award, handed out annually by The Literary Review.) Baddiel was relieved to find that McEwan’s sex scenes were written in “grandmaster prose” — is that a good thing or a bad thing? — “so McEwan buys himself a free pass out of the Bad Sex award.”

headline: Indian Shepherds Stoop to Conquer Caste System
text: NEW DELHI, June 2 — A fight for the right to be downwardly mobile exploded this week in north India, as a powerful community of Indian shepherds asserted that the best way to rise up in modern society was to take a step down in the regimented class hierarchy here.

headline: As Bonds Pursues Aaron, Sponsors Shun Bonds
text: The day Barry Bonds becomes baseball’s home run king will be like any other in terms of his commercial appeal. He will still be one of the least-liked professional athletes in the United States, according to a fan survey.

headline: A Dwindling Congregation, Aiming to Reclaim Their Parish
text: Joy McAleer has had a front-row seat to the troubles of her church.

headline: Uncle Sam Wants You
text: To the Editor:

headline: Prom Night During Wartime; Fighting the Curse of Poor Penmanship; Envisioning Abolition of the Death Penalty (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Contemporary Showcase at Wadsworth Atheneum
text: “Connecticut Contemporary” is the first show in recent memory at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, America’s oldest public art museum, to deal seriously with contemporary art. The show is spectacular but comes at a difficult time for the 165-year-old institution, with the departure in April of the director, Willard Holmes, after less than four years in the job, for reasons that have not yet been made public. More than a dozen other staff members have also left in the last year, leaving vacant senior administrative and curatorial positions.

headline: When China Reopened, I Rushed in Too Fast
text: I WAITED for him that afternoon in a large dreary room under the watch of a guard sitting high above on a wooden platform. When the door opened and he entered, his face was in shadow but so familiar. It had been 15 years since I’d seen him, but I would have recognized the gait anywhere. He didn’t lift his gaze as he walked toward the metal table and four chairs that were fixed to the floor.

headline: Peerless Stallion
text: It takes a brave writer to tackle a subject as well documented as Secretariat, among the most popular racehorses ever. Already celebrated in two substantive biographies, Big Red, as he was called, was such a media darling that he has been commemorated on a United States postage stamp. As Lawrence Scanlan notes, Secretariat came of age during the corrupt Watergate era, and since he didn’t cheat, lie or order any illegal wiretaps, he embodied the wholesome values Americans treasure. When his picture appeared on the cover of Time in 1973, many readers found it “refreshing” to see the front end of a horse in the space usually reserved for politicians.

headline: Claire Tisne, Ian Haft
text: Claire Marvel Tisne, the daughter of Jean and Peter B. Tisne of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Ian David Aaron Haft, the son of Dr. Gail Klein Haft and Dr. Jacob I. Haft of Tenafly, N.J. Rabbi Ari Fridkis officiated at the Metropolitan Building in Long Island City, Queens, with the Rev. Dr. William Nye, a minister of the United Church of Christ, taking part.

headline: The Week in Connecticut
text: Wolf Pack Hockey Team to Stay in Hartford

headline: Finding a Proper Home for 8.5 Tons of Iron
text: THEY stand at attention, some 40 yards apart, inside the walls of Fort Monmouth, awaiting further orders.

headline: No, Not Everyone Enjoyed the Show
text: It was 40 years ago last Friday that the Beatles released “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band,” widely, though not universally, considered the greatest rock album of all time.

headline: A New Engine Makes Waves
text: BMW’S new 3-liter twin-turbo engine has received top honors in the 2007 International Engine of the Year Awards.

headline: Let Them In, or Send Them Back? (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: House Carries Storied Name but Is Defined by Steak
text: DID the “good gray poet” like red meat? Does it matter? Naming a steakhouse for Walt Whitman is a question of location. Whitman’s Steakhouse, which opened in Huntington Station in early April, is about a mile from the Walt Whitman Birthplace in West Hills. (A shopping mall that also bears his name is even closer to the birthplace.)

headline: An Enemy We Can Work With
text: London

headline: In Newark, Hope on the Rise (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Any Limits on Co-op Board Terms?
text: Q I have lived in the same co-op apartment for six years now, and each May I receive a packet including the building financials and a proxy ballot for the board of directors’ election. My co-op is a complex of several large buildings, which makes the co-op board an anonymous bunch.

headline: Genius and Misfit Aren’t Synonyms, or Are They?
text: THE story of the college dropout who became the world’s richest man still has the power to inspire us. It affirms our deeply engrained view that rejecting the received wisdom (do my own thing!) is a path to creativity and wealth.

headline: Need a Room? Why Not Try the Drain Pipe?
text: Forget luxury tents and designer pods. The newest trend in alternative hotel accommodation is a combination of the two — a compact, minimally decorated space set in the great outdoors.

headline: Sauvignon Blancs by the Dozen
text: A recent sampling of a dozen Long Island sauvignon blancs showed that they easily compete with local chardonnays for meals and perhaps have an edge as aperitifs. Generally, they go nicely with seafood.

headline: A Much-Loved Library, Locked for Two Years
text: Like other parents in the Highbridge section of the South Bronx, Yesenia Mercado sees her local library branch on West 168th Street as more than just a repository of books.

headline: Surf’s Up, but the Water Is Brown
text: Los Angeles

headline: Fingers That Keep the Most Treasured Violins Fit
text: CREMONA, Italy — A violin, it turns out, needs to be played, just as a car needs to be driven and a human body shooed off the couch. In this city that produced the best violins ever made, that job belongs to Andrea Mosconi. He is 75, and for the past 30 years, six days a week, he has finger-fed 300-year-old violins, worth millions, a diet of Bach, Tchaikovsky and Bartok.

headline: No Chewing the Pearls
text: No Chewing the Pearls

headline: Heather John, John Fogarty
text: Heather Mary John and John Linehan Fogarty were married yesterday at Meadowood Napa Valley, a resort and private club in St. Helena, Calif. The Rev. Gerald P. Caprio, a Benedictine monk, officiated.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Wrong Focus on Lacrosse

headline: Phuong Cao, Douglas Fields
text: Phuong Anh Cao and Dr. Douglas William Fields were married last evening in New York Harbor aboard the Noa Danielle, a yacht. Harold Silverman, a retired State Supreme Court justice in the Bronx, officiated.

headline: A Television Audition for a Part in and of Life
text: THERE was outrage aplenty last week when a Dutch television network said it would broadcast a reality show featuring three patients competing for a kidney from a terminally ill woman. Viewers were to send text messages to help the woman, identified only as Lisa, make her choice.

headline: In Turkey, It’s First Down and Miles to Go
text: Until recently, I never would have guessed that a football mecca could take shape anywhere near the actual Mecca. But then I received an e-mail message from a Hilmi Celtikciolu.

headline: Republicrats of Long Island
text: The failure of the Suffolk County Republican Party to put up its own candidate for county executive this year is an embarrassment for the G.O.P. and a triumph for the incumbent, Steve Levy, a Democrat who won the Republicans’ cross-endorsement on May 24.

headline: As Dollar Sinks, European Cruises Could Be a Bargain
text: DESPITE the rising euro and the near-record pound, Europe is emerging as the unexpected star of this summer’s cruising season. With companies from the American cruising giants to boutique lines that specialize in river and Arctic itineraries expanding their presence throughout the Continent, European cruise capacity is expected to increase 23 percent this summer over last, according to Cruise Industry News, with an additional 10 percent more growth predicted for next year.

headline: President’s Push on Immigration Tests G.O.P. Base
text: WASHINGTON, June 2 — President Bush’s advocacy of an immigration overhaul and his attacks on critics of the plan are provoking an unusually intense backlash from conservatives who form the bulwark of his remaining support, splintering his base and laying bare divisions within a party whose unity has been the envy of Democrats.

headline: Suzanne Smalley, Seth Hanlon
text: Suzanne Marie Smalley and Seth David Hanlon were married last evening in Pelham Manor, N.Y. Ellen Gesmer, an acting State Supreme Court justice in the Bronx, officiated at the New York Athletic Club Travers Island Boathouse.

headline: Killed in the Line of Work
text: New Haven

headline: Charming Filly
text: BEFORE Barbaro, there was Ruffian. More than three decades have elapsed since that great horse broke down on the Belmont Park backstretch in perhaps the most hyped race ever, yet she continues to rouse the popular imagination. This week, nearly 32 years after the fact, a television movie about that licorice-black filly is scheduled for broadcast by ABC. The consultant on the project was William Nack, author of the renowned “Secretariat: The Making of a Champion.” Experiencing on the set a déjà vu trip back to the mid-1970s (felons have received lesser sentences), Nack was stirred again by the memory of Ruffian. As he writes in this short, fascinating, melancholy hybrid of turf history and personal memoir, “I have thought of Ruffian so often over the years that today she flits around like a ghost in all the mustier rooms of my reveries, a boarder who has had a run of the place.”

headline: Funny as All Get-Out
text: In David Lynch’s film “The Elephant Man,” a shrouded John Merrick (played by John Hurt) steps off a train and manages for a moment to move unnoticed through the crowd. Soon, though, a child points him out, and Merrick no longer belongs to the throng but is hounded by it, chased until he has no escape, and finally, turning unmasked to his tormentors, he lets forth with “I am not an animal!” — a cry now so famous as to beg farce, to suggest fodder for, say, a Mel Brooks movie. Except that “The Elephant Man” already is a Mel Brooks movie.

headline: Who Benefits From This Buyback?
text: LOOK at the shares of NVR Inc., the parent of Ryan Homes, Fox Ridge Homes and NVHomes, and you might just think that the real estate bubble never popped. The nation’s 10th-largest seller of residential housing, NVR has generated stock gains of 21 percent so far this year. Its seven largest peers — including D. R. Horton, Toll Brothers, the Lennar Corporation and KB Home — have posted losses ranging from 5.3 percent to 18.5 percent this year.

headline: The Boy Wonders of Lacrosse
text: There are a few ways to differentiate the identical twin brothers Rhamel and Shamel Bratton. Shamel has a slightly rounder face, and Rhamel is a bit more outgoing.

headline: Even Wookiees Need a Good Belly Laugh
text: SOMETIMES, after a long day of working with Wookiees, Ewoks, Jedi knights and Mandalorian bounty hunters, even the employees of Lucasfilm need a break. And when they get distracted, like anyone else stuck in an office, they surf the Web.

headline: Travel Tips From a Dog’s Best Friend
text: TRAVELING with pets is an increasingly common affair, as many pet owners have decided that Fido deserves a summer vacation as much as they do, and shouldn’t be left behind in a kennel while they are off lounging on a beach or taking in the mountain air.

headline: Maxine Goldstein, Berkeley Hynes
text: Maxine Elizabeth Goldstein, the daughter of Mark Goldstein of New York and the late Marilyn Goldstein, was married last evening to Berkeley Hynes, the son of Shirley and John Hynes of Toronto. Rabbi Alon Levkovitz officiated at the Wölffer Estate Vineyard in Sagaponack, N.Y.

headline: The Week in Westchester
text: Chief Katonah’s Descendants Oppose Stewart

headline: Señor Hot Dog
text: Juan Pablo Montoya has made quite an impression on Nascar’s top drivers since he decided last summer to forgo the Eurofabulous world of Formula One. Few drivers are as suited to changing disciplines as Montoya, a 31-year-old Colombian who won a CART title at 24, the Indy 500 on his first attempt and seven Formula One races. The talented, sometimes irascible driver has lodged himself in the top half of Nascar’s Nextel Cup rankings and, in March, won the Mexico City race in the Busch Series, Nascar’s second-highest level, before rankling officials by raising his middle finger to a TV camera in April. (He was later fined.) Here he talks about leaving Europe, aggressive driving and his unexpectedly proletarian tastes.

headline: Jennifer Ametrano, Juan Rodriguez
text: Jennifer M. Ametrano and Juan Carlos Rodriguez were married last evening at St. Ann Catholic Church in West Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Seamus Murtagh performed the ceremony.

headline: No Fuss. No Cleanup. It’s Called a Dinner Party.
text: SOME people are meant to entertain; when it comes to party giving, they have a grace and confidence that elude many of us. In wondrous shows of multitasking, these hosts converse easily with guests while putting last-minute touches on dinner in their bright, stainless-steel kitchens. Jewel-like appetizers circulate along with flutes of Champagne. Even as it unfolds, the party is a happy memory, and glory accrues to the partygiver.

headline: Serbian Players Emerge From a Broken Country
text: PARIS, June 2  For more than four hours, as he faced break points and tie breakers and a crowd of 10,000 cheering against him, Novak Djokovic refused to crumble.

headline: Edward’s End
text: They were young, educated, and both virgins on this, their wedding night, and they lived in a time when a conversation about sexual difficulties was plainly impossible. But it is never easy.  The geographical distinction that marks Chesil Beach in England is the grading of the shingle — the pebbles, that is — that forms its 18 miles: the pebbles are arranged, by wind and rain, in a spectrum of sizes and textures, so that the beach forms a spatial map of time. Each stone confesses a part of its relation to the whole. Local fishermen brag of the ability to make a blind identification of the original placement, on Chesil Beach, of a given stone.

headline: Tiffany Zientz, Alexander Heckler
text: Tiffany Lee Zientz and Alexander Patrick Heckler were married last evening by Rabbi Terry A. Bookman at the Four Seasons Hotel in Miami.

headline: Correction: A Star’s (Pre-Celebrity) Turn on the Soccer Field
text: An article last Sunday about the movie “Gracie,” based on events in the life of the actress Elisabeth Shue and her family, misstated the cause of death of Ms. Shue’s brother William. He died of injuries suffered in a fall, not in a car accident.

headline: Rev. John Macquarrie, 87, Scottish Theologian, Dies
text: The Rev. Dr. John Macquarrie, an influential theologian whose graceful writing and sagacious melding of existentialist philosophy with orthodox Christian thought offered intellectually penetrating rationales for belief in God, died on May 28 in Oxford, England, where he lived. He was 87.

headline: Shine On
text: An early warm-weather surprise: the appearance of silver handbags and shoes as an alternative to summer white. There are even three sculptured stainless steel trees by the artist Roxy Paine in Madison Square Park, at Fifth Avenue and 23rd Street. The shimmering silver bags mark a departure from the heavy hardware decorations on purses last winter, instead relying on quilting for a textured surface. This is echoed in the huge silver rock that looks like a fallen meteorite in the park.

headline: Summer Doldrums? Maybe Not
text: THE old admonition to “sell in May, then go away,” seems to have gone unheeded this time around, as stocks rose through the month and ended the week at all-time highs.

headline: Siren
text: Ingrid Bergman held the screen with the imposing beauty of an earthbound though no less pristine Garbo, but her assurance was flecked with melancholy, ambivalence, even neurasthenic sensitivity. Projecting wholesomeness along with a hint of the perverse, she could strategically unbutton that tightly corseted persona in a manner designed to make the sympathetically aroused viewer wonder: What’s a nice Victorian girl like this doing in a sadistic place like Hitchcock’s “Notorious”? (Having a blast playing undercover doxy to Cary Grant’s casehardened F.B.I. pimp, that’s what — abandoning body and soul to slow death as if that were the ultimate stoic test of true romance.)

headline: Where History and Wine Making Meet in Austria
text: FOLLOW the Danube northwest out of Vienna by car, train or bicycle, and the cityscape shaped by the Hapsburgs and the Secessionist architect Otto Wagner quickly slides away into verdant countryside. Hamlets pop up, like tiny Kahlenbergerdorf, looking like an Epcot Center idealization of a Mitteleuropean village; Wagner's Art Nouveau Church of St. Leopold looms stark and lovely on a hilltop.

headline: 4 Men Accused of Plot to Blow Up Kennedy Airport Terminals and Fuel Lines
text: Four men, including a onetime airport cargo handler and a former member of the Parliament of Guyana, were charged yesterday with plotting to blow up fuel tanks, terminal buildings and the web of fuel lines running beneath Kennedy International Airport.

headline: It’s Not Their Party, but They’ll Still Take Levy
text: THE Suffolk County Republican Party has endorsed a Democrat for county executive for the first time, giving its support to Steve Levy for re-election.

headline: The Strong, Not So Silent Type
text: Mathias Augustyniak and Michael Amzalag have seen the future, and frankly, they are not impressed. The French graphic design duo known professionally as M/M (Paris) are sitting in their office in the 10th Arrondisement, having just returned from Digital, Life, Design, a new technology conference in Munich where their friend the Swiss curator Hans Ulrich Obrist was a panelist. “Mr. Craig Something was speaking,” Augustyniak says, referring to Craig Newmark, the founder of Craigslist. “It was this parallel world full of people you hear about but have never met.” Not that the two have anything against venturing into parallel worlds. It’s just that the worlds they are used to inhabiting are better-designed. “The reality they produce has nothing to do with the reality we are in,” Augustyniak continues. “We are crossing many realities. Then you enter this world with no visual culture.”

headline: Vintage Trend
text: Retail Wine Chains

headline: Name Aside, Don’t Focus on the Cheese
text: AT a restaurant named Fromagerie, I expect an amazing cheese plate.

headline: Tara Mark, Kenneth Rosenblum
text: Tara Jocelyn Mark and Kenneth Adam Rosenblum were married last night at the Pierre. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein officiated, with Cantor Richard Botton taking part.

headline: The Décor Says Caribbean, but the Menu Says French
text: IN décor, La Salière, whose name in French means salt shaker, speaks more of the South Seas or the Caribbean than of a French brasserie, what with the netting, starfish and tank stocked with iridescent tropical fish.

headline: What ‘Support Our Troops’ Entails
text: Whenever and however American troops withdraw from Iraq, a flood of wounded and psychologically damaged veterans will present the nation for decades to come with costly needs that already are overwhelming government services.

headline: A Cozy Balcony, With Overtones of the Bard
text: When Debby Murphy, a golf pro, saw the small balcony of the one-bedroom condominium that her boyfriend was buying on Park Avenue in Murray Hill, she was charmed.

headline: Longtime Emblems of City Roofs, Still Going Strong
text: THEY stand at the crest of the New York skyline like rustic, weathered sentinels. Their design has changed little in more than a century, and though they resemble a relic from a forgotten time, wooden water tanks remain a fixture of the cityscape.

headline: Karen DiYanni and Ned Peterson
text: Karen Elizabeth DiYanni and Ned King Peterson were married yesterday in New York. Msgr. Thomas Leonard performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer.

headline: A Spa Town Reclaims Its Glory
text: EIGHT miles of barbed-wire security fencing is up. Beach promenades have been scrubbed clean. And when the world leaders from eight industrial countries arrive this week for the G-8 summit, the spa town of Heiligendamm, on Germany’s Baltic coast, will have come full circle.

headline: Read Any Good Books Lately?
text: We asked a handful of writers what books they’ve enjoyed most over the last few months, and why. Their choices — from best sellers to poetry collections to a philosophy of science — are idiosyncratic and instructive.

headline: Books Worth a Spot on a Car Buff’s Shelf
text: In any field, there are certain books that are essential. Some are handy references, others provide the perspective of history and still others are simply good reads.

headline: 14 U.S. Troops Killed in Iraq Over Weekend
text: BAGHDAD, June 3 — The escalating pace of troop deaths continued over the weekend as 14 more American servicemen were reported killed in Iraq, all but one from makeshift bombs that insurgents have been employing with greater lethality against American soldiers and armored vehicles.

headline: A Haunting Curtain Call
text: As written, the final image of R. C. Sherriff’s World War I play “Journey’s End” is the collapse of the dugout in which its characters have spent the previous hours of stage time, now blasted into the ground by German fire. But that’s not the end of the play as seen this season at the Belasco Theater on Broadway. “The effect was unaffordable,” the director David Grindley said, “and a little obvious.”

headline: Two Streets, Two Players, One Little Town in Georgia
text: The town of Cairo, Ga., (population 9,400) has two streets named for prominent native sons: Jackie Robinson Memorial Drive and Willie Harris Drive. Willie what?

headline: Cut and Run
text: Trenton

headline: Valerie Witoshkin, Charles Fox
text: Valerie Witoshkin and Charles Garrett Fox were married yesterday by the Right Rev. Vincent Saverino at St. Michael the Archangel Russian Orthodox Church in Philadelphia.

headline: A Question of Debris as Drivers Voice Doubts
text: DOVER, Del., June 2 — Stock cars are wondrous contraptions, built to run for hundreds of miles on hot summer afternoons, often while banging into other stock cars. But they are, after all, still pieces of machinery. They can, and often do, fall apart.

headline: Innocents Lost
text: Who is this Nathan Englander, at 37 so young in novelist years, but already possessed of an old master’s voice? Well, it’s not his voice exactly; one senses that Bernard Malamud and Isaac Bashevis Singer are living under the name Nathan Englander in a witness protection program for Jewish fabulists. But the man’s apparent lack of vanity is impressive.

headline: In the Wee Small Hours
text: Should the aliens ever descend in their sleek ships and train their great scanners on our population centers, capturing our deeds and dreams for transmission back to cosmic headquarters, let’s hope they show us the patient tenderness of Haruki Murakami, the Japanese novelist, who himself is not wholly of this world. In a dozen books on our existence here — not in Japan or any special nation but as children of gravity, as earthlings — Murakami has done as good a job as any contemporary writer of pleading humanity’s poignant case before the court of whoever may be out there. Have mercy, oh interstellar lords. We’re lonesome and small and we know not what we do, only that we’re obliged by God or nature to bathe, dress, eat and keep on doing it.

headline: Patricia Murphy, Todd Stein
text: Patricia Marie Murphy and Todd Matthew Stein were married yesterday at Great Meadow, an equestrian center in The Plains, Va. Norman E. Cartwright-Brown, a Virginia civil marriage celebrant, officiated.

headline: Making Accidents Less Likely to Happen
text: ALMOST every home or apartment has at least a few accidents waiting to happen, and if they do occur, they can cause thousands of dollars in damage.

headline: Vive le Tour? Bien Sur!
text: Since Lance Armstrong pedaled triumphantly into the sunset in 2005, his sport seems to have embarked on a sincere and surprisingly efficient effort to destroy itself, most notably by a theatrical series of drug scandals. Though we’re shocked — shocked! — that anybody in this toughest of endurance races would illicitly boost his octane, it’s hard not to be impressed by the magnitude of the bamboozlement. Exhibit A: Operation Puerto, a Spanish investigation that began in May 2006 and that uncovered, among other violations, a freezer brimming with 223 bags of blood from over 100 top riders, plus coded notes tracking their “treatments.” Say what you will about the seriousness of Balco: until the day when a sizable chunk of Major League Baseball stars are storing doped blood at the clinic for stretch-run transfusions, American sports still have some catching up to do. All of which leaves us in a dilemma: do we pass grim judgment (a pox on les cheaters!), or sit back on July 7 with a cold sauvignon blanc and toast the world’s most grueling, beautiful, unbelievable race? We’ve made our choice. Ã votre santé!

headline: A Battle With Depression and Suicidal Tendencies
text: Susan Endersbe, a schizophrenic who lived in Minneapolis, battled depression all her life. When her illness worsened, she usually checked into a hospital, which she did for the last time on May 7, 1994. On that occasion, doctors gave her an antidepressant, and three weeks later she said she felt ready to leave soon, according to nurses’ notes.

headline: What’s on Sunday Night
text: 8 P.M. (MTV) 2007 MTV MOVIE AWARDS Sarah Silverman, left, is host of this year’s ceremony, with duties ranging from frisking patrons at the door to serving popcorn  the Golden Bucket variety. Awards, presented live at the Gibson Amphitheater in Universal City, include breakthrough performance and “best” in categories like villain, performance, comedic performance, kiss, fight and summer movie you haven’t seen yet. Jessica Alba, Victoria Beckham, Jessica Biel, Cameron Diaz, Zac Efron, Ioan Gruffudd, Samuel L. Jackson Mandy Moore and Bruce Willis are among the presenters. Amy Winehouse, Rihanna and Jay-Z will perform. Viewers will choose best movie spoof from among hundreds of amateur film clips at mtvmovieawards.yahoo.com.

headline: In a Busy Season, a Return Engagement?
text: How likely is it that a major hurricane will strike Miami this year? Or Galveston, Tex.? Or the Outer Banks of North Carolina?

headline: Ambassador Sees Long-Term Effort in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, June 3 — Pointing to a long-term American presence in Iraq, Ryan C. Crocker, the American ambassador in Baghdad, said today that the process of stabilizing the country and achieving political accommodation “will take a lot longer than September.”

headline: Our Green Bubble
text: Surely the most glaring contrast in American political life today is the amount of words, speeches and magazine covers devoted to the necessity of “going green,” “combating climate change” and gaining “energy security,” and the actual solutions being offered by our leaders to do any of these things. You could very comfortably drive a Hummer through the gap between our words and deeds.

headline: Ashley True, Aaron Lang
text: Ashley Elizabeth True, the daughter of Thea True and T. Craig True of Amelia Island Fla., is to be married today to Aaron Charles Lang, the son of Dr. Enid A. Lang and Norton D. Lang of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Cathy Barksdale, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the Ribault Club on Fort George Island in Jacksonville, Fla.

headline: 4 More Hostages Taken in Nigeria; Rebels Seek Talks
text: DAKAR, Senegal, June 2 — A militant group in Nigeria’s oil-producing Niger Delta said Saturday that it would temporarily cease its campaign of pipeline attacks, bombings and kidnappings to allow for a negotiated settlement of its grievances with the newly elected government.

headline: Demand for School Chiefs Pushes Salaries Up
text: SALARIES for school superintendents rose at a rate well above inflation in Westchester last year, according to new state figures. School board officials attribute the increase to the difficulty of finding candidates capable of meeting the high expectations of suburban parents and homeowners.

headline: Between a Mother and a Daughter
text: It was not your typical schoolyard conversation.

headline: Boy Born to Rebel Hostage Shocks War-Weary Colombia
text: BOGOTÁ, Colombia, May 30 — His name is Emmanuel.

headline: The Heroic, the Hermetic and the Honky-Tonk
text: Erol Josué

headline: Women of the Revolution
text: In 1791, Olympe de Gouges, a radical pamphleteer, published a response to the Declaration of the Rights of Man and the Citizen, which proclaimed France a constitutional monarchy and gave all men of property the right to vote. “Woman is born free and lives equal to man in her rights,” reads the first article of her Declaration of the Rights of Woman and the Female Citizen, which demanded full political rights and responsibilities for women. Since “woman has the right to mount the scaffold,” Gouges noted, “she must equally have the right to mount the rostrum.”

headline: A New Outpost in the Civilian World
text: LAST week Westhab, a nonprofit organization that has built and managed housing, mostly for homeless families and singles, for 26 years, opened its first residence for veterans: a century-old Victorian home in Yonkers renovated for $1.1 million.

headline: Prom Night During Wartime; Immigration Laws and Disobedience; Fighting the Curse of Poor Penmanship (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: The Accidental Environmentalist
text: An article on May 20 about the Japanese architect Shigeru Ban misstated the word stenciled on crates that are part of an exhibit in his Nomadic Museum. It is Cosco, an acronym for the China Ocean Shipping Group Company, not Costco, the American warehouse store.

headline: Freelancers Inc.
text: THE smallest of small businesses — the self-employed and freelancers — rarely get their voices heard in the halls of government. And when small-business concerns are publicly debated, all too often they are simply a mask for proposals that are really intended to benefit corporate interests — farm subsidies and the estate tax cut come to mind.

headline: North American Songbird
text: PICTURE Lucille Ball and Tinkerbell engaged in a duet and you have an apt metaphor for the neo-folk singer Becky Stark, who suggests an impish fairy from a faraway land. Her eyes are wide, and her madcap stories full of exclamation points. She seems perpetually atwitter, at once ditzy and all knowing.

headline: Comings and Goings
text: JetBlue and Expedia.com have announced a deal in which the online travel agency will list JetBlue flights for the next five years. Last August, JetBlue, known for its independence within the travel industry, began selling flights through Sabre Holdings, which owns Travelocity.com, another online travel agency that has been offering JetBlue flights on a testing basis since last September. ... Travelers spending the night near Chicago’s O’Hare airport can now do it in style. The Hyatt Regency O’Hare has undergone a $60 million renovation, which includes a new restaurant, a private lounge with leather walls, a 24-hour gym and a business center. Nightly rates start at $219 (www.ohare.hyatt.com). ... The Courtauld Institute of Art Gallery in London (www.courtauld.ac.uk) will play host to England’s first exhibition devoted exclusively to the works of the German Renaissance painter, Lucas Cranach the Elder (1472-1553). The highlight of the exhibition, from June 21 through Sept. 23, will be Cranach’s “Adam and Eve” (1526), above. Gallery admission is 5 euros; free for those under 18 and students and for all on Mondays from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. ... Blue Man Group, the extremely popular multimedia theatrical experience, will begin performances at Universal Orlando Resort’s Sharp Aquos Theater this Wednesday. The theater, which features a hard-to-miss 30-foot-tall Blue Man facade, is accessible from both the Universal CityWalk and the Universal Studios theme park. Tickets start at $59, and $49 for ages 3 to 9 (www.universalorlando.com).

headline: Jennifer Openshaw and Randy Schwimmer
text: JENNIFER OPENSHAW had been walking for hours before she settled into a cafe on a side street in Florence. Her hair was pulled back in a ponytail, she wore no makeup and she had on sweat pants, a T-shirt and sneakers. Though weary from the walking, she contentedly began eating a mocha gelato.

headline: Sweet Française
text: The tricky thing about writing historical novels isn’t getting the details right. It’s knowing which details to leave out — even if that means keeping most of your painstaking research to yourself. You want a novel to read like a novel, not a pageant with elaborate stage sets and showy costumes. This is a skill that suspense novelists like Joseph Kanon and Alan Furst have mastered. And so, for the most part, has the author of “April in Paris,” the German screenwriter Michael Wallner. But where Kanon and Furst create worlds peopled by complex characters who breathe a rich atmosphere, Wallner has produced somewhat lighter fare.

headline: Do You Believe in Magic?
text: My friends here in western Massachusetts usually don’t let me down. Kris, the truck-stop waitress, referred me to Michelle, a bartender at the gentlemen’s club down the road, who directed me to Kim, the red-haired dancer with an ankh-tattoo armband, who referred me to an ex-boyfriend’s wife’s girlfriend, another redhead, who met me outside an American Legion hall in Chicopee (Nipmuck for “land of violent pee”) and informed me that magic mushrooms were “out of season,” but she could get me LSD instead. “Acid — same deal as mushrooms,” she said. Besides, she wondered why a guy in his 60s wanted to experiment with shrooms. The answer was obvious. I had a review to write.

headline: The Not-So-Tell-Tale Heart
text: Sue Cox says that her 17-year-old son, Tim, “started playing sports practically in the womb.” A standout on junior-league basketball and Pop Warner football teams in Hudson, N.H., he was, by high school, among the top basketball players in the state as well as a starting safety on the football team. “I lived for sports, you could say,” Tim says.

headline: Malicious Boycotts
text: The University and College Union, a newly formed British union of college teachers, shamefully called last week for a boycott on contacts and exchanges with Israeli academic institutions. That follows on the shameful call in April by the National Union of Journalists in Britain to boycott Israeli goods.

headline: Silent Running
text: HICKSVILLE

headline: Comics
text: Few “underground” cartoonists deserve that subterranean title so fully as Kim Deitch. He was there at the beginning of the movement, drawing for The East Village Other in 1967, and his work retains much of that psychedelic, R. Crumb-like earthiness.

headline: Fighting Worsens as Lebanese Army Surrounds Militants
text: TRIPOLI, Lebanon, June 2 — Heavy shelling and gunfire continued for the second day at the Nahr al Bared refugee camp, as the Lebanese Army intensified its offensive against the Fatah al Islam militia.

The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about the Heinrich Heine Memorial in the Bronx, misstated its location on the Grand Concourse. It is 161st Street, not 164th Street. (It was moved from 164th Street in 1999.)

headline: Thompson Makes Strong Pitch to Conservative Republicans
text: RICHMOND, Va., June 2 — In a preview of the themes he is likely to emphasize in a presidential campaign, Fred D. Thompson tossed some red meat to Republicans here Saturday night, assailing the immigration bill in Congress and warning of a mushroom cloud he said radicals around the world were waiting to see rise over the United States.

headline: A Wall Talks, but What Does It Say?
text: MICHAEL NAMER had for years heard rumors that something beautiful was hidden behind the walls at 151 Wooster Street, a building he owns in SoHo, near Houston Street.

headline: Plot Was Unlikely to Work, Experts Say, Citing Safeguards and Pipeline Structure
text: Federal authorities said that four men were hoping to blow up Kennedy International Airport and a large swath of Queens by detonating a fuel pipeline and storage tanks, but oil industry executives and local officials said yesterday that such a plot was probably not feasible.

headline: Gay Inmates to Be Granted Conjugal Visits in California
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 — Gay and lesbian prisoners in California will be allowed overnight visits with their partners under a new prison policy, believed to be the first time a state has allowed same-sex conjugal stays.

headline: Parallel Paths
text: The protagonist of Javier Cercas’s 2001 novel, “Soldiers of Salamis,” self-deprecatingly claims he can’t give up writing because his writing never amounted to anything to begin with. Cercas could say the same for his own career as a Spanish novelist — until that book, a stealthily brilliant semifictional account of the Spanish Civil War, became an unexpected best seller in Spain and abroad. Now Cercas has written another novel about the aftermath of war — this time the Vietnam War — and art has caught up with life: his writer protagonist is wildly, cravenly successful, and Cercas-the-author embarks on a dual reckoning with the nature of war and the writing life.

headline: Thousands Wait to Hear Ousted Pakistani Justice
text: ABBOTTABAD, Pakistan, Sunday, June 3  Pakistan’s suspended chief justice led a cavalcade of about 100 cars jammed with lawyers and political supporters on a 75-mile trip from Islamabad on Saturday, continuing to protest his dismissal by Gen. Pervez Musharraf two months ago.

headline: Whose Katonah™ Is It, Anyway?
text: “The familiar and the fancy are combined to splendid effect in the Katonah™ Collection,” the people at Martha Stewart’s empire tell us, pitching a $12 catalogue of furniture and home furnishings that sell for a lot more than that. The line “showcases classic American style, accented with a touch of formal refinement,” which presumably is how they do things in Katonah, where Ms. Stewart owns a 153-acre estate.

headline: Shattered
text: On the one hand, it’s bad timing: who would want their 9/11 novel to be published so soon after Don DeLillo’s 9/11 novel? DeLillo, it’s fair to say, began circling this material long ago. (The cover of “Underworld,” to name one uncanny example, had a planelike bird flying toward the twin towers.) On the other hand, if your novel happens to be as finely wrought, deeply felt and mercifully funny as Helen Schulman’s “Day at the Beach,” then this timing turns out to be an affirming coincidence, allowing us to see how another talented writer can alchemize that same terrible day.

headline: A Defeat Feels Like Yet Another Body Blow for Yankees
text: BOSTON, June 2 — There have been so many days like this, so many games when the bad news piles so high for the Yankees that the loss on the field seems secondary, and almost inevitable.

headline: Serena Hoy, James Reilly
text: Serena Jeanine Hoy and James Dalton Reilly were married last evening at St. John’s College in Annapolis, Md. Judge Merrick B. Garland of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit officiated.

headline: Curiouser and Curiouser
text: To the Editor:

headline: King or Queen for a Day? Have We Got a Castle for You
text: VERONA

headline: When It’s Time to Pay the Piper
text: ASSESSMENTS come in all sizes, none of them custom-tailored. Though apartment owners in straitened financial circumstances or on fixed incomes may be tempted to throw themselves on the mercy of the board, they shouldn’t expect much.

headline: Boomtown
text: How do you keep suspense alive when you open a story with an atomic blast? It’s something that addicts of the high-tension television series “24” asked themselves earlier this year when, on the second night of the new season, a suitcase nuke exploded in California, releasing a mushroom cloud over Valencia. As the next episodes unfolded, the audience wrestled with an uneasy concept: a nuclear strike isn’t the end of the world — that is, not for its survivors. For the purposes of dramatic fiction, at least, the bomb was just a starting shot that set off a mad dash for security and compromise, a race no human would want to run, given the choice.

headline: A Grand Opening for BMW’s Quick-Tanning Machine
text: DRIVING a BMW 3 Series after some time away is like being reunited with a favorite band. The in-line 6 sounds its opening notes and you think, “Hey, I remember that song.”

headline: Modernist Times
text: The recent death of Arthur Schlesinger Jr. was a sad reminder of how the public intellectual is passing from our midst. That is to say, the individual still bold enough to put his mind and his knowledge to use in analyzing the world around us, in language that most of us can understand, and with an eye toward effecting practical improvements. This is apparently a rarer skill set than most of us might once have imagined.

headline: Leading Men Lead the Field: Five Riveting Performances Make for a Stiff Competition
text: A WALL of smoke separates Barry Champlain from anyone who might get close to him. The wall is erected eight times a week by Liev Schreiber, whose brilliant, chain-smoking performance as Barry, the antagonistic shock jock in the Broadway revival of Eric Bogosian’s “Talk Radio,” is the best argument going for the continued existence of cigarettes.

headline: A Moscow Winter Tableau
text: As the second act opened of “Voyage,” the beginning of Tom Stoppard’s trilogy, “The Coast of Utopia,” the season’s most visually sublime moment came into full view. We were in Moscow now, in March of 1834, having left the idyll of Premukhino, the Bakunin family estate, a place of long meals, pastoral languor.

headline: Olivia Cowley, Julian Wassenaar
text: Olivia Lorillard Cowley, a daughter of Edith L. Cowley and Robert W. Cowley of Newport, R.I., was married there last evening to Julian Smith Wassenaar, a son of Christine A. Smith of Santa Barbara, Calif., and Paul R. Wassenaar of La Jolla, Calif. The Rev. Mark J. Pruitt, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Trinity Church.

headline: A Jazzman So Cool You Want Him Frozen at His Peak
text: AT the very end of Bruce Weber’s seductive, unsettling “Let’s Get Lost,” the movie’s subject, the semi-legendary cool-jazz trumpeter and singer Chet Baker, looks back on the shooting of the film and says, in a quavery, almost tearful voice, “It was a dream.” Although in the preceding two hours Mr. Baker has delivered a fair number of dubiously reliable utterances, you’re inclined to believe him on this one because that’s what the movie feels like to the viewer too. It’s nominally a documentary (Oscar-nominated in that category in 1989), but it documents something that only faintly resembles waking reality. And Mr. Baker, who wanders through “Let’s Get Lost” with the eerie deliberateness of a somnambulist, appears to be a man who knows a thing or two about dreams.

headline: Directions: Hug, Smile, Schmooze, Repeat
text: GENTLEMEN,” the photographer said, “hug each other.”

headline: Eternal Sunshine
text: What accounts for the stupefying popular success of Doris Day? Like Elvis, she was generally underserved by her motion pictures, though her charisma and forthright personality always carried her through. She is the No. 1 female box-office star of all time, setting the record over three seismic decades — the 1940s, ’50s and ’60s. Did she embody McCarthyism or transcend it? As John Updike once said, “I’m always looking for insights into the real Doris Day because I’m stuck with this infatuation and need to explain it to myself.”

headline: It Takes Money
text: FROM the stacks of allergy medicine at Duane Reade to the students “doing homework” at the Sheep Meadow in Central Park, it’s clear that spring has overtaken New York. Which means it’s time for apartment owners to come together in their annual meetings and debate what to do to the spaces they have the fortune, or misfortune, to share.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: COMEDY

headline: Palestinian Militant Is Killed as the Air Fire Over Gaza Declines
text: JERUSALEM, June 2  A field commander from the Palestinian militant faction Islamic Jihad was killed in an Israeli air attack on his vehicle in Khan Yunis, in the southern Gaza Strip, on Friday night, army officials and Islamic Jihad said.

headline: Stephanie J. Block’s Cold
text: Stephanie J. Block was sick, bad. She had such a nasty bug that she missed a few previews of “The Pirate Queen,” a show that sits squarely on her shoulders (she plays the title character) and that she even had to leave in the middle of a critics’ night performance.

headline: The Musicians of the Orchestra Pit
text: As anyone who regularly attends musicals can attest, the sound of music on Broadway these days is often about as appealing as the throb of a jackhammer or the blare of a bus horn. Those distracting little microphones crawling like insects out of the hairlines of the performers are a bit of an eyesore, but what really sets the nerves on edge is the tidal wave of mushy, amplified sound that now seems to be the standard for Broadway musicals.

headline: A Critique of Obama Doubles as an Invite
text: The chairman of the Ford Motor Company has a question for Senator Barack Obama: Have you driven a Ford lately?

headline: Bridgid Curry and Amos Presler
text: Bridgid Theresa Curry, a daughter of Anne B. Curry and Dr. Thomas A. Curry of Pottsville, Pa., was married yesterday to Amos Hargrave Presler, a son of the Rev. Jane Butterfield Presler and the Rev. Dr. Titus L. Presler of New York. The Rev. Michael Stone performed the ceremony at St. Ambrose Roman Catholic Church in Schuylkill Haven, Pa., with the bridegroom’s father taking part.

headline: A League of His Own
text: Sports anniversaries pile up with insidious regularity. Whereas a D-Day comes around only once a war, the Super Bowl adds another Roman numeral every January (or February), and college basketball gives us the Final Four like clockwork every March (or April). This all but guarantees that in 5- or 10-year increments, we will look back in sepia tones with weepy eyes at various athletic accomplishments, replaying their “firsts” and measuring their importance. Only a few justify such commemoration. Some live on from sheer spontaneous drama, as with Bobby Thomson’s 1951 home run. Some gather weight over time, as with the victory of Texas Western’s black starting five against an all-white Kentucky team in the 1966 N.C.A.A. basketball finals. And a handful are heavy with significance both at the moment and long beyond, as with Jackie Robinson’s entry into major-league baseball as its first modern-day African-American player, 60 years ago this season — an operatic tale cannily orchestrated by Branch Rickey, the president of the Brooklyn Dodgers, and brilliantly performed by Robinson.

headline: For Dallas, New Prosecutor Means an End to the Old Ways
text: DALLAS  Craig Watkins calls himself a different kind of prosecutor.

headline: For a Gussied-Up Street, a Song of Simpler Days
text: Of all the whining about gentrification in Brooklyn, this may be the first time the complaints have been set to an energetic beat with a bass line, a violin interlude and backup vocals.

headline:
Prom Night During Wartime; Fighting the Curse
of Poor Penmanship (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A French White Under the Radar
text: Château Lamothe de Haux’s citric, mouthwatering 2006 Bordeaux blanc could replace entire lists of white wines in the city’s seafood restaurants.

headline: Children’s Books
text: Nearly a century after Gabrielle (Coco) Chanel opened her first shop on the exclusive Rue Cambon in Paris, the name Chanel remains synonymous with fashion.

headline: Mariam and Laila
text: Khaled Hosseini’s first book, “The Kite Runner” (2003), spent more than two years on best-seller lists in the United States. More than four million copies are in print, and a movie adaptation is also in the works. After such success and fame, some writers might have postponed the challenge of a second novel, preferring to collect their royalty checks and not tempt fate or a backlash. Some might have rushed into print with something, anything, to cash in on their newfound visibility. And some might not have had anything more to say. Hosseini doesn’t fit any of these categories.

headline: The Other Machu Picchu
text: DAWN had just broken, and the lost city of the Incas lay empty — not a tourist in sight. From the priests’ district, the high point of the ruins, the bright green central plaza stretched along the narrow summit of a high ridge and dropped precipitously on both sides to a turquoise river thousands of feet below.

headline: If Wanderlust Strikes, Their House Goes, Too
text: FOR most people, a home is an anchor. It secures you to a particular spot and dampens the occasional impulse to set off in pursuit of a crazy dream.

headline: Fervently French, Pétanque Draws All Ages
text: Yorktown Heights

headline: James Lowers His Profile and Raises Cavaliers to Finals
text: CLEVELAND, June 2 — LeBron James hurled the ball with all his rippling strength high into the rafters, and the confetti — like everything and everyone else here — soon followed on cue in Cleveland.

headline: Reviving a Birthplace of Civil Rights
text: J. W. ROBINSON, 80, remembers when the Sweet Auburn neighborhood in Atlanta was a mecca for aspiring African-American professionals like himself. Just out of college in the early 1950s, Mr. Robinson, a fledgling architect, used to frequent the stylish establishments along the 1.5-mile-long stretch of Auburn Avenue — among them the Royal Peacock, a nightclub that featured Ray Charles and well-known jazz performers of the day.

headline: Techno-Touches
text: In “The Merchant of Venice,” when Tubal learned the whereabouts of his friend Shylock’s runaway daughter, Jessica, Shylock didn’t have to wait long for the news in the Theater for a New Audience production this year. He got a call from Tubal on his cellphone.

headline: 6 Billion Bits of Data About Me, Me, Me!
text: JAMES D. WATSON, who helped crack the DNA code half a century ago, last week became the first person handed the full text of his own DNA on a small computer disk. But he won’t be the last.

headline: She’s All a Blur
text: If you saw Lauryn Williams on the street, you wouldn’t think she was the reigning world champion in the 100-meter sprint. But the 5-foot-3, 127-pound Williams has always been faster than bigger, taller athletes; in elementary school, she outran boys five and six years her senior. “That’s when I started to know I had talent,” the 23-year-old Williams says. At 20, she won the silver medal in the 100-meter dash at the 2004 Athens Olympics. The next year she earned gold at the World Championships, a title she’ll defend this August in Osaka, Japan. So how is it that someone so small can run so fast?

headline: In Police Hiring Crisis, Clouds of Contention
text: Any hope for a quick end to the long-running contract dispute between Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the city’s main police union seemed to vanish last week when the union appealed a state official’s order for arbitration to move forward.

headline: Everybody Into the Pool!
text: Founders Park pool in Islamorada, Fla., is a 50-meter oasis of fresh water flanked by the turquoise Gulf of Mexico, a rock’s throw to the west, and the white-capped Atlantic, a quarter-mile to the east.

headline: Correction: Lamont’s Message to Students: Stay Involved
text: A column last Sunday on a teach-in at Weston High School featuring Ned Lamont misspelled the writer’s name. It is Gerri Hirshey, not Hershey.

headline: Mindy Feinberg, Stefan Gutow
text: Mindy Rebecca Feinberg and Dr. Stefan Harris Gutow were married yesterday evening at the American Visionary Art Museum in Baltimore. Rabbi William Kuhn officiated.

headline: Catherine Bennett, Sophien Bennaceur
text: Catherine Gilbert Bennett, a daughter of Ellen and Robert S. Bennett of Washington, was married there last evening to Sophien Lazhar Bennaceur, a son of Dalila and Taieb L. Bennaceur of Nabeul, Tunisia. Judge Paul L. Friedman of the Federal District Court officiated at Evermay, a Federal-era house.

headline: Alice, Let’s Eat
text: On Aug. 28, 1971, Chez Panisse opened for business. The evening light was streaming across Shattuck Avenue in Berkeley. In the kitchen, a complicated sauce for canard aux olives was being attempted. No one there thought American cooking was about to be sent off in a new direction. The question was whether the restaurant could make it through the evening. True to the kind of well-intentioned venture it was, it almost didn’t.

headline: Dick Cheney Rules
text: Americans are accustomed to Vice President Dick Cheney’s waiting out a terrorist threat in a “secure undisclosed location.” Now it seems that Mr. Cheney wears the cloak of invisibility in secure disclosed locations.

headline: Crash-Test Kudos for 2 Convertibles
text: IN the first crash tests of convertibles by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, the Saab 9-3 and Volvo C70 earned the top rating, good, for protection in front, side and rear collisions.

headline: Soviet-Style ‘Torture’ Becomes ‘Interrogation’
text: HOW did the United States, in the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks, come to adopt interrogation techniques copied from the Soviet Union and other cold war adversaries?

headline: Schools’ Deep-Pocketed Partners
text: Greenwich, Conn.

headline: Correction: The Alchemist’s Moment: The Reclusive Mr. Polke
text: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the artist Sigmar Polke misidentified the country that took control of his birthplace, Oels, Silesia, in 1945. It was Poland, not East Germany. (Mr. Polke’s family moved from Silesia to East Germany at the end of World War II.)

text: Mountain View, Calif.

Rubenstein of Golden, Colo., is to be married today to Hays Nathaniel Golden, the son of Trudy Anna Legge Golden and Arthur Golden of Brookline, Mass. The ceremony, at Saltmeadows, the summer home of the bridegroom’s parents in South Dartmouth, Mass., will be led by Jason B. Rubenstein, the bride’s brother, who has permission to officiate from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

headline: Breakdown
text: Rosa Lane, a successful journalist living a cautious, insulated life in London, finds herself suddenly aware that she has been stuck in a holding pattern: “Sitting at her desk that day, sweating into her shirt, she thought, If they told me I would never do anything more than this, would I want to live or die on the spot? Then she thought, What is the reason for it all, what is it for?”

headline: Howl
text: Mention the term “doggie lit” to most winners of England’s T. S. Eliot Prize for poetry and they’ll probably think you’re referring to a graduate course on classical representations of Cerberus — or maybe to something Hollywood starlets give their Chihuahuas to browse while getting doggie pedicures. But Mark Doty, the only American to have won the prize (for his 1993 collection “My Alexandria”), is that rare thing: a serious poet with what seems to be a keen eye for trends. At a time when John Grogan’s “Marley & Me” has revealed a public appetite for the gushing reveries of a dog owner, and Joan Didion’s “Year of Magical Thinking” proved that readers can handle articulate narratives of grief, Doty has delivered a memoir that is both at once.

headline: Current Thinking
text: When Mayor Michael Bloomberg recently announced his vision of development in New York City over the next 25 years, he highlighted a plan to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions by 30 percent. To anyone who has studied the history of power consumption in the United States, his proposal sounded a curious echo. New York, after all, was home to one of the country’s first central power stations, built by Thomas Edison in 1882. No individual deserves more credit, or blame, for America’s voracious electricity consumption than Edison, who conceived not only that generating station but also the notoriously inefficient incandescent bulb and a slew of volt-thirsty devices.

headline: Just Like Us — Only Better
text: Was there ever a golf moment at once more horrific and more riveting than Phil Mickelson’s meltdown on the final hole of last year’s United States Open at Winged Foot Golf Club? You couldn’t watch, and at the same time you couldn’t not watch.

headline: Seeing More in a Marina
text: BAY SHORE

headline: Downtown, Meet Waterfront
text: JODI CUNNINGHAM, a 48-year-old single mother from Jericho, spent two years shopping for a house she could afford, scouring the market in Plainview, Syosset and Jericho for a half-million-dollar home that didn’t need extensive repairs.

headline: An Around-the-World Ticket for Your Portfolio
text: FOREIGN stocks can add some ballast to your portfolio, despite the effects of globalization.

headline: Free Your Mind, and Your Spine Will Follow
text: ELEVEN hyper-alert dancers stood stock still in a line, fighting the irresistible rhythms of the pulsing Arabic music. Suddenly one erupted in movement, ducking and twisting with astonishing liquid quickness. Then she froze. Down the line a second dancer burst into motion: another spineless creature from the same strange planet. Abruptly the whole line turned sideways and pounded the air with sinuous arms and hard fists, then froze.

text: Joan Rappoport and Steven Bruce Rosenfeld are to be married today. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel is to officiate at Eleven Madison Park, a restaurant in New York.

headline: Familiarity Is Breeding Fraternity for Coaches
text: CLEVELAND, June 2 — Earlier in the playoffs, Cavaliers Coach Mike Brown got a telephone call before a game.
