headline: A Hot-Selling Weapon, an Inviting Target
text: LAST February, Jim Zumbo, a burly, 66-year-old outdoors writer, got a phone call at his home near Cody, Wyo., from the rock star — and outspoken Second Amendment champion — Ted Nugent. “You messed up, man,” Mr. Zumbo says Mr. Nugent told him. “Big time.”

headline: Albany Discovers Obesity
text: Children learn a lot at school, not all of it for the better. As the Institute of Medicine reported in April, too many children pick up very bad eating habits, habits that can eventually kill them. Part of the problem is what the institute calls “competitive foods.” Instead of choosing the standard lunch, students choose junk food, much of it loaded with sugar, fat and salt — the fuel for future diabetes or heart disease.

headline: Dow and S.& P. End the Week at Record Highs
text: It was a short but glorious week for the stock market, with both the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index closing on Friday at record highs.

headline: U.S. Strikes Inside Somalia, Bombing Suspected Militant Hide-Out
text: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 2 — American forces struck inside Somalia on Friday, bombarding a mountainous area where suspected militants were hiding out, Somali officials said Saturday. It was the third known American strike on Somali soil this year.

headline: Water World
text: There’s something about ocean diving that inspires deep thinking — or at least thoughts that are apparently profound. Once while wreck diving for a television documentary, I unexpectedly found myself surrounded by several pregnant tiger sharks. Euphorically succumbing to nitrogen narcosis, I was drawn to the sharks, dopily fixated on the commingling of species, wondering why we couldn’t all just get along, until my dive master dragged me to safety. (Perhaps I should have been more concerned about the food chain.) In any case, I initially wrote off my ill-timed reverie on interdependence as the reaction of a stoned neophyte diver. But I’ve since read enough about diving to realize that insight comes from unlikely places under those refracted waters.

headline: LaTasha White and Leland Richards Jr.
text: LaTasha White and Leland Richards Jr. were married last evening at Belle Voir Manor in Bensalem, Pa. The Rev. William Lee, a Baptist minister, officiated.

headline: Failed Presidents Ain’t What They Used to Be
text: A few weeks ago I did something I never expected to do in my life. I shed a tear for Richard Milhous Nixon.

headline: Kara Visconti, Frank Blanco
text: Kara Visconti and Frank Blanco were married yesterday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan. The Rev. George M. Witt, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: ‘Dog Years: A Memoir’
text: No dog has ever said a word, but that doesn't mean they live outside the world of speech. They listen acutely. They wait to hear a term-biscuit, walk-and an inflection they know. What a stream of incomprehensible signs passes over them as they wait, patiently, for one of a few familiar words! Because they do not speak, except in the most limited fashion, we are always trying to figure them out. The expression is telling: to "figure out" is to make figures of speech, to invent metaphors to help us understand the world. To choose to live with a dog is to agree to participate in a long process of interpretation-a mutual agreement, though the human being holds most of the cards.

headline: ‘After Dark’
‘Spy Wars’
text: When the door opened in front of him, my visitor knew he was being led into a secret CIA apartment. But which of us was really being led? As he took my welcoming hand I had no idea that it was to drag me and my service into a labyrinth so complex that even today, more than forty years later, my successors have still not found their way through its twists and turns.

headline: ‘Redemption Song: The Ballad of Joe Strummer’
text: This is how I heard about Joe's death: Don Letts, the Rastafarian film director who had made all the Clash videos, called me at around 9:30 on the evening of December 22, 2002.

headline: ‘Rickles’ Book’
text: Jackson Heights, Queens, was no special place, but my dad, Max, was a special guy. Here's the kind of guy he was: If he was your friend and came over to your house and your wife was in a housecoat, he could hug her and you wouldn't think twice. There was nothing distasteful about Max S. Rickles. (I never knew what the "S." stood for, and neither did he.) Everyone loved my dad. The man was all heart.

headline: ‘Josephine Baker in Art and Life’
text: Josephine Baker's cultural legacy is still alive beyond the hundredth anniversary of her birth in 1906. It exists in live performances, art, photography, fashion, film, literature, and social activism. Baker mesmerized audiences during her lifetime and continues to attract and mystify biographers. Much recent scholarship on Baker has placed her in a pantheon of black feminist heroines, which often has produced a larger-than-life, one-dimensional image. Regardless of the reasons for such depictions, there is a need to remove Baker from reductive stereotypes and to humanize her legacy. This book explores the complex construction of Baker's multiple images in art and life. It is concerned with how art transforms social life, and how life imitates art. Although it presents and evaluates carefully researched biographical facts, it is not a biography. Rather, it offers critical reflections on the symbolic Baker and the images that she and her collaborators constructed during the era of modernity and for the postmodern future.

headline: ‘From a Cause to a Style’
text: In the 1980s, the Prince of Wales, who has adopted a number of surprising causes for a prince in the course of his life, became for a time the most influential critic of architecture, urban design, and planning in Great Britain. Both modernist architecture and modernist city planning had been very successful in Britain-as indeed they have been almost everywhere-in shaping new towns and rebuilding the centers of old cities and towns. But ordinary people often looked on the results with dismay. The prince's interventions and criticisms received wide publicity, and were effective in derailing some high-profile projects by modernist architects.

headline: ‘Liberty’
text: Every Tuesday evening in the early years of the revolution, Germaine de Staël held a small dinner at her hôtel in the rue du Bac, on Paris's left bank. She invited a catholic assortment of liberal, anglophile nobles, their glamorous wives and mistresses, and ambitious young men of middling rank. 'Go hence to Mme de Staël's,' wrote Gouverneur Morris, the one-legged American envoy to Paris, in his apple-green journal in January 1791. 'I meet here the world.'

headline: ‘The Fragile Edge’
text: All day we have been observing the surgeonfish, which the Tahitians call maroa and the French call chirurgien, streaming over the outer reef slopes in tightly knit single files. Now, in the final hour of daylight, scores of them coalesce into banners of yellow-and-blue fins, flowing gaudily over the contours of the coral toward the edge of Tiputa Pass. Bunched into agitated crowds of hundreds, they rise above the reefs, swarming and butting each other in a chaos of seeming cross purposes.

headline: ‘Fathers and Sons: The Autobiography of a Family’
text: I shall begin with a telephone call. It was half past seven on the morning of 17 January 2001 - annus horribilis - when I was woken by the ringing.

headline: ‘A Day at the Beach’
text: She yawned.

headline: ‘The Lost Cities’
text: "Did too!"

headline: ‘Contested Waters’
text: Philadelphia opened one of the earliest municipal pools in America on June 21, 1884, at the intersection of Twelfth and Wharton Streets. The "swimming bath," as it was commonly called, was so popular with the boys and young men of this immigrant, working-class neighborhood that they regularly waited an hour in line to enter. During the first few days, the crowd outside the pool often became unruly. The youths argued, fought, and tried to sneak ahead of one another in line. On the night of June 24, the usual ruckus escalated into a small riot. It started when the superintendent informed the expectant swimmers that they would not be admitted that evening because the pool was already filled to capacity. As the crowd grew incensed, the superintendent retreated inside the building and bolted the door. According to a local newspaper, the fifty or so young men who had been turned away "concluded to override his authority by the superiority of their numbers." They tore the door from its hinges and knocked down the fence that surrounded the pool. The city had stationed a police detail at the pool in anticipation of disorderly behavior, but the four officers were no match for the angry crowd. They were "tossed about like little bits of driftwood in rough water." Police reinforcements eventually restored order "with a liberal application of their clubs," but not before the pool and the reputation of the bathers had been severely damaged. The Philadelphia Evening Bulletin editorialized that "the good [the pool] has accomplished amongst the unwashed down-town youths has been more than counterbalanced by the harm a certain gang of roughs has seen fit in their ignorant and brutal natures to inflict." Commissioner of City Property William Dixey, whose department administered the pool, promised that "if such conduct is kept up," he would "close the house and keep it closed."

headline: ‘On Chesil Beach’
text: They were young, educated, and both virgins on this, their wedding night, and they lived in a time when a conversation about sexual difficulties was plainly impossible. But it is never easy. They had just sat down to supper in a tiny sitting room on the first floor of a Georgian inn. In the next room, visible through the open door, was a four-poster bed, rather narrow, whose bedcover was pure white and stretched startlingly smooth, as though by no human hand. Edward did not mention that he had never stayed in a hotel before, whereas Florence, after many trips as a child with her father, was an old hand. Superficially, they were in fine spirits. Their wedding, at St. Mary's, Oxford, had gone well; the service was decorous, the reception jolly, the send-off from school and college friends raucous and uplifting. Her parents had not condescended to his, as they had feared, and his mother had not significantly misbehaved, or completely forgotten the purpose of the occasion. The couple had driven away in a small car belonging to Florence's mother and arrived in the early evening at their hotel on the Dorset coast in weather that was not perfect for mid-July or the circumstances, but entirely adequate: it was not raining, but nor was it quite warm enough, according to Florence, to eat outside on the terrace as they had hoped. Edward thought it was, but, polite to a fault, he would not think of contradicting her on such an evening.

headline: ‘Ingrid’
text: "I'll be Mother," Ingrid Bergman said. She picked up the ornate silver teapot and poured.

headline: ‘April in Paris’
text: I learned about the transfer before noon. The small stripes of light had reached the windowsill. My major came in and kept one hand on the doorknob while gesturing to me with the other to keep my seat. He wanted to know if the hogwash from Marseille was ready yet. I pointed to the half-written sheet still in the typewriter. I could go when I reached the end of the page, he said.

headline: ‘The Ministry of Special Cases’
text: Jews bury themselves the way they live, crowded together, encroaching on one another's space. The headstones were packed tight, the bodies underneath elbow to elbow and head to toe. Kaddish led Pato through uneven rows over uneven ground on the Benevolent Self side. He cupped his hand over the eye of the flashlight to smother the light. His fingers glowed orange, red in between, as he ran his fist along the face of a stone.

headline: ‘Empire of Blue Water’
text: In the winter of 1654, a newly commissioned frigate named the Fagons was dispatched from the ancient city of Portsmouth on a secret mission. Its journey was short; it sailed around the southeast corner of England into the quiet harbor of Deal. There at the dock waited the ship's only cargo: a forty-four-year-old Anglican rector named Thomas Gage.

headline: ‘The Sack of Panama’
text: 'Land ahead on the starboard bow!' It was noon on 25 May 1666 when the ageing privateer, Captain Edward Mansfield, heard the lookout's cry. He clambered up into the rigging to check his position. One quick look through his perspective glass and he could relax. There was no mistaking the rugged hills, over a thousand feet high, of the lonely island which the English called Providence and the Spaniards called Santa Catalina. The old captain glanced back at the rest of his squadron. All four ships were still in sight, spread out across the otherwise empty sea. They all looked as though they had been a long time out of port, weather-beaten, paint faded, sails patched, but still moving well through the water, their bottoms clean after a recent careening. Three of them were very small, lateen-rigged sloops with no deck or cabin to protect their cramped crews from sun and sea and rain; and even the fourth was only about fifty tons, a small, square-rigged, half-decked frigate which, like Mansfield's own similar ship, had been recently captured from the Spaniards off the Central American coast. None of them carried many cannon, but no one who saw them would have been in any doubt that they were best to be avoided. Small, fast ships like these, crammed with men who knew from experience that four muskets could do as much execution as one cannon, had terrorized the waters and coastal settlements of the Caribbean for decades. Mansfield signalled the frigate to furl her topsails to reduce visibility and crept forward towards his goal. By late afternoon he was only twelve miles from the southernmost point of the island, and the squadron hove to until nightfall. Tomorrow, with any luck, the island would be his.

headline: Paperback Row
text: MAYFLOWER: A Story of Courage, Community, and War, by Nathaniel Philbrick. (Penguin, $16.) This absorbing history recreates the Pilgrims’ perilous 1620 voyage, the founding of the Plymouth Colony and its first contacts with the native inhabitants of Massachusetts. Philbrick, the author of the National Book Award-winning “In the Heart of the Sea,” finds striking parallels between past and present, particularly the way Plymouth’s leaders, including Miles Standish, rejected diplomatic overtures toward the Indians and instead pursued a policy of violent aggression that led to the needless bloodshed of King Philip’s War. The Book Review named “Mayflower” one of the 10 best books of 2006; our reviewer, Russell Shorto, called it a “vivid and remarkably fresh retelling.”

headline: Editor’s Choice
text: THE OCCUPATION OF IRAQ: Winning the War, Losing the Peace, by Ali A. Allawi. (Yale University, $28.) Iraq’s former defense minister tries to pinpoint the role of the country’s new political class in shaping the catastrophe there.

headline: Spoleto Festival U.S.A: An Impressive Young Ensemble
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. – The main reason I wanted to talk to Emmanuel Villaume, the music director of the Spoleto Festival U.S.A., on Saturday morning was to discuss his band, the fulsomely named Ginn Resorts Spoleto Festival U.S.A. Orchestra. I had already been mightily impressed with its work in two operas, the Brecht-Weill “Aufstieg und Fall der Stadt Mahagonny” and Gluck’s “Ile de Merlin.” And I became even more impressed on Saturday, hearing the group rehearse Strauss’s “Till Eulenspiegel” in the afternoon for an orchestral concert on June 5, then hearing it in the pit in the evening for Pascal Dusapin’s demanding opera “Faustus, the Last Night.”

headline: In Iowa, Clinton Sits at Table 44
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa – At the Iowa Democratic Party’s Hall of Fame dinner here Saturday night, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton took her seat at Table 44 in the middle of the ballroom. Coincidence? Hardly. If elected, she would be the nation’s 44th president, so the table moniker provided a good visual for the photographers hovering around her.

headline: American Soldiers on Patrol
text: Three months after the start of the Baghdad security plan, U.S. and Iraqi troops control less than a third of the city, according to commanders and an internal assessment.

headline: The Democrats’ Second 2008 Presidential Debate
text: The following is a transcript of the 2008 Democratic primary presidential debate hosted by CNN. The participants were Senator Joesph Biden, Senator Hillary Clinton, Senator Christopher Dodd, John Edwards, Mike Gravel, Rep. Dennis Kucinich, Senator Barack Obama and Governor William Richardson. The debate was moderated by Wolf Blitzer, with additional questions by Tom Fahey, State House Bureau Chief of the New Hampshire Union Leader and Scott Spradling, Political Director of WMUR-TV. Transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency.

headline: Le Mans gets into gear
text: I dropped in to Le Mans yesterday to check out the action on this weekend of testing for the 24-Hour race, which takes place 16 – 17 June. I had the good fortune to be able to visit the garages of Peugeot and Pescarolo. As I write these words, the day of testing is coming to an end. With 45 minutes left, Sébastien Bourdais leads the 55-car field in his diesel-powered Peugeot. You can check out the times and other news at the Le Mans 24-Hour site.

text: This year's Tony nominees for best actor are especially impressive.

headline: The Show Outside the Show
text: There is no doubt that the 300 or so cars in this year’s Greenwich Concours d’Elegance are what you would expect. They are beautiful, many of them are rare, and people come from around the region to attend the two-day event. The concours, which has been held every year since 1996, took place in a park along the harbor of Greenwich, Conn., Saturday and Sunday, with a Christie’s auto auction as Sunday’s highlight.

headline: Getting Ready for Tonight’s Debate
text: A full Times team will be in place for the debates tonight and on Tuesday in New Hampshire, and we’ll be back with Katharine Q. Seelye live-blogging the events, which begin at 7 p.m. Eastern time and will be broadcast live on CNN.

headline: Beltran Plans to Return Tuesday
text: Raise your hand if you expected to see the Ben Johnson-Endy Chavez-Carlos Gomez triumvirate starting in the outfield this season. Didn’t think so. As the Mets battle injuries to Moises Alou, Shawn Green and, most recently, Carlos Beltran, that is what they have. Unless you’re hurt, you’re playing is how Willie Randolph feels.

headline: We’ll Start a New Streak in 2008
text: They say that, over time, a player’s performance rises or regresses to the mean. That is, a few games may produce one kind of result, but over time everything balances out. I can tell you for certain that this is true.

headline: DeSalvo to Start on Monday
text: When the Yankees first learned that Roger Clemens would be unable to pitch tomorrow in Chicago, they reluctantly viewed Kei Igawa as their best option to start in his place. But the gruesome injury to Doug Mientkiewicz, which requires a disabled list stay that could last two months, opened a roster spot for Matt DeSalvo, and he will start on Monday instead.

headline: Sunday Sampler Platter
text: Iraq, immigration and presidential politics – where would the talk shows be without them?

headline: Debate Preview — Live From New Hampshire
text: GOFFSTOWN — Hi everyone. We’re in place on a chilly, rainy night at St. Anselm’s College in New Hampshire for the second Democratic debate of the season. This one has three sponsors: CNN, The Manchester Union Leader and WMUR-TV.

headline: Live-Blogging the New Hampshire Debate
text: 9:15 p.m. With the debate over, most of the candidates have left, many to go to the Spin Room, or to mingle with the audience down on the floor. But here is where the rock stars separate themselves from the pack: Mr. Obama and Mrs. Clinton have moved to the edge of the stage and are reaching down to the audience to shake hands and sign autographs. Mr. Obama has become so engrossed that he has crouched down on the stage to be closer to eye level with the voters.

headline: The Un-Schadenfreude
text: A while back, a writer friend of mine produced one of the bestselling books of the year, and on the strength of his royalties, moved to a large Manhattan penthouse with extensive river views. And of course I was thrilled by his success. Truly.

headline: Your Comments on my North Korea Column
text: In addition to my Monday column on North Korea, I also have a video prepared by my travel buddy, Naka Nathaniel, based on our interviews with the North Koreans. Check it out.

headline: Another Spin of the Wheel
text: In the past year I have come to expect that the respondents to these columns will be learned, eloquent and precise in the articulation of their positions. (I have also learned that, no matter how remote the connection, they will be able to use whatever I write as a springboard to a denunciation of the Bush administration.) But my expectations were exceeded by the comments posted to my last piece on the impossibility of avoiding “spin” in a world (our world) where perception and expression necessarily proceed from some angled perspective or point of view. With passion and precision (and often at some length) the authors of these comments alerted me to at least two mistakes.

headline: Fever Builds for iPhone (Anxiety Too)
text: Steve Jobs, the world’s consummate salesman, has succeeded in building expectations for the iPhone. The bar-of-soap-size phone is being coveted as a talisman for a digital age, and the hysteria is beginning to reach levels usually reserved for video-game machines at Christmas.

headline: The Debate Talk-o-Meter
text: As promised, Senator Chris Dodd’s campaign calculated the number of minutes each candidate spoke during tonight’s Democratic debate in New Hampshire.

headline: Postscript to the Democratic Debate
text: GOFFSTOWN — Well, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton dominated this debate _ and so did her husband. Has a spouse ever suffused a debate the way former President Bill Clinton suffused this one?

headline: Surge in Adoptions Raises Concern in Ethiopia
text: ST. PAUL — Ethiopia was not on Mark and Vera Westrum-Ostrom’s list when they first visited Children’s Home Society & Family Services here to explore an international adoption.

headline: Somalia’s Prime Minister Survives Suicide Attack; 7 Others Die
text: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 3 — A suicide bomber narrowly missed killing Somalia’s transitional prime minister on Sunday afternoon after he rammed a pickup truck packed with explosives into the gates of the prime minister’s house in Mogadishu, the capital.

headline: Obama in Second Place
text: One of the lessons journalists should have learned from the 2000 election campaign is that what a candidate says about policy isn’t just a guide to his or her thinking about a specific issue — it’s the best way to get a true sense of the candidate’s character.

headline: Trial of Black Raises Conflict Issue
text: Maclean’s Magazine, a leading Canadian weekly newsmagazine, has been as eager to cover the trial of Conrad M. Black as any other Canadian news outlet.

headline: Pérez Has a Bad Day and Mets Lose
text: There was nothing unusual about the message scrawled on the dry-erase board that greeted players walking into the Mets’ clubhouse yesterday morning. “Regular Day, 1:10 p.m.,” it read, and the team acted accordingly. Oliver Pérez balanced an orange pillow atop his head. Rubén Gotay and José Reyes clamored for autographs from a champion boxer. Ben Johnson downed a fluorescent-green drink that he said tasted like “lemon-lime Tums.”

headline: Why the Silver Surfer Isn’t the Coin of the Realm
text: The studio behind a coming summer movie, “Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer,” has roused the ire of the United States Mint with its promotional gimmick for the film, in which Marvel Comics superheroes battle a metallic alien.

headline: New Liver Cancer Drug Is Promising, Doctors Say
text: CHICAGO, June 3 — A new drug looks poised to become the first effective treatment for liver cancer, one of the most common and deadliest cancers in the world and one whose incidence has been rising in the United States, doctors said here Sunday.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: A BREAK IN THE ACTION It will be a relatively slow week for economic news, led by the report on the trade deficit for April (Friday). Other reports will include April factory orders (Monday), the Institute for Supply Management’s nonmanufacturing index (Tuesday), revised first-quarter productivity and labor costs (Wednesday) and April numbers for wholesale trade and consumer credit (Thursday).

headline: Democratic Lawmaker Indicted
text: WASHINGTON, June 4 — Representative William J. Jefferson of Louisiana was indicted today on corruption charges in connection with an inquiry that has yielded reports of cash stuffed into home freezers and murky financial transactions with several African countries in what Justice Department officials called a sordid episode of corruption that touched two continents..

headline: In or Out of Eden, One Man’s Unicorn May Be Another’s Apatosaurus
text: There are some extraordinary fossils at the new Creation Museum, which opened last week in Petersburg, Ky., including one that preserves a perch with a half-eaten herring in its mouth. And there are some extraordinary creatures at the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan, in a new show that also opened last week, including a life-size unicorn, a gold griffin and not a few dragons.

headline: For the Record
text: An article on Tuesday about a drop in crime in East Orange, N.J., which city officials attribute to the Police Department’s use of new surveillance technology, misstated the number of precincts in the Queens South division of the New York Police Department, a division that the East Orange police director, Jose M. Cordero, formerly ran. There are 8, not 18.

headline: Ballet With Headstands, and Other Quirky Contrasts
text: The three pieces on the program presented by Ben Munisteri Dance Projects on Thursday night at Dance New Amsterdam use ballet extensively. So extensively that you start to think that the work might look even better coming from a ballet company. But the extended lines, small beats of the feet and tight, whirling turns are democratically apportioned — some of the dancers look balletic, some don’t — and interspersed with other things: jumping jacks, handstands, ordinary walks and crouches.

headline: Kevorkian Speaks After His Release From Prison
text: SOUTHFIELD, Mich., June 3 — Jack Kevorkian, the former pathologist once known as Doctor Death, says he will never again counsel a terminally ill person on how to die. But eight years behind bars and a strict list of promises to gain parole have done nothing to mellow the blunt, passionate, combative advocate for physician-assisted suicide.

headline: Iraq Is the Flash Point as Eight Democratic Rivals Clash
text: GOFFSTOWN, N.H., June 3 — The three leading candidates for the Democratic presidential nomination attacked each other overtly and subtly Sunday over Iraq and their judgment, honesty and leadership in handling that war.

headline: Listing Top Jobs but Charging Candidates to Seek Them
text: RECRUITERS with six-figure jobs to fill know better than to post them online and start a stampede of marginally qualified job seekers. But they also know that the Web is the easiest way to find applicants.

headline: Bush Climate Plan: Amid Nays, Some Maybes
text: President Bush’s shift last week toward cutting worldwide emissions linked to global warming was greeted with widespread skepticism. But mixed in with the doubts was a substantial dose of support, albeit conditional.

headline: Hamas Militant Say They Shelled Border Crossing
text: JERUSALEM, June 3 — The military wing of Hamas claimed responsibility for firing mortar shells at the Erez crossing on the Gaza-Israel border on Sunday, slightly wounding four Israeli soldiers, hours after Israeli forces shot and killed a Palestinian man in the West Bank city of Jenin.

headline: No, Not Everyone Skips the Commercials
text: Last Thursday, Nielsen Media Research began releasing standardized information about viewership of commercials. The numbers came as a relief to television executives, showing that viewers who own DVRs do not fast-forward through the ads as much as had been feared.

headline: Rev. David Kirk, 72, Crusader for New York City’s Disenfranchised, Dies
text: The Rev. David Kirk, an Eastern Orthodox priest who spent most of his adult life working with New York City’s disenfranchised, died on May 23 at Emmaus House, the communal residence for the homeless that he founded in Harlem more than 40 years ago. He was 72.

headline: Sheik Buys Breeding Rights to Street Sense
text: Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum’s breeding operation has bought the breeding rights of the Kentucky Derby winner Street Sense and will stand him at a farm in Kentucky when his racing career is over.

headline: A Linebacker’s Legend Is Growing in Kansas
text: In the midst of the spring period to evaluate high school football players last month, college football’s most elite coaches took a detour from the traditional recruiting hotbeds — California, Florida and Texas — to an unlikely destination, southern Kansas.

headline: One Had Stature and One Didn’t, but Neither Seemed an Extremist
text: Abdul Kadir and Russell M. Defreitas met in Georgetown in their native Guyana in late February, according to federal investigators. They walked together with another man to a mall downtown.

headline: Niche Cellphone Company in California Files for Bankruptcy Protection
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 3 — Amp’d Mobile, a niche cellphone provider aimed at the young and technologically sophisticated, has filed for bankruptcy protection.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,469 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Friday:

headline: For the Record
text: The Executive Pursuits column in Business Day on May 5, about selling hot dogs at Shea Stadium, misinterpreted a survey by the National Hot Dog and Sausage Council and referred incorrectly to hot dog sales at Shea. Although the stadium sells an average of just under 20,000 hot dogs a game, and ranks No. 1 among major league ballparks who responded to the questionnaire from the hot dog council, Shea does not lead all ballparks in sales. It trails Yankee Stadium, which sells about 30,000 a game but did not answer the survey. (A reader raised the issue after an article on May 11 about the introduction of Latin food at Yankee Stadium mentioned the higher figure for the Yankees. Unfortunately for the reader, who vowed not to “consume any dogs at either stadium until it has been settled,” this correction was delayed for research; but the Mets have a home game tomorrow night.)

headline: Everybody Talks About the Weather; All of a Sudden, It’s Controversial
text: ATLANTA — For 25 years, they have been talking about the weather nonstop.

headline: For the Record
text: Artist renderings with an article in Science Times on Sept. 12, 2006, about plans by a biomedical research institute in China to construct a building with a design inspired by cells omitted credit for two artists. Besides Sloan Kulper, the renderings were by Audrey Roy and Shuguang Zhang. The omission was pointed out recently in an e-mail message from Mr. Kulper.

headline: Whistling Past the Graveyard as the Wait Goes On
text: Boston

headline: Ruling Helps Prosecutors in Death Penalty Cases
text: WASHINGTON, June 4 — The Supreme Court today strengthened the hand of prosecutors in death penalty cases by making it easier to remove potential jurors who express ambivalence about the death penalty or confusion about how it should be applied.

headline: Specialized Software Maker Is Said to Be in Buyout Talks
text: Cadence Design Systems, one of the largest makers of the software used to design computer chips, is in talks with at least two buyout firms about a possible sale of the company, two people close to the matter said yesterday.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: ‘Gone With the Wind’ Goes Musical in London

headline: James Leads a New Generation to Its Moment
text: Cleveland

headline: The Superfabulous World of Rufus Wainwright
text: A few weeks ago, on his way to an appearance at the Union Square Barnes & Noble to promote his new album, “Release the Stars,” Rufus Wainwright decided his all-black outfit was a little dour for a meet-and-greet. “Fashion emergency!” he said. So he dashed down to the antique-jewelry shop below his apartment and picked up a 1920s Czech glass necklace, which sparkled atop his black T-shirt.

headline: Bronx: Voter Registration Urged
text: State Senator Jeffrey D. Klein said yesterday that New York should expand its efforts to encourage young people to register to vote. Senator Klein, a Democrat who represents parts of the Bronx and Westchester County, said a survey of 60 colleges and universities in the state conducted by his staff found that none of the private institutions mailed voter forms to students and only 10 percent of the public ones did so. Only half of the private universities surveyed provided registration information on campus, he said. Senator Klein has proposed requiring the state to mail voter registration forms to all residents when they turn 18.

headline: Title-Starved Cleveland Pins Hopes on Cavaliers
text: CLEVELAND, June 3 — LeBron James took the microphone as M.C. of the franchise revival, stepping to center court to cheers of delirium. Minutes after guiding the Cleveland Cavaliers to their first Eastern Conference championship with a 98-82 romp against the Detroit Pistons on Saturday in Game 6, James thanked the fans, 20,562 strong, at Quicken Loans Arena.

headline: Gates Cautious About Gains in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 3 — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates arrived here in the Afghan capital on Sunday, expressing guarded optimism about the progress of the military campaign against a resurgent Taliban.

headline: A Mexican Baby Boom in New York Shows the Strength of a New Immigrant Group
text: When Lilian Vazquez was born in Brooklyn on Thursday, a rosy 8 pounds 12 ounces and 20 ½ inches, she joined a baby boom among Mexican New Yorkers — one that bucks an overall decline in New York City births.

headline: Treasury Auctions Scheduled for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

headline: The Internets, They Can Be Cruel
text: THE Internet can sometimes seem overrun with versions of Simon, the alpha male tech guy from the BBC series “The Office.”

headline: Gates Says Iranian Weapons Flowing Into Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 4 — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said today that Iranian weapons had begun flowing into Afghanistan in recent months. But he said that he and President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan agreed that there was no direct evidence that the Iranian government was behind the arms shipments.

headline: For the Record
text: The Media Equation column in Business Day on Monday, about the news media’s efforts to cover the war in Iraq, misspelled the given name of a photographer who chronicled the Civil War. He was Mathew Brady, not Matthew.

headline: Former Leader Talks of Return to Pakistan, and Maybe Power
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 3 — Former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto is stirring up Pakistani politics by quietly talking through intermediaries about a power-sharing deal with the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, and suggesting in an interview that she could return to Pakistan before the end of the year.

headline: For the Record
text: A credit for an illustration with an essay in Science Times on May 22 about a doctor who witnessed a patient’s last night misspelled the given name of the artist and reversed it with her surname. She is Tifenn Python, not Python Tiffen.

headline: Chinese Commemorate 18th Anniversary of Tiananmen Crackdown
text: HONG KONG, June 4 — A candlelight vigil here this evening to mark the 18th anniversary of the military crackdown on the Tiananmen Square demonstrations drew an unusually large crowd, apparently in response to the recent assertion by the leader of Hong Kong’s pro-Beijing party that no massacre took place in 1989.

headline: Bound by Blood, but Separated by a Breach in Sanity
text: Sigourney Weaver and Kristine Nielsen serve their specialties with such gusto in “Crazy Mary,” the new comedy by A. R. Gurney that opened last night at Playwrights Horizons, that it feels ungallant to point out that their characters are as artificial as hard-plastic dolls.

headline: Terrorists, Chemicals and Trains
text: A bill is moving forward in Congress that would take important and much-needed steps to protect Americans from terrorist attacks. But it may not address one of the most glaring vulnerabilities: chemicals traveling by rail. The House has voted to include restrictions on rail transport of deadly chemicals, but the Senate has not.

headline: Ed Yost, 87, Father of Modern Hot-Air Ballooning, Dies
text: Ed Yost, who fastened two propane tanks to what essentially looked like a lawn chair, attached that contraption to a 40-foot-diameter white nylon balloon and sailed above the Nebraska plain on a brisk fall day in 1960, becoming “the father of modern hot-air ballooning,” died May 27 at his home in Vadito, N.M. He was 87.

headline: Show Us the Money
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Shake-Up at JWT in Chicago After Loss of Kraft Foods
text: JWT is shaking up the leadership of its Chicago office after the office lost a large part of its important Kraft Foods account.

headline: Mr. Murdoch Comes Round for Tea
text: The meeting later today between Rupert Murdoch and the Bancroft family that could determine the fate of Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, would seem to be a very modern media moment.

headline: A Theme Song for Clinton: ‘I’m a Believer’ vs. ‘Cold as Ice’
text: When Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton asked YouTube viewers to vote on a theme song for her presidential campaign, she certainly got the attention she wanted — and a whole lot of jokes at her expense.

headline: Dinner Disappears, and African Penguins Pay the Price
text: ROBBEN ISLAND, South Africa, May 28 — Striding across a barren patch of this windswept isle, Les Underhill paused, then bent down for a closer look at his discovery: one adult African penguin and two three-week-old chicks, huddled in an earthy depression about as big as the average bathroom basin.

headline: Canadiens of the 1950s Are Still the Kings of the Cup
text: Dynasties don’t exist in the N.H.L. anymore, and they are seldom seen in any other sport. Not since the Detroit Red Wings won the Stanley Cup in 1997 and 1998 has the same N.H.L. franchise reigned in consecutive seasons. All the more reason hockey’s most dynamic dynasty, the Montreal Canadiens of Maurice Richard and Jean Béliveau, who won the Cup a record five years in a row half a century ago, was honored in Ottawa over the weekend.

headline: Fever Builds for iPhone (Anxiety Too)
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 3 — During an onscreen demonstration of the iPhone in Apple’s sprawling retail store here recently, an employee, clad in a black T-shirt, of course, surprised a potential customer.

headline: At-Home Fertility Screening Available for Men
text: Many men, faced with the prospect of going to the doctor for a fertility evaluation, will tell you: they would rather just stay home.

headline: Chinese Stocks Fall After Government Increases Taxes
text: SHANGHAI, June 4 — China’s stock market tumbled again today in one of the biggest sell-offs in years. It followed the government’s move last week to impose higher taxes on stock trades.

headline: Papers Portray Plot as More Talk Than Action
text: The plot as painted by law enforcement officials was cataclysmic: A home-grown Islamic terrorist had in mind detonating fuel storage tanks and pipelines and setting fire to Kennedy International Airport, not to mention a substantial swath of Queens.

headline: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about Reading to Rover, a program at the Westport Public Library in Connecticut in which children read to dogs as a form of therapy, misspelled the given name of the children’s librarian. She is Lynne Perrigo, not Lynn.

headline: Bruno Inquiry Scrutinizes Thoroughbred Transactions
text: Federal authorities investigating the business dealings of Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader of the State Senate, have been examining records related to his purchases and sales of thoroughbred horses.

headline: In Video, Insurgents Claim 2 Missing G.I.’s Are Dead
text: BAGHDAD, June 4 — A Sunni Arab insurgent group released a video on Monday that showed the military identification cards of two missing American soldiers abducted in an ambush south of Baghdad last month, and the group claimed the two had been killed along with one other soldier.

headline: Congress Hobbles the AIDS Fight
text: Washington, D.C., is one of America’s AIDS hot spots. A significant proportion of infections can be traced back to intravenous drug users who shared contaminated needles and then passed on the infection to spouses, lovers or unborn children.

headline: Inspired by Nicklaus, Choi Wins Memorial
text: DUBLIN, Ohio, June 3  When K. J. Choi was 16 and living in Wando, South Korea, his physical education teacher gave him a copy of an instructional book by Jack Nicklaus.

headline: Wake Up, Princess, the Movies Are Calling
text: In the land of Ballet Ever After, two heroines meet. Odette mimes (as she does in the traditional “Swan Lake”), “That lake is made of my mother’s tears.” Whereupon Aurora (as refashioned in American Ballet Theater’s new production of “The Sleeping Beauty”) replies: “Lake! My mother cried me a river (remember the song?) when I pricked my finger and they thought I was dead. But my prince drank from the river’s waters and sailed up it to find me. ...”

headline: Bill Whitman, 92, Is Dead; Scoured the Earth for Rare Fruit
text: William F. Whitman Jr., a self-taught horticulturist who became renowned for collecting rare tropical fruits from around the world and popularizing them in the United States, died Wednesday at his home in Bal Harbour, Fla. He was 92.

headline: Bush Goes to Europe in Wake of Putin’s Threat
text: BERLIN, June 4 — President Bush flew to Europe today for talks with world leaders later this week, including President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, in the wake of a threat by Mr. Putin to point Russian missiles at Europe if the United States builds its missile defense system in Poland and the Czech Republic.

headline: You Hear Those People? They’re Animals!
text: “Creature Comforts,” a new stop-motion animation series on CBS, is from the British outfit that has given us the characters of Wallace and Gromit and the clever film “Chicken Run.” In the new show, clay animals with human voices make various observations about attraction, doctors — life. It may seem an odd thing to say, but “Creature Comforts” reminds me in some tiny way of “The Sopranos” because just as it is always unfailingly funny when mob men and their coterie speak of “Moby-Dick” and the “human condition,” it makes you laugh when a fake pig, speaking as a middle-aged woman, talks about losing weight.

headline: Harvard Is Licensing More Than 50 Patents to a Nanotechnology Start-Up
text: George M. Whitesides, a Harvard University chemist, is a renowned specialist in nanotechnology, a field built on the behavior of materials as small as one molecule thick. But there is nothing tiny about the patent portfolio that Harvard has amassed over the last 25 years based on work in his lab.

headline: Escape From North Korea
text: CHINESE-NORTH KOREAN BORDER

headline: Bloomberg Cast as Enemy No. 1 of Gun Rights
text: In New York, Michael R. Bloomberg is known as the billionaire media mogul who became mayor. But in many parts of the country, he is the man who would take away your guns.

headline: With Mientkiewicz Out, Yankees Fill in Missing Pieces
text: BOSTON, June 3  Doug Mientkiewicz was driven home by his wife on Sunday. He was a wounded passenger, having sustained a concussion, a neck sprain and a fractured bone in his right wrist on Saturday in a collision at Fenway Park. From a baseball standpoint, the wrist injury is the most serious, and it will keep him out a minimum of six weeks.

headline: Dear Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: On Upper East Side, Two Seek Vacated Assembly Seat
text: The Upper East Side was once the reliable foothold of the liberal Republican politician. It was the home of John V. Lindsay and, most recently, State Senator Roy M. Goodman. But in the last decade, the neighborhood has become increasingly Democratic, and Republican officeholders have become fixtures of the past.

headline: Palm Is Said to Sell Stake to Equity Firm in Revamping
text: Palm Inc., the struggling hand-held device company that makes the Treo, reached a deal yesterday to sell a quarter of the company to Elevation Partners, a private equity firm, for about $325 million as part of a plan to reorganize the company, according to people involved in the negotiations.

headline: For Red Sox, the Relief Is Almost Beyond Belief
text: Boston

headline: Fighting in Lebanese Refugee Camp Rages, and Spreads
text: SIDON, Lebanon, Monday, June 4 — The deadly volley of shelling and sniper fire at a refugee camp in northern Lebanon intensified Sunday, and fighting broke out between militants and the army in another camp in the south, increasing fears that the two-week battle between the Lebanese Army and Islamist militants could spread to other parts of the country.

headline: Rock on, but Hang on to Your Literary Gigs
text: What kind of rock band gets up before noon? For that matter, what kind of band reads and writes? The Rock Bottom Remainders do both, and have also been known, while on tour, to tune in to “The NewsHour With Jim Lehrer.” At a little after 6 on Thursday morning they turned up at the studio of “Good Morning America” to do a promotional spot for a Friday-night benefit coinciding with BookExpo America, the big publishing fair that took place in New York over the weekend. The green-room spread included, instead of greenies and quarts of Jack, platters of fresh fruit and, at the request of Roy Blount Jr., one of the band’s founding members, a big pan of grits.

headline: China Releases Climate Change Plan
text: BEIJING, June 4 — China today released its first comprehensive strategy on addressing climate change, a plan that calls for improving energy efficiency and controlling greenhouse gas emissions but that rejects mandatory caps on emissions that could harm the country’s sizzling economy.

headline: All Over but the Shouting
text: CHICAGO, June 3 —Bobby Cox remained one ejection shy Sunday of tying John McGraw for a dubious distinction and unofficial baseball record. But Lou Piniella showed again Saturday that he has no current equal for flamboyant temper tantrums that often bring banishment by umpires.

headline: A Great Horse, but Who Takes the Winnings?
text: When Curlin chased down the Kentucky Derby winner Street Sense to capture the Preakness Stakes, his owners bounded to the winners’ circle at Pimlico Race Course. They were an eclectic bunch that included a winemaker, a computer magnate, an investment banker and two lawyers.

headline: Freezing Out East on the Way to Second Place
text: The Long Island Spring Regional starts in Smithtown tomorrow. The tournament chairman, Steve Conrad of Manhasset, N.Y., played on Memorial Day weekend in the Easterns Regional in New York City. He and his teammates, Diana Schuld of Glen Head, N.Y., Ruth Stober of Great Neck, N.Y., and Michael Abramson of Montclair, N.J., finished second in the Open Swiss Teams behind Steven Petersell, Qiang Wang and Sam Wang of New York and Jian Wang of New Milford, N.J. They might have been third but for the diagramed deal.

headline: What Stroke Victims Don’t Know (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Way to Give Authors a Lucrative Second Platform
text: Even before Lawrence Wright, a staff writer for The New Yorker, won a Pulitzer Prize for his book “The Looming Tower: Al Qaeda and the Road to 9/11,” he was one of the busiest lecturing authors published by Alfred A. Knopf. For April and May, he had been booked to speak at Princeton and Wesleyan Universities, at a public relations seminar in Santa Barbara, Calif., and at a lunch in Chicago sponsored by the Northern Trust Bank.

headline:
Talk to the Newsroom:
National Editor Suzanne Daley
text: Suzanne Daley, The Times's national editor, answered reader questions June 4 through 8, 2007.

headline: Romney’s Fortunes Tied to Business Riches
text: WASHINGTON, June 3 — Mitt Romney owes his nearly $350 million fortune and his political career to a delicate negotiation with his boss in the summer of 1983.

headline: Compete With China (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Oddity in Picking Jurors Opens Door to Racial Bias
text: Allen Snyder, a black man, is on death row in Louisiana. An all-white jury in Jefferson Parish, in the New Orleans suburbs, sentenced him to death in 1996 for the fatal stabbing of a man his wife was seeing.

headline: 14 More American Servicemen Are Killed in Iraq, Most of Them by Makeshift Bombs
text: BAGHDAD, June 3  The pace of American troop deaths increased this weekend as 14 more servicemen were reported killed in Iraq, all but one from makeshift bombs that insurgents have been employing with greater lethality against American soldiers and armored vehicles. Twenty-one soldiers and an Iraqi interpreter were wounded.

headline: Love and Debt: The Game of Life Now Takes Plastic
text: If life’s a game, I can only hope it’s not a game like the Game of Life. That’s the one where you drive a plastic car along a winding path, going to work or college and picking up pink and blue pegs for children until you end up at a McMansion and get to count your money. I played it with my young daughter a couple of times and found it excruciating, probably because of how effectively it boiled life down to its plodding essence, a march to suburban retirement. It made me long for the solace of death, but that is not an option in this game.

headline: Opposition in Senegal Boycotts Vote
text: DAKAR, Senegal, June 3  Voters in Senegal on Sunday largely stayed home from an election to choose a new national assembly amid widespread apathy and after a call for a boycott by the main opposition parties.

headline: The Man Behind the Curtain: Political Strategy and Spin
text: Among the many stirring words written by Robert Shrum are these: “Since I was very young, I have had a profound reverence for this office I hold. I’ve been honored that you, the people, have entrusted it to me. I am proud of what we have accomplished together.” And about wife and daughter, Hillary and Chelsea: “Their forgiveness and love, expressed so often as we sat alone together this weekend, means far more than I can ever say.”

headline: Qiagen to Buy Digene, Maker of Tests for Cancer-Causing Virus
text: Qiagen, a Dutch maker of tools for gene research, has agreed to buy the Digene Corporation for $1.6 billion in shares and cash to gain tests for a virus that causes cervical cancer and sexually transmitted diseases.

headline: Rodriguez Lifts Weight With Homer in 9th
text: BOSTON, Monday, June 4 — He was down to his last strike with two outs in the ninth inning of Sunday night’s game, at the end of what might be the longest week of his life. Alex Rodriguez — bad boy of the tabloids, violator of baseball etiquette, object of ridicule and scorn at Fenway Park — was fighting.

headline: Walls of Art for Everyone, but Made by Not Just Anyone
text: The sticky-sweet smell of spray paint hung in the hot air as members of Tats Cru covered a rooftop wall with crazy kinetic letters. They were far from prying eyes, though not because they were doing anything illegal. In fact, the man whose business occupied the football-field-size building was their patron, allowing them and other graffiti artists to use the roof as their own open-air atelier. Here among the drab warehouses of the Hunts Point Cooperative Market, they had the privacy to try out new designs, repainting and refining until they were pleased with the results.

headline: Waxing Philosophical, Booksellers Face the Digital
text: John Updike would not be pleased.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about charges being brought in Brazil against two American pilots, whose corporate jet was involved in a midair collision last year over the Amazon with a Brazilian airliner that went down with 154 people aboard, misstated a Brazilian judge’s position on the case. He said in a statement issued in Portuguese on Friday that the two pilots, Joseph Lepore and Jan Paul Paladino, should be charged with exposing an aircraft to danger; he did not say they were guilty of having done so. (Go to Article)

headline: Immigration Sabotage
text: The Senate plans to resume debate today on its proposed immigration overhaul, which has withstood more than a week of bombardment from critics right and left. More than 100 amendments are circling, many designed to make the tortuously drafted compromise meaner, narrower and nastier.

headline: William Silver, 59, Early Gay Applicant for Ministry, Is Dead
text: William Silver, whose 1975 application for ordination in the United Presbyterian Church — the first by an openly gay man — set off a continuing debate in the church over admitting homosexuals into the ministry, died on May 26. He was 59 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: Romney Is Central Target of McCain Counterattack
text: Senator John McCain, facing increasing anger from fellow Republicans over his support of the immigration bill in Congress, is ramping up his counterattack against a main rival in the presidential campaign, Mitt Romney, by accusing him of “pandering for votes” in opposing the measure.

headline: Reader Responses
text: The following are excerpts of reader responses to the article, "Small Business Not as Usual," by Ron Nixon and Elizabeth Olson:

headline: The Look of War (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Air of Truth
text: Arlington, Va.

headline: Phone Equipment Manufacturer May Be Sold
text: Avaya was near a deal last night to sell itself to Silver Lake Partners and the Texas Pacific Group for more than $8 billion in the latest buyout in the telecommunications industry, according to people briefed on the sale.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 3, 2007

headline: Hamas Fires Mortars After Palestinian Is Killed
text: JERUSALEM, June 3 — The military wing of Hamas claimed responsibility for firing mortar shells at the Erez crossing on the Gaza-Israel border on Sunday, slightly wounding four Israeli soldiers, hours after Israeli forces shot and killed a Palestinian man in the West Bank city of Jenin.

headline: NBC Names Program Executive to Head TV Studio
text: NBC Universal took another step in revamping its television entertainment operations yesterday, appointing Katherine Pope as president of its television production studio, NBC Universal Television.

headline: Rain Postpones Nascar Race
text: The 400-mile Nascar Nextel Cup race scheduled for yesterday afternoon at Dover International Speedway in Delaware was postponed until noon today because of heavy rain. The race is the sixth of the year using the new Car of Tomorrow. Ryan Newman will start from the pole position, and Dale Earnhardt Jr. will start second, his best starting position in 13 races this season.Although skies over the racetrack were still leaden, rain stopped long enough for workers to attempt to dry the track so the race could start just after its scheduled time of 1:45 p.m. But it began to rain again, and the race was postponed a half-hour later.It was the third time in the past four Nextel Cup races, including those at Richmond and Darlington, that a race has been pushed back one day because of poor weather. There is a 60 percent chance of showers today.

headline: Liberian Boycotts Trial at The Hague
text: THE HAGUE, June 4  On the first day of his trial, Charles G. Taylor, one of Africa’s most tyrannical warlords and the former president of Liberia, refused to appear in court today, and he sent word that he was firing his lawyer, apparently wanting to obstruct proceedings that aim to cover a decade of bloody warfare and extraordinary cruelties.

headline: Netflix Prize Still Awaits a Movie Seer
text: Sometimes a good idea becomes a great one after it is set loose.

headline: Flirting, but Serious, Kicking Off With a Hit
text: RIHANNA

headline: Commanders Say Push in Baghdad Is Short of Goal
text: BAGHDAD, June 3 — Three months after the start of the Baghdad security plan that has added thousands of American and Iraqi troops to the capital, they control fewer than one-third of the city’s neighborhoods, far short of the initial goal for the operation, according to some commanders and an internal military assessment.

headline: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, two picture captions on Tuesday with an article in Science Times about private rooms in neonatal intensive care units misspelled the surname of a woman whose son was born prematurely in St. Paul. She is Robyn Frandrup, not Frandrep. Also, the article misstated the month that Amillia Taylor, who was born at just over 21 weeks’ gestation, was released from a Miami hospital. It was February, not April.

headline: Tiny Bit of Hardware With Marley Software
text: When reggae singer Bob Marley released “Exodus” in 1977, fans most likely bought it as a vinyl record, then over the decades went on to purchase it on CD or to download it. But those same boomers now can buy the album in a format that will impress even their computer-using children: on a U.S.B. flash drive.

headline: Publishers Creating Their Own In-House Ad Agencies
text: Like executives at advertising agencies, Richard D. Beckman and his team talk to managers at consumer brand companies about the customers they want to reach. Four to six weeks later, they present a marketing and advertising plan.

headline: Judge Throws Out Charges in Guantánamo Prisoner Case
text: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba, June 4 — A military judge here dismissed the war crimes charges against a Canadian detainee today, saying there was a flaw in the procedure the military has used to file such charges against Guantánamo detainees.

headline: Cancer Experts Threatened After Opposing Drug
text: CHICAGO, June 3 — Two prominent prostate cancer experts have been threatened for opposing approval of a controversial new drug and are being protected by bodyguards as they attend the nation’s largest cancer conference here.

headline: In Lawmakers’ Eyes, All Power Plants Are Not Created Equal
text: ALBANY — Are there more coal-fired and nuclear power plants in New York’s future?

headline: Sharapova Fends Off Jeers and Schnyder’s Two Match Points
text: PARIS, June 3 — Her long blond ponytail soaked with sweat, Maria Sharapova stood at midcourt Sunday, smiling and blowing kisses to the crowd booing her.

headline: Fighting in Lebanese Camp Worsens
text: TRIPOLI, Lebanon, June 4—Two Lebanese soldiers and two militants were killed in fighting in Ain al Hilwe refugee camp in southern Lebanon early today, capping a night of violence in both northern and southern Lebanon.

An article on Saturday about charges being brought in Brazil against two American pilots, whose corporate jet was involved in a mid-air collision last year over the Amazon with a Brazilian airliner that went down with 154 people aboard, misstated a Brazilian judge’s position on the case. He said in a statement issued in Portuguese on Friday that the two pilots, Joseph Lepore and Jan Paul Paladino, should be charged with exposing an aircraft to danger; he did not say they were guilty of having done so.

headline: The Mass in Latin (Redux) (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pettitte Hurts His Back
text: Remember that great catch by Melky Cabrera Sunday night, the one in the third inning where he ran forever to track down Wily Mo Pena’s drive on the distant center field warning track? Great moment for the Yankees, right?

headline: After Three Playoffs, Candidates Finals Are Set
text: Alexei Shirov, Boris Gelfand and Levon Aronian advanced to the final round of the candidates after winning their tiebreak contests. They join Gata Kamsky, Alexander Grischuk, Evgeny Bareev, Peter Leko and Sergei Rublevsky in the candidates final to select four qualifiers for the world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. All the matches, preliminary and final, are taking place in Elista, Kalmykia. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.

headline: Experiencing Brad Cloepfil's Vision
text: Images from Brad Cloepfil's reworking of Edward Durell Stone's "lollipop" building at Columbus Circle.

headline: A way to bike the dolce vita
text: OK, Lets start with the reality: Central Rome is not made-for-cycling. There are no bike lanes and the streets are narrow. The drivers are nuts. Scooters swarm like bees. It is hilly. Most Italians consider bicycles the lowest form of transportation. If you want a taste what it is like to cycle in the center of Rome, check out this video by Austrian performance artist, Rainer Ganahl, who cycled in the center here with a camera on his helmet. (OK, he was cycling against traffic.) As he noted, he didn’t see a single other cyclist during his 16 minute terror ride. On the other hand, the Italian police didn’t seem to mind that he was cycling in the middle of the street into oncoming traffic.

headline: Phones Add New Photo Features
text: Phone cameras have become more sophisticated, but most still need to focus more on image quality and ease of use.

headline: $4 Million Homes
text: Tour five-bedroom homes in Boca Raton, Fla., and Boulder, Colo., and a Napa Valley estate with five structures, a pool, a pond and a tennis court.

headline: Magnificent Miami Beach
text: Pool

headline: Earbud Upgrade
text: Better headphones equal better sound for portable music players.

headline: S.E.C. Sides Against Banks in Enron Suit, Report Says
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission has decided to support shareholders suing Wall Street banks for damages over Enron‘s collapse in a seminal case before the Supreme Court, according to The Washington Post.

headline: Tribute to a Senate Role Model
text: Warren M. Anderson, who served as Senate majority leader from 1973 to 1988, died last week at age 91.

headline: Jazz I.P.O. Closed Down in Debut
text: Jazz Pharmaceuticals, after pricing below its expected range, closed down in its first day on the Nasdaq. The initial public offering of the biotechnology firm, backed by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, hit a sour note as a negative press report and skeptical investors depressed demand for its $108 million initial public offering.

headline: NanoH2 Ceans Up With $5 Million in Fresh Funding
text: NanoH2O, a desalination company that grew out of research at UCLA, has raised $5 million. The company is trying to commercialize a membrane that consists of a matrix of porous polymer sheets embedded with specially designed nanoparticles that purify water. Investors include Khosla Ventures.

headline: Cadence Said to Be in Buyout Talks
text: Cadence Design Systems, one of the largest makers of the software used to design computer chips, is in talks with at least two buyout firms about a possible sale of the company, The New York Times reported.

headline: Merc Chief Tub-Thumps C.B.O.T. Bid
text: The war of words in the battle for control of the Chicago Board of Trade continued Friday, as the top executive of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange said that he remains convinced the C.B.O.T. will accept his exchange’s bid over a rival bid from the Intercontinental Exchange.

headline: British Property Firm Unloads U.S. Life Sciences Portfolio
text: A British property firm, Segro, has agreed to sell its life sciences real-estate business in the United States to Health Care Property Investors for $2.9 billion as it moves to focus on Britain and continental Europe. Segro, formerly Slough Estates, said on Monday it would return 250 million pounds ($495 million) of the proceeds from the sale of Slough Estates USA to shareholders via a special dividend.

headline: Xstrata Won’t Raise LionOre Bid
text: Xstrata  said Friday it would not match the 6.8 billion Canadian dollars ($6.4 billion), bid by the Russian mining titan Norilsk Nickel for LionOre Mining International. Xstrata, which negotiated a break-up fee of 305 million with LionOre, has extended its offer of 25 Canadian dollars a share to June 15.

headline: IAC to Open a Venture Capital Unit
text: IAC/InterActive, the New York-based media and e-commerce conglomerate run by the former Hollywood mogul Barry Diller, is starting a venture investing arm called Primal Ventures, The San Jose Mercury News reported.

headline: AXA Sells Insurance Assets to Dutch Financial Firm
text: A Dutch financial group, SNS Reaal, is to buy the Dutch insurance operations of France’s AXA for 1.75 billion euros ($2.35 billion) to double its domestic market share and cut costs.

headline: Blackstone Opens Wallet for Alliant
text: The Blackstone Group struck a deal to buy its first insurance broker, saying Sunday it would purchase the privately held Alliant Insurance Services. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but Reuters said the price tag comes to $1.2 billion.

headline: Bloomberg’s Slow-Moving Plan
text: The Real Estate Board of New York will start running television commercials today in support of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s long-range environmental plan, which includes a proposal to charge fees to drive below 86th Street during peak hours.

headline: Digital Photos on the Mantelpiece
text: There is an elegant way to free snapshots from computer hard drives: the digital picture frame.

headline: Anadarko Sells Assets to Atlas for $1.85 Billion
text: the oil and natural gas producer Anadarko Petroleum said late Sunday it is selling natural gas gathering systems and associated processing plants to Atlas Pipeline Partners for $1.85 billion.

headline: Spain’s Realia Aims for $1.34 Billion I.P.O.
text: Realia, jointly owned by the savings bank Caja Madrid and a construction group, FCC, hopes to confound skeptics of the Spanish property sector by raising more than 1 billion euros ($1.34 billion) in an initial public offering on Wednesday, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Kinds of Vulgarity
text: The Empire Zone continues its efforts to create a full historical record of the March 14 dust-up between Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, amid tense budget negotiations. As previously reported, words were exchanged and voices were raised in the governor’s office, according to several people present or close by. And after Mr. Bruno made a lewd reference to the close political relationship of the governor and the Senate minority leader, Malcolm A. Smith, Mr. Spitzer stormed out of his office, saying, “I’m not going to abide that kind of vulgarity.”

headline: Ferox Capital Names Former Morgan Stanley Banker as C.E.O.
text: Ferox Capital Management has hired a longtime Morgan Stanley banker, Jack Inglis, as chief executive officer. Mr. Inglis, who left Morgan Stanley in January after 15 years there, will take over the day-to-day operations at the $2 billion British hedge fund so that its founder, Jeremy Herrmann, can concentrate on his role as chief investment officer.

headline: Highbridge Taps Goldman Alumnus for Buyout Fund
text: In yet another example of hedge funds, investment banks and private equity shops blurring the lines of their respective businesses, Highbridge Capital Management, the hedge fund company with $34 billion of assets, has hired a former Goldman Sachs executive, Scott Kapnick, to start a private-equity business, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: TXU Bidders May Have to Sweeten Offer, Analysts Say
text: The buyout shops that want to buy the energy firm TXU may have to raise their offer to persuade shareholders to accept, analysts said. The $45 billion offer by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group to buy the Dallas power company just survived a contentious legislative session unharmed.

headline: Google Brings in Big Guns for DoubleClick Review
text: As it awaits the green light from federal antitrust regulators, Google disclosed last week in a government filing that it is putting new lobbying muscle, including a former high-ranking Justice Department antitrust lawyer, behind its proposed $3.1 billion acquisition of the online advertising firm DoubleClick.

headline: The Myth of (the Original) Cerberus
text: It has forged a historic deal to buy Chrysler for $7.4 billion, one of most audacious deals in private equity’s history. It has taken stakes in 50 companies around the world, often after bare-knuckled negotiations. It has even purchased Remington Arms and Bushmaster Firearms, two of the top makers of so-called black rifles, styled after the assault weapons used by the military.

headline: Tribune Reaches $350 Million Settlement with I.R.S.
text: Tribune announced Friday that it had reached a settlement with the Internal Revenue Service that would return to the company as much as $350 million of a disputed $1 billion tax payment it made in late 2005.

headline: Carlyle’s Deal for PQ Reaps Big Windfall for JPMorgan
text: PQ, a specialty chemical manufacturer, is being sold for the second time in less than three years, bringing its owner a huge profit. The Carlyle Group said Friday that it had agreed to pay $1.5 billion for the company, making it a home run for the private-equity arm of JPMorgan Chase, which bought PQ for $626 million in February 2005.

headline: Hey Buddy, Need Tickets?
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer signed a law late last week that legalized ticket scalping.

headline: Qiagen to Buy Digene, Maker of H.P.V. Diagnostic Tests
text: Qiagen, a Dutch maker of tools for gene research, has agreed to buy Digene for $1.6 billion in shares and cash to gain tests for a virus that causes cervical cancer and sexually transmitted diseases.

headline: Immigration Bill Takes Center Stage
text: The Senate returns today for what could be the decisive week for immigration legislation. Many lawmakers will no doubt prefer debating the bill rather than discussing it with voters back home.

headline: Amex Close to Private Banking Sale, Report Says
text: American Express is expected to sell its private banking business “within weeks,” Reuters reported, citing a source familiar with the matter. The buyer wasn’t identified, but the source told Reuters that the private banking unit would likely be acquired by a “global institution.”

headline: Avaya May Be Sold to Silver Lake and Texas Pacific
text: Avaya was near a deal last night to sell itself to Silver Lake Partners and the Texas Pacific Group for more than $8 billion in the latest buyout in the telecommunications industry, according to The New York Times.

headline: All Power Plants Not Equal?
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer and lawmakers have been negotiating for several weeks to revive a law that speeds approval of power plants by overriding local ordinances. This week, the issue will be the subject of one of three rare public conference committees held by the Democrat-led Assembly and the Republican-controlled Senate.

headline: Palm Is Said to Sell Stake to Equity Firm in Revamping
text: Palm, the struggling hand-held device company that makes the Treo, reached a deal on Sunday to sell a quarter of the company to Elevation Partners, a private equity firm, for about $325 million as part of a plan to reorganize the company, The New York Times reported.

headline: Amp’d Mobile Seeks Bankruptcy Protection
text: Amp’d Mobile, a niche cellphone startup that raised $360 million from backers including MTV Networks and Universal Music, has filed for bankruptcy protection to restructure its business.

headline: Has Hedge Fund Activism Run Its Course?
text: Among hedge funds, the activists have been in the klieg lights for a while now — and have reaped big returns for themselves and for shareholders. But a new academic study, which Financial News described as the most comprehensive yet produced, has found that those returns are falling as more funds chase fewer attractive targets.

headline: Monday Motorsports
text: In IndyCar, Tony Kanaan got some redemption. One week after a tough Indy 500, which he had been leading before rain temporarily halted the race on the 113th lap, Kanaan took advantage of a late crash by Helio Castroneves to jump in front with 25 laps to go at the Milwaukee Mile. From that point, Kanaan ran away from the pack, finishing 2.57 seconds ahead of Dario Franchitti, who leads the championship. But after the race, all eyes were on Danica Patrick, who had some heated words with Dan Wheldon. The two had bumped wheels on the 88th lap as she tried to pass Wheldon and Franchitti. “I was clearly inside of him,” she said. “I’m not sure what was lost in translation there, but I was clearly inside of him.”

headline: Dominion to Sell Oil and Gas Assets for $6.5 Billion
text: Dominion Resources said Monday it agreed to sell most of its onshore oil and gas exploration business to holding company Loew’s Corporation and XTO Energy for about $6.5 billion.

headline: Flextronics to Buy Rival in $3.6 Billion Deal
text: Flextronics International, a company that manufactures electronics for customers such as Cisco, Dell and Eastman Kodak, said Monday it will acquire rival Solectron in a deal it valued at $3.6 billion. The combination would create company with annual revenue of more than $30 billion, Singapore-based Flextronics said in a press release.

headline: Romney’s Presidential Run Puts Spotlight on Bain Capital
text: Nearly 24 years ago, Bill Bain the head of the consulting firm Bain & Company called one of his rising stars into his office. Mr. Bain asked Mitt Romney to start up a sister firm, focusing on private investments and venture capital — but was surprised to discover that Mr. Romney was reluctant to do so.

headline: What’s Next in Mr. Murdoch’s Playbook?
text: Dow Jones‘s controlling Bancroft family is expected to sit down today with Rupert Murdoch for a meeting that could determine the fate of his $5 billion bid for the company. The next hurdle in the negotiations will likely be what bankers call “social issues,” The New York Times’s DealBook wrote Sunday — specifically, how Mr. Murdoch plans to protect the editorial independence of The Wall Street Journal. On Monday, The Times’s Media Equation column looked at how Mr. Murdoch might play his role as ardent suitor to a skeptical audience.

headline: Democrats at the Sojourners Forum
text: The following is a transcript of the forum sponsored by Sojourners/Call to Renewal and broadcast on CNN on Monday night, as provided by Morningside Partners, via CNN.

headline: N.H.R.A.: Why Rent When You Can Own?
text: Drag racing fans were surprised to learn May 30 that the National Hot Rod Association had sold its professional racing series and other assets for $121 million.

headline: Paris Hilton Reports to the Big House
text: In the category of celebrity justice, some get away with rehab, others are forced into community service, and then there are the especially unlucky ones.

headline: McCain Takes On Immigration Critics
text: CORAL GABLES, Fla. – Senator John McCain is about to deliver his full-throated defense of the Senate’s proposal to overhaul the nation’s immigration laws – coupled with some sharp words for presidential rivals like Mitt Romney who oppose the measure – in a speech here to the Greater Miami Chamber of Commerce.

headline: Food Fight!
text: Back to the farm? Several writers — notably Barbara Kingsolver and Michael Pollan — have written best-sellers urging us eat local and organic, but Ronald Bailey at Reason has some qualms:Kingsolver adopts absolutely every one the modern urban fables with regard to food production, starting with the claim that organic is more nutritious. There is very little scientific evidence for that claim. In addition, organic is not necessarily better for nature since yields are generally lower than conventional farming, which means that more land must be used to produce food. Reading Kingsolver, one could also conclude that pesticides were created by giant chemical companies whose sole aim was to cause cancer. But even the American Cancer Society agrees that there is “no evidence that residues of pesticides and herbicides at the low doses found in foods increase the risk of cancer.” Studies also show that eliminating pesticides could cut corn yields by 30 percent, rice by 57 percent, soybeans by 37 percent, and wheat by 24 percent. Again, that would mean that a lot more of nature would have to be plowed up to maintain the food supply at current levels.

headline: Bid for Laureate Education Is Raised
text: Bidders for Laureate Education have increased their offer for the company, a for-profit operator of universities. Laureate’s board has accepted the new $62-per-share bid, up from a previous offer of $60.50, but it remains to be seen whether the company’s shareholders will get on board. After the bidding group, led by members of Laureate’s management and including private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and hedge fund SAC Capital Management, made its original, $3.1 billion offer in January, several large stakeholders of Laureate said they thought it was too low.

headline: CBS Makes Eyes at CNN, Again
text: Sumner Redstone and Leslie Moonves are nothing if not determined — or stubborn, depending on whom you ask. The latest proof: Though they have been rebuffed by Time Warner before, CBS’s chairman (that’s Mr. Redstone) and chief executive (Mr. Moonves) said at the company’s annual meeting that they’re still interested in acquiring the media conglomerate’s cable-news network, CNN.

headline: Clinton and Female Ambition
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was pumped up this morning over her performance in Sunday night’s debate, trading a perfectly executed high-five with the tennis legend Billie Jean King at a “Women for Hillary” campaign event and even taking on the “pundits” who suggest she is more than a little ambitious.

headline: British Buyout Chief Questions Industry Tax Break
text: Like their counterparts in the Unites States, European private equity firms are facing criticism for the relatively low taxes they pay on “carried interest,” which makes up the bulk of income for buyout fund managers.
