A leading figure in the industry, Nicholas Ferguson, has “broken the sector’s taboo on tax,” as the Financial Times puts it, making the observation that he and his cohorts “pay less tax than a cleaning lady.” (We’re not sure what his cleaning lady earns, but we assume he means a lower tax rate, not a lower dollar figure.)

headline: Decision by the U.S. Court of Appeals
text: Editors' Note: This text contains potentially offensive language.

headline: Putin: British Request Is Stupid
text: In the Russian response to Britain’s effort to get it to extradite a suspect in the murder of Alexander V. Litvinenko, first came a high-road legal argument, then a sensational counter-accusation by the accused man, and now President Vladimir V. Putin has stepped in with a salty dismissal. From The A.P.:

headline: Accredited to Sell Itself to Lone Star for $400 Million
text: Accredited Home Lenders, the subprime mortgage lender that said in March its survival might be in doubt, will be sold to private-equity firm Lone Star Funds for about $400 million in cash.

headline: Suitors Are Said to Be Circling Bally
text: Even as Bally Total Fitness prepares to slim down in bankruptcy, several potential suitors, including buyout firms, are expressing interest in the company, The New York Post reported Monday, citing unnamed sources. Among the names the newspaper drops are J.H. Whitney & Company and the Texas Pacific Group.

headline: Oh, I Believe in Yesterday
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Get Ready for iPhone Madness
text: OK, dudes, here it comes: the iPhone. June 29 is the official date, and here the official first three TV ads.

headline: Chiang Mai spa review
text: We drove back from the village to the hotel, back to that alternate universe called the Mandarin Oriental Dhara Dhevi, Chiang Mai, where we were happy to check out the spa. (No, really, I am not in the employ of the Mandarin!)

headline: For the Record
text: The Economic Scene column in Business Day on Thursday, about the limitations of the current copyright law and proposals to fix it, misstated the year that changes in the law went into effect. It was 1978, not 1964. (Under the revised law, books published before 1964 could have their copyright renewed in the 28th year after their initial registration.)

headline: A Deflating Cricket Murder Mystery
text: After following every juke and fumble in the Jamaican inquiry into the death of the Pakistan national cricket team’s coach in March, it looks like we’re right back where we started.

headline: Blackstone Reveals More Ahead of I.P.O. Road Show
text: As the Blackstone Group prepares to pitch the story of its initial public offering to investors, the firm’s prospectus is ballooning to “Ulysses”-esque proportions. The private equity firm filed an amended version of its I.P.O. documents Monday morning, and the filing has grown to a total of 673 pages, including exhibits and appendices, according to 10KWizard.com.

headline: A Bushie Praises the Press!!!
text: The Chicago Tribune noted a historic event: A member of the Bush administration praised the news media. The Tribune writes:

headline: Bruno’s Business Dealings
text: Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, was cheerfully dismissive today, as always, of recent news reports that the federal investigation into his business dealings has widened to include his purchase of two thoroughbreds from a real estate developer and Republican campaign donor.

headline: Loews to Acquire Gas Assets from Dominion for $4 Billion
text: The conglomerate Loews said on Monday it would buy gas exploration and production assets in three states from Dominion Resources for $4.025 billion in cash, betting on rising natural gas prices as it diversifies its revenue stream. The company said it will retain Dominion’s existing management, led by Timothy Parker, a senior vice president of exploration and production.

headline: UBS’s Hedge Fund: A Post-Mortem
text: The troubled mortgage market has been cited as the main culprit in the death of UBS‘s hedge-fund operation, Dillon Read Capital Management. But according to an article from Bloomberg News, a slew of sour bets on real estate was just the coup de grace.

headline: Is Dow Jones’s Union Pursuing an ESOP?
text: Even as the Bancroft family finally sat down with Rupert Murdoch on Monday, it appeared other players in the Dow Jones saga were trying to take matters into their own hands — possibly literally.

headline: The Night Shift in Newark
text: On patrol with the officers of Newark's Fifth Precinct during the violent Saturday night shift.

headline: The Night Shift in Newark
text: On patrol with the officers of Newark's Fifth Precinct during the violent Friday night shift.

headline: Who Gets a Wikipedia Entry?
text: [Update, May 5, 9:02 AM The Stokke entry has been restored. It focuses on her pole vaulting career, and also mentions the internet stardom in one sentence. The debate is not over, it seems. At the top of the entry, a note explains that “This article is being considered for deletion for the second time.” Thanks, Abeg92]

headline: Who Got Burned in the Amp’d Flameout
text: In March, when Amp’d Mobile announced what would soon prove to be its last round of venture capital — the last in its current incarnation anyway — DealBook noted that the company “apparently knows how to push the right buttons with venture investors.” Three months later, the exceptionally well-funded reseller of wireless phone service (it raised $350 million from investors including MTV Networks) has pushed the panic button, filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection Friday in a move that will almost certainly leave some venture backers a lot poorer.

headline: The Panama Syndrome
text: A poisonous solvent sold by counterfeiters and mixed into drugs has figured in mass poisonings around the world that killed thousands.

headline: Executive Pursuits
text: Harry Hurt III learns a few tricks of the sideshow trade.

headline: BlogTalk: A Loss on the Left
text: The lefty blogosphere is mourning the loss of one of its own, Steve Gilliard. The founder and full-time co-author of The News Blog died on Saturday at age 41 following a series of heart and kidney problems.

headline: Soul in the Hole
text: Kobe Bryant apparently can’t make up his mind, and neither can Billy Donovan, the Florida University coach who reportedly is trying to back out of a contract he signed with the Orlando Magic over the weekend.

headline: 2008: Democrats and Faith
text: How do the three leading Democratic presidential candidates talk about their faith? How do their religious backgrounds infuse and influence their policy decisions? What role should God play in public life? In their private lives?

headline: Escaping Reality
text: Given all the aggravation we have had trying to get our dream home built, what better stress reducer than to escape reality by watching a movie?

headline: Taxes and Stock Options
text: A Senate hearing on Tuesday will examine the fact that many companies get a much bigger tax deduction for their employee stock options than they report on their income statements to shareholders. Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, thinks this is costing the Treasury a lot of money.

headline: Jefferson Indictment on Corruption Charges
text: Representative William Jefferson, Democrat of Louisiana, has been indicted on 16 counts involving corruption, including conspiracy to solicit bribes by a public official, scheme to defraud citizens of honest services by wire faud, money laundering, obstruction and a pattern of racketeering activity. A copy of the indictment can be read here.

headline: Results of the “Photoshop Pogue” Contest
text: Oh, dear God.

headline: Thompson Will Shadow G.O.P. Debate as Fox’s Guest
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Former Senator Fred Thompson, who has all but declared his candidacy for president, may not be on the stage at Tuesday night’s Republican debate in New Hampshire, but he will have another platform all to himself – on the Fox News Channel.

headline: My Legislative Wish List. And Yours?
text: Ahead of Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s public meeting on Wednesday with legislative leaders, the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, asked the governor in an open letter to take up discussion of three priorities for Senate Republicans.

headline: Law & Order: Special White House Unit
text: The likely entrance of Fred D. Thompson — a.k.a. District Attorney Arthur Branch of Manhattan — into the 2008 presidential race raises the question: who else from the abundant franchise of “Law & Order” shows might be a good fit in helping run a superpower?

headline: Were the Democrats Blitzed?
text: The Chris Dodd campaign’s “Talk Clock” makes a persuasive case that moderator Wolf Blitzer, by speaking more than any of the candidates except Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama, dominated Sunday’s Democratic presidential debate. But pretty much everyone else thinks Hillary Clinton was the winner.

headline: A Breakdown on Clinton Ratings
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s ratings in the latest New York Times/CBS News poll suggest that unlike her Democratic rivals, her favorability ratings worsen as voters’ income and education levels increase. The poll also found that Mrs. Clinton was far better known than her opponents, but more than half of those who had an opinion of her had a negative one.

headline: If Bush and Cheney Can Curse …
text: The Second Circuit Court of Appeals issued a fascinating decision today in a case pitting the television networks against the government over indecency rules involving expletives.

headline: What a Way to Come Home
text: My name is Mike Jernigan. I am a United States Marine Corps corporal who was medically retired in December of 2005. I served in Iraq for six months out of a seven month deployment. I was blinded by a roadside bomb on August 22, 2004 during a patrol near the town of Mahmudiya. Coming home was wild ride. I was medevac’d to the 31st Combat Support Hospital in Baghdad.

headline: Next Up: The G.O.P. 10
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Tuesday night, it will be the Republicans’ turn to debate in New Hampshire, and two issues are likely to figure prominently: immigration and terrorism threats, particularly the reported plot to blow up fuel lines at Kennedy International Airport.

headline: Q & A: Really?
text: For more than two years, Anahad O’Connor has written the Really? column for Science Times, tackling strange subjects and misleading myths about our health and the world we live in. He’s discovered over the years that some commonplace cures and explanations carry weight (tea may help lower your stress levels), while others are just plain bogus (pricking a stroke victim’s fingers is no way to help him). Plus, he’s looked into some lighthearted myths, such as whether chocolate really is an aphrodisiac.

headline: To Spray or Not to Spray
text: Would more pesticide spraying be good for us, not to mention some of our favorite animals and trees?

headline: Leaving the Chaos Behind
text: They began college with dreams of parties and friends. But four years later, Iraq's college graduates are eager to flee their country.

headline: April Factory Orders and Capital Goods Send Mixed Signals
text: Orders placed with American factories rose less than forecast in April, while gains in capital-goods spending might presage stronger business investment in coming months.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption in the Square Feet section of Business Day on Wednesday with an article on renovations at the Woolworth Building in Lower Manhattan misidentified one of the two people shown. The man at the left is Roy A. Suskin, vice president of development at the Witkoff Group, which is renovating the building — not Richard Woodward, an associate at the architecture firm Gerner Kronick & Valcarcel.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on May 22 about a delay in adding specially equipped computerized train cars to the crowded L subway line misstated the overall growth in subway ridership from 1995 to 2006. It rose 37 percent, not 46 percent. The article also referred incorrectly to the ridership at the Bedford Avenue station in Brooklyn during the same period. Although ridership at Bedford increased significantly, it did not rise 139 percent. (It is not possible to compare total ridership at individual stations from 1995 to 2006 because in 1998 New York City Transit changed the way it counts students who ride the subway at no cost. Excluding students, ridership at Bedford Avenue increased 131 percent from 1995 to 2006.)

headline: A Million Little Pieces
text: Over a year ago, Joe Biden, Les Gelb and others proposed a federal solution for Iraq. The basic argument was that Iraq is a ruptured society and there is no way to reconstitute it from the center.

headline: Nassau Rejects Poet Nominee Over Words About War in Iraq
text: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., June 4 — The news release announcing the designation of Maxwell Corydon Wheat Jr. as Nassau County’s first poet laureate had already been drafted. But it was not to be.

headline: A Blueprint for a Comeback, but Not the Tools
text: Until the Red Sox won the World Series in 2004, they had long tortured their frenzied fans by practicing what I called the Ultimate Tease. They would lure their fans into thinking they were going to win the World Series so they could obliterate “1918” from their vocabulary, then fall short at the last moment, sometimes in the regular season, like in 1978, sometimes in the postseason, like in 2003 and 1986.

headline: For Wood Ants, Bits of Resin Each Day Keep the Doctor Away
text: When packing blankets or sweaters away in the attic, the wise homemaker will scatter mothballs in with them. Chemicals from the mothballs permeate the storage container and kill off any bugs.

headline: Europe Moves to Make Big Polluters Pay for Emissions
text: BRUSSELS, June 4 — Europe is moving toward making significant changes to its emissions-trading system that could force large polluters to pay for most, if not all, permits to produce climate-changing gases, European officials said Monday.

headline: New Haven Approves Program to Issue Illegal Immigrants IDs
text: NEW HAVEN, June 4  The Board of Aldermen on Monday night made municipal identification cards available to illegal immigrants, in what city officials said was the first such program in the nation. The measure was approved by a vote of 25 to 1.

headline: China Stocks Extend Loss, Falling 8.3%
text: SHANGHAI, June 4 — China’s stock markets tumbled again on Monday, worsening one of the biggest sell-offs in years after the government’s move last week to impose a higher tax on stock trades.

headline: 9 Arrested in Plan to Oust Laos Government
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 4  Federal agents raided more than a dozen homes and businesses in California and arrested nine men on Monday, breaking up what they said was a plot to overthrow the government of Laos.

headline: Basque Group Ends Ceasefire
text: MADRID, June 5 — ETA, the armed Basque separatist group, called off its 15-month ceasefire today and vowed to resume its violent struggle for an independent Basque nation.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,474 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Ex-Cisco Executive to Lead Joost, Internet TV Provider
text: Michelangelo Volpi spent 5 of his 13 years at Cisco Systems selling networking equipment to the companies like Comcast and Time Warner Cable that bring television into living rooms.

headline: Conrad Black Defense Balks on Trump
text: CHICAGO, June 4 — In Canada, at least, the criminal fraud case of Conrad M. Black was billed as “the trial of the century” as it began more than two months ago.

headline: Blair Calls on Moderates to Reclaim the Public Debate Over Islam
text: LONDON, June 4  As part of his series of farewells, Prime Minister Tony Blair addressed a government-organized conference on Islam on Monday, and declared that the religion’s “authentic voices” should be given a stage over the voices of extremism.

headline: Election Day
text: There is a primary election today in New Jersey for the State Senate and the General Assembly. Polls are open from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. Voter assistance is available toll free at 1-877-NJVOTER (1-877-658-6837). There is a special election on the East Side of Manhattan in the 65th Assembly District. Polls are open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. Voters can call the New York City Board of Elections toll free at 1-866-VOTENYC (1-866-868-3692).

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Time Begins for Paris Hilton

headline: The Parthenon Looks Solid From My Cellphone
text: WHY wait until you get back from vacation to share the photos from your trip? With a decent cellphone camera and the power of the Web, you can upload photos while still on the road to let friends and family live vicariously through you.

headline: Court Rebuffs F.C.C. on Fines for Indecency
text: WASHINGTON, June 4 — If President Bush and Vice President Cheney can blurt out vulgar language, then the government cannot punish broadcast television stations for broadcasting the same words in similarly fleeting contexts.

headline: Star Power Backfires, Costing Agency a Client
text: LONDON — Dead celebrities are hot. From Einstein to Elvis and Gene Kelly to Orville Redenbacher, they keep popping up as posthumous pitchmen for everything from cars to cola.

headline: Affordable Housing (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lawmaker Indictment Could Hurt State
text: NEW ORLEANS, June 4 — Even after the F.B.I. raided Representative William J. Jefferson’s office and recovered $90,000 in marked bills from a freezer in his home, the congressman’s voters stayed loyal. His largely black constituency elected him for a ninth term in November, and many voters said he had been unfairly singled out.

headline: What’s on Tuesday Night
text: 9 P.M. (ABC) THE 2007 ALMA AWARDS Eva Longoria, left, is host of this ceremony honoring Latino achievement in the United States in film, television and music. Nominees include Gael García Bernal, Jesse Garcia, Cameron Diaz, Eva Mendes, Alfonso Cuarón, “Babel,” “Ugly Betty” and “Quinceañera.” Jessica Alba, Andy Garcia, George Lopez, Mario Lopez and Ms. Mendes are scheduled to appear; Mr. Lopez will be honored for special achievement in television; Los Lobos will receive the Pioneer in Music award. And Prince will perform.

headline: Breaking the Barriers of Music in a New York Marathon
text: Woodstock, Lollapalooza, Bonnaroo  for decades, rock performers and fans have gathered in sweeping celebrations of music and tribal bonding. Excluding the Bayreuth Festival, the closest analog in the classical music world is probably the 12-hour marathon concerts staged regularly since 1987 by the collective Bang on a Can, founded that year by the composers Michael Gordon, David Lang and Julia Wolfe.

headline: Italian Bid for Top Title Blends Passion With Optimism
text: VALENCIA, Spain, June 4 — The race was on. The spinnakers were up in the distance, and it was quiet enough to hear a Cup drop on Luna Rossa Challenge’s guest boat.

headline: Working the Reward System, Mile by Circuitous Mile
text: I’m an independent film producer based in both New York City and Hollywood. I’ve only been at this for a few years. And I have to say that at the beginning, it was tough. In my business, you have to be able to meet with agents, writers and directors at a moment’s notice. If you don’t, you stand the chance of losing out on the rights to a great story.

headline: Nutrition: Vitamin D and Calcium Intake Found to Affect Breast Cancer
text: Consuming high levels of vitamin D and calcium may offer some protection against the most aggressive kinds of breast cancer, a new study reports, but only in premenopausal women.

headline: Family Dissidents Could Block Dow Jones Sale
text: The Bancrofts, who control Dow Jones & Company, are talking to Rupert Murdoch, and Wall Street clearly expects that most of the family’s members will agree to sell their company to the company Mr. Murdoch controls.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column yesterday about the tribute “Celebrating Bobby Short,” at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency through June 16, misidentified a performer who will take part on June 12. It will be Wynton Marsalis — not Liza Minnelli, who had been scheduled to perform earlier but will not be taking part.

headline: Old Friends Become Rivals in Hudson County Primary
text: JERSEY CITY, June 4 — To some veteran political hands in Hudson County, Tuesday’s Democratic primary evokes the alternate universe of the Superman comic planet Bizarro World.

headline: Edwards, Clinton and Obama Describe Journeys of Faith
text: WASHINGTON, June 4 — One presidential hopeful described how prayer helped him survive his son’s death and his wife’s cancer diagnosis. Another spoke about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the role of faith in forgiving those who treat others unjustly. A third said of her husband’s infidelity, “I’m not sure I would have gotten through it without my faith.”

headline: Dangerous Nuts?
text: Q. Is eating nuts and seeds really dangerous for those with diverticulosis but no symptoms?

headline: Letters to Judge Defend and Denounce Libby
text: WASHINGTON, June 5 — Scooter Libby is a patriot and a wonderful family man. He is a criminal who should go to prison. He is a man who may have done something wrong, but he is a good man at heart.

headline: A Makeover at Ask.com: A New Look and More
text: Jim Lanzone, the chief executive of Ask.com, the fourth-most-used Internet search engine in the United States, believes that it is time to move beyond the 10 blue links  the standard way to display Web search results.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day yesterday about Harvard’s plans to license more than 50 patents to Nano-Terra, a nanotechnology start-up, misstated the surname of the vice chairman of the company. He is Carmichael Roberts, not Rogers.

headline: Gadgets for All of You
text: ALISON SHEPARD, a marketing associate for a record label in Manhattan, straps an ultrathin iPod Nano onto her arm before she goes for a run. When she returns to her apartment, she takes off the Nano and turns on the bulkier iPod that has replaced her home music system.

headline: Federal Appeals Court Rejects Michigan’s Ban on a Controversial Method of Abortion
text: CHICAGO, June 4  The State of Michigan’s third attempt in a decade to ban a procedure known among anti-abortion activists as partial-birth abortion was declared unconstitutional by a federal appeals court on Monday, less than two months after the Supreme Court narrowly upheld a federal law banning the method.

headline: A Painful Lymph Illness Often Follows Cancer
text: Pat Malone had her lymph nodes removed as part of her breast cancer treatment, and for almost a decade she managed to keep her lymphedema, a chronic condition that causes swelling from an accumulation of fluid, under control. Then she decided to paint her kitchen.

headline: The Universe, Expanding Beyond All Understanding
text: When Albert Einstein was starting out on his cosmological quest 100 years ago, the universe was apparently a pretty simple and static place. Common wisdom had it that all creation consisted of an island of stars and nebulae known as the Milky Way surrounded by infinite darkness.

headline: Congressman Sought Bribes, Indictment Says
text: WASHINGTON, June 4 — Representative William J. Jefferson, the Louisiana Democrat at the center of an investigation that included an F.B.I. raid at his Congressional office and accusations that he hid $90,000 in bribe money in his home freezer, was indicted Monday by a federal grand jury on 16 corruption-related felony counts.

headline: Gates Says Arms Go to Taliban, but Iran’s Role Is Not Certain
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 4 — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Monday that Iranian weapons were being smuggled into Afghanistan and into the hands of Taliban fighters, but that it was unclear whether Iran’s government was behind the arms shipments.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 4, 2007

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Friday about the travels of a patient with a dangerous form of tuberculosis misidentified the flight that the patient, Andrew Speaker, took from Atlanta to Paris on May 12. It was Air France Flight 385, not 285. (As the article noted, the flight was also designated Delta 8517.) Because of an editing error, the article misidentified the point where Mr. Speaker crossed the border from Canada when he re-entered the country on May 24. It was Champlain, N.Y., not Plattsburgh, which is just south of Champlain.

headline: Today’s Managing Partner in Team Clinton & Clinton
text: Given all the sobering things that have happened since the turn of the millennium — from the terrorist attacks of 9/11 to the war in Iraq to the Bush administration’s efforts to expand executive power and curtail civil liberties — the sex and real estate follies of the Clinton White House now feel as if they belong to an era long ago and far, far away. Indeed, Carl Bernstein’s new biography of Hillary Rodham Clinton often feels like a very long, very slow acid flashback to the 1990s, rehashing and reexamining, in minute detail, matters like Monica, Whitewater, bimbo eruptions and the state of the Clintons’ marriage.

headline: A Summer Sequel That No One Wants to See
text: IF you have sat for hours recently at an airport or, worse, in a plane stranded for hours on a ramp, this is not exactly going to be a breaking news flash for you.

headline: New Name and Mission for Museum of Television
text: First it was named the Museum of Broadcasting, and then, as cable and direct satellite grew, it became the Museum of Television and Radio. Now, in the Internet and cellphone era, that name seems out of date as well, so the museum is renaming itself again, this time as the Paley Center for Media, after the late CBS founder William S. Paley.

headline: Two Women Fall Short in Qualifier for  Men’s Bowling Tour
text: Kelly Kulick, who became the first woman to qualify for the Professional Bowlers Association Tour last year, could not repeat the accomplishment this year.

headline: Coming of Age and Showing a Much Sweeter Side
text: From a distance, Animal Collective always looks like a band that’s going to make a lot of noise. The jungle-y name, with its co-operative implications; the group’s love of echo and yelping, unusual percussion and guitar strumming; the fact that any of its four members might or might not be playing on their albums or tours: you could add this up and reasonably assume that Animal Collective is one of those bands that it’s more fun to be in than to see.

headline: Chinese Stocks Rebound After Drop
text: HONG KONG, June 5 — Share prices in China plunged another 7 percent this morning, only to turn around in the afternoon to finish with gains after the government authorized four large funds to raise money for the purchase of stocks.

headline: Memo Pad
text: AIRLINE REPORT CARD: OUCH! The airline industry may be back in the black, but passengers are still seeing red, according to a Consumer Reports survey that will be published in its July issue. Over all, the industry’s average score for satisfaction is lower than the scores for hotels and rental car companies and “better only than such perennials of frustration as wireless carriers, cable TV operators and computer tech support,” the magazine reports. Here is how the top 18 major domestic airlines stacked up in customer satisfaction. JetBlue was rated best. Consumer Reports said the carrier’s numerous flight delays in mid-February “seem to have had little effect” on the survey. In descending order, the others are Midwest, Southwest, Frontier, Hawaiian, Aloha, Alaska, Spirit, Continental, AirTran, Delta, American, ATA, Northwest, American Eagle, United, and America West and US Air, which merged in 2005 and recently combined all operations. In the Consumer Reports survey on hotels, Ritz-Carlton, a Marriott luxury brand, was chosen as top in overall satisfaction, while Homewood Suites from Hilton and SpringHill Suites from Marriott were cited as “excellent values.” Ritz-Carlton was also ranked at the top of the Market Metrix hospitality index survey taken in the first quarter of 2007.

headline: Police and Black Kids (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Photo Sharing Even the Folks Can Handle
text: RECEPTIVENESS to new technologies often seems related to age. For example, more 13-year-olds than 63-year-olds understand phrases like “Waz ^?” and “N2MH.” (In case you’re over 13, those expressions are cellphonese for, “What’s up?” and “Not too much here.”)

headline: Fateful Voice of a Generation Still Drowns Out Real Science
text: For Rachel Carson admirers, it has not been a silent spring. They’ve been celebrating the centennial of her birthday with paeans to her saintliness. A new generation is reading her book in school — and mostly learning the wrong lesson from it.

headline: McQuarters Has Clean Cut From a Trend-Setting Past
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 4 — Those who do not know R. W. McQuarters’s name or face may recall his hair.

headline: Padilla Jury Begins to Hear Wiretapped Conversations
text: MIAMI, June 4  Prosecutors on Monday began playing the wiretapped telephone conversations at the heart of the terrorism case against Jose Padilla, including several in which a co-defendant discussed sending satellite phones, military tents and other equipment to “brothers” in Chechnya in the mid-1990s.

headline: Bush Says Russians Have Derailed Democratic Reform
text: PRAGUE, June 5 — President Bush delivered a double-barreled message to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia today, two days before the leaders are to meet in Germany, by assuring Mr. Putin that he has nothing to fear from a missile defense system but also chiding him for derailing democratic reforms.

headline: Prevention: Soy Nuts Seem to Help Women’s Blood Pressure
text: Substituting a half-cup of soy nuts — baked soybeans — for other types of protein in a healthy diet may help lower a postmenopausal woman’s blood pressure, a small study has found.

headline: A Point System for Immigrants Incites Passions
text: WASHINGTON, June 4 — Ekaterina D. Atanasova, a civil engineer from Bulgaria who lives in southern Maine, wants to bring her husband to the United States. Under the Senate immigration bill, he would get high marks — at least 74 points — because he too is a civil engineer, has a master’s degree and is fluent in English.

headline: Asset Manager to Oppose Biomet Takeover Offer
text: At least one significant investor in Biomet, an artificial joint maker, plans to vote against a proposed $10.9 billion deal for the company, in the latest instance of shareholder dissatisfaction over buyouts.

headline: Under a Divided City, Evidence of a Once United One
text: JERUSALEM, June 4 — Dig nearly anywhere in this city, and you hit the remains of an earlier civilization. One of the latest such finds is a narrow strip of antiquity that runs down the middle of a main road through what is now Shuafat, a Palestinian neighborhood in north Jerusalem.

headline: Libby Receives 30 Months in Prison in C.I.A. Leak Case
text: WASHINGTON, June 5 — I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to the vice president and one of the principal architects of President Bush’s foreign policy, was sentenced today to 30 months in prison for lying during a C.I.A. leak investigation that became part of a fierce debate over the war in Iraq.

headline: And Jerry Mathers as ... Tracy Turnblad’s Father?
text: It shouldn’t have seemed weird, but it did: Jerry Mathers, also known as TV’s Beaver, having just polished off a 16-ounce steak at the Palm, picked up his cellphone and called his girlfriend, asking her to come over for dessert.

headline: Forgetting May Be Part of the Process of Remembering
text: Whether drawing a mental blank on a new A.T.M. password, a favorite recipe or an old boyfriend, people have ample opportunity every day to curse their own forgetfulness. But forgetting is also a blessing, and researchers reported on Sunday that the ability to block certain memories reduces the demands on the brain when it is trying to recall something important.

headline: Hong Kong’s Tiananmen Vigil Draws Crowd After Official’s Denial
text: HONG KONG, June 4  A candlelight vigil here on Monday evening to observe the 18th anniversary of the military crackdown on the Tiananmen Square demonstrations in Beijing drew an unusually large crowd, apparently in response to the recent assertion by the leader of Hong Kong’s pro-China party that no massacre took place.

headline: Musharraf Issues Decree Cracking Down on News Media
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 4 — In an apparent move to curb news media coverage of the continuing political crisis over his suspension of the country’s chief justice, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the president of Pakistan, issued a decree on Monday that gives the government more powers to shut down independent television channels.

headline: Dr. Kevorkian’s Wrong Way
text: Dr. Jack Kevorkian  a k a “Doctor Death” for helping chronically ill and terminally ill patients commit suicide  has emerged from prison as deluded and unrepentant as ever. Brushing aside criticism by other supporters of medically assisted suicide that his tactics were reckless and harmful to their cause, Dr. Kevorkian asserted: “I did it right. I didn’t care what they did or didn’t do. When I’m going to do it, I’m going to do it right.”

headline: Palm Sells 25% Stake to Equity Firm in Revamping
text: Palm Inc., the struggling hand-held device company that makes the Treo, has reached a deal to sell a quarter of the company to Elevation Partners, a private equity firm, for about $325 million as part of a plan to reorganize the company.

headline: A Top Clinton Aide Draws Criticism From Unions
text: The presidents of two large labor unions have written to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton to complain that Mark Penn, her pollster and chief strategist, is chief executive of a public relations firm that is helping a company fight a unionization drive.

headline: For Once, News Is Good for Ailing Pitchers
text: CHICAGO, June 4 — The way this season has gone, the Yankees have learned not to expect too much from their fragile pitchers. But they seem optimistic that Andy Pettitte and Roger Clemens will start the first two games of this weekend’s home series against the Pittsburgh Pirates.

headline: Art as a Bitter Pill, Coated With Sweetener
text: IN a sweet, thin voice that broke into a giggle, Andrea Dezsö showed her delicately made book of paintings, which took her a year to complete.

headline: New DVDs: Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis
text: DEAN MARTIN

headline: 2 Sides Meet Face to Face on Dow Jones
text: In their first face-to-face meeting, the family that controls Dow Jones & Company yesterday told Rupert Murdoch, a suitor some family members mistrust deeply, that it would sell him the company only if its jewel, The Wall Street Journal, could be shielded from editorial interference from him.

headline: Protests Mark Six-Day War’s Anniversary
text: HEBRON, West Bank, June 5 — Conflicting ideologies and internal divisions came to the forefront today as Israelis and Palestinians marked the 40th anniversary of the start of the Six-Day War in June 1967.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A headline on Friday about a growing movement in Britain to boycott Israel economically and culturally referred incorrectly in some copies to a decision reached by the union of public service employees, the largest British labor union. The union said a resolution that would call for a boycott of Israel would be considered at its upcoming annual meeting. The union did not call for such a boycott.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, the Religion Journal column on Saturday, about Web sites that attract Mormons who have left the faith or are questioning it, misattributed an observation about the role of the family in Mormon life. It was Philip L. Barlow, who will lead a Mormon studies program at Utah State University — not Jeff Ricks, executive manager of the Post-Mormon Community — who made the points that the family role “is in-built into the theology” and that because the family is conceived of as eternal, a wayward Mormon is “threatening to that family unit for all eternity.”

headline: 4th Suspect Surrenders in Airport Plot
text: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, June 5 — The fourth suspect in a terrorist plot to ignite jet fuel tanks at Kennedy International Airport in Queens surrendered this morning, police officials in Trinidad said today.

headline: Aggressive, Infuriating and Successful
text: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., June 1 — Practice was just under way for the Detroit Shock, defending champion of the Women’s National Basketball Association, and Coach Bill Laimbeer was not entirely happy with the conditioning drills. Few people will talk back to a man who is 6 feet 11 inches and always considers himself the smartest person in the room. This does not include Laimbeer’s assistant, Rick Mahorn, who is only an inch shorter and is often the funniest person in the room.

headline: Safe Harbor for Exploited Children
text: The New York State Legislature is rightly pleased with itself for passing a new law that offers tougher penalties for sex traffickers, as well as help for their victims who are often smuggled in from abroad and forced to work as sex slaves. As important as it is, the trafficking law fails to deal with the serious and growing problem of American children, some as young as 13 years old, who are dragooned into prostitution by brutal pimps.

headline: New Findings Add Nuance to Discussion of Early Sex
text: Girls who have sex at an early age are at slightly greater risk than their peers for feeling depressed, a new study has found. But their self-esteem suffers only if the sex occurs outside a romantic relationship.

headline: The TB Patient and the What-Ifs (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Manhattan: New York Remains Safest Big City
text: Crime fell 5.3 percent in New York City last year, and New York is still the safest big city in the United States, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday in releasing statistics from the F.B.I.’s preliminary crime report for 2006. Violent crime in New York dropped 4.6 percent, and the city reported the fewest crimes per 100,000 residents among the nation’s largest cities, the mayor said. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said crime had fallen an additional 8.5 percent in the first several months of this year. Nationwide, crime increased 1.3 percent last year, according to the F.B.I. report.

headline: The Claim: Caffeine Can Increase the Risk of Miscarriage
text: THE FACTS

headline: When Are Photos Like Penny Stocks? When They Sell.
text: Earn big money taking photographs in your spare time!

headline: Palm Investor Sees Hand-Held Free-for-All
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 4 — The private equity investment in Palm Inc. is an ambitious gamble that the history of two companies dominating the personal computer industry will not repeat itself in the market for cellphones and other hand-held devices.

headline: Old N.B.A. Try Is Becoming Cautionary Tale
text: Maybe Rick Pitino shared with Billy Donovan what he best remembers about his last N.B.A. coaching experience, when the grass in Boston looked so much greener than Kentucky’s but life with the Celtics left him feeling a discredited shade of blue.

headline: The Doctor’s Computer Will See You Now (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Donovan’s N.B.A. Stay Is Expected to Be Brief
text: Just days after Billy Donovan agreed to a five-year, $27.5 million deal to coach the Orlando Magic, it appears he is heading back to the University of Florida.

headline: When Fakery Turns Fatal
text: WUDI, China — They might be called China’s renegade businessmen, small entrepreneurs who are experts at counterfeiting and willing to go to extraordinary lengths to make a profit. But just how far out of the Chinese mainstream are they?

headline: Sinister Cellphone Brings Marital Pot to Bloody Boil
text: Gasp!

headline: Japan: Popular Support for Abe Falls Again
text: Support for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe dropped to its lowest since he took office in September, hovering at 30 percent in a poll by the national daily Asahi Shimbun. Other polls indicated a similar slide in Mr. Abe’s approval ratings, which have suffered from the recent suicide of his scandal-tainted agricultural minister and from the government’s mishandling of pension records. The fall increased the possibility that his governing Liberal Democratic Party might lose seats in July’s upper house election; an outright defeat could spur calls for him to step down as party leader and prime minister.

headline: China: 180,000 Displaced After Strong Quake
text: Rescue efforts continued in southwestern Yunnan Province as roughly 180,000 people were evacuated from their homes after a Sunday morning earthquake that registered a magnitude 6.4 killed at least three people and injured more than 300, according to state news media. More than 1,000 aftershocks have rattled the nerves of residents in the city of Pu’er, in a mountainous region of Yunnan. Roughly 2,000 soldiers and rescue workers are at the scene, and evacuees are living in tents or public buildings.

headline: Putin Supports Longer Term for Successor to Presidency
text: MOSCOW, June 4  President Vladimir V. Putin said that Russia could benefit from longer presidential terms, though he again ruled out the possibility that he would remain in office after the expiration of his second term next year, according to remarks published Monday.

headline: Military Judges Dismiss Charges for 2 Detainees
text: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba, June 4 — The government’s new system for trying Guantánamo detainees was thrown into turmoil Monday, when military judges in separate decisions dismissed war crimes charges against two of the detainees.

headline: Opinions, Far Apart, Underscore Immigration Bill’s Obstacles
text: WASHINGTON, June 4 — Representative José E. Serrano, Democrat of the Bronx, objects to a recent bipartisan proposal on immigration policy because, he says, it would create an underclass of immigrant workers with few rights.

headline: First Chickens in Americas Were Brought From Polynesia
text: Why did the chicken cross the Pacific Ocean? To get to the other side, in South America. How? By Polynesian canoes, which apparently arrived at least 100 years before Europeans settled the continent.

headline: The Disorder Is Sensory; the Diagnosis, Elusive
text: DENVER — Almost every parent of young children has heard an anguished cry or two (or 200) something like:

headline: In Camden, Campbell Co. Says It May Go if Sears Building Stays
text: CAMDEN, N.J. — For decades after it was built in 1927, shoppers drove to the Sears, Roebuck & Company store on Admiral Wilson Boulevard just beyond the center of town. A colonnaded temple to both commerce and the automobile, the store, in the classical revival style, had a lot with parking spaces for about 600 cars.

headline: Avaya Deal Reached
text: Two equity firms, Silver Lake Partners and the Texas Pacific Group, agreed last night to acquire Avaya, the computer-networking company, for $8.2 billion.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Saturday about differing accounts of the travels of an Atlanta lawyer with a dangerous form of tuberculosis misattributed comments about the Italian Health Ministry’s contacts with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. It was Cesare Fassari, a spokesman for the ministry, who told a reporter that Dr. Maria Grazia Pompa, the head of its tuberculosis surveillance program, “contacted the C.D.C. and said, ‘Weren’t you supposed to contact us?’ ” Mr. Fassari also said, “At that time, the disease centers confirmed that there was a case but did not provide details.” The comments were not made to the reporter by Dr. Pompa.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article and picture caption on Friday about President Bush’s new proposal for setting a goal to reduce greenhouse gas emissions misstated the location of his speech announcing the plan. Mr. Bush spoke in an auditorium in the Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center in Washington, which also houses the offices of the United States Agency for International Development. He did not speak at the agency. (Go to Article)

headline: Nassau Tax Relief System Faces Pressure
text: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., June 1 — Every year, droves of Nassau County homeowners seek tax relief by challenging their property assessments, generating a deluge of cases seen nowhere else in the state.

headline: The Bears’ Tank Johnson Is Suspended by the N.F.L.
text: Tank Johnson of the Chicago Bears has been suspended without pay for the first eight games of the 2007 regular season for violating the National Football League’s personal-conduct policy. Commissioner Roger Goodell said yesterday that the suspension could be reduced to six games if Johnson avoided legal trouble and attended counseling.

headline: A Confident Sarkozy Talks Foreign Policy
text: PARIS, June 4  In his first formal encounter with foreign journalists since assuming office last month, President Nicolas Sarkozy worked hard to be informal.

headline: Sharing a Hobby, Online and in Person
text: THE compliment came unexpectedly, an appreciation of Wendy Roth’s digital photos of the 100-foot-tall, cooled-lava Keremeos columns in British Columbia.

headline: A Pupil of Shostakovich, Who Influenced His Mentor
text: The gifted composer Mieczyslaw Weinberg (1919-1996) said he considered himself Shostakovich’s “pupil, his flesh and blood.” Given how frequently those two friends met to compare notes and the difficult circumstances in which they composed, it’s not surprising that Mr. Weinberg’s musical language sounds like a dialect of Shostakovich’s.

headline: Competing as Software Goes to Web
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 4 — Can two bitter rivals save the desktop operating system?

headline: In Tennessee, Goats Eat the ‘Vine That Ate the South’
text: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — Summer is settling onto Missionary Ridge overlooking this southeast Tennessee city. Swallows glide on the warm breeze rustling the hackberry trees, kudzu vines sprout along the hillside and the goats are back at work.

headline: Rhode Island Bishop Condemns Giuliani’s Position on Abortion
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani has come under fire from the Roman Catholic bishop of Providence, R.I., who has criticized Mr. Giuliani’s support of abortion rights, calling the position pathetic, confusing and hypocritical.

headline: In Search of New York at a Hip-Hop Summit
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 3 — Every summer the radio station Hot 97 organizes Summer Jam, New York’s foremost hip-hop concert. (Though it’s held across the river.) Titans clash, stars show up unannounced, fans render their ruthless judgment. It seems that every year Summer Jam proves a point.

headline: 4 Die in Fighting at Camp in Southern Lebanon
text: TRIPOLI, Lebanon, June 4 — Two soldiers and two militants were killed in fighting in the southern Lebanese refugee camp of Ain al Hilwe early Monday. The deaths sealed a night of violence in northern and southern Lebanon that caused fears that the 16-day siege of a refugee camp on the outskirts of this northern Lebanese town may have spread.

headline: Clete Boyer, 70, a Yankee Known for His Slick Fielding, Dies
text: Clete Boyer, the sharp-fielding third baseman who played on Yankees teams that won five consecutive pennants in the 1960s, died yesterday in Atlanta. He was 70.

headline: Queens: President Appointed for L.I.R.R.
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday appointed a former Nassau County official as the new president of the Long Island Rail Road. The appointee, Helena E. Williams, a lawyer, served as a deputy county executive in Nassau County from late 2002 until February. She had previously worked at the authority and had run its Long Island Bus division from 1993 to 1998. Ms. Williams, who is to begin work on June 18, will be the first woman to run the Long Island Rail Road, the country’s busiest commuter railroad, with 82 million riders each year. The previous president, James J. Dermody, retired in September. Raymond P. Kenny has been serving as acting president. Ms. Williams, a resident of Nassau County since 1985, lives in Garden City. As head of the railroad, she will receive a yearly compensation package worth $272,000.

headline: When a Picture Is So Good It Deserves a Frame
text: THE time is right for buying digital picture frames. More than 30 million digital cameras were sold in the United States last year alone, yet millions of snapshots taken with them are never printed. Instead, they remain stuck on computer hard drives, brought up only by an occasional slide show or screensaver.

headline: Heart Health: Women Who Drink a Little May Lower Heart-Attack Risk
text: Women who drink moderate amounts of alcohol may reduce their risk for nonfatal heart attack, provided that they do not become drunk, according to a recent study.

headline: Warner Group in Deal to Offer Free Music via Internet Site
text: Major labels have fought several legal battles to try to keep fans from listening to music without paying for it. Now one label, the Warner Music Group, has made a deal with an Internet start-up, Lala.com, that will allow anyone to listen to its music free, with the idea that doing so will drive music sales.

headline: Tribunal System, Newly Righted, Stumbles Again
text: The Bush administration’s attempt to create an alternative justice system for terrorism suspects, in the works for more than five years, has yet to complete a single trial.

headline: TV Reporter to Run for a Senate Seat
text: ATLANTA, June 4  A former television investigative reporter announced Monday that he would seek the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate, in a campaign that will most likely pit him against a frequent subject of his news reports.

headline: Phone Cameras May Have Extras, but Don’t Toss Your Point-and-Shoot
text: AT one time, a cellphone with a built-in camera seemed as unlikely a pairing as a double major in organic chemistry and costume design, but many people now regard camera phones as de rigueur for spontaneous photo-ops. Yet continuous improvements in the camera portions of these devices raise a question for gift-givers: do people even need a regular camera anymore?

headline: Schumer Calls for Energy Efficiency
text: Looking to create national energy-saving standards and to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, Senator Charles E. Schumer said yesterday that he was introducing a measure that would require cities and states to increase energy efficiency in new buildings by 30 percent in the next five years and by 50 percent before 2022. Under the measure, to be introduced next week as an amendment to the Senate energy bill, cities and states would face penalties unless they adopted a standard nationwide code or their own codes requiring energy-efficient systems and designs. Cities that met the standards would be exempt from the penalties even if their states failed to do so, Mr. Schumer said. The amendment, he said, is meant to bring the country in line with the standards in California and New York City, which recently overhauled its building code to require so-called green-building practices.

headline: Music and Dance in Review
text: DATAROCK

headline: Craig Thomas, Senator From Wyoming, Dies at 74
text: Senator Craig Thomas of Wyoming, who combined a deep love of Western rural life with a 23-year public career in Cheyenne and Washington, died Monday evening in Bethesda, Md. He was 74.

headline: Sudden Growth
text: Seven years ago, I planted a pair of white spruces  Picea glauca. They came by mail in slender tubes from a nursery in Oregon, mere wisps of vegetation. I wasn’t sure where I wanted to put them, so I stuck them in an improvised nursery bed, beside the sweet corn and the pole beans. A year later I moved them just inside the fence along the gravel road that runs past our place. It has been to their liking. Those trees are now well over 10 feet tall  lone emissaries from the great forest of white spruces that reaches across Canada.

headline: A Lesson in Efficiency (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bill France Jr., 74, Dies; Gave Nascar Its National Reach
text: Bill France Jr., who took over Nascar from his father when it was a regional stock-car racing attraction and transformed it into a multibillion-dollar enterprise with a national presence, died Monday at his home in Daytona Beach, Fla. He was 74.

headline: Feeling Pinch, Racetrack Casinos Again Seek Lower Tax Rate
text: Lucy DePadova, a retired jewelry saleswoman from New Jersey, paused a moment to assess the casino floor at Yonkers Raceway, where rows of 5,500 high-tech slot machines, or video lottery terminals, ran the length of three air-conditioned football fields.

headline: It Isn’t That Images Fade, It’s That They Can Vanish
text: GATINEAU, Quebec

headline: Albany: Monitoring for Acid Rain
text: Officials with the Adirondack Council, an environmental group, are lobbying to reverse planned reductions in the federal budget that would severely limit or eliminate several acid rain monitoring programs. The proposed budget would cut $1 million, about 25 percent, from one program that measures atmospheric gases. Two other programs that sample lakes and streams in the Adirondacks and other areas of the Northeast on an annual combined budget of less than $1 million would also be eliminated. Acid rain remains a serious problem in many parts of the country, but nowhere has it been more damaging than in the Adirondacks, where vast forests have been decimated and more than 500 lakes and ponds have been left unable to support many species of native fish. “Closing down, even for a few months, will wipe out 21 years of continuously collected scientific data,” Brian L. Houseal, the council’s executive director, said in a statement.

headline: China Issues Plan on Global Warming
text: BEIJING, June 4 — With global warming high on the agenda for the world’s industrial powers gathering later this week in Germany, China staked out its position on Monday by releasing its first national strategy on climate change, a plan that promises to improve energy efficiency but rejects any mandatory caps on greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Inquiry Into Role of Tuberculosis Patient’s Father-in-Law
text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is investigating what role, if any, a staff scientist played in the international health scare set off by the odyssey of his son-in-law, who has extremely drug-resistant tuberculosis.

headline: Indian Officials to Rule How ‘Backward’ Group Is
text: NEW DELHI, June 4 — They burned buses during the morning rush hour. They threw stones at trains packed with passengers and at the police. By Monday evening, after a week of violent protests that began in tourist-friendly Rajasthan State and ended up here unsettling the nation’s capital, the Gujjars got their way.

headline: And Now for the Weather (and Climate) Report …
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: In Iraq, Does the Korea Analogy Fit? (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Puerto Rico’s AIDS Care in Disarray Over Funds
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — His emaciated body advertises the damage wreaked by the AIDS virus. But over the last year, Rolando Warren González, 41, a former steel band member, has faced an extra challenge to his survival.

headline: Nadal Wins and Will Meet Mentor in Quarterfinals
text: PARIS, June 4 — Dressed in his signature pirate outfit, bright blue bandanna clinging to his sweaty brow, Rafael Nadal won his fourth-round match Monday at the French Open, defeating Lleyton Hewitt, 6-3, 6-1, 7-6 (5).

headline: Giuliani Makes 9/11 His Brand
text: The Republican candidates for president will go at it again tonight, debating in New Hampshire. Terrorism and national security are bound to figure as topics, and we all know what that means: Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will have another chance to assert proprietary rights to Sept. 11 and how we should understand that day.

headline: Dozens Killed in Violence Around Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, June 5 — Up to 18 people were killed south of Falluja today when a suicide bomber driving a truck packed with high explosives plowed into a busy commercial district. The attack also wounded at least 15 people, according to a local Iraqi police official.

headline: Contract for Advanced Smallpox Vaccine
text: The federal government announced the award of a $500 million contract to a European pharmaceutical company to deliver 20 million doses of an advanced smallpox vaccine. The government already has a stockpile of vaccine that could be used to immunize every American in the event of a smallpox attack by terrorists. But because the existing vaccine sometimes causes serious side effects, the Department of Health and Human Services is asking the company, Bavarian Nordic A/S, of Denmark, to make enough of its vaccine to immunize about 10 million Americans like patients on chemotherapy or people with H.I.V./AIDS. The company said the contract could be worth $1.6 billion.

headline: Senator Craig Thomas of Wyoming Dies at 74
text: WASHINGTON, June 4 — Senator Craig Thomas, a three-term Republican from Wyoming, died Monday evening, just hours after his staff reported that the treatment he was receiving for leukemia was no longer working. He was 74.

headline: Accents on the Wrong Syl-LA-ble
text: It was not what Sergei Petukhov said. It was how he said it.

headline: Venture Fund to Seek Out Cost Cutters in Health Care
text: Venture investment in the health business typically chases miracle cures and high-technology gadgets, like bioengineered drugs and new medical devices. They promise much but cost a lot.

headline: Inquiry Into Jackson Hewitt’s Tax Return Practices Widens
text: Federal authorities have expanded an investigation into allegations that Jackson Hewitt offices helped prepare fraudulent income-tax returns that allowed customers to obtain refunds illegally.

headline: Albany: New Internet Consumer Protection Law
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer signed legislation yesterday that will broaden consumer protections for New Yorkers who shop online. The law will bring the protections for online shoppers in line with those for consumers who buy goods over the phone or by mail. Among other provisions, it will prohibit online retailers from accepting an order they cannot ship within 30 days and require advertising and promotional materials to include the retailer’s legal name, address and the conditions under which refunds will be issued. Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, who said that his office’s Internet Bureau received 1,000 consumer complaints last year and that the bill, passed by the Legislature in May, would “put businesses on notice that the Internet is no longer the Wild West of commerce.”

headline: Making Tunes a Fixture on the Patio
text: HOME entertainment systems have been making music outdoors since wind-up phonographs first wound up on the veranda. You can get the same effect today by taking out a portable stereo, but more homeowners are permanently installing speakers outdoors.

headline: A Team of 2, Following the Scent of Polar Bears
text: The hunt begins with a loud shout in Spanish by Linda J. Gormezano.

headline: That Warm Sound of Old in a Cold, Compressed World
text: ABOUT 20 years ago, Roger Adler, a guitarist and keyboard player in the Chicago area, gladly gave up his antiquated record player, his collection of 2,000 albums and the ritualistic care that the vinyl records required. For years, he enjoyed the convenience of CDs and then MP3s.

headline: The Questions Are Big, but the Devil’s in the Details
text: CHARLESTON, S.C., June 3 — There are operas of action and operas of stasis. But while Pascal Dusapin’s “Faustus, the Last Night” certainly qualifies as static, it might more accurately be called an opera of suspension. It seems to float, a quality borne out in the staging here at the Sottile Theater as part of the Spoleto Festival U.S.A.

headline: Iraq Insurgent Group Claims It Killed Missing U.S. Soldiers
text: BAGHDAD, June 4  A Sunni insurgent group released a videotape on Monday that showed the military identification cards of two missing American soldiers who were captured last month south of Baghdad, and a narrator said they had been killed.

headline: HBO Names 4 New Top Corporate Officers
text: HBO announced a new lineup of four top corporate officers today to replace Chris Albrecht, the chief executive who resigned last month. The group will be headed by Bill Nelson as the new chairman and chief executive.

headline: Cars and Bikes Can Mix, When the Rules of the Road Are Clear
text: A journalist who regularly bicycled to work in Washington was killed when he rode headlong into the door of a truck as the driver opened it.

headline: Bargain-Basement Acquisitions Help Mets Reach the Top
text: At 12:01 a.m. on Dec. 21, 2005, the office of Commissioner Bud Selig sent an e-mail message to every team in baseball listing 50 players who had become free agents because their teams had not offered them contracts for the next season.

headline: Samuel A. Garrison, 65, Lawyer Who Fought Nixon Impeachment, Dies
text: Samuel A. Garrison III, who as chief Republican counsel to the House Judiciary Committee in its Watergate investigation in 1974 argued against the impeachment of President Richard M. Nixon, died on May 27 near his home in Roanoke, Va. He was 65.

headline: Outcomes: Lycopene Does Not Fight Off Prostate Cancer, Study Shows
text: Some recent studies have suggested that lycopene, a chemical in tomatoes and other red fruits, is protective against prostate cancer, but a large prospective study has found that it has no effect.

headline: Ruling Helps Prosecutors in Death Penalty Cases
text: WASHINGTON, June 4 — The Supreme Court on Monday strengthened the hand of prosecutors in death penalty cases by making it easier to remove potential jurors who express ambivalence about the death penalty or confusion about how it should be applied.

headline: Wading Through Formats: JPEG, TIFF and Friends
text: A DIGITAL camera can save photos in a file format called JPEG, and sometimes in other formats like TIFF or RAW. A computer’s photo software offers even more choices. While the options can seem bewildering, it pays to know something about them. Format choice can make a big difference, depending on what you want to do with your pictures.

headline: Liberian Ex-Leader Boycotts War Crimes Trial as It Opens
text: THE HAGUE, June 4 — On the first day of his trial, former President Charles G. Taylor of Liberia, one of Africa’s most tyrannical warlords, refused to appear in court on Monday and sent word that he was firing his lawyer, apparently wanting to deflect attention from proceedings that aim to cover a decade of warfare and extraordinary cruelties.

headline: NATO Sinks Second Boat Full of Taliban Fighters
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 5 — The Afghan defense ministry said that NATO helicopters attacked and sank a second boat full of Taliban fighters trying to escape across the Helmand River in southern Afghanistan. All of the 20 to 30 Taliban fighters on board were drowned, according to the spokesman, Gen. Zaher Azimi.

headline: Shining a Halogen Light on a Senator’s Dark Corners
text: Two new biographies of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, the New York Democrat who is a leading contender for her party’s presidential nomination, will put readers in mind of Edward Gibbon’s observation that history is essentially the recounting of “the crimes, follies and misfortunes of mankind.” Mrs. Clinton’s Senate spokesman, Philippe Reines, has complained that these biographies “are nothing more than cash for rehash,” containing nothing new and largely focusing on the details of the suspected corruption that never produced indictments, despite the considerable efforts of a special prosecutor.

headline: Stormy Weather, Brought to You By ...
text: For years, Ace promoted itself as “the place with the helpful hardware man.” Now, Ace wants to be the helpful place when it comes to coping with hurricanes.

headline: An Unacceptable Nominee
text: President Bush’s latest appeals court nominee, Leslie Southwick, has a disturbing history of insensitivity to blacks and other minority groups. The Senate should reject this nomination and make clear to the White House that it will reject all future nominees who do not meet the high standards of fairness that are essential for such important posts.

headline: Letters
text: Care For the Earliest Newborns

headline: A Perennial Search for Perfect Wheat
text: PULLMAN, Wash. — It is a gleaming prize for wheat farmers, and environmentally correct, to boot: a perennial food plant that requires plowing only once every three to five years and prevents dust storms, stems soil erosion and even absorbs carbon to help mitigate climate change.

headline: Dominating Dover, Truex Earns First Cup Victory
text: DOVER, Del., June 4 — Martin Truex Jr., the often overlooked teammate of Dale Earnhardt Jr., won his first Nascar Nextel Cup race Monday before half-filled grandstands, just hours after the former Nascar president Bill France Jr. died.

headline: Republicans Face Off in New Hampshire
text: MANCHESTER, N.H., June 5 — The Republican presidential candidates waged verbal combat tonight in the Congressional battle over a proposed immigration overhaul, with Senator John McCain, an author of a pending compromise plan, defending the controversial proposals in a Republican debate and demanding that his competitors offer “a better idea.”

headline: France: Rare White Lion Cubs Die at Zoo
text: Four white lion cubs, three females and a male, whose birth last month at the zoo in Jurques, in western France, added to the roughly 30 white lions in captivity worldwide, have died, zoo officials said. The cubs were vulnerable to infection because they had been bottle fed after being rejected by their mother.

headline: Untangling the Choices and Finding Headphones
text: THE headphone cords that tether ears to portable music players can carry subtle messages. They may declare, “I’m hip,” or, “I’m above your world — I’m not part of it.”

headline: Renovation Slowly Adds Some Light to Lollipops
text: The controversial white block of a building is still shrouded in dark netting. The hard-hatted men perched on the surrounding scaffolding won’t wrap up their work until the middle of next year. But behind the scrim, the “lollipop” building at 2 Columbus Circle is steadily changing into a new home for the Museum of Arts and Design.

headline: The Passion of Al Gore
text: Al Gore is earnestly talking about the long-term implications of the energy and climate crises, and how the Arctic ice cap is receding much faster than computer models had predicted, and how difficult and delicate a task it will be to try and set things straight in Iraq.

headline: An Evening Full of Trios, Combining Bach and Ballet
text: In life there can never be too much Bach. If only the same could be said for New York City Ballet’s latest compilation program, “Three by Bach,” an evening of dances by George Balanchine, Christopher d’Amboise and Jerome Robbins, whose portion was a revival of his sparkling 1997 “Brandenburg.” For a program to fulfill an artistic craving, variety is crucial.

headline: Terror Arrests Puzzle Many in Guyanese Enclave in Queens
text: Over the course of 30 years, the sober-sided houses of Richmond Hill, Queens, have been transformed into an echo of the Caribbean, with candy-colored paint jobs, fanciful ironwork and beds of vivid flowers. Immigrants in this neighborhood care passionately about their houses, as well as their cricket teams and Bollywood musicals. Terrorism does not seem to fit here.

headline: A New Way to Clean Up
text: When people talk about their career transitions, they often become natural storytellers, skipping over the dull bits and zooming in on the moments of high drama and epiphany. Stan Halpern’s career shift always takes him back to the heart attack he suffered in 1997.

headline: What if Israel Had Turned Back?
text: Jerusalem

headline: Yankees’ Revival Takes a Wrong Turn
text: CHICAGO, June 4 — Roger Clemens was supposed to rumble into the Yankees’ clubhouse Monday and make everything better. He would have received his pregame rubdown — analgesic ointment smothered over his legs, back and shoulders, a pitcher’s war paint — and strode to the mound, an old sheriff back in town.

headline: Third G.O.P. Debate
text: The following is a transcript of the 2008 Republican presidential candidates debate hosted by CNN, WMUR-TV and The New Hampshire Union Leader. The participants were Senator Sam Brownback, the former Virginia Gov. James Gilmore, the former New York City mayor Rudy Giuliani, Rep. Duncan Hunter, the former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee, Sen. John McCain, Rep. Ron Paul, the former Massachusetts Gov. Mitt Romney, Rep. Tom Tancredo, and the former Wisconsin Gov. Tommy Thompson and the moderator was Wolf Blitzer.

headline: Wyoming Senator in Serious Condition
text: Senator Craig Thomas, Republican of Wyoming, is in serious condition at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., as he battles leukemia and an infection, according to a statement from his office. Mr. Thomas learned that he had leukemia in 2006, before he was elected to his third Senate term.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A front-page article and picture caption on Friday about President Bush’s new proposal for setting a goal to reduce greenhouse gas emissions misstated the location of his speech announcing the plan. Mr. Bush spoke in an auditorium in the Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center in Washington, which also houses the offices of the United States Agency for International Development. He did not speak at the agency.

headline: Cheated of Future, Iraqi Graduates Want to Flee
text: BAGHDAD, June 4 — They started college just before or after the American invasion with dreams of new friends and parties, brilliant teachers and advanced degrees that would lead to stellar jobs, marriage and children. Success seemed well within their grasp.

headline: Both Parties Expect Corzine’s Choice for Chief Justice to Be a Fair and Moderate Voice
text: TRENTON, June 4 — When Gov. Jon S. Corzine officially nominated Attorney General Stuart Rabner on Monday as the next chief justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court, he said he expected Mr. Rabner, 46, to “shape our history long, long after this administration’s service under the golden dome has long since passed.”

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on Saturday about Wallace Seawell, a Hollywood photographer, misspelled the given name of one of the celebrities he photographed. She was Ava Gardner, not Eva.

headline: Bush to Seek a Bit of Unity With Putin
text: PRAGUE, June 4 — At a moment of rising tensions between Washington and Moscow, President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia appear likely to use a meeting in Germany this week to focus on the one area where they appear to share a common interest: slowing Iran’s ability to produce nuclear fuel.

headline: No Clemens, No Chance Against White Sox
text: Not much to say about this one here in rainy Chicago tonight. The Yankees scored three in the ninth but it wasn’t enough in a 6-4 loss. Matt DeSalvo pitched an inning and a third, gave up three runs, and that was about it. Jim Thome and Paul Konerko homered to put the game out of reach.

headline: Flying with ‘Air France’
text: Years ago, two old stock-car racers were in Nascar’s Daytona Beach, Fla., headquarters, reminiscing about how fast they used to drive from various racetracks to Daytona. It was “the record,” as they called it. Who had it?

headline: F.C.C. Rebuffed by Court on Indecency Fines
text: A federal appeals panel struck down the government policy that allows stations and networks to be fined if they broadcast shows containing obscene language.

headline: Comparing the Photo-Sharing Sites
Still keen on Spain?
text: The good news about the Spanish property market slowdown is that there are good deals to be had for those still interested in buying a home there. One city that continues to lure buyers is Alicante, one of the most well-known towns on the Costa Blanca. In Alicante — popular for its university, beautiful beaches, and quality properties — the average home price is now $341,000.

headline: Views of the Museum
text:
Additional images of the Steven Holl expansion of the
Nelson-Atkins Museum in Kansas City, Mo.

headline: Theater Briefs
text: Recent rains have washed out the first preview of the Public Theater's presentation of Shakespeare's "Romeo and Juliet" at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.

headline: An Election Day, for Some
text: There is a special election today on the East Side of Manhattan in the 65th Assembly District. Polls are open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. For details, voters can call the New York City Board of Elections toll free at 1 (866) VOTENYC (868-3692).

headline: Former Enron Official Sentenced to 2 Years
text: The former chief operating officer of Enron‘s broadband Internet division, Kevin P. Hannon, was sentenced to two years in federal prison and fined $125,000 for his role in the fraud that led to the company’s collapse, a court official said on Monday. Mr. Hannon was sentenced by Judge Vanessa Gilmore of United States District Court in Houston.

headline: Eschewing Trump, Black’s Defense Tries to Contain the Circus
text: In Canada, at least, the criminal fraud case of Conrad M. Black was billed as “the trial of the century” as it began more than two months ago. Accusations that Mr. Black and three colleagues had looted more than $60 million from the international newspaper conglomerate that he built promised to put not just Mr. Black’s oversize ego and life on display, but also a frothy brew of high finance, high society and high intrigue.

headline: Inside Murdoch’s Meeting With the Bancrofts
text: In their first face-to-face meeting, the family that controls Dow Jones & Company told Rupert Murdoch on Monday that it would sell him the company only if its jewel, The Wall Street Journal, could be shielded from editorial interference from him, according to a report in The New York Times.

headline: I.C.E., Waiting on CBOT, Buys Commodity Trader
text: The IntercontinentalExchange, the Atlanta commmodities exchange that is currently pressing an unsolicited $11 billion buyout bid for Chicago Board of Trade parent CBOT Holdings, disclosed Monday that it had agreed to acquire the commodity trading business of ChemConnect of Houston.

headline: American Express Is Said to Be Near a Sale of Private Bank
text: American Express is expected to sell its private banking business within a matter of weeks, according to Reuters, in a sale that could fetch between $1 billion to $2 billion for the credit card and travel services company.

headline: Uranium One Stakes Claim for Energy Metals
text: Fast-growing Uranium One extended its aggressive acquisition spree offering 1.8 billion Canadian dollars ($1.7 billion) in stock for Vancouver’s Energy Metals. The takeover would give Toronto-based Uranium One a slate of American assets including near-term production from projects in Texas, Wyoming, New Mexico and Utah.

headline: Chicago Bank Tries to Break Up Bear’s Bid for Doral
text: FBOP, a privately held Chicago bank holding company, is trying to muscle in on Bear Stearns‘s deal for a controlling stake in cash-strapped Doral Financial of Puerto Rico.

headline: Doctor in your town?
text: I spent much of last week covering the story of the American lawyer with tuberculosis who flew around Europe potentially exposing others, afraid (he said) of being put in quarantine here in Rome. I was thinking that one of the problems was this: When you’re in a strange city, where you may not know the language, it is often hard to get medical advice or care you can trust. To that end, I’ve asked all our Globespotters reporters to recommend a good English speaking medical practice where they live. We’ll put it up in the “travel basics” box for each city. But if you have recommendations, please write in…

headline: Joost Names Former Cisco Executive as C.E.O.
text: The high-profile Internet start-up Joost announced Tuesday that it had hired Michelangelo Volpi, a veteran executive of Cisco Systems, as its new chief executive. Joost, which is based in London, is building a global television network of full-length TV shows and movies and sending it to viewers over the Internet.

headline: Indian Bank Seeks $2.5 Billion in Overseas Share Sale, Report Says
text: The ICICI Bank may raise $2.5 billion in the biggest overseas share sale by an Indian company, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Asset Manager to Oppose Biomet Takeover Offer
text: At least one significant investor in Biomet, an artificial joint maker, plans to vote against a proposed $10.9 billion deal for the company, in the latest instance of shareholder dissatisfaction over buyouts.

headline: Royal Bank of Scotland Says Earnings Will Beat Estimates
text: the Royal Bank of Scotland Group, the British bank leading a takeover bid for ABN Amro, said first-half earnings will rise more than 8.1 percent, beating analysts’ estimates, as bad consumer loans declined in Britain.

headline: Prosecutors May Add Charges in ‘Squawk Box’ Retrial
text: Three ex-brokers at Citigroup, Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers  face a November retrial on charges they conspired to commit fraud by letting day traders eavesdrop on the firm’s internal “squawk boxes.”

headline: Software Deals Set Torrid Pace in 2007
text: Big-ticket acquisitions by Cisco Systems, Oracle and a variety of buyout firms helped drive software mergers and acquisitions to record levels so far this year. An analyst firm, The 451 Group, takes a look at the nearly $28 billion in software deal activity in the first five months of 2007.

headline: Venture Fund to Seek Out Cost Cutters in Health Care
text: Venture investment in the health business typically chases miracle cures and high-technology gadgets, like bioengineered drugs and new medical devices. They promise much but cost a lot.

headline: Top Tokyo Banker at Merill to Start His Own Investment Firm
text: Jesper Koll, one of the best known foreign commentators on Japan’s economy, resigned from Merrill Lynch in Tokyo to form an investment company. The move is the latest in a string of departures of investment banking executives looking to start their own firms.

headline: China’s Citic Eyes $2.4 Billion Offering
