text: Chinese stocks may be slumping now, but Citic Securities, China’s most profitable securities house, believes there will still be an appetite for its shares. The company indicated Tuesday that it plans to sell up to 350 million new A shares on the Shanghai market, which could raise some $2.4 billion to back its expansion plan to become a first-class investment bank.

headline: With $2 Billion War Chest, Pershing Is Said to Target an Icon
text: Pershing Square Capital Management, a New York hedge fund with a gift for shaking up corporate boardrooms, has raised $2 billion that will be dedicated to an activist assault on just one specific, iconic American company, The New York Post reported.

headline: Activist Hedge Funds Targets J-Power in Japan Test
text: The Children’s Investment Fund, the activist hedge fund whose demands put Dutch bank ABN Amro in play, is scouring Japan for deals but sees its struggle to raise the dividend at Japanese electric power wholesaler J-Power as a test case for further investment in the country.

headline: Commerzbank Jumps on Rumors of a Citigroup Deal
text: Shares in Germany’s Commerzbank, which has been persistently cited as a possible takeover target, jumped more than 3 percent on Tuesday to near a seven-year peak on market talk that Citigroup was likely to bid about 45 euros ($61) per share for the bank, traders said.

headline: IceBreaker Warms Up With $7.2 Million Round
text: The start-up behind the mobile matchmaking service “Crush or Flush” is feeling the love from venture investors, who agreed to put $7.2 million into the company. IceBreaker, which markets a cellphone-based dating service, said Tuesday that Frazier Technology Ventures and Lightspeed Venture Partners led its latest financing round. “Crush or Flush,” which works a bit like the once-popular “Hot or Not” Web site, is not yet generating revenue, according to the Seattle Post-Intelligencer’s Venture Blog. An IceBreaker marketing executive told the blog that his business was considering adding advertising or selling subscriptions.

headline: A Look Back
text: The six-day Arab-Israeli conflict in 1967 ended in a military victory for Israel, a sober defeat for the Arab armies, and began Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

headline: GE to Buy Canadian Assets from Dundee REIT
text: General Electric‘s real estate unit agreed to buy office and industrial buildings in Canada from Dundee Real Estate Investment Trust for about 2.4 billion Canadian dollars ($2.3 billion) and will purchase an 18 percent stake in the company. The purchase, which gives G.E. a toehold in faster-growing markets to tap global demand, includes 180 properties located primarily in Ontario, Quebec and Newfoundland.

headline: Analysts Divided on Possible Cadence Deal
text: A New York Times report that Cadence Design Systems, a software maker, was in talks with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Blackstone Group about a possible buyout had analysts divided on whether such a deal would materialize.

headline: New Palm Investor Sees Hand-Held Free-for-All
text: The private equity investment in Palm, announced Monday, is just the latest indication of the intense new competition that will increasingly blur the lines between telecommunications, computing and entertainment during the next several years. The stakes are so high that none of the major players in any of those three industries can afford to be left out.

headline: As Private Equity Hunts, Its Prey May Be Adapting
text: As private equity firms continue to gobble up assets at unprecedented rate for unprecedented sums, their deal-frenzy is causing a chain reaction among firms who are eager to escape the clutches of these cash-rich hunters.

headline: Venture Backers Tune Into Video-Sharing Site Blip.tv
text: Blip.tv, a two-year-old video-sharing Web site, said Tuesday it raised its first round of venture capital funding. The round was led by Ambient Sound Investments, a fund created by founding engineers from Internet-telephone company Skype, Blip.tv said. The amount of the funding wasn’t disclosed. Jeffrey Sechrest, co-head of media and entertainment at investment bank Lazard, also participated in the round, Blip.tv said.

headline: Warner Group in Deal to Offer Free Music via Internet Site
text: Major labels have fought several legal battles to try to keep fans from listening to music without paying for it. Now one label, the Warner Music Group, has made a deal with an Internet start-up, Lala.com, that will allow anyone to listen to its music free, with the idea that doing so will drive music sales.

headline: Buyout Firms Reach Deal to Buy Avaya
text: Silver Lake Partners and the Texas Pacific Group agreed Monday night to acquire Avaya, the computer-networking company, for $8.2 billion. The deal, priced at $17.50 a share, puts the two private equity firms in control of the world’s biggest maker of corporate phone equipment, letting them go head to head with Cisco Systems in the $5 billion market for Web-based gear. Monday’s agreement calls for Avaya to seek out other potential buyers over the next 50 days.

headline: When in Bangkok, go Italian
text: Anyone who lives in Bangkok is constantly asked for restaurant recommendations by friends flying in for a few good meals. Often my answer is, “How about Italian food?” There are superb Italian restaurants in Bangkok. Within a 15-minute walk of my apartment in the Langsuan area I can count more than a half-dozen. Thais have long had an affinity for Italian food and at some point over the past decade the number of high-end Italian restaurants reached a critical mass. It became profitable to fly in a whole range of meats and ingredients as varied as fresh mozzarella di bufala and Sorrento lemons (one chef insists that only lemons from southern Italy will do the trick for his Tagliatelle al Limone). This week a group of Italian chefs has banded together to put on what they are calling, “The Splendor of Italian Cuisine.” I certainly agree with the concept. The festival, which is being held at 11 top Italian restaurants in the capital through June 10, has the faint whiff of a marketing gimmick. But I’m a sucker for gimmicks that involve risotto and prosciutto crudo. Biscotti, the Italian restaurant at the Four Seasons (Tel: +66 2 255 5443), offers a 6-course menu for 1,500 baht ($44). Other restaurants involved in the festival include La Scala at the Sukhothai hotel (Tel: +66 2 344 8888) Spasso at the Grande Hyatt Erawan (Tel: +66 2 254 12340) and Gianni’s on Soi Tonson, near Central Chidlom department store (Tel: +66 2 252 1619).

headline: Kiss, Kiss: The CFDA Awards
text: Oscar de la Renta looked mildly stunned last night when Steven Kolb, the executive director of the CFDA, hurried toward the podium to inform the mistress of ceremonies Ellen Barkin that there were TWO winners of the Women’s Designer of the Year award. Everyone seemed surprised, not least Lazaro Hernandez and Jack McCollough of Proenza Schouler, the other winner, who got up from their table (with Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen) and joined de la Renta. He made a special point of acknowledging his wife, Annette de la Renta, who was sitting next to Patrick McCarthy of WWD, and noting, not insignificantly, that he had been making clothes for more than 40 years.

headline: Creation Differences
text: Robert T. Miller, an assistant professor at the Villanova University School of Law, says that part of Sam Brownback’s New York Times op-ed on evolution is “obviously wrong.” But Miller does not object to Brownback’s evaluation of the science. Instead, he opposes the Kansas senator’s “general observations on the relationship between faith and reason,” which Miller believes are “worrying.” Miller writes at On the Square, the First Things blog:

headline: Smashing a Hot Dog Record
text: One quick way to demonstrate Takeru Kobayashi’s stature in the world of competitive eating is to refer to a fan-turned-peer named Crazy Legs Conti. “To compare Kobayashi to Michael Jordan or Tiger Woods is to slight Kobayashi,” he claimed.

headline: Families and Newspapers: A Volatile Mix
text: A prominent family late Monday cut its longstanding ties with the newspaper business. No, not the Bancrofts — the Chandlers.

headline: Diving in Punta del Este, Uruguay
text: Do you know if there are any diving centers and diving places in Punta del Este? I hope you can give me a good answer soon. Please give me a link to a diving center site if you know one.

headline: In Which I Become Indiana Jones
text: The Harvard Crimson has a fun profile of me, based on digging up old college roommates and bosses. I love Jeff Toobin’s reference to me as “the Indiana Jones of our generation of journalists.” That’s better than many of the things I get called….

headline: Debunking the Higher Bit Rate Myth
text: So last week, Apple began its experiment of selling non-protected, higher-quality songs on the iTunes Store for a 30-cent premium.

headline: Focus on Immigration
text: With the Republican debate tonight in New Hampshire, the differences among the candidates on the compromise immigration legislation now under consideration in the Senate are likely to be enunciated. While some of the Democratic candidates talked about the bill at their debate on Sunday night, the disagreements among them were minor in comparison to the spectrum of views among the G.O.P. field.

headline: Parsing Clinton’s Views on Gay Marriage
text: Is Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton preparing to endorse gay marriage?

headline: Libby’s Sentence: 30 Months and a $250,000 Fine
text: I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney known since childhood as Scooter, was sentenced this morning to 30 months in prison for lying to investigators checking into the unmasking of a C.I.A. operative whose husband helped fuel a fierce public debate over the administration’s case for going to war in Iraq.

headline: Op-Ed: Five Questions About ‘Murdow’
text: By Anant K. Sundaram

headline: Burkle to Team with Dow Jones’ Union
text: Is Dow Jones becoming a case of deja vu all over again?

headline: Ready for Pricier Emissions?
text: For years European industry has fought off the idea that companies should buy permits to pollute under the EU’s program for complying with the Kyoto Protocol. Industry seemed to have a strong argument: The European economy was lagging the United States while China and India were shooting ahead. More regulation, said worried industrialists, was the last thing the region’s power, pulp, cement and steel factories needed if they were to keep factories open and workers employed.

headline: AIDS  Outpaces Treatment
text: For each sub-Saharan African who was placed on anti-AIDS drugs last year, five more were infected.

headline: The Week Ahead
text: Alison Smale, managing editor of The International Herald Tribune, discusses the Group of 8 summit in Germany.

headline: For Law Firm, Giuliani’s Halo Becomes a Glare
text: When he joined the Texas law firm Bracewell & Patterson in 2005 (and put his name on the door), Rudolph Giuliani said the move had nothing to do with a presidential run. Since then, the former mayor of New York has declared his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination, collected more campaign contributions in Texas than any other Republican candidate and named the firm’s managing partner, Patrick Oxford, as his campaign chairman.

headline: A Powerful Cyclone Hits Oman
text: Tropical Cyclone Gonu, the strongest storm to hit the strategic sultanate of Oman since the 1970’s, has prompted the shutdown of important energy distribution centers, a rush inland, the proclamation of a national holiday until Sunday, concern for turtles  and a surfer alert about 40-foot waves.

headline: Thompson Favors Libby Pardon
text: The 30-month sentence handed down today for I. Lewis “Scooter” Libby could become a rallying cry for Fred D. Thompson, the all-but declared Republican presidential candidate.

headline: Make It Snappy, but Not Too Snappy
text: When asparagus are in season and on the menu, I always order them. To me they are a total indulgence and it must have something to do with their scarcity in my childhood: they were not available year round.

headline: Could Alcatel-Lucent Consider an Avaya Reunion?
text: Avaya has agreed to be acquired by two private equity firms for $8.2 billion, but it’s not a done deal yet. As with many recent buyout agreements, terms call for a go-shop period during which the target company can solicit better offers. Although go-shops haven’t tended to smoke out rival bidders (Triad Hospitals is an exception), an analyst at Prudential says he thinks “other parties remain interested.” Among those that might peer through the go-shop window, according to Prudential’s Inder Singh, is Alcatel-Lucent. Avaya, which sells telecommunications gear, was spun off from Lucent in 2000, so a deal between the two would be reunion of sorts.

headline: Bikinis à la Mode
text: Some years ago, when Jean Paul Gaultier was really sinking teeth into couture, he held a show in the former home of Marie Laure de Noailles, an enormous house in the Place des États Unis. I have a memory of rounding the corner — a wet January day — and seeing the bronze statue of Myron T. Herrick. Now there’s a name a girl can’t forget. Herrick was the American ambassador to France when Lindbergh landed in Paris, in May 1927. I knew this because I happened to be reading Scott Berg’s biography of Lindbergh. A trip to a fashion show helped square a minor figure in history. A few nights later I was at a cocktail party at the American Embassy, and Felix Rohatyn, then ambassador, told me he loathed Lingbergh because of his Nazi sympathies. I was glad I had read Berg’s great biography, which spelled out the sources of Lingbergh’s self-absorbed, self-reliant character.

headline: A $112-a-Month MetroCard?
text: Well, maybe not that much. But not all is well in the land of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

headline: Solectron Takeover Sparks Guessing Game
text: This week’s deal in which Flextronics International will acquire Solectron for $3.6 billion has analysts wondering whether more consolidation is coming in the electronics manufacturing services sector — the business of making electronics on contract for other companies. There are plenty of potential targets out there, but some analysts warn against overexuberance, largely because buyers seem scarce. Investors seem to be unsure. After gaining on Monday, when the Solectron deal was announced, shares of many of the industry’s players fell on Tuesday.

headline: F.T.C. Seeks to Block Whole Foods-Wild Oats Deal
text: Concerned that one company might corner the market on organic broccoli and all kinds of other natural fare, federal regulators are suing to block Whole Foods Market‘s $565 million acquisition of a rival grocery chain, Wild Oats Markets, the two companies said Tuesday. The companies added that they will file a challenge in court.

headline: Gaming With Google’s Help
text: Alex Trebek offers no lifelines to contestants with the audacity to hit their buzzer. Just silence, and then a little needling. And if your brain doesn’t bail you out, that’s it. You failed.

headline: I Now Pronounce You, Economic Benefit
text: Of all the arguments brought to bear in support of legalizing same-sex marriage, this one appears to be rather original: New York City, according to a new analysis by the city comptroller, could reap $142 million in economic benefits over three years, primarily from a surge in spending by residents and visitors on weddings and by their out-of-town guests.

headline: Avandia Commercial
text: GlaxoSmithKline Avandia advertisement with Jane Seymour(Fall 2001).

headline: Avandia Commercial
text: GlaxoSmithKline Avandia advertisement with Della Reese (June 2004 - Dec. 2004).

headline: "Avandia Montage"
text: An advertisement for GlaxoSmithKline's Avandia Type 2 diabetes medication.

headline: Senator Craig Lyle Thomas, 74
text: Senators took to the floor today to pay tribute to Senator Craig Thomas, Republican of Wyoming, who died last night after a short battle with acute myeloid leukemia.

headline: Bear Dips Its Toe in the Sand with Saudi Joint Venture
text: In the latest move by American investment banks into the Middle East, Bear Stearns will join with a group of Saudi executives to form a joint venture to provide financial products compliant with Islamic law, MarketWatch reported Tuesday.

headline: 2008: Democrats on Their Faith
text: While the religious views of Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton, Barack Obama and former Senator John Edwards received wide coverage at Monday’s forum organized by the evangelical group, Sojourners, four other Democratic presidential hopefuls also had a chance to weigh in during the second hour. Senators Joe Biden and Chris Dodd, New Mexico Gov. Bill Richardson and Representative Dennis Kucinich – all Catholics – candidly spoke with CNN’s Paula Zahn about faith and politics.

headline: Klobuchar Gets D.S.C.C. Leadership Spot
text: Just five months into her first term, Senator Amy Klobuchar, Democrat of Minnesota, has been given a leadership position within the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.

headline: Starrett City Tenants Go to Albany
text: Nearly 150 Starrett City residents rallied outside the office of the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, this afternoon, clamoring for him to appear. The residents want the Senate to pass a bill that would ensure their rents would not soar if a potential sale of Starrett, the massive Brooklyn apartment complex, goes through.

headline: Frugal Traveler: Tell Matt Where to Go in Indiana
text: Next week, the Frugal Traveler is driving to Indiana. He needs your help. Do you know a cheap motel, a great place to eat or a must-see attraction? Share your tips with Matt here.

headline: Will the Libby Case Enter the G.O.P. Debate?
text: GOFFSTOWN, N.H., _ As the 10 candidates for the Republican nomination for president prepare for tonight’s debate, the matter of I. Lewis Libby, Vice President Cheney’s former chief of staff, has suddenly moved to the front burner. A federal judge sentenced Mr. Libby this morning to 30 months in prison after he was convicted of obstructing justice in the case involving Valeria Plame Wilson.

headline: More Useless Knowledge
text: When army ants are sweeping across the forest on one of their massive predatory raids, potholes tend to slow them down. And just the other day, British researchers revealed how these hard-charging creatures deal with the impediment: Individual ants fling themselves down and bridge the potholes with their bodies. In fact, the volunteers seem to size-match themselves to the holes they choose to plug. And when the army has tramped across their backs, they get up, dust themselves off, and head home to join the communal feast.

headline: Site of Virginia Tech Massacre to Reopen
text: Norris Hall, where a student killed 30 students in nine minutes on April 16, is reopening, but not for classes, Virginia Tech announced today.

headline: Hillary’s Iowa Problem
text: Is Iowa a more sexist place than the rest of America? Linda Lantor Fandel, the deputy editorial page editor of The Des Moines Register, fears that it is, and that Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign is suffering because of it.

headline: Michigan Wins, and Jeter Rubs It In
text: I’ve known Derek Jeter for six years, and we have a cordial relationship, like he seems to have with every writer. But he’s never used my name. Today he sees me and pipes up, loud enough for the other writers to hear, “Hey Tyler, where’d you go to college?”

headline: Ships Passing in the Morning
text: On Wednesday morning, some Staten Island ferry riders are in for a brush with grayness.

headline: Live-Blogging the G.O.P. Debate
text: GOFFSTOWN, N.H.

headline: Beltran’s Back
text: Hard-luck pitchers often say they are a victim of poor run support. Over his last two starts, Tom Glavine has gotten literally nothing. The Mets did not score against either John Smoltz or Barry Zito while losing, 2-1 and 3-0. Perhaps with Carlos Beltran, who missed the last three games with a bruised right knee, back in the lineup tonight against Philadelphia, Glavine’s luck may change.

headline: How I Learned to Relax
Mets Dodging Draft
text: For the first time in history, MLB’s first-year player draft will be televised. Or at least the first round. The fun begins at 2 p.m. Thursday on ESPN2, but unless you’re a Mets fan who has special interest in local players like the New Jersey high school pitcher Rick Porcello or Rutgers shortstop Todd Frazier, you could probably find better things to do with your time.

headline: The War in Present Tense
text: I’ve been reorganizing the garage all morning. Rearranging journals and notebooks written years ago, weeding through boxes marked “miscellaneous” for any seemingly useful item, throwing out a broken warming plate that never worked to begin with, trash-bagging old clothes for the goodwill bin at the local grocery store — basically sloughing away the material things that seem to accumulate so easily in my life, packrat that I am. But for some reason when I get to my Army duffel bags I don’t leave them closed. I undo their snap-links, grab each green bag with my name and unit numbers still stenciled on them, and flip them upside down to dump everything out onto the concrete floor.

headline: A Taxi Ride to Remember
text: Until recently, my craziest taxi ride occurred a few years ago in Newark, N.J. That escapade involved a shared taxi, a rear window being kicked out, me diving into the passenger footwell, and the cabbie attempting to run over the guy who’d just skipped paying fare. It turns out that I had to go to Hockenheim, Germany, to top this wild tale.

headline: F. Thompson on Fox
text: While Fred Thompson, the former senator from Tennessee, wasn’t among the Republican candidates on stage at the G.O.P. debate, he appeared just afterward on Fox News Channel’s “Hannity & Colmes.”

headline: Ready for the N.B.A. Throne, but Not Like Mike
text: The National Basketball Association has been in search of a transcendent star with staying power since Michael Jordan retired in 1998; television viewership of the finals is down 55 percent since that year. The league may have found its savior in LeBron James, who can sometimes score like Jordan or Kobe Bryant but who can also pass like Magic Johnson.

headline: NBC Universal Signs Head of Studio to a Five-Year Agreement
text: LOS ANGELES, June 5 — A week after a messy shake-up of the management of its television unit, NBC Universal has signed Ron Meyer, the president and chief operating officer of Universal Studios, to a new five-year contract. He will oversee movie production, theme parks and studio operations “through at least 2012,” the company said.

headline: Looking Beyond L. L. Bean
text: FREEPORT, Me. — Downtown Freeport hardly looks like a place that needs to reinvent itself. Perhaps best known as the home of L. L. Bean’s three large retail outposts, it also offers luxury names like Burberry, Cole Haan and Polo Ralph Lauren and dozens of well-appointed outlets.

headline: Red Hook Vendors Pressed to Get New Permit
text: PUPUSAS, sunburns, soccer: could this be the last summer to get them all at the same place?

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day yesterday about efforts by Microsoft and Apple to develop their next operating systems misspelled the surname of a technology executive who commented on the migration of computer functions to the Web. He is Nova Spivack, not Spivak.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about Bill France Jr., the former president of Nascar, rendered incorrectly the name of the organization. It is the National Association of Stock Car Auto Racing, not the National Association of Stock Car Racing.

headline: Can He Unleash the Force?
text: In mythic tales from “Superman” to “Star Wars” to “Spider-Man,” there comes a moment when the young superhero has to learn to harness his powers. That’s the challenge Barack Obama faces now.

headline: Glavine Does His Part, but the Mets Don’t Help Him Out
text: If Tom Glavine were granted three wishes, he might consider bypassing the rigmarole of the first two and get right down to business. He would like to have won his 300th career game three weeks ago — as soon as possible, in other words — so that life can return to normal.

headline: Wall Collapses on Staten Island in Concrete Avalanche
text: A 50-foot-high retaining wall behind a large hilltop house owned by a high-profile Staten Island lawyer collapsed late Monday night, unleashing an avalanche of concrete blocks weighing hundreds of pounds each into the yards of smaller homes below.

headline: South Korea: Hanwha’s Chairman Indicted
text: South Korean prosecutors indicted Kim Seung Yun, the chairman of an industrial company, the Hanwha Group, on six charges in connection with what the authorities say was a revenge attack on employees of a bar in Seoul. Prosecutors charged Mr. Kim and a bodyguard, both arrested on May 11, with confinement and causing bodily harm with a weapon, the Seoul Central District Prosecutors’ Office said. A Hanwha Group spokesman, Ju Cheol Beom, declined to comment.

headline: What You Get for... $4 Million
text: Oakville, Calif.

headline: Protestors Keep Tensions High at Summit
text: KÜHLUNGSBORN, Germany, June 6 — They lurked in the woods, fifty strong, wearing black hoods and bandannas, and wielding tree limbs. At a signal given by one of their number, they sprang forward and threw their debris across a road here, creating a barricade that brought traffic to a screeching halt.

headline: Afghanistan Exhibition Provokes Questions
text: The National Geographic Society has struck a $1 million deal with the Afghan government to bring a rare cache of gold artifacts to the United States in a traveling exhibition. But some cultural experts who have followed the negotiations are questioning whether Afghanistan is being properly compensated.

headline: Riders of the World, Unite! Skateboarding Sprouts as Team Sport
text: After months of wooing sponsors, and drafting bylaws and articles of incorporation, all Jeff Stern needed to create the first high school skateboard league was teenage skaters to get onboard and compete.

headline: Dining Briefs
text: REVISITS

headline: Long-Drawn-Out and Ready to Eat: Fresh Pastas on Essex Street
text: Vadim Ponorovsky, the owner of Paradou, a bistro in the meatpacking district, and Paradou Marché, a crepe and sandwich counter in the Essex Street Market, has opened Casa Tua in the market, specializing in freshly made ravioli and other pastas, and sauces. David Shemesh, the chef, may encourage you to try his beet and goat cheese ravioli — he’s making it at right — or his seven-herb fettuccine. And in a spirit of adventure, you might consider his earthy sumac fettuccine, flavored Middle Eastern style, and toss it with olives, olive oil, lemon zest and chilies. Pasta with sauce at cafe tables is $8 to $10, from 11:30 a.m. until the market closes (at 6 p.m. Monday to Wednesday, and 7 p.m. Thursday to Saturday). Pasta for two, to take home, is $6.50 to $14, and sauces are $3.50: 120 Essex Street (Delancey Street), (212) 477-4177.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A map of Central Asia with an article on Saturday about the construction of a bridge linking Tajikistan and Afghanistan misidentified the country shown in the lower left. It is Iran, not Azerbaijan.

headline: Seventeen Hits and a Sigh of Relief for the Yankees
text: CHICAGO, June 5 — To Johnny Damon, explaining the Yankees’ troubles has been simple. When only three everyday players are hitting the way they should, he has said, that leaves six others dragging down the team.

headline: Mob Case Defendant Is Shot in Brooklyn
text: A reputed mobster associated with the Gambino crime family was shot at least three times while sitting in his car on a Brooklyn street yesterday morning, the police said.

headline: Gehry to Design Battery Park Playground
text: Frank Gehry, the architect known for his buildings adorned with undulating banners of titanium, is set make his first foray into the world of monkey bars and swing sets with a new playground at Battery Park, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said today.

headline: Stock Market Falters as Bond Yields Rise
text: The stock market posted its first decline in a week after bond yields surged to a nine-month high amid signs that the economy might be gaining momentum.

headline: Coal-to-Liquid Fuels (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sweet and Sour Sit Down to Dessert
text: RHUBARB is an alarmingly sour vegetable passed off as a fruit, but requiring a huge mound of sugar to effect the transformation.

headline: Getting Into College, Strumming His Own Tune
text: DOYLESTOWN, Pa.

headline: Iraq’s Brain Drain (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Eternal Vaudeville of the Spiritual Mind
text: God is in the curriculum in the lively lecture hall that has been made of the New York Theater Workshop, where Rinde Eckert’s “Horizon” opened last night. But even the fiercest secularist should find pleasure in this engaging performance piece, which is set in the seminary-without-walls of one man’s mind.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Chefs on the Move

headline: American Trade Specialist Resigns
text: Franklin L. Lavin, under secretary of commerce for international trade, who prodded China to reduce trade barriers by backing new tariffs on Chinese goods, announced his resignation yesterday. Mr. Lavin plans to leave on July 13, less than two years after taking the post. He is joining the Washington office of Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate services company. He led negotiations for the United States at the World Trade Organization over how to rework trade laws.

headline: Recipe: Zucchini Carpaccio With Avocado
text: Adapted from “Vegetable Harvest” (Morrow, 2007)

headline: From Turkey Waste, a New Fuel and a New Fight
text: BENSON, Minn. — For anyone curious about what thousands of tons of turkey litter looks like, piled high into an indoor olfactory-assaulting mountain of manure, this old railroad stop on the extreme edge of alternative energy production is the place to be.

headline: Albany: Nominees for SUNY Board
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer yesterday announced three nominees to fill coming vacancies on the State University of New York board. Besides Carl T. Hayden, whom Mr. Spitzer had identified as his choice as SUNY’s chairman, the governor yesterday named H. Carl McCall, a former state comptroller and a former president of New York City’s Board of Education, and Linda S. Sanford, a senior vice president at I.B.M. The governor appoints 15 of SUNY’s 16 board members, subject to State Senate approval. The other seat is held by a student.

headline: Clinton Backs Change to Marriage Law
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has told a gay rights organization that she supports the repeal of one provision of the federal Defense of Marriage Act, the 1996 law signed by her husband that says states and the federal government do not have to recognize gay marriages and unions from other states. On the questionnaire for the Human Rights Campaign, Mrs. Clinton said she opposed the part of the law that would prohibit the federal government from recognizing same-sex relationships. Her advisers said that she continued to oppose gay marriage. Her response on the questionnaire puts her in line with her rivals for her party’s nomination.

headline: Keeping a Watch on Winter
text: Yesterday brought an end to another public comment period on another winter use plan for Yellowstone National Park, a plan that would raise the number of snowmobiles allowed into the park from 250 to 720 per day. The National Park Service has now spent some $10 million over the past decade examining over and over again the effects of snowmobiles on Yellowstone. The scientific results have been consistent. The best alternative, environmentally speaking, is to do away with snowmobiles altogether. There have also been more than 700,000 public comments on this question. The public has been consistent, too  consistently against snowmobiles.

headline: Transplant Team Dies in Jet Crash; Mechanical Problems Suspected
text: DETROIT, June 5 — What was meant to be a mission to save the life of a man in desperate need of a lung transplant ended instead on Monday in the deaths of four members of a medical team and two pilots of a plane that crashed while racing to fly the organs from Milwaukee to Michigan.

headline: Fed Chief Dims Hopes for a Rate Cut
text: The stock market stumbled yesterday as Wall Street seemed to grasp that the Federal Reserve is in no hurry to lower interest rates.

headline: A Vestige of British Rule Is About to Vanish, Unmourned
text: HONG KONG, June 5 — Queen’s Pier is a simple building, a few short columns and a low roof next to Hong Kong’s harbor, designed and built after World War II for official events like the arrival and departure of colonial governors.

headline: The Expanding Meatball Universe, From Mama’s Table to Esca
text: IF you’ve ever suspected that meatballs were a dead end for a restaurant’s leftovers, you no longer have reason to fear. These days, chefs are free associating with well-sourced ingredients, clever substitutions and dazzling techniques. Others are refining more authentic variations that highlight the meatball’s global appeal (see also: kofte, nem nuong, frikadell, kottbuller, albóndigas, keftedes, tsukune).

headline: New AIDS Cases in Africa Outpace Treatment Gains
text: BEIRA, Mozambique — Four years ago, the region surrounding this somnolent seaport, Mozambique’s second largest city, offered hardly any AIDS-prevention advice to pregnant women. Today, two dozen health clinics give mothers-to-be H.I.V. counseling, tests and medicine to protect their newborns from catching the virus.

headline: Panel Asks Official About Politics in Hiring
text: WASHINGTON, June 5 — A senior Justice Department official acknowledged to Senate investigators Tuesday that he once bragged about his success in hiring conservative Republican lawyers onto his staff that handled civil rights cases.

headline: Case of the Deadbeat Dad Is Closed but Unsolved
text: As the official letter began with the inspiring words, “You are hereby summoned,” Mike Shaieb took a minute to digest the contents. Well, several minutes.

headline: Recipe: Creamy Lemon-Chive Dressing
text: Adapted from “Vegetable Harvest” (Morrow, 2007)

headline: Automakers Push to Head Off Tighter Fuel Standards
text: WASHINGTON, June 6 —Automobile executives are making progress in their resistance to tougher fuel economy requirements, an issue that sharply pits powerful Congressional Democrats from Michigan against party leaders who want to pass energy legislation by the end of this month.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: The Return of Tap Water

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,476 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Mickelson Will Rest His Injured Wrist
text: Phil Mickelson has decided to skip the St. Jude Championship in Memphis this week as he tries to recuperate from an injured left wrist in time for the United States Open, which begins June 14 at Oakmont Country Club near Pittsburgh.

headline: Major Claims Are Settled in 2005 Collapse
text: Shortly after 3 p.m., on May 12, 2005, a 150-foot section of a nearly century-old retaining wall high above the Henry Hudson Parkway in Manhattan gave way in a thundering and frightening avalanche.

headline: Ready for N.B.A. Throne, but Not Like Mike
text: CLEVELAND, June 5 — LeBron James was still a teenager when he was cast as a basketball messiah in television commercials and labeled The Chosen One on magazine covers. Now at the age of 22, James may soon fulfill all of the hyperbolic promise — if the viewing public can adapt to a new kind of superstar.

headline: Cyclone Nears Iran and Oman
text: Oman and Iran girded for heavy flooding and winds today as the strongest cyclone ever recorded by scientists in the northwestern Arabian Sea began to hit coastlines that have little experience with such powerful storms.

headline: The Best of the Bad Cops Keeps Walking a Hard Line
text: When Michael Chiklis’s agent first read the script for “The Shield” in 2001, he advised the actor not to audition. If Mr. Chiklis wanted the lead role in the cops-and-gangs drama — and he did — he shouldn’t have to abase himself with a tryout, his agent argued. Mr. Chiklis, after all, had already starred in “The Commish” on ABC and “Daddio” on NBC. He was almost a household name.

headline: Reader Responses
text: Here are excerpts from reader responses to my June 6 column on health care:

headline: To the Envelope Pushers, Cheers!
text: THEY go by many names. Most familiarly and perhaps most unkindly, they’re called wine geeks. They’re also known as zealots, extremists and even the wine counterculture.

headline: A Translucent and Radiant Partner With the Past
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 31 — Working on theoretical proposals and the occasional house commission, Steven Holl emerged as a rare, original talent in the 1980s. The strength of his vision was rooted in a desire to reconnect architecture to the physical world — the shifting nature of light, the reflective surfaces of water, the texture of materials — and an atavistic love of craft.

headline: Charges Filed Against 6 Men in Plot to Attack Base
text: A federal grand jury in New Jersey has charged five men in a plot to kill American soldiers at the Fort Dix military base, and charged a sixth with illegally helping some of the others to obtain weapons, prosecutors said yesterday.

headline: Charles Evans, 81, a Founder of Fashion Line, Dies
text: Charles Evans, a founder of the fashion house Evan-Picone and who was also executive producer of the film “Tootsie,” died Saturday in Manhattan. He was 81.

headline: Gitmo: A National Disgrace
text: Ever since President Bush rammed the Military Commissions Act of 2006 through Congress to lend a pretense of legality to his detention camp at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, we have urged Congress to amend the law to restore basic human rights and judicial process. Rulings by military judges this week suggest that the special detention system is so fundamentally corrupt that the only solution is to tear it down and start again.

headline: Service Industries’ Expansion Picked Up Pace Last Month
text: Service industry expansion unexpectedly accelerated last month to the highest level in more than a year, a sign the economy is strengthening.

headline: Filly Rags to Riches Will Take on the Boys at Belmont
text: What had been shaping up as a ho-hum Belmont Stakes received some star power yesterday when the filly Rags to Riches was confirmed as a starter for the 139th running of the race Saturday.

headline: Abbas Pulls Out of  Talks With Israel
text: JERUSALEM, June 6 — The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, has pulled out of planned talks this week with Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert, after the two sides could not agree on an agenda.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about C. C. Myers, a contractor whose company finished repairs well ahead of deadline for a highway ramp that linked parts of the East Bay to San Francisco, incorrectly described the type of cowboy boots he favors. They are ostrich, not peacock.

headline: Talking the Dream, Growing the Brand
text: ATLANTA — What looks from the outside like roughly 70,000 square feet of warehouse space near the King Center is the home of Tyler Perry Studios, where Mr. Perry is living his dream of running a media empire. On this day in late May, the dream meant talking and talking, so he really wanted something for his chapped lips.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on May 3 about an I.B.M. advance in chip-making referred imprecisely to recent developments in the field. I.B.M. and Intel — not Intel alone — announced in January that they would take advantage of a new insulating material for their chips. (It is I.B.M.’s more recent work, involving a manufacturing process that creates insulating vacuum channels in chips, that sets it apart from Intel’s approach.) A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message on May 4; this correction was delayed for research.

headline: Chastising Putin, Bush Says Russia Derails Reform
text: PRAGUE, June 5 — President Bush delivered a two-pronged message to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Tuesday, two days before their scheduled meeting in Germany, chiding Mr. Putin for derailing democratic reforms while assuring the Russian leader that he had nothing to fear from a missile defense system in Europe.

headline: Libya: Equity Firm Buys Stake in Oil Refiner
text: The private equity firm Colony Capital agreed to acquire control of Tamoil of Libya for 4 billion euros ($5.4 billion). The Libyan government will retain 35 percent of the company, which operates refineries and gas stations, Colony said. Tamoil, based in Switzerland and owned by the Libyan government under the name Oilinvest B.V., owns three refineries  in Germany, Italy and Switzerland  and 2,500 gas stations in Italy.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Putin Honors Solzhenitsyn

headline: Manhattan: Man Sought in Hotel Robberies
text: The police said yesterday that they were seeking a man who recently robbed guests at two hotels in Manhattan. In the first robbery, on April 13 at the Millenium Hilton downtown, the man followed a couple and a 9-year-old girl to their room, held them at gunpoint, then bound and robbed them of cash, jewelry and electronics, the police said. In the second robbery, on Thursday night at the Roosevelt Hotel on East 45th Street, the man forced himself into a woman’s room as she was entering, assaulted her and took her handbag, the police said. The robber is described as a white man, about 5 foot 7 and about 25 years old, with a stocky build, wearing a blue baseball cap and a black pea coat. Anyone with information should call 1-800-577-TIPS, the police said.

headline: Manhattan: Economic Benefits of Same-Sex Marriage
text: Legalizing gay marriage would bring New York City $142 million in economic benefits over the first three years, according to an economic analysis released yesterday by William C. Thompson, the comptroller. Mr. Thompson, a likely candidate for mayor in 2009, wrote in the report that the benefits would come mainly from increased spending of residents and visitors on their weddings, including items like hotel stays.

headline: Erratic Week for China Stocks as Policies Seem to Shift
text: HONG KONG, June 5  The Chinese government is learning the dangers of intervening in stock markets, as policy shifts by the government and even speculation of policy shifts have led to sharp swings in share prices on the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock markets over the last week.

headline: Charles Maynes, 68, Statesman, Is Dead
text: Charles William Maynes, a longtime editor of Foreign Policy magazine who was also a former assistant secretary of state, died on Saturday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 68.

headline: U.S. Set to Defend Gold Cup
text: Before the United States played Guatemala in a friendly match in March, the North Americans were flying high. They had won three straight games under their new coach Bob Bradley, including a 2-0 victory over archrivals Mexico and a masterful 3-1 dismantling of World Cup darlings Ecuador. But the Guatemalans weren’t intimidated. Playing a defensive style, they completely stymied the U.S. attack, and held the superpower to a scoreless draw.

headline: Senate Rejects Immigration Stricture
text: WASHINGTON, June 6 — The proposed immigration-overhaul bill survived a crucial test this afternoon as the Senate rejected a measure that would have made it much harder for many illegal immigrants to eventually achieve legal status. By a vote of 51 to 46, the senators defeated a proposal to bar legal status for aliens who disobey deportation orders or who engage in identity fraud. The proposal was made in the form of an amendment, offered by Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, to an overall immigration bill that is being debated.

headline: Arrest of 30 Leads Youths to Organize in Brooklyn
text: The hue and cry over the arrests of about 30 students on the way to a friend’s wake in Bushwick, Brooklyn, last month has spurred a growing youth movement against racial profiling.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 5, 2007

headline: Manhattan: Man Charged With Posing as a Lawyer
text: A Long Island man who worked as a lawyer at a major New York law firm for four years  even though, prosecutors said, he had never gone to law school  pleaded not guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court to charges of impersonating a lawyer and stealing at least $284,350 in salary from his firm. The man, Brian Valery, 32, of Massapequa Park, was promoted from paralegal to lawyer at the firm, Anderson Kill & Olick, in 2002, and was earning $155,000 plus bonuses when he was fired in October 2006, prosecutors said. His lawyer, Joseph R. Conway, said Mr. Valery, who is now unemployed, faced related charges in Connecticut and expected to have charges brought against him in Brooklyn.

headline: Libby Given 30 Months for Lying in C.I.A. Leak Case
text: WASHINGTON, June 5 — I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney and one of the principal architects of President Bush’s foreign policy, was sentenced Tuesday to 30 months in prison for lying during a C.I.A. leak investigation that became part of a fierce debate over the war in Iraq.

headline: G.M. Chief Tells Shareholders to Take Long View
text: WILMINGTON, Del., June 5 — The chairman and chief executive of General Motors, Rick Wagoner, faced more than two hours of criticism from shareholders at the annual meeting here Tuesday, but he countered that the company had made major progress in turning around its fortunes last year. And he urged patience for the long term.

headline: Interrogation Abuses (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: On Avandia, a Niche Strategy Now Under Stress
text: Could a widely praised approach to drug marketing now be at risk of backfiring? That is a question confronting GlaxoSmithKline and its diabetes treatment Avandia, which is now clouded by concerns over the drug’s safety.

headline: Stocks Drop on Fed Comment on Interest Rates
text: The stock market stumbled today as Wall Street seemed to grasp that the Federal Reserve is in no hurry to lower interest rates.

headline: Red Bulls Import a Little Excellence
text: Gone are the shoulder-length hair and the wide headband, and the disdain for the generally miserable weather of the English midlands.

headline: Expletive Policy Deleted
text: At the Billboard Music Awards in 2002, Cher had a salty rejoinder to critics who “have been telling me I’m on the way out every year.” At the same event in 2003, Nicole Richie had some earthy reflections on the difficulties of cleaning a Prada purse. It’s hard to believe these comments threaten the nation’s well-being, but the Federal Communications Commission found them indecent and profane. That threatened Fox Broadcasting, which televised the awards show, with major fines. This week, in a very welcome decision, a federal appeals court overturned the F.C.C.’s indecency policy.

headline: The Constant Comfort of an Old Friend
text: THERE are restaurants with more shimmer, and there are certainly restaurants with more spark. There are restaurants that take bigger chances and stake bolder claims to your attention.

headline: Democrats Hope to Expand Rights at Guantánamo
text: WASHINGTON, June 5 — A day after two military judges ruled against the Bush administration’s system for trying terrorism detainees, Democrats seized on the rulings on Tuesday as evidence that Congress should restore the right of those held at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to challenge their detentions.

headline: Farnsworth Sees No Need to Clear the Air With Clemens
text: CHICAGO, June 5  Kyle Farnsworth first met Roger Clemens at one of the lowest points of his career. Farnsworth, then the closer for the Atlanta Braves, had blown the save in the final game of a division series against Clemens’s Houston Astros in 2005.

headline: Is U.S. Safer Since 9/11? Clinton and Rivals Spar
text: The Bush administration’s efforts to thwart terrorism at home have created a fissure among the three leading Democratic presidential candidates, with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton coming under attack for saying that America is safer now than before 9/11 — contrary to a popular line of argument among some Democratic officials.

headline: Manhattan: Hotelier Buys 1951 House
text: The hotelier André Balazs bought Maison Tropicale, a small 1951 aluminum-paneled house by the French designer Jean Prouvé, for $4.97 million yesterday, Christie’s auction house said. Christie’s had estimated that the house would go for $4 million to $6 million. (The final price includes Christie’s commission: 20 percent of the first $500,000 and 12 percent of the rest.) The house had been on view since mid-May in Long Island City. Prouvé designed it as a prototype for prefabricated homes for French colonial officials stationed in Africa. The seller, Eric Touchaleaume, a French antiques dealer, has said he plans to use the proceeds to finance a Prouvé museum that will travel in another Maison Tropicale.

headline: Victory Is in View for Team New Zealand
text: VALENCIA, Spain, June 5  Emirates Team New Zealand was in front for good again Tuesday, and as usual in this one-sided Louis Vuitton Cup finals, which the Kiwis now lead, 4-0, the crew member with the best view was Adam Beashel.

headline: Sea Lions Hit by High Levels of Acid Poison in California
text: LOS ANGELES, June 5 — A distressed, possibly pregnant sea lion was wheeled recently into the Marine Mammal Care Center here, just as two other lions were herded into cages in preparation for their return to the ocean.

headline: Recipe: Rhubarb ‘Big Crumb’ Coffeecake
text: Time: 1 1/2 hours, plus cooling

headline: Asbury Park: Sewage Spill Closes Beaches
text: About two miles of beaches, from Deal south to Bradley Beach, were closed yesterday after a pipe broke at the Asbury Park sewage treatment plant, Monmouth County officials said. Beaches in Allenhurst, Loch Arbour, Asbury Park and Ocean Grove were also closed. The pipe, which has since been repaired, released about half a million gallons of partly treated sewage into the Atlantic Ocean between 3:30 a.m. and 9:30 a.m. yesterday, said William Simmons, the county’s environmental health coordinator. Results from water quality tests, expected this afternoon, will determine whether the beaches can reopen. Compiled by John Sullivan

headline: Steps on the Road to Energy Reform (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: On Kentucky’s Bourbon Trail
text: GRADUALLY the hills and pastures of Tennessee, which for hours had rolled on like a sinuous green wave, came to an end. The stands of hilltop trees, once so bulbous and neat, like broccoli tops, grew wilder and chaotic. And instead of flowing up, over and around the swells in the earth, U.S. Route 31E now cut right through them, exposing the white limestone below the topsoil. It was the only “Welcome to Kentucky” sign I needed.

headline: Cuomo Broadens Student Loan Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON, June 6 — Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, whose scrutiny of student loans exposed secret ties between universities and lenders, said today that he was broadening his investigation to examine the criteria lenders use when making loans and whether they violated civil rights statutes.

headline: Jail Time for Scooter Libby
text: The jail sentence and fine imposed on Scooter Libby, the former chief of staff for Vice President Dick Cheney, are an appropriate  indeed necessary  punishment for his repeated lies to a grand jury and to F.B.I. agents investigating a possible smear campaign orchestrated by the White House. Although Mr. Libby plans to appeal, as he has every legal right to, the judge ought to send him to jail now as a lesson that such efforts to frustrate justice will not be tolerated.

headline: Gates Urges Stronger U.S. Ties With Europe
text: COLLEVILLE-SUR-MER, France, June 6 — Beside a churning sea and an ocean of white marble crosses, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said today that the United States and its European allies should honor the thousands of Americans buried here by strengthening the alliance they died defending.

headline: F.T.C. to Sue in Bid to Halt Food Merger
text: Wild Oats Markets may not become part of the natural foods empire of Whole Foods Market, after all.

headline: A Middle-Class Hamptons Is Vacated on Town’s Orders
text: STRATFORD, Conn., June 4 — Up and down a sandy road here, hard to find even with a map, residents were emptying their weekend homes as fast as they could on Friday to beat the tide. Cars have been scarce on this scruffy peninsula since the bridge to the mainland burned in 1996. But suddenly, moving trucks, having arrived by boat, were as plentiful as rose hip bushes.

headline: Recipe: Couscous Salad With Spinach
text: Adapted from “Vegetable Harvest” (Morrow, 2007)

headline: Baghdad Gallery Owner Hopes Culture Can Dispel Hate
text: BAGHDAD, June 1 — He may be the last hopeful man in Iraq.

headline: Unleashing the Dogs That Abhor
text: The N.F.L. scene has become the puppy mill for pit-bull lore.

headline: Pakistan Questions 2 in Daniel Pearl Killing
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 5  Pakistani officials said they were investigating two people arrested Monday in Kashmor, a remote town in the southern province of Sindh, for any links to the killing of the American journalist Daniel Pearl in 2002.

headline: What a Mess
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank

headline: To Keep Its Parakeets Wild, San Francisco Bans Handouts
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 5 — In what may be a legislative first for San Francisco, the city’s Board of Supervisors on Tuesday banned the feeding of a tourist attraction.

headline: Diabetes Drug Still Has Heart Risks, Doctors Warn
text: A medical study intended to demonstrate the heart safety of a well-known diabetes treatment seems, instead, to have added to the controversy over the drug.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Monday about William F. Whitman Jr., a horticulturist and collector of rare fruit, referred incorrectly to an underwater camera he built with his brother Dudley earlier in his career. It was a film camera, not a video camera.

headline: The Partition That Divided a City and a Civilization
text: After the Berlin Wall came down in 1989, the government of the soon-to-be-former German Democratic Republic pulled off a breathtakingly cynical stunt. It auctioned the thing off, one piece at a time. Adding a special piquancy to the event, at the Hotel Parc Pallas in Monte Carlo, was the official responsible for transporting the wall from Germany.

headline: D. Nelson Adams, 97, Tax Law Specialist, Dies
text: D. Nelson Adams, a former managing partner of Davis Polk & Wardwell, one of the nation’s most prominent law firms, died on Thursday at his home in Barneveld, N.Y. He was 97 and also had a home in Manhattan.

headline: Suicide Attack Near Falluja Kills 18 in Commercial Area
text: BAGHDAD, June 5 — Eighteen people were killed south of Falluja on Tuesday when a suicide bomber driving a truck packed with explosives plowed into a busy commercial district, the local Iraqi police said. Fifteen others were wounded.

headline: Vigorous and Rebellious, a Master Composer in His Youth
text: Summer at Mannes College the New School for Music is a seamless succession of mini-festivals and institutes that cover everything from music theory and analysis to keyboard virtuosity, contemporary music and the guitar and vocal repertory. The main purpose is to instruct the conservatory’s students, but the programs also give the school a public presence by way of open master classes, lectures, panel discussions and performances. The Mannes Beethoven Institute, which began its weeklong run on Sunday, is now in its seventh year and has been directed from the start by the pianist Thomas Sauer.

headline: Ethics Panel to Investigate Congressman on Conduct
text: WASHINGTON, June 5 — Under pressure from Republicans, the House ethics committee announced Tuesday it would open an inquiry into the conduct of Representative William J. Jefferson, who relinquished his sole committee assignment in the wake of his indictment on corruption charges.

headline: Vignettes That Wind Lusciously in and Out of the Music
text: Olu Dara and Dianne McIntyre seldom perform together anymore, and that is a great pity. Their sensibilities fit hand in glove; their complementary sly humor and sweetness create vignettes of everyday people who somehow manage to rise above simply getting along in life.

headline: A Hands-On Hotel Owner Who Values Independence
text: CHICAGO — Arriving at the InterContinental Hotel on North Michigan Avenue on a warm afternoon, Laurence S. Geller notices that the doorman, Hussain al-Mosawy, is wearing a new addition to his summer uniform: a white safari hat.

headline: The Dog Who Breathed a New Business
text: WHO would have thought that a middle-age couple who held government jobs and were a tad unsure what an entrepreneur was would make a small fortune from their beloved dog’s bad breath?

headline: In Paris, Bringing Vegetables Out to Play
text: ON Sunday mornings, there’s an organic market on Boulevard Raspail in Paris where everything screams “Eat me.”

headline: Radio Time to Join List of eBay Items Up for Auction
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 5  The auction giant eBay said it would begin selling radio airtime to advertisers starting Wednesday, expanding into a business that Google entered last year

headline: The Six-Day War, Plus 40 Years (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Symbolism Takes a Back Seat to the World’s Abrasive Realities
text: Within the first few minutes of her show at the Bowery Ballroom on Monday night, Keren Ann charted a complex constellation of feelings: wistfulness, disdain, self-pity, indignation, whimsy. She was singing a breakup song, naturally — “In Your Back,” from her self-titled fifth album — but making it sound more momentous than most.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day yesterday about a private equity investment in Palm Inc. gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the surname of a research analyst at Gartner, who discussed the market for cellphones and other hand-held devices. He is Todd Kort, not Cort.

headline: Serena Williams Falters and Henin Capitalizes
text: PARIS, June 5 — The most anticipated and potentially heated match at the French Open so far — Serena Williams against Justine Henin — fizzled nearly from the start Tuesday.

headline: Administration Seeks Overhaul of Patent System
text: The Bush administration wants to reform the nation’s patent system by requiring better information from inventors and allowing public scrutiny of applications, according to the director of the government’s patent office.

headline: Health Care as if Costs Didn’t Matter
text: In a saner world, the place where you live wouldn’t have much effect on how doctors treated your back problems. In our world, it can make all the difference.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The TV Watch column on Friday, about Fred D. Thompson, the former senator and actor on “Law & Order,” who has taken steps to run for president, misstated the year of the Senate Watergate hearings, when he was named minority counsel for the committee investigating the scandal. It was 1973, not 1974.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Saturday about high-powered public policy debates held by Robert Rosenkranz, a New York investor and philanthropist, used an outdated title in some copies for one participant, Bob Barr. He is now a consultant on public policy; he is no longer a United States representative.

headline: A Romanian Town Slouches Toward Revolution and Beyond
text: At the beginning of “The 18th Brumaire of Louis Napoleon,” Karl Marx famously observes that history repeats itself, first as tragedy, then as farce. He forgot to add that the commemoration of history can raise farce to a whole new level of absurdity. This, at any rate, is among the insights offered by the Romanian director Corneliu Porumboiu’s acutely funny first feature, “12:08 East of Bucharest.”

headline: Albany: Crime Dropped Statewide Last Year
text: State officials yesterday released preliminary crime statistics for 2006, reporting a modest decrease in the crime rate over 2005. Violent crime decreased by 4.6 percent in New York City and 2.3 percent in the rest of the state; nationwide, according to federal statistics released this week, the rate of violent crime increased slightly. There were roughly 476,000 reported crimes in the state last year, the lowest volume since statewide reporting began nearly 40 years ago, officials said.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A timeline in some copies on Sunday about the events leading up to charges against four men in what the authorities said was a plot to blow up terminals and fuel lines at Kennedy International Airport misspelled the given name of one suspect in some copies. He is Russell Defreitas, not Russel.

headline: Recipe: Almond and Buttermilk Sorbet
text: Adapted from“Vegetable Harvest” (Morrow, 2007)

headline: Proposal for New Jail Rules Draws Fire From Inmate Advocates
text: The board that oversees the city’s Department of Correction has put off a final vote on changes to the rules governing the daily lives of city inmates — the most significant changes since 1978 — following an outcry by the City Bar Association, the Legal Aid Society and other groups that have called the changes draconian and inhumane.

headline: Martínez Is Taking Awhile to Find His Comfort Zone
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., June 5  In an obscure warm-up area at the Mets’ minor league camp Tuesday, Pedro Martínez pitched off a mound for the first time in more than eight months. He came away feeling he had passed a basic first test toward rebuilding his career.

headline: Nets and Knicks Show Togetherness in Working Out Draft Prospects
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y., June 5 — There is nothing unusual about the Knicks’ working out draft prospects at this time of year. There is nothing unusual about the Nets’ doing the same. But the Knicks and Nets working out their players together? Now that’s unheard of. Until now.

headline: Craig Thomas, 74, G.O.P Senator From Wyoming, Dies
text: Senator Craig Thomas, a Wyoming Republican who combined a deep love of Western rural life with a 23-year public career in his home state and Washington, died Monday evening in Bethesda, Md. He was 74 and had homes in Casper, Wyo., and Arlington, Va.

headline: Canada: Lowe’s Is Planning to Open Six Stores
text: The Lowe’s Companies, the home-improvement retailer, will open up to six stores in Canada by the end of January 2008. At least four stores will be in southwestern Ontario, including Toronto, said Doug Robinson, Lowe’s president of Canadian operations.

headline: New Study Finds Gains Since No Child Left Behind
text: Student achievement has increased and test score gaps between white students and black and Hispanic students have narrowed in many states since President Bush signed the No Child Left Behind law in 2002, according to a new survey of state scores in reading and math.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A front-page picture caption on Thursday and a related article in sports about Mel Renfro, a former star defensive back for the Dallas Cowboys who participated in a health study of retired athletes, misstated part of the name of the shrine in Ohio that honors football greats like him. It is the Pro Football Hall of Fame, not the National Football League’s Hall of Fame.

headline: Manhattan: Special Trains Planned for Football Games
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it planned to run special trains from the Metro-North Railroad’s New Haven line to Secaucus, N.J., for Giants and Jets football games at the Meadowlands, beginning in the second half of 2009. The trains would switch in New Rochelle from Metro-North tracks to Amtrak tracks and then run through Pennsylvania Station to New Jersey. Riders could take a shuttle train from Secaucus to the Meadowlands. The pilot program would also make it possible for subway or bus riders or riders on other commuter railroads to buy a single ticket allowing them to transfer at Penn Station to the Metro-North football trains or to New Jersey Transit trains bound for the Secaucus-Meadowlands shuttle.

headline: Vioxx Damage Award
text: A judge who threw out a $51 million damage award against Merck last year over its Vioxx painkiller reversed himself and awarded $1.6 million to the plaintiff, a former F.B.I. agent who blamed the drug for his heart attack.

headline: Dinner at the Foodies’: Purslane and Anxiety
text: RICHARD FAULK still recalls, with a twinge of shame, the day he and his girlfriend, Jeanine Villalobos, served store-bought tortillas to guests.

headline: South Africa: Health Minister Snubs Aids Meeting
text: The health minister, long known for questioning the scientific tenets of the AIDS epidemic, has turned down an invitation to address the nation’s third annual conference on the disease because she was not given a conspicuous spot on the conference agenda, Vice President Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka said. The minister, Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, was excluded from opening ceremonies at the conference, in Durban, but had been scheduled to speak today at a gathering of AIDS experts and activists. Ms. Mlambo-Ngcuka, who did speak at the opening session, criticized the event’s organizers for relegating Dr. Tshabalala-Msimang to a lesser spot on the program. The health minister’s speech was to mark her return to public life after a long illness culminating early this year in a liver transplant.

headline: Former Brooklyn Officials Surrender for Prison Terms
text: One man helped lead the State Assembly and controlled the Brooklyn Democratic Party, the largest such organization east of Chicago. The other presided over matrimonial cases in the borough, deciding hundreds of child custody or family finance disputes. Both left court in handcuffs yesterday to begin serving prison sentences for corruption.

headline: Home Depot Meeting (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: China: Optimism on Pollution
text: China has reached a “turning point” in reversing its runaway pollution problems and expects to see reductions in air and water pollution in the coming months, according to Zhang Lijun, a top official with the State Environmental Protection Administration. Mr. Zhang, left, used a news conference to predict that emissions of sulfur dioxide in the air and levels of water pollution measured by a process known as chemical oxygen demand would fall this year. Cutting those areas of pollution are the main indicators in China’s nationwide plan for a 10 percent reduction in pollution by 2010. Last year, China failed to meet its goal of two percent reductions in each category and instead registered small increases. But Mr. Zhang said improvements had become evident after government programs to install pollution technology on coal-fired power plants, as well as the installation of new wastewater treatment equipment. He acknowledged that other pollutants, including ammonia, continued to rise. And greenhouse gas emissions like carbon dioxide are increasing rapidly.

headline: Rifts on Russia and Climate Seen at G-8 Summit
text: ROSTOCK, Germany, June 6 — On the eve of a meeting of the leaders of the Group of 8 wealthy industrial nations, the United States remained deeply at odds with many of its international partners on climate change, and work still needed to be done before an agreement could be reached on cutting greenhouse gas emissions, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said today.

headline: A Routine Traffic Stop Leads to Gunshots and Questions
text: CLIFTON, N.J., June 5  John Kubasta has spent much of his life defying the notion that being permanently disabled means being permanently dependent on others.

headline: Traditional Korean Marriage Meets Match on the Internet
text: SEOUL, South Korea, June 5  Sitting in his office crammed with files and boxes, Lee Woong-jin, a 42-year-old entrepreneur, talks enthusiastically about his latest moneymaking plan: merging the age-old Korean matchmaking tradition with the vibrant South Korean Internet culture.

headline: Strong Cyclone Heading for Southern Iran
text: The strongest cyclone ever recorded by scientists in the northwestern Arabian Sea churned up the coast of Oman today and was on track to hit land in southern Iran, sending high winds and waves through a region that is used for oil exports and civilian and military shipping traffic.

headline: Run, Gobble, Gobble, Run: Vying for Pac-Man Acclaim
text: Wakka wakka wakka.

headline: Steven Gilliard Jr., 42, Dies; Founder of Liberal Political Blog
text: Steven Gilliard Jr., a political journalist who found his calling as a combative and influential blogger on the left, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 42.

headline: Why Wait for the G-8?
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: A Guide to America’s Cheese Trail
text: A FEW years ago, I spent a week traveling the byways of New England in search of the best cheesemakers. As the rest of the world hurries on, remote farms are quietly turning milk into everything from charming little goat pyramids to big bold wheels of aged cows’ milk cheese. Down many dirt roads there was marvelous cheese to taste from the animals grazing in the nearby fields.

headline: Restitution Deal Made
text: A former sales chief at CA Inc., the software maker, has agreed to pay $29.7 million in restitution after pleading guilty last year to criminal charges in a scheme to raise the company’s quarterly revenue artificially through backdated sales contracts.

headline: HBO Moves to Fill Executive Void
text: HBO announced a new lineup of four top corporate officers yesterday to succeed Chris Albrecht, the chief executive who resigned last month. The group will be led by Bill Nelson as the chairman and chief executive.

headline: Recipe: Veal and Ricotta Meatballs
text: Adapted from Marco Canora

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A map of Central Asia with an article on Saturday about the construction of a bridge linking Tajikistan and Afghanistan misidentified the country shown in the lower left. It is Iran, not Azerbaijan. (Go to Article)

headline: Recipe: Tuna Meatballs
text: Adapted from “The Young Man and the Sea,” by David Pasternack and Ed Levine (Artisan, 2007)

headline: Straphangers’ Warning: Fares May Have to Rise
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will have to raise revenues significantly to stave off looming deficits in the next several years, increasing pressure on the authority to increase transit fares and bridge and tunnel tolls, according to a study by the city’s Independent Budget Office.

headline: A Mastery in Swing Time That Endures for All Time
text: There was a time in American music when Ella Fitzgerald seemed to be an eternal constant, an irresistible force and immovable object rolled into one mighty voice. At once girlish, wise and all-forgiving, Fitzgerald’s singing transcended age, race, sex and genre.

headline: New Jersey Court Voids Death Penalty Conviction
text: TRENTON, June 5  The New Jersey Supreme Court on Tuesday vacated the murder conviction and death sentence of a Pennsylvania man imprisoned since 1994. The court ruled that the trial judge and two lawyers who represented the man had failed to pursue the potential bias of a juror.

headline: To an Equine Athlete Dying Young
text: Caution: Tears will flow from watching “Barbaro,” the HBO Sports documentary that tells the life story of a horse Hemingway would have loved, one who exhibited grace under great pressure. Like the other innocent animals we love, horses “trust us, live alongside us, honoring our many commands,” the narrator, Liev Schreiber, says. “And when we ask them to — they run.”

headline: Donald Johanos, 79, a Conductor of Symphony Orchestras, Is Dead
text: Donald Johanos, a former music director of the Dallas and Honolulu Symphonies and a prominent member of the generation of American conductors who emerged after World War II, died in Naples, Fla., on May 29. He was 79.

headline: Mexican Court’s Media Ruling Shows Support for Competition
text: MEXICO CITY, June 5 — In a defeat for Mexico’s television duopoly, the Supreme Court struck down crucial provisions of a media law on Tuesday, sending a clear message in favor of greater economic competition.

headline: Newark: County Must Change Jail Health Contract
text: A State Superior Court judge yesterday ordered Essex County to reject the winning bidder for the health contract at the county jail and give it to a company that challenged the award, county officials said. The award, made in December to Correctional Health Services, which has held the contract for 15 years, was challenged by a rival company, CFG Health Systems, said Joyce Wilson Harley, the county administrator. Judge Rachel Davidson found that the county had improperly awarded the contract and ordered that CFG be declared the winner. Lori E. Grifa, a lawyer for Correctional Health Services, said it had filed for a stay of the judge’s order.

headline: Mets’ Lineup Gets a Boost as Beltrán Returns
text: The Mets’ struggling offense received a boost last night against Philadelphia when Carlos Beltrán rejoined the lineup after missing three games because of a bruised right knee.

headline: The Wounded Return Home, and Another Battle Begins
text: The broadcast tonight of “War Wounds: Home and Still Fighting” on TLC is early enough that some people might tune it in while eating dinner. That would be a mistake.

headline: Dow Jones Union Seeks Billionaire’s Help in Finding Alternative Bidder to Murdoch
text: Hoping to head off a takeover by Rupert Murdoch, the main union of the Dow Jones & Company employees is shopping around for another bidder and has begun talks with aides to Ronald W. Burkle, a California billionaire, union officials and others said yesterday.

headline: 30 Taliban Reported Drowned as NATO Sinks Boat
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 5  The Afghan Defense Ministry said Tuesday that a boat full of fleeing Taliban fighters had been fired upon by NATO helicopters and sunk in the Helmand River, in southern Afghanistan. All on board, between 20 and 30 guerrillas, drowned, said Gen. Zaher Azimi, a ministry spokesman.

headline: Comptroller’s Aide Wins Upper East Side Assembly Seat
text: Micah Z. Kellner, an aide to the New York City comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., won a special election yesterday for an Assembly seat representing the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

headline: Investing in Prague
text: Since Edward Barner moved to Prague from Los Angeles in 1993 he has bought and sold more than 20 apartments, with an average return of 500 percent on each one. But now Mr. Barner has just two apartments, and even though he is living in one of them, he plans to sell them both.

headline: G.O.P. Candidates at Odds Over Immigration Overhaul
text: The Republican presidential candidates waged verbal combat last night in the Congressional battle over a proposed immigration overhaul, with Senator John McCain, an author of a pending compromise plan, defending the controversial proposals in a Republican debate in Goffstown, N.H., and demanding that his competitors offer “a better idea.”

headline: Study May Fuel Debate Over Title IX’s Effect on Men’s Sports
text: As Title IX commemorates its 35th anniversary this month, a study released yesterday will further agitate the debate over whether it has damaged men’s college athletics and caused the elimination of dozens of men’s teams.

headline: Doll Web Sites Drive Girls to Stay Home and Play
text: Presleigh Montemayor often gets home after a long day and spends some time with her family. Then she logs onto the Internet, leaving the real world and joining a virtual one. But the digital utopia of Second Life is not for her. Presleigh, who is 9 years old, prefers a Web site called Cartoon Doll Emporium.

headline: Irate Fairy Is at the Door; Double-Check the Guest List
text: Gelsey Kirkland did not kill the infant Aurora, as she laughingly threatened to do in a recent interview, when American Ballet Theater performed “The Sleeping Beauty” on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. She didn’t need to. Dancing Carabosse for the first time in this new production, staged by the company’s director, Kevin McKenzie, and Ms. Kirkland, she made the vengeful fairy believably capable of any evil.

headline: Coptic Christian Fights Deportation to Egypt, Fearing Torture
text: An Egyptian Coptic Christian who was permitted to stay in the United States because of the probable threat of torture back home is now fighting deportation on a murder charge in Egypt.

headline: Agency Warns of Surge in Drug-Resistant TB
text: Tuberculosis may reach the point where most new cases in some countries are resistant to many drugs unless far greater efforts are made now to stop the spread of the infection, World Health Organization officials said yesterday.

headline: Georgia: Goldman Sachs Endows King Chair
text: Goldman Sachs Group donated $2 million to endow a chair at Morehouse College in Atlanta that will oversee the collected writings of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The chair will supervise the compilation of 10,000 pieces of Dr. King’s writings and manuscripts, Goldman Sachs said. Dr. King was a 1948 graduate of the all-male, historically black college. A group of civic leaders, businesses and philanthropists based in Atlanta bought the collection, which includes a draft of Dr. King’s 1963 “I Have a Dream” speech, last year after it was to be auctioned by Sotheby’s for more than $30 million.

headline: Food Calendar
text: Free Caffeine Downtown

headline: Anniversary of 1967 War Shows Lasting Divisions
text: JERUSALEM, June 5 — The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, said Tuesday that the Palestinians were on the brink of civil war and that their internal battles were as dangerous to their welfare as Israeli occupation has been, if not more so.

headline: Changing Views on Gays in the Military
text: Bill Clinton’s promise to lift the ban on gays in the military provoked one of the most wrenching fights of his first year in office. It roiled his relationships with Congress and the military, consumed huge amounts of political capital, and ultimately ended in an uneasy compromise: “Don’t ask, don’t tell.”

headline: Scientists Turn to the Internet and Venture Capitalists for Backing
