text: Before the coming of the Internet and venture capital, the discoveries of many scientists came to the attention — and the benefit — of the public only after years or decades. But times have changed.

headline: Praise at U.N. for a New U.S. Envoy’s Inclusive Tactics and Convivial Style
text: UNITED NATIONS, June 5 — One by one, the ambassadors at an unusually jolly diplomatic dinner last month rose to pay tribute to the new American ambassador, Zalmay Khalilzad.

headline: Police Arrest Fourth Suspect in J.F.K. Case
text: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, June 5  The fourth suspect in what the authorities have described as a terrorist plot to ignite jet fuel tanks at Kennedy International Airport in Queens surrendered to the police Tuesday morning, and angrily told reporters after a court hearing that the case against him was a “setup.”

headline: Russia: Putin Wants Moscow Mayor to Stay
text: President Vladimir V. Putin suggested that he would reappoint Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov of Moscow, who had previously said that he would leave office after his term expired in December. The leaders of Russia’s 86 regions, which include Moscow, have served at the president’s behest since constitutional changes passed after the Beslan terrorist attack in 2004. A power broker in his own right, Mr. Luzhkov, above with Mr. Putin, has used his popularity to win two popular elections since his appointment in 1992. At a tour of an experimental affordable housing project in Moscow, Mr. Putin asked the mayor to remain in office, ostensibly to address several outstanding housing problems in the capital. The Kremlin will likely seek to wield Mr. Luzhkov’s influence for its benefit in the forthcoming parliamentary and presidential elections.

headline: Campaign Finance Overhaul Would Rein in Major Donors
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and City Council leaders have agreed on a major overhaul of the city’s campaign finance laws intended to enhance the power of small donors and reduce the influence of those who do business with the city, including real estate developers.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Science Times yesterday about sensory integration disorder in children misspelled the surname of a therapist and researcher who first argued that sensory problems were more than symptoms of other disorders. She is A. Jean Ayres, not Ayers. The article also misspelled the given name of a father whose son received therapy for sensory problems. He is Antony Pougnet, not Anthony.

headline: What’s on Wednesday night
text: 8 P.M. (13) WE LOVE ELLA! A TRIBUTE TO THE FIRST LADY OF SONG “Great Performances” salutes Ella Fitzgerald, left, in honor of what would have been her 90th birthday (April 25) in this concert special taped at the Galen Center of the University of Southern California. Patti Austin, Natalie Cole, K. D. Lang, Nancy Wilson, Wynonna Judd, Stevie Wonder and Ruben Studdard, among others, perform Fitzgerald favorites. Quincy Jones and Ms. Cole are hosts of this 90-minute special, which includes interviews, a slide show and never-before-released vocal tracks.

headline: Voters Send Mixed Signals to Democratic Organization in New Jersey Primaries
text: JERSEY CITY, June 5  Democratic voters in urban New Jersey delivered a mixed message to traditional machine politics in Tuesday’s legislative primaries.

headline: Recipe: Pork Meatballs With Yogurt Dressing
text: Adapted from Akhtar Nawab

headline: Reid Says He Will Seek to End Debate on Immigration Bill
text: WASHINGTON, June 5 — The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, said Tuesday that he would try to force an end to debate on a comprehensive immigration bill, leaving the fate of the legislation in question.

headline: Commuter Ticket to Hades: A Ghost Haunts the Railroad
text: In Takeshi Furusawa’s “Ghost Train,” a group of high school students tries to unravel a mystery that leads the teenagers into the bowels of their city, and into a nest of elements familiar from other Japanese supernatural horror movies.

headline: Pressel Handles Stress of Success
text: Morgan Pressel turned heads for playing through adolescence, becoming the youngest player to qualify for the United States Women’s Open when she was 12 and the youngest to win an L.P.G.A. Tour major, at 18.

headline: British Grocer Set to Dip Toe in U.S. Market
text: LONDON — Britain’s largest retailer, Tesco, is finally ready for its American debut.

headline: Biologists Make Skin Cells Work Like Stem Cells
text: In a surprising advance that could sidestep the ethical debates surrounding stem cell biology, researchers have come much closer to a major goal of regenerative medicine, the conversion of a patient’s cells into specialized tissues that might replace those lost to disease.

headline: The Many Lives of a Dancer, Explored Upon the Stage
text: Over the weekend, it was possible at Lincoln Center to see all the generations of a School of American Ballet dancer’s life onstage. On Saturday afternoon, the curtain rose at the New York State Theater to reveal, at the start of Balanchine’s “Mozartiana,” Kyra Nichols, in her farewell season with New York City Ballet, framed by four tiny girls from the school, who danced the opening Preghiera with her. Ms. Nichols’s way of including the children in her dance of prayer while gently opening herself to the light, to the stage space and to the music made this a sublime image.

headline: Man Dies in Shootout With Police Officers in New Brunswick
text: A 21-year-old man was killed and a police officer wounded in a shootout in New Brunswick, N.J., last night, the Middlesex County prosecutor said.

headline: Extra Virgin Anti-Inflammatories
text: FOR a newcomer to the world of olive oil connoisseurship, the sound effects from the 20 or so tasters at the Los Angeles County Fairgrounds in Pomona, Calif., were startling. The low murmurs of discussion were punctuated by loud, sharp slurps, and loud, sharp coughs. Slurps and coughs, hour after hour. On the second day I made two notes to myself: reread “The Magic Mountain”; check in with Dr. Beauchamp.

headline: Silence = Despotism
text: Stanford, Calif.

headline: Basque Separatists Call Off Cease-Fire in Spain
text: MADRID, June 5 — Spain was bracing for fresh attacks by the Basque separatist group ETA on Tuesday after the group called off a 15-month-old cease-fire and vowed to resume its battle for an independent Basque nation.

headline: Demonstrations at the Group of 8 Summit
text: Several thousand anti-globalization protesters blocked roads and railway lines leading to the Heiligendamm resort.

headline: Gorgeous Gleneagles
text: Glenmor

headline: Preserving the Music
text: Guitar makers are rethinking the notion that there is an inexhaustible supply of wood to make their instruments.

headline: U. S.-Mexico Rivalry Headlines Gold Cup
text: The Concacaf Gold Cup tournament, which began Wednesday, has never carried a great deal of prestige in the wider world of soccer. But among the teams competing for the championship of North and Central America and the Caribbean, the importance of the tournament has grown steadily since the first tournament was staged in 1991.

headline: Scenes of Milford, Pa.
text: This carefully-updated old town is located on the Delaware River about 80 miles from Manhattan.

headline: Frugal Traveler: Nashville
text: The Frugal Traveler finds himself drawn to the older and grittier aspects of Nashville, the heart of the country music world.

headline: Traditional Fishermen in Laos
text: Despite threats to the local fish population, the Mekong River remains one of the largest fishing resources in the world.

headline: Alan Ayckbourn Eases Up
text: The prolific English playwright Alan Ayckbourn, 68, whose plays include "Absurd Person Singular," "The Norman Conquests" and the Tony Award-winning "Bedroom Farce," will step down in 2008 after 37 years as the artistic director of the Stephen Joseph Theater in Scarborough, England, the BBC reported. He will continue to direct his plays at the theater and any new work by him will have its premiere there.

headline: Theater Briefs
text: "The Pirate Queen," the $16 million musical by Alain Boublil and Claude-Michel Schönberg, is giving up the ship on June 17, when it will have played only 85 performances and 32 previews.

headline: Finding Room for an Actor Fit for the Stage
text: When Christian McKay appears on stage in “Rosebud: The Lives of Orson Welles,” one wonders if the casting session took any longer than the time it would to drink a glass of ice water on a hot day. What nature hasn’t already bestowed on him in Wellesian aura and appearance, he meticulously affects. The jowls, the quizzical eyes and sonorous baritone: Mr. McKay is Welles to the soles of his feet, annunciating every word as if the future of proper diction depended on him. There are no girdles here. Mr. McKay lets out his gut (or a quite good facsimile of one), stretching the buttonholes on the fly of his trousers to maximum capacity.

headline: Irony and Other Theatrical Hazards
text: If this review was written in the style of “I.E., in Other Words,” the tedious new satire by the Bats, the resident acting company of the Flea Theater, it might begin something like this: insert snappy introduction putting play in context, followed by short plot description with some dismissive adjectives.

headline: Burritos for Sophocles
text: Vengeance has always been one of the most passionate of human Pursuits and Sophocles’ “Electra” is one of dramatic literature’s most compelling studies of the extremes to which it can lead. Unfortunately, an adaptation of the play by Alfred Preisser being staged by the Classical Theater of Harlem is more of a spoof of a Greek tragedy than a serious attempt to revive one.

headline: From the Lips of a Pop Icon
text: How much you enjoy “All Her Faces: A Portrait of Dusty Springfield” will depend on two things: what sort of activity you’ve engaged in before the performance, and how strong an affection you harbor for the White Lady of Soul.

headline: Colony Captures Libya’s Tamoil in $5.4 Billion Deal
text: The private equity firm Colony Capital agreed to acquire control of Tamoil of Libya for 4 billion euros ($5.4 billion). The Libyan government will retain 35 percent of the company, which operates refineries and gas stations, Colony said.

headline: Commerce Undersecretary to Join Cushman & Wakefield
text: Franklin L. Lavin, under secretary of commerce for international trade, said on Tuesday that he will resign to join the real estate firm Cushman & Wakefield. Mr. Lavin, who prodded China to reduce trade barriers by backing new tariffs on Chinese goods, plans to leave on July 13, less than two years after taking the post.

headline: Former CA Executive Makes Restitution
text: A former sales chief at CA, the software maker, has agreed to pay $29.7 million in restitution after pleading guilty last year to criminal charges in a scheme to raise the company’s quarterly revenue artificially through backdated sales contracts.

headline: I.B.M. Settles Suit Over Stock Expenses
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission said Tuesday that I.B.M. had settled a case in which it had been accused of misleading investors by overestimating the impact of stock-based compensation expenses on quarterly earnings in 2005.

headline: V.C.’s Have a Crush on IceBreaker
text: IceBreaker has landed $7.2 million in new financing, money that the Bellevue, Wash. startup will use to continue marketing its mobile dating service, Crush or Flush. It also plans to use funds to bolster a research and development center in Beijing, where the company employs more than 20 people and is looking to add more.

headline: Third Avenue Adds Managing Director
text: Third Avenue Management, an investment firm led by Martin J. Whitman, said it hired Erik Kleinbeck as a managing director in its client services and business development group. Mr. Kleinbeck, previously a managing director at Sparx Investment & Research, will focus on Third Avenue’s alternative investment vehicles, Third Avenue said.

headline: Firm Launches Synthetic Fund Amid Fee Debate
text: Jerome Abernathy, former head of research at the hedge fund giant Moore Capital Management, opened a new fund on Tuesday that tries to replicate returns generated by the industry, but with lower fees.

headline: Ousted RadioShack Chief Goes it Alone With New Venture
text: After a very public fall from grace, the ousted chief executive of RadioShack, Dave Edmondson, is gearing up for his second-act as an entrepreneur.

headline: Starent Networks Raises $126 Million in I.P.O.
text: Starent Networks, which provides hardware and software for mobile telephone services, raised $126.4 million in an initial public offering Tuesday, above a forecast range. The offering of 10.5 million shares sold for $12 a share, compared with a forecast range of $9 to $11, Reuters reported.

headline: The Private-Equity Approach to Executive Pay
text: With scrutiny of executive pay practices heating up in the United States, the private equity industry may have something to add to the debate.

headline: AstraZeneca C.F.O. Leaves for Goldman Post
text: The British drugmaker AstraZeneca on Wednesday said its chief financial officer, Jon Symonds, is quitting after 10 years, opting for an investment-banking post instead. Mr. Symonds is leaving AstraZeneca in July, and in September he will become a managing director at Goldman Sachs.

headline: Iverness Gets Big Dog Status as Buying Binge Continues
text: Inverness Medical Innovations may not be a household name, but the Massachusetts medical-testing company is becoming a force to be reckoned with as it continues one of the biggest shopping sprees in the healthcare industry.

headline: Shareholders Approve Outback Buyout
text: Shareholders of the owner of the Outback Steakhouse restaurant brand on Tuesday approved a $3.2 billion takeover offer from a private investor group. The consortium, which includes Bain Capital Partners and investment funds affiliated with Catterton Management offered $41.15 a share in cash for OSI Restaurant Partners.

headline: Are Investment Banks Running Too Lean?
text: Top investment banks are struggling to cope with the record volume of deals, and their overworked staffs are in danger of making costly mistakes, The Financial Times reports. Many banks are reluctant to bulk up their staff and the shortages are especially keen in financial hubs in continental Europe and Asia, the article says. One headhunter tells the newspaper that “vice presidents are very stretched with many junior staff working beyond their experience.”

headline: 2 Ex-Putnam Managers Settle Market-Timing Charges
text: Two former fund managers for Putnam Investments of Boston agreed to pay a total of $1.5 million to settle allegations they inappropriately traded mutual fund shares and potentially harmed other fund investors, federal and state regulators said on Tuesday.

headline: Debitel Dials Up Deal for Talkline
text: Debitel, the largest German reseller of mobile phone services, agreed on Tuesday to buy Talkline from TDC of Denmark for 560 million euros ($756 million), adding 3.8 million customers to its rolls.

headline: Hedge Funds and Private Equity: An Uneasy Alliance?
text: Hedge funds and private equity funds seem to have a good routine going, with activist funds goading many companies into buyout deals and then buying the debt used to fund them. But Thorold Barker of The Financial Times cautions that this symbiosis could unravel if and when many of these big buyout deals start to go bad.

headline: Teachers’ Pension and Providence Join Bid for BCE
text: Another bidder for BCE, the parent of Canada’s largest telecommunications company, has officially entered the race.

headline: Tudor Investment Shutters Small-Stock Fund
text: Tudor Investment, the hedge-fund firm run by Paul Tudor Jones, is shutting its $550 million small-company stock fund after returns failed to meet expectations.

headline: Google Forges Deal for PeakStream
text: Google said it has purchased closely held PeakStream, a start-up that sells tools for programming chips with multiple processing units.

headline: Indian Miner to Raise $1.65 Billion in U.S. and Japan Offerings
text: A copper and zinc miner, Vedanta Resources, is raising $1.65 billion through a share offering in the United States and Japan by its main subsidiary, Sterlite Industries. The proceeds of the offer will be used to fund a move into power generation and to buy back a minority shareholding in its zinc business from the Indian government.

headline: G.M. Chief Seeks to Assuage Buyout Fears
text: The chairman and chief executive of General Motors, Rick Wagoner, sought to reassure shareholders at the auto makers annual meeting that the company was not headed for a private equity buyout like its rival, Chrysler, but he shied away from categorical refusal on the subject.

headline: Enel Pays Big for Stake in Russian Power Company
text: Italy’s Enel , which is poised to take over Spain’s biggest utility, will expand its presence in Russia after it beat rivals to buy a one-quarter stake in the Russian wholesale generation company OAO OGK-5 for about $1.52 billion.

headline: Private Equity’s Technology Buying Spree
text: With Elevation Partners‘ investment in Palm, the buyout deal for telecom-equipment firm Avaya and reports of private equity interest in Cadence Design Systems, private equity firms seem to be leaping with open checkbooks into areas where they once feared to tread: technology and telecommunications.

headline: French Regulators Examine Deutsche Bank on Hedge Fund Trades
text: French regulators are examining whether Deutsche Bank enabled hedge funds to trade on inside information, destroying tapes and failing to keep written records of phone conversations when lining up buyers for a 2002 Vivendi Universal securities sale, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Lenders Strike Cautious Note on Private Equity Lending
text: Alarm bells were sounded on Tuesday by two major lenders to buyout shops about the way loans are being handed out to fund the booming private equity sector. Meanwhile, a deal by the Texas Pacific Group for the Japanese electronics maker JVC might also be jeopardized by banks looking to tighten their belts.

headline: Funds Press TD Ameritrade to Make a Deal
text: Steven Cohen seems intent on burnishing his nascent image as a swashbuckling activist shareholder. On Tuesday, TD Ameritrade, owner of Ameritrade, the nation’s largest online broker, said in a regulatory filing that its board has received a letter from SAC Capital and Jana Partners urging the company to find a merger partner, and quickly.

headline: Blackstone’s Accounting Switch to Cut Earnings
text: The Blackstone Group, which is preparing for an initial public offering, dropped plans to adopt a new accounting standard that would have let it book profits at the time of a buyout. The change greatly reduced its pro forma earnings and could make it more difficult for the private equity giant to justify a $34 billion valuation, Breakingviews said.

headline: Getting the Most Out of Your Wi-Fi Menu
text: Whoa, did I learn my lesson!

headline: Prudential to Close Equity Research Unit
text: The analysts at Prudential Equity Group have issued their last buys, holds and sells (or, to be more exact, their last overweights, neutral weights and underweights).

headline: Hands Off the Popemobile!
text: A man apparently attempted to board the Popemobile without permission today as it carried Benedict XVI to his customary weekly audience in St. Peter’s Square.

headline: Dawn of the B-List Republicans
text: Blitzed again? The Republicans debated last night, and Wolf Blitzer won again, suggests another “Talk Clock” infographic from Chris Dodd’s campaign.

headline: Fred Thompson on Fox News Channel
text: While the ten Republican presidential candidates participated in a televised debate this evening, former Senator Fred Thompson appeared on FOX News Channel's "Hannity & Colmes" following the debate. Below is the full rushed transcript.

headline: A Republican Bastion No More?
text: Republican hopes to regain a foothold on the Upper East Side were dashed last night. For years, moderate Republicans held a number of elected positions on the Upper East Side, once home to Mayor John V. Lindsay.

headline: Buzz Over Mayor’s ‘Get a Life’ Remark
text: On Monday, the day before a fourth man in a suspected plot to bomb jet fuel tankers at Kennedy International Airport turned himself in to the authorities, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg waded once again into the emotional discussions of how ordinary residents can conduct themselves in a post-9/11 world.

headline: Wines With a Difference
text: In my column in Wednesday’s paper I pay tribute to that under-recognized group on the margins of wine culture known as wine geeks. I try to make the case that these people play a vital role, not only insuring that we have a wonderful diversity of wine selections now but also in being among the first to discover tomorrow’s must-have bottles.

headline: Debate Outtakes
text: Last night’s debate among the Republican candidates for the G.O.P. presidential nomination gave the top contenders ample time to explain some of their core beliefs. Among the more memorable moments were Senator John McCain’s ardent defense of his belief in the current Iraq war strategy and impassioned defense of his support for the immigration legislation; former Mayor Rudy Giuliani’s succinct responses to questions about the Iraq invasion, terrorism and his humorous comeback to the sound glitches caused by lightning from a storm; and former Gov. Mitt Romney’s elaborative explanation and embrace of his Mormon faith.

headline: Grayz Anatomy
text: In today’s Dining Briefs column, you’ll notice that one of the three briefs talks about dishes being “rehearsed,” in a sense, for the new sort-of-restaurant Grayz, which is scheduled to open in September in midtown.

headline: NASA Chief Regrets Warming Comments
text: The NASA chief regrets but apparently does not retract global warming comments that caused an uproar with climate scientists, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Venice Biennale: Tottering on the Tarmac
text: The slogan of the 52nd annual Venice Biennale’s international art exhibition can be seen everywhere in this city, even in red-and-green advertisements atop the baggage carousels at Marco Polo airport: “Think With the Senses, Feel With the Mind.” When I got here early the other morning, I was feeling with my mind — quite strongly — that my bags had to be coming down that ramp sometime soon. But they kept not coming — 15 minutes, 20, half an hour. The clock on the wall said 11:30 a.m. My body told me it was 5:30 a.m. (as it was back in New York.) The bright sunshine outside seemed like a cruel joke. If art has any power these days, I hope it is the power of making jet lag go away.

headline: A Hybrid of Nonsensical Thinking
text: The Honda Accord Hybrid was killed on Monday. Honda will not have an Accord Hybrid in its line when the next-generation Accord arrives this fall.

headline: Venice Biennale: Scoping Out the Crowds
text: If you arrive in Venice a few days before the Biennale parties and unofficial, really-early, almost-secret, I’m-extremely-important openings, one of the games you can play is: Art Person or Not Art Person. Biennale or not, the city is already packed with tourists by this time of year. On Sunday, few of them looked like they were here to see the latest in contemporary art. But by Tuesday, you could begin to sense the coming invasion. That bald guy with the Grizzly Adams beard and the neck tattoo? Probably an art person. The three British women who boarded my vaporetto all wearing gray peasant dresses that screamed expensive independent designer? No question. Funky glasses and fanny pack? Sneaky, hard to tell. I spotted a woman on the same boat with khaki cigarette pants, expensive hairdo and lime-green ballet flats. I was convinced. But my wife pointed out, “Maybe she’s just Italian.”

headline: Rethinking Not Asking and Not Telling
text: Robin Toner writes about the changing views among Democrats regarding gays serving in the U.S. military.

headline: Challenge to Grocery Deal Leaves Many Asking Why
text: The Federal Trade Commission’s decision to try to block the merger of Whole Foods Market and Wild Oats Markets is getting some shocked reactions from Web commentators — and even the technology-focused blog TechDirt blog is weighing in on the newly troubled supermarket deal.

headline: 2 Degrees of Separation Between Bush & Merkel
text: A Greenpeace banner on the Eiffel Tower, Paris. Christophe Ena/AP

headline: ‘Pulling a Lou’
text: Guest Post by DAN SALTZSTEIN

headline: Giuliani to Skip Iowa Straw Poll
text: In a move that bucks years of tradition, Rudolph W. Giuliani has decided not to compete in the earliest indicator of where Republican primary voters stand, the Ames Iowa straw poll.

headline: Venice Biennale: Some Very Familiar Faces
text: One of the earliest parties of the rolling Biennale opening week here was held on the roof and grounds of the Peggy Guggenheim Collection on the Grand Canal, to mark the opening of “All in the Present Must Be Transformed: Matthew Barney and Joseph Beuys,” a show examining affinities between the work of the two groundbreaking artists, one of whom (Beuys) gravitated toward molten fat as a sculptural material and the other (Barney) toward petroleum jelly. While not officially part of the Biennale, the show was timed to coincide with it, moving from the Deutsche Guggenheim in Berlin, where it originated.

headline: Baseball’s Fantasy World
text: In this month’s issue of PLAY, Bryan Curtis argues that fans who play fantasy baseball are part of an intellectual revolution, having devised a way to interact with the game that doesn’t depend on watching the actual games for enjoyment. At PLAY we’re wondering: How has fantasy baseball changed the relationship between fans and the game?

headline: Merrill Lures Co-Head of Morgan’s Power Group
text: Jonathan Grundy has resigned from Morgan Stanley to join Merrill Lynch as head of energy, power, and infrastructure origination for Europe, the Middle East, and Africa. Mr. Grundy had been co-head of Morgan Stanley’s power and utilities group.

headline: Venice Biennale: Revenge of the Raptors
text: One of the artists who seems to be getting a lot of attention is also among the youngest, David Altmejd, 32, representing Canada. He has been known mostly for his recurrent werewolf motif: heads of fanged changelings sprouting crystals and mirrors and chains, as if decaying or exploding. “It’s partly about our fear of our animal instincts,” Andrea Rosen, Mr. Altmejd’s dealer, says, “but transformed into things that are beautiful.”

headline: Activists’ Deal Push Boosts Brokers’ Shares
text: In an otherwise dismal day for the stock market, investors in TD Ameritrade have something to celebrate. Shares in the nation’s largest online broker rose 4.75 percent Wednesday, after the company disclosed that two hedge funds are calling for it to explore a sale. And the stock of one of their preferred merger partners shot up even more.

headline: A More Friendly Facade?
text: Dear Betsy, Richard, Julien, Johan, Jay  and other readers who commented that the facade is too imposing and formal, and reminiscent of a “McMansion:”

headline: Clinton Book Review: First You See It…
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign operation includes a website called HillaryHub.com  — a campaign newsroom of sorts, with links to articles and blog items that are flattering to Mrs. Clinton.

headline: Matching All Those Billions
text: Want to win elected office? First, become a billionaire.

headline: An Idea From Down Under: Law Firm I.P.O.’s
text: Given that it’s not legal, American law firms are unlikely to be holding initial public offerings any time soon. But it has already happened in Australia, and, according to American Lawyer, it is apt to happen in Britain within a few years.

headline: Saving the Spacesuit for History
text: The history of the American spacesuit may be missing a chapter if NASA doesn’t change its plans.

headline: Candidates Finals Begin and It Was a Good Day to Play White
text: Levon Aronian, Peter Leko and Alexander Grischuk, all playing White, took the lead in their final candidates matches with victories in the first games. The matches are to determine qualifiers for the world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. They are being played in Elista, Kalmykia. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.

headline: Notes on the News
text: Some news items that turned up in our dolphin-safe Web nets.

headline: CBOT Executives Warn of Dangers in ICE Bid
text: The war of words over the Chicago Board of Trade grew more hostile on Wednesday as its parent company warned of catastrophe if the IntercontinentalExchange took over the exchange.

headline: Movie Minutes: '12:08 East'
text: The New York Times Co-Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "1208 East of Bucharest," a bittersweet look back at the 1989 Romanian revolution.

headline: Down by the Dumpster
text: Drew Cline, the editorial page editor of New Hampshire’s Union Leader, files an on-the-scene report from the “activists’ corral” outside last night’s Republican presidential debate, where the turnout by Brownback supporters was, to put it politely, unimpressive. Cline writes on his Union Leader blog:

headline: Blogtalk: The Debate From the Right
text: Conservative bloggers and pundits have been weighing in with their thoughts on last night’s Republican debate in New Hampshire, and while the reviews are somewhat mixed, many gave high marks to former mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

headline: The Ultimate Computer Challenge?
text: A six-game match between two computer programs billed as the Ultimate Computer Challenge kicked off today in Elista, Kalmykia. The match, between versions of commercially available software programs, is running concurrently with the final candidates matches to select human qualifiers for the world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. In fact, the computer match is taking place on the same playing stage as the candidates finals.

headline: Movie Minutes: 'La Vie en Rose'
text: The New York Times Co-Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "La Vie en Rose," about the legendary French singer Edith Piaf.

headline: Do a Little, Talk a Lot
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders met for their latest public meeting this afternoon — their fifth such session in the last five weeks.

headline: McCain to Skip Ames Poll, Too
text: Strike Two for the Ames Iowa Straw Poll. Senator John McCain has decided to follow his Republican rival, Rudolph W. Giuliani, and not take part in the summer event.

headline: Watersports at Aquafest in Shek O
text: Addendum: This event, cancelled because of rain, is now on June 23. Updated info at www.d2adrenaline.com.

headline: Fund-Raisers, Belly-Busters
text: We get even hungrier than usual on Wednesdays, when the newspapers run their mouth-watering food features. Apparently, the campaigns are responding to the same Pavlovian pages with their food-themed fund-raising gimmicks.

headline: Serbia’s on a Hot Streak
text: Sure, Kosovo still wants out and grim reminders of war keep emerging, but Serbians are feeling the love lately in European centers of politics, sport and culture.

headline: The News From Shea Hospital
text: Most of the injury news coming out of the Mets’ clubhouse recently has revolved around their banged-up outfield. Not surprisingly, Moises Alou’s left quadriceps and Shawn Green’s broken right foot were again on the tip of Willie Randolph’s tongue, although a few more injuries emerged, too.

headline: ‘Sopranos’ Grief
text: I welcome any advice anyone has about a certain problem: How is a person supposed to live without “The Sopranos”?

headline: Willie Seinfeld?
text: Willie Randolph will never be confused with, say, Dave Chappelle or Jerry Seinfeld or Insert Your Favorite Comedian Here, but for some reason during his pregame interview session with reporters (perhaps because the ESPN announcers were listening in) he was in a particularly good mood. I even laughed out loud a few times.

headline: Talkin’ Baseball With the Yankees
text: Alex Rodriguez is at his best when he’s stripped away from the politics of being A-Rod and he just talks about baseball. There are few players I’ve ever covered who can get as in-depth on the game when they want to.

headline: Then and Now
text: I spent almost a year in the Sunni Triangle. I somehow avoided the hundreds of mortar attacks on my base, the I.E.D.s on some of the most dangerous roads in Iraq, the R.P.G. fired at my convoy. It’s the path of the ages I feel I’ve traveled, where able bodied Americans go to war for their country, either by choice or not, and the best way to illustrate my journey is with a simple then and now. It is a desert full of memories I can conjure up, and every grain of sand is in ultra-sharp focus like a 7-megapixel photo.

headline: Your Comments on my China-Guantanamo Column
text: In Thursday’s column, my last from the China trip, I write about human rights abuses in China — and the way our own American policies undermine our moral authority and ability to raise these concerns. Please post your comments on it here.

headline: Synthetic v. Natural Pesticides
text: I’ve been getting questions about the biochemist Bruce Ames’ work, which I briefly cite in the Findings column as evidence that synthetic pesticides in our diet are a minuscule risk for cancer. So let me elaborate on the work done by him and his colleague, Lois Swirsky Gold, the director of the Carcinogenic Potency Project at Berkeley.

headline: Furor Over Proposed Jail Rules
text: Sewell Chan reports from City Council hearings on the Board of Corrections' proposed rules on the treatment of prisoners.

headline: Despite the Dumb Jokes, Stereotypes May Reflect Some Smart Choices
text: A quick Web search identifies thousands of jokes about dumb blondes, this one among them: A married couple were awakened by a call at 2 a.m. The wife, a blonde, picked up the phone, listened a moment and said, “How should I know, that’s 200 miles from here!” and hung up. Her husband asked, “Who was that?” She replied, “I don’t know; some woman wanting to know if the coast is clear.”

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article yesterday about Sameh Khouzam, a man accused of murder who says he will be tortured if he is deported back to Egypt, misspelled the surname of a spokesman for Immigration and Customs Enforcement who said there were extensive deliberations within the government about deporting Mr. Khouzam. He is Marc Raimondi, not Raimondo.

headline: Wang Shows Effectiveness Good Pitching Can Have
text: CHICAGO, June 6  The signs of life are hard to miss now. The Yankees have won five of their last seven games, with dormant bats stirring and a defense that is starting to make a difference.

headline: Away From the Set but Not Away From HDTV
text: It’s summertime, and catching your favorite TV shows is not so easy when you are on vacation or a weekend outing. A cheap, portable TV is one option, but what if you’ve developed a taste for high definition? Plextor has come out with its Mini Digital HDTV Receiver, which connects to a laptop’s U.S.B. port. The receiver, which sells for $99 and is available at www.plextor.com, has an external antenna and software that scans for over-the-air HD signals.

headline: Through Erik Satie’s Music, a Trip Back in Time to the Soundless and the Surreal
text: “It’s so intense I can’t stand it,” the pianist Bruce Levingston said laughingly after playing Erik Satie’s Sarabande No. 2, Gnossienne No. 4 and Gymnopédie No. 1 to open his concert at the French Institute Alliance Française’s Florence Gould Hall on Tuesday.

headline: Chinese Auto Parts Enter the Global Market
text: JINZHOU, China — Zhao Qingjie’s favorite book, he says, is a Chinese translation of Lee A. Iacocca’s autobiography.

text: ITunes and Vista,

headline: As Cellphones Multiply, Phone Books Get Slimmer
text: Parents have used them as booster chairs for children. Marksmen have fired at them for target practice. And musclemen have ripped them in half as a show of strength.

headline: Judge Rejects Main Argument of Effort to Stop Atlantic Yards Project in Brooklyn
text: A federal judge yesterday dismissed the most significant lawsuit against the Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn, dealing a major setback to opponents of the $4 billion project.

headline: Tough Art With a Candy Center
text: VENICE, June 6 — The artist Felix Gonzalez-Torres, who died of AIDS in 1996 at 38, did not exactly fit the profile of a secret agent, an infiltrator foiling lines of defense. He was a generous man with a handsome, cherubic face and wicked sense of humor. He loved cats. And some of his best-known art is made of candy, mounds of it, free for the taking and endlessly replenished, a Willy Wonka vision of Post-Minimalism.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about GlaxoSmithKline’s efforts to market its diabetes treatment Avandia to African-Americans, misstated the name of a television network that is typically used when marketers want to reach black audiences. It is Black Entertainment Television, or BET  not the Black Entertainment Network.

headline: Decisively, One Women’s Team Earns Itself a Trip to Shanghai
text: The first team has qualified for the world championships from the trials taking place in Schaumburg, Ill.

headline: Loving New Orleans, With a Ready Escape
text: NEW ORLEANS

headline: Garden Q.&A.
text: Droopy Dahlias

headline: Tough Shot for Mickelson
text: Phil Mickelson, profiled as "Mr. Unpredictable” by Charles McGrath in this month’s PLAY, has opted for a cortisone shot in his injured left wrist and a week of rest, adding another level of uncertainty to his effort to win his first United States Open next week (as if the specter of last year’s 18th-hole meltdown at Winged Foot wasn’t enough). Mickelson is skipping this week’s Stanford St. Jude Championship and says he’ll be fine for the Open, at the Oakmont Country Club in Pittsburgh, but ailing wrists and deep rough don’t make an ideal golf pairing. After all, Mickelson injured the wrist during a recent practice round at Oakmont. Pros who are practicing there this week are saying the course is tougher than Winged Foot, where the winning score was 5 over. There’s already enough preying on a golfer’s mind at a U.S. Open — it features the harshest conditions and the most grueling mental challenge. Wondering whether your wrist can hold up is the last thing you need. Looks like Mickelson is already down a few strokes.

headline: Out From the Ethical Deep Freeze
text: Just as House Democrats’ fervid promises of ethics reform are running out of steam comes the bribery indictment of one of their own, William Jefferson, the Louisiana representative accused of stashing $90,000 in marked bills in his home freezer. Surely the image of Mr. Jefferson allegedly using the Congressional dining room to transact quid-pro-quo corruption schemes is the strongest possible wake-up call for foot-dragging members to face up to the need for aggressive ethics enforcement. The existing ethics committee produced cobwebs, not early-warning alerts, as recent scandals were launching several lawmakers, staffers and lobbyists on prison careers.

headline: Smooth Lips for Men (Yes, Men!)
text: HE carries one in his pocket, said Landon Yeager, an auditor from Dallas. “One in my gym bag, one in my briefcase, one in my desk and one in my car.”

headline: The Virtually Untrammeled Power of Presidential Pardons
text: WASHINGTON, June 6 — When it comes to high-profile presidential pardons, the big one, of course, was President Gerald R. Ford’s pardon of Richard M. Nixon.

headline: Duncan Has Parker. James Has Himself.
text: SAN ANTONIO, June 6 — The Cleveland Cavaliers bumped into their first logistical challenge here Wednesday, on the eve of their first N.B.A. finals: Who takes the microphone at the league-mandated news conference?

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some copies on May 11 about the arrest of a New York police officer on charges of killing his estranged girlfriend misspelled the name of a Queens restaurant where they had met in an effort to reconcile. It is the Kaieteur Restaurant & Sports Bar  not Kiteur.

headline: At Group of 8 Meeting, Bush Rebuffs Germany on Cutting Emissions
text: ROSTOCK, Germany, June 6 — As leaders of wealthy nations converged Wednesday on a Baltic Sea resort for their annual meeting, the White House effectively derailed a climate change initiative backed by one of President Bush’s strongest European allies, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany.

headline: Where Is the Yankees’ Real First Baseman?
text: While the Yankees hold their breath waiting for Roger Clemens to rescue their rotation, they continue to suffer from the absence of a real Yankee first baseman.

headline: Traveling Ever Lighter
text: ONE effortless way for hikers to pick up the pace is to carry lighter gear.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report by the BBC in the “Arts, Briefly” column yesterday, about the intention of the British playwright Alan Ayckbourn to retire next year from his post as artistic director of the Stephen Joseph Theater in Scarborough, England, misstated the year he was knighted. It was 1997, not this year.

headline: A Long, Uncertain Path for New Cell Technique
text: While intriguing, a new approach for producing embryonic stem cells faces considerable hurdles before it can be used to develop medical treatments, executives from stem cell and other biotechnology companies said yesterday.

headline: Arnold Lappert, 86, Who Heard Corregidor Fall, Is Dead
text: Arnold Lappert, the Army radio technician in Hawaii who received the last messages from the island of Corregidor before its surrender to the Japanese in May 1942, and nearly four years later realized a quest to find the fellow New Yorker who sent those final desperate words, died Friday in Dania, Fla. He was 86.

headline: Bracing for the Demise of the Big Guy
text: CLIFTON, N.J.

headline: Sharapova Loses in French Open Semis
text: PARIS, June 7 — On her way to beating Maria Sharapova today to make it to the French Open final, Ana Ivanovic hardly said a word.

headline: Warning: Don’t Swat That Fly, She May Be One of the Stars
text: David Ives’s “Time Flies & Others by Ives” is popular among acting students, and it’s not just because the amusing collection of compact one-acts features comic roles perfect for performers who love to show off. Receiving a spirited production by the director Jordana Kritzer, this show also speaks quite sympathetically to people struggling to make a way for themselves. They are comedies that embrace the little guy — or, in the case of the first playlet, the little fly.

headline: Defeat’s Killing Fields
text: SOME opponents of the Iraq war are toying with the idea of American defeat. A number of them are simply predicting it, while others advocate measures that would make it more likely. Lending intellectual respectability to all this is an argument that takes a strange comfort from the outcome of the Vietnam War. The defeat of the American enterprise in Indochina, it is said, turned out not to be as bad as expected. The United States recovered, and no lasting price was paid.

headline: A Voice for Small Business
text: Steven C. Preston, 46, a former executive vice president at ServiceMaster, became administrator of the Small Business Administration in July 2006. He sat down recently in his Washington office to discuss his efforts and those of Congress to overhaul the agency, which has been hit with budget and staff cuts. Following are excerpts:

headline: Partisan Battles Mark End of Regular Hartford Session
text: HARTFORD, June 7 — As the state legislature prepared to end its regular lawmaking session on Wednesday, there were times when the political leaders could not even agree to disagree.

headline: Pull Over, You With the Lead Foot: Your TV Career Awaits
text: True-crime reality shows can be named after the enforcers (“Dog the Bounty Hunter”), the miscreants (“America’s Most Wanted”) or both (“Bandits vs. Smokies”). The creators of “Speeders,” which makes its debut tonight on Court TV, went with the bad guys — perhaps because the natural alternative, “Traffic Cops,” would have made it just a little too obvious where they got their ideas.

headline: Bombs Hit Shiites in Baghdad; Turkish Threats Grow Acute
text: BAGHDAD, June 6  A pair of car bombs struck one of the most heavily protected Shiite areas on Wednesday, the Kadhimiya district of Baghdad, killing three people and wounding 25, the Iraqi police said.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Talking Business column in Business Day on May 26, about Home Depot, referred incorrectly to protesters at the company’s 2006 annual meeting for shareholders. A number of workers protested the compensation of Bob Nardelli, the chief executive at the time, but only one employee who attended  not several  wore a chicken suit as part of the demonstration.

headline: Jack Valenti’s Memoir Suffers Without a Key Salesman
text: LOS ANGELES, June 6 — Jack Valenti’s death has created a marketing problem that would have challenged even him.

headline: For Student Play About Iraq War, Banned in School, Curtains Finally Go Up in Connecticut
text: FAIRFIELD, Conn., June 6 — Three months after their principal canceled a school production they had prepared on the war in Iraq, a group of Wilton High School students staged a dramatic reading of the play Wednesday night to a packed house at a nearby theater.

headline: Moss Expects to Produce for Patriots
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., June 6  Randy Moss smiled at the suggestion that joining the New England Patriots marked a new beginning.

headline: State School Standards Vary Widely in Study
text: What students must learn to be deemed academically proficient varies drastically from state to state, the United States Department of Education said today in a report that, for the first time, showed the specific extent of the differences.

headline: Doctor Says He Was Assailed for Challenging Drug’s Safety
text: WASHINGTON, June 6 — The business of developing and selling new drugs is fraught with peril and setbacks. Billions of dollars are at stake. Nerves are on edge. Tempers flare.

headline: Cuomo Plans to Broaden Student-Lending Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON, June 6 — Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, whose scrutiny of student loans has exposed ties between universities and lenders, said Wednesday that he was broadening his inquiry to examine the criteria lenders use when making loans, and whether they violate civil rights statutes.

headline: Can the Americans Right the Ship?
text: What will a reported $200 million get you en route to the America’s Cup? For BMW Oracle, the American team owned by Larry Ellison, it got them “thumped” by Luna Rossa, the Italian team with more shallow pockets, says John Tayman, who wrote about the America’s Cup for this month’s issue of PLAY.

headline: Heartthrob Swooning and Concert T-Shirts
text: WANTAGH, N.Y., June 5 — It was a breezy Tuesday night here at the Nikon at Jones Beach Theater, and the stands were filled with screaming teenagers and a few nonscreaming parents. Early on, Pete Wentz, the bassist and lead celebrity — but not lead singer — of Fall Out Boy, took a moment to reassure the nonscreamers.

headline: Brooklyn: Universities Pledge Emissions Cuts
text: The presidents of nine universities in New York City promised yesterday to cut greenhouse gas emissions from their campuses by 30 percent over the next 10 years. The pledges, made during a news conference at Pratt Institute, came in response to a challenge by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has set the same objectives for all city-owned buildings as part of his environmental sustainability plan for the city. According to a city study, buildings account for nearly 80 percent of the city’s greenhouse gas emissions, which have been linked to global warming. The participating schools are Barnard, Columbia, Cooper Union, all 23 campuses of the City University of New York, Fordham, New York University, Pratt, St. John’s University and the New School. Asked if the retrofits might require tuition increases, the president of one university said it was a possibility; others said they would seek other financing.

headline: Kiwis Earn Cup Rematch Against Their Top Rival
text: VALENCIA, Spain, June 6  “Bring it home,” read the T-shirts of the New Zealanders who have turned this distant harbor into a sunny enclave of their cloudier land.

headline: A Dark, Rock ’n’ Roll Oasis in the Shine of the Hamptons
text: IF you are not acquainted with the oeuvre of John Varvatos, the first things you need to know are the following: he invented the boxer brief for Calvin Klein and, in partnership with Converse, the laceless Chuck Taylor.

headline: Brooklyn: Hearing for Airport Defendant Postponed
text: A detention hearing in Federal District Court for one of four men charged in a plot to blow up fuel lines at Kennedy Airport was postponed yesterday after the defendant, Russell Defreitas, 63, decided not to seek bail at this time, prosecutors said. A new hearing date was not set yesterday afternoon.

headline: I.R.S. Moves to Close Tax Shelter Shortly After I.B.M. Uses It to Save $1.6 Billion
text: For the second time in 12 months, the government has moved to block a tax shelter that had been aimed at converting billions of dollars of corporate profits, on which taxes have yet to be paid, into profits that will never be taxed.

headline: Calmer Talk From U.S. and Russia
text: HEILIGENDAMM, Germany, June 6  Russia and the United States on Wednesday appeared to step back from their confrontation over American plans for installations in Europe relating to a missile shield, as President Bush said Russia was not a threat to Europe and the Russian foreign minister withdrew a threat to pull out of a conventional arms treaty.

headline: Curlin Gets His Chance to Become a Big Star
text: As good as he is, Curlin has never been the big star. There were 20 horses in the Kentucky Derby, too many for any one to stand out as the one to watch. In the Preakness Stakes, it was all about Street Sense, which was no surprise considering he was dominant two weeks earlier in the Derby.

headline: To Appeal to Women, Too, Gadgets Go Beyond ‘Cute’ and ‘Pink’
text: Nancy Duarte professes no affection or affinity for consumer electronics. Despite being a founder of a presentation technology company in Silicon Valley, she does not go gaga for gigabytes. “I’m not typically wired and connected,” Ms. Duarte said without apology. “I don’t have a belt with all things electronic hanging off of it. I’m not a BlackBerry person.”

text: BEIJING

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,485 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

text: An article yesterday about Sameh Khouzam, a man accused of murder who says he will be tortured if he is deported back to Egypt, misspelled the surname of a spokesman for Immigration and Customs Enforcement who said there were extensive deliberations within the government about deporting Mr. Khouzam. He is Marc Raimondi, not Raimondo. (Go to Article)

headline: India Has Fewer AIDS Victims Than Thought
text: NEW DELHI, June 7 — India, which has repeatedly been accused of denying the size of its AIDS epidemic, probably has millions fewer victims than has been widely believed, according to a new household survey that has not yet been released.

headline: Ducks Bring Cup to the West Coast
text: ANAHEIM, Calif., June 6 — The Anaheim Ducks got their Disney ending after all.

headline: Pennsylvania Republican, Convicted in ’80s Bribery, Backs Giuliani
text: In a recent letter to donors, Robert B. Asher, a prominent Pennsylvania Republican and prolific fund-raiser, wrote, “I am proud to say that I have agreed to be the state political chairman for Mayor Rudy Giuliani.”

headline: From Database to Crime Scene: Network Is Potent Police Weapon
text: By the time a police van pulled up outside a Morningside Heights apartment on April 14 where a 23-year-old Columbia University graduate student had been tortured for 19 hours, her assailant was long gone. But inside the van, laptop computers were humming with a wireless link to a high-tech nerve center in Police Headquarters, next to the Manhattan approach to the Brooklyn Bridge.

headline: When a High-Definition Picture Is Too Good to Believe, See How It Handles This Test Disc
text: With the specially produced videos that play in electronics stores, those HDTVs and DVD players produce pictures so astounding you can scarcely believe your eyes.

headline: From Pucker and Pout to Hip-Hop Hit
text: RUN-D.M.C. had its Adidas, Busta Rhymes had his Courvoisier and Lil’ Kim, the fashion plate turned convicted perjurer, has used her couplets to praise the work of everyone from Marc Jacobs to Jacob the Jeweler.

headline: TB Patient Gives His Account to Congress
text: In a Senate hearing, Andrew Speaker yesterday contradicted some accounts by government officials about the timing of who knew what and when about his plans to travel abroad after being told that he had extremely drug-resistant tuberculosis.

headline: Brooklyn: Sentence for Practicing Law Without a License
text: A woman who represented clients in Family Court without a license to practice law was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to five years’ probation. Law enforcement officials said that the woman, Natasha Riley, 44, represented at least seven clients, including minors seeking disposition of criminal charges and parents seeking child custody, charging $300 to $900 per court appearance. At one hearing, law enforcement officials said, Ms. Riley offered an objection couched in a barnyard epithet, raising the suspicions of the judge. Ms. Riley, who pleaded guilty to filing a false instrument, was also ordered to repay her clients $3,267.

headline: Biologists Make Skin Cells Work Like Stem Cells
text: In a surprising advance that could sidestep the ethical debates surrounding stem cell biology, researchers have come much closer to a major goal of regenerative medicine, the conversion of a patient’s cells into specialized tissues that might replace those lost to disease.

headline: This Gehry Work to Revolve Around Play, as in Ground
text: Frank Gehry, the architect known for buildings adorned with undulating banners of titanium, is set to make his first foray into the world of monkey bars and swings with a new playground at Battery Park, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday.

headline: Ballot Boxes? Yes. Actual Democracy? Tough Question.
text: CAIRO, June 6 — This is election season in the Middle East. Syria just held presidential and parliamentary elections. Algeria held parliamentary elections. Egyptians will be asked to vote next week on a new upper house of Parliament. There will soon be elections in Jordan, Morocco and Oman, followed by elections in Qatar. So is democracy suddenly taking root in the strongman’s last regional stronghold?

headline: Stocks Decline on Inflation Fears
text: For the second straight day, Wall Street recoiled today at the prospect that inflation would not settle down enough to suit the Federal Reserve. And investors appeared to worry not only that interest rates will stay where they are, but that the Fed could raise them even higher.

headline: Pakistan Arrests 300 Workers From Opposition
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 6 — The police have arrested more than 300 political party workers over the past few days in a crackdown before a protest planned this week against new government curbs on the news media, a government official acknowledged Wednesday.

headline: Clemens Appears Set to Return on Saturday
text: CHICAGO, June 6  Roger Clemens threw batting practice Wednesday in Tampa, Fla., and he seemed to have passed the final test before he rejoins the Yankees on Saturday against the Pittsburgh Pirates.

headline: Libby and the Scales of Justice (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Administration Seeks Overhaul of Patent System
text: The Bush administration wants to revamp the nation’s patent system, requiring better information from inventors and allowing public scrutiny of applications, according to the patent office’s chief.

headline: F.D.A. Issues Strictest Warning on Diabetes Drugs
text: WASHINGTON, June 6  The Food and Drug Administration has called for the toughest safety warning on two diabetes drugs, Avandia and Actos, whose health risks have become a focus of Congressional concern.

headline: Vote on New Rules for Jail Inmates Is Delayed
text: The board that oversees the city’s Department of Correction has put off a final vote on changes to the rules governing the daily lives of city inmates — the most significant changes since 1978 — after an outcry by the City Bar Association, the Legal Aid Society and other groups that have called the changes draconian and inhumane.

headline: China Reminds Hong Kong Who’s Boss
text: Wu Bangguo, the chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People’s Congress, said at a conference in Beijing that Hong Kong had considerable autonomy only because the central government had chosen to authorize that autonomy. Under the Sino-British Joint Declaration of 1984, China promised Britain that as part of the return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule China would preserve “a high degree of autonomy” for the territory. But Chinese officials focus these days on the Basic Law, a Beijing-drafted document that serves as Hong Kong’s mini-constitution and gives broad powers to the Standing Committee in Beijing to set policy in Hong Kong by interpreting the territory’s laws. Mr. Wu spoke ahead of the 10th anniversary on July 1 of Hong Kong’s return to China.

headline: Independence Still the Issue at Dow Jones
text: In 1981, Rupert Murdoch and a division of his News Corporation made extraordinary promises about not meddling in the news pages of The Times of London and The Sunday Times, which they were about to take over. But in short order, no one doubted who was firmly in control of the newsrooms.

headline: Residential Sales
text: Manhattan

headline: A Little Bit Country, a Little Bit Jersey
text: THE prospect of rocking to Li’l Anne and Hot Cayenne and savoring boiled crayfish and grilled alligator sausage sent visitors in streams last week to Michael Arnone’s Crawfish Festival, where they peeled off their shirts — and their citified ways. The crowd at the Sussex County Fairgrounds in Augusta, N.J., swapped a buttoned-down style for one best described as country-festive, showing off straw hats, riotously colorful bandanas and meadow-sweeping patchwork skirts.

headline: It Takes a Rule Breaker to Create Dance for Rebels
text: At the premiere of Bill T. Jones and Arnie Zane’s dance piece “Secret Pastures” in 1985, Mr. Zane’s parents noticed Madonna and Andy Warhol two rows behind them. Still skeptical about their son’s involvement with Mr. Jones on and off stage and the couple’s confrontational, self-revealing dances, they were nonetheless impressed. “Now you guys are beginning to get somewhere,” Mr. Zane’s father told them. “If you don’t blow it, maybe you’ll get to Broadway.”

headline: Saudi Said to Receive Money for British Arms Deal
text: LONDON, June 7 — Confronted today with fresh allegations of impropriety in a major British arms deal with Saudi Arabia, Prime Minister Tony Blair once again defended his decision to cancel an official inquiry into the multi-billion-dollar agreement.

headline: For Hikers in a Hurry to Get Fit Fast
text: SO many trails, so little time. With summer around the corner in the Pacific Northwest, Dan Lauren, 48, faces this frustrating state of affairs every weekend.

headline: More Fears on Inflation Hit Stocks
text: After rising almost uninterruptedly for three months, the stock market tumbled for a second day yesterday over fears that inflation is not settling down enough to satisfy the Federal Reserve.

headline: Manhattan: City Worker Charged Over Water Tests
text: A city employee who was supposed to check the purity of New York City’s drinking water was charged in Federal District Court yesterday with making false entries in official water-monitoring records. The man, Nicholas Miritello, 44, of Wappingers Falls, is charged with four instances of recording test results in 2005 on the cloudiness of water that he had not actually tested, federal prosecutors said. If convicted, he faces a maximum of 20 years in prison. The Department of Environmental Protection, which runs the water system, has been under federal oversight since 2001 because of similar record-keeping irregularities and other violations of federal law.

headline: Stealing the Scene Along With the Store
text: ON Monday night, the 33-year-old designer Phillip Lim, who worked quietly behind the scenes in other designers’ studios for a decade before putting his name on a label that is now sold at Neiman Marcus, won the fashion industry’s highest award for emerging talent. Yet his obvious pleasure at being recognized by the Council of Fashion Designers of America at its annual ceremony must have been tempered by the fact that he was handed his statuette by two women who also call themselves young designers — Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen.

headline: Before Punishing Giambi, Selig Wants His Help
text: After Jason Giambi of the Yankees tacitly admitted last month to using steroids, Commissioner Bud Selig was placed in an awkward position. Selig wants to show that he is tough on steroid users, but punishing Giambi is problematic because if he used steroids, it occurred before Major League Baseball punished players for using performance-enhancing substances.

headline: Tentative Deal Reached for Darfur Peacekeeping Force
text: UNITED NATIONS, June 6  The United Nations and the African Union struck a tentative deal on Wednesday to end disagreement over the command of a 23,000-soldier joint peacekeeping force proposed for Darfur.

headline: Next Week
text: Charles McGrath looks at the United States Open at Oakmont Country Club in Pittsburgh and whether Phil Mickelson, if he’s recovered from a minor wrist injury, can recover in a larger sense from his meltdown on the final hole of last year’s Open at Winged Foot. Plus, Gretchen Reynolds on one of the risks of summer activity: heat illness.

headline: A Room of Sound From Golf Ball-Size Speakers (Plus Subwoofer)
text: When the wee home audio gremlins invade your home at night to change your wireless settings and turn up your TV, they will be quite enamored with the Sony DAV-IS10 audio system and its five tiny speakers. The system also includes a larger subwoofer, a DVD/CD player and a radio receiver.

headline: Baseball’s Fantasy World
text: In this month’s issue of PLAY, Bryan Curtis argues that fans who play fantasy baseball are part of an intellectual revolution, having devised a way to interact with the game that doesn’t depend on watching the actual games for enjoyment. At PLAY we’re wondering: How has fantasy baseball changed the relationship between fans and the game?

headline: On a Corner, a Shutter Clicks as Poets and Punks Pass in Review
text: It was getting close to midnight when a man who goes by the name Swami taped a hand-lettered placard reading “Pearls Before Swine” to a phone booth on the west side of Avenue A in Lower Manhattan.

headline: A Lifetime Spent Fleeing the Savagery That Follows
text: Born in filth on a ship full of German refugees in New York harbor in 1936, Rebecca Schwart, like so many of Joyce Carol Oates’s heroines, will live a life touched by enough violence to supply a slasher movie. At 13 she is cornered by her shotgun-wielding father, the eponymous gravedigger, who has killed a man and blown his wife into a headless heap inside their hovel near the cemetery gates. Instead of murdering his daughter too, he sends himself into oblivion, showering her with gore. “She’d wiped that face off her own damn face!” Ms. Oates writes of Rebecca. “She’d picked that face out of her hair.”

headline: Researchers Detect Variations in DNA That Underlie Seven Common Diseases
text: Applying a new genomic technique to a large group of patients, researchers in Britain have detected DNA variations that underlie seven common diseases, discovering unexpected links between them.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts on Monday about the Rock Bottom Remainders, a rock band of popular authors, misspelled the given name of a singer who performed with the band at Webster Hall on Friday night. She is Lesley Gore, not Leslie.

headline: Shirley: Boy Drowns in Pool
text: A Long Island toddler drowned in a neighbor’s pool yesterday after wandering away from home, the Suffolk County police said. The boy, Anthony Muniz, 3, was reported missing by his mother, Denise Morrisette of Auborn Avenue, shortly after 9 a.m., the police said. After searching the neighborhood and knocking on doors, neighbors and Ms. Morrisette found the boy in a neighbor’s pool. The police said the in-ground pool had been properly fenced. Compiled by John Sullivan

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about a plan to return straying bison to Yellowstone National Park referred incorrectly in some copies to the type of animals from a herd north of the park that were found infected with brucellosis last month. They were cattle, not bison.

headline: 2012 Olympic Logo: Sparks Precede the Flame
text: LONDON, June 6 — It was said to provoke epileptic seizures. Someone compared it to a broken swastika or “some sort of comical sex act between ‘The Simpsons.’ ” The mayor was not amused.

headline: CBS, Bowing to Protests, Brings Back ‘Jericho’
text: LOS ANGELES, June 6 — Three weeks after CBS’s cancellation of the apocalyptic drama “Jericho” set off a sustained and creative protest by fans of the first-season series, the network reversed course and announced on Wednesday that it had ordered seven additional episodes to be broadcast late this year or early in 2008.

headline: One Saloon Singer to Another, Encompassing Two Universes
text: Now that James Brown is gone, the designation Hardest-Working Man in Show Business is up for grabs. One candidate for the title would have to be Michael Feinstein, the multitasking singer, pianist, all-around entertainer, intrepid archivist and strict watchdog of old-guard pop traditions.

headline: High-Jumper Learns Fast and Thrives
text: SACRAMENTO, June 6 — A little more than a year ago, Donald Thomas was a shooting guard at Lindenwood University, an N.A.I.A. school in St. Charles, Mo. He had played

headline: A Small Strategy for Selling Concerts
text: The music industry may seem like a broken record of bad news these days, with plunging album sales and confusion over the digital future. But in the concert business at least one corner is booming: clubs.

headline: Auto Chiefs Make Headway Against a Mileage Increase
text: WASHINGTON, June 6  Automobile companies seem to be making progress in tamping down Democratic proposals for tougher fuel economy requirements, an issue that pits powerful Democrats from Michigan against some national leaders of their own party.

headline: Behind the Glass Wall
text: WHEN Philip Johnson’s Glass House in New Canaan, Conn., officially opens to the public on June 21, paying visitors will have a chance to explore one of the world’s most celebrated works of Modernism for the first time since its completion in 1949. The diminutive glass-and-steel building and its uncluttered interior, which have barely changed in 58 years, are so spare that it is hard to imagine that anyone ever lived there. But for nearly all that time, it was the constantly used country retreat of its round-spectacled creator, who shared it after 1960 with David Whitney.

headline: House Passes Stem Cell Bill Despite Veto Threat
text: WASHINGTON, June 7 — The House gave final Congressional approval today to legislation intended to ease restrictions on federal financing of embryonic stem cell research, sending a bipartisan measure to the White House that President Bush has pledged to veto.

headline: China to Revise Rules on Food and Drug Safety
text: SHANGHAI, June 6  Responding to growing international concerns about tainted food and counterfeit drugs, China said late Tuesday that it was overhauling its food and drug safety regulations and would introduce nationwide inspections.

headline: China: Car Sales Rise 34% in May
text: China’s car sales rose 23 percent in May, as price cuts and new models attracted more people to showrooms. Customers bought 488,500 passenger cars, multipurpose vehicles and sport-utility vehicles in May, the China Association of Automobile Manufacturers said.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 6, 2007

headline: Afghans Seek Men Who Killed Broadcaster as She Slept
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 6 — An Afghan journalist was shot dead by unknown gunmen in her home north of Kabul on Tuesday night as she slept beside her 10-month-old baby, Afghan officials said Wednesday.

headline: Travelers Face Frustrations With Passport Rule Changes
text: HOUSTON, June 6 — With government phone lines jammed by record numbers of passport-seekers, Veronica Alvarez and three anxious friends hoping to travel to Cancun next week showed up at the federal building here on Wednesday at 3 a.m.

headline: Immigration Bill Fails to Win Crucial Vote in Senate
text: WASHINGTON, June 7 — A bill that would overhaul immigration law suffered a crippling defeat this evening in the Senate, casting grave doubt on the prospects for changing the system any time soon.

headline: He’s 9 Years Old  and a Video-Game Circuit Star
text: HOLBROOK, N.Y., June 5  Victor M. De Leon III has been playing video games on the professional circuit for five years now, racking up thousands of dollars in prizes and endorsements at tournaments around the country. He has a national corporate sponsor, a publicist and a Web site, with 531 photos chronicling his career. A documentary filmmaker has been following him for months.

headline: Saving Trees Is Music to Guitar Makers’ Ears
text: Christian F. Martin IV is the sixth generation to run his family’s renowned guitar-making business, C. F. Martin & Company. But he is surely the first to worry about the availability of the distinctive woods needed to build Martin guitars, the choice of musicians like Sting, Paul Simon, Jimmy Buffett and John Mayer.

headline: Yonkers Agency Approves Controversial Development
text: YONKERS, June 6  After three years of divisive debate marred by suspicions of back-room deals and political favoritism, a proposal to build houses, offices and shops on an 81-acre site off the Sprain Brook Parkway cleared its last hurdle here on Wednesday. The Industrial Development Agency, a quasi-governmental body, approved $22 million in mortgage and sales tax exemptions for the developer.

headline: The Candidates’ Faith (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about a contest for YouTube viewers to choose a theme song for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign referred incorrectly to a Billy Joel song. The song, “New York State of Mind,” was on the album “Turnstiles”; the album is not named for the song.

headline: Prudential Financial to Close Research Unit
text: Prudential Financial has been trying for years to figure out what to do with its small, struggling equity research and sales business. Yesterday, the company said it had decided to shut the operation.

headline: Colorado: Report on Mauling
text: The police have closed an inquiry into the mauling death of a zookeeper at the Denver Zoo, clearing the zoo of criminal wrongdoing. The zookeeper, Ashlee Pfaff, 27, was killed by a 140-pound male jaguar Feb. 24. According to the police report, the results of which were published yesterday in The Rocky Mountain News, armed zoo personnel rushed to Ms. Pfaff’s aid, fending off the jaguar with a fire extinguisher and eventually shooting and wounding the animal after it approached them. A veterinarian euthanized the jaguar after the attack. It is unclear why a door to the jaguar’s enclosure was ajar, allowing the animal to pounce on Ms. Pfaff.

headline: An Immigration Compromise Divides Republican Senators
text: WASHINGTON, June 6 — Senator Jeff Sessions, a conservative former federal prosecutor from Alabama, says he is anything but anti-immigration. But he is dead set against what he says is a misguided and flawed immigration proposal he says will not secure the nation’s borders while rewarding those who have sneaked across them.

headline: Citigroup and NASD Settle BellSouth Case
text: NASD, a regulator of brokerage firms, said yesterday that Citigroup will pay $15.2 million to settle claims that its brokers had coaxed employees of the BellSouth Corporation into retiring early on exaggerated projections for investment returns.

headline: Looking for Leadership
text: If there is a point to gathering the leaders of eight of the world’s richest and most powerful nations each year, it is to thrash out policies for tackling the most pressing and contentious problems.

headline: F.D.A. Calls for New Warnings on Diabetes Drugs
text: WASHINGTON, June 6 — The government’s top drug regulator told a packed House hearing today that the agency had recently decided to put the agency’s most serious safety warning on two diabetes drugs — Avandia and Actos — whose health risks have become a focus of Congressional concern.

headline: Rights Groups Call for End to Secret Detentions
text: WASHINGTON, June 6 — Six human rights groups on Wednesday released a list of 39 people they believe have been secretly imprisoned by the United States and whose whereabouts are unknown, calling on the Bush administration to abandon such detentions.

headline: Thousands of Protesters Foil Some German Security Measures and Clash With the Police
text: KÜHLUNGSBORN, Germany, June 6 — They lurked in the woods, 50 strong, wearing black hoods and bandannas, and wielding tree limbs. At a signal, they sprang forward and threw their debris across one of the bigger roads here, creating a barricade that brought traffic to a halt.

headline: Beethoven’s Fraternity of Friends and Peers
text: The Emerson String Quartet knows how to give itself a party, and how to turn a composer’s quartet cycle into a high-concept marathon. Its Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall — an expansive look at the Beethoven quartets, juxtaposed with works by composers who influenced him and felt his influence — is part of the group’s celebration of its 30th anniversary.

headline: General Tells Senate U.S. Must Prevail in Iraq
text: The Army officer named to be the Bush administration’s war-coordination “czar” told a Senate panel today that America continues to have vital interests in the Middle East, and that it must prevail in the conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Feud Over Land Parcel Shadows Plans for a Permanent Memorial to United Flight 93
text: SHANKSVILLE, Pa., June 6  Two employees of the National Park Service used a garbage bag and duct tape on Wednesday to cover an unauthorized box erected to receive donations at a temporary memorial where visitors pay homage daily to the 40 victims of United Flight 93.

headline: The Inadequacy of Civil Unions
text: A potentially groundbreaking legal battle over Connecticut’s exclusion of gay people from the state’s marriage law has catapulted the debate over same-sex marriage to a new level.

headline: Sorenstam Strives to Become What She Was
text: At times, Annika Sorenstam broke into the kind of giddy smile that would rarely be coaxed from her in the middle of a competitive round. This occasion, she said, was worth letting a little joy break through her usual focused facade.

headline: Accord to Protect Wine Names
text: Australia agreed to stop using names like champagne and port as part of an accord with the European Union that helps protect the union’s wine industry by preserving traditional production methods and names. “The agreement safeguards the E.U.’s wine-labeling regime, gives full protection to E.U. geographical indications, including for wines intended to be exported, and includes a clear Australian commitment to protect E.U. traditional expressions,” the European Commission said. The agreement replaces an existing accord that dates from 1994 and provides for Australia to phase out the use of “a number of important E.U. names” within a year.

headline: Where a Screen Isn’t an Option, a Hand-Held Uses Audio
text: The Icon mobile manager has just about everything you would expect in a hand-held organizer, including a calendar, address book, clock, word processor, calculator, voice recorder, and Wi-Fi and Bluetooth connectivity. What it does not have is a screen, because this pocket-size device from LevelStar was designed for visually impaired users.

headline: A Confident But Close Victory Over Guatemala
text: Even playing the last 18 minutes with 10 men didn’t stop the United States from opening up its Gold Cup defense with a comfortable 1-0 victory over Guatemala, in theory the toughest opponent in its group.

headline: CBS Bringing ‘Jericho’ Back After Protests From Fans
text: LOS ANGELES, June 6 — Three weeks after CBS’s cancellation of the apocalyptic drama “Jericho” set off a sustained and creative protest by fans of the first-season series, the network reversed course and announced on Wednesday that it had ordered seven new episodes for broadcast late this year or early in 2008.

headline: A Beloved Brooklyn Pizzeria Is Closed, Again, by the Health Dept.
text: It was about lunchtime yesterday when Eugene Kaplun stood in front of a pizzeria in Brooklyn, not believing what he was seeing. He read the yellow sign. He read the brown sign. Neither was a menu.

headline: Giuliani and McCain to Skip Straw Poll in Iowa
text: NEW CASTLE, N.H., June 6 — Bucking a ritual for Republican presidential candidates, Rudolph W. Giuliani and Senator John McCain announced Wednesday that they would skip participation in what has been a significant early test of candidate strength, the straw poll in Ames, Iowa, this summer.

headline: Easier Connections for the Networked Family
text: Connecting printers and hard drives for use over a network has been a daunting task for even the most knowledgeable. With the Belkin Network U.S.B. Hub, all that is needed is to put a plug into a socket.

headline: Europe’s Central Bank Raises Interest Rates
text: FRANKFURT, June 6 — The European Central Bank on Wednesday raised borrowing costs to their highest level in nearly six years, pointing to a humming economy that, while welcome, raised the risk of higher inflation. It also hinted at additional increases, prompting a slide in European stock markets.

headline: Arguments Over Removal of Schoolbook on Cuba
