text: MIAMI, June 6 — A three-judge panel heard arguments on Wednesday over the Miami-Dade County school board’s decision to remove a children’s book about Cuba from elementary school libraries. Board members said the book painted too rosy a picture of life in Cuba.

headline: Britain: Muhammad Ranks No. 2 in Boys’ Names
text: Muhammad is now the second most popular name for baby boys in Britain, outstripped only by Jack, The Times of London reported. It said it based its conclusion on an analysis of 3,000 names provided by the Office for National Statistics for births in 2006 and had taken into account 14 different spellings for the name. Using the spelling Muhammad in its article, the newspaper said that the popularity of the name came from the growing number of young Muslim couples having families. Many of these parents chose the name of the prophet in order to show a solidarity with their religion, the newspaper said. According to the Times analysis, Muhammad (5,991) could outscore Jack (6,928) by the end of this year if the name’s current rate of popularity continued. The names Thomas and Joshua followed Muhammad closely in third and fourth places. No other Muslim names showed up in the list of 20 names published by the newspaper.

headline: Manhattan: Police Request Denied in Surveillance Case
text: Lawyers representing protesters who have sued the city, claiming they were improperly arrested during the 2004 Republican National Convention, do not have to reveal whether they provided confidential information about the case to the news media, a federal judge has ruled. On Tuesday, Magistrate Judge James C. Francis IV of Federal District Court denied a motion by the Police Department to compel statements from the protesters’ lawyers, saying that the police first had to establish that the information, reported in The New York Times, did not come from sources within the department. The judge said that the information  documents that detail police intelligence gathering  were nonconfidential. Lawyers for the city said yesterday that they were reviewing the decision.

headline: Britain: Hedge Fund Creates Research Institute
text: The Man Group, the largest publicly traded hedge fund in the world, said it would pay £13.8 million ($27 million) to set up a research institute at Oxford University. The funds, to be paid over five years, will create the Oxford-Man Institute of Quantitative Finance and endow a professorship. The initiative is a way for Man, which uses mathematical models to make investments, to find mathematicians, who have become increasingly scarce as students planning careers in hedge funds study business instead.

headline: Martin Meyerson, 84, Leader at 3 Universities, Dies
text: Martin Meyerson, a former president of the University of Pennsylvania and the State University of New York at Buffalo, died on Saturday near his home in Philadelphia. In 1965, he helped calm tensions as acting chancellor of the University of California, Berkeley, in the demonstrations of the Free Speech Movement. He was 84.

headline: Connecticut Girl Missing Nearly a Year Is Found in a Closet
text: When the police showed up with search warrants yesterday morning at a scruffy house on a busy street corner in West Hartford, Conn., they assumed they were looking for evidence in the possible killing of a 15-year-old girl, missing for almost a year.

headline: Master Stroke
text: While he continues to struggle in the pool with the new kicking technique that he learned at the Race Club Swim Camp, Jim Thornton says he’s found that the skill seems natural in open water. On Saturday, he will test that kick in competition for the first time during a two-mile open water swim in western Pennsylvania. As he wrote in this month’s issue of PLAY, his instructor at the camp in Islamorada, Fla., Jon Olsen, a four-time Olympic gold medalist, focused on five flaws in his freestyle stroke, providing some simple solutions like keeping his head down and back flat. “It’s amazing how often you have to remind yourself to do these things,” he says. Three weeks after the camp, and while fighting a nasty cold, Thornton, 54, swam his fastest 100-yard race in five years, a performance he called a “triumph over infirmity and petulance.” Thornton recommends the intensive instruction that specialized schools and camps provide. Even those new to the sport, he says, will benefit from learning the right techniques “before they’ve spent years practicing the wrong thing.”

headline: Manhattan: Man Charged in Subway Robberies
text: A Bronx man has been arrested and charged with six counts of robbery in connection with a series of robberies on subway trains, the police said yesterday. The man, Miguel Ortiz, 27, of Morris Avenue, was arrested about 7:30 p.m. on Tuesday after a woman exited a No. 2 train at the Wall Street Station and told a police officer that a man on the train had just stolen her necklace and pocketbook. When officers stopped the train at 14th Street, another woman told them that a man had just robbed her. After his arrest, the police said, Mr. Ortiz was also charged with robbing women on other trains and at 109th Street in Manhattan.

headline: After the Fight, Booker’s Top Antagonist Is Still Standing
text: NEWARK, June 6  It was the kind of triumph that would fill any up-and-coming political force with glee. Mayor Cory A. Booker, who took City Hall in a landslide here last year, threw his newfound heft behind six legislative candidates in Tuesday’s Democratic primary and found himself celebrating victory with five of them.

headline: Promoting a Thirst for Sprite in Teenage Cellphone Users
text: The Coca-Cola Company is hoping its new mobile site for social networking, Sprite Yard, will become the MySpace of the cellphone world.

headline: Switzerland: How Ötzi the Iceman Died
text: Ötzi, the Neolithic iceman whose well-preserved body was found in the Alps in 1991, bled to death after being hit in the back by an arrow, Swiss scientists said. The arrowhead itself had already been found, but new CAT scans show that it cut an artery, causing internal bleeding, according to Frank J. Rühli of the Anatomy Institute of Zurich University. “A lesion of an artery close to the shoulder has been found, thanks to a CAT scan,” he said.

headline: Where’s EuroArnold?
text: As long as President Bush does not give German Chancellor Angela Merkel another one of those surprise neck rubs, the Group of 8 meetings should settle into cautious choreography on how to bring down the planet’s fever and reduce global inequities.

headline: Pro Scouts Go Diamond Mining at Los Angeles-Area Powerhouse
text: CHATSWORTH, Calif., June 6 — The Chatsworth High School baseball team walked single file through the campus quad Wednesday, one future millionaire after another.

headline: Above Midtown, a Lilliputian Universe
text: I’VE never really loved miniature worlds because the real thing always seemed so much more compelling. Why put little teacups around a tiny table, when you can have a tea party with real cake? Why stick moss and ferns in a glass box, when you can go wading in the stream where they grow wild along the banks?

headline: Congestion Pricing Proposal Races Ahead
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s congestion pricing plan got a boost today from the governor and the United States secretary of transportation, who announced that New York City was one of nine finalists for a share of $1.1 billion in federal money intended to fight traffic in major urban areas.

headline: Injured Alou Is Running; Running Out of Patience
text: Moises Alou is running out of patience. Desperate for a remedy for his ailing left quadriceps, Alou even tried rubbing the muscle with an ointment that he gives to his horses. It did not work.

headline: Abbas and Olmert Delay Meeting; Withheld Funds at Issue
text: JERUSALEM, June 6  A meeting scheduled for Thursday between the prime minister of Israel, Ehud Olmert, and the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, has been postponed, largely over what appeared to be the issue of the conditions under which Israel would turn over tax revenues it collects for the Palestinians.

headline: A 17-Year-Old Turns Pro and Looks to Be the Man
text: There is a touch of Paul Bunyan in the story of Tony Finau, a 17-year-old golfer who stands 6 feet 4 inches, weighs 205 pounds and carries only one wood, 12 irons and a putter in his bag.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 7 P.M. (Cartoon Network) CLASS OF 3000 André Benjamin, a k a André 3000 of the hip-hop group OutKast, lends his voice to Sunny Bridges in the second season of this vaguely autobiographical animated series about a star who gives up everything to teach a group of musical prodigies in Atlanta. In tonight’s episode the students decide to replace all their teachers with celebrities, since things are going so well with Sunny.

headline: Mets Stumble as Outfield Absorbs Another Hit
text: The Mets’ night got off on the wrong foot, so to speak, when Damion Easley took himself out of the lineup with an injured right knee. David Newhan, like Easley a natural second baseman, replaced him in left field, and if he had not been available, General Manager Omar Minaya and his staff may have started combing the streets of Flushing for anyone with outfield experience.

headline: With Buyout, the Isles Have Finally Seen the Back of Yashin
text: The quirky Islanders conceded perhaps their biggest business blunder in franchise history yesterday when they gave up on Alexei Yashin, buying out the last four years of his weighty 10-year contract.

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q. I envy my neighbor’s elegant backyard waterfall. How can I install one?

headline: Trading Brews for Bags? High Five!
text: WHILE many city dwellers are escaping to the beach this weekend, the irreverent owners of two Crumpler bag shops in Manhattan are planning a promotion seemingly devised by Homer Simpson: Bring them beer, and in exchange they will give you one of their practical carryalls.

headline: Administration Seeks Overhaul of Patent System
text: The Bush administration wants to reform the nation’s patent system by requiring better information from inventors and allowing public scrutiny of applications, according to the director of the government’s patent office.

headline: North Korea Fires Missiles Off Coast
text: SEOUL, June 7 — North Korea test-fired short-range missiles off its west coast today, drawing an annoyed reaction from the United States and a dismissive one from South Korea.

headline: Agreed: We All Love Narciso
text: ON Tuesday evening at Il Cantinori, the Greenwich Village restaurant, Jerry and Jessica Seinfeld were waiting for guests to arrive at a dinner they were giving for their friend Narciso Rodriguez. Mr. Seinfeld had decided to wait at his place at one of the front tables, and though he didn’t quite have fork and knife in hand, he looked like any number of American husbands at the dinner hour. “I’m just here to eat,” he said in his mock sensible tone.

headline: Louisiana: Public Housing Opens
text: Four public housing duplexes are opening in the devastated Upper Ninth Ward of New Orleans, the secretary of the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development announced at a news conference. The secretary, Alphonso R. Jackson, said that more than 100 housing units would be rebuilt in the neighborhood before the end of the year at the New Desire development, on the site of a city housing project that before Hurricane Katrina was being turned into a mixed-income development. Protesters at the news conference said they were representing thousands of former public-housing residents who have been unable to return to the city because, they said, the federal government refuses to reopen even projects that suffered little damage in the storm.

headline: Sudanese Lawyers Receive Guidance for Possible Trials Over Darfur
text: LONDON, June 6  As international pressure increases over the situation in Darfur, Sudanese lawyers are looking ahead to the day when victims of mass rape and torture seek justice in tribunals like the International Criminal Court in The Hague.

headline: Nadal Extends His Perfect Record at the French Open
text: PARIS, June 6 — For more than two hours, Rafael Nadal played his quarterfinal match at the French Open as if he had never seen the man on the opposite side of the net.

headline: Spain: A Madrid Terror Defendant Is Freed
text: One of the 29 defendants in the Madrid train bombings trial has been cleared of all charges and is a free man, CNN reported on its Web site, citing his lawyer and a court spokeswoman. It said prosecutors had dropped all charges against the Moroccan-born defendant, Brahim Moussaten, 23, for lack of evidence. He was accused of having helped two suspects escape after the 2004 attacks, one who is now a defendant in the trial and another who is believed to have died in Iraq as a suicide bomber. Mr. Moussaten’s brother and an uncle remain on trial.

headline: ‘Deranged’ Man Hurls Himself at Pope, Who Seems Unfazed
text: ROME, June 6 — A man the Vatican described as “clearly deranged” sprang over a barricade on Wednesday and landed a yard or so behind a waving Pope Benedict XVI as he rode in an uncovered popemobile through crowds at St. Peter’s Square.

headline: Brooklyn: Couple Found Dead, With Gun Nearby
text: A man and woman were found dead in their apartment in East New York last night in what investigators are calling a possible murder-suicide, the police said. The couple, identified as Veldora Dixon, 39, and Tito Jemmoot, 35, each had a gunshot wound in the head when they were found in the apartment at 712 Pennsylvania Avenue. Their bodies were found in their bed, and a 9-millimeter gun was found near Mr. Jemmoot’s body, the police said. The police were alerted to the body about 7:30 p.m. by a friend of the family, who wondered why the couple had missed an appointment.

headline: Conrad Black Loses Bid to Recall a Witness
text: CHICAGO, June 6 (Bloomberg News) — The former media baron Conrad M. Black, charged with fraud and racketeering, lost his motion on Wednesday to recall the chief prosecution witness, F. David Radler. At the same time, the judge denied a request for a mistrial by one of Mr. Black’s co-defendants, Mark S. Kipnis.

headline: Handbag Suit Settled
text: Fendi, the Italian maker of luxury products, settled a lawsuit yesterday against Wal-Mart Stores that contended the retailer had sold counterfeit handbags and wallets in its Sam’s Club stores.

headline: ‘omg my mom joined facebook!!’
text: I HAVE reached a curious point in life. Although I feel like the same precocious know-it-all cynic I always was, I suddenly am surrounded by younger precocious know-it-all cynics whose main purpose appears to be to remind me that I’ve lost my edge.

headline: Pennsylvania: Stay Is Extended
text: A federal judge has extended a stay of deportation for Sameh Khouzam, an Egyptian Coptic Christian who faces repatriation for a murder charge in Egypt. Mr. Khouzam, 38, of Lancaster, Pa., was to be deported June 7, but deportation has been stayed until June 18, court documents show. Mr. Khouzam fled to the United States nine years ago, claiming that he had been detained and tortured because he refused to convert to Islam. He denies the murder accusation. In 2004, a federal appeals court allowed Mr. Khouzam to remain in the United States because it determined that he would quite likely face torture if he returned to Egypt. After being freed from detention in 2006, Mr. Khouzam was detained again May 29, after the Egyptian government provided diplomatic assurances that he would not be tortured.

headline: If Only ...the Drama of the Single Child (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Listen Up, Everybody: I’m in Menopause
text: IT was 8 a.m. on a Friday and Deb Caruana, 51, a personal trainer in Manhattan, had just finished working out with two of her clients, Jackie Greenberg, an interior designer in her 30s, and her father, Ronald Greenberg, 59, an art dealer.

headline: Europe and U.S. Move Toward Climate Deal
text: HEILIGENDAMM, Germany, June 7 — The United States agreed today to “seriously consider” a European proposal to combat global warming by halving greenhouse gas emissions by 2050, breaking a trans-Atlantic deadlock at a meeting here of the world’s richest industrial nations.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: City Settles Art Dispute

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Mark Harris, who wrote the baseball novel “Bang the Drum Slowly” and other books, gave an incorrect identification in some copies for the actor who played catcher Bruce Pearson in a 1956 television adaptation of that novel. He was Albert Salmi  not George Peppard, who played another ballplayer, Piney Woods, in the production. The obituary also misidentified a university at which Mr. Harris taught. It was Arizona State University, not the University of Arizona.

headline: Senate Rejects Most Efforts to Change Immigration Bill
text: WASHINGTON, June 6 — The Senate signaled support for major provisions of a comprehensive immigration bill on Wednesday by rejecting many proposed amendments, including one that would have made it much harder for many illegal immigrants to achieve legal status.

headline: ‘Silent Amnesty’: Where the Hard Right Goes Soft on Immigration
text: All right, seal the border. Then what?

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The listing of lottery results on Monday misstated the dates the winning numbers were drawn. They were from June 3 and June 2, not May 3 and May 2.

headline: Campaign Funds for Alaskan; Road Aid to Florida
text: WASHINGTON, June 6  It is no secret that campaign contributions sometimes lead to lucrative official favors. Rarely, though, are the tradeoffs quite as obvious as in the twisted case of Coconut Road.

headline: Calendar
text: Design and Technology in Japan

headline: When Pardons Turn Political
text: WASHINGTON, June 6 — President Bush has pardoned 113 people during his presidency, including a Tennessee bootlegger and a Mississippi odometer cheat.

headline: Japan: Executive Leaves Citigroup
text: Citigroup, which recently acquired a majority stake in the Nikko Cordial Corporation, said Brandon Ginsberg had resigned as co-head of equities at its Japanese investment bank. Mr. Ginsberg has already left, said Masufumi Yoshino, head of corporate communications at Nikko Citigroup in Tokyo. No further details were available. The departure is the second change of senior managers at the unit since Citigroup bought 61 percent in April.

headline: Romantic Side of Brahms: So Dark, So Brooding
text: An orchestra festival can aspire to cast new light on a particular composer or period, dust off the familiar and uncover the less known. Or it can be a way to keep its musicians busy.

headline: Converters Signal a New Era for TVs
text: At midnight on Feb. 17, 2009, the rabbit ears and the rooftop antennas that still guide television signals into nearly 1 of every 5 American homes will be rendered useless — unless they are tethered to a new device, including two versions unveiled yesterday, that the government will spend as much as $80 a household to help families buy.

headline: Jim Clark, Sheriff Who Enforced Segregation, Dies at 84
text: Jim Clark, the former sheriff in Selma, Ala., whose violent, highly public attempts to maintain the status quo there in the Jim Crow era are widely believed to have contributed, however inadvertently, to the success of the voting rights movement, died Monday in Elba, Ala. He was 84 and had been living in a nursing home there.

headline: Free Judges’ Pay
text: SINCE Gov. Eliot Spitzer reappointed me chief judge three months ago, fair pay for our judges has been the consuming issue. In these critical, final days before the Legislature adjourns, New Yorkers deserve a frank explanation of why raising judicial pay and replacing New York’s broken system of compensation matter — and why so much is at stake if Albany fails to act now.

headline: Early Advice on Successor for Prosecutor
text: WASHINGTON, June 6  Five days after senior Justice Department officials gave the White House the first official list of possible United States attorneys to be dismissed, an executive of a conservative legal group offered the Bush administration a recommendation for one replacement candidate, documents released Wednesday show.

headline: Italy: 5 Acquitted in Banker’s 1982 Death
text: A court in Rome acquitted five people accused of conspiring to murder Roberto Calvi, who was president of Banco Ambrosiano, one of Italy’s largest private banks, and a financial adviser to the Vatican when he was found hanged under Blackfriars Bridge in London in 1982, his pockets stuffed with rocks, bricks and cash. The presiding judge cited a lack of evidence. The defendants included Giuseppe Caló, known as the Mafia’s “treasurer.” Prosecutors argued that Mr. Calvi, known as “God’s banker” because of his Vatican connections, was killed for stealing Mafia money he was supposed to launder. His death was at first ruled a suicide, but the case was reopened in 2003 as a murder inquiry. With yesterday’s court ruling, it remains unsolved.

headline: Brazil: Bank Cuts Benchmark Rate
text: The country’s central bank cut the benchmark lending rate to a record low as a rally in Brazil’s currency holds inflation at an eight-year low. Policy makers, led by the bank’s president, Henrique Meirelles, 61, lowered the overnight lending rate by half a percentage point, to 12 percent.

headline: In a Virtual Universe, the Politics Turn Real
text: The kingdom is in crisis. After pledging to treat its citizens equally, the government stands accused of unfairly favoring one powerful, well-connected political faction. Many citizens have taken to open dissent, even revolt, and some are threatening to emigrate permanently.

headline: City Nonprofit Group Gets Money for Merit Pay at Charter Schools
text: The United States Department of Education has awarded a $10.5 million grant to a New York City nonprofit group to create merit pay systems in 10 local charter schools, local and federal education officials announced yesterday.

headline: Why Give Away the Airwaves? (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Not-So-High- Definition Camcorders
text: Uh-oh, it’s started. The electronics industry has begun diluting the term high-definition.

headline: Goals Are Both Met and Missed in Clinton Fund-Raising
text: As the Clinton presidential campaign raises money this spring, Hillary and Bill Clinton have had many ups and a few downs. Gov. Jon Corzine of New Jersey is delivering at least $1 million, and their friend Warren Buffett an additional $500,000. And Mrs. Clinton’s brother Tony kept the peace in the family by coming through with $175,000 at a Pennsylvania fund-raiser — right after his daughter’s baptism.

headline: Bombings Near Iraqi Police Station Kill at Least 9
text: BAGHDAD, June 7 — A suicide bomber and bus bomb exploded near a police station in northern Iraq today, killing at least nine people and wounding 22, the authorities said.

headline: Brooklyn: Mayor Promotes Congestion Pricing
text: Congestion pricing could help the Metropolitan Transportation Authority avoid fare increases, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. Mr. Bloomberg made his comments at a news conference at Pratt Institute the day after an analysis by the city’s Independent Budget Office showed that transit fares could go as high as $3 over the next three years. “Maybe congestion pricing would generate enough to help them for a long time and postpone a fare increase,” said Mr. Bloomberg, who has been pressuring Albany to approve his plan. “If you don’t give them another source of revenue, then the likelihood of less mass transit and higher fares is clearly there.”

headline: Fashion Paper Joins Bottom-of-the-Front-Page Club
text: With today’s issue, Women’s Wear Daily, the longtime chronicler of the fashion world, becomes the latest newspaper to sell a piece of valuable real estate: advertising space on its front page.

headline: Brazilian Numbers Game Ties Officials to Mobsters
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The illegal lottery known as “the animal game” is as visible a part of the urban landscape here as Ipanema beach or Sugarloaf mountain. On thousands of street corners, vendors sit all day at little wooden booths, pads of paper in hand, taking money from bettors, who return later to check results posted on lampposts or walls.

headline: Putin Presents Bush With Plan on Missile Shield
text: ROSTOCK, Germany, June 7 — After months of angrily rejecting a White House plan for missile defense in Europe, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia surprised President Bush to day with an offer to build a joint system in the former Soviet Republic of Azerbaijan.

headline: Recalling D-Day, Gates Urges a Stronger Alliance
text: COLLEVILLE-SUR-MER, France, June 6 — Beside a churning sea and an ocean of white marble crosses, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Wednesday that the United States and its European allies should honor the thousands of Americans buried here by strengthening the alliance that they died defending.

headline: AstraZeneca Loses C.F.O. to Goldman Sachs
text: LONDON, June 6  AstraZeneca, Britain’s second-largest drug maker after GlaxoSmithKline, said on Wednesday that its chief financial officer was leaving to join to Goldman Sachs just months after it paid $15.2 billion to buy MedImmune.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts on May 29 about “Fallujah,” a play in London about the American attack in 2004 on the Iraqi city of that name, misidentified the nationality of a journalist whose account was one of those used for the script. The journalist, Dahr Jamail, is American, not Canadian. The article also referred incorrectly to another documentary play, with which “Fallujah” was contrasted. That play, “Guantánamo: ‘Honor Bound to Defend Freedom,’ ” was a full production; the actors did not sit on the stage and read scripts.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on May 26 about Coca-Cola’s acquisition of Glaceau, the maker of Vitaminwater, misstated a financial result for Glaceau that is considered a crucial indicator of market value. The company had an estimated $350 million in sales, not earnings, in 2006.

headline: 60 Products
text: With inspiration from "60 Minutes," gadgets too good to pass up in this summer rerun.

headline: omg my mom joined facebook!!
text: In her Cyberfamilias column today in Thursday Styles, Michelle Slatalla writes about how she joined Facebook, the social networking site that recently expanded its membership beyond students, to keep up with her daughter. The teenager viewed it as super creepy.

headline: Ducks Capture First Title
Go Team!
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Making Waves
text: Images from the movie "Surf's Up."

headline: China's Pork Crisis
text: Rising prices is causing Chinese companies to raise prices for exports, particularly on one critical commodity: pork.

headline: Thrill of the Heist
text: Images from "Ocean's Thirteen."

headline: The Venice Biennale in Pictures
text: Additional images from the 2007 international art exhibition.

headline: Recent Openings
text: New shows in New York include "Horizon" and "Crazy Mary."

headline: Physical Culture | Gear Test, Bike Racks
text: Josh Simonds, cycling coach, tests bike racks.

headline: Inside the Torture Factory
text: Benefiting from a higher budget, Eli Roth’s follow-up to his generally odious “Hostel” may sport glossier production values, but its driving motivation — to push the boundaries of exploitative nastiness — remains just as low.

headline: Genstar Closes $1.55 Billion Buyout Fund
text: Genstar Capital, a private equity firm focused on midsize companies, said it closed its fifth private equity fund at $1.55 billion. That amount far exceeded the fund’s initial target of $1 billion. Genstar’s latest fund was also more than three times the size of the one it raised in 2004.

headline: UBS Agrees to $115 Million Enron Payment
text: The Enron Creditors Recovery Corporation, formerly known as Enron, announced on Wednesday that UBS had agreed to pay $115 million to settle litigation over the collapse of Enron.

headline: The Brutal Struggle for Survival
text: The events recounted in “Miriam” are horrific, and the story behind it is moving. Matt Cimber made this World War II drama after his friend Max Guefen told him about his cousin Miriam’s struggle to survive in German-occupied Lithuania, where her family was robbed, brutalized and eventually shipped to a concentration camp. Unfortunately, the finished product feels like a 1970s exploitation movie in prestige-picture drag.

headline: Birds on Boards
text: Ever since Luc Jacquet's endearing documentary "March of the Penguins" persuaded Hollywood that penguins are the new Bambis, we have endured singing, wisecracking and even tap-dancing versions. Now, treading eagerly on the flippers of last year's "Happy Feet," comes "Surf's Up," a computer-animated comedy featuring birds on boards.

headline: A Rocker’s Climb From Despair
text: Early in the documentary "You're Gonna Miss Me," the film's subject, the psychedelic rocker and drug-damaged schizophrenic Roky Erickson, ambles through his Austin, Tex., home, clutching a Mr. Potato Head doll. It's a potent image that's all the more effective for being tossed off: Mr. Erickson, the lead singer of the 13th Floor Elevators and maybe the most influential 1960s pop star that most folks haven't heard of, has had so little control over his life and image for so many years that he's become a goofy blank slate.

headline: Conrad Black Loses Bid to Recall a Witness
text: The former media baron Conrad M. Black, charged with fraud and racketeering, lost his motion on Wednesday to recall the chief prosecution witness, F. David Radler. At the same time, the judge denied a request for a mistrial by one of Mr. Black’s co-defendants, Mark S. Kipnis.

headline: Citigroup and NASD Settle BellSouth Case
text: NASD, a regulator of brokerage firms, said on Wednesday that Citigroup will pay $15.2 million to settle claims that its brokers had coaxed employees of BellSouth into retiring early on exaggerated projections for investment returns.

headline: I.B.M.’s $1.6 Billion Tax Shelter Now an I.R.S. Target
text: For the second time in 12 months, the government has moved to block a tax shelter that had been aimed at converting billions of dollars of corporate profits, on which taxes have yet to be paid, into profits that will never be taxed.

headline: Criticism Mounts Over Yahoo Chief’s Pay Package
text: Yahoo‘s Terry Semel may be heading for a pay cut. As the Internet giant lags behind Google and with its much ballyhooed Panama project – the nickname for the firm’s overhaul of its search advertising system — yet to materialize, investors and industry observers are casting a critical eye on the chief executive’s $71 million compensation package.

headline: V.C.’s Just Can’t Get Enough Clean Tech
text: Recently published research confirms what any venture capital investor would tell you: clean tech is hot.

headline: Canada’s Stelco Likely to Be Sold Whole, C.E.O. Says
text: Stelco, the Canadian steel company that announced last week that it is exploring the possibility of sale, is likely to be sold whole rather than in parts, its chief executive said Wednesday.

headline: British Hotel Group Drops $3.4 Billion I.P.O.
text: A British hotel group, Vector pulled the plug on its planned 1.7 billion pound ($3.4 billion) initial public offering Wednesday night after investors failed to support what would have been the biggest share sale in London this year.

headline: Cerberus Affiliates Seek to Raise $11 Billion
text: Cerberus Capital Management, the private equity firm that recently agreed to buy Chrysler, has created affiliates that plan to raise more than $11 billion for investments, Reuters reported, citing regulatory filings. The six affiliates have already raised about $10.5 billion, Reuters said.

headline: Spain Orders Search and Capture of Odyssey’s Ships
text: The story of the discovery of a disputed undersea trove of gold and silver valued at $500 million by an American company continues to unfold like a pirate adventure.

headline: Man Group Goes Back to School
text: The Man Group, the largest publicly traded hedge fund in the world, is sending future hedge fund managers back to school. Man said on Wednesday that it would pay 13.8 million pounds ($27 million) to set up a research institute at Oxford University. The funds, to be paid over five years, will create the Oxford-Man Institute of Quantitative Finance and endow a professorship.

headline: Buyout Shops Sue Aeroflex Over Break-Up Fee
text: Two private equity firms whose takeover offer for Aeroflex was scuttled last month in favor of a competing bid are suing the company over the size of a break-up fee that was part of their original purchase agreement.

headline: Alcoa Files for Antitrust Approval for Possible Alcan Deal
text: The aluminum giant Alcoa, taking the next step in trying to take over its reluctant acquisition target Alcan, said Wednesday it had filed with antitrust authorities in the United States to gain approval for the $27 billion hostile deal.

headline: New Sun Nutrition Swallows $25 Million
text: New Sun Nutrition, a maker of energy drinks, has swallowed $25 million in a first round of funding from Oak Investment Partners. Oak invested alongside Radar Partners and Thomas Weisel, the chairman and chief executive of Thomas Weisel Partners, the San Francisco boutique investment bank.

headline: Amgen Doubles Down on Future Products
text: The Biotech giant Amgen said Wednesday it would buy Alantos Pharmaceuticals for $300 million, marking its second acquisition of a private biotech company this week. Alantos’ lead drug is a small-molecule treatment for Type 2 diabetes.

headline: Hedge Funds Put the Squeeze on Tribune Buyout
text: Sam Zell’s agreement to buy Tribune, the publisher of the Los Angeles Times and owner of the Chicago Cubs, prompted three hedge funds to seek profits in the fine print of $1.26 billion of bonds, Bloomberg News said.

headline: Redstone: No Viacom or CBS Buyout on the Horizon
text: Sumner Redstone, who controls both CBS and Viacom, said Wednesday that, despite rampant speculation on Wall Street, he has no plans to take either of those media giants private. “That has been suggested to me and Philippe and to Les,” Mr. Redstone said during an interview on CNBC, referring to the chiefs of Viacom and CBS, respectively.

headline: British Regulators Approve Verint Deal
text: British antitrust regulators have cleared the acquisition last month of Witness Systems by a software provider in the United States, Verint Systems, for $950 million. In a report released Wednesday, the British Office of Free Trade wrote that the purchase is not expected to result in less competition in Britain.

headline: Venice Biennale: Intimations of Mortality
text: The weather here keeps threatening to take a Thomas-Mannish turn, “that hateful sultriness in the narrow streets” that hangs low, “like exhalations, not dissipating.” But aside from a little rain, the thousands of art patrons, collectors, dealers, artists and writers streaming along the water toward the exhibitions at the Giardini and the Arsenale have been lucky.

headline: Monster C.F.O.’s Resignation Reignites Buyout Rumors
text: Shares of Monster Worldwide, parent of the jobs Web site Monster.com, fell more than 2 percent on Wednesday after it said its chief financial officer, Larry Baker, was resigning in a management shake-up. Timothy Yates will succeed Mr. Baker, who was leaving to pursue other interests, the company said.

headline: Columnist Seeks to Decode Wall Street’s Deal-Speak
text: Wall Street has its own language that requires some insider knowledge to speak fluently, according to MarketWatch’s David Weidner. So, in his latest, column, Mr. Weidner has put some of the most recent headlines through his decoder.

headline: Hedge Funds Accuse Bear of Loan Market Manipulation
text: Hedge fund managers are accusing Bear Stearns of trying to manipulate the market in securities based on subprime mortgages, according to press reports.

headline: British Billionaire to Buy Newcastle United
text: Newcastle United, the English Premier League soccer club, will be sold to a British sportswear tycoon, Mike Ashley, in a cash deal valuing it at about 134 million pounds ($267 million). The deal comes after Newcastle’s chairman, Freddy Shepherd, and his family agreed to sell their 28 percent stake in the club to Mr. Ashley.

headline: This Judge Is No Longer Rated
text: Gerald P. Garson, the disgraced former State Supreme Court judge, has been sentenced to 3 to 10 years in prison for bribery and official misconduct, as Michael Brick reported yesterday.

headline: Activist Shareholders Demand A Vodafone Shake-Up
text: John Mayo, the former deputy chief executive of Marconi, is backing a group of investors who are seeking to restructure Vodafone and unlock up to 38 billion ($76 billion) in value from the mobile phone group.

headline: At Home in a Pristine Box
text: Memories of life and death in an architectural masterwork.

headline: Gardening in the heart of Paris
text: For a few weeks, urban dwellers can revel in a vast, verdant garden that has sprouted outside Paris City Hall. Alongside a giant, gurgling water can and an oversized armchair, upholstered in natural vines, are thousands of plants, trees and micro gardens grouped by categories to tickle the senses or attract butterflies.

headline: Under Pressure, Biomet Agrees to Higher Takeover Bid
text: Biomet, the orthopedic device maker, accepted a sweetened takeover bid of $11.4 billion on Thursday from a group of private equity firms after an influential shareholder advisory firm urged the company’s shareholders to reject a previous $10.9 billion offer.

headline: Evercore Names New Finance Chief
text: Evercore Partners, the investment banking boutique, said its chief financial officer, David Wezdenko, was leaving the firm, to be succeeded by Robert Walsh, a senior partner at Deloitte & Touche.

headline: Two Views on How the Buyout Boom Might End
text: Much of Wall Street has been trying to figure out what factors could bring an end to the recent run of big buyout deals. Wilbur Ross, the billionaire financier, has his own view, and it sounds pretty grim.

headline: Philadelphia Inquirer Owner Casts Eye on Dow Jones
text: Another investor has expressed interest in the idea of putting together a rival bid for Dow Jones, the family-controlled publishing company that is fielding a $5 billion takeover offer from Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation.

headline: Currents
text: Frank Gehry's sculptural style comes to the table and more.

headline: Monaco Grand Prix retrospective
text: There is probably no other Formula One event that invites a photographer to go quite so mad as at Monaco. I have just completed a day-by-day photo retrospective of the Monaco Grand Prix from the Wednesday to the Sunday, with explanatory descriptions. It seems that it is now or never to take a look at this before we become involved in the Canadian Grand Prix, for which practice starts tomorrow.

headline: The Unpardonable
text: Free Scooter! But don’t pardon him. William Otis, special counsel for President George H.W. Bush and a former federal prosecutor, thinks Scooter Libby’s lies were too damaging to the “fundamental rule of law that the grand jury is entitled to every man’s evidence” for Libby to merit a full pardon from the current President Bush.

headline: Paris Hilton Leaves Prison for House Arrest
text: After a four night stay in jail, Paris Hilton was released early this morning and put under house arrest, The Los Angeles Sheriff’s Department announced today.

headline: Personal Shopper
text: Porcelain, recycled plastic and a bronze stump adorn the lawn.

headline: AIDS Awareness in India
text: If the results of a survey are correct, India is no longer the world’s supposed leader of people infected with AIDS.

headline: Congestion Pricing Racing Forward
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s congestion pricing proposal got a huge boost this morning.

headline: Wachovia to Hire 300 Private Bankers
text: Wachovia said on Thursday it would hire nearly 300 private bankers to cater to affluent customers as it revamps its wealth management unit. Over the next three years, the Charlotte bank plans to more than double the 240 relationship managers in its private banking unit aimed at clients with investable assets between $250,000 and $5 million. The bankers will target high-growth markets such as Florida, Texas, California and New York.

headline: 2008: Campaign Calculations
text: We’re not even into the middle of June and the fund-raising expectations game for the second quarter ending this month is already in high gear, as is the decision-making by some campaigns looking ahead to spending in the third quarter this summer.

headline: Edwards Tackles “Are We Safer Now?”
text: Former North Carolina Senator John Edwards is set to hold a news conference in New York today to detail his own national security plan.Excerpts of his speech show that he will continue the riff off of whether the nation is safer now, a theme produced heated exchanges during the Democratic debate on Sunday, as he criticized the views of his rivals, especially Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Venice Biennale: Prankster at Work
text: If there is a court jester for this far-flung kingdom of art called the Venice Biennale, it is a Romanian artist named Dan Perjovschi, who has been making spontaneous, hilarious and scathing drawings on the walls of museums and other art spaces for a decade.

headline: PNC Financial Acquires a New Jersey Bank for $403 Million
text: The PNC Financial Services Group said Thursday it would pay $403 million to acquire the Yardville National Bancorp a central New Jersey bank that has struggled with regulatory problems and complaints from its largest shareholder.

headline: The Best Croissant in Paris
text: One of the great pleasures of returning to France on an overnight flight from North America or Asia is arriving in the world’s most beautiful city as it wakes.

headline: Time Inc. Chief Imagines ‘Marriage’ With Scripps
text: Ann Moore’s dream house would apparently include parts of E.W. Scripps.

headline: Clinton’s Block Party
text: Although the Clinton event last night in a downtown D.C. parking lot was billed as “Club 44,’’ the thousands of women who streamed in and out didn’t quite fit the clubbing demographic.

headline: Breaking Down the Walls Between Mac OS X and Windows
text: I'm a bi-platform kinda guy. Not just because I need to be conversant in both Mac OS X and Windows for my job, but also because my life revolves around certain Mac programs and certain Windows programs.

headline: Senate Barbs Fly on Immigration
text: The intense Senate debate over immigration has produced some memorable exchanges with political overtones.

headline: … And We All Went to the Seashore
text: Today we do a little follow-up on some Screens fairy tales:

headline: Affordable Hotels in Moscow and St. Petersburg
text: I am traveling with a friend to St. Petersburg and Moscow mid-July, and I’m looking for affordable hotels near the city center or main tourist attractions. Any suggestions?

headline: Housing With Higher Rates
text: Wall Street wizards have been expecting higher long-term interest rates for a couple of years, but some now seem surprised they are arriving. The yield on the 10-year United States Treasury note climbed above 5 percent today, and there have been rises in most other countries as well. Maybe China is less willing to buy American and European bonds. Maybe there is something else.

headline: Breaking Down the Walls Between Mac OS X and Windows
text: I’m a bi-platform kinda guy. Not just because I need to be conversant in both Mac OS X and Windows for my job, but also because my life revolves around certain Mac programs and certain Windows programs.

headline: Podcast: Fershtay? It’s Yiddish
text: Podcast: Only in New York (mp3)

headline: A Tax Holiday for High-Rolling C.F.O.’s
text: The rule of unintended consequences strikes again.

headline: Time Warner Plans AOL Decision This Year
text: Here’s a reason to look forward to 2008: By then, the nonstop speculation about the fate of AOL should finally be over. Richard Parsons, the chief executive of Time Warner, said Thursday that the media conglomerate would make a decision on AOL’s future by the end of this year.

headline: The Forgotten ’90s Classic
text: Reading the Rob Sass article on TVR last weekend, I was sad to see it end with TVR’s 1987 departure from America, which meant no mention of the Peter Wheeler-era Griffith, possibly the most important TVR of my lifetime.

headline: On Second Day of Finals, All Games Are Drawn
text: Levon Aronian, Alexander Grischuk and Peter Leko preserved their leads in the candidates finals by drawing the second games of their matches. The other match between Gata Kamsky of the United States and Boris Gelfand of Isreal remained tied after their second draw. The matches are being held in Elista, Kalmykia, to select four qualifiers to the world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.

headline: Amaranth to Pension Fund: You Knew the Risks
text: Amaranth Advisors has a response for managers of San Diego County’s pension fund, who are smarting over big losses they took when the hedge fund collapsed. It goes something like this: We warned you.

headline: A Paris arrival
text: 81 Victor Hugo

headline: In Dow Jones Bidding, (Vague) New Names Surface
text: A Los Angeles billionaire and the owner of The Philadelphia Inquirer have already acknowledged that they are interested in a potential counteroffer for Dow Jones & Company. Now it appears that YouTube‘s Chad Hurley or the folks behind Lonelygirl15 may want in as well.

headline: What About Paris?
text: At a press conference today in New York City, John Edwards tackled some of the more weighty topics in the race for the White House. After reminding reporters that “terrorism is still alive, and ongoing, and a serious threat to America and to the rest of the world” and outlining his plan for a 10,000 member “Marshal Corps” to win back the hearts and minds of people around the world, one intrepid member of the press corps attempted to hold the feet of Mr. Edwards to the fire on what is surely the issue on the minds of most Americans.

headline: Jimmy Buffett’s first show in Paris
text: Jimmy Buffett has romanticized Paris in a number of his songs, and the singer, a self-described Francophile, has even owned an apartment in the city. But he has waited until now to play his first-ever Paris concert.

headline: Win Recognition
text: E.M. Rose Builders, Branford, CT - Owner Eric Rose has a goal to be the best and his industry has awarded him for his achievement.

headline: Do  What Works
text: Done Galleries, Sydney, Australia - Painter and entrepreneur Ken Done explains that the market will tell you what to make and how to price it.

headline: Listen to Customers
text: Record Technology, Camarillo, CA - Owner Don MacInnis tells how his top-selling product was invented by customers.

headline: Acquire the Competition
text: Café Pilon, Miami, Florida - Enrique Souto and his brothers have grown the business their father started by buying their competitors.

headline: Choose A Powerful Name
text: Bridgecreek, Huntington Beach, CA - Founder Frank Jao's vision was to build bridges between his country of origin and his new home in America.

headline: Lashing Out at Hilton’s Release
text: The best of the deluge of Lede comments and reactions from around the Web on the end of Paris Hilton’s prison term:

headline: Borrowing Less
text: The Federal Reserve’s flow of funds data came out today, and one interesting thing is how rapidly mortgage borrowing is falling. Americans borrowed (on a net basis) $127.6 billion in the first quarter of this year, a figure that is only 40 percent of the borrowing in the peak quarter, the third quarter of 2005.

headline: PlaNYC Bill Introduced in State Senate
text: Just in, courtesy of Aaron Naparstek, the guru of Streetsblog: the 154-page bill [pdf] introducing Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s comprehensive PlaNYC program to make New York City environmentally sustainable. Expect policy analysts, lobbyists and legislative aides to be poring over this legislation with a magnifying glass over the next few days and weeks.

headline: You Win-Lose Some
Venice Biennale: The Event in Pictures
text: A slide show of additional images from the Biennale.

headline: NYSE Euronext Strives to Go Global, but What to Call It?
text: Less than a year has passed since the New York Stock Exchange merged with Euronext, forming NYSE Euronext and a major player in the global exchange market. Now, it seems, the firm is hungry for even more partners.

headline: Biden Gets a Brief Iraq Moment
text: Although Senator Joe Biden took the lead weeks ago in calling for a 90-minute debate on Iraq among the presidential candidates, his plans to take part in a forum last night on that very topic were all but derailed by the Senate’s deliberation on the immigration bill.

headline: Signs: The Seed Is Planted
text: A strange feeling came over me as the C-130 landed at Fort Bragg, N.C. After 11 months in Iraq, I wasn’t scared any more, but it felt like the rest of America was.

headline: Yanks Reel In College Righty
text: On the day he would be drafted into professional baseball, Andrew Brackman went fishing on the Ohio River with his family. Brackman, who lives in Cincinnati, said he fishes a lot but never catches anything.

headline: End of (School) Year Frenzy
text: That time of year thou may’st in me beholdWhen sitters to their far-off homes hath fled,When camp and health forms make my blood run coldAnd all I want to do is lie in bed.In me thou see’st the frenzied wide-eyed stareOf one whose work time has been cut in twoAnd yet cannot resist the year-end snareOf read-a-louds, teacher gifts, and hot glue.In me thou see’st the envy, vile and greenOf those who smile while Spring turns into heatSuiting up for tennis, Pilates, tooAnd sporting perfectly manicured feet.This thou perceiv’st, all around me I hearOthers expressing their equal ill cheer.

headline: Blair’s Accord With Libya Worries Kin From Lockerbie
text: LONDON, June 7  Alex Salmond, the newly elected first minister of Scotland, expressed concern Thursday that the British government had struck a deal that might permit the only person convicted in the 1988 Lockerbie bombing to return to Libya to complete his sentence.

headline: For ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell,’ Split on Party Lines
Argentine Visitor Arrives With Armloads of Rhythm
text: The Argentine pianist and composer Guillermo Klein brought his big band to the Village Vanguard for the first time last summer, and New York reacted as it should. Word got around, and an artist whose music was easy to follow even if its referents were hard to determine — having crafted his individual, worldly, not-quite-jazz in various basements in New York, Buenos Aires and Barcelona — became a little less obscure that week.

headline: Brooklyn: DNA Evidence in Bouncer’s Murder Case
text: Prosecutors have disclosed DNA evidence in a triple-murder case against a bar bouncer connected to the Sweet Cherry strip parlor in Sunset Park. Months after the killings, the defendant, Stephen Sakai, was arrested carrying a washcloth with what appeared to be a bloodstain, his lawyer, Kleon C. Andreadis, said yesterday after a pretrial hearing in State Supreme Court. The Brooklyn district attorney’s office is expected to try to link the DNA to Mr. Sakai. Mr. Sakai and two of the victims in the case, both of whom were killed in 2005, worked or spent time at the Sweet Cherry, which the authorities finally shut down last year after nearly a decade of trying. In a separate case in Manhattan, Mr. Sakai is charged with shooting four patrons outside a dance club in Chelsea in May 2006, killing one.

headline: Brooklyn: Drug Arrests Near Children’s Museum
text: The authorities yesterday interrupted a sophisticated drug organization operating in Crown Heights, said Charles J. Hynes, the district attorney. Raiding several safe houses around the Brooklyn Children’s Museum, the police arrested 11 people, ranging in age from 23 to 67, on conspiracy, drug and weapons charges. Investigators secretly videotaped suspects weighing and measuring drugs, then bought or seized 2.8 pounds of cocaine and 8 pounds of marijuana, Mr. Hynes said. They also seized binoculars and radio equipment used for countersurveillance of the police.

headline: Part Coach, Part Motivator and 100 Percent Welcomed
text: CHICAGO, June 7 — Tyler Clippard had just earned his first major league victory when a call came for him on the cellphone of a Yankees staff member. Clippard, 22, was in the visitors’ clubhouse at Shea Stadium, and the pitcher with more victories than anyone alive wanted to talk to him. Roger Clemens was on the line.

headline: House Votes to Expand Stem Cell Research
text: WASHINGTON, June 7 — The House gave final Congressional approval on Thursday to legislation aimed at easing restrictions on federal financing of embryonic stem cell research, but Democratic leaders in both chambers conceded they were short of the votes needed to override a veto threatened by President Bush.

headline: Manhattan: Police Department Starts Video Podcasts
text: The Police Department has begun a monthly series of video podcasts offering an inside look at the department, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced yesterday. The videos will be available for download through the iTunes service to iPod users and can also be viewed online at the Police Department’s Web site, nyc.gov/html/nypd/home.html. The first episode features a six-minute look at the department’s harbor and scuba units.

headline: Manhattan: Two Fatally Shot
text: Two young men were fatally shot on a street in East Harlem early yesterday, the police said. The victims, Manuel Sabatera, 27, and Joshua Agard, 17, were each shot several times about 4:30 a.m. as they gathered with others who were listening to music and playing dice in front of 404 East 105th Street, an investigator said. A separate group approached Mr. Sabatera and Mr. Agard, with at least one of them firing a .40-caliber handgun, the investigator said. The investigator said Mr. Agard appeared to be the target. Mr. Sabatera was pronounced dead at Metropolitan Hospital Center; Mr. Agard was pronounced dead at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital, the police said. There were no arrests yesterday, the police said. Among detectives’ leading theories was that drugs played a role, the police said.

headline: Edwards Answers His Critics With Attack on ‘Terror Doctrine’
text: Former Senator John Edwards struck back yesterday at Republican critics who have called him soft on the war on terrorism, saying the party’s candidates “seem intent on trying to one-up each other in trying to be a bigger, badder, George Bush.”

headline: Paying the Price on Both Ends of a Hangman’s Rope
text: Timothy Spall is the quintessential blundering bloke in English movies. You’ve seen him in several Mike Leigh films, playing a portly working-class oaf with a sloping chin and chipmunk teeth, wearing a look of wide-eyed bafflement as he lumbers through life. Usually his characters convey a profound reticence. But when the stored-up indignities visited upon them become too much to bear, they can explode with apoplectic outrage.

headline: Getting a Deal on Some Pricey Political Real Estate
text: DES MOINES — Eight years ago this weekend, a campaign plane with the name “Great Expectations” landed in Iowa. George W. Bush was at the top of the manifest, making his maiden voyage to a state that would launch his candidacy for the White House.

headline: The Only Child (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 7, 2007

headline: In a Connecticut River, Fatter Fish and Happier Fishermen
text: THE Housatonic River, which flows through western Connecticut to Long Island Sound, made local headlines earlier this spring for flooding that uprooted trees and damaged homes. The bigger story, though, at least in the eyes of fishermen, is the river's improved health.

headline: A TB Patient Turns to His Inner Lawyer
text: ATLANTA, June 7 — Until last week, Theodore and Andrew Speaker had devoted their legal skills to the workaday custody disputes and personal injury claims that clients brought to their small father-son practice here.

headline: The Season for Sea Turtles
text: BARELY an hour into a beach excursion one May morning last year, Lisa Ellington had, as she describes it, the experience of a lifetime. A longtime lover of marine life, Ms. Ellington, who lives in San Antonio, had dreamed of seeing a sea turtle emerge from the surf to lay its eggs on the beach. Despite knowing that her chances were slim, she drove two hours to Padre Island National Seashore on the Texas coast, where rare Kemp’s ridley sea turtles were known to nest.

headline: Agency Sides With Ford in Parts Case
text: The Ford Motor Company won a ruling yesterday that barred the import of copycat grilles, headlamps and other parts for its top-selling F-150 truck.

headline: Former Killing Ground Becomes Shrine to Stalin’s Victims
text: BUTOVO, Russia — Barbed wire still lines the perimeter of the secret police compound here on the southern edge of Moscow where more, perhaps far more, than 20,000 people were shot and buried from August 1937 through October 1938, at the height of Stalin’s purges.

headline: Paraiso del Mar
text: WHAT Oceanfront residential resort.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Advertising column on Tuesday, about a decision by the London office of Saatchi & Saatchi to feature images of Kurt Cobain and other dead rock stars in ads for Dr. Martens footwear, included an outdated reference to an agency that arranges licensing deals involving deceased celebrities. The agency, Roger Richman, has been incorporated into Corbis; it is no longer a stand-alone agency.

headline: Spitzer Has a New Plan for Racing Franchise
text: ALBANY, June 7 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer has a proposal that would keep horse racing in the hands of the New York Racing Association, but would give one of the three private groups bidding on the state’s horse racing franchise control over future casino gambling operations.

headline: A Snake Around Her Neck and a Tragedy in Her Past
text: Bindi Irwin is 8 years old, she has straight bangs and crimped pigtails, and she has already appeared on both “Larry King Live” and “The Ellen DeGeneres Show.” The daughter of the celebrity naturalist Steve Irwin, who was killed by a stingray in his native Australia last year, Miss Irwin has become a kind of Shirley Temple of the wildlife conservation movement. “I’m trying to get across the message that don’t be afraid of animals,” People magazine quoted her as saying after her father’s death. “They’re just put on this earth to help the environment and everything like that.”

headline: To Gain Among Muslims, Indonesia Offers to Mediate Middle East Disputes
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — In April, Indonesia held a gathering of Sunni and Shiite clerics and scholars in an effort to contribute to reconciliation in Iraq, where the death toll is overwhelmingly the result of Muslims killing Muslims.

headline: The Yankees Draft a 6-Foot-10 Pitcher, Elating at Least One of Their Players
text: CHICAGO, June 7 — Before the 2006 season, Alex Rodriguez visited his neighbor Ramon Corona at North Carolina State. Corona is the Wolfpack’s second baseman, and Rodriguez attended a weekend series. He watched from behind the catcher as a 6-foot-10 right-hander warmed up.

headline: Mother Awarded $10 Million Asks Reopening of Police Case
text: The mother of an unarmed man killed by an undercover police officer seven years ago called on the Bronx district attorney’s office yesterday to reopen a criminal investigation after a jury awarded her $10.45 million for the wrongful death of her son.

headline: The Churn
text: People

headline: Lies, Sighs and Politics
text: In Tuesday’s Republican presidential debate, Mitt Romney completely misrepresented how we ended up in Iraq. Later, Mike Huckabee mistakenly claimed that it was Ronald Reagan’s birthday.

headline: Dow Jones Enhances the Severance Packages for Senior Managers
text: Dow Jones & Company may or may not be close to a sale, but yesterday it sweetened the pot for managers in case of a takeover.

headline: Some Small Law Firms Find Strength in Numbers
text: Steven Spielvogel, a lanky 40-year-old lawyer who, with his angular looks and jet black hair, resembles Ric Ocasek of the 1980s band the Cars, has been on something of a tour of his own.

headline: Fire at Motel in Georgia Kills 5 People and Injures 6
text: ATLANTA, June 7  Five people died and six were injured after a fast-moving fire engulfed a motel in Riverdale, Ga., on Thursday morning.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: U.S. Planning to Ease Rules on Passports, Official Says
text: HOUSTON, June 7  Responding to anguished travelers at risk of being grounded by a broken passport system, the government is expected to announce on Friday that it will ease its rules for summer travel in the Western Hemisphere, a Bush administration official said Thursday.

headline: Italy: Terrorism Suspects Held in Italy and Britain
text: The authorities in Milan issued arrest warrants for nine men suspected of providing logistical and financial support to Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, North Africa’s most active terrorist group. By evening, at least two of the suspects were in Italian custody. British authorities made a separate arrest in North London as part of the sweep. The North African group, formerly the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat, claimed responsibility for the suicide bombings in Algiers in April that killed 33 people.

headline: The Shame of the Cherokee Nation
text: Many members of Congress were rightly outraged by the Cherokee Nation’s decision earlier this year to revoke the tribal citizenship of about 2,800 descendants of slaves once owned by the tribe. The tribe’s leaders have since tried to avoid any punishment by restoring partial rights to some black members. Congress should disregard that ruse and move ahead with legislation that would force the Cherokee to comply with their treaty obligations and court decisions that guarantee black members full citizenship rights, including the right to vote and hold tribal office.

headline: Britain: Cadbury Acquires Gum Maker in Turkey
text: Cadbury Schweppes said it had agreed to buy Intergum of Turkey for $450 million to gain almost half of the country’s chewing gum market. Intergum, which has a 46 percent market share in Turkey, will be acquired from the Amram family, Cadbury said. Cadbury, which is based in London, is in the process of selling or spinning off its North American soft drinks unit, which makes Dr Pepper and 7Up.

headline: A Right to Panhandle? (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Vodafone Investors Seek Verizon Wireless Spinoff
text: LONDON, June 7 — The Vodafone Group, the world’s largest cellphone company, said on Thursday that it had received a letter from a group of shareholders asking it to return as much as £38 billion ($75 billion) to investors in part by spinning off its stake in Verizon Wireless.

headline: Rise in China’s Pork Prices Signals End to Cheap Output
text: GAOYAO, China, June 1 — Few things are as essential to the Chinese as their pigs.

headline: Once More, Cows Attract a Visitor to New York City
text: Many things draw visitors to New York: Broadway musicals, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, games at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Hartford: Commission Has Authority Over Sculpture
text: The State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the Historic District Commission of Fairfield has the authority to rule on whether an 80-foot-long sculpture may be installed in front of a house in the town’s Southport Historic District. The homeowner, Andrew J. Hall, had argued that the artwork, by the German sculptor Anselm Kiefer, was not subject to commission approval because it could not legally be considered a structure. The Supreme Court affirmed a lower court’s decision, saying the six-ton concrete and steel work fit within the commission’s jurisdiction. Mr. Hall said the decision meant the town “forfeits a major sculpture by one of the world’s greatest artists.” Compiled by John Sullivan

headline: Trading One Beach Retreat for Another
text: PROVINCETOWN was good to Mark Doty and his partner, Paul Lisicky, who shared an 18th-century Cape-style house there for the first 10 years of their 12-year relationship. Mr. Doty had gone there first, to seek solace with a former partner who was dying of AIDS, and wound up staying on for years with Mr. Lisicky. It was the ideal place for the pair of writers  rich with both literary and gay history, and home to an inspiring mix of dreamy landscapes and thrumming resort-town life.

headline: Strolling Within the Strange World of ‘Blue Velvet’
text: What would it be like to step inside a movie?

headline: Flights in Northeast Face Delays
text: Thunderstorms and computer failure combined to produce extensive air traffic delays in the Northeast this afternoon, with airports reporting departure delays of two hours or longer.

headline: New Jersey Senate Panel Supports Penalty for Smoking in Cars With Children Aboard
text: TRENTON, June 7  Smoking in New Jersey has been banned from the workplace, public buildings, bars, restaurants and even large swaths of the casino floors in Atlantic City. The next frontier is the family car with children aboard.

headline: Singing His Heart Out for the City of New Orleans
text: “I’m not going to dwell on it; I’m tired of talking about it,” the singer John Boutté said at Joe’s Pub on Wednesday night. He was referring to the state of affairs in New Orleans, where he was born and reared and where he still resides. And while the second part of his statement seemed true enough, the first part quickly proved otherwise.

headline: Bork v. Yale Club: Jurist Seeks Redress Over a Fall
text: In his days as a legal scholar, Robert H. Bork, the onetime Supreme Court nominee, engaged, as many scholars do, in high-minded debates about the august issues of the law. He wrote widely — sometimes controversially — about antitrust issues, the right to privacy and the limitations of the First Amendment.

headline: Pennsylvania Tries to Sell Itself as Backup for Wall Street During a Disaster
text: Hoping to capitalize on fears of the chaos another terrorist attack might cause in New York’s financial industry, Pennsylvania officials are promoting a corner of their state as Wall Street West.

headline: Quirks and Attitude to Burn
text: New York galleries are in the habit of saving their best — their newest, boldest, oddest — for last, for the annual blitz of end-of-season group shows that give exposure to underseen artists and freelance gigs to promising curators, while the commercial heat is down.

headline: Mexico’s Court Limits Reach of Big Media
text: MEXICO CITY, June 7 — The Mexican Supreme Court overwhelmingly voted Thursday to declare parts of a new media law unconstitutional, a blow to the country’s two main broadcasters who had hoped to extend their dominance in television to the Internet and telephone service.

headline: ‘Grey’s’ Star Said to Be Off the Show
text: Isaiah Washington, a star of the hit ABC television series “Grey’s Anatomy,” who became embroiled in a furor after he twice used an anti-gay slur against a co-star, will not return in the fall, an executive informed of the decision said last night.

headline: It’s Subpoena Time
text: For months, senators have listened to a parade of well-coached Justice Department witnesses claiming to know nothing about how nine prosecutors were chosen for firing. This week, it was the turn of Bradley Schlozman, a former federal attorney in Missouri, to be uninformative and not credible. It is time for Senator Patrick Leahy, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, to deliver subpoenas that have been approved for Karl Rove, former White House counsel Harriet Miers and their top aides, and to make them testify in public and under oath.

headline: Spurs Show That James Has Much to Learn
text: SAN ANTONIO, June 7 — The education of LeBron James, rising N.B.A. star, took on a decidedly rougher edge Thursday night, right around the time that he at last encountered the San Antonio Spurs.

headline: Selanne Takes Road Less Traveled on Way to the Stanley Cup Title
text: ANAHEIM, Calif., June 7 — Even when their logo was a cartoon, when their arena was a pond, when their name was a punch line, Teemu Selanne took them seriously.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Tuesday in the special Circuits section about the trend for consumers to have two or more models of some digital devices misstated the storage capacity of one model of Apple’s iPhone, which will be on the market at the end of the month. The model, which is to cost $599, has eight gigabytes of storage, not five.

headline: Gaza: One Dead in Factional Firefight
text: A Palestinian man was killed and at least nine other people were wounded in factional fighting in the southern Gaza Strip town of Rafah. Each of the rival factions, Hamas and Fatah, blamed the other for starting the shooting. The dead man belonged to Fatah. A report this week by the Palestinian Independent Commission for Citizens’ Rights said 616 Palestinians had been killed in internal fighting since the beginning of 2006. In the first half of May, fierce factional clashes left about 50 dead in Gaza. The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah, warned this week that the Palestinians were “on the verge of civil war.”

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page News Analysis article yesterday about the possibility of a presidential pardon for I. Lewis Libby Jr., who was convicted of lying to investigators in the C.I.A. leak case, referred incorrectly to Terence Hunt, a reporter for The Associated Press, in describing a scene in which President Bush cut off one reporter’s follow-up question about a pardon by moving on to another reporter who asked about Russia. Mr. Hunt was the reporter who tried to ask the follow-up question about the pardon; he was not the reporter who “changed the subject” to the new tensions about Russia. And it was an unidentified reporter  not Mr. Bush  who said, “Nice going, Terry.”

headline: Biomet Accepts Sweetened Takeover Offer
text: A group of private equity firms bidding for Biomet, a maker of artificial joints, sweetened its offer to $11.4 billion after a prominent shareholder adviser criticized its previous bid as too low.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on May 15 about the International Atomic Energy Agency’s latest assessment of Iran’s nuclear program referred imprecisely to information found in a design document that the agency’s inspectors have seen in Iran but that the Iranian authorities have declined to explain. The information shows how to make uranium into hemispheres, not spheres. (Depending on their precise design, some types of hemispheres of highly enriched uranium can be suitable for manufacturing a nuclear weapon.) (Go to Article)

headline: Congressman Pleads Not Guilty to Bribery
text: Representative William Jefferson, a Louisiana Democrat, pleaded not guilty today to federal charges that he solicited hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes while trying to arrange business deals in Africa.

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed article on May 21, about veganism, mischaracterized an aspect of traditional vegetarian Indian diets. Generally, these diets are lacto-vegetarian; they do not include eggs.

headline: Biased Drug Research (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Compromise on Global Warming Plan Averts Impasse at Group of 8 Meeting
text: HEILIGENDAMM, Germany, June 7 — The United States agreed Thursday to “consider seriously” a European plan to combat global warming by cutting in half worldwide greenhouse gas emissions by 2050, averting a trans-Atlantic deadlock at a meeting here of the world’s richest industrial nations.

headline: Tee Time Anytime
text: WHO Kevin Hoyle, 55, owner of a wealth management firm, from Rancho Santa Fe, Calif.

headline: G-8 Summit Winds Down With Africa Aid Pledge
text: HEILIGENDAMM, Germany, June 8 — As the Group of 8 summit meeting moved toward a conclusion, leaders reaffirmed a 2005 pledge of $60 billion to counter HIV and other illnesses in Africa, but did not set any new deadlines for delivering the aid.

headline: Child Rape Trial Relies on Confession, True or False
text: When the videotape began to play in a Queens courtroom this week, the jurors sat spellbound. For nearly half an hour, they watched as a day care worker named Khemwatie Bedessie described the sequence of events that she said led her to have sexual intercourse with a 4-year-old boy.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: West Side Garbage Plan (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: When Home Was Where the Art Was
text: One of the continuing rhetorical questions of our artistic era, asked in a 1971 essay by the art historian Linda Nochlin, is “Why have there been no great women artists?” One answer was already at large, thanks to Virginia Woolf, who put it this way in 1929 in “A Room of One’s Own”: “For most of history, Anonymous was a woman.”

headline: Something’s Up, and It’s Not the Surf
text: None of the music in David Milch’s new surfing series on HBO is by the Beach Boys. The surfing scenes are few and fleeting.

headline: Web Site Editor at BusinessWeek
text: John A. Byrne, executive editor of BusinessWeek, was named yesterday to lead the magazine’s Web site.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Sculpture Sale Is a Record

headline: A Reputed Mob Figure Is Found Shot to Death in His Bed
text: The reputed mobster was found face up in his white striped pajamas, his mouth agape, half hanging off his bed in his Brooklyn home. He had been shot once near his ear, in the back of his head, and late last night investigators were still searching for a motive.

headline: States Found to Vary Widely on Education
text: Academic standards vary so drastically from state to state that a fourth grader judged proficient in reading in Mississippi or Tennessee would fall far short of that mark in Massachusetts and South Carolina, the United States Department of Education said yesterday in a report that, for the first time, measured the extent of the differences.

headline: Philip K. Dick: A Sage of the Future Whose Time Has Finally Come
text: Philip K. Dick was still an obscure pulp novelist known mainly to teenage boys when a friend predicted that he would one day have more impact on the world than celebrated writers like William Faulkner, Norman Mailer and Kurt Vonnegut. The prediction seemed almost delusional in the 1960s, when Dick was popping pills around the clock and churning out novels in a science fiction ghetto from which he seemed destined never to escape.

headline: Arrests of 31 in U.S. Sweep Bring Fear in New Haven
text: NEW HAVEN, June 7 — Over the last several years, this city has gone to great lengths to turn itself into a kind of haven, quite literally, for illegal immigrants. It was not that new immigrants were pouring in, but that there were thousands already living here, and the officials who have long run the city wanted to bring them out of the shadows.

headline: As the Local Economy Prospers, So Does the Lobbying Industry
text: The strong local economy that is driving record city surpluses is also helping the lobbying industry.

headline: For a Cinematic Object of Desire, a Second Act
text: Released in 1967 to outrage and condemnation, Luis Buñuel’s sublime “Belle de Jour” stars a frosty, breathtakingly young Catherine Deneuve as a proper bourgeois wife who, by becoming a whore, liberates herself, ruins her husband and possibly goes mad. That, at least, is one way to read the film’s perverse and intentionally ambiguous finale, with its frozen teardrop, ringing bells, beatific smiles and the startling image of the paralyzed, catatonic husband rising like Lazarus from his wheelchair, as if suddenly, miraculously healed.

headline: At G-8 Meeting, a Familiar Song (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: At Haditha Hearing, Dueling Views of a Battalion Commander
text: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., June 7 — Through three combat deployments in Iraq, a Bronze Star and numerous combat ribbons, Lt. Col. Jeffrey R. Chessani’s Marine Corps career has been defined, it seems, by terrorist bombs.

headline: Let’s Twist Again, Dude, as the Screws Turn
text: Rehab as a spectator sport has become such a girlie affair, thanks to the pink-tinged public meltdowns of Britney, Lindsay, et al., that it’s kind of gratifying to watch Neil LaBute grease the road to recovery with his patented brand of testosterone.

headline: Brooklyn: Judge Questions Murder Charges
text: Prosecutors and the police failed to ask important questions about the killing of a witness to a Mafia murder, a judge said yesterday at a pretrial hearing. The judge, Gustin L. Reichbach of State Supreme Court, said he would decide on Monday whether to dismiss murder charges against the defendant, John Sinagra. Mr. Sinagra is charged with the 1990 killing of the witness, Patrick Porco, 18. Prosecutors brought murder charges against Mr. Sinagra last year as part of their case against a former F.B.I. supervisor, Roy Lindley DeVecchio, who has been accused of helping a Mafia informer commit several killings. Justice Reichbach called a series of hearings compelling prosecutors to show good cause for their delay in bringing charges. Prosecutors have disclosed documents showing that Mr. Sinagra was named as a suspect as early as 1995, but that the police later closed the case, attributing the Porco killing to a man who had since died.

headline: They Always Come Out Ahead; Bet on It
text: Ah, bliss, the gang’s all here, well, the guys anyway, looking fighting trim and Hollywood beautiful, at your disposable pleasure as well as mine. There’s George, of course, as in Mr. Clooney, lovely and lean and a touch more gray, smiling and gliding his way through the shimmer and gleam. Brad, henceforth known as Pitt the Elder, looks a wee tired around the eyes, like a baby-bottle warmer on 3 a.m. call, while Matt Damon looks handsomer, somehow more adult, now that he has a lucrative action franchise to call his own. The third time really is a charm.
