text: POP

headline: Cellphone Ban in Schools (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Built for Stargazing
text: IN an astronomy village, a hush falls at night as the sky turns dark and the stars appear. Roofs roll back and telescopes aim for the heavens. All the neighbors are stargazing, and nobody turns on the lights.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Pace to Retire as Joint Chiefs Chairman
text: WASHINGTON, June 8 — Gen. Peter Pace is being replaced as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, a move that reflects a feeling among top civilian officials at the Pentagon and in the White House that the American military needs new leadership after years of being strained by the conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: A One-Light Town Grows Into a Second-Home Hotspot
text: A decade ago, an average visit to Milford, Pa., might have lasted about 20 seconds, which is how long it takes for the one traffic light in this small northeastern Pennsylvania town to turn from yellow to red to green.

headline: Immigration Bill Sponsors Vow to Press On
text: WASHINGTON, June 8 — The authors of a comprehensive immigration bill said today that they would try to resuscitate the measure, which stalled Thursday when the Senate refused to cut off debate, as President Bush urged senators from both parties to bring the bill back to the floor.

headline: State Lawmakers Give Bloomberg Traffic Plan a Cool Reception
text: State lawmakers gave a cordial but cool reception today to the congestion pricing plan proposed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, asking whether it amounted to a regressive tax on middle-class drivers and whether its costs were worth the promised benefits.

headline: After Key Arrest by Serbia, European Union Is to Reopen Talks
text: BELGRADE, Serbia, June 7  The European Union said Thursday that it would resume negotiations with Serbia next week on an agreement that is the first step toward possible membership in the bloc.

headline: Reading the Body Language at the Summit
text: HEILIGENDAMM, German, June 8 -- Body language is everything when world leaders gather — especially when one of those leaders is President Bush.

headline: Demands for Loan Information
text: The Senate Banking Committee and Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York sent joint letters to the nation’s 20 largest student lenders, demanding information on how they set rates and fees on student loans, as part of a growing investigation into possible discrimination in student lending. The letter gives lenders until the end of next week to say which criteria they use, including “college, college location, graduation rate, historic default rate, gender, age, parental income, credit history and any other factors used or considered in underwriting determinations.” Separately, the House Education Committee made a similar request of the five top student lenders, “to help determine whether the lenders offer less favorable terms to students at predominately minority colleges.”

headline: Handicapping the Tonys (I Got the Plays Right Here)
text: Let’s get one thing out of the way first: That 800-pound mobster in the room. Remember TiVo, people? The theater industry is counting on you to use it.

headline: New War Czar Wins Praise, but White House Is Faulted
text: WASHINGTON, June 7 — Senate Democrats praised the three-star Army general picked by President Bush as the new Iraq coordinator but sought to bury elements of that Iraq policy, saying the need to appoint an Iraq “czar” four years after the invasion proved the White House had lost control of the war effort.

headline: Reviving the Hamilton Agenda
text: These days there seem to be four schools of political economic thought. First, there are the limited government conservatives, who think taxes should be low and the state should be as small as possible. Second, there are the Hamiltonians, who believe in free market capitalism but think government should help people get the tools they need to compete in it.

headline: Waiting for Al Gore (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some copies on Wednesday about a shootout in New Brunswick, N.J., in which a 21-year-old man was killed and a police officer was wounded gave an erroneous surname from the police for the dead man. He was Sixto Martinez, not Hernandez. The article also misspelled the surname of a neighbor of Mr. Martinez’s who said she heard shots fired but thought they were firecrackers. She is Daniela Tamarez, not Taniarez.

headline: Phillies Rally Against Wagner, and Sweep Mets
text: A fan seated behind the Mets’ dugout held up a bright orange sign with black lettering during the top of the sixth inning yesterday that read, “We believe.”

headline: China: Students Riot
text: Hundreds of angry students rioted on Wednesday night in the central city of Zhengzhou after a city inspector beat a female student, according to a Hong Kong-based rights group, the Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy. It reported that students from three universities poured into the streets, overturning cars and destroying property for more than four hours. The rampage apparently erupted after an inspector knocked out the front teeth of the female student, who was running an illegal street vending stall. The police later detained a handful of students. A local newspaper also reported that several inspectors were later fired or reprimanded.

headline: Artificial Sweetener Rivals Renew a Heated Court Fight
text: The sugar wars have a sour new chapter.

headline: The Chorus Is Dancing, and the Mother’s Grim
text: Death pervades “The House of Bernarda Alba,” not only the two that are knelled at the beginning and end of Federico García Lorca’s last play but also the suffocating atmosphere that permeates life for the inhabitants inside. The National Asian American Theater Company has mounted a first-rate revival in an adaptation by Chay Yew that is somewhat abbreviated but maintains García Lorca’s tragic claustrophobia.

headline: A New Danger in Iraq
text: Absolutely the last thing Iraq needs right now is to have thousands of Turkish troops pour across the border into the country’s one relatively peaceful region  the Kurdish-administered northeast. Turkey’s government needs to know that it will reap nothing but disaster if that happens.

headline: Shakespeare, Naturally
text: ALL the world’s a stage, sure, but what might Shakespeare have made of the dramatic possibilities of a Lower East Side parking lot, with cars backing out right into the Capulets’ masked ball? Or “Love’s Labour’s Lost” on a stroll through Central Park, as helmeted bicyclists whiz by?

headline: Protests Rage Against Musharraf; Aides Criticize Justice He Ousted
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 7 — In protests around the country, thousands of lawyers and members of opposition parties demonstrated Thursday against new government curbs on the news media, as senior military and intelligence officials presented affidavits to the Supreme Court in the case against the suspended chief justice.

headline: Happening Upon a Look at an Optimistic Lincoln
text: WASHINGTON, June 7 — It was a historian’s dream: alone in dimly lighted stacks, leafing through hundreds of yellowed papers and stumbling across a document that clarifies a pivotal moment in United States history.

headline: Turkey Rattles Its Sabers at Militant Kurds in Iraq
text: CIZRE, Turkey, June 7 — Turkey is stepping up its presence along its border with Iraq to levels not seen in years in an effort to root out Kurdish separatist guerrillas who take refuge in northern Iraq.

headline: Immigrant Bill, Short 15 Votes, Stalls in Senate
text: WASHINGTON, June 7 —The sweeping immigration overhaul endorsed by President Bush crumbled in the Senate on Thursday night, leaving the future of one of the administration’s chief domestic priorities in serious doubt.

headline: Secret Prisons in 2 Countries Held Qaeda Suspects, Report Says
text: LONDON, June 7  Investigators have confirmed the existence of clandestine C.I.A. prisons in Romania and Poland housing leading members of Al Qaeda, contends a new report from the Council of Europe, the European human rights monitoring agency.

headline: A French Songbird’s Life, in Chronological Disorder
text: As if acknowledging the challenges it faces in finding an American audience, “La Vie en Rose,” Olivier Dahan’s long, feverish film biography of Édith Piaf, notes that its heroine, an incomparably bright star in the French cultural firmament, never quite caught on over here. After a less than rapturous stateside reception, the film’s Piaf (played by Marion Cotillard) observes that Americans just don’t get her, and though she seems to have a good time in New York and California, the incomprehension appears to have been mutual. She won’t even try a corned beef sandwich at a Manhattan delicatessen.

headline: War Notions: Victory, Defeat, Reality (8 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A sports headline and an article in some copies yesterday about the Anaheim Ducks’ defeat of the Ottawa Senators to capture the Stanley Cup referred incorrectly to the accomplishment. Anaheim is the first West Coast team to win the Cup since the National Hockey League took control starting with the 1927 playoffs; it is not the first West Coast team ever to win the championship. That distinction is held by the Vancouver Millionaires, who took the Cup in 1915. (The Seattle Metropolitans won in 1917, and the Victoria Cougars in 1925.)

headline: One City’s Home Sellers Do Better on Their Own
text: It sounds like the setup for a dull economist’s joke. Who gets the better deal: the cautious economist who sells his house through a real estate agent, or his risk-taking colleague who finds a buyer on his own?

headline: After Setbacks, Shuttle Is Ready for Launching
text: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 7 — Three months after its external fuel tank took thousands of dings and pockmarks from the golf-ball-size hailstones of a freakish winter storm, the space shuttle Atlantis is ready to fly.

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The David Pogue column in the special Circuits section on Tuesday, about Web sites for sharing and printing photos, incorrectly described a feature of one site, Kodak Gallery. While a user with a free or paid account can upload photos to the site (kodakgallery.com) and allow others to view them, the site does not allow others to download them. But it has a “Print@Home” feature that lets others print photos without downloading them.

headline: Pitchers Dominate First Round of the Draft
text: It helped to be a left-handed pitcher yesterday during the first round of Major League Baseball’s first-year player draft, or a pitcher of any kind.

headline: Paris Hilton Is Ordered Back to Jail
text: LOS ANGELES, June 8  The national obsession with celebrity collided head-on with the more serious issue of the equal application of justice on Friday, as a judge sent the socialite Paris Hilton back to jail some 36 hours after she was released for an unspecified medical problem.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: New Hampshire to Repeal Parental Notification Law
text: BOSTON, June 7  New Hampshire will become the first state to repeal a law requiring teenage girls to notify their parents before having an abortion, under a bill that won final passage in the State Senate on Thursday.

headline: Bronx: Bones Found in Sinkhole
text: City officials inspecting a sinkhole yesterday discovered what may be human remains underground, the police said. The sinkhole, near Wilson Avenue and East 214th Street in Williamsbridge, developed several weeks ago and grew to about 3 feet square, neighbors said. Residents had complained to the Department of Environmental Protection, which sent workers yesterday. Department employees found several bones, including what appeared to be a femur and a jaw bone. The remains will be passed to the medical examiner’s office, the police said.

headline: Democrats May Subpoena N.S.A. Documents
text: WASHINGTON, June 7 — Senior House Democrats threatened Thursday to issue subpoenas to obtain secret legal opinions and other documents from the Justice Department related to the National Security Agency’s domestic wiretapping program.

headline: Yields on Treasuries Climb; Shares Tumble Again
text: Not long ago, Wall Street trembled when it looked as if the slowing American economy might be getting worse. But now, anxiety over the potential for higher inflation, driven by a strong global economy, is preoccupying investors.

headline: Art in Review
text: NICK Z. AND KAI ALTHOFF

headline: ’96 Winner of the Tour Loses Title for Doping
text: The organizer of the Tour de France declared yesterday that the 1996 version of cycling’s most important race no longer had a winner.

headline: Putin Surprises Bush With Plan on Missile Shield
text: ROSTOCK, Germany, June 7 — After months of angrily rejecting a White House plan for missile defense in Europe, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia surprised President Bush on Thursday with an offer to build a joint system in the former Soviet Republic of Azerbaijan.

headline: Afghanistan: Hostages Swapped for Taliban Body
text: The Taliban released four members of an Afghan medical team kidnapped and held hostage since March after the government handed over the body of the senior Taliban commander Mullah Dadullah, said Qayum Pukhla, the director of the health department in Kandahar. The four, a doctor, two nurses and a driver described as thin and frail, were quickly reunited with their families. Members of the Taliban said that the Afghan government handed over the body of Mullah Dadullah, killed in fighting last month, on Wednesday evening and that was why they released the four hostages. They said they had killed the fifth member of the team, a pharmacist, because the government did not hand over the commander’s body within the ultimatum set earlier this week.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A television review on Wednesday about “We Love Ella! A Tribute to the First Lady of Song,” a PBS “Great Performances” concert, misidentified the site of the concert. It was Los Angeles, not San Diego.

headline: Thrust Into Spotlight, Trainer Is Unable to Shake Past
text: Until the third Saturday in May, Steve Asmussen was mostly known in thoroughbred racing circles as a driven and ambitious second-generation horseman. He trains 200 horses in a half-dozen sites from Texas to New York. Some are relatively cheap claiming horses, others are of a much higher caliber. They help him win a lot of races.

headline: America’s Cup Gets Interesting
text: VALENCIA, Spain -- Now the America’s Cup gets really interesting, even if the sailing is not guaranteed to do the same.

headline: Wie Endures a Rough Week and First Round
text: HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., June 7  It was obvious from the start, when Michelle Wie took aim at her first fairway of this L.P.G.A. Championship with a 3-wood in her hands, that she was not the same golfer who contended for the title here last year.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,487 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Manhattan: Money to Support Parents in Schools
text: Robert Jackson, the chairman of the City Council Education Committee, yesterday proposed a $3.2 million budget outlay to support programs that encourage parent involvement in public schools. “We want parents to be empowered for themselves and for their children,” Mr. Jackson, said at a news conference on the steps of City Hall, echoing a common complaint by parents that the Department of Education fails to seek their input before making decisions. If approved, the money would help pay for educational outreach, a parents hot line for resolving school issues and other support services.

headline: Bombs and Gunmen in Iraq Kill at Least 22 and Wound 55
text: BAGHDAD, June 7 — A suicide bomber detonated his explosives and a bus bomb exploded minutes apart near a police station in northern Iraq on Thursday, killing at least nine people and wounding 22, the authorities said.

headline: A Girl Recovers at a Hospital, but Answers and a Happy Ending Remain Elusive
text: Unable to hold back tears, the mother of a 15-year-old Connecticut girl who was discovered in a locked crawl space at the home of three adults said yesterday that she was impatient to get her daughter back.

headline: In Napa, Wilderness Above the Wineries
text: AFTER hours of tromping through the hills of Napa County, beneath towering redwoods, over mountain creeks, past ruins of 19th-century homesteads, there still wasn't a single grape to be seen.

headline: Veterans’ Benefits System Needs Overhaul, Panel Says
text: A panel of medical experts called yesterday for a sweeping overhaul of the way veterans’ disability claims are judged, saying the current system is riddled with obsolete medical definitions and ignores the impact of injuries on veterans’ quality of life.

headline: Larry Leon Hamlin, 58, Dies; Promoted Black Theaters
text: Larry Leon Hamlin, the founder and executive director of the National Black Theater Festival, a gathering for theater professionals and an influential showcase for artists, died Wednesday at his home in Pfafftown, N.C. He was 58.

headline: Movers Come to Times Sq., but the Name Stays
text: Let’s say that a company moves out of a New York neighborhood that has borne its name for more than a century. Let’s also say that we are talking about the place where the ball drops every New Year’s Eve. In this age of naming rights and branding strategies, some people might be eager for a change.

headline: Janet S. Sainer, 88, Leader of New York Office for Elderly, Dies
text: Janet S. Sainer, who as commissioner of New York City’s Department for the Aging in the 1980s created programs to keep older people active, educate them on health issues, provide them with meals on weekends and help their caregivers, died Monday while attending a training conference on the elderly in Denver. She was 88 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: Inflation Fears Again Chill the Markets
text: Anxiety over high inflation, which has preoccupied investors all week, sent bond prices falling today and pushed the interest rate on the benchmark United States Treasury note above 5 percent for the first time since last summer.

headline: Good Form Once, but Now a Dark Horse
text: MANCHESTER, N.H., June 7 — How does a presidential candidate, consigned to the “lower tier,” distinguish himself in a field of 10 Republican hopefuls whose debates are a diorama of white male politicians in dark suits?

headline: Italy Braces for Legal Fight Over Secret C.I.A. Program
text: ROME, June 7 — There is no dispute over the central event of Feb. 17, 2003, on Via Guerzoni in Milan: an imam, known as Abu Omar and eyed as a terrorism suspect, vanished while walking to his mosque.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (Disney) JOHNNY KAPAHALA: BACK ON BOARD (2007) In this sequel to “Johnny Tsunami,” the 1999 Disney movie, Johnny Kapahala (Brandon Baker, left), now a 17-year-old Vermont snowboarder, returns to his hometown in Hawaii for the wedding of his surfer grandfather (Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa) — and meets 12-year-old Chris, who is soon to be his uncle. Turns out that Uncle Chris (Jake T. Austin) is a budding rebel with a passion for mountain boarding and a surly attitude. When Chris joins the Dirt Devils, a tough boarding crew, Johnny tries his hand at the sport in an attempt at family bonding. Beware: rocky patches ahead!

headline: Brooklyn: Fire Kills Infant and Injures Others
text: A fire swept through a home in East New York last night, killing a baby and injuring three other people, including two children, the Fire Department said. The fire at 182 Atkins Avenue was reported at 9:48 p.m. and was under control within 20 minutes, department officials said. The conditions of the injured people were not known, and investigators were still trying to determine the cause last night.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Public Lives profile on May 25, about Martin Garbus, a Manhattan lawyer representing the fired radio host Don Imus in his pending lawsuit against CBS, misidentified the mentor to Mr. Garbus who won all nine cases he argued before the United States Supreme Court. It was Ephraim London  not Emile Zola Berman, who represented Sirhan B. Sirhan, Robert F. Kennedy’s assassin.

headline: Putin Offers Alternatives on Missile Defense
text: MOSCOW, June 8 —President Vladimir V. Putin today offered new suggestions for alternatives to a missile defense system in Europe, suggesting that Russia would not object to American interceptor missiles in Iraq, Turkey or at sea, and proposing that Russian and the West study emerging missile threats together.

headline: Putting the We Back in Wii
text: TOKYO, June 7 — If there is a secret to the smash success of Nintendo’s Wii video game console, it may be this: even the creative loner can benefit from having friends.

headline: The Joys of Teaching? Get Lost, Mr. Chips
text: The gawky, overweight high school students in the fictional documentary “Chalk” are the antithesis of the sleek mean girls and buff junior studs of the typical Hollywood high school melodrama. Slouched glumly in their seats, they regard a new teacher with the blank gazes of bored, sullen prisoners serving out their sentences.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Sunday about the Reebok Grand Prix track and field event on Randalls Island referred incorrectly in some copies to the wind speed during the 100-meter dash. It was recorded at 2.2 meters a second, not miles an hour. The allowable wind speed for a world record to count in the event is 2.0 meters a second, not miles an hour.

headline: As Money Pours in, Hedge Funds Come to Look More Like the Markets
text: “We are somewhere between the third and fifth inning in the growth of assets invested in alternative strategies,” said Todd Builione, a managing partner at Highbridge Capital Management, a $34 billion hedge fund that is majority owned by JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Steroid Investigators Requested Giambi’s Cooperation
text: Before Commissioner Bud Selig requested that Jason Giambi of the Yankees meet with George J. Mitchell for Mitchell’s investigation into the use of performance-enhancing substances in Major League Baseball, Mitchell had already sent Giambi a letter seeking his cooperation.

headline: New York in All Its Nuts-and-Bolts Glory
text: The exhibition “New York Rises” makes a case for adding Eugene de Salignac, the official photographer for the New York City Department of Bridges, Plant and Structures from 1903 to 1934, to the canon of American photographers whose images are forever linked with the city. If he is not the equal of Berenice Abbott, Margaret Bourke-White, Walker Evans and Alfred Stieglitz, his work now on view at the Museum of the City of New York demonstrates that he is at least their kin.

headline: Curators Under the Sea
text: Chicago

headline: A Vigilant Eye on Threats to the ‘Capital of the World’
text: MARK J. MERSHON, the assistant director in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s New York City headquarters, is not quite sure he wants it known that he considers the bluish fabric of the office furniture he inherited “just horrible.” Slippery. Shiny. Not particularly masculine. Has to be offensive, he notes, for him to even notice it.

headline: Do You Want to Be a Music Critic This Summer?
text: The old saying “Everyone’s a critic” has taken on added meaning in the age of blogging. Millions of people are now able to share their opinions with the public, a privilege formerly limited to professionals with mainstream bully pulpits.

headline: A Hail of Shots Kills 3 Young Men in Brooklyn
text: A placid evening of socializing by a group of friends on a stoop in Brownsville, Brooklyn, turned bloody Wednesday night when a gunman walked up and opened fire, killing three young men, the police and neighbors said yesterday.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: A VIOLENT SPECTACLE’S LAST GASP

headline: British Contractor Paid Saudi, Reports Say
text: LONDON, June 7 — A major British arms contractor paid more than $2 billion clandestinely into bank accounts in Washington controlled by Prince Bandar bin Sultan of Saudi Arabia, two British news organizations reported Thursday. Prince Bandar denied accepting “improper secret commissions.”

headline: Bronx: Man Shot to Death
text: A 26-year-old man was fatally shot about 5:30 p.m. yesterday on Fulton Avenue near East 172nd Street, the police said. The man, who was shot several times, including once in the head, was taken to St. Barnabas Hospital in critical condition and later pronounced dead. The police did not release his identity. No arrests had been made.

headline: The Diana Chronicles
text: Like any writer examining the life and death of Diana, Princess of Wales, Tina Brown must peer into the world of British royalty with nose pressed to the glass. Unlike almost all of the others, Ms. Brown does not fog the windowpanes. In “The Diana Chronicles”  which is her “maiden foray into long-form nonfiction,” or first book  this celebrated editor, mover and shaker brings her own sort of privilege to the realm of aristocratic fairy tales. She knows this world much better than many who inhabit it.

headline: City Traffic Pricing Wins U.S. and Spitzer’s Favor
text: ALBANY, June 7 — Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan to reduce traffic by charging people who drive into the busiest parts of Manhattan received significant support on Thursday as Gov. Eliot Spitzer endorsed the idea and the Bush administration indicated that New York stood to gain hundreds of millions of dollars if the plan were enacted.

headline: Ivanovic Reaches the French Open Final With a Smile
text: PARIS, June 7 — With eyes wide and eyebrows raised, Ana Ivanovic watched Maria Sharapova’s final forehand sail past the baseline to end their semifinal match at the French Open.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on May 15 about the International Atomic Energy Agency’s latest assessment of Iran’s nuclear program referred imprecisely to information found in a design document that the agency’s inspectors have seen in Iran but that the Iranian authorities have declined to explain. The information shows how to make uranium into hemispheres, not spheres. (Depending on their precise design, some types of hemispheres of highly enriched uranium can be suitable for manufacturing a nuclear weapon.)

headline: Hamas Leader Calls for End to Clashes
text: JERUSALEM, June 8 — The Palestinian prime minister, Ismail Haniya of Hamas, today called for warring factions to muster the political will to stop the continuing intra-Palestinian clashes between his own faction and Fatah, who sit together in a unity government.

headline: Mexico: Cemex Gains Control of Rinker
text: Cemex, the Mexican cement maker, gained a controlling stake in the Rinker Group of Australia, completing its largest acquisition and increasing its share of the United States market with the $14.2 billion deal. In a filing to the Australian stock exchange, Cemex said it had received acceptances from investors holding 50.34 percent of Rinker. The offer for all of Rinker’s shares expires June 22. Cemex, based in Monterrey, Mexico, had to sweeten its six-month-old unsolicited offer by 22 percent in April to win management approval. Rinker, which is based in Sydney, receives about 80 percent of sales from the United States, where Cemex is already the largest cement company.

headline: Candidates’ Tax Plans Are a Mystery
text: Opportunities for real tax reform are rare. But when they do come along, something good can happen only if political leaders are prepared with a plan they can sell to a populace that knows the shortcomings of the present system but is suspicious of changes that may cost them money.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Savannah, a City Close to Its Ghosts
text: WHEN it comes to finding child-friendly haunts in the South, Savannah might not be the first city that comes to mind. After all, endless tours of historic mansions and myriad distinctive, though largely grown-up, galleries and stores would be enough to bore any energetic youngster. But it turns out that this vibrant 18th-century port city — and nearby Tybee Island, with its lovely, expansive beach — can be equal fun for young and old.

headline: Sprinter From Queens Tries to Go the Distance
text: SACRAMENTO, June 7 — Natasha Hastings craved running success so badly that three times during the week of Christmas she drove more than 200 miles from her family’s new home south of Atlanta to Columbia, S.C., for a day of training with Curtis Frye, her coach at South Carolina.

headline: For the Adventurous, an Earthbound Ride on the Shuttle
text: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 7  Hitching a ride on the space shuttle comes to the lucky few only after a long selection process and arduous training. But the Kennedy Space Center visitor complex has worked with current and former astronauts to develop a ride that just may be the next best thing.

headline: Defense Team for Bonds’s Trainer Is Set to Argue for His Release
text: Since the investigation of the Bay Area Laboratory Co-Operative began five years ago, one man has spent more time behind bars than anyone in the federal drug case: Greg Anderson, the former personal trainer of Barry Bonds.

headline: Good Day for Torre, but Not Everyone’s Happy
text: CHICAGO, June 7 — Joe Torre needed six victories to reach 2,000 for his managerial career, and it seemed as if he might not make it. The Yankees were going nowhere last Wednesday, with five losses in a row, so Torre canceled batting practice and benched Bobby Abreu.

headline: Baby Dies in East New York Fire
text: An infant girl was killed in a Brooklyn fire last night when her mother left three children at home by themselves to get Chinese food, the police and neighbors said. Two neighbors who dashed into the apartment to save one of the older children were initially unaware of the baby, who was in a stroller in a bedroom.

headline: India, Said to Play Down AIDS, Has Many Fewer With Virus Than Thought, Study Finds
text: NEW DELHI, June 7 — India, which has been repeatedly accused of denying the size of its AIDS epidemic, probably has millions fewer victims than has been widely believed, according to a new but still unreleased household survey.

headline: Harvey R. Colten, 68, a Pediatric Immunologist, Is Dead
text: Dr. Harvey R. Colten, a pediatric immunologist and a leading medical educator at Columbia University whose research helped isolate a gene tied to respiratory failure in infants, died on May 24 in Manhattan. He was 68.

headline: Florida: Recordings for Jury’s Ears First
text: A federal judge in Miami ruled that the government does not have to provide reporters covering the terrorism trial of Jose Padilla with recordings of wiretapped phone calls until a day after the jury hears them. The judge, Marcia G. Cooke of Federal District Court, did order the government to give reporters transcripts of the recordings the same day they are played in court, but as late as 10 p.m. That could make it difficult or impossible for news outlets to report on the proceedings as they happen. The Associated Press, joined by CNN, The New York Times and The Washington Post, filed a motion last week requesting the transcripts and tapes on the same day they are presented to the jury.

headline: Owner Is Accused of Looting His Car Service to Seek Office in Africa
text: The president of a Brooklyn-based car service business not only looted his own company but also used the money to finance his campaign for elective office in his native Ghana, prosecutors said yesterday.

headline: U.S. Border Passport Rules Suspended
text: Responding to anguished travelers at risk of being grounded by a broken passport system, the government announced today that it is easing its rules for summer travel in the Western Hemisphere.

headline: The Park’s the Thing
text: A selection of summer Shakespeare presentations in New York. Schedule and ticket information is available from the companies.

headline: Bribery Investigation Looks at Senator Stevens
text: GIRDWOOD, Alaska — The neighbors of Senator Ted Stevens occasionally catch a glimpse of him at his house in this ski resort outside Anchorage.

headline: Don’t Ask, Don’t Translate
text: Atlanta

headline: Mets Activate Valentín and Put Chávez on Disabled List
text: As expected, the Mets placed outfielder Endy Chávez on the 15-day disabled list yesterday and activated second baseman José Valentín. The move reflected the way the Mets’ season has been going: Just when one player is healthy enough to return, another is injured.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Wednesday with a sports article about the Mets’ 4-2 extra-innings loss to the Phillies carried an incorrect credit. The photograph of a play at home plate involving the Mets’ David Wright and the Philliles’ Carlos Ruiz was by Ray Stubblebine of Reuters, not Barton Silverman of The New York Times.

headline: Setback Aside, James Transcends His Generation
text: San Antonio

headline: Patent Ruling Strikes a Blow at Qualcomm
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 7 — Millions of new mobile phones containing certain Qualcomm semiconductors could be barred from import into the United States under a ruling issued Thursday by a federal government agency in a patent dispute.

headline: G-8 Summit Winds Down With Africa Aid Pledge
text: KUÜHLUNGSBORN, Germany, June 8 — Adjourning a meeting marked by some surprises and a less contentious tone than many expected, the leaders of the world’s richest industrial nations pledged today to commit $60 billion for treatment of AIDS and other diseases in the developing world.

headline: At a London Fair, a Helping Hand, a Discerning Eye
text: Because some people find the process of acquiring antiques intimidating, Clarion Arts, the organizer of the Summer Fair Olympia in London, has sought out an impartial team of experts to accompany visitors around that arts and antiques fair this week.

headline: A Venetian Customs House for Contemporary Art
text: Venice, June 7 — François Pinault, the luxury-goods magnate and art collector who owns Christie’s, arrived here this week not simply to peruse the hundreds of art installations that make up this year’s Venice Biennale, but also for the formal signing of an agreement on Friday between the City of Venice and his Palazzo Grassi to create a contemporary-art center in an unused customs house called Punta della Dogana, at the entrance to the Grand Canal.

headline: In One City, Home Sellers Find It Pays to Cut Out Middleman
text: A study to be released today based on home-sales data from 1998 to 2004 in Madison, Wis., says that people in that city who sold their homes through real estate agents typically did not get a higher sale price than people who sold their homes themselves. When the agent’s commission is factored in, the for-sale-by-owner people came out ahead financially.

headline: A New Era: United States 1, Guatemala 0
text: This was the United States’s first competitive match under Coach Bob Bradley and without the retired veterans Brian McBride, Claudio Reyna and Eddie Pope. How does the future of the U.S. team look to you?

headline: No Moose Call to Schilling on the Near Miss
text: Until Boston’s Curt Schilling lost a no-hitter Thursday with two outs in the ninth inning at Oakland, the Yankees’ Mike Mussina had the dubious distinction of being the last pitcher to come so close to a no-hitter without getting it.

headline: Can a Subtenant Collect an Overcharge?
text: Q I am subletting a rent-stabilized apartment. I recently found out that the original tenant is charging me about $400 more than his rent and that in our contract he states that I am his roommate rather than subtenant. Can I get back what he has overcharged?

headline: For sale: Rupert Murdoch’s former home
text: Exterior

headline: Getting in Tune
text: Additional images from the restoration of the Wanamaker Organ in Philadelphia.

headline: Teach Your Parents Well
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Pulse
text: Who’s your daddy?  Here’s his gift.

headline: Theater Briefs
text: With the sinking of "The Pirate Queen" it's now official: The new musical "Young Frankenstein" — excuse us, "The New Mel Brooks Musical Young Frankenstein" — will open at the Hilton Theater on Broadway on Nov. 8, with previews set to begin on Oct. 11.

headline: U.S. Commitment-Phobia
text: German Chancellor Angela Merkel and U.S. President George Bush during the second working meeting at the G8 Summit. Guido Bergmann/ Bundesregierung/AP

headline: The Artists Take Over
text: Additional images from Swedish artists' unofficial annexation of the Isola San Michele.

headline: Where Off Off Took Off
text: Last fall the theater company Peculiar Works Project took audiences back in time by way of a tour that meandered through Greenwich Village, stopping at Off Off Broadway’s earliest locales. Along the way actors performed excerpts from seminal works of downtown theater. But the company was only telling half the story.

headline: Ravaged Beauty
text: Bridesmaids have had a hostile relationship with their dresses for years. Now, brides are acting the same way.

headline: Cemex Gains Control of Rinker
text: Cemex, the Mexican cement maker, gained a controlling stake in the Rinker Group of Australia, completing its largest acquisition and increasing its share of the United States market with the $14.2 billion deal. In a filing with the Australian stock exchange, Cemex said it had received acceptances from investors holding 50.34 percent of Rinker.

headline: Mexico’s Court Limits Reach of Big Media
text: The Mexican Supreme Court overwhelmingly voted Thursday to declare parts of a new media law unconstitutional, a blow to the country’s two main broadcasters who had hoped to extend their dominance in television to the Internet and telephone service.

headline: Pennsylvania Pitches ‘Wall Street West’
text: Hoping to capitalize on fears of the chaos another terrorist attack might cause in New York’s financial industry, Pennsylvania officials are promoting a corner of their state as Wall Street West. So far, however, the real Wall Street hasn’t shown any serious interest in putting data backup centers in that part of Pennsylvania.

headline: Hedge Funds Are Looking More Like the Markets
text: Alternative investments continue to be the rage among wealth managers for a number of reasons, including the low correlations that hedge funds have historically had with major equity and bond markets. (In other words, when those markets tank, hedge funds, in general, do not.)

headline: 2 Executives at Center of Dow Chemical Scandal File Suit
text: Two former Dow Chemical executives have sued the company, seeking payment of their legal fees for lawsuits and a Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry. Ex-Chief Financial Officer J. Pedro Reinhard and former Executive Vice President Romeo Kreinberg, were fired April 12 after being accused of holding unauthorized talks to sell the largest U.S. chemical maker.

headline: Some Small Law Firms Find Strength in Numbers
text: The International Network of Boutique Law Firms, founded by lawyer Steven Spielvogel in 2004, aims to provide options to those lawyers who have decided against spending their days grinding out billable hours on a large firm’s time sheet.

headline: London Journal: Spring Ends With a Flourish
text: During June in New York the concert season typically winds down. Not so in London, it would seem, where big things are happening this week, more than enough to entice me to visit.

headline: Infinera Captures Big First-Day Gains
text: Share of Infinera, a maker of optical computer chips, rose as much as 63 percent in their market opening on Thursday, a day after the company raised $182 million in an initial public offering.

headline: Small Shareholders Band Together Against Genzyme Bid
text: Angry at what they say is an unfairly priced takeover attempt by Genzyme, more than three dozen small shareholders of the biotechnology firm Bioenvision are trying to band together to block Genzyme’s deal to buy the company.

headline: Tyco Board Approves Split
text: Tyco International, the industrial conglomerate, said Thursday that its board had formally approved its separation into three publicly traded companies.

headline: Calpers Puts $400 Million in Private Equity Fund’s Coffers
text: The California Public Employees’ Retirement System, the largest public pension fund in the United States, put $400 million in a Pacific Corporate Group investment unit focused on developing countries. The unit, PCG International, will invest the money in private equity funds in international markets including Japan, China, India, Central Europe, Latin America and Africa, the company said.

headline: Microsoft Picks Up Data Management Firm
text: Microsoft said Thursday it had acquired Stratature, a privately held company that specializes in so-called master data management software. Through the acquisition, Microsoft will build master data management tools into its Office System line.

headline: Cash in Hand, AstraZeneca Remains on the Prowl
text: AstraZeneca, the British drugmaker, plans to continue making acquisitions to fill its product pipeline, its chief executive, David Brennan, told Bloomberg News.

headline: Another Management Shake-Up at Revver
text: Revver, a video-sharing Web site, said Thursday that its chief executive, Steven Starr, has stepped down in the struggling venture-backed company’s second executive shakeup in the past six months.

headline: For Activist Fund Manager, PNC Deal May Be A Double-Edge Sword
text: After campaigning for three years to force Yardville National Bancorp of New Jersey to put itself up for sale, Larry Seidman, the hedge fund manager, might mark the company’s sale to the PNC Financial Services Group for $403 million as a sweet success.

headline: China Properties Raises $299 Million in London Offering
text: China Central Properties, an investor in distressed real estate assets, said it had raised 151.2 million pounds ($299 million) in a London share sale as it seeks funds to buy incomplete developments in the country. China Central sold 151.23 million new shares at a price of 1 pound each, the company said in a statement. China Central shares will trade on the AIM Market of the London Stock exchange.

headline: May Merger Continues to Drag on Macy’s
text: Macy’s reported further evidence Thursday that stores it acquired through a merger with the May Department Stores continue to be a drag on sales. For the month of May, Macy’s saw sales at stores open at least a year drop 3.3 percent, more than the 1.4 percent that analysts were expecting.

headline: New Zealand Regulators Block Warehouse Group Bid
text: Woolworths and Foodstuffs NZ, New Zealand’s biggest grocers, were barred by antitrust regulators from buying the Warehouse Group, the largest non-food retailer in the nation. Warehouse shares fell 8 percent.

headline: Discover Gets Ready to Go It Alone
text: Discover Financial Services is scheduled to split from Morgan Stanley on July 2, trading on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol “DFS.” But The Chicago Tribune says the credit-card issuer will face a number of challenges on its own.

headline: Bank of America Said to Appeal Ruling on LaSalle Deal
text: Bank of America, seeking to overturn a decision that halted its $21 billion acquisition of the LaSalle Bank, is expected to claim that a Dutch commercial court acted in a “shocking” and unlawful manner in freezing the transaction, The Financial Times reported, citing a copy of the appeal filing the newspaper obtained. The sale of LaSalle has emerged as a key element in the larger takeover battle for the Dutch bank ABN Amro.

headline: Venice Biennale: Lining Up for Britain’s Bad Girl
text: The Biennale is now under full steam, with lines to get into some of the more popular exhibitions in the Giardini, like the British pavilion, with the my-most-intimate-thoughts-up-in-neon work of Tracey Emin.

headline: Societe Generale Said to Explore BNP Merger
text: In a deal that could create a French banking giant, Societe Generale is exploring possible merger options with its larger domestic rival, BNP Paribas, the French economic newspaper Les Echos reported.

headline: Merrill Names New Investment Banking Executives
text: Merrill Lynch‘s Andrea Orcel, who took over investment banking and capital markets two weeks ago, named his deputies, Bloomberg News reported, citing a company memorandum.

headline: Soul Searching on the Sell Side
text: Prudential Financial‘s recent decision to close its equity research group is just the latest change in an industry that is trying to find its way in a shifting Wall Street landscape. BusinessWeek examines some of the pressures on sell-side analysis, including restrictions on “soft dollars,” as well as the new business models that are being developed.

headline: Dow Jones Sews More Golden Parachutes
text: Dow Jones & Company may or may not be close to a sale, but on Thursday, it sweetened the pot for managers in case of a takeover.

headline: 2008: Immigration Fallout
text: Immigration issues rocked the Republican field at Tuesday night’s debate, with all but Senator John McCain finding serious flaws with various parts of the legislation. The mounting opposition, from many quarters including Democrats, put a lot of pressure on the compromise bill. It failed last night in the Senate, and The Times’s Carl Hulse and Robert Pear give us the play by play of how the bill’s sponsors came up short and what it means:

headline: Longing For a Third Way on Stem Cells
text: The last two days have brought two important headlines related to stem-cell research: that the Congress is once more trying to ease restrictions on federal financing for embryonic stem cells, and that researchers have made important progress on ways to turn ordinary cells into stem cells.

headline: A Smooth Liftoff
text: The shuttle Atlantis thundered off the launching pad on a mission to continue building the International Space Station.

headline: Paris and Scooter on the Scales of Justice
text: The Liberation of Paris: George Washington University professor Orin Kerr adapts the rhetoric of the Free Scooter crowd to the cause of another celebrity crook, Paris Hilton. Kerr writes at The Volokh Conspiracy, a legal group blog:

headline: ‘Outside the Blast Zone’
text: The other day, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg told people who worry about terrorist threats to “get a life” — and got some positive feedback. Now comes the news that Pennsylvania officials hope to capitalize on fears of chaos should another terrorist attack hit New York’s financial district. Call it Wall Street West.Gov. Edward G. Rendell’s administration maintains that since the region is about 100 miles west of Manhattan, it is outside New York City’s theoretical nuclear blast zone. It is ideally situated, they say, to be a safe retreat from the metropolis, but close enough to be linked directly to the computers that run the banking and trading systems.

headline: Deutsche Rejoins Hertz’s Underwriting Caravan
text: It looks as if Deutsche Bank has put an embarrassing e-mail episode behind it.

headline: Venice Biennale: A Watery Stillness (Sometimes)
text: One of the best things about Venice (in contrast to another great city on the water like, say, New York) is that you will never hear the sound of a car (or a car alarm) or a bus or a screeching, screaming taxi or an early-morning garbage truck that sounds as if it is hoisting entire brownstones and emptying their contents.

headline: For Online Brokers, Another Deal Option
text: Steven Cohen of the hedge fund SAC Capital may want TD Ameritrade to strike a deal with Charles Schwab or E*Trade Financial, but an analyst at Banc of America Securities has other ideas.

headline: In Bloom
text: Dozens of private gardens in New Jersey and on Long Island are opened to the public each year, with some drawing thousands of visitors.

headline: For More Buyouts, Tender Is the Offer
text: When Biomet announced Thursday that it had accepted an increased takeover offer from a group of private equity firms, the agreement was remarkable for a few reasons.

headline: Sharing a Virtual Canvas
text: In a world where Web sites can be spreadsheets, word processors, movie theaters and matchmaking databases, it took something as simple as DoodleNow.com to freak me out.

headline: Jefferson Vows to Fight Charges
text: Shortly after pleading not guilty to 16 fraud/corruption charges and being released on $100,000 bail, Representative William Jefferson defended himself before the media outside of a federal courthouse in Alexandria, Va.

headline: Rugs Reconsidered
text: Images from “The Great Cover-Up” at the American Folk Art Museum.

headline: A backwards glance
text: The Thursday press conference was not so kind to two drivers who started their first full seasons in Formula One as teammates 10 years ago. Giancarlo Fisichella had already done several races the year before at Minardi, but when he joined Jordan in 1997 as Ralf Schumacher’s teammate, it made for quite an explosive couple.

headline: Frieden Interview: ‘The Politics of Opposition’
text: The city’s health commissioner, Dr. Thomas Frieden, gave a frank interview to Christopher Murray of The Gay City News on a wide range of his agency’s policies that have drawn opposition from some groups that represent gays, lesbians, bisexuals and transgendered people.

headline: Two Days of Chaos…A President visits Rome
text: courtesy of AP

headline: The Selling of Congestion Pricing
text: There was a time, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg told an audience today at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, when he, too, was skeptical of congestion pricing.

headline: Audra McDonald
text: Ahead of Sunday's Tony Awards ceremony, the actress, who is nominated for her role in "110 in the Shade," answered readers' questions.

headline: Campaign Cash: $3,417,030
text: That’s the total amount of commitments from fundraisers that former President Bill Clinton is headlining this spring for his wife’s presidential campaign, according to an internal Clinton finance document provided to The Times.

headline: Funds Demand Ameritrade’s Records of Merger Talks
text: SAC Capital and Jana Partners have raised the stakes in their proxy fight for TD Ameritrade.

headline: Taking Questions: A Traffic Expert on Congestion Pricing
text: This afternoon, we arranged for Michael Horodniceanu, one of the foremost experts on traffic in New York City, to take questions from readers on the subject of congestion pricing. Dr. Horodniceanu was the city’s traffic commissioner from 1986 to 1990. He is currently chairman and chief executive of Urbitran, an engineering, architectural and planning company based in Manhattan. This Q&A is now closed, but readers are invited to continue the discussion in the comments below.

headline: Down by the Shake Shack
text: I think we should all make a pact to gather in 10 years to chew on the Tom Ford empire. Ford put out a statement this morning about a plan to have 100 free-standing Tom Ford boutiques over the next decade. In three years, he says he’ll open shops in L.A., Hawaii, London and Milan. Other cities down the road will include Moscow and Hong Kong, and he’ll have in-store deals with Neiman’s and Villa Moda. Oh, and Daslu in Brazil. Maybe in his spare time he could design Valentino…. just a thought.

headline: C.E.O.’s and Mergers: Nothing to Lose?
text: Here’s a coin-flipping game anybody would love to play. Heads: you get pots of money. Tails: you get smaller pots of money.

headline: From Our ‘DUI for Famous People’ Dept.
text: So here’s something new: A celebrity whose fame stemmed at least as much from good looks and sex appeal as from actual work product is nabbed for driving while blotto again, but nonetheless manages to avoid jail time.

headline: Weekend Reading: Letters from Robert Chapman
text: Shareholder activism has proven especially popular — and lucrative — for hedge funds over the past year, but few practitioners show the epistolary flair of, say, Third Point‘s Daniel Loeb, known for his eloquently barbed letters to companies that he thinks need to change their ways. Another expert in this art is Robert Chapman, who is at it again — with the kid gloves firmly off.

headline: Google Map Bites Founder
text: The privacy concerns over Google Maps bouncing around Web may have just bounced back … into the co-founder’s office. Valleywag has located the home of Larry Page.

headline: Chiang Mai, the mini Bangkok
text: Chiang Mai is a popular get-away from Bangkok, as it’s only about an hour’s flight away and is relatively cooler in the hot, rainy months. I’d never gone before, but I knew what I was expecting: a small city with ancient temples, old buildings, sprawling markets, outlying villages, cute cafes and homey guest houses.All those things were there, but the whole was bigger and more commercial than I had thought; the main road along one side of the river was packed with cars, scooters, pick-up trucks and some seriously assertive tuk-tuk drivers.There some nice little streets, shops and pubs in the area along the river, but there was also a Starbucks, 7-Eleven, Subway, McDonalds, etc. Further up, somewhat desperate looking, scantily clad women milled around al fresco pool halls where nobody was playing pool. The night bazaar is impressively large, but touristy. Not that I’m going to go on a PC rant against U.S. coffee chains or thinly veiled girlie bars; it just felt too much like a mini-Bangkok to be a peaceful getaway, especially in the evening.

headline: Skipping the Straw Poll
text: With so many more stops on the road to the White House in 2008, why spend hundreds of thousands of dollars or more on a fleeting August afternoon in Iowa, particularly if victory is far from assured?

headline: The Second Floor Redux
text: You get to judge, too, but when I saw the latest drawings our architect, Greg, sent, I thought we were a lot closer.

headline: Out of Their Shells
text: Times food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, makes a fast and tasty salad of fresh crab and peas.

headline: A Hill of Beans
text: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, makes a variety of bean salads.

headline: London Journal: Casing the Neighborhood
text: While I’m in London this week there are also some enticing concerts at the elegant and intimate Wigmore Hall, including a recital of Beethoven sonatas by the fine British pianist Paul Lewis. Alas, I’m otherwise booked, with events to cover every night. This is additionally frustrating, because I’m staying with good friends about a block away on enchanting Wigmore Street.

headline: To Break a Tsunami Alarm
text: Angry villagers in Aceh, Indonesia, have done the last thing one would expect: break a Tsunami alarm by hurling stones at it until it went on the fritz. Have they gone absolutely mad?

headline: All Things Steak
text: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, shows how to grill steaks.

headline: Your Turn: Traffic Questions for Readers
text: It seems to be congestion pricing day. Our expert on the subject had to return to his life, but thanks to all who posed questions.

headline: The Shape of Things That Came
text: I’m going to ask for some help here, because I’m having trouble tracking down some information, though it may be of no use to anybody but myself. The issue is bottle shapes. More specifically, the shape of Champagne bottles and Chablis bottles.

headline: Paris Hilton Ordered Back to Jail
text: This roller coaster ride of celebrity justice was first filled with schadenfreude, then outrage. Does renewed faith that The System Ultimately Works come next?

headline: Adventures in Drive-Thru Retailing
text: Something there is in Dwight Thomas, to hear the police tell it, that does not love a mall.

headline: Gingrich Assesses the Republican Field
text: During a speech in Washington this morning, former House Speaker Newt Gingrich gently praised several fellow Republicans who have launched presidential bids, criticized one and offered few clues about the chances he would step into the race.

headline: Skoda Bakes the Cake
text: Car companies are always trying to capture consumers’ attention in their ads but the Czech auto company Skoda takes the cake — or should we say, bakes the cake. Skoda, part of the Volkswagen Group, has delighted television viewers across Europe (and YouTube subscribers around the world) with its commercial for the newest verson of its Fabia minicar. In the ad — from the minds of Fallon London — a team of model makers and bakers concoct a life-size Fabia out of all sorts of edible goodies. Even the Skoda badge can be savored.

headline: Building a Better Mayonnaise
text: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, jazzes up store-bought mayonnaise with a little help from a friend.

headline: Vows: Tatiana and Craig
text: Tatiana Rosak and Craig Birkelund had no idea that a New Year's Eve kiss would change their  lives.

headline: Is Bork’s Trip and Fall a Misstep?
Using Alliance Partner Airlines for Miles and Upgrades
text: My husband and I are planning to celebrate our 10th anniversary exploring New Zealand. Since this isn’t until 2010, do you have any suggestions for ways to earn points while we wait that would enable us to upgrade to first class for the long flight? We aren’t frequent fliers, but we do have credit cards.

headline: The Motown Mess
text: Here in Detroit, home of one of my alma mater’s most esteemed graduates, the Mets will embark upon the most challenging stretch of their season.

headline: Image Craft
text: A look at the the making of Suellen Parker's artwork for The New York Times Magazine cover.

headline: Will Fred Thompson Play in Ames?
text: The not-yet-announced presidential candidate, Fred Thompson, jawboned today with a top Iowa Republican who is trying to lure him into entering the straw poll in August in Ames. The meeting was reported earlier today in The Washington Post.

headline: At Candidates Finals, Two Wins and Two Near Misses
text: For three of today’s matches, it was dèja vu all over again as the players repeated the openings from the first game of the finals. Peter Leko took a commanding lead in his candidates finals match over Evgeny Bareev and Boris Gelfand won to move in front of Gata Kamsky in their match. The games in the other two finals matches were drawn, but unlike yesterday, all the games today were hard fought. The matches are being played in Elista, Kalmykia, to determine four qualifiers for the world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.

headline: Out of Prison, Ex-Mayor of Providence Forgoes Boston Job
text: BOSTON, June 8  Vincent A. Cianci Jr., the colorfully controversial former mayor of Providence, R.I., was supposed to go from prison to posh.

headline: Ruling Likely to Spur Convictions in Capital Cases
text: A decision by the Supreme Court on Monday that made it easier for prosecutors to exclude people who express reservations about the death penalty from capital juries will make the panels whiter and more conviction-prone, experts in law and psychology said this week.

headline: Races Going Exactly as Florida State Sprinter Planned
text: SACRAMENTO, June 8  In a major track and field meet like the N.C.A.A. outdoor championships, it’s not how you start, but how you finish.

headline: Mientkiewicz Faces Surgery and Hopes for a July Return
text: Doug Mientkiewicz, the injured first baseman, showed up in the Yankees’ clubhouse yesterday afternoon with a cast on his right wrist and a hopeful sound in his voice. He said he would have surgery in New York on Tuesday to put a pin in his wrist to repair a broken bone.

headline: The Road to Somewhere
text: Representative Don Young is a man of few words. He offered an obscene gesture the other day in response to a reporter curious about his travels as king of the Congressional pork dispensers. Far from his home district in Alaska, Mr. Young, the ranking Republican for transportation spending, was feted by Florida land developers who chipped in $40,000 for his re-election drive last year. Fast as quo follows quid, Mr. Young tailored a choice piece of Florida pork  $10 million in taxpayer money for a cross-wetlands connection to the federal interstate. The connector would boost the value of thousands of acres that Mr. Young’s contributors want to develop over the objections of environmentalists.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 8, 2007

headline: A Right to Panhandle? (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bush Meets Pope Benedict for the First Time
text: VATICAN CITY, June 9 — President Bush met today for the first time with Pope Benedict XVI, a religious conservative like the American president but who raised his worries in their private meeting about the war in Iraq.

headline: Celebrating the Larger-Than-Life Man Who Coaxed Balanchine to America
text: Lincoln Kirstein came vividly alive in several aspects of his larger-than-life personality on Thursday night at the New York State Theater, when the New York City Ballet presented “Honoring Lincoln.” It would not have seemed surprising if an image of Kirstein, co-founder with George Balanchine of the company and its affiliated School of American Ballet, had risen along with the British flag at the end of “Union Jack,” the closing ballet in this centennial tribute.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Insider column yesterday on the Street Scene page of Business Day, about investment strategies involving hedge funds, misstated the amount of money managed by one such fund, Highbridge Capital Management, which is majority owned by JPMorgan Chase. It is about $34 billion, not $15.7 billion. (Go to Article)

headline: G-8 Leaders Reaffirm Promises of Billions to Battle AIDS and Other Diseases
text: KÜHLUNGSBORN, Germany, June 8 — Adjourning a meeting featuring some surprises and a less contentious tone than many expected, the leaders of the world’s richest industrial nations pledged Friday to commit $60 billion for treatment of AIDS and other diseases in the developing world.

headline: Patient Gets Transplant Despite Crash
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 8 — A man whose lung-transplant operation was aborted after the plane carrying the organs from Milwaukee crashed into Lake Michigan this week, killing six people, is recovering after receiving lungs from another donor.

headline: (Don’t Go Back to) San Francisco
text: Los Angeles

headline: Anticipated Trip Brings Much-Needed Win
text: DETROIT, June 8 — Damion Easley played three seasons at Comerica Park, long enough to know every nook and cranny of the cavernous stadium, but he was not about to play tour guide Friday. “Didn’t like the gaps too much,” Easley said.

headline: A Tentative First Step in Addressing Faith and Politics
text: Almost a century ago, G. K. Chesterton made a comment that could most appropriately be applied to Monday night’s forum at which leading Democratic presidential candidates discussed faith and politics: anything worth doing “is worth doing badly.”

headline: Nominee for Joint Chiefs Is Called a Pragmatist
text: WASHINGTON, June 8  By recommending Adm. Michael G. Mullen to be the next chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates has chosen a low-key pragmatist without a well-established stake in the Iraq strategy to be the country’s next senior military adviser.

headline: Edwin Traisman, 91, Dies; Helped Create Iconic Foods
text: Edwin Traisman, a food scientist who helped standardize McDonald’s French fries and develop Cheez Whiz for Kraft Foods, as well as researching the risks of E. coli bacteria, died Tuesday in Madison, Wis. He was 91 and lived in Monona, Wis.

headline: F.T.C. Details Objections to a Food Merger
text: The purchase of Wild Oats Markets by a larger rival, Whole Foods Market, would increase concentration of the country’s natural and organic supermarkets and lead to increased prices, the Federal Trade Commission said in documents released yesterday.

headline: Tapping Global Talent in Software
text: Henning Kagermann, 59, chief executive of SAP, the big German software company, is guiding two transformations. The first is the increasing globalization of the engineering work at the company, which traditionally handled technical development at its home in Walldorf. The second is the continuing opening up of SAP’s technology itself in response to the rise of the Internet and the growing popularity of Web-based computing. Both trends are affecting all large technology companies today. Yet the shifts seem particularly notable at SAP.

headline: Contractor Must-Have List: Hammer, Nails, License, Insurance ...
text: ONE of the best pieces of advice any homeowner will receive when doing renovations or repairs is to use a licensed and insured contractor.

headline: Celebrity Justice Cuts Both Ways for Paris Hilton
text: LOS ANGELES, June 8 — The national obsession with celebrity collided head-on with the more serious issue of the equal application of justice on Friday, as a judge sent the socialite Paris Hilton back to jail some 36 hours after she was released for an unspecified medical problem.

headline: Sheila Ballantyne, 70, Portraitist of Family Angst, Is Dead
text: Sheila Ballantyne, a critically praised novelist whose work ranged over death, deception and family life — more often than not, these were all of a piece — died on May 2 at her home in Berkeley, Calif. She was 70.

headline: Putin Proposes Alternatives on Missile Defense
text: MOSCOW, June 8 — President Vladimir V. Putin offered new suggestions on Friday for alternatives to a missile defense system in Europe, saying Russia would not object to American interceptor missiles in Iraq, Turkey or at sea, and proposing that Russia and the West study emerging missile threats jointly.

headline: A Rare Case of Confident Consumers Disapproving of a President
text: IT’S not the economy, stupid. It’s the war.

headline: Caution: Lower Truck Sales Ahead
text: DETROIT, June 8 — For most of their history, pickups have been to auto companies what they were to their customers: reliable workhorses, with Detroit counting on them for big sales and profits even as flashier cars came and went.

headline: It’s Jeter’s Night From Start to Finish
text: Last night’s 5-4 Yankees victory over Pittsburgh — won on a bases-loaded infield single by Derek Jeter in the 10th inning — was not a flawless game, but it was a delight for those who enjoy good pitching, especially from left-handed starters.

headline: Astronaut Profiles
text: Col. Frederick W. Sturckow, of the U.S. Marine Corps, goes by Rick or “CJ,” and was shuttle pilot on flights in 1998 and 2001. “When I get back, all I can think about,” he said, is “ when can I go do that again?”

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 9 P.M. (ABC) RUFFIAN  (2007) Right on the heels of the Belmont Stakes (5:30 p.m. on ABC), and with the memory of Barbaro still fresh, comes this drama about the horse heralded as the greatest thoroughbred filly of all time. After winning the Filly Triple Crown early in 1975, the undefeated Ruffian went on to run a “battle of the sexes” match against the Kentucky Derby winner Foolish Pleasure on July 6 at Belmont Park. The race ended in sorrow when, with Ruffian leading Foolish Pleasure by half a length, two bones in her right front leg snapped. After a 12-hour surgery, Ruffian caused further damage to herself when she thrashed around on the floor of her padded stall, and she was euthanized shortly after. The film, directed by Yves Simoneau (HBO’s “Bury My Heart at Wounded Knee”), stars Sam Shepard, above, as Frank Whiteley, the trainer who guided Ruffian’s ascent, and Frank Whaley as the sportswriter Bill Nack, who wrote the book the movie is based on.

headline: TB Patient Says Officials Are Trying to Blame Him to Cover Mistakes
text: By the time Andrew Speaker and his wife returned from Europe late last month, government officials and news reports had already branded him as a runaway tuberculosis patient who had deliberately evaded health officials and knowingly put other people at risk by traveling on crowded airplanes.

headline: Ex-Champion Is Prepared to Join March
text: Emile Griffith will ride in the parade of champions at the International Boxing Hall of Fame induction tomorrow in Canastota, N.Y., as he has done almost every year since he was enshrined in 1990.

headline: Ivory Coast: Cocoa Fueled Civil War
text: A report by the anticorruption organization Global Witness found that profits from smuggled and mishandled cocoa had helped pay for the civil war that has split the country for the past five years. It said that at least $118 million from the cocoa trade in Ivory Coast, the world’s biggest producer, was used by the government, which controlled the south, and the rebels who controlled the north, to fuel the conflict and enrich its leaders. Valuable mineral resources like diamonds, oil and gold have spawned and fueled vast conflicts across Africa for decades, and the research in Ivory Coast demonstrated how a valuable cash crop can play a similar role, Global Witness said.

headline: Youth Remains L.P.G.A. Flavor, but Davies Is Still Old Reliable
text: HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., June 8 — As soon as Se Ri Pak completed her first round Thursday at the L.P.G.A. Championship and her Hall of Fame to-do list was done, the focus shifted to Laura Davies.

headline: Newspapers Trimming Classical Critics
text: Classical music criticism, a high-minded endeavor that has been around at least as long as newspapers and reached an English-language peak with George Bernard Shaw, has taken a series of hits in recent months.

headline: Philip Morris Tries Smokeless Tobacco Product
text: Philip Morris USA, the tobacco company, said late yesterday that it would test-market four flavors of a smokeless tobacco product known as snus under the Marlboro brand name in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, starting in August.

headline: Kitty Carlisle Hart Service
text: A memorial service for the actress, singer and arts advocate Kitty Carlisle Hart, who died on April 17 at 96, will be held on Tuesday at noon at the Majestic Theater, 245 West 44th Street, in Manhattan.

headline: Good Homework Produces a Slam Swing at a Semifinal
text: The U.S.A.-2 team for the Venice Cup will be Shawn Quinn, Sue Picus, Hjordis Eythorsdottir and Rozanne Pollack. On Wednesday in Schaumburg, Ill., they defeated Kathleen Sulgrove, Candace Griffey, Cindy Bernstein, Sally Wheeler, Laurie Kranyak and Linda McGarry by 192 international match points to 158.

headline: Bush, Feeling Ill and Resting, Attracts Notice by Absence
text: HEILIGENDAMM, Germany, June 8 — Was it something he ate?

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Insider column yesterday on the Street Scene page of Business Day, about investment strategies involving hedge funds, misstated the amount of money managed by one such fund, Highbridge Capital Management, which is majority owned by JPMorgan Chase. It is about $34 billion, not $15.7 billion.

headline: California: Los Angeles Mayor and Wife to Separate
text: Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa of Los Angles announced that he and his wife of 20 years, Corina Villaraigosa, would separate. “Each of us loves our children more than anything in the world,” Mr. Villaraigosa said in a statement. “And we are committed to working together for their benefit.” The mayor and his wife, a teacher, have two teenage children. Rumors about the Villaraigosas marriage have been swirling for months; the two were rarely seen together, and Mr. Villaraigosa was spotted without his wedding ring, which he attributed to weight loss, denying his marriage was ending.

headline: Privacy Is an Issue for Critics of Cameras
text: With the mayor’s congestion-pricing plan gaining political support, some critics said yesterday that the network of several hundred cameras that would be installed on the streets of Manhattan could be too intrusive.

headline: Palestinians Clash With Israeli Soldiers
text: JERUSALEM, June 9 — At least four Palestinian gunmen using an armored vehicle and grenade launchers broke through Israel’s border fence from Gaza today and fought a gun battle with Israeli soldiers, while Israeli troops entered Gaza near the southern town of Rafah to search for weapons and tunnels used to smuggle arms and explosives from Egypt.

headline: Russia: National Park for the Siberian Tiger
text: The government has created a 200,000-acre natural park in the Far East to protect the country’s endangered Siberian tigers, the Natural Resources Ministry confirmed. The Russian Far East is home to about 500 Siberian tigers.

headline: U.S. Trade Gap Lower Than Expected
text: The trade deficit narrowed in April, as American businesses exported more goods and services to meet rising demand from overseas.

headline: At Venice Biennale, Artists Plant Flag for Their State (of Mind)
text: VENICE, June 8 — From Albania to Venezuela, there are officially 77 countries taking part in this year’s Venice Biennale, shipping in crates of their most eye-catching art. But unbeknownst to most of the thronging crowds, there is a 78th nation involved (a kingdom, to be precise), one that does not show up on any of the lists. It has no pavilion and will give no lavish party. It isn’t even showing any art to speak of. And if you look on a map of the world, you will not find it, exactly.

text: SEQUOIA NATIONAL FOREST, Calif. — “Forward paddle! Stop!”

headline: Indian Reservation Reeling in Wave of Youth Suicides and Attempts
text: ROSEBUD, S.D. — The two suicides struck the Rosebud Sioux Reservation like a random virus. No one saw them coming.

headline: A Plan to Pay for Top Scores on Some Tests Gains Ground
text: Roland G. Fryer, a 30-year-old Harvard economist known for his study of racial inequality in schools, is back in New York to again promote a big idea: Pay students cash for high scores on standardized tests and their performance might improve. And he has captured the attention of Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: Arguing Case, Murder Suspect Is Convicted
text: Despite a spirited summation replete with equal parts cogent argument and classic conspiracy theory, punctuated by deep sighs, vivid similes and repeated admonishments to remain alert even as the dinner hour drew near, a Brooklyn man who served as his own defense lawyer was convicted yesterday of murder.

headline: Dance and Costumes Thrive (Oh, There’s Singing Too)
text: Nelly Furtado got cheers when she asked her audience, “Are you ready to get loose?” on Thursday night at the WaMu Theater at Madison Square Garden (formerly the Theater at Madison Square Garden). We were ready, but she wasn’t. In a pop spectacle of costume changes and set pieces with dancers, Ms. Furtado hit her marks, but she didn’t make it look like much fun.

headline: Outside Manhattan, Many Oppose Congestion Plan
text: Mayor Bloomberg’s fast-advancing plan to charge drivers $8 to drive in the most congested parts of Manhattan may seem geared mostly toward the suburbanites whom many blame for Manhattan’s perpetually snarled weekday traffic.

headline: From Harlem, Bearing Clubs and Wisdom for Golfers
text: Ervin McLean reclined on his stoop on West 130th Street near Lenox Avenue, a can of Ballantine Ale in his hand and $160 in his pocket from a day’s work carrying golf clubs at the Blind Brook Club in Rye Brook, N.Y.

headline: Facing Gap in Budget, Newark Plans Buyout Offers
text: NEWARK, June 8  Mayor Cory A. Booker, who is facing a yawning budget deficit, announced on Friday that he would offer buyout packages to hundreds of city employees in an effort to forestall layoffs, tax increases or reductions in municipal services.

headline: When Megabytes Triumph Over Muscle
text: “Shredderman Rules,” a junior high movie on Nickelodeon tonight, appears at first glance to be a typical revenge-of-the-nerds comedy. It has the usual lineup: a smart, awkward hero; a rich bad guy; clueless adults; and an unattainable love interest. In this formula character generally wins out, and right makes might.

headline: Rights Group Offers Grim View of C.I.A. Jails
text: PARIS, June 8 — In a report on Friday, the lead investigator for the Council of Europe gave a bleak description of secret prisons run by the Central Intelligence Agency in Eastern Europe, with information he said was gleaned from anonymous intelligence agents.

headline: When Second Graders Run Wild, With Federal Approval
text: WEST BABYLON, N.Y., June 8 — As a result of some speeches made and some laws passed somewhere far away where the president lives, all the kids in Debra Thuma’s second-grade class at the Tooker Avenue Elementary School were down on the floor, bicycle-pedaling their legs in the air on Friday morning.

text: Here’s a peculiar collaboration, perhaps the oddest of the season: Riccardo Muti conducted the pianist Lang Lang in Beethoven’s “Emperor” Concerto on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall.

text: Rags to Riches’ father, A. P. Indy, won the Belmont Stakes in 1992, and her mother, Better Than Honour, produced last year’s winner, Jazil. So why did Michael Tabor, the owner, and Todd Pletcher, the trainer, agonize over whether to run Rags to Riches in the Belmont today?

headline: Spain Arrests an ETA Leader in a Government Crackdown
text: MADRID, June 8 — The Spanish police arrested the leader of the political wing of the violent Basque separatist group ETA on Friday. The move signaled a new government crackdown after the group renounced a 15-month cease-fire earlier this week.
