headline: Trans-Pacific Chicken
text: In the litter of our meals lie the bones of a forgotten history. In this case, chicken bones found at a Chilean archaeological site called. Their DNA closely resemble prehistoric chicken bones found in Polynesia and radiocarbon dating suggests that the chickens these bones belonged to made it to the New World about a century before any European explorer. The research team that made the discovery calls this “the first unequivocal evidence for a pre-European introduction of chickens to South America.”

headline: Antiquities Trial Fixes on Collectors’ Role
text: ROME, June 8 — It was a “sophisticated method of laundering,” a prosecution witness testified on Friday in a trial courtroom here. Private collectors would acquire looted artifacts and eventually donate them to museums, she said.

headline: Jeweler to Pay $400,000 in Online Auction Fraud Settlement
text: A Manhattan jewelry dealer who directed his employees to secretly place bids that inflated the price of goods his company auctioned on eBay has agreed to pay $400,000 to settle a civil fraud complaint, the New York attorney general, Andrew Cuomo, said yesterday.

headline: In Legislators’ Scrutiny, Traffic Proposal Faces Hard Questioning
text: New York State lawmakers gave a cordial but cool reception yesterday to the congestion pricing plan proposed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, asking whether it amounted to a regressive tax on middle-class drivers and whether its costs were worth the promised benefits.

headline: Finding Profits When Times Are Tough
text: THE problem with doing something well is that people expect you to do even better next time. Corporate profit margins  earnings as a percentage of revenues  have been running at close to all-time highs, but they can improve only so much.

headline: Deal Making Heats Up as Does Food and Drug Scrutiny
text: Deal makers powered ahead, even as one pending merger faced a regulatory hurdle. Makers of diabetes drugs agreed to use the most severe warning on labels, and broadcasters won a favorable federal court ruling regarding obscenities.

headline: A Failure of Leadership
text: The immigration compromise collapsed on the floor of the Senate Thursday night. Many of its hard-line foes are celebrating, but their glee is vindictive and hollow. They have blocked one avenue to an immigration overhaul while offering nothing better, thwarting bipartisanship to satisfy their reflexive loathing for amnesty, which they define as anything that helps illegal immigrants get right with the law.

headline: No-Confidence Resolution on Gonzales Is Scheduled
text: WASHINGTON, June 8 — Senate Democrats said Friday that they intended to bring a no-confidence resolution against Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales to a vote on Monday, a symbolic maneuver that could be their final effort to force his ouster.

headline: Investigating Mislabeling of Workers
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer is planning to step up enforcement against thousands of companies that illegally misclassify workers as independent contractors to cheat on taxes and skimp on employee benefits, the state labor commissioner said yesterday.

headline: What’s in a Slur? A New Play Searches for Answers

headline: Besieged by Protests, Pakistan Suspends Curbs on TV
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 8  After a barrage of criticism and nationwide protests by journalists and rights groups, the Pakistani government has suspended its restrictions on independent television stations.

headline: Shock Defeats the Liberty in a Battle of Unbeatens
text: When the schedule for the W.N.B.A. season was announced months ago, there was no reason to expect that last night’s game at Madison Square Garden would include two undefeated teams. For starters, the Liberty was coming off its worst season in franchise history. And while the defending champion Detroit Shock was expected to be strong again, unbeaten teams have never met this late in the season.

text: This article was reported by Carl Hulse, Robert Pear and Jeff Zeleny and written by Mr. Hulse.

headline: Today in Business
text: SALES INCREASE AT MCDONALD’S The McDonald’s Corporation posted its largest monthly sales increase in more than three years, helped by the popularity of its small sandwiches in France and a big green ogre called Shrek in the United States. The chain said sales rose 8.7 percent in May at restaurants open at least 13 months. Wall Street analysts had been expecting a rise of 5 percent, according to research notes.

headline: As Senate Deal Sinks, So Does Bush’s Power
text: The breakthrough on the “grand bargain” on immigration a few weeks ago had brought new life to a White House under siege, putting a long-sought goal suddenly within reach. After many grim months, there was almost giddiness at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A brief art review in Weekend yesterday about Paul Pfeiffer’s exhibition “Live From Neverland” at the Project gallery in Manhattan misstated the year of his double show at the Project and the Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea. It was 2004, not last year.

headline: Quantifying the Role of School Ties in Investing
text: A new study circulating through hedge funds and university campuses points to the powerful role that old-school ties play in the world of investing.

headline: Chairman of Joint Chiefs Will Not Be Reappointed
text: WASHINGTON, June 8 — The Bush administration said Friday that it would not reappoint Gen. Peter Pace to a second term as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, making him the highest-ranking officer to be a political casualty of the fight over Iraq.

headline: Amid the Shirts and Socks, a Concert Can Break Out
text: PHILADELPHIA — What do you do if you buy a famous downtown department store and find an organ with 28,482 pipes occupying thousands of square feet of perfectly good retail space?

headline: Nadal and Federer Set Up Classic Paris Rematch
text: PARIS, June 8  Once his match was over and the final beads of sweat had trickled down Roger Federer’s glistening face, he disappeared into the tunnel off the main court at the French Open. And for hours, he waited.

headline: U.S. Issues Reprieve on New Passport Rules
text: Easing rules that played havoc with the vacation plans of millions of Americans, the State Department and the Department of Homeland Security formally announced yesterday that they were temporarily suspending new passport requirements for travel to neighboring countries.

headline: Spurs’ Victory Illustrates James Is a One-Man Show
text: SAN ANTONIO, June 8 — LeBron James completed his public relations duties for the day, and it was time to segue from the hype of the N.B.A. finals to preparing for the N.B.A. finals. But his path down the court was quickly cut off and — as he often was in Game 1 — James was quickly surrounded and stifled.

headline: With New Law, China Reports Drop in Executions
text: BEIJING, June 8 — China, which puts more inmates to death than the rest of the world combined, is reporting fewer executions this year after reinstating a requirement that every death case be reviewed and approved by the country’s highest court.

headline: Vamps, Grooves and All Sorts of Ideas, Old and New
text: Around the time he turned 30, in 2003, the trumpeter Nicholas Payton started loosening up his music, taking strides away from established form. Every good jazz bandleader has to work on his own technique on the one hand, and his ensemble concept on the other; a balance is desired. Perhaps because Mr. Payton started his career in the 1990s as such an imposing player, with a New Orleans pedigree and the ability to pull off early-jazz repertory concerts as well as post-bop, it’s taken a while for him to bring his ideas about composition and bandleading into balance with his own playing.

headline: Spanish Guitars, Fast Footwork, Everything but the Cafe
text: Flamenco is a soloist’s art, an expression of emotion and individuality that is ideally performed in the casual surroundings of cafes and noisy bars. But it’s also an ever more popular theatrical form, and flamenco artists have to battle with the conundrum of choreographing spontaneity and reliably evoking the heat and passion that audiences love.

headline: The Dissonance of Everyday Life, the Harmony of Nature
text: The composer Richard Wilson has had to wait so long for the New York premiere of “In Schrafft’s,” his lively piece set to W. H. Auden’s poem of the same title, that the once ubiquitous restaurant referred to is long gone.

headline: Europeans Fail to Agree on Financing Big Satellite Project
text: BRUSSELS, June 8  European governments failed to agree Friday on how to salvage their troubled satellite navigation system, Galileo, adding to doubts about their ability to continue to finance “grand European projects” like the European rival to the Global Positioning System of the United States.

headline: Palestinian Premier Urges End to Factional Clashes
text: JERUSALEM, June 8 — The Palestinian prime minister, Ismail Haniya of Hamas, called Friday for the political will to stop another round of intra-Palestinian clashes between his own faction and Fatah, which sit together in a unity government.

headline: Syrian Arms Dealer Arrested in Spain and Indicted in U.S.
text: A Syrian arms dealer under investigation for nearly 30 years was arrested Thursday night and charged in a sprawling plot to ship weapons  including C-4 explosives and surface-to-air missiles  to guerrillas in Colombia seeking to attack American forces serving there on antidrug missions, American prosecutors said yesterday.

text: “When you put your foot on the gas in this company,” Jeffrey R. Immelt said a few weeks ago, with just the slightest trace of a satisfied smile, “the car goes forward.”

headline: Welterweight Champion Has a New Skill: English
text: Miguel Cotto, a world champion welterweight boxer, is packing a new punch that he says can help him blow past his opponents in more ways than one. He is speaking English.

headline: Rancor Level Rises in Rift Over Danone China Venture
text: SHANGHAI, June 8 — A dispute between Groupe Danone, the French dairy and beverage maker, and its Chinese partner, the beverage maker Wahaha, became even stranger on Friday when Wahaha released several letters written by employees that denounced Danone for being run by “rascals” who were committing “evil deeds.”

headline: NASA Leader Regrets Global Warming Comments
text: NASA administrator Michael D. Griffin said Friday that he regretted having sparked a furor last week when, in an interview with National Public Radio, he said he was not sure climate change “is a problem we must wrestle with.”

headline: Surgeon General Nominee Is Assailed for Church Role
text: WASHINGTON, June 8  President Bush’s nomination of Dr. James W. Holsinger Jr., a Kentucky cardiologist, to be surgeon general is drawing criticism from gay rights groups, physicians and lawmakers who say they are troubled by opinions critical of homosexuality that Dr. Holsinger has voiced in nearly 20 years as a high-ranking layman in the United Methodist Church.

headline: Italy Prosecutes C.I.A. Agents in Kidnapping
text: ROME, June 8 — A trial that charges American and Italian intelligence operatives with kidnapping a radical imam in 2003 opened Friday in Milan, the first prosecution involving the contentious American policy of abducting terrorism suspects for interrogation elsewhere.

headline: David Halberstam Service
text: A memorial service for the Pulitzer Prize-winning war reporter and author David Halberstam is scheduled for 4 p.m. on Tuesday at Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, in Manhattan. Mr. Halberstam died on April 23 at the age of 73.

headline: Israelis Ask, What Have We Gained Since the ’67 War?
text: JERUSALEM, June 8 — In the months before the 1967 Middle East war, Israel was in a spiral of self-doubt, the 19-year experiment of an independent Jewish state looking shaky.

headline: Giambi Has Little to Say on Issue of Selig’s Request
text: Jason Giambi hobbled out of Yankee Stadium in the bottom of the seventh inning last night, wearing camouflage pants, a dark T-shirt and a black walking boot on his injured left foot. He was very willing to discuss his foot problems, but not so willing to discuss his other problems.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on May 29 about Russia’s strategy to gain a monopoly in natural gas exports to Asia through Gazprom misstated the percentage of ownership in the Kovykta gas field by TNK-BP, which is being accused by the Kremlin of having failed to meet license requirements. It is 63 percent, not 65.

headline: World View Podcast
Man Agrees to DNA Tests in Deaths of Prostitutes
text: MAYS LANDING, N.J., June 8 — A man who stayed at a motel on the outskirts of Atlantic City shortly before four prostitutes were found dead there agreed on Friday to submit to DNA tests.

headline: The Bottom Line: Sheffield Is Right to Speak Out
text: The quality that most sports journalists respect about Gary Sheffield — even if it makes us uncomfortable — is his candor. I learned long ago that if you don’t want to know the answer, you don’t ask Sheffield the question.

headline: At Irvine, $99 Proves a Small Price for Success
text: IRVINE, Calif., June 5  The 1999 student elections at the University of California Irvine included a referendum on baseball.

headline: Abstract Drones, Delivered With Quiet Conviction
text: There was plenty of time to consider the properties of a drone during Califone’s show at the Blender Theater at Gramercy on Thursday night. Again and again, songs migrated back to their root tonalities, nudged along by stark and sober rhythms. The stylistic implication was variously Appalachian, Celtic, aboriginal or electronic, with roughly equal proportions of post-rock minimalism and Delta blues.

headline: Shuttle Atlantis Appears to Have Flawless Liftoff
text: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 8 — The shuttle Atlantis thundered off the launching pad into a stunningly clear evening sky on Friday on a mission to continue building the International Space Station.

headline: As Beetle Threatens, 10,000 Staten Island Trees Die by Chain Saw
text: The work crews with their chain saws and grapples and wood chippers fan out across the scrubby forest in northwestern Staten Island in search of trees spray-painted with red bull’s-eyes.

headline: F.B.I. Agent Tells Padilla Jury of Coded Plans for Jihad
text: MIAMI, June 8  Jurors in the federal terrorism case against Jose Padilla heard his voice for the first time Friday, discussing  by the government’s account  secret plans to travel overseas and wage jihad.

headline: Court Blocks Sri Lanka’s Effort to Expel Tamils From Capital
text: NEW DELHI, June 8  The Sri Lankan government’s efforts to expel ethnic minority Tamils living in Colombo, the capital, met with a barrage of criticism from home and abroad on Friday and was quashed by the country’s highest court.

headline: Lots of Froth but No Bubble
text: MARC ANDREESSEN, the inventor of the first commercially viable Web browser and the co-creator of Netscape, finally has a blog. And he started this week with a splash: in his third post, he offered a harsh (for him) rebuttal of the spreading notion that there is a new Internet bubble forming, that Silicon Valley is overexuberant about “Web 2.0,” and that soon it will all come crashing down (blog.pmarca.com).

headline: Nasty, Unfinished Cold War Business
text: Vladimir Putin has proved again what a canny player he is, calling President Bush’s bluff and suggesting that parts of Mr. Bush’s cherished missile defense system could be based at an old Soviet radar station in Azerbaijan or perhaps in Turkey or even Iraq. It’s hard to know if the Russian president is serious or just trying to stall the effort. Despite Mr. Bush’s impatience, there’s plenty of time to try to find out: the American shield and the Iranian missiles it’s supposed to deflect are years away from working.

text: A pop music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday about an upcoming Neville Brothers concert at the Prospect Park Bandshell in Brooklyn misstated the time. The concert will be at 8 p.m. on Thursday  not at 5:30, which is the time for a pre-concert gala.

headline: Beethoven to Brahms to Ives: Tribute to a Tortured Legacy
text: The line from Beethoven through Brahms to Charles Ives is as complex as it is obvious. Brahms adopted gestures, if not actual themes, from Beethoven, and Ives borrowed from both.

headline: Wife and Son of Police Chief Are Among 50 Killed in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, June 8 — More than 50 people were killed in attacks across Iraq on Friday, including 14 who died when gunmen stormed a police chief’s home northeast of Baghdad and raked the occupants with automatic fire.

headline: For One Visit, Bush Will Feel Pro-U.S. Glow
text: TIRANA, Albania, June 8 — The highlight of President Bush’s European tour may well be his visit on Sunday to this tiny country, one of the few places left where he can bask in unabashed pro-American sentiment without a protester in sight.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Page 6 in some copies of this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section about shows at the Hilton Theater on Broadway included an outdated reference to the current tenant, “The Pirate Queen,” which initially had an open-ended run. After the section went to press, producers announced that it would close on June 17.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Weekend yesterday about Shakespeare plays being performed outdoors in New York this summer misidentified the site and misstated the date of the “Henry IV” directed four years ago by Jack O’Brien, who commented on theater companies’ different approaches. It was the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center in November 2003, not the Delacorte Theater in Central Park four summers ago.

headline: The Holdout
text: Billy's Antiques and Props is a reminder of a different era for the Bowery, one before Whole Foods.

headline: More From Venice
text: Additional images from the 2007 Venice Biennale.

headline: London Journal: A Foggy Day in Aldeburgh Town
text: ALDEBURGH, England — Here I am in “Peter Grimes” country. This small seacoast town two hours northeast of London by train has long been renowned for its mid-June music festival, founded by Benjamin Britten; the tenor Peter Pears, Britten’s lifelong partner and principal muse; and their friend Eric Crozier, the librettist and opera producer. Britten and Pears moved here in 1947 and lived here for the rest of their lives, though they kept a flat in London.

headline: Venice Biennale: Pictures from the Exhibition
text: A slide show of additional images from the 2007 Biennale.

headline: Venice Biennale: Turkey and Mexico Have Their Day
text: As the Biennale reaches full speed, with huge crowds elbowing to see art, several countries are getting their first real moments in the sun. Turkey has its own pavilion this year for the first time, with a show by the artist Huseyin Alptekin called “Don’t Complain.” (A good rejoinder to anyone here moaning about sore feet or a hangover with the grandeur of St. Mark’s Cathedral rising in the background.)

headline: Iraq Poems

text: This week’s Sunday morning lineup features hearty portions of immigration and Iraq, served up with a side of presidential politics and a sprinkling of Hillary Clinton biographers.

headline: London Journal: From Aldeburgh, Glimpses of Venice
text: ALDEBURGH, England — When Benjamin Britten and Peter Pears moved here in 1947, they lived at first in a handsome house that they loved, right on the seashore. In 1953, a storm flooded the ground floor. What finally drove them away, though, was the endless curiosity of passersby on the beachfront who could see the famous composer and his partner at home.

headline: Lewis Hamilton’s great performance, and his great preparation
text: How does Hamilton go to a new track and immediately get on the pace? Today he scored pole position, beating Fernando Alonso, his teammate, who won the race at this track last year. Hamilton had never driven on the track in Canada!

headline: The Master of Both Leagues

headline: USA 2, T&T 0: Solid Win, or Sign of Trouble?
text: The U.S. Men’s National Team had little trouble disposing of a Trinidad and Tobago squad made up of second-choice players, thus assuring the Yanks of passage to the Concacaf Gold Cup tournament’s knockout stage. But what does a 2-0 victory over such an unprepossessing team, followed by an unimpressive 1-0 over Guatemala, really mean? Cool efficiency, or a vulnerable giant? … Respond!

headline: Venice Biennale: Bidding Farewell
text: There are so many things you can indulge in while in Venice, but during the Biennale, sleep is not one of them. It is my last day here, after five days of hard-charging art appreciation, and as I write this final missive it is only about three hours before my taxi arrives to take me to the airport.The things I will miss, in no particular order:

headline: ‘Copy!’
text: LISTEN. The sound is muffled by wall-to-wall carpet tiles and fabric-lined cubicles. But it’s still there, embedded in the concrete and steel sinews of the old factory at 229 West 43rd Street, where The New York Times was written and edited yesterday for the last time.

headline: Correction:  Options for Reimbursement  When a Tour Falls Through
text: The Q&A column on June 3 about reimbursement options when a tour falls through misstated a recommendation about when to buy insurance policies that cover full refunds. Vikki Corliss, a spokeswoman at InsureMyTrip.com, a travel insurance comparison site, said that it is best to buy coverage before or within 7 to 21 days (varies by plan) after you have made your first deposit on the tour; she did not say within 7 to 12 days. headline: Charming, Sunny Décor; The Food Is Even Better
text: A SWEET, simple spot, Wildthyme gives few clues to the fireworks generated in the kitchen. The rousing food sets off sparks, turning a meal into a party. Every dish sampled, with one lone exception, deserved cheers.

headline: Palestinians Attempt to Capture Israeli Soldier

headline: Plots, Politics and the Weight of Page 1
text: PUBLIC Editor No. 3 doesn’t officially open his window for business until next week. But already an issue has popped up that is filled with themes I’m sure to revisit over the next two years of examining and commenting on the news judgment of The Times.

headline: In a Stirring Belmont, the Filly Beats the Fellas
text: No, it did not start well for Rags to Riches, or for that matter the filly’s jockey, John Velazquez, or her trainer, Todd Pletcher. She stumbled out of the gate for the 139th running of the Belmont Stakes, and for a heart-in-your-throat moment, Velazquez and Pletcher had a simultaneous and bitter thought: Why did we do this? Why did we run this girl against the boys when history told us it was foolish?

headline: Where ‘Sumptuous’ Is No Exaggeration
text: THE swell co-ops on Fifth Avenue are not, in their essentials, a whole lot different from your typical elevator apartment house. After all, there is only so much you can do with the arrangement of windows.

headline: In Shackleton’s Wake, With a Hot Tub
text: The vast, icy land of Antarctica, “the White Continent,” has attracted explorers since the early days of the 20th century — from Roald Amundsen and Ernest Shackleton to Robert Falcon Scott and Richard E. Byrd — each determined to conquer this unconquerable continent.

headline: In Pennsylvania Hamlet, Much Ado About Goo
text: THIS July, as they have for the past seven, fright freaks will swarm into Phoenixville, Pa., a flyspeck steel town at the junction of French Creek and the Schuylkill River. It was here in a nearby field that a movie legend was born. After oozing from a meteorite, an amorphous alien — looking like the love child of a lava lamp and a Gummy Bear — attached itself to dogs, hermits and groping teenagers, literally sucking the life out of them.

headline: Three Couples, One Party: Just Add Zingers and Angst
text: “Place Setting,” at the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch, the first full-length play by the actor and writer Jack Canfora, has all the snap, crackle and pop of a breakfast cereal, even though much of the action takes place at a New Year’s dinner party on the eve of the millennium. It’s hard to say which of the three couples on stage is more mismatched and miserable: Andrea, a tightly wound Martha Stewart wannabe, and Greg, who can’t stop tossing verbal darts; Charlotte, the slinky fiancée of buttoned-up Lenny, Greg’s brother; or Laura and Richard, both way too downtown — in different ways — for their own good.

headline: New York: Yours, Mine and Theirs
text: IT was another of those apocalypse-could-be weekends in New York. F.B.I. agents and police officers nabbed a retired cargo handler allegedly pursuing his golden-years dream of blowing up J.F.K., not to mention half of Queens.

text: Beverly Hills, Calif.

headline: Capturing Angkor Before Tourism Works Its Changes
text: THERE is a moment at Angkor, the vast complex of ancient temples in the Cambodian jungle, that every visitor hopes for. Perhaps it comes while passing under a 60-foot-high gate carved a thousand years ago, or at sunrise when the lotus-like spires are reflected in a placid pool of water. Or maybe it comes when you encounter a centuries-old tree, growing straight from a sandstone slab and slowly devouring a temple.

headline: Rocket Scientist or Auto Mechanic? The Distinction Is Blurring

text: MY father was a civilian who worked for the United States government in intelligence. My family moved between Germany, where I was born, and Panama, Thailand and the United States.

headline: A Semiretired Martin Still Makes His Moves
text: LONG POND, Pa., June 9  Mark Martin, the 48-year-old stock-car driver with snowy hair and a flock of crow’s feet perched outside his eyes, is semiretired and plans to stay that way. But he is not exactly puttering into the sunset on a golf cart.

headline: Corporate Korea Corks the Bottle as Women Rise
text: SEOUL, South Korea — In a time-honored practice in South Korea’s corporate culture, the 38-year-old manager at an online game company took his 10-person team on twice-weekly after-work drinking bouts. He exhorted his subordinates to drink, including a 29-year-old graphic designer who protested that her limit was two glasses of beer.

headline: Strange Land
text: In Naeem Murr’s first two novels, set in London and its environs, social workers administered to demonic child prostitutes and bardic welfare cheats while tackling their own severe personal problems. In “The Perfect Man,” his third novel, Murr, who was born and raised in London and now lives in the United States, brings his slightly gothic sensibility to bear on the heart of America. The book takes place chiefly in Pisgah, Mo., the small town where Rajiv Travers, a half-Indian, half-English boy, comes of age in the 1950s. This “Our Town”-ish locale is an ideal showcase for Murr’s impressive talents, previously deployed on a widely divergent cast of British characters. Here, Murr weaves an elaborate plot, shifting perspective between small-town characters — adults, outcasts and the handful of teenagers who form the novel’s core.

text: The Garden Conservancy's Open Days program invites visitors to the following gardens on the dates listed. Tickets are $5 and can be purchased at each garden.

headline: The Hallelujah People

headline: Michal Fromer, Harris Mufson

headline: 36 Hours in New York
text: THINK of New York City as photography's oyster. As a subject, photographers have been endlessly attracted to its streets (Lee Friedlander), night life (Weegee), world-famous skyline (Berenice Abbott) and all the refracted angles in between. As a place to view great works, it offers possibilities that are endless, from museums and galleries devoted to the art form, to restaurants and bars that hang rarified works. The city is the world's media capital, so photography not only attracts artists and shutterbugs alike, but it's also a big business, fueling everything from advertising and modeling agencies to retouching labs and frame shops. With so much to see, the trick is to edit out the visual distractions — just as with any good photograph.

headline: Is It Just a Strong Market, or the Bubble, Part 2?
text: THE Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index is close to where it stood just before the bursting of the Internet bubble in March 2000. That makes some investors nervous: Could the market be forming another bubble?

headline: Correction: Surprising Herself, a Class Act Returns
text: An article on April 29 about Angela Lansbury and her return to Broadway misstated the number of times she has been nominated for an Emmy Award. It is 18, not 15. (She has never won.)

headline: My Husband May Out-Mom Me
text: I USED to date a lot of guys who needed taking care of, and I was never very good at it. I didn’t take chicken soup when they were sick or nod emphatically when they said things like, “I’m a better monologuist than Eric Bogosian, don’t you think?”

headline: The Dance of the Final Bow
text: AFTER the show the curtain falls, and there are those for whom it will not rise again. Some discover only in retrospect that they will no longer perform because of injury or illness. Others leave the stage quietly, telling nobody their plans until after their last performance. Some, however, choose the moment and the manner of their going and give advance notice to the world. There are never so many true ballerinas that it’s comfortable to say goodbye even to one of them, but coincidence has ordained that this month brings the formal farewell performances of four international ballerinas, all of whom have been admired in New York. Four!

headline: Microsoft Finds Legal Defender in Justice Dept.

text: Our eyes met across a baseball field, where our 6-year-old sons, who are teammates, were taking batting practice. We exchanged awkward smiles and quick head bobs. I glanced at my wife to make sure she had not picked up any of our signs.

headline: The Night Visitor
text: AT 2 a.m. the reedy doorbell of my Upper East Side apartment sounded twice. As I woke up, my first thought was fire, but I could smell no smoke. There were no ladder trucks parked outside my walk-up, as there had been several months earlier when one of my neighbors — a jet-lagged flight attendant — fell asleep while roasting a chicken. By midnight her stove was in flames.

headline: Leiter Still Sees Value in a Pitching Rubber
text: Al Leiter does not appear at many card shows. But as he signed various items last month at a show in Secaucus, N.J., he was put in an unusual position. For the first time in his life, Leiter wanted to keep a fan’s memorabilia.

headline: I Was Hooked on Horror Flicks Dumped to DVD!
text: IF you’re one of those troubled creatures who lurk around the nethermost shelves of the video store, you already know one of Hollywood’s dark secrets: Every year scores of horror movies never make it to the screen at all and are instead dumped right onto the DVD market, where they earn a total of about $150 million a year. According to a trailer from Lionsgate, which last fall packaged some of these DVD releases as an “After Dark HorrorFest: Eight Movies to Die For,” this is because the content of certain movies is “considered too graphic, too disturbing and too shocking for general audiences.” Only Lionsgate, the trailer went on to say, had “defied the system” by delivering such material right to the home DVD player.

headline: What’s on Sunday Night

O’Byrne, Christopher Plummer and Liev Schreiber) in years. It also includes some notable musical performances, including numbers from “Grey Gardens,” “Spring Awakening” and “110 in the Shade.” More than 60 nominees and other celebrities, including Harry Connick Jr., Claire Danes, Jeff Daniels, Brian Dennehy, Carla Gugino, Neil Patrick Harris, Audra McDonald, Bernadette Peters, Kevin Spacey and Rainn Wilson, are scheduled to appear. headline: Proximity to Darkness
text: Larky, fitfully brilliant, as profane as they are aphoristic, Leonard Michaels’s stories stand alongside those of his best Jewish contemporaries — Grace Paley and Philip Roth. Like theirs, Michaels’s vernacular achieves the level of song. And yet, though much celebrated during his lifetime — Michaels died at 70 in 2003 — his sexually kinetic work is little read today. But perhaps now it will be, with the republication of his work in two new volumes that should bring Michaels to a new generation of readers and remind us of his lasting achievement. “The Collected Stories” includes the full contents of his acclaimed first two volumes, “Going Places” (1969) and “I Would Have Saved Them if I Could” (1975), as well as selections from his later writing, including all the existing Nachman stories. “Sylvia” is a fictionalized memoir, first published in 1992, about Michaels’s first wife, Sylvia Bloch, who committed suicide.

headline: The Mind of the South
text: I had to stop reading this book in public. I laughed out loud too often and too uproariously for the company in a bus or plane or cafe. What was worse, if I tried to explain myself my Southern accent, usually kept in check when I’m traveling in the North or abroad (where I live), came back like kudzu after a summer rain. “Y’all got to read this,” I heard myself saying to an older couple staring at me on a flight to Rome last month. (They were Americans, as I knew by their Bermuda shorts.) I don’t normally say “y’all” except when I’m making my annual pilgrimage to South Carolina, and then only for a couple of weeks — although I always do, it is true, feel better about myself when I’m drawing out my vowels.

headline: A Forgettable Legislative Session

headline: In Keeping Things Green, the Task Is to Handle More With Less
text: DURING George E. Pataki’s three terms as governor, the amount of land managed by the State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation increased by 66,000 acres. At the same time, department staffing fell by about 250 and capital improvements languished.

headline: Correction: Drama: Another Casualty of War
text: An article on May 27 about war dramas in theater and on film referred incorrectly to the outcome of the battle of Thermopylae, depicted in “300.” The small band of Spartans was defeated by the Persians, not the other way around.

headline: Shop Stewards on Fantasy Island?
text: One thing that can be said about the war for Fisher Island is that everyone involved wants only what’s best for the place. This 216-acre property with 34 sprawling Mediterranean-style luxury condominium buildings sits conveniently surrounded by Miami Beach, the city of Miami, Biscayne Bay and the Atlantic Ocean. It is an island paradise containing every possible indulgence that someone with a great deal of money and an enormous need to be coddled might desire. Fisher Island’s fortunate 1,400, fewer than one-third of them full-time residents, can play on the golf course created by P. B. Dye, of the famed course-design family, or on one of 18 tennis courts — clay, grass and hard court surfaces. There are two marinas — one for large yachts and one for larger yachts — and a state-of-the-art gym, complete with a Roman waterfall for aching backs and, along with yoga and Pilates, classes with names like Waves of Steel and Esto Es Tango! The sand on the beach is imported from the Bahamas and cleared daily of seaweed, so it is always soft and white. There are swimming pools, not just at the health spa, but also in each condo complex. Perpetually blooming tropical flowers perfume the air; caged toucans twitter in banyan trees, flamingos wade lazily in their own private pond. Kids attend a special island private school where cameras, wired into the condos, allow anxious parents to monitor their offspring from home; the playground, naturally, is gently padded.

headline: Service Compris
text: The chef Thomas Keller’s affection for culinary quotation marks — “macaroni and cheese” made with orzo and lobster; “bacon and eggs” with braised pig’s head and quail eggs — is his signature, a stylistic calling card as particular as a Hemingway cadence or a Tiger Woods swing.

headline: The Office
text: The Pentagon is not generally considered a significant work of architecture, but perhaps it should be. In a period when every new art museum and luxury condo tower is touted as “iconic,” the Pentagon is the real thing: a globally recognized symbol. This concrete behemoth — the largest office building in the world — is also the product of considerable human ingenuity and resourcefulness, as Steve Vogel amply demonstrates in his interesting account. The Library of Congress categorizes “The Pentagon” as history and architecture, but it is really biography — the biography of a building.

headline: Carroll Leatherman, William Brett

headline: Finding Out What the Neighbors Paid
text: Q Are condo sale prices public information? I found a Web site that is charging a fee for providing sale prices, but I wonder if there is a free New York City Web site where the same information can be found? How about co-op sales?

headline: A Bloody Cut Above Your Everyday Zombie Film
text: HORROR movies have always provided a safe haven for indulging anxieties, whether they are about giving birth (“It’s Alive”), buying a home (“The Amityville Horror”) or having sex (almost all of them). So it’s probably no coincidence that teenagers who grew up with terrorist alerts and photos of war are flocking in large numbers to increasingly graphic, torture-filled films that make Freddy Krueger look like a sweetie pie.

headline: Snapshots That Do More Than Bore Friends
text: FEW sentences in the English language are more dreaded than this seemingly innocent offer: “Oh, I must show you the pictures from my vacation.” Who wants to see endless shots of a friend lounging by a pool or in front of a monument, or — worse yet — their kids doing the very same things?

headline: Ancient Road, Timeless Trip
text: The Silk Road is the popular name for a system of caravan trade routes that dates back more than 2,000 years, an important economic artery that stretched roughly 7,000 miles, from the Mediterranean to China’s Yellow River Valley. Earlier this year, the photographer Jehad Nga, on assignment for the Travel section, spent three weeks retracing part of the historic route in central Asia, driving from Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan, to Dushanbe, Tajikistan.

headline: Following Conceptualism, From Point A to Point B
text: No modern movement has been more successful in expanding the expressive possibilities of art than Conceptualism has. It has even scrambled conventional art disciplines, as evidenced by a thoughtful new exhibition at Yale University Art Gallery devoted to the humble role of lines in drawing. Around 60 drawings from the collection tell the tale of how drawing became dark, wild and crazy.

headline: Up Front
text: “I first heard of Leonard Michaels not as a writer but as the teacher of English 134, an undergraduate creative writing class at the University of California, Berkeley,” in the late 1970s, Mona Simpson recalled in an e-mail message. “Students killed to get in. Hundreds applied. He took 12.” In the first session, a student asked if they should all photocopy their stories and hand them around. “ ‘No need,’ Michaels said from the podium. ‘We will be working orally.’ ”

headline: Bodies of Evidence
text: Well, it’s that time of year when the big novels are rolled out, and here they come: barrels of books by big-name writers like Michael Connelly, Janet Evanovich, Robert B. Parker, Lee Child and Mary Higgins Clark. But with publishers now pushing some best-selling authors to produce a book or two (or even three) a year, even the most faithful reader can feel the need for a palate cleanser. Personally, I find that nothing restores my devotion to genre novels, or my respect for their sheer craft, than plunging into a traditional whodunit or a complicated procedural.

headline: Sarkozy’s Party on the Way to a Big Victory
text: PARIS, June 10 — President Nicolas Sarkozy’s center-right camp was on course to win a landslide victory in Parliament today after the first round of France’s legislative elections, cementing his power to implement reforms in Europe’s third-largest economy.

headline: To Pick Winners, Start by Weeding Out the Losers
text: INVESTORS who want to add a margin of safety when searching for hot growth stocks may want to consider a grading system developed by Partha S. Mohanram, an associate professor at Columbia University’s business school.

headline: Theater Listings
text: SKETCHFEST NYC Since the first SketchFest in Seattle eight years ago, sketch comedy festivals have been popping up in cities from Los Angeles to Toronto. New York has plenty of cutups too, and it joined the fun two years ago with Sketchfest NYC, an annual event taking place this weekend. “The goal is to make people realize what sketch comedy is,” said Alexander Zalben, a producer of Sketchfest NYC. “It’s not just people in their fraternities putting on funny skits about their professors.” Unlike improvisation or standup comedy, sketch consists of short written scenes rehearsed in advance. (Think of “Saturday Night Live.”) The content may be funny, but Mr. Zalben and his co-producers, Keith Michel, Becky Poole and Elizabeth Ellis, are serious about this type of humor. “We weren’t going to aim for being the biggest,” Mr. Zalben said. “It’s more important to aim for a consistent level of quality.” Instead of opening the festival to all performers, the producers watched more than 100 live-performance tapes, and chose 21 groups for the festival.

headline: Street Sense Has a Future Canoodling, Mostly for Profit
text: She stumbled coming out of the gate, and that will be part of the legacy of Rags to Riches — the sudden stabbing fear of danger. We have seen that all too often in the Triple Crown. Too many horses have come apart in the spring.

headline: If They Talked, It Wouldn’t Be a Secret
text: Mystery meat is one thing, mystery ice cream quite another. Especially when the cryptic confection in question — a flavor known at Zita’s Homemade Ice Cream only as 91716 — is a just-right amalgam of chocolate-covered pretzel bits, caramel, peanut butter and chocolate chips in a rich vanilla ice cream base ($2.10 for a scoop).

headline: Mary McBride and Leslie Klotz
text: MARY McBRIDE, a country-folk singer and songwriter, lives like someone chasing a tornado, with little concern for safety, convention, income or comfort. Until a year ago, her home was an unrenovated Brooklyn loft, furnished with a picnic table, a bed and a life-size portrait of Dolly Parton. “She was happy as a clam,” said Greg Unis, her landlord and a friend.

headline: The Inequality Conundrum
text: In 1976, Richard Freeman wrote a book called “The Overeducated American.” So many Americans had been getting college degrees that the relative wages of white-collar professionals had started to fall. It no longer paid to go to college and, for most of the ’70s, fewer people did. Just so, incomes of the educated began to rise again.

headline: N.F.L. Study Authors Dispute Concussion Finding
text: For several years, many medical experts have maintained that high school football players who sustain concussions should not return to the games in which they are injured. So when doctors commissioned by the National Football League published a study two years ago concluding “it might be safe” for such players to do so, the assertion sparked widespread criticism. Now the criticism is coming from authors of the paper itself.

headline: With Iraq War as a Backdrop, Speakers Reflect on the Future
text: For many if not most members of the class of 2007, the war in Iraq has been the constant background of their college years. And so as seniors graduated from thousands of colleges and universities in recent weeks, the war was on the mind of many commencement speakers. Some criticized its prosecution, others commended the sacrifices of the hundreds of thousands of volunteers serving in the armed forces, but few ignored the continuing struggle.

headline: Lady Luck as Bridesmaid

headline: From Scraps of Memory, Reinventing a Forgotten Grandmother
text: Most of us can’t imagine growing up among people for whom fame is the norm. Lynn Redgrave, the daughter of a celebrated couple whose friends and colleagues were celebrities too, grew up in just such a home. So there must have been an extra pang for her when, arriving at the grave of her maternal grandmother, the distinctly unfamous Beatrice Kempson, she found the headstone blank — eroded by England’s acid rain.

headline: Land of Plenty
text: AFTER the privations of the Depression and war years, Congress passed and President Harry Truman signed the Employment Act of 1946, which made it federal policy to maintain “the propensity to consume.” The choice of the word “propensity” would have seemed droll, were any Congress capable of drollery. That mild noun hardly does justice to the primal urge, the almost metabolic necessity, for consumption that Americans felt as they came up, as it were, for their first breath of air since October 1929.

headline: My Dog Days
text: MY little guy is growing up fast. He’s toilet-trained, he goes uncomplainingly to sleep and he no longer chews on his playmates’ faces until they bleed. He is 8 months old, and I know, years from now, that I will always remember this summer as the time he and I fell in love.

headline: The Ballad of the Spurned CD
text: ON a recent Sunday afternoon in Park Slope, no one could blame Drew Hoffman, a graduate student who is moving to Montreal, for first trying to unload a few relics at a stoop sale. Surely, though, he’d made a mistake. Amid the wreckage of artifacts — a stone-age printer, old course books from Hunter College, a threadbare Dead Kennedys T-shirt from high school — were boxes and boxes of CDs. They were good ones, too, like “Southpaw Grammar” by Morrissey, the former lead singer of the Smiths, and “Chutes Too Narrow” by the Shins.

headline: Just Don’t Get Crumbs in the Books

headline: New in Town, Talking Funny
text: THE blessing of being a comedian from New Zealand is that your accent will make anything you say sound a little bit funny to American ears, whether you intend it or not. The curse is that your naturally laid-back attitude and innate stoicism will cause some people — say, television executives — to doubt your commitment to your art, and others to question your career choice altogether.

headline: Slumping Wie Posts Worst Score as a Professional
text: HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., June 9 — Michelle Wie carded an 11-over-par 83 on Saturday in the third round of the L.P.G.A. Championship at Bulle Rock Golf Course outside Baltimore. It was her highest score since turning professional in October 2005 and her worst score since posting an 85 four years ago, when she was 13.

headline: Mr. Murdoch and The Journal
text: Editorial pages generally do not compliment the competition, but today we write in praise of The Wall Street Journal. The Journal, the crown jewel of Dow Jones & Company, produces a balanced and trustworthy news report that is required reading for corporate and political leaders around the world. The question is whether that news operation will survive if Rupert Murdoch persuades the Bancroft family to sell Dow Jones, and thus The Journal.

headline: Tangible Family Values
text: Just about everyone pays homage to the value of the family. But when it comes to helping families manage financially when a child or aging parent is sick, not much is offered. That is especially so for families with low incomes.

headline: Warsaw Underground
text: The Poles, probably more than any other Europeans, must feel they deserve a little peace, freedom and prosperity. Sandwiched between the neighbors from hell (Germany, Russia), they were at the back of the line when the late 20th century dispensed its favors. But now here are democracy, economic growth and membership in the European Union; Poland’s future, on the surface, appears rosier than ever.

headline: Tabloid Princess
text: Admittedly, I’m biased. On July 29, 1981, when Lady Diana Spencer married Prince Charles, I was in London with my family. I was 11, and like millions of people, I couldn’t get enough of the “Shy Di” fairy tale: ugly (O.K., gangly) duckling meets handsome (O.K., gangly) prince and becomes luminous royal swan. In the new couple’s honor, I spent a month’s allowance on wedding memorabilia. My prize purchase was a Diana coffee mug with a wide-brimmed ceramic hat. “Only the girls are going in for this lot,” the sales clerk grumbled. He might have been talking about the fairy princess myth itself. Sometimes against their better judgment, women the world over were entranced by the prospect of untold leisure, unequaled glamour and redemptive metamorphosis that this particular myth promised. Ladies, let’s be honest: who really among us hasn’t dreamed of becoming a princess?

headline: Chinese Leave Guantánamo for Albanian Limbo
text: TIRANA, Albania — Ahktar Qassim Basit says he is not angry about the four years he spent as an American prisoner at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, before his captors mumbled a brief apology and flew him to this drab Balkan capital to begin a new life as a refugee.

headline: The Door Key That Can’t Be Misplaced
text: IT’S a common juggling act on the doorstep: rummaging for the house keys with one hand while balancing a bag of groceries with the other. Now a manufacturer is aiming to streamline household entry with a deadbolt lock that reduces the need to fish for keys. Instead, the lock opens with the swipe of a finger.

headline: Pope Shares Iraq Concerns in Meeting With Bush

headline: Fistful of Dollars
text: Q: As the creator of the hit show “Entourage,” which follows four buddies from Queens on their adventures in Hollywood, you’ve become a leading chronicler of the American dream at its most nakedly materialistic. So perhaps it’s not surprising that you’re planning a new HBO series devoted to a group of hedge-fund guys in New York. Why do you find the subject of money so interesting? Sadly, right now, that’s the world people are aspiring to. You have Harvard-educated medical doctors who would rather work at an investment bank than try to cure cancer, and that’s the wish-fulfillment lifestyle that I play into.

headline: As the Nazis and Adolescence Took Hold
text: MORE than 60 years ago, as she awaited the final horrors of the Holocaust in the Bedzin ghetto of Poland, a 14-year-old Jewish girl named Rutka Laskier committed her thoughts to a diary. Although the journal covers only a few months in 1943, its arresting combination of detail — from Nazi atrocities to adolescent infatuation — has drawn comparisons to the celebrated diary of Anne Frank.

text: Race weekend at Lowe’s Motor Speedway in Concord, N.C., just outside Charlotte, is 2,000 acres of pure American spectacle. headline: The Democrats Lag on Warming

On the vital issues of energy independence and global warming they are not only in danger of getting more of the same but also, unless Nancy Pelosi and other Democratic leaders step forward, winding up in worse shape than they were under the Republicans.

headline: Inside the List
text: VEGANGELICALS: In the world of vegan cookbook writers, these are embattled times. Nina Planck’s recent Op-Ed essay in The New York Times, “Death by Veganism,” argued that children and a vegan diet don’t mix, and the essay hit No. 1 on this paper’s “most e-mailed” list. Vegans fired back bitterly on countless Web sites and blogs. This meaty fuss made me wonder: What is this country’s best-selling vegan cookbook, anyway?

text: THE day that New York adopts congestion pricing, charging me to drive from one part of the city to another, is the day I move to Long Island. Why? Because as much as I love Queens and its proximity to Manhattan, I can’t afford another tax.

headline: This Time, Sensitivity to Prices

Many similar warnings have caused barely a ripple on Wall Street, but after the Fed chief, Ben S. Bernanke, reiterated them early last week in remarks to a conference of bankers, bond yields rose and the stock market sank.

headline: Don’t Tread on Them
text: FOR video game aficionados who came of age in the late 1970s, the aliens from Space Invaders are symbols of menace. Shaped like robotic jellyfish, they would descend inexorably toward a player’s laser cannon, coming in ever-faster swarms as the game progressed. Sooner or later, the aliens would triumph, leaving the defeated player to contemplate — if only for an instant — the horrors of life on a conquered planet.

headline: In Prague, a World of Stage Design
text: WHEN Arnold Aronson, a theater professor at Columbia University, received the offer several years ago to serve as general commissioner of the Prague Quadrennial, he knew it might be hard to brag about. “Everyone knows the Oscars, the Tonys, even the Venice Biennale,” he explained. “I tell people all the time what I’m doing, and they say they’ve never heard of it.”

headline: Kamsky Quits, Returns, Quits. Is He Really Back This Time?

headline: 7 Nights of Bright Eyes (in as Many Colors)
text: BY nature rock bloggers are an obsessive bunch, but few take their fixations as far as the artist Andrew Kuo. On the blog earlboykins.blogspot.com Mr. Kuo meticulously dissects indie rock and hip-hop records and shows and then transforms the data into complicated, brightly colored charts and diagrams. The joke is, the more banal the information or sweeping the generalization, the more complex the graphics. “It’s a comment on fans’ short attention spans,” he said. “You think you can glance at a pie chart and decide whether or not to buy a record, but then you’re forced to work to figure it out.”

headline: The Old Revolutionary

Maharaj had left politics four years earlier, when Thabo Mbeki succeeded Nelson Mandela as president, and was working in the private sector.

headline: Why Ask for the Moon if You Have the Stars?
text: RED HOOK is one of those rare New York neighborhoods where the stars aren’t completely obscured by city lights. By late summer, Gita Nandan and Jens Veneman will be able to track them from their bathtub, which they’re preparing to relocate to their back deck. And if the gardening gods are beneficent, they’ll be able to reach out of the suds to snag cashew fruit from the scraggly tree they nursed to life from seeds they brought back from Cambodia.

headline: Larry Summers’s Evolution
text: Back in the 1980s, two young Harvard professors trying to reinvigorate the Democratic Party would meet at the Wursthaus restaurant in Cambridge, Mass., to have lunch and argue with each other. They must have made for an entertaining sight, one of them bearish and the other less than five feet tall, debating each other in a dark Harvard Square dive. The argument, in a nutshell, came to this. The smaller man — Robert Reich, a future secretary of labor — argued for something that he called “industrial policy.” Since the government couldn’t avoid having a big influence on the economy, he said, it should at least do so in a way that promoted fast-growing industries and invested in worthy public projects.

headline: With Win Against Judah, Cotto Announces His Arrival Among Sport’s Elite
text: Through the first 29 fights of his professional boxing career, Miguel Cotto was a fighter with undeniable talent and promise. All he lacked was a marquee moment.

headline: Players to Watch
text: The Dodgers’ Juan Pierre has hit .214 this month. He is hitting .269 over all, with an on-base percentage of .297. Pierre has hit below .280 only once in his major league career. But he also has not hit .300, something he accomplished in four of his first five seasons, since 2004. Despite his downturn, Pierre said last week that he would not do anything different to break a recent fly-ball tendency.

headline: Why Classical Matters; Paul McCartney; the Tony Awards

headline: The Poverty Platform
text: In April 1964, when Lyndon Johnson sought to rally public support for his new War on Poverty, he did it while sitting on a pile of two-by-fours on a front porch in Inez, Ky. — an appearance that helped establish the Appalachian South as a national symbol of economic deprivation. And so it was fitting that John Edwards, announcing his candidacy for president at the end of last year, chose as his setting not his hometown, Robbins, N.C., where he unveiled his first presidential campaign four years earlier, but the front yard of a mangled brick house in New Orleans’s Upper Ninth Ward. New Orleans is the new national shorthand for neglect, and it is, not coincidentally, the spiritual center of Edwards’s campaign. After Hurricane Katrina washed away, with brutal efficiency, some of America’s most impoverished neighborhoods, Edwards took more than 700 students to the submerged city to help rebuild homes and schools, and in the months since then, he has never stayed away for long. “I can always tell when he’s been to New Orleans,” says Bruce Raynor, a co-president of the hotel and garment workers’ union, who is close to the former senator. “His passions are stirred. It angers him.”

headline: The Class-Consciousness Raiser
text: By the time Ruby Payne sat down for lunch, she had been at it for three hours straight, standing alone behind a lectern on a wide stage in a cavernous convention hall, parked between two American flags, instructing an audience of 1,400 Georgians in the hidden rules of class. No notes, no warm-up act, just Ruby, with her Midwestern-by-way-of-East-Texas drawl and her crisp white shirt, her pinstriped business suit and bright red lipstick and blow-dried blond hair, a wireless microphone hooked around her right ear. She had already explained why rich people don’t eat casseroles, why poor people hang their pictures high up on the wall, why middle-class people pretend to like people they can’t stand. She had gone through the difference between generational poverty and situational poverty and the difference between new money and old money, and she had done a riff on how middle-class people are so self-satisfied that they think everyone wants to be middle class.

headline: His and Not Hers

Despite this disparity, he insists that if we wed I must then bear half the cost of everything. I think married people should pool their resources, contributing what they can. He thinks I am looking for a sugar daddy. You? — name withheld, New York

headline: The Greatest Art for the Littlest Readers

She then moves on to the combination of collage and pastels in an innovative mixed-media work and the shimmering effect produced by layering paint in a favorite watercolor.

headline: From a Pandora’s Box, a Spilling of Dreams

This is understandable, for along with the legendary shenanigans of its leading practitioners — which ranged from dabbling with hallucinogens to automatic writing — it also inspired some seductive, memorable images. Rejecting reason, the artists embraced the fantasy world of dreams.

headline: Editors’ Note
text: The Cooking roundup last Sunday, written by Amanda Hesser, included a review of Patricia Wells’s “Vegetable Harvest.” In 1999, Wells contributed a jacket blurb for Hesser’s book “The Cook and the Gardener.” The Book Review has a policy against assigning a review in those circumstances, but by the time Hesser told editors about the blurb, the issue had already gone to press. Had the editors known of the conflict, Wells’s book would not have been included.

headline: At the Movies
text: A mouthwatering curiosity is what the viewer takes away from Edward Hopper’s painting “The Sheridan Theatre” (1937), the subject of a splendid little exhibition at the Newark Museum. The painting depicts a disquieting scene of a woman alone at the back of a movie theater, watched by two figures, one of them an usher. Is she waiting for friends, or has she simply arrived late? We don’t know, for her behavior doesn’t fit with any typical pattern of moviegoing.

headline: Comings & Goings
text: Canceled flight? Change of plans? Just plain busy? Grab your smart phone or PDA and visit www.tripsync.com to reserve a car, flight or hotel using real-time information. Any portable, Web-enabled device is compatible with the service, which is free. Microsoft Outlook fans should be especially excited about TripSync, as it instantly updates the reserved travel information on each user’s calendar. ... On July 7, the New Seven Wonders of the World are to be announced in Lisbon. The selections are being made by voters who signed on to www.new7wonders.com; among the nominees are Chichén-Itzá in Mexico, the Great Wall of China and the Acropolis in Greece (below). For those champing at the bit to attend the announcement ceremony, Abreu Tours is offering three-night and six-night packages, starting at $431 a person a night (double occupancy). Participants may choose from a variety of hotels, with optional car rental and airfare (www.abreu-tours.com). ... Intrepid Travel, an adventure tourism company based in Australia, is offering six new family itineraries: Europe, Switzerland, Turkey, Morocco, Egypt and Nepal. The trips are geared toward children ages 6 to 17, and there is a maximum of two children per adult. Rates vary, and don’t include airfare and some meals. The Nepal Family Adventure, for example, an 11-day trip that includes white-water rafting, a visit to a crocodile breeding center, elephant rides and camping in the Himalayas, costs $830 a person (www.intrepidtravel.com). ... An Avis promotion (www.avis.com) is doubling the number of free iTunes downloads with car rentals. Usually, a customer who rents a vehicle for five days or more receives 10 downloads, but through June, customers get 20.

headline: Should We Globalize Labor Too?
text: The Arniko Highway climbs out of Kathmandu in long wending loops that pay twin tribute to the impassability of Himalayan terrain and the implausibility of its development. Outside Africa, no country is poorer than Nepal. Its per capita income looks like a misprint: $270 a year. Sudan’s is more than twice as high. Nearly two-thirds of Nepalis lack electricity. Half the preschoolers are malnourished. To the list of recent woes add regicide — 10 royals slaughtered in 2001 by a suicidal prince — and a Maoist insurgency.

headline: The Great Midtown Cover-Up
text: ANYONE strolling down a nine-block stretch of Broadway in Midtown at noon on a sunny day this spring could be forgiven for thinking that it was either nighttime or unexpectedly gloomy. Nine sidewalk sheds, some up to a full block long, could be found between Times Square and Herald Square. All had been erected around existing buildings, not at sites where construction was taking place.

headline: On the Road With History’s Father
text: Ryszard Kapuscinski disappeared in the dead of winter, January 2007, half as well known as his influence would lead one to expect. He went into the beyond Nobel-less, like Joyce and Proust and Nabokov, but to many who read him he was as exalted: “deity” was used, more than once, in his assorted funeral songs. While such desperate formulations as “world literature” conjure up bongos, beads and sitting Indian-style, the books Kapuscinski wrote may actually qualify, as evocative and singular in English as they are in their native (and what is said to be austerely fine) Polish. For many of us, the day of his death was a dark, cold day.

headline: Using Alliance Partner Airlines For Miles and Upgrades
text: My husband and I are planning to celebrate our 10th anniversary exploring New Zealand. headline: Raw
text: When I first tried sushi in Tokyo in the fall of 1977, I thought of myself as an intrepid culinary adventurer who, if he survived the experience, would return to America to tell the incredible, unbelievable tale of the day he ate raw fish on rice balls. Someday, perhaps, I would tell my children. By the time I returned to the States two years later, I found sushi bars in Midtown Manhattan; within a few years, nigiri sushi became the signature forage of the Young Urban Professional. As for my children, they eat sushi three or four times a week. They developed a taste for it when they were living in Nashville, Tenn., which, though it lacks any convincing French or Italian restaurants, has several fine sushi bars. From very different perspectives, “The Zen of Fish,” by Trevor Corson, and “The Sushi Economy,” by Sasha Issenberg, attempt to account for the transformation of sushi from a provincial street snack to the international luxury cuisine of the 21st century.

headline: North Korea Misspent Funds From U.N., Diplomats Say
text: WASHINGTON, June 9 — Senior American diplomats at the United Nations have compiled new information indicating that several million dollars in United Nations development money had been paid to a North Korean entity closely associated with that nation’s programs to develop unconventional weapons and sell missiles abroad.

headline: Between Skid Row and Starbucks
text: THE dive bars, pawnshops and flophouses for the misanthropic, misbegotten and mostly down-and-out have disappeared. The rock club CBGB closed in October, Whole Foods opened in March and at least 20 Starbucks outlets are entrenched within a mile radius. The Bowery’s gritty glory days may well be over, pushed out by surging rents and the ever-rising tide of gentrification.

headline: Does the ‘G’ Stand for Ghost?
text: In theory, the G train, the lime green line that never enters Manhattan, runs for about 14 miles, from Red Hook, Brooklyn, all the way to Forest Hills, Queens. For residents of Jackson Heights who enjoy the cuisines of Carroll Gardens, for example, or for Greenpointers who shop at the Queens Center mall in Elmhurst, the G can be a straight shot, no train changes needed.

headline: Laugh Lines: Jay Leno, David Letterman and Conan  O’Brien
text: JAY LENO

headline: They Came. They Conquered. They Posed.
text: TOURISM is by some economic measures the largest business in the world. Oil companies, airlines and manufacturers of ski boots, bikinis and chocolate mints for hotel pillows all depend on its vitality. It is also an unsteady business, erected not on our material need to visit Florence or the Grand Tetons but on the illusions that lead us there, or anywhere beyond the horizon of home.

headline: A Potato Diary, From Obsession to Heartache
text: THIS spring, when the seed potatoes arrived at our local grain-and-feed store, I circled the barrels of dusty little tubers. I was talking to myself: Should I? Dare I plant a spud  again? Mortified, our teenage daughter walked away from me, whispering, “Give it up, Mom. It’ll be the same as all the other times.”

headline: Newcomers, End to End

headline: Correction:  Tuscan Summer: Food, Wine and Music Galore
text: A photograph with the In Transit column on May 27 about summer music festivals in Tuscany was published in error. It depicted the fortress at Montalcino, not the villa La Foce, which is the site for much of the Incontri in Terra di Siena festival.

headline: Cool Reception for Bible Park in Bible Belt
text: MURFREESBORO, Tenn., June 6 — Behind Blackman United Methodist Church, on a low hillock overlooking a freshly mown meadow, wooden benches face a sturdy altar table and a plywood lectern. A plain cross, slightly bowed by weather, towers over the outdoor chapel.

text: Victoria Odette Hays, a daughter of Odette and Spencer B. Hays of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Michael Adam Feuerstein, a son of Deborah and Richard Feuerstein of Scarsdale, N.Y. Cantor Henry Weintraub performed the ceremony at the Point O’ Woods Yacht Squadron on Fire Island in New York , with the Right Rev. John S. Spong, the former bishop of the Episcopal diocese of Newark, taking part.

text: The trial of Charles Taylor, former president of Liberia, is looking like the trial of Slobodan Milosevic, former leader of Yugoslavia, and that is too bad.

headline: Old-Vine Charm in a Zinfandel
text: Few zinfandels are as deeply seductive as the 2005 Mohr-Fry Ranches version from the small St. Amant Winery in Lodi, Calif. Vines planted in 1944 gave the grapes rich character.

headline: This Time, It’s for Fun
text: Five police officers thrust their fists into the center of a circle and bellowed: “One, two, three. Defense!” The basketball game erupted into a storm of furious dribbling and decisive dunks. Sneakers screeched on the gleaming gym floor.

headline: Pak Inspires New Generation of Countrywomen
text: HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., June 9  Darkness used to be Se Ri Pak’s trusty companion on the L.P.G.A. Tour, her long days of practice fueled by a fervent belief that the last one to leave the course was destined to finish first.

headline: The Commuter Cocktail Hour
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority — worried, in part, about sloppy drunks bothering other passengers and being menaces on the drive home from the train station — recently entertained the idea of prohibiting the sale or use of alcohol on Metro-North and Long Island Rail Road trains.

headline: Beware of Exploding Mortgages
text: ANYONE who believes that the worst is over in the subprime mortgage fiasco need merely wait awhile. A tsunami of interest rate increases on these loans is headed your way.

headline: Carolyn Petersen, Christopher Perera
text: Carolyn Elizabeth Petersen and Christopher Davis Perera were married last evening by the Rev. Paul Thompson at St. Andrews by the Sea Episcopal Church in Hyannis Port, Mass.

headline: Brooklyn’s Lessons
text: In a Brooklyn courtroom last week, two men who were once among the borough’s seediest power brokers learned how long they will now have to spend in prison. Former Assemblyman Clarence Norman, once the Democratic Party kingpin for the county, can expect two to five years behind bars, maybe more. Mr. Norman was convicted of extortion, soliciting illegal contributions and stealing from his re-election committee.

headline: Two More Weeks
text: About this time every year, the New York Legislature starts to kick into high gear. These are the last few days of the year’s official session, and often that deadline is enough to make Albany’s regulars summon the final oomph needed to finish six months of business in two short weeks.

headline: She Bought Another Island. People Are Wondering.
text: BRANFORD

headline: New Kicks on Route 66 for Commercial Builders
text: ALONG Route 66, which connected Chicago to Los Angeles from 1926 to 1985, roadside motels and their signature neon signs have been celebrated in books, songs and movies, as motoring west became an expression of American independence and freedom.

headline: Gays in a Methodist Town? No Problem (Until Now)
text: OCEAN GROVE

headline: Private Loans Deepen a Crisis in Student Debt
text: WASHINGTON — As the first in her immigrant family to attend college, Lucia DiPoi said she had few clues about financing her college education. So when financial aid and low-interest government loans did not stretch far enough, Ms. DiPoi applied for $49,000 in private loans, too. “How bad could it be?” she recalls thinking.

headline: Knowing Not
text: Decline-and-fall books, like E. D. Hirsch Jr.’s “Cultural Literacy” and Allan Bloom’s “Closing of the American Mind,” can leave the reader torn between depression and elation: by detailing how stupid everyone else is, the authors leave us feeling better about ourselves. (“I know which has more members, the Supreme Court or the Supremes!”) So it was with smug anticipation that I opened “Religious Literacy,” Stephen Prothero’s jeremiad about declining religious knowledge. Most Americans “cannot name one of the four Gospels,” Prothero writes, “and many high school seniors think that Sodom and Gomorrah were husband and wife.” Religious illiteracy cuts across generations, and the devout scarcely know more than the secular do. In one survey of high school students, most evangelicals did not recognize that “Blessed are the poor in spirit” is from the Sermon on the Mount.

headline: Safaris Where the Hunt Is for the Perfect Picture
text: THE golden light was falling on the Mojave Desert, but no matter where Alberto Zanella pointed his fancy new camera, the rusting chemical tanks looked like an orange blur. He tried steadying the camera by kneeling on the sand, to no avail. Then he tried fidgeting with the autofocus mode, but wasn’t sure how — the manual was back at the hotel.

headline: A Plan for All Seasons: Swim in July, Skate in December
text: Dan Freed, a 36-year-old journalist and a new Brooklyn resident, has long had a knack for finding places to swim. In Chicago, where he grew up, it was Lake Michigan, and during the eight years he lived in East Harlem, he walked to Central Park, to the Lasker Rink and Pool, an unusual hybrid designed for swimming in warm weather and ice skating in the cold.

headline: Janet King and Bryan Sekino
text: Janet Chi-Ying King, a daughter of Dr. Nelly T. Loo and James V. King of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., was married last evening to Bryan Takashi Sekino, the son of Lucia and Warren T. Sekino of Holmdel, N.J. The Rev. Edmondo Sombilon performed the ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in New York.

headline: Adjusted Income
text: Let’s start by saying I have a lot of money. I’ve acquired it by writing children’s books about terrible things happening to orphans, and this seems like such a crazy and possibly monstrous way of acquiring money that I give a lot of it away. I mean, I guess it’s a lot. Let me put it like this: My wife and I recently became obsessed with a Web site where you plug in the amount of money you made in a year and find out where you stand. If your salary equaled the amount of money my wife and I gave Planned Parenthood one year, you’d be in the richest 1 percent in the world, which is pretty great. Still, there would be 60 million people richer than you, and that’s a lot. They wouldn’t fit in your home, for example, even though you’d have the sort of home that only the top 1 percent of people in the world can afford.

headline: Sweet Teens
text: Central Park, long a backdrop for wedding parties, is becoming a photo op for more youthful if look-alike events, quinceañeras, or 15th birthday celebrations, and sweet 16ths. Latino traditions that are growing ever more elaborate, they often feature Cinderella gowns, towering tiaras or flower headdresses, and as many as 24 attendants.

headline: Two’s a Crowd in This Listing
text: THE developer of a luxury building on the Upper East Side told Dolly Lenz, one of the city’s top brokers, six months ago that she was fired as the exclusive agent — but she’s still refusing to go.

text: Julia Elizabeth Phelan, the daughter of Mary F. Phelan of Washington, and John J. Phelan of Guilford, Conn., was married yesterday to Benjamin Philip Sylla, the son of Mary Eloise Sylla and Philip M. Sylla of Portland, Ore. Msgr. Charles V. Antonicelli performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Joseph’s on Capitol Hill in Washington.

headline: As ‘Continuing Care’ Grows, So Do the Payment Options
text: WHEN Robert and Jean LaCamera decided that it was time to move to a retirement community, they knew exactly where they wanted to go. Mr. LaCamera’s mother had spent her last years at Whitney Center in Hamden, Conn., a continuing care retirement community offering independent living, assisted-living services and a nursing home, all on one campus. “It was an excellent experience for her,” Mrs. LaCamera said.

headline: The Guidebook for Taking a Life
text: We were in a small house in Zarqa, Jordan, trying to interview two heavily bearded Islamic militants about their distribution of recruitment videos when one of us asked one too many questions.

headline: Buildingwide Cable Service: Must All Co-op Owners Pay?
text: Q The board of the co-op where I live is having the building wired for cable. The only way the cable company will do this is if everyone signs up for a three-year commitment. The board intends to include the cable bill with the maintenance each month. If I don't want the cable service, must I pay for it anyway?

headline: ‘The Age of Abundance’
text: On July 24, 1959, in the depths of the Cold War, Vice President Richard Nixon and Soviet premier Nikita Khrushchev stood face-to-face, close enough to smell each other's breath. Dozens of journalists and dignitaries crowded around them in increasingly nervous silence as the two argued heatedly. Khrushchev, the bald, brash son of Ukrainian peasants, raised his booming voice and waved his stubby hands in the air. Nixon, nearly a head taller, hovered over him, struggling to maintain his composure but then jabbing a finger into his adversary's chest. Precipitating this superpower showdown was a disagreement over ... washing machines.

headline: ‘The Zen of Fish’
text: Kate Murray's alarm clock went off at 5:30 a.m. She forced her eyes open. Her college classes had never started before noon.

text: This was written before the midterm elections of 2006, in which, as we now know, America-even as far South as Virginia-began to take my advice. Much remains to be seen.

headline: Nadal Wins French Open
text: Rafael Nadal defeated his rival Roger Federer to win his third straight French Open.

headline: Being There: What Makes Great Travel Photography
text: Michele McNally, assistant managing editor for photography at The Times, describes what she thinks makes a great travel picture, with photographs from the Travel section archives.

headline: Editor’s Choice
text: ON CHESIL BEACH, by Ian McEwan. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $22.) Consisting largely of a single sex scene played out on a couple’s wedding night, this seeming novel of manners is as much a horror story as any McEwan has written.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE POSSIBILITY OF AN ISLAND, by Michel Houellebecq. Translated by Gavin Bowd. (Vintage International, $14.95.) In this ingenious novel by a French author and provocateur, Daniel, a middle-aged film producer and emotional failure, joins a cult of sexually promiscuous health fanatics who achieve immortality through cloning. The narrative alternates between Daniel and one of his clones, Daniel24, who picks up the story of Daniel — and the story of human history — thousands of years in the future, when Daniel24 and his fellow “neohumans” live in a world ravaged by environmental disaster and almost completely devoid of human interaction. In the Book Review, Stephen Metcalf called this novel “brilliant and searing” and Houellebecq’s antihero “delightfully lubricious.”
