headline: Summer Music Magic in Rome, Starts Now
text: An important head’s up: Rome, a musical backwater most of the year, is flooded with wonderful concert offerings during the summer. There are more than a dozen music festivals spanning the next two months. And most of the events are held outside, in relatively small parks or venues, under beautiful breezy summer sunsets. Tickets are cheap and the music ranges from mainstream to classical to Italian opera to wonderfully eclectic ethnic bands. Last summer I saw Senegalese superstar Youssou N’Dour, with his crystalline voice, a Portugese jazz flutist and Eric Burden (yes, that Eric Burden — of the Animals and House of the Rising Sun fame).

headline: A Filly Rides to Victory
text: Rags to Riches was just the 22nd filly in the history of Belmont. Only two others had been successful, the last a filly named Tanya in 1905.

text: The biggest night of the year for the theater community brought out the stars, dressed to the hilt.

headline: Correction: Soviet-Style ‘Torture’ Becomes ‘Interrogation’
text: The Word for Word article last Sunday excerpting a 1956 medical journal article on Communist interrogation methods misstated the name of the journal. It is The Archives of Neurology and Psychiatry, not The Annals of Neurology and Psychology. In addition, the meaning of the acronym SERE, an American military training program, was misstated. SERE stands for Survival, Evasion, Resistance, and Escape — not Survival, Evasion, Reconnaissance and Escape.

headline: Lackluster Play Puts United States’ Resolve in Question
text: The United States’ 2-0 victory over Trinidad and Tobago Saturday afternoon was never in doubt and put the Americans through to the Gold Cup tournament’s knockout stage. Still, it raised a nagging question in its aftermath: once they get a lead, why can’t the Yanks effectively kill off a game?

text: As he prepares to announce his candidacy for president, probably sometime next month, former Senator Fred Thompson is on a persuasion tour this week, not a listening tour.

headline: London Journal: Remembering an Aldeburgh Regular
text: ALDEBURGH, England — Understandably, the memory of Mstislav Rostropovich, who died in April, is permeating the festival here. The master cellist, impassioned conductor and courageous global citizen was a devoted friend of Benjamin Britten and Peter Pears. He and Britten first met in 1960 in Moscow at a concert, when Mr. Rostropovich played Shostakovich’s First Cello Concerto. He soon became a regular at the festival and a frequent guest at Red House, the home of Britten and Pears here, now a library.

headline: Politics and Cyberspace
text: We caught up the other day with a conference about campaign politics and the Internet, where Joe Trippi took time out from baking, er, burning pies with the Edwards campaign to trace the arc of the influence of politics on cyberspace, and vice versa. A few of the e-advisers to the campaigns, namely those with the Clinton, Obama and McCain operations, also attended. They didn’t give away many trade secrets, but offered some insights into what works and what doesn’t at this stage of the election cycle.

headline: Sunday Sampler Platter
text: Colin Powell made news on Sunday, calling for the immediate closing –- immediate as in “this afternoon” — of the Guantánamo detention center. The former secretary of state also said that he had met twice with Senator Barack Obama as the young Democratic presidential candidate sought foreign-policy advice. And the retired general and Bush administration veteran left open the distinct possibility of endorsing a non-Republicancandidate.

headline: Two massive F1 stories in Canada
text: Between now and the U.S. Grand Prix in one week, there will be so much to talk about that I have decided to put up only two photographs of the two biggest stories in a Canadian Grand Prix that was just overflowing with stories. Below, the one massive story is that of Lewis Hamilton’s victory, and it’s obvious repercussions, and the other of the accident from which Robert Kubica miraculously came out alive and with only a sprained ankle and a slight concussion. (In the confusion after the accidents, early reports said he had a broken right leg or a broken foot.)

headline: The Three Atheists
text: Writings against God and religion have been around as long as God and religion have been around. But every so often an epidemic of the genre breaks out and a spate of such writings achieves the status of notoriety (which is what their authors had been aiming for). This has now happened to three books published in the last three years: Sam Harris’s “The End of Faith: Religion, Terror and The Future of Reason” (2004, 2005), Richard Dawkins’s “The God Delusion” (2006) and Christopher Hitchens’s “God is Not Great: How Religion Poisons Everything” (2007). (Were this the kind of analysis performed in Lancelot Andrewes’s sermons, I would note the fact that the names of all three authors end in “s,” signifying, no doubt, the presence of Sin and Satan.)

text: For years, Johnny Five lived in a cave in the Bronx.  Then in December 2006, he was offered an apartment.

headline: Potentially Incompatible Goals at F.D.A.
text: Safety and speed are the yin and yang of drug regulation. Patients want immediate access to breakthrough medicines but also want to believe the drugs are safe.

headline: In Return Home to Mexico Grave, an Industry Rises
text: CONWAY, Ark. — Héctor Acevedo was 22, in this country illegally and far from his mother when he died last month in a car accident outside of town just across the Arkansas River.

headline: Heavy Rains Set Off Flooding in Southern China
text: BEIJING, June 10  Torrential rains in southern China have unleashed surging floodwaters that have swept through small cities and farming villages, claiming at least 66 lives, forcing nearly 600,000 people to be relocated and destroying millions of dollars in property, the state news media reported Sunday.

headline: A Publishing Quandary: Do Excerpts Help Sales?
text: When the July issue of Vanity Fair hits newsstands tomorrow, those hungry for news and gossip about the British royal family may find sustenance in the magazine’s excerpt from “The Diana Chronicles,” Tina Brown’s evocation of the life and times of the Princess of Wales.

headline: Romney’s Run Has Mormons Wary of Scrutiny
text: LOGAN, Utah — In this wide valley where the twin spires of the Mormon temple dominate the landscape and some neighborhoods have a Mormon chapel every few blocks, Mitt Romney’s bid for president is both a proud sign of progress and a cause of trepidation.

headline: Richard Rorty, Philosopher, Dies at 75
text: Richard Rorty, whose inventive work on philosophy, politics, literary theory and more made him one of the world’s most influential contemporary thinkers, died Friday in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 75.

headline: Strands May Be Delicate, but They’re All Connected
text: In Michael Ondaatje’s “Divisadero” an illuminating exchange takes place between Lucien Segura, who will go on to become a famously mysterious French writer, and Marie-Neige, the young bride of a brutal older man. Lucien and Marie-Neige have been “like two flammable matches side by side in a tinderbox.” But their attraction, like many of the undercurrents in this turbulent, wandering novel, is one of many strong passions that can only indirectly be expressed.

headline: One Last Family Gathering
text: There was no good ending, so “The Sopranos” left off without one.

headline: Antihistamine Shows Promise in Treating Alzheimer’s
text: A drug long used as an antihistamine in Russia is showing what some scientists characterize as surprisingly strong results in treating Alzheimer’s disease.

headline: Court Says Military Cannot Hold 'Enemy Combatant'
text: In a stinging rejection of one of the Bush administration’s central assertions about the scope of executive authority to combat terrorism, a federal appeals court ordered the Pentagon to release a man being held as an enemy combatant.

headline: With Her Own Company, a Former Dancer Reunites Elements of Her Past
text: It takes seeing the work of George Balanchine and Maurice Béjart side by side to reveal the distance Suzanne Farrell traveled in 1969, when a devastating rupture with Balanchine and his New York City Ballet led her to Europe, and Mr. Béjart’s company, for five years. Considering the culture shock it engenders in a viewer, one can only imagine how disorienting it must have been for this great ballerina, steeped in the grand, austere clarity of Balanchine’s vision, to sink into Béjart’s decadent emotionalism.

headline: Warning: Trains Coming. A Masterpiece Is at Risk.
text: BARCELONA, Spain — With its soaring but impossibly slender columns and masonry that resembles heavy frosting, Antonio Gaudí’s unfinished masterwork La Sagrada Familia seems as if it might suddenly collapse on itself, like a surreal cake.

headline: John McGovern, 85, Allergist, Investor and Philanthropist, Dies
text: Dr. John P. McGovern, a Houston allergist and real-estate investor whose philanthropy helped endow medical facilities at Duke University, the Texas Medical Center and other institutions, died on May 31 in Galveston, Tex. He was 85.

headline: Factional Violence Continues in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM, June 11 — Factional violence raged in Gaza today between the rival Palestinian factions, Hamas and Fatah, despite a new cease-fire that was supposed to have come into effect at 11 a.m.

headline: Missing a Sweep, but Little Else
text: Todd Pletcher confessed that it had yet to become real to him. How he had led Rags to Riches to the paddock for the Belmont Stakes on Saturday, then met the filly in the winner’s circle, where both were toasted for a rare racing feat. She had broken his 0-for-28 streak of futility in Triple Crown races; she had become the third filly to win in the 139 years of the Belmont, known as the Test of the Champion, and the first since Tanya in 1905.

headline: Press Boxes Become an Afterthought, After the Thought of Luxury Seats
text: CHICAGO, June 6 — The original press box at the 16-year-old U.S. Cellular Field was a fine place to cover a White Sox game. From their nest behind home plate, reporters could easily discern the spin of a curveball or hear the thwack of bat on ball.

headline: The Night Christopher Wheeldon Met Oscar Wilde
text: Christopher Wheeldon’s new work, “The Nightingale and the Rose,” is mysterious, unwieldy and haunting. It is also one of his most beautiful and daringly imaginative works. But be warned: “Nightingale” may break your heart.

headline: Marijuana Law in Connecticut Gains Ground
text: HARTFORD, June 10 — Seventeen years ago, Mark Braunstein dived 60 feet off a footbridge into a river, landed wrong and became a paraplegic. A librarian at Connecticut College, Mr. Braunstein, 55, walks with the aid of crutches and leg braces. He smokes marijuana every three days or so to control the pain and spasms in his feet that would otherwise immobilize him.

headline: Sony’s Other Games Division Makes Push in New Direction
text: Sony has a long and colorful history of failure on the Internet. But there has been a bright spot, one Sony operation — Sony Online Entertainment, based in San Diego — has built a legitimately innovative and successful Internet business.

headline: Clinton Finds Subtle Ways to Cast Herself as a Trailblazer
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is not much of a gambler, in politics or life: She refers to herself as part of the “sensible center” in the Senate, and only occasionally has she laid money on the table (blackjack is her game).

headline: Sporadic Fighting Continues in Lebanon Refugee Camp
text: TRIPOLI, Lebanon, June 10  As the conflict between Lebanese soldiers and militants inspired by Al Qaeda entered its fourth week on Sunday, there was sporadic fighting at the Nahr al Bared Palestinian refugee camp where most of the earlier battles had taken place.

headline: Bush Vows to Get Immigration Bill Passed
text: SOFIA, Bulgaria, June 11 — As he heads home from an eight-day European swing to face a hostile Congress, President Bush lashed out today at Democrats for scheduling a vote of no confidence on his attorney general, and vowed to get his stalled immigration legislation passed, saying, “I’ll see you at the bill signing.”

headline: Building a Mini Metropolis Known as the U.S. Open
text: When the United States Open begins this week at Oakmont Country Club outside Pittsburgh, a challenging, manicured golf course will be only part of the scene.

headline: No Prize Money (This Time) for 9-Year-Old Star of Video Game Circuit
text: Victor M. De Leon III, a 9-year-old Long Island boy believed to be the world’s youngest professional video game player, finished out of the prize money in his latest tournament, the Major League Gaming Pro Circuit Event, which ended yesterday at the Meadowlands in New Jersey.

headline: When Lots of Money Makes You Feel Rich
text: Anyone who has ever thrown around a stack of liras or rupees knows that people are sometimes more extravagant with currencies that have high face values. A paper recently published in The Journal of Consumer Research explored that effect.

headline: Pinning Down the Money Value of a Person’s Life
text: HOW much is your life worth? How about a year of life? How much is your vision worth? What about being pain-free? Able to walk unassisted? Have sex?

headline: As Legislative Session Wanes, So Does Leaders’ Momentum
text: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzer would have preferred more progress by now, with two weeks left in the legislative session.

headline: Rolling Stone Finding Out Green Isn’t Green Enough
text: Just about every major magazine has made some sort of nod to global warming, and Rolling Stone plans to do so in its June 28 issue: on top of the requisite interview with former Vice President Al Gore and an essay by the environmentalist Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the magazine will start printing on paper that is said to have less of a negative impact on the environment.

headline: Onetime Mob Stronghold Hears Echo of the Old Days
text: On Bath Avenue, in a part of Brooklyn once dominated by gangsters and wiseguys, times have changed.

headline: Path to 300 Wins Gets Rocky for Glavine
text: DETROIT, June 10  Tom Glavine lay on the Comerica Park grass, his body contorted in a position as uncomfortable as his afternoon. He had just flipped a ball to the backstop, giving Detroit yet another run, and his momentum caused him to tumble forward so that his knees touched his nose. He stayed there for a few seconds, stuck in a moment he could not escape, then rose to one knee and gazed toward the outfield.

headline: Health Costs Push Companies to Set Targets for Workers
text: WATCH your cholesterol and triglycerides. Your boss and fellow workers are counting on it. As the nation’s employers aim to get their money’s worth from ever more expensive medical insurance, many are playing a bigger role in managing and monitoring their workers’ health.

headline: Homer J. Stewart, 91, Aerospace Engineer, Dies
text: Homer J. Stewart, an aerospace engineer and rocket propulsion expert who in 1958 helped launch the first successful American satellite, Explorer 1, while he kept tabs on rival efforts by the Russians, died on May 26 at his home in Altadena, Calif. He was 91.

headline: Newark: Girl Killed by Hit-and-Run Driver
text: A 12-year-old girl was killed by a hit-and-run driver last evening while she was attending the Portuguese Festival, the police said. The girl, identified as Kaitlyn Velez of Pennsylvania, was struck shortly before 6 p.m. near the intersection of Elm and Congress Streets by a blue Econoline van with the word “Construction” on the side, the police said. The van sped off and the girl was taken to University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey Hospital, where she died. The police were looking for the driver last night.

headline: New CDs
text: QUEENS OF THE STONE AGE “Era Vulgaris” (Interscope)

headline: A Test of the Senate
text: The Senate has scheduled a no-confidence vote today on Attorney General Alberto Gonzales. No one who has followed the news needs to be told why it is necessary. Mr. Gonzales is the Michael Brown of the Justice Department, smilingly presiding over incompetence, chaos and malfeasance, while President Bush insists that he is doing a heck of a job. Today’s vote should get the support not only of Democrats, but of every Republican senator concerned about the American justice system.

headline: Takeover Zeal in the News Industry Is Seen Subsiding
text: The McClatchy Company bought Knight Ridder and then sold pieces of it, the Tribune Company took itself private under a plan devised by the real estate developer Samuel Zell, and Rupert Murdoch has mounted a strong run at Dow Jones & Company— all in the last year.

headline: Cautious Optimism on Stem Cells (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Dignity and the Military (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: States Finding Fiscal Surprise: A Cash Surplus
text: State lawmakers across the country, their coffers unexpectedly full of cash, have been handing out tax cuts, spending money on fixing roads, schools and public buildings, and socking something away for less fruitful years.

headline: Spurs Show No Mercy in Dismantling Cavaliers
text: SAN ANTONIO, June 10 — It was understood, even before the N.B.A. finals got going last week, that the San Antonio Spurs were a fearsome force, capable of great and powerful things. It appears they can be a little destructive, too.

headline: Putin Plays Down I.M.F. and W.T.O.
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia, June 10 — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia called Sunday for a new global economic framework that would play down the role of institutions like the International Monetary Fund and the World Trade Organization and instead emphasize regional alliances.

headline: Outspoken Political Scientist Denied Tenure at DePaul
text: Norman Finkelstein, the political scientist whose bid for a permanent position at DePaul University stirred up charges of anti-Semitism, personal vendettas and outside interference in the hiring process, was informed Friday that he had been denied tenure by the university.

headline: Blast in Kenya Kills One
text: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 11 — A mysterious explosion rocked downtown Nairobi this morning, killing one person, possibly the bomber, and injuring 31 others.

headline: Ethics in Medicine (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gordon Gambles on the Weather and Wins at Pocono
text: LONG POND, Pa., June 10 — At the moment Jeff Gordon won his fourth Nextel Cup race of the season Sunday night, his blue Chevrolet was covered with a rain-spattered tarpaulin and was parked on pit road, 235 miles from the scheduled finish.

headline: Mandatory Coverage Is Easier Said Than Done
text: IT’S a seemingly simple solution to a nationwide problem: if people do not have health insurance, just require that they buy it. The idea of making coverage compulsory to help reduce the number of uninsured Americans  currently 45 million  is gaining momentum. With a law passed last year, Massachusetts became the first state to mandate coverage. Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California has supported the idea, proposing that his state do the same. In Illinois, mandatory health insurance has become part of a broader discussion of health reform.

headline: We Have Always Depended on Strangeness of Families
text: Three HBO tragedies have comedic set-ups. A middle-class mob boss seeks therapy. A groovy Los Angeles family lives in a mortuary. And, most recently, a Utah entrepreneur has three wives.

headline: Manhattan: Man Killed in Hit-Run Accident
text: A Brooklyn man was killed when he was struck by a car while crossing East 22nd Street early yesterday morning, the police said. The man, Matthew Hopkins, 26, of Montgomery Street, was crossing near the intersection of Park Avenue South about 4:09 a.m. when he was hit by a 1991 Honda, which continued without stopping, the police said. No arrests had been made yesterday evening.

headline: Ousmane Sembène, 84, Dies; Led Cinema’s Advance in Africa
text: Ousmane Sembène, the Senegalese filmmaker and writer who was a crucial figure in Africa’s postcolonial cultural awakening, has died at his home in Dakar, Senegal. His family, which announced his death on Sunday, said Mr. Sembène had been ill since December. He was 84.

headline: A TheirSpace for Drug Sales Reps
text: THE drug sales representative was expecting a $12,000 performance bonus. Unfortunately, the rep’s chance to jump to a better job at another drug company required that the move be made a month before the bonus would be issued. Was it possible to start the new job without the old employer knowing and still collect the bonus?

headline: Environmental Bounty Hunters, on Trail of Cash, Are in California Official’s Sights
text: In the great traditions of the Old West, California deputizes bounty hunters to help enforce its environmental laws.

headline: Who Pays for Efficiency?
text: SAVING money can be expensive.

headline: U.S. Arming Sunnis in Iraq to Battle Old Qaeda Allies
text: BAGHDAD, June 10 — With the four-month-old increase in American troops showing only modest success in curbing insurgent attacks, American commanders are turning to another strategy that they acknowledge is fraught with risk: arming Sunni Arab groups that have promised to fight militants linked with Al Qaeda who have been their allies in the past.

headline: Forget Tickling the Keys, It’s All About the Power
text: OJAI, Calif., June 10  Behind the rise of the all-powerful Romantic movement was the piano and its essential paradox: a percussion instrument (hit it, and it makes noise) that would be tamed and stroked until it sang like the human voice. By the 1920s music had had enough of this romance and returned the instrument to its primary nature: hit it, and it sounds like a drum.

headline: Bankruptcy Filing May Delay Pornography on Cellphones
text: Amp’d Mobile’s filing for protection from bankruptcy on June 1 may have one unexpected side effect: a delay in the introduction of sex-oriented programming on cellphones.

headline: Treasury Sales Set
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financings this week includes today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

headline: Top Editor Is Leaving Book Post
text: Daniel Menaker, the executive editor in chief of the Random House Publishing Group who was hired four years ago for his strong literary credentials, is leaving the company at the end of June.

headline: Marketers Are Joining the Varsity
text: Athletes, if they are talented, train hard and get a break or two, can climb the sports ladder from high school to college to the pros. Madison Avenue, sensing a lucrative opportunity, is heading the other way.

headline: Longing in England: ‘Death in Venice’ on Two Stages
text: ALDEBURGH, England, June 10 — Many devotees of Benjamin Britten feel that his final opera, “Death in Venice,” based on the Thomas Mann novella and first presented at the Aldeburgh Festival in 1973, is a profound, piercing and inexplicably neglected masterpiece. At the moment, though, the opera seems anything but neglected, at least in Britten’s native land. The Aldeburgh Festival, which Britten helped found, is presenting a grippingly austere production of the opera, its first staging here in nearly 30 years. The first performance, on Friday night, provided a momentous opening for this renowned festival’s 60th anniversary.

headline: Schumer to Propose New College Loan Rules
text: Senator Charles E. Schumer and Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo yesterday announced a plan to change college loan applications. The proposal, which Senator Schumer said he would introduce as federal legislation, would require that lenders detail loan amounts, interest and fees in a table on loan applications. “A high school graduate shouldn’t need a law degree to pick a loan for college,” Mr. Schumer said in a statement.

headline: As Fifth Ave. Brims With Pride, Even the Horses Dance
text: As the sidewalks along Fifth Avenue began to fill and the bands took their places behind the police and the politicians for yesterday’s Puerto Rican Day Parade, Tony Flores took a deep breath and smiled.

headline: Nadal Defeats Federer for French Open Title
text: PARIS, June 10 — With clay the color of terra cotta caked on his clothes, Rafael Nadal climbed into the grandstand Sunday at Roland Garros to celebrate his third consecutive French Open victory.

headline: Iraq’s Parliament Leaders Agree to Remove Speaker
text: BAGHDAD, June 10 — Iraq’s leading political blocs on Sunday agreed to replace the speaker of Parliament, Mahmoud Mashhadani, a Sunni, after hearing accusations that his bodyguards assaulted a Shiite lawmaker as the speaker cursed him and then dragged him to the speaker’s office.

headline: Take Me Out to the Bling Blineo (I Don’t Care if I Ever Get Back)
text: It seemed like a great idea: a reggaetón grudge match in Shea Stadium on the eve of the Puerto Rican Day parade. Daddy Yankee and Don Omar  two of the genre’s biggest stars, and longtime rivals  were scheduled to be the headliners at El Bling Blineo, a Saturday night concert organized (and tirelessly promoted) by the reggaetón radio station La Kalle, 105.9 FM.

headline: Brooklyn: Man Shot and Killed in Street
text: A Brooklyn man was fatally shot shortly after 11 a.m. yesterday in a fight on the street in Bushwick, the authorities said. Acquaintances identified the man as Jose Torres, who they said was in his early 20s. He was pronounced dead at the scene, near the corner of Stanhope Street and Wyckoff Avenue, where, a witness said, he had been shot several times. The witness, who declined to be identified by name, said that Mr. Torres was riding his bicycle when he was approached by the other man. When Mr. Torres got off the bicycle and began fighting, the other man pulled out a gun and fired, the witness said. The police arrested Adrian Aguiliar, 30, of Brooklyn and charged him with murder and criminal possession of a weapon.

headline: City’s White Elephant Now Looks Like a Transit Workhorse
text: MORGANTOWN, W.Va., June 4 — During its troubled years of construction and testing in the early 1970s, the Personal Rapid Transit system that snakes through this hilly college town was derided as a fiasco and a waste of money that perhaps should be dynamited rather than finished.

headline: ‘Spring Awakening’ and ‘Coast of Utopia’ Rack Up Tony Awards
text: The 61st annual Tony Awards last night were dominated by two shows drawn from the 19th century: “Spring Awakening,” about sexually frustrated German teenagers in that era, won best musical and most of the other musical awards, while “The Coast of Utopia,” Tom Stoppard’s epic period trilogy about Russian intellectuals, set a record for the most awards won by a play in Tony history.

headline: A Spectrum of Disputes
text: Madison, Wis.

headline: Democrats Say They May Revisit Immigration Bill
text: WASHINGTON, June 10 — Senate Democrats opened the door to reviving the stalled immigration measure on Sunday, calling on Republicans to resolve their internal divisions and produce an agreement on how to move the legislation forward.

headline: Pakistan’s Dictator
text: If Gen. Pervez Musharraf were the democratic leader he indignantly insists he is, he would not be so busy threatening independent news outlets, arresting hundreds of opposition politicians and berating parliamentary leaders and ministers from his own party for insufficient loyalty to his arbitrary and widely unpopular policies.

headline: In Biotech Brews, Questions of Consistency
text: VACAVILLE, Calif.

headline: Mental Health in Prisons
text: The New York State Legislature set an important national example when it passed a bill that would dramatically improve treatment for mentally ill prison inmates. Gov. Eliot Spitzer seems to regard the bill as unnecessary and tried to head it off by making changes of his own earlier this spring. But Mr. Spitzer’s tinkering is no substitute for the thoroughgoing reforms in this bill, which would end once and for all the horrific maltreatment and neglect that mentally ill inmates suffer in New York.

headline: Box Office for Horror Movies Is Weak, Verging on Horrible
text: LOS ANGELES, June 10 — Moviegoers put a nail in the coffin of a dying horror boom this weekend, as “Hostel: Part II” opened to just $8.8 million in ticket sales, far behind the crime caper “Ocean’s Thirteen” in a three-day period of relatively soft box office performance.

headline: Station Astronauts Examine Shuttle
text: The crew of the International Space Station welcomed the seven astronauts from the shuttle Atlantis aboard on Sunday, the third day of the shuttle’s mission.

headline: A Dog or a Cat? New Tests to Fool Automated Spammers
text: On the Internet, nobody knows you’re a human — until you fill out a captcha.

headline: Yankees Keep Smashing Their Way Toward .500
text: The offense was relentless and merciless yesterday, but that has been the case a lot lately. The Yankees are scoring runs in bunches, and they are getting contributions from a player whose season once appeared to be a lost cause. Add pitching that has been effective if not spectacular, and you have a six-game winning streak from a team that no longer resembles the underachieving bunch that stumbled its way through April and May.

headline: Call the Doctor
text: When the news broke last month that significant questions had been raised about an increase in the risk of a heart attack for users of Avandia, I followed the reports with a bit more avidity than most.

headline: Investing: WebMD’s Fever Chart
text: CAPITALIZING on the national preoccupation with things medical, WebMD Health has built the most-visited and fastest-growing health site on the Internet. Should investors click on its stock?

headline: Musharraf Rescinds Media Regulations After Public Outcry
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 10  Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, has formally withdrawn his decree that imposed new regulations on the news media, government officials said over the weekend. The president made his decision after he met with industry leaders, and after journalists and opposition parties strongly protested the decree, officials said.

headline: A Few Details of the iPhone Galvanize the Apple Cadre
text: These days advertisers fret over DVR owners fast-forwarding through their commercials, but that was far from the case with the release by Apple last week of four iPhone commercials, which viewers pored over with Talmudic intensity.

headline: Revolution, as in Beatles (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: For LeBron James, Baptism by Finals Fire
text: San Antonio

headline: Dear Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Pettersen’s Putts Seal L.P.G.A. Championship
text: HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., June 10  All Suzann Pettersen had to do to win her first major championship Sunday was two-putt from 30 feet. As she stood over her uphill putt on her 72nd hole of the L.P.G.A. Championship, the fans surrounding the 18th green grew quiet.

headline: No-Confidence Vote on Gonzales Fails in the Senate
text: WASHINGTON, June 11 — Senate Democrats fell short this afternoon in their effort to hold a vote of no confidence in Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales but still registered a strong, if symbolic, rebuke of the nation’s chief law enforcement officer.

headline: Iraq’s Parliament Votes to Remove Speaker
text: BAGHDAD, June 11 — Just over two-thirds of the 168 Iraqi parliament members present at today’s session voted in favor of a resolution to remove the body’s speaker, Mahmoud Mashhadani, opening the way for the coalition of Sunni political groups who had installed him last year to replace him.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 9 P.M. (HBO) BIG LOVE The Henricksons, America’s favorite polygamists, return for a new season on a new night, with some damage control in the wake of the family’s exposure when wife No. 1, Barb, was being considered for mother of the year. (And with seven children scattered among three homes, why not?) Tonight the patriarch Bill (Bill Paxton, above with Jeanne Tripplehorn) scrambles to find out who betrayed him, and Barb (Ms. Tripplehorn) retreats into her own world, leaving wives No. 2, Nicki (Chloë Sevigny), and No. 3, Margene (Ginnifer Goodwin), to pick up the slack. Meanwhile Roman (Harry Dean Stanton) tries to intimidate Joey (Shawn Doyle) after Joey’s wife, Wanda (Melora Waters), poisoned Roman’s son, Alby (Matt Ross). And back at home, the eldest daughter, Sarah (Amanda Seyfried), catches the eye of Scott (Aaron Paul) at a meeting for ex-Mormons.

headline: NBC Studied Dow Jones Bid With Microsoft
text: General Electric’s NBC unit and Microsoft explored making a joint bid for Dow Jones but decided against it a week ago, a person close to NBC and Microsoft said yesterday.

headline: The Former Queen of Buzz Conjures a Golden Heyday
text: Tina Brown, the once highly conspicuous editor of Vanity Fair, The New Yorker and the short-lived Talk, has just written “The Diana Chronicles,” about the British princess who, like her, reigned as a golden girl over the transatlantic media world during the 1980s and ’90s.

headline: Battle for Bermuda Bowl Slot Turns Close With a Late Surge
text: As the final of the trial to select the U.S.A.-2 team for this year’s Bermuda Bowl headed toward its conclusion late last night in Shaumburg, Ill., what had seemed a runaway suddenly turned close. The 120-board match pitted Nick Nickell, Dick Freeman, Bob Hamman, Paul Soloway, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell against Russ Ekeblad, Ron Rubin, Fred Gitelman, Brad Moss, Chip Martel and Lew Stansby, with Ekeblad surging late. (The final result is at usbf.org.)

headline: The Poets of War
text: Last month I invited readers to send in poems for my second Iraq Poetry Contest.

headline: Libby’s Supporters Who Wrote to Judge Learn That Letters Take on New Life on the Web
text: In what may be a sign of things to come, the lawyers for I. Lewis Libby Jr. last month invoked the rarely used courtroom tactic: the “bloggers can be mean” defense.

headline: New Passport Rules Bring Worry Over Tourism at Niagara Falls
text: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 10 — Standing at Prospect Point in Niagara Falls State Park, Paul Cranley looked through the mist formed by millions of gallons of water dropping more than 160 feet to the gorge below.

headline: Cosmetics Heir to Lead World Jewish Congress
text: Ronald S. Lauder, the cosmetics magnate, won his bid to become the first elected president of the World Jewish Congress, the tiny nonprofit group that faced down some of the world’s largest banks to win billions for Holocaust victims but is now struggling to recover from scandals resulting from lax financial controls.

headline: Israeli Airstrikes, Aiming at Militants, Hit Gaza City
text: JERUSALEM, June 10 — The Israeli Air Force struck at least two buildings in Gaza City early Sunday morning in what appeared to be a response to a raid across the Gaza-Israel border by Palestinian militants on Saturday.

headline: Cotto’s Knockout Victory Against Judah Fails to Impress Mayweather Jr.
text: Miguel Cotto’s dominating victory against Zab Judah on Saturday night has lifted him to a new level of prominence. But he still lacks the leverage to earn the biggest fight out there: against Floyd Mayweather Jr., considered by many to be the best pound-for-pound boxer in the world.

headline: Queens Leader Supports Bloomberg’s Traffic Plan
text: The Bloomberg administration’s plan to charge drivers in the busiest parts of Manhattan won support yesterday from Representative Joseph Crowley, the influential chairman of the Queens Democratic Party, whose endorsement could help reshape the fight where resistance to the plan has been among the strongest, in the boroughs outside Manhattan.

headline: What She Wants: Retro, Soul and Hip-Hop (Just a Little Bit)
text: Joss Stone came to Central Park SummerStage on Friday night with a full soul band, complete with horns and backup singers. She’s just 20 years old and English, but she has decided her favorite music was made in the United States years before she was born: soul from about 1964 to 1974.

headline: Taliban Fire Rockets During Speech by Karzai
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 10 — Militants fired rockets on a district town on Sunday as President Hamid Karzai was giving an address to elders and residents during a visit to Ghazni Province, south of Kabul, officials said.

headline: An Editor’s Untimely Departure Is Captured in Just a Flicker
text: Call it a bit of a “video killed the radio star” moment, circa 2007: John Curley, who had been a deputy managing editor of The San Francisco Chronicle, announced that he was let go from the newspaper by posting the news on Flickr, the photo-sharing Web site.

headline: Need a Knee Replaced? Check Your ZIP Code.
text: WHY does health care for the average Medicare patient cost nearly twice as much a year in New Jersey, at $8,076, as it does in Hawaii, at $4,529?

headline: Both Sides Say Project Is Pivotal Issue for Brazil
text: PORTO VELHO, Brazil — The eternal tension between Brazil’s need for economic growth and the damage that can cause to the environment are nowhere more visible than here in this corner of the western Amazon region.

headline: On Rough Day, a Rookie Arrives
text: MONTREAL, June 10 (AP)  Lewis Hamilton, the first black driver in Formula One history, added his first series victory to an already remarkable résumé by winning the Canadian Grand Prix on Sunday.

headline: Queens: Three Men Stabbed in Fight
text: Three men were stabbed, one of whom was critically injured, in a fight in Astoria early yesterday, the police said. The men, whom the police did not identify, were arguing with another group near Club Fashion, on Steinway Street, about 3 a.m. when someone in the other group stabbed them, the police said. One man, who was stabbed in the neck and chest, was in critical condition at Elmhurst Hospital Center, the police said. The other two men suffered minor cuts. No arrests had been made.

headline: Colt Versus Filly: What’s All the Fuss?
text: During the stretch run of the Preakness Stakes, American racing fans screamed as Street Sense and Curlin battled to the wire. “Spectacular,” “heart-pounding” and “remarkable” were the adjectives that appeared in the papers the next day.

headline: Market Owner Is Cited in Fire Where 5 Men Were Trapped
text: The owner of a Queens supermarket was accused yesterday of violating city codes after a blaze on Friday night in which firefighters rescued five workers who had been locked inside the store and were found in the basement, huddled, crying and blackened by smoke.

headline: Sarkozy’s Party Heads Toward Huge Legislative Majority in France
text: PARIS, Monday, June 11 — President Nicolas Sarkozy’s center-right party was on course to win an overwhelming parliamentary majority after the first round of French legislative elections on Sunday, cementing his power to enact changes that he says are needed to rescue France from economic and social malaise.

headline: At Creative Artists, a Bit of Blushing After a Corporate Kiss-Off
text: LOS ANGELES, June 10 — For the powers at the Creative Artists Agency, Hollywood’s pre-eminent talent representative, the coming blockbuster “Transformers” has already brought a lesson in the cold-hearted ways of corporate entertainment.

headline: Thousands Hail Bush in Visit to Albania
text: TIRANA, Albania, June 10 — His poll numbers may be in the basement, but when he zipped through this small, relentlessly pro-American nation on Sunday, President Bush was treated like a rock star.

headline: For Snow, Beating Expectations Is Part of Game
text: SAN ANTONIO, June 10 — The Cleveland Cavaliers’ finals fate will probably not turn on an Eric Snow jump shot, pass or hand check of Tony Parker. But if Snow somehow saves the series, it may not even qualify as the most unlikely development of his N.B.A. career.

headline: Judge Throws Out Sentence in Teen Sex Case
text: ATLANTA, June 11 — A Georgia Superior Court judge today ordered the release of Genarlow Wilson, who has served two years of 10-year prison sentence for having consensual oral sex with another teenager at a party when he was 17. Prosecutors said they would appeal the order.

headline: In Pursuing Vick, Government Bares Its Teeth
text: Michael Vick may or may not have played a role in an apparent dog fighting ring. But Vick, the Atlanta Falcons’ besieged quarterback. has already been indicted in the court of public opinion and by the news media, which increasingly embrace the presumption of guilt as vital to entertainment value.

headline: Nonorganic Exceptions Ruffle Enthusiasts of Organic Food
text: The latest battle over what can be called organic involves beer and gelatin, food colorings and casings for sausage. The Department of Agriculture, the final arbiter of all things organic, is poised to approve a list of nonorganic ingredients that can be used in food stamped with its green-and-white organic seal.

headline: What’s the Flavor of the Month? Medical Devices.
text: LUKE EVNIN contends there is money to be made giving people with fading vision a poke in the eye.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,494 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans over the weekend:

headline: Lottery Numbers
Art in the Present Tense: Politics, Loss and Beauty
text: VENICE, June 9 — This picture-postcard city of shimmering lagoons is plastered with red-and-green posters that read “Think With the Senses — Feel with the Mind. Art in the Present Tense,” the theme of the 52nd Venice Biennale. Since Wednesday collectors and curators, artists and dealers have flocked here to look at and to gauge the state of new art.

headline: Will I Ever Be O.K. Again?
text: Like I said before, I was at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda. Md., when I first returned. This was an interesting time; I was on enough pain medicine to tranquilize a small militia. I had some very creative hallucinations. When I was still in bad shape my nurse left on Univision while I was sleeping. The next morning I woke up speaking Spanish. One night the N.B.A. draft was left on T.V. for the evening. When I awoke the next morning, I hired my brother J.P. as my agent. When you are drafted in the second round by the Dallas Mavericks you need an agent. My first instructions to him were to get me a Rolex. I had to fire him, as it has been almost three years and he has not gotten me signed and I still do not have my Rolex.

headline: One Last Family Gathering: You Eat, You Talk, It’s Over
text: In her review of the last episode of “The Sopranos,” Alessandra Stanley said:

headline: Prestigious Panama
text: YOO, the London developer dubbed the “Prada of the property industry,” is breaking ground on a new project in September in Panama City — an increasingly popular spot among retirees. YOO Panama is a 56-storey single tower on Balboa Avenue, the only stretch of land along the ocean in Panama City.

headline: A Ballerina Bids Adieu
text: Additional images from Darcey Bussell's final performance at The Royal Opera House.

headline: At the Vatican, saintly patience required
text: St Peters, The Vatican

headline: The First Post
text: Welcome to the first post of the Book Review’s first blog.

headline: What’s the Flavor of the Month? Medical Devices
text: Venture capitalists, apparently, are going cuckoo for medical-device companies at the expense of past favorites like computer-related start-ups or drug-development companies.

headline: Book Ads: The Golden Age, 1962-73
text: Advertisements for books have been around nearly as long as books themselves, and in The New York Times, they’ve appeared since shortly after the first issue of the newspaper went to press in September 1851. They’ve been part of the stand-alone Book Review since it began appearing on Saturdays, in 1896, and Sundays, in 1911.

headline: Former Casino Investigator Bids for Trump Entertainment
text: Dennis Gomes, a former gambling executive and regulator, wants to be the star of his own casino. Mr. Gomes, whose work as an investigator for the Nevada State Control Board was the basis for Martin Scorsese’s film “Casino,” is teaming up with JEMB Realty to bid for Donald J. Trump’s Atlantic City casino company, Trump Entertainment Resorts.

headline: TXU Bidders Bargain With Regulators on Coal Plants
text: Private equity firms bidding for the Texas utility TXU have offered up to $30 million for air pollution-reduction programs in Central Texas, but only if local officials allow three new coal-fired power plants.

headline: Hopeful Signs From China and India?
text: Fears are growing about the polluting power of India and China. The reason is clear enough: Both countries are industrializing fast and pumping out vast amounts of greenhouse gases to meet global demand for their goods. Yet governments in both countries continue to marshal two powerful arguments to resist calls to cut their greenhouse gas emissions. First, China and India emit less pollution per person than developed-world countries and secondly, Chinese and Indian officials say pollution constraints would impede lifting millions out of poverty.

headline: Sherritt Deal Gets Thumbs Up from Dynatec Shareholders
text: Shareholders of the Canadian mining company Dynatec overwhelmingly approved a takeover bid of 1.5 billion Canadian dollars ($1.4 billion) from the nickel miner Sherritt International. At a meeting in Toronto, Dynatech investors voted 99 percent in favor of the deal that will give Sherritt a 40 percent stake in the coveted Ambatovy nickel project in Madagascar.

headline: J.P. Morgan to Testify on Greek Bond Role
text: A J.P. Morgan executive will testify to the Greek parliament on Tuesday about its recent role in underwriting a controversial 280 million euro ($374 million) structured bond that was sold to local pension funds this year.

headline: Limelight Networks I.P.O. Brings Home the Bacon
text: Following a $240 million initial public offering, shares of Limelight Networks, a digital content delivery company, rose almost 50 percent in their opening Friday. The Deal.com notes that the offering was a boon for the books of Goldman Sachs Capital Partners. Its investment in Limelight has grown about sixfold in less than a year.

headline: Blackstone Brings German Packagin Firm to Market
text: As the Blackstone Group prepares for its own market opening, the company completed a successful initial public offering of one of its portfolio companies, Gerresheimer, a German packaging company. On Friday, Blackstone set the terms of the offering, which raised 1.01 billion euros ($1.36 billion), the biggest this year in Germany.

headline: Candidates Finals: One Match Is Tied, One Is Nearly Over
text: Sergei Rublevsky of Russia won yesterday to draw even with Alexander Grischuk of Russia in their candidates match. The other three matches were drawn, preserving the leads of Peter Leko of Hungary, Levon Aronian of Armenia and Boris Gelfand of Israel. The matches are being played in Elista, Kalmykia, to select four qualifiers for the world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.

headline: Rexam Acquires Plastics Unit
text: Rexam, the world’s largest maker of beverage cans, will acquire the plastics business of Owens-Illinois for $1.83 billion, adding as much as 50 percent to its sales in the industry.

headline: Microsoft Finds Legal Defender in Justice Department
text: Nearly a decade after the government began its landmark effort to break up Microsoft, the Bush administration has sharply changed course by repeatedly defending the company both in the United States and abroad against accusations of anticompetitive conduct, including the recent rejection of a complaint by Google.

headline: Being Goldman Sachs’ Mr. Blankfein
text: While Goldman Sachs is the most imitated, envied and at times griped-about investment bank around, its chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, is still intent on proving himself and his firm to the world, writes The New York Times’ Jenny Anderson, who in her profile describes Mr. Blankfein as a far cry from central casting’s idea of a chief executive.

headline: After Camp La Guardia
text: What was once New York City's largest homeless shelter recently shut its doors.

headline: Lawmakers Eye Restrictions on Leasing Toll Roads
text: The trucking industry and congressional Democrats are trying to put the brakes on state efforts to lease toll roads to Macquarie Bank, Goldman Sachs and other private investors.

headline: Atticus Reportedly Takes Barlcays Stake to Influence Takeover
text: Atticus Capital has snapped up a stake in Britain’s Barclay‘s bank to discourage the bank from continuing with its $85.1 billion effort to buy the Dutch bank ABN Amro, according to press reports.

headline: Apax Mulls Deal for Indian Software Firm, Report Says
text: The private equity investor Apax Partners Worldwide is in talks with Patni Computer Systems, a software company based in Mumbai, regarding a possible stake in the company, but it may find itself in competition with an existing shareholder, General Atlantic, and other potential buyers, says The Deal.com.

headline: Takeover Zeal in the News Industry Is Seen Subsiding
text: McClatchy bought Knight Ridder and then sold pieces of it; Tribune took itself private under a plan devised by the real estate developer Samuel Zell; and Rupert Murdoch has mounted a run at Dow Jones & Company – all in the last year.

headline: Eye-Fi Captures First Round Funding
text: Eye-Fi said Monday it had captured $5.5 million in a first round of funding to further develop its wireless memory card that promises to upload and sends photos from digital cameras to computers and social-networking sites. Opus Capital and Shasta Ventures co-led funding of the startup, which is based in Mountain View, Calif.

headline: Amp’d Bankruptcy May Delay Pornography on Cellphones
text: Amp’d Mobile‘s filing for protection from bankruptcy on June 1 may have one unexpected side effect: a delay in the introduction of sex-oriented programming on cellphones.

headline: I.B.M. Offers $743 Million for Telelogic of Sweden
text: International Business Machines, the world’s largest computer-services provider, agreed to buy Telelogic for 5.2 billion kronor ($743 million), adding software design systems used by DaimlerChrysler and ABB.

headline: Ford Is Said to Hire Banks to Run Sale of Luxury Brands
text: Ford Motor has hired Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and HSBC to sell Jaguar and Land Rover, its two British luxury brands, The Financial Times reported Monday. The planned sale does not include Volvo, Ford’s third premium brand, and is said to be in its early stages, the paper said.

headline: Blackstone Founders to Reap $2.3 Billion in I.P.O.
text: Blackstone Group, the giant private equity firm founded by Stephen Schwarzman and Peter Peterson, has revealed just how lucrative its proposed $4.7 billion initial public offering is expected to be for its top executives.

headline: Help for Victims of Violence
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer signed a bill last week that prevents landlords from penalizing victims of domestic violence if they break their leases. In a message explaining his approval, Mr. Spitzer wrote:

headline: Alert the Courtroom Sketch Artist Lobby
text: One of the late entries among the issues being discussed in the closing weeks of the legislative session is a proposal to allow video cameras in courtrooms. The issue is of increasing interest to newspapers as well as television networks because of the increasing sophistication of newspaper Web sites.

headline: Corn: Vegetable, Fruit or Grain?
text: Lawmakers waded into the treacherous terrain of botany last week.

headline: Breaking Bread, Trading Horses
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer would have preferred more progress by now, with two weeks left in the legislative session.

headline: NBC Studied Dow Jones Bid With Microsoft
text: General Electric‘s NBC unit and Microsoft explored making a joint bid for Dow Jones but decided against it about a week ago, according to news reports Monday.

headline: 2008: Romney Thrills, Worries Mormons
text: Could the first woman or African American president be in the country’s future in 2008? Or, perhaps, the first Mormon?

headline: The Senate Confronts a Gonzales Vote
text: Senate Democrats will try today to force a vote of “no confidence” in Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales. But Republicans are confident that they can defeat the maneuver.

headline: Mastering the YouTube Campaign
Cramer on Murdoch: Patience Will Pay Off
text: James Cramer says he knows first-hand how badly Rupert Murdoch wants Dow Jones. Writing this week in New York magazine, Mr. Cramer, the former hedge fund manager who is now host of the “Mad Money” show on CNBC, tells the story of how Mr. Murdoch called him 11 years ago to discuss the notion of a bid for Dow Jones, which publishes The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Solving the Sopranos
text: In one of the articles covering online betting on the final episode of “The Sopranos,” the network offered some advice that may or may not have been based on insider information. David Chase, the show’s director, “defies all theories of probability,” said an HBO spokesman.

headline: Food, Glorious Food
text: It seems that many of the sites that we pass in our usual travels are really hungry for odd food news. First we noticed a photo essay in Time magazine showing families around the world posing with their favorite foodstuffs rising up the Technorati rankings.

headline: Affiliated Computer Opens Up Bidding for Company
text: Affiliated Computer Services, the technology services provider, said on Sunday that it had opened up the bidding for the company, ending its exclusive bargaining with Cerberus Capital Management and its founder and chairman. In a news reelase, the company said that Lazard will actively solicit competing bids from June 16 through August 9.

headline: H&R Block Shares Rise Amid Buyout Speculation
text: Will a slimmed-down H&R Block look more appealing to private equity? That is what an analyst at UBS Investment Bank was suggesting Monday.

headline: End of An Era
text: Three articles in The Times this weekend tell all anyone needs to know about the state of the newspaper industry.Daniel Wakin reports that papers around the country are shedding classical music critics. It is not that publishers suddenly care less about music; it is that papers are cutting staff left and right as they try to maintain profit margins while advertising declines in print editions and papers give away their content on the Internet.

headline: Clinton Finds Subtle Ways to Cast Herself as a Trailblazer
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign finds ways to embrace and celebrate other people who have worked to get close to the winner’s circle.

headline: Read Daniel Menaker
text: The news that Daniel Menaker is leaving Random House hit a lot of people hard this morning – he’s been a force for good in the literary world, and during his career at The New Yorker and Random House he’s championed so many interesting and important writers it’s impossible to count them all.

headline: Corrections
text: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

headline: Go Forth and Change the World
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Carlyle Creates New Financial Services Group
text: The Carlyle Group said Monday that it had created a new group that will invest in the financial services sector, including banking and insurance.

headline: D.E. Shaw to Buy Insurer in ‘Take-Under’
text: The James River Group, an insurance company that went public two years ago, said Monday it had agreed to be acquired by D.E. Shaw & Company, a hedge-fund firm, for $575 million. At $34.50 a share, D.E. Shaw’s offer did not come with a premium to Friday’s closing share price for $35.18; it was nearly 2 percent below it.

headline: Morgan Stanley’s McVey to Join Fortress
text: Morgan Stanley‘s chief United States investment strategist, Henry McVey, will resign after 12 years at the investment bank. He will join the Fortress Investment Group, the hedge fund and private equity group.

headline: Can Bush Lead a Tourism Wave to Albania?
text: Reports about President Bush’s trip to Albania sounded more inviting than most tourism commercials (please see “So Where the Bloody Hell Are You?”).

headline: A refuge of light and art in Paris
text: When friends come to visit in Paris from abroad they usually make a tour of all the usual museums, the Louvre and the Musée d’Orsay. But I try to steer people seeking a luminous refuge in the City of Lights to the recently refurbished Petit Palais.

headline: It’s Hard Out There for an S.P.A.C.
text: You might think that shopping with other people’s money would be an easy mission in life. But for the dozens of “blank-check companies” — which raise cash through initial public offerings for the sole purpose of making acquisitions — sealing the deal can take a lot of effort.

headline: New Comptroller Wants Out of Sudan
text: Thomas P. DiNapoli, the state comptroller and former assemblyman, appeared at his major first news conference today since he was was installed in February.

headline: Silver Has Answers (and Questions)
text: Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver is, once again, emerging as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s biggest obstacle in Albany.

headline: Warner Still Considering Bid for EMI
text: This is one tune that Warner Music cannot get out of its head.

headline: Afghan Firefight
text: The Times's C. J. Chivers explains the anatomy of a firefight against the  Taliban in Afghanistan.

headline: Monday Morning Motorsports
text: In Formula One, Lewis Hamilton earned the first win of his career at the Canadian Grand Prix. In a wild and crazy crash-filled race, Hamilton started from pole. Despite a poor start, he held onto the lead through the first corner as Fernando Alonso, his teammate at McLaren-Mercedes, skipped into the grass. And while the action behind him verged on the surreal, including several crashes and four safety cars, Hamilton never lost the advantage. “It was a fairly simple race, apart from the restarts,” he said. “On those, I was just trying to keep the tires warm and not make a mistake. The last few laps I was just counting down.”

headline: More on What the Survey Said
text: In a post a few weeks ago, I reported some of the results so far from a survey that Professor Sherry Kimes of Cornell University was conducting through the Diner’s Journal web site. (Digression: Can I tell you how much I loved writing that last sentence? It makes this blog sound like an important instrument of social research. I have goose bumps.)

headline: We Respond to Questions About the House
text: Thanks for all of your comments and questions. Here are our answers to specific questions that seem to be causing confusion.

headline: Fixing the Friendly Skies
text: With hours of flight delays due to computer glitches over the weekend and today’s scary and sketchy report about five near-collisions above New York airports, the state of the nation’s air traffic control system is getting its share of attention.

headline: Tribal Dance
text: War, too, makes for strange bedfellows, and the Bush administration is dealing today with the complications that inevitably ensue from such indiscretions: The Times reports that United States commanders are “arming Sunni Arab groups that have promised to fight militants linked with Al Qaeda who have been their allies in the past”; The Washington Post reports  that “A tribal coalition formed to oppose the extremist group al-Qaeda in Iraq, a development that U.S. officials say has reduced violence in Iraq’s troubled Anbar province, is beginning to splinter”; while the Baltimore Sun finds that “Sudan has secretly worked with the C.I.A. to spy on the insurgency in Iraq – an example of how the United States has continued to cooperate with the Sudanese regime even while condemning its role in the killing of tens of thousands of civilians in Darfur.”

headline: ‘Sopranos’ Allegedly Solved, or ‘I guess you never hear it coming when it’s your turn’
text: EDITOR’S NOTE: To protect the identities of some goodfellas who work in the finance sector, some names and places have been deleted below. Guess Screens is not as bold as it once pretended (we’re really just afraid of a shakedown). Anyway …

headline: Senator Reid on a Few Choice G.O.P. Candidates
text: Courtesy of Carl Hulse, our chief congressional correspondent:

headline: Heading Out on the Win-A-Trip Journey…
text: I’m in a car headed to the airport with my win-a-trip winners. After coming back from my 25th college reunion on Sunday, I packed and rushed to the office in time to meet Leana Wen and Will Okun, the winners. There they were, sitting in my office – and though I hadn’t met them before, they felt like old friends.

headline: The Greening of the Urban Animal
text: A few days ago, for the first time in our history as a species, the human population of the planet Earth became predominantly urban, not rural. Some bold researchers pinned down this epochal moment of passage to May 23, 2007. The date was of course a polite statistical fiction, based on a United Nations estimate of how fast people worldwide are shaking off the dust of the countryside and moving into town.

headline: Travel questions you never dared ask…
text: Photo taken at Angkor Wat, Cambodia by Mariann Lawrence (Courtesy of World Hum)

headline: Working the YouTube Moment
text: David All, of TechRepublican and DomeNation and the DavidAllGroup, has posted tips for candidates to work the YouTube environs. It’s instructive, certainly, but also illuminating.

headline: Campaign Cash: Edwards Leads on ActBlue
text: As the presidential candidates go through their last round of second-quarter fund-raising that ends June 30, the numbers are clicking at ActBlue, an Internet site that has already collected $23 million for Democratic office-seekers.

headline: The Price of Dinner
text: My final days in St. Louis have been filled with excitement, anticipation, and trepidation. How does this “win-a-trip” really work, and what would it be like to work with Nick Kristof? What should we expect, and what unexpected challenges will we face? How much DEET and how many pairs of underwear should I pack? What will I write about, and how should I figure out “my” approach? How can I best convey what I see and hear to you, our readers?

headline: ESL Is Said to Seek Billions in New Investments
text: With private equity and hedge funds in the ascendant and investors clamoring to get in, what better time for one of the top figures in alternative investments to trawl for more money?

headline: The Way She Looked That Night
text: On the looks-are-just-superficial-anyway front, John Edwards has been lampooned for his “I Feel Pretty” primping in front of a mirror. Now Senator Hillary Clinton is drawing notice, decidedly positive notice, for a glamorous turn at last week’s New Hampshire debate.

headline: The Thompson Challenge
text: Fred Thompson has to be grateful for friends like Georgette Mosbacher.

headline: Of Starbucks, G.I. Bills, and Elated Nausea
text: I decided very early in my Marine Corps career that I would separate and become a full-time civilian after my initial contract was completed. The decision didn’t come from any deep-seeded disgruntlement or dissatisfaction with the Marine Corps, but was merely what I considered the best path for me to meet the goals I set for myself and my family. I wasn’t worried about finding a job after separation. There were and are plenty of opportunities for mechanical engineers, so I wasn’t sweating that part of it.

headline: Thinking Blue (And Orange, Too)
text: At pretty much every other stadium in baseball, the press entrance is on street level, through a team office or a side door. Not Dodger Stadium. It’s built onto a hill overlooking downtown Los Angeles, and the media enters at the very top of the stadium. The view is breathtaking. Palm trees ringing the outfield and in the distance. A perfectly-manicured field. And, in homage to the famous Hollywood sign, a “Think Blue” sign well beyond the fence in left-center field. It’s amazing to me that this place is two years older than Shea.

headline: Unluckiest City for Sports
text: The Philadelphia Phillies have lost more games than any professional franchise in any sport. The Phillies are 14 losses from a particular threshold of ignominy — the 10,000th defeat for a club that has won one lonely World Series title (in 1980) during its 125 years of often dreadful existence.

headline: The Discoverer’s DNA
text: When scientists talk about sequencing the human genome, they have been talking so far about creating a composite picture drawn from the gene sequences of many people. That has now changed for good. Recently, the director of the Human Genome Sequencing Center at the Baylor College of Medicine gave James D. Watson  who with Francis Crick discovered the structure of the DNA molecule  two DVDs that contained the complete sequence of Mr. Watson’s DNA.

headline: Opening Statements in Case on Autism and Vaccinations
text: WASHINGTON, June 11 — Lawyers began arguments on Monday in the first of several test cases that may help decide whether the government should pay millions of dollars to parents of autistic children.

headline: Blackstone Founders Prepare to Count Their Billions
text: Meet Wall Street’s soon-to-be $8 billion man, Stephen A. Schwarzman, and his $3 billion partner, Peter G. Peterson.

headline: Passport Pandemonium
text: PASSPORT PANDEMONIUM The confusion and delays in passport processing are a warning to plan far ahead to renew or obtain a passport, travel industry trade groups say. Since Jan 23, United States citizens as well as those from Canada, Mexico and the Caribbean have been required for the first time to present a valid passport when entering the United States by air. A rush for passports has created long processing delays, partly because of confusion among some travelers, who mistakenly thought they needed a passport to return to the United States from Canada or Mexico by car. That requirement will not take effect until next year. Maura Harty, the assistant secretary of state for consular affairs, said that the demand for passports was “over and beyond even the enormous demand we had expected,” leading to the delays. In response, the State Department adjusted the rules so that through Sept. 30, those who can show proof they have applied for a passport, even if they have not received it, are exempt. The required documents are a government-issued photo ID and a printout showing that they have applied for a passport, which can be downloaded from travel.state.gov.passport.

headline: Judges Say U.S. Can’t Hold Man as ‘Combatant’
text: The federal appeals court in Richmond, Va., ruled yesterday that the president may not declare civilians in this country to be “enemy combatants” and have the military hold them indefinitely. The ruling was a stinging rejection of one of the Bush administration’s central assertions about the scope of executive authority to combat terrorism.

headline: Apple Releasing a Windows Browser
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 11 — Apple said Monday that it would make its Safari Web browser available for Windows-based PCs, opening a new front in its rivalry with Microsoft.

headline: Central African Republic: Aid Worker Shot Dead
text: A French aid worker with the group Doctors Without Borders was killed in a volley of gunfire in an area of this vast and lawless country that had recently suffered through a rebel attack and army reprisals. The worker, a 27-year-old logistics specialist named Elsa Serfass, was part of an assessment mission that was sent to evaluate the medical needs of displaced villagers, the latest victims of an increasingly violent conflict between rebels in the northwest of the country and government troops. Dozens of villages have been set on fire in the last 18 months as the army has tried to flush out the rebels, forcing nearly 300,000 to flee their homes.

headline: Cancer Drug May Elude Many Women Who Need It
text: CHICAGO — The breast cancer drug Herceptin is considered the model for the future of medicine tailored to each individual. The drug is given only to the 20 percent of breast cancer patients whose tumors have a particular genetic characteristic.

headline: Democrats in Florida Rebuff Party on Primary
text: MIAMI, June 11 — Rebuffing pressure from the Democratic National Committee, the Florida Democratic Party decided on Monday to make the results of the presidential primary on Jan. 29 binding.

headline: Amy Sullivan, 54, Who Led Advances at O’Neill Center, Dies
text: Amy Sullivan, who as executive director of the Eugene O’Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn., restored the finances of an institution long known for discovering significant playwrights early in their careers, died Sunday at her home in Old Lyme, Conn. She was 54.

headline: British Company to Investigate Its Own Deal With the Saudis
text: LONDON, June 11 — BAE Systems, Britain’s biggest weapons maker, is planning to set up an independent commission to examine its business practices following allegations about payments linked to a Saudi Arabian arms deal in the 1980s, an official at the company said Monday.

headline: When Seasickness Persists After a Return to Solid Ground
text: When 71-year-old Marilyn Josselyn finished a weeklong cruise on the Volga River in Russia with her husband, Roger, in 1998, she expected to feel like a bobbing buoy for a little while after returning to land. “I felt a rocking sensation, but I thought it was just the usual kind of thing,” she said. But when the feeling persisted for weeks, then months, she began to realize something in her brain was truly off kilter.

headline: Save the Last Dance for Covent Garden
text: LONDON, June 11 — On Friday night Darcey Bussell, the most internationally renowned and locally adored British ballerina since Margot Fonteyn, bade farewell to ballet and to the Royal Ballet at Covent Garden, her home for almost all of her 20-year career. Flowers showered from high boxes beside the proscenium arch until they lined the apron of the stage; scores of bouquets were brought on by current and former dancers; cameras were held aloft to record the occasion; and the whole event was televised.

headline: Giuliani Renews Ties With the Police Chief He Ousted
text: The two men, Rudolph W. Giuliani and his former police commissioner William J. Bratton, had not spoken to each other in 10 years. When they had crossed paths at social gatherings, they exchanged little more than icy nods.

headline: The Weight of the Evidence
text: Q. How do they weigh greenhouse gas emissions?

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: ‘Sleeping Beauty’ Dancer

headline: As Breeders Test DNA, Dogs Become Guinea Pigs
text: FORT MOTT STATE PARK, N.J. — When mutant, muscle-bound puppies started showing up in litters of champion racing whippets, the breeders of the normally sleek dogs invited scientists to take DNA samples at race meets here and across the country. They hoped to find a genetic cause for the condition and a way to purge it from the breed.

headline: At Risk: Carbon Monoxide Detectors Not Standard in Hotel Rooms
text: Carbon monoxide detectors are not hard to find. They are available in many stores, and a growing number of people are using them in their homes.

headline: ‘Been There?’ Sometimes That Isn’t the Point
text: During our first year as psychiatric residents at a veterans’ hospital, any patient could reliably stump my colleagues and me by asking one simple question: “If you weren’t in Vietnam, how can you possibly help me?”

headline: TheStreet.com Cancels an Investing Contest
text: TheStreet.com said last night that it would cancel the first round of its “Beat the Street” competition because some players used trading strategies that compromised the integrity of the system.

headline: In Senate Vote, G.O.P. Fights Off Gonzales Rebuke
text: WASHINGTON, June 11 — Senate Republicans blocked a symbolic no-confidence vote against Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales on Monday evening, dismissing the measure as an irrelevant gesture, though Democrats had hoped it might intensify pressure on Mr. Gonzales to resign.

headline: ’86 Law Looms Over Immigration Fight
text: WASHINGTON, June 11 — When President Bush goes to Capitol Hill on Tuesday to push for revival of a comprehensive immigration bill, he will have to wrestle with the ghost of a 1986 law that promised to solve the problem of illegal immigration.

headline: Menendez Is Set to Endorse Clinton for President, Aides Say
text: WASHINGTON, June 11 — Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who is seeking the Democratic presidential nomination, has picked up the endorsement of Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey, one of the most influential Democrats in his state and a prominent Hispanic member of Congress, aides to both lawmakers said on Monday.

headline: Belmont Coverage Pays Off This Year
text: From the moment that ESPN’s ABC Sports went on the air Saturday with the Belmont Stakes, one thing was pleasantly apparent.

headline: The Sexually Exploited Ask for Change: Help, Not Jail
text: She identified herself as Patrice Waters, 18 years old. The name, she allowed later, was an invention to protect herself. But the age was genuine, she said, and so was her story. They’re what matter most.

headline: Suburbs Are Graying Faster Than Big Cities
text: America’s suburbs, historically a haven for young families with children, are aging more rapidly than the nation’s central cities as the first suburban generation grows older.

headline: Pakistan: Judge Gains Legal Ground
text: The Supreme Court agreed to allow its suspended chief justice, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, to contest his removal by President Pervez Musharraf before the full court. Mr. Chaudhry, who had become increasingly independent, was suspended in March on the ground that he had misused his office. The dismissal set off a nationwide backlash that has created the greatest challenge to the rule of General Musharraf since he seized power in a coup in 1999.

headline: 3 Guardsmen Charged With Human Smuggling
text: HOUSTON, June 11 — Three members of the Texas National Guard helping patrol the Mexican border have been charged with human smuggling after federal agents found one of them in uniform driving a van crammed with 24 illegal immigrants north of Laredo, the Justice Department said Monday.

headline: You’d Ask for Them by Name, if It Were More Memorable
text: The performers who played in Zankel Hall on Saturday night were among the brightest, most promising postgraduate musicians the city has to offer, including several seen regularly in buzz-worthy independent groups.

headline: 208 Arrested at Puerto Rican Day Parade, an Increase
text: The police disclosed yesterday that 208 people were arrested at the Puerto Rican Day Parade on Sunday — more than in previous years — after reports that members of the Latin Kings gang planned to join the parade. But several of those arrested said they had simply been swept up with the crowd and denied having any gang associations.

headline: As the Cheering of Tony Night Fades, Broadway Still Faces a Summer of Closings
text: Just about everyone along Broadway knew that “Spring Awakening” would do well at Sunday night’s Tony Awards, but there was still some surprise heard at the after-parties: Few thought it would do quite as well as it did.

headline: Menopause, in the Open (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Battling a Nasty Green Invader From the Deep
text: SCHROON, N.Y. — Nosing into a shallow bay on Schroon Lake, Steve LaMere peered over the side of his pontoon boat. He was on an unusual reconnaissance mission, looking for signs of an aggressive aquatic invader, a stringy herb from Eurasia that once adorned American aquariums but has no business here in the Adirondacks — or anywhere in North America.

headline: After the Bomb
text: THE probability of a nuclear weapon one day going off in an American city cannot be calculated, but it is larger than it was five years ago. Potential sources of bombs or the fissile materials to make them have proliferated in North Korea and Iran. Russia’s arsenal remains incompletely secured 15 years after the end of the Soviet Union. And Pakistan’s nuclear technology, already put on the market once by Abdul Qadeer Khan, could go to terrorists if the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, cannot control radicals in that country.

headline: New Jersey Is Closer to Letting Voters Decide on Property Tax Relief
text: TRENTON, June 11 — A standoff over a 1-cent sales tax increase led to a government shutdown last year. But on Monday, the Assembly voted 79 to 1 to allow voters to decide whether they wanted all of the proceeds of that increase to go toward property tax relief for local governments.

headline: A Compass That Can Clash With Modern Life
text: CAIRO, June 11 — First came the breast-feeding fatwa. It declared that the Islamic restriction on unmarried men and women being together could be lifted at work if the woman breast-fed her male colleagues five times, to establish family ties. Then came the urine fatwa. It said that drinking the urine of the Prophet Muhammad was deemed a blessing.

headline: A Filmmaker Who Found Africa’s Voice
text: Ousmane Sembène, by consensus the father of African cinema, was nearly 40 when he started making films. (He was 84 when he died over the weekend at his home in Dakar). By 1960, the year that Senegal, his native country, won its independence from France, he was already a novelist of some reputation in Francophone African circles.

headline: Bush, on European Tour, Perfects the Art of Meet and Run
text: SOFIA, Bulgaria, June 11 — “It’s good to be here in your beautiful country,” President Bush told President Georgi Parvanov of Bulgaria on Monday morning. He would be in the “beautiful country” for roughly 20 hours, half of them spent inside his hotel. In the world of White House travel, that is an eternity.

headline: Afghan Forces Found Bomb Like Type Used in Iraq
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 11  Afghan security forces found a sophisticated roadside bomb of the type used in Iraq in the center of Kabul last month, the first time such a device has been discovered in the capital, an Afghan intelligence official said Monday. The bomb was primed to hit a convoy of high-ranking Afghan officials or international forces, the official said.

headline: Renewal: Not Just for Library Books Anymore
