text: There is the Security Council and the World Council of Churches, the Council of Europe and innumerable city councils. Now, a leading lodging chain is adding to the assembly of assemblages with what it is calling a Renewal Council.

headline: State Bar Weighs Law License of Duke Prosecutor
text: RALEIGH, N.C., June 12 — Michael B. Nifong, the prosecutor who brought rape charges against three Duke University students, found himself in a crowded courtroom today with the tables turned. Mr. Nifong’s law license is hanging in the balance of an ethics trial focused on his motives and tactics in pursuing the now-dismissed case.

headline: In Mexico, Diabetes Strains Lives and Budgets
text: MEXICO CITY, June 11 — Ten years after she learned she had Type 2 diabetes, Teresa Sánchez bought her first blood sugar meter, a small, hand-held device that cost $100, a quarter of her monthly pension.

headline: The Irresistible Fantasy of the Invisible Man, and Machine
text: Humans have always dreamed of invisibility. Perseus, in Greek mythology, had a cap to make him disappear. Leprechauns and other magical creatures did it on their own.

headline: Discovering Good Fun in Mournful Dark Moods
text: A mournful streak runs through the lyrics of Architecture in Helsinki, like these from “The Cemetery”: “I don’t wanna fall face down/In the flood of the tears from the years that we loved and we messed up.” But those words, like most of the band’s set on Friday night at Fillmore New York (the renamed Irving Plaza), arrived with manic glee.

headline: Euro RSCG to Create Cracker Ads for Kraft
text: Kraft Foods in Northfield, Ill., has awarded the North American creative assignments for the Ritz and Triscuit lines of crackers to Euro RSCG Worldwide in New York, part of Havas. Spending was estimated at $50 million.

headline: Campaigning as Trailblazer, by Proxy and Association
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is not much of a gambler, in politics or life: She refers to herself as part of the “sensible center” in the Senate, and only occasionally has she laid money on the table (blackjack is her game).

headline: Court to Weigh Disparities in Cocaine Laws
text: WASHINGTON, June 11 — The Supreme Court, expanding its review of federal criminal sentencing, agreed Monday to consider the proper judicial response to the sharp disparity in the way the law treats crack cocaine and cocaine powder.

headline: He’s Cornering the Market on Misfit TV Heroes
text: Denis Leary would seem an unlikely candidate to become the Dick Wolf of dark, morally muddied TV series about firefighters, cops and lawyers — and perhaps no more so than on a morning last week on an Upper East Side playground.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Sunday about commencement speeches at colleges around the country referred imprecisely to comments by Boyd Tinsley, an electric violinist in the Dave Matthews Band, at his alma mater, the University of Virginia. He spoke the day before graduation at the university’s valedictory exercises, not at the commencement. As the roundup of speeches noted, the novelist John Grisham was the commencement speaker.

headline: 9 Die in Fierce Palestinian Factional Fighting
text: JERUSALEM, June 11 — The worst factional fighting in nearly a month raged among Palestinians on Monday, with gunmen reportedly firing at the prime minister’s home and office and violence elsewhere in Gaza leaving at least nine dead.

headline: New DVDs
text: LATE OZU

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,499 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: In Parting Shot, Blair Calls Press a ‘Feral Beast’
text: LONDON, June 12  In the land that produced “Scoop,” Evelyn Waugh’s novel of journalistic ambition and ineptitude, it would seem unsurprising for politicians to criticize reporters on occasion. But was it justified, as Prime Minister Tony Blair did today, to call the press a “feral beast”?

headline: Silver Challenges Health Benefits Promised in Manhattan Toll Plan
text: ALBANY, June 11 — Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, in his strongest language yet against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan to charge people who drive into the most congested parts of Manhattan during the day, questioned the health benefits of the proposal yesterday. He also suggested that many of the environmental goals Mr. Bloomberg has outlined could be accomplished without congestion pricing.

headline: The Divide in Caring for Our Kids
text: A few weeks ago, Teri Hatcher, one of the stars of the television series “Desperate Housewives,” was on David Letterman’s show, talking very animatedly about a time when her daughter needed emergency dental care.

headline: Cancer Drug Representatives Spelled Out the Way to Profit
text: Medicare’s decision to reform the way it paid for cancer drugs came after a decade in which oncologists collectively made billions of dollars on the drugs they prescribed. Many doctors say those profits did not affect their prescribing patterns.

headline: Princeton Track Team to Compete in China
text: Overseas trips were once common for Ivy League track teams. Until a half-century ago, meets frequently involved the combined teams of Oxford and Cambridge against colleges like Yale, Harvard and Princeton.

headline: U.S. Warns Iraq That Progress Is Needed Soon
text: BAGHDAD, June 11 — The top American military commander for the Middle East has warned Iraq’s prime minister in a closed-door conversation that the Iraqi government needs to make tangible political progress by next month to counter the growing tide of opposition to the war in Congress.

headline: A Work in a Prism, Offering Varied Points of View
text: How does a ballerina solve a problem like Aurora? It’s no easy task, especially when she is held captive by a production as muddled as American Ballet Theater’s busy, dramaturge-heavy version of “The Sleeping Beauty.” Still, just as the frequent predicament of ballet in New York has become a variation on the theme of bad show, good dancers, five cast changes last week at the Metropolitan Opera House offered new interpretations  and glimmers of hope for the work’s future.

headline: A Planet Is Too Hot for Life, but Another May Be Just Right
text: So much for the Goldilocks planet.

headline: Dissident Challenges U.N. Role on Kosovo
text: PRISTINA, Kosovo, June 11  Like countless ethnic Albanians in Kosovo, Albin Kurti spent the weekend glued to his television set, watching President Bush’s visit to Albania. He was eager to see what Mr. Bush would say from just across the border about Kosovo’s efforts to gain its independence from Serbia.

headline: Mocking an Olympics Logo, but Loving the Attention
text: LONDON, June 11 — Has any marketer ever gotten more for its money than the London Olympics organizers when they introduced a new logo for the 2012 Games?

headline: Cricket Coach Not Murdered, Jamaican Police Say
text: MEXICO CITY, June 12 — Jamaica police said today that Bob Woolmer, the Pakistani cricket coach who was found unconscious in his hotel room in March after his team lost in an upset in the Cricket World Cup, was not murdered as they had previously thought, but died of unspecified natural causes.

headline: Over an Open Mike, Young Voices Speak in Verse
text: IT was 30 minutes before the open microphone part of the show was to begin, and one poet was already nervous.

headline: Male Depression Is Linked to Poor Sibling Relations
text: Men who had poor relationships with siblings during childhood are at significantly greater risk for depression in adulthood than those who got along better, a new study has found.

headline: A Chance of Yankee Thunder at Fenway
text: Projections in baseball are overused and meaningless. It’s just plain foolish to say or think that because Alex Rodriguez hit 14 home runs in the Yankees’ first 18 games that he’s going to hit 126 home runs this season. Not even Barry Bonds, in his body-boggling prime, could have done that.

headline: Rising Rapper Is Fatally Shot Outside His Home in Queens
text: A 24-year-old Queens rapper whose career appeared to be on the rise was fatally shot as he was heading into his apartment building at 5 a.m. yesterday in Far Rockaway, the police said.

headline: Manhattan: Six Charged With Trafficking in Stolen Cars
text: Six men were charged yesterday with altering identifying marks on hundreds of stolen cars and reselling them over the past eight years, federal prosecutors said. Operating from New York City, the men applied for automobile titles from states including New Jersey and Georgia, then altered them to disguise the fact that the cars were stolen, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. They also altered vehicle identification numbers, a practice known as retagging, Mr. Garcia said.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A sports article in some copies yesterday about Eric Snow’s role with the Cleveland Cavaliers in this year’s N.B.A. finals misstated the year of a previous trip to the finals by Snow when he was with Seattle. It was 1996, not 1995.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: ARK Advisors, which helps advertisers search for agencies, was opened by three longtime industry executives, who are all principals in the consulting company. They are Ann Billock, Ken Robinson and Russel Wohlwerth. Ms. Billock and Mr. Wohlwerth were formerly at A/Team Advertising Advisors, New York, and Mr. Robinson was formerly business development director at StrawberryFrog; he previously worked with Ms. Billock at Roth Associates. Ms. Billock and Mr. Robinson are based in New York and Mr. Wohlwerth is based in Los Angeles.

headline: Educational Side Effects (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: After the Immigration Bill Stalled (8 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Exercise: To Encourage Walking, Make It Personal
text: People who want some exercise often need to do little more than get off their, er, couches and go for a walk. Despite numerous studies linking walking to better health, many people cannot seem to bring themselves to do even that.

headline: TV Writers Were Also Watching ‘Sopranos’
text: After he completed the final episode of “The Sopranos,” David Chase told publicity executives at HBO that he was leaving for France and would not take any calls asking him to comment about the ending of his classic television series.

headline: Day of Split Outcomes in Teenage Sex Case
text: ATLANTA, June 11  A judge on Monday ordered the release of a man who is serving a widely criticized 10-year prison sentence without parole for having consensual oral sex with a 15-year-old girl when he was 17.

headline: Qwest Chief Executive to Retire
text: Richard C. Notebaert, who is credited with bringing Qwest Communications back from an accounting scandal and the brink of bankruptcy, surprised investors yesterday by announcing that he planned to resign as chief executive and chairman.

headline: Peel Off the Layers, and Tiffany Peeks Out
text: Hidden beneath decades of modernization, the physical past often re-emerges to tell its story of old New York.

headline: Soloists Run Small Businesses, Too
text: NOT everyone who starts a business wants to have employees.

headline: Having a Baby: Home Visits May Reduce Infant Deaths, Findings Show
text: Health workers may be able to reduce the number of infant deaths by making regular visits before and after birth to the homes of pregnant women considered at risk.

headline: Delay in Prosecution Brings an End to a Murder Charge
text: The case against John Sinagra was about as serious as they come: Prosecutors charged him with first-degree murder, saying he had acted on orders from a Colombo crime family capo, using information from a Federal Bureau of Investigation supervisor, to forever silence an 18-year-old man, a witness to a Mafia killing.

headline: 3 Plead Not Guilty to String of New Jersey Bank Thefts
text: TRENTON, June 11 — Three men accused of stealing more than $87,000 in a string of bank robberies in New Jersey, including an attempted robbery in April that led to the death of an F.B.I. agent, pleaded not guilty Monday in federal court here to conspiracy and other charges.

headline: For Politicians in Britain, the Post-Blair Era Has Already Begun
text: LONDON, June 11  For the past few weeks, like a wannabe rock band on provincial tour, a clutch of British politicians has been crisscrossing the land, from Glasgow to Cardiff to Oxford.

headline: U.N. Monitor Urges Defusing of Stalemate Over Iran
text: WASHINGTON, June 11  The director general of the United Nations nuclear inspection agency warned Tehran and Washington for the first time on Monday that their yearlong stalemate over Iran’s nuclear activities was turning into a “brewing confrontation” that he said “urgently needs to be defused.”

headline: Shuttle Mission Extended to Fix Insulation Blanket
text: NASA managers said Monday night that they would extend the mission of the space shuttle Atlantis for a spacewalk to repair a problem that could cause heating damage during re-entry.

headline: Rare Stamps Fetch $9 Million
text: William H. Gross, the bond investor and chief investment officer of Pimco, confirmed his prowess in another area yesterday when his collection of 19th- and early 20th-century British stamps was auctioned in New York for $9.1 million.

headline: Laborers Seek Back Wages in Lawsuits
text: The Asian-American Legal Defense and Education Fund filed four lawsuits yesterday on behalf of six Sikh and Bangladeshi laborers who are seeking to win thousands of dollars in what they claim are unpaid wages from five construction contractors. The suits  one filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, two in Federal District Court in Brooklyn and one in State Supreme Court in Queens  accuse the companies of breach of contract and violations of minimum-wage laws at construction sites, including a veterans hospital in Northport and a residential building in the Bronx.

headline: Trade Board Deal Cleared
text: WASHINGTON, June 11 (Dow Jones) — The Justice Department said on Monday that the proposed merger between Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings and Chicago Board of Trade Holdings would not pose a threat to competition.

headline: Pettersen Adds Mind Game to Her Golf Game
text: HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., June 11  The target golf that Suzann Pettersen is playing these days has her taking direct aim at the world’s top-ranked female player, Lorena Ochoa.

headline: Bush Lobbies G.O.P. Senators on Immigration
text: WASHINGTON, June 12 — President Bush made a rare trip to the Capitol today, meeting with Senate Republicans over lunch in an attempt to revive the immigration bill and vowing not to give up.

headline: Sports Briefing
text: MARATHON

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 7 P.M. (Cinemax) HAVE YOU SEEN ANDY? In August 1976 Andy Puglisi, 10 (middle, in turtleneck), disappeared from a public pool in Lawrence, Mass., where he was playing with dozens of children, including Melanie Perkins. In this documentary Ms. Perkins, now a filmmaker, looks for answers through interviews with other neighborhood children, Andy’s family, police officers and forensics experts, and uncovers new evidence in this still unsolved case.

headline: YouTube Sets Tests of Video Blocking
text: Google says it will soon begin testing a long-awaited system that can block unauthorized copyrighted clips from being uploaded to YouTube, the popular video-sharing site it bought last year.

headline: Celebrities Are Present; Mets Are Absent
text: LOS ANGELES, June 11 — The celebrities came out to Dodger Stadium in droves Monday night. Wearing blue and orange, Jerry Seinfeld and Hilary Swank cheered on the Mets. Hedging his bets, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar sported a Brooklyn Dodgers cap. Posh Spice flitted around before the game, receiving tips on how to throw a baseball.

headline: Their Season in an Ebb, the Mets Show No Panic
text: LOS ANGELES, June 11 — Unlike many 23-year-olds straight out of college, Joe Smith is making $380,000 this year. Enough money, one would think, to splurge for room service on the road and for high-speed Internet service in his Queens apartment. Out of habit, Smith is stuck in his Ramen-for-dinner ways, living the way he did a year ago at this time, when he was an unheralded third-round pick with a common name and an uncommon delivery.

headline: Women Behind Bars, Real or Imaginary
text: Susanna Moore writes about women in search of an identity, women who are, more often than not, self-destructive, victimized, conflicted and desperate to escape or transcend an oppressive past. And she writes about these women in two utterly different modes: 1) the lyrical and nostalgic, which she used to enormous effect in her 2003 novel, “One Last Look,” and her early novels set in Hawaii (“My Old Sweetheart,” “The Whiteness of Bones,” “Sleeping Beauties”); and 2), the transgressive and graphic, which she used jarringly in her 1995 erotic thriller, “In the Cut.”

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts yesterday about the leading movies in ticket sales over the weekend misstated the given name of the vice chairman of Lionsgate, who commented on the recent decline in sales for horror films like “Hostel: Part II,” which ranked sixth over the weekend. He is Michael Burns, not Mark.

headline: Forging His Own Way in the Shadow of an Icon
text: People see the number, the short-cropped hair, the stiff-shouldered swagger, the pretty jump shot, and reach a logical conclusion. Sasha Pavlovic must be mimicking Drazen Petrovic, paying tribute to a former countryman, a linchpin on his favorite basketball team before it was Balkanized out of existence, into history.

headline: Big Radio Makes a Grab for Internet Listeners
text: Last week a radio D.J. known as Vibegrrl, who works the midday shift on Hot 99.5, a Washington pop station, offered her listeners the chance to receive tickets to see the rock band Hinder.

headline: Yankees Weigh Their Options and Draft a Pitcher With Two
text: As the only ambidextrous pitcher in college baseball, Pat Venditte can choose which arm he throws with. But when it comes to professional baseball, he has only one immediate choice: the Yankees.

headline: Explosion Rocks Nairobi; Signs Point to Terrorism
text: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 11 — A mysterious explosion, which witnesses described as a bomb, rocked downtown Nairobi on Monday morning, killing one person, possibly the bomber, and wounding 31 others.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in the special Circuits section on June 5 about ways to restore rich sound to digital music misstated the data rates at which compressed MP3 music files are recorded. The standard rate is 128 kilobits per second, not 128 bits per second. Higher, and better-sounding, rates are 160 and 190 kilobits per second.

headline: Lawmakers Seek Inquiry of AIDS Spending
text: Two members of Congress have asked the Government Accountability Office to investigate what they called the H.I.V./AIDS crisis in Puerto Rico and the federal oversight of money provided for care of indigent AIDS patients there. In a letter to Comptroller General David M. Walker, the two lawmakers, Representative Nydia M. Velázquez, Democrat of New York, and Representative Hilda L. Solis, Democrat of California, cited testimony from community and patient groups in Puerto Rico and recent news accounts indicating that the Puerto Rican authorities have mismanaged federal money meant for groups helping AIDS patients, and that many patients have endured waits for lifesaving drug therapies. The letter called on the G.A.O. to scrutinize actions taken by the Health Resources and Services Administration, the federal agency that dispenses money under the Ryan White Care Act, to ensure that that money is better spent. Some $53 million went to Puerto Rico last year.

headline: Sudan Surprise
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: When School Is Out, Getting Good Food In
text: No one can dispute that American children are fatter than ever. Much of the blame has been placed on schools — lunch programs high in calories, snack and soda machines in the schools and curtailed or absent physical activities during the school day.

headline: That Nice Midwestern Mom, the One Who’s Handy With a Knife
text: It’s not a good sign when the most exciting moments in a play have to do with cutlery. Center stage in “The Butcher of Baraboo,” which incidentally is not about a theater critic in Wisconsin, is a humongous meat cleaver, so ominously prominent in this gothic comedy that at one point it even gets its own spotlight.

headline: In Sudan, an Animal Migration to Rival Serengeti
text: The first aerial survey of southern Sudan in 25 years has revealed vast migrating herds, rivaling those of the Serengeti plains, that have managed to survive 25 years of civil war, the Wildlife Conservation Society and Southern Sudan will announce today at a news conference in New York.

headline: For a Russian Builder of Nuclear Plants, Business Is Booming
text: MOSCOW, June 6 — The Russian nuclear power company Atomstroyexport has been roundly criticized for helping Iran build its nuclear program. But neither that project nor the company’s mouthful of a name has hurt its business prospects.

headline: U.S. Pushes Iraqi Leader to Pursue Changes
text: BAGHDAD, June 12 — Deputy Secretary of State John D. Negroponte visited Baghdad on Tuesday to pressure Iraq’s Shiite-led government to complete a series of political changes intended to reconcile the country’s warring sects.

headline: Fidelity Reports a 10.5% Stake in Delta Air Lines
text: Fidelity Investments, the mutual fund company, said yesterday in a regulatory filing that it held a 10.5 percent stake in Delta Air Lines.

headline: Leaders for the America’s Cup Teams Have Different Perspectives
text: VALENCIA, Spain, June 11  An edgy America’s Cup competition grew edgier Monday, when the head of Alinghi expressed disappointment with the opposition’s plans and suggested that its leaders were ungrateful for the financial support he had provided when they were struggling to create a syndicate.

headline: Still Dying in Congo
text: Darfur is not the only place where people are dying in staggering numbers. Conflict in the Democratic Republic of Congo has taken more than three million lives in the last nine years. Since damping down a civil war in 2003, the outside world has largely focused on the struggle for power in the capital, Kinshasa, culminating in elections last year that were mostly free and fair.

headline: Drug Maker Fined in Plavix Case
text: WASHINGTON, June 11  The drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb pleaded guilty on Monday to making false statements to a federal agency, ending an unusual criminal case involving its blockbuster blood-thinning drug Plavix.

headline: Canadian Real Estate Concern Makes Bid for Australian Developer
text: OTTAWA, June 11  The Canadian real estate investor Brookfield Asset Management made a cash offer on Monday worth 4.2 billion Australian dollars ($3.55 billion) for Multiplex, a troubled Australian developer and contractor.

headline: In the Company of Women: Pioneers, Mavericks and All
text: According to the American Symphony Orchestra League, works composed by women amounted to 1 percent of the music played by 300 of its member ensembles in the 2004-5 season. That sobering if unsurprising figure was cited in the program for “Notable Women,” a three-weekend festival the St. Luke’s Chamber Ensemble is presenting at the Chelsea Art Museum and Dia:Beacon.

headline: Spurs’ Winning Culture Has Other Teams Wanting the Secret
text: SAN ANTONIO, June 11  Tim Duncan’s team is halfway to its fourth championship, and in the distance, one can almost hear the commemorative DVDs being pressed and labeled.

headline: Manhattan: Man Admits Role in Widespread Spam Campaign
text: A Brooklyn man admitted in Federal District Court yesterday that he had violated federal law by taking part in a widespread effort to send spam e-mail messages to America Online customers, federal prosecutors said. The man, Adam Vitale, 26, was charged with sending junk e-mail messages to 1.2 million subscribers in August 2005, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Garcia said that Mr. Vitale admitted hiding the origin of the mail by using other computers to relay and transmit the spam. He faces up to 11 years in prison when he is sentenced in September, prosecutors said.

headline: Solar Panels, Biofuel and Tidal Turbines in Bloomberg Plans
text: Moving to harness cleaner forms of energy to meet the city’s growing power demands, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced a plan yesterday to outfit municipal buildings with solar panels and to begin buying heating oil containing biofuels.

headline: Bono’s Poverty-Fighting Plan Promoted by Two Ex-Senators
text: WASHINGTON, June 11 — Two former Senate leaders who were once fierce adversaries, Bill Frist and Tom Daschle, joined together Monday to promote a bipartisan effort to make global poverty a central issue of the 2008 presidential race.

headline: Iraqi Parliament Votes to Oust Speaker Who Intimidated Members
text: BAGHDAD, June 11  Parliament approved a resolution on Monday that would force the resignation of the speaker, Mahmoud Mashhadani. The vote underscored the widespread discontent with Mr. Mashhadani, a Sunni Arab politician who has done little to build consensus among Iraq’s political blocs.

headline: Light Fantastic: Flirting With Invisibility
text: Increasingly, physicists are constructing materials that bend light the “wrong” way, an optical trick that could lead to sharper-than-ever lenses or maybe even make objects disappear.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A map with an article on Friday about a decision by Turkey to step up its military presence along its borders misstated the name of the country’s largest lake. It is Lake Van, not Lake Gölü.

headline: U.S. Forces Kill Afghan Police Officers
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 12 — American-led forces killed seven Afghan policemen and injured five more in an exchange of fire early this morning that Afghan police officials said was a result of mistaken identity.

headline: Shelter Closes, Residents Move on and Fortunes Diverge
text: A few weeks ago, the last resident of what was once New York City’s largest homeless shelter, Camp La Guardia, packed his bags and left.

headline: Congress Turns to Energy, and Lobbyists Arrive
text: WASHINGTON, June 11 — Having tried and failed to overhaul the nation’s immigration laws last week, Congress begins what some say is an even more divisive project this week: taming America’s thirst for oil.

headline: Incentives Limit Any Savings in Treating Cancer
text: When Medicare cracked down two years ago on profits that doctors made on drugs they administered to patients in their offices, it ended a windfall worth hundreds of thousands of dollars a year for each physician.

headline: Hearst Sues for Access to Names in Inquiry
text: When the United States attorney’s office announced that it had reached a plea agreement with Kirk Radomski, a former Mets clubhouse attendant who said he sold performance-enhancing drugs to major league baseball players, the government said it would provide information from its investigation to baseball for its own inquiry into drug use.

headline: Manhattan: New Coordinator for Trade Center Health Issues
text: Nearly six years after the attack on the World Trade Center, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has appointed a public relations specialist to coordinate New York City’s response to the mounting health issues of people who were exposed to dust and smoke from the collapsed towers. The new coordinator, Jeffrey Hon, will advise the mayor on 9/11 health issues and oversee the way municipal pension programs respond to requests from employees who were exposed to the toxic dust. Mr. Hon, 53, was a spokesman for the American Red Cross September 11 Recovery Program, which provides financial assistance for mental and physical health care for those most directly affected by the attack. Yesterday, Mr. Bloomberg also named a 15-member panel to review findings on the effects of exposure at ground zero and the adequacy of medical services available to those exposed, The Associated Press reported. The panel includes representatives of Mount Sinai Medical Center and the city Fire Department.

headline: Thailand Freezes Former Prime Minister's Bank Accounts
text: BANGKOK, June 12 — By freezing bank accounts on Monday holding $1.6 billion, the ruling generals of Thailand have hit Thaksin Shinawatra, the tycoon turned politician, where it hurts. But they also emboldened the former prime minister’s supporters and stirred sympathy among what were Mr. Thaksin’s most ardent detractors.

headline: Dancing That Pulls Viewers Right Out of Their Seats
text: At the start of Ohad Naharin’s “Decadance,” performed by the Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet on Saturday night, a line of dancers stands immobile in front of the audience. Then a body twitches and bursts into a buckling, convulsive dance, arms and legs lashing and flailing to the rhythms of Habib Alla Jamal’s music. Each of the dancers is compelled into dance until they all join in a fist-shaking crouch, no longer individuals but part of a tribal crowd.

headline: Brooklyn: Nanny Sentenced in Toddler’s Death
text: A nanny was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 17 years in prison for the death of a 19-month-old boy. The nanny, Tammy Williams, 43, of East New York, pleaded guilty to manslaughter, admitting that in March 2005 she put duct tape over the mouth of the boy, Jaylen Robinson, to stop his crying. The boy suffocated. Prosecutors have said that Ms. Williams's own daughter was a witness to the killing. In court yesterday, an assistant district attorney, Jacqueline Kagan, said the plea agreement "will save the defendant's own child from having to testify against her." A defense lawyer, Peter J. Guadagnino Jr., said that Ms. Williams was in poor mental health and that "I know she's very sorry for what she did.".

headline: Lottery Numbers
Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article yesterday about the American military’s new strategy of arming some Sunni Arab groups in Iraq gave an incorrect identification in some copies for the river where the body of a kidnapped American soldier was found last month. It was the Euphrates, not the Tigris. (Go to Article)

headline: Great Architecture Finds a Home in Indiana
text: THE sign said “Dining Room,” and its red Deco neon shone valiantly against the empty blue sky. Below was a whitewashed country diner, with only a few cars and pickups in the parking lot; by this late afternoon hour, everyone in North Vernon, Ind., had long since lunched.

headline: There Are No Timeouts or Substitutes in Golf
text: OAKMONT, Pa., June 11 — Three years ago, at the lush and leafy K Club near Dublin, Ireland, Thomas Bjorn walked off the course in the middle of his round on the European Tour, saying he was fighting demons in his head. The golf course, with its thick trees and winding rivers, had all but suffocated him, Bjorn said. He did not want to take another swing.

headline: Top Democrat Plans Advance List of Earmarks
text: WASHINGTON, June 11 — A top House Democrat delivered a promise — and a threat — on Monday about the disclosure of the pet projects known as earmarks.

headline: But the Wrong Coat Was So Much Nicer Than Mine
text: My business travel is fairly uneventful. But a flight this year did force me onto a slippery slope of morality.

headline: Tradition Is Renewed at Pocono
text: LONG POND, Pa., June 11  In what has become a tradition, two Nascar officials last Friday walked into the office of Dr. Joseph Mattioli, the longtime owner of Pocono Raceway, and handed him a sheaf of papers known as an annual sanction agreement.

headline: For Yahoo, an Ordeal of Dissent
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 11  When Terry S. Semel, Yahoo’s chief executive, faces shareholders at the company’s annual meeting on Tuesday, Eric Jackson will be there to pepper him with questions.

headline: New York Tightens Scrutiny of Court-Appointed Experts
text: New York City is moving to tighten oversight of court-appointed experts who help defense lawyers after city investigators said they had discovered that a convicted felon was placed on the list of such experts and billed the city $61,000 for work he did not do.

headline: My Accent, Your Accent (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lee Nagrin, 78, Innovator in Performance Art, Dies
text: Lee Nagrin, a noted Off Broadway performance artist, director and member of Meredith Monk’s theater company, The House, died Thursday in Manhattan. She was 78.

headline: She Calls It ‘Phenomena.’ Everyone Else Calls It Art.
text: When people call Felice Frankel an artist, she winces.

headline: Nutrition: Calorie Intake May Affect Bone Health of Young Women
text: When a young woman stops menstruating, doctors often take it as a red flag that she may not be eating enough, which, among other problems, can inhibit bone formation.

headline: Misdirected Studies on Avandia
text: Eight years and seven million patients later, we still don’t know whether the diabetes drug, Avandia, is safe or effective. This is largely because the manufacturer, GlaxoSmithKline, failed to vigorously pursue questions about cardiac safety and the Food and Drug Administration acquiesced in its feeble efforts. Both either ignored or tried to silence scientists who raised the alarm.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A front-page article yesterday about the American military’s new strategy of arming some Sunni Arab groups in Iraq gave an incorrect identification in some copies for the river where the body of a kidnapped American soldier was found last month. It was the Euphrates, not the Tigris.

headline: U.S. Close to Deal to Release Frozen North Korean Funds
text: WASHINGTON, June 11  The United States appears to be close to reaching a deal to transfer $25 million in frozen funds to North Korea, with Russia and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York acting as intermediaries, in hopes of getting North Korea to begin to dismantle its nuclear arms program, American officials said Monday.

headline: New Haven: Mayor Seeks Halt to Immigration Raids
text: Mayor John DeStefano Jr. asked the federal government yesterday to “back off” from any further raids on illegal immigrants until allegations that agents broke rules in conducting one such raid last Wednesday could be addressed. The mayor said yesterday that another raid was “imminent.” At the same time, three Connecticut lawmakers  Senators Christopher J. Dodd and Joseph I. Lieberman and Representative Rosa L. DeLauro  wrote to Michael Chertoff, left, the homeland security secretary, seeking answers to questions about procedures used during the raid. The lawmakers also asked whether the timing of the raid was tied to a decision by city officials to provide identification cards to all residents, including illegal immigrants.

headline: Queens: Storekeeper Shot
text: The owner of an Ozone Park bodega was shot last night in what investigators believe was an attempted robbery of his store, the police said. Three men entered the bodega, at 133-45 135th Street, around 9:30 p.m. and shot the owner in the face, the police said. He was taken to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, where he was in critical condition.

headline: California: A.C.L.U. Files Suit Over Missing Man
text: A developmentally disabled man who was born and raised in Los Angeles County and is a United States citizen was illegally deported to Mexico last month by immigration agents screening inmates at a jail, according to a federal lawsuit filed by the American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California. The man, Pedro Guzman, 29, of Lancaster, Calif., has now been reported missing in Tijuana, Mexico, family members said. The lawsuit accuses federal authorities of failing to ascertain his citizenship and refusing to help find him in Mexico. Mr. Guzman, who was serving a sentence for misdemeanor trespassing, said in a brief telephone conversation with a family member after he was removed that he told jailers he was born in California, the lawsuit said. Virginia Kice, a spokeswoman for the federal immigration agency, said it “had no reason to believe that it improperly removed” Mr. Guzman.

headline: At Aldeburgh Festival, Surprise Is the Tradition
text: ALDEBURGH, England, June 10 — From its inception, in 1948, the Aldeburgh Festival has been a place where old and new music happily, sometimes provocatively, coexist. In his program book essay for the 60th anniversary of the festival, now under way, the critic Paul Griffiths reminds us that the inaugural festival, which lasted a week, offered “new works by young composers, Mozart chamber music, songs by Britten and Schubert, a new small-scale opera, a recital by a great pianist and a dash of Purcell — things that were to be replicated in virtually every festival since.”

headline: A Ruling for Justice
text: For years, President Bush has made the grandiose claim that the Congressional authorization to attack Afghanistan after 9/11 was a declaration of a “war on terror” that gave him the power to decide who the combatants are and throw them into military prisons forever.

headline: Croatian Serb Convicted of Atrocities
text: PARIS, June 12 — The U.N. war crimes court hearing cases from the former Yugoslavia today found a former henchman of president Slobodan Milosevic guilty of multiple crimes while heading a Serbian separatist rebellion and sentenced him to 35 years in prison.

headline: Warming in the Arctic? Blame the Snow. The Dirty Snow, That Is.
text: Carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases get most of the blame for climate change. And rightly so, as they are by far the most dominant influence globally.

headline: Effort to Advise on Risky Loans Runs Into Snag
text: CHICAGO, June 7 — With a growing number of homeowners running into problems paying their mortgages, Illinois came up with an idea to protect people like Cassandra McKinney from lenders — and themselves.

headline: How to Handle Unruly Students? (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Letters
text: Debating an Author’s Legacy

headline: High Court Rules Against Home Aide on Wages
text: The United States Supreme Court ruled yesterday against a home care aide from Queens and upheld federal regulations that exempt most home care workers from minimum-wage and overtime protections.

headline: Sleek, Fast and Focused: The Cells That Make Dad Dad
text: We are fast approaching Father’s Day, the festive occasion on which we plague Dad with yet another necktie or collect phone call and just generally strive to remind the big guy of the central verity of paternity — that it’s a lot more fun to become a father than to be one. “I won’t lie to you,” said the great Homer Simpson. “Fatherhood isn’t easy like motherhood.” Yet in our insistence that men are more than elaborately engineered gamete vectors, we neglect the marvels of their elaborately engineered gametes. As the scientists who study male germ cells will readily attest, sperm are some of the most extraordinary cells of the body, a triumph of efficient packaging, sleek design and superspecialization. Human sperm are extremely compact, and they’ve been stripped of a normal cell’s protein-making machinery; but when cast into the forbidding environment of the female reproductive tract, they will learn on the job and change their search strategies and swim strokes as needed.

headline: The Inevitability of Bumps
text: People who fly a lot tend to be nonchalant about the experience — until the plane hits a patch of choppy air. Then, as cups start skidding across tray tables and luggage jostles overhead, even some frequent fliers admit to gripping the armrest with fear.

headline: More Clues in the Legend (or Is It Fact?) of Romulus
text: The story of Romulus and Remus is almost as old as Rome. The orphan twins were suckled by a she-wolf in a cave on the banks of the Tiber. Romulus grew up to found Rome in 753 B. C.

headline: Parents and Health Experts Try to Ease Italy’s Pollution
text: MILAN — This part of northern Italy is renowned for fashion, food, Fiat. But now it has another, less welcome claim to fame: the cities here have the worst air pollution in Europe.

headline: The Next Culture War
text: The conventional view is that an angry band of conservative activists driven by nativism and economic insecurity is killing immigration reform. But this view is wrong in almost every respect.

headline: Top Executive at EADS Quits in Dispute Over Marketing
text: PARIS, June 11 — Jean-Paul Gut, the chief operating officer of EADS, quit Monday over what he called disagreements over policy and strategy, adding further turmoil to the company’s top management one week before the Paris air show.

headline: Spain: Parties Find Common Ground on ETA
text: José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, the Socialist prime minister, and Mariano Rajoy, the leader of the Popular Party, the conservative opposition, fiercely divided over Mr. Zapatero’s earlier efforts to broker a peace deal with the violent Basque separatist group ETA, held their first meeting since the group called off a cease-fire last week. Officials from both sides offered an upbeat assessment of the meeting as a step toward healing the leaders’ bitter rift and forging a united front against ETA.

headline: Canada: Onex Joins Group Bidding for Bell
text: The Onex Corporation, Canada’s largest investment firm, has joined the Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board in its bid for Bell Canada, the country’s largest telephone company. Onex will bring additional capital to the bid and help ensure that the pension fund’s bid meets Canadian ownership requirements for telecommunications companies. Others in the bidding group include Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Caisse de Dépôt et Placement du Québec, that province’s biggest pension fund. Bell, which changed its name from BCE last week, has formally recognized two other bidding groups, one led by the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan, Bell’s largest stockholder with 6.3 percent of its shares, and the other led by Cerberus Capital Management working with unnamed Canadian investors.

headline: Milestone Marks What Phillies Fans Already Knew
text: PHILADELPHIA, June 11 — During the 1920s and ’30s, when the Phillies inhabited a park called the Baker Bowl, the fence in right field was adorned by a giant advertisement for soap that read: “The Phillies Use Lifebuoy.”

headline: Venezuela Dances to Devilish Beat to Promote Tourism
text: SAN FRANCISCO DE YARE, Venezuela, June 7 — Wearing blood-colored costumes and devilish papier-mâché masks that would make a gargoyle grimace, hundreds of worshipers disguised as demons danced through the streets here Thursday in one of Venezuela’s most exalted religious rituals.

headline: A Battle Over Who’s Helping Disabled Players Rages Anew
text: CHICAGO, June 11 — The feud over pension and disability benefits escalated Monday between a group of disgruntled National Football League veterans and the league’s players union.

headline: Clashes as Egyptians Vote
text: CAIRO, June 11 — One man was shot dead on Monday and at least four people were wounded in clashes between the supporters of rival candidates in elections for the Shura Council, the upper house of the Egyptian Parliament.

headline: Rape Suspect Says She Was Fooled Into Confessing
text: A Queens day care worker accused of raping a 4-year-old boy told jurors yesterday that she falsely confessed to the crime on videotape because a detective promised he would release her if she did.

headline: Psychiatrists’ Pay (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Our Towns column on Thursday, about Sue Sadik, a woman from Clifton, N.J., who reflected on her passion for all things “Sopranos” in advance of the series’ final episode, misspelled the name of the real street and town where the fictional Satriale’s Pork Store is located. It is Kearny Avenue in Kearny, not Kearney. The article also gave an erroneous spelling in some copies for a restaurant chain that Ms. Sadik referred to in disparaging catering options in California, a state she compared unfavorably to New Jersey. It is Applebee’s, not Appleby’s.

headline: Sole U.S. Company That Enriches Uranium Is Struggling to Stay in Business
text: WASHINGTON, June 11 — Seventy years after the United States invented uranium enrichment, the sole American company in the business is struggling to survive, while nuclear power experts worry that its failure would leave the Russians dominant in the market for fuel processing.

headline: Risk of Civil War as Palestinians Step Up Attacks
text: JERUSALEM, June 12 — Gunmen of the rival Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah sharply escalated their fight for supremacy on Tuesday, with Hamas taking over much of the northern Gaza Strip in what began to look increasingly like a civil war.

headline: Oh, the Songs Shine Bright in Some Old Kentucky Homes
text: Many, many strings are plucked in “The Rhythm of My Soul: Kentucky Roots Music,” a documentary by Roger Sherman tonight on PBS, but all that boinging never really convinces you that Kentucky has anything more to boast about musically than assorted other states. The film feels like an attempt to cut into the dominance of Nashville, and though it does introduce some swell pickers and fiddlers you’ve probably never heard of, in general Nashville has nothing to worry about.

headline: The Claim: Brown Sugar Is Healthier Than White Sugar
text: THE FACTS

headline: Flight Snags Are Arriving on Schedule
text: The nation’s air-travel system fell apart again last Friday night, when the space shuttle Atlantis was just about the only flight that was on time on the East Coast.

headline: New York Students Post Higher Math Scores
text: Math scores for students across New York State improved significantly this year, pushed higher by consistent performance gains in New York City, according to scores on the annual statewide math exam released by state officials today.

headline: Mother Nature’s Pesticides
text: When I posted on research by Bruce Ames and Lois Swirsky Gold showing that humans ingest a lot more natural pesticides than synthetic pesticides, I expected a sequel to the earlier denunciations from Rachel Carson’s admirers. (To answer their most frequent question: No, I am not accepting bribes from chemical companies.)

headline: A Kitchen Incubator
text: La Cocina is a shared-use space created two years ago to provide a platform for women entrepreneurs without assets.

headline: A Tour of Palazzo Tornabuoni
text: See inside a new fractional ownership residence in Florence, which will offer 36 apartments by spring 2008.

headline: Onex Joins Group Bidding for Canada’s Bell
text: Onex, Canada’s largest investment firm, has joined the Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board in its bid for Bell Canada, the country’s largest telephone company. Onex will bring additional capital to the bid and help ensure that the pension fund’s bid meets Canadian ownership requirements for telecommunications companies.

headline: Canada’s Brookfield Makes Bid for Australian Developer
text: Brookfield Asset Management, the Canadian real estate investor, on Monday bid 4.2 billion Australian dollars ($3.55 billion) for Multiplex, a troubled Australian developer and contractor. The directors of Multiplex, which was sued over repeated delays in the construction of the new Wembley Stadium in London, have approved the offer. Now, it is subject to shareholder approval.

headline: ‘Sopranos’ Director Jumps Into the Debate
text: In an interview with The Newark Star-Ledger, David Chase responded to angry fans, critics, bloggers and neighborhood gadflys about how he ended his show. In short, he wasn’t being sadistic, as some have suggested.

headline: Justice Department Clears C.B.O.T-Merc Deal
text: The Justice Department said Monday that the proposed $10.3 billion merger between Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings and Chicago Board of Trade Holdings would not pose a threat to competition. The decision gives a leg up to the Merc as it tries to fend off an $11.2 billion unsolicited offer from the IntercontinentalExchange of Atlanta.

headline: Fidelity Reports a 10.5% Stake in Delta Air Lines
text: Fidelity Investments said on Monday in a regulatory filing that it held a 10.5 percent stake in Delta Air Lines, making it the third-largest shareholder in the airline, which emerged from bankruptcy last month. The FMR Corporation, the holding company of Fidelity Investments, said that it controlled 25.1 million shares of the carrier. The stock is valued at $461.1 million based on Monday’s closing price of $18.38.

headline: Even Under New Management, Take-Two Posts a Loss
text: New management of Take-Two Interactive Software, publisher of the popular Grand Theft Auto video games, said on Monday that the company would cut jobs and costs as it posted its sixth quarterly loss in a row. The company, whose management was replaced by dissident investors in March, said that it expected to cut costs by $25 million a year.

headline: As Qwest Chief Retires, Is a Buyout on the Horizon?
text: Richard C. Notebaert, who is credited with bringing Qwest Communications back from an accounting scandal and the brink of bankruptcy, surprised investors Monday by announcing that he planned to resign as chief executive and chairman.

headline: Dubai Mercantile Exchange Says I.P.O. Is Possible
text: The Dubai Mercantile Exchange‘s chairman told Reuters that the company is considering an initial public offering as one of its options for growth, but added that it is “still early days.” The exchange, which is backed by the New York Mercantile Exchange, opened on June 1, trading futures contracts in Oman sour crude.

headline: For Yahoo, an Ordeal of Dissent
text: When Terry S. Semel, Yahoo‘s chief executive, faces shareholders at the company’s annual meeting on Tuesday, questions over his pay package are expected to be a hot topic for some investors.

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Stake in Chinese Tool Maker
text: Jana Partners, the hedge-fund manager run by Barry Rosenstein, agreed to buy a 30 percent stake in the Shenyang Machine Tool Group.

headline: This Start-Up Would Like You to Meet Your Virtual Doorman
text: The doorman occupies a complex spot in the New York City class system: the doorman is at once status-symbol, diplomat and taxi-hailer. And now, he may be virtual, if one start-up has its way.

headline: Chinese Firm Mines Peru Copper
text: Peru Copper of Vancouver said Monday that the Aluminum Corporation of China had agreed to buy the company for about 840 million Canadian dollars ($791 million) as the Chinese firm expands to meet booming domestic demand.

headline: Providence Equity Buys Equity Stake in NexTag
text: A private equity firm, Providence Equity Partners, has bought a two-thirds equity-only stake in a privately held Internet shopping site, NexTag, for $830 million, The Deal.com reported. Morgenthaler Ventures, which has backed NexTag since 1999, will retain an equity stake in the company, which allows people to compare prices for a wide range of goods from real estate to car insurance to groceries, according to the report.

headline: Pzena Investment Files for I.P.O.
text: Pzena Investment Management, which oversees more than $28 billion in assets for institutions, wealthy individuals and mutual funds, filed to raise as much as $150 million in an initial public offering. Goldman Sachs and UBS Securities are lead underwriters for the proposed offering.

headline: French Water Utility Plans a $3.5 Billion Share Sale
text: Veolia Environnement, the world’s biggest water company, plans to raise 2.6 billion euros ($3.5 billion) from a sale of new shares for expansion following a series of acquisitions in Europe and the United States.

headline: Allianz Sells Stake in Hana Financial
text: Allianz, Europe’s biggest insurer, sold 463 billion won ($497 million) of shares in Hana Financial Group, a South Korean bank, ending a seven-year equity partnership with the company, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: FastSoft Receives $4 Million from V.C.s
text: FastSoft, which has developed software to speed up Internet data transmissions, said Monday it had raised $4 million in funding led by Miramar Venture Partners. The funds will be used for sales and marketing and product development.

headline: Investors Flock to One of India’s Biggest I.P.O.’s
text: DLF, a developer attempting to raise a maximum 96.3 billion rupees ($2.4 billion) in an initial share sale, got bids for all the stock offered on optimism the company will gain from a property boom.

headline: Enel to Sell $4.7 Billion in Bonds to Fund Endesa Deal
text: Enel, Italy’s largest utility, set initial terms on a sale of at least $4.7 billion of bonds denominated in pounds and euros to help fund its acquisition of a Spanish rival, Endesa.

headline: Bancrofts Said to Prepare New Proposal for Murdoch
text: The family that controls Dow Jones is preparing to submit a new set of proposals to News Corporation on how to protect The Wall Street Journal’s editorial independence in a potential sale, The Journal reported. Separately, The Times of London, which is owned by News Corporation, reported Tuesday that General Electric is still considering an offer for Dow Jones after talks of a joint bid with Microsoft broke down.

headline: Alcoa Chief Reluctant to Raise Alcan Bid
text: Alcoa‘s chief executive, Alain Belda, indicated Monday he was reluctant to raise his company’s hostile $28.4 billion bid for its Canadian rival Alcan. “At the moment, we think this is a full price,” he said, speaking on the sidelines of a J.P. Morgan conference in New York. “I’d hate to have to go higher than that at this point.”

headline: Yodel-Ay-Ee-Oooo
text: Leukerbad

headline: Are New York Lawyers Getting Shortchanged?
text: It may be a stretch to argue that beginning lawyers at big law firms need more money, but those practicing in New York could make a strong case for a raise, says The National Law Journal.

headline: Fund Manager Fights Back Against Shareholder Activists
text: As hedge fund managers continue to play an increasingly active role in trying to steer companies to improve their value, one British investment manager is expressing concern that this new breed of activist investor is undermining long-term planning with a calculated assault to boost share prices

headline: London Regulators to Survey Private Equity Lending
text: London market regulators are planning to conduct a twice-yearly survey of banks that lend to private equity houses to monitor the “excessive” levels of debt the fast-growing industry has been injecting into the businesses it controls, according to The Guardian

headline: On Hedge Funds, Batting Averages and Fat Tails
text: Hedge funds and those who do business with them were warned Monday by a Treasury official not to operate “under the false illusion” that systemic risk from their activities was not a “real possibility.”

headline: Lehman Posts Record 2nd-Quarter Profit

headline: 2008: Campaign Heals Some Old Wounds
text: A former mayor and his police chief, who have long since parted ways, renew ties. Two former lawmakers – once bitter adversaries – find common cause. And, a presidential candidate and her Senate colleague seek to tighten their alliance with an endorsement today. Seems there’s something about campaign season that brings people together.

text: We’re filing this under our continuing coverage of nonlethal weapons …

headline: Facebook Free-for-All
text: When the social networking site Facebook opened itself up to third-party businesses a few weeks ago, users found new features from a few dozen outside sites, including Microsoft, Amazon and just one political candidate: Senator Barack Obama’s.

headline: Before First Votes, the Money Count
text: The first primary votes are still more than a half-year off, but the next installment of an important proxy contest — the money primary — is only weeks away. So the presidential candidates are all shaking the money tree this week, hoping for impressive tallies after the second-quarter reporting period ends June 30.

headline: Immigration Is on the Bush Menu
text: There is no word on what’s being served for lunch today when President Bush makes a rare visit to the weekly Senate Republican policy lunch on Capitol Hill.

headline: Blackstone Hires Head of Public Markets

headline: Young Americans Try to Gain Traction
text: In its final game of the Gold Cup first round, the United States men's soccer team faces El Salvador Tuesday in Foxboro. For the U.S., which has already advanced to the quarterfinals, the game has little competitive significance. But, like the tournament itself, the match will measure the American team's ability to break down physical, defensive opponents.

headline: Amis Goes to War
text: Martin Amis’s recent profile of Tony Blair, “The Long Kiss Goodbye,” which ran in The Guardian, is one of the year’s great pieces of literary journalism. Amis followed Blair to the White House, where, in a surreal scene, he was offered a “bonbon” by a passing Karl Rove. (Not quite a Nixon/Elvis moment, but close.) Amis also flew with Blair to Iraq.

headline: Family Excursions in and Around Taormina, Sicily
text: I am thinking about a visit to Sicily with my wife and kids (5 and 8). We’ve been to Italy, but not Sicily. We are thinking about spending a week in Taormina in a villa outside the city. I’d appreciate any thoughts.

headline: Giuliani’s 12 Commitments
text: BEDFORD, NH, June 11 – Rudolph W. Giuliani, seeking to bring together a variety of issues that he has talked about in recent months and outline an agenda for his campaign, said that among his top priorities were overhauling the education system, achieving energy independence, and moving towards more consumer driven health care.

headline: ‘Covenant Lite': Lending Without Brakes
text: There is at least one parallel between the housing market and the private equity industry: In both areas, banks have, at least until recently, been lending money on very borrower-friendly terms. An important question is whether the trend will turn out differently for private equity funds than for homeowners, many of whom have begun defaulting on the mortgages that they obtained so easily.

headline: N.B.A. Jersey Economics
text: Kobe Bryant sold more jerseys than any other player last season, the N.B.A. announced, completing a rebound after his popularity dipped as he faced rape charges that were later dropped and a string of early exits from the playoffs.

headline: The Sweet Smell of Failure
text: Failure, it seems, can actually be measured as success. Failed executives often profit handsomely from lucrative pay packages. They are booted out, generous stock options in hand. Golden parachutes break their fall from grace.

headline: Dim sum for hungover fashionistas
text: Weekend brunching is a big deal in this city of workaholics, as it’s one of the few times you actually can get a group together for a meal. Restaurants fall over each other vying for the brunch crowd, resulting in an enormous range of options.

headline: Giuliani Critic Joins Team Thompson
text: The Fred Thompson for President campaign – assuming it happens, which is a pretty good assumption — has scored a fairly high-profile hire.

headline: The Week Ahead
text: Alison Smale, Managing Editor of the International Herald Tribune, discusses the events in the world this week.

headline: D.E. Shaw Urges Sale of Brokerage Software Maker
text: Building up its shareholder-activist credentials, D.E. Shaw has raised its holdings in Investment Technology Group and is urging the maker of brokerage technology to consider a sale, the company said in a regulatory filing Tuesday.

headline: Poll Shows Republican Unease
text: As they look toward the 2008 election, Republican voters are less satisfied with their field of presidential candidates than are Democratic voters, and strong majorities of both parties disapprove of the current Congress according to the latest Los Angeles Times/Bloomberg Poll.

headline: Chaucerian Frauds!

headline: All About Rent: Cheers, Jeers and Song
text: Tenants came expecting a fight. After last year, when the city allowed landlords to raise rents by up to 7.25 percent in a meeting marred by outbursts and disruption, today’s public meeting for the city’s Rent Guidelines Board might have ended badly.

headline: A Vote for Philly
text: I’m from Philadelphia, so you can guess where I stand as to which is the most star-crossed city. But I will say that Cleveland is a close second. I mean, they don’t even have a hockey team to let them down every year, at least not since those Cleveland Barons folded. And it must be agonizing to be a Browns fan, haunted by memories of John Elway and Ernest Byner and Art Modell.

headline: Interleague Intrigue
text: One of the things I enjoy about interleague play are the matchups of old World Series teams.

headline: Spam and Punishment
text: A 26-year-old man from Brooklyn has pleaded guilty for getting caught spamming 1.2 million AOL accounts in 2005. While some observers see a moral victory for AOL and others see a hollow victory in an unwinnable war, one important question being raised concerns crime and punishment.

headline: London Journal: At English National, a Turn for the Better
text: In February 2004, I had a meeting here with Sean Doran, then the new head of the English National Opera. The company had been grappling for years with managerial turnovers, chronic deficits and general chaos.

headline: Bush’s Watch Theft: Debunked
text: UPDATED, 8:58 PM ETA theory that emerged in an Italian newspaper and gained prominence on a Balkans newscast posted to YouTube has now been debunked by two mainstream news organizations.
