headline: Your Ideas for Africa Coverage
text: So I’ve landed safe and sound in Kigali, Rwanda. It’s 1:25 in the morning here, but I’m jetlagged….

headline: Candidates Finals: Three Are Through, Two Must Play on
text: Peter Leko, Boris Gelfand and Levon Aronian clinched their candidates matches finals to qualify for the world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. Alexander Grischuk and Sergei Rublevsky were tied at the end of regulation and must play tie-break games tomorrow to determine the fourth qualifier. The matches were held in Elista, Kalmykia, over the last two weeks and can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.

headline: Thompson Wants to Be President
text: How much deeper can Fred Thompson wade into the presidential waters without actually announcing that he is a candidate?

headline: There Is Always a Perimeter
text: I just got out of prison.

headline: U.S. Gets Its Groove Back Against El Salvador
text: Bob Bradley has tinkered with the U.S. lineup with mixed results, but now he seems to have an embarrassment of attacking riches.

headline: Providing a Welcome Mat
text: Sodertalje, Sweden, a thriving town about 18 miles southwest of Stockholm, has become the haven of choice for many Iraqi Christians.

headline: Blair Compares News Media to ‘Feral Beast’ in Angry Parting Shot
text: LONDON, June 12  In the land that produced “Scoop,” Evelyn Waugh’s comic novel of journalistic mischief, it would barely seem surprising for politicians to let rip at reporters. But was it going too far for Prime Minister Tony Blair to call the press a “feral beast”?

headline: Returning to a Favorite Role for an Almost-Final Goodbye
text: Alessandra Ferri has given many riveting performances in the title role of Kenneth MacMillan’s “Manon,” a near-perfect vehicle for the dramatic intelligence and physical gifts that have made her one of the great ballerinas of the last two decades.

headline: Young Coach Finds His Way in the Finals
text: CLEVELAND, June 12  If Mike Brown, the 37-year-old coach of the Cleveland Cavaliers, has seemed overwhelmed by his first trip to the N.B.A. finals, his placid expression would never reflect it.

headline: Chinese Consumer Prices Rose 3.4% in May; Other Gauges More Restrained
text: Inflation in China reached a 27-month high of 3.4 percent in May, government statisticians announced yesterday, but the increase in consumer prices was heavily concentrated in food, while figures for growth in the money supply and in loans suggested that the broader economy was not yet overheating.

headline: New Fate for Rudolph House: Deal to Relocate It Collapses
text: Plans to move a 1956 house designed by Paul Rudolph from a bluff in Rhode Island rather than demolish it fell through yesterday, the parties involved said.

headline: Bad Is Good in One-Act Operas Featuring the Sin of Infidelity
text: Nothing gets an opera moving like one of the seven deadly sins, and if you can make the sin comic rather than deadly, so much the better. Seymour Barab has written several one-act comic operas and short operatic scenes about lust — more specifically, adultery — and on Monday evening the After Dinner Opera Company offered several at the Leonard Nimoy Thalia Theater at Symphony Space.

headline: Reynolds Finds New Home at MLB.com as Analyst
text: Harold Reynolds went to work yesterday as an analyst for MLB.com, almost 11 months after being fired by ESPN in a disputed sexual-harassment case. He is suing ESPN for wrongful termination and damages.

headline: Touring Tradition
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Attacks Escalate as Palestinians Fight for Power
text: JERUSALEM, June 12 — Gunmen of rival Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah sharply escalated their fight for supremacy on Tuesday, with Hamas taking over much of the northern Gaza Strip in what is beginning to look increasingly like a civil war.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on June 5 about Samuel A. Garrison III, the chief Republican counsel to the House Judiciary Committee during the Watergate investigation, misstated the date of the resignation of President Richard M. Nixon. It was Aug. 9, 1974 — not Aug. 8, which was the date he announced that he would resign effective at noon the following day. Also, the obituary referred incorrectly to the three articles of impeachment passed by the Judiciary Committee. Only one article — not all three — charged Mr. Nixon with obstruction of justice. The others charged abuse of power and defiance of committee subpoenas.

headline: Cavaliers Let Opportunity Pass Them By
text: CLEVELAND, June 12 — LeBron James drove desperately to the basket with just under 15 seconds remaining and with his Cleveland Cavaliers trailing by a basket. Running into San Antonio’s best two defenders, Bruce Bowen and Tim Duncan — the savvy veterans who have confronted him at every turn in these N.B.A. finals — James spun to pass the ball to Anderson Varejão.

headline: Manhattan: Salesman Admits Stealing Secrets
text: A salesman for a software consulting company has admitted stealing confidential company information and giving it to a competitor, federal prosecutors said yesterday. The salesman, Louis Giuffre, 46, of Lake Grove in Suffolk County, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court on Monday to interstate transportation of stolen property, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Giuffre admitted that while working for the consulting company, Netsoft, last summer, he sent confidential information to a rival company by e-mail, Mr. Garcia said. Prosecutors said the competitor ultimately won a contract that Netsoft had been trying to secure. Mr. Giuffre faces up to 10 years in prison when he is sentenced in September, prosecutors said.

headline: What Was Old Is New as TV Revisits Branding
text: A COMING television series about Madison Avenue, set in the days when sponsors’ products were regularly woven into the plots of shows, is — yes — getting a sponsor whose product will be regularly woven into the plot of each episode.

headline: Setback for Ill Workers at Nuclear Bomb Plant
text: LAKEWOOD, Colo., June 12— A federal advisory panel recommended Tuesday that thousands of former workers at a nuclear weapons plant be denied immediate government compensation for illnesses that they say result from years of radiation exposure there.

headline: A Setting So Romantic They’re Now Married to It
text: IF looks alone could make a restaurant, Provence would have nothing to worry about.

headline: David Halberstam Remembered as Writer Dedicated to Conveying Truth
text: David Halberstam, the Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist and author who was killed in a car crash in California on April 23, was remembered yesterday as a gifted storyteller who was determined to tell his readers the truth.

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed article on June 3, about the anniversary of “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band,” misquoted the lyrics of a song on the album. The line from the song, “Getting Better,” is “I used to be cruel to my woman,” not “I was cruel.”

headline: U.S. Inquiry Hampered by Iraq Violence, Investigators Say
text: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., June 12  Two naval investigators testified at a military hearing here on Tuesday that their inquiry into allegations that marines killed 24 Iraqi civilians in Haditha in 2005 was hampered by insurgent bombs and gunfire as well as the absence of basic equipment like tape recorders.

headline: Broadcasters’ Service (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Diagnosis: Conflict of Interest
text: Boston

headline: Former Executive of CA Inc. Will Pay Restitution
text: A federal judge in Brooklyn approved an agreement Tuesday in which the former sales chief of CA, Stephen Richards, who pleaded guilty in an accounting fraud case at the company, will pay more than $29 million in restitution.

headline: The Hectic Chronicles
text: HEY, all you work addicts out there, get a life.

headline: The Night We Watched as Tony Went ... (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: CBS Chairman Rebukes Dan Rather

headline: Knicks to Play Exhibition Against Top Israeli Team
text: The Knicks, who have not won an N.B.A. title in three decades, will open their preseason schedule Oct. 11 against Maccabi Tel Aviv, a club that has won 47 Israeli championships. The event will benefit a charity for disadvantaged Israeli children, if not necessarily the Knicks themselves.

headline: The President and His Friends, Younger and More Animated
text: Too lil’, too late. The animated satire “Lil’ Bush” makes its television debut tonight on Comedy Central, and if you think the moment has passed for a show about pint-size, foul-mouthed versions of George W. Bush, Dick Cheney, Donald H. Rumsfeld and Condoleezza Rice getting into all kinds of mischief, you’re not alone. (For one thing, hasn’t Lil’ Rummy been sent home already?)

headline: Recipe: Pea and Crab Salad
text: Time: 15 minutes

headline: Silence in the Senate
text: The most remarkable thing about the debate on Attorney General Alberto Gonzales this week was what didn’t happen. Barely a word was said in praise of him or his management of the Justice Department. The message was clear even though the Republicans prevented a no-confidence vote through the threat of a filibuster — a tactic that until recently they claimed to abhor. The sound of Mr. Gonzales not being defended was deafening.

headline: Near the U.N., a Run on Office Space
text: The United Nations has been wrestling with how to renovate its headquarters in New York for nearly a decade. The creaky Secretariat and General Assembly buildings, perched along the East River in Midtown Manhattan, have not been refurbished since they were completed in 1952. Even the original mechanical and engineering systems are still in place.

headline: Shake-Up in Newsroom of Journal
text: The Wall Street Journal, already roiled by a proposed takeover by Rupert Murdoch, today announced a major newsroom shake-up, including the reassignment and replacement of several top editors, officials there say.

headline: Romney Steps Up Advertising Push
text: Mitt Romney has stepped up what is already the costliest early advertising push in a presidential campaign, an effort that his advisers and several media experts credit with helping vault him to the lead in the Republican field in some recent polls in Iowa and New Hampshire.

headline: Beethoven’s Adventures: A Narrative and Context
text: The Emerson String Quartet’s Beethoven Quartets in Context series looks great on paper and lives up to its promise. The idea was to build on the Beethoven quartet cycle by surrounding his works with scores by other composers. But the results have been more than that. Besides showing Beethoven’s development, from the Classically scaled early quartets to the titanic late ones, the series is focusing on compositional problems he grappled with and how other composers tackled similar issues.

headline: Second U.S. Official Presses Iraqi Premier for Action
text: BAGHDAD, June 12  Deputy Secretary of State John D. Negroponte visited Baghdad on Tuesday to press Iraq’s Shiite-led government to complete a series of political reforms intended to reconcile the country’s warring sects.

headline: Turkish Premier Opposes Move on Militants in Iraq
text: ISTANBUL, June 12 —Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan took a strong public stance against a military incursion into northern Iraq on Tuesday, in an indication that he would not back the military’s request for a major offensive.

headline: Texas: DNA Affirms Conviction
text: A prisoner serving 40 years for raping a 12-year-old girl in 1993 got his wish, but it was not what he intended. The prisoner, Culberson Henry, applied for a retesting of the evidence under a 2001 law allowing inmates claiming wrongful conviction to petition for DNA review. The request was granted last year and the results confirmed his guilt, reported Craig Watkins, district attorney of Dallas County, where 13 prisoners were recently exonerated after DNA testing. “Equally important,” Mr. Watkins said, it works the other way, too.

headline: A Lack of Ethics (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Virginia Tech Report Cites Privacy Law Problems
text: WASHINGTON June 13 — Complicated privacy laws have left education, health care, and law enforcement officials confused about what they can legally tell one another concerning dangerous and mentally ill people, and that confusion has limited the ability of these officials to prevent the kind of violence that occurred at Virginia Tech, according to a federal report released today.

headline: Loser, Loser Burning Bright in the Grim Helsinki Night
text: A mood of cosmic desolation seeps like late autumn sunlight filtered through clouds in “Lights in the Dusk,” the Finnish filmmaker Aki Kaurismaki’s haunting meditation on the downward spiral of a solitary loser in contemporary Helsinki. This hapless everyman, Koistinen (Janne Hyytiainen), a night watchman for a security company, patrols a block of stores that include a fancy jewelry shop ripe for burglary.

headline: Attention, Web Surfers: The Following Film Trailer May Be Racy or Graphic
text: LOS ANGELES, June 12 — Hollywood has been circulating movie trailers on the Web for years, but only now is the film industry retrofitting its rating system to give the studios a chance to showcase their racier material online.

headline: Don Herbert, ‘Mr. Wizard’ to Science Buffs, Dies at 89
text: Don Herbert, who unlocked the wonders of science for youngsters of the 1950s and ’60s as television’s Mr. Wizard, died yesterday at his home in the Bell Canyon section of Los Angeles. He was 89.

headline: Iraqis Are Failing to Meet U.S. Benchmarks
text: BAGHDAD, June 12 — Iraq’s political leaders have failed to reach agreements on nearly every law that the Americans have demanded as benchmarks, despite heavy pressure from Congress, the White House and top military commanders. With only three months until progress reports are due in Washington, the deadlock has reached a point where many Iraqi and American officials now question whether any substantive laws will pass before the end of the year.

headline: A Woman’s Market Is in the Second Home
text: As women play ever-larger roles in family real estate decisions, developers from Florida to Florence are seriously rethinking the luxury second-home market.

headline: Recipe: Lamb Schnitzels With Mint-Horseradish Pesto
text: Time: 40 minutes

headline: Recipe: Moroccan Anise-Flavored Bread (Khubz)
text: 1 package active dry yeast

headline: A Rat With a Whisk and a Dream
text: FOR someone who works in a restaurant, watching a rat try to become a chef might seem like just another day at work.

headline: A Math Lesson on College Loans
text: Burlington, Vt.

headline: A New Television Campaign, Starring the Bronx as a Tourist’s Delight
text: Television viewers in the New York region will learn about a new and intriguing tourist destination this month. It is an exotic land the size of Paris, an urban retreat that gave the world not only hip-hop but also Billy Joel, and is home to a zoo, a baseball stadium and a jeer disguised as a cheer.

headline: Alas, Poor Art Market: A Multimillion-Dollar Head Case
text: LONDON, June 7 — Presumably it was pure coincidence.

headline: European Union Split on Solution to African and Iraqi Refugee Influx
text: BRUSSELS, June 12  Appeals by Malta and Sweden for help in sharing the burden of thousands of African and Iraqi refugees streaming into the European Union were rebuffed Tuesday as union interior ministers clashed on how to solve the problem.

headline: War Crimes Tribunal Sentences Serb to 35 Years
text: PARIS, June 12 — The United Nations war crimes court established to hear cases from the former Yugoslavia found a former henchman of president Slobodan Milosevic guilty on Tuesday of multiple crimes while leading a Serbian separatist rebellion and handed down a sentence of 35 years.

headline: Albany: Spitzer Reconsidering Medical Marijuana
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer said yesterday that he was open to making the medical use of marijuana legal in New York, reversing a position he took during the campaign. It was unclear, however, whether the Legislature would pass such a bill. “There was a moment during a debate last summer, I think, where I spoke more negatively of it based upon what I understood the medical considerations to be,” the governor said. “I’ve taken a hard look at it over the past number of months, and I’m open to signing a bill if it’s properly structured.” The Democrat-led Assembly is expected to pass a bill before the session ends next week, but it is unclear whether it will be taken up in the Republican-led Senate. “It’s a bill that is under review, but it’s not right now on our radar,” said John McArdle, a spokesman for Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader.

headline: Corrections
text: An article yesterday about the high number of arrests at this year’s Puerto Rican Day Parade in Manhattan referred incorrectly to the estimated number of arrests at last year’s parade. The figure of 50 to 60 arrests last year was taken from an article that ran in The Times in 2006; the estimate did not come from the New York police in the course of reporting yesterday’s article. (The 2006 article cited “at least 50” arrests, but the Police Department disputes that figure, saying 151 people were arrested.) (Go to Article) An article about the reaction to this year’s arrests appears today.

headline: Recipe: Chicken With Couscous
text: 1 4-pound chicken, skinned and cut into chunks (thighs in half, breasts in thirds, drumsticks and wings left whole, and backbone discarded)

headline: Ethics Hearing for Duke Prosecutor
text: RALEIGH, N.C., June 12 — Two months after the North Carolina attorney general dismissed sexual assault charges against three former Duke University lacrosse players, the prosecutor who brought the case found himself in a crowded courtroom Tuesday, facing charges that could lead to his own disbarment.

headline: Surviving Under Mao: A Slacker’s Guide
text: Kang Zhengguo, a poet and student of literature, loved to write. The watchful guardians of the Chinese Communist Party made sure that he got plenty of practice. His favorite forms were the lyric poem and the diary. Theirs was the confession, and Mr. Kang turned them out by the dozen throughout his life, expiating one supposed crime after another by denouncing himself as a reactionary element, a deviationist and whatever else was on the political menu that day.

headline: Banking Group Names Chief Executive
text: The Australia and New Zealand Banking Group hired Michael Smith, head of Asia for HSBC Holdings, as chief executive to drive expansion in Asia, where the bank plans to double investment. Mr. Smith, 50, who worked for HSBC for 29 years, succeeds John McFarlane, who ran the bank for a decade. “I’ve watched the Australian banks for a number of years and often wondered why they haven’t done more in Asia,” Mr. Smith said in an interview. ‘‘When a market like Australia becomes mature, you have to look for opportunities elsewhere and I really do feel there is a significant opportunity in Asia.”

headline: Watching Your Every Move
text: Internet users are abuzz over Google’s new Street View feature, which displays ground-level photos of urban blocks that in some cases even look through the windows of homes. If that feels like Big Brother, consider the reams of private information that Google collects on its users every day through the search terms they enter on its site.

headline: Spitzer Expects Federal Funds for Congestion Plan; Lawmakers’ Doubts Remain
text: ALBANY, June 12  Gov. Eliot Spitzer expressed optimism on Tuesday about the chances of getting federal funds to carry out Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s congestion-pricing plan, even as lawmakers continued to question its wisdom. The lawmakers also said it was unlikely to come up for a vote before the end of the regular legislative session next week.

headline: Greenberg Rebuttal
text: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, tried to turn the tables on his accusers yesterday.

headline: Doing the People’s Business, in All Its Somnolent Glory
text: Frederick Wiseman’s documentaries were famous for having integrity, and then, quick as a flash, they became famous for being boring. “State Legislature,” a two-part, billion-minute program about, well, you know what it’s about, is set in the state capital building in Boise, Idaho. It appears tonight on PBS.

headline: Casting Ballot From Abroad Is No Sure Bet
text: Over the last six years, the Defense Department has spent more than $30 million trying to find an efficient way for American soldiers and civilians living abroad to vote in elections back home.

headline: Ohio Experiment Survives Cuts by Becoming a Charter School
text: CINCINNATI, June 12  An experimental public high school in Dayton that has had success in sending low-income students to college will become a charter school under the control of the University of Dayton, the school district has decided.

headline: A Dose of Art and Entertainment Revives a Suburb
text: SILVER SPRING, Md., June 12 — Washington’s first suburban shopping district had its heyday here in the 1950s, but as people moved farther out and new malls sprouted to serve them, retailers and then offices left in droves, sending Silver Spring into a decades-long decline.

headline: Shimon Peres Wins Israeli Presidency
text: JERUSALEM, June 13 — Ehud Barak, a former prime minister of Israel, returned to the political scene as the new head the Labor party today, and Shimon Peres, the deputy prime minister and elder statesman of the ruling Kadima party was elected by parliament to the largely ceremonial post of president of Israel.

headline: A Moroccan Oven That’s Open to All
text: ASSILAH, Morocco

headline: ConAgra’s Chief Is Moving to Revitalize Some Venerable Brands
text: OMAHA, June 12 — It wasn’t too long ago that the sleek and expansive test kitchens at ConAgra Foods were little more than decoration.

headline: Mayor and Council Agree on Budget, Providing Breaks on Property and Sales Tax
text: New York City taxpayers would get a larger-than-expected break on their property taxes under a deal announced last night by city leaders on a $59 billion budget. The pact would also use a record $4.4 billion surplus to eliminate taxes on clothing and shoes and increase library service to six days a week.

headline: The Unspeakable Delights of Zweigelt
text: A GRAPE and a wine that go by the name zweigelt have immediate obstacles to overcome on the path toward popularity. First and foremost is the fact that the American wine-drinking public is attracted to melodious wine terminology drawn from the romance languages. Chardonnay and merlot and Chianti and Rioja flow beautifully from the tongue, with connotations of captivating pleasures. Germanic words like zweigelt, blaufränkisch and, yes, rotwein, do not.

headline: City Students Lead Big Rise on N.Y. Math Tests
text: Math scores for students across New York State improved significantly in every grade tested this year, powered by sizable gains in New York City, according to results of the annual statewide math exam released by education officials yesterday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Technology Group Seeks to Save Power
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., June 12 — Google and Intel are leading a consortium of major technology companies in an effort to sharply reduce the amount of power wasted by personal computers and servers.

headline: A Chinese Company Fights Its French Partner
text: HANGZHOU, China, June 12 — A dispute between Groupe Danone, the French multinational company, and a brash Chinese executive has escalated into a battle for control of the country’s largest beverage maker.

headline: M.T.A. Falls Further Behind on Antiterrorism Projects
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has dropped further behind schedule on a series of projects that are intended to make the region’s bus, subway and commuter rail systems less vulnerable to terrorist attacks, according to a report released yesterday by the state comptroller’s office.

headline: Named for Piety, Laced With Profanity
text: OAKMONT, Pa., June 12 — There are 20 benches in the middle of Oakmont Country Club where no golfer wants to stop and take a rest.

headline: The Line Between Civilian and Soldier
text: Before the Sept. 11 attacks, there were soldiers and civilians, and it was pretty easy to tell them apart.

headline: What You Get for... $700,000
text: Vineyard Haven, Mass.

headline: Suffolk’s Leader Wins a Following on Immigration
text: HAUPPAUGE, N.Y. — A recent day in May began in crisis mode for Steve Levy, the Suffolk County executive, over an allegation that a police crackdown on unlicensed drivers amounted to the ethnic profiling of illegal immigrants.

headline: That iPhone Has a Keyboard, but It’s Not Mechanical
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 12 — If there is a billion-dollar gamble underlying Apple’s iPhone, it lies in what this smart cellphone does not have: a mechanical keyboard.

headline: Academy Eases 3-to-a-Movie Producer Limit
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 13 — Producers take heart: It just got a little easier to put your hands on an Oscar.

headline: Budget Agreement Is Near, New Jersey Officials Say
text: TRENTON, JUNE 12 — Gov. Jon S. Corzine and the Democratic leaders of the Assembly and Senate said Tuesday afternoon that they had reached “broad agreement on the framework” for a new state budget and expected its official adoption well before the statutory June 30 deadline.

headline: 5 Children Die in Pittsburgh House Fire
text: PITTSBURGH, June 12 — Five young children from two families died Tuesday in an early morning fire after their mothers left them in the home overnight with a teenage baby sitter who has not been found, the police said.

headline: Puerto Rico Parade Organizers Denounce Arrests
text: The organizers of the Puerto Rican Day parade criticized the New York City Police Department today for arresting more than 200 people at Sunday’s parade, many of them for unlawful assembly.

headline: Bankrupt Lender Dismisses 2 Executives
text: New Century Financial, the bankrupt housing lender, disclosed yesterday that it had fired its chief executive and an executive vice president and named its chief restructuring officer to the post of chief executive.

headline: This Is a Test. Results May Vary.
text: We know the script. It opens with a Greek chorus lamenting how poorly students are reading. A pedagogic hero — a new chancellor or state commissioner — appears on the scene with a fresh quiver of weapons and schedules improved tests.

headline: Bond Yields Soar, Driving Shares Down
text: The cost of borrowing headed higher yesterday and drove the stock market down sharply.

headline: Socrates as a Woman, and Other Twists on the Ancients
text: Socrates didn’t much care for the theater, or so Plato insists in “The Republic.” “All poetical imitations are ruinous to the understanding of the hearers,” Socrates declares at one point.

headline: Good Choice for the Chiefs
text: A strong, independent chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff can help protect the country against badly conceived and managed military operations  like the disastrous misconduct of the war in Iraq. Regrettably, the last two chairmen proved neither strong nor independent, refusing to stand up to the bullying and ideological blindness of former Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld.

headline: Contemporary Solar Systems, With Some Classical Moons
text: OJAI, Calif., June 11 — The Ojai Valley, an hour and a half north of Los Angeles, was filmdom’s original Shangri-La: a fictional Himalayan pocket of natural luxury imagined by the writer James Hilton and made palpable for the screen by Hollywood cameras brought here on location. With the 1937 movie “Lost Horizon,” Shangri-La entered the vocabulary, evoking welcome, secrecy and unexpected beauty.

headline: A Trinidadian Dispute Runneth Over as Cup Money Does Not
text: Trinidad and Tobago went to Germany last summer as the smallest nation, in terms of population, at the World Cup. This year, the Soca Warriors came to the United States for the Concacaf Gold Cup with a prodigious headache.

headline: Far From War, a Town With a Well-Used Welcome Mat
text: SODERTALJE, Sweden, June 11 — Walking down the carpeted aisle of Sodertalje’s low-slung St. John’s Church on a recent morning, Anders Lago’s broad, blond features looked out of place among the crowd of hundreds of black-clad Iraqi mourners at a memorial service.

headline: Albany: New Rules for Pipeline Security
text: Ten days after four men were accused of plotting to destroy fuel lines at Kennedy International Airport, state legislators have introduced a bill that would allow the enforcement of more stringent security measures at similar pipelines across the state. The legislation  sponsored by Assemblyman Michael N. Gianaris, a Queens Democrat, and Senator Dean G. Skelos, a Rockville Centre Republican  calls for officials to review security at private pipelines that carry jet fuel and to make recommendations for improvements by the end of 2008. The state could then require companies to enact additional safeguards based on the recommendations. Roy Haase, a spokesman for Buckeye Partners, the Pennsylvania company that operates the tanks at Kennedy, said Buckeye employees “patrol every foot of the pipeline at least once per week.”

headline: Recipe: Tagine of Fish
text: 3 tablespoons olive oil

headline: Bad Month Gets Worse for Maine and the Mets
text: LOS ANGELES, June 12 — Willie Randolph won two World Series rings by age 24, played for demanding managers like Billy Martin and Lou Piniella, and was hired after 12 failed managerial interviews. He says he has seen it all, done it all, in his 36 seasons in professional baseball, and that includes grinding through slumps like the one the Mets are mired in now.

headline: Sale Possible as Ford Considers Its Options for Jaguar and Land Rover
text: DEARBORN, Mich., June 12 — First, Aston Martin left the Ford Motor Company fold. Will Jaguar and Land Rover follow?

headline: Manhattan: Agreement With Metro-North Workers
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority appeared to have averted a possible summer strike on the Metro-North Railroad with the announcement yesterday of agreement on a new contract with the Teamsters Union, which represents track workers. It was the last of a series of union-authority agreements this year. Representatives of the authority and the union refused to disclose the terms of the agreement, which runs through mid-2010. Chris Silvera, secretary-treasurer of Teamsters Local 808, predicted that the local’s 600 members would ratify the agreement this month. Mr. Silvera and the authority’s executive director and chief executive, Elliot G. Sander, made the announcement at a news conference at Grand Central Terminal. Under federal rules that govern commuter railroads, the Teamsters could have gone on strike in July.

headline: Once Upon a Pea
text: THE rhythms of life have changed so much that the idea of shelling peas for a weeknight meal is pretty much out of the question. A weekend leisure activity, perhaps, but for dinner on a Wednesday? Let’s get real.

headline: A Cult Swallows Up Teenagers for a Strange Rental Business
text: One of the most ambitious tonal mash-ups in memory, “Noriko’s Dinner Table” is a domestic comedy, a bloody psychological thriller and a comment on intergenerational tension and the fragility of identity. It’s also a sort of sequel to “Suicide Club,” written and directed by the same filmmaker, Sion Sono, that replays its predecessor’s key event from a new vantage point.

headline: A New Yogurt Maker, With an Eye on Earth
text: Oko, a new frozen yogurt shop in Park Slope, Brooklyn, dispenses only two flavors for now, tangy plain and wild berry, but offers an array of toppings that include fresh raspberries, blackberries, strawberries, diced mango and pineapple, several kinds of nuts and chocolate bits. Cups are $3, $3.75 and $5.

headline: Lamb With a Pesto that Packs a Wallop
text: AUSTRIAN red wines are not the stuff of everyday drinking. That’s mainly because they are not front and center in wine shops and on wine lists. But they should be.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,502 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the following deaths yesterday:

headline: Fat, Glorious Fat, Moves to the Center of the Plate
text: I’M not sure it’s possible to behave with much dignity around seven glistening pounds of pork butt, but on a recent night at Momofuku Ssam Bar, five friends and I weren’t even encouraged to try.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A film review in Weekend on Friday about “Surf’s Up” misidentified the animal that ate Cody’s father. It was a killer whale, not a shark.

headline: On Sinkerball Night, Yankees Keep Rising
text: It was a bad night to be a worm, a lonely night to be an outfielder and — as always, these days — a great night to be a Yankee.

headline: Food Calendar
text: A Taste of the North Sea

headline: A Tale of Two Tonys, Exiting Tormented

headline: Democrats Propose Loan Plan for Coal Plants
text: WASHINGTON, June 12 — As the Senate began debate today on a sprawling bill to reduce oil consumption, top Democrats were circulating a proposal to provide $10 billion in loans for plants that make diesel fuel from coal.

headline: Queens: Man Sentenced for Killing Bridge Painter
text: A homeless man was sentenced yesterday to 23 years in prison for fatally shooting a bridge painter who asked him to move his belongings from a Grand Central Parkway overpass during a painting job in November 2004, prosecutors said. The man, Steven Boyd, 47, pleaded guilty to manslaughter on May 7, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Boyd admitted that when the painter, James Gaviglia, 38, of Middle Village, asked him to move his makeshift shelter from an overpass in Corona, he shot him repeatedly with a pistol, then lit a cigar and waited for the police, Mr. Brown said.

9 P.M. (NBC) LAST COMIC STANDING The search for the funniest people out there goes global in this two-hour season premiere, with stops in Montreal, Sydney and London before heading back to Los Angeles, Minneapolis, San Antonio and Tempe, Ariz. But first, the series’s three scouts — Alonzo Bodden, in white shirt, the Season 3 winner; ANT; and Kathleen Madigan, far left — travel to New York to audition hopefuls for the prize of $250,000, a talent contract with NBC Universal and a half-hour comedy special.

headline: And Now, the Authentic Candidate (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Off the Menu
text: Open Now

headline: Newark: Volunteer Group Official Is Sentenced
text: A former executive vice president of the nonprofit group 100 Black Men of New Jersey was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to 21 months in prison for fraudulently obtaining $156,000 from the organization, federal prosecutors said. The former officer, Keith DaCosta, 44, of Newark, admitted using bank accounts affiliated with the organization for personal use, including hotel stays, meals and a $374 hat, and entering into leases for office equipment with his personal home health care company, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney.

headline: Recipe: Lamb and Bulgur Kibbe With Garlic Yogurt Sauce
text: Time: 40 minutes

headline: A Different Sudan
text: To many of us, Sudan means one thing  the ongoing disaster called Darfur. But scientists flying over Southern Sudan  the site of a separate civil war that finally ended in 2005  have discovered vast numbers of migrating animals: herds of antelope and gazelle that may rival the scale of the great migration in Serengeti.

headline: Federal Grant for a Medical Mission Goes Awry
text: In theory, it was simple: Congress gave two decommissioned Coast Guard cutters to a faith-based group in California, directing that the ships be used only to provide medical services to islands in the Central and South Pacific.

headline: Après Vous, Oscar Wilde (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Clemens Joins Teammates; Johnson Stays in Desert
text: Roger Clemens is not a scheduled starter against the Arizona Diamondbacks this week, yet he was at Yankee Stadium yesterday, roaming the clubhouse and the field like any other teammate. The Yankees have told Clemens he can come and go as he pleases on the days he does not start, but Clemens is here now.

headline: Senators Seek to Penalize China for Trade Policy
text: WASHINGTON, June 13 — A group of leading Republican and Democratic senators, signaling growing Congressional impatience with Chinese trade practices, proposed legislation today aimed at forcing penalties on China over its policy of suppressing the value of its currency to promote exports.

headline: Scrutiny on Tax Rates That Fund Managers Pay
text: The backlash against the tremendous wealth being created by managers of hedge funds and private equity funds may be gaining strength.

headline: Seeking a Bank Robber With a Taste for Hats
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J., June 12  You have to tip your hat, literally, to the man who has robbed 17 banks in northern New Jersey since last fall.

headline: 7 Afghans Die in Erroneous Exchange of Fire
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 12  American-led forces killed seven Afghan policemen and wounded five more in an exchange of fire early Tuesday that Afghan police officials said was a result of mistaken identity.

headline: Orthopedic Surgery (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about the Puerto Rican Day Parade in Manhattan misstated the difference in length between this year’s parade and the one in 1958, which one paradegoer, Tony Flores, took part in as a Boy Scout from Brooklyn. The 1958 parade was eight blocks shorter, not “at least a dozen.”

headline: Vietnamese President to Visit Washington Next Week
text: HANOI, June 13 — President Nguyen Minh Triet of Vietnam is bracing himself for criticism over his country’s human rights record when he travels to Washington next week, the first Vietnamese head of state to do so since the Vietnam War ended 32 years ago.

headline: Day Care Worker Is Convicted of Raping a 4-Year-Old Boy
text: A Queens jury, forced to render a stark judgment on a videotaped confession, yesterday found a day care worker guilty of raping and sexually abusing a 4-year-old boy in her care.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the shooting death of Rudolph Izzi, a loan shark and reputed mobster, included an erroneous reference in some copies to his place of residence. As noted elsewhere in the article, he lived in Brooklyn, not Staten Island.

headline: Left Wrist, Meet Right Wrist
text: He tweaked his wrist last month by muscling practice balls out of a rough as thick and tangled as pompoms on the United States Open course at Oakmont Country Club.

headline: Judge Tries Suing Pants Off Dry Cleaners
text: WASHINGTON, June 12 — Roy L. Pearson Jr. wanted to dress sharply for his new job as an administrative law judge here. So when his neighborhood dry cleaner misplaced a pair of expensive pants he had planned to wear his first week on the bench, Judge Pearson was annoyed.

headline: Hart Was Doyenne of the Arts and Showbiz
text: Frank Sinatra’s “You Make Me Feel So Young” might seem a peculiar choice to open a memorial celebration. But if the person being remembered is Kitty Carlisle Hart, the entertainer and culture grande dame who died in April but was singing the standards in cabaret bars and on stages well into her 90s, it makes plenty of sense.

headline: Letters
text: Converted by Meatballs

headline: Kibbe Raw (Good) and Cooked (Better)
text: MOST of the time, my husband, Daniel, is an eager accomplice when it comes to my more outré culinary cravings. He has gamely sampled braised chicken feet in Chinatown, crispy tripe tacos in Hell’s Kitchen and even the deep-fried Gummi octopuses I made one afternoon in an oil-ridden frenzy. But when it came to raw lamb kibbe for dinner, he put the kibosh on my plan.

headline: Bush Lobbies G.O.P. Senators on Immigration
text: WASHINGTON, June 12  In an effort to revive a crippled immigration bill, President Bush visited the Capitol on Tuesday to try to assure wary Senate Republicans personally that border security was a driving force behind his push for changes in immigration law.

headline: Indonesia Says Militant Is in Custody
text: Indonesian police confirmed today that Abu Dujana, a major southeast Asia terrorist leader, had been arrested and is in custody in Central Java.

headline: Shiite Leaders Appeal for Calm After New Shrine Attack
text: BAGHDAD, June 13 — One of Iraq’s most sacred Shiite shrines, the Imam al-Askari mosque in Samarra, was attacked and severely damaged again today, just over a year after a previous attack on the site unleashed a tide of sectarian bloodletting across the country.

headline: Correction
text: An article yesterday about the high number of arrests at this year’s Puerto Rican Day Parade in Manhattan referred incorrectly to the estimated number of arrests at last year’s parade. The figure of 50 to 60 arrests last year was taken from an article that ran in The Times in 2006; the estimate did not come from the New York police in the course of reporting yesterday’s article. (The 2006 article cited “at least 50” arrests, but the Police Department disputes that figure, saying 151 people were arrested.) An article about the reaction to this year’s arrests appears today.

headline: Hamas Forces Seize Control Over Much of Gaza
text: JERUSALEM, June 13 — Hamas forces consolidated control over much of Gaza on Wednesday, taking command of the main north-south road and blowing up a Fatah headquarters in Khan Yunis, in the south.

headline: For the Mets’ Captain, the Sea Is Always Calm
text: LOS ANGELES, June 12 — It was April 2005, and the sheen of Willie Randolph’s first season as the Mets’ manager was still fresh. The losses piled up — one, two, three, four, five in a row — placing him in danger of returning to Shea Stadium for the home opener without a victory. Pressure? For someone who won two World Series rings by age 24, played for Billy Martin and Lou Piniella and was hired after 12 failed managerial interviews, this, he said, was nothing.

headline: Google to Reduce History of Personal Searches
text: PARIS, June 12  Faced with criticism from privacy activists and questions from the European Union, Google announced on Tuesday that it would cut back on how long it keeps the Web search histories of users, to 18 months from 24.

headline: Dissident Shareholders Send Message to Yahoo
text: SANTA CLARA, Calif., June 12  Yahoo said on Tuesday that about a third of its shareholders had voted against the re-election of one or more company directors. The vote against some directors had been recommended by three Wall Street advisory firms who complained about what they described as excessive executive pay.

headline: Lehman Profit Climbs 27%
text: Lehman Brothers, the investment bank, reported today that its profit in the second quarter had increased 27 percent, a record for the firm and potentially auguring a good week for Wall Street earning reports.

headline: Searching for the Secret to Attracting the Youth Vote
text: Maybe it started with Howard Dean, or maybe it was Al Gore, or maybe it was as long ago as when Bill Clinton talked about his underwear on MTV, but campaigns are putting a lot of energy into courting the youth vote. Links to the online hangouts of the under-25 set, YouTube, MySpace and Facebook among them, are all over the candidates’ home pages, especially those of the Democratic candidates. Some campaigns have hired youth vote coordinators to mobilize young voters.

headline: Trying to Give Police the Right Answer, Even When It’s Wrong
text: Ask him a question. Ozem Goldwire holds onto it across a half-dozen conversational detours, and keeps working on it until he is sure you have gotten precisely what you were looking for.

headline: Queens: Doctor Charged With Insurance Fraud
text: A doctor who works at a clinic in Jamaica has been charged with insurance fraud, accused of billing insurance companies for tests that were never performed on victims of motor vehicle accidents, prosecutors said yesterday. The doctor, Alexander Israeli, 53, of Middle Village, was arraigned in Criminal Court on Monday night on charges of grand larceny and insurance fraud, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said that Dr. Israeli billed insurance companies last year for $21,000 worth of neurological tests that were not performed. He faces loss of his medical license and up to seven years in prison if convicted, prosecutors said.

headline: Mickelson Plays in Pain Because It’s the Open
text: OAKMONT, Pa., June 12 — With a black wrap covering his injured left wrist, Phil Mickelson played nine holes at Oakmont Country Club on Tuesday with diminished expectations.

headline: Dispute Over Arrest Pattern at the Puerto Rican Parade
text: Details of the complaints by police against the people arrested at the Puerto Rican Day Parade on Sunday outline a pattern in the way they were arrested, according to documents released yesterday.

headline: College Leaders Push for Carbon Neutrality
text: Cape Cod Community College is erecting a wind turbine and will soon install solar panels. The dining halls at Furman University in Greenville, S.C., are offering more fresh produce from local farms. Arizona State University is distributing free bus passes to every student, employee and faculty member.

headline: China Inflation Hits 3.4 Percent in May
text: Inflation in China reached a 27-month high of 3.4 percent in May, government statisticians announced today, but the price increases were heavily concentrated in food while separate figures for growth in the money supply and loans suggested that the broader economy was not yet overheating.

headline: South Africa Strike Foreshadows Political Contest
text: JOHANNESBURG, June 12 — A nationwide strike by South Africa’s public-service unions lumbered into its 12th day on Tuesday, shuttering schools, crippling hospitals and hamstringing courts — but not moving President Thabo Mbeki’s government far toward a settlement.

headline: Europe Plans a Quieter and Cleaner Passenger Jet
text: BRUSSELS, June 12 — Driven by concerns that it is falling behind on airplane development, the European Union is planning a 1.6 billion-euro public-private partnership to help its aviation industry develop a generation of greener and quieter aircraft.

headline: Amid Alleluias, Festival Hall Resurrected
text: LONDON, June 12 — All four of the resident orchestras at the Royal Festival Hall — the London Philharmonic, the Philharmonia Orchestra, the London Sinfonietta and the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment — took part in the grand and substantive gala concert on Monday night to reinaugurate the hall after a major two-year, $234 million renovation. The refurbishment was both keenly and nervously anticipated. When the Festival Hall opened in 1951 on the south bank of the Thames, this formidable concrete building, rising almost literally from the ashes of World War II, was embraced as a symbol of British fortitude and renewal.

headline: After Finally Admitting Killing, Man Finally Goes Free
text: Carmine Carini had a decision to make. He was 47 years old. Nearly half that time he had spent in prison for the murder of a Brooklyn record shop owner, a man shot three times to the head and dumped from a car in the watermark style of a Mafia execution.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A listing of results on Monday from the Prefontaine Classic track-and-field meet in Eugene, Ore., reversed the top two finishers in the men’s high jump. Tora Harris was first and Jesse Williams second.

headline: The ‘Combatant’ and the Evidence (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Place to Go if You Like It Hot
text: MA la, the uppercut combo of chili heat and the peculiar numbing effect of the Sichuan peppercorn, is the flavor profile most associated with Sichuan eating.

headline: Defense Rests in Black Trial
text: CHICAGO, June 12 (Bloomberg News) — Conrad M. Black, the former chairman of Hollinger International, and three other former company executives rested their defense on federal fraud charges Tuesday without taking the stand. Closing arguments are set for Monday.

headline: New Presidential Debate Site? Clearly, YouTube
text: The quadrennial ritual of presidential debates has long followed a tried and true format.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A map on Monday with an article about fears that tourism in the Niagara Falls area will suffer when tighter border restrictions take effect mislabeled an island in the Niagara River between New York and Ontario. It is Goat Island, not Duck Island.

headline: Before Fourth Season, a Chat With Fifth and Sixth Graders
text: TRENTON, June 12  Eli Manning sat in the principal’s office Tuesday, waiting to address a group of fifth and sixth graders.

headline: A Home Big Enough to House the Cousins
text: The setting of “Tyler Perry’s House of Payne,” a new comedy on TBS, is a tidy ranch with black shutters and neat landscaping. The proprietor, Curtis Payne, known as Pops, is an aging firefighter who has done well enough to own a place to maintain his extended family.

headline: Giant Bird-Like Dinosaur Fossil Found in China
text: Scientists have uncovered a huge surprise in the Inner Mongolia region of northern China: the fossil skeleton of an unusually robust bird-like dinosaur that lived 70 million years ago. The animal appeared to be a young adult 25 feet long and weighing 3,000 pounds and, if it had lived longer, would probably have grown even larger.

headline: In Mamaroneck, Taking a More Hospitable Approach to Day Laborers
text: MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 12 — The placard, about the size of a record cover, was perched on the sidewalk outside a church on Old White Plains Road, so discreet it could have easily escaped the notice of drivers passing by. Steel-blue type on a white background offered a modest invitation to contractors used to trolling the streets here in search of help: Hire Workers!

headline: Symptoms Found for Early Check on Ovary Cancer
text: Cancer experts have identified a set of health problems that may be symptoms of ovarian cancer, and they are urging women who have the symptoms for more than a few weeks to see their doctors.

headline: Bill Is Delayed by Republicans Over Earmarks
text: WASHINGTON, June 12 — No longer in charge of writing spending bills since they lost their majority, House Republicans are unleashing a previously unseen indignation at the pet projects that individual lawmakers attach to such bills.

headline: Earnhardt Will Announce His Decision and May Join Nemesis
text: Dale Earnhardt Jr., the most popular driver in Nascar, will announce this morning what team he will race for beginning in 2008 amid indications that he will sign with the powerhouse Hendrick Motorsports.

headline: Earnhardt Joins Nascar Powerhouse Hendrick
text: MOORESVILLE, N.C., June 13 - Dale Earnhardt Jr. flashed a broad smile as he stood next to car owner Rick Hendrick, the cameras clicking as they captured the moment that will change Nascar forever.

headline: Recipe: Confit Byaldi
text: FOR PIPERADE

headline: Senate Democrats Propose Loans for Coal-Based Fuel Plants
text: WASHINGTON, June 12 — As the Senate began debate Tuesday on a sprawling bill to reduce oil consumption, top Democrats were circulating a proposal to provide $10 billion in loans for plants that make diesel fuel from coal.

headline: Subpoena Vote Is Set in Wiretap Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON, June 12  The Senate Judiciary Committee is set to vote Thursday on whether to authorize subpoenas to gain access to Justice Department documents related to the National Security Agency’s domestic wiretapping program, including a series of secret legal opinions.

headline: 2 Ex-Bush Aides Subpoenaed in Attorneys Case
text: WASHINGTON, June 13 — Two former White House officials were subpoenaed today as Congressional Democrats intensified pressure on the Bush administration over the dismissals of eight United States attorneys.

headline: Cut the Nuclear Arsenal (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Las Vegas Caters to Asia’s High Rollers
text: LAS VEGAS — Without the dreamy postcard views of the neon-pulsing Strip, visitors to the V.I.P. lounge at the top of the Venetian hotel and casino here might think they had taken an elevator to someplace in Hong Kong or Shanghai.

headline: Ireland: Greens Close to Coalition Deal With Ahern
text: The Green Party has moved closer to a coalition accord with Fianna Fail, the party of Prime Minister Bertie Ahern, left, after the parties reached agreement on climate change, education and political reform, the Green Party negotiator, Dan Boyle, said in comments on RTE radio in Dublin. Negotiations between the parties resumed yesterday after talks collapsed on June 8. Mr. Ahern, in power since 1997, turned to the Greens after his party failed to win enough seats in the May 24 election to allow it to govern alone. Ireland’s new Parliament will meet tomorrow, with lawmakers selecting a speaker and prime minister.

headline: Lehman Brothers Profit Climbs 27%
text: Lehman Brothers, the investment bank, reported yesterday that its profit in the second quarter rose 27 percent, a record for the firm and potentially auguring a good week for Wall Street earning reports.

headline: Giuliani Sets Forth a Dozen Priorities for His Presidency
text: BEDFORD, N.H., June 12 — Rudolph W. Giuliani on Tuesday outlined what he said would be the 12 major priorities of his presidency, among them fighting terrorism, cutting taxes, achieving energy independence and, in a new theme for him, overhauling the education system.

headline: Cricket Coach’s Death Not a Murder, Police Say
text: MEXICO CITY, June 12 — Bob Woolmer, the coach of the Pakistani cricket team who was found unconscious in his hotel room in March after his team was ousted from the Cricket World Cup, was not murdered as the police had previously thought but died of unspecified natural causes, the Jamaican police said Tuesday.

headline: Sudan Relents on Peacekeepers in Darfur
text: DAKAR, Senegal, June 12  After resisting for months, Sudan has agreed to a joint United Nations and African Union force of nearly 20,000 peacekeepers in Darfur, its western province and the site of one of the world’s worst humanitarian crises, the African Union said Tuesday.

headline: Stirring Composers, Musicians and Theater Artists Into a Stew
text: Informal salon concerts are largely a thing of the distant past. But Jed Distler and Célia Cooke, the directors of ComposersCollaborative inc, offer an attractive update of that old model with Serial Underground, the monthly series they organize at the Cornelia Street Café in the West Village. There, composers, musicians and theater artists mix and mingle, presenting recent pieces and works in progress in an unbuttoned setting.

headline: Cornell Medical School to Get $400 Million for Research Centers
text: A group of philanthropists led by Joan and Sanford I. Weill plans to announce today that it has pledged $400 million to build research centers and to recruit senior scientists for Weill Medical College of Cornell University.

headline: Glitch Blamed for Fire Alarm on Orbiter
text: Astronauts and mission managers scrambled yesterday when a fire alarm went off on the Russian part of the International Space Station. Within 20 minutes, however, the problem was determined to be a software glitch.

headline: Attracting Vacation Home Renters
text: Several years ago, after arriving at her vacation rental on Oneida Lake in upstate New York, Christine Karpinski noticed that the house lacked an essential amenity: a barbecue. “I called the owner and he agreed to bring me one,” Ms. Karpinski said. “How can you rent out a place without a grill?” Ms. Karpinski maintains the Web site How to Rent by Owner.

headline: Audience Participation Welcome (but Shhh)
text: There are plenty of singers who inspire their fans to sing along. And then there is Feist, the indie-rock chanteuse from Canada. She is a restless polymath with a catalog of great songs and a voice like carved steam. At Town Hall on Monday, during the first of two sold-out shows, she encouraged audience participation, but no one seemed eager to drown her out. When Feist opens her mouth, there is only one reasonable reaction: shut up.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An art review in Weekend on Friday about group shows at New York galleries referred incorrectly to a show at CRG in Chelsea that includes the work of Colby Bird, who has a sculpture in one of the group shows reviewed, “In Defense of Ardor,” at Bellwether in Chelsea. The show at CRG is a two-man show of work by Mr. Bird and Joshua Fields, not a solo show by Mr. Bird.

headline: Answers Sought in Guard Smuggling Case
text: HOUSTON, June 12 — A soldier awarded a Purple Heart for service in Iraq and two other Texas National Guardsmen charged with human smuggling remained in jail in Laredo on Tuesday as federal authorities expanded their investigation into how 24 illegal immigrants wound up in a Guard-leased van deep into Texas.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on June 4 about Abdul Kadir and Russell M. Defreitas, two of the four men accused of plotting to blow up Kennedy International Airport, referred imprecisely to Mr. Kadir’s role in the Linden Fund, a charity in Guyana, his home country. As a board member and former mayor of Linden, Guyana’s second-largest city, he used his contacts to help speed up the distribution of money and supplies sent to Guyana by donors in the United States, but he was not “in charge” of receiving and disbursing money and supplies.

headline: Between Dust and Deliverance
text: Ramallah, West Bank

headline: China: Cities Suffer More Pollution
text: Air and water quality in Chinese cities is worsening, according to a report of the Environmental Protection Administration. According to the agency’s latest survey, just 38 percent of 585 cities monitored enjoyed air quality that reached minimal national standards, down from 45 percent in a 2005 survey.

headline: Guess Who’s Back?
text: Every year, it seems, Mariano Rivera struggles for a bit and the fans and the news media wonder if he’s finally lost it. It’s a legitimate story, because some day, Rivera won’t be Rivera anymore. But that day is not upon us.

headline: Fat, Glorious Fat, Moves to the Center of the Plate
text: Frank Bruni says that “these are times of bold temptation, as well as prompt surrender, for a carnivorous glutton in New York.”

headline: It’s Not “All Geek to Me”
text: Arrrgh, bad news: evidently, the ratings for “It’s All Geek to Me” (my funny tech show) were low. So Discovery execs have decided NOT to broadcast the final 2 episodes on the Science Channel. Instead, they intend to put those two episodes, complete, here on the Web. (That’s what they SAY. They’re still not posted.)

headline: The Markings on the Wall
text: Additional images from the exhibit "Projects 85: Dan Perjovschi" at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: 36 Hours in Milan
text: Shopping, strolling and eating on a weekend tour of this Italian city.

headline: Hitting the Road
Mega Dittos
text: I am a Chicago high school teacher who (unfortunately) rarely travels or writes, on a journey to Africa with an award-winning international correspondent who reports with inspired, accessible, concise language and offers a breadth of knowledge from years of working and living in foreign lands. With so many experienced writers and entertainers sharing stories and reports from Africa, why in the world would you ever want to read my blog? I hope my daily photographs and stories will reach and relate to other uninformed young people who seek a fresh, unlearned and detailed perspective into the daily life and youth culture of sub-Sahara Africa.

headline: Visions of Basel
text: Additional images from the international art fair in Switzerland.

headline: Expanding the Text
text: A look at productions by the Target Margin Theater company.

headline: On the Waterfront
text: Additional images from the Brooklyn waterfront, which the National Trust for Historic Preservation has declared an endangered site.

headline: Currents
text: Landlocked goldfish worth their weight in 24-karat and more.

headline: Is Green Just About Profits?
text: One of the things that is really bothering me these days is that “going green” is so often presented as an opportunity for making money. Yesterday we hear the potentially good news that the E.U. is planning a 1.6 billion Euro public project called Clean Sky to develop greener aircraft.

headline: Physical Culture | Gear Test, Gloves
text: Katherine Whiteside, the author of “The Way We Garden Now,” tests gloves while building a raised-bed potager.

headline: War Returns to Sri Lanka
text: After a cease-fire that quelled violence for nearly four years, war is again scarring Sri Lankan life.

headline: United States Climbs in FIFA Rankings
text: The United States men's soccer team, fresh off three straight first-round shutout victories in the Concacaf Gold Cup, is riding an eight-game unbeaten streak under the team's new coach, Bob Bradley.

headline: A Caregiver Not in a Giving Mood
text: Read that a play is about a woman who finds romance while caring for her disabled father, and your treacle meter is likely to start flashing an urgent warning: well-intentioned feel-good mush ahead. That plot description fits “The Rules of Charity,” but this dark, scalding play by John Belluso is not remotely what you’re expecting.

headline: Life Lessons, Behind the Wheel
text: The “are we there yet?” of a family trip is magnified — or condensed — into two acts in Anastasia Traina’s play “From Riverdale to Riverhead.” The title is purely descriptive; it denotes the journey of three achingly stereotyped sisters and their niece to visit the son of one of the sisters, Louise, in jail. Virtually the entire action of the piece, which opened last weekend at Studio Dante, consists of four women riding, talking, bickering and crying in a car.

headline: For This Group, the Party’s Over
text: “Rabbit,” a new play by the young British writer Nina Raine, feels a bit like an episode of “Friends” set in an abbey. It is chatty and high-strung. It is stark and funereal. It is Bella, the central figure, a woman in glittery high heels and an unadorned black dress who embodies a tension that Ms. Raine tries to grab but can never quite clutch — the tension between the enticement of sex and the denial of its most profound implications.

headline: Notes on the Loser’s Lounge
text: The Mint Theater makes other companies look ridiculous by lovingly producing forgotten plays that are much better than many that are repeatedly revived.

headline: Blackstone Plans a June I.P.O.
text: The Blackstone Group wants investors to save the date: The buyout shop’s much-awaited initial public offering is set for the week of June 25, underwriters said.

headline: V.C.’s High on Botanical Drug Companies
text: Phytomedics, a developer of an arthritis drug based on extracts from the Chinese Thunder God Vine, has nabbed $9 million in Series B funding, an event that the Red Herring suggests could signal new market opportunities for plant-based medicines and a tempering of Big Pharma’s suspicion of herbal remedies.

headline: Greenberg Files Rebuttal in Lawsuit
text: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, tried to turn the tables on his accusers on Tuesday. In a court filing in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, Mr. Greenberg said testimony from three A.I.G. employees would discredit recent accusations by the State of New York.

headline: Bank to End Deals With Officers’ Kin
text: Apparently, there has been a little too much family spirit at Commerce Bancorp. The bank, based in Cherry Hill, N.J., said it would end contracts with companies owned by executives and their relatives by the end of the year, halting a practice that has drawn the attention of regulators.

headline: Defense Rests in Black Trial
text: Conrad M. Black, the former chairman of Hollinger International, and three other former company executives rested their defense on federal fraud charges Tuesday without taking the stand. Closing arguments are set for Monday.

headline: Ex-Citi Executives’ Buyout Shop Makes Investment
text: Brysam Global Partners, a private equity firm set up by two former Citigroup executives, has made its first investment, taking a $230 million stake in a Mexican financial services group. Brysam, which was started earlier this year by Robert Willumstad, former president and chief operating officer of Citi, and Marge Magner, former chairman and chief executive of Citi’s global consumer group, will take a 28 percent stake in Ixe Grupo Financiero.

headline: New Century Dismisses 2 Top Executives
text: New Century Financial, the bankrupt housing lender, disclosed on Tuesday that it had fired its chief executive and an executive vice president and named its chief restructuring officer to the post of chief executive.

headline: Former Executive of CA Will Pay Restitution
text: A federal judge in Brooklyn approved an agreement Tuesday in which the former sales chief of CA, Stephen Richards, who pleaded guilty in an accounting fraud case at the company, will pay more than $29 million in restitution.

headline: Morgan Stanley Settles Metals Lawsuit
text: Morgan Stanley will pay $4.4 million to settle a class-action lawsuit with brokerage clients who bought precious metals and paid storage fees, according to a court filing.

headline: Openads Gets First Venture Funding
text: Openads, a supplier of open-source online advertising software, has received $5 million in initial venture funding from a group led by Index Ventures. Openads’ ad-server technology competes with DoubleClick, which Google recently acquired, but at a different end of the market, Reuters reported.

headline: Suitor Revises Bid for Chicago Board
text: IntercontinentalExchange resubmitted a proposal Tuesday to acquire Chicago Board of Trade Holdings, with enhancements that included allowing the Chicago board’s shareholders to receive cash instead of stock.

headline: A Chinese Company Fights Its French Partner
text: A dispute between Groupe Danone, the French multinational company, and a brash Chinese executive has escalated into a battle for control of the country’s largest beverage maker, in what some observers are calling a cautionary tale.

headline: Ford Confirms Review of Luxury Brands
text: Ford Motor confirmed Tuesday that it was working with financial advisers to sort out the future of Jaguar and Land Rover, which have been rumored to be up for sale for more than a year.

headline: HSBC Executive to Take Top Post at ANZ
text: The head of HSBC‘s Asian business, Michael Smith, unexpectedly resigned to become chief executive of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, signaling that ANZ will continue an aggressive expansion into Asia. Mr. Smith, 50, who worked for HSBC for 29 years, succeeds John McFarlane, who ran the bank for a decade.

headline: Four Banks Ordered to Stand Trial in Parmalat Case
text: A Milan judge has ordered four banks, Morgan Stanley, Deutsche Bank, UBS and Citigroup, to stand trial in connection with the 2003 bankruptcy of the Italian dairy company Parmalat, the banks said. Judge Cesare Tacconi set the date for Jan. 22, the four firms confirmed Wednesday.

headline: Frugal Traveler: Columbus, Ind.
text: In Columbus, Ind., the Frugal Traveler saves money on lodging by staying with a family he found through CouchSurfing.com.

headline: Santander Considers Real Estate Sale to Fund Bank
text: Santander Central Hispano, Spain’s biggest bank, may raise 4 billion euros ($5.3 billion) selling real estate assets including the bank’s headquarters to provide funds for its banking business. The lender hopes to make a 1.4 billion euro gain by selling or signing lease-backs for 44 buildings in Spain, including its new headquarters at Boadilla del Monte outside Madrid, a spokeswoman for the bank told Bloomberg News on Wednesday.

headline: An Increasingly Visible D.E. Shaw Hires Its First P.R. Executive
text: As D.E. Shaw continues to ramp up its public persona — increasingly taking an active role in pressuring companies to shape-up — it seems the firm felt it needed someone to take care of its burgeoning new image.

headline: Hong Kong Cozies Up to Hedge Funds
text: Hong Kong’s Securities and Futures Commission is planning to simplify licensing requirements to make it easy for hedge fund managers to set up shop there, HedgeFund.Net reported. The commission will speed up the licensing process and exempt some staff members of hedge fund firms from having to take exams. Firms that are already licensed or registered in the United States or United Kingdom will benefit from an expedited licensing process, the agency said.

headline: Dissident Shareholders Send a Message to Yahoo
text: Yahoo said on Tuesday that about a third of its shareholders had voted against the re-election of one or more company directors. The vote against some directors had been recommended by three Wall Street advisory firms who complained about what they described as excessive executive pay.

headline: Ackman’s Pershing Opposes Ceridian Sale
text: Ceridian‘s largest shareholder, Pershing Square Capital Management, has opposed the company’s sale to Thomas H. Lee Partners and Fidelity National Financial, saying the offer is too low.

headline: ComScore Eyes $80 Million I.P.O.
text: ComScore, an Internet market-research company, plans to raise as much as $80 million in an initial public offering, according to a regulatory filing.

headline: As Murdoch Looms, a Shake-Up in Newsroom of Journal
text: The Wall Street Journal, already roiled by a proposed takeover by Rupert Murdoch, will announce on Wednesday a major newsroom shake-up, including the reassignment and replacement of several top editors, The New York Times reported.

headline: Barclays May Sweeten Cash Portion of ABN Offer
text: Barclays has drawn up contingency plans to restructure its all-share offer for ABN Amro, the Dutch bank, with a significant cash sweetener in case it is forced into a full-blown takeover battle, The Financial Times reported.

headline: May Is Banner Month for Venture-Backed I.P.O.’s
text: Venture-backed initial public offerings had their best month in years last month as 11 companies raised $1.6 billion from I.P.O.s on American exchanges. That figure represents the most money raised since August 2004 when the debut of Google raised that figure to nearly $1.9 billion, according to statistics released Tuesday by Thomson Financial and the National Venture Capital Association.

headline: Banks Try to Distance Themselves from ‘Covenant-Lite’ Frenzy
text: The debate over whether the less-restrictive loans that banks have been handing out at an unprecedented rate to private equity groups will end in more bankruptcies is far from settled, as DealBook noted on Tuesday.

headline: In the Hamptons, a Hedge Row Goes Public
text: With a single e-mail, a hedge fund chief, James Chanos, delivered all the ingredients of a Wall Street gossip item tailor-made for a slow week in mid-June.

headline: Jones Apparel in Talks to Sell Barneys to Dubai Fund, Report Says
text: The Jones Apparel Group is nearing a deal to sell its Barneys New York luxury department store chain to a private-equity firm owned by the Dubai government, The New York Post reported, in a deal that may worth about $950 million.

headline: Rubin Urges Scrutiny of Private-Equity Tax Treatment
text: The backlash against the tremendous wealth being created by managers of hedge funds and private equity funds may be gaining strength, The New York Times noted. On Tuesday, a former treasury secretary, Robert E. Rubin, made a case for doubling the tax rate paid by private equity and hedge fund managers.

headline: G.O.P. Rivals Gear Up for Thompson
text: While former Tennessee Senator Fred Thompson stopped short of officially announcing his candidacy for president on The Tonight Show with Jay Leno last night, he made his intentions clear enough. Though he told the late night audience that he has “never craved” the presidency, he expressed an interest in the job. Mr. Thompson’s supporters will more than likely have to wait until next month for an actual announcement.

headline: Group Is Said to Offer Bid for Macquarie Stake in Rome Airports
text: A group of investors based in Italy made an informal offer on Tuesday to buy out Macquarie‘s 45 percent stake in Rome’s airports for about 1.1 billion euros ($1.5 billion), The Financial Times reported. The Australian financial firm is considering whether to take the offer or to counter by buying the Italian group’s 51 percent stake, the paper said.

headline: Mourning Mr. Wizard
text: One of the bigger YouTube sensations so far can be credited to an ingenious combination of a two-liter bottle of Diet Coke and and a few Mentos. But the inspiration behind it stretches all the way back to the 1950s and Don Herbert, who died on Tuesday at 89.

headline: Sites on the 2007 list of most-endangered historic places designated by the National Trust for Historic Preservation.
text: 1. Brooklyn's Industrial Waterfront. Once a booming 19th-century industrial waterfront supported by generations of immigrants, Brooklyn's heritage is at risk as historic dockyards and factories are being demolished by developers anxious to cash in on the area's newly hip status, the trust says.

headline:
Living With Music:
A Playlist by George Saunders
text: On Wednesdays, this blog will be the delivery vehicle for “Living With Music,” a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage. Why? Because books and music, on good days, just seem to go together. And because the “celebrity playlists” on iTunes never get around to asking writers to pitch in.

headline: Things Fall Together
text: Chinua Achebe has won the Man Booker International Prize [NYT / Guardian], reportedly beating out writers like Salman Rushdie, Philip Roth, Alice Munro, Carlos Fuentes and Michael Ondaatje.

headline: Attacks on a Revered Shrine
Game Geeks Against Climate Change
Searching for the Secret to the Youth Vote
text: Will links to MySpace and Facebook bring voters under 25 to the polls in record numbers?

headline: Considering Cyprus?
text: Troulli

headline: Factional Fighting in Gaza
text: The Hamas party further consolidated its control of northern Gaza in Palestinian factional battles.

headline: Piggy Memories
text: In today’s Dining section, I write about the proliferation of restaurants and dishes that promote eating with fatty, meaty abandon. This kind of eating often involves pork, and it often involves offal. The restaurants and dishes in question put a diner in touch with his or her most carnivorous, gluttonous, barbaric self, and they leave a diner with fingers slicked with grease and a belly filled, quite possibly, with belly (pork, lamb).

headline: United States Gets Its Groove Back
text: The United States cemented its position Tuesday at the top of Group B with a convincing 4-0 drubbing of El Salvador in the Gold Cup at Gillette Stadium in Foxboro, Mass.

headline: Goldman Gets a Spot on Blackstone’s I.P.O. Team
text: Amid all the fuss over Stephen Schwarzman’s $400 million paycheck, another interesting nugget in Blackstone Group‘s latest I.P.O. prospectus went largely overlooked: Goldman Sachs, which had previously been left out of the club of investment banks underwriting Blackstone’s $4.7 billion public offering, has been added to the list.

headline: Talking Shop With Cisco’s Dealmaker
text: Cisco isn’t afraid to make surprising deals — even big ones. In March, it announced a $3.2 billion acquisition of WebEx, causing several pundits to wonder why the company, which makes networking gear, would buy a videoconferencing firm. That deal came just after the much smaller acquisition of Tribe.net, a social-networking Web site that had long been eclipsed by MySpace, Facebook, and others.

headline: Boutique Hotels Berlin — Q!
text: Berlin, so hip in so many ways, hasn’t been on the leading-edge of the trend in designer hotels. That’s either good or bad, depending on whether you find these minimalist places exciting or an excuse to charge five-star prices for closet-size rooms. But now there are a growing number of hotels that are safeguarding Berlin’s reputation as one of Europe’s coolest cities.

headline: The Trevi Fountain Gets a Break
text: Herbert Muschamp, a former architecture critic for The New York Times, mused last December that the Trevi Fountain had been running for so long that it “wouldn’t mind being stopped, for its life must be getting tiresome:”

headline: Beaujolais Delights
text: I’ve had so many great bottles of 2005 Beaujolais that I’m having trouble containing myself. In fact, I’m about to buy a bunch, some for drinking this summer and some to age for a few years, which means my wine storage situation won’t be able to contain itself either. Drink faster, right?

headline: Ceridian Welcomes Better Bids; Stock Creeps Higher
text: So far, the Wasserstein effect is looking pretty muted.

headline: Found Poetry: Sheep on the Run
text: Date: Wed, 13 Jun 2007 12:47:49 -0400To City EditorFrom: Al Baker, police bureau chiefSubject: on the sheep

headline: Subprime Woes Said to Hit Bear Stearns Hedge Fund
text: What is it about big investment banks and hedge funds? UBS closed its fund earlier this year, and Goldman Sachs‘ flagship fund, Global Alpha, has been on a 16-month losing streak.

headline: Shareholder Activism: Boon, Bane or Both?
text: Carl Icahn may believe (and he may be right) that his corporate agitations have created $50 billion in shareholder value over the past few years, as Fortune reported last month. But the larger question — perhaps more important now than in years — remains: Do the actions of activist investors benefit the rest of a company’s stakeholders?

headline: Sheep on the Run: An Update
text: Animals — including this morning’s runaway sheep — appear to be running amok today.

headline: Detroit Forecast: Colder Winter Ahead
text: It may be too early to begin a death watch, but there’s more bad news ahead for Detroit’s once-invincible auto show. Porsche will not have a display at the North American International Auto Show next January. Don’t worry, Detroit, you’ll always have winter.

headline: McCain Campaign Circulates Romney Video
