text: Senator John McCain’s presidential campaign today  circulated a video clip to reporters showing Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor, reiterating at a May 2005 news conference his commitment to maintaining the state’s laws that allowed women to undergo abortions.

headline: Spielberg Gives Clinton Top Billing
text: LOS ANGELES — Steven Spielberg’s exploratory phase is over: He’s a Hillary Clinton man.

headline: Palestine, Split
text: So, Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas has finally declared the struggle between his Fatah party and Hamas a “civil war.” ­Is that, in itself, a sign of progress? Hugh Hewitt thinks it is, at least if it leads the mainstream media to follow his lead:

headline: We Respond to Readers’ Concerns About the House’s Style and Size
text: Most readers have asked if the design of the house will be out of place on Anna Maria. For us, the answer is no.

headline: The Last Word on Bush’s Watch
text: Above, President Bush’s watch, on his wrist, today. On YouTube, an NBC video showing him pocketing it himself in Albania. After speculation — in varying degrees of caution — stretched across the Web and into The Lede on Tuesday, he deserves the last word on this. “I have never seen such a ludicrous story,” Mr. Bush told reporters. “Unbelievable.” (Photo: Ron Edmonds/AP)

headline: My Car Is Better Than A.J. Soprano’s!
text: Everybody knows that “The Sopranos” is a savage critique of American society.

headline: Don’t Buy Local!
text: A lot of people have begun to lose their appetite lately at the thought that their food travels, on average, 1,500 miles from farmer to dinner plate. Buying, instead, from local farmers looks increasingly appealing: We get fresher produce (and benediction from Alice Waters), while also preserving open space and protecting local jobs.

headline: Democrats on Traffic Fees: Thumbs Down
text: The Assembly Democrats’ steering committee — a group of about 30 members picked by Speaker Sheldon Silver to help guide consensus on important policy for the Democratic majority — met today to talk about congestion pricing for New York City.

headline: Vows: Betsy and Pam
text: Betsy Hall and Pam Palumbo are taking a stand and calling their civil union a marriage.

headline: "Courage" From John Edwards
text: First aired on May 3, 2007 in Washington D.C. The ad was created to  coincide with President Bush's veto of the Iraq funding bill.

headline: 9 Hours of Swimming
text: In recent years, the 28.5 mile swim around Manhattan has become increasingly popular among relatively novice swimmers.

headline: In Rwanda With Nick Kristof
text: On his first day in Africa, Will Okun, a teacher from Chicago, visits a school at a refugee camp in Rwanda.

headline: 2008: Obama Girl and More
text: Racing around our e-mails and clocking up the views on YouTube is an incredibly racy, well, steamy new video “I Got a Crush … on Obama” by a student (Obama Girl) and a new Web site, barelypolitical — uh-huh — that teases it’ll give us more info later.

headline: YouTube and the Debates
text: The quadrennial ritual of presidential debates has long followed a tried and true format.

headline: Facts and Figures From the June Swoon
text: After the Mets lost to the Arizona Diamondbacks on June 1, this is how the N.L. East Standings looked:Team*W*L*PCT*GBNY Mets 34 19 .642 —Atlanta 31 23 .574 3.5Philadelphia 26 28 .481 8.5Florida 26 29 .473 9.5Washington 23 32 .418 12

headline: The Pangs of Family Mealtime Guilt
text: In the Life’s Work column in today’s Thursday Styles section, Lisa Belkin writes about the challenges and import of the family dinner.

headline: A Note to TiVonians
text: Thanks to reader Scott L. for this link, which takes you to the Buy.com page for the TiVo Series 3.

headline: A Window Into War (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Efforts to Avert Sectarian Reprisals After Shrine Attack
text: BAGHDAD, June 13 — Two explosions on Wednesday that appeared to have been set by Sunni extremists with links to Al Qaeda toppled the twin golden minarets that were most of what remained of one of Iraq’s most revered Shiite shrines after a devastating bombing by Al Qaeda last year.

headline: Security Is Focus of Revised Effort on Immigration
text: WASHINGTON, June 13 — The White House and senators from both parties mapped out possible changes in a comprehensive immigration bill on Wednesday, so they could better portray it as a way to bolster national security rather than to grant amnesty to millions of illegal immigrants.

headline: Networks Ink Ads Deal for Fall Television Season
text: The upfront market for the 2007-8 television season is getting under way with a large, significant deal between the NBC Universal division of the General Electric Company and the media agencies owned by the WPP Group.

headline: Commuters Still Driving Alone
text: Despite high gasoline prices, the share of commuters driving alone has increased slightly since 2000 while the proportion in car pools dropped and those using mass transit remained about the same, according to a Census Bureau analysis released yesterday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Former Chairman of G.O.P. Will Join Bush’s Inner Circle
text: WASHINGTON, June 13 — Ed Gillespie, a prominent Washington lobbyist, former chairman of the Republican National Committee and longtime adviser to President Bush, will join the White House inner circle as the next counselor to the president, Mr. Bush said Wednesday.

headline: Planned Parks May Cost City Too Much, Group Warns
text: In a city with few backyards, everyone loves a park  but not many people consider who is going to pay for all that grass.

headline: Southeast Asian Terrorist Leader Is Under Arrest
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 13 — After several days of uncertainty, the Indonesian police confirmed Wednesday that Abu Dujana, a major Southeast Asian terrorist leader and a most-wanted fugitive in Indonesia, had been arrested and was in custody in central Java.

headline: Computer Flaw Could Imperil Space Station
text: The Russian computers that help keep the International Space Station in orbit were out of commission for the second day, a glitch that could imperil the $100 billion orbiting laboratory if it is not corrected.

headline: Seeing Manhattan From Sea Level
text: The visibility in some of the waterways surrounding Manhattan is so poor that a swimmer can barely see his own hands. The water is cold, the currents are powerful and debris can include plastic bags and dead fish.

headline: A Phone for the Sly Can Record Calls and Store Them on a Computer
text: The Ipevo Free.2 phone is slim, sleek and potentially sneaky. The phone, which makes calls over the Internet, can record your calls and save them on the hard drive of your computer.

headline: Skateboarding in Olympics: Rad or Bad?
text: It is definitely not cycling. Some say it is not a sport at all. Still, skateboarding  with creative assistance from cycling’s international governing body  appears headed for the Olympics in a bid to make the 111-year-old Games more attractive to a younger audience.

headline: North Carolina: Grahams Say They Will Be Buried at New Library
text: The Rev. Billy Graham announced that he and his wife, Ruth Bell Graham, have decided to be buried at the new Billy Graham Library in Charlotte. Mrs. Graham, who has been bedridden for several years, has reportedly slipped into a coma. Disagreements between the Grahams’ children over the couple’s burial site became public last year. Mrs. Graham, 86, preferred a long-planned site at the Cove, a retreat center in Asheville that she helped design for the Billy Graham Evangelistic Association. Asheville is nearer to the couple’s mountain homestead in Montreat.

headline: Calendar
text: Drawing With David Macaulay

headline: Edwards to Press Insurers on Health Care Premiums
text: DETROIT, June 14 — John Edwards pressed his signature issue of universal health care coverage today, saying that he would force insurance companies to spend at least 85 percent of the premiums they collect directly on patient care.

headline: F.D.A. Panel Votes Against Weight-Loss Drug
text: A drug once viewed as a possible magic bullet against obesity was rejected today by a federal advisory panel, which cited concerns that it increases the risk of neurological and psychiatric problems, including suicide.

headline: Pedaling in Their Dreams
text: Forget about Lance and Landis. Let’s not talk about the Tour. The world’s toughest bicycle race -- the Race Across America -- kicked off at noon on June 10, and it will go nonstop for the next week straight through to a time cutoff on June 22. The coast-to-coast course follows a 3,043-mile route on highways and county roads from Oceanside, Calif., to Atlantic City, and riders pedal around the clock, some forgoing sleep for days on end. Top solo riders average 350 miles a day and will finish after more than a week of near-constant motion. Relay teams of two, four, or eight racers average 500 miles a day. About 200 competitors -- including soloists and team riders -- are competing this year, the biggest showing ever for a competition now in its 26th year. As of Thursday morning, the leading solo riders -- Jure Robic, Wolfgang Fasching, and last year's winner, Daniel Wyss -- were spinning sleeplessly through the high plains of Kansas.

headline: Chase Bank Set to Build Tower by Ground Zero
text: After months of sharp bargaining and threats to relocate, JPMorgan Chase is expected to announce today that it has struck a deal to build a skyscraper near ground zero and move its investment banking headquarters from Midtown, according to government officials and real estate executives.

headline: House Votes to Bolster Database on Gun Buyers
text: WASHINGTON, June 13 — The House voted Wednesday to close a loophole in gun control laws that allowed the Virginia Tech gunman to buy firearms even though he had been committed to a mental hospital. The Senate is likely to follow suit, marking the first time since 1996 that Congress has approved a measure strengthening gun control.

headline: Georgia Aquarium Mourns Another of Its Whale Sharks
text: ATLANTA, June 13 — For the second time in five months, the Georgia Aquarium is mourning one of its stars, a young whale shark named Norton who was euthanized by veterinarians early Wednesday morning after he stopped swimming and slipped to the bottom of his tank.

headline: An Unexpected Odd Couple: Free Markets and Freedom
text: When President Bush declared last week that political openness naturally accompanied economic openness, his counterparts in Beijing and Moscow were not the only ones to object. Liberal and conservative intellectuals, even once ardent supporters, have backed away from the century-old theory that democracy and capitalism, like Paris Hilton and paparazzi, need each other to survive.

headline: Fixing Silent Movies in Windows
text: Fixing Silent Movies In Windows

headline: Losing Count
text: THE Holocaust has always been marked by numbers. There was the numbering of arms in death camps and the staggering death toll where the words six million became both a body count and a synonym for an unspeakable crime. After the Holocaust, Germany performed the necessary long division in paying token reparations to survivors. More recently, Swiss banks and European insurance companies have concealed bank account and policy numbers belonging to dead Jews.

headline: The Pangs of Family Mealtime Guilt
text: ON a recent weeknight at my house, my 16-year-old gobbled leftover pasta and a protein bar at 5:15, then raced off to baby-sit at 5:30. My 13-year-old left for Hebrew school at 6, where dinner is served in the form of pizza and salad (though I can’t swear that he ever eats the salad). My husband, whose usual commute brings him home at about 7, drove directly to pay a condolence call at 7:30, where he snacked on a cookie. I ate low-carb cereal standing at the kitchen sink.

headline: Never Mind the Name: Balanchine’s ’60s Hit Seeks to Sparkle Again
text: George Balanchine’s “Jewels” was said to have been inspired by a visit to Van Cleef & Arpels, though he made sure to say publicly that the ballet had nothing to do with gems. The supposed theme, the jewel-strewn look of the work and several rave reviews made ”Jewels” the kind of hit that ballet seldom had in the mid-1960s, when the work was first performed.

headline: Chase Bank Announces Plan to Build Tower at Ground Zero
text: JPMorgan Chase announced today that it has struck a deal to build a skyscraper near ground zero and move its investment banking headquarters from Midtown.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Sunday about the decline of the South Korean tradition of drinking after work referred incorrectly to Norske Skog, a paper company that acquired a South Korean mill whose hard-drinking culture changed under the new owner. It is Norwegian, not Swedish.

headline: Six Men Charged in Fort Dix Plot Plead Not Guilty
text: CAMDEN, N.J., June 14 — Six men accused of planning to kill soldiers at the Fort Dix military base pleaded not guilty today to the charges against them, accusations that include training with guns, conducting surveillance of military installations and acquiring weapons in preparation for the attack on the base.

headline: Power in the Shower: New Zing for the Bathroom
text: IF taking out a home-equity loan to renovate your bathroom seems too daunting, why not try a quick fix? A new rug, a mat for the shower stall or even a wall-mounted cabinet for extra storage can make a bathroom feel fresh and work more efficiently.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Bob Dylan Wins Asturias Prize

headline: The Mets Just Love to See Clemens Sweat
text: In the amateur draft in June 1981, the Mets took a college outfielder named Terry Blocker with their first-round pick. Blocker would go on to have one hit for the Mets. With their fifth-round pick, the Mets drafted a high school shortstop named Steve Phillips and signed him for $42,000. Phillips never played in the majors.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An illustration with a short article in Science Times on Tuesday about the effect that soot in snow has on warming in the Arctic incorrectly included a penguin. Penguins do not live in the Arctic; the northernmost penguins are those on the Galápagos Islands, around the Equator.

headline: 70 Million Years Ago, Birdlike Giant in China
text: Scientists have uncovered a huge surprise in the Inner Mongolia region of northern China: the fossil skeleton of an unusually robust birdlike dinosaur that lived 70 million years ago. The animal appeared to be a young adult 25 feet long and weighing 3,000 pounds and, if it had lived longer, would probably have grown even larger.

headline: San Francisco Fights Official Over Residency
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 13  For six months or so, Ed Jew, a new member of San Francisco Board of Supervisors, has spoken on all sorts of issues involving this city. He has spoken about San Francisco laws, San Francisco people and even San Francisco animals.

headline: N.B.A. Players to Combat Hunger
text: The National Basketball Players Association yesterday announced its initiative to feed one million people in Kenya, through its formal partnership with the organization Feed the Children.

headline: As the Rich Get Richer, the Nascar Field Tilts
text: MOORESVILLE, N.C., June 13  Dale Earnhardt Jr. flashed a broad smile as he stood next to the race-team owner Rick Hendrick with cameras clicking away, capturing the moment that marked the beginning of a new era in Nascar.

headline: Awaiting Trial, Ex-Labor Leader Puts on a Hard Hat
text: As he walked down West 59th Street yesterday, a burly man in a blue hard hat, he looked like thousands of other electricians in the city.

headline: A Small Rebound in the 2nd Quarter
text: Words like “modest,” “moderate” and “somewhat faster” do not typically describe the type of economy that sends Wall Street on a tear.

headline: Anti-Syrian Lawmaker Killed in Lebanon Blast
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 13 — A powerful bomb exploded at a popular seaside club here on Wednesday, killing a prominent lawmaker and nine other people. It was the deadliest in a string of recent explosions that have rattled this city and shaken its fragile sense of stability.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Sunday about the decline of the South Korean tradition of drinking after work referred incorrectly to Norske Skog, a paper company that acquired a South Korean mill whose hard-drinking culture changed under the new owner. It is Norwegian, not Swedish. (Go to Article)

headline: With Immigration Bill Stalled, Advocates Push Forward
text: LOS ANGELES, June 13 — As officials in Washington discussed ways to revive an immigration bill stalled in the Senate, immigrant advocates moved forward on Wednesday with a new round of lobbying that they hope will lead illegal immigrants out of the shadows.

headline: 4 in Senate Seek Penalty for China
text: WASHINGTON, June 13 — Four leading Democratic and Republican senators proposed legislation Wednesday aimed at penalizing China over its export practices and predicted that they would have the votes to pass it in Congress this year even if it was vetoed by President Bush.

headline: Battle Over Math in New Jersey Drives Off a New Schools Chief
text: Parents, some involved in a campaign against the math teaching in the highly regarded Ridgewood, N.J., school district, were to have met the new superintendent at a reception last Monday night.

headline: Sharing Views of Past, Present and Purgatory
text: One of two things usually happens when something goes on for a long time (long being an outrageously subjective concept in the arts). Either the activity builds in impact, like a Pina Bausch spectacle, or you largely forget it’s there, like a Norah Jones album.

headline: Only Wild Fish Matter in ‘Endangered’ Count, Judge Rules
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 — A federal district judge in Seattle on Wednesday nullified a Bush administration policy that counts hatchery fish along with wild fish when making decisions about which species should be protected under the Endangered Species Act.

headline: Keeper of the Saudi Secrets
text: British Prime Minister Tony Blair seems determined to use his final weeks in office to show how far he has strayed from the pledges of clean government that helped sweep him to power a decade ago. Defending his decision to block a corruption investigation into the sale of fighter jets and other weapons to Saudi Arabia, Mr. Blair said last week that the probe would have led nowhere except to the “complete wreckage” of a vital strategic relationship.

headline: Germany: Anger Over U.S. Lawmaker’s Remark on Schröder
text: German officials heatedly protested remarks made by Representative Tom Lantos, a Democrat of California who is chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, in which he described former Chancellor Gerhard Schröder as a “political prostitute” for taking a job with a Russian state gas company. The government spokesman, Ulrich Wilhelm, said the comment, made in a speech at the dedication ceremony for a victims of Communism memorial in Washington on Tuesday, was “unseemly.” The foreign minister, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, said it had breached the bounds of decorum and was a “discredit” to Mr. Lantos. Mr. Schröder has been criticized within Germany for his new job, overseeing a pipeline project.

headline: In for a Penny, in for the Pounce
text: BASEL, Switzerland, June 13 — “Is there anything left?” Anne Mosseri-Marlio asked as she surveyed the red dots beside many of the paintings in Paula Cooper’s booth.

headline: Mets Try Clubhouse Humor to Offset Their Frustration
text: LOS ANGELES, June 13  Five Mets players sat around a small card table before Tuesday’s game playing dominoes. They were shouting, laughing, enjoying themselves. A few hours later, after another disheartening loss, the only sounds coming from the clubhouse were from the attendants banging dirt off cleats. A few coaches sat at their stalls, their heads lowered. From across the room, John Maine, the losing pitcher, threw a half-filled (half-empty?) water bottle into his locker.

headline: A Sense of Anxiety a Shirt Won’t Cover
text: ON a recent afternoon, Dr. Michelle Copeland, a plastic surgeon whose offices face the Metropolitan Museum of Art, clicked her computer’s mouse as images of young men’s torsos flickered across the screen. Unlike the ancient Greek statues of Herakles or the bronze discus throwers in the newly renovated galleries across the street, the young men in Dr. Copeland’s digital images were a bit different: Rather than bearing the broad, flat chests of Greek athletes, their pectoral areas assumed a fuller, more feminine shape.

headline: Violence Rising in Much of Iraq, Pentagon Says
text: WASHINGTON, June 13 — Violence increased throughout much of Iraq in recent months, despite a security crackdown in Baghdad that at least temporarily reduced sectarian killings there, according to a quarterly assessment of security conditions issued Wednesday by the Pentagon.

headline: Oscar Rules Regarding Producing Are Relaxed
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 13  Producers take heart: It just got a little easier to put your hands on an Oscar.

headline: Losses Are Taking a Toll on the Frustrated Mets
text: LOS ANGELES, June 13 — The Mets are not panicking. They are not scared. Yet the losses are stacking up in staggering fashion, five in a row and 9 in 10 games with the 9-1 drubbing by the Los Angeles Dodgers on Wednesday night, and in small but distinct ways this dreadful stretch is starting to wear on them.

headline: For Those Who Missed the ’60s or Just Can’t Remember
text: FASHION, depending on which designer you ask, is currently about futurism, romanticism, athleticism or the revival of 1980s-ism. Funny how no one ever mentions hippies.

headline: EBay Says Fraud Crackdown Has Worked
text: The online auction giant eBay wants the world to know that it is trying to clean up its site.

headline: Who, Me Take Running Class?
text: WHEN Steve Huda began running nearly three decades ago, he gave little thought to putting one foot in front of the other. “I did what most people do,” said Mr. Huda, 53, a computer specialist from Centennial, Colo. “I just went out and ran.”

headline: China: Automaker Acquires Two Ventures
text: The Shanghai Automotive Company, China’s largest carmaker, agreed to buy out its partners in a truck maker and an auto-parts venture for 1.48 billion yuan ($194 million) to combine and expand its commercial-vehicle operations. The operations being taken over, the Shanghai Huizhong Automotive Manufacturing Company and the Shanghai Wanzhong Automotive Components Company, will become part of a Shanghai Automotive unit, the SAIC Motor Corporation, Shanghai Automotive said. The automaker already owns half of both ventures. The move is in line with a government plan to combine the country’s automakers.

headline: Rudolf Arnheim, 102, Psychologist and Scholar of Art and Ideas, Dies
text: Rudolf Arnheim, a distinguished psychologist, philosopher and critic whose work explored the cognitive basis of art — how we interpret it and, by extension, the world — died on Saturday at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 102.

headline: Iran May Know of Weapons for Taliban, Gates Contends
text: RAMSTEIN AIR BASE, Germany, June 13  The flow of illicit weapons from Iran to Taliban fighters in Afghanistan has reached such large quantities that it suggests that the shipments are taking place with the knowledge of the government in Tehran, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Wednesday.

headline: Barneys Could Be Sold to Dubai Firm
text: The Jones Apparel Group is close to an agreement to sell Barneys New York, the fashionable clothing retailer, for about $825 million to the investment arm of the Dubai government, people involved in the talks said yesterday.

headline: Out-Levi-ing Levi Strauss
text: Tokyo

headline: Tennessee: University Cannot Sell Artwork, Judge Says
text: A Nashville judge has ruled that Fisk University cannot sell artwork from its Stieglitz Collection, including Georgia O’Keeffe’s signature painting “Radiator Building-Night, New York.” Tuesday’s chancery court ruling came in a legal dispute over the university’s right to sell the O’Keeffe and a painting by Marsden Hartley; both were donated by Ms. O’Keeffe in 1949. The university announced plans to sell the two paintings in late 2005 to bolster its endowment and pay for campus improvements.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about the conviction of a Brooklyn man, Gregory Zalevsky, for the 2004 murder of his girlfriend, Irina Ilyina, misstated their ages. He is 52, not 57, and she was 31 at the time of her death, not 34. (Both errors appeared in an article about his trial on June 2, and the incorrect age for Ms. Ilyina first appeared in an article about Mr. Zalevsky’s arrest on July 8, 2004.)

headline: YouTube Passes Debates to a New Generation
text: The quadrennial ritual of presidential debates has long followed a tried and true format.

headline: A Resort Cottage to Go
text: WHEN it became unbearably hot and humid last month in Houston, Jane Moore, a 60-year-old primary school reading consultant, left her house to stay in her park model trailer in South Fork, Colo. “It’s very cool and beautiful here,” she said in a telephone interview, snug in her park model, which looks like an elongated cottage, is surrounded by a white picket fence and overlooks the Rio Grande. She bought the land and the park model in October. “People don’t understand what park models are,” she said. “They’re not tacky.”

headline: Winning Is Best Change That Els Can Make
text: OAKMONT, Pa., June 13 — There have been small scars and deeper bruises in the career of Ernie Els, whether from a surgeon’s blade or the heartbreak of 18 holes gone wrong.

headline: An Obama Patron and Friend Until an Indictment
text: CHICAGO — Antoin Rezko, an entrepreneur of considerable charm who found riches in fast food and real estate, is known around Chicago as a collector of politicians.

headline: Wall St. Journal Will Raise Price to $1.50
text: The Wall Street Journal will raise its weekday newsstand price from $1 to $1.50, starting July 16, the newspaper’s parent, Dow Jones & Company, said yesterday.

headline: Refinery Considered for South Dakota
text: Hyperion Resources, a closely held Dallas investment firm, said it might build an oil refinery in South Dakota to capitalize on record gasoline prices.

headline: Battle for Control of China’s Largest Beverage Maker Escalates
text: SHANGHAI, June 13 — The former chairman of the Wahaha Group and many of the company’s top executives joined forces Wednesday to denounce their longtime partner, Groupe Danone, the French food and beverage giant, and threatened to form a company that would break away from its joint venture.

headline: The Only Thing Missing Is Bananarama
text: AH, cruel summer.

headline: For Democratic Leaders, a Fear That the Focus on the War Has Blurred
text: WASHINGTON, June 13  President Bush had barely left the Capitol after immigration talks there on Tuesday when Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, walked onto the Senate floor to call for a moment of silence. It was time, Mr. Reid said, to pay tribute to American soldiers in Iraq as their death toll reached 3,500.

headline: Justice Dept. Reshapes Its Civil Rights Mission
text: WASHINGTON, June 13 — In recent years, the Bush administration has recast the federal government’s role in civil rights by aggressively pursuing religion-oriented cases while significantly diminishing its involvement in the traditional area of race.

headline: At 44, Wells Is the Anti-Clemens
text: SAN DIEGO, June 10 — The reunions happened to be scheduled for the same day, one at Yankee Stadium, the other at All Souls Episcopal Church in San Diego.

headline: Headphones to Shut Out the World
text: As you may have heard, air travel this summer isn’t going to be pretty.

headline: MacBook Pros Look Like Older Models, but the Innards Are Different
text: Apple rarely makes sweeping changes to its product line, which is why its new MacBook Pro laptops look identical to older models. Only the innards are different, offering improved wireless networking and processing speed.

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q. How can I hide my ugly windows without blocking the light?

headline: A Classico-Minimalist
text: THERE were no turtle rumps, dormice or sows’ vulvas in the freezer of Jesse Browner’s Chelsea kitchen recently, but there was boar meat, and his pantry — a swell pullout number hidden in a cabinet — held a whiffy bottle of garum, a fish-infused oil that smells something like a restaurant’s Dumpster on a really hot day.

headline: Prima Ballerina With Supple Grace and a Will of Steel
text: When Diana Vishneva was 9, she was denied admission to the Vaganova Ballet Academy in Leningrad, the school that has produced generations of stars (Nijinsky, Pavlova, Nureyev and Mikhail Baryshnikov among them). Her spine was malformed and would cause her problems later, the authorities said. And her legs didn’t lift high enough.

headline: Kurt Waldheim, Former U.N. Chief, Is Dead at 88
text: Kurt Waldheim, the former United Nations Secretary General and President of Austria whose hidden ties to Nazi organizations and war crimes was exposed late in his career, died today at his home in Vienna. He was 88.

headline: The Dust Is Thick: It’s Time to Vacuum the Elephants
text: The hydraulic lift lurched up, bringing the back of an African elephant into full view. To Mike Peter Smith, who was cleaning the elephant yesterday, its spine took the form of a gently sloping mountain range with peaks behind the head and near the rear legs.

headline: What if You Met the Enemy and It Really Was You, and Then It Happened Again
text: It isn’t often you walk around a corner and run into yourself, but it happens occasionally in Raw Danger, a survival game in which the player lives through the aftermath of a tsunami as several characters.

headline: The Cat With Only Hats
text: A NEW hat shop seems like a strange place to lament the demise of the hat business. But then the very idea of a hat shop is something of an anachronism.

headline: Germany: VW Narrows American Loss
text: Volkswagen narrowed its North American first-half loss by reducing discounts and warranty claims and concentrating on sales of the most profitable models, the company said. Volkswagen’s sales have fallen this year in the United States as the company prepares new models for 2008. The company sold 91,743 vehicles in the United States in the first five months, a 4.4 percent drop from a year earlier. Sales in 2007 will be flat, Mr. Hallmark said.

headline: A Retreat in Ulster County, Shipped Partly From Bolivia
text: FOUR years ago Henry Scott, a media consultant living in Manhattan, hired Sergio Guardia to design a weekend house on a wooded site in Kerhonkson, N.Y. Mr. Guardia, an architect who was born in Bolivia and trained at Harvard’s Graduate School of Design, came up with plans for a futuristic house set on thick steel beams cantilevered over a hillside.

headline: Mixing, Matching and Mirth for Oakmont’s First 36 Holes
text: OAKMONT, Pa., June 13 — The course at Oakmont Country Club has greens that slope like a funhouse floor and about as much breathing room as polyester knit pants. If the weather this week is hot and dry, the world’s best golfers are liable to stagger through the United States Open with faces longer than the 667-yard 12th hole.

headline: A High-Definition Media PC That Evokes Legendary Technology
text: According to urban legend, aliens crash-landed in the desert outside Roswell, N.M., and their remains are hidden in the Air Force’s Hangar 18. Inside Alienware’s Hangar 18, however, you will find only high-end PC components and high-definition video playback systems.

headline: Queens: 20 Years for Killing Father
text: A Queens woman who killed her father by striking him with a hammer in 2004 was sentenced to 20 years in prison yesterday, prosecutors said. The woman, Laura Martin, 46, pleaded guilty last month in State Supreme Court to manslaughter, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Ms. Martin was charged with beating her father, John Martin, 67, with a hammer in their Long Island City home and then going out to buy drugs. She told the police that he had been attacked during a break-in, Mr. Brown said.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (CBS) PIRATE MASTER It’s never easy at the top — of the mast, that is. Capt. Joe Don, left, is riding high for the moment, but in this reality TV jibe at “Pirates of the Caribbean” there are plenty of buccaneers who are ready to throw him over. In a high-seas version of a straw poll, half the pirate contestants are backing the captain, while the others are ready for a mutiny. They’ll have to find the $35,000 bounty first.

headline: Yes, Kilroy Was Here, Armed With Agitprop
text: Drawing is a verb, according to Richard Serra, and the Romanian artist Dan Perjovschi seems to agree. This spring, as cranes were hoisting Mr. Serra’s steel sculptures into the Museum of Modern Art for his retrospective, Mr. Perjovschi was scaling the eastern wall of the building’s atrium in a cherry picker.

headline: In Health Care, Cost Isn’t Proof of High Quality
text: Stark evidence that high medical payments do not necessarily buy high-quality patient care is presented in a hospital study set for release today.

headline: Stocks Rise on Upbeat Economic Reports
text: Everything Wall Street has been worried about in the last week — rising bond yields, high inflation, the strength of the economy — seemed to weigh less heavily on investors today, and stocks began to recover.

headline: You Can Smooth or Zap but Will the Results Hit Home?
text: IN pursuit of a glowing, smooth, youthful complexion, Ann Runnels, 44, has tried Botox, microdermabrasion, injectable fillers, Fraxel lasers (a treatment said to stimulate cell growth) and the usual array of creams, ointments and $120-a-bottle serums.

headline: House Panel Passes Bill to Cut Subsidies to Student Lenders
text: WASHINGTON, June 13  The House education committee voted Wednesday to cut subsidies to student lenders and to halve the interest rates on a key student loan program over the next five years.

headline: Legislators Grapple Over How to Legalize Medical Marijuana Use
text: ALBANY, June 13  Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders said this week that the use of marijuana for medical purposes should be made legal in New York State.

headline: Next Week
text: A look at the man behind soccer’s Gold Cup, the anti-World Cup with the downmarket reputation, as the tournament moves toward a conclusion. Also, the summer hotspot for tennis: Vermont.

headline: Panel Says Liberian Ex-Leader’s Wealth Hasn’t Vanished
text: DAKAR, Senegal, June 13 — When Charles G. Taylor’s long-awaited trial on 11 war crimes and crimes against humanity opened in The Hague on June 4, Mr. Taylor upended the proceedings by refusing to appear, saying he was too poor to afford his own defense and unhappy with the one provided by the court, despite having amassed a personal fortune estimated at half a billion dollars while in power in Liberia.

headline: Manhattan: St. Vincent Gets New Chief
text: The chief executive of Catholic Health and Human Services in New Jersey has been selected to become the next president of St. Vincent Catholic Medical Centers, the Manhattan-based hospital and health care network, officials at St. Vincent announced yesterday. The new president, Henry Amoroso, will lead St. Vincent as it works to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy this summer, officials said. In addition to leading the Newark-based hospital and charity system, Mr. Amoroso was principal adviser on urban health care to Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark, officials said.

headline: Congressional Payback (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Personal (pH) Balance
text: PATRICIA O’HARA considers herself a methodical, detail-oriented person.

headline: Let Doctors Act (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Several Mosques Attacked, but Iraq Is Mostly Calm
text: BAGHDAD, June 14 — A handful of Sunni mosques were attacked today in retaliation for the destruction of two minarets at one of Iraq’s most revered Shiite shrines on Wednesday, and there was scattered violence around the country, as has become the norm.

headline: Wall Street to Get Guidelines on E-Mail
text: Try to imagine Wall Street getting through one day without cellphones, BlackBerrys or sending messages through Bloomberg terminals. No, really.

headline: Nomination of Chief Justice Raises Questions in Trenton
text: TRENTON, June 13  Several African-American lawmakers raised questions on Wednesday about the nomination of New Jersey’s attorney general to lead the state’s Supreme Court, saying that Gov. Jon S. Corzine should have consulted more widely among them and given minority candidates more consideration.

headline: Few Good Options for U.S. on Palestinian Violence
text: WASHINGTON, June 13 — For two years, the United States has tried to choke off Hamas, the militant Islamic group that has been ascendant in Gaza and the West Bank, while throwing limited aid and support to Fatah, its more moderate Palestinian rival. Now, with Fatah, the party of the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, on the verge of collapse in Gaza, Washington is facing a shrinking menu of alternatives.

headline: Kellogg to Phase Out Some Food Ads to Children
text: Froot Loops’ days on Saturday morning television may be numbered.

headline: The Summer of Love (and Rivalry, Too) (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Justices Throw Out Challenge to Murder Conviction
text: WASHINGTON, June 14 — The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that an Ohio prisoner’s challenge of his murder conviction must be thrown out because he missed a filing deadline by a few days — not through his or his lawyer’s fault, but because a federal judge made a mistake.

headline: Lab Chief Explains DNA Report in Duke Case
text: RALEIGH, N.C., June 13  The prosecutor in the Duke lacrosse case had nothing to do with a laboratory’s decision to not say in a report that tests had found DNA from at least four unknown men on the body and underwear of a stripper who accused the students of gang rape, the lab director said Wednesday.

headline: In a City of Power Brokers, a Young Visitor Who Is Truly Worshipped
text: WASHINGTON, June 13 — Even by the standards of the luminaries who sweep through Washington, the little girl in front of Lafayette Elementary School almost six miles north of the White House was special.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Tuesday about industry lobbying to shape energy legislation gave an incorrect identification in some copies for the group that is running advertisements in favor of expanded use of alternative fuels. It is the Energy Security Leadership Council, not the National Commission on Energy Policy. The article also left an incorrect impression in some copies that John Rowe, the chief executive of the Exelon Corporation, an electric utility company that operates nuclear power plants, was connected to those advertisements. The article noted that Mr. Rowe, “coincidentally or not,” is a co-founder of the Energy Security Leadership Council.” In fact, he is the head of the National Commission on Energy Policy.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Friday about a lawsuit filed by Robert H. Bork, the onetime Supreme Court nominee, against the Yale Club in Manhattan over injuries he suffered during a fall from a dais incorrectly rendered an account of the incident by Cricket Farnsworth, the office manager for The New Criterion magazine, which had invited Mr. Bork to speak at the club. Ms. Farnsworth said that Mr. Bork went on to deliver his speech after his fall; she did not also say that he managed to make his way back to the dais first.

headline: In Shift, Judge Eases Limits on Surveillance by the Police
text: In a startling legal reversal, a federal judge in Manhattan decided yesterday to vacate his own order that had greatly limited the New York police in videotaping people at public gatherings. He said the reversal was based partly on new information.

headline: An Economical Alternative to a Higher-End Canon
text: Canon’s 8-megapixel S5 IS, which just went on sale, is considered a bridge camera — crossing the gap between a pocket point-and-shoot and heftier single-lens reflex models, known as DSLRs. Those high-end cameras have interchangeable lenses, which can be costly and hard to change without dirt finding its way to the charged image sensor. The resulting spots on images can be a real problem.

headline: Sex-Positive Feminism and the Single Snail
text: Ariane Anthony is probably the only New York choreographer and performance artist who could get away with portraying, on the same evening, an at least superficially earnest lecturer on global warming and a glamorous gardener who eventually falls in love with the snails she intends to exterminate. Ms. Anthony did both, and more, in “Snail and other spirited dances and films” on Sunday night at the Construction Company on East 18th Street in Manhattan.

headline: Markets Soar on Upbeat Economic Data
text: Stocks surged yesterday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to its biggest gain in almost 11 months, after the bond market rallied and a government report on retail sales exceeded economists’ estimates.

headline: Miller’s Path to Eight Under Went From Tee to Green
text: Oakmont, Pa.

headline: Putting Energy Hogs in the Home on a Strict Low-Power Diet
text: I THOUGHT I was pretty good about energy conservation, but it turns out that I’ve been a bit of a hypocrite. I drive a reasonably fuel-efficient car, I work at home so I don’t use fuel to commute and I am replacing incandescent bulbs in my home with energy-efficient fluorescent bulbs.

headline: The River and the Man
text: Two months after completing a 3,278-mile swim down the Amazon River, Martin Strel -- profiled by Ed Zuckerman in the June issue of PLAY -- is back in Slovenia and, according to his son, Borut, profoundly affected by the experience. “Martin has told me many times he is dreaming daily about the Amazon swim and just cannot forget it,” Borut wrote in an e-mail message. “It looks like this swim changed his life.” Strel is still drained from the Amazon swim, Borut says, and “cannot even train at half power.” Nevertheless, Strel is telling people he is reborn. “He feels like he did 20 years ago,” Borut says.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Friday about higher pork prices in China amid fears of rising inflation referred incorrectly to the time period in which pig prices increased 71.3 percent. It was in April compared with the same month a year earlier; the prices did not increase that much from March to April.

headline: Japan: Current-Account Surplus Rises
text: The current-account surplus widened at the fastest rate in three years in April as exports rose and a weaker yen increased the value of investments abroad. The surplus expanded 50.3 percent, to 1.99 trillion yen ($16 billion), from a year earlier, as growth in exports to Asia and Europe helped offset a decline in shipments to the United States, the Ministry of Finance said. The trade balance climbed 34.7 percent. Exports climbed 7.3 percent from a year earlier, and imports advanced 3.2 percent.

headline: Woman and Three Children Found Dead Near Chicago
text: CHICAGO, June 14 — A mother and her three children were found shot to death early today in a sport utility vehicle parked near an interstate about 50 miles southwest of here, the authorities said.

headline: Bronx: Suspect Rescued From Ledge
text: Police officers with the Emergency Services Unit broke through a window and grabbed a suspect who was clinging to a 23rd-story ledge of a building near the Bruckner Expressway early yesterday morning, the police said. The suspect, Francisco Correra Jr., was charged with assault and with violating an order of protection, the police said. Mr. Correra, 33, was charged with hitting his father about 5:30 a.m. at their apartment building at 950 Underhill Avenue, the police said. When officers arrived, Mr. Correra had left the apartment and gone to the building’s roof, the police said.

headline: Arrest Uncovers Divide in Hmong-Americans
text: ST. PAUL, June 9 — Year after year, Vang Pao, the most recognized leader of Hmong people in the United States, described his dream when he appeared at Hmong New Year celebrations, ceremonies for new refugees, memorial dedications. Someday, he said, he would carry his people home to a free Laos.

headline: Town Went Too Far in Trying to Take Land, Court Says
text: In a decision that could affect redevelopment battles across New Jersey, the State Supreme Court ruled unanimously yesterday that a town had overstepped the State Constitution’s definition of “blight” when it tried to take private property for development.

headline: Updating Maps on the Spot and Sharing the Fixes
text: Out-of-date maps can throw a wrench into your driving plans, but TomTom’s new Map Share software combines cartography with community to allow users to update maps on the go — and later share the results with others.

headline: Bid to Ban Gay Marriage Fails in Massachusetts
text: BOSTON, June 14 — Same-sex marriage will remain legal in Massachusetts, as its proponents today won a pitched months-long battle to defeat a proposed constitutional amendment to define marriage as between a man and a woman.

headline: Gaza Turmoil Prompts Abbas to Dissolve Government
text: JERUSALEM, June 14 — The Palestinian territories seemed headed Thursday to a turbulent political divide. Masked Hamas gunmen took control of the Gaza Strip and the Palestinian president dissolved the three-month-old unity government, declaring a state of emergency and plans for elections.

headline: Staten Island: Sentence in Scalding Case
text: A Staten Island man was sentenced yesterday to 20 years in prison for scalding a 3-year-old boy in a bathtub in 2005, prosecutors said. The man, Michael Duhs, 34, of Seaview Avenue, was convicted of assault and child endangerment in State Supreme Court in February, said Daniel M. Donovan Jr., the Staten Island district attorney. Mr. Donovan said Mr. Duhs was charged with scalding his live-in companion’s son on Sept. 16, 2005, and not seeking medical attention for the child until the mother returned home six hours later. The boy suffered third-degree burns over 10 percent of his body, Mr. Donovan said.

headline: The Times Promotes Circulation Official
text: Yasmin Namini, senior vice president for circulation at the New York Times Media Group, has been promoted to senior vice president for marketing and circulation.

headline: Queens Bodega Owner Dies After Being Shot in Robbery
text: A Queens bodega owner died yesterday after being shot during a robbery on Monday by three men the police said may have carried out as many as 16 other robberies since March 17.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report in the National Briefing column on June 7 about the opening of four public housing duplexes in New Orleans misidentified their location. It is the Upper Ninth Ward, not the Lower Ninth Ward.

headline: A First for the Cavaliers Still Endures
text: Shortly after the Cleveland Cavaliers closed out an emotional playoff series against Detroit, I met a Cleveland police officer who said he was a friend of a friend who knew the legendary Robert Bingo Smith — the original Cleveland Cavalier.

headline: Writer Convicted of Kidnapping Expresses Remorse in Letter to Judge
text: The Women’s Wear Daily writer convicted of kidnapping and sexually molesting a former colleague has submitted a long, sometimes flowery, sometimes analytic letter to the judge who is going to sentence him on Monday.

headline: Coughlin Wants Less Talk, More Wins
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 13  Tom Coughlin wants to coach a Giants team that does more winning and less bickering.

headline: Showcasing His Growth, Parker Quiets His Critics
text: CLEVELAND, June 13 — When Tony Parker talked about growing pains with a vindicated grin Wednesday, he was not talking about the agony that has been LeBron James’s first N.B.A. finals.

headline: Manhattan: More on Congestion Plan
text: Trucks that meet tougher emissions standards would pay just $7 rather than the $21 fee charged to other trucks to enter the busiest parts of Manhattan under a new provision of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s congestion pricing plan, the mayor said yesterday. He made the announcement at Gracie Mansion, surrounded by labor leaders who endorsed his overall environmental program, PlaNYC. Officials said that cleaner, more efficient trucks, as well as those retrofitted to reduce emissions by 85 percent, would qualify for the discounts. Mr. Bloomberg said that there were no plans to reduce the $8 automobile fee for lower-emission cars like hybrids because the program was intended both to reduce traffic and to raise revenue.

headline: Above the Store, a Little R&D
text: ROMANA RAFFETTO met her husband, Gino, at a cafe on West Fourth Street just a few weeks after she arrived in New York in 1957; she had come by ship, having traveled from her hometown of Asolo, just outside Venice.

headline: New Haven: Yale Buying Research Site
text: Yale University said yesterday that it was acquiring the Bayer HealthCare complex in West Haven and Orange, about seven miles from its main campus in New Haven. Bayer announced in November that it was leaving the 136-acre site, where it conducted research and had its headquarters. When efforts to find another pharmaceutical company to take over the property failed, it was put up for auction. Yale was the winner, but declined to disclose the price. Richard C. Levin, Yale’s president, said the acquisition would enable the university to accelerate its science research program.

headline: The Artist’s Kitchen, Recycled and Curated
text: SIMONE LEIGH, 39, lives in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, on the second floor of a squat brick building that was once a garage for Ebbets Field. Ms. Leigh is an artist who makes swollen and lovely ceramic objects — eggs, breasts, missiles, plantains — that she assembles into large installations about race, history and gender.

headline: Senate Leaders Agree to Revive Immigration Bill
text: WASHINGTON, June 14 — Senate leaders announced an agreement this evening to put a comprehensive immigration bill back on track for further debate and possible passage.

headline: Ex-Premier of Israel Takes Helm of Labor Party
text: JERUSALEM, June 13 — Ehud Barak, a former prime minister of Israel, returned to the political scene on Wednesday as the new leader of the Labor Party, and the deputy prime minister and elder statesman, Shimon Peres of the ruling Kadima Party, was elected by Parliament to the largely ceremonial post of president.

headline: Hartford: Senator Quits Leadership Job
text: Louis C. DeLuca, left, the State Senate minority leader, resigned yesterday from his leadership post, according to a statement from the Senate Republicans. Mr. DeLuca, Republican of Woodbury, pleaded guilty this month to a misdemeanor charge of asking a businessman now facing racketeering charges to have someone threaten a man Senator DeLuca believed was abusing a family member. The businessman, James Galante, a trash hauler, had not been charged at the time; he has since pleaded not guilty. In a statement, Senate Republicans said Senator John McKinney, of Fairfield, would assume the leadership role until the caucus elected a new leader. Senator DeLuca, 73, said he looked “forward to continuing to be a productive member of our caucus.”

headline: Hamas Seizes Broad Control in Gaza Strip
text: JERUSALEM, June 13 — Hamas forces consolidated control over much of Gaza on Wednesday, taking command of the main north-south road and blowing up a Fatah headquarters in Khan Yunis, in the south.

headline: Big-Name Playwrights, Still Bargain Tickets
text: The Signature Theater Company, the 16-year-old Off Broadway theater that dedicates each season to the work of one American playwright, announced yesterday its next four seasons, which will feature plays by Edward Albee, Charles Mee, Suzan-Lori Parks and Tony Kushner.

headline: Multigenerational Cooking
text: TEN years ago, right after the birth of Paulette Mullings-Bradnock’s son Reginald, her mother came to visit from Kingston, Jamaica.

headline: Kitchen Tales
text: THE American kitchen has been an aspirational space ever since electricity and post-World War I prosperity commingled in a nifty new appliance called the refrigerator. “There are scads of ads from the 1920s showing people in tuxedos and evening gowns literally adoring their fridge,” said Victoria Matranga, a historian of industrial design and the design programs coordinator at the International Housewares Association near Chicago. Then as now, Ms. Matranga said, owning the right appliance flagged your social status by showing off your understanding of technology and progress, not to mention your prowess as a breadwinner. The kitchen has also long been a very personal space, not just a place where we tell stories about who we are, but a highly functional theater for those stories (even if the stories have nothing to do with the preparation of food).

headline: F.D.A. Panel Rejects Drug for Obesity
text: A drug once viewed as a possible magic bullet against obesity was rejected yesterday by a federal advisory panel because of worries that it causes neurological and psychiatric problems and increases the risk of suicide.

headline: Teaching Policy Chief Takes Top School Job in Baltimore, and Klein Taps Brooklyn Educator
text: After one year, Andrés Alonso, the senior instructional official in the New York City public schools, is resigning as Chancellor Joel I. Klein’s top deputy to become chief executive of the Baltimore public schools.

headline: Irish Green Party to Support Deal That May Give It Governing Role
text: DUBLIN, June 13  The leadership of Ireland’s Green Party agreed Wednesday to support a deal with Prime Minister Bertie Ahern that could make it a part of the government for the first time.

headline: Rules of the Road
text: FOR distance running (versus sprinting) most experts agree on the following principles of proper form:

headline: The Only Heat Is From Hot Sauce
text: JILL PETTIJOHN, a raw-food cook and advocate, has earned a bit of fame in the fashion world, both as Donna Karan’s personal chef and as the purveyor of five-day juice fasts, the juices for which are delivered daily to winter-swollen fashion editors from her raw-food restaurant, Jill's, in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. She may have been responsible for a rash of public non-eating this spring, reckoned Kate Betts, editor of Time Style & Design magazine. Ms. Betts and her husband spent a week sipping Ms. Pettijohn’s juices and then pretending to eat at her many meal-centered business and social functions. “I even saw men pushing their food around their plates,” she said.

headline: Reading the Cards Well Enough to Collect Them All
text: The final of the trial to select the U.S.A.-2 team for this year’s Bermuda Bowl world championship ended Sunday night in Schaumburg, Ill., with Nick Nickell, Dick Freeman, Bob Hamman, Paul Soloway, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell winning the 120-board match. They defeated Russ Ekeblad, Ron Rubin, Fred Gitelman, Brad Moss, Chip Martel and Lew Stansby by 271 international match points to 225.

headline: Computer Problem on Space Station Persists
text: The Russian computers that help keep the International Space Station in orbit remained largely out of commission today, although Russian engineers appeared to be making some progress in correcting a glitch that could imperil the $100 billion space laboratory.

headline: Parade Officials Criticize Police Over Arrest Total
text: The organizers of the Puerto Rican Day Parade criticized the police yesterday for arresting more than 200 people Sunday, many of them on charges of unlawful assembly.

headline: You Were Expecting Maybe Tragedy?
text: When Truman Capote became an Oscar-worthy movie character and “In Cold Blood” bounced back onto bestseller lists, The New Yorker sportingly published yet another Woody Allen instant classic. Titled “Above the Law, Below the Box Springs,” it mimics the absurd solemnity and keen attention to minutiae that color self-important crime reporting in rural settings, lampooning a style well known to New Yorker readers.

headline: Vintage Performance From Mussina
text: Their seats are in the front row of Section 616, in the upper deck behind home plate at Yankee Stadium, a convenient spot for paying homage to the Yankees’ starting pitcher. Gary DeSpirito and his son, Anthony, from Hawthorne, N.J., attend eight games a year in those seats, and most of the time the pitcher is Mike Mussina.

headline: At Oakmont, No Tin Cup; Just a Steel Curtain
text: When I wrote about Phil Mickelson for this month’s PLAY, I called him a favorite for the United States Open. I hadn’t reckoned on the clingy rough at Oakmont wringing out his wrist two weeks before the tournament began. A guy I know, a former club champ who can still knock the ball around, played in an outing there recently, and he came away physically intact but psychically maimed. The championship tees were roped off and the greens had yet to be given their pre-tournament shave. Even so, my friend disappeared into the rough, failed to break 100 and was shell-shocked for days.

headline: Arctic Plants Have Adjusted to Climate Changes
text: Many Arctic plant species have readily adjusted to big climate changes, repeatedly re-colonizing the rugged islands of Norway’s remote Svalbard archipelago through 20,000 years of warm and cool spells since the frigid peak of the last ice age, researchers say.

headline: Another Sorry Ascension
text: It apparently wasn’t enough for the Bush administration to pack the Department of Justice with political operatives. The White House has now nominated one of the most meddlesome of those partisans, Hans von Spakovsky, to a powerful post on the Federal Election Commission.

headline: Baron Guy de Rothschild, Leader of French Arm of Bank Dynasty, Dies at 98
text: Baron Guy de Rothschild, the patriarch of the French branch of the famous banking dynasty who rebuilt and expanded its Paris bank after it was seized during World War II and then saw it survive another government takeover in the 1980s, died Tuesday in Paris. He was 98.

headline: Funds Released in North Korea Deal
text: HONG KONG, June 14  The banking authorities in the United States and Macao today began to transfer millions of dollars to North Korea and end a dispute that has stalled an agreement to dismantle the North’s nuclear programs, officials from the Macao government said.

headline: Another Spin for ‘Buy American’
text: GENERAL MOTORS has clearly been hurt by consumers who simply refuse to buy an American brand of vehicle. But the automaker has decided to use its heritage as a competitive advantage rather than a weakness, since it is one adjective that competitors like Toyota and Honda cannot use.

headline: Bork v. Bork
text: There are many versions of the cliché that “a conservative is a liberal who has been mugged,” and Robert Bork has just given rise to another. A tort plaintiff, it turns out, is a critic of tort lawsuits who has slipped and fallen at the Yale Club.

headline: S.E.C. Ends Decades-Old Price Limits on Short Selling
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted yesterday to end price restrictions on short selling, meaning that investors seeking to sell a share that they do not own will no longer be barred from doing so because the price of the stock is falling.

headline: Blogger’s Ejection May Mean Suit for N.C.A.A.
text: The eviction of a newspaper reporter from a baseball press box for blogging about a game while it was in progress has stirred a debate about First Amendment rights, intellectual property rights and contract law.

headline: When the Real Estate Market Sizzles, the Oven Stays Cold
text: THE Wolf oven in this open kitchen with cherry wood veneer cabinets still has the plastic wrapping on its shelves, though its owner, Dennis Mangone, 47, has lived here for two years. But the kitchen has uses besides cooking.

headline: South Africa’s City Workers Join Spreading Strike for Higher Wages
text: JOHANNESBURG, June 13  South Africa’s municipal workers joined provincial and national government employees in a bitter strike on Wednesday, walking off their jobs to march by the thousands in scores of cities and bringing activity in some places to a halt.

headline: 2 Greens, Blue Line, a Yellow Golfer
text: OAKMONT, Pa., June 13  Bubba Watson was taking a break between shots on the practice range at the Oakmont Country Club on Wednesday when the conversation in his entourage of four turned to the rules about putting on the practice green. Watson’s eyes widened when he was told, incorrectly, as it turned out, that golfers would face disqualification if their putts rolled over the blue line separating the practice green from the ninth green.

headline: The Loose Reins on U.S. Teenagers Can Produce Trouble or Entrepreneurs
text: Michael S. Dell (of Dell Inc.) sold stamps to collectors when he was 12 and Bill Gates founded Microsoft when he was 19. Facebook, the social networking site, was the brainchild of Mark Zuckerberg, a Harvard University sophomore at the time. A study by the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor showed that the United States was unusual among developed countries in having a higher business start-up rate among its 18- to 24-year-olds than its 35- to 44-year-olds.

headline: Jazz With a Casual Urgency, Played in Support of Peace
text: Since moving to New York in the early 1990s the tenor saxophonist Donny McCaslin has built a reputation for versatility, poise and a vigorous approach to improvisation. Not coincidentally he now holds a sideman post in two of the more prominent ensembles in jazz, the Maria Schneider Orchestra and the Dave Douglas Quintet. And he has been increasingly productive as a bandleader, drawing from the well of similarly broad-minded New York musicians and writing music that suits their worldly ideals.

headline: Corporate Chiefs, It’s Time to Go Green (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gonzales and the Senate Vote (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Stormy Weather for Soloists as Battles Rage All Around
text: When a jazz club audience completely rolls over for a band and gives it full license, the band can do extraordinary things — instinctive, daring, almost unreasonable things.

headline: Prisoner Killed Kentucky Police Chief, Officials Say
text: CAVE CITY, Ky., June 13  The longtime police chief of a rural town in eastern Kentucky was shot dead Wednesday by a handcuffed prisoner he was driving to the county jail, officials said.

headline: And the Oscar-Winning Filmmaker Goes to ...
text: After a flirtation with Senator Barack Obama, and maxing out his contributions to both Mr. Obama and former Senator John Edwards, Steven Spielberg threw his support behind Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton for president. Mr. Spielberg cited Mrs. Clinton’s “experience and strength” in a statement posted on her campaign Web site. “I’ve taken the time to familiarize myself with the impressive field of Democratic candidates and am convinced that Hillary Clinton is the most qualified candidate to lead us from her first day in the White House,” he said. “Hillary is a strong leader and is respected the world over. As president, she will bring America back together, rebuild our prestige abroad and ensure our protection here at home.”

headline: Unwelcome at Home, Student Play Is a Hit in New York
text: Backstage at the Vineyard Theater, Taylor Telyan, 18, was bent over an ironing board, ironing her hair. A few feet away, her friend and castmate Tara Ross, also 18, was applying makeup; outside their door, a couple of boys were sacked out on a couch, studying notes in binders. They had 35 minutes until their Off Broadway debut.

headline: Africa’s World War
text: THE RWANDA-BURUNDI BORDER

headline: Summer Challenge: Handling the Heat
text: With temperatures for summer activities likely to reach into the 80s and 90s around much of the country, it’s a good time to reflect on heat illness, which incapacitates thousands of athletes every summer and, in the form of heat stroke, can kill. Last year, the American College of Sports Medicine published new consensus guidelines about avoiding, recognizing and treating heat-related illnesses. (Keep a tub filled with ice near the playing field, for instance.)

headline: Explosives Are Found in Lockers in New Jersey School
text: WAYNE, N.J., June 13 — A high school was evacuated here during the last full day of classes after a total of 16 gunpowder-filled devices with fuses were found in two lockers on Wednesday morning, officials said.

headline: Day of Police Chases, Some Woolly, Some Winged, All Wild
text: The stark, hard-edged and dramatically capitalized words of a police bulletin said it all: “A SHEEP RUNNING IN THE STREET. OFFICERS CANVASSED THE AREA AND LOCATED THE SHEEP/LAMB AND REQUESTED ESU.”

headline: For Mrs. Giuliani, Not the Usual Campaign Trail for a Candidate’s Wife
text: Three months ago, as Rudolph W. Giuliani was starting his quest for the Republican nomination, his campaign sought to introduce the political world to his third wife, Judith, having her speak at a fund-raiser in New York, while Mr. Giuliani suggested on national television that his wife might someday even sit in on cabinet meetings.

headline: 2 Committees Subpoena Ex-Officials on Dismissals
text: WASHINGTON, June 13 — The Senate and House Judiciary Committees issued subpoenas on Wednesday to Harriet E. Miers, the former White House counsel, and Sara M. Taylor, the former political director, ratcheting up the pressure on the White House to cooperate with the Congressional inquiry into last year’s firings of federal prosecutors.

headline: China: Retail Sales Surged in May
text: Retail sales unexpectedly accelerated at the fastest rate in three years, lifted by rising incomes and a stock market that has doubled this year. Sales rose 15.9 percent from a year earlier to 715.8 billion yuan ($94 billion) after gaining 15.5 percent in April, the statistics bureau said. The gain was the biggest since May 2004 after adjusting for distortions caused by China’s Lunar New Year holidays.

headline: Dry Cleaner Calls $54 Million Lawsuit Over Pants a ‘Nightmare’
text: WASHINGTON, June 13  A pair of charcoal-colored pants at the center of a $54 million lawsuit was unfurled in a courtroom here on Wednesday, introduced into evidence by a defense lawyer who called the lawsuit a “nightmare” for his clients.

headline: Correction: Listen Up, Everybody: I’m in Menopause
text: Because of an editing error, an article last week about menopause referred incorrectly to the theater production “Menopause: the Musical.” It had its premiere in Orlando, Fla., not in New York.

headline: N.J. Legislators’ Pet Spending Projects, Exposed
text: TRENTON, June 12 — As part of the effort to bring greater transparency to the state’s budget process and reduce the potential for corruption, the Legislature on Wednesday released for the first time a list of special projects and other changes to the $33.5 billion budget being requested by individual lawmakers.

headline: Google Gives Up on Competing With eBay’s Big Boston Party
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 13  It had all the appearances of a marketing stunt gone awry, the Internet industry’s version of a wily playground taunt that quickly escalated into a tense standoff, until the taunter  Google, in this case  blinked.

headline: Family Forestry
text: There is a crisis brewing in America’s vast forest lands, but it has little to do with the health of the woods: the acreage is essentially the same as it was a century ago, and there is over 30 percent more wood volume per acre than in 1952.

headline: Vietnam’s Leader Wants U.S. Visit to Be All Business
text: HANOI, Vietnam, June 13 — Bracing himself for criticism over Vietnam’s human rights record, President Nguyen Minh Triet said Wednesday that he would keep his eye firmly on trade and investment when he visited the United States next week.

headline: Fighting the Web, Sports Teams Seek to Control Ticket Resales
text: When the N.B.A. finals resume today in Cleveland, Dan Gilbert, the owner of the Cavaliers, will be showing off the youngest, flashiest asset in his portfolio.

headline: If You Really Need the Big Price Tag
text: WHEN I walked up to Theory’s flagship store in the meatpacking district, I saw a model teetering outside on the uneven cobblestones of Gansevoort Street, getting some last-minute touch-ups for a photo shoot. She was wearing a cream-colored coat that was gathered in the back with clips, like an exoskeletal spine.

headline: Brooklyn Waterfront Called Endangered Site
text: The mighty Monitor, the ironclad Civil War ship, was built on Greenpoint’s gritty waterfront. The Graving Dock at the Todd Shipyards in Red Hook was the terminal for ships traveling from the Erie Canal. The Old Dutch Mustard Company in Williamsburg churned out prepared mustard, vinegars and fruit juice for half a century. The mustard building was torn down last fall, and other sites in Brooklyn are soon to be transformed into apartments and stores in an ambitious neighborhood revitalization effort that is a cornerstone of the Bloomberg administration’s economic development initiative. But today the National Trust for Historic Preservation plans to sound the alarm by declaring Brooklyn’s industrial waterfront one of America’s 11 most endangered historic places.

headline: Iran’s Nuclear Program (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: American Held in Torture Case Leaves Prison in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 13 (AP)  An American imprisoned in Afghanistan for running a private jail for terrorism suspects has left the Afghan prison where he was held for almost three years and has departed the country, the warden said Wednesday.

headline: Wrong Image? It Depends on Beholder
text: NEW CITY, N.Y.

headline: NBC Developing Web Site for Students
text: Imagine Tim Russert introducing a classroom history lesson about the Articles of Confederation, or Brian Williams describing the reverberations of the Stamp Act.

headline: Judge Won't Delay Libby Prison Term
text: WASHINGTON, June 14  A federal judge refused today to delay the start of the prison sentence for I. Lewis Libby Jr. in the C.I.A. leak case while he appeals his conviction, meaning he could be ordered to surrender within two months.

headline: Upfront TV Market Starts With NBC Universal Deal
text: The upfront market for the 2007-8 television season is getting under way with a large deal between the NBC Universal division of the General Electric Company and the media agencies owned by the WPP Group.

headline: Theories About Separatist Group Muddy Terrorism Trial in Madrid
text: MADRID, June 13  For the past three months, more than two dozen defendants have been on trial in Madrid on charges that they orchestrated one of the worst terrorist attacks in Europe’s recent history  the bombing of four commuter trains on March 11, 2004, which killed 191 people and wounded at least 1,800. But at many points during the trial, the courtroom has been absorbed by a sideshow  the effort by a handful of lawyers for some victims to demonstrate that ETA, the armed Basque separatist group, had a part in the bombings.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,504 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Detox Survivor, Check Your Straitjacket at the Door and Get Ready to Rock
text: The rock musical has become the live-performance equivalent of the road movie: a ubiquitous convention turned rite of passage as one aspirant after another seeks to achieve its perfect fulfillment. If it falters — which it often does — it’s less often on the “rock” than on the “musical” part. That is, a band drapes its songs over an often ambitious, and sometimes squirm-inducing, story.

headline: Trial Ordered in Italy for 4 Big Banks in Parmalat’s Failure
text: MILAN, June 13 — An Italian judge on Wednesday ordered Citigroup, Deutsche Bank, Morgan Stanley and UBS, as well as 13 employees of the four banks, to stand trial on charges of market manipulation in the events that led to the multibillion-dollar bankruptcy filing of the Italian dairy company Parmalat in 2003.

headline: Where the Goods Are Odd
text: This time of year, Alaska is paradise. King Salmon hustle up to the front porch of Anchorage. Softball games unfold in the buttery glow of the midnight sun. And the woods are full of mega fauna in frisky pursuit.

headline: For Cavaliers-Spurs, Where Have All the Viewers Gone?
text: What has become of the N.B.A. finals? Yes, they will continue tonight on ABC with San Antonio leading, 3-0, and yes, there will be hopes that LeBron James can lead Cleveland to a victory or two before his Cavaliers succumb to the Spurs. But if fan aversion to this series continues at its current pace, these finals could be the least-viewed in at least 22 years, if not longer.

headline: Mr. Fundamental
text: Tim Duncan has his Spurs within reach of a fourth N.B.A. title, and has won two most valuable player awards, but is considered by some to be a boring player. Should Duncan’s style of play affect his standing among the league’s all-time great big men?

headline: A Failure to Protect Our Troops
text: The Bush administration and military leaders in Washington are always claiming that they will do anything to support American troops fighting in Iraq. That makes it all the more infuriating to learn that, for more than two years, the Pentagon largely ignored urgent requests from field commanders for better armor-protected vehicles that could have saved untold lives and limbs.

headline: Kellogg to Curb Marketing of Foods to Children
text: Froot Loops’ days on Saturday morning television may be numbered.

headline: Fun in the Booth as the Yanks’ Surge Continues
text: The Times’ seat in the Yankee Stadium press box is located right next to the visiting TV booth. Separated by a panel of glass, I’ve sat next to a whole bunch of guys from my old baseball card collection, incluiding Bert Blyleven, Jerry Remy, Ron Fairly, Buck Martinez and the funniest guy in baseball (trust me), The One And Only Rex Hudler.

headline: Recent Openings
text: New shows in New York include "In a Dark Dark House" and "The Butcher of Baraboo."

headline: Art in the Everyday
text: Images of Venice's readymades, from the city's campos and palazzos.

headline: To the Matinee and Back
text: By the millions, day-trippers visit New York every year to see the Saturday or Wednesday matinees on Broadway.

headline: Diverging Fortunes
text: A golf resort in Oregon benefits from a variety of subsidies, the kind of indirect favors that influence the flow of money from public to private interests.

headline: Glimpses of Hope
text: Today begins with a bad story, and ends with a good one. We had heard about a settlement of recent returnees from Josh Ruxin, our gracious host in Kigali and director of Rwanda’s Millennium Villages Project. Millions of Rwandans left Rwanda in the decades of instability leading up to the genocide, and many settled permanently in surrounding countries. Some have since been forcibly sent back, including this group of about 2,000 people from Tanzania. The group we encountered had all been settled in Tanzania since the 1980s, and had established sustainable farms and small businesses. Many were even born in Tanzania and had never set foot in Rwanda. Last November, they were stripped of their belongings and chased out of their villages, and told to return to Rwanda. Rwanda has a right of return policy reminiscent of Israel. (“Rwanda will never turn away our own people,” a Rwandan woman told us, “We are one people, and no matter where they come from, they belong with us.”) The refugees, or more correctly, the returnees, were welcome into the country.

headline: Armageddon Comes Knocking
text: Given that the finest special effects in this crashing bore are Jessica Alba's pillowy lips, which look as if they could save lives in a 175-mile-an-hour car crash, it's no wonder some viewers might find themselves wishing that the promised end of the world might happen a bit sooner. At least there would be some bounce to go along with the big bang. Woe unto the impatient: it takes well over an hour before Armageddon comes knock, knock, knocking on the door to this particular hell, by which time the guy with the director's credit, Tim Story, has shown that he checked out the latest Superman movie before slapping together this amalgam of recycled ideas, dead air, dumb quips, casual sexism and pseudoscientific mumbo jumbo.

headline: Under a Big Top
text: Photos of performances at Spiegelworld, a blend of cabaret, circus and burlesque.

headline: Down ‘n dirty dim sum
text: There’s a scene in Christopher New’s novel, A Change of Flag, in which a murderous triad boss invites a down-and-out street thug to an impressive dim sum meal to lure him into switching loyalties. The location was the ultimate in old Hong Kong gangster chic: the Luk Yu Teahouse.

headline: Colorful Tributes
text: Images from Neo Rauch's "para" at The Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Despite Honors, Misery for ‘Company’
text: "Company" may have won the Tony Award for best revival of a musical on Sunday night, but that accolade, along with honors from the Drama Desk, the Outer Critics Circle and the Drama League, won't prevent the final curtain from falling on it on July 1.

headline: Who Said ‘Break a Leg’?
text: James Carpinello, who is playing the lead male role, Sonny, in the Douglas Carter Beane musical "Xanadu," currently in previews at the Helen Hayes Theater, badly injured his foot during a rehearsal on Tuesday. (This kind of thing happens when much of a show takes place on roller skates.)

headline: The Best Coffee in Rome or Take that Paris!
text: If — as my colleague in Paris notes — Parisians are serious about their croissants, then Romans can be equally discriminating about coffee, in particular, their early morning cappuccino.

headline: Shanghai Automotive Absorbs Venture
text: Shanghai Automotive, China’s largest carmaker, agreed to buy out its partners in a truck maker and an auto-parts venture for 1.48 billion yuan ($194 million) to combine and expand its commercial-vehicle operations.

headline: News Corporation to Sell 9 TV Stations
text: Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, which is making a $5 billion bid for Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, said on Wednesday that it planned to sell nine of its Fox-affiliated TV stations. The stations are generally in the smallest markets served by the News Corporation’s 35-station television group.
