headline: A.I.G. Sues Ex-Officers Over Deals and Earnings
text: The American International Group sued its former chief executive, Maurice R. Greenberg, and its former chief financial officer, Howard I. Smith, on Wednesday, becoming the sole plaintiff in a case seeking more than $1 billion in damages.

headline: Lehman to Merge Two Residential Mortgage Units
text: Lehman Brothers said Wednesday it would merge two residential mortgage units, cutting 400 jobs.

headline: Today’s Teens, Today’s Entrepreneurs
text: Michael S. Dell sold stamps to collectors when he was 12 and Bill Gates founded Microsoft when he was 19. Facebook, the social networking site, was the brainchild of Mark Zuckerberg, a Harvard sophomore at the time. A study by the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor showed that the United States was unusual among developed countries in having a higher business start-up rate among its 18- to 24-year-olds than its 35- to 44-year-olds.

headline: Logical Therapuetics Gets $30 Million Injection
text: A drug developer, Logical Therapeutics, has raised $30 million in Series B funding, as venture capitalists eye an opportunity created by the spectacular fall of anti-inflammatory drug Vioxx three years back.

headline: Zell Lobbies Washington on Tribune Deal
text: Chicago financier Sam Zell made the rounds on Capitol Hill this week, drumming up support for a buyout of Tribune in an effort to pressure federal regulators to grant waivers necessary to own both newspapers and TV stations in Los Angeles and four other cities.

headline: Your City, Your Room
text: Welcome to City Room, a new blog from the metropolitan staff of The New York Times.

headline: All in the Genes
text: There is an in-joke smothered under the wooden dialogue of "And Then Came Love," an inept romantic comedy that for reasons known only to God drew Vanessa Williams, Eartha Kitt, Ben Vereen and Stephen Spinella into its swamp of clichés. Ms. Kitt's character, Mona, is a scowling termagant as fearsomely strait-laced as Lady Bracknell in "The Importance of Being Earnest" — a play that figures prominently (and ludicrously) in the story. It's a hoot to watch Ms. Kitt, pop music's original vamp, look down her nose and pester her daughter, Julie (Ms. Williams), a single mother and successful magazine reporter, to marry and be respectable.

headline: The Comedy of Capitalism
text: Maybe you have to have been brought up in a formerly Communist country to recognize and fully appreciate what might be called capitalist propaganda. What does it mean? It entails promoting a starry-eyed shop-till-you-drop ethos in a population accustomed to deprivation. How easy that appetite is to stimulate is demonstrated in the cheeky documentary "Czech Dream," whose creators, Vit Klusak and Filip Remunda, two students at the Prague Film Academy, used state money to stage an elaborate hoax.

headline: Battle for China’s Largest Beverage Maker Escalates
text: The former chairman of the Wahaha Group and many of the company’s top executives joined forces Wednesday to denounce their longtime partner, Groupe Danone, the French food and beverage giant, and threatened to form a company that would break away from its joint venture.

headline: A Family Struggling to Heal
text: “Beyond Hatred,” a documentary about a murder victim’s family struggling to heal, is an example of a film whose style doesn’t merely suit its story but amplifies its meanings.

headline: Fighting Words
text: Any attempt to elucidate the most vitriolic turf dispute of our time in just 73 minutes may seem insanely ambitious, but Isidore Rosmarin, the documentary filmmaker and producer, was not deterred. In “Blood and Tears: The Arab-Israeli Conflict,” he methodically traces the battle from its biblical origins to the fragile present through the eyes of everyone from fundamentalist Muslims to committed Zionists.

headline: A Difficult Subject and a Delicate Balance
text: The documentary "Unborn in the USA" is billed as a rigorously objective look at the anti-abortion movement, and that's accurate — but only to a point. The people who are the filmmakers' subjects are passionate, sometimes intemperate and often in-your-face aggressive, and the movie's topic is a powder keg regardless.

headline: Baron Guy de Rothschild Dies at 98
text: Baron Guy de Rothschild, the patriarch of the French branch of the famous banking dynasty who rebuilt and expanded its Paris bank after it was seized during World War II and then saw it survive another government takeover in the 1980s, died Tuesday in Paris. He was 98.

headline: Entrepreneur Muscles In on Tesco’s Garden Deal
text: Shares in Britain’s Dobbies Garden Centres soared more than 17 percent after the Scottish entrepreneur Tom Hunter doubled his stake and said that he was considering launching a bid to rival that of the British supermarket chain Tesco.

headline: Britain Explores Options for Venture Capital Fund
text: CDC, the government-owned fund that pioneered venture capital investment in Britain’s former colonies, has hired Morgan Stanley to advise it on a possible initial public offering or sale, The Times of London reported.

headline: V.C.’s Tune into PermissionTV
text: Web video platform provider PermissionTV has closed a $9 million Series C round of funding led by new investors Castile Ventures and Point Judith Capital.

headline: Citi Raises $2.2 Billion in Landmark Japanese Bond Sale
text: Citigroup raised 270 billion yen ($2.2 billion) in Japan’s biggest bond sale by a foreign firm, tapping demand for higher returns than investors can receive from the nation’s companies.

headline: An ‘Epic’ Dodgeball Battle in Silicon Valley
text: As the dog days of summer approach, some Silicon Valley venture capitalists and entrepreneurs decided to take their deal-making to the dodgeball court.

headline: Three Mid-Market Buyout Shops Sew Up Funds
text: Blackstone Group dominated the news with its upcoming initial public offering, but it was a busy week for some smaller private equity shops as well. Three buyout firms, Avista Capital Partners, VMG Equity Partners and Sterling Capital Partners, announced that each has closed a new private equity fund to invest in the middle market.

headline: Hedge Funds Warn S.E.C. of Sub-Prime Manipulation
text: A group of hedge funds has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to be on the lookout for manipulation of bonds backed by sub-prime mortgages.

headline: Goldman Seeks Stake in Indian Asset Manager
text: Goldman Sachs offered to invest in ICICI Financial Services to profit from increasing demand for India’s asset-management and insurance businesses.

headline: Noise-Canceling Headphones
text: David Pogue puts to the test headphones that aim to reduce background noise.

headline: Wesfarmers Seeks $10 Billion from Banks for Coles Bid
text: A buyout group led by Wesfarmers, Australia’s biggest home improvement retailer, is seeking to raise about 12 billion Australian dollars ($10 billion) to pay for an offer for Coles Group, according to Bloomberg News. The group met with 11 international and domestic banks in Melbourne Wednesday about loans and a possible bond sale, Bloomberg reported.

headline: Who’s Who at City Room
text: Updated, March 2010 | City Room, a live-news blog about the five boroughs of New York City, is a collaborative effort by reporters and editors of The Times. Listed below are some of the staff members involved:

headline: Will IHOP Serve Up an Offer for Applebee’s?
text: A report on Wednesday that the pancake chain IHOP might be about to toss Applebee’s International onto its menu in a $2 billion deal, left analysts skeptical that such a deal was really in the offing.

headline: Could Blackstone Regret Going Public?
text: The Blackstone Group is set to go public during a golden age of private equity investing. But what could happen if the environment gets tarnished by inflation, unfavorable regulation and other unpleasantness?

headline: Wall Street to Get Guidelines on Electronic Messages
text: Try to imagine Wall Street getting through one day without cellphones, BlackBerrys or sending messages through Bloomberg terminals. No, really.

headline: J.P. Morgan Set to Build Tower by Ground Zero
text: After months of sharp bargaining and threats to relocate, J.P. Morgan Chase is expected to announce Thursday that it has struck a deal to build a skyscraper near ground zero and move its investment banking headquarters from Midtown, according to The New York Times.

headline: Barneys Deal Is Boon for Jones Chief
text: Following a report that the Jones Apparel Group is close to an agreement to sell Barneys New York, the fashionable clothing retailer, for $950 million to the investment arm of the Dubai government, The New York Times put the price tag closer to $825 million.

headline: S.E.C. Ends Decades-Old Price Limits on Short Selling
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted Wednesday to end price restrictions on short selling, meaning that investors seeking to sell a share that they do not own will no longer be barred from doing so because the price of the stock is falling.

headline: Concerns Grow Over ‘Equity Bridges’
text: The recent popularity of equity bridge loans, used to finance private equity deals, is worrying some analysts, regulators and even the investment bankers who arrange them. Goldman Sachs has told its mergers and acquisitions staff to avoid them, an unnamed banker who works there told Reuters. Another banker who arranges buyouts called equity bridges “really bad business.”

headline: Hertz Prices Offering
text: Hertz Global Holdings said Wednesday that the offering by certain of its stockholders of 51.8 million shares of its common stock was priced at $22.25 a share. The shares are being sold by the private equity funds Clayton Dubilier & Rice, the Carlyle Group and Merrill Lynch Global Private Equity. Hertz raised $1.32 billion from its initial stock offering, most of which paid for a dividend for owners Clayton Dubilier, Carlyle and Merrill Lynch.

headline: Subprime Woes Sting Bear Stearns’ 2nd-Quarter Profit
text: The subprime mortgage market took a toll on Bear Stearns‘s second-quarter earnings, as the investment bank’s profits fell 33 percent from the same period a year ago despite record revenue for the quarter, the firm said on Thursday.

headline: Paris Hilton’s Jail Term, Taken Seriously
text: Who would’ve guessed that Paris Hilton would help “underscore the profound effect of the Sheriff’s Department’s early-release program” in Los Angeles?

headline: John From Cincinnati
text: Is there a support group for John Updike obsessives? (Maybe it’s here, at The Centaurian, a Web site I admire but find so spectacularly hideous, in terms of design, that I half-expect to learn it causes epilectic fits in some readers, like that 2012 British Olympics logo.) If one exists, sign me up.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Sirens
text: When New York City police officers have to use their sirens, they have the option to mix and match a series of screeches and wails. Below are the sounds at their disposal as well and one more -- the Rumbler -- which may soon be added to their repertoire.

headline: Goldman’s Profits Rise, But Just Barely
text: Goldman Sachs, the world’s most-profitable investment bank, reported earnings of $2.33 billion in the second quarter, a modest increase from last year’s second-quarter profit of $2.31 billion.

headline: About Comments and Moderation
text: Comments on NYTimes.com are moderated. For details, see the answers to frequently asked questions about comment policies.We encourage readers to use their real names or initials. City Room values civil, thoughtful comments representing a range of views about news and issues in the five boroughs of New York City.

headline: The Fighting Cormackians
text: You’d think these would be heady times for the people who gather at Cormac McCarthy.com, the official Web site of the Cormac McCarthy Society. Their man appeared on television last week, emerging like a biblical apparition. The Coen Brothers film of “No Country for Old Men” will be in theaters soon. McCarthy’s “The Road” won a Pulitzer Prize two months back.

headline: 2008: Obama’s Circle of Friends
text: While Illinois Senator Barack Obama is making all sorts of new friends these days (we urge you not to miss the vocal stylings of his newest devotee, Obama Girl), it is his relationship with a few old acquaintances that has his campaign worried.

headline: Hong Kong warnings

headline: Off the Pace
On The Market
No Jeans Left (Below) Behind

For exposing their underwear as they waddle around town, they could face six months in jail and a $500 fine.

headline: Dow Jones Stock Has Reached a Top, Analyst Says
text: A UBS analyst, Bruce S. Shipman, has some advice for holders of Dow Jones stock: sell now. “With the market pricing the stock as if a deal were a certainty,” he wrote in a research note issued Thursday, “we advise investors to take profits.”

headline: Mr. Fundamental

headline: Racing’s the Pits
text: When the Corvette Racing team offered me a prime spot to watch the 75th running of the 24 Hours of Le Mans, I did the unexpected. I said no. Instead, I told the team I wanted to forgo the champagne and shrimp cocktail of the media lounge in favor of being put to actual work. I explained that I wanted to see what it’s like to be inside a race team, and to write an article about being a member of the pit crew in the most famous endurance race in the world. To my surprise, they said yes!

headline: A Hard Hitting Interview With Times Reader’s Data Guy
text: Lately I’ve noticed an increase in e-mails and blog comments from people asking about how articles are handled in Times Reader. After a couple of attempts to answer the questions myself I realized I wasn’t “in the know” as much as I thought I was. Then it dawned on me. I work at the New York Times. Which means I can act like a journalist — almost — in a way.

headline: Reporting the Rx Sellers’ Generosity
text: When Minnesota became the first state to require drug makers to disclose gifts and payments made to the health care industry, the results were alarming. Doctors and other medical workers had received nearly $60 million in gifts from pharmaceutical companies over an eight-year period. Patient advocates and other groups that support lower drug costs cried foul, though many doctors said their prescription choices were not affected by the payments.

headline: J.P Morgan Woos Top U.S. Banker From HSBC

headline: A Blackstone Retirement: No Jet, But Maybe a Book?

headline: Straight Out of Norway
text: Per who? No one will be asking that question much longer. The Norwegian novelist Per Petterson has beaten out a posse of big names to win the Impac Dublin award for his flinty book “Out Stealing Horses” (Graywolf Press), translated by Anne Born. It seriously impressed our reviewer, Thomas McGuane – he compares Petterson with the likes of Knut Hamsun and J.M. Coetzee. (Look for McGuane’s review – it went to press last night – on Sunday, June 24.) The novel is about a man in his late 60s, living in rural solitude, who’s forced to come to grips with both his past and what’s left of his family.

I cited Paul Collier’s superb new book, “The Bottom Billion,” about the development challenges in Africa.

headline: Bouncing Rates
text: Bond prices plunge one day and soar the next. There were rumors yesterday, when prices leaped, that China was buying a lot of bonds. When prices decline, there is speculation that its appetite for American paper is almost sated. Every month it takes in another $10 billion or so that must be invested somewhere.

headline: Squint
text: Life is a train of moods like a string of beads; and as we pass through them they prove to be many colored lenses, which paint the world their own hue, and each shows us only what lies in its own focus.

headline: Senate Bill Threatens to Derail Private Equity I.P.O.’s
text: Senate legislation would force Blackstone Group to pay taxes as a corporation instead of as a partnership after 2012, a move that may threaten the buyout firm’s initial public offering later this month.

headline: The Wet Planet: Mars with Ocean
text: Did an ocean once cover nearly a third of Mars? Researchers have long thought they saw the remnant of an ancient seabed on its surface, but they had a hard time explaining what happened to the oceanfront property. There were features that looked like remnants of shorelines, but they varied so much in elevation that it was hard to explain how they could have bordered the same sea.

headline: Thou Shalt Not Digg Thyself
text: In the race to draw more readers of the Web, individual sites seek any edge they can find, from sketchy marketing tactics to partnerships with larger sites to the dark arts of search engine optimization.

Eliot Spitzer have briefed senior legislative aides on their idea of breaking the state horse-racing franchise in two, allowing the New York Racing Association to continue running the racing operations while giving control of future gambling operations to one of several bidders.

text: Senior aides to Gov. headline: Bruno: ‘Very Respectfully, That Is Nuts’
text: And now, more from the always entertaining and highly flammable relationship of Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno.

headline: Bruno: ‘Very Respectfully, That Is Nuts’
text: And now, for the latest chapter in the always entertaining and highly flammable relationship of Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno. In our latest chapter, Mr. Bruno ripped the governor’s campaign finance reform plan at some length.

headline: Bonnaroo: The Warm-up
text: MANCHESTER, TENN.–For one weekend a year, 700 acres of green Tennessee farmland turns into the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival, which gets started modestly tonight and runs through Sunday on six main stages. The main headliners are Tool on Friday, the Police on Saturday and, in a jam band finale, Widespread Panic on Sunday. The festival sold out to capacity today: 80,000 tickets at about $200 each.

headline: Rebels With a Cause
text: Jeffrey Gettleman travels with the Ogaden National Liberation Front, a  separatist rebel movement in eastern Ethiopia.

headline: Who’s for Hillary. And Who Isn’t.
text: According to a Washington Post – ABC News poll published earlier this week, Hillary Rodham Clinton’s most consistent and enthusiastic female support is now coming from high school graduates with incomes of less than $50,000 a year. Young women like her best. Over age 45, college-educated, higher-earning women like her least. In fact, asked who they found most “honest,” “trustworthy” and “inspiring,” these women – Clinton’s peers – expressed more of a kinship with Barack Obama.

headline: Bonnaroo: A Portable Jazz Club
text: MANCHESTER, TENN.–Bonnaroo has a new feature this year: a fulltime jazz stage, sponsored by Blue Note Records. It’s a smart marketing move for the label. Bonnaroo brings out listeners who care about instrumental music, and some of them are bound to appreciate unhyphenated jazz. (Since Bonnaroo’s stages have names like Which Stage, That Tent and The Other Tent, the jazz one is called Somethin’ Else, after a Cannonball Adderley album on Blue Note.) It’s a tent tucked away at the edge of the field, set up like a jazz club with tables and waitress service–an odd apparition in rural Tennessee. Unfortunately, it’s not ideal acoustically; its ventilation fan can be as loud as a quiet jazz passage.

headline: To Dismay of Some in Florida, Legislators Cut Property Taxes
text: MIAMI, June 14  Addressing rising anger about the cost of owning a home in Florida  and the recent troubles of the state’s real estate industry  the Legislature on Thursday approved a plan for a property tax cut it said would be the largest in state history.

headline: Wholesale Prices Up, but Consumers May Be Spared
text: Rising energy prices pushed inflation at the producer level up significantly in May, the government said today.

headline: Experts Advise on Combating Radicalization
text: While the United States has expended enormous effort in fighting terrorists in Iraq and Afghanistan, it has neglected the fight for the hearts and minds of young radicals in Internet chat rooms and other places where they cluster, experts on radicalization told a House panel yesterday.

headline: Japanese Show Seeks a Berth in Basel
text: BASEL, Switzerland, June 14 — Takashi Murakami, the Japanese artist and curator, arrived here on Tuesday, not just to peruse the thousands of artworks on view at Art Basel, the annual contemporary art fair, but also to scout possible sites for his Geisai show, which Mr. Murakami has been running twice a year in the Big Sight Exhibition Center in Tokyo since 2002.

headline: Correction: Built for Stargazing
text: An article last Friday about second-home developments for amateur astronomers misstated the surname of a resident of Arizona Sky Village. He is Bob Sandine, not Kitzman. The article also misstated the name of the Connecticut town where he and his wife, Dr. Irene Kitzman, have their primary residence. It is Hamden, not New Hamden.

headline: Congress and the Caregivers
text: A retired home health aide who sued her employer for unpaid overtime lost big this week in the Supreme Court  and so did fairness and the health care system. A regulation that was ill-conceived and is cruelly applied is depriving an increasingly important group of health care providers of a decent living.

headline: Palestinians at War
text: In two days of fierce fighting, the gunmen of Hamas have virtually taken over the Gaza Strip. This is a defeat for Palestinians, and a defeat for Israeli and American policy as well.

headline: Hard to Find Good Help? Not in This Little Town
text: Much like zombies, zombie movies show no sign of rolling over and staying dead, really, truly, most sincerely dead. In recent years, they have run speedily amok in Danny Boyle’s spine-tingler “28 Days Later” and its sequel, “28 Weeks Later” (where the virus-stricken creatures are more zomboid than true zombies), as well as in the remake of George A. Romero’s “Dawn of the Dead.” Ever the classicist, Mr. Romero keeps his zombies moving slow but steady in his rollicking “Land of the Dead,” the 2005 chapter in the zombie epic that shuddered into existence with his 1968 masterwork, “Night of the Living Dead.”

headline: Britain: Tool Rental Company Buys a Rival
text: Speedy Hire, a British tool-rental company, agreed to buy Finning International’s Hewden Tools business for £115 million ($227 million) to add branches and expand its range of drills, scaffolding and generators. Speedy, based in Newton-le-Willows, northwest England, will pay cash for the operation, part of the Hewden Stuart subsidiary of Finning, which is based in Vancouver, British Columbia. The purchase will increase Speedy Hire’s annual revenue by at least 20 percent, to more than £400 million, the chief executive, Steve J. Corcoran, said on a conference call.

headline: MySpace Mini-Episodes, Courtesy of Honda
text: YEARS after Volkswagen challenged drivers to “Think small,” another automaker, Honda, plans to run smaller commercials for a smaller car in smaller versions of television series.

headline: Indian Tycoon Considers Buying Airline Stake
text: MUMBAI, India, June 14 — An Indian tycoon, Vijay Mallya, is pursuing another takeover deal, soon after buying a stake in a rival airline, as well as a Scottish liquor company.

headline: Nellie Lutcher, 94, R & B Singer, Dies
text: Nellie Lutcher, a singer and pianist who had a string of rhythm-and-blues hits in the late 1940s and continued performing into the early 1990s, died last Friday in Los Angeles. She was 94.

headline: On Royalty
text: Reflecting on his own loss of power, the English-educated King Farouk of Egypt once predicted that by the end of the 20th century there would be only five monarchies left in the world: the kings of hearts, diamonds, clubs and spades, and the king of England.

headline: Russian Military Officers Are Convicted of Killing 6 Chechens
text: MOSCOW, June 14 — A Russian military court on Thursday convicted four officers in their third trial for multiple killings in Chechnya. They were given sentences of 9 to 14 years.

headline: Senate Leaders Agree to Revive Immigration Bill
text: WASHINGTON, June 14 — Senate Democratic and Republican leaders announced on Thursday that they had agreed on a way to revive a comprehensive immigration bill that was pulled off the Senate floor seven days ago.

headline: Kurt Waldheim, Former U.N. Chief, Is Dead at 88
text: Kurt Waldheim, the former United Nations secretary general and president of Austria whose hidden ties to Nazi organizations and war crimes were exposed late in his career, died yesterday at his home in Vienna. He was 88.

headline: Bill Would Raise Taxes on Public Equity Firms
text: Talk about trying to rain on their parade.

headline: Wall St. Firms Hurt by the Subprime Lending Fallout
text: Wall Street firms insisted for months that the meltdown in the subprime housing market was contained — and might even offer substantial opportunities for making profits. The market seems to have come back to bite them.

headline: House Agreement Ends Impasse Over Lawmakers’ Pet Projects
text: WASHINGTON, June 14 — Democrats and Republicans in the House reached agreement Thursday night on how to handle the lawmaker pet projects known as “earmarks,” ending a standoff that brought legislative activity in the House to a halt.

headline: Manhattan: Aid for Congestion Plan Disputed
text: The chairman of the House Subcommittee on Highways and Transit yesterday said the Bush administration was exceeding its authority by offering New York City up to $500 million for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposed congestion pricing plan. Representative Peter DeFazio, Democrat of Oregon, said he had “serious doubts” that the mayor’s plan qualified for federal financing under the funds the federal Department of Transportation is proposing to use. But Jeffrey N. Shane, the transportation undersecretary for policy, said the department had “ample statutory and regulatory authority” to authorize the money under several different programs. The federal money has been a major selling point in Mr. Bloomberg’s efforts to win approval for the program in the State Assembly.

headline: Brooklyn: Youth Accused of Bias Killing
text: A Brooklyn teenager was indicted yesterday on charges that he had fatally stabbed a 20-year-old man because he was gay, prosecutors said. Omar Willock, 17, was charged with murder in the second degree as a hate crime, said Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney. Mr. Hynes said Mr. Willock is charged with stabbing Roberto Duncanson, 20, after shouting antigay remarks. Mr. Hynes said Mr. Duncanson tried to walk away, but Mr. Willock stabbed him four times.

headline: Gasoline Pushed Up Producer Prices in May
text: A double-digit jump in the price of gasoline pushed inflation at the wholesale level up in May, but tame increases for most other goods suggested that price increases were largely contained and businesses would not react by raising prices.

headline: Earsplitting Symphony, With the Maestro in Blue
text: There is the yelp, an electronic yodel that grabs attention at intersections or kicks off chases. There is the wail, more traditional; it sounds like the windup police sirens of yore. There is the “ hi-lo,” dubbed the “European” siren by some, because it evokes the police chases seen — and heard — in French and Italian films.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on May 30 by The Associated Press about Barbara Cox Anthony, an heir to the Cox media fortune, incorrectly described the inheritance. Ms. Anthony and her sister, Anne Cox Chambers, and their older brother, James M. Cox Jr., all held equal interests in the company before the death of Mr. Cox in 1974, at which time the sisters received his share; they did not inherit the entire company from Mr. Cox.

text: OAKMONT, Pa., June 14  Billy Goddard did his job Thursday, which is to say he walked several paces behind his employer and spoke only when spoken to.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Plant! Water! Weed!
text: SINCE the early 1980s, when Arlene Kagle bought a weekend home with her husband in Stanfordville, N.Y., and began gardening, her flower beds have gone through more phases than the moon. “Things went from looking glorious to too many coreopsis to none, and from no black-eyed Susans to endless mounds,” said Dr. Kagle, a psychologist in private practice in New York and Dutchess County.

headline: Grab a Cocktail and Listen to the Vintage-Chic Band
text: “When the band first started I was wearing cocktail dresses and we were playing ‘I Dream of Jeannie.’ ” Thomas M. Lauderdale, the founder of Pink Martini, offered that reminiscence on Wednesday night while surveying a full house at Carnegie Hall. As he must have expected, the line got a knowing laugh, followed by a round of applause.

headline: Guilty Plea Entered in Tax Shelter Case
text: A former employee of the accounting firm Ernst & Young pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit tax fraud yesterday, a month after similar charges were filed against four current and former employees of the firm.

headline: NASA Optimistic on Space Station Repair
text: NASA officials said yesterday that they fully expected engineers to resolve an unprecedented failure of computers on the International Space Station, though they cautioned that the process could take days.

headline: Problems With Space Station’s Computers Persist
text: Russian engineers working with crashing computers aboard the International Space Station were not able to bring them back into full working order overnight, a NASA mission manager said this morning.

headline: Rodriguez and Pettitte Turn Success Into Victory
text: When the Yankees played in Chicago last week, Manager Joe Torre considered giving Alex Rodriguez a day off. Torre guessed that Rodriguez might be worn down mentally by the swirl of stories about his private life, and worn down physically by playing every game this season.

headline: Where It All Started
text: INDEPENDENCE DAY means fireworks and parades all over the United States, but in cities that played roles in the American Revolution, the commemorations go to another level. Some of the best Fourth of July parties this year will be in Boston; Philadelphia; Charleston, S.C.; Bennington, Vt.; and Yorktown, Va.

headline: Protesters of Shark Hunt Have New Strategy: They Get a Bigger Group
text: MONTAUK, N.Y., June 10 — When about 250 fishing boats sail out of Montauk Harbor on Friday in the hope of reeling in an enormous shark, and a share of $700,000 in prize money, they will be leaving trouble in their wake.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on the Street Scene page in Business Day last Friday about the International Network of Boutique Law Firms rendered incorrectly a word in a quotation from the founder of the organization, Steven Spielvogel, who commented on his experiences as an associate at Sullivan & Cromwell. He said, “When I carried a Sullivan & Cromwell litigation bag and it said S.&C. on it, it was a rebuttable presumption that you were an amazing lawyer and brilliant”  not a “reputable” presumption.

headline: Wife of Rev. Billy Graham Dies at 87
text: Ruth Bell Graham, the Rev. Billy Graham’s wife and confidant who for more than 60 years devoted herself to his career as the 20th century’s most enduring evangelist, died yesterday at her home in Montreat, N.C. She was 87.

headline: Duke Case Prosecutor Says He Will Resign
text: RALEIGH, N.C. June 15 — Durham County district attorney Michael B. Nifong said today he plans to resign his job, after admitting that he had “crossed the line” of ethical standards in some of the public statements he made about the Duke University lacrosse players he charged with rape.

headline: Kentucky: Indictment Issued in Fen-Phen Settlement
text: Three Lexington lawyers illegally kept $65 million in settlement money that should have been distributed to their clients, according to an indictment for wire fraud issued by a federal grand jury in Covington. The money was part of $200 million settlement of a civil suit claiming that about 440 people had been injured by the diet drug fen-phen. The lawyers, William J. Gallion, Shirley A. Cunningham Jr. and Melbourne Mills Jr., were entitled to about a third of the settlement but took twice that, the indictment said. The lawyers have denied criminal wrongdoing.

headline: Bronx: Man Seeks Permission to Stay in U.S.
text: The West African man who lost his wife and four children in a Bronx fire in March that claimed 10 lives in all asked immigration officials yesterday to allow him to stay in the United States now that he has returned from burying his family in his homeland of Mali. The man, Mamadou Soumare, 48, is an illegal immigrant, and he received temporary travel permission for the trip. One of Mr. Soumare’s lawyers asked the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services to grant his case “deferred action” status, which removes the threat of deportation. A spokesman for Citizenship and Immigration Services said the request is being reviewed.

headline: Vero Beach Hotel & Club and Pacifico
text: Vero Beach Hotel & Club

headline: Where Mountain Bikers Carved Their Dream Terrain
text: THERE is a spot on the Zippety trail, a sinewy, 10-inch-wide track of hard-packed dirt near Fruita, Colo., where the sides drop away so steeply it’s like biking down the tip of a knife blade. It’s the kind of trail that demands a pause before you commit yourself, so I gazed out over the broad Grand Valley to the snaking Colorado River and the red sandstone towers of the Colorado National Monument beyond.

headline: Lineman, Dead at 36, Exposes Brain Injuries
text: WEST SENECA, N.Y., June 13 — Mary Strzelczyk spoke to the computer screen as clearly as it was speaking to her. “Oh, Justin,” she said through sobs, “I’m so sorry.”

headline: U.S. to Keep Europe as Site for Missile Defense
text: BRUSSELS, June 14 — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates made clear Thursday that the United States would not alter plans to deploy parts of a missile defense system in Poland and the Czech Republic, despite an unexpected proposal by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to use a radar base in Azerbaijan instead.

headline: Commuters Get a Chance to Take Their Complaints to the Top
text: Ivette Davila, who had an hour to kill yesterday on her way from the cable television network where she works during the day to the store where she works at night, could have done many things in the sprawling Atlantic Avenue subway station in Brooklyn.

headline: Manhattan: Two Guilty of Heroin Smuggling
text: Two Nigerian men have been convicted of conspiring to smuggle heroin into the United States after an investigation that stretched from Kabul to Manhattan, federal prosecutors said. The men, Emmanuel Obi Maduka and Chimdi Ibiam, were convicted on Wednesday in Federal District Court of conspiracy to sell heroin and smuggle it into the United States, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: China: Strong Rate of Growth Persists
text: China’s government reported industrial production growth unexpectedly accelerated in May, hours after Prime Minister Wen Jiabao, left, said further steps were needed to cool the country’s economy. Output rose 18.1 percent in May from a year earlier, the National Bureau of Statistics said, after gaining 17.4 percent in April. Mr. Wen said Wednesday that monetary policy needed “moderate tightening,” underscoring the failure of two interest rate increases this year to slow the economy. Record trade surpluses have pumped money into the financial system, stoking investment, inflation and a stock market boom. For the first five months, industrial production climbed 18.1 percent from the period last year, up from 16.6 percent growth for all of 2006.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on June 4 about a new drug for liver cancer misstated the improvement in survival for patients who took the drug, compared with patients who took a placebo. The drug extended the lives of patients by about 35 percent, not 44 percent.

headline: Palestinian Split Deepens; Government in Chaos
text: JERUSALEM, June 14 — The Palestinian territories seemed headed Thursday to a turbulent political divide. Masked Hamas gunmen took control of the Gaza Strip and the Fatah president dissolved the 3-month-old unity government, declaring a state of emergency and plans for elections.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a reorganization of the newsroom at The Wall Street Journal misstated the middle initial of its managing editor. He is Marcus W. Brauchli, not Marcus E.
