text: Long Island City, on the waterfront at the western edge of Queens, is widely seen as the next frontier in the city’s plan to remake the waterfront, with new housing developments within walking distance of the area’s many transit stations. The area is still home to some of the city’s largest public housing developments, and for many years, residents of the area had little access to public libraries. There were two makeshift branches of the Queens Library, shoehorned into uncomfortable spaces in the Ravenswood and Queensbridge housing projects. “They were apartment-sized,” the director of the Queens Library, Thomas W. Galante, told me this morning.

headline: Blackstone: Tax Law Could Shrink Firm’s Valuation
text: Just how much of a hit would Blackstone Group take if, as two United States senators have proposed, it had to pay the same tax rate as other publicly traded companies?

headline: Tulsa’s Buried Belvedere Sees the Sun Again
text: UPDATE, June 16, 2007, 9:44 a.m. Sadly, but hardly a surprise, the protective covering couldn’t keep 50 years of groundwater away from the buried Belvedere. As The Associated Press reported this morning, “crews removed a multilayered protective wrapping caked with red mud, revealing a vintage vehicle that was covered in rust and wouldn’t crank.”

headline: Signs of Investor Burnout in Ethanol I.P.O.’s
text: The initial public offering Thursday of BioFuel Energy was described in the Red Herring as “lackluster.” But worse adjectives might be applied to the public debut of the ethanol maker. It cut its offering price several times in the weeks leading up to the I.P.O. It had filed to sell 9.5 million shares for between $16 and $18. It ended up selling 5.25 million shares at $10.50 each. After a bumpy first day of trading, the stock closed up a penny. And at midday Friday, they were trading at $10.37.

headline: Kim Chan: The Zen of Comedy
text: A 90-year-old actor looks back across decades of on-screen laughter and real-life adversity.

headline: Ryan Adams: 'Pearls on a String'
text: Ryan Adams performs a song from "Easy Tiger." (Courtesy of Lost Highway Records)

headline: The Women of Rwanda
text: “They kept raping me, even though I had maggots crawling out of me.”

headline: Buried Car Unearthed in Oklahoma
text: Hundreds of onlookers gathered to watch the raising of a gold and white Plymouth Belvedere to celebrate Oklahoma's 50 years of statehood.

headline: In F.T.C. Fight, Whole Foods Turns to the Web
text: As it attempts to fight an antitrust suit by the Federal Trade Commission over its proposed deal for Wild Oats Markets, Whole Foods Market has turned from the legal arena to the court of public opinion.

headline: Traffic Fees and the ‘Plains of Hesitation’
text: Add yet another strange wrinkle to the imbroglio over Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s congestion pricing plan. In a letter sent yesterday, the chairman of the House Subcommittee on Highways and Transit urged Albany’s “Big Three” to “carefully consider the expectation” that the $500 million in federal funds promised by the mayor will actually come through. Turns out the Department of Transportation may not have the proper authority to give up the goods.

headline: Hesitation, Bleached Bones and Traffic Fees
text: Add yet another strange wrinkle to the imbroglio over Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s congestion pricing plan. In a letter sent yesterday, the chairman of the House Subcommittee on Highways and Transit urged Albany’s “Big Three” to “carefully consider the expectation” that the $500 million in federal funds promised by the mayor will actually come through. Turns out the Department of Transportation may not have the proper authority to give up the goods.

headline: Farewell to a Vintage Home
text: This is my last working day in the old New York Times building, at 229 West 43rd Street, and since I’ve spent quite a bit of time here over the last 23 years, permit me a brief departure from our usual subjects.

headline: A Question of Scale
text: The Upper West Side north of 96th Street is experiencing a period of profound physical change. New luxury residential towers are rising 30 stories or more, twice the height of the 14- and 16-story buildings that have defined the neighborhood for a century. Small businesses are giving way to blocklong retail development.

headline: Easy Riders (and With a Brand, Too)
text: First there was the official New York City memorabilia. Then there was the official New York City condom. Now there’s the official New York City bike helmet.

headline: Environmentalmania? (Part Deux)
text: An abundance of Fisking — described by Wikipedia as a “detailed point-by-point criticism that highlights errors, disputes the analysis of presented facts, or highlights other problems in a statement, article or essay” —­ was one of the original glories of the blogosphere, but the practice has fallen into disuse as an emphasis on briefer, pithier comments has blossomed. Marlo Lewis of Planet Gore is a throwback, however, and her current, very lengthy takedown of a speech by Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid on energy policy is, whether one agrees with her or not, a masterpiece of the form. For those too hurried to take it all in, here’s her point in a nutshell:

headline: Easy Riders (and With a Brand, Too)
text: First there was the official New York City memorabilia. Then there was the official New York City condom. Now there’s the official New York City bike helmet.

headline: Albany Spelling Check: Marihuana?
text: When the Assembly passed a bill last week that legalized the “medical use of marihuana,” copy editors across the state did a double-take. Shouldn’t that be spelled with a J?

headline: Toasting Blackstone’s Billion-Dollar Grandpa
text: Though the big news for the Blackstone Group on Thursday was a Senate bill that seemed to take aim at the private equity firm’s initial public offering, Stephen A. Schwarzman had other things on his mind. Chief among them: He had just become a first-time grandfather — two times over.

headline: Rain Doesn’t Soak Spirits at Le Mans
text: Packed train stations and gridlock on every street are proof enough that we’re less than one day away from the world’s greatest 24 hour auto race.

headline: Rwanda, Past and Present
text: In 1994, Rwanda was the scene of killings at a rate of 10,000 people per day, and bludgeoned bodies literally lined the streets. When the Rwandan Patriotic Front (the current government of Rwanda) took over, they found dead people, moribund services, crumbled houses, and decimated hospitals. Latrines and lakes were stuffed with bodies, and churches were filled by the bodies of thousands of parishioners whose killings were facilitated by their own ministers. There was no government to speak of.

headline: War at Home: The Battleground of Summer
text: A coalition of antiwar groups is looking to make it a long, uncomfortable summer for 40 Republican members of Congress who are opposed to setting a timeline to end the war in Iraq.

headline: The Big Move
text: After 94 years on West 43rd Street, The Times moved south to its new home on Eighth Avenue.

headline: A Note to Readers
text: Byron Calame’s tenure as the public editor ended on May 6 with the publication of his final column.

headline: Paging Carl Pavano, Please Move Your Car
text: One of the things I’m sure will be different about the new Yankee Stadium is the media parking. Right now, we’re in the same lot as the players, and the beat writers park in the next row. It’s a sweet deal, and it probably won’t last.

headline: London Journal: An American’s View of a British View of America
text: I am writing this on my laptop, on a sunny, nicely breezy morning in London, sitting on a bench in Russell Square in the Bloomsbury section of town. My nifty guidebook tells me that this is where T.S. Eliot, dubbed the “Pope of Russell Square,” used to come to escape his emotionally troubled first wife when he was an editor and, later, the director of the Faber & Faber publishing house. There are students from the nearby University of London sitting on the lawn, reading and writing.

headline: Bill Clinton on Congestion Pricing
text: Is there anyone at this point who hasn’t weighed in on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan to impose weekday traffic fees in Manhattan? Former President Bill Clinton mentioned Mr. Bloomberg’s congestion pricing proposal today during the annual luncheon of the National Partnership for Women and Families in Washington. Mr. Clinton did not explicitly endorse or criticize the plan, but he suggested that traffic fees would be “slightly regressive for lower-income working people that have no option but to drive.” He focused on the potential for creating jobs by making buildings more environmentally friendly.

headline: Bill Clinton on Congestion Pricing
text: Is there anyone at this point who hasn’t weighed in on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan to impose weekday traffic fees in Manhattan?

headline: A Changing Metropolis
text: Times reporter Sewell Chan introduces his new project, City Room, a blog about the New York City experience.

headline: Learning Spanish With Jose Reyes (Yankee Stadium Edition)
text: One of my favorite things about Shea Stadium, and admittedly there aren’t that many, is that 30-second segment featuring Jose Reyes and his Spanish Academy. With the Mets on a 10-game road trip, I haven’t gotten my fix recently, so I asked Reyes for a Spanish word today.

headline: Win a Trip: Meeting Great Leaders
text: Leana Wen, who's traveling with Nicholas D. Kristof in Africa, reports on her visits with Rwanda's president and Dr. Paul Farmer.

headline: The Handwriting on the Road
text: The artist Eve S. Mosher, who is drawing a chalk line along 70 miles of New York coastal neighborhoods, at work. Videography by Justin Lange.

headline: Turning On the Faucet of Emotion
text: Here I stand, weighted down in the sand again, about to enter another foreign territory. I’m marching into a world I have never seen, a world where I am the intruder. Instead of carrying a 40-pound rucksack, I wear a 40-pound aluminum tank. Rather than a crooked Kevlar, I wear a tight neoprene hood. My desert uniform is buried; on this journey I wear a 14-millimeter wetsuit. On my feet I wear booties and soon will don fins. My hands are gloved. Here, a regulator allows me to survive, rather than a protective gas mask. The temperature is 52 degrees, not 118. I carry a Riffe spear gun instead of an M16. I have a compass, a watch, and a plan in case I lose my buddy. My stomach is in knots, but from excitement instead of fear. We are on an underwater hunt.

headline: Bonnaroo: Two Well-Traveled Guitarists
text: MANCHESTER, TENN.–Early Friday afternoon at Bonnaroo brought two well-traveled guitarists playing to grab nonbelievers. James (Blood) Ulmer led a jazz-rock power trio in a set that fell into a pattern: he sang blues songs alternating with instrumentals. The blues were political and personal complaints, including denunciations of the war, a song about Hurricane Katrina and a song about money troubles that announced, “I ain’t broke but I’m badly bent.” And the instrumentals veered toward the harmolodic zigzags of Ornette Coleman: setting out melodies at willful, shifty speeds, improvising over a vamp. In both blues and instrumentals, he loosed a new idea at each break: searing sustained lines, phrases that scurried into different keys, bent and wah-wahed notes, crunched funk chords. Each idea could have been the seed of a whole solo, but Mr. Ulmer kept coming up with more.

headline: Bonnaroo: Restless, Free and Easy
text: He managed to make make his standard stage patter work with a very different audience, which means it’s either universal or downright generic: “Bonnaroo is all about being free and easy,” he announced, leading into his twangy, restless “Free and Easy (Down the Road I Go).”

headline: Spark From Reyes Overcomes Heat From Clemens
text: Their symbolic subway cars were headed in opposite directions. The Yankees were the hottest team in the majors, the Mets the coldest. The Bronx was up, Queens was down and, last night, both batteries were on.

headline: Broad Effort to Resurrect Immigration Bill
text: WASHINGTON, June 15 — At 4:30 p.m. on June 7, the Roman Catholic Church defied the sponsors of a comprehensive immigration bill and urged the Senate not to move toward final passage of the measure without significant changes.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report on theater news in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Thursday included incorrect information from the Godlight Theater Company about its plans to present a stage adaptation of Kurt Vonnegut’s “Slaughterhouse-Five” at 59E59 Theaters. It might be presented there this winter or next spring; it is not scheduled for September.

headline: Work Done on Space Station Computers
text: Russian astronauts and engineers may have corrected a problem yesterday that caused computers aboard the International Space Station to crash and raised the possibility that the station might have to be evacuated.

headline: An Advocate Lends a Hand as Social Justice Goals Unify Faiths
text: CHICAGO

headline: Ritual Fence Set for Jews in Manhattan Is Extended
text: Jews living in a large area of Manhattan who regularly observe the Sabbath will have a much easier time of it today. An eruv, a line that delineates the concept of domestic space for Orthodox Jews and dictates where they may carry items on the day of rest, has been extended from Midtown to Houston Street.

headline: Jeter Lets Chance to Know What’s Coming Sail On By
text: Derek Jeter had a chance for some authentic, inside information about how another major league team planned to pitch him. But Jeter, the Yankees’ shortstop, refused to listen yesterday.

headline: Canada: Report Critical of ‘Broken’ Mounties
text: The head of an investigation into the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, David A. Brown, said in a report that the force’s management and operations structure was “horribly broken.” Mr. Brown, the former head of the Ontario Securities Commission, was asked by the government to examine how the force had handled allegations that money was misspent by administrators of the pension and insurance fund. He concluded that officers who raised questions had been punished, that those responsible were not held to account and that an ostensibly independent investigation by Ottawa’s municipal police force, which found no wrongdoing, was effectively guided by the Mounties. He was particularly critical of the “autocratic leadership style” of the Mounties’ former commissioner, Giuliano Zaccardelli. Mr. Zaccardelli resigned this year after retracting some of his parliamentary testimony about the case of Maher Arar, the Canadian citizen deported to Syria by the United States after the Mounties provided erroneous information suggesting that he was a terrorism suspect.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Clarkson Cancels Tour

headline: R. F. Dial, 62, Dies; Convict Fled With Warden’s Wife
text: Randolph F. Dial, an artist and confessed hit man who fled a life sentence for murder to spend nearly 11 years on the run with a deputy warden’s wife, died Wednesday in the infirmary of the Oklahoma State Penitentiary in McAlester. He was 62.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A pop music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday about Accordionology, a festival this weekend at Barbès in Park Slope, Brooklyn, misidentified the bass player shown in the accompanying picture. He is Trevor Dunn, not Drew Gress. The entry also misidentified the title of the new album by Will Holshouser, who is playing in the festival. It is “Singing to a Bee,” not “Reed Song,” which was an earlier recording.

headline: China: Workers Told to Wear T-Shirts to Save Energy
text: In an effort to conserve energy, the government has urged office workers to abandon business suits in favor of T-shirts and other informal wear. The message was delivered in a week when air-conditioning in many government offices was turned off and inspectors sent to hotels and office buildings in Beijing to enforce new temperature guidelines.

headline: Tax Gap Puts Private Equity Firms on Hot Seat
text: This week, Goldman Sachs, Wall Street’s most profitable firm, reported that it earned about $3.4 billion for the second quarter. As always, it set aside a big chunk of money  $1.1 billion, or about 32 percent  to pay corporate income taxes on its healthy profits.

headline: N.B.A. Finals Have Lowest Viewership
text: The San Antonio Spurs’ sweep of the Cleveland Cavaliers produced the N.B.A.’s least-viewed championship, with an average of 9.2 million viewers, as measured by Nielsen Media Research. The previous low, almost 9.9 million, was in 2003 when the Spurs defeated the Nets.

headline: Pearson Is Said to Seek a Partner for a Takeover of Dow Jones
text: Pearson, the publisher of The Financial Times, is exploring a rival takeover offer for Dow Jones & Company, and has discussed a joint bid with General Electric and the Hearst Corporation, people familiar with the talks said yesterday.

headline: Out Amid the Cold Night Air the Devil Dares to Tread
text: Wednesday evening was so unseasonably cold that it felt as if hell had frozen over Central Park during the Metropolitan Opera’s concert performance of Gounod’s “Faust,” which opened its annual free summer series.

headline: Spurs Give Cavaliers, and Others, a Look at How It’s Done
text: The marketing slogans that accompanied LeBron James and the Cleveland Cavaliers to their first N.B.A. finals lay like discarded signposts the day after the Cavaliers’ quick capitulation to the San Antonio Spurs.

headline: Pakistani Judge’s Lawyers Are Confident of Winning His Reinstatement
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 14 — Lawyers representing the suspended chief justice, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, in Supreme Court hearings said in an interview this week that they were confident that they could win the case and secure his reinstatement by the end of the month.

headline: The Matriarch of Penticton Against the World
text: The World Wide Bridge Contest, in which the same deals are played at bridge clubs around the world, began 21 years ago. This year’s events were played on June 1 and 2, with players in Nepal participating for the first time.

headline: In the Classroom, a New Focus on Quieting the Mind
text: OAKLAND, Calif., June 12  The lesson began with the striking of a Tibetan singing bowl to induce mindful awareness.

headline: Building a TV Station and a Platform for Leftists
text: CARACAS, Venezuela

headline: Video Game Arrives in the Flesh (Lots of It)
text: There was a time when movies like “DOA: Dead or Alive” lurked sheepishly at schoolboy height on video store shelves, spines straining to accommodate the charms of their actresses. But the multiplex is a beast that needs constant feeding, and sometimes the meal has to be cheese.

headline: Home on the Rainforest
text: DEEP within Madagascar, more than 1,300 square miles of rainforest continue to breathe in carbon dioxide and breathe out oxygen every day, helping to keep the planet cool. That may not seem like a big achievement for a bunch of trees, but elsewhere around the world tropical forests like this one are being felled to make way for timber and mining operations, cattle ranches and, increasingly, sugar and palm oil plantations to fuel the world’s growing thirst for ethanol.

headline: Gilead’s Drug Is Approved to Treat a Rare Disease
text: Gilead Sciences won approval yesterday for a new drug to treat a life-threatening lung disease, stealing a march on another company, Encysive Pharmaceuticals, which learned yesterday that its similar drug would not be approved yet.

headline: On His First Visit to Fenway, Bonds Has Some Kind Words
text: BOSTON, June 15  Shortly before Barry Bonds of the Giants played his first game at Fenway Park on Friday night, he answered many questions with platitudes. But he responded to one directly and forcefully.

headline: A Fixture in the Heart of Harlem Faces Another Fight
text: The sounds of jazz in the 1970s slowly gave way to the hip-hop that now blasts from cars rolling down 125th Street in Harlem. The street itself has been transformed, as chain stores have moved into the area they long shunned. Through it all, Sikhulu Shange, 65, has been a constant, a looming presence behind the register of his music store, the Record Shack.

headline: At Camp, Conquering Fears and Hearing Cheers
text: CLARYVILLE, N.Y., June 13 — As her classmates pulled on a rope to raise her above the forest floor in the giant swing, Tanisha Polanco, 15, announced that she needed a hug. And that she wanted to get down. And that she was going to cry.

headline: Spiritual Guidance and Smooth Sailing for the Fire Dept.
text: Three stout red ships muscled north along the East River. They seemed to grow larger against the backdrop of Governors Island as they approached Pier 17.

headline: Singing! Dancing! Tragedy! Comedy! Resurrecting a 1600s Operatic Spectacle
text: BOSTON, June 14 — Baroque opera was the Busby Berkeley extravaganza of its day. It focused on spectacle and pageantry, and with composers like Jean-Baptiste Lully cranking out an opera a year, it was eminently disposable.

headline: Publisher of Men’s Magazines Is Sold to Private Equity Fund
text: Dennis Publishing, the magazine company behind three of the most successful publications aimed at young men in the United States  Maxim, Stuff and Blender  was acquired for an undisclosed price by the private equity fund, Quadrangle Capital Partners II, Quadrangle said yesterday.

headline: An Artist’s Look Back at Her Life, Now Ended
text: It has become almost obligatory among those attending memorial services to comment that the departed one seems somehow so present, as if he or she were there looking on, enjoying, even participating. But this observation rarely has the lapel-grabbing force it acquires in “Behind the Lid,” a remarkable environmental theater piece by the performance artist Lee Nagrin and the puppeteer Basil Twist.

headline: How Great Leaders Juggle Ideas
text: WHEN we look for ways to improve our life at work, how we can make better decisions, for example, or try to figure out the next step in our career, invariably one thing we do is look at what great leaders have done. This is why books like “Straight From the Gut,” by John F. Welch Jr., and those by Lee A. Iacocca sell so well.

headline: As Lower Manhattan Recovers, Many Question Use of Subsidies
text: JPMorgan Chase’s announcement on Thursday that it would build a $2 billion investment banking headquarters downtown and move 7,000 employees there was only the latest illustration of how far Lower Manhattan has come since the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center.

headline: Not Everyone Is in the Red on Trade With China
text: The great Chinese export machine is producing rising trade surpluses with the United States and soaring surpluses with Europe. But when it comes to the rest of the world, it is running a trade deficit.

headline: Hazardous Teenage Years (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Slashing and Warming
text: Buried in the final communiqué issued at the recent Group of 8 summit in Germany was an important and overdue pledge to help poorer nations reduce the global warming emissions caused by the slashing and burning of their tropical forests.

headline: In Iraq, Gates Says Progress Toward Peace Is Lagging
text: CAMP VICTORY, Iraq, June 15 — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates arrived here late on Friday bluntly expressing disappointment with the pace of political reconciliation under Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, even as the final units of the American troop increase were moving into position and bombings threatened to inspire more sectarian violence.

headline: On West Bank, a Show of Force by Fatah
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank, June 15 — The preacher at the main mosque here in the Palestinian Authority’s administrative capital in the West Bank called for reconciliation during Friday Prayer, a day after Hamas violently seized control of Gaza.

headline: Facing Sanction, Duke Prosecutor Plans to Resign
text: RALEIGH, N.C., June 15 —Michael B. Nifong, the Durham County district attorney, announced Friday that he would resign, as he faces disciplinary charges for his handling of a sexual assault prosecution against three former Duke University lacrosse players who were later declared innocent.

headline: Russia Says It Opened Criminal Inquiry Into British Espionage
text: MOSCOW, June 15  Russia’s intelligence service said Friday that it had opened a criminal investigation into British espionage here in Russia, based on statements and undisclosed evidence provided by a businessman who is accused of poisoning Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. officer and a Kremlin critic.

headline: Injured Mickelson’s Chances of Making Cut Were Fat or Slim
text: OAKMONT, Pa., June 15 — The caddie Jim Mackay, who is known as Bones, is paid to feed numbers into the golfing machine that is Phil Mickelson. Yards to the green, feet to the pin; those are the figures that Mackay is used to calculating.

headline: Martin J. Weber, 102, Dies; Innovator in Graphic Techniques
text: Martin J. Weber, a graphic artist, typographer and art director who invented a widely adopted technique that gave two-dimensional images the illusion of appearing in three dimensions, died last Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 102.

headline: A 50-Year-Old Time Capsule Sees Daylight, but Will It Start?
text: A muddy, rusty 1957 Plymouth Belvedere was lifted out of the Oklahoma earth yesterday, 50 years after the citizens of Tulsa deposited the coupe in an underground vault near the county courthouse to commemorate the state’s 50th anniversary.

headline: Against Former Teammate, Delgado Again Struggles to Produce for Mets
text: Carlos Delgado of the Mets patiently listened to the statistics, heard that he had a .324 average against Roger Clemens, then pushed the numbers aside and called them meaningless.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on Monday about the philosopher Richard Rorty misidentified the source of the quotation, “There is no basis for deciding what counts as knowledge and truth other than what one’s peers will let one get away with in the open exchange of claims, counterclaims and reasons.” It was from Charles Guignon and David R. Hiley in the introduction to the book “Richard Rorty,” which they edited; it was not from Mr. Rorty.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on May 25 about the influence of the war in Iraq on this year’s graduating class at the United States Military Academy referred incorrectly to Brig. Gen. William B. Kunzig Jr. of Minneapolis, an alumnus who was on campus for the annual alumni review. General Kunzig, 97, class of 1932, was the oldest living graduate at the ceremony, not the oldest living graduate of West Point. (According to the academy, that title belongs to Benjamin Whitehouse, 104, a retired colonel from Brewster, Mass., who graduated in 1927.)

headline: Prosecutor in Duke Case Is Disbarred for Ethics Breaches
text: RALEIGH, N.C., June 16 — In a case that has brought one surprise after another, a disciplinary hearing panel found Michael B. Nifong, the Durham County district attorney, guilty today of ethical violations while pressing a false accusation of sexual assault against three former Duke University lacrosse players. The panel then ruled that Mr. Nifong should be disbarred.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on Tuesday about Amy Sullivan, a former executive director of the Eugene O’Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn., misstated the history of the National Theater Institute, a program of the center, and referred incorrectly to it. The institute was founded in 1970, more than 30 years before Ms. Sullivan became executive director at the center. She did not create it, and it is not a summer program. She added a summer session.

headline: A Program to Match the Personality of Its Conductor
text: “About to Be” would have made a good title for the New York Philharmonic concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday. Rossini’s Overture to “Semiramide” finds an Italian local-boy-made-good at the beginning of his wider European career. Schubert’s Third Symphony places a Viennese teenager somewhere between his already prolific boyhood and a short but even more prolific adult life. Dvorak’s Fifth Symphony marks the onset of the Czech composer’s career-making publishing deal with the Simrock company and the support of Brahms that made it possible.

headline: Indonesia Reports the Arrest of a 2nd Top Terrorism Suspect
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 15  The leader of the Southeast Asia terrorist network Jemaah Islamiyah was seized last weekend during raids by Indonesia’s antiterrorism force, the police said at a news conference on Friday.

headline: Another Justice Dept. Official Resigns
text: WASHINGTON, June 15 — Another Justice Department official involved in last year’s dismissals of federal prosecutors is resigning, department officials said on Friday.

headline: Flip Side of the Dream
text: Camden, N.J.

headline: Father and Son Try Sparing the Rod
text: The sun had begun to set as I stood at the edge of my favorite golf course pond. The slanting rays were warming the northern shore, giving the bass a comfortable place to bask. A foursome was teeing off in the distance, but we were well out of sight, and this was a good thing. I’m sure my party of two would have provided quite a distraction to any unsuspecting golfer. It’s odd enough to see someone fishing a water hazard. But instead of fly rods, we wielded what looked like car-vacs with stubby plastic poles attached.

headline: Sleuth Expands the Case File
text: FOR nearly a year until this week, Sharesleuth, the “investigative” business Web site financed by the billionaire entrepreneur Mark Cuban, had published articles about just two companies. But in what may signal a departure, Sharesleuth has published an article about a third company: the Orthopedic Development Corporation, which is marketing a new spinal implant procedure (sharesleuth.com).

headline: Second Sunni Mosque Is Blown Up in Basra
text: BAGHDAD, June 16 — Hooded gunmen clad in black blew up another Sunni mosque in the southern city of Basra today after ordering the police officers at the mosque to flee, and despite a curfew imposed by Iraq’s central government, witnesses and security officials said.

headline: Pests That Bite and Slither? Call Snake Wranglers
text: LOS ANGELES, June 14  For Sam the Weimaraner, things had been quite grave. A rattlesnake bite to the snout  the unhappy result of flower bed pursuit  had left him unconscious, lying in his owner’s garage in Topanga Canyon, an IV dangling from his paw.

headline: Blast Destroys Sunni Mosque in Iraq, Raising Fears of Reprisals
text: BAGHDAD, June 15 — A powerful explosion that reduced a large Sunni Arab mosque to rubble near the southern city of Basra on Friday morning appeared to signal that the cycle of revenge violence, following the bombing of a sacred Shiite shrine in Samarra on Wednesday, has not entirely unfolded.

headline: House Passes Security Bill That President Opposes
text: WASHINGTON, June 15The House on Friday approved the spending of $37.4 billion next year by the Department of Homeland Security, calling for significantly more spending than proposed by the Bush administration, including hundreds of millions in extra state and local antiterrorism grants.

headline: Fatah Seizes Public Buildings in the West Bank
text: JERUSALEM, June 16 — The Fatah faction, crushed in Gaza, moved to consolidate control over the West Bank today, seizing public buildings, including the Parliament, and preparing to swear in a new government that did not include its rival, Hamas.

headline: An End to Pants-Grabbing Armrests: 2010, Railroads Say
text: Come 2010, the Long Island Rail Road will be safe for trousers again.

headline: Course Is Hard, No Matter How You Cut It
text: OAKMONT, Pa., June 15 — It was the closest thing to a day of misspent golf, a day when the players waded through weeds and crept behind bunkers that looked like benches.

headline: In Aftermath of Gaza Battle, Grim Realities
text: GAZA, June 15 — This packed, impoverished coastal strip had a postrevolutionary feel on Friday: the green flag of Hamas, victor over Fatah in what amounted to a five-day civil war, flew over public buildings where once the multicolored Palestinian one had been.

headline: Mother Charged After Sons’ 4 A.M. Walk
text: FAIRVIEW, N.J., June 15 — Al Carbone, a Bergen County cabdriver, was nearing the end of his shift about 4 a.m. Friday when a man approached him in the parking lot of the A.&P. here and told him that two children were wandering in front of the supermarket.

headline: Of London and Paris (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 7:15 P.M. (HBO) THE MUSIC IN ME: A FAMILY SPECIAL A bevy of young musicians from around the country, two of whom are pictured above, demonstrate the various cultural traditions they’re carrying on. The six featured in this special include an 11-year-old tin-whistle player, a 10-year-old mariachi singer and guitar player, and an 11-year-old classical composer. And two young girls discuss how playing the piano helped them survive cancer.

headline: Fuel Prices Aside, Inflation Is Tame
text: A leap in gasoline prices pushed the overall rate of inflation higher last month, government data showed today, but consumer prices nationwide generally appear to be increasing at a consistently slower rate.

headline: Hoofers in Search of Heroes
text: The DancemOpolitan dance cabaret series at Joe’s Pub at the Public Theater are essentially gatherings of the downtown dance clan, performers and their friends.

headline: Man Is Guilty of Manslaughter in ’06 Stabbing of Neighbor
text: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 15 — A Connecticut man pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter here on Friday in the stabbing death last summer of his Fairfield neighbor who he mistakenly believed had molested his 2-year-old daughter.

headline: The Scarlet Letter
text: By this time next week, the left-for-dead Senate immigration bill should be up off the slab, lurching toward a final vote. It almost died when Republicans tried to weigh it down with too many harsh amendments. But now it’s coming back, thanks to some late attention from President Bush, a rush to repackage it as a super-heavy-duty enforcement measure — with $4.4 billion to be thrown at the border right away, as a good-faith gesture to the anti-amnesty crowd — and a deal to limit the amendments from both parties to only a couple dozen.

headline: Shunned by Bloomberg, Newsman Is a Gadfly in Exile
text: As the publisher of a small independent newspaper, Rafael Martínez Alequin has tormented generations of politicians, raising hackles with pointed — some say pointless — questions, often about the interplay of race and class in the city.

headline: Considering the Crime, Not the Suspect
text: Because of the wiring of his brain, Ozem Goldwire must account for every minute in an hour. Asked what happened on the day he came home from work in January 2006 and found his sister dead in bed, Mr. Goldwire reports that his alarm went off at 5 a.m., and he took the B-20 bus at 6:18. “I got to work at 7:04,” he says, and so his narrative spools, one precise moment after the next, until he gets off the bus at night and opens the door to his house in Brooklyn.

headline: Switzerland: Big Rail Tunnel Opens
text: Switzerland opened the 21.5-mile Lötschberg Tunnel beneath the Alps, the world’s longest railway land tunnel and part of the country’s plan to shift freight traffic off the roads and speed up passenger transportation. It joins Frutigen near the capital, Bern, in the north with Raron in the Rhône Valley to the south, cutting travel time for trains crossing from Germany to Italy by about 90 minutes and bringing skiers to resorts like Zermatt more quickly.

headline: Colonial Roots Have Spread Worldwide
text: Few names are as evocative of American history as that of Ethan Allen and his Green Mountain Boys. But today Ethan Allen, the furniture and home furnishings company based in Danbury, Conn., is thoroughly international. Its chief executive is Farooq Kathwari, 62, who was born in Kashmir. Its manufacturing base is increasingly international as are its design motifs. Mr. Kathwari recently discussed the international influence. Following are excerpts:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A sports article yesterday about two lawyers indicted in Kentucky on federal charges of conspiring to defraud clients in a $200 million lawsuit settlement with the maker of the diet drug fen-phen omitted the name of a third lawyer who was indicted. Melbourne Mills Jr. was also charged  but unlike the other two, Shirley A. Cunningham Jr. and William J. Gallion, he was not a part-owner of the Preakness champion Curlin. (Unaware of the sports article, the editors of the National Briefing column ran another one that omitted the lawyers’ horse-owning backgrounds.)

headline: In the Underworld, Looking for Beams of Blessed Light
text: In her latest program Neta Pulvermacher reveals not just a trilogy of dances, but also three sides of the choreographer herself, linked by madcap visions of heaven and hell. In a sense her dancers, performing on Thursday night at Dance New Amsterdam, embody spirits, somberly or comically trapped in underworld landscapes, where even Elvis Presley makes an appearance. But it is the concluding “Air,” in which she drops the veneer of storytelling, that is the most stirring.

headline: Slumping Confidence in Bonds Tied to Subprime Mortgages
text: A series of indexes that gauge investor confidence in subprime mortgage bonds dropped sharply this week and neared the pessimistic levels that they last sank to in late February when several large lenders collapsed.

headline: Homeless in New York (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nomination Feud Redraws Battle Lines in Trenton
text: TRENTON, June 15 — Even considering the odd manner in which politics are played in New Jersey, where feuding party colleagues shut down state government and Senate candidates avoid unpopular vice presidents, this week’s dispute over Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s nominee for chief justice of the State Supreme Court was especially curious.

headline: Speedy Reyes and Goméz Help Fuel a Stellar Outing by Pérez
text: In the old days, players did not get their own rooms on road trips. They shared them, leading one to wonder what sort of high jinks would ensue if three of the Mets’ most high-strung players — José Reyes, Carlos Gómez and Oliver Pérez — were roommates.

headline: For the Mets, C Is for Cold Bats and L Is for Lineup Change
text: Manager Willie Randolph opened his pregame interview session with a response straight out of “Sesame Street.” Asked why Carlos Beltrán was moved up to hit second last night, Randolph said, “His name starts with a B and it’s the second letter in the alphabet. How do you like that?”

headline: Prescription for Pain
text: A dozen states are already bucking the federal government and giving the chronically ill access to medical marijuana. Now residents of New York and Connecticut who are ill or dying may soon have that chance to find relief from their pain or nausea.

headline: With a Few Exceptions, the Advice Remains: Don’t Touch That Nest Egg
text: Conventional wisdom says not to pull money out of retirement accounts except for actual retirement. Most Americans have enough difficulty building up a nest egg, and cracking it prematurely could mean living on cat food (slang for Social Security) later.

headline: It Might Pay to Follow Your Bliss
text: REMEMBER the fable about the ant and the grasshopper? The ant works hard all summer, socking away provisions for the winter; the grasshopper frolics away each day. The ant warns the grasshopper that he’s being hedonistic and short-sighted. The grasshopper ignores the ant, and continues on his merry way  only to perish when winter sets in.

headline: The Suicide Anarchists (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: He Wants to Make It Here, Again
text: Roger Clemens could have been in Boston, in a matchup for the aged, going after Barry Bonds and the Giants with his best friend of his athletic old age, the pitch he calls Mr. Splitty. He could have had a pleasant, commuter-friendly night in Houston after facing the Mariners. But who more than Clemens knows that there is no fiercer and famous interleague baseball than the version played in New York, New York?

headline: Sifting the Palestinian Rubble (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fans Online Sift for Clues in the ‘Sopranos’ Finale
text: Nearly a week after the HBO series “The Sopranos” itself went to black forever, the debate about what its final scene — in which the screen goes black for 10 seconds as Tony Soprano and members of his family eat in a diner — might really mean has raged on, especially on blogs. Online, fans have either been railing about the “cop-out” of the ending or trying to fill in the blanks of the final episode themselves (or, often, both).

headline: Polished and Upbeat, Romney Tries to Connect
text: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa — Mitt Romney loves the word “great.” As in, “Have a great day,” “Things are going great,” “I’m feeling great.” Mr. Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, also looks great, sounds great and smells great, like shaving cream. Everyone who asks him something gets a “Thanks, great question.”

headline: Corrections
text: Editors’ Note

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A sports article yesterday about Justin Strzelczyk, a former National Football League player who was found post-mortem to have had early signs of brain damage that experts said was most likely caused by football concussions, misidentified the medical institution where Bennet Omalu, the doctor who made the diagnosis, is a clinical instructor of neuropathology. It is the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, not the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center.

headline: The Handwriting on the Road: An Artist Draws the Flood Line
text: In landscape drawing, lines are usually representations of the contours of the observed world: a horizon, a mountain ridge, a tendril. But a line that the artist Eve S. Mosher began drawing last month is striving for a different kind of effect. To begin with, it is not of the landscape, exactly. It is on it.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on June 9 about preparations for President Bush’s visit to Albania misstated the position of Bernard Kouchner, the new foreign minister of France, before the American-led invasion of Iraq in 2003. Although he advocated removing Saddam Hussein from power with pressure from Europe, the United States and other countries through the United Nations, backed by a continuing military buildup, he did not support the war.

headline: A New Kind of Politics Closely Resembles the Old
text: WASHINGTON, June 15 — Senator Barack Obama often offers a crisp sales pitch to voters, imploring them to be part of something new, different and hopeful. “If you want a new kind of politics,” he says, “it’s time to turn the page.”

headline: Cost of Gas and Food Rose Sharply Last Month
text: Americans felt the pinch of higher gas prices and eroding wages last month, even as an important gauge of inflation drifted lower, government figures showed yesterday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Eyes Antiterror Rules for Small Jets and Boats
text: WASHINGTON, June 15 — Acknowledging that the nation remains too vulnerable to terrorist attack by small planes and recreational boats, the Department of Homeland Security is considering new requirements to allow authorities to identify operators and passengers in millions of these vehicles as they ply the coasts and skies.

headline: Podiums of London Welcome Newcomers
text: LONDON, June 15  The three leading orchestras of this major music capital are now going through changes in artistic leadership. All the newcomers have been in action this week. It’s as if London had deliberately planned a showcase of the new guard for the benefit of those here for the reopening of the Royal Festival Hall.

headline: Insurers Suspend the Marketing of Some Medicare Plans
text: The UnitedHealth Group, Humana and five other insurers are suspending the marketing of some federal government health plans after complaints that unscrupulous agents were duping elderly Americans into buying the coverage.

headline: Globalization in Every Loaf
text: DOWNERS GROVE, Ill.  In a glassed-off area in the headquarters of Sara Lee, a handful of specialists study computer screens and flat-screen televisions beaming the latest weather reports and commodity prices. They are sourcing ingredients from all over the world to make Sara Lee’s assortment of breads, deli meats and microwaveable desserts.

headline: Well, He Did Get an A on the Eating Part
text: I HUNKERED over a six-burner commercial stove, my pulse pounding and my hands dripping with extra virgin olive oil. It was half past noon on an otherwise auspicious Sunday inside a 12th-floor teaching kitchen at the Institute of Culinary Education in the Chelsea section of Manhattan. Eight chicken breasts marinated in fresh garlic and herbs were sizzling on a cast iron grill pan atop the stove — and I was feeling the heat.

headline: Discovering New Truths in Themes Developed Long Ago
text: In its Beethoven Quartets in Context concerts at Carnegie Hall, the Emerson String Quartet has raised the bar for ensembles interested in thematic programming by taking a commonplace idea  presenting the Beethoven quartets with works by other composers  and turning it into a revelatory series. To say that the other composers influenced Beethoven or were influenced by him isn’t saying much when the earlier composers are Bach, Mozart and Haydn, and the successors are anyone who composed after him. But the Emerson has thought deeply about its juxtapositions.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 4 Bystanders in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 16 — A suicide bomber driving a taxi set off his explosives near a convoy of American civilian contractors and accompanying soldiers here this morning, killing himself and four bystanders but only wounding one of his intended targets, the Kabul police said.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report in the Extra Time soccer roundup on Wednesday, about complications surrounding David Beckham’s arrival in the United States to play with the Los Angeles Galaxy, misstated the location of a game scheduled for Oct. 18 between the Galaxy and the Red Bulls that Beckham might miss. It will be in Los Angeles, not at Giants Stadium. (The teams will play on Aug. 18 at Giants Stadium.)

headline: Government Financial Crisis May Claim Jerusalem Symphony
text: TEL AVIV, June 15  On the eve of its 70th anniversary, sharp budget cuts threaten the existence of the Jerusalem Symphony Orchestra.

headline: Former Bush Aide Fights Nickname: Gov. Privatize
text: INDIANAPOLIS — At this rate, critics of Gov. Mitch Daniels grouse, all of Indiana will be run by private corporations.

headline: 7 Men Sentenced in Qaeda Bomb Plot in the U.S. and Britain
text: LONDON, June 15 — A British court handed down lengthy prison sentences on Friday to seven men who served as accomplices to a Qaeda terrorist planning spectacular attacks in the United States and Britain.

headline: Disease Prevention (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Some Curbs Put on the Appetites for Debt and Sugar
text: Consumers cast a worried eye on the bond market as mortgage rates rose, while investors rode a bullish wave to end the week. Blackstone’s founders were poised for a big payoff as they prepared for an initial offering.

headline: Specialist in Tough (to) Love
text: Hype and hokiness aside, some reality shows are appealing because they seem real. Buffalo is the setting for “Confessions of a Matchmaker,” tonight on A&E. Nobody will confuse that town with Hollywood, Manhattan or the castle on “The Bachelor.” Establishing shots show us a gritty, snowy industrial city in the unforgiving north, with a heroine to match.

headline: One Word for Airplane Makers: Plastics
text: PARIS, June 15 — In the 1999 comedy “Pushing Tin,” John Cusack and Billy Bob Thornton portray rival air traffic controllers who spend their workday guiding planes in and out of New York’s airports.

headline: Cherokee Freedmen (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Arizona-Mexico Discussion Focuses on Border Violence
text: TUCSON, June 15 — For more than 50 years the governments of Arizona and its Mexican neighboring state, Sonora, have gathered regularly to strike agreements, pledge cooperation and bask in border bonhomie.

headline: Adult-Only Froot Loops
text: Childhood obesity too often starts at home  in front of the television set. Children are defenseless against the wiles of Madison Avenue, and studies show most cannot understand the difference between an advertisement and the rest of their television fare. Even worse, these snappy ads directed at the young help create bad eating habits for life.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,509 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

headline: Washington’s Secret Gun Files
text: A NARROWLY divided Congress will vote in the coming days on whether to renew legislation that stops the federal government from sharing with local police departments and prosecutors crucial information about guns used in crimes. The Tiahrt amendment, first passed in 2003, prohibits Washington from releasing crime data about guns that used to be provided to state and local law enforcement. If House members reauthorize the measure, they will harm efforts to curtail gun violence in this country.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report in the Metro Briefing column on June 8 gave the wrong date in some copies for the start of audio podcasts on the New York Police Department’s Web site. The podcasts began in September 2005, not last November.

headline: A Criminal in the Suburbs, but With a British Accent
text: Until the dawn of the 23rd century — at the very earliest, you suppose — any new family drama on television seeking to dissect class and criminality will exist in the penumbra of another. The arrival of such a series will call to mind what legendarily came before: its moral inquiries, its occasionally bewildering points of plot. I speak here, of course, of “Knot’s Landing,” the pioneer of subdivision gothic, a genre whose spigots have leaked ever more ghoulishly since.

headline: Iran Strategy Stirs Debate at White House
text: WASHINGTON, June 15 — A year after President Bush and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice announced a new strategy toward Iran, a behind-the-scenes debate has broken out within the administration over whether the approach has any hope of reining in Iran’s nuclear program, according to senior administration officials.

headline: Russia: A ‘Surprise’ Putin Successor Is Hinted
text: A senior adviser to President Vladimir V. Putin, Igor I. Shuvalov, added new intrigue to the question of who might succeed Mr. Putin when he steps down next year. Mr. Shuvalov, in remarks widely reported in Russia, told a conference at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington on Thursday that Mr. Putin might yet turn to someone other than one of the two aides routinely touted as his most likely successor: Sergei B. Ivanov and Dmitri A. Medvedev. “People talk about two candidates, possible candidates,” he said, according to the center, “but, you know, my president could trade another surprise, and maybe even late during this year you will know about another possible figure.” His remarks revived speculation in Russia about other political figures close to Mr. Putin who might yet emerge. Mr. Shuvalov emphasized that Mr. Putin intended to step down, saying he did not want Russia to follow other post-Soviet states, like Belarus and Turkmenistan, whose leaders changed their constitutions to retain authoritarian power.

headline: Speedy Reyes and Gómez Help Fuel a Stellar Outing by Pérez
text: In the old days, players did not get their own rooms on road trips. They shared them, leading one to wonder what sort of high jinks would ensue if three of the Mets’ most high-strung players — José Reyes, Carlos Gómez and Oliver Pérez — were roommates.

headline: Arts Criticism (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Reports of Forced Labor Unsettle China
text: SHANGHAI, June 15  Su Jinduo and Su Jinpeng, brother and sister, were traveling home by bus from a vacation visit to Qingdao during the Chinese New Year when they disappeared.

headline: Streisand Tours, and New York Musicians Cheer
text: Thank you, Barbra.

headline: U.S.G.A.’s Urban Drive Is Well Short
text: Oakmont, Pa.

headline: Bill for Direct Vote to Elect President Is Blocked in Turkey
text: ISTANBUL, June 15 — President Ahmet Necdet Sezer refused Friday to approve a bill that would allow for direct presidential elections, a move that will result in a national referendum on the measure.

headline: Leonard Pickell Jr., 53, Is Dead; Ex-Leader Who Stole From Beard Foundation
text: Leonard F. Pickell Jr., the former president of the James Beard Foundation who was imprisoned for stealing from it after years of promoting it as one of the nation’s top culinary institutions, died on Wednesday at his home in Howell, N.J. He was 53.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a decision by the National Trust for Historic Preservation to declare Brooklyn’s industrial waterfront one of the country’s most endangered historic places misstated the nature of the roofing at the Domino Sugar Refinery in Williamsburg, which is within the area. None of the buildings are topped by a dome; the Revere Sugar Factory in Red Hook, which has been mostly demolished, had a dome.

headline: In Writer’s Trial, Testimony of Life as Strange as Fiction
text: The life of a writer bears about the same relation to the work as everyday reality does to a dream. In both cases, a glancing transformation takes place.

headline: A 66 on a Tough Course Wows a Tough Audience
text: OAKMONT, Pa., June 15 — When the Englishman Paul Casey holed an 18-inch birdie putt at the ninth hole to complete his round of four-under-par 66, the golfers who were putting on the portion of the ninth green that is set aside for practice stopped what they were doing to applaud his effort.

headline: Claudia Cohen, 56, Socialite and a Reporter of Gossip, Is Dead
text: Claudia Cohen, a high-profile gossip reporter for television and newspapers who was a frequent subject of the gossip columns herself, partly because of her marriage to, and remunerative divorce from, the billionaire businessman Ronald O. Perelman, died yesterday in Manhattan. She was 56 and had homes in Manhattan and Easthampton, N.Y.

headline: Penn National Gaming Accepts Takeover Bid
text: The gambling world is dominated by a few high-profile names like MGM Mirage, Wynn Resorts, Harrah’s Entertainment — the same few corporations that, not coincidentally, dominate Las Vegas.

headline: Europe Backs Abbas in Fight for Control of West Bank
text: BRUSSELS, June 15  The European Union extended firm support to the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, on Friday and said it would continue humanitarian and financial aid in the Palestinian territories despite Hamas’s seizure of control in Gaza.

headline: Julie Thoma Wright, 49, Who Helped Create Market for Modern Design, Is Dead
text: Julie Thoma Wright, a founder and co-owner of Wright, the Chicago auction house that helped create the market for 20th-century modern design, died on Monday in Chicago. She was 49.

headline: Clerk Accused of Fixing Tickets for Suspect in Ft. Dix Terror Plot
text: A court clerk in southern New Jersey was dragged into the outer orbit of the Fort Dix terror case this week after she was charged with altering traffic tickets issued to one of the six suspects who have been indicted, the authorities announced yesterday.

headline: Bollywood Goes to Europe and Finds Love
text: If Bollywood has a credo, it might be that everything is possible. The corollary is just as important: Nothing is too big or too obvious. A character is in Paris? Fine. He must dance with his love in front of the Louvre, the Eiffel Tower, the Arc de Triomphe and the Obelisk of Luxor. The song they sing? “Ticket to Hollywood,” of course.

headline: Can a Vision Save All of Africa?
text: It was “Malaria in Africa Week” here in New York. Not officially, of course. But by coincidence, two big malaria-related events took place that were by turns moving, inspiring and invigorating.

headline: Hints of New Kosovo Talks
text: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia, June 15  The United States envoy to Kosovo said Friday that Western nations could put off plans to make the province independent of Serbia, if doing so might bring Russia on board.

headline: Web Help for Getting Mortgage the Criminal Way
text: Want to buy a home, but hampered by bad credit, an empty bank account or no job? No problem!

headline: Contractor Is Shot Twice in Queens
text: A contractor was shot and critically wounded early yesterday as he walked out of his house in the Whitestone section of Queens, the police said.

headline: William C. Mercer, 88, Former Phone Executive, Dies
text: William C. Mercer, the former president and chairman of the New England Telephone Company, died on June 6 in Westwood, Mass. He was 88.

headline: The First Domed City
text: PHOENIX

headline: Juanita Swedenburg, 82, Dies; Won Suit on Wine Shipping
text: Juanita Swedenburg, a Virginia winery and vineyard owner who in 2005 won a battle in the United States Supreme Court to tear down protectionist barriers that kept wineries from shipping directly to consumers in other states, died June 9 at her home in Middleburg, Va. She was 82.

headline: The Dental Needs of Our Children (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Council Budget Is Adopted, With Members’ Pet Projects Identified
text: There were the usual earmarks for things like Boy Scouts and churches, Greek-American radio and day care, even some money sprinkled in for fireworks. Only this time, there was a little more explanation of who was responsible for the money.

headline: Bonnaroo: Hot Chip Seduction
text: MANCHESTER, TENN.–A little Bonnaroo music education: I wandered from the tent where Gillian Welch (and her partner David Rawlings) had just finished two bluegrass-tinged songs with John Paul Jones from Led Zeppelin joining them on mandolin. (Unfortunately, neither one was Led Zeppelin’s “Battle of Evermore.”) I was headed for Hot Chip, the band that matches pumping electronica to plaintive songs, and as I got closer I thought I was misguided: the minor-key tune and steady beat drifting across the field made me think I was heading toward a band playing some mountain hoedown. No, it was Hot Chip, and the steady 16th-note pulse wasn’t old-timey music; it was electronic, but I was seduced by the segue.

headline: Buddies After All
text: Two former undercover detectives in their early 40s look to one another as they confront serious illness in the wake of 9/11.

headline: Gorgeous in Grenada
text: Exterior

headline: Comparing AMGs
Luang Prabang, a city even a cynic can love
text: There’s a lovely thing one can still do in parts of Buddhist Asia. You get up before dawn to buy food at the market. Then you line up with the villagers at the side of the road, taking care to remove your shoes. As the sun rises, a procession of monks in their brilliant orange robes emerges silently from around a corner. Each carries as a tub which the villagers –and you, if you wish — fill with handfuls of fruit, sweets or rice as offerings.

headline: Poor U.S. Finishing Makes Hard Work of Panama
text: Two goals in two minutes from a Landon Donovan penalty and a fine glancing header by Carlos Bocanegra gave the United States a 2-1 victory over Panama in the quarterfinals of the Concacaf Gold Cup in Foxborough, Mass., Saturday. The win sets up a semifinal matchup with Canada Thursday at Soldier Field in Chicago.

headline: Wedding Bells in Queens
text: Couples line up at Queens Borough Hall every Friday   to tie the knot.

headline: Bloomsday!
text: I was just sitting down and reading for the first time in a while in the calm before the storm, and suddenly began to wonder just which way I should be attacking this momentous weekend, wondering which end of the string to pull first, as it were. After all, it’s the U.S. Grand Prix at Indianapolis, but in France, it’s the 24 Hours of Le Mans. Adrian Newey, the all important technical director of Red Bull (and more or less of Toro Rosso), is not over there at Indy this weekend with his F1 teams, Newey is in France at Le Mans with a sports car racing team. No, not as a technical director, Newey is racing as an amateur driver in the 24 hour race!

headline: Bonnaroo: Tool’s Ache and Bombast
text: MANCHESTER, TENN.– “I smell patchouli,” Maynard James Keenan of Tool wisecracked when the band arrived onstage to headline Friday’s Bonnaroo festival lineup. When it was announced, Tool seemed like an odd booking choice for Bonnaroo. The festival’s core of jam bands and grinning fans in tie-dye doesn’t fit Tool’s baleful image. But musically, Tool isn’t that much of a stretch from Bonnaroo’s Saturday headliner, the Police. Both bands are paragons of intricacy, concocting guitar-bass-drum patterns that demand quick fingers and easily slip into odd meters. Both bands have singers who are generally melodic crooners, not shouters or barkers; both Mr. Keenan and Sting have a wistful ache in their voices.

headline: We Come to Bury Him
text: It’s looking more and more like that 10-second blackout at the end of “The Sopranos” was the dark silence inside Tony’s capo.

headline: London Journal: No Standing Please. We’re British.
text: For 10 days in London and Aldeburgh I have been among audiences that certainly seemed to appreciate what they were hearing every bit as much as I did. But one thing I’ve noticed: No matter how excited audiences here get, standing ovations never happen.

headline: 2008: Not-So-New Politics, New Fallout
text: We begin our news summary this morning with an issue that has definitely exercised Caucus readers. Adam Nagourney posted on the backstory of a memo, released “without attribution” by Senator Barack Obama’s campaign but ultimately procured and re-released by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign, which included critical analyses of her finances. Today, The Times’s Jeff Zeleny steps back to examine how this and other wrinkles affect the sheen on Mr. Obama’s “new kind of politics.”

headline: Under the Senate Leader’s Tent
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer once memorably declared at a public meeting with top lawmakers that they were convening in “my room” with “my rules.” Last Monday, Senate majority leader Joseph L. Bruno invited the governor to his lavish annual picnic for Senate Republicans at his upstate farm. “This is my tent,” the majority leader was said to have quipped, “my farm.” The Legislative session ends next Thursday, and the outcome of several issues will depend on how well the state’s top Democrat and Republican are getting along. By the end of this week, they were skirmishing again at a public negotiating session, where Mr. Bruno called the governor’s campaign finance proposals “nuts” and “nonsense.”

headline: Posada at First, Celebs on the Field, and More
text: Some tidbits before the start of Saturday’s Subway Series game…

headline: Bonnaroo: Late Night Led Zep Medleys and Passed-out Fans
text: MANCHESTER, TENN.–Bonnaroo’s late nights are bewildering. After the headline set, the mid-level jam bands vamp into the night. The same fields where I’ve been wandering all day are now unevenly lighted and populated by more or less vertical dancers, seated groups and sacked-out people who peaked too early to get back to their campgrounds. It’s a tribute to the courtesy of Bonnaroo’s audience that more people don’t wake up with footprints on them.

headline: Pre-Race Celebrity
text: While I was walking through the back of pit lane at the 24 Hours of Le Mans, only minutes before the drop of the green flag at 3:00 p.m. (9:00 a.m. E.S.T.), a teenage boy came running toward me. In his right hand he had a racing helmet, in his left a black magic marker. “Oh no,” I thought, “this kid thinks I’m a one of the race car drivers!” Dressed in a Corvette Racing team jumpsuit and still fresh-faced from the pre-race excitement, maybe I did have an aura of self-confidence and that bouncy walk that racecar drivers have perfected. Still, I couldn’t lie.

headline: A Wild Afternoon in the Bronx
text: In case you hadn’t heard, Omar Minaya is featured in a lengthy cover article in this week’s Sports Illustrated, written by the excellent Gary Smith. Minaya said that he was initially reluctant to open up so much about his private life and family history, but that he felt it was important to perpetuate the memory of his parents, who are deceased. His children, Teddy and Justin, never met them.

headline: Young people of a Rwandan pygmy village
Where Is the U.S. Soccer Team’s Killer Instinct?
text: Another win, but a whole host of missed opportunities. The United States reached the semifinals of the CONCACAF Gold Cup with a 2-1 win over Panama Saturday, but where is the Americans’ killer instinct? What does U.S. coach Bob Bradley need to do to get his team to stop misfiring and to start scoring goals early and often?

headline: Roommates Who Almost Weren’t
text: AS soon as Chris Roan and Justin Fluck become colleagues — as advertising salesmen at the satirical newspaper The Onion — they became friends. Later, they became roommates. The first was effortless. The second, not so much.

headline: Miles to Go Before They Sleep
text: In politics, reaching consensus is more difficult in good times than in bad. Both Republicans and Democrats had big ideas about how to spend a large surplus that now approaches $1 billion. But endless debate and discussion over six months never helped them find common ground. Now the General Assembly needs a special session to complete the most basic task of government: passing a budget.

headline: The New Lady Chatterley: Sober, Sensual, French
text: THE years have not been kind to Lady Chatterley. Nor for that matter have the movies. Scandalous in her day, the sexual adventuress of D. H. Lawrence’s best-known novel has matured into something of a pop-culture joke, remembered less as a symbol of erotic liberation than a soft-core staple of late-night cable.

headline: Nascar Watches as Team Blends Oil and Water
text: Beer cans rained down on Jeff Gordon’s No. 24 Chevrolet back on April 29, when he accomplished the unthinkable, winning at Talladega Superspeedway to surpass the beloved Dale Earnhardt and move into sixth place on the career Nascar victory list. It was messy and mean, and perfectly in keeping with fans that are maniacally devoted to all things Earnhardt.

headline: For Questions and Complaints

headline: An Elegy for Three Sisters. Chekhov? No, Wasserstein.
text: There’s a moment in Act II of Wendy Wasserstein’s “Sisters Rosensweig” in which Geoffrey Duncan, the bisexual theater director, mourns all the friends he has lost to AIDS: “I’ve seen too many lights that never had their chance to glow burn out overnight. I’ve tried for years to make sense of all this, and all I know is life is random.” Today, those lines stand as a lament for Ms. Wasserstein herself, whose inimitable voice was prematurely stilled last year, when she died of lymphoma at 55.

headline: Hamas May Find It Needs Its Enemy
text: ISLAMIST fighters of Hamas seized control of Gaza last week. For the first time in the history of the Palestinians’ fight for nationhood, there seemed a real possibility that two Palestines rather than one might emerge — one in Gaza, dominated by Hamas, the other in the West Bank, led by Fatah.

headline: As Leaders Tumble Back, Woods Is There to Meet Them

headline: Thinking Beyond Asphalt
text: The announcement that the state Department of Transportation plans to extend regional train service to sporting events is a good sign that the department is no longer trying to pave over the entire state but is shifting its focus to mass transit. This is welcome news in a state whose neglect of mass transit has led to more air pollution and congested highways.

headline: It’s Not Over Until the Bride’s Father Sings
text: I COULDN’T have found a more effective way to break my father’s heart. I eloped to City Hall — a dingy room in the Manhattan Municipal Building, to be specific.

headline: 5 Die in Kabul Suicide Blast; U.S. Gunfire Kills Afghan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 16  A suicide bomber driving a taxi set off his explosives near a convoy of United States civilian contractors and accompanying soldiers here Saturday morning, killing himself and four bystanders, the Kabul police said. One of his intended targets was wounded.

headline: Children’s Books
text: The colonial upper classes had a problem: keeping the lower classes down. They solved it by hypnotizing the middle class with “the language of liberty and equality.” This trick caused the middle class to ignore the plights of black slaves, poor whites and Indians and to fight King George. Our nation was born.

headline: Air Power
text: If HBO is looking to develop a series based on environmental politics, then “Cape Wind: Money, Celebrity, Class, Politics, and the Battle for Our Energy Future on Nantucket Sound” is a natural for the option, with the Kennedys sitting in for the Sopranos, Nantucket Sound for the Meadowlands and phrases like “environmental impact statement” replacing “swimming with the fishes.” Cameos will include Elizabeth Taylor as the former wife of the anti-wind-farm Senator John Warner; Warner’s former mother-in-law Bunny Mellon, the nonagenarian Listerine heiress who decorated the Kennedy White House (behind the scenes) and helped establish the Oyster Harbors Club; and Walter Cronkite, who, as the co-authors Wendy Williams and Robert Whitcomb have it, starts out on the side of darkness only to turn toward the light, or in this case, the wind. The setting is Horseshoe Shoal, about five miles off the coast of Cape Cod, where, in 2001, an energy developer named Jim Gordon proposed what he still hopes will be America’s first offshore wind farm, an array of 130 turbines, 440 feet tall, that would create 468 megawatts of electrical energy, the only dangerous fumes being those emanating from the mad-as-hell multimillion-dollar homeowners on the Cape, Martha’s Vineyard and Nantucket.

text: I am competing for a job at a firm that does work for a tobacco company on whose account I would have to work. This makes me deeply uncomfortable. headline: First-Family Values
text: It’s a good bet that whoever moves into the White House in January 2009 will offer the American people a more contemporary tableau of family life than the one we have witnessed for the last six years. George and Laura Bush seem to be an admirably well-suited and loving couple, the very model of a first family (minus a few untoward events involving the kids). They’re a throwback couple, like Rob and Laura Petrie from “The Dick Van Dyke Show” — one amiable and slightly buffoonish, the other tolerant and wryly exasperated. The fictional Laura (played by Mary Tyler Moore) was a lot goofier than the real one; but each knew her place, which was in the home, by the side of her man.

headline: A 50-Year-Old Upstart Redefines ‘Emerging’
text: AT his film studio on Lafayette Street downtown, Michael Somoroff and his team were shooting a commercial for Taco Bell: one assistant adjusted the lighting, another rearranged tomatoes and a few artfully strewn sprigs of cilantro. Two days earlier Mr. Somoroff had been standing in a Napa Valley industrial hanger, watching the final stages of construction on “Illumination I,” a 12-ton sculpture to be installed on the grounds of the Rothko Chapel in Houston. All part of the double life of an up-and-coming artist.

headline: Impounded Fathers

headline: A Father Never Stops Counting
text: I’VE done the math more than once over the past 38 years. The first time was in 1969. I was a typical unfocused, unkempt, underachieving and generally unrepentant sixth-year antiwar undergraduate at the University of Wisconsin. In a drafty cottage on Lake Kegonsa, with my brand new colicky son howling into my shoulder, I would pace across the messy living room, back and forth, my lips and fingers desperately trying to quantify how many years, months, days, minutes until the tiny screamer would be 18 and I’d be my free and easy hipster self again.

headline: Correction: The Week of June 3-9: You Can’t Be Too Careful
text: A graphic last Sunday about health and safety issues misspelled the name of a new diagnosis for the shoulder pain caused by playing tennis on Wii, the video game console. It is acute Wiiitis, not Wiitis. The article also omitted the name of the journal that published the letter in which the diagnosis, and its name, was reported. It is The New England Journal of Medicine.

headline: Who Needs Pocket Change When You’ve Got Plastic?
text: Every morning on his way to the Concord, Calif., high school where he teaches physical education and health, John Nunan buys his breakfast. After he swipes his card through the reader, his bank debits the purchase from his account. He often repeats the process for lunch and dinner.

headline: Home Alone
text: For decades, students of American society have offered dueling theories about how encountering racial and ethnic diversity affects the way we live. One says that simple contact — being tossed into a stew of different cultures, values, languages and styles of dress — is likely to nourish tolerance and trust. Familiarity, in this view, trumps insularity. Others argue that just throwing people together is rarely enough to breed solidarity: when diversity increases, they assert, people tend to stick to their own groups and distrust those who are different from them.

headline: Not in My Front Yard

headline: Twilight of the Trainspotters?
