headline: Ferry and Wineries Extend Tourism Campaign
text: A CAMPAIGN begun in March to attract New Englanders to tourist-related businesses on the North Fork with discounts at wineries and restaurants and on the Cross Sound Ferry has been extended through the summer, organizers say.

headline: European Contender Has History to Overcome
text: OAKMONT, Pa.

headline: Water Shed
text: The French know a thing or two about symmetry. In the late 19th century, the picturesque banks of the Seine west of Paris were a favorite subject of the Impressionists; Renoir painted his famous “Luncheon of the Boating Party” on the balcony of the Maison Fournaise, on an island (now called L’Ãle des Impressionnistes) at Chatou. Today, floating just next door to the Maison Fournaise (restored as a restaurant), there is an artistic enterprise that is as modern now as the Impressionists were then. The Centre National de l’Estampe et de l’Art Imprimé, or Cneai — a contemporary art center devoted to prints, multiples and artist publications — commissioned the Paris-based designers Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec, who are brothers, to design a dwelling for its artist-in-residence program. But instead of a house, Cneai asked for a houseboat — a reference to the bateaux-lavoirs, or laundry boats, that dotted the river until the early 20th century. The new structure, however, needed a contemporary form.

headline: Olmert Assails Hamas and Vows Cooperation With Abbas
text: JERUSALEM, June 16 —Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel, deploring the “brutality of the Palestinians against their own people,” said that Israel would “cooperate fully” with a new government installed by the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas.

headline: Ryan Adams Didn’t Die. Now the Work Begins.
text: ONE afternoon, as Ryan Adams was recording his new album, “Easy Tiger” (Lost Highway), at Electric Lady Studios in Greenwich Village, the singer-songwriter Steve Earle dropped by to visit. Jimi Hendrix had built Electric Lady in the late 1960s, and Mr. Earle pointed out that “there are some good ghosts here.”

headline: Kaitlin Rahl, Nicholas Brandt
text: Katherine Farrell Rahl and Nicholas Doran Brandt were married last evening at the Madison Beach Club in Madison, Conn. The Rev. Nancy E.R. Leckerling, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

headline: L. L. Bean May Let You Try Gear at Maine Center
text: L. L. Bean in Freeport, Me., has long been a destination for those in search of everything from a fishing rod to flannel sheets. Now, the 95-year-old retailer has plans to lure sports enthusiasts with a nearby outdoor adventure center, where customers will actually be able to try out the equipment (and the sport) before investing in the gear.

headline: Sarah Kramer, Robert Fenster
text: Sarah Elizabeth Kramer, the daughter of Rachel Schwartz and Dr. Peter D. Kramer of Providence, R.I., is to be married there today to Robert Jonathan Fenster, the son of Albert Fenster of New York and the late Mollyanne Marks and the stepson of Gail Sanger. Rabbi Wayne Franklin is to officiate at the Aldrich House, a 19th-century mansion that is used for public events.

headline: Storefront Takeout, From Scratch
text: The comfort food that Church’s Kitchen serves is sustenance not only for the stomach, but also for the soul. The golden-fried chicken, juicy with a crispy crust, is just one of the many homey choices on the menu at this family-run takeout shop in the Vauxhall area of Union.

headline: A Constellation of Tauruses
text: NINE flying white Ford Tauruses, intertwined with ribbons of light and hovering inside a gallery space went on display recently at the Seattle Art Museum (seattleartmuseum.org). They are part of an art piece by Cai Guo-Qiang, the Chinese artist who lives in New York City, called “Inopportune: Stage One.” The same piece had been installed at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art.

headline: When Is a Pain Doctor a Drug Pusher?
text: Ronald McIver is a prisoner in a medium-security federal compound in Butner, N.C. He is 63 years old, of medium height and overweight, with a white Santa Claus beard, white hair and a calm, direct and intelligent manner. He is serving 30 years for drug trafficking, and so will likely live there the rest of his life. McIver (pronounced mi-KEE-ver) has not been convicted of drug trafficking in the classic sense. He is a doctor who for years treated patients suffering from chronic pain. At the Pain Therapy Center, his small storefront office not far from Main Street in Greenwood, S.C., he cracked backs, gave trigger-point injections and put patients through physical therapy. He administered ultrasound and gravity-inversion therapy and devised exercise regimens. And he wrote prescriptions for high doses of opioid drugs like OxyContin.

headline: Lessons in Giving, and Getting, More
text: MINEOLA, N.Y.

headline: Brooke Harlow, Kevin Lynyak
text: Drew Brooke Harlow and Kevin Scott Lynyak were married yesterday afternoon at St. Mary, Our Lady of the Isle Roman Catholic Church on Nantucket in Massachusetts. The Rev. Timothy R. Scully officiated.

headline: Molly Krause, Edward Fienning
text: Mary Alice Krause, a daughter of Alice and Peter C. Krause of New York, was married yesterday to First Lt. Edward Baldwin Fienning, a son of Suzanne and Charles E. Fienning of Sumter, S.C. The Rev. Edward W. Fitzgerald officiated at St. Mary of the Annunciation Roman Catholic Church in Charleston, S.C.

headline: 36 Hours in Milan
text: MILAN doesn't cater to tourists. Its many pleasures are intended mainly for the Milanese, who are expert at making — and spending — money. This is the home, after all, of Armani and Prada. But step outside the central shopping district and you'll find a growing number of stores that showcase young fashion and furniture designers. There's also an exploding restaurant scene. Sri Lankan food may be as easy to find as anything cooked alla Milanese (battered and fried). In fact, the only meal that may elude you is “The Last Supper.”

headline: The Year of the Goat
text: Five years ago, when my boyfriend and I traveled to South Texas to interview for a job to cook on a ranch, our prospective employers — the ranch owners — did a crafty thing. They took us to Nuevo Laredo, the Mexican town just across the Rio Grande from Laredo, to seduce us with some “this is why it’s fun to live in Texas” persuasion. First stop: margaritas at the Cadillac Bar (oh, how they flowed), and then we taxied to a restaurant famous for tender, smoky, spit-roasted goat. The next morning, I embraced two new truths: I had accepted a life-changing job in rural isolation and a favorite new meat to barbecue.

headline: A Final Swing Typifies Beltrán’s Struggles
text: The impulse in Carlos Beltrán’s brain fired a signal through his spinal column, to his hands, to his legs, that told him to swing at the first pitch from Mariano Rivera. He knew it would be a cut fastball. How could Beltrán not? That’s what Rivera does. But when that cutter zipped toward him, darting upward at the last millisecond, Beltrán swung and popped up.

headline: The Boys in the Band Are in AARP
text: DARREN REIS isn’t opposed to the band practice that takes place in his house every Tuesday night. But there’s only so much loud rock music he is willing to tolerate. So when the umpteenth rendition of the Monkees’ “Last Train to Clarksville” starts rattling the windows, he goes downstairs, knocks on the door and makes his entreaty: “Dad, do you think you guys could keep it down? I’m trying to study.”

headline: Ashley Snowdon, Elliott Blanchard
text: Ashley Hill Snowdon, a daughter of Susie Snowdon of McLean, Va., and Richard W. Snowdon III of Washington, was married yesterday afternoon to Alan Elliott Blanchard, a son of Ann E. Blanchard and Alan F. Blanchard of New York. The Rev. Douglass T. Lind, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of Stonington, Conn.

headline: The Shoe Changes, but the Fit Doesn’t. He Can Explain.
text: THE shoe is about as elemental as it gets. Although the materials, the designs and the manufacturing process have changed tremendously over the last 150 years, a shoe still comes down to a sole connected to an upper part, with inner support for the foot.

headline: Evita Torre, Christopher Walsh
text: Evita Nancy Sison Torre, the daughter of Dr. Evita Q. Sison-Torre and Dr. Pablo L. Torre Jr. of Manhattan, was married yesterday to Christopher Edward Walsh, a son of Maureen Walsh and Gerard J. Walsh of Rockaway Park, Queens. The Rev. Alfredo Balinong, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the University Parish, Church of St. Joseph in Manhattan.

headline: Correction: Time’s Guardian
text: An article on June 3 about the city’s clock master, Marvin Schneider, inaccurately described a 5,000-pound bell that rings hourly in the Clock Tower Building. The bell is bronze, not brass. (Go to Article)

headline: A Family in Harmony
text: WHAT if you traded goombahs for goofballs and whack jobs for wacky musical numbers? You’d get something like “Flight of the Conchords,” the new series making its debut tonight as part of HBO’s now Sopranos-less Sunday night lineup.

headline: Working Under a New Title, but Using the Same Albany Charm
text: White Plains

headline: Ah, to Be Old, Male and Single
text: MANHATTAN may have a scarcity of affordable apartments and parking spaces, but apparently it has no shortage of older widows and comely divorcées, many of whom wanted to date my newly widowed father. Whenever I visited him at his Upper East Side apartment, it was not uncommon for us to be interrupted by the doorman calling up to say, “A lady just left a Bundt cake downstairs.”

headline: Palestinian Split Poses a Policy Quandary for U.S.
text: JERUSALEM, June 16 — With the two Palestinian territories increasingly isolated from each other by a week of brutal warfare between rival factions, Israel and the United States seem agreed on a policy to treat them as separate entities to support Fatah in the West Bank and squeeze Hamas in the Gaza Strip.

headline: Julia Green, Andrew Shane
text: Julia Claire Green and Andrew Lawrence Shane, lawyers, were married last evening by Cantor Bruce Ruben at the New-York Historical Society in New York.

headline: The Watch List
text: Pirates shortstop JACK WILSON was on the bench for four consecutive games last week, with some speculating that a lack of hustle on defense had landed him there. After a meeting with team officials, Wilson, right, a former All-Star, played Friday and had hits in his first two at-bats.

headline: What’s Insured and What Isn’t
text: A SURVEY by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners has found that many people believe their homeowners’ insurance covers losses that are not, in fact, covered.

headline: F.D.A. Tracked Poisoned Drugs, but Trail Went Cold in China
text: After a drug ingredient from China killed dozens of Haitian children a decade ago, a senior American health official sent a cable to her investigators: find out who made the poisonous ingredient and why a state-owned company in China exported it as safe, pharmaceutical-grade glycerin.

headline: Bus Bombing Kills at Least 24 in Afghan Capital
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 17 — A mammoth explosion tore through a police bus in the heart of Kabul on Sunday, killing at least 24 people — 22 of them police academy instructors on their way to work — in one of the deadliest insurgent attacks in Afghanistan since the fall of the Taliban in 2001.

headline: North Toward Home
text: Thornton Blackburn is hardly a household name, but he was an important figure in the history of American slavery. In “I’ve Got a Home in Glory Land,” the historian and archaeologist Karolyn Smardz Frost rescues him from obscurity and shows how he helped make Canada a safe haven for fugitive slaves.

headline: A Friday Night Out, a Bloody Bar Fight, and the Death of a Brother
text: Nothing seemed out of the ordinary when Carlos Tenemaza ambled to the men’s room in a Bronx tavern late Friday, feeling a slight glow from the night’s first beer. He was with his brother, Jose, and a friend, and they were standing by the pool table, bantering with a group of men.

headline: The Week in Westchester
text: Dozens of students at a Yorktown middle school became ill last month apparently because they drank too much flavored milk during a giveaway — not because the beverages were tainted.

headline: A Little Night Music
text: BELOW ground, on the subway platform for the No. 1 train at Lincoln Center, Martin Jennings — “Serious Music Man,” as his business card declares — is preparing for his 10:23 p.m. performance. An Englishman in his mid-40s, he readies himself, his aluminum music stand holding a complete score of Sergei Prokofiev’s “Romeo and Juliet,” not the standard subway saxophonist’s fare. Mr. Jennings, who is tall and dark-haired, wears a red velvet jacket; he keeps time on the tenor sax with the tap of a black Oxford.

headline: Where Thieves Lurk, Making a Wary Living
text: Every night, before he shuts off the lights of his bodega in South Ozone Park, Queens, Reynaldo Rojas takes out some plastic bags and fills them with dozens of cigarette packs and phone cards from behind the counter. He empties the cigar box he uses as a cash register and tucks a wad of bills into his pants.

headline: Making the House Party a Movable Feast
text: SOME husbands, if they remember, present their wives with a gift made of tin or aluminum on their 10th anniversary. Not Jeffrey Dishner. Instead, the chief operating officer of the Starwood Capital Group plotted — with the help of Homebase Abroad, a luxury villa company that specializes in Italy — to arrange a week in Tuscany last year as a surprise for his wife, Cathy, to be shared with more than two dozen friends and family members.

headline: Don’t Listen to What the Man Says
text: If the Supreme Court, with its new conservative majority, wanted to announce that it was getting out of the fairness business, it could hardly have done better than its decision last week in the case of Keith Bowles. The court took away Mr. Bowles’s right to challenge his murder conviction in a ruling that was so wrong and mean-spirited that it seemed like an outtake from MTV’s practical joke show “Punk’d.”

headline: Sun’s Success Assists Casino and W.N.B.A.
text: UNCASVILLE

headline: A Cozy Inn With Upscale Cuisine
text: I CAN’T imagine that there is a bad season for visiting the Bee and Thistle Inn in Old Lyme. Late spring, however, is unquestionably a great season.

headline: Correction: Snapshots That Do More Than Bore Friends
text: The Practical Traveler column on June 10 about sharing photographs online misspelled the surname of a man who chronicled the travels of his family around the world on SmugMug.com, a photo-sharing Web site. He is John Higham, not Highman.

headline: With a Big Name Out, a New Favorite Emerges
text: OAKMONT, Pa., June 16  After the early exit of one of the fan favorites, Phil Mickelson, the crowds at Oakmont Country Club threw their voices behind another lovable American left-hander, who is trying to win his first United States Open.

headline: Periodically at the Table
text: Westport, Conn.

headline: Into the Wood
text: A biography of a late-18th-century English artist whose medium was the woodblock? I confess to having been bewildered by the assignment. Why would anyone care? I thumbed through the book, which is filled with illustrations of country scenes, each about two inches across. Charming enough, at first glance, the kind of sentimental drawings found on packages of soap or seeds, meant to suggest old-time value. Then I got to the beasts — the foumart, the cur fox, the baboon, the Chillingham bull — and suddenly, gazing at a handsome illustration of a lion, I remembered, as a child, pulling down an impossibly heavy old leatherbound book of fables, full of magical drawings of wolves and crows and bears, intense in their detail while managing to leave much to the imagination. A few days later, a friend sent me Donald Hall’s book about Eagle Pond, his home in New Hampshire, and there were more woodcuts: of skaters on the ice, a dog curled at his master’s feet, clouds billowing over mountains, clapboard houses and placid streams. Apart from slicing my palm open with an X-Acto knife while cutting a picture into a block of linoleum during seventh-grade art class, I haven’t spent five seconds thinking about woodcuts. Yet they’re everywhere you look.

headline: Taking the Cannoli to a New Level
text: Are you a cannoli lover who thinks the traditional Italian dessert can’t be improved on? Then visit Homestyle Desserts Bakery in Peekskill for one of their latest creations.

headline: Move by North Korea to Allow Inspectors Is Welcomed
text: SEOUL, June 17 - Officials in South Korea and the United States today welcomed a move by North Korea to invite the United Nations nuclear watchdog back to the Communist state for the first time in four and a half years to discuss shutting down the North’s main nuclear complex.

headline: Eva Temkin, David Lehn Jr.
text: Eva Abigail Temkin and David Mark Lehn Jr., both litigation associates at law firms, were married on Friday at the United States Federal Courthouse in Brooklyn. The officiant was Judge John Gleeson of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York.

headline: Letters
text: Balancing the Pay Scale

headline: Jennifer Morris, Michael Gollust
text: Jennifer Jean Morris and Michael Adam Gollust were married last evening at Pochron Studios, a photography studio and loft space in Brooklyn. The Rev. Kim Kirkley, an interfaith minister, officiated.

headline: Will Blackstone Have the Honor of Its Own Tax Law?
text: LAST week, Uncle Sam made his first foray into possibly raising taxes on the private equity and hedge fund industry with what Wall Street has dubbed “the Blackstone bill.”

headline: Now Showing: The Pager and the Noisy Moviegoer
text: When the lights go out at the movies, the sound of crunching popcorn and the slurping of sodas can be bad enough. But what about that annoying woman three rows back who not only leaves her cellphone on, but answers it when it rings? Not to mention that beefy guy at the end of the row who insists on narrating the onscreen action?

headline: The Best Seat Above the House
text: Jim Maloney Jr. gave me a lift to Yankee Stadium on Thursday so that I could enjoy a seat he has been using for the past 25 years.

headline: Presidential Stone Walls
text: The template for the Bush administration’s mania for secrecy was signed by the president six years ago — Executive Order 13233, reversing the presumption of right of public access to presidential papers. This basic right of taxpayers and historians alike was embedded in the 1978 laws enacted after the Nixon administration. The reforms established a reasonable 12-year waiting period for access. But Mr. Bush’s reversal lets presidents or vice presidents (guess who?) keep their records sealed in perpetuity unless they or their heirs approve access.

headline: Bookshelf
text: EVERY FRIDAY. By Dan Yaccarino. Henry Holt. $16.95. (Ages 3 to 7) “Friday is my favorite day,” a small boy tells us, because every Friday he and his dad go for breakfast together at the local diner. In cheerful gouache illustrations, they wave to passersby, watch shops open and buildings going up; “everyone is rushing, but we’re taking our time.” A note from the author tells us the book is based on his weekly ritual with his own son. It is also a valentine to good dads and neighborhood diners, and a reminder on Father’s Day that the “little traditions” are sometimes the best ones.

headline: Curb Job
text: Taxi drivers are the most enduring oppressed minority in New York City history. Race, ethnicity and religion are not sources of the oppression. It lies entirely in the nature of the work. Trapped for about 12 hours each day in the worst traffic in the United States, taxi drivers must suffer the savage frustrations of jammed streets, double-parked cars, immense trucks, drivers from New Jersey — and they can’t succumb to the explosive therapy of road rage. Their living depends on self-control.

headline: Take It Slow, Don’t Have Many Kids and Enjoy Cold Water
text: ESKIMO hunters killed a bowhead whale off the coast of Alaska last month and began to chainsaw their way into its blubber. They stopped when the saw hit the tip of an old harpoon lodged deep inside the whale. Historians identified it last week as part of a bomb lance, a harpoon manufactured for only a few years in the late 1800s in New Bedford, Mass. Whalers probably fired it at the bowhead around 1890, when the whale was probably a teenager, and it carried the harpoon for the next 115 years before finally being killed by a modern one.

headline: Brooke Pederson, Peter Lund
text: Brooke Elizabeth Pederson, the daughter of Marcia and Timothy Pederson of Chesterfield, Mo., was married yesterday to Peter Bailey Lund, the son of Judith Bailey and Michael S. Lund of Washington. The Rev. Paul S. Hammer, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Portage Point Inn in Onekama, Mich.

headline: In War-Crimes Trial, a Signal to Africans (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Scooter’s Sopranos Go to the Mattresses
text: AS a weary nation awaited the fade-out of "The Sopranos" last Sunday, the widow of the actual Mafia don John Gotti visited his tomb in Queens to observe the fifth anniversary of his death. Victoria Gotti was not pleased to find reporters lying in wait.

headline: Correction: When Should a Kid Start Kindergarten?
text: An article on June 3 about the age that children start kindergarten omitted the name of an author of a seminal paper that analyzed the topic. The co-author (with Kelly Bedard) of “The Persistence of Early Childhood Maturity: International Evidence of Long-Run Age Effects” is Elizabeth Dhuey.

headline: When Does a Housing Slump Become a Bust?
text: MANY Americans fear the consequences of a housing bust, but few know what one would really look like.

headline: Mea Culpa, Said the Bond Market Watchers
text: THE stock market has spent the better part of the last two weeks trying to figure out what higher bond yields really mean for equities. So far, it’s hard to conclude very much, except that higher yields have brought higher volatility to stocks, with the Dow Jones industrial average having either lost or gained more than 100 points in five of the last eight trading days.

headline: Correction
text: An article on Page 48 of The Times Magazine today, about Dr. Ronald McIver, who is imprisoned for drug trafficking, gives an erroneous account of the trial testimony of one of his patients, Leslie Smith. Mr. Smith testified that he injected drugs that Dr. McIver prescribed; he did not testify that Dr. McIver sold the drugs.

headline: Recycling With a Twist: When Trash Becomes Art
text: STAMFORD, Conn., June 15 — From afar, the giant object that appears to have cartwheeled into Latham Park looks like a bright-red starburst. On closer view, it consists of six metal filing cabinets that have been welded in an acrobatic design that almost defies gravity.

headline: Lauren Porcaro, Christopher Dorment Jr.
text: Lauren Cathleen Porcaro and Christopher S. Dorment Jr. were married yesterday at St. Benedict Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx. Msgr. Edmund J. Whalen performed the ceremony.

headline: Christian Composer, Inspired by Allah’s 99 Names
text: CHILDE OKEFORD, England

headline: The Week on Long Island
text: While Nassau County could break even this year with proper management, it has a projected budget deficit of $142 million next year before any corrective measures are taken and a gap of $241 million by 2010, according to Eric C. Naughton, director of the county’s Office of Legislative Budget Review.

headline: G.I.’s in Iraq Open Big Offensive Against Al Qaeda
text: BAGHDAD, June 16 — With the influx of tens of thousands of additional combat troops into Iraq now complete, American forces have begun a wide offensive against Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia on the outskirts of Baghdad, the top American commander in Iraq said Saturday.

headline: Love Is All Around
text: EVERY Friday outside the red brick facade of Queens Borough Hall in Kew Gardens, couples in various modes of dress — including the occasional long white gown — can be seen filing past a stained sign written in faded black marker. An arrow labeled “Summons Line” points to the left; another, labeled “Marriage,” points right.

headline: Those Eyes. That Grin. Those Ding Dongs.
text: IN nearly every episode of the first season of “CHiPs” a Volkswagen Beetle the color of a blood orange putters somewhere in the background, riding down the highway or parked at an illicit auto chop shop. An odd thing to notice, perhaps, but then, the featherweight 1977-83 motorcycle-cop series, which gave television one of its earliest and most popular Latino action heroes in Erik Estrada, leaves plenty of room for a not-unsatisfied mind to wander. Take it from someone who has counted (for a while anyway) the Beetles in it.

headline: AMG: Passcode to Absolute Power in a Mercedes-Benz
text: MUSCLE cars are inseparable from America and the ’60s, their innocence sweetly harmonized by the Beach Boys, their more sinister side chronicled in films from “Bullitt” to “Grindhouse.”

headline: Royal Festival Hall Reopens After Facelift
text: The South Bank of the Thames in London — home of the Tate Modern and Shakespeare’s Globe theater — welcomed a new version of an old favorite on June 11 with the reopening of the Royal Festival Hall.

headline: Time Travel
text: A Great Gatsby afternoon dance and picnic on June 9 opened the series of free summer weekends on the 150 acres of the historic section of Governors Island, a six-minute ferry ride from the southern tip of Manhattan. Many of the guests dressed in period clothes to dance under the shade trees to Michael Arenella and His Dreamland Orchestra.

headline: In the Heart of Hempstead
text: Hempstead Village has seen two recent attempts to revitalize its streetscape, both well-meaning and both badly flawed. One involved dropping big-box chain stores onto the edges of downtown, in the belief that the answer to tired old blight is fresh new blight. The other is an infusion of cash to put new streetlights and trash cans on Franklin Avenue as it enters Hempstead from Garden City, prettifying one of the most jarring boundaries between rich and poor, white and nonwhite, leafy streets and mean ones that you will see in any part of staunchly segregated Long Island.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Blame a Lack of Enforcement

headline: Tara Lowenberg, Scott Lonker
text: Tara Alexis Lowenberg, the daughter of Dr. Marc Lowenberg of New York and the late Sandra Ross Lowenberg, was married last evening to Scott Isaac Lonker, the son of Lyn Lipschutz of Lambertville, N.J., and Michael Lonker of Los Angeles. Rabbi Jay Henry Moses officiated at the home of the bride’s father in Water Mill, N.Y.

headline: One Place Where Everything Is Harmonious
text: SOME guys like to play golf in their free time. Others prefer fishing. And then there are those fellows whose hobby involves getting together with about 85 other men to sing barbershop harmony.

headline: Catherine Tynan, Brendan O’Dwyer
text: Catherine Anne Tynan, a daughter of Mary Ann and Patrick Tynan of Dedham, Mass., was married last evening to Brendan Keith O’Dwyer, the son of Marianna and Brian O’Dwyer of New York. Janet Weston, a friend of the bride’s family, was authorized by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate at Gedney Farm in New Marlborough, Mass.

headline: Julie King, Daniel Oliver
text: Julie Frances King and Daniel Geoff Oliver were married yesterday in Canton, Ohio. The Rev. Ronald M. Klingler performed the ceremony at St. John the Baptist Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Crashing Cars When They’re Still a Gleam in the Designer’s Eye
text: WITH fuel prices high and the pressure to reduce carbon dioxide emissions rising, automakers are finding themselves in the familiar squeeze of balancing customer wants with government mandates.

headline: Can Pakistan Mix Well With Democracy?
text: TENS of thousands of pro-Western moderates took to the streets of Pakistan recently and demanded an end to military rule. Benazir Bhutto, the country’s exiled former prime minister, is offering to return and push for democracy, which she says would act as an antidote to extremism.

headline: Page Travelstead, Joshua Keay
text: Page Ware Travelstead, the daughter of Brooke and Malcolm Travelstead of Climax, N.Y., was married there last evening to Joshua Blackmer Keay, the son of Marcia P. Keay and David B. Keay of Cape Coral, Fla. Robert Aberlin, a minister affiliated with the Rose Ministries, officiated at Bluestone Farm, the bride’s family home.

headline: Recent Immigrants and Latino Religion; Water Towers: Old and Reliable; Crack Down on Sidewalk Sheds; Vital Decisions for the Dying; Growing Up at the Library (5 Letters)
text: Recent Immigrants and Latino Religion

headline: Debating the Benefits of Wind Power (2 Letters)
text: Debating the Benefits of Wind Power

headline: Four More Days
text: Albany is now at the final four — the final four days, that is, before this year’s legislative session is scheduled to end. A lot can be done, undone or done badly in that time. Here is our list of what should be possible:

headline: Donk My Ride
text: The allure of aesthetics has been a fact of automobile design for many decades. But carmakers have never been able to match the inventiveness of some car owners, dating back at least to creators of tangerine-flake objets d’art that Tom Wolfe celebrated in the 1960s. To believe that auto expressionists will run out of gas at some point is to underestimate their ability to create previously unimaginable novelty. Picture, for instance, a 1976 Impala improbably perched on 26-inch wheels and painted in colors inspired by a variety of Hawaiian Punch. This is what’s called a donk.

headline: Kathleen Rudkin and William McMullan Jr.
text: Kathleen Dougherty Rudkin, a daughter of Kathleen MacClarence Rudkin and Thomas Gilbert Rudkin of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to William Holt McMullan Jr., the son of Carolyn Stevens McMullan and William Holt McMullan of Hattiesburg, Miss. The Rev. Nicholas T. Porter performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn.

headline: New Releases Reflect Artistry
text: JOHN IRVING LEVENBERG, who was hired in 2005 to set the style for the winemaking team at Bedell Cellars in Cutchogue, has begun to leave his imprint. A new white, a rosé and three reds all reflect the pleasure principle.

headline: ‘Mr. Mom’ Aside, Dads at Work Are Still the Norm
text: Times have certainly changed since the days of “Leave It to Beaver,” when Ward Cleaver, in a business suit, won the bread and June Cleaver, in an apron, served it. But we are far from being a “Mr. Mom” society, too.

headline: A Regional Approach to Economic Growth; My Son, Too, Lost to Drugs (2 Letters)
text: A Regional Approach to Economic Growth

headline: First Steps in Mamaroneck
text: With an agreement to stop harassing day laborers and the opening of a privately run day labor hiring site in a village church, Mamaroneck took some long-overdue steps last week toward developing a responsible and humane approach to its influx of immigrant workers.

headline: Freedom to Want
text: WHEN Eric Hoffstead, a homeless panhandler, asked a New Rochelle police officer for a dollar, he was promptly arrested for violating the state loitering law, which prohibits begging. But Mr. Hoffstead took issue with the charge, asking his court-appointed lawyer to challenge his arrest on the ground that asking for money is a form of speech protected by the First Amendment.

headline: Patrick Chung, Matthew Burt
text: Patrick Shuao-Fong Chung and Matthew Fraser Burt affirmed their partnership last evening at the Memorial Church of Harvard in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Peter J. Gomes led the ceremony.

headline: Like Father?
text: For a little while, my father had it all: a loving wife, three healthy kids and a booming import-export business in Seoul that brought in so much cash that the president of Korea awarded him a medal of achievement. But then the gas crisis of 1973 bankrupted his company, and a year later he left my mother, sisters and me for the United States to regain his financial footing. He knew it wouldn’t be easy, but he had some old contacts and a brother in New York.

text: Maya Rabinovitch, a daughter of Marianna and Edward Rabinovitch of Upper Saddle River, N.J., and Eric Matthew Fishman, the son of Helene and Sandy Fishman of Springfield, N.J., were married last evening at the Hilton Pearl River in Pearl River, N.Y. Rabbi Stanley Skolnik officiated.

headline: An Inflation Hedge May Be Worth a Second Look
text: THEY guarantee that your investment will be protected against inflation, but Treasury inflation-protected securities, known as TIPS, underperformed conventional Treasuries in 2005 and 2006.

George Edward Wisnieski, a son of Candace Cushman Wisnieski and Anthony M. Wisnieski of Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Aidan Logan, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the United States Naval Academy Chapel in Annapolis, Md.

headline: Mad Scionists: Young, Hip and a Bit Less Square
text: IN December 2006, while other automakers were getting ready to unveil their new models at the Detroit auto show in January, Scion held a party in Miami. The guests were 300 owners of its cars who were entertained by the musician Ludacris. At the end of the evening, the new Scion xB and xD models were revealed.

headline: Astor’s Place
text: Imagine the frustration of a carload of people stumped by a particularly baffling Botticelli guessing game subject. Famous? Yes. Born in the 20th century? Yes. Female? Yes. Actress? No. Singer? No. Athlete? No. Artist? No. Activist? No. Hostage? No. Politician? No. TV host? No. Chef? No. Writer? Sort of. Still alive? Not sure. Unless someone were to luck into the question “Is she an exceptionally generous, gracious and well-dressed widow?” the game could easily zip through 20 No’s to its close without nearing the desired name: Brooke Astor.

headline: Sophia Lynn, David Frederick
text: Sophia Lynn and David Charles Frederick are to be married today. Judge James E. Boasberg of the Washington Superior Court is to officiate at the Armed Forces Retirement Home in Washington.

headline: The Ugly Part Wasn’t His Face
text: WILLIAM MURPHY, a retired policeman from Evansville, Wis., has been dealt more than his share of life’s bad cards.

headline: Children’s Books
text: Andrew Clements set the standard for the school story in 1996 with his first novel, “Frindle,” which went on to sell more than two million copies. The classic school story is set in elementary or middle school, and the characters are people whom readers can identify with. Most of these stories take place in Middle America, but they can also be set in an urban environment. The kids are not seriously troubled, their parents aren’t dead, missing or on drugs. All of these accounts are plausible.

headline: Two Screenwriters With No Complaints
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: School Basics: Reading, Writing, Arithmetic, Real Estate
text: LIKE the number of bedrooms or proximity to parks, quality of schools is a factor that can make or break a decision on whether to plunk down a small fortune on a house.

headline: Returning to Broadway on Celestial Roller Skates
text: Douglas Carter Beane is having a Broadway moment. His play “The Little Dog Laughed,” a Faustian tale about a closeted actor navigating the demands of Hollywood hustlers, was nominated for a Tony Award for best play. (It lost to “The Coast of Utopia.”) Julie White, the show’s caustically funny leading lady, won the Tony for her performance as the actor’s conniving agent. Mr. Beane, whose other plays included “As Bees in Honey Drown,” has also written the book for the new stage adaptation of the 1980 movie musical “Xanadu,” which starred Olivia Newton-John as a beautiful, breathy muse named Kira (Kerry Butler plays her on Broadway) who comes to earth to help an artist open his dream roller disco and had songs by the Electric Light Orchestra. The show is scheduled to open soon at the Helen Hayes Theater.

headline: Who’s Vacuuming Minnie Pearl’s House?
text: Tom Oreck, the chief executive of the vacuum cleaner maker founded by his father, David, has a whole lot of new floor space to keep clean. The younger Mr. Oreck paid $4.6 million this month for a 7,800-square-foot mansion in Nashville that was once owned by the Grand Ole Opry star Minnie Pearl and her husband, Henry Cannon. The home sits on 4.7 acres near the Tennessee governor’s mansion.

headline: Maggie Hymowitz, Scott Sequeira
text: Dr. Maggie Blair Hymowitz and Dr. Scott James Sequeira were married last evening at the Rosecliff mansion in Newport, R.I. Anne M. Collins, a former clerk of the Newport County Superior Court, officiated.

headline: Renewal Push Turns Avenue in Decline Into Tree-Lined Shopping District
text: MAPLEWOOD

headline: White House and Lawmakers Alike Face Risks in an Executive Privilege Fight
text: WASHINGTON, June 16  President Bush was strangely quiet this week when Democrats issued subpoenas to two former White House officials in the firing of federal prosecutors.

headline: On This Street, Bargains Are Just Part of the Appeal
text: ANTWERP wakes up late and languorously on a Sunday. At 10 a.m. on a balmy April morning, waiters were just setting up the outdoor tables along the normally bustling Hoogstraat, which leads from the Grote Markt to Sint-Jansvliet.

headline: Fatah, Routed in Gaza, Reinforces Hold on West Bank
text: JERUSALEM, June 16 — The Fatah faction, crushed this week in Gaza, moved to consolidate control over the West Bank on Saturday, seizing public buildings, including the parliament, and preparing to swear in a new government that did not include its rival, Hamas.

headline: High Anxiety
text: IT was two years ago, in June 2005, that residents of the Upper West Side got their first glimpse of the two glass-sheathed towers that were to rise on Broadway at 99th Street. The local community board was having its monthly land use meeting — not generally an occasion of high drama — and Gary Barnett, president of the Extell Development Company, came to share renderings of his proposed buildings. As he unveiled them, a gasp was heard throughout the room. “People shrieked,” recalls Sheldon Fine, chairman of Community Board 7.

headline: For the Record
text: An article in Arts & Leisure today about the playwright Douglas Carter Beane includes an outdated reference to the opening of “Xanadu.” The musical’s opening has been postponed, with a date still to be determined. It will not open on June 26.

headline: Oh, to Be 19 and an Entrepreneur
text: LORD, I loved being 19. If I had the chance to do it all again, I’d start up my life at that age. For most relatively “normal” guys like me, life at 19 is a joyously ephemeral state of being in between. Your adolescence is not quite behind you; your adulthood is not quite at hand. You can appropriate the privileges of a grownup without facing the responsibilities. And if you’re lucky, you can still put it all on your parents’ tab.

headline: Correction: A Reluctant Fraternity, Thinking Post-Black
text: An article on June 10 about the recipients of prizes awarded by the William H. Johnson Foundation misstated the role of Steve Turner. He is a founder of the organization — not the founder of the awards gala, which began as a foundation project. The article also omitted another founder. She is Victoria Dailey.

headline: Fusion Fare, With a Seafood Emphasis
text: CITRUS is a dramatic kind of place, with high ceilings, pressed-tin walls and vivid murals reminiscent of Mondrian, Miró and Marimekko.

headline: The Merman of La Scala
text: IN the grand jeté of life, no one can help but be aware of the inexorable downward tug of gravity.

headline: A Mix of Mass-Market and Couture
text: FOR budding furniture and product designers, the Design Academy Eindhoven, in the southern part of the Netherlands, is a hot ticket. The success of the school’s graduates — some of whom have introduced hugely successful products while still in their 20s — is the envy of rival institutions.

headline: Can You Be Too Fashionable?
text: STANDING with her back to a room full of Kohl’s department store executives in a Manhattan studio, Vera Wang reviewed prototypes from an exclusive new collection of mainstream fashion that Kohl’s plans to sell under her name. “This is all black,” said Ms. Wang, dismissively. “Black is very ’90s.”

headline: Amita Mahajan and Deepak Vadada
text: Dr. Amita Mahajan and Dr. Deepak Vadada were married yesterday at the Sheraton Parsippany Hotel in New Jersey. Pandit Venugopal G. Devdhar, a Hindu priest, officiated.

headline: Correction: The Geisha-and-Houseboy-Liberation Theater
text: An article on May 20 about the Pan Asian Repertory Theater referred incorrectly in two references to Daniel Dae Kim, who has acted with the troupe. He is Mr. Kim, not Mr. Dae Kim.

headline: Vivian Thomson, Patrick Roach
text: Vivian Elizabeth Thomson and Patrick Joseph Roach were married yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Alane Cameron Miles, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, officiated at Pavilion VII on the University of Virginia campus in Charlottesville.

headline: ‘Doors Open’
text: It occurred to Allan Cruikshank that the reason he made a good banker was that he was intrinsically boring. He had never taken a risk in his life. This meant he was cautious and prudent, and therefore good at not losing his clients’ money. But banking had also made him cynical. It was a truism that those who already had money would find it easy to increase their wealth, and they never seemed very grateful for Allan’s work on their (often unmerited) behalf. Some of the High Net Worth individuals on his books owned three or four homes, yachts, racehorses, private islands and numerous works of art. Yet they seemed to appreciate very little, being too busy amassing yet more. He found them dull and blinkered, and wondered if they thought of him the same way. Then there were his fellow account executives at First Caledonian Bank, some of whom hardly registered his existence. The chief executive had met him a dozen times, yet never seemed to remember him. With a drink in one hand and a canapé in the other, he would regale Allan time and again with the same anecdote, while Allan smiled and tried to sound interested throughout and surprised by the predictable punch line.

headline: Woman Warriors
text: To appreciate the delicious irony of the title of “Throw Like a Girl,” Jean Thompson’s boldly unconventional new story collection, you need to consider it in context: in the title story, two college friends have reunited in New York, where one of them is living with her dyspeptic boyfriend, known to the reader as “What’s-his-name.” One night, after What’s-his-name has been especially pillish, the young women begin picking up chunks of broken sidewalk and hurling them at him. “He couldn’t ignore us any longer when we hit him, pretty hard, once between his shoulder blades and then beneath his ear,” Thompson writes. What’s-his-name’s shrill response before running away — “You’re crazy, you know that? Besides, you throw like a girl!” — prompts hilarity from the women. “You’re so much smarter than me,” says What’s-his-name’s girlfriend. “I don’t see you with a jerk.”

headline: When Demagogues Play the Leprosy Card, Watch Out
text: People who want to reform immigration by putting America in lockdown have not been shy about using fear and revulsion to get their point across. Illegal immigrants, they say, are invading the country to reconquer it, to erode our Anglo-Saxon culture and to make us all sick.

headline: With a Bow to Springsteen, a Band Plays On
text: UP close, Mark Salore doesn’t look much like Bruce Springsteen. Except, perhaps, for the stud in his left ear and a wispy bit of beard. Mr. Salore is shorter than the Boss, his complexion darker, his nose slightly bigger. An astonishing transformation takes place, though, when he gets onstage with his tribute band, Tramps Like Us. He punches out the opening riff to “Cadillac Ranch,” the group kicks in behind him, the crowd erupts in war cries and air guitar riffs, and it suddenly seems as if Bruce and the E Street Band have commandeered the Vintage Bar in White Plains.

headline: New Homes Confront Old Burial Grounds
text: DAC ENTERPRISES, a small, mostly residential developer in Georgia, bought about 118 acres in Hall County, just south of the city of Lula, with the idea of selling lots to builders to put up single-family houses. The transaction, completed in 2004, seemed routine for the fast-growing exurb, 50 miles northeast of Atlanta.

headline: Reagan on Reagan
text: Not since the 19th century has a United States president kept a diary through his entire White House tenure, and this volume tells us more about Ronald Reagan than many of his biographies. Besides which, not a few interpretive bits of gold are sprinkled amid the grit and gravel of diplomatic niceties, Congressional consultations and after-dinner entertainments.

headline: Cellphone Exposes Flaw in 911 System
text: ON a drizzling Sunday morning last month, Adrienne Pincus hit the brakes on her bicycle as two riders — one a close friend — crashed on a rain-slicked road in Norwalk, Conn., near the start of the Bloomin’ Metric, one of region’s most popular cycling events.

headline: Willkommen! Life Is a Spiegeltent, Old Chum
text: VALLEJO GANTNER is a devotee of spiegeltents: those 1920s European traveling pavilions of teak and leaded glass, velvet and brocade, banquettes and beveled mirrors. He knows the handful of owners in Belgium and the Netherlands who rent the last surviving spiegeltents to a lucky few cities each year. And in his native Melbourne and in his former job as director of the Dublin Fringe Festival, he produced shows in spiegeltents that drew throngs.

headline: Young Beyond Its Years
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Tall, Gangly and Not So Hidden in Plain Sight
text: Marine Park, a leafy neighborhood of detached houses in southern Brooklyn, is a quiet place where neighbors are proud to say they know one another. The kind of place, as the president of the Marine Park Civic Association, Greg Borruso, says, where if you don’t water your lawn on Tuesday, a neighbor will water it for you on Wednesday.

headline: Among Firefighters in New York, Mixed Views on Giuliani
text: Their images are permanently etched in photographs after the fall of the World Trade Center towers, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and firefighters cloaked in the same gray dust. For months afterward, they stood together at funerals. Mr. Giuliani, in his eulogy, always asked for a round of applause to celebrate the dead firefighter’s life.

headline: Alice Stagg, Thor Mann
text: Alice Miriam Stagg and Thor Tembeya Mann, management consultants, were married yesterday by Rabbi Dennis Shulman at the Grounds for Sculpture, a museum and park in Hamilton, N.J.

headline: Inside the List
text: MARGINALIA:  Reviews of Michael Ondaatje’s new novel, “Divisadero,” have been mixed to positive. But even critics who’ve admired it — see Erica Wagner’s review this week — have found it to be, at times, a slog. (In The Los Angeles Times, Thomas Meaney wrote about the novel’s narrator: “Ondaatje has left us in the hands of an English Ph.D., one whose literary pretensions are on full display.”)

headline: Correction: Income Inequality, Writ Larger
text: The Economic View column last Sunday, about income inequality in the United States, misstated the top marginal rate for federal income taxes. It is 35 percent, not 36 percent.

headline: Slow Track This Nominee
text: New Jersey Attorney General Stuart Rabner, who is Gov. Jon Corzine’s choice for chief justice of the state’s Supreme Court, is viewed as a nonpolitical straight arrow with no tolerance for ethical shortcomings. That is an essential character trait in New Jersey, given the state’s record of corruption. But it is not the only quality the state’s top judge must have.

headline: Homes for an ‘Overlooked Market’
text: MOUNT VERNON

headline: Design Meets Dance, and Rules Are Broken
text: SUPPOSE your daughter is getting married, and her wedding dress won’t be ready until the morning of the wedding, but it’s by Dior,” the composer Morton Feldman said to a friend in 1958. He was explaining how Merce Cunningham could be choreographing “Summerspace” in one part of the country while Robert Rauschenberg was designing it in another and he, Feldman, was composing the music in a third. By that time this wait-till-the-wedding compositional formula for Cunningham dance theater had already been established. According to its rules the choreography, design and music are created separately and may be brought together as late as opening night, with the artists knowing little if anything about one another’s plans save the dimensions of the stage, the number and physical details of the dancers, and the work’s duration in time.

text: Stanford, Calif.

text: WITH a thud, 75 Wall Street, a huge hotel-and-luxury-condominium building, has landed in the financial district — another residential offering typical of the area, where it seems a weekend’s-worth of amenities can be experienced in the course of an elevator ride.

headline: Turning Down the Volume in the Next Cubicle
text: Q. Your co-workers sometimes have loud conversations near you, and they don’t seem to realize that the noise is keeping you from concentrating. What should you do?

headline: As Close to Mexico as the County Gets
text: THE first thing you’ll notice about Sunset Grille in White Plains is the tortilla chips automatically placed at each table. Thicker and darker than the usual fare, they have a richer, nuttier taste as well. The green and red salsas that accompany them are different, too. They lack the electric color and processed taste of most Mexican restaurants’ offerings.

headline: Habitat for Humanity’s Homes Faulted in Florida
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — When Habitat for Humanity built the Fairway Oaks development here seven years ago, Mary Zeigler thought, “This is a blessing.” In just 17 days, an army of 10,000 volunteers, including former President Jimmy Carter and first lady Rosalynn Carter, built 85 low-cost houses, one of the nonprofit group’s biggest “blitz build” projects.

text: POLITICALLY, Dr. Stephen Fox and Shirley Lasker are a close match — both wear their activism on their sleeve. You’d think, then, that romance between the two would be smooth sailing.

headline: Stricker May Be Fashioning Another Comeback Story at U.S. Open
text: OAKMONT, Pa., June 16  Tiger Woods is not the only golfer on the leader board who will be stalking his third United States Open title Sunday. Lee Janzen, the champion in 1993 and 1998, was seven strokes back Saturday after his third consecutive three-over-par 73.

headline: Venice. Art. Ubiquitous.
text: “The mere use of one’s eyes in Venice is happiness enough.”

headline: Comings and Goings
text: A message to those who have applied for — and are eagerly awaiting — passports: relax. The Departments of State and Homeland Security announced on June 8 that through Sept. 30, United States citizens traveling to Canada, Mexico, the Caribbean and Bermuda may enter and depart the United States by air as long as they have a government-issued photo identification and proof that they have applied for a passport. The Western Hemisphere Travel Initiative, which has required passports for all air travel outside of United States territories since Jan. 23, has created a record demand for passports, meaning longer processing and turnaround times. Details are at www.travel.state.gov. ... Want more “Pirates of the Caribbean”? Hotels on Dominica, which provided some locations for the movies starring Johnny Depp (below), have created packages for pirate-crazy travelers. A seven-night experience offered by Calibishie Lodges (www.calibishie-lodges.com) includes visits to eight spots used in the movies; it is available for $599 a person, double occupancy, if reserved by June 30. A seven-day package offered by the Tamarind Tree Hotel and Restaurant (www.tamarindtreedominica.com) includes tours led by the driver for Gore Verbinski, the movie’s director, starting at $1,615 a person, double, with all meals. Other pirate-themed packages are being offered by the Anchorage Hotel (www.anchoragehotel.dm), the Hummingbird Inn (www.find-us.net/hummingbird) — ask at these two when you reserve — and the Fort Young Hotel (www.fortyounghotel.com). ... American Airlines (www.aa.com) recently announced that all AAdvantage members must redeem or accrue miles at least once every 18 months to keep their accounts active. Starting Dec. 15, mileage accounts that have not changed in the previous year and a half will expire.

headline: The Light Stuff
text: Capriccio Cafe is the kind of place where going out for a bite is really about being outside. Sure, this Italian eatery has indoor seating, but a vast majority of the chairs — more than 80 — are on Stamford’s restaurant row, flanked attractively by a leafy cottonwood on one side and two crabapple trees on the other.

headline: Where’s the Melody? It’s Everywhere You Look
text: HIS old report cards read Shaffer Chimere Smith, but to the rest of us he’s known by two syllables: Ne-Yo. Ne-Yo, a 24-year-old Grammy-nominated R&B singer-songwriter, was back home in Atlanta after a trip to Japan to publicize his sophomore album, “Because of You” (Def Jam). He was in town temporarily to celebrate the opening of his recording studio — with kitchens! — and to announce a talent contest. (The winner scored a record deal with Ne-Yo’s label, Compound Entertainment.) Seemingly the victim of a jampacked schedule, he was getting dressed while on the phone with Winter Miller. A thoughtful sentence about melody was punctuated with a request for socks. Nearing the end of his list and finally dressed, though still shirtless, he spoke from the car on the way to greet the press and fans at the new studio. The next day he was off again for his national tour.

headline: Correction: Detroit’s Sticker Shock on Fuel Efficiency
text: An article last Sunday on the resistance of American automakers to proposals that would significantly increase gasoline mileage misspelled the name of the chief executive of the Ford Motor company. He is Alan R. Mulally, not Mullaly.

headline: A Basketball Prospect Yearning for Peace and Quiet
text: ALIQUIPPA, Pa.  Herb Pope rises early each morning and dribbles a basketball to a nearby park. Along the way, he passes trash-filled yards and abandoned homes with boarded-up windows.

headline: Manhattan House Divided
text: BREAKING up is hard to do, particularly for the developers of one of the most ambitious and expensive condominium conversions ever: the redevelopment of the Manhattan House, a complex with 582 apartments on a full square block on East 66th Street and Third Avenue.

headline: Picking Up the Pieces
text: “I come from Divisadero Street,” Anna tells us in Michael Ondaatje’s fifth novel. “Divisadero, from the Spanish word for ‘division,’ the street that at one time was the dividing line between San Francisco and the fields of the Presidio. Or it might derive from the word divisar, meaning ‘to gaze at something from a distance.’ ”

headline: Unleashed Joy
text: Q. Just after I crossed the footbridge into the Ramble of Central Park the other day, I saw a woman receiving a citation for having her dogs off their leashes by the lake. Don’t the city parks have areas outside dog runs where dog owners are allowed to let their pets run free?

headline: The Cranes Are Back, and So Are the Tenants
text: BELLEVUE, Wash.

headline: Children’s Books | Young Adults
text: Beowulf,” a 3,000-line epic poem composed early in the eighth century, is the first significant text written in English, or in what eventually became English. What interests scholars about the story is its place in our linguistic development, and also the way it blends both Christian and pagan details. But what recommends “Beowulf” to children — and to older readers who haven’t lost a child’s delight in stories that are both scary and gory — is that it’s also a first-rate horror yarn, featuring slaughter, dismemberment and underwater sword fights.

headline: Charles Lee Remington, Butterfly Expert, Dies at 85
text: Charles Lee Remington, the intellectual patriarch of modern American lepidopterology, the scientific study of butterflies and moths, died on May 31 in Hamden, Conn. He was 85.

headline: The Best Hotel in Town May Now Be at the Airport
text: If you’ve passed through one of several major United States airports recently, you might have noticed something that has actually made you want to miss your connection: a luxury hotel linked right to the terminal, no shuttle ride needed.

headline: Despite Calls for Restraint, Sunni Mosque Is Bombed in Southern Iraq City
text: BAGHDAD, June 16 — Hooded gunmen clad in black blew up another Sunni mosque in the southern city of Basra on Saturday after ordering the police at the mosque to flee, and despite a curfew imposed by Iraq’s central government, witnesses and security officials said.

headline: Campbell’s Opportunity
text: Ever since 1869, when the fruit merchant Joseph Campbell shook hands on a deal that would establish one of the nation’s food giants, the Campbell Soup Company has been a mainstay in Camden, a southern New Jersey city that has long since fallen on hard times.

headline: Aronian-Carlsen Was Liveliest of the Candidates Matches
text: There were no real surprises at the candidates matches, held May 27 to June 13 in Elista, Kalmykia, a Russian republic, to select four qualifiers for the World Championship Tournament in Mexico City in September and October.

headline: The Life of the Chinese Gold Farmer
text: It was an hour before midnight, three hours into the night shift with nine more to go. At his workstation in a small, fluorescent-lighted office space in Nanjing, China, Li Qiwen sat shirtless and chain-smoking, gazing purposefully at the online computer game in front of him. The screen showed a lightly wooded mountain terrain, studded with castle ruins and grazing deer, in which warrior monks milled about. Li, or rather his staff-wielding wizard character, had been slaying the enemy monks since 8 p.m., mouse-clicking on one corpse after another, each time gathering a few dozen virtual coins — and maybe a magic weapon or two — into an increasingly laden backpack.

headline: To the Rumble of Trucks, Add the Roar of Buses
text: Dieter Kist, a contractor with a graying beard, has lived on truck-laden Cooper Avenue in Glendale, Queens, for three years. In that time, his parked car has been hit three times by other vehicles, and at night he is lulled to sleep by the rumble of 18-wheelers hauling cargo.

headline: Unlikely Problem: Anchor of Rotation Drags Mets Down
text: If Tom Glavine doesn’t get to 300 this season, the Mets aren’t going anywhere  not to the World Series, not to the National League Championship Series, not to the playoffs period.

headline: Thomas Agonistes
text: After all the twisted racial history of the United States Supreme Court, Clarence Thomas was confirmed by the Senate with the smallest margin of victory in more than 100 years, with little professional scrutiny and with a level of manipulative political rancor that diminished everyone directly involved. The effect on Thomas, we learn from this impeccably researched and probing biography, was to reinforce the chronic contradictions with which he has long lived.

headline: Going Nose-to-Nose With a Great White
text: IT was not the most comfortable position in which I had ever found myself. Encased inside a ten-foot-long aluminum cage that dangled off the side of the dive boat, submerged up to my neck in 57-degree sea water, I peered with difficulty through a fogged-in scuba mask at the placid Indian Ocean. My feet rested on a thick metal bar about three feet below the surface; my knees were propped up against my chest. Though a wet suit kept my body reasonably well insulated, my exposed hands were freezing and turning numb.

headline: Michelle Norkus, Scott Kreitz
text: Michelle Norkus and Scott F. Kreitz were married yesterday at St. Catharine Church in Spring Lake, N.J. Msgr. Thomas A. Luebking, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Pure Gilbert and Sullivan? No. But Still a Glorious Thing.
text: Unbuckle your swashbuckle, channel your inner Johnny Depp and prepare to have a blast at “Pirates!” — a delightful new adaptation of Gilbert and Sullivan’s classic “Pirates of Penzance” at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn.

headline: Anika Proskurowski and Kenneth Natori
text: Anika Yael Proskurowski, a daughter of Maxine and Andrzej Proskurowski of Eugene, Ore., was married last evening to Kenneth Cruz Natori, the son of Josie Cruz Natori and Kenneth Natori of New York. The Rev. Carleton Jones officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York, and the Most Rev. Leonardo Z. Legaspi, the archbishop of the diocese of Caceres in the Philippines and a friend of the bridegroom’s family, participated in the ceremony.

headline: Mets Said to Be Looking Into an M.L.S. Franchise
text: Mr. Met, the mascot of New York’s National League baseball team, may not speak fluent Spanish yet, but the club has recast itself with a strong Hispanic flavor and may soon expand beyond America’s pastime and embrace the world’s game: soccer.

headline: A Kids’ Invention That Rocks (and Scoops)
text: MASSAPEQUA PARK

headline: A Boycott Built on Bias
text: Two weeks ago I took part in commencement for this year’s doctoral candidates at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem. The ceremony was held in the amphitheater on Mount Scopus, which faces out onto the Dead Sea and the Mountains of Moab. The setting sun framed the graduate students in a reddish-orange glow against a spectacular biblical backdrop.

headline: Israel Shenker, 82, a Reporter With the Instincts of a Scholar, Dies
text: Israel Shenker, a scholar trapped in a newsman’s body who was known to readers of The New York Times for his vast erudition and sly, subversive wit, died on June 9 at Kibbutz Shoval in southern Israel. He was 82.

headline: Partners Bound by the Ties of 9/11
text: FOR two former undercover detectives in their early 40s who cheated death time and again, no day is ordinary, not anymore, and certainly not a day like this one on the shore of Long Island — a day showered with sea spray and salt air; with clam bellies in a bucket at their sides and jigs tempting stripers in the surf; with sand and sky, wind and waves, straight talk about life and mocking chatter about death.

headline: A Chance to Focus on Earnings
text: A light economic calendar this week should give traders a chance to look ahead to second-quarter earnings announcements. It might also provide a respite from their fixation on the bond market.

headline: Prenatal Scare
text: Clare Clark’s first novel, published in 2005, was inauspiciously — but accurately — titled. “The Great Stink” offered a richly imagined re-creation of Victorian London’s sewers, a murky labyrinth in which a mildly crazy ex-soldier, newly employed as an engineer, discovers a corpse and finds himself suspected of murder. Praised for the ingenuity of its plotting, this accomplished book also won plaudits for the authenticity of its detail and its almost queasily intense exuberance. Clark, who paid generous acknowledgment to the inspiration of Peter Ackroyd’s pyrotechnic style, joined him as a highflier, soaring through a dreamscape of her own imagining, yet grounding it in the bricks, mortar and mud of a well-researched past. Her strikingly well-written book was also huge fun to read.

headline: Correction: Between a Mother and a Daughter

We threaded past the sleeping shopping malls and shiny multiplexes, down a series of winding streets and through a stone pedestrian tunnel, until we emerged beneath raised train tracks.

headline: Up Front
text: In a 1991 Op-Ed article for The New York Times, Orlando Patterson — then, as now, a professor of sociology at Harvard — said of the Clarence Thomas-Anita Hill uproar, “The hearings ... brought to light the fact that the American public is way ahead of its journalistic and social-science commentators with respect to race relations.” Patterson, who reviews “Supreme Discomfort,” a biography of Thomas, on the cover of this issue, elaborated in an e-mail message: “The American public has in recent decades adopted far more nuanced and progressive views than its political and intellectual leaders on both right and left. We are currently living through a good example of this in the immigration debate.” As for race relations today, he thinks “extremism on both sides is flatly rejected. The great majority of black Americans, including the black poor, do not blame their problems on race, as the academic army of social scientists insists on telling them they should, and getting lifetime tenure for it.”

The vote is not scheduled to be on the ballot until 2008, but New Jersey educators know that if they want to win a bond election for school renovations, repairs or construction, they must do their homework.

headline: Anger Management
text: As the manager of the Chicago Cubs, you were suspended this month after a very public meltdown in which you stormed out of the dugout and kicked dirt on the umpire. But aren’t temper tantrums by baseball managers a venerable American tradition? You know what? They probably want the mangers to be more like Stepford wives. If that’s what they want, that’s O.K. Times have changed. My kicking-dirt episodes are over. You can put them in the archives.

headline: The Inner Lives of Men
text: Since academic novels usually focus on the nasty rivalries and inflated egos of their characters, they have served as vehicles for broad satire, not serious themes. One great exception is Willa Cather’s 1925 novel, “The Professor’s House.” Cather used the traditional calling of a scholar and the atrophy of his marriage to convey her own growing alienation from the modern world. Her novel has only one successor, another book that invokes the life of learning as a rebuke to the wasteful wars and cheap compromises of the wider world. John Williams’s “Stoner” is something rarer than a great novel — it is a perfect novel, so well told and beautifully written, so deeply moving, that it takes your breath away. Ignored on publication in 1965, a clamorous year, it has been kept alive by enthusiasts who go into print every decade to rediscover it, including Irving Howe in The New Republic in 1966, C. P. Snow in The Financial Times in 1973, Dan Wakefield in Ploughshares in 1981 and Steve Almond in Tin House in 2003. They invariably wonder why no one has heard of the book. “Why isn’t this book famous?” Snow kept asking. Now, along with Williams’s earlier novel, “Butcher’s Crossing” (1960), “Stoner” is available in a handsome reprint by New York Review Books. Both books deserve to be widely read, but their dark, comfortless vision raises the question of whether this can be expected.

headline: Mayor’s Turbulent Evening Is Big Case for Small Court
text: BRADLEY BEACH, N.J., June 14 — Here in this shore town, a land of funnel cake and miniature golf, the talk is not of ocean tides and sand flies but of pepper spray and handcuffs. Not of saltwater taffy and lazy afternoons with Stephen King, but of motions of emergent relief and mornings with a judge.

headline: ‘Divisadero’
text: By our grandfather's cabin, on the high ridge, opposite a slope of buckeye trees, Claire sits on her horse, wrapped in a thick blanket. She has camped all night and lit a fire in the hearth of that small structure our ancestor built more than a generation ago, and which he lived in like a hermit or some creature, when he first came to this country. He was a self-sufficient bachelor who eventually owned all the land he looked down onto. He married lackadaisically when he was forty, had one son, and left him this farm along the Petaluma road.

headline: ‘Nature’s Engraver: A Life of Thomas Bewick’
text: Printing from woodblocks is the oldest way of all. Before Gutenberg invented moveable type around 1450, books and broadsheets were produced by writing the text on wood in reverse, as in a mirror, and then cutting painstakingly round the letters, dabbing the block with ink and pressing paper on top. With the new metal type, printers still used the blocks for illustrations and a single block could be used over and over again, on different pages, in different books. The early cutters worked on the 'side-grain' of the wood, a plank cut along the trunk, often of a fruitwood such as pear or cherry, using carpenters' tools - knives, chisels and gouges. When designed by masters like Dürer or Holbein these woodcuts could attain an astounding delicacy, but increasingly book publishers preferred to use copper engravings which gave a finer effect, and the crude woodcuts were banished to broadsides and chapbooks. Slowly, however, craftsmen tried using the dense end-grain of wood, sliced across the trunk or branch rather than along it like a plank. Boxwood proved the best, because box grows so slowly that the growth-lines are very close and on its hard surface the engravers could use the fine tools employed on silver or copper.

headline: ‘I've Got a Home in Glory Land’
text: In 1985, archaeologists in downtown Toronto made a remarkable find. Beneath the old Sackville Street School playground were traces of a house, a shed, and a mysterious cellar. Municipal records revealed that the original landowner had been "Thornton Blackburn, cabman, colored." He and his wife were fugitive slaves from Kentucky who had settled in Toronto in 1834 and had gone on to become wealthy and successful businesspeople. The Thornton and Lucie Blackburn Site became the first archaeological dig on an Underground Railroad site in Canada.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE WHISTLING SEASON, by Ivan Doig. (Harvest/Harcourt, $14. ) A presiding figure in the literature of the American West, Doig sets his latest novel, like most of his books, in rural Montana. His narrator, a school superintendent named Paul Milliron, looks back to the fall of 1909, when he was 13 and his recently widowed father answered a newspaper ad from a woman seeking employment. The housekeeper, Rose Llewellyn, is as feisty and willful as she is charming, and she brings with her a surprise guest — her scholarly brother, who, after the elopement of the community’s only teacher, takes over the one-room schoolhouse. “The land and its people — the family, the neighbors — are laid out before us with a fresh, natural openness,” Sven Birkerts wrote in the Book Review.

headline: Roaring Engines, Filthy Fingernails
text: At 5 a.m. in Le Mans, there is a mix of emotions, mostly of the sleep-craving variety. I’ve been put to work cleaning tires and shuttling them between the Corvette Racing team and Michelin’s makeshift headquarters across the paddock. I knew it wasn’t going to be glamorous, but after catching a glimpse of myself in a mirror, I realized that I look like I’ve spent a day in a coal mine. Brake dust is on my face, in my hair, in my ears, and under my nails. Whether I like it or not, I’ll be bringing home a pound or two of Corvette brake dust as a souvenir.

headline: 24 Hours, No Pitstops
text: As the head of timing and scoring for the Corvette Racing team, Melanie Correll never starts something she won’t finish. This is especially true when it’s the 24 Hours of Le Mans. Having worked for Corvette Racing since 2000, Correll records the lap times for every car, regardless of its category or whether it has been penalized or is headed down the pit lane behind her. She does this without breaks, catnaps or a single trip to the restroom. She is stationed in Corvette’s pit stand on the main straightaway from beginning to end.

headline: Comparing the Two Territories
text: Palestinians of the West Bank (about 2.5 million): From Israel's founding in 1948 until the 1967 war, the region was administered by Jordan and the Palestinians there tended to identify with the more secular societies of Jordan, Syria or Lebanon, where many went to study. With greater freedom of movement, a healthier economy, and better educational opportunities than in Gaza, the Palestinians on the West Bank generally feel superior to their Gazan cousins.

headline: Nkunda’s Rebels
text: Last night at dinner, we were joined by a young Italian woman who had been kidnapped and held hostage in Iraq, a story that received a good deal of world media attention. Less than 10 hours later in the Congo, Nick Kristof was advising Leana and me how to respond in case we were stopped by bandits or soldiers on our journey from the city of Goma to the mountains for an interview with “warlord” (media’s words)/”liberator of my people” (his words) Laurent Nkunda. He is the leader of the Military Council for the Defense of the People, a rebel group that is amassing soldiers and arms in opposition to the current national government of Congo.

headline: Bonnaroo: Hippie Fashion Statements and Protest Songs
text: MANCHESTER, TENN.–Back in the 1960’s, the hippie counterculture briefly looked like a political opposition to a protracted war. At Bonnaroo this year, hippie fashion statements also go with protest songs and anti-Bush pronouncements. Perhaps that’s no suprise at a festival that includes longtime politically inclined rappers like the Roots, Michael Franti and El-P, who tour to the same collegiate audience that comes to Bonnaroo. Friday’s lineup also included Manu Chao, the globe-trotting, mostly Spanish-speaking songwriter whose hopped-up reggae and ska songs decry violence and poverty, support human rights (especially for immigrants and displaced people) and savor romance and marijuana.

headline: Spurned Activists ‘Rename’ a Street
text: Undeterred by the City Council’s decision to reject the naming of a Brooklyn street after the militant black activist Sonny Carson, almost 300 people gathered at a Bedford-Stuyvesant intersection on Saturday to rename the street anyway.

headline: Bonnaroo: Lyrics — From Nonsensical to Elaborate
text: MANCHESTER, Tenn.– Who needs lyrics? Saturday afternoon at Bonnaroo was full of pop bands who are in some ways the craftsmanlike, structure-obsessed opposite of happily sprawling jam bands.

headline: Bonnaroo: The Ghost of Jerry Garcia
text: MANCHESTER, Tenn.–There’s always a Bonnaroo moment when the ghost of Jerry Garcia arrives. For me, that would be the set by the guitarist Keller Williams and his group WMD’s, with both Mr. Williams and a second guitarist trading Garcia’s bluegrass-like picking and chromatic slides while the band picked up a Dead-style lilt. The homage was obvious; it was also a pretty good one.

headline: Past and Present
text: Older actresses are finding a place on TV.

headline: Dr. McIver’s Pain; Richard Paey’s Hope
text: When is a pain doctor a drug pusher? If you’ve read Tina Rosenberg’s excellent article on Dr. Ronald McIver, you know the answer to that question posed on the cover of the Times Magazine: When a prosecutor and a few jurors think they know more about medicine than he does. It didn’t matter that there was no evidence Dr. McIver intentionally dealt drugs — he’s serving a 30-year sentence for not meeting the jurors’ standards of pain treatment.

headline: Bonnaroo: The Police — Vital and Experimental
text: MANCHESTER, TENN. — Of course the reunited Police belonged at Bonnaroo, the festival built on jam bands. What disappeared when the band broke up in 1983 was a chance to hear the interaction of three musicians whose blend and friction forged one of rock’s most original ensemble sounds. They left behind terse, neatly arranged studio albums and a few live recordings. Now, on tour again, they are jamming the alternatives. Their Bonnaroo set interspersed familiar arrangements with new ones, often within the same song. There were sparks, teases, intriguing excursions and a few misfires, but the Police sounded vital, still fascinated by Sting’s songs and ready to tear into them anew.

headline: Happy Father’s Day
text: Tonight’s the final installment of Subway Series 2007 (at least for the regular season). I’m sure the Mets are hoping for a better Father’s Day outcome than this one from 1964. Fathers and sons at Dodger Stadium will be having fun today. Same goes for Fenway Park. What a great idea, a Father’s Day catch at the ballpark.

headline: Q & A: Alber Elbaz of Lanvin
text: For a branch of fashion that matters to very few people, haute couture generates serious debate. In early July, Dior will celebrate its 60th anniversary with a show at Versailles. Valentino will have a 45th blow-out in Rome. There’s a sense, however, that couture is again in some kind of transit phase. The Valentino company has a new owner and there’s a question of what will happen to couture when Valentino retires. This past Thursday, in Paris, I sat down with Alber Elbaz to ask what couture means to a younger generation of design innovators. What would induce a designer like Elbaz, or Marc Jacobs, or Nicolas Ghesquiere, to want to be part of an old-school couture house? Are they—and fashion—missing something?

headline: Win a Trip: Meeting a Warlord
text: Leana Wen, who's traveling with Nick Kristof in Africa, reports on her visit to the mountain headquarters of a rebel leader in eastern Congo.

headline: Your Comments on my Warlord Column
text: Monday’s column will be about the catastrophic warfare and chaos in Congo, told through a visit to a warlord (he calls himself “a liberator”) in eastern Congo. I’m on satellite phone and not able to post much while in the Congo, but please post your comments below. You can also see the blogging of my companions for this trip, Will Okun and Leana Wen, at www.nytimes.com/twofortheroad.

headline: Controversy Grows Over Arrests at Puerto Rican Day Parade
text: A week after the mass arrests at the Puerto Rican Day Parade, it seems fair to say that the parade is at the center of a controversy of an intensity not seen in nearly a decade.

headline: Are You Ready to Pay to Park on Your Street?
text: New York City could start charging residents to park in their own neighborhoods under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s congestion pricing plan. The mayor’s proposal, which was introduced in the State Senate this month, would charge most drivers $8 to enter Manhattan below 86th Street on weekdays. To mollify people just outside the zone who feared their streets would turn into parking lots, the Senate bill would allow the city to issue permits so that most parking spots would be restricted to neighborhood residents.

headline: The Death of an Italian Innovator
text: Wire services in Italy and France report this evening in Italy that Gianfranco Ferre has died at the age of 62. He suffered a cerebral hemorrhage on Friday in Milan and was hospitalized. Ferre was for many years a leading designer in Milan, beginning his career in the mid 1970s after receiving a degree in architecture.
