There was always something over-the-top about Ferre’s clothes—the white shirt collars always high and sculptural, the leather often laced and assertive, the coats swinging. I once began a review of a Ferre show, in the early 90s, with: “Diva, can you dig it?” His clothes had a great sexual energy, if you got your head into them, and I loved that he didn’t seem to care a jot about trends and skinny models and so forth. His Dior period was not especially memorable, at least for me, and perhaps that’s because he never seemed very happy there (living in the Plaza Athenee), and of course Dior in the early 90s was in transition, not the old style but not quite yet the new era of Galliano and Bernard Arnault.

headline: Atheism and Evidence
text: Atheists like Sam Harris, Richard Dawkins and Christopher Hitchens believe (in Dawkins’s words) that “there is nothing beyond the natural, physical world” and that “if there is something that appears to lie beyond the natural world, we hope eventually to understand it and embrace it within the natural.”

headline: Rest for Damon?
text: The Yankees have been using Johnny Damon as their designated hitter lately, but they will not have a D.H. in the upcoming six-game road trip to Colorado and San Francisco.

headline: The All-Day Night Patrol
text: While I was home convalescing in St. Pete, with my new dome, I did not do much of anything. I was still having serious problems with my sleeping and was going out to the local bars drinking excessively. My family would invite me and my wife out for family time and were told that I was not interested. My wife never even asked me if I wanted to go to any of these family functions. She seems to have been trying to separate me from my family.

headline: Empire Zone Has Moved … to City Room
text: After more than a year, 1,909 posts and 11,000 reader comments (plus 91,771 blocked spam comments), The Empire Zone blog went on hiatus. But this is not a farewell to blogging.

headline: Merit-Based Pay for Teachers
text: Merit pay, or compensating teachers for classroom performance rather than their years on the job and coursework completed, found some support in the 1980s among policy makers and school administrators, who saw it as a way to encourage good teachers to work harder and to weed out the bad ones. But teachers saw it as a gimmick used by principals to reward cronies based on favoritism.

headline: We Invite You to Try City Room
text: The Newark06 blog is no longer active.

headline: Behind the Che Bandannas, Shades of Potential Militias
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, June 17 — Visitors to the Alexis Vive Collective, one of the most radical of the pro-Chávez groups that thrive in the hillside slums of this city’s western fringe, can see the writing on the wall — quite literally — as they approach. The group’s headquarters are just past the murals of Jesus with an assault rifle and Che Guevara puffing on a cigar.

headline: EBay Moves to Recharge Its Auctions
text: BOSTON — In 1998, eBay’s chief executive, Meg Whitman, changed the background color of the site’s home page from gray to white. Rather than simply switching colors overnight, though, Ms. Whitman directed eBay’s engineers to bleach the gray over the course of 30 days. At the end of the month, the company asked users if they noticed anything different. No one did.

headline: Airbus Hopes Its Planes, Not Its Setbacks, Will Stand Out
text: PARIS, June 17 — The A380 superjumbo, swooping high above Le Bourget airfield during its daily demonstration flights, may cast a long shadow over the Paris air show this year. Production delays for the much-publicized 555-seat A380, have been the catalyst for Airbus’s outsize woes over the last year.

headline: CNN and YouTube Keep Reporters Dangling
text: If the news conference that CNN and YouTube held last week to discuss their first-of-a-kind presidential debate was any sort of omen, there might be a few kinks for the companies to work out in the months ahead.

headline: Get Ready for More Canoodling: Page Six Expands
text: The New York Post’s Page Six gossip column has had its own share of negative media attention in the last year, but that does not seem to have scared off advertisers.

headline: Holding a Mirror Up to Israeli Destiny, the Past and the Prologue
text: Tom Segev, an Israeli columnist and historian, sums up the meaning for Israel of the 1967 war with two jokes. The first, heard in the months before the war, when Israelis feared a second Holocaust at the hands of their Arab neighbors, is of a sign hanging near the boarding gate at the national airport, asking the last one out of the country to turn off the lights. The second, told after the six days in which Israel defeated the armies of Egypt, Syria and Jordan and quadrupled the territory under its control, involves two officers talking about how to spend their day. “ ‘Let’s conquer Cairo,’ one proposes. The other replies, ‘But what will we do after lunch?’ ”

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,510 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Saturday:

headline: Treasury Auctions Scheduled for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

headline: Death Toll Climbs to 6 After Stunt by Race Car
text: NASHVILLE, June 17 — The death toll increased overnight to six after a race car spun out of control at a children’s charity event in Selmer, Tenn., state highway officials said Sunday.

headline: Upbraided by Blair, the British Press Bites Back
text: LONDON, June 17 — The likening of the British media to a “feral beast” last week by Tony Blair, Britain’s departing prime minister, evoked some angry reactions from the accused. But it may have failed to provoke the larger debate he may have hoped for.

headline: In Albany, Life Has Seeped Out of Night Life
text: ALBANY — Martin Connor flicked his eyes down the bar, surveying all the unoccupied chairs. The room was too empty. The music was too loud. “I never see legislators here anymore,” he groused, lacing his fingers around a glass of pinot noir.

headline: Late Start Has Sent Mets’ Mota to Fringe
text: When reliever Guillermo Mota entered in the sixth inning of the Mets’ 11-8 loss to the Yankees on Saturday, the Mets were trailing by three runs. When he left before the eighth, the Mets were behind by five.

headline: Indonesian Terror Group Limits Attacks
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 17 — Long before the arrests of two of its top militants last week, the region’s major terrorist group had been moving away from the tactic of large-scale attacks, experts said Sunday.

headline: Regardless of the Reason, Women Have the Stage
text: Concerts exclusively by female composers create a political quandary for their instigators. Women in music history have been notable for their absence, and recent demands for attention have given the nature-nurture debate a new field of battle. Why have there been so few women in music’s past, and why are there so many in its present?

headline: Focus of Video Games Shifts to Lure More Casual Players
text: PARIS, June 17 — Critics may fume about violent killer video games, but top manufacturers are starting to beat some of their swords into beauty tips.

headline: Brooklyn: Three Struck by Cab on Sidewalk
text: A driver lost control of his livery cab on Flatbush Avenue yesterday afternoon and drove onto the sidewalk, striking two teenage boys and a man, the police said. The accident occurred at 3:20 p.m. on the northbound side of Flatbush at East 29th Street. One teenager, 15, was taken to Kings County Hospital Center in extremely critical condition, the police said. A man with him, whose age was unknown, was in critical condition at the same hospital, while a 16-year-old was in critical condition at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, the police said. Alcohol was not a factor in the accident, and the driver was not charged yesterday afternoon, the police said. Neither the driver nor a passenger in the car was seriously injured.

headline: A Harsh Lesson in Finances for After-School Students
text: Graduating from high school should not be in the realm of the incredible. Tell that to Joseph Guerrero. He arrived at Lower East Side Preparatory High School two years ago as a 19-year-old fleeing a much larger school where he had spent a few frustrating, anonymous years. He had talked to nobody and kept to himself.

headline: Using His Best Sales Pitch, Wadsworth Receives a Chance With the Jets
text: As he did for years on the football field, Andre Wadsworth quickly sized up the men who were quietly taking his measure. This rectangular playing field was a long conference table in an office building in Atlanta, around which sat 20 men affiliated with the North American operations of the car manufacturer Porsche.

headline: Drug Companies and Doctors’ Education (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Holocaust Survivors Seek Accountability (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Looking Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS On a slow week for economic data, there will be an update on the housing market with a report on housing starts for May (Tuesday). There will also be leading economic indicators for May (Thursday).

headline: Sudan and U.N. Reach New Peacekeeping Deal for Darfur
text: CAPE TOWN, June 17  The United Nations Security Council and the Sudanese government on Sunday hammered out the major details of a proposal to send more than 20,000 peacekeeping troops to Darfur, clearing the way for a joint force with the African Union, which will be led and paid for by the United Nations.

headline: For Upper Manhattan, ‘Congestion Pricing’ Has a Hidden Cost
text: ALBANY — New York City could start charging residents for the right to park in their own neighborhoods under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan for “congestion pricing.”

headline: A Wary Veteran Patrols the Daunting Home Front
text: “I was kicking down doors, driving Humvees,” is the terse way Rob Timmins summarizes a year in Iraq. His description of his new job  roaming the American home front trying to get Americans to care about other returning soldiers  is more complicated. “The Support Our Troops magnets on people’s cars will eventually come off, and 5, 10 years from now, who will remember the veterans?” asks the 25-year-old Mr. Timmins, outspoken as the Staten Island bartender he used to be.

headline: Big Parcel in Adirondacks Sold to Nature Conservancy
text: The last big piece of privately owned timber land in the Adirondacks — a craggy 161,000-acre wilderness of hardwood forests, 80 mountain peaks, 70 crystal clear lakes and ponds, rivers, white water gorges, and secluded bogs — has been sold for $110 million to the Nature Conservancy, a move that is intended to protect the land from future development.

headline: French Conservatives Win; Socialists Make Gains
text: PARIS, Monday, June 18  The conservative party of President Nicolas Sarkozy won a solid victory in parliamentary elections on Sunday, but in a surprise, it failed to trounce the opposition on the left the way both the polls and politicians had predicted.

headline: Backing Abbas, U.S. Ends Embargo on Palestinian Aid
text: WASHINGTON, June 18—The United States today ended a 15-month economic and political embargo of the Palestinian Authority in a bid to bolster President Mahmoud Abbas and the new Fatah-led emergency government that he has established in the West Bank as a counterweight to Hamas-controlled Gaza.

headline: Early Diagnosis of Ovarian Cancer (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Best Buy Awards Accounts to BBDO and Crispin Porter
text: Best Buy in Minneapolis has awarded large assignments to two agencies.

headline: U.S. and Iraqi Troops Begin Big Offensive
text: BAGHDAD, June 18 — American and Iraqi troops began major military operations north and south of Baghdad today, while deep in the south near the Iranian border, a ferocious battle between American troops and Shiite militants left at least 20 dead and wounded scores more, Iraqi and American officials.

headline: Opera’s Inner Soap Dishes the Divas
text: An opera wife I know used to describe the atmosphere backstage as “ ‘Peyton Place’ with classical music in the background.” In “The Second Tosca,” which opened June 13 at the 45th Street Theater, the playwright Tom Rowan taps the comic potential of this promising environment. The aging diva trying for one more triumph? The ambitious, coldhearted conductor? Sex, jealousy and the ghosts of the past? They are all here, drawn in enough detail to transcend mere caricature, brought to life by an excellent cast and enlivened with a lot of humor. The piece is not without its flaws; still, even nonopera lovers should enjoy themselves.

headline: In France, Socialists’ First Couple Are No More
text: PARIS, June 18 — A day after President Nicolas Sarkozy’s conservative party captured a smaller majority in the French Parliament than expected, the Socialist Party was struggling to adjust to the awkward reality that its first couple — Ségolène Royal and François Hollande — had split up.

headline: Another Attempt to Match Readers and Relevant News
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 17  Ian Clarke was a 23-year-old computer scientist living in Scotland in 2000 when he started a global controversy by deploying an online system called Freenet. The system was intended to make it possible to share information anonymously, and to make it virtually impossible to remove from the Internet once it was placed there.

headline: In Beginning, Even Jeter Doubted Jeter
text: This was before the 2,242 hits, before the four World Series rings, before he became the captain of the Yankees and before he attracted comparisons to Joe DiMaggio. This was Derek Jeter in Tampa, Fla., 15 years ago. This was Jeter’s first day playing professionally for the Yankees.

headline: Things Going Right for Red Sox, but for All the Wrong Reasons
text: BOSTON, June 17 — An hour before the Red Sox played the Giants in the middle game of their weekend series, Boston catcher Jason Varitek jumped up in front of his locker, knocked over his chair, kicked one of his shoes across the room and shouted as he dived on the floor of the Fenway Park clubhouse.

headline: A British Channel and Its Two Faces
text: LONDON, June 17 — First came “Embarrassing Illnesses,” in which doctors advised young Britons on how to deal with ailments like anal warts. That was followed by “Big Brother,” the reality television series in which misfits are locked into a house and prodded until their behavior turns embarrassing.

headline: Not Everyone Wants Channel That’s All Big Ten, All the Time
text: One barometer for classic sports conflict in the Big Ten is Ohio State and Michigan at the Big House in Ann Arbor. But a percolating fight between the conference and Comcast is evolving into a battle that Keith Jackson, in his rumbling baritone, might call one between two “big uglies.”

headline: The Supreme Court’s Bonus Babies
text: Washington

headline: Gianfranco Ferré, Italian Designer, Dies at 62
text: Gianfranco Ferré, the Italian fashion designer noted for a consistently singular vision in his signature ready-to-wear collection and for opening the doors of French haute couture to foreign-born designers, died Sunday night in Milan. He was 62.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: ‘Four’ Proves Bigger Than ‘Thirteen’

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about proposed new anti-terrorism regulations for small boats gave the wrong rank for the Coast Guard’s commandant, Thad W. Allen. He is an admiral, not a vice admiral. (Go to Article)

headline: Two Cheers on Global AIDS
text: Now that the Group of 8 industrialized nations has pledged to commit $60 billion to combat AIDS and other diseases around the world in coming years  a substantial sum by any reckoning  Congress and other national legislatures ought to look hard for additional funds to close a looming gap between the funds committed and the needs of desperate patients.

headline: Postmodern Thoughts, Illuminated by the Practices of a Premodern Tribe
text: News of the death of the philosopher Richard Rorty on June 8 came as I was reading about a small Brazilian tribe that the French anthropologist Claude Lévi-Strauss studied in the 1930s. A strange accident, a haphazard juxtaposition — but for a moment this pragmatist philosopher and a fading tribal culture glanced against each other, revealing something unusual about the contemporary scene.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Furyk’s Emotional Charge Up the Leader Board Fizzles on the 17th
text: OAKMONT, Pa., June 17 — A second United States Open title was in Jim Furyk’s grasp Sunday as he stood on the No. 17 tee, gripping his driver.

headline: Showing Style With Black and Gold, or Giving Cause for Arrest?
text: Fashion has always been something of a uniform. Goths, hippies, preppies, Madison Avenue ladies who lunch: each group has its look.

headline: In Ethiopia, Fear and Cries of Army Brutality
text: IN THE OGADEN DESERT, Ethiopia — The rebels march 300 strong across the crunchy earth, young men with dreadlocks and AK-47s slung over their shoulders.

headline: Wind Helps Push Bonds Closer to Mark
text: BOSTON, June 17 — On Friday night, on his first visit to Fenway Park, Barry Bonds hit a long fly ball that looked like a home run as it passed high above the foul pole in right field. But it was ruled foul.

headline: New Lyrics for Israel
text: AS Israel prepares to celebrate its 60th birthday next year, it’s time to update its national anthem, “Hatikvah” (“The Hope”). Only a single phrase needs to be changed: “nefesh Yehudi,” which means a Jewish soul, should be replaced with “nefesh Israeli,” an Israeli soul. Why tamper with a beautiful, stirring hymn? To solve what we might call the “Hatikvah” contradiction.

headline: Classic Qualities Have Role in Contemporary Sound
text: Few composers represent the shock of the new as convincingly as Iannis Xenakis, who transmuted the impersonal logic of higher mathematics into sounds of elemental power and daunting ferocity. Xenakis hardly reinvented music from scratch: the precision of Bach, the feeling of inevitability associated with Beethoven, Chopin’s poetry and Debussy’s painterly quality can all be heard in his 1980 piano work, “Mists.” But when Marc Ponthus opened the first concert of the Institute and Festival for Contemporary Performance on Friday night with an exhilarating account of that piece, it seemed to herald a radical break from convention, along with a compelling embrace of the new and unexpected.

headline: End Looms for Iraq Arms Inspection Unit
text: UNITED NATIONS, June 16 — The search for Saddam Hussein’s weapons of mass destruction appears close to an official conclusion, several years after their absence became a foregone one.

headline: A Festival With More Than Just Jam-Bands
text: MANCHESTER, Tenn., June 17 — Each year the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival insists it’s not just a hippie jam-band festival. This year two of Bonnaroo’s three headliners came from way off the jam-band circuit — Tool on Friday night and the Police on Saturday. Other performers on the three-and-a-half-day schedule spanned British rock, Canadian pop, soul, bluegrass, reggae, jazz and alternative hip-hop along with jam-band stalwarts like Sunday’s finale headliner, Widespread Panic.

headline: Europeans Fear New U.S. Requirement Could Hurt Travelers
text: WASHINGTON, June 17 — Measures moving through Congress, including a requirement for travelers in some countries to register travel plans online 48 hours before departure, have raised fears in Europe of disruptions in the trans-Atlantic flow of business and leisure travel.

headline: Air Force Hopes to Cut Oil’s Role in Fuel
text: The United States Air Force has decided to push development of a new type of fuel to power its bombers and fighters, mixing conventional jet fuel with fuels from nonpetroleum sources that could eventually limit military dependence on imported oil.

headline: End Vietnam’s Air War
text: Sun Valley, Idaho

headline: Editor’s Charge: His Lawyer Fell Short
text: People like to gripe about their lawyers after their cases go south. Listen, for instance, to Norman Pearlstine, who presided over the debacle that ended with Time Inc.’s disclosure of the identity of a source to a special prosecutor two summers ago.

headline: Wang, Baffling Mets, Extends Yankees’ June Push
text: For a team that is having trouble scoring, the most welcome sight is a grooved fastball or a hanging curve. The Mets are as good at pummeling those pitches as any team. But batters cannot hit those pitches if they do not exist. And last night they were few and far between.

headline: Abbas Swears In Emergency Government
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank, June 17 — The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah, swore in an emergency government at his headquarters here on Sunday, reasserting his authority over the West Bank days after Fatah’s rival, Hamas, routed his forces in Gaza and seized power there.

headline: True Winner at Oakmont: The Course
text: Oakmont, Pa.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 10 P.M. (NBC) DATELINE NBC This summer is the 10th anniversary of the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, and the usually reticent Princes William, 24, and Harry, 22, are speaking out. They discuss the tribute concert for their mother and their lives since her death, as well as their memories of her, with Matt Lauer (above right, with Princes Harry, left, and William).

headline: Veteran’s ‘Giselle,’ Full of Spontaneity, and No Apologies
text: NEW HAVEN, June 15 — While glasnost was a buzzword, no ballerina exemplified it better than Nina Ananiashvili. When, after a long hiatus, the Bolshoi began again to tour Britain and America in 1986-7, she was its youngest star, marvelously fresh in the full-length “Raymonda” and “Giselle.” She soon began interleaving her Bolshoi career with engagements in the West. She has danced Balanchine with New York City Ballet, Ashton and MacMillan with the Royal Ballet of London, Bournonville with the Royal Danish Ballet, Petipa with the Kirov Ballet: That is, she, like no one else, has gone to all the main choreographic centers of ballet classicism to dance their home choreography, and she remains too a principal guest artist with American Ballet Theater. (She dances “Swan Lake” there on June 28.)

headline: Marvel Wants to Flex Its Own Heroic Muscles as a Moviemaker
text: LOS ANGELES, June 17 — This month David Maisel, the newly minted chairman of Marvel Studios, was discussing plot points in his Beverly Hills office with Edward Norton, the Academy Award-nominated actor whom he has cast as the star of a new version of “The Incredible Hulk.”

headline: Taking On Big Donors, McCain Takes a Big Risk
text: WASHINGTON, June 17 — A ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee like Senator John McCain could normally bank on a bonanza of campaign contributions from the defense industry, especially if he was under pressure to raise money fast.

headline: Checking In With Glimmer Twins, Plato and Aristotle
text: Meet Aristotle sporting Doc Martens, and hear Plato interpreted by the light of a disco ball at the new kooky klassics double feature at the Kitchen.

headline: Long Reviled, Merit Pay Gains Among Teachers
text: MINNEAPOLIS — For years, the unionized teaching profession opposed few ideas more vehemently than merit pay, but those objections appear to be eroding as school districts in dozens of states experiment with plans that compensate teachers partly based on classroom performance.

headline: Cadbury Expected to Sell Beverage Unit, Including 7-Up
text: Cadbury Schweppes is preparing to announce tomorrow that is will sell its American beverage business, which includes 7-Up, Dr Pepper and Snapple, according to people close to the company.

headline: After Bus Attack, Afghan Police Mourn Their Own
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 17 — A mammoth explosion tore through a police bus in the heart of Kabul on Sunday morning, killing at least 24 people — 22 of them police academy instructors on their way to work — in one of the deadliest insurgent attacks in Afghanistan since the fall of the Taliban in 2001.

headline: New CDs
text: BON JOVI “Lost Highway” (Island)

headline: Tiny but Hungry, Moth May Peril California Crops
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 15 — Full grown, the light brown apple moth is roughly the size of a nickel: a little dirt-colored insect with an adult life span shorter than the average summer vacation.

headline: On the Campaign Trail With Elizabeth Edwards
text: TIPTON, Iowa, June 16 — Elizabeth Edwards was holding court in the sweltering basement at the Cedar County Courthouse in Tipton, where local Democrats fanned themselves under fluorescent light. Her husband, John Edwards, making his second run for the presidency, watched and winced as she quizzed her audience about what they knew of his biography.

headline: Cabrera Is Last Man Standing at U.S. Open
text: OAKMONT, Pa., June 17 — He took deep drags from a stubby cigarette and footlong divots from Oakmont Country Club until, at last, Ángel Cabrera walked off the 18th green with the hopes of a nation and the burden of a lead in a major championship.

headline: During Intermission, Cellphones Are Brandished in a Promotion
text: Typically you are told to turn off your cellphone before a performance. But at a recent Saturday matinee of “Spring Awakening,” the Broadway musical that garnered eight Tony Awards last week, the audience was told to do just the opposite.

headline: The Best Judges Business Can Buy
text: The problem of wealthy interests’ trying to influence court decisions by pouring money into state judicial elections continues to escalate, according to a newly released report. So does the threat to the impartiality, independence and integrity of the nation’s courts. If the courts are going to pursue justice rather than advance special-interest agendas, states must either adopt public financing and strict fund-raising rules for judicial elections or switch to a nonelective merit selection system.

headline: Restaurant Reservations Go Online
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 17 — Town Hall, one of the busiest restaurants in this food-crazed city, seems the very model of old-fashioned dining. Patrons who arrive to claim their reserved seats are greeted by a hostess who consults a piece of paper with the day’s reservations and leads her guests to the appointed table.

headline: Fashion Writer Sentenced in Attack on Woman
text: Peter Braunstein, the former writer for Women’s Wear Daily who was convicted on charges that on Halloween 2005, while dressed as a firefighter, he tied up, sexually molested and terrorized a former colleague, was sentenced to 18 years to life in prison today.

headline: Supreme Court Upholds Rights for Car Passengers
text: WASHINGTON, June 18 — A passenger as well as a driver has the right to challenge the legality of a police officer’s decision to stop a car, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today.

headline: Talks for Chip Software Maker Are Said to Bog Down on Price
text: Buyout talks between Cadence Design Systems, one of the largest makers of the software used to design computer chips, and two private equity firms appear to have stalled over price, according to people close to the matter.

headline: Vowing to Love, Cherish and Root for Brooklyn Cyclones
text: The rush begins in midwinter. The pantry needs stocking, credit cards are paid off and spring cleaning begins well before the last frost has thawed.

headline: Justices Turn Back Antitrust Suits Against Wall St. Firms
text: WASHINGTON, June 18  The Supreme Court ruled in favor of more than a dozen Wall Street investment banks today as it found that they could not be sued under antitrust law over losses in the crash of technology stocks seven years ago.

headline: Short and Happy (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Brooklyn: 18-Month-Old Run Over in Driveway
text: An 18-month-old boy was killed when he was run over by a neighbor’s car in a Flatbush driveway yesterday shortly after 5 p.m., the police said. The boy was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead on arrival. The neighbor, who was backing the car out on East 26th Street near Avenue I, was unaware of the accident and drove away from the scene. It is unclear whether the toddler was being supervised when he was hit. No charges are expected to be filed against the neighbor, the police said.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about proposed new anti-terrorism regulations for small boats gave the wrong rank for the Coast Guard’s commandant, Thad W. Allen. He is an admiral, not a vice admiral.

headline: Ex-Businessman Wins Runoff for Dallas Mayor
text: DALLAS, June 17 —Voters here on Saturday chose a retired businessman as their next mayor, ending a bid by a three-term city councilman who if elected would have become the first openly gay elected leader of a major American city.

headline: Robert Tracy, 52, Dance Writer, Is Dead
text: Robert Tracy, a prolific dance writer, died on June 7 in Manhattan. He was 52.

headline: Iraqi Journalist Found Dead as Security Lags
text: BAGHDAD, June 17 — The body of the political editor of a government-financed newspaper was found Sunday in the main Baghdad mortuary.

headline: Sir Wally Herbert, Explorer of the Iciest Corners on Earth, Dies at 72
text: Sir Wally Herbert, the first man to walk across the icebound Arctic Ocean and, some contend, the first to reach the North Pole on foot, a feat long credited to Rear Adm. Robert E. Peary, died Tuesday in Scotland at 72.

headline: Computer Cookies and How They Crumble
text: Tiny files called “cookies” are the lifeblood of online advertising. When a computer visits a site or sees an ad for the first time, the site’s server slips a cookie onto the visitor’s hard drive, identifying the computer in future dealings with that site or ad network. Cookies let online hosts determine the number of unique visitors they reach, a key metric for advertisers.

headline: Preppie Afro-Pop and Other Odd Blends
text: For a proactive indie-rock fan in 2007 a debut album is more like an end product than a starting point. By the time that first shrink-wrapped and bar-coded CD finds its way into shops, the band will probably be old news, having suffered through many online cycles of hype and backlash. In a world that won’t wait patiently for an album release date, it probably makes more sense to talk about a debut MP3, a debut YouTube appearance, a debut MySpace page.

headline: Conquering the Peak Test of Technology
text: AFTER weeks of climbing, Rod Baber recently reached the summit of Mount Everest, a dream fulfilled. At the top of the world, as dawn was breaking, he took off his oxygen mask and called his voice mailbox, leaving an exuberant, if weary, message.

headline: Dear Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Brooklyn: Two Killed in Crashes
text: Two men died and a third man was seriously injured in two motor vehicle accidents Saturday night and early yesterday, the police said. A 58-year-old man was killed when he drove a Mercedes-Benz through a fence and into a parked car at 3:45 a.m. yesterday at Pennsylvania Avenue near the Belt Parkway. In the other accident, a 27-year-old man was killed and his passenger, also a man in his 20s, suffered head and neck injuries when the motorcycle they were riding collided with a 1999 Ford Taurus at 10 p.m. Saturday at Rockaway Parkway and Church Avenue in Brownsville. The injured man was listed in stable condition at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, the police said. No charges were expected.

headline: Gore to Bring Talk of Green to Ad Festival
text: The brightest lights in the advertising business are gathering in Cannes, France, this week for an annual celebration of the art of persuading consumers to part with their money. In the industry’s biggest international get-together, awards will be given for the best ads for products like cars, clothing, food and air travel.

headline: G.E. and Pearson Are Said to Study Bid for Dow Jones
text: The General Electric Company, the parent of NBC, and Pearson, the publisher of The Financial Times, are exploring a joint bid for Dow Jones & Company to rival an offer made by the News Corporation, people familiar with the talks said yesterday.

headline: New Capos’ Taut Smiles at HBO
text: The keening that followed the 11 seconds of inky blackness at the end of “The Sopranos” finale has finally begun to die down. But the executives at HBO could be forgiven for feeling like they are still staring into that dark place.

headline: Democrats Press Plan to Channel Billions in Oil Subsidies to Renewable Fuels
text: WASHINGTON, June 16 — Senate Democrats are seeking a major reversal of energy tax policies that would take billions of dollars in tax breaks and other benefits from the oil industry to underwrite renewable fuels.

headline: Gunmen Kill Palestinian at Israeli-Gaza Border
text: JERUSALEM, June 18 — A Palestinian man was killed Monday at the volatile and closed border between Israel and Gaza, after Palestinian gunmen opened fire on Israeli soldiers, officials said. The incident took place near the area where several hundred people trying to flee Gaza have been camped out, and Israeli troops fired back.

headline: 7 Afghan Children Killed in U.S.-Led Airstrike
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 18 — Seven children were killed during an airstrike by the American-led coalition against a religious compound thought to be an Al Qaeda sanctuary in remote eastern Afghanistan, the coalition reported today.

headline: Staking His Campaign on Iowa, Edwards Makes a Populist Pitch to the Left
text: TIPTON, Iowa, June 16 — Four years ago — facing what seemed to be a certain defeat in the Iowa Democratic caucuses — John Edwards recast his presidential campaign with weeks to go before the vote, unveiling an emotionally powerful speech about poverty that he delivered relentlessly across the state. Mr. Edwards came within a few thousand votes of victory. To this day, he tells associates he would have won with another week.

headline: Autism Debate Strains a Family and Its Charity
text: A year after their grandson Christian received a diagnosis of autism in 2004, Bob Wright, then chairman of NBC/Universal, and his wife, Suzanne, founded Autism Speaks, a mega-charity dedicated to curing the dreaded neurological disorder that affects one of every 150 children in America today.

headline: Retail Giant Will Remake Private Bank
text: Bank of America built its brand as a financial supermarket that could be all things to all people. Now, it will see if a new name can burnish its private bank's reputation in catering to the very rich.

headline: Pigs With Cellphones, but No Condoms
text: IN a commercial for Trojan condoms that has its premiere tonight, women in a bar are surrounded by anthropomorphized, cellphone-toting pigs. One shuffles to the men’s room, where, after procuring a condom from a vending machine, he is transformed into a head-turner in his 20s. When he returns to the bar, a fetching blond who had been indifferent now smiles at him invitingly.

headline: In Defense, the Timing Is Everything
text: The most common defensive error is not counting. The diagramed deal features another common defensive card-play error. It arose during the HBL International Pairs, the opening event at the Peek Freans 14th Asia and Middle East Bridge Championships in Karachi, Pakistan, in May.

headline: Matching Masterpieces With History’s Flash Points
text: There was a time, not so long ago, when “popularizer” was a derogatory term used by academics to dismiss the popularity of a more successful colleague.

headline: Private Equity Deal Expected for Lexicon Pharmaceuticals
text: Lexicon Pharmaceuticals, a developer of treatments for diseases like irritable bowel syndrome, is expected to announce today that it has signed deals with two private equity firms that will invest nearly $300 million into the 12-year-old publicly held company.

headline: Dinner With a Warlord
text: A HILLTOP IN EASTERN CONGO

headline: Police to Adopt Changes Following Fatal Shooting
text: The New York Police Department is moving to require officers to take breathalyzer tests whenever anyone is killed or wounded by police action, and to psychologically screen candidates for undercover work, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced today, accepting the recommendations of a panel formed after an unarmed man was fatally shot in Queens in a volley of 50 police bullets.

headline: Muddy Waters
text: The Environmental Protection Agency and the Army Corps of Engineers have finally issued guidelines about which streams and wetlands are subject to federal jurisdiction. Unfortunately, they are just as confusing as the Supreme Court decision they are supposed to carry out  guaranteeing endless litigation, while increasing the chances that valuable wetlands will be needlessly destroyed.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the way cancer doctors practice medicine misstated a title for Dr. Peter Eisenberg. He is a former director of the American Society of Clinical Oncology, not a current director. His term ended on June 4. The article also misstated the price of Avastin, a cancer drug. For an average lung cancer patient, it is $8,800 a month, not $8,800 a dose.

headline: Coney Island Plan Is Scaled Back, but Critics Are Skeptical
text: The developer who wants to remake Coney Island’s amusement district has a new plan and says that you’re going to love it.

headline: Queens: Man Shot by Police in Critical Condition
text: A man who was shot by police officers on Saturday night after the authorities said he refused to drop a pellet gun that looked like a handgun remained in critical but stable condition yesterday at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, the police said. The man was identified as Luis A. Dominguez, 49, of Rosedale. The shooting occurred near his home shortly before 9 p.m., when several officers surrounded him and repeatedly ordered him to drop the gun before firing several shots, witnesses and the police said. Mr. Dominguez was shot in the torso, the police said. A lieutenant suffered a minor shoulder injury, and the police said yesterday it was unclear whether the lieutenant had been grazed by a bullet from a fellow officer. An investigation is continuing, the police said. A neighbor said Mr. Dominguez was prone to hostility when he had been drinking. “He kept going up the street, hiding behind a tree with the gun,” said the neighbor, Zita Young, 43. “I ran to the deli to get one of the guys to see if they could talk to him or help him. By that time we heard the gunshots go off. I wasn’t counting, but it was a lot.”

headline: Doctor, Give Me the News, and Sew Me Up Pretty
text: The deglamorization that doctors have suffered with the rise of H.M.O.’s in American life has had its corrective on television, where medical dramas seem to labor ever more aggressively to establish the physician’s genius. It is an immensely long gurney ride from the era of “St. Elsewhere” in the 1980s to the current moment of “House,” on which Hugh Laurie represents medicine as a field not of workaday mechanics but of brash intellectualism and analytical skill. How could a mere M.D. suffice?

headline: Journey’s Song Gets a Bump From TV Once Again
text: “The Sopranos” is over, but the last song featured on the show, “Don’t Stop Believin’, ” which the band Journey released in 1981, keeps going as its lyrics say, “on and on and on and on.”

headline: Envoy Sees North Korea Progress
text: BEIJING, June 18 — North Korea could be ready to begin shutting its plutonium producing reactor within weeks as the first step toward disabling the unit by the end of this year, the top American negotiator on the North’s nuclear weapons program said here today.

headline: For A-Rod and Critics, It’s Now Wait and See
text: An hour after the Yankees defeated the Mets in the second game of a three-game series, Alex Rodriguez poked his head into Joe Torre’s office. Torre had finished his postgame interviews and most members of the news media had left when Rodriguez stopped by.

headline: Hey, Giovanni, Put a Shirt on. You’ll Catch Cold.
text: LONDON, June 17 — The Royal Opera House in Covent Garden recently broadcast its production of Mozart’s “Don Giovanni” on outdoor screens around this city, part of the BP Summer Big Screens initiative. The revival of this grippingly spare and psychologically probing 2002 staging by the director Francesca Zambello, shown on Friday evening, was especially suited to big-screen close-ups thanks to an exceptionally attractive and involving cast.

headline: The half-century mortgage
text: How would you feel about paying off your mortgage over the next 50 years? This week, a specialist broker in Britain called The Mortgage Lender announced it was developing a mortgage spanning half a century. The idea is that monthly payments are reduced to a more manageable level.

headline: A hidden treasure at the British Museum
text: Bristish Museum (AP)

headline: Second Stage’s New Season
text: The New York premiere of Edward Albee's "Peter and Jerry" and the world premiere of "Farragut North," a dark political comedy by Beau Willimon, are among the offerings in Second Stage Theater's 2007-8 season, the company is to announce today.

headline: Another Attempt to Match Readers and Relevant News
text: Ian Clarke, the computer scientist who sparked global controversy with his online system called Freenet, which was intended to make it possible to share information anonymously and to make it virtually impossible to be removed from the Internet once it was placed there, is at it again.

headline: Lexicon Strikes Two Deals with Private Equity
text: Lexicon Pharmaceuticals, a developer of treatments for diseases like irritable bowel syndrome, has signed deals with two private equity firms that will invest nearly $300 million into the 12-year-old publicly held company.

headline: Stock Exchanges Continue Game of Musical Chairs
text: Unconfirmed reports Friday that the New York Mercantile Exchange is seeking a buyer at the same time that the Chicago Board of Trade is in the throes of a merger agreement re-emphasized what a tumultuous period this is for the world’s financial markets, as they focus nearly as much on buying and selling each other as they do on trading products.

headline: C.I.A.’s Venture Fund Spends on Surveillance Software Firm
text: In-Q-Tel, a private investment firm launched by the Central Intelligence Agency to support domestic intelligence agencies, has invested in an image sensor maker Pixim, the company said last week. The investment was part of a $15 million funding round announced in March that included Tallwood Venture Capital, Ridgewood Capital and the Mayfield Fund.

headline: Private Equity Firm Takes Majority Stake in Taiwan Bank
text: Consolidation in Taiwan’s banking sector continues as a private equity firm, The Longreach Group, announced at the end of last week that it would invest 23 billion New Taiwan dollars ($694 million) to acquire 51 percent of the EnTie Commercial Bank.

headline: S.E.C. to Probe Hain Celestial’s Practices
text: The Hain Celestial Group said Friday it had been informed by the Securities and Exchange Commission that the agency is conducting an informal inquiry into the company’s stock option practices. Hain, the American company that makes organic and natural foods and personal care items, said it would cooperate with the investigation.

headline: Wachovia Named in Brokerage Lawsuit
text: Wachovia, which agreed last month to buy A.G. Edwards for $6.8 billion, has been added to a federal lawsuit accusing large brokerages of moving customers’ idle cash into low-yielding accounts to boost profits.

headline: Microsoft Takes Stake in Chinese Game Maker
text: Microsoft will take a stake in Shanghai-listed Changhong Electric and work with the firm to jointly develop entertainment products that can be accessed via the Internet, Changhong said. Changhong Electric said in a statement on Monday that Microsoft would take a 94-million-yuan ($12.3 million) stake in the firm by purchasing 15 million new shares.

headline: Boutique Bank Said to Be Prepping Rival Bid for Sanctuary
text: The battle for the British music group Sanctuary may not be over yet, with a London-listed investment bank, Crosby Capital Partners, preparing a counterbid to trump Universal Music Group‘s 20 pence-per-share offer, according to The Guardian. Crosby, which has offices in Hong Kong and London, has appointed lawyers from SJ Berwin to help make its offer for the troubled music group, which manages Sir Elton John and James Blunt, the report said.

headline: France’s Areva Bids $2.3 Billion for Uranium Producer
text: The French nuclear giant Areva has presented a cash bid worth 2.5 billion Canadian dollars ($2.3 billion) for UraMin, a South Africa-headquartered company interlisted on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Areva said Friday it is bidding 7.75 Canadian dollars per share for UraMin stock, which closed Thursday at 7.94 Canadian dollars.

headline: Kohlberg Kravis Is Said to Lead Bidding for Air Canada Unit
text: Air Canada Technical Services will name a buyer as early as Monday, and signs point to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts edging out Lufthansa Technik Group of Germany in a close race, according to The Globe and Mail.

headline: G.E. and Pearson Explore Bid for Dow Jones
text: After making an overture to Microsoft about a joint bid for Dow Jones, the General Electric Company, the parent of NBC, is now exploring that idea with Pearson, the publisher of The Financial Times, according to reports on Monday. The talks are still preliminary, and Rupert Murdoch’s $5 billion offer for Dow Jones represents a “a very high threshold,” The New York Times said. The Wall Street Journal quoted several sources describing the possibility of a deal as a “long shot.”

headline: British Paint Maker Rejects $14 Billion Bid from Dutch Rival
text: Shares in Imperial Chemical Industries  of Britain, the maker of Dulux paints, rose 16 percent Monday after it rejected a 7.2 billion pound ($14.2 billion) takeover bid from Akzo Nobel, a Dutch rival and the maker of Crown paints.

headline: Everquest Financial Linked to Troubled Bear Fund
text: As Bear Stearns struggles with big losses at one of its hedge funds, MarketWatch notes that the troubled fund has ties to Everquest Financial, a company that filed plans for an initial public offering last month.

headline: Chadbourne & Parke in Merger Talks With U.K. Law Firm
text: The New York law firm Chadbourne & Parke is in preliminary merger discussions with the Watson, Farley & Williams law firm of London, Chadbourne’s managing partner, Charlie O’Neill, told The American Lawyer magazine.

headline: Backed By Merrill, Marvel Flexes Moviemaking Muscles
text: David Maisel, the newly minted chairman of Marvel Studios, was until recently a little-known deal maker trained by the former kingpin Michael S. Ovitz.

headline: John Edwards in Iowa
text: On the campaign trail with John Edwards in Iowa, where he has made the state the place where his candidacy will rise or fall.

headline: Finish Line Laces Up Deal With Genesco
text: Finish Line, the footwear retailer, said Monday it had agreed to buy Genesco, which owns the teenager-focused Journeys sneaker chain and the Johnston & Murphy brand of dress shoes, for $1.5 billion, or $54.50 a share. The deal, which the boards of directors at both companies are supporting, came after Genesco rejected two bids from Foot Locker, the second of which was for $51 a share.

headline: Buyout Shops Prep I.P.O. for Hedge Fund Administrator
text: The hedge fund administrator GlobeOp is planning to make an initial public offering on the London Stock Exchange. GlobeOp said it hoped to get $102 million for the 20.4-million-share offering. A Boston buyout specialist, TA Associates, and Mezzanine Management are offering the stock and will both retain a “significant holding” in GlobeOp after the shares are sold.

headline: BHP Considers New $40 Billion Bid for Alcoa, Report Says
text: BHP Billiton, the world’s largest mining company, has revived plans for a $40 billion (£20.2 billion) takeover of Alcoa, according to The Times of London. The newspaper, without citing any named sources, said BHP is in the early stages of evaluating the merits of a takeover. BHP, based in Melbourne, “is not thought to have” formally approached Alcoa, the Times reported.

headline: Private Equity Mania Sours Plays for Short Sellers
text: Is private equity raining on short-sellers’ parade?

headline: 2008: The Iowa Trail
text: The campaign trail through Iowa was well-worn this weekend as many of the presidential candidates made stops in the state. Former Senator John Edwards is one of the hopefuls who have been crisscrossing Iowa in recent days, and as The Times’s Adam Nagourney reports, for Mr. Edwards it is part of a strategy that reflects “just how much he has settled on this state as the place where his bid for the Democratic presidential nomination will rise or fall.” But Mr. Edwards is running a different kind of campaign this time around than in 2004 when he lost the Iowa caucuses to Senator John Kerry:

headline: Morning Buzz: Coney Dreams, Broken Buses, Soup to Nuts
text: Is Coney Island — where a storied past and dilapidated present have been the stubborn reality for as long as anyone can remember — about to get its groove back?

headline: Simons Antes Up for Buyout Fund
text: James Simons, founder of the hedge fund Renaissance Technologies and a top earner in his field, is putting some of his cash into a new leveraged buyout fund, according to Long Island Business News. Mr. Simons, who led Alpha Magazine’s list of the top 25 hedge fund earners, is the largest investor in a new $115 million leveraged buyout fund raised by Topspin Partners, the report said.

headline: Bank of America to Remake Its Private Bank
text: The Bank of America built its brand as a financial supermarket that could be all things to all people. Now, it will see if a new name can burnish its private bank’s reputation in catering to the very rich.

headline: Talks for Chip Software Maker Are Said to Bog Down on Price
text: Buyout talks between Cadence Design Systems, one of the largest makers of the software used to design computer chips, and two private equity firms appear to have stalled over price, The New York Times reported.

headline: Immigration to Resurface in the Senate
text: The immigration bill is scheduled to make its reappearance in the Senate by the end of this week but the outlook for its future depends on who you ask.

headline: On the Trail With Mrs. Edwards
text: In his Web column today, Adam Nagourney writes about the Edwards campaign’s recent swing through Iowa:

headline: Forget Boxes, Move the Whole House!
text: The Lede ended last week focused on digging up a 1957 Plymouth Belvedere in Tulsa, so why not start this one off with the relocation of an 1883 carriage house in Portland?

headline: Investors Cool to Goldman’s Hedge Funds
text: Goldman Sachs‘s alternative investment funds, including its hedge funds, experienced net inflows of zero in the latest quarter for the first time since the bank began reporting such data in 2004, the Financial News said. Last year, by comparison, the bank reported net inflows of $32 billion.

headline: The Human Cost of War
text: I saw my first patient in the Congo today. Her name is Yohanita Nyiahabimana. She is a 41-year old woman who lives in the village of Malehe, about an hour from Goma. She was carried out of her house by her neighbors when they heard that we were coming. There she lay on some tattered blankets, all 50 pounds of her under the unforgiving African sun.

headline: Cadbury Expected to Sell Beverage Unit, Including 7-Up
text: Cadbury Schweppes is preparing to announce Tuesday that it will sell its American beverage business, which includes 7-Up, Dr Pepper and Snapple, according to The New York Times. Cadbury said in March that it would split its confectionary and soft drinks businesses, but had not determined whether it would sell the beverage business or spin it off.

headline: Giving Blood but Getting Nothing
text: The practice of collecting blood samples from Amazon Indians has aroused suspicions in Brazil. Joaquina Karitiana says researchers broke promises to her tribe.

headline: Bonnaroo: An Afternoon of Death
text: MANCHESTER, TENN.–Sunday was for the Bonnaroo diehards. The big mainstream headliners, Tool and the Police, were gone, and so were some of their fans. Theafternoon lineup leaned toward roots and blues–and, for some reason, songs about death. I started my afternoon with Mavis Staples, who recently released, “We’ll Never Turn Back” (Anti), an album of songs from her days in the civil-rights movement. She sang some of them, along with her gospel-soul hit, “I’ll Take You There”; then, since it was Father’s Day, she dedicated a song to her dad, Roebuck Staples, who led the Staple Singers. It was “Will the Circle Be Unbroken”–a funeral song–sung with gutsy rasps and the optimism of a gospel believer.

headline: Bonnaroo:Ornette Coleman Collapses
text: MANCHESTER, TENN.–The jazz composer, saxophonist, trumpeter and violinist Ornette Coleman, 77, collapsed during his Bonnaroo set. He was playing one of his tenderly quizzical ballad lines on alto saxophone when he toppled suddenly to the stage. A few minutes later, he was helped to his feet, sipped some water and was walked off the stage. Suffering from heat exhaustion and dehydration, he was given fluids, taken to a local hospital and released a few hours later.

headline: Bill Targets Blackstone, But Who Really Gets Hurt?
text: It seems aimed squarely at the Blackstone Group, but last week’s bill proposing to raise taxes on publicly traded buyout funds, if it were to become law, would probably cause many other firms to reconsider the idea of getting ticker symbols of their own. That could mean less of the transparency that many lawmakers were hoping to see in the industry, and might even result in less taxes for Treasury coffers, not more, Andrew Ross Sorkin wrote in his latest DealBook column in The New York Times.

headline: Bonnaroo: A Marriage Proposal During the White Stripes
text: MANCHESTER, TENN.–Now I get it. Years ago, when I saw the White Stripes in clubs, they struck me as a loud, unsubtle, monotonous remake of a remake: everything I had disliked about 1970’s blues-rock, reincarnated in artsy red, black and white clothes. The wacky “Get Behind Me Satan” partly changed my mind, convincing me that the White Stripes wanted no part of blues-country-roots authenticity. And at Bonnaroo, where they played to tens of thousands of people at the outdoor Which Stage, they made even more sense.

headline: Topps to Postpone Vote on Private Equity Buyout
text: Topps said Monday that it would postpone a vote on a $385 million buyout offer by two private equity firms, including one run by Michael D. Eisner, after a Delaware chancery court judge ruled that the baseball card maker must disclose more information about the deal. Topps said it would also allow a rival, Upper Deck, to make a tender offer to its shareholders, in accordance with the decision by Judge Leo Strine Jr.

headline: Bonnaroo: Wilco Gets Noisy
text: MANCHESTER, TENN.–Wilco’s new album, “Sky Blue Sky” (Nonesuch), is relatively noise-free after the band’s two previous studio albums, which were laced with electronics and noise. Onstage at Bonnaroo, songs that began as gently strummed or picked folk-rock sprouted episodes of noise–frenetic electric-guitar tremolos, two-fisted keyboard pummeling, volcanic drum crescendoes–even in older songs like “Via Chicago,” which had three giant eruptions while Jeff Tweedy kept singing its modest melody. Wilco won’t be mistaken for mellow any time soon.

headline: Bonnaroo: A Farewell to Jamming, With $2.50 Bottles of Water
text: MANCHESTER, TENN.–The Southern rock jam band Widespread Panic, which has been a Bonnaroo regular from the beginning, closed out the festival with its built-in paradox. Many of its songs (and borrowed ones, like Vic Chesnutt’s “Sewing Machine”) are about feeling unsure, out of place, a little precarious. But the music is never less than confident, riding hefty blues-rock riffs with Jimmy Herring’s breakneck, cascading guitar lines and Domingo (Sonny) Ortiz’s ebullient percussion. The fans came prepared. When the band began “Chilly Water,” a song about feeling out of place in the city, the audience waited until the chorus–“Gimme some of that cool, cool water”–and suddenly big splashes of water ($2.50 a bottle from the concessions, free from fountains) were flung across the field. Bonnaroo was almost over, and they could resupply back in the real world.

headline: Hares Disrupt Milan’s Airport
text: In the sad club of dwindling wildlife populations, the birds and the bees are joined by the tortoise, but not the hare, apparently.

headline: Anti-Socialist Film Critics Gone Wild
Giuliani Meets With Israel’s Olmert
text: Rudolph Giuliani, who has had close ties to Jewish leaders since he was mayor of New York City, met privately with Israel’s Prime Minister Ehud Olmert today.

headline: Top Chef: Judging the Judging
text: I notice that in response to my post about the season opener of “Top Chef,” one of its judges, Tom Colicchio, wrote in to quibble with the implication that the Bravo network has a hand in determining which contestants are eliminated and which make it deep into the competition.

headline: G.E., Dow Jones and the MSNBC Factor
text: As General Electric casts around for partners in a possible rival bid for Dow Jones, its chief executive, Jeffrey Immelt, might want to keep five letters in the back of his mind: MSNBC.

headline: Hotter Summers, Fewer Jobs
text: The arrival of summer on Thursday means hundreds of thousands of New York teenagers who don’t attend camp or summer programs will soon have a lot of free time on their hands.

headline: The Skim
text: A quick hike through this past Sunday’s book sections.

headline: What Died When Rorty Died?
text: Screens plans to go broke overestimating everyone’s intelligence today, including its own.

headline: Midnight Train to Freedom
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Q&A: Life in Iraq
text: Iraq is now the second most unstable country in the world, outranked in that category only by Sudan, according to an annual survey conducted by Foreign Policy magazine.

headline: Court Shields Banks from I.P.O. Antitrust Suits
text: Private equity firms may be feeling unfriendly vibes from Washington these days, but the Supreme Court just gave Wall Street’s investment banks a big hug. In a 7-1 ruling, the nation’s highest court ruled that banks including Credit Suisse, Citigroup and Morgan Stanley are immune from antitrust lawsuits that alleged they conspired to drive up prices of initial public offerings in the late 1990’s.

headline: Could An Underbid Win Dow Jones?
text: The news that Pearson and General Electric are thinking about making a counter-offer for Dow Jones raises the interesting question: Could an underbid succeed?

headline: A Reader Asks: Where’s the Morgue?
text: Q. Good morning. I was just wondering — what happened to the morgue? Did it go with you to the new building or is it all digitized? — Arlene Herring on Your City, Your Room.

headline: Fashion Writer Sentenced to 20 Years in Attack
text: Peter Braunstein, the former fashion writer, was just sentenced to 20 years to life in prison on charges he dressed up as a firefighter, kidnapped and sexually abused a co-worker. Anemona Hartocollis of The Times is in State Supreme Court in Manhattan reporting on the sentencing. NYTimes.com will have more shortly.

headline: Have Analysts Gotten Better, or Just Lucky?
text: A lot has changed since 2003, when Eliot Spitzer, then New York’s attorney general, reached a settlement with Wall Street firms intended to bring more independence to their equity research arms, whose reputations were tarnished by questions about conflicted loyalties.

headline: Michael Moore’s Movie Leaks to the Web
text: UPDATE, June 19, 5:23 PM ET After a documentary leaked in a serious way over the weekend, the studio has decided to move up the opening. Michael Cieply tells it well.

headline: The Rising Cost of Meat on a Stick
text: The cost of food and beverage rose by 3.9 percent in May from the same month a year earlier, about 1 percent higher than the inflation rate and the biggest jump in three years, according to the Labor Department.

headline: In Hedge Fund Haven, a Golf Course Goes Begging
text: Presidential hopefuls have been traveling hat in hand to Greenwich, Conn., usually leaving with wads of hedge-fund money. But the town’s own public golf course has been far less successful at prying cash out of the hands of Greenwich’s well-heeled citizens.

headline: For Some, Limited Access to Access NYC
text: Click on the Web site of Access NYC, a portal that the New York City government started last fall to make it easier for residents to fill out forms and apply for benefits, and you will see messages in English, Spanish, Chinese, Arabic, Haitian Creole, Korean and Russian.

headline: McCain Cites Romney Stem Cell Shift
text: Senator John McCain’s presidential campaign stepped up its attacks on Republican rival Mitt Romney today, sending a March 2005 clip to this reporter that appears to highlight anew an apparent change in Mr. Romney’s position today on taxpayer financing of embryonic stem cell cell research.

headline: Tick, Tick, Tick in Albany
text: There are four working days left in the legislative session in Albany. (Well, three-and-a-half.) Which brings up an issue that irked good-government types when Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the Legislature were trying to get their budget passed. Under the state constitution, lawmakers are supposed to get three days to look over — and, presumably, debate or modify — the final version of any bills. In practice, as anyone who follows the capital knows, legislation is often crafted behind closed doors by governors and the leaders of the Senate and Assembly, presented to the rank-and-file as a fait accompli, and voted while the paper’s still warm from printing.

headline: CIT Buys Midmarket M&A Advisory Firm
text: CIT Group, the New York-based financing firm, said Monday it would acquire Edgeview Partners, a mergers and acquisitions adviser whose clients include many buyout firms. CIT did not disclose the price it paid for Edgeview, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., but said in a press release that the deal was part of an effort to expand its offerings to the private equity industry.

headline: Report on Stalled Buyout Talks Drag on Cadence Shares
text: Shares in Cadence Design Systems fell Monday following a report that buyout talks for the maker of chip design software have hit a wall. The stock was trading at $22.25 Monday afternoon, down 4.5 percent.

headline: Hotel Chelsea Is Under New Management
text: Updated 6 p.m.  By some accounts, Stanley Bard, the managing partner, and the rest of the Bard family, have been forced out of running the hotel they have operated for about half a century, but the hotel’s board of managers put out a news release today saying the Bards would still “have a role” and that David Bard would remain on the board.

headline: When It’s Good to Be Endangered
text: When the National Trust for Historic Preservation last week named the Brooklyn industrial waterfront the most endangered place in America, much hand-wringing ensued. The wharves, warehouses and factories of the Brooklyn coastline, a legacy of the borough’s manufacturing past, “are being demolished by developers anxious to cash in on the area’s newly hip status,” the trust glumly warned.

headline: Darfur’s Conflict and Global Warming
text: United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki-Moon’s op-ed article tracing the vicious ethnic conflict in Darfur to a drought that was caused “at least in part from climate change” may have sounded surprising to some observers.

headline: Could an Underbid Win Dow Jones?
text: As chatter rises over the prospect of a General Electric–Pearson bid for Dow Jones, many have been wondering how that combination could possibly trump News Corporation‘s $60-a-share offer. Most analysts and pundits see Rupert Murdoch’s bid, worth about $5 billion, as too rich to be beaten. The septuagenarian media mogul could also open his wallet even wider, according to common wisdom.

headline: Former Enron Broadband C.E.O. Is Sentenced
text: The former chief of Enron‘s high-speed Internet unit, who turned government witness and testified in the trial of Jeffrey Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay, was sentenced Monday to 27 months in prison. Nearly three years ago, Kenneth Rice, 48, pleaded guilty to securities fraud and agreed to help federal prosecutors on other cases related to the energy giant’s collapse. His sentencing was postponed as he cooperated with prosecutors.

headline: For One Bidder, No Horsing Around
text: There is a fine line between publicly, gently lobbying a governor on something, and pushing so hard it boomerangs. And one of the groups bidding for New York’s thoroughbred racing franchise is trying to walk it.

headline: For Council Speaker, It’s Easy Being Green
text: In just a year and a half as the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn has become a valued ally of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. She has broken with him on some minor issues (the ban on metal baseball bats comes to mind), but has sided with him on most major ones, like budget priorities.

headline: Calpers Jumps on the Activism Bandwagon
text: As shareholder activists grab the spotlight more often — the most recent example being The Children’s Investment Fund‘s pushing for a sale of ABN Amro — one of the largest institutional investors in the United States has decided to hitch itself to itself to their star.

headline: Special Education Parents Offer Mixed Views
text: The five-page, 45-question parent survey by the Citywide Council on Special Education looked simple enough. But interpreting the results has been anything but.Betsy Gotbaum, the city’s public advocate, released a report this morning, “Left in the Dark.” It reported results from the survey [pdf], which was conducted from Oct. 1 to Nov. 30 and involved 2,026 parents of students with moderate to severe disabilities in District 75, the citywide full-time special education district.

headline: Obama Calls His Clinton Document ‘Screw-Up’
text: Senator Barack Obama disavowed the document his campaign aimed at Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton last week, saying today that it was “stupid and caustic.”

headline: Kobe Bryant, Messy Blogger
text: Add one more thing to Kobe Bryant’s long list of talents: he can send news coverage rippling across the Web with a simple change of a timestamp.

headline: Taxing Matters
text: On the surface, the news coming out of Florida last week seemed so promising: “The Florida Legislature passed the biggest property-tax cut in state history,” one report began.

headline: A Post-Powell Problem
text: A lot of liberals blame Colin Powell for persuading them to support the notion of getting into the Iraq war, but is Colin Powell also to blame for the Bush administration’s inability to get the United States out of the Iraq war? In a roundabout way, yes, suggests Andrew J. Bacevich, a professor of history and international relations at Boston University, in The Boston Globe’s “Ideas” section.In a long essay arguing for the abolishment of the position of the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Bacevich says Powell is indirectly to blame for the nation’s poor military leadership since he stepped down as chairman of the Joint Chiefs. Bacevich writes:

headline: One Week Later: Sopranos Chatter
text: Got a minute? The Sopranos links got too heavy, and The Lede had to put them down next to the gabagool. We’ve got fun clicks, new theories and some statistics about the finale that is still a matter of heavy debate, especially about whether Tony lived or died.

headline: Monday Morning Motorsports
text: In Formula One, Lewis Hamilton did it again.

headline: 24 Hours… and Ready for More
text: I survived 24 hours in the pits of the Corvette Racing team at the 24 Hours of Le Mans — and had a beer poured on my head to prove it!

headline: Egalitarian Tall Tales
text: A few weeks back a puff piece in a New Zealand newspaper extolled a trucking company that “has fostered an egalitarian culture … and does not believe in hierarchy, bureaucracy or superiority.” The same article also noted that company headquarters features this saying in bold text on a lobby wall: “The man on top of the mountain didn’t fall there.”

headline: Americans in Paris
text: Forget about freedom fries. American businessmen have come to the Paris air show in full force.

headline: Spitzer Nominates a New M.T.A. Chairman
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer has nominated H. Dale Hemmerdinger, a real estate executive, to be the next chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, succeeding Peter S. Kalikow.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage Bill Leaves Committee
text: A bill to legalize same-sex marriage just passed the State Assembly’s judiciary committee on a 16-5 vote, with the only nay votes being those of the committee’s five Republicans. It now goes to the rules committee, and from there, possibly, to a first-ever floor vote in the Assembly.

headline: Semel’s Resignation, Deal Making and the Activists
text: As Yahoo announced that Terry S. Semel was stepping down as chief executive of the beleaguered Internet giant, two questions arose: Is Yahoo in play? What now for the shareholder activists?

headline: Edwards Kicks Off ‘Eventful’ Month
text: Democratic presidential candidate John Edwards and Eventful, the online site that lets users “demand” appearances by celebrities and candidates, kicked off a month-long contest today.

headline: Mike Gravel: Behind the Music
text: While the Obama Girl video became a mini-rage on YouTube last week, another kind of rock video was silently racking up the page views.

headline: Political Sites Drawing More Eyeballs
text: May was good for political Web sites. An Internet researcher, comScore Inc., reports that traffic to such sites jumped 17 percent to nine million unique visitors last month, the highest rate of increase among the 110 categories that the company studies.

headline: Opting Out of Poll, but Not Out of Iowa
text: Two of the leading Republican candidates for president have said this month that they will not participate in the Ames, Iowa, straw poll, a ritual showing of political strength in that early caucus state. Their decisions raised doubts about whether Iowa would maintain its importance in selecting the party’s nominee.

headline: The Altruist’s Paradox: Should It Hurt to Be Nice?
text: In my Findings column, I report the possible sighting of a “true altruist,” a being that some have argued is even rarer than the one sought by Diogenes (the ancient Greek eccentric who went around with a lamp, fruitlessly searching for an honest man).

headline: Yankees Get Boost From Loss of Giambi
text: It has been a long, lonely period for Jason Giambi. He has not played for the Yankees this month because of a foot injury, and he may not play again this season. In addition, Giambi must decide by Thursday if he plans to cooperate with baseball’s investigation into steroid use.

headline: Yahoo’s Chief Resigns, and a Founder Takes Over
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 — When Yahoo hired Terry S. Semel as its chief executive in the midst of the dot-com implosion in 2001, it became a bit of an oddity in Silicon Valley: a technology company run by a Hollywood executive.

headline: It’s (Not) Just a Bug
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Symptoms and Ovarian Cancer
text: Frustrated at the lack of a good screening test for ovarian cancer, advocacy groups have persuaded professional cancer organizations to endorse a list of persistent symptoms that might indicate the presence of the disease. The list could have a very beneficial effect in alerting patients — and doctors who have been dismissive of complaints of generalized discomfort — that ovarian cancer is present at an early stage when it is most treatable.

headline: Duncan and Jeter: Fundamental Similarity
text: The reporter had a question and, as usual, Derek Jeter gave an answer, if not exactly the one being sought.

headline: Airbus Secures Big Orders at Air Show
text: PARIS, June 18 — Airlines gave a big lift to the order book for the next-generation Airbus A350 on Monday, announcing contracts for 114 of the planes on the first day of the Paris air show. The vote of confidence puts the program on more solid footing, although it is still well behind the Boeing Company’s rival jet.

headline: Change at the Chelsea, Shelter of the Arts
text: For six decades the Bard family has managed the Hotel Chelsea, overseeing a bohemian enclave that has been a long-term home for writers, artists and musicians including Mark Twain, O. Henry, Tennessee Williams, Dylan Thomas, Andy Warhol, and Sid Vicious and Nancy Spungen.

headline: Ex-Enron Executive Sentenced to Prison
text: The former chief of the Internet unit at Enron has been sentenced to 27 months in prison for helping mislead investors in the fraud that sent Enron, the world’s largest energy trader, into bankruptcy.

headline: Italy: Search for Immigrants Whose Vessel Sank
text: The Italian Coast Guard continued its search for bodies after a vessel carrying immigrants sank off the southern Italian island of Lampedusa over the weekend. So far 11 of the 14 bodies they saw have been recovered, according to a Coast Guard spokesman who said the nationality of the victims remained unknown. Lampedusa, south of Sicily, is one of the main destinations of immigrants seeking to enter Europe from across the Mediterranean.

headline: Sweet Spark May Hold Clue to How Things Break
text: The Wint-O-Green Life Saver Effect, long of interest to children and adults chewing the candies in pitch-black closets to see the blue-white sparks shooting out of their mouths, could provide scientists a way to better understand how things break. At the atomic level, that is.

headline: A Yankee Needs an Ambulance, to Help His Home Country
text: When Robinson Canó, second baseman for the New York Yankees, went comparison shopping for a new vehicle recently, he wound up at a Bronx hospital.

headline: As More Toys Are Recalled, Trail Ends in China
text: WASHINGTON, June 18 — China manufactured every one of the 24 kinds of toys recalled for safety reasons in the United States so far this year, including the enormously popular Thomas & Friends wooden train sets, a record that is causing alarm among consumer advocates, parents and regulators.

headline: For Twins’ Santana, Pitching’s Fine Line Leads Straight to .500
text: MINNEAPOLIS, June 15  The 2-2 fastball from Johan Santana in the sixth inning Thursday night crossed the plate low, not by much, but enough for Atlanta’s Matt Diaz to take it for ball three. Santana’s next pitch, a slider, did not break down and away enough, and the right-handed-hitting Diaz flicked a ground ball inside the first-base line for a two-out double that drove in a run.

headline: Utah: Bear Kills Boy on Family Camping Trip
text: A black bear pulled an 11-year-old boy from his family’s tent and killed him in a remote wilderness area near Timpanogos Cave National Monument. The attack on Sunday night was the first fatal mauling by a black bear in Utah history, researchers and federal officials said. The boy’s mother, stepfather and 6-year-old brother were sleeping when the bear ripped a hole in the tent and carried off the boy, who was still in his sleeping bag. Utah County sheriff’s deputies found the body about 400 yards from the tent. Wildlife officers killed the bear yesterday; an examination of the remains confirmed that it was the killer, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Space Station Passes Test After Repairs to Computers
text: Russian computers on the International Space Station passed a crucial test yesterday and are back in operation following a weeklong glitch that might have led to the station’s evacuation had it not been fixed.

headline: Florida Is Slow to See the Need to Save Water
text: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., June 12 — Even as a drought and unprecedented water restrictions strip many Florida lawns of their lushness, Mark Harding has few takers for the artificial grass he sells from a showroom here. Inquiries are up, he said, but swapping turf for less thirsty alternatives remains hard for Floridians to get their heads around.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A sports article in some copies on Sunday about Boston’s 1-0 victory against San Francisco referred incorrectly to the history of the interleague series between the Red Sox and the Giants. This was their first meeting since June 2004 — not since the World Series in 1912, the year they last played each other at Fenway Park.

headline: New Chairman for Victoria and Albert
text: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain yesterday appointed John Tusa chairman of the Victoria and Albert Museum. Mr. Tusa, who will begin his four-year term on Nov. 1, is the managing director of the Barbican Center in London and was previously the managing director of the BBC World Service. He is the author of two books on the arts and has been the chairman of the advisory committee to the Government Art Collection, a trustee of the National Portrait Gallery and the Design Museum and deputy chairman of the English National Opera. He was knighted in 2003.

headline: Memo Pad
text: GROWING AIR FLEET  As the global economy grows and diversifies, the number of commercial airliners in service is increasing sharply. In its annual forecast, Boeing said that 28,600 new commercial airplanes would be delivered in the next 20 years, when a total of 36,400 airliners would be flying the global skies. “Over the next 20 years, the center of gravity of the world airline fleet will move substantially toward the Asia-Pacific region,” Boeing said in a report issued before the Paris air show this week. More than a third of the aircraft will be delivered to Asia-Pacific airlines, compared with about a quarter for North America. Within 20 years, the domestic market in China alone will increase to more than half the size of the domestic United States market, from its current one-fifth of the United States market, Boeing said. The company has been outpacing its rival Airbus in selling wide-body and other long-haul jets, including the 787, which is scheduled for initial deliveries next year.

headline: Central Islip, N.Y.: Man Charged in Auto Shop Fire
