text: A Selden man has been charged with causing a fire last week that destroyed three cars and damaged a fourth at an auto repair shop on Sunrise Highway, the Suffolk County police said yesterday. The police said the man, Randy Galluzi, 38, was attempting to steal gasoline by using a cordless power drill to cut a hole in the bottom of a vehicle’s gas tank at Sonrise Automotive about 9:20 p.m. last Wednesday. The gas ignited, and although Mr. Galluzi was able to escape without injury, the draining gas spread the fire to other vehicles, the police said. Mr. Galluzi was charged with criminal mischief and petit larceny, the police said. He pleaded not guilty yesterday at his arraignment in First District Court, according to the Suffolk County district attorney’s office.

headline: Unwanted Result of Ballot Confusion: A Beerless Town
text: POTTER, N.Y., June 16 —This sleepy Finger Lakes town, which does not lay claim to any actual lakefront, misses much of the tourism that helps support the picturesque region. Agriculture is the main industry here in this dot of a town of 1,800, where drivers have to yield to roosters that wander onto the road.

headline: Big Part of OxyContin Profit Was Consumed by Penalties
text: The $634.5 million in penalties and fines that the maker of the painkiller OxyContin and some of its executives agreed to pay to resolve a false marketing charge represents 90 percent of the profits it initially made from the drug, according to court documents filed by federal prosecutors.

headline: Taxes a Pleasure? Check the Brain Scan
text: The University of Oregon announced a new piece of research last week with a startling headline: “Paying taxes, according to the brain, can bring satisfaction.”

headline: A Summer for Shooting a New S.L.R.
text: To an ordinary person, the summer might mean barbecues, baseball games and trips to the beach. To a photography nut, however, it means longer days of sunlight, brighter subject colors (beach balls, bathing suits) and more people who don’t have to be told to “Smile!”

headline: Bloomberg Quits G.O.P., Stirring Talk About ’08 Race
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York announced this evening that he was quitting the Republican Party and changing his political affiliation to independent.

headline: Correction
text: A headline and article in Business Day last Tuesday about a decision by TheStreet.com not to award prize money in the first round of its “Beat the Street” competition referred incorrectly to the reason for its action. Although TheStreet.com did say that some players used trading strategies that compromised the integrity of the system, it did not identify any of them or accuse any individual of “cheating” in the contest — including J. McKeown, who was leading the contest.

headline: Owners Push New Arena, but Residents Fear Change
text: NEWARK, June 18 — After all the years of hyperbolic talk, the failed promises and the false starts, the behemoth looming over downtown is a steel and glass affirmation that good things can happen to this star-crossed city.

headline: The Netherlands: Milosevic Aide Faces Trial
text: Vlastimir Djordjevic, an aide to the former Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic, will appear in court in The Hague today to face charges of murder and persecution. Mr. Djordjevic, who was unexpectedly handed over to the war crimes tribunal on Sunday, had been living in Russia. He was arrested in Montenegro, where the police said he had arrived under a false identity. Mr. Djordjevic led Serbia’s security police during the 1999 Kosovo war. Prosecutors say he had a major role in deporting Kosovo Albanians. His arrest leaves four others on the run.

headline: Across the Borders, Across the Years (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: ICI Rejects Bid by Akzo Nobel
text: LONDON, June 18 — Imperial Chemical Industries, Britain’s largest specialty chemical maker, said Monday that it had rejected a takeover bid from Akzo Nobel worth £7.2 billion ($14 billion), terming the offer too low.

headline: Judge Says He Will Suspend Durham Prosecutor
text: The senior judge in Durham, N.C., said last night that he would file orders this morning to immediately suspend from office Michael B. Nifong, the district attorney at the center of the Duke lacrosse case.

headline: Queens: Two Men Killed in Separate Shootings
text: Two men were fatally shot about a mile apart in Jamaica early yesterday, the police said. One man, Charles Williamson, 27, of Williamsburg, Va., was shot in the head at 127-05 176th Street about 12:20 a.m., the police said. A half-hour later, the police said, Germaine Persaud, 21, of Queens, was shot in front of his home at 119-46 192nd Street by a man wearing a red bandana.

headline: Maine Is Back on Track, and So Are the Mets
text: John Maine had certainly been part of the problem of late for the Mets, who entered last night having lost seven of eight games. After a strong start to the season, Maine had won only once since May 9. But last night, he was the solution.

headline: Maine Law Caps Carbon Dioxide Emissions
text: BOSTON, June 18  Gov. John Baldacci of Maine signed a bill on Monday establishing how the state will reduce pollution and cap power plant emissions in a regional effort to reduce carbon dioxide output.

headline: Letters
text: The Visual Side of Science

headline: Randolph Isn’t Concerned With Beltrán’s Leg Woes
text: Manager Willie Randolph continued to play down the seriousness of Carlos Beltrán’s injured left quadriceps before last night’s game against the Minnesota Twins, and he questioned why the leg problem seems to have developed into a major story.

headline: Woods Faces Challenges, Being a Father Among Them
text: OAKMONT, Pa., June 18 — When Tiger Woods tapped in for par Sunday on the final hole at Oakmont Country Club, his work in the 107th United States Open was not finished.

headline: Colin Fletcher, 85, a Trailblazer of Modern Backpacking, Dies
text: Colin Fletcher, whose ornate prose and prosaic tips on subjects like choosing the right hiking boots helped start the modern backpacking movement, died June 12 in Monterey, Calif. He was 85.

headline: Brothers to the Bitter End
text: SO the masked men of Fatah have the run of the West Bank while the masked men of Hamas have their dominion in Gaza. Some see this as a tolerable situation, maybe even an improvement, envisioning a secularist Fatah-run state living peacefully alongside Israel and a small, radical Gaza hemmed in by Israeli troops. It’s always tempting to look for salvation in disaster, but in this case it’s sheer fantasy.

headline: Climate-Change Scorecard Aims to Influence Consumers
text: Coke or Pepsi? McDonald’s or Burger King? Amazon or Yahoo?

headline: Imagining the Day After the Unimaginable (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections
text: A headline and article in Business Day last Tuesday about a decision by TheStreet.com not to award prize money in the first round of its “Beat the Street” competition referred incorrectly to the reason for its action. Although TheStreet.com did say that some players used trading strategies that compromised the integrity of the system, it did not identify any of them or accuse any individual of “cheating” in the contest — including J. McKeown, who was leading the contest. (Go to Article)

headline: Mortgages Give Wall St. New Worries
text: After the first cracks in the subprime mortgage business appeared late last year, several large lenders were forced into bankruptcy.

headline: Trying to Capture a Trick of Light, a Tug of Memory
text: NORTH ADAMS, Mass. — Without light, we couldn’t see the world. If there were no sun, the world would be in constant darkness, and, despite our eyes, everything would be invisible. This obvious point is a crucial one for artists, scientists and philosophers exploring the limits of visual perception.

headline: United Nations to Help Lebanon Investigation
text: The Security Council approved a request from Lebanon’s prime minister to have the United Nations commission investigating the 2005 assassination of the former Lebanese prime minister, Rafik Hariri, help investigate last week’s killing of a legislator, Walid Eido. Mr. Eido died in an attack similar to the one that had killed Mr. Hariri, when a vehicle parked along the same road in Beirut blew up as his car passed. Like Mr. Hariri, Mr. Eido was opposed to past Syrian domination of Lebanon’s politics. Preliminary findings of the commission have implicated Syrian intelligence services in Mr. Hariri’s murder.

headline: The City’s New Motto: ‘See You in Court’
text: Manufacturing is all but gone from New York. The information technology industry, while on a roll, does not quite have the Silicon Alley ’90s buzz. This city is in danger of falling behind London as a financial capital.

headline: For the Angler, a Flash of Color Among the Freighters
text: PANAMA  There are several ways to experience the Panama Canal.

headline: Second Stage’s New Season
text: The New York premiere of Edward Albee’s “Peter and Jerry” and the world premiere of “Farragut North,” a dark political comedy by Beau Willimon, are among the offerings in Second Stage Theater’s 2007-8 season, the company is to announce today. The season is scheduled to begin on Oct. 19 with Mr. Albee’s play, which is two of his one-acts combined: his 1958 “Zoo Story” and a more recent prequel, “Homelife.” Pam MacKinnon, who directed the world premiere at Hartford Stage in 2004, will direct a cast featuring Bill Pullman, Johanna Day and Dallas Roberts. Next up will be “Next to Normal,” a new musical with book and lyrics by Brian Yorkey and music by Tom Kitt (“High Fidelity”). Michael Greif (“Grey Gardens”) is slated to direct. Mr. Willimon’s play, third on the schedule, will be followed by a revival of Richard Nelson’s 1990 comedy, “Some Americans Abroad,” to be directed by Gordon Edelstein. Second Stage is busy between now and the start of the new season, its 29th, though. Sarah Ruhl’s “Eurydice” is running through July 21, and the annual Second Stage Theater Uptown series is presenting Marisa Wegrzyn’s “Butcher of Baraboo” through June 30, to be followed by “Election Day,” a comedy by Josh Tobiessen, directed by Jeremy Dobrish, which will run from July 16 through Aug. 18. The Uptown series is presented at the McGinn/Cazale Theater on Broadway at 76th Street.

headline: Conservancy Buys Large Area of Adirondack Wilderness
text: The last big piece of privately owned timberland in the Adirondacks — a craggy 161,000-acre wilderness of hardwood forests, 80 mountain peaks, 70 crystal-clear lakes and ponds, undammed rivers, white water gorges and secluded bogs — has been sold for $110 million to the Nature Conservancy, in a move intended to protect the land from future development.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Now You See ‘Sicko,’ Now You Don’t

headline: Loving Arizona, Even When It Sizzles (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lola Wasserstein, Playwright’s Mother, Dies at 89
text: Lola S. Wasserstein, whose larger-than-life personality provided inspiration for sprightly maternal characters in the plays of her daughter Wendy, died Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 89.

headline: Rags to Riches Will Probably Not Race Colts Again This Year
text: Although no firm plans have been made for the Belmont Stakes winner Rags to Riches beyond her next scheduled start, it appears she may not face colts in the Travers Stakes or at any time this year.

headline: Report Faults Oversight by Smithsonian Regents
text: WASHINGTON, June 18 — In a high-profile mea culpa the Smithsonian Institution issued a report on Monday saying that its Board of Regents had failed to provide the oversight that might have prevented extravagant spending by its former chief executive, Lawrence M. Small, who resigned in March, and other missteps by the organization.

headline: Saving Young Skin From the Sun’s Perils
text: Dr. Michael L. Ramsey, a dermatologist at the Geisinger Medical Center in Danville, Pa., coaches his son’s Little League team these summery days when he’s not removing patients’ skin cancers.

headline: Millions of Missing Birds, Vanishing in Plain Sight
text: Last week, the Audubon Society released a new report describing the sharp and startling population decline of some of the most familiar and common birds in America: several kinds of sparrows, the Northern bobwhite, the Eastern meadowlark, the common grackle and the common tern. The average decline of the 20 species in the Audubon Society’s report is 68 percent.

headline: 9 Firefighters Are Killed in South Carolina Blaze
text: CHARLESTON, S.C., June 19 — Nine firefighters were killed when a blazing furniture-store building collapsed on them Monday night. It was the worst loss of life for American firefighters since the terror attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Senate Republicans Propose Changes to Congestion Plan
text: ALBANY, June 18 — Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s “congestion pricing” proposal received mixed political signals on Monday and appeared unlikely to be resolved in the last week of the legislative session.

headline: With Rise in Radiation Exposure, Experts Urge Caution on Tests
text: Advances in radiology have radically transformed medical practice, with CT scans and nuclear medicine exams providing physicians with the ability to quickly pinpoint internal bleeding, diagnose kidney stones or confirm appendicitis, assess thyroid function and identify and open blockages in the blood vessels to the heart.

headline: Obama Apologizes for Memo
text: Senator Barack Obama said his campaign “made a mistake” last week when it distributed a document criticizing the support Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has received from Indian-Americans and companies that do business in India. “The memo’s caustic tone and its focus on contributions by Indian-Americans to the Clinton campaign was potentially hurtful, and as such, unacceptable,” Mr. Obama said in a letter to Indian-Americans. The document, which referred to Mrs. Clinton as D-Punjab, caused a furor among Indian-American groups. Mr. Obama said he did not know about the memo, but added, “I consider the entire campaign, and in particular myself, responsible for the mistake.”

headline: Airbus Seeks a Welcome in Alabama
text: PARIS, June 18 — Louis Gallois, the co-chief executive of EADS, the parent company of Airbus, could have his pick of invitations among dozens of parties during the Paris air show, the giant industry gathering this week.

headline: Ending a Climb, Shares Slip Amid Concern on Housing
text: Most stocks fell yesterday for the first time in four days after confidence in the home building industry dropped to a 16-year low, renewing concern that the housing slump was not over.

headline: Crunch Time on Energy
text: The Senate will tell us this week whether it really wants to do something about oil dependency and global warming or if it is just fooling around.

headline: French Socialists’ First Couple Disclose a Parting of Ways
text: PARIS, June 18 — A day after President Nicolas Sarkozy’s conservative party captured a smaller majority in Parliament than expected, France’s Socialist Party was struggling to adjust to the awkward reality that its first couple — Ségolène Royal and François Hollande — had split up.

headline: Trial Starts for Former Chief in Options-Backdating Case
text: Prosecutors pursuing executives for backdating stock options began the first courtroom test of their crackdown as the former chief executive of Brocade Communications went on trial in federal court in San Francisco.

headline: When Dollars Trump Compassion
text: You won’t see these stories on television, but Marian Wright Edelman and Dr. Irwin Redlener could talk to you all day and all night about children whose lives have been lost or ruined because they didn’t have health insurance.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article last Tuesday about a vote by the New Jersey General Assembly to allow voters to decide whether all proceeds from a 1-cent tax increase approved last year should go to property tax relief for local governments referred incorrectly at one point to the type of tax that was increased. As noted elsewhere in the article, it was the sales tax, not the property tax.

headline: Monets Fetch Millions
text: Monet’s 1904 painting “Waterloo Bridge, Temps Couvert,” sold last night for $31.7 million, before commission, at Christie’s International in London, Bloomberg News reported. The price was twice the estimate, but another Monet, “Les Arceaux des Roses, Giverny,” painted in 1913, fetched only $15.9 million, short of the $17.8 million estimate. “Waterloo Bride,” once owned by the filmmaker Alexander Korda, was bought by a telephone bidder; “Roses,” from a New York collection, went to an unidentified buyer in the auction room. The Monet auction record is $39.2 million, including commission. The sale ushered in a week of London auctions.

headline: States Face Decisions on Who Is Mentally Fit to Vote
Antibiotic Use in First Year May Increase Asthma Risk
text: The use of antibiotics in the first year of life is associated with an increased risk for asthma at age 7, a new study has found, and the reason may be that antibiotics destroy not only disease-causing microbes, but also those that are helpful to the developing immune system.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about the unearthing of a 1957 Plymouth Belvedere and a time capsule, which had been buried in Tulsa., Okla, to commemorate 50 years of statehood, misidentified one of the items in the capsule. It was a 48-star flag, not a 46-star flag.

headline: Handel Instead of Tchaikovsky With the Rockets’ Red Glare
text: Mimi has died, poor thing; cue the fireworks. Though a staple at Central Park concerts by the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic, fireworks often sit oddly on a program. How often can the Met offer the exultant “Fidelio,” after all, and how often does it offer the star-crossed “Bohème”? And how often can the Philharmonic present Tchaikovsky’s “1812”?

headline: Lottery Numbers
Footnote
text: The Broadway revival of Eric Bogosian’s “Talk Radio,” starring Liev Schreiber, will close Sunday after 150 performances at the Longacre Theater.

headline: New Focus on a Forlorn Cleveland Tower
text: CLEVELAND, June 17 — Marcel Breuer, one of the fathers of modern architecture, built only one skyscraper, the 29-story Cleveland Trust Tower, which today stands abandoned on a forlorn block downtown.

headline: Glossy Insert at Gannett, and Maybe Dow Jones
text: The Gannett Company plans to introduce a glossy magazine insert for USA Today later this year, and Dow Jones & Company is contemplating a similar move for The Wall Street Journal, as both companies seek to capture more of the high-end consumer advertising market.

headline: Semel Steps Aside as Yahoo Chief
text: In the face of increasing unrest among investors, Yahoo’s chief executive, Terry S. Semel, said today that he was stepping down to assume a non-executive advisory role with the company. He will be replaced by Jerry Yang, a Yahoo co-founder.

headline: For California Wines, Nothing Succeeds Like ‘Secession’
text: Decades ago, articles about how California was growing to become the biggest state in the union would invariably offer context by explaining how the state would rank globally if it were an independent country.

headline: Sifting the Garbage for a Green Polymer
text: Carbon dioxide. Orange peels. Chicken feathers. Olive oil. Potato peels. E. coli bacteria. It is as if chemists have gone Dumpster diving in their hunt to make biodegradable, sustainable and renewable plastics. Most bioplastics are made from plants like corn, soy, sugar cane and switch grass, but scientists have recently turned to trash in an effort to make so-called green polymers, essentially plastics from garbage.

headline: Is Boycotting Israelis an Anti-Semitic Act? (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Leader of the L.I.R.R. Looks North for Inspiration
text: For years, the Long Island Rail Road has had to suffer the indignity of being compared unfavorably, and perhaps not always fairly, with its sister railroad, Metro-North, which routinely scores better on performance measures like customer satisfaction and the ability to make trains run on time.

headline: Police May Face an Alcohol Test After Shootings
text: The New York City Police Department is moving to require officers to take breath tests for alcohol if they shoot someone and to undergo a psychological screening when they become candidates for undercover work, Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced yesterday. Both measures are among the recommendations of a panel created after a Queens man was fatally shot in November in a volley of 50 bullets fired by officers.

headline: Moore’s ‘Sicko’ Will Be Released Ahead of Schedule
text: LOS ANGELES, June 19 — Hyped in Cuba, unveiled in Cannes, pirated on YouTube, and rallied around last week in Sacramento, Calif., by nurses chanting for the health insurance system’s demise, Michael Moore’s documentary “Sicko” is finally ready to meet its American audience — or at least some of it — a week ahead of schedule.

headline: RC2’s Train Wreck
text: In the toy business, RC2 was the little company that could.

headline: A Literary Dynasty, Warts and All
text: In a letter to his 6-year-old son, which closes this volume, Alexander Waugh — son of the satirist Auberon Waugh and grandson of the novelist Evelyn Waugh — dispenses some advice: “Beware of seriousness: it is a form of stupidity,” “Fear boredom,” “Never use the word ‘ersatz,’ ” and “Bear the name of Waugh with pride.” The Waugh name, he goes on, “is not a satchel of rocks, or a blotchy birthmark, or a tuxedo with medals for you to swank about in”: “Do not let it browbeat you into thinking you have to become a writer, that it is your destiny or your duty to do so. It isn’t. There is no point in writing unless you have something to say and are determined to say it well.”

headline: At 90, an Environmentalist From the ’70s Still Has Hope
text: Before Al Gore became synonymous with global warming, Barry Commoner was warning the public about the delicate condition of planet Earth. Long associated with the Center for the Biology of Natural Systems at Queens College, Dr. Commoner has for decades been agitating to restore ecological balance to the biosphere, whether by outlawing nuclear testing or spreading the practice of recycling. Time magazine once nicknamed him “the Paul Revere of the environmental movement.”

headline: Bob Barker Gives CBS a Good Goodbye
text: After five decades on network television, Bob Barker appeared on CBS’s “Price is Right” Friday for the last time, ending 35 years as host of America’s longest-running game show. Nielsen estimated 8.7 million viewers tuned in at 8 p.m. to watch the prime-time encore of the farewell show, which CBS televised earlier Friday in its usual daytime slot. Following the sendoff, CBS broadcast the “34th Annual Daytime Emmy Awards,” during which Mr. Barker was honored with his 19th trophy. The awards show drew 8.3 million viewers from 9 to 11, putting the network in first place for the night. CBS was also No. 1 on Sunday, getting a boost from back-to-back repeats of “Cold Case” at 8 (7.2 million) and at 9 (9 million) followed by “Without a Trace” at 10 (8.6 million). But NBC finished on top for the night among adults 18 to 49, benefiting from a 45-minute overrun of its U.S. Open golf coverage in the 7 p.m. hour. From 9 to 11 a repeat of NBC’s “Last Comic Standing” led the time period in the demographic, while attracting only 4.9 million viewers.

headline: Travels With Charlie, From Kansas to the Moon
text: Kenneth Branagh, who is Irish, was sensational as one of the last century’s most famous Americans, Franklin Delano Roosevelt, in the 2005 HBO film “Warm Springs.” Jonathan Rhys Meyers, who is Irish, was pretty good as another, Elvis Presley, in a CBS movie that same year. But foreigners who dare trifle with America’s cultural reference points had better make sure that they leave every iota of the accent at home and that they are doing more than just recycling stock imagery.

headline: Albany: Nomination for M.T.A. Chairman
text: A real estate executive was nominated yesterday by Gov. Eliot Spitzer to become the next chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the governor’s office announced. The nominee, H. Dale Hemmerdinger, is a former chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission and president of the Hemmerdinger Corporation, a real estate development company, the governor’s office said. Mr. Hemmerdinger is also president of Atco Properties and Management, a member of the board of Valley National Bank and a trustee of New York University. If confirmed by the State Senate, he will succeed Peter S. Kalikow, a Pataki administration appointee who said recently that it was time for him to move on.

headline: The Stories of Refugees, Wrapped in Stereotypes
text: In its more unfortunate passages, “Rain in a Dry Land,” Anne Makepeace’s film about two Somali refugee families being relocated to the United States, reinforces unpleasant stereotypes that some people still harbor about Africa: that everybody over there is so illiterate and backward that airplanes and staircases and telephones baffle them.

headline: Correction
text: An article in The Magazine on Sunday about Dr. Ronald McIver, who is imprisoned for drug trafficking, gave an erroneous account of the trial testimony of one of his patients, Leslie Smith. And a correction in this space on Sunday again referred incorrectly to that testimony. The only point Mr. Smith made in his testimony was that he acknowledged injecting drugs prescribed by Dr. McIver. Mr. Smith never raised the issue of whether he himself sold any drugs that were left over to buy other drugs. And he never referred to Dr. McIver in the context of the leftover drugs — either that Dr. McIver sold them or did not sell them.

headline: Desperation Rises at Closed Border Crossings Between Gaza Strip and Israel
text: JERUSALEM, June 18  A Palestinian man was killed Monday at the volatile and closed border between Israel and Gaza after Palestinian gunmen opened fire on Israeli soldiers, officials said. The attack took place near the area where several hundred people trying to flee Gaza had been camped out and Israeli troops fired back.

headline: Patterns: Aspirin Linked to Lower Risk of Cancer and Heart Disease
text: Regular aspirin use may significantly reduce the incidence of both cancer and heart disease, according to a large new study, but other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, or Nsaids, have no effect.

headline: Arrington Injured in a Motorcycle Accident
text: The former Giants and Washington Redskins linebacker LaVar Arrington was hospitalized yesterday with multiple injuries after crashing his motorcycle. His agent, Carl Poston, said Arrington sustained a broken arm, at least one broken rib and a leg contusion.

headline: I.B.M. to Show Stream Computing System
text: I.B.M. is introducing a high-performance computer system that is intended to rapidly analyze data as it streams in from many sources, increasing the speed and accuracy of decision making in fields as diverse as security surveillance and Wall Street trading.

headline: New Jersey Court Says Showing of Mental Retardation Can Block Execution
text: TRENTON, June 18  In another setback for the death penalty in New Jersey, the State Supreme Court established ground rules yesterday for how a defendant, after being convicted of a capital crime, could show mental retardation and secure a sentence of life imprisonment.

headline: Savion Glover’s Objections to Festivals Reflect a Schism in the Tap World
text: In three weeks many of the biggest names in tap will converge on New York City as Tony Waag’s American Tap Dance Foundation presents its annual Tap City festival at the Duke on 42nd Street. But the biggest name in tap today won’t be found at any of its jams or samplers.

headline: Endangered After-School Programs
text: It was just a few years ago that New York got serious about expanding high quality after-school programs that complement classroom learning with academic, arts, sports and other meaningful activities. Participation has risen steadily, and the programs have gotten high marks. Many school officials see a link between these after-school activities and improvements in test scores and attendance, reduced dropout rates and college enrollment.

headline: A Tough Act I, but the Second Has Some Funny Bits
text: KIM CHAN, like many character actors, has a face that is more familiar than his name. His high cheekbones, the mischief in his eyes and his knack for both serious and comedic performances seemed to be what Hollywood always looked for when casting roles for Asians.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on May 2 about the expansion of Latin American companies into the United States misstated the relationship of one such company, Grupo Bimbo, with Wonder Bread. Grupo Bimbo makes and distributes Wonder Bread only in Mexico, where it has acquired the rights from Wonder Bread’s parent, the Interstate Brands Corporation. Grupo Bimbo does not own Wonder Bread. The error was pointed out by Grupo Bimbo shortly after the article appeared. This correction was delayed while another question about the article was researched.

headline: Google and Utility to Test Hybrids That Sell Back Power
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., June 18 — Google and Pacific Gas & Electric have unveiled their vision of a future in which cars and trucks are partly powered by the country’s electric grids, and vice versa.

headline: Cockroaches Conditioned to Salivate at a Scent, Not Pavlov’s Dinner Bell
text: More than a century ago, Ivan Pavlov first demonstrated classical conditioning in dogs. The animals learned to associate food with a stimulus — the sound of a bell — such that they would salivate upon hearing the sound even when no food was present.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,515 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Power Foods
text: Q. Is eating fortified foods (for example, orange juice enriched with calcium and vitamin D or flour with folic acid) any better than just taking the nutrients in pill form?

headline: U.S. Unfreezes Millions in Aid to Palestinians
text: WASHINGTON, June 18 — The United States on Monday ended an economic and political embargo of the Palestinian Authority in a bid to bolster President Mahmoud Abbas and the new Fatah-led emergency government he has established in the West Bank as a counterweight to Hamas-controlled Gaza.

headline: Amateur Video Is Latest in Bryant Drama
text: Kobe Bryant has not appeared on radio or television in three weeks. He is not even in the United States. But in the lull between a less-than-compelling N.B.A. finals and an intriguing draft, Bryant is again commandeering headlines, and the league’s attention, without saying a word.

headline: Pennsylvania: Deportation Stay Is Extended
text: A federal judge has granted an indefinite stay of deportation to Sameh Khouzam, an Egyptian Coptic Christian who faces repatriation for a murder charge in Egypt. Mr. Khouzam, 38, of Lancaster, had received a stay of deportation until June 18. Now, the stay has been extended until his case is concluded, court documents show. Mr. Khouzam fled to the United States nine years ago, claiming he had been detained and tortured because he refused to convert to Islam. He denies the murder accusation. After being freed from detention in 2006, Mr. Khouzam was detained again May 29, after the Egyptian government provided diplomatic assurances that he would not be tortured.

headline: Scholars Race to Recover a Lost Kingdom on the Nile
text: On the periphery of history in antiquity, there was a land known as Kush. Overshadowed by Egypt, to the north, it was a place of uncharted breadth and depth far up the Nile, a mystery verging on myth. One thing the Egyptians did know and recorded — Kush had gold.

headline: Ringo Starr Goes Digital
text: Ringo Starr is going online. Beginning on Aug. 28 his EMI Music albums, including “Sentimental Journey” (1970), “Beaucoups of Blues” (1970), “Ringo” (1973) and “Goodnight Vienna” (1974) will be available for downloading, along with six Ringo Starr ring tones and “Photograph: The Very Best of Ringo Starr,” a career- and label-spanning 20-track collection of his solo recordings. “Photograph” will be available in CD and CD/DVD form, as well as digitally. The CD/DVD collector’s edition includes seven previously unreleased film and video clips.

headline: Chinese Singer Wins BBC Prize
text: A 23-year-old bass-baritone from the Shanghai Conservatory of Music has won the BBC Cardiff Singer of the World competition, the BBC reported. Triumphing over four finalists remaining from the 25 singers chosen to audition, the winner, Shen Yang, was the youngest competitor in the weeklong contest, which once helped to start the international career of the bass-baritone Bryn Terfel. Mr. Shen received a trophy from Joan Sutherland, the patron of the competition, and $30,000 in prize money and engagements with the BBC and the Welsh National Opera. Afterward Mr. Shen said, “I think the competition is not only a competition; it’s a big singing party in the world.”

headline: Schools Plan to Pay Cash for Marks
text: New York City students could earn as much as $500 a year for doing well on standardized tests and showing up for class in a new program to begin this fall, city officials announced yesterday. And the Harvard economist who created the program is joining the inner circle of Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein, according to an official briefed on the hiring.

headline: Some Lenders Are Setting Rates College by College
text: Andrew M. Cuomo, attorney general of New York, said yesterday in a letter to Congress that his investigation of the student loan business had found “a significant number of lenders” that determine eligibility for private loans and set interest rates based in large part on the colleges the students attend rather than the borrowers’ credit-worthiness.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Saturday about the planned national tour of the musical “Spring Awakening” misidentified the director. The production will be directed by Michael Mayer, who won a Tony this month for his direction of the musical, not by Carole Shorenstein Hays. (Ms. Hays is president of SHN, which is bringing “Spring Awakening” to the Curran Theater in San Francisco in the fall of 2008.)

headline: A New Global Blueprint
text: A few weeks ago, the Miller Center of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia brought together some big thinkers to discuss the future of American foreign policy, and guess what? They couldn’t agree.

headline: Finding Passion at Work
text: THIS week I’m introducing The Coaches Roundtable, in which a rotating panel of career coaches and advisers will answer reader questions. Career advice is a funny thing. Because advisers can give contrary advice, it can be helpful to collect ideas, try a few and see which ones work for you. At times, just the language can make the difference. My first coach told me that I shouldn’t expect to have a single-track career, and I finally felt free to figure out my new direction liberated from the idea of a traditional job.

headline: Question Time for Nominee Linked to Interrogations
text: WASHINGTON, June 18  In the months after the Sept. 11 attacks, at a time when the Central Intelligence Agency had long been out of the interrogation business, senior C.I.A. officers scrambled to build a program to question terror suspects in secret jails abroad.

headline: 7 Children Killed in Airstrike in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 18  Seven children were killed during an airstrike by the United States-led coalition against a religious compound thought to be a Qaeda sanctuary in remote eastern Afghanistan, the coalition said Monday.

headline: Motion Picture Academy Seeks Fresh Faces
text: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences opened its rolls slightly yesterday, extending invitations to 115 prospective members. The additions would bring the film academy’s voting membership to just under 6,000, and fell short of the maximum of 150 new members authorized by academy rules for the year. Among actors 16 invitees include Jennifer Aniston, Steve Carell, Daniel Craig and Christopher Plummer. Six directors invited to join included Peter Berg, Antoine Fuqua and Paul Greengrass.

headline: A Passion for Soccer and the Environment
text: BOULDER, Colo.  In marketing terms, last year’s slogan was a bit of a clunker. “Boulder County’s Most Competitive Soccer Team,” as advertised on a side of the van that shuttles the Colorado Rapids under-23 players to practice, might have been accurate. But it failed to attract more than a couple of hundred fans to any of the team’s home games.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Christina Albee joined CondéNet, New York, as associate publisher at Style.com and Men.style.com. She succeeds Jeff Lundwall, who left, the company said, to start a recruiting firm specializing in advertising sales positions. Ms. Albee had most recently been New York advertising director at InStyle and associate publisher at InStyle Weddings, both part of the Time Inc. unit of Time Warner. CondéNet is part of the Condé Nast Publications division of Advance Publications.

headline: Thommie Walsh, Dancer and Tony Winner, Dies at 57
text: Thommie Walsh, a Tony-winning choreographer who also created the role of Bobby in the original production of “A Chorus Line,” died Saturday at his mother’s home in Auburn, N.Y. He was 57.

headline: Bush Embraces Abbas at Meeting With Olmert
text: WASHINGTON, June 19 — President Bush threw his weight behind President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority today, using an Oval Office meeting with Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel to declare Mr. Abbas “the president of all the Palestinians” and praise him as “a reasonable voice among the extremists” in the Middle East.

headline: Zimbabwe Opens First Talks With Opposition
text: JOHANNESBURG, June 18  Members of Zimbabwe’s government and its political opposition met in Pretoria over the weekend for their first face-to-face talks since South Africa was asked in March to mediate between them.

headline: Despite Bush’s Promises, Georgians Remain Skeptical About Immigration Bill
text: MARIETTA, Ga., June 18 — If President Bush thought he could win support for a comprehensive immigration bill by promising to secure the border and step up law enforcement, he would be dismayed by the reaction here.

headline: U.S. Says North Korea May Begin Shutting Reactor in Weeks
text: BEIJING, June 18  North Korea could be ready to begin shutting down its plutonium-producing reactor within weeks as the first step toward disabling it by the end of this year, the top United States negotiator on North Korea’s nuclear weapons program said here on Monday.

headline: Sperm Donors (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Test Driving an Air Taxi: Quiet, Quick but Not Cheap
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — I don’t know if the air taxi model will work. But I do know that it flies.

headline: Judge Dissolves Civil Union in Custody Fight
text: A family court judge in Vermont on Friday dissolved a civil union between two women whose fight over their daughter had attracted national attention and for a time put a judge in Virginia at odds with one in Vermont over whether a child can have two mothers.

headline: Outcomes: Hospital Work-Hour Rules Seen as Better for Patients
text: Rules limiting the number of hours hospital interns and residents can work were intended to improve patient care, but there were fears that signing cases over to a new team at a specified time would be harmful. Those fears have not been realized, according to a new study, and the work-hour rules have resulted in better care for patients.

headline: At Risk: Hostile Outlook May Affect Breathing, Research Shows
text: Having a hostile attitude may affect your breathing, a new study reports.

headline: ‘The Kingdom’ Gambles That Entertainment Can Trump Politics
text: LOS ANGELES, June 18 — “The Kingdom,” a coming film about the F.B.I.’s pursuit of Islamic bad guys in a not particularly hospitable Saudi Arabia, appears on the surface to tread on treacherous and polarized political ground. But after a test screening before a deliberately diversified audience in the London borough of Wandsworth earlier this year, the director Peter Berg began to suspect that his terror thriller might survive its birth into a contentious world, after all.

headline: Closing Arguments Begin in Black Trial
text: CHICAGO, June 18 — With a few strokes of his pen, Conrad M. Black “systematically stole” $60 million from the company he ran and controlled, a federal prosecutor said Monday in her closing argument against the former press tycoon and three associates.

headline: A Co-op on Sutton Place Sues to Keep Its Backyard
text: The owners of an exclusive co-op on Sutton Place South have taken to the barricades, or at least to State Supreme Court in Manhattan, in an attempt to block the city from seizing a swath of their emerald green backyard for a public park.

headline: Kidnapping Trial of C.I.A. Agents Is Suspended by Judge in Italy
text: MILAN, June 18 — An Italian judge on Monday suspended the kidnapping trial of 25 Central Intelligence Agency operatives, a United States military officer and some of Italy’s former top spies, to await a ruling on whether prosecutors overstepped their bounds and violated state secrecy laws as they gathered evidence.

headline: New DVDs
text: THE 36TH CHAMBER OF SHAOLIN

headline: Passengers Granted Same Right as Drivers
text: WASHINGTON, June 18 — The Supreme Court on Monday extended to automobile passengers the same right that drivers have: the right to challenge the validity of a decision by the police to stop the car.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about comments by Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates that the United States would not alter its plans to deploy a missile defense system in Poland and the Czech Republic, despite a proposal by Russia that the United States instead use a radar base in Azerbaijan, referred incorrectly to the former status of Poland and the Czech Republic. They were Soviet satellite states, not Soviet states.

headline: Bridging Gaps Between Hospital and Home
text: Almost as soon as patients are admitted to 9 Silver, a general medicine floor at Beth Israel Medical Center in downtown Manhattan, Alicia Tennenbaum starts planning how to get them to leave.

headline: Justices Back Underwriters on New Issues
text: WASHINGTON, June 18 — The securities industry dodged a bullet on Monday when the Supreme Court threw out a private antitrust suit that accused 10 leading investment banks of conspiring to fix prices for the initial public offerings of hundreds of technology companies during the 1990s.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (TCM) ON DANGEROUS GROUND Ida Lupino, born into an Italian theater family, acted in films steadily from the age of 13 and in the 1950s was one of the few female directors working in Hollywood. Turner Classic Movies is paying tribute to this actress, director, writer and producer throughout June; tonight a series of her performances will be showcased, starting with this 1952 drama about a police detective (Robert Ryan) who helps a blind girl (Ms. Lupino, above with Mr. Ryan) whose brother has been murdered. Next, at 9:30 p.m., is “While the City Sleeps” (1956); at 11:15 p.m. Ms. Lupino plays a widow terrorized by a deranged handyman in “Beware, My Lovely” (1952); and at 12:45 a.m. comes “Ladies in Retirement” (1941), an understated thriller about women living on the moors.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Paris Air Show misstated Boeing’s manufacturing schedule for its 787. The plane will be rolled out at Boeing’s plant in Everett, Wash., on July 8; that is not the date for the inaugural flight.

headline: Military Strikes Insurgents’ Base East of Baghdad
text: BAQUBA, Iraq, Tuesday, June 19 — The American military began a major attack against Sunni insurgent positions here in the capital of Diyala Province overnight, part of a larger operation aimed at blunting the persistent car and suicide bombings that have terrorized Iraqis and thwarted political reconciliation.

headline: A Beethoven Who’s Happy but Fed Up With Niceties
text: The Emerson String Quartet ended its long and busy residency at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night fittingly, with Beethoven’s farewell to the medium but also with a new piece by Kaija Saariaho. In the last three weeks the Emerson has coached and presented young ensembles and itself gone through the Beethoven repertory onstage, adding other composers to its programs here and there.

headline: Awareness: Enforcement of Hygiene Inconsistent at Petting Zoos
text: Along with lambs, ducks and rabbits, petting zoos may also feature E. coli, salmonella and other disease-causing microorganisms. But according to a new study, few zoos consistently enforce hygienic practices that would keep these germs from spreading to humans.

headline: Thai Junta Orders Return of Ex-Prime Minister
text: BANGKOK, June 19 — Ramping up their campaign against the man they ousted from power, the military government in Thailand today ordered the former prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, to return to the country by the end of the month or face arrest on charges of concealing financial assets.

headline: Running Guns to Gaza: A Living in the Desert
text: RAFAH, Egypt, June 17 — The Hamas military takeover of Gaza last week was partly fueled by caches of weapons smuggled through tunnels below this gritty Sinai border town. Two days spent with smugglers here suggest that to stanch the flow of weapons, Egypt will have to address the economic and social concerns of the region, and not rely solely on its security forces.

headline: Liberating Effects of Captive Conversation
text: I’ve been in the business of designing broadcast and recording studios for about 30 years, and since the beginning I’ve been traveling at least once a week. I’ve learned that the captive conversation between me and my seatmate can have some unexpected business or personal consequences that are downright karmic.

headline: The Power of Memory to Triumph Over Death
text: The most famous unheeded advice in the history of Western literature may be the admonition given by the ruler of the underworld to Orpheus, when that grieving youth went down to retrieve his wife, Eurydice, from the depths, and the lovers began their journey back upward.

headline: Finish Line to Buy Genesco for $1.5 Billion
text: Genesco, the company behind footwear names like the teenager-focused Journeys chain of stores and the Johnston & Murphy brand of shoes, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell itself to a smaller retailer, Finish Line, for $1.5 billion.

headline: On the Horizon, Personalized Depression Drugs
text: Imagine that you are depressed and see a psychiatrist who explains that you have clinical depression and would benefit from an antidepressant. So far, so good. But then the doctor tells you there is a 60 percent chance that you’ll feel better with this antidepressant and that it could take as long as four to six weeks to find out, during which time you’ll probably have some side effects from the drug.

headline: Antitrust Complaints Prompt Changes to Vista
text: WASHINGTON, June 19 — Microsoft has agreed to make changes to its Windows Vista operating system in response to a complaint by Google that a feature of Vista is anticompetitive, lawyers involved in the case said today.

headline: Atlantis Disconnects From Space Station
text: The space shuttle Atlantis disconnected from the International Space Station this morning as the two spacecraft passed over New Guinea, a quiet end to a busy, tumultuous 10-day visit.

headline: The Claim:  Hydrogen Peroxide Is a Good Treatment for Small Wounds
text: THE FACTS

headline: A Staple of the News Media, but Is Rodriguez a YES Man?
text: Except for a plaque or a retired number in Monument Park at Yankee Stadium, there appears to be no greater confirmation of greatness for a past or present Yankee than to be the subject of a “Yankeeography” on the YES Network.

headline: A Veteran Umpire Isn’t Ready to Toss Himself
text: Headlines in some newspapers last Friday said: “Veteran umpire calling it quits,” “Froemming to retire at end of season” or “Froemming announces he’ll retire at end of season.” The daily agate transactions said, “Major League Baseball  announced that umpire Bruce Froemming will retire at end of season.”

headline: U.S. Is ‘Really in Trouble,’ Says Bloomberg, Sounding Like a Candidate
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., June 18 — Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, sounding every inch the presidential candidate he insists he is not, brought his message of pragmatic, nonpartisan leadership to California on Monday, telling a crowd of Google employees that the nation was “really in trouble.”

headline: A Militant Fights From a Basement on Emergency Street
text: AIN AL HILWE REFUGEE CAMP, Lebanon — On a recent afternoon, with the smoke still rising from buildings burned in fierce fighting here between Islamist militants and the Lebanese Army, a man calling himself Abu Omar gave a tour of his squalid neighborhood.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A music review in Weekend on Friday about Paul McCartney, at the Highline Ballroom in Manhattan, misidentified the instrument he played when he sang “Here Today.” It was an acoustic guitar, not a piano.

headline: Getting Law Firms to Like Commercials
text: TELEVISION advertising has long been frowned on in the legal profession, as it can conjure images of ambulance-chasing personal injury lawyers and, in some cases, can run afoul of state laws. But a new partnership between a prominent legal directory and an Internet-based advertising agency is trying to overcome these negatives.

headline: Truck Bombing Kills Scores at Shiite Mosque in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD, June 19 — A suicide bomber barreled a truck filled with cooking gas and explosives into a square bordered by a large Shiite mosque in the heart of Baghdad on Tuesday, just as worshipers were finishing midday prayers. The Interior Ministry said at least 61 people were killed and 130 wounded.

headline: Radiology Was Young, and So Was I
text: Some people are born with silver spoons in their mouths. I grew up in a lead cocoon.

headline: Iowa Goes for Edwards (Elizabeth, at Least)
text: TIPTON, Iowa, June 16 — Elizabeth Edwards was holding court in the sweltering basement at the Cedar County Courthouse in Tipton, where local Democrats fanned themselves under fluorescent light. Her husband, John Edwards, making his second run for the presidency, watched and winced as she quizzed her audience about what they knew of his biography.

headline: New Jersey Civil Union Board Hears Bias Charge
text: TRENTON, June 18  The commission that monitors how well civil unions are working for New Jersey’s same-sex couples met for the first time on Monday and heard about the first official discrimination complaint filed to the state.

headline: Ornette Coleman Collapses
text: The jazz saxophonist Ornette Coleman, 77, collapsed onstage from heat stroke at the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival in Manchester, Tenn., on Sunday and was given intravenous fluids in a nearby medical tent before he was taken to Coffey County Hospital, Reuters reported. He is next scheduled to perform with the Ornette Coleman Quartet in Kongsberg, Norway, on July 6.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article by Bloomberg News in Business Day on June 13 about the fraud trial of Conrad M. Black misspelled the surname of an attorney for Mark S. Kipnis, a co-defendant. And a correction in this space on Friday also misspelled his surname. He is Michael Swartz — not Schwartz or Schwarz.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Friday about a Senate bill that would increase taxes on publicly traded equity firms and hedge funds gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the surname of a Democratic lawmaker from Montana who sponsored the legislation. He is Senator Max Baucus, not Bachus.

headline: Now You See ‘Sicko,’ Now You Don’t
text: Michael Moore’s documentary about health care in the United States, “Sicko,” appeared then disappeared from the Internet as the weekend gave way to Monday, The Associated Press reported. First at least two YouTube users posted a pirated 124-minute, 14-video-clip version of the $9 million film, which is not scheduled for nationwide release until June 29. Each of the clips attracted 500 to 600 viewers to the video-sharing Web site over the weekend before YouTube pulled the links, citing a copyright claim by Lionsgate, which is distributing “Sicko” with the Weinstein Company. Sarah Rothman, a Weinstein spokeswoman, said in a statement that it was “responding aggressively to protect our film.” Mr. Moore, whose previous films include “Roger & Me” and “Fahrenheit 9/11,” has supported the downloading of pirated films as long as the pirates do not profit.

headline: Writer Sentenced for Sexually Tormenting Former Colleague
text: Peter Braunstein, the former Women’s Wear Daily writer convicted of terrorizing a former colleague for 13 hours in 2005 after dressing as a firefighter to gain access to her apartment, was sentenced to 18 years to life in prison yesterday.

headline: Brooklyn: Sentencing for Woman’s Murder
text: A man who served as his own defense lawyer was sentenced yesterday to 32 years to life in prison for killing a companion. At his sentencing in State Supreme Court, the man, Gregory Zalevsky, 52, submitted a handwritten 29-page motion to vacate his conviction for the murder of Irina Ilyina, 31, a mother of two from New Jersey. Ms. Ilyina, who had been dating Mr. Zalevsky while seeking a divorce from her husband, was found smothered in Mr. Zalevsky’s Brighton Beach apartment in July 2004. In the courtroom, Justice Matthew J. D’Emic denied Mr. Zalevsky’s motion. Ms. Ilyina’s parents, sister and former husband asked for a long prison sentence, calling Mr. Zalevsky a “monster.” In a statement to the court, Mr. Zalevsky said he expected to be exonerated.

headline: Not All Plane Beds Are Equally Restful
text: The latest dogfight in the highly competitive airline industry is for bragging rights to the best night’s sleep in the sky.

headline: Win a Trip: Paging Dr. Wen
text: Will Okun, who's traveling with Nick Kristof in Africa, reports on what happened when his fellow winner was confronted with a medical emergency.

headline: Union Members and Activists Will Give Democrats a Listen
text: Democratic presidential candidates may come under scrutiny today and tomorrow from two important party constituencies: labor union members and liberal activists.

headline: $30 Million Homes
text: A two-bedroom condominium in New York City, an eight-bedroom house Aspen, Colo. and a nine-bedroom house Bel Air, Calif.

headline: 9 Firefighters Killed in Blaze
text: Fire swept through a warehouse in Charleston, S.C., collapsing the building’s roof.

headline: Fashionable, Tommy?
text: I was walking on the rue Saint-HonorÃ© in Paris at dusk last night and couldn’t help noticing the sheer volume of light pouring from the windows of fashionable stores like Brooks Brothers and Tumi. There were hardly any other strollers at that hour, and the shops were shut. But most looked open and ready to welcome customers.

headline: Vague, Like the Ending
text: The posting on Craigslist was vague, something about “set dressing” and a movie company and a sale. Those in the know had two words: The Sopranos.

headline: Viva Las Vegas
text: Peebles

headline: Glorious Cheese
text: From cow to plate: a camembert's journey.

headline: Theater Briefs
text: The musical "Xanadu" has a new opening date: July 10. The show was to have opened at the Helen Hayes Theater on June 26, but a roller-skating injury suffered by its leading man, James Carpinello, led to a postponement. Mr. Carpinello has been replaced by Cheyenne Jackson.

headline: A Lost Kingdom on the Nile
text: The kingdom of Kush flourished with the political and military prowess to maintain control over a wide territory in Africa.
From The Times archives, original coverage of the Charles Becker case and the Satan's Circus neighborhood in Manhattan. (In pdf format)

headline: J.P. Morgan Names Credit Card Chief
text: J.P. Morgan Chase has hired Gordon A. Smith from American Express to head its credit card unit, succeeding Richard J. Srednicki, 59, who plans to retire next quarter. Mr. Smith, 48, has spent his entire career, more than 25 years, at American Express, including the last two as head of the global commercial card group.

headline: Options-Backdating Trial Starts for Former Brocade Chief
text: Prosecutors pursuing executives for backdating stock options began the first courtroom test of their crackdown as the former chief executive of Brocade Communications went on trial in federal court in San Francisco.

headline: Queen Elizabeth 2 Sold to Dubai-Owned Company
text: The Queen Elizabeth 2, the majestic ocean liner that carried millions of people across the Atlantic during its 40-year history, has been sold to a Dubai-owned company for $100 million, the company said Monday.

headline: Parmalat Announces Settlement Agreements
text: Parmalat announced three settlement agreements Monday related to the dairy group’s 2003 failure, with Merrill Lynch, ING Bank and Banca Monte Parma of Italy, for a total of 72 million euros ($96.5 million).

headline: Blackstone Makes Its First Management Buyout in India
text: The private equity firm Blackstone Group said Monday that it had agreed to buy an Indian back-office company, Intelenet Global Services, for an undisclosed sum, in its first management buyout in India.

headline: To Avoid Takeover, Akzo May Up Imperial Bid
text: The move by Akzo Nobel, the world’s largest maker of paints and coatings, to buy a British rival, Imperial Chemical Industries, may be a defensive play to avoid a hostile takeover of its own.

headline: Holy Land’s New Lure: Bikini Babes
text: During the conflict with Lebanon last year, Israeli tourism industry didn’t disappear; it just went south, away from the fighting. Now, with a new set of life-or-death concerns emerging, the nation’s tourism industry again soldiers on.

headline: Electronic Arts to Reorganize
text: Electronic Arts, the world’s biggest video game publisher, said on Friday it would reorganize into four units in an efficiency drive by its new chief executive, John Riccitiello. Under the plan, Electronic Arts will consist of units that focus on sports, casual games, the Sims franchise and other games.

headline: For Wendy’s, a Sale May Be Its Most Palatable Option
text: Wendy’s International, which in April said it formed a special committee of directors to review options, seems to be leaning toward a sale of the company.

headline: Troubled Bear Fund Gets Breathing Room from Creditors
text: Bear Stearns got a one-day reprieve from lenders to try to arrange a rescue plan for a troubled hedge fund, according to press reports. The fund, Bear Stearns High Grade Structured Credit Strategies Enhanced Leveraged Fund, has experienced large losses and margin calls from creditors, as its bets on the subprime mortgage market went bad.

headline: Closing Arguments Begin in Black Trial
text: With a few strokes of his pen, Conrad M. Black “systematically stole” $60 million from the company he ran and controlled, a federal prosecutor said Monday in her closing argument against the former press tycoon and three associates.

headline: Warburg Pincus Set for Big Gain on Polypore I.P.O.
text: Polypore International set a price range for its upcoming initial public offering that would yield Warburg Pincus, which bought the company three years ago, a 120 percent to 135 percent gain on its equity investment of about $300 million.

headline: Intel Gives K2 Network Capital to Play With
text: K2 Network, an online game publisher that has been bringing multiplayer Asian games to the United States market, said it won $16 million in a second round of funding led by Intel‘s venture capital arm. The round included new investors Khosla Ventures , Greycroft Ventures and Novel TMT Ventures.

headline: Cinven in $2.85 Billion British Hospital Deal
text: Cinven on Monday agreed to buy Britain’s third-largest network of private hospitals from the British United Provident Association for 1.44 billion pounds ($2.85 billion).

headline: Friendly Sale Ends Not-So-Friendly Battle Within
text: Friendly Ice Cream‘s decision to sell the Northeast chain, known for its Fribble milkshake, to a private equity firm has headed off a proxy battle showdown and ended a lawsuit filed by the company’s cofounder that accused Friendly’s chairman of mismanagement.

headline: Sean Bell Shooting Leads to Overhaul in Police Undercover Work
text: The local news today is dominated by Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly’s announcement yesterday of 19 changes in undercover procedures — including a new requirement that officers be tested for alcohol consumption in all cases where they have been involved in a shooting that results in injury or death.The recommendations, from a panel of top police commanders, are the broadest changes in official policy in years. They are a response to the police shooting in November of Sean Bell, an unarmed 23-year-old black man in Queens, which set off a wave of public protest and anger over police tactics. Two of the five officers involved in the shooting have been charged with manslaughter.

headline: Citigroup Still Considering German Bank Deal
text: Citigroup on Tuesday reiterated its interest in buying a bank in Germany but played down recent talk that it was about to swoop on Commerzbank. “We are not in any talks at all with Commerzbank,” Sue Harnett, Citigroup’s German head, told Reuters at a news conference.

headline: Cybersource Buys Electronic Payments Rival
text: The electronic payments company Authorize.Net Holdings will be acquired by a rival, CyberSource in a $565 million deal.

headline: Saudi Prince to Offer His Kingdom to the Public
text: Kingdom Holding, the Saudi Arabian investment firm owned by billionaire Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, plans to sell a 3.15 billion-riyal ($840 million) stake in an initial public offering.

headline: Are Online Pet Stores Gaining New Allure?
text: Break out that sock puppet. Investors are backing online pet stores again.

headline: Private Equity Fund Back on Bidding List for Alitalia
text: Italy has allowed the American private equity firm MatlinPatterson to re-enter the auction for the national airline Alitalia — in what Reuters calls an apparent about-face amid fears that one of the two existing bidders may pull out.

headline: Indian Metals Producer Raises $1.75 Billion in U.S. Share Sale
text: Sterlite Industries, the copper and zinc producer controlled by the billionaire Anil Agarwal, sold $1.75 billion of stock in the United States. Sterlite, based in Mumbai, sold 130.44 million American depositary receipts at $13.44 apiece, the unit of Vedanta Resources said in a statement to the Bombay Stock Exchange on Tuesday.

headline: ING Enters Turkey With Oyak Deal
text: ING, the Dutch banking and insurance group, on Tuesday moved into the Turkish banking sector with a $2.67 billion cash acquisition of Oyak Bank and said it would invest to rapidly extend market share by opening branches, improving marketing and expanding Internet banking.

headline: Google Foundation to Invest in Give-and-Take Hybrid
text: Google and Pacific Gas & Electric have introduced their vision of a future in which cars and trucks are partly powered by the country’s electric grids, and vice versa.

headline: Document: 19 Changes in Undercover Procedures
text: Following is the full text of the news release  issued late yesterday by the New York Police Department detailing the findings of a panel charged with reviewing undercover procedures. [Note: The release was incorrectly dated May 18.]Commissioner Kelly Announces Undercover Panel Recommendations: Mandatory Alcohol Testing in Shootings With Fatalities or InjuriesPolice Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced today 19 recommendations of a special panel that he appointed to review New York City Police Department undercover procedures in the wake of the Sean Bell shooting.

headline: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, In His Own Words
text: ABORTION April 27, 2006; Fund-raiser for Naral Pro-Choice New York  "Reproductive choice is a fundamental human right, and we can never take it for granted."

headline: Quadrangle’s Rattner: How the Credit Bubble Will Burst
text: When it comes to today’s credit markets, the specter of a certain six-letter word seems to be haunting many observers including banks and the Federal Reserve. But perhaps most strikingly, a few of the debt boom’s biggest beneficiaries — private equity — have sounded notes of caution.

headline: Cellphones for Kids
text: If you're going to issue your child a cellphone, it had better be ultra-simple, ultra-limited, ultra-rugged and ultra-parent-controlled.

headline: Cadbury Says It Favors Sale of Beverages Unit
text: Cadbury Schweppes said Tuesday that it sees a sale of its American beverage unit, rather than a spinoff, as the most likely option as the world’s biggest confectioner also announced plans to cut 15 percent of its work force — some 7,500 jobs — in an efficiency drive.

headline: Latest Poll Shows Approval of Spitzer Rising
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s approval rating has shot up to 60 percent from 48 percent in April, but only 22 percent think his hard-charging “steamroller” style is working, according to a Quinnipiac University poll released this morning.

headline: Yahoo’s C.E.O. Change Reignites Deal Chatter
text: As Yahoo announced late Monday that Terry S. Semel was stepping down as its chief executive, at least two big questions immediately arose: Is the Internet giant in play? And will shareholder activists jump into the game?

headline: Pearson Shareholder Criticizes Potential Dow Jones Bid
text: Though Pearson is exploring the possibility of bidding alongside General Electric for Dow Jones, Pearson’s third-largest shareholder, Schroders, an investment company, urged the company not to get into a bidding war with Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, The Telegraph reported Tuesday.

headline: Hit Entertainment Statement
text: The following is a statement from Hit Entertainment released by Bender/Helper Impact, an outside public-relations agency:

headline: 2008: Candidate Bloomberg?
text: Though he may look like a candidate for president and sound like a candidate for president, New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg told an audience in California on Monday that – despite speculation to the contrary – he was not a candidate for president. During his speech to employees at the high-tech company, Google, the mayor did not rule out the possibility and instead delivered a serious message:

headline: Bloomberg Courts the Power Brokers
text: As any student of New York politics knows, there is more than one way to put pressure on state or city legislators. One is to go to legislative leaders, like Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno, or City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn. When they speak, people listen.

headline: The Romney-Rockwell Video
text: A prominent part of Mitt Romney’s pitch to conservative voters and others across America is his family photo album. He mentions his five sons, 10 grandchildren and one wife — his high school sweetheart no less — almost without fail on the campaign trail.

headline: True Believers
Displaced
text: From the high vantage point of our trucks, we could see the long lines of people stretching through the town’s center and masses more throbbing behind a barricade, pressing for the opportunity to just wait in line. I had seen a similar commotion once before in Chicago, at a record signing by singer R. Kelly. But this is Rutshuru in the eastern Congo: these people were fighting for food.

headline: Blackstone I.P.O. to Price Thursday
text: One of the most anticipated initial public offerings of the year may arrive sooner than expected. The Blackstone Group will price its share offering on Thursday, The Associated Press reported citing one of the offering’s underwriters, Morgan Stanley. The firm was originally expected to go public next week.

headline: Ulurp: Is That the Sound of Columbia Absorbing Part of Harlem?
text: The acronym may sound amusing — it stands for Uniform Land Use Review Procedure — but to those opposed to the expansion of Columbia University’s campus, it is the shot that signals the start of a metaphorical ground war.

headline: Jim and Mario
text: Do you ever get the feeling there are great parties going on that you haven’t been invited to?

headline: Manufacturers Seen as Potential Buyout Bait
text: Options traders are apparently not the only ones who see Illinois Tool Works as a possible candidate for a leveraged buyout. The company, whose products include industrial fasteners and commercial meat slicers, was one of the manufacturers that Victor Consoli, a credit strategist at Bear Stearns, flagged this week as potentially attractive to private equity firms.

headline: The Best Time to Visit and Swim in Brittany
text: What is the best time to go to Brittany? What is the temperature of the ocean in August?

headline: Freeing James Baldwin
text: The Times Literary Supplement, or TLS, that most venerable and high-minded of England’s weekly book sections – Virginia Woolf and Henry James were contributors – has had a makeover. Thankfully, not all that much has changed. A long list of contributing editors has been added up at the front. The editor, Peter Stothard, now writes a small introductory note to each issue. (Did you know Stothard has a blog?) And the brilliant N.B. column, written by James Campbell, has been moved to the back page, so you no longer have to go foraging for it.

headline: On the Trail of the Dolphin Whackers
text: When the first dead dolphin washed ashore on May 29 in southern California, there was little cause for alarm. When four more followed, concern rose considerably. Evidence that four of the five had been shot in the head sent Michelle Zetwo, a special agent for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s Fisheries Office for Law Enforcement, on a murder investigation.

headline: Debate Over Upper West Side Towers Livens Up
text: [Note: Jim Rasenberger wrote an article in The City on Sunday about the disagreement over two tall glass towers rising on Broadway at 99th Street. The article has generated several dozen reader comments. City Room asked Mr. Rasenberger, the author of “High Steel: The Daring Men Who Built the World’s Greatest Skyline” (2004), to respond to the comments, in the context of broad public concern about the pace and scope of development in the city.]

headline: Weill Says Big Is Beautiful; Hedge Fund Disagrees
text: Sanford Weill, the retired chairman of Citigroup, recently told Bloomberg News that the bank’s enormousness isn’t a disadvantage. “Being large and having a strong balance sheet enables a company to withstand the financial turmoil that happens every now and then in global markets,” he said.

headline: Redskins’ Owner to Buy Dick Clark Productions
text: The private equity firm owned by Daniel Snyder, owner of the Washington Redskins, agreed on Tuesday to buy Dick Clark Productions for $175 million, acquiring a library of live music shows including “American Bandstand.”

text: On second thought, it appears the joke may be on us. Greg Newton’s ability to open the window of his Gulfstream V jet should have given us pause. We tip our hats to Mr. Newton.

headline: 2009 Prius: Not So Fast
Understanding Al Gore
text: Readers respond to David Brooks’s May 29 column, “The Vulcan Utopia.”

headline: Universities in New York Condemn British Professors’ Israel Boycott
text: At least three universities in New York City have become involved in the widening and impassioned debate over last month’s decision by the main British union of college professors to support a boycott of Israel.

headline: Quasi-Religious Poised for Political Power
text: Readers respond to David Brooks’s May 25 column, “The Catholic Boom.”

headline: Collateral Damage from Blackstone Bill?
text: When two United States senators introduced a bill Thursday that would more than double the tax rate for publicly traded buyout firms, it was seen as a direct shot at the Blackstone Group, which is preparing to go public, and at the Fortress Investment Group, which went public in February.

headline: Arrested for Being Young
text: Readers respond to Bob Herbert’s May 29 column, “Small Incidents are Creating a Big Problem With the N.Y.P.D..“

headline: Coulda, Woulda . . .Shoulda?
text: Readers respond to Bob Herbert’s June 5 column, “The Passion of Al Gore.”

headline: Bruno Says ‘We’re Not Doing Gay Marriage’
text: The State Assembly might be voting on gay marriage as early as today, but the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, said of his chamber, “We’re not doing gay marriage by Thursday; that’s for sure, or this year.”

headline: Bristol’s Court Victory May Inspire Suitors
text: Shares of Bristol-Myers Squibb jumped nearly 5 percent Tuesday after a judge upheld the patent on Plavix, a lucrative anticlotting drug that it co-markets with Sanofi-Aventis. The ruling was not a surprise: The judge had been sending signals all along that he was inclined to rule in Bristol-Myers’s favor.

headline: City Installs Beach Mats for the Disabled
text: Wading into the summer waters has gotten a bit easier for the disabled and elderly at four city beaches.

headline: More Rorty
text: According to Richard Rorty, natural disasters can kill thousands and millions of people, but leave Western institutions intact.

headline: Delivering Moo Shoo? Strap on a Helmet
text: A law requiring bicycle-riding delivery workers to wear helmets while on their rounds takes effect on July 26, but it is far from clear whether thousands of affected businesses know about the new rules. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed the law on March 28; the proposal had strong support from representatives of bike-messenger and food-delivery businesses.

headline: The Yankees Are Coming! The Yankees Are Coming!
text: Greetings from Denver, where your bottle of contact lens solution exhales when you open it.

headline: Expedia Announces a Buyback, Not a Buyout
text: As it turns out, last week’s rumors that Expedia was planning to go private were less than half true — about 42 percent, to be more precise. That’s how much of Expedia’s public stock the online travel company is proposing to buy back from investors under a $3.5 billion share repurchase program it announced early Tuesday.

headline: Another Deck of Cards for U.S. Troops in Iraq
text: In the grand scheme of things in Iraq, “it’s a pretty tough sell to ask people to care about a bunch of old rocks with funny writing,” as Mathew Bogdanos put it in March.

headline: BC Partners to Buy Intelsat in $5 Billion Deal
text: Intelsat, the world’s largest satellite operator, said Tuesday it had agreed to sell a majority stake of the company to a group led by a London private equity firm, BC Partners, for $5 billion.

headline: Many Like It Pink
text: Much has been said and written about the rise of rosé wine in recent years, about the long distance it has traveled from the time when it signaled vintages of white zinfandel easily mistaken for sweet punch.

headline: Frugal Traveler: Tell Matt Where to Go in South Dakota and Nebraska
text: Next week, the Frugal Traveler is driving to South Dakota and Nebraska. He needs your help. Do you know a cheap motel, a great place to eat or a must-see attraction? Share your tips with Matt here.

text: The attempted bailout of the Bear Stearns hedge fund that lost money in mortgage securities is taking place largely behind closed doors, with big banks acting both as creditors — who want their money now — and as owners of similar securities — who do not want to see prices plunge.

text: Alison Smale, of the International Herald Tribune, discusses the events in the world this week.

text: A report released today by the Brennan Center for Justice begins with this grim portrait:

headline: Starbucks Accused of Firing Outspoken Barista
text: The Starbucks Corporation has gotten in trouble again with the National Labor Relations Board over how it treats pro-union employees.

headline: Frames – A New Electronics Category
text: One of the most wonderful things about technology is how after the economies of scale in production cause the prices to drop, the technology is re-purposed into new gadgets.

headline: ‘Sicko’ to Hit Theaters Early
text: After a documentary leaked in a serious way over the weekend, the studio has decided to move up the opening. Michael Cieply tells it well:

headline: Home Depot to Sell Supply Unit for $10 Billion
text: Home Depot has agreed to sell its Home Depot Supply Unit to three private equity firms — Bain Capital, the Carlyle Group and Clayton Dubilier & Rice for $10.3 billion, the buyers announced this afternoon, confirming a report by DealBook.

headline: Some Things Should Change
text: Here we are in our new building. Plenty of light and fresh air. Clean and trim. Everything brand new, except what we brought with us. Not so much soul yet, but it’ll come.

headline: Defensive Driving With the Vatican
text: ”Guidelines for the Pastoral Care of the Road”

headline: Phillips Up, Phelps Designated for Assignment
text: In spring training, Josh Phelps beat out Andy Phillips for a spot on the Yankees’ roster as the right-handed hitting first baseman. Now, Phillips has beaten out Phelps.

headline: A Juneteenth Riddle: Was Duffield Street a Stop on the Underground Railroad?
text: New York City insists that six 19th-century houses on Duffield Street in Downtown Brooklyn were not, in fact, a way station for runaway slaves before the Civil War. A group of politicians and local historians begs to differ. A two-year, city-financed study of the matter found no persuasive evidence that the houses were ever part of the underground railroad, but skeptics are unconvinced.

headline: Skip the Song, See the Video
text: Hillary Clinton may or may not make a good president, but there’s near unanimity in opinionland that you shouldn’t let her DJ your next party. The selection of Celine Dion’s “You and I” as the winner of Sen. Clinton’s online campaign-song contest has received denunciation across the political spectrum.

headline: Bloomberg Leaving Republican Party
text: UPDATED, 10:28 p.m.

headline: Democrats Court the Antiwar Base
