text: Several of the candidates vying for the Democratic presidential nomination used a forum in Washington today to build support among the party’s liberal base. They also sought to distinguish their views from those of their opponents on a variety of issues, most notably, the war in Iraq.

headline: Mayor Bloomberg Quits the G.O.P.
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg announced tonight that he is quitting the Republican party and changing his affiliation to independent.

headline: Discussion: Concussions in Sports
text: Concussions, described as a “silent epidemic” in sports, and other brain injuries have become an increasingly talked about issue in youth sports. Information about these injuries can be sparse.

headline: Bruno on the Mayor’s ‘Remarkable Record’
text: Responses to Mr. Bloomberg’s party switch have started coming in. The State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican of Rensselaer County, who has been close to the mayor, issued this statement at 6:20 p.m. that made no direct reference, in three paragraphs, to the mayor’s decision:

headline: Google Earth Vacation
text: I was killing some time with Google Earth last week and decided to look around my old stomping ground in Iraq. The imagery of the area was surprisingly good, and I had many a chuckle and a sigh as I perused the landscape of AO Raleigh, the area of operations that includes Falluja and its outlying areas.

headline: A Day in the Life of Win-a-Trip
text: What is life like on Win-a-Trip? Will and I had asked Nick on the plane ride here about free time. Nick responded, “What free time? We work all day and write all night.”

headline: L’Espoir
text: Today we visited Jomba, a town that was attacked by rebel soldiers about a month ago. A local priest was killed during the attacks, and the villagers left and recently returned.

headline: Win a Trip: Misery Camp
text: Leana Wen, who's traveling with Nicholas D. Kristof in Africa, reports on people fleeing the war in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

headline: McCain’s Tough Line on Castro, Chavez
text: Senator John McCain is warning that as president he “will not passively await the long-overdue demise of the Castro dictatorship” in Cuba in a speech on Latin America that he plans to deliver in Palm Beach, Fla., on Wednesday afternoon.

headline: Living In Her Lonely World
text: Um, I’m dying?

headline: A Real New York Brawl?
text: Is New York big enough for three presidential candidates?

headline: Frugal Traveler: West Lima, Wis.
text: In West Lima, Wis., population 65, the Frugal Traveler visits an intentional community of artists and anarchists.

headline: Medical Marijuana Measure Falls With Connecticut Governor’s Veto
text: STAMFORD, Conn., June 19  After struggling with what was described as one of the most difficult decisions in her three-year tenure, Gov. M. Jodi Rell vetoed a measure today that would have legalized the use of marijuana for certain medical conditions.

headline: Shuttle Detaches From Space Station
text: The space shuttle Atlantis undocked from the International Space Station. After backing away about 450 feet, the Atlantis flew around the space station, taking pictures of the station’s new configuration, including a 17.2-ton truss installed during the shuttle astronauts’ nine-day visit. Later, the astronauts used a camera attached to the shuttle’s robotic arm to perform a final check for damage to the nose cone and the leading edges of the wings. The astronauts will test the orbiter’s flight systems today in preparation for a scheduled landing tomorrow at Cape Canaveral, Fla., weather permitting; otherwise, the shuttle will remain in orbit another day.

headline: U.S. Seeks to Block Exits for Iraq Insurgents
text: BAQUBA, Iraq, June 19 — In more than four years in Iraq, American forces have been confounded by insurgents who have often slipped away only to fight another day. The war in Iraq has been likened to the arcade game of whack-a-mole, where as soon as you knock down one mole another pops up.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a picture caption in some copies on June 10 with an article about Ivory Coast’s political fragility misidentified a religious structure built in Yamoussoukro, the official capital, by Félix Houphouët-Boigny, the longtime president, whose death in 1993 helped to precipitate events that led to a civil war. It is a basilica, not a mosque.

headline: Mac Morgan, 89, Bass-Baritone Who Went on to Teach Voice, Dies
text: Mac Morgan, an American bass-baritone who sang on radio, television and the stage from the 1940s to the 1970s and who was later chairman of the voice department at Boston University, died on June 12 in Carrollton, Ga., where he lived. He was 89. He died of complications of an appendectomy, said his daughter Anne Morgan.

headline: Yankees Offer Only a Wisp of Offense
text: DENVER, June 19 — All of the seats at Coors Field are painted green, except for one row ringing most of the ballpark, 20 rows high in the third deck. That line of seats is purple, representing a mile above sea level. On Tuesday, though, you could not see it.

headline: Home Depot Sells a Unit That Never Fit
text: Home Depot agreed yesterday to sell its Home Depot Supply Unit to a group of private equity firms for more than $10.3 billion. Members of the consortium — Bain Capital, the Carlyle Group and Clayton, Dubilier & Rice — will take an equal stake in the company.

headline: White House Report Lauds Immigrants’ Positive Effects
text: WASHINGTON, June 19 — Hoping to influence Congressional debate, the White House issued a report on Tuesday saying, “Immigration has a positive effect on the American economy as a whole and on the income of native-born American workers.”

headline: Smithsonian Report Due
text: A committee created to review the compensation and expenses paid to the former Smithsonian Secretary Lawrence M. Small is to post its report online this morning at 8, Eastern time. Mr. Small resigned in March after an audit showed that the Smithsonian had paid for his frequent use of personal luxuries like chauffeured cars and catered meals. The report, which will also address the Smithsonian’s governance issues, was prepared by an independent review committee composed of three people outside the Smithsonian: Charles A. Bowsher, a former comptroller general; A. W. Smith Jr., known as Pete, the former chief executive of the Private Sector Council, a nonprofit organization for improving the management of federal government; and Stephen D. Potts, chairman of the Ethics Resource Center. The report is separate from one issued on Monday by the Smithsonian’s Committee on Governance — also established in March — four of whose five members also sit on the Board of Regents, the Smithsonian’s governing body. The independent review committee’s report, along with a lengthy appendix, will be available at smithsonianirc.org.

headline: Questioning Authority?
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Living in a Portuguese Wine Region
text: Following your dreams can be harder than you expect, as Jerry and Carolee Luper found when they moved to the Douro, Portugal’s best known wine region, to run their own small vineyard and winemaking business.

headline: A Deal Worth Cheering
text: The steady march of major timber companies to new locations in the southern United States and overseas has exposed millions of acres to development, ratcheting up the already fierce pressures on the nation’s dwindling supply of open space. With most federal open-space programs cut to the bone, the task of preserving these lands for future generations has fallen increasingly to private groups.

headline: Staking Out the Dead and Having a Lively Time of It
text: Jason Hawes, a jovial, bald hulk who resembles Vic Mackey of “The Shield,” runs his own vigilante team on “Ghost Hunters.” But unlike Mackey’s fictional rogue cops, the TAPS gang on this Sci Fi reality show doesn’t whack anyone: the quarry is already dead.

headline: You May Call It a Daydream. She Just Calls It Her Life.
text: In “One Thing I Like to Say Is,” a sensitive new play by Amy Fox that is part of Clubbed Thumb’s Summerworks series, the promising romance of Lina and James suffers a fairly major setback. “I have some sad news about James,” Lina (a wry Amy Staats) says with a doleful glance. “He does not exist.”

headline: A Spotlight on African-Americans in Modern-Dance History
text: “Dance in America: Dancing in the Light,” the fourth and final program in the American Dance Festival’s Emmy Award-winning “Free to Dance,” brings this documentary series to a rich and satisfying close tonight. The one-hour show, part of “Great Performances” on PBS, chronicles more than a half-century of American modern-dance history, from Asadata Dafora’s “Ostrich” to the first section of Bill T. Jones’s “D-Man in the Waters.”

headline: After Shake-Up, What Now for Yahoo?
text: Should Yahoo stop trying to beat Google at its own game? Should it step up the pace and grow even larger through mergers and acquisitions?

headline: A Dish Whose Heart Longs for Spring
text: NEW YORK chefs have been flaunting peas, fava beans and ramps on their menus since March, but as every farmers’ market devotee knows, it’s all a great big spring vegetable charade. By the time the vernal equinox hits, we’re desperate to trade brussels sprouts for asparagus, but the really divine local produce is still months away.

headline: Some Texans Fear Border Fence Will Sever Routine of Daily Life
text: McALLEN, Tex., June 15 — Antonio N. Zavaleta, a vice president and professor of anthropology at the University of Texas branch in Brownsville, saw a slight problem in the route of a border fence that federal officials displayed at a community meeting earlier this month.

headline: Brooklyn: Developer Charged With Bribery
text: The developer of a multifamily house on Maple Street near Kings County Hospital Center was charged with bribery yesterday after offering a building inspector $1,000 to overlook a safety violation, city investigators said. The man, Vauguens Michel, 49, was charged with bribery and rewarding official misconduct, according to the Department of Investigation. Rose Gill Hearn, the investigation commissioner, said that Mr. Michel offered the bribe to an inspector who had found shoring work on the site to be inadequate. The inspector reported the offer to the Department of Investigation, Ms. Gill Hearn said.

headline: Coria’s Lawyers Look to Restore a Reputation
text: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 19 — Guillermo Coria, a tennis player from Argentina, took to an unfamiliar court Tuesday. The spectators included eight jurors, a judge and a major nutritional supplement manufacturer, which Coria is claiming is responsible for his positive steroid test six years ago.

headline: Some Cities Will Get Early Look at ‘Sicko’
text: LOS ANGELES, June 19 — Hyped in Cuba, unveiled in Cannes, pirated on YouTube and rallied around last week in Sacramento by nurses chanting for the demise of the current health insurance system, Michael Moore’s documentary “Sicko” is finally ready to meet its American audience — or at least some of it — a week ahead of schedule.

headline: Smoothing the Way for Those Seeking a Day at the Beach
text: Milagros Franco was 8 the last time she was on a beach. That was 23 years ago. So Ms. Franco said she was elated yesterday to be spending a bright, balmy day at Brighton Beach in Brooklyn.

headline: N.F.L. Program Gives New Meaning to a Set Formation
text: MOUNT LAUREL, N.J., June 19 — Five N.F.L. players sat inside a dimly lit film-editing room at the sprawling headquarters of NFL Films, tucked deep in a South Jersey office park. They had traded their eye black for pancake makeup, their uniforms and helmets for smart suits and silk ties.

headline: Baghdad Book Takes $60,000 Prize
text: “Imperial Life in the Emerald City” (Knopf), a vividly detailed portrait of the Green Zone in Baghdad and the Coalition Provisional Authority, which ran Iraq’s government from April 2003 to June 2004, has won the $60,000 Samuel Johnson Prize, billed as the world’s richest award for nonfiction, Reuters reported. The book, written by Rajiv Chandrasekaran, the former Baghdad bureau chief of The Washington Post, was drawn from hundreds of interviews and documents. Helena Kennedy, chairwoman of the judges, said, “The writing is cool, exact and never overstated and in many places very humorous as the jaw-dropping idiocy of the American action is revealed.”

headline: The Shadow Goes
text: Los Angeles

headline: Letters
text: An Insider’s Guide to Kibbe

headline: Recruited to Rescue Washington’s Schools
text: Fresh out of college, Michelle A. Rhee joined Teach for America, the fast-track teacher training program, landing at Harlem Park Community School in Baltimore. The public school ranked near the bottom in city reading and math scores, and as a new teacher, Ms. Rhee got a classroom of 35 children achieving the worst and behaving the worst.

headline: Army Corps Details Flood Risks Facing New Orleans
text: After nearly two years of work, the Army Corps of Engineers revealed today which New Orleans neighborhoods and blocks were the most vulnerable to flooding and which were the best protected. The report shows that despite considerable improvement, large swaths of the city are still likely to be flooded in a major storm.

headline: Competing Visions for Governors Island
text: In the four years since the federal government sold Governors Island to the state and city for $1, government officials have been baffled over what to do with this isolated but magically haunting place.

headline: ‘Soul’ of an Anthem: Jewish or Israeli? (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bloomberg Insists He Is Not Running for President
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg used his 15 minutes of fame as a Potential Presidential Candidate to showcase one of his pet local projects, the city’s 311 Call Center.

headline: Recipe: Braised Spring Vegetables
text: 1 tablespoon unsalted butter  1 bunch radishes, trimmed and quartered lengthwise 1 1/2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil 1 red onion, halved lengthwise and thinly sliced  3 thyme sprigs (optional) Pinch sugar Kosher salt 2 garlic cloves, very thinly sliced 1 bunch scallions, trimmed and halved lengthwise 1/4 cup white wine  1 bunch asparagus (about 1 pound), trimmed and cut into 1-inch lengths 1 bunch Swiss chard (preferably red), leaves torn into bite-size pieces, stems cut into 1-inch lengths 1/2 pound sugar snap peas, trimmed  1 cup vegetable or chicken broth Freshly ground black pepper  1 cup shelled fresh or frozen peas (about 1 pound in the shell) 1 small head Boston lettuce, torn into bite-size pieces 6 tablespoons grated Parmesan Cornmeal-herb dumplings (see recipe), or prepared polenta or buttered noodles.

headline: Nominee for C.I.A. Counsel Offers Few Details in His Senate Confirmation Hearing
text: WASHINGTON, June 19 — As a 31-year veteran of the Central Intelligence Agency, John A. Rizzo is privy to some of the nation’s most closely held secrets. As the top lawyer at the agency for much of the last six years, he had a central role in C.I.A. detention and interrogation of prisoners in secret jails abroad.

headline: Footnotes
text: The musical “Xanadu” has a new opening date: July 10. The show was to have opened at the Helen Hayes Theater on June 26, but a roller-skating injury suffered by its leading man, James Carpinello, led to a postponement. Mr. Carpinello has been replaced by Cheyenne Jackson. ... “LoveMusik,” starring Michael Cerveris and Donna Murphy as Kurt Weill and Lotte Lenya, will end its limited engagement at the Biltmore Theater on Sunday. The Manhattan Theater Club production will have played 24 previews and 61 regular performances. ... The run of the romantic comedy “The Irish Play,” written by Tim McGuillicuddy and directed by Theodore Mann, artistic director of Circle in the Square, has been extended indefinitely at the Irish Arts Center. ... Tony Danza will don a black producer’s hat once more to reprise the role of the conniving Max Bialystock in the Las Vegas production of the Mel Brooks musical “The Producers” in Las Vegas, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Danza, one of many Maxes in the Broadway production, will enter the Las Vegas cast on Aug. 13 for an 18-week run of 126 shows. ... The concert promotion company the Bowery Presents announced yesterday that the Music Hall of Williamsburg in Brooklyn will open on Sept. 4 with Patti Smith and Her Band.

headline: Girardi Likely Front-Runner After Meeting With Orioles
text: Joe Girardi, a former Yankees player and coach, sounded enthusiastic yesterday after meeting with the Baltimore Orioles about their vacant managerial position. It would be surprising if he is not offered the opportunity to succeed Sam Perlozzo, who was fired Monday.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening This Week

headline: Embracing Change, TV Networks Find Stronger Demand for Ads
text: WHO said you can’t teach an old medium new tricks?

headline: European Parliament: You Call That Vodka?
text: European Parliament legislators offended vodka purists by backing a proposed definition of vodka that says it must be made from grain or potatoes. But to the horror of traditionalists, they said vodka could also be made from ingredients like sugar beets, apples and raisins, as long as vodka bottles were properly labeled. Countries in the so-called vodka belt, which includes Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland and Sweden, wanted a definition that would allow vodka to be made only of grain, potatoes and molasses.

headline: Comedy of Errors Is No Laughing Matter for the Mets
text: Even a defending Cy Young award winner like Minnesota’s Johan Santana needs a little help, and he received plenty of it from both teams last night at Shea Stadium. His Twins supported him with 13 hits and the Mets made four errors as Santana won a four-hit shutout, 9-0.

headline: Bush Will Pair Veto With New Cell Initiative
text: WASHINGTON, June 19  President Bush will issue an executive order intended to encourage scientific advances in regenerative medicine, according to senior White House officials who said Mr. Bush would announce the initiative on Wednesday, just as he vetoes a measure promoting embryonic stem cell research.

headline: Selig May Have Perfect Witness in Giambi
text: The parameters of Jason Giambi’s potential meeting with baseball’s steroid investigators could leave the head detective George Mitchell with a strategic decision: Does he place the lug on the couch or in a hot seat?

headline: Thai Government Orders Ousted Leader to Return to Face Charges
text: BANGKOK, June 19 — Thailand’s military government on Tuesday ordered Thaksin Shinawatra, the man it ousted from power, to return to the country by June 29 or face arrest on charges of concealing assets.

headline: Former First Couple Mimics TV’s Former First Couple
text: This untitled video, produced by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign, introduces the winning song in her contest for a campaign theme. The viewer clicks on a separate link to find that Internet voters have chosen Celine Dion’s “You and I.” The video so precisely mimics the final scene of the final episode of “The Sopranos” broadcast two Sundays ago that in a few short hours on the Web it has become known as The Sopranos video.

headline: Insider Trading Can Now Touch Many Corners of the World
text: Life in the great Pakistan bull market had been good to Ajaz Rahim. He had a big house in an affluent Karachi neighborhood, a swimming pool with a wave machine and a Yamaha motorcycle that people who know him say he liked to ride without a helmet.

headline: Examining Black-Latino Relations, Gently
text: Earlier this spring, in train stations and subway cars across the city, advertisements began appearing for a play that was to begin a limited engagement at Florence Gould Hall of the Alliance Française. This might easily pass without comment, were it not for the matter of the show’s already quiet if substantial success. “Platanos & Collard Greens” was first produced in a tiny Midtown theater — 70 seats — in 2003 and has moved gradually and intermittently to larger spaces since, with virtually nothing but conversation to endorse it.

headline: Losing Antioch, and Its Flame (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Beneath the Bucolic Gurgling, Throbbing Electronica
text: Open the CD booklet of “Person Pitch” (Paw Tracks), the marvelous recent album from the Animal Collective member known as Panda Bear, who played the Bowery Ballroom on Monday night, and you won’t find any song lyrics. Instead, you’ll find collages and two pages of acknowledgments. On one page Panda Bear thanks Mom and Dad and lots of other people who know him by his real name, Noah Lennox. On the other he lists more than 100 musical acts.

headline: House Committee Favors 5-Year Extension of Farm Policies, Rejecting Even Modest Shifts
text: WASHINGTON, June 19  Amid growing calls for alterations in farm policy, the House panel that oversees subsidies to farmers voted Tuesday to maintain the status quo by extending current policies for five years.

headline: Prosecutor in Duke Case Is Suspended
text: Michael B. Nifong, the disbarred district attorney of Durham County, N.C., was served an order at his home yesterday that suspended him from office and was told to turn in his parking pass and office key.

headline: Writer Testifies About Source of Nom de Plume
text: The case of Laura Albert — professionally known as JT Leroy — could be read as a literary cautionary tale, the story of a writer who hid behind her own assumed identity and lost herself for many years while reaching for the truth.

headline: Anyone Wanting Adu’s No. 11 Must Pay Dearly
text: Freddy Adu finally has his number.

headline: Lawmakers to Investigate Bush on Laws and Intent
text: WASHINGTON, June 19  Lawmakers say they plan to dig deeper into the Bush administration’s use of bill-signing statements as ways to circumvent Congressional intent.

headline: China and the Chest Thumpers
text: The latest blame China bill, unveiled last week in the Senate, is not as bad as earlier proposals. Gone are the ham-fisted tariffs that lawmakers once threatened to impose if China did not raise the value of its currency, the yuan. In their place is a more gradual process for inflicting economic and political pain unless Beijing moves faster to lift the yuan.

headline: What Hamas Wants
text: Gaza City

headline: College Loan Program (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lottery Numbers
Some Things to Change, and Some to Leave the Same
text: RESTAURANTS, like people, aren’t easy. They seldom come in tidy packages of all good or all bad. One minute you’re madly in love and then — snap! — you’re not sure, the spell fracturing as the next course comes, as you readjust your gaze. You wish you could change half a dozen things. You wouldn’t tinker at all with half a dozen others.

headline: Police Say Fugitive Hunted for a Shooting on S.I. Was Heavily Armed
text: A woman who was arrested in Philadelphia on Monday on charges of shooting a co-founder of a Staten Island commune last year had apparently planned for the possibility of armed violence, the police said yesterday. The woman, Rebekah Johnson, had an AK-47 assault rifle and 1,000 rounds of ammunition in her apartment in North Philadelphia, the police said.

headline: What You Get for ... $30 Million
text: New York City

headline: Bloomberg Severs G.O.P. Ties, Fueling Further Talk of ’08 Bid
text: LOS ANGELES, June 19 — Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced Tuesday that he was dropping his Republican affiliation, a step that could clear the way for him to make an independent bid for the presidency.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the various factors that will offset New York City’s 7 percent across-the-board cut in property taxes referred incorrectly in some copies to a state law that limits the amount that the assessed value of a house can rise each year. It can rise no more than 6 percent in a year or 20 percent over five years — not over three years.

headline: Karzai Cites Taliban Shift to Terror Attacks
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 19  Taliban insurgents have shifted their tactics to rely more on terrorist attacks, in part out of frustration with their flagging insurgent campaign, said President Hamid Karzai and the commander of American military forces in the Middle East.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on June 10 about a dispute between Vermont and a group of Civil War re-enactors over possession of a cannon referred incorrectly to a decision by former Gov. Mortimer Proctor about what to do with the cannon in the 1960s. He entrusted it to the re-enactors group itself, the Second Battery Vermont Light Artillery — not to James Dassatti or Richard Fifield, both of whom led the battery at different times. Also, the article misidentified the type of clothing that Ronald Crisman, who runs the Vermont Veterans Militia Museum and Library, wore to a legislative hearing on the current dispute. He wore contemporary clothing, not a Civil War uniform.

headline: Not for Bean Counters
text: UNTIL not long ago, the term “bean salad” was rarely used without being preceded by the word “three,” and the three-bean salad was usually a staple of the bad salad bar. But the world of real bean salads can extend the range of your repertory.

headline: Gazans Adjust to Power Shift as New Rulers Revel in Their Victory
text: GAZA, June 19 — Muhammad al-Borniah, 23, shook a little on Tuesday as he showed off the tiny cell, No. 13, where he spent five days in January as a prisoner of the Palestinian Preventive Security, the elite Fatah force that dealt with subversion.

headline: Army Provides a Sense of Unity in Fractured Lebanon
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — With the Lebanese government mired in political crisis, Parliament unable to meet, and sectarian tensions rising, many of this country’s institutions are slowly crumbling away.

headline: Report Assails Pay of Ex-Chief of Smithsonian
text: Even though his supposed fund-raising acumen was used to justify his ballooning salary, the chief executive of the Smithsonian Institution raised less private money for the museum complex last year than his predecessor did in 1999, an independent committee said in a scathing report issued today.

headline: Critic Leaves Newsday for New York Magazine
text: Justin Davidson, Newsday’s music critic, will move to New York magazine and also take on the role of architecture critic, the magazine said yesterday. New York’s previous music critic, Peter G. Davis, left earlier this month. The magazine has been without a staff architecture critic since 2004.

headline: Grapes and Power: A Mondavi Melodrama
text: CALL it Greek tragedy or Shakespearean drama, Biblical strife, Freudian acting out or even soap opera. You wouldn’t be exaggerating, and you wouldn’t be wrong.

headline: New Human Rights Council Brings Limited Change
text: The Human Rights Council, created to be an improvement on the discredited Human Rights Commission, which seldom exposed notorious rights violators, marked the end of what critics called a disappointing first year by abolishing independent rights monitors for Belarus and Cuba. The Geneva-based council did maintain monitors for 10 countries, including Cambodia, Myanmar North Korea and Sudan, and agreed to new rules obliging all 47 member states to have their rights records scrutinized.

headline: Vilma Espín, Rebel and Wife of Raúl Castro, Dies at 77
text: Vilma Espín, an idealistic socialite who fought alongside Fidel and Raúl Castro in the mountains of Cuba and later, as Raúl Castro’s wife, became a prominent advocate of women’s rights and a powerful member of the Cuban Communist Party, died Monday in Havana. She was 77.

headline: 6 Gaza Militants Killed in Clashes With Israel
text: JERUSALEM, June 20 — In a sudden escalation of Israeli-Palestinian violence today, at least six Palestinian militants were killed in clashes with Israeli soldiers in Gaza and the West Bank, according to army officials and Palestinian news reports, and the Israeli air force attacked two rocket launchers in northern Gaza after they had fired two rockets into Israel.

headline: From a Japanese Chef, Chinese, but Not Takeout
text: NEXT month New Yorkers will get their first taste of a Chinese dish called fiery pepper hunt. The combined forces of every General Tso in town will be no match for it.

headline: U.S. Open Has Higher Ratings
text: Ángel Cabrera’s victory in the United States Open on Sunday attracted an average of 9.5 million viewers, 37 percent more than last year, and the most since Tiger Woods’s victory in 2002. While the final round produced a 6.4 rating, the final half-hour, in which Cabrera watched from the clubhouse as Woods missed a birdie putt to tie the tournament, spiked to a 10.1.

headline: Well, We Found 140,000
text: The post-Watergate law requiring the preservation of presidential records has proved to be no match for the Bush White House’s stealthy use of back-channel e-mail messages via the Republican National Committee’s computer system. Congressional investigators have discovered that while 88 White House staffers had accounts at the G.O.P. computer banks, there are no e-mail archives to be found for 51 of them.

headline: The Fighting Business Brothers and Other Tales
text: WHEN a fistfight breaks out between two men in the office, you have to figure that the ill feeling between them runs deep.

headline: New York Law to Expand by Staying Put
text: Expansions are rarely easy in space-challenged Manhattan, and sometimes it’s just easier to chuck an address and move elsewhere. But as officials at New York Law School in TriBeCa are demonstrating, it can pay to stay in place, if a real estate owner is able to think creatively to extract as much value as possible from a property and to make a move at exactly the right moment.

headline: An Athlete Doing Battle With His Past
text: The term “sports film” doesn’t do justice to the director Szabolcs Hajdu’s movie “White Palms,” a punishing, beautiful drama about a troubled 30-something Hungarian gymnast who gets a job as a coach training 2001 Calgary Olympic hopefuls. The film is shot and edited in an austere, quasi-documentary style reminiscent of that of films by the Dardenne brothers (“The Son”) and cast mainly with skilled gymnasts who perform their own routines.

headline: Silver Wields Power by Keeping Albany Guessing
text: What will Shelly do?

headline: 9 Firefighters Die in South Carolina Blaze
text: CHARLESTON, S.C., June 19 — The early reports were bad enough: four firefighters had died as a fire in a furniture warehouse became an inferno of exploding windows, columns of flame and steel beams twisted from 1,000-degree heat.

headline: Microsoft to Alter Windows Vista
text: WASHINGTON, June 20 — Microsoft has agreed to make changes to its Windows Vista operating system in response to a complaint by Google that a feature of Vista is anticompetitive, lawyers involved in the case said on Tuesday.

headline: Into Middle America but Staying on the Fringe
text: DRIVING the back roads, you sometimes cross state borders unknowingly. Without the enormous “Welcome to ...!” signs you see on the Interstates, all you have to identify your new surroundings are subtle clues in the landscape — knobbier pine trees, say, or highways named for local heroes.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts on Saturday about a project in which the artist Eve S. Mosher is drawing a chalk line 10 feet above sea level in areas of New York City that could be threatened by flooding linked to global warming misstated the estimate of how often flooding at that level could occur, according to research by NASA’s Goddard Institute for Space Studies at Columbia University. In a worst-case scenario, the 10-foot line could mark the zone for flooding that would occur every 19 years, on average, by the decade of the 2050s — not every eight years, on average, by the year 2050.

headline: Robin Olds, 84, Fighter Ace and Hero of Big Vietnam Battle, Dies
text: Brig. Gen. Robin Olds, a World War II fighter ace who became an aviation legend by commanding the Air Force wing that shot down seven MIGs over North Vietnam in the biggest air battle of the Vietnam War, died last Thursday at his home in Steamboat Springs, Colo. He was 84.

headline: Kids’ Eating Habits (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Appeal of a Chateau
text: Even on a gray and drizzly day, the appeal of the Château du Feÿ is immediately apparent. Behind the wrought-iron gate, a fountain plays in the courtyard and the rosy brick and pale stone facade of the long, low Louis XIII abode — one of France’s Monuments Historiques — is more welcoming than imperious.

headline: Life Term for Killer of Buffalo-Area Abortion Provider
text: BUFFALO, N.Y., June 19  An avowed opponent of abortion rights already in prison for murdering an obstetrician in 1998 was sentenced again on Tuesday, this time in federal court, to spend the rest of his life behind bars.

headline: Boeing Scores With Dreamliner Order
text: PARIS, June 19 — International Lease Finance Corporation, the world’s largest commercial jet leasing company, signed an agreement Tuesday with Boeing for an order of 52 787 Dreamliners, raising the total number of orders for the hot-selling wide-body plane to 634.

headline: Shakespeare’s Doomed Lovers, Acting and Dancing
text: A glowingly handsome evocation of the Italian Renaissance, Kenneth MacMillan’s “Romeo and Juliet,” created for the Royal Ballet at Covent Garden in 1965, long ago became the standard version of the ballet. It has proved itself a fluent mixture of dance and acting, absorbing in its response to both Shakespeare’s story and Prokofiev’s score.

headline: Royal Visit Is an NBC Hit
text: The British royal offspring invaded American television on Monday, posting the night’s highest ratings and giving NBC an easy victory over all. Nielsen estimated that 12.2 million viewers tuned in at 10 p.m. to watch NBC’s “Dateline” interview with Matt Lauer and Princes William and Harry.  The taped conversation, pegged to the 10th anniversary of the death of the princes’ mother, Diana, Princess of Wales, drew NBC’s best ratings in the time slot since January’s “Golden Globes.” Earlier in the night NBC’s “Deal or No Deal” earned 11.9 million viewers, dominating the 8 p.m. hour. Fox ranked second on Monday among adults 18 to 49, leading the 9 p.m. hour in that demographic with “Hell’s Kitchen” (7.3 million). Meanwhile, the premiere of NBC’s “Age of Love” attracted 7 million viewers at 9 and a third-place finish in the 18-to-49 set. In the network news race, CBS’s “Evening News With Katie Couric” averaged less than 6 million viewers last week in third place (5.9 million). ABC’s “World News With Charles Gibson” finished first for the eighth consecutive week (7.5 million), ahead of NBC’s “Nightly News With Brian Williams” (7.1 million).

headline: Reader Responses
text: Following are excerpts from reader responses to David Leonhardt’s June 20 column on outsourcing and Thomas the Tank Engine:

headline: Florham Park: Two Shooting Victims Found in House
text: A 40-year-old man and a 20-year-old woman were found dead of gunshot wounds in a single-family house on Riverside Drive on Monday afternoon, the Morris County prosecutor’s office said yesterday. There were no signs that anyone had broken into the house, the prosecutor, Michael M. Rubbinaccio, said. While the victims’ identities were withheld pending notification of next of kin, neighbors identified the man as Charles A. Kondakjian, a handyman whose wife died recently. Adam DeFalco, whose brother lives on the same block, said that Mr. Kondakjian had been keeping company with a young woman, and that the two would occasionally visit the neighborhood deli together. Investigators towed a silver Mountaineer sport utility vehicle, which neighbors said had been there all weekend, from the driveway yesterday.

headline: Preserving the Land
text: Housing developments, subdivisions and strip malls are the antithesis of a setting for a vacation retreat. And to prevent this sort of growth, many second homeowners are taking an active role in ensuring that their refuge in the country stays sprawl free.

headline: Some Lenders Dislike Plan to Save Bear Stearns Fund
text: An effort to save a troubled hedge fund at Bear Stearns hit a major hurdle yesterday when Merrill Lynch signaled that it would move forward with plans to auction $850 million in subprime securities that had been held as collateral.

headline: After Meeting Israeli Leader, Bush Gives Support to Abbas
text: WASHINGTON, June 19 — President Bush threw his weight behind President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority on Tuesday, using an Oval Office meeting with Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel to declare Mr. Abbas “the president of all the Palestinians” and praise him as “a reasonable voice among the extremists” in the Middle East.

headline: To Commit a Hate Crime, Must the Criminal Truly Hate the Victim?
text: In her courtroom on the 21st floor of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday, Justice Jill Konviser-Levine sat and pondered the question of hate.

headline: Microsoft Has Deal to Get Exclusive Episodes of Grand Theft Auto IV for Its Xbox Unit
text: It turns out that maybe crime does pay, at least if it’s in Grand Theft Auto.

headline: More Than 20 Killed in Pakistani Tribal Region
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, June 19  What appears to have been a missile attack killed more than 20 people in the North Waziristan tribal region of Pakistan close to the Afghan border on Tuesday, Pakistani security officials said.

headline: More Monet Millions
text: Monet’s 1904 water lily painting “Nympheas” sold last night for $32.8 million, before commission, at Sotheby’s in London, Bloomberg News reported. The painting was bought by an unidentified bidder from the family of a collector who bought it in the 1920s from Monet’s son, Michel. His 1904 painting “Waterloo Bridge, Temps Couvert” fetched $31.7 million, before commission, the previous night at Christie’s International in London.

headline: Dining Briefs
text: NEW PLACES

headline: U.S. Presses Blair to Become Mideast Envoy
text: WASHINGTON, June 20—The United States is pressing Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain to become a special envoy to the Middle East representing the diplomatic “quartet” of world powers , Bush administration officials said today.

headline: Senator Drops Objections to Corzine Court Nominee
text: NEWARK, June 19  Ending a weeklong silent protest, a New Jersey state senator withdrew her objection on Tuesday to Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s nominee for chief justice of the State Supreme Court.

headline: Truck Bomb Hits Baghdad Mosque, and 61 Are Killed
text: BAGHDAD, June 19 — A suicide bomber barreled a truck filled with cooking gas and explosives into a square bordered by a large Shiite mosque in the heart of Baghdad on Tuesday, just as worshipers were finishing midday prayers. The Interior Ministry said at least 61 people were killed and 130 wounded.

headline: Calendar
text: Solstice Celebrations

headline: In a Quick Fix, the Yankees Put Phillips at First Base
text: DENVER, June 19  For strategic reasons, the Yankees’ recent surge came at the right time. They are back in the pennant race, not striving to enter it, and thus are not desperate for help as the July 31 trading deadline approaches.

headline: Panel Supports Tax Breaks for Coal and Non-Oil Fuel
text: WASHINGTON, June 19 — The Senate Finance Committee approved $28 billion in tax breaks on Tuesday to underwrite renewable fuels and “clean coal” technology, all at the expense of the oil industry.

headline: Doctors’ Education (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A music review on Monday about “Don Giovanni,” at the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden in London, referred incorrectly to Erwin Schrott, who portrayed the title role. He is a bass, not a baritone.

headline: Industrial China’s Ravaging of Nature, Made Disturbingly Sublime
text: At one point in the absorbing if unsettling documentary “Manufactured Landscapes,” about the work of the Canadian photographer Edward Burtynsky, a few unnamed voices try to assure a couple of Chinese officials not to worry. Mr. Burtynsky, these voices say, will make everything — meaning the mountains of coal that seem to stretch on forever behind them — beautiful. And so Mr. Burtynsky does. Whether in a coal distribution center or a garbage dump, he turns the grotesque into something beautiful, or at least something that looks good on a gallery wall.

headline: Power to the People (and Some Pop Too)
text: During the last few moments of the True Colors Tour, which arrived at Radio City Music Hall on Monday night, the evening’s sprawling cast delivered an affirmative anthem. Not surprisingly, it was “True Colors,” the Cyndi Lauper ballad that once felt a bit more intimate in tone. And the climax was visual as well as musical: Ms. Lauper and all the other performers each raised a fist in the air.

headline: Black’s Lawyers Hammer Former Partner’s Testimony
text: CHICAGO, June 19 — It was an enormous betrayal by his former associates — and not any act of criminal fraud — that led Conrad M. Black to the Chicago courtroom where, if convicted, he could face the rest of his days in prison, lawyers for the media baron said in their closing arguments.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption in The Arts yesterday with an article about a report from the Smithsonian Institution saying that its Board of Regents failed to provide proper oversight reversed the identities of two Smithsonian officials. Roger W. Sant, chairman of the Board of Regents’ executive committee, was second from the left, and Cristián Samper, the Smithsonian’s acting secretary, was third from the left.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A chart yesterday about the number of television appearances made by presidential candidates in 2006 and 2007 omitted the time frame during which the numbers were tracked. The data was through June 10 of each year.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on Friday about Kurt Waldheim, the former diplomat and president of Austria, misstated the level of support he had in 1981 in his unsuccessful bid for a third term as secretary general of the United Nations. Although he retired from the United Nations after failing to win a unanimous vote of the five permanent members with veto power, his candidacy did indeed win some support, including that of the United States and the Soviet Union; it did not lack support entirely. Also, the obituary misidentified the chancellor of Austria whom Mr. Waldheim served under as foreign minister, from 1968 to 1970. He was Josef Klaus — not Bruno Kreisky, who became chancellor in 1970.

headline: Cadbury to Cut Jobs and Sell Beverage Unit
text: LONDON, June 19 — Cadbury Schweppes, the biggest candy maker in the world, said today that it planned to cut 7,500 jobs and sell the United States beverage unit that made Dr Pepper, Snapple and 7-Up to become more profitable.

headline: Politics Forcing Detroit to Back New Fuel Rules
text: WASHINGTON, June 19 — For a quarter-century, American automakers and their allies argued that any legislation to increase fuel economy standards would rob them of profits, force them to lay off workers and deprive consumers of the vehicles they wanted to buy.

headline: 007 Director Named
text: Marc Foster has been chosen to direct the 22nd James Bond screen adventure. Mr. Foster’s credits include “Stranger Than Fiction” and the forthcoming “Kite Runner,” based on the best-selling novel by Khaled Hosseini. Filming is to begin at Pinewood Studios in London in December, and worldwide release is expected on Nov. 7, 2008.

headline: Giuliani Left Group on Iraq After Warning, Article Says
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani quit the high-profile Iraq Study Group after failing to attend the group’s meetings, and financial filings showed that he chose to give two lucrative speeches on days the panel was meeting.

headline: Running Fast and Free, Elite Team Keeps It Simple
text: A dozen women with impressive college and high school running résumés are pushing one of New York City’s largest running clubs to pick up its pace. Mary Wittenberg, the chief executive of New York Road Runners, compares it to a battle between the all-stars and the walk-ons.

headline: AIDS Research Gets a Home at Brooklyn Army Terminal
text: Late last year, the International AIDS Vaccine Initiative, a global nonprofit company that hopes to speed the development of an H.I.V. vaccine, seemed on the verge of abandoning its plan to open a new laboratory in Brooklyn. The potential defection would have dealt a serious blow to the city’s long-running efforts to attract more well-paying biotechnology research and manufacturing businesses.

headline: Bush Again Vetoes Bill on Stem Cell Research
text: WASHINGTON, June 20 — President Bush today issued his second veto of a measure lifting his restrictions on human embryonic stem cell experiments, a move that effectively pushed the contentious scientific and ethical debate surrounding the research into the 2008 presidential campaign.

headline: PBS’s ‘Exposé’ Is to Appear Online Before Being Broadcast
text: “Exposé: America’s Investigative Reports” returns this weekend for its second season on PBS, with a 20-week run of episodes that highlight investigative reporting from news outlets nationwide. But this season viewers who cannot wait until the broadcast premiere on Friday night can watch each new episode beforehand in streaming Internet video.

headline: Balanchine’s ‘Square Dance’ Returns to Square One
text: Fifty years ago George Balanchine created “Square Dance,” a whimsical marriage of ballet set to music by Vivaldi and Corelli and the hoedown world, with an actual square-dance caller. He later scaled back the hoedown aspect and struck out the caller, but to mark the work’s anniversary the Vail International Dance Festival will open on July 29 with a performance of the original by the Pacific Northwest Ballet. The festival’s executive director, Damian Woetzel, said on Monday that the caller would be Scott Wise, a Broadway actor and director. Works by Twyla Tharp and Jerome Robbins will also be on the program. Pacific Northwest will perform “Square Dance” the next night in the more familiar caller-free version, said Mr. Woetzel, a New York City Ballet dancer making his debut this summer as director of the festival.

headline: Terry Hoeppner, 59, Who Coached Football at Two Universities, Dies
text: Terry Hoeppner, a college football coach who led Miami of Ohio to two consecutive bowl appearances before becoming the head coach at Indiana, died yesterday in Bloomington, Ind. He was 59.

headline: State Dept. Expands Staffing to Handle Passport Backlog
text: WASHINGTON, June 19  The State Department will catch up with the increased demand for passports by this fall, a department official told a Senate committee on Tuesday, saying the department has hired more employees, opened a new processing center and expanded work hours.

headline: Trash Station on West Side Creates Split in Assembly
text: ALBANY, June 19  A group of assemblymen from Upper Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn sharply criticized several colleagues on Tuesday for blocking a recycling station planned for the West Side of Manhattan, saying any delay would prolong the health risks their mostly low-income black and Hispanic constituents face.

headline: Manhattan: Tiffany Support for Lower Manhattan
text: The Tiffany & Company Foundation announced yesterday that it would give $1 million to each of three nonprofit organizations working in Lower Manhattan: the National Parks of New York Harbor Conservancy, which promotes access to parks around New York Harbor; the Battery Conservancy, which is building an ocean-themed ride in the Battery; and Friends of the High Line, which supports a park that is set to open next year on an abandoned overhead train track that runs from Gansevoort Street to 20th Street. The gifts are connected with Tiffany’s plan to open a store at 37 Wall Street in October. The main store is on Fifth Avenue at 57th Street.

headline: Old MacDonald Now Has a Book Contract
text: JOHN PETERSON is not your typical farmer. He is prone to wearing feather boas while driving his tractor and to putting on a bumblebee suit and breaking into interpretive dance between rows of organic vegetables. And while some farmers hunker down with seed catalogs in the off-season, Mr. Peterson takes a sabbatical from his farm, Angelic Organics, in Caledonia, Ill., and spends the winter in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, writing as often as he can. Over the years he has written plays, short stories, a cookbook and a newsletter that he sends to his customers.

headline: Heavy Fighting as Troops Pursue Iraqi Insurgents
text: BAGHDAD, June 20 —American troops continued their aggressively push today in Baquba, the capital of Diyala Province, in an effort to rid it of extremists believed to be part of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia.

headline: Some Colleges to Drop Out of U.S. News Rankings
text: ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 19 — The presidents of dozens of liberal arts colleges have decided to stop participating in the annual college rankings by U.S. News and World Report.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a picture caption in some copies on June 10 with an article about Ivory Coast’s political fragility misidentified a religious structure built in Yamoussoukro, the official capital, by Félix Houphouët-Boigny, the longtime president, whose death in 1993 helped to precipitate events that led to a civil war. It is a basilica, not a mosque. (Go to Article)

headline: For Julie Harris, a Stage to Call Her Own
text: WELLFLEET, Mass. — It doesn’t have a name yet, the large, earth-tone building that since last summer has risen out of the sand next to the cedar-shingled post office here, but that’s what you get when you ask Julie Harris if you can name a professional theater after her. Fortunately for the Wellfleet Harbor Actors Theater, Ms. Harris was open to compromise.

headline: For a Corrupt New York, a Lawman Who Fit In
text: Back when Times Square was young, the average New York policeman dealt with criminals in one of two ways. He applied his nightstick or held out his hand for a bribe. The nightstick work was often artistic, a subtle tap on the skull or the feet that sent a lightning bolt of pain straight through the system.

headline: Recipe: Cornmeal-Herb Dumplings
text: Salt 1 cup all-purpose flour 1 cup cornmeal 1 teaspoon baking powder 1/2 teaspoon kosher salt 1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper 2 tablespoons chopped mint 2 tablespoons chopped chives  1/2 cup buttermilk, more if needed 2 large eggs, beaten.

headline: Seeking a Souvenir of Those Mobsters You Hate to Love
text: The posting on Craigslist was vague, something about “set dressing” and a movie company and a sale. Cash only.

headline: Clash Nears in the Senate on Legislation Helping Unions Organize
text: WASHINGTON, June 19 — Senate Democratic leaders moved Tuesday to force a vote on organized labor’s top legislative priority, a bill that would make it far easier to organize workers. But Republican leaders vowed to kill the measure, voicing confidence that they could defeat a motion cutting off debate and bringing it to a vote this week.

headline: Sarkozy Reshuffles Cabinet After an Election Setback
text: PARIS, June 19  President Nicolas Sarkozy hastily altered his month-old government on Tuesday, adding women, ethnic minorities and members of rival parties to his cabinet.

headline: Beltrán Is Talking to Himself, but Is Still Muted at the Plate
text: Carlos Beltrán talked to himself in the batting cage yesterday, giving himself little reminders about what he should do. Stay back. See the ball. Hit the ball. Do not pull every pitch. He swung, then went back to talking to himself.

headline: Blackstone to Set a Stock Offering Price Sooner Than Expected
text: The wait for one of the most eagerly awaited initial public stock offerings of the year got a couple of days shorter yesterday.

headline: A Lesson That Thomas Could Teach
text: A typical Thomas the Tank Engine story is a little morality play about hubris. The stories take place on the fictional Island of Sodor, where train cars with faces and personalities go about their work.

headline: YouTube to Be Available in 7 Additional Languages
text: PARIS, June 19  After laboriously converting PayPal, the Internet payment service, for use in China a few years ago, Steve Chen swore that he would never go through another “localization” of a Web company.

headline: European Agency Backs In-Flight Calls
text: PARIS, June 19  European regulators have cleared the use of mobile phones and BlackBerry devices by airline passengers during flights, Airbus announced on Tuesday.

headline: Between Teacher and Student: The Suspicions Are Growing
text: TEANECK, N.J., June 13 — The accusation could not have been lodged against a more respected or popular educator: James Darden, an eighth-grade English teacher who was honored with a school assembly last year after winning a prestigious teaching award.

headline: Avenel: Girl Killed on Train Tracks
text: A 12-year-old girl was struck and killed by a New Jersey Transit train yesterday afternoon, railroad officials said. Dan Stessel, a spokesman for New Jersey Transit, said the transit police thought the girl, who was not identified, was playing with four or five friends on the tracks east of the Avenel Station. Mr. Stessel said the spot was near an overpass where Route 1 and 9 cross the tracks, but was not near any ground-level crossings. “The engineer sounded the horn and applied the emergency brakes, but was unable to stop in time,” he said. The girl was struck just before 2:30 by a train on its way from Hoboken to Bayhead. None of the 250 passengers were injured when the brakes were applied, Mr. Stessel said.

headline: Drunken Drivers May Face Two New Felony Charges
text: ALBANY, June 19  Gov. Eliot Spitzer and top lawmakers agreed Tuesday to toughen penalties for driving while intoxicated and to create a homicide charge aimed specifically at drunken drivers.

headline: North Korea Talks Likely to Resume Next Month
text: TOKYO, June 20 — The stalled six-nation talks over North Korea’s nuclear program are likely to resume next month after international nuclear inspectors visit North Korea next week, the chief United States negotiator said here today.

headline: A Graduate of Stanford by Way of a Transfer
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Viviana Alcazar hovered at her mother’s hospital bed, feeling the alternating tugs of ambition and obligation, knowing which one would prevail. It was late 2002, and she was a year into community college and daring to think of transferring to a university. Meanwhile, her mother, Elisa, had stomach cancer and was scheduled for an operation and chemotherapy and given a prognosis full of question marks.

headline: Tentative Budget Agreement Is Reached in Connecticut
text: STAMFORD, Conn., June 19  Averting a possible government shutdown, Democratic legislative leaders in Connecticut have shaken hands with the state’s Republican governor, M. Jodi Rell, on a budget for the coming fiscal year that provides more state money for education and health care while not increasing taxes on wealthier residents.

headline: Correction: A Rat With a Whisk and a Dream
text: An article last Wednesday about the animated film “Ratatouille” misstated the role of Brad Lewis. He is the producer, not the director.

headline: Sports Briefing
text: PRO BASKETBALL

headline: Enforcement of Calorie-Count Rule Is Delayed
text: In response to a federal lawsuit, New York City health officials said yesterday that they would wait three months before enforcing a new rule that requires most major fast-food and chain restaurants to prominently display calorie information on their menus.

headline: Carmela Got Gold Jewelry. Hillary Wants a White House.
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Tattoo Remorse: When the Thrill Is Gone (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pastry Chefs, Refusing to Be Sweet
text: TWO decades ago a pastry chef might have dreamed of stocking the cake trolley that was pushed around the carpeted dining room of a stodgy restaurant uptown.

headline: The Changing of the Guard at the Chelsea
text: Someone in the new management told Stanley Bard yesterday to stop hanging around the front desk of the Chelsea Hotel, which he has run for 50 years, more or less. He had come to work a bit later than his usual 5:30 a.m., but Mr. Bard, 73, does not have an actual job any more. He was shelved this week.

headline: In the Amazon, Giving Blood but Getting Nothing
text: KYOWÃ, Brazil — As the Karitiana Indians remember it, the first researchers to draw their blood came here in the late 1970s, shortly after the Amazon tribe began sustained contact with the outside world. In 1996, another team visited, promising medicine if the Karitiana would just give more blood, so they dutifully lined up again.

headline: Earliest Gunshot Victim in New World Is Reported
text: Archaeologists in Peru have uncovered the human skeleton of what they conclude is the earliest known gunshot victim in the New World.

headline: Player Silence on Concussions May Block N.F.L. Guidelines
text: CHICAGO, June 19  The National Football League gathered team medical personnel, members of its concussion research committee and several outside critics for a summit Tuesday that was roundly complimented as a candid discussion regarding brain injuries, specifically the decision on when a player who sustains a concussion may safely return to action.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (CBS) AFI’S 100 YEARS ... 100 MOVIES: 10TH ANNIVERSARY EDITION For the 10th year, the American Film Institute counts down the top 100 movies of all time as selected from 400 candidates by 1,500 leaders in the film industry, and adds some films from 1996 through 2006 to the ballot. New this year: “American Beauty,” “The Aviator,” “Brokeback Mountain,” “Lord of the Rings,” “The Matrix,” “Saving Private Ryan,” “Sideways” (above), “Traffic” and “Titanic.” The winners will be announced by celebrities including Tim Allen, Halle Berry, Peter Bogdanovich, Jeff Bridges, Laurence Fishburne, Peter Fonda, Harrison Ford, Dennis Hopper, Spike Lee, Shirley MacLaine, Liza Minnelli, Sydney Pollack, Martin Scorsese and M. Night Shyamalan. Morgan Freeman is host.

headline: Recipe: Bean Salads
text: 2 cups dried beans, split peas or lentils, sorted

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,517 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A sports article Monday about tense negotiations over the Big Ten Network’s placement on cable systems misstated the financial terms of a new 10-year contract that the Big Ten has with ESPN and ABC. It is worth $1 billion, or an average of $100 million a year — not a total of $100 million.

headline: Behind the Masks
text: Every war has THE picture that captures its essence, and the Palestinian civil war in Gaza is no exception. My nominee would be the photograph of a Hamas fighter in Gaza, lounging in a senior Fatah official’s office over which he had just taken control. The masked Hamas fighter in jeans is relaxing in an ornate chair, holding a rifle in one hand and speaking — through the opening in his mask — on a telephone in the other. It has the weird feel of a Gap ad for Halloween.

headline: Food Stuff
text: Mushrooms, Tame and Wild David Falkowski grows several kinds of mushrooms in a barn on the northern edge of the farm fields in Bridgehampton, N.Y., on land his father and grandfather farmed before him. He is devoted to organic farming, and his shiitakes and blue and king oyster mushrooms (all $20 a pound), which sprout from bark and straw, are sold at the farmer’s markets in Sag Harbor on Saturday mornings and East Hampton on Wednesday mornings.

headline: A Poetic Moment (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Police Sobriety Test Proposal Could Lead to a Showdown With Unions
text: The Police Department and leading police unions might be headed for a showdown over a proposal to administer sobriety tests to officers who shoot someone on or off duty.

headline: If Rules Change, Will Camembert Stay the Same?
text: CAMEMBERT, France

headline: Israel Lets Food and Medicine Enter Gaza to Avert Crisis
text: JERUSALEM, June 19 — Israel allowed 12 trucks of food and medical supplies to enter the Gaza Strip on Tuesday, Israeli officials and international aid representatives said, in an effort to avert a looming humanitarian crisis now that Hamas is in control.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
text: DETROIT RETHINKS ITS POSITION American automakers have reversed years of stalwart opposition to any legislation to increase fuel economy standards, and are now willing to accept a modest increase in mileage standards in the hopes of silencing calls for even tougher targets.

headline: New Rules for Undercover Cops
text: The fatal shooting of Sean Bell by undercover police officers on his wedding day last November revealed some serious problems with New York’s undercover police procedures. Commissioner Ray Kelly has wisely agreed to heed the recommendations of a panel of law enforcement experts to make changes, including requiring a breathalyzer test if an undercover cop shoots anyone.

headline: Barclays May Drop Symbol
text: LONDON, June 19 — Barclays, the British bank that is bidding for ABN Amro, is considering dropping its eagle logo because of concerns by ABN Amro that it could remind some clients of the Nazi regime, two people close to both banks said.

headline: Head of Budget Office Quits; Successor Is Chosen
text: WASHINGTON, June 19  President Bush accepted the resignation of Rob Portman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, on Tuesday, replacing him with Jim Nussle, a former Iowa congressman with a record of battling the Democrats on behalf of administration budget and tax priorities.

headline: Court Upholds Plavix Patent
text: A federal district judge in Manhattan upheld the patent on the anti- clotting drug Plavix yesterday, removing a weighty uncertainty for Bristol-Myers Squibb and Sanofi-Aventis, the companies that market the widely used product.

headline: Court Upholds Patent on Plavix
text: A federal judge in Manhattan today upheld the patent on the anticlotting drug Plavix, good news for the companies that co-market the blockbuster product, Bristol-Myers Squibb and Sanofi-Aventis.

headline: Home Depot Agrees to Sell Supply Unit
text: Home Depot agreed today to sell its Home Depot Supply Unit to a group of private equity firms for more than $10.3 billion. Members of the consortium — Bain Capital, the Carlyle Group and Clayton, Dubilier & Rice — will take an equal stake in the company.

headline: Mike Wallace: The Grid, Yellow Fever and Real Estate
text: Here is the latest installment from Mike Wallace, the historian and author of “Gotham,” who took questions from readers this week. He will post more answers on Friday, but he is not accepting any new questions.

headline: Attention Bangkok shoppers
text: Shopaholics in Asia never have to travel very far to reach a gleaming shopping mall. But nothing quite beats the mile-long strip of 6 large shopping centers in central Bangkok connected by an outdoor walkway. The “skywalk” as it’s called opened two years ago but is not publicized and few foreign visitors seem to know about it.The “Skywalk” is open from 6am to midnight

headline: The Next Prince Fielder
text: I think I just met him. His name is Jackson Holliday and he’s 3 years old.

headline: 36 Hours in Paradise
text: A weekend in Bali, what could be the perfect tropical retreat.

headline: The Wellcome Collection
text: Additional images from the Wellcome Collection in London.

headline: Water and Wine in Portugal
text: A look inside the Quinta da Carolina and its vineyards in the Douro region of Portugal.

headline: The sky’s the limit
text: The house may be a fixer-upper but Park Place outside London reportedly has been snapped up for a mere £42 million — or about $84 million.

headline: Fishing and Fashion in Aveiro
text: Although it isn’t the provincial place it once was, this Portuguese fishing town still has plenty of traditional charm.

headline: Here, There and Everywhere
text: The hippie revival has little of the impetus that drove the first wave, if you can remember those times.

headline: An Emotional Debate Before the Passage of a Marriage Bill
text: Members of the State Assembly debated a bill legalizing same-sex marriage on Tuesday night in speeches that were emotional but not angry. The bill eventually passed, 85-61, and now goes to the State Senate, where the Republican leadership vows it will die.

headline: Barclays May Drop Eagle Symbol if ABN Deal Goes Through
text: Barclays, the British bank that is bidding for ABN Amro, is considering dropping its eagle logo because of concerns by ABN Amro that it could remind some clients of the Nazi regime, The New York Times reported.

headline: Royal Philips Turns On $688 Million Light Deal
text: Royal Philips Electronics said Tuesday it was offering about $688 million for Color Kinetics, a lighting company based in Boston, with the support of the company’s management. Philips, based in Amsterdam, is the world’s largest lighting company, while Color Kinetics makes light-emitting diode systems for professionals.

headline: With Zenter Deal, Google Makes Its Own PowerPoint
text: Google has acquired an online slide presentation company, Zenter, filling out its web-based office software portfolio with an application similar to Microsoft‘s popular PowerPoint.

headline: Digital Single-Lens Reflex Cameras Are Put to the Test
text: David Pogue tests a few of the latest digital S.L.R.s.

headline: Black’s Lawyers Hammer Former Partner’s Testimony
text: It was an enormous betrayal by his former associates – and not any act of criminal fraud – that led Conrad M. Black to the Chicago courtroom where, if convicted, he could face the rest of his days in prison, lawyers for the media baron said in their closing arguments.

headline: V.C.’s Shower Advent Solar With Cash
text: A solar cell and module maker Advent Solar, said on Tuesday it had secured more than $70 million in a series D funding to ramp up production at its four-month old production facility.

headline: Visage Gets Cash to Help Start-Ups Avoid Amp’d Pitfalls
text: Despite some high-profile setbacks in its target market of mobile virtual network operators, Visage Mobile closed a $10 million fifth round of venture capital, bringing total investment in the six-year-old company to more than $80 million to enhance boost its subscriber management services.

headline: Candover Hunts the Netherlands’ Stork
text: The Dutch conglomerate Stork is in talks with London buyout shop Candover regarding a possible takeover worth about 1.45 billion euros ($1.9 billion).

headline: Investcorp Closes New Private Equity Fund
text: Investcorp said Tuesday it had held the first closing of a new private equity pool at $620 million. Officials from Investcorp declined to comment beyond the firm’s announcement about the vehicle, Investcorp Private Equity 2007 Fund LP, but The Deal.com reported that the pool has a $1 billion target.

headline: Lehman Plans $500 Million Private Equity I.P.O.
text: Lehman Brothers said on Wednesday it plans to raise $500 million in an initial public offering of a fund that will invest in a pool of private equity funds. Lehman Brothers Private Equity Partners is set to launch on the Euronext in Amsterdam in late July.

headline: Petrochina Seeks $6 Billion in Shanghai Share Sale
text: PetroChina is planning the nation’s biggest share sale this year to raise as much as $6 billion in Shanghai for overseas acquisitions, increased oil drilling and refinery construction.

headline: Bailout for Bear Stearns Fund Said to Lose Support
text: An effort to save a troubled hedge fund at Bear Stearns hit a major hurdle Tuesday when Merrill Lynch signaled that it would move forward with plans to auction $850 million in subprime securities that had been held as collateral, The New York Times reported.

headline: Symbion Says Yes to Buyout Firms
text: Symbion Health, an Australian health care company, accepted a new, higher bids for its vitamins and pharmacy businesses, paving the way for a buyout of the company for 2.8 billion Australian dollars ($2.4 billion). Ironbridge Capital and Archer Capital matched a rival bid by Sigma Pharmaceuticals to clinch the Melbourne-based company’s recommendation, according to a statement to the Australian Stock Exchange Wednesday.

headline: Ousted Fannie Mae Chief Accuses Regulator of Hiding Inquiry Details
text: Franklin Raines, the ousted chief executive of Fannie Mae, said regulators are withholding documents that may show a deliberate attempt to drive down the mortgage-finance company’s stock.

headline: In Managing Money for the Rich, UBS Comes Out on Top
text: UBS, the biggest money manager for the wealthy, widened its lead over Citigroup and Merrill Lynch last year as rising stock markets attracted new funds, according to consulting firm Scorpio Partnership.

headline: Whole Foods Chief’s Memo Ignites War of the Words
text: When the Federal Trade Commission announced its decision this month to try to block the $565 million merger of Whole Foods Market and Wild Oats Markets, the move left some analysts and industry observers scratching their heads.

headline: BofA Chief Says Flood of Easy Credit to Continue, for Now
text: As Bank of America‘s chief executive, Kenneth Lewis, sees it, private-equity firms will enjoy “unprecedented” access to financing for at least a few more years before a deal “goes bad” — but that his own firm has begun to reconsider private-euity loans.

headline: Behind Blackstone’s Rush to Market
text: The wait for one of the most eagerly awaited initial public stock offerings of the year got a couple of days shorter Tuesday. The Blackstone Group will price its initial offering Thursday night, according to the Web site of Morgan Stanley, one of the underwriters. The offering was originally scheduled to begin sometime next week.

headline: BofA’s Former Finance Chief to Join Cerberus
text: As financial services becomes a hot sector for leveraged buyouts, Cerberus Capital Management has hired a longtime bank executive to run the division in charge of those businesses. Alvaro de Molina, formerly Bank of America‘s chief financial officer, will run that unit, a Cerberus spokesman confirmed to Financial News.

headline: Morgan Stanley’s Profits Rise, Defying Subprime Slump
text: Morgan Stanley, appearing to rise above the mortgage-related woes that have hurt some of its rivals, said Wednesday that its net income increased 40 percent in the latest quarter.

headline: He’s No Longer a Lame Duck, but Will He Fly?
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s announcement last night that he was leaving the Republican Party and becoming a political independent made headlines across the country and was a front-page article in The Washington Post, The Boston Globe and other national and regional newspapers.

headline: After Shake-Up, What Now for Yahoo?
text: As industry watchers tried to divine whether Yahoo would be put in play following the the resignation of Terry S. Semel as the Internet giant’s chief executive, The New York Times suggested that another radical proposition is being whispered inside and outside the company: stop trying to beat Google at its own game.

headline: Insider Trading Goes Global
text: The story of Ajaz Rahim, a former executive at Faysal Bank in Pakistan, and his friend Hafiz Muhammad Zubair Naseem, a Credit Suisse banker who American prosecutors allege provided Mr. Rahim with insider information for stock trades, is a timeless tale of hubris and aspiration.

headline: L.A. Police Chief Wins 2nd Term
text: Commissioner William J. Bratton has received a new vote of confidence at the Los Angeles Police Department as investigations simmer away concerning his officers’ harsh tactics at an immigration protest.

headline: New York, New York (and New York)
text: A Quinnipiac University poll taken days ago — before Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s announcement last night that he was leaving the Republican Party — found that in a three-way race, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton would win 43 percent of voters statewide, followed by former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani with 29 percent and Mayor Bloomberg with 16 percent.

headline: Madison Dearborn to Buy Nuveen for $5.75 Billion
text: Nuveen Investments, a money manager catering to wealthy investors, agreed on Wednesday to be acquired by a group led by Madison Dearborn Partners for about $5.75 billion, as private equity finds itself plunging deeper into financial-services deals.

headline: 2008: It’s Bloomberg’s Day
text: With a trip through California this week that has resembled a political campaign swing and an announcement late Tuesday that he is leaving the Republican party, New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg has managed to fuel rumors that he is edging closer to a run for president even as he reiterates that he has no plans to do so.

headline: The Revolution Will Be Monopolized
text: This is still CNN: Joshua Levy, co-founder of the blog techPresident, which tracks the role of the Web in the 2008 campaign, is disappointed by the rules for the two presidential debates co-sponsored by CNN and YouTube (the first one will feature the Democratic candidates next month in Charleston, S.C.). Because all of the questions will come from YouTube videos created by Internet users, the debate is being advertised as “a revolution in citizen participation in presidential politics,” Levy notes.

headline: Ex-Poet Laureate on Guantánamo Poetry
text: The imminent publication of a book of poetry gets front page treatment in The Wall Street Journal today. “Poems From Guantánamo: The Detainees Speak” gives readers “an unusual glimpse into the emotional lives of the largely nameless and faceless prisoners there,” the paper explains.

headline: Rybka Wins World Computer Championship. Bring on Deep Junior?
text: Rybka ran away from the field to win the 15th World Computer Chess Championship in Amsterdam from June 11 to 18. The championship was organized by the International Computer Games Association. Final standings and games can be found here at the ICGA’s Web site.

headline: Kerkorian Drops Pursuit of MGM Casinos
text: The billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian has withdrawn his efforts to acquire two of MGM Mirage‘s top Las Vegas properties, the casino operator said on Wednesday. Mr. Kerkorian, MGM’s largest shareholder, had been pursuing the Bellagio (where he likes to stay when he’s in town) and the City Center, but told the company’s board Tuesday that his Tracinda vehicle was pulling its offer.

headline: Clinton Gets Better Reception on Iraq
text: Here’s a totally unscientific but not unimportant measure of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s evolution from Iraq war supporter to antiwar partisan in the last year: She was booed more lightly and gently at this morning’s Take Back America gathering of liberal activists than she was a year ago.

headline: A Less Tragic Ending to ‘Romeo and Juliet’
text: The thunderstorm that swept the metropolitan area on Tuesday night brought airports to a grinding halt, but it saved the lives of Romeo and Juliet. Flights at La Guardia, Kennedy and Newark-Liberty Airports were delayed for three to five hours starting in the early evening. At the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, it began pouring at the end of the fourth act of “Romeo and Juliet” at Shakespeare in the Park, right after Juliet drank the fake poison. Camryn Manheim, who plays the nurse, said in an interview, “I thought we’ll keep going,” expecting to finish the play “even if lightning strikes us.”

headline: Domestic Violence Spending: Reactive, Not Preventive?
text: In 2005, New York City’s domestic violence hot line took almost 125,000 calls; the police recorded more than 226,000 domestic violence situations (about 620 per day); and 68 people were killed by family members — accounting for almost 13 percent of all homicides.Those facts come from a new report [pdf] by the city’s Independent Budget Office. The human toll of domestic violence is readily apparent; the purpose of the report is to estimate the financial impact of domestic violence on the city.

headline:
Living with Music:
A Playlist by Darcey Steinke
text: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for “Living With Music,” a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage. Why? Because books and music, on good days, just seem to go together. And because the “celebrity playlists” on iTunes never get around to asking writers to pitch in.

headline: ‘I am listening with all I am’
text: Christian Wiman – an occasional contributor to The Book Review, and a poet, critic, essayist and the recently-married editor of Poetry magazine – writes about his battle with incurable cancer of the blood in the new issue of The American Scholar. It’s a devastating essay about poetry, about falling in love, about grief and about faith.

headline: Dare We Speculate … Mayor Gotbaum?
text: Paging some election lawyers … we’re a bit confused.

headline: Delphi and UAW May Announce Deal Today, Report Says
text: Delphi and the United Auto Workers union are expected to announce as early as Wednesday a tentative labor agreement that could move Delphi, the nation’s largest auto supplier, closer to emerging from bankruptcy, The Detroit Free Press reported, citing unnamed hourly workers and people close to the negotiations.

headline: Blackstone Holds Firm on I.P.O. Price
text: Last week’s surprise out of Washington — a bill that could jack up the tax rate for publicly traded private equity firms — does not seem to be much of a concern for the Blackstone Group‘s underwriters. Or Fortress Investment Group‘s shareholders, for that matter.

headline: Quality Soccer Talent North of the 49th Parallel
text: Correction Appended.

headline: Morgan Stanley Raises $8 Billion Real Estate Fund
text: Morgan Stanley has added to its real estate ambitions, announcing Wednesday that it has raised $8 billion to invest in the field and intending to spend almost half of that in Japan. With those funds, the investment bank has now raised the world’s largest global real estate fund, according to Bloomberg News — topping rivals like the Blackstone Group, which took private Equity Office Properties, the nation’s largest office landlord.

headline: In the Role of David, Introducing Guadeloupe
