text: While the Gold Cup semifinal between the United States and Canada is virtually devoid of controversy or sensation, Thursday night's other semifinal at Soldier Field, Mexico vs. Guadeloupe, is positively overflowing with commotion.

headline: Audit Cites Sluggish Governors Island Project
text: Updated, 9:06 p.m. June 25

headline: Rise of the Carborgs
text: In the third hour of a recent road trip, my friend Jay, who lives in Manhattan, brought up his Carborg Theory.

headline: In Praise of Proprietary Elitists
text: The prevailing orthodoxy in technology circles is that openness is not only good thing, but a winning strategy. Open innovation, we’re told, is the way of the future. Sharing, not hoarding, is the path to not only virtue but success.

headline: Satan's Circus
text: Original documents and images from the Charles Becker case.

headline: Correction
text: A front-page article on June 11 about the reaction of Mormons to the presidential candidacy of Mitt Romney, who is a Mormon, referred imprecisely to Mr. Romney's position on gay rights. While he opposes gay marriage and civil unions, the article should not have said he has embraced an "anti-gay agenda."

headline: Correction
text: An article in Business Day yesterday about a federal court decision that upheld the patent on Plavix, a blood thinner marketed by Bristol-Myers Squibb and Sanofi-Aventis, misstated the potential financial damages that the Canadian drug maker Apotex might have to pay the companies for selling a generic version last year. The potential damages could be $500 million to $600 million, not $500,000 to $600,000.

headline: High Noon for the Mayor
text: Live Blogging From the City Room

headline: The Limits of Early Polling
text: For at least a generation, press critics have complained bitterly about the news media's obsession with polls and the horse race aspect of the presidential campaign. The constant focus on who's ahead is a pointless distraction, those critics argue, from what should be the real substance of the campaign – such as what the candidates would do as president.

headline: Personal Carbon Allowances
text: An Emissary carbon credit card / courtesy of Designstream

headline: Goldman Sachs’s Emergency $50 Billion Stash
text: The troubles at Bear Stearns have shown that even bulge-bracket investment banks can find themselves in a jam when their investments go south. But Bear is just dealing with a troubled hedge fund — what would happen in a broader market collapse, or a worldwide liquidity crisis?

headline: The Limits of Early Polling
text: In her web column today, Robin Toner writes:

headline: Win a Lifetime in Congo
text: This win-a-trip journey is supposed to take weeks, but I’ve been a bit concerned that we might end up stuck here in our Congo hotel washing dishes for weeks. The problem is that you can’t use credit cards in Congo, of course, and so everything revolves around cash. I brought my supply of $100 bills, well secreted, but it turns out that nobody here takes U.S. currency from 1999 or earlier.

headline: Computer Glitch Briefly Grounds United
text: From the guy sitting two cubes away from The Lede, all the way to the International Space Station, ’tis the season for inexplicable computer meltdowns.

headline: Credit Suisse Adds to Investment Banking Team
text: There are two new managing directors in Credit Suisse‘s investment banking group. The firm said in an internal memo that Tom Delbrook, previously the vice president of finance at the shipping giant UPS, would join the firm’s general industrial and services group, covering the transportation, shipping and logistics industries out of New York.

headline: Darfur and Congo
text: I’ve often been asked why I write so much more about Darfur than Congo, since far more people have been killed in Congo. After all, fewer than half a million have probably died in Darfur, compared to 4 million in Congo.

headline: Your Comments on my Congo Column
text: My Thursday column is about a woman in an eastern Congo village whom we found, starving to death — a war casualty as much as any other. You can also find video about the case, and Will and Leana’s blogs about it, at www.nytimes.com/twofortheroad. Please post your comments here.

headline: McClatchy Considers Parting with CareerBuilder Stake
text: Beset by shrinking advertising revenues, newspaper companies have been flailing to find solutions to prop up their income. One solution that McClatchy, the company that bought Knight Ridder last year, is now entertaining: selling its stake in CareerBuilder, the job search Web site. McClatchy, one of the nation’s largest publishers, co-owns the site along with Tribune and Gannett.

headline: Without a Face
text: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman’s June 20 column, “Behind the Masks.”

headline: Which Way Out?
text: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman’s June 13 column, “Between Dust and Deliverance.”

headline: A Fourth Way to Peace
text: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman’s June 6 column, “What a Mess.”

headline: Marsh & McLennan: Too Expensive to Take Private?
text: Speculation is once again mounting that private equity firms are circling Marsh & McLennan, the big insurance conglomerate.

headline: L.S.E. Confirms Talks with Borsa Italiana
text: The London Stock Exchange may finally have found an acceptable partner: the stock market on Wednesday confirmed that it was in talks with Borsa Italiana of Milan about a possible merger. “London Stock Exchange Group PLC confirms that it is in discussions with Borsa Italiana SpA. to establish whether a merger of the two businesses can be agreed,” the exchange said.

headline: Romney-McCain: Turnabout
text: PALM BEACH, Fla. — The McCain campaign has taken delight this year in highlighting Mitt Romney’s shifting stances on abortion, immigration, and several other issues. So the Romney campaign was quick to note an apparent shift by John McCain.

headline: After Nuveen, Who’s Next?
text: Have private equity firms found a new place to spend their overflowing buyout funds?

headline: Held ‘Hostage’ in a Gridlocked Albany
text: With Albany lawmakers about a day and a half away from their political drop-dead point – the session is officially scheduled to close at 5 p.m. on Thursday – the proverbial horns of the State Legislature remain tightly locked.

headline: I am Rachel Carson
text: Rachel Louise Carson was born 100 years ago, in 1907, and her classic “Silent Spring” (1962) turns 45 this year. Tributes have been popping up everywere.

headline: Plans, Glorious Plans
text: When the package arrived in the mail, it seemed like an unexpected present.Inside was something wonderful: The large-format renderings of our dream home from Allison Ramsey Architects. Up until this point, we had been viewing the plans on our computer or on printouts. They were serviceable, but hardly exciting.

headline: Bloomberg Says He’s Not a Candidate …
text: It’s just 925 days and about 10 hours until Michael R. Bloomberg’s second term as mayor of New York is over, but who’s counting?

headline: To Treat or Not to Treat
text: Not everyone approved when we took Yohanita, a severely malnourished woman, from her village to the hospital. Dr. Lisa Dillabaugh, a Pediatrics resident, posted an opposing view:

headline: Mike Wallace: Creative Uses for Governors Island
text: Here is the latest installment from Mike Wallace, the historian and author of “Gotham,” who took questions from readers. He will post more answers on Friday, but he is not accepting any new questions.

headline: The Week Ahead
text: Alison Smale, of the International Herald Tribune, discusses the events in the world this week.

headline: Goldman Raises $4 Billion for New Property Fund
text: Et tu, Goldman Sachs?

headline: Rebels With a Cause
text: Jeffrey Gettleman travels with the Ogaden National Liberation Front, a  separatist rebel movement in eastern Ethiopia.

headline: Romeo and Juliet in the Park
text: Melena Ryzik of The Times reports on the Public Theater's party for Shakespeare in the Park.

headline: Figuring the Bloomberg Factor
text: Bloomberg, good for the Democrats? First Read, the blog of the NBC News political unit, speculates that a Michael Bloomberg presidential candidacy would help the Democratic nominee in November 2008: “Why? It’s simple — the South. The irony of a Bloomberg candidacy is that it could make the Democrats more competitive in the South because their 35 percent base vote in the South is made up of die-hard Democrats.”

headline: Nintendo Deals With Good Versus Wiivil
text: The familiar lines of debate over video games and violence are front and center again after Britain’s banning of “Manhunt 2,” but Nintendo’s Wii may be changing the landscape.

headline: How to Succeed in New York
text: Wikipedia lists more than 1,200 people in the line of succession to the British throne. The line of succession to the United States presidency includes 18 titles, from the vice president to the secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, the most recently created Cabinet-level department.

headline: Update on Yohanita
text: We went back to HEAL Africa to visit Yohanita, the 41-year old woman we had found in the village of Malehe to be suffering from infection and severe malnutrition. I was relieved to see that she was lying in bed, fully conscious, and able to speak in full sentences. Feza, the girl who came down from the village, was at her bedside and feeding her some porridge and potatoes, which Yohanita was eating in big spoonfuls.

headline: Report Says E.P.A. Misled Public About Indoor Air Hazards of 9/11
text: Federal environmental officials misled Lower Manhattan residents about the extent of contamination in their condominiums and apartments after the collapse of the World Trade Center, according to a preliminary report released today by the Government Accountability Office.According to the report, which was made public during a Senate subcommittee hearing in Washington, the Environmental Protection Agency did not accurately report the results of a residential cleanup program in 2002 and 2003. More than 4,000 apartments in Lower Manhattan were professionally decontaminated in that program, and the agency reported that only a “very small” number of air samples taken in those residences showed unsafe levels of asbestos.

headline: McCain Plays Down the Money Chase
text: PALM BEACH, Fla. — Senator John McCain acknowledged here today that fundraising has “been very tough,’’ but said that his brand of retail politics does not demand huge sums of money this early in the campaign.

headline: Dow Jones’ Board Takes Lead in News Corp. Talks
text: In the latest twists in the Dow Jones saga, the company said on Wednesday that its board of directors has taken the lead in negotiating with Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation. The move may push the publisher of The Wall Street Journal closer and faster to a sale.

headline: Blogtalk: All About Bloomberg
text: When it comes to New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg and whether he’ll actually make a bid for the White House, the only point of agreement among some prominent bloggers is that the billionaire mayor has the resources to mount a serious campaign.

headline: Fear
text: I can hear the music pulsating in the thick Congo night, inviting me. “Come over, dance, drink, have a good time, enjoy life.” But I am scared to leave the hotel at night.

headline: Merrill Kicks Off Auction for Assets in Bear Stearns Fund
text: The fate of Bear Stearns‘ beleaguered subprime-securities hedge fund was up in the air Wednesday afternoon, as at least one major lender has begun auctioning off its collateral.

headline: The Rule of the Decent Interval
text: Call me shallow, but I am fond of those little extemporaneous rules, like Murphy’s Law or the Peter Principle, that allow us to recognize and ridicule familiar patterns of social behavior. And I’d like to propose one of my own.

headline: One Year Later: My Real Father’s Day
text: I have never cried much. In fact, I could probably count on one hand how many times I had really cried, as an adult, up until the time I came home from Iraq. During my tour, I couldn’t even shed a tear at my mom’s memorial service. I felt cold and numb because of everything going on around me. Not callous, just gifted at compartmentalizing emotions. I’ve cried more in the last year than I have in a lifetime. But here’s the catch. They have all been tears of joy, in moments where I am simply overwhelmed and feel so very lucky to be home with my kids.

headline: Yahoo Good, Google Better (a Lot Better)
text: It’s become a monthly ritual with few surprises. Web audience measuring firms report numbers for Web search traffic in the United States. Yahoo does well. Google does a lot better. Microsoft and others barely hold on, or worse.

headline: ‘I Do Not Wish to Enroll in a Party’
text: See the voter registration form Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg submitted to the City Board of Elections for yourself.

headline: ‘The Only Reason to Run for President Is to Win’
text: This evening, the NewsHour with Jim Lehrer broadcast excerpts from an interview Judy Woodruff conducted on Tuesday in Los Angeles with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa of Los Angeles. The interview occurred before Mr. Bloomberg’s surprise announcement that he was leaving the Republican Party.In the interview, Ms. Woodruff asked the mayor why he would not run for president as an independent, and he replied, “You don’t have to run for president to get the issues out there. The only reason to run for president is to win and be president and to try to affect not just dialogue, but try to change things.”

headline: Remember to Stay Home
text: Just a travel advisory:This year’s E3, the annual garish neon-drenched video game industry trade show, is a shadow of its former self. And you’re not invited.The show used to take place at the Los Angeles Convention Center in May and was a take-all-comers, lavish show with lots of booth babes and millions spent by the major video game companies to promote their latest technology and products.

headline: Q & A: Sarah Jessica Parker
text: A few years ago you could dismiss an actor for attempting to put his or her name on anything other than a movie or a TV show. Two bullet-proof exceptions were Paul Newman (spaghetti sauce) and Elizabeth Taylor (perfume). They had, in addition to talent and looks, a massive store of goodwill with the American people that exempted them from scorn. Now, all the roles have been if not quite reversed then shuffled: average Joes get to become divas (thanks to “American Idol”), musicians are statesmen (Bono), designers are artists (Hedi Slimane), bloggers are the new tastemakers, and actors are making jeans. Actors have a hard time winning our approval as designers, in part because the new tastemakers can so readily make them the object of our contempt (I cite the catalog of red-carpet disasters on Go Fug Yourself), and in part because we suspect that the mastery of one craft doesn’t presume an ability to master another without demeaning both.

headline: They Both Start With “P”
text: Oliver Perez is not much of a basketball fan. But he was sitting alone on a clubhouse couch at about 5:30, watching on ESPN Classic the replay of Game 6 of the 1993 N.B.A. Finals. The Chicago Bulls clinched their third consecutive championship that night in Phoenix, and the big shot, a three-pointer by John Paxson, came with 3.9 seconds left. Perez looked as if he had never seen it before, and he said, “Wow” over and over and over again.

headline: Six Degrees of Mike Gallego
text: When Derek Jeter joined the Yankees, he was given No. 2 — probably, he guesses, because he was skinny and it was the smallest jersey size. The last player to wear it before him was infielder Mike Gallego.

headline: Win a Trip: Photos of Hope
text: Will Okun, who is traveling with Nicholas D. Kristof in Africa, discussed his photographic style.

headline: Congressman’s Brother Is Said to Have Bribed School Official
text: NEW ORLEANS, June 20  The former president of the Orleans Parish School Board pleaded guilty in federal court on Wednesday to taking $140,000 in bribes from a political operative thought to be the older brother of Representative William J. Jefferson, who has been indicted on bribery charges.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about the bombing of a Sunni Arab mosque near the southern Iraqi city of Basra misstated the name of the mosque. (The error was repeated in an article on Sunday about violence in Iraq.) It is the Talha Bin Obeidallah Mosque, not Talha Bin al-Zubair.

headline: Bronx: Woman Guilty in Son’s Death
text: A Bronx mother has pleaded guilty to manslaughter for failing to obtain medical attention for her 4-year-old son after he was beaten by her live-in boyfriend, prosecutors said yesterday. The mother, Aleshia Smith, 28, admitted in State Supreme Court on Tuesday that she had “recklessly caused the death” of her son, Quachaun Browne, in January 2006 by not immediately seeking medical help, the Bronx district attorney’s office said. Ms. Smith will be sentenced to 2 ½ to 7 ½ years in prison in July, prosecutors said. The boyfriend, Jose Calderon, 19, has pleaded not guilty to murder charges. Prosecutors said Mr. Calderon beat the child over a period of several days because he had broken a television set.

headline: General Strike Over Rising Fuel Price Takes Hold in Nigerian Cities
text: LAGOS, Nigeria, June 20  Shop shutters stayed bolted and young men played soccer on roads that were usually choked with traffic as the first day of an indefinite general strike and fuel shortages brought cities across Nigeria to a hush on Wednesday.

headline: Democratizing the Nation’s Capital
text: Just in time for next month’s rockets’ red glare, a measure to give the residents of Washington D.C. their long-denied right to a full vote in the House of Representatives is making headway in the Senate. The legislation, already passed by the House, is gaining unexpected support from Senate Republicans finally struck by the injustice of the meeting place of democracy being denied its democratic right.

headline: U.S. Is Urging Blair to Be Lead Mideast Envoy
text: WASHINGTON, June 20 — The United States is pressing Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain to become a special envoy to the Middle East, representing the diplomatic “quartet” of world powers, administration officials said Wednesday.

headline: Health Coverage for All Americans (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: London Weighs In on ‘Rings’
text: Mixed reviews greeted “The Lord of the Rings, ” a $25 million musical, after it opened on Tuesday at the Theater Royal in London, The Associated Press reported. Billed as the most expensive production in West End history, the show, revised from a version that drew a mixed response in Toronto in 2006, received enthusiastic notices from The Times of London (a “wonder”) and The Guardian, but The Financial Times said it could not “muster a single memorable tune,” and Charles Spencer of The Daily Telegraph said, “Its run, I fear, will be nasty, brutish and short.”

headline: Space Shuttle to Stay in Orbit Another Day
text: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla., June 21 — The space shuttle Atlantis will stay in orbit another day. Mission managers called off both landing opportunities this afternoon because of rain showers within 35 miles of the landing runway here.

headline: Bronx: Man Dies as He Flees Police
text: A Bronx man fell to his death on Tuesday night as he tried to escape through a window when police officers arrived at his door with an arrest warrant, the police said yesterday. The man, James Harris, 42, of 1900 Grand Concourse, was pronounced dead at the scene. The police said that Mr. Harris was being sought on charges of trademark counterfeiting and that he tried to escape when officers knocked on the door of his fourth-floor apartment.

headline: Up to 5 Are Missing in Flooded Catskill Town
text: Rescue workers searched frantically yesterday for as many as five people reported missing in the southern Catskill town of Colchester after flash floods washed away several homes, a dozen vehicles and a bridge, state and local officials said.

headline: How the U.S. Has Kept the Productivity Playing Field Tilted to Its Advantage
text: Americans’ anxiety level over competitiveness with other nations has grown in recent years. A large number of Americans appear to believe that the United States will not be able to succeed in an open world market, and they argue in favor of reducing our exposure to the outside.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption in some copies on Sunday with a Sports of The Times column, about the success of famous players at the United States Open, included incorrect information from The Associated Press about the golfer shown hitting out of sand at the 1953 Open. It was an unidentified golfer; it was not Ben Hogan, who won the tournament. (Research by The Times and by The A.P. failed to produce an identification.)

headline: Brooklyn: Ex-Judge Ordered to Prison
text: An appeals court judge yesterday denied a stay of sentence for a former State Supreme Court justice convicted of corruption charges and ordered him to begin serving his 3-to-10-year prison term. The former judge, Gerald Garson, was convicted in April of accepting bribes to manipulate the outcome of matrimonial cases in his Brooklyn court. At his sentencing on June 5, Mr. Garson’s $15,000 bail was revoked, but his lawyers won a temporary reprieve that afternoon. They argued that Mr. Garson, 74 and ailing, should remain free while he appealed the verdict on the grounds that the evidence was insufficient. In documents filed with the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, Second Department, prosecutors argued that the verdict was supported by “overwhelming evidence,” and yesterday, in a one-page decision, Associate Justice Edward D. Carni revoked the temporary stay.

headline: Bell Canada Discussing a Merger With Western Provinces Carrier
text: OTTAWA, June 20  Bell Canada, the target of at least three possible privatization bids, said Wednesday that it was discussing a possible merger with Telus, the leading phone company in western Canada.

headline: Antonio Aguilar, 88, Ranchera Singer, Dies
text: MEXICO CITY, June 20 — Antonio Aguilar, the film star and ranchera singer who was considered the undisputed master of his genre for decades, died here on Tuesday. He was 88.

headline: T.G.I. Friday’s Finds Smaller Portions Add to Customer Traffic
text: Four months after it introduced smaller portions to its menu, T.G.I. Friday’s is finding that less food translates into more customers and, perhaps, bigger profits.

headline: William LeMessurier, 81, Structural Engineer, Dies
text: William J. LeMessurier, a structural engineer who became a hero to other structural engineers when he detected and repaired a potentially catastrophic flaw in the Citicorp building in Manhattan, died on June 14 in Casco, Me. He was 81.

headline: Senate Approves Stricter Fuel Standards for Autos
text: WASHINGTON, June 21 — The Senate voted this evening to raise fuel-economy requirements for cars and sport utility vehicles, demanding that they get 35 miles per gallon by 2020.

headline: Injured Schilling to Miss Two Starts
text: ATLANTA, June 20 — The Red Sox have carved out a large lead in the American League East largely because of a starting rotation that has for the most part stayed healthy. Aside from a blister that cost Josh Beckett two starts, the starters have hummed along and the team has received sensational late-inning relief from the rookie Hideki Okajima.

headline: Lack of References Subverts Brown’s Glowing Résumé
text: There were seven empty seats on the N.B.A. coaching carousel when it reached maximum velocity in late May. The whirling has nearly stopped, and six coaches have settled into place — one reliable old hand, two less-proven retreads and three virtual rookies.

headline: Pension Relief for Airlines Faulted by Some Legislators
text: A pension measure tucked into last month’s Iraq war spending bill is causing some leading members of Congress to complain that American Airlines got a break worth almost $2 billion without proper scrutiny.

headline: Japanese Company Donates Funds to Restore Munch Paintings
text: A Japanese company operating in Norway has pledged $670,000 toward the restoration of the Edvard Munch paintings “The Scream” and “Madonna,” above, damaged during a brazen daylight armed theft from the Munch Museum in Oslo in 2004, Agence France-Presse reported. The Oslo city authorities said the donation by Idemitsu Petroleum of Japan to the Munch Museum would be applied to restoration of, and research into, the two paintings, which were chipped, scratched, punctured and harmed by humidity, and are now undergoing repair. Three men suspected of participating in the robbery have been sentenced to prison and fined.

headline: Garden Q.&A.
text: Confused Bleeding Heart

headline: Mets’ Defensive Lapses Few and Far Between
text: Tom Glavine’s 8-year-old son, Peyton, was watching the Mets’ game Tuesday night and did not like what he saw. He asked his father why David Wright, after making his second error of the game, threw his glove in the dugout.

headline: Out of a Packing Box, Not Stuff, but Souls
text: I WAS initiated young into the cult of clutter. Opening a drawer in my childhood kitchen meant finding birthday cards sticky from a leaking pen, a recipe for moussaka never made, bits of yarn and a Hot Wheels car missing a door. Occasionally, my mother attempted organization by topic (Vacation Ideas, Children’s Vaccinations, Restaurants to Try), but she never got hanging files, so the folders slipped and slid over one another. Dad had a secretary at work to organize his papers, and at home he directed seasonal weekend purges that inevitably threw Barbies out with the bath water.

headline: An MP3 Player That Is Designed to Shake Up Music Listening
text: Music and food have always been compatible, which may be why a salt-shaker-shaped MP3 player sounds like fun. After all, the idea of shaking something to mix up the contents — in this case a music playlist — is something even a baby can understand. The $40 Sansa Shaker from SanDisk also comes with an onboard speaker, making it possible to share audio files with everyone at the table. It’s like a micro-size jukebox.

headline: Shiite Rivalries Slash at a Once Calm Iraqi City
text: DIWANIYA, Iraq — The Shiite heartland of southern Iraq has generally been an oasis of calm in contrast to Baghdad and the central part of the country, but now violence is convulsing this city. Shiites are killing and kidnapping other Shiites, the police force is made up of competing militias and the inner city is a web of impoverished streets where idealized portraits of young men, killed in recent gun battles with Iraqi and American troops, hang from signposts above empty lots.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on May 26 about Rochester’s economic decline referred imprecisely to the number of universities there and misstated the percentage change in population over the past three decades. There is one university, the University of Rochester, within the city limits, not six. (The other five are in suburban Rochester). The population decline was 26 percent, not 40 percent.

headline: China: Investment Fund Plans Bond Issue
text: The Chinese legislature plans a review next week of the Finance Ministry’s plans for a bond issue to raise money for a new state-run foreign investment fund, the government said. The fund agreed last month to acquire a nonvoting stake of nearly 10 percent in the Blackstone Group. By selling yuan-denominated bonds to buy foreign currency for overseas investments, the fund would be partly replacing similar bond sales and currency purchases conducted until now by the central bank. While Chinese officials have said that it is not their intention to drive down the value of the dollar, economists are waiting to see whether the new investment fund will allocate as much of its bond proceeds to dollar-denominated purchases as the central bank has; more than two-thirds of the $1.2 trillion in reserves managed by the central bank are thought to be in dollars.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,524 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q.What is the most economical way to wallpaper a room?

headline: Britain’s Private Equity Firms Try to Make the Case for Their Low Taxes
text: LONDON, June 20 — Executives from four large private equity firms went to Parliament on Tuesday and defended the low British tax rate imposed on their profits.

headline: A Prime Minister Cool to Culture Will Leave Behind a Hot Arts Scene
text: LONDON, June 20 — Over the past 10 years, while cultural innovation has seemingly been sparse in traditional creative breeding grounds like the United States and France, the arts have been flourishing in Britain. Never before have museums been so popular; not since the 1960s have artists, composers, playwrights, designers and the like enjoyed such prestige.

headline: Tricks Get Trickier, Raising Questions of Safety
text: Jeremy Stenberg has not competed in a freestyle motocross event since falling out of the sky during the Dew Tour last June in Louisville, Ky.

headline: Song That Comes From the Words of Friends
text: The composer David Del Tredici has written of three times during his career when he felt compelled to reject all he had been taught and rely on instincts — three times he had to, in a sense, come out.

headline: Another Step Toward Invisibility for the Cellphone Headset
text: Determining whether someone speaking into the air is on the phone or just a little odd is becoming harder.

headline: Justices Tighten Rules on Shareholder Suits
text: WASHINGTON, June 21 — The Supreme Court dealt a new blow today to investors suing companies over accusations of fraud when it set a higher standard to prevent the lawsuits from being dismissed.

headline: Egypt Arranges Peace Summit in Support of Abbas
text: GAZA, June 21 — In a gesture of support for Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah, Egypt has organized a summit meeting for him and the leaders of Jordan and Israel that is to take place on Monday, Israel announced today.

headline: Mini-Series Revisits the Yankees’ Melodrama During the Summer of ’77
text: LITTLE FALLS, N.J., June 20  Joe Grifasi was at the Yogi Berra Museum here Wednesday explaining his approach to portraying Berra in “The Bronx Is Burning,” the eight-part miniseries on ESPN that begins July 9.

headline: Report Warns of Risks in Federal Liens Notices
text: Federal government agencies have risked exposing millions of Social Security numbers to identity thieves by including the numbers in federal liens notices that are sent to local governments and are often made available over the Internet, federal investigators said in a report expected to be released today.

headline: Airport Tries to Rein In Greeters’ Generosity Toward Troops
text: BOSTON, June 20 — For several years, the Maine Troop Greeters have welcomed soldiers from every military transport plane that has landed at Bangor International Airport with hugs, handshakes, cookies and homemade goodies.

headline: Report Says U.S. Misled City on Dust From Ground Zero
text: WASHINGTON, June 20 — Federal environmental officials misled Lower Manhattan residents about the extent of contamination in their condominiums and apartments after the collapse of the World Trade Center, according to a preliminary report released on Wednesday by the Government Accountability Office.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on May 30 by The Associated Press about Barbara Cox Anthony, an heir to the Cox media fortune, incorrectly described her inheritance. And a correction in this space on Friday misattributed the error. Ms. Anthony and her sister, Anne Cox Chambers, and their older brother, James M. Cox Jr., all held equal interests in the company before the death of Mr. Cox in 1974, at which time the sisters received his share; they did not inherit the entire company from Mr. Cox. The error was introduced by an editor, not by The A.P.

headline: Around the Campfire, Global Ghost Stories
text: UNLIKE many parents, Maria Valero does not mind that her son Enrique spends hours on the Internet talking with friends. That is because Enrique, 12, and his family live in Caracas, Venezuela, and by sending instant messages to the American children he befriended during his summers at Mountain Camp, near Lake Tahoe in California, he keeps his English skills sharp.

headline: Republicans Losing the West
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.

headline: Gay Marriage, a Touchy Issue, Touches Legislators’ Emotions
text: ALBANY, June 20  Teresa R. Sayward did not hesitate when she rose from her seat on Tuesday night to address her colleagues in the State Assembly. An observant Catholic from a small, conservative upstate town, she had rarely shared the story of her son, Glenn, 42, and his struggle to come to terms with his gay identity decades ago.

headline: Napoleon’s Toothbrush Finally Has a Home
text: LONDON, June 20 — Self-made millionaires (or billionaires today) often acquire respectability by investing in great art. Then, at the appropriate time, they donate or bequeath it to museums willing to give their names to a gallery or wing.

headline: Next Week
text: Next week, Will Leitch of Deadspin.com makes his debut as a regular contributor to the PLAY e-mail newsletter, spinning his distinct brand of commentary on the oddities and follies of the sports world.

headline: New Delay for Passports Along Borders
text: WASHINGTON, June 20  The Bush administration on Wednesday postponed rules that would require passports for United States citizens re-entering the country by land or sea from Canada, Mexico, Bermuda or Caribbean countries.

headline: Fast, Dazzling, Large and Deluxe
text: PARIS, June 20 — The Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass is not the kind of guy who flies commercial. If his latest venture takes to the skies, he will not be the kind who flies subsonic either.

headline: Anger at Coach Fuels Racial Divide in Rural Colorado
text: LA JARA, Colo.  The photograph, of four popular high school students standing side by side, each clutching a gun in one hand and giving a stiff-armed Nazi salute with the other, terrified many people in La Jara and the surrounding poor farming communities of the San Luis Valley. Its discovery further intensified a bitter racial divide between supporters of a longtime coach, who is black, and a largely white group of students and their parents.

headline: World Business Briefing
text: ASIA

headline: Corrections: Kitchen Tales
text: An article last Thursday about six home kitchens misstated the age for Simone Leigh, an artist whose kitchen is decorated with found objects. She is 39, not 46. The article also misstated the location for Jill’s, a restaurant owned by Jill Pettijohn, whose home kitchen was featured. It is in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, not Red Hook.

headline: U.S. Holds Direct Talks in North Korea on Arms
text: TOKYO, June 21 — The United States’ chief nuclear negotiator began a surprise two-day visit to North Korea today, saying he wanted to speed up six-nation talks aimed at dismantling North Korea’s nuclear program.

headline: For the Record
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on June 11 about the dedication of Cole Porter’s childhood home in Peru, Ind., as a bed and breakfast and museum, referred imprecisely to the financing of the restoration of the house. It was financed by tax-deductible funds accepted by the Ole Olsen Memorial Theater in Peru, not by the theater’s own funds.

headline: Toby Keith’s ‘Big Dog’ Is No. 1
text: Toby Keith is No. 1 on the Billboard chart this week with “Big Dog Daddy” (Show Dog Nashville), though in what has become a familiar pattern for the music industry, record sales were low across the board. “Big Dog Daddy” sold 204,000 copies in its first week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The Brooklyn rapper Fabolous reached No. 2 this week with his new “From Nothin’ to Somethin’ ” (Def Jam), selling 159,000 copies. Paul McCartney’s “Memory Almost Full” (Hear Music) remained at No. 3 with 107,000, a decline of 34 percent from last week. DJ Khaled’s new “We the Best” (Koch) reached No. 8, and “The Traveling Wilburys Collection” (Rhino) opened at No. 9.

headline: City Mourns Firefighters and 9 Lost on the Job: Fathers, Mentors, Friends
text: CHARLESTON, S.C., June 20 — Technically, Art Wittner had the day off. But as the last surviving member of the Monday night shift from his firehouse, Station 16, he could not think of staying away from work.

headline: Hail to the Teacher (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lilly, Matriarch of U.S. Team, Refuses to Fade to Gray
text: CLEVELAND, June 15  The other day, a visitor suggested to Kristine Lilly that she might have a pair of jeans older than some of her teammates on the United States women’s soccer team.

headline: Coria Settles With Company He Claims Made a Bad Pill
text: Guillermo Coria, a professional tennis player from Argentina, reached a settlement in a New Brunswick, N.J., court yesterday with the supplement manufacturer that he said made a contaminated multivitamin that led to a positive steroid test six years ago.

headline: PGA Tour Moves Closer to Adopting Drug Policy
text: Tim Finchem, the commissioner of the PGA Tour, said yesterday that the organization may institute a policy on performance-enhancing drugs, including testing, by the end of the year.

headline: Grown-Up Films Vie for Viewers in Summer
text: LOS ANGELES, June 19 — When Gary Palmucci, the general manager of a small New York film distributor, was picking a date to release “Lady Chatterley,” a buzzed-about French retelling of the steamy D. H. Lawrence story, he knew he wanted to open the movie in the summer.

headline: No, Despite the Polls, It’s Not Really a Horse Race (Not Yet, Anyway)
text: For at least a generation, press critics have complained bitterly about the news media’s obsession with polls and the horse-race aspect of the presidential campaign. The constant focus on who is ahead is a pointless distraction, those critics argue, from what should be the real substance of the campaign, like what the candidates would do as president.

headline: As National Candidate, Bloomberg Would Have to Multitask
text: It seemed to be no coincidence that the day after he announced his formal departure from the Republican Party and left open the door to an independent presidential campaign, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg mundanely announced yesterday that the city’s 311 customer service telephone line had received its 50 millionth call.

headline: Congress Weighs End to Private Equity Tax Break
text: Leaders of the tax-writing committees in Congress are considering a new proposal to end a little-known tax break that has allowed wealthy financiers who run private equity firms and hedge funds to cut their total income tax bills by billions of dollars, aides to lawmakers say.

headline: Jones Faces Felony Charges in Las Vegas
text: Already serving a one-year suspension from the National Football League, Pacman Jones will face two felony charges stemming from a strip club disturbance in February that led to three people being shot.

headline: Trenton: Lesbians File Discrimination Complaint
text: Two lesbians from Ocean Grove have filed a complaint with the New Jersey Division on Civil Rights, claiming that the Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association, a Methodist organization, illegally discriminated against them when it denied their request to rent the boardwalk pavilion for their civil union ceremony in September. In the complaint, filed on Tuesday, the women, Harriet Bernstein and Luisa Paster, note that the pavilion is regularly used for weddings of heterosexual couples. The division will investigate to see if there is sufficient evidence of discrimination; if so, the case will be referred to an administrative law judge. Compiled by John Sullivan

headline: Once Again, Yankees’ Bats Are Stifled by Rockies
text: DENVER, June 20 — The Yankees came here as the hottest team in the American League. With their rollicking offense in the thin air of Colorado against a traditional also-ran, the Yankees had reason to believe they would thrive at Coors Field.

headline: Giambi Is Likely to Meet With Mitchell
text: Jason Giambi of the Yankees is expected to announce today that he will cooperate with former Senator George J. Mitchell’s investigation into the use of performance-enhancing substances in Major League Baseball.

headline: Late-Session Measures Stir Scrutiny and Skepticism
text: ALBANY, June 20  A torrent of bills and amendments are swirling through the halls of the Capitol as the legislative session here comes to a close. Some are big bills, like campaign finance or same-sex marriage legislation, loudly debated and widely pondered. Some are small bills, often championed by a lone and lonely lawmaker, like a proposal to name the Concord the official state grape.

headline: Oxfam Suggests Benefit in Africa if U.S. Cuts Cotton Subsidies
text: Eliminating billions of dollars in federal subsidies to American cotton growers each year would reduce American cotton production and exports, raise world prices by about 10 percent and modestly improve the incomes of millions of poor cotton farmers in Africa, according to a new study by Oxfam, the aid group.

headline: 50 Years of Heavy Reading, and Looking for More
text: LONG BEACH, N.Y., June 15 — The longest-running book club in this Long Island beach community may be one of the longest-lived book clubs on the planet, for all anyone knows. But, irony of ironies — as any irony-invoking book club member might appreciate — the members are having a hard time remembering just how old their club really is.

headline: Zeev Schiff, 74, Author and Dean of Israel Military Correspondents, Dies
text: JERUSALEM, June 20 — Zeev Schiff, the dean of Israeli military correspondents, defense editor of the newspaper Haaretz and author of numerous books, died Tuesday in Tel Aviv. He was 74.

headline: Academic Boycotts (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Smithsonian Ex-Chief Criticized in Report
text: Though his talent for fund-raising was cited to justify his ballooning salary, private donations to the Smithsonian Institution actually declined under its former chief executive, Lawrence M. Small, an independent committee said in a scathing report issued yesterday.

headline: For the Fashion-Conscious, a Laptop With Substance and Style
text: For some, customizing a laptop involves a few Blink-182 stickers and a black marker. Sony is kicking things up a notch with its Vaio CR series of fashion-forward, customizable laptops in five colors.

headline: Digital S.L.R.’s That Let You Shoot Like a Pro
text: To an ordinary person, the summer might mean barbecues, baseball games and trips to the beach. To a photography nut, however, it means longer days of sunlight, brighter subject colors (beach balls, bathing suits) and more people who don’t have to be told to “Smile!”

headline: Serving Some Gumbo From Old New Orleans
text: Even before Hurricane Katrina the Preservation Hall Jazz Band had been reviving. Now, touring heavily, making new records and collaborations, and perhaps carrying a sharper mandate of cultural preservation — because the New Orleans we knew really is gone — the band has become worth another hearing.

headline: Brooklyn: Suspect Sought in Sex Attack
text: Officers conducted a widespread manhunt in Brooklyn last night after a woman, identified by an official as a police officer, was sexually assaulted in Bay Ridge, the police said. The assault occurred near 95 Bay Ridge Avenue around 7 p.m., they said.

headline: Whole Foods Deal
text: Whole Foods Market, the largest American natural-foods grocer, agreed yesterday to sell 35 of Wild Oats Markets’ stores to the private equity firm Apollo Management.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in the Dining section yesterday about restaurants run by pastry chefs misstated the dates that ChikaLicious (203 East 10th Street), one of the first such restaurants in New York, will close for renovations. It will be closed from July 2-5; it is not closed now. The article also misspelled the name of a new place the restaurant’s owners will be opening. It is ChikaLicious Puddin’, not Pudding.

headline: Afghanistan: Bomb Kills 3 Canadians
text: Three Canadian soldiers were killed when a roadside bomb tore through their vehicle in southern Afghanistan, according to NATO officials and the Canadian government. Additionally, two Afghan drivers died when their convoy was attacked by the Taliban, said Ghulam Jalani, deputy police chief of Zabul Province.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day last Thursday about eBay’s fight against fraudulent auctions misstated the name of a trade group that provided information about illegal software sales on the site. The group is the Software and Information Industry Association, not the Software Industry Association of America.

headline: Wal-Mart to Expand Banking Services
text: Wal-Mart Stores said today that it would rapidly expand the financial services offered in its stores, extending the reach of its retailing empire into the bank accounts of its shoppers.

headline: Suggested Reading
text: Wimbledon starts on Monday, and once again John McEnroe will provide television commentary. McEnroe won Wimbledon three times, alternately displaying exquisite shotmaking and tantrums so demonstrative that the London tabloids labeled him “Superbrat.”

headline: Science Panel Finds Fault With Estimates of Coal Supply
text: WASHINGTON, June 20  The United States may not have nearly as much coal as is popularly believed, and mining the remaining resources may be more dangerous for workers and the environment than current operations, the National Academy of Sciences said in a report Wednesday.

headline: For 2 Years, Bloomberg Aides Prepared for Bid
text: WASHINGTON, June 20 — The announcement by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York that he was leaving the Republican Party to become an independent was made after nearly two years in which his aides had laid the groundwork for a potential independent run for president.

headline: Corrections: Behind the Glass Wall
text: An article on June 7 about Philip Johnson’s Glass House in New Canaan, Conn., misspelled the surname of the archivist of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, who was a visitor to the house. He is David Vaughan, not Vaughn.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A dance review yesterday about the American Ballet Theater’s production of “Romeo and Juliet,” at the Metropolitan Opera House, misidentified the dancer who portrays Paris. He is Gennadi Saveliev  not Jared Matthews, who is Benvolio.

headline: Big Money for Little E
text: So you’ve been hearing about Dale Earnhardt Jr. changing race teams, effective at the end of this Nascar season, but you don’t know what the fuss is about? The main reason this is such a big deal, as always, is money.

headline: Residential Sales
text: Manhattan

headline: Morgan Stanley’s Profits Rise, Defying Subprime Slump
text: Morgan Stanley, driven by its trading and investment banking divisions, reported a robust second quarter yesterday with a 41 percent increase in net earnings.

headline: Putting on Lip Gloss, and a Show, for YouTube Viewers
text: MANY women slap on their makeup in front of the mirror before they dash out the door: a quick coat of foundation, a dusting of blush, a brush of eye shadow, a twirl of the mascara wand and a quick smear of lip gloss. The beauty ritual hardly varies, and audiences generally aren’t invited.

headline: Not Buying It
text: ON a Friday evening last month, the day after New York University’s class of 2007 graduated, about 15 men and women assembled in front of Third Avenue North, an N.Y.U. dormitory on Third Avenue and 12th Street. They had come to take advantage of the university’s end-of-the-year move-out, when students’ discarded items are loaded into big green trash bins by the curb.

headline: At Wal-Mart, a Back Door Into Banking
text: Wal-Mart failed to get approval for a bank. But the giant discount chain is effectively building one anyway.

headline: Yahoo Buying a High School and College Sports Network
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 — Just one day after the management shake-up at Yahoo, the company’s board was called on to make a decision that had nothing to do with the resignation of Terry S. Semel as chief executive or the appointment of the co-founder Jerry Yang to succeed him.

headline: Really, Really Rosie
text: Watched Rosie this morning. You know, Rosie O’Donnell. She’s that homebody who lives with her wife and kids and hangs out with her good-time girlfriends and says whatever she wants.

headline: In Colorado, Matsui’s Problems Have Vanished Into Thin Air
text: DENVER, June 20  Kazuo Matsui stood on his tiptoes by his locker at Coors Field on Tuesday, smiling easily as he rubbed his feet along the raised dimples on a curved slab of wood. He was giving his feet a massage, and he eagerly showed a visitor a chart displaying various pressure points. Stimulating the nerve endings, it said, can have powerful effects on overall circulation.

headline: United Nations: Russia Rejects Kosovo Plan
text: The United States and European countries on the Security Council circulated a new resolution calling for independence for Kosovo, the breakaway province of Serbia, and delaying carrying out the plan for four months, but Russia, whose objections to a previous version led to the revision, rejected it. Kosovo has welcomed the plan and has threatened to declare independence on its own if the United Nations does not act, but Vitaly I. Churkin, Russia’s ambassador, called it “unacceptable.”

headline: Lawsuit Casts Doubt on TV Reality
text: The celebrity chef Gordon Ramsay has been accused of falsifying scenes in a new Fox television reality show that gives him a week’s time to make over failing restaurants and records his confrontations with staff, The Associated Press reported. The lawsuit, brought by Martin R. Hyde, a former general manager at Dillon’s in Manhattan, said Mr. Ramsay falsely claimed that meat was spoiled, used a defective chair to imply that the restaurant’s furniture was shoddy and hired actors to pose as customers to make the restaurant appear busy by the end of the week. Asking for millions in damages and a court order to stop the show from being broadcast as scheduled in the fall, Mr. Hyde also maintained that Mr. Ramsay humiliated him and drove him to quit to avoid further abuse. James Curich, a spokesman for Mr. Ramsay, said he could not comment on the lawsuit because he had not seen it. Jennifer Sprague, a Fox spokeswoman in Los Angeles, said she could not comment, and Andrew Blackmore, a manager at Dillon’s, said he had signed a release stating that he could not discuss the show with the news media. A year ago Mr. Ramsay won $138,000 and an apology in a libel suit in London against the publishers of The Evening Standard, which had accused him of faking scenes in his reality show “Kitchen Nightmares,” also about a restaurant makeover. “I won’t let people write anything they want about me,” he said.

headline: A Plea to Let a Punishment Fit the Prank
text: MONTROSE, N.Y.

headline: ‘Talent’ Beats the Competition
text: “America’s Got Talent” has got America watching. Nielsen estimated that an average of 12.4 million viewers tuned in on Tuesday to watch this two-hour competition, from NBC, earn its second-best ratings ever among adults 18 to 49, more than doubling those of its closest competitor at both 8 and 9 p.m. NBC easily won the night, leading the 10 o’clock hour as well with a repeat of “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (9.4 million). CBS ranked second with reruns of “NCIS” at 8 (9.3 million), “The Unit” at 9 (5.9 million), and “48 Hours” at 10 (6.8 million). Fox finished ahead of ABC in third, as its repeat of “House” at 9 (6.6 million) compensated for its low-performing “On the Lot” at 8 (2.4 million).

headline: The Empire Slate
text: Hamden, Conn.

headline: Kazakhstan Ballot Called 2 Years Early
text: ALMATY, Kazakhstan, June 20  Kazakhstan’s lower house of Parliament was dissolved Wednesday in preparation for early elections.

headline: 14 U.S. Soldiers Killed in Iraq in 2 Days
text: BAGHDAD, June 21 — Fourteen Americans were killed in combat in five incidents, most in Baghdad, in a 48-hour period ending Thursday, the military announced.

headline: Joggers Know His Sculptures; Meet the Artist Behind Them
text: This falls into the now-you-know category: The artist who has been intriguing bikers and joggers with driftwood sculptures along the Hudson River in Manhattan has been identified as Tom Loback.

headline: Rival Hunters on the Run in a Cat-and-Mouse Game
text: There’s a scene in Thomas Perry’s “Silence” in which a powerful male executive from the entertainment world, naked, is tended to by two young female assistants. Since “Silence” technically qualifies as a thriller, and since so many thrillers have strong sleaze components, it’s easy to imagine where this setup might lead.

headline: His Charge: Find a Key to Students’ Success
text: Roland G. Fryer, who was hired by Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein to advise him on how to narrow the racial gap in achievement in the city’s schools, made his professional name in economics by applying complex algorithms to document how black students fall behind their white peers. But his life story challenges his own calculations.

headline: Central Islip: Bank Robbery Charges
text: A Suffolk County man accused of robbing five banks on Long Island in the last three months pleaded not guilty yesterday at his arraignment in First District Court, the Suffolk County district attorney’s office said. The man, Steven P. Bertuglia, 34, was arrested on Tuesday night as he sat in his car in Mount Sinai, the Suffolk police said. In addition to being charged with robbing five banks, he is suspected of robbing others on Long Island and in New York City, Connecticut and New Jersey, the police said.

headline: The Number 61
text: Alex Rodriguez is on pace to hit 63 home runs, the most since steroid testing began in 2003, and the most by any player not associated with the steriod scandal. At PLAY, that got us thinking: Will 61, Roger Maris's record before Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa surpassed it in 1998, again become a benchmark (albeit unofficial) for home runs in a season? Should it?

headline: ‘Citizen Kane’ Wins an Election
text: “Citizen Kane” has held onto its title in a once-a-decade poll as the best of all American films, winning the top spot for the second time in a row in a poll of film critics, historians and others conducted by the American Film Institute, Reuters reported. “The Godfather” moved up a notch to take second place, dropping “Casablanca” into third in the ranking of the 100 best films. “Raging Bull” moved up 20 places, to No. 4, followed by “Singin’ in the Rain,” “Gone With the Wind,” “Lawrence of Arabia,” “Schindler’s List,” “Vertigo” and “The Wizard of Oz.” D. W. Griffith’s “Intolerance” (1916) was voted into the Top 100, but his “Birth of a Nation” (1915) was voted out, despite its technical innovations. Of 43 newly eligible films, released from 1966 to 2006, “Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring” appeared (50th place), as did “Saving Private Ryan” (71), “Titanic” (83) and “The Sixth Sense” (89). The results were disclosed on the CBS special “100 Years, 100 movies, 10th Anniversary Edition.”

headline: Mr. Bush’s Stem Cell Diversion
text: The executive order on stem cells issued by President Bush yesterday seeks to reorient research in new directions that may or may not pay off. But make no mistake, it is no substitute for the bill expanding embryonic stem cell research that Mr. Bush vetoed at the same time because it would involve the destruction of microscopic entities  smaller than the period at the end of this sentence  that the president deems a nascent form of life.

headline: Truth in Cereal (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Queens: Man Charged in Fatal Shooting
text: A Queens man was charged yesterday with fatally shooting a man in the street after an argument in a nearby bodega, prosecutors said. The man, Sherwin Thompson, 20, of 119th Avenue in South Jamaica, was charged with murder, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Thompson repeatedly shot Germaine Persaud, 21, about 1 a.m. on Monday as Mr. Persaud stood in front of his house on 192nd Street.

headline: For Some Things, It’s O.K. to Be Sticky (Yoga Mats)
text: WHICH one of these is not like the others: urdhva mukha svanasana, chaturanga dandasana, polyvinyl chloride. The first two are Sanskrit names for yoga poses, the third, a toxic plastic often used in sticky yoga mats.

headline: Woods Chases Nicklaus as a Father
text: The world has seen the evolution of Tiger Woods from prodigy to wunderkind to amateur champion to winner of multi Masters, Opens and P.G.A. Championships to multi-multimillionaire to husband and now to father. And a few days before his wife, Elin, delivered their daughter, Sam Alexis, the morning after he tied for second at the United States Open, he was asked how being a parent would change his golf life.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Dark Work in a Sunny Spot
text: WARREN BEATTY, for whom the novelist Susanna Moore once worked, found her voice so hilarious that he cast her in his film “Shampoo,” Ms. Moore was saying at her Brooklyn apartment the other day. It is an odd voice, high-pitched, and, as even she points out, over-enunciated; the voice of a schoolmistress who taught less privileged youth a century or so back. It is not the voice one would expect, given that the book that brought her notoriety a dozen years ago was the erotic thriller “In the Cut,” and that her latest novel, “The Big Girls,” set in a women’s prison, has again stirred the critics into a lather of moral indignation.

headline: Zoellick Obtains Board Support to Lead World Bank, Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON, June 20  Robert B. Zoellick, President Bush’s nominee for president of the World Bank, secured the support of the bank’s board of directors on Wednesday after reporting to them about his recent meetings with bank representatives around the world, bank officials said.

headline: North Dakota Is Sued in Church-State Case
text: A group that advocates strict separation of church and state has sued North Dakota to bar public financing of an association that provides therapeutic and rehabilitative services for troubled youth by steeping them in Christian teachings, Bible readings, religious services and rituals.

headline: Bringing Home Lessons Learned on the Battlefield
text: AT 38, Thomas J. Deierlein had carved out a busy, fulfilling Madison Avenue career, working as chief operating officer for Dynamic Logic, a market research company that gauges the effectiveness of advertising. After more than a decade in the business, his days as an elite Army Ranger were far behind him — or so he thought until October 2005.

headline: The Bloomberg Question
text: We probably should know better, but for now we’re going to take a politician at face value and believe Michael Bloomberg when he says he is not running for president. His line yesterday about running only if he was the last person on earth was Shermanesque by today’s standards. And we’re not ready to weigh in on whether New York’s billionaire mayor should be America’s billionaire president.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day yesterday about International Lease Finance Corporation’s order for Boeing 787 Dreamliners misstated the size of the company’s provisional order for Airbus A350s before the plane’s 2006 redesign. The order was for 16 planes, not 12.

headline: Trying to Unite Europe, Again
text: José Manuel Barroso, the president of the European Commission, spoke good sense this week when he declared that negotiations on reorganizing the European Union can’t start from scratch every time a member state has a change of government.

headline: Plenty of Love Up North
text: The unlikely hotspot for tennis this summer is Vermont, better known for ski racing than pros acing. But Stowe’s 360 tennis courts (in a “Sound of Music” setting) easily outnumber ski trails, and on July 14 and 15, the Topnotch Resort and Spa in Stowe hosts the Fed Cup semifinal between the United States and Russia. The women’s tournament is expected to draw Serena Williams, Venus Williams and Maria Sharapova. Tickets are scarce, but guests staying at the Topnotch can still buy passes at prices from $75 to$225; lower-priced rooms are sold out, but villas starting at $1,100 per night are available. Finally, those craving strawberries and cream at Wimbledon, June 25 to July 8, can catch courtside seats through the Stowe-based Grand Slam Tennis Tours. Last-minute packages including hotels, admission, meals and more start at $3,625 for four nights.

headline: New Rules Expected on Safety of Nanotechnology Products
text: DuPont and Environmental Defense, one of the nation’s largest environmental groups, plan to release jointly developed guidelines today for evaluating the safety and environmental risks of nanotechnology products.

headline: Calendar
text: Thinking Design

headline: If You Like the Safari Browser for the iPhone, You’ll Love Opera Mini for Cellphones
text: Apple’s iPhone, which goes on sale June 29, gets oohs and ahhs for a number of reasons, a big one being the way its Safari Web browser displays pages just like the desktop version, then lets you run your fingers over the screen to zoom in and out.

headline: They Take the Bounce Out of Bowser
text: FILLED with trepidation about being tied down, Mary Turner and her husband, Richard Shein, decided to put off parenthood awhile and see how they did with a dog. Ms. Turner, a lawyer, found Bingo, “a darling cinnamon-colored puppy,” trembling in a cage at an animal shelter near their home in San Bernardino, Calif.

headline: A Student, a Teacher and a Glimpse of War
text: MALEHE, Congo

headline: Bush Vetoes Measure on Stem Cell Research
text: WASHINGTON, June 20 — President Bush on Wednesday issued his second veto of a measure lifting his restrictions on human embryonic stem cell experiments. The move effectively pushed the contentious scientific and ethical debate surrounding the research into the 2008 presidential campaign.

headline: Albany: New Head of Ethics Commission
text: John D. Feerick, chairman of the State Ethics Commission, said yesterday that he had selected Herbert Teitelbaum, a New York lawyer, as executive director of the commission. He also said he would recommend Mr. Teitelbaum for the same post at a soon-to-be-created public integrity commission combining the existing ethics and lobbying commissions. When the merger takes place, David Grandeau, the executive director of the Temporary State Commission on Lobbying, will probably be out of a job. “I met with John Feerick about a month and a half ago, once, and it was very clear to me that he was intent on choosing someone other than me,” Mr. Grandeau said. Mr. Teitelbaum is a senior partner in the New York office of Bryan Cave. His wife, Ruth J. Abram, founded the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, which has lobbied extensively in Albany. Mr. Feerick said that he was “enormously impressed” by Mr. Teitelbaum and that a spouse’s work should not be held against a candidate.

headline: Germany: Labor Deal at Deutsche Telekom
text: Deutsche Telekom agreed with the Ver.di union on terms to transfer 50,000 workers to jobs that pay less, paving the way to end five weeks of strikes at the company. The employees will take a 6.5 percent pay cut and lengthen the workweek by four hours, Deutsche Telekom’s personnel chief, Thomas Sattelberger, said at a news conference with Ver.di in Bad Neuenahr, Germany. The deal allows Deutsche Telekom to set up T-Service, a customer service unit that is part of a cost-cutting program aimed at saving 900 million euros ($1.2 billion). As many as 16,000 workers a day have gone on strike across Germany since May 11 to protest Deutsche Telekom’s initial plan to cut pay by 9 percent. As part of the agreement, Deutsche Telekom would raise the “variable” portion of workers’ salary and promised it would not sell the service unit before 2010.

headline: Starting the Day Together (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Orleans Still at Risk, Army Data Show
text: After nearly two years of work, the Army Corps of Engineers revealed yesterday which New Orleans neighborhoods and blocks were the most vulnerable to flooding, and which were the best protected. The report shows that despite considerable improvement, large swaths of the city are still likely to be flooded in a major storm.

headline: Spitzer Pushes for a Last-Minute Deal on 3 Disputed Issues
text: ALBANY, June 20 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer was trying to reach a broad deal Wednesday to end the legislative session by linking together three contentious issues, people with knowledge of the negotiations said. The issues included his own campaign finance reform plan, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s congestion pricing proposal and a measure to grant pay raises to lawmakers.

headline: Precedents Begin to Fall for Roberts Court
text: WASHINGTON, June 20 — No Supreme Court nominee could be confirmed these days without paying homage to the judicial doctrine of “stare decisis,” Latin for “to stand by things decided.” Yet experienced listeners have learned to take these professions of devotion to precedent “cum grano salis,” Latin for “with a grain of salt.”

headline: Mexico Moves to Cut Back Tax Loopholes for Businesses
text: MEXICO CITY, June 20 — Hoping to raise Mexico’s tax collection rate to offset future declines in oil revenue, President Felipe Calderón presented a tax package to Congress Wednesday that seeks to close many of the loopholes that businesses have used to avoid paying taxes.

headline: Small Companies That Try to Bring Innovative Technology to Teaching
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — There is a growing cluster of companies in the Northwest looking to capitalize on educational needs.

headline: Northwest Ingenuity, Many Ways
text: LANGLEY, Wash.

headline: Quilter Sues Art Dealer
text: The great-granddaughter of a woman who belonged to a group of quiltmakers in Gee’s Bend, Ala., whose work has become celebrated in the art world, has filed suit against three Atlanta art dealers claiming that they have illegally taken two century-old quilts made by her great-grandmother. The woman, Lucinda Pettway Franklin, contends that one of the dealers, Matt Arnett, asked two years ago to borrow the quilts to have them examined and photographed for a book. But the quilts, along with another made by her mother and an aunt, have not been returned, despite requests, according to the lawsuit, which was filed on Tuesday in Alabama. Newer quilts of their kind sell for tens of thousands of dollars; the value of older ones is much higher. The suit is the third filed recently against Mr. Arnett; his brother, Paul; and his father, William, who have long represented and promoted the quilters in Gee’s Bend, an isolated, historically black community. Two earlier suits say that the Arnetts have defrauded Gee’s Bend quilters. Gregory H. Hawley, a lawyer representing the Arnetts, was unavailable for comment yesterday, his law firm said. In previous interviews he has denied the claims in the first two lawsuits.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 10 P.M. (A&E) STREET THIEF (2006) Are we watching a real thief as he successfully plans and carries out his break-ins? Or is this just an extremely realistic portrayal of a fictional character named Kaspar Carr? The director Malik Bader (playing Kaspar, above) has fielded such questions since this “filmed record” of a Chicago burglar amazed audiences at the 2006 Tribeca Film Festival. (Shortly before the event one of the film’s producers was arrested on charges of armed robbery and kidnapping in connection with a truck hijacking.) Tonight the film, fictional or otherwise, makes its television debut.

headline: Letters Show Deep Value Giuliani Puts on Loyalty
text: “Loyalty” is a word that has long defined Rudolph W. Giuliani’s leadership style. But rarely has there been as documented an outpouring of that support as the 92 letters Mr. Giuliani wrote for Dennis E. Szybala during four months in 1981.

headline: The Times Is Raising Newspaper Prices
text: The New York Times Company will increase the newsstand and home-delivery prices for the newspaper next month, the company’s chief executive said at an investor conference yesterday.

headline: Now Playing in the U.S., Soccer’s Garage Band
text: A year after the world's best soccer teams convened in Germany to crown a World Cup champion, 12 teams from North and Central America and the Caribbean came to the United States this month to determine the top team in the fourth-best footballing region of the world. This is the world's most popular sport dialed down a few notches. The tournament, called the Concacaf Gold Cup, is the red-headed stepchild of regional soccer tournaments. It lags behind the glamorous European Championship, the more prestigious Copa America (which starts June 26 in Venezuela) and it may even trail the African Cup of Nations in terms of excitement and talent.

headline: College Lists? No Thanks (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Where Jeter Is Concerned, Rockie Shortstop Is Just a Fan
text: DENVER, June 20  Troy Tulowitzki is only 22 years old, which means he was 11 during the 1996 season, when Derek Jeter was the American League rookie of the year. Tulowitzki was born in Santa Clara, Calif., and grew up near San Francisco. But Jeter was his hero.

headline: Poised to Be New Jersey’s Attorney General
text: TRENTON, June 20 — Some years ago, when assistants to District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan were debating the merits of law school graduates who had applied to work in the office, the conversation turned to pastry.

headline: Recalling the Princess They Called Mother
text: MONACO

headline: Trying on Enlightenment for Size
text: IT says size 2, but it’s so-o-o huge!” New stock had just arrived at Diane Von Furstenberg’s newly opened store in the meatpacking district, and staff members were trying things on, their conversation carrying into the dressing room where a red and white floral wrap dress ($325) was presenting me with troubles of my own.

headline: U.S. Courting a Somewhat Skittish Friend in Central Asia
text: ASHGABAT, Turkmenistan, June 20  The president of reclusive and authoritarian Turkmenistan said Wednesday that he was willing to expand his relations with Washington and with American businesses and that he would continue to cooperate with efforts to stabilize neighboring Afghanistan.

headline: A Leader of Hamas Warns of West Bank Peril for Fatah
text: GAZA, June 20 — Mahmoud Zahar, perhaps the most influential Hamas leader in Gaza, warned Wednesday that Fatah’s effort to repress Hamas in the West Bank could lead to Fatah’s downfall there as well.

headline: Music Genres, as You See Fit
text: Q. I have music in my MP3 collection that doesn’t fall into the standard categories that iTunes provides. Is there a way to make my own music genres within the program?

headline: Embracing Many Mediums to Focus on the Message
text: Linder is the nom d’art for Linder Sterling, a British artist, musician and performer who was born Linda Mulvey in Liverpool in 1954. A compact exhibition of drawings, photomontages, video and ephemera devoted to her has been organized at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center by Neville Wakefield, a senior curatorial adviser at the museum. “Linder” is an intriguing exploration of the overlapping worlds of art and music, but walking through the show tends to call to mind a roster of more memorable women.

headline: U.S. to Hold Direct Talks in North Korea on Arms
text: WASHINGTON, June 20 — In a sharp reversal of strategy, the Bush administration on Wednesday secretly dispatched its top North Korea negotiator to the country’s capital, Pyongyang, for one-on-one talks about the North Koreans giving up their nuclear arsenal.

headline: Economics, Religion and Politics, in Bite Size
text: The Ensemble Studio Theater is in such a remote location — walk west on 52nd Street and just keep going — that by the time you arrive at its door, you feel as if you have discovered a hidden cultural treasure. At its best the Marathon — the theater’s annual one-act festival that has showcased new work by everyone from David Mamet to Tennessee Williams, and which this year is divided into two five-play series — offers a similar sensation.

headline: Corrections
text: A front-page article on June 11 about the reaction of Mormons to the presidential candidacy of Mitt Romney, who is a Mormon, referred imprecisely to Mr. Romney’s position on gay rights. While he opposes gay marriage and civil unions, the article should not have said he has embraced an “anti-gay agenda.” (Go to Article)

headline: All the Films You Want to See, but When?
text: THE DVD became the most popular way to view movies for good reasons. The discs are sturdy, and the crisp images do not degrade with repeated showings. They take up little space. Some DVD players are cheaper than buying a DVD movie.

headline: Fast-Growing China Says Little of Child Slavery’s Role
text: SHANGHAI, June 20 — There is a certain ritualistic aspect to stories in China like the one this past week about the hundreds of people, many of them teenagers or even younger, who were forced to work under slavelike conditions in the brick kilns of Shanxi Province. First, Chinese readers are horrified by a picture of their country that many say they hardly recognize, then a villain is rounded up, and finally, after a torrent of unusually blunt and emotionally charged news reports and editorials, the matter drops from view, ensuring that the larger issue goes unresolved.

headline: Kenneth Franklin, Astronomer, Dies at 84
text: Kenneth L. Franklin, long the Hayden Planetarium’s top astronomer, whose accomplishments included helping pinpoint the first noise known to have come from another planet and inventing a watch for use on the moon, died in Boulder, Colo., on Monday when the sun rose in New York at 5:07 a.m. He was 84, and had for years provided astronomical information to this newspaper, including the hour of sunrise.

headline: Beauty Tips and Clips
text: WATCHING dozens of beauty videos on YouTube, I learned makeup and hair tricks that I’m embarrassed to admit I didn’t know.

headline: Few Choices for Workers at Dow Jones
text: Looking at the potential bidders for Dow Jones & Company  Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation and a joint effort by General Electric and Pearson  some reporters and editors at The Wall Street Journal are calling the decision a choice between “trash or slash.” And they are wondering which might be worse.

headline: As the Mets Flounder, Gómez Could Be a Catch
text: Carlos Gómez has few friends in New York, so he has been surprised when strangers have stopped him, acted as if they had known him forever and talked about the catch. Five weeks into his major league career, Gómez already has a tremendous defensive play attached to him like a tattoo.

headline: Study Says Eldest Children Have Higher I.Q.s
text: The eldest children in families tend to develop higher I.Q.’s than their siblings, researchers are reporting today, in a large study that could settle more than a half-century of scientific debate about the relationship between I.Q. and birth order.

headline: A Band Minds Its Manners, but Is Coy About Its Suits
text: Carlos Dengler, better known as Carlos D., the bassist and keyboardist for the moody New York band Interpol, is out of his self-described hedonist phase.

headline: At Trial, Writer Recalls an Alter Ego That Took Over
text: The case of Laura Albert — professionally known as JT Leroy — could be read as a literary cautionary tale, the story of a writer who hid behind her own assumed identity and lost herself while reaching for the truth.

headline: Unusual Court Case at Center of Pakistan’s Political Fight
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 20  The case is simply called The Chief Justice v. The President. It plays out daily in plush Supreme Court chambers before a bench of 13 men who could well decide the outcome of Pakistan’s political crisis.

headline: Bear Stearns Staves Off Collapse of 2 Hedge Funds
text: The high-stakes game of brinksmanship began early yesterday on Wall Street, and continued throughout the day. Bankers traded telephone calls, frenetically negotiating the fate of two hedge funds.

headline: Heavy Fighting as U.S. Troops Squeeze Insurgents in Iraq City
text: BAQUBA, Iraq, June 20  Fighting was heavy in parts of Baquba on Wednesday as American troops continued to squeeze a large section of the city in an effort to rid it of insurgents believed to be part of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia.

headline: A Week Since She Vanished, and Still Little Light Is Shed
text: CANTON, Ohio, June 20 — From the moment her mother entered her home last Friday and found her missing, the circumstances surrounding the disappearance of Jessie Davis were most unsettling.

headline: Another Summer of Love
text: JANIS JOPLIN looms large in Kim Matulova’s consciousness — not least Ms. Joplin’s free-form hair, flounced frocks and fingers choked with rings. “My style is, like, gypsy,” Ms. Matulova said last week, “something like a ghetto hippie.”

headline: National Education Board Reviews Election Procedures
text: The officers of the National Association of State Boards of Education are reviewing their election procedures, after a nominee’s withdrawal left them with only one candidate for the office of president-elect: a member of the Kansas school board who supported its efforts against the teaching of evolution.

headline: Libyans Weigh a Deal to Free Medical Workers in H.I.V. Case
text: ROME, June 20  The European Union and hundreds of Libyan families whose children are infected with the virus that causes AIDS are expected to announce an agreement on Friday in Brussels to remove an important obstacle in the case of six foreign medical workers whom Libya accuses of intentionally infecting the children, an official connected to the negotiations said Wednesday.

headline: Red Carpet or Rehab, It All Sells
text: THE image of Lindsay Lohan passed out in a car over Memorial Day weekend may have stalled her acting career, but it has done wonders for hoodie sales at American Apparel.

headline: Giuliani May See a Rival in Successor
text: Seven weeks after the 2001 terror attacks, Rudolph W. Giuliani gave a last-minute electoral nod to a billionaire media mogul running for mayor.

headline: Not Just Another Day at the Board of Elections
