text: On a typical day, Troy Johnson, chief clerk of the New York County Board of Elections, busies himself making sure voters are registered, absentee ballot requests are answered and the copious records inside the board’s 10th-floor office downtown on Varick Street are scrupulously maintained.

headline: Indian Tycoon Spreads His Wings in Aviation
text: Vijay Mallya, an Indian liquor and airline magnate who revels in the tycoon lifestyle, wants to bring his good times to the rest of the world.

headline: June Has Been Anything but Fun So Far for Mets
text: Offering a diversion from the ugliness unfolding on the field, the out-of-town scoreboard at Shea Stadium last night showed highlights from the Red Sox-Braves game from Atlanta. Some fans hollered when the score, very much in Boston’s favor, was announced. As long as the Braves continue to lose, the first-place Mets, no matter how poorly they play, would not lose any ground.

headline: On the Waterfront: A Matter of Preservation (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Staying Connected via Cellphone (and Cellphone Bill)
text: MY daughter graduated from high school last week. As she heads to college, my husband warned me that we face four years of a crushing financial burden, with enormous regular payments that he fears could lead to bankruptcy.

headline: Firefighter Falls to Death in  Blaze in Brooklyn
text: A firefighter was killed this evening after falling at a burning building in Brooklyn, officials said.

headline: Newly Released
text: June is beach-read month, and a number of this month’s new releases would do nicely under a beach umbrella. Much of Ann Brashares’s new book takes place on Fire Island, and will undoubtedly be spotted there as well. Other novels take place in 17th-century Persia, in World War I-era France and among a very smart herd of sheep.

headline: Queens: Man Fatally Stabbed
text: A 24-year-old man was stabbed to death shortly before 3 a.m. yesterday outside a strip club on Steinway Street in Astoria, the police said. The man, who was identified as Jason Brown of Bay Shore, in Suffolk County, was pronounced dead on arrival at Elmhurst General Hospital, the police said. He had been stabbed several times in the torso by another man during a dispute outside the strip club, Club Riviera, the police said. The assailant escaped, the police said, and no weapon was recovered.

headline: An iPod Rival Can Browse the Net and Download Audio and Video
text: Archos has always been the underdog in the portable media player race. While it manufactured some of the first real MP3 players, its products have been overshadowed by the iPod. With its new 605 Wi-Fi, this wallflower is hoping to be the belle of the ball.

headline: Hamas Conquest of Gaza Disturbs Arab World With Echoes of Recent Splits and Alliances
text: CAIRO, June 20  The conquest of the Gaza Strip by Hamas has frightened Arab leaders because it was characterized by the same dynamics that have been agitating the region.

headline: Words, Actions and Hamas (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Disposable’ Trump Is Promoted to Giant Killer
text: First look at only the West hand in the diagramed deal. You are on lead against six spades. Declarer showed four spades, five diamonds and two key cards (one ace and the trump king, or two aces) but no trump queen. Dummy revealed five or more clubs, four spades and sufficient strength to drive to slam opposite a minimum opening bid. What would you lead?

headline: And Finally, Sleep
text: What does it take to win the ultra-cycling competition Race Across America? Try 8 days, 19 hours, and 33 minutes. Try 3,043 miles on a bike, with little or no sleep, day after pedal-cranking day. That’s what Jure Robic, a 42-year-old Slovene competitor, endured to win the solo division in this year’s race, which started in Oceanside, Calif., on June 10; Robic reached the finish line in Atlantic City Tuesday morning, and the race as a whole wraps up tomorrow. Thirty solo competitors and several teams with up to eight riders switching off signed up for this year’s race, which ran through vast stretches of desert, mountains, Great Plains, and endless American roadways. As of this morning, 13 solo competitors in the men's race (all five women missed time cutoffs) were battling saddle sores and exhaustion while trying to make the final time cut at the finish line tomorrow night.

headline: Your Questions About the IPhone
text: Hmmm, let’s see… what shall I cover in my column next week?

headline: Pettitte Says He Quit on Himself
text: Sometimes, you watch a game and go talk to the pitcher, and you can’t believe he’s describing what you just saw. Esteban Loaiza was like that; he would give up 6 runs in 5 innings and talk about how he actually pitched pretty well.

headline: Immortal Syria
text: The Old City of Damascus, the Silk Road bazaars of Aleppo and the ruins of ancient Palmyra attest to Syria's Bronze Age, classical, biblical and Islamic history.

headline: Closing Shop
text: Images from the Heritage Book Shop in Los Angeles, which is set to close.

headline: An Unlucky Number
text: A troubled writer, a haunted hotel room — who else but Stephen King? In "1408," adapted from a 2002 short story by Mr. King, John Cusack is the hack who drags his emotional baggage to Room 1408 of the Dolphin Hotel in Manhattan, accommodations whose history of grisly deaths demands investigation. Once there, he learns that checking out might not be an option.

headline: A Jumbled Real World
text: The domestic drama "Longing" ("Sehnsucht)" tells of a rural firefighter named Markus (Andreas Müller) who visits another town with his colleagues and ends up getting drunk and falling into bed with a kindly waitress named Rose (Anett Dornbusch). Marcus can't stop seeing Rose; unfortunately, he's already happily married to a wonderful woman named Ella (Ilka Welz).

headline: A Look at Loss and Reinvention
text: "What do you do when nothing is left?" is the question that drives "The Real Dirt on Farmer John," Taggart Siegel's fascinating documentary about loss and reinvention. If you're John Peterson, the progressive Illinois farmer whom Mr. Siegel filmed through 25 years of friendship and multiple crises, you pick yourself up and start again — with the camera running, of course.

headline: U.S. Is Urging Blair to Be Lead Mideast Envoy
text: The United States is pressing Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain to become a special envoy to the Middle East, working on behalf of the diplomatic “quartet” of world powers to help the Palestinian president build the institutions and apparatus necessary for a viable state.

headline: Munich, No. 1 even where it (maybe) hurts……….
text: English Garden, Munich (AP)

headline: A Global Array
text: Images from Documenta 12, an international art show in Kassel, Germany.

headline: Day Trip: Trailing Van Gogh
text: Auvers sur Oise

headline: Hospital Death Rates
text: The following are the hospitals with the lowest and highest mortality rates for patients treated for heart attacks or heart failure, according to an analysis of about 5,000 hospitals by the Department of Health and Human Services.

headline: Whole Foods to Unload Wild Oats Stake to Apollo
text: Whole Foods Market, the largest American natural-foods grocer, agreed yesterday to sell 35 of Wild Oats Markets‘ stores to the private equity firm Apollo Management.

headline: Allied Capital Settles With S.E.C., Giving Greenlight More Ammo
text: Allied Capital, a business development company, said Wednesday that it had settled a four-year investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into its valuation practices. Allied, which provides debt and equity financing for middle-market companies, settled the S.E.C.’s informal investigation without admitting or denying agency allegations, according to Allied and the S.E.C.

headline: In Suit, Ex-A.I.G. Chief Says Others Are Liable for Restatement
text: Maurice R. Greenberg, former chief executive of the American International Group, sued 16 current and former executives and directors Wednesday, seeking to hold them liable for a results restatement and a $1.64 billion regulatory settlement he considered unnecessary.

headline: Watchdog Group Is Given a Name
text: The merger of the United States brokerage industry’s two major watchdogs finally has a name: the Securities Industry Regulatory Authority, or SIRA.

headline: Accounting Rule Is Eased for Foreign Companies
text: Federal regulators tentatively agreed Wednesday to ease an accounting requirement for foreign companies that trade on United States exchanges. The move comes amid concerns that U.S. stock markets are losing out to overseas competitors due, in part, to what critics see as a overly-burdensome regulatory environment.

headline: Bell Canada Discussing a Merger With Western Provinces Carrier
text: Bell Canada, the target of at least three possible privatization bids, said Wednesday that it was discussing a possible merger with Telus, the leading phone company in western Canada. If combined, Bell, which is based in Montreal, and Telus, based in Vancouver, would have a market capitalization of C$53.2 billion ($50 billion) based on Wednesday’s stock prices.

headline: Britain’s Private Equity Chiefs Defend Their Tax Breaks
text: Executives from four large private equity firms went to Parliament on Tuesday and defended the low British tax rate imposed on their profits.

headline: Man Group Prices Brokerage I.P.O.
text: Man Group, Europe’s largest publicly traded hedge fund, said Thursday it expects its United States brokerage to price its shares at $36 to $39 each when they list on the New York Stock Exchange. The price range values the entire business at as much as $5 billion.

headline: Yahoo Buying a High School and College Sports Network
text: Just one day after the management shake-up at Yahoo, the company’s board was called on to make a decision that had nothing to do with the resignation of Terry S. Semel as chief executive or the appointment of the co-founder Jerry Yang to succeed him.

headline: Gannett Takes the Lead on 4Info
text: Newspaper and broadcasting giant Gannett led a $10 million fourth round of venture funding in mobile advertising company 4Info. 4Info, based in Palo Alto, lets people get news and other information via text messaging on their mobile phones.

headline: Nuveen Deal GetsThumbs Down from Debt Analysts
text: Private equity player Madison Dearborn Partners‘ $6.3 billion deal for municipal bond fund Nuveen Investments may gladden the hearts of investors, but it doesn’t have debt analysts cheering, BusinessWeek noted.

headline: Lone Star to Sell Korea Exchange Shares
text: Lone Star Funds, the buyout firm whose attempt to sell Korea Exchange Bank last year was blocked by a legal dispute, offered an 11.3 percent stake in the company for as much as $1.1 billion.

headline: Deutsche Bank, 4 Hedge Funds Fined in Vivendi Inquiry
text: Deutsche Bank and four hedge funds including GLG Partners were fined a combined 6.25 million euros ($8.4 million) by France’s market regulator after an insider trading investigation into a Vivendi Universal securities sale in 2002.

headline: Alcan Opens Books to BHP and Rio Tinto, Report Says
text: Alcan, seeking to fend off a $27.7 billion hostile bid from Alcoa, has given BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto Group access to its financial data, according to The Sydney Morning Herald.

headline: Luxottica Tries Oakley On for Size
text: The Luxottica Group, the world’s biggest eyewear maker, said Wednesday that it would buy the American sunglasses maker Oakley Inc. in an all-cash deal worth about $2.1 billion.

headline: Congress May Challenge Private Equity’s Big Tax Break
text: For private equity chiefs, the other shoe — and a much bigger one — may be about to drop in Washington.

headline: U.S. Said to Investigate Kickbacks in Stock Lending
text: Federal prosecutors are close to bringing criminal charges against as many as a dozen current and former Wall Street employees in connection with a kickback scheme involving loans of stocks and bonds to hedge funds and short sellers, BusinessWeek reported. So far, federal prosecutors have reportedly secured guilty pleas from three confidential witnesses in the case.

headline: Atticus Phones In Opposition to Barclays’ ABN Bid
text: Atticus Capital, the hedge fund manager with more than $14 billion in assets, reiterated its opposition to Barclays proposed $68.2 billion euros ($91.4 billion) deal to buy Dutch bank ABN Amro.

headline: Few Choices for Workers at Dow Jones
text: Looking at the potential bidders for Dow Jones & Company – Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation and a joint effort by General Electric and Pearson – some reporters and editors at The Wall Street Journal are calling the decision a choice between “trash or slash.” And they are wondering which might be worse.

headline: Bear Stearns Staves Off Collapse of 2 Hedge Funds
text: The high-stakes game of brinksmanship began early yesterday on Wall Street, and continued throughout the day. Bankers traded telephone calls, frenetically negotiating the fate of Bear Stearns two hedge funds.

headline: BlackBerrys: A Spy Tale of Three Cities
text: As Wall Street workers consider new guidelines on how and when to use their BlackBerrys, Paris has taken the issue a bit further, deciding that the ubiquitous hand-held devices may pose a threat to French national security.

headline: L.S.E. May Offer $2 Billion for Italian Rival, Report Says
text: The London Stock Exchange is planning to offer about 1.5 billion euros ($2.01 billion) for Borsa Italiana, Reuters reported Thursday citing an unnamed source. The deal would value the Borsa, which is privately-owned by Italian banks, above the 1.2 billion to 1.4 billion euros valuation placed on it last year when the Milan-based bourse planned for an initial public offering.

headline: The Headliner Takes the Stage, but It Proves Anticlimactic
text: If Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s announcement on Tuesday night that he was leaving the Republican Party amounted to a political earthquake — or at least a tremor? — there were no real aftershocks on Wednesday, judging by this morning’s papers. Indeed, the big political news of the day — Mayor Bloomberg’s insistence that he was not planning to run for president — seemed almost anticlimactic as speculation about his ambitions swirled around him. But he still got his headlines.

headline: I.S.S. Recommends Vote Against Icahn’s Offer for Lear
text: Institutional Shareholder Services has recommended that shareholders of Lear reject Carl C. Icahn’s proposed $36-a-share offer for the auto parts supplier, lending serious opposition to the shareholder activist’s bid.

headline: Mary McCarthy at 95
text: Mary McCarthy, were she alive, would be 95 today – she was born on June 21, 1912.

headline: Corzine: Bloomberg’s Move No Surprise
text: For Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg never seemed to be a good fit with the Republican Party.

headline: 2008: A Closer Look At Bloomberg
text: Need help making sense of the strange week that has unfolded around New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg? Fortunately, a set of stories gets beneath the surface of the mayor’s unexpected announcement and cryptic statements of recent days.

headline: Podcast: ‘The Switch Is On’
text: Following is the draft script of the weekly “Only in New York” audio podcast. Listen at left or download  it to a portable player.

headline: Austin Reels After Man Is Beaten to Death
text: Even with the chain of events pieced together by the police so far, it’s hard to comprehend the flash violence that broke out in an East Austin, Tex., parking lot on Tuesday. Even the police chief was shocked, and his expression of that — “This is an anomaly for Austin” — could’ve applied to the nation as well.

headline: On the Move …
text: Tony Blair: British prime minister was considered a World Bank chief candidate, and now he’s up for the job of Mideast envoy?

headline: A New Vision for the East River
text: This morning, with a four-borough boat tour leaving from South Street Seaport in Manhattan and ending at the Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn, more than 50 community groups are announcing the East River Agenda, a plan to make riverfront neighborhoods a centerpiece of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s PlaNYC vision for improving the city’s environment over the next 30 years.

headline: Giuliani Prefers His Godfather Imitation
text: DES MOINES — Years before he became known as the squeegee-busting mayor of New York and ages before his name became forever linked with Sept. 11, Rudy Giuliani made his reputation fighting the mafia.

headline: The Number 61
text: Alex Rodriguez is on pace to hit 65 home runs, the most since steroid testing began in 2003, and the most by any player not associated with the steriod scandal. At PLAY, that got us thinking: Will 61, Roger Maris’s record before Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa surpassed it in 1998, again become a benchmark (albeit unofficial) for home runs in a season? Should it?

headline: What to See and Do in Slovenia in and Around the Capital
text: This is my first time traveling to Slovenia. Can you give me tips for sightseeing and attractions? And what do you suggest I see in Ljubljana?

headline: Even Less Confidence in Congress
JT and Me
text: I was born in West Virginia – my grandfather, Archie Garner, was a coal miner – and throughout my life I’ve followed West Virginia writers as closely as I’ve followed the fortunes of the nearby Pittsburgh, Pa. sports teams.

headline: Finding a Hassle-Free Way to Transfer Files
text: Readers seem to love it when they hear about tech "experts" like me getting trapped in technical hell. Seems to be a form of schadenfreude, that delicious German word meaning, "taking pleasure in other people's misfortune."

headline: Sample Platter
text: As Screens has pointed out before, you can learn much from the sloppy comments section on YouTube. Consider, for example, the notes that follow one version of Senator Hillary Clinton’s take-off on the last scene of “The Sopranos.”

headline: Yoga at the Crossroads of the World
text: About 80 men and women — some from as far as California and Honduras — woke up extra early to visit one of the world’s busiest intersections in search for serenity.

headline: LVMH Enters Talks to Buy Les Echos
text: A wealthy businessman proposes buying a major provider of business news, setting off fears among its employees that their editorial integrity would be compromised.

headline: Personal Shopper
text: Daydream designs for the lazy afternoon ahead.

headline: Currents
text: A flea-market-style restaurant, carefully curated and more.

headline: UBS Paves the Way for More Infrastructure Deals
text: As state governments consider selling toll roads, airports and bridges to close budget gaps, UBS is bolstering its team of investment bankers that advise on such deals. The Swiss firm said Wednesday it hired three bankers for its infrastructure group ahead of what it expects to be a rise in privatizations in the United States.

headline: Recent Openings
text: New shows in New York include "Behind the Lid" and "Radio."

headline: Finding a Hassle-Free Way to Send Files
text: Readers seem to love it when they hear about tech “experts” like me getting trapped in technical hell. Seems to be a form of schadenfreude, that delicious German word meaning, “taking pleasure in other people’s misfortune.”

headline: Romeo and Juliet in the Park
text: Melena Ryzik of The Times reports on the Public Theater's party for Shakespeare in the Park.

headline: Mauer Roots for Posada, One Catcher for Another
text: Joe Mauer of the Minnesota Twins became the first catcher to win the American League’s batting title when he hit .347 in 2006. Mauer edged Derek Jeter of the Yankees, who hit .343.

headline: Public Land
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Justices Tighten Rules on Shareholder Suits
text: The Supreme Court on Thursday imposed a strict standard that investors must meet to keep alive their lawsuits alleging securities fraud. In an 8-1 decision, the justices said that courts must weigh possible innocent explanations for defendants’ conduct at the very start of a securities fraud case. Doing so can lead to early dismissal of investors’ lawsuits.

headline: Report Says City’s Smoking Rate Has Plummeted
text: New York City’s smoking rate fell by 20 percent from 2002 to 2006, with 240,000 fewer smokers, according to a new report by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: Campaign Cash: Reporters as Donors
text: Bill Dedman, an investigative reporter with MSNBC.com, posted a set of articles online today about journalists who have contributed to candidates, political parties and political groups. He combed through federal filings of contributions to campaigns and organizations, and here are his findings:

headline: K.K.R. Hires Bankers for a Potential I.P.O.
text: Even as the Blackstone Group prepared to price its initial public offering Thursday night amid heightened scrutiny from Washington, one of its major rivals was considering stepping into the limelight. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has hired Morgan Stanley and Citigroup to prepare a possible I.P.O. later this year, people familiar with the matter told DealBook. The news was first reported by CNBC’s Charles Gasparino.

headline: Assembly to Microsoft: Reboot
text: We reported today on several disputable and under-the-radar bills or proposals circulating through the Assembly, including language apparently being circulated by lobbyists for Microsoft that critics say would gut the state’s voting-machine integrity law.

headline: Edwards Starts Texting for Dollars
text: Many of us have come to rely on cell phone text messaging to ask and answer all sorts of everyday questions – things like: “Want 2 meet 4 coffee?” or “U going 2 the pty @ 8?”

headline: Rupert Murdoch’s $12 Billion Trial Balloon
text: There is a lot of skepticism surrounding the idea that News Corporation will trade MySpace for a 25 percent stake in Yahoo. Reports of the talks, which the Tech Confidential blog describes as having the distinct smell of a “well-timed leak,” are said to be very preliminary, and Yahoo may decide that it’s not interested.

headline: Secret Societies: Yale and Disneyland
text: Skull and Bones spent what must have been an excruciating day or so on news sites across the Web this week when The Associated Press put out a story about the Apache quest to retrieve Geronimo’s remains, a legend fortified with a few pieces of evidence.

headline: Silver Gives Green Light to Bill for H.I.V. Testing of Rape Suspects
text: A bill that would require H.I.V. testing of suspects indicted on rape charges appears likely to become law.

headline: G.E. and Pearson End Talks on Dow Jones Bid
text: One potential white knight for Dow Jones has ridden into the sunset.

headline: Turf War Over a Brooklyn Patronage Prize
text: It seems as if there is always some political battle within the boroughs of New York City where, on center stage, is either race and ethnicity. Or a turf war waged by one political club or another, or the party organization seeking to flex its muscles.

headline: The War at Home: Feuding Democrats
text: As the Senate prepares to open another major debate over Iraq next month, a dispute is percolating in an unlikely corner: two Democrats who both voted against going to war.

headline: Island Hopping
text: After an unusual spike in news about islands, The Lede takes a tour from Japan to New York.

headline: A Special Break for Atlantic Yards
text: The State Assembly passed a significant expansion of New York City’s 421a tax-incentive program this afternoon, and Senate approval is expected shortly in Albany. The current program provides property tax abatements to developers in certain neighborhoods of the city if 20 percent of the units in any building are priced for lower-income residents, making 80 percent of the area median income.

headline: Summer Begins … Now
text: Today is the day. At 2:06 p.m. — right now — the sun is at its highest point. Or something like that.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene
text: Director Michael Winterbottom dissects a scene from "A Mighty Heart," starring Angelina Jolie.

headline: Two More Politicians Line Up to Blast Blackstone I.P.O.
text: Yet more politicians have taken aim at the Blackstone Group‘s forthcoming initial public offering on the eve of its pricing. In a letter to the Securities and Exchange Commission Thursday, Henry A. Waxman, the Democratic chairman of the House Oversight Committee, and Dennis Kucinich, a Democratic congressman from Ohio and a presidential hopeful, warned that the I.P.O. may present “new and undisclosed risks.”

headline: Carefully Headed Racing Buffs Attend Ascot
text: The annual spectacle let's racegoers find creative diversions with hat-styles from elegant to outlandish.

headline: Deal Is Near on Congestion Pricing Panel
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer emerged briefly from end-of-session legislative negotiations today to say that a deal is near on a commission to examine Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s congestion pricing plan in Albany.

headline: Evercore Hires Energy Banker from Citi
text: Stephen P. Schaible, formerly a managing director and head of global energy banking at Citigroup, will join Evercore Partners in September as a senior managing director, where he cover the energy and chemicals sectors out of New York, Evercore said Thursday.

headline: With Bonds Closing In, Torre Feels for Aaron
text: The Yankees travel to San Francisco after today’s game in Denver, and there they will face Barry Bonds, who needs eight home runs to break Hank Aaron’s record of 755.

headline: Killing in the Name of God
text: The most bizarre experience on this trip so far has been the visit to General Laurent Nkunda. It’s hardly an everyday occurrence to go to the military camp of an actual “warlord” who is accused of raping and massacring thousands. (He prefers to be referred to as “liberator of the people”, and denies all allegations against him.) That a journalist well known for opposing him had just been assassinated in the Congo, and that General Nkunda made several references to our security, made us apprehensive during the interview and cautious in subsequent reporting.

headline: New Head for State Art Collection
text: Agnes Gund, 68, a longtime arts patron and president emerita of the Museum of Modern Art, has been named chairwoman of the Empire State Plaza Art Commission. The Empire State Plaza Art Collection began in the late 1960s under the patronage of Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller and — like the Rockefeller family — has had longstanding ties to the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Prognosis Excellent
text: The instant reviews of “Sicko,” Michael Moore’s new movie, are beginning to trickle onto the Web. Eric Alterman, who has taken his “Altercation” blog from MSBNC.com to Media Matters, calls it “by far Moore’s best film: good humored, compelling, and, amazingly, it’s actually fun.”

headline: Fleet-Footed Lehman Women Trounce Rivals
text: Lehman Brothers consistently ranks high in Wall Street’s investment-banking league tables, but it was the sisters at Lehman who dominated day one of this year’s J.P. Morgan Corporate Challenge. The annual footrace in New York’s Central Park is historically so crowded with Wall Streeters that Banker’s Ball dubs it the “Bankerthon.”

headline: Mike Wallace: ‘Gotham,’ Public Health, the Meaning of ‘Manhattan’
text: Here is the latest installment from Mike Wallace, the historian and author of “Gotham,” who has been taking questions from readers this week. He will post more answers on Friday, but he is not accepting any new questions.

headline: Q & A:  Nicole Kaplan
text: Nicole Kaplan has been the executive pastry chef at the Italian restaurant Del Posto since January. She made her reputation with the work she did before then at Eleven Madison Park, where she spent seven years and where her desserts were one of the restaurant’s standout attractions.

headline: Peltz Takes a Stake in Kraft
text: Billionaire investor Nelson Peltz bought a 3 percent stake in Kraft Foods, a person with knowledge of the matter told Bloomberg News, confirming a report by CNBC. The company’s shares jumped 6.6 percent, the most in 11 months.

headline: The Nature of F1’s green effort
text: Formula One made the cover story of Nature magazine today, as the highly respected science journal investigates Max Mosley’s green future for the sport. The cover has the headline: “HOW GREEN IS THIS?” with a photo of a McLaren and a Ferrari racing. Inside, the headline reads: “Formula 1 racing: Power games”

headline: Staten Island: The Exception to the Decline in Smoking
text: Always ready to buck a citywide trend, Staten Island was the one borough where the smoking rate did not decline dramatically over the past four years, according to statistics the city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene released today. The borough remains the city’s smokingest, by an increasingly wide margin.

headline: Supreme Court Takes A Middle Course
text: The Supreme Court decision in Tellabs today drew praise from trade groups for banks and trial lawyers. That alone should be an indication that it is anything but definitive in its effect. Even the Tellabs case may yet survive and go to trial, depending on how lower courts assess the facts in light of today’s opinion.

headline: Beware of Being Swallowed by Sand
text: Just when you thought it was safe to go back on the beach. … Now comes a report about the dangers of sand holes. Never mind the jellyfish — you probably know how to spot them in the water. This year, you’re also going to have to look down at the sand to avoid falling into a potentially dangerous hole. It could collapse around you. The Star Ledger’s Belmar Benny, a blogger, writes about the latest beach menace.

headline: Blackstone Prices at $31 a Unit in $4.13 Billion I.P.O.
text: They did it.

headline: America is Catching Up
text: Often, the best way to know what will be in the stores next year is to look at what the chip makers are doing now.

headline: Harry Potter Spoiler Spreads
text: Can you believe that someone posted the ending of Harry Potter on the the Web?

headline: Virginity, Lost
text: Do you suppose it’s possible today, somewhere in America, to graduate from high school with one’s virginity intact? Everything would seem to point away from the possibility.

headline: Nader Weighs a Run
text: He’s baaaack.

headline: Movie Minutes: 'Lady Chatterley'
text: The New York Times Co-Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "Lady Chatterley," a French take on D. H. Lawrence's racy novel.

headline: The Veil of French Politics
text: Ségolène Royal was the first woman from a major political party to run for President of France. She was the first French cabinet minister to give birth while in office. And now she has become the first French political figure to break up with her boyfriend – Socialist party head Francois Hollande, her concubin, according to French law, and the father of her four children – on the public airwaves.

headline: Movie Minutes: 'Sicko'
text: The New York Times Co-Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "Sicko," Michael Moore's documentary on the American health insurance industry.

headline: Win a Trip: Starfish in Congo
text: Leana Wen, who is traveling with Nicholas D. Kristof in Africa, followed up on the care of Yohanita.

headline: Immigration Hovers Over Bush-Sessions Event
text: ATHENS, Ala., — Senator Jeff Sessions, the Alabama Republican, is one of President Bush’s staunchest opponents on legislation to overhaul the nation’s immigration laws. But that didn’t stop Mr. Bush from traveling to Mobile today to raise money for Mr. Sessions’ reelection campaign.

headline: Buy My Eyeballs
text: For decades, media companies have struck an implicit bargain with consumers: put up with our advertisements, and we’ll give you content for free or on the cheap. But, lately, people have become a bit spoiled. Lots of content on the Internet is free without ads or it runs with ads that can easily be clicked shut. And more and more households have TiVos and other digital video recorders that allow people to zap past commercials.

headline: Ask the Transportation Commissioner
text: Update: Read answers.

headline: A Look at the Air Show
text: Highlights of the Paris air show, including Lockheed Martin's Joint Strike Fighter.

headline: June Blooms in the Bronx
text: The Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden re-opens after a $2.5 million renovation. The one-acre garden is in the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

headline: Readers’ Questions: Birth Order and Intelligence
text: In a recent study on birth order and intelligence, Norwegian researchers report that eldest children have higher I.Q.s than their younger siblings. Why would that be? There are as many guesses as there are scientists. “Virtually anyone who has a sibling is a birth-order theorist,” says Dr. Frank Sulloway, an expert on family dynamics at the University of California, Berkeley. Dr. Sulloway answered readers’ questions about the study and its implications; his answers appear below. [Editors’ note: questions are no longer being accepted.]

headline: Giuliani on Citgo, Cuba — and, Um, Gays and Hollywood
text: HIALEAH, Fla. – Rudolph Giuliani often talks about how dictators, bullies and tyrants need to be confronted and challenged.

headline: Slicing The Impact of Apple’s iPhone
text: I am intrigued by a theory proffered by John Hodulik, a telecommunications industry analyst with UBS Warburg. He believes that Nokia and Motorola could actually indirectly benefit from the sale of Apple’s competing iPhone. The reason has to do with the economics of handset subsidies — y’know, the few dollars to few hundred dollars that carriers give you to get you to buy a new handset and sign up for a two-year contract.

headline: Edwards Revisits ‘Two Americas’
text: Riffing off his Two Americas campaign theme, John Edwards took aim at the financial services industry in a speech tonight in New York, where he blamed a lack of industry regulation for the demise of the American Dream.

headline: Who Buys This Stock?
text: In my Friday column, I discuss Universal Express, a penny stock that is issuing billions of shares of stock each quarter. Those shares are evidently being sold in the market, and the cash enables the company to stay in business. A federal judge has ruled that those sales are illegal, but that has not stopped them.

headline: Did the United States Get a Gift?
text: Referee Benito Archundia’s decision to disallow a last-ditch Canadian equalizer helped send the United States advance to the Gold Cup final but left the Canadians fuming. Did Archundia get it right, or did he blow the call? Who are the best and worst referees at this year’s tournament, and why?

headline: Spy Director Ends Program on Satellites
text: WASHINGTON, June 21 The nation’s top intelligence official has decided to terminate a multibillion-dollar spy satellite program beset by spiraling costs and opposition from powerful lawmakers.

headline: Rosewood Residences at Mayakobá & Jubilee, Florida
text: Rosewood Residences at Mayakobá

headline: C.I.A. to Release Documents on Decades-Old Misdeeds
text: The Central Intelligence Agency will make public next week a collection of long-secret documents compiled in 1974 that detail domestic spying, assassination plots and other C.I.A. misdeeds in the 1960s and early 1970s, the agency’s director, Gen. Michael V. Hayden, said yesterday.

headline: Honk? No, Pray if You Hear a Loud Crack
text: O.K., we agree that “Deadliest Catch” has no peer. That landmark Discovery Channel series, which chronicles the derring-do of commercial crab-fishing boats off the Alaskan coast, ended Tuesday, with its highest-rated episode ever.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on May 9 about a new course at the State University of New York at Stony Brook on how to be an informed consumer of print, broadcast and Internet journalism misspelled the surname of a vice president of the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation, which helps finance the course. He is Eric Newton, not Newtown. The error was pointed out by Mr. Newton in an e-mail message this week.

headline: The Principle of 2nd Home, 2nd Vote
text: MOST people who buy a second home are seeking refuge, a place to recharge their psychic batteries, to leave the worries and trivia of their jobs and hometowns behind. The last thing on their minds, generally, is to get sucked into the whirlpool of local politics.

headline: Soup With Everything: A Freaky All-American Party in California
text: WHERE is this place? We tilted the handmade map every which way, reread the directions a fourth time and made yet another U-turn on a gorgeous dirt road lined with craggy oaks and broken fences. We’d driven four hours from San Francisco into the golden hills of Northern California with a sack of jalapeño peppers, and were nervous we wouldn’t make it before the welcome gate closed.

headline: High Goals for Reducing Emissions in New Jersey
text: The New Jersey Legislature passed a bill yesterday that set ambitious goals for reducing emissions of greenhouse gases from power plants, refineries, motor vehicles and other sources that contribute to global warming.

headline: Family Behind Foxwoods Loses Hold in Tribe
text: MASHANTUCKET PEQUOT INDIAN RESERVATION, Conn. — Things are different now for the Hayward family, who took this tiny tribal nation on a dizzying odyssey two decades ago from virtual dust to startling wealth and power.

headline: Japan: Abe Delays National Election
text: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe delayed the critical upper house election by a week, to July 29 from July 22, by extending Parliament’s current session by 12 days, in what was seen as a desperate move to regain popular support and dampen widespread anger over the government’s admission that it had misplaced payment information for millions of pensioners. Polls show that support for Mr. Abe and his Liberal Democratic Party has fallen dangerously low among potential voters, with the main opposition Democratic Party scoring higher in some polls. A significant defeat could put pressure on Mr. Abe to step down as party leader and prime minister, though his party would keep the prime minister’s post through its control over the lower house.

headline: U.S. Troops Find Buried Dangers at Outpost
text: ARAB JABOUR, Iraq, June 21 — The troops who settled into this jungle of tall grasses and sunburned palms five days ago fast discovered a new feature of an area that the military had neglected for more than a year: dozens of huge bombs buried beneath the road, some big enough to destroy a 130,000-pound Abrams tank.

headline: Girardi Rejects Shot at Managing the Orioles
text: Joe Girardi has turned down an opportunity to become the next manager of the Baltimore Orioles. Girardi told the team that accepting the position would not be conducive with his family situation.

headline: Dinner With Dad (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: New York Man Is Convicted in Nantucket Stabbing Death
text: NANTUCKET, Mass., June 21 — A New York man was convicted on Thursday of stabbing to death a Manhattan woman three years ago on this affluent island two days after she ended their relationship.

headline: Court Rules Coach’s Violations Are Not a Form of Free Speech
text: WASHINGTON, June 21  The Supreme Court on Thursday rejected the claim by a high school football powerhouse in Tennessee that its coach’s recruiting violations were a form of free speech that could not be penalized by the state athletic association.

headline: N.J. Man Kills 2 Daughters and Himself
text: A man apparently drowned his two young daughters in a bathtub and then hanged himself from the rafters of the attic in his home in Montclair, N.J., the Montclair police said yesterday.

headline: In Birdsong, a Call to Protect the Earth (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Brisk Demand in Emerging Markets Keeps Aircraft Makers Busy
text: NEW DELHI, June 21 — In the 1990s, a start-up airline or one in emerging markets would begin service with a few old planes and wait until customer demand and profits were solid before taking on the cost of new ones.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Woody Allen Gets His Night at the Opera

headline: Vetoing Stem Cells, Vetoing Life (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Queens: Hate Crimes Alleged in Assault on Elderly Women
text: A Long Island City man has been indicted on hate crimes charges in connection with the mugging of two elderly women in March, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Jack Rhodes, 44, of Vernon Boulevard, was indicted on charges of burglary, robbery and assault as hate crimes, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, adding that prosecutors believe that Mr. Rhodes chose his victims because of their advanced age. Mr. Brown said Mr. Rhodes repeatedly punched a 101-year-old woman while mugging her in the vestibule of her building on Highland Avenue in Jamaica Hills on March 4. She suffered a broken cheekbone. He also repeatedly punched an 85-year-old woman during a robbery in her 170th Street building about half an hour later, Mr. Brown said. She was cut and bruised by the attack. Mr. Rhodes pleaded not guilty at his arraignment yesterday in State Supreme Court.

headline: London Exchange May Bid $2 Billion for Borsa Italiana
text: The London Stock Exchange was considering making a bid of $2 billion to acquire Borsa Italiana, the operator of the stock exchange in Milan, two people close to the companies said. The two exchanges discussed a potential merger and were set to continue discussions today, a spokesman for Borsa Italiana said. The spokesman, Alessandro Pavesi, said the proposal from the London exchange is the only one being considered. Both exchanges have fended off takeover approaches in the last year, and a merger might help them avoid a takeover in the future, said Rupak Ghose, an analyst at Credit Suisse in London. “It is not surprising that the L.S.E. is looking at different alternatives to become larger and hence avoid becoming acquired,” Mr. Ghose said in a note to investors.

headline: Stop-Time and Symmetry, Punch Lines and Pathos
text: Branford Marsalis and Joshua Redman are in good places. By the end of their JVC Jazz Festival concert on Wednesday at Town Hall — Mr. Redman’s trio went first, Mr. Marsalis’s quartet second — they had put the crowd into happy exhaustion. It had been pummeled with hard stuff, engaged by delicate stuff, and there had been remarkably little glibness going around.

headline: Chinese Food in America (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Firefighter’s Fatal Fall Cut Short a Lifelong Pursuit
text: Firefighter Daniel F. Pujdak fell to his death yesterday while trying to save an artist’s loft less than two miles from the three-story aluminum-sided house in Greenpoint where he was raised.

headline: Kazakhstan: Unicredit Unit Bids for Bank
text: Bank Austria Creditanstalt, a unit of UniCredit, bid $2.2 billion to acquire AO ATF Bank of Kazakhstan to tap an oil-related boom in the former Soviet Union. Bank Austria said that it had agreed to buy at least 85 percent of the bank, which is based in Almaty and has corporate and retail operations, and that it hopes to acquire the remaining shares. ATF Bank has 110 branches and assets valued at 6.3 billion euros ($8.4 billion) and a market share of 11.8 percent. Austria Creditanstalt is based in Vienna, and UniCredit is based in Milan.

headline: G.M. to Alter Tiger Woods’s Role in Its Ads
text: DETROIT, June 21  After eight years as the face of Buick, Tiger Woods is still less than half the age of an average Buick owner.

headline: Old bin Laden Interview Is Allowed Into Padilla’s Trial
text: MIAMI, June 21  Over strong objections from the defense, the judge in the terrorism case against Jose Padilla ruled on Thursday that prosecutors could play parts of an old television interview with Osama bin Laden to bolster their case against Mr. Padilla and two co-defendants.

headline: New Wharton Dean
text: Thomas S. Robertson, a professor of marketing, has been named dean of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, university officials announced. Dr. Robertson, left, is currently the executive faculty director of the Institute for Developing Nations at Emory University in Atlanta. Dr. Robertson taught from 1971 to 1994 at Wharton. He will succeed Patrick Harker, who will become president of the University of Delaware.

headline: Tapping Out Fusion: Is That One Tutu Too Many?
text: No one has ever mistaken Savion Glover for Fred Astaire, and therein lies his appeal. With his signature dreadlocks, baggy clothes and rambunctious virtuosity, Mr. Glover, 33, is often credited with single-handedly reviving tap dance from genteel movie entertainment to a vibrant American art form with the street cred and youthful appeal of hip-hop.

headline: Without O’Donnell, ‘View’ Keeps Its Viewers
text: Maybe they don’t miss Rosie so much after all.

headline: Surveillance Program Debated
text: The chairman of the House Intelligence Committee said that former Attorney General John Ashcroft told the panel in a closed session that the Bush administration was sharply split over the legality of the domestic eavesdropping program. Representative Silvestre Reyes, a Texas Democrat who leads the panel, said that it was clear to him that “there was enormous debate in the administration about the legal basis” for the program. Also, the Senate Judiciary Committee authorized, but did not issue, subpoenas to Mr. Gonzales and to the custodian of records for the president’s office to turn over all documents related to the eavesdropping program.

headline: Fixing the College Loan Mess
text: Congress has reacted to the college loan scandal with several strong proposals that would go a long way toward ending corruption while making loans more affordable for students and taxpayers. The House has passed a bill that would make it a crime for lenders to solicit business by offering college officials anything of value and force lenders to disclose any existing deals. And both houses are on the verge of approving legislation that would cut some $19 billion in wasteful subsidies to the Federal Family Education Loan Program.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A sports article on April 8 about Michigan State’s 3-1 victory over Boston College to capture the N.C.A.A. men’s ice hockey championship misidentified the player who scored the only goal for the Eagles. It was Brian Boyle  not Brock Bradford, who had the assist. The reporter pointed out the error this week.

headline: Painting a Rosy Picture of a Costly Fighter Jet
text: LE BOURGET, France, June 21 — With jets screaming overhead, macho often mixes with Mach 1 here at the Paris air show. But the Lockheed Martin Corporation chose a softer approach to show the might of its next-generation radar-evading, supersonic fighter jet.

headline: Home Depot Amendment
text: Squatting beside the bulk of the Senate immigration bill — a once-in-a-generation attempt to change millions of lives and the direction of the nation — you will find a squalid little amendment. It was placed there by Senator Johnny Isakson of Georgia to benefit an Atlanta-based corporate constituent, Home Depot.

headline: Art in Review
text: DAVID LAMELAS Maccarone 630 Greenwich Street, at Morton Street, West Village Through July 28

headline: Land of Lincoln
text: How do Americans love Abraham Lincoln? Andrew Ferguson counts the ways in “Land of Lincoln,” his hilarious, offbeat tour of Lincoln shrines, statues, cabins and museums. The 16th president comes in many forms, and every one, it seems, has a following, right down to Lincoln the chief executive officer, dispenser of corporate leadership tips.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Fleeting Structures and Nomadic Art
text: LONDON, June 21 — A futuristic structure rising about 18 feet will soon appear on an open field just south of the Serpentine Gallery in Kensington Gardens here. The work of the London architect Zaha Hadid and her partner, Patrik Schumacher, the creation will exist for only a week, timed to coincide with the annual Serpentine summer party on July 11.

headline: After One Objection, Senate Confirms Corzine’s Choice for Chief Justice
text: TRENTON, June 21 — Despite an unexpected objection from a lone legislator that surfaced a week ago, the New Jersey Senate on Thursday confirmed Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s choice for chief justice of the State Supreme Court.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article last Friday about declining populations of once common birds misidentified one shorebird in decline. It is the common tern, not the greater tern.

headline: Justices Support Guidelines for Sentencing
text: WASHINGTON, June 21  Defendants may find it more difficult to challenge a sentence that is within the guidelines issued by the United States Sentencing Commission, under a ruling by the Supreme Court on Thursday.

headline: Louise Bourgeois, Evoking Heart and Libido
text: Such is the fame of the 95-year-old sculptor Louise Bourgeois that you never have to hunt very hard for a show of her work. Even as we speak, a glimpse of her prodigious production is on view at the Storm King Art Center in Mountainville, N.Y.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on June 13 about Don Herbert, who appeared on television in the 1950s and ’60s as Mr. Wizard, misstated the name of the institution in Princeton, N.J., with which the physicist Frank Wilczek was affiliated in 1990, when he was interviewed about informal approaches to teaching science and praised Mr. Herbert. It is the Institute for Advanced Study, not Studies.

headline: Outdoors Is the Way Up in Ogden, Utah
text: WEDGED between old stockyards and a boarded-up packing plant on the western edge of town, the kayak park is not easy to find. But it is just the kind of thing that draws outdoor enthusiasts to Ogden, Utah.

headline: Upbeat Economic News Helps Lift Shares
text: Stocks rebounded yesterday from their worst day in two weeks after Merrill Lynch assuaged concern of a looming credit crisis and the latest government report on the economy showed growth was accelerating.

headline: Once Again, Trade Effort Stumbles on Subsidies
text: FRANKFURT, June 21  A high-level meeting aimed at salvaging global trade talks collapsed Thursday when the United States and the European Union fell out with India and Brazil over plans to cut agricultural subsidies and tariffs.

headline: Sudden Power Show Sets Up Rematch for North Carolina
text: OMAHA, June 21 — The setup was perfect. Rice and North Carolina, who met in Thursday night’s bracket final at the College World Series, had been stunned and eliminated last year by Oregon State, the surprise champion.

headline: New Community Center Gets Youths Off Streets and in the Ring
text: NEWARK, June 21 — The fight was brief. The mayor of Newark, Cory A. Booker, floated like a butterfly, bouncing around a bit in oversized gloves. But it was 14-year-old Shakor Jackson who stung like a bee.

headline: Research Finds Firstborns Gain the Higher I.Q.
text: The eldest children in families tend to develop higher I.Q.’s than their siblings, researchers are reporting today, in a large study that could settle more than a half-century of scientific debate about the relationship between I.Q. and birth order.

headline: Climbing Out on a Limb and Then Crawling Back
text: The low-key comedy “Broken English,” about a romance-scarred professional woman named Nora Wilder (Parker Posey) who invigorates her life with help from a handsome, sensitive, fedora-clad Frenchman (Melvil Poupaud), is a textbook example of an Indiewood film: a Hollywood fantasy wrapped in plain brown paper.

headline: The Little Engine That Could Poison
text: FOR decades, Thomas the Tank Engine and his fellow trains have been teaching children important life lessons. Now the plucky locomotives — especially the haughty and sometimes naughty James the Red Engine — are serving up important lessons about regulating environmental poisons in the global economy.

headline: The China Puzzle
text: The “Chinese miracle” has been the biggest economic story for several years now, a tale of a nation rising from the ashes of a Stalinist command economy to become the world’s premier trading partner. But China reminds us with distressing regularity that the progress has been selective.

headline: Renewed to Keep the Bloom on the Rose
text: Rose Month events at the New York Botanical Garden conclude this weekend with free tours of the Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden and question-and-answer sessions with experts.

headline: Brooklyn: Second Reprieve on Judge’s Sentence
text: A former judge was given a second reprieve on his prison sentence yesterday and allowed to enter an alcohol detoxification program. The former judge, Gerald P. Garson, 74, was convicted of accepting bribes to manipulate matrimonial cases in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. This month, Justice Jeffrey Berry of State Supreme Court sentenced Mr. Garson to 3 to 10 years, but after the hearing, an appellate court judge gave Mr. Garson a temporary stay to file an appeal. This week, the appellate court judge ordered Mr. Garson to begin his sentence and revoked the stay. But yesterday, Justice Berry, responding to defense arguments that Mr. Garson would probably die in prison without treatment for alcoholism, allowed Mr. Garson to attend a detoxification program until July 5 before beginning his sentence.

headline: Afghans Say NATO Bombs Kill 25 Civilians
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 22 — At least 25 civilians, including nine women, three babies and an elderly village mullah, were killed in an air strike early this morning when they were caught in a battle between Taliban and NATO forces in southern Afghanistan, said the police chief of Helmand province.

headline: Pakistan: Like Rushdie, a Lofty Title for bin Laden
text: A group of clerics, the Pakistan Ulema Council, said they had given Osama bin Laden the title Saifullah, or sword of Allah, in response to the British government’s decision to give Salman Rushdie, the author of “The Satanic Verses,” a knighthood. The chairman of the council, Tahir Ashrafi, said that since Mr. Rushdie, who is considered a blasphemer by many Muslims in Pakistan, had been given the title “Sir,” then Mr. bin Laden, a holy warrior in the eyes of the council, should be given a parallel title. The gesture was a more lighthearted reaction to the honor for Mr. Rushdie than the noisy protests of demonstrators in some cities of Pakistan. On Monday, Pakistan’s Parliament passed a resolution condemning the knighthood and said it should be withdrawn.

headline: Might Drink Your Blood, but Otherwise Not Bad Guys
text: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 20 — These days Charity Bokindo, the district commissioner of Nairobi North, is taking no chances.

headline: A Successful Cultural Exchange With No High-Fives
text: VALENCIA, Spain, June 21  So how do you take two proud Americans like Terry Hutchinson and Kevin Hall and turn them each into someone who could pass for a Kiwi?

headline: Manhattan: Marketing Officer Resigns
text: New York City’s chief marketing officer, Maureen J. Reidy, resigned yesterday to become chief operating officer of IMG Fashion, which puts on Fashion Week shows. Ms. Reidy had been responsible for sponsorship deals for the city and attracting major events, like the 2004 Republican National Convention and the 2008 Major League Baseball All-Star Game. George A. Fertitta, chief executive of NYC & Company, the city’s marketing and tourism promotion agency, has not decided how to replace Ms. Reidy, a spokeswoman said.

headline: British Girl Sues  for Right to Wear Chastity Ring
text: LONDON, June 22 — At a time of passionate debate over religious clothing and emblems, a 16-year-old British Christian sued her school in court today for the right to wear a so-called purity ring symbolizing her commitment to pre-marital chastity.

headline: Oh, Dolly! When Sheep Go Bad, Forget the Peace in the Valley
text: “It’s an exciting time to be involved in agricultural science.” The achievement of “Black Sheep,” a pastoral horror-comedy from New Zealand, can be measured in its ability to make that sentence sound both sinister and hilarious. The movie is essentially a silly, grisly elaboration of a simple idea: What if sheep started running amok, feasting on human flesh and turning their victims into huge ovine zombies?

headline: The Bones We Carried
text: Chicago

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Hank Medress, 68, Doo-Wop Singer on ‘Lion Sleeps Tonight’, Dies
text: Hank Medress, a founding member of the 1960s doo-wop group the Tokens, whose biggest hit was “The Lion Sleeps Tonight,” died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 68.

headline: Nine Days Ahead of Schedule, New Jersey Legislature Passes a Budget
text: TRENTON, June 21 — It was like the Legislature’s version of speed-dating.

headline: Open Wide and Say ‘Shame’
text: It has become a journalistic cliché and therefore an inevitable part of the prerelease discussion of “Sicko” to refer to Michael Moore as a controversial, polarizing figure. While that description is not necessarily wrong, it strikes me as self-fulfilling (since the controversy usually originates in media reports on how controversial Mr. Moore is) and trivial. Any filmmaker, politically outspoken or not, whose work is worth discussing will be argued about. But in Mr. Moore’s case the arguments are more often about him than about the subjects of his movies.

headline: Israel: Gay Parade Draws 2,500
text: A parade in Jerusalem in favor of gay rights passed off largely peacefully despite vocal opposition and protests by ultra-Orthodox citizens. The police arrested a man they said was carrying a homemade bomb he said he intended to put along the route. Some 2,500 people marched, according to the police, half the 5,000 that had been expected.

headline: Picturing the Past
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Corrections
text: The Keeping Score column on Sunday, about new baseball research into hitting and fielding trends that can help assess the impact of pitchers, referred incorrectly to the status of the journeyman Glendon Rusch. He is recovering from a blood-clot scare last season, and is not pitching now; he is not out of the game because he “appears to have run out of employers to disappoint” with his statistically below-average pitching. (Go to Article)

headline: New U.N. Plan Commits $2.15 Billion to Fight Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis
text: The World Health Organization yesterday released a plan intended to prevent hundreds of thousands of cases of drug-resistant tuberculosis and save up to 134,000 lives by 2008.

headline: When Preaching Flops
text: A little while ago, a national study authorized by Congress found that abstinence education programs don’t work. That gave liberals a chance to feel superior because it turns out that preaching traditional morality to students doesn’t change behavior.

headline: Agency Is Target in Cheney Fight on Secrecy Data
text: For four years, Vice President Dick Cheney has resisted routine oversight of his office’s handling of classified information, and when the National Archives unit that monitors classification in the executive branch objected, the vice president’s office suggested abolishing the oversight unit, according to documents released yesterday by a Democratic congressman.

headline: In Surprise Move, U.S. Envoy Visits North Korea
text: TOKYO, June 21 — The United States’ chief nuclear negotiator on Thursday began a surprise two-day visit to North Korea, saying he wanted to speed up six-nation talks aimed at dismantling North Korea’s nuclear program.

headline: Senate Adopts Energy Bill Raising Mileage for Cars
text: WASHINGTON, June 21 — The Senate passed a broad energy bill late Thursday that would, among other things, require the first big increase in fuel mileage requirements for passenger cars in more than two decades.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about the defense editor of the newspaper Haaretz who was considered the dean of Israeli military correspondents misstated his surname at one point. As the article noted, he was Zeev Schiff and in subsequent references he should have been identified as Mr. Schiff, not Mr. Haaretz.

headline: A Yoga Class’s Path to Serenity Leads Through Times Square
text: Its fame and its claim to being the crossroads of the world make Times Square a prime spot for a variety of events, from protests to race-car demonstrations. But it would seem a poor setting for something meant to produce serenity.

headline: Are Bonuses for Law Clerks Also Good for Society? (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lottery Numbers
Splat! One Less Mutant to Deal With
text: IS that all you’ve got?!”

headline: Author Defrauded Movie Company, Jury Finds
text: JT Leroy, the authorial “other” whom the writer Laura Albert employed as her alter ego and self-protective proxy in the world, was found yesterday by a jury in Manhattan to be not just a fictional creation but a fraud.

headline: Survivors Recount Fatal Catskill Flood as Missing Are Sought
text: COLCHESTER, N.Y., June 22 — It was not the first flood for Josephine Banks, whose property sits amid the fabled trout streams of the western Catskill Mountains. And so when the water started rising on Tuesday night, she had a strategy: Throw open the doors of the barn where she has a second-floor apartment and let the roiling creek flow through.

headline: What Is Bloomberg Really Trying to Do? (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Firefighter Falls to His Death in Brooklyn Fire
text: A 23-year-old firefighter was killed in Brooklyn yesterday when he fell four stories while fighting a small blaze ignited by a cigarette that had been left on a windowsill, officials said.

headline: For the Record
text: An article on Sunday about the disbarment of Michael B. Nifong, the district attorney in Durham County, N.C., misstated the surname of a North Carolina State Bar lawyer who made closing arguments in the ethics trial of Mr. Nifong. He is Doug Brocker, not Doug Brock.

headline: Shaken and Stirred: For Liquor Campaigns, the Web’s the Thing
text: TO introduce Reyka, an Icelandic vodka, William Grant & Sons is running a quirky campaign with a wit as dry as a well-made martini. There are erupting volcanoes, enigmatic puffins, “fun facts” about Iceland and comely women dressed for the cold rather than as they typically appear in liquor ads.

headline: Dog Day at Christie’s
text: Bowing to a dog-crazed public, Christie’s is holding its first New York sale today dedicated to dogs in art: 95 paintings and sculptures dating from the 17th century to the present.

headline: Rain and Clouds Make NASA Cancel Shuttle Landing
text: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla., June 21 — Rain and clouds forced NASA to wave off two landing opportunities for the space shuttle Atlantis Thursday afternoon.

headline: 14 Americans Are Killed in Combat in 2 Days
text: BAGHDAD, June 21 — Fourteen Americans were killed in combat in five attacks, most in Baghdad, in a 48-hour period ending Thursday, the military announced.

headline: Shuttle Lands Safely in California
text: The space shuttle Atlantis set down safely at Edwards Air Force Base in California today at 3:49 p.m. Eastern time, ending its 5.8-million-mile, 14-day mission.

headline: One Day (and Dead Body) at a Time
text: With its shadows and gallows humor, “You Kill Me” goes about as dark as a comedy can go before turning into tragedy or self-parody. Its ethnic stereotypes are Polish mobsters from Buffalo, which just means that they eat kielbasa instead of Italian sausage and traffic in real snow. They don’t have much juice, only a chunk of the city, but they speak the same patois as the usual players, doing shakedowns and takedowns between analyzing this and that. They’re not especially wise, these guys; if anything, they’re kind of sad.

headline: In Colorado, Yankees Take a Turn for the Worse
text: DENVER, June 21 — As Roger Clemens threw his warm-up pitches before the bottom of the first inning, a fan in the front row at Coors Field held up a sign chiding the Yankees for paying “$28 million for a dinosaur.”

headline: CBS Leads in Ad Commitments for Fall Season
text: The sale of commercial time before the start of the 2007-8 broadcast television season is winding up as three big networks garner commitments from advertisers.

headline: Bush Advisers Weigh Closing Guantánamo Prison Sooner
text: WASHINGTON, June 22 — President Bush’s top advisers have reopened an internal debate over how quickly to close the American detention unit for suspected terrorists at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, according to administration officials familiar with the deliberations.

headline: Trails, Trains and a Syrup House in Woodstock, Vt.
text: WOODSTOCK, Vt., is an old-fashioned town that's not stuck in the past. Mixed in with vintage grocery stores, antique farms and a covered bridge is a comfortable assortment of coffee shops, art stores and fun boutiques with an upscale but rural tinge, like the Vermont Flannel Company (20 Central Street, 802-476-5226; www.vermontflannel.com), which sells everything from nightshirts to red and green tartan flannel underwear.

headline: In Sweep of Iraqi Town, Sectarian Fears Percolate
text: BAQUBA, Iraq, June 21 — After two days of clawing their way toward insurgent strongholds in western Baquba, American troops on Thursday began one of the most delicate phases of the operation: reintroducing the city’s residents to their own army.

headline: Making Waves in Dairyland
text: WASHINGTON, June 19 — Ron Kind, a Democratic representative from Wisconsin dairyland, is making a name for himself as a crusader for big changes in farm policy. It’s making many of his colleagues nervous.

headline: Mexico Moves to Send Ex-Governor to U.S. on Drug Charges
text: MEXICO CITY, June 21  Mexico took the first steps on Thursday toward extraditing the former governor of Quintana Roo to the United States, where he is wanted in New York City on charges of drug trafficking, money laundering and racketeering.

headline: Ed Friendly, 85, a Producer of ‘Little House’, Dies
text: Ed Friendly, co-producer of hit television shows including the rambunctious “Rowan & Martin’s Laugh-In” and the frontier saga “Little House on the Prairie,” died Sunday at his home in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif. He was 85.

headline: A Time to Reflect, as Some Orchestra Members Bid Goodbye
text: Certain places on the calendar, arbitrarily chosen though they are, invite people to contemplate the trajectories of their lives, their present positions and what brought them there. The last subscription series of the New York Philharmonic’s season began on Wednesday night. New hirings were announced from the stage, and five retiring members were given public goodbyes.

headline: Spitzer and Legislature Sprint to Finish Line
text: ALBANY, June 21  Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s first legislative session was coming to a fractious close on Thursday night, as he and top lawmakers failed to reach agreement on a wide range of issues as they rushed to finish business for the summer.

headline: Why Pro-Choice Is a Bad Choice for Democrats
text: Washington

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: ABC Says It Was Outbid for Paris Hilton Interview
text: How much is an interview with Paris Hilton worth? Representatives of ABC News said yesterday that they had lost to NBC for the first interview with Paris Hilton after her release from jail next week because ABC was unwilling to make a “high six-figure deal” with Ms. Hilton’s family.

headline: New Jersey Man Kills 2 Daughters and Self
text: A man apparently drowned his two young daughters in a bathtub and then hanged himself from the rafters of the attic in his home in Montclair, N.J., the Montclair police said yesterday.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A sports article on Wednesday about a lawsuit by the tennis player Guillermo Coria against a nutritional supplement company that he blames for his positive steroid test referred incorrectly to an arrangement in professional basketball designed to ensure safe and pure supplements for athletes. The N.B.A. players union, not the league itself, has such a deal with a supplement maker.

headline: Bosnia: Study Puts War Dead at 97,207
text: A total of 97,207 people were killed or disappeared in the 1992-1995 war in Bosnia, according to a three-year study by the Sarajevo-based Research and Documentation Center. The center, which describes itself as independent and nonpartisan, said it had names for all the dead cited in its study. It said that close to two-thirds of the casualties, 64,036, were Bosnian Muslims, followed by Serbs, 24,905, and Croats, 7,788, while 478 were of other nationalities. Almost half of the casualties died in the first year of the war. Of the total dead, 57,523 were directly involved in the war and 39,684 were civilians.

headline: For Schumer, the Double-Edged Sword of Cozying Up to Hedge Funds
text: They are not normally a shy group, the hedge fund managers, private equity titans and Wall Street executives whose net worth has suddenly become a national issue. But last spring, when a group of them gathered at the Regency in New York for a Democratic fund-raiser, they were downright bashful.

headline: School Crossing Guard Is Charged With 1,000 Counts of Child Molesting
text: BERWICK, Pa., June 21 — Michele Andreas says she is never going to trust anyone to watch her three boys again.

headline: Seen on the Street: Photographers’ ‘Everyday Epiphanies’
text: When artists talk about “training the eye,” they generally don’t mean doing exercises to maintain 20/20 vision. They mean honing a set of instincts, learning to see relationships among colors or objects or spaces. The title of this small but potent collection of contemporary photographs from the Metropolitan Museum’s collection describes this kind of vision another way: seeing what is “Hidden in Plain Sight.” The show focuses mostly on versions of street, rather than studio, photography.

headline: Backing Fatah and Abbas, Egypt Organizes Summit Meeting for Palestinian Leader
text: GAZA, June 21 — In a gesture of support for the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah, Egypt has organized a summit meeting in which he will meet with President Hosni Mubarak and the Jordanian and Israeli leaders.

headline: With ABN Amro in Play, Chief of Barclays Capital Savors a New Test
text: LONDON, June 21 — Robert E. Diamond Jr., the 55-year-old president of Barclays, grinned, rubbed his palms together, and then hopped up and down in his office chair like a 5-year-old.

headline: Budget Nominee Knows Thing or Two About Spending
text: WASHINGTON, June 21 — Former Representative Jim Nussle of Iowa, President Bush’s new choice for budget director, is no stranger to the ways in which members of Congress can drive federal spending higher.

headline: Brooklyn: Attack on Officer Investigated
text: The police yesterday continued their investigation of the sexual assault of an off-duty police officer who was attacked at knifepoint by a masked man in her Brooklyn apartment on Wednesday night. The woman, whose name, age and rank were not released, had just gotten off work when, shortly after 6:30 p.m., she was attacked by a man who investigators believe broke into her Bay Ridge apartment through a rear window where an air-conditioner had been installed, the police said. The man grabbed her from behind, sexually assaulted her and then fled, possibly through the same window, the police said. The woman called another officer from her precinct to report the attack. It was not known if she knew her attacker or if he knew she was an officer.

headline: Mets and Glavine Backing Into a Corner
text: Andy Van Slyke batted .354 in 65 career at-bats, including the postseason, against Tom Glavine. But he says he believes he had only one hit off him, a home run in the 1991 National League Championship Series.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: Bob Evans, 89, Restaurateur With Chain Built on Sausage, Dies
text: Bob Evans, who turned a 12-stool restaurant into a nationwide chain and food empire with the help of his homemade sausage, died yesterday, Bob Evans Farm Inc. said. He was 89.

headline: Niceness Counts in Ark-Building, Too
text: “Evan Almighty,” in which Steve Carell, playing a newly elected congressman from Buffalo, is commanded by God (Morgan Freeman) to build an ark, is a movie far less interesting than its premise. It is also slightly less interesting than its hugely popular predecessor, “Bruce Almighty,” which starred Jim Carrey. But there is nonetheless a fruitful franchise in the making here, a potentially endless series of movies with popular, sometimes naughty comedians acting out wholesome modern-day versions of well-known Bible stories.

headline: Scooping Up a Deal
text: WHO Joyce Tang, 29, the owner of a technology consulting company, from San Diego

headline: G.E. and Pearson Decide Against Dow Jones Bid
text: General Electric Company said today that it and Pearson, the British publisher, had decided against making an offer for Dow Jones & Company, owner of The Wall Street Journal, leaving Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation as the sole bidder.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A brief report in the Off the Menu column in the Dining section on Wednesday, about the opening of the restaurant Muse in Water Mill, N.Y., misstated the telephone number. It is (631) 726-2606.

headline: Foundation With Real Money Ventures Into Virtual World
text: For the first time, one of the nation’s largest foundations is venturing into virtual worlds to play host to activities and discussions and explore the role that philanthropy might play there.

headline: Peltz Is Said to Be Pressing for Sale of Some Kraft Brands
text: Nelson Peltz, the activist investor, does not like Fruity Pebbles cereal or Maxwell House coffee.

headline: In Aiding Poor, Edwards Built Bridge to 2008
text: John Edwards ended 2004 with a problem: how to keep alive his public profile without the benefit of a presidential campaign that could finance his travels and pay for his political staff.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Investors’ Suits Face Higher Bar, Justices Rule
text: WASHINGTON, June 21 — The Supreme Court on Thursday dealt a blow to investors who want to sue companies and executives because of suspected fraud, setting a higher standard for class-action lawsuits to go forward.

headline: This Time, It’s Personal: Mayor Blasts U.S. Envoy on London Toll
text: LONDON, June 21 — Diplomatic it was not. In a feud with the American ambassador here, London’s mayor notched up the vitriol on Thursday to the point of wishing harm, even terminal harm, to Washington’s envoy.

headline: In Writer’s Trial, a Conflict Over Roles of Art and Money
text: Florenz Ziegfeld’s notion of art’s subservience to commerce is an old idea in the entertainment field. In another form, it might be rendered that art is there only to make a buck.

headline: Blackstone Rival Plans Own I.P.O.
text: Now that the Blackstone Group is off and running, it needs to start looking over its shoulder.

headline: Killings Surge in Oakland, and Officials Are Unable to Explain Why
text: OAKLAND, Calif., June 15 — The names of friends and family members killed in this city over the last two years come easily to Rob Wilson, a rangy, dreadlocked 17-year-old gang member.

headline: People
text: People

headline: Speaking Simply of War and the True Courage of Heroes
text: In “Beyond Glory,” a solo show about war veterans that opened last night at the Laura Pels Theater, Stephen Lang portrays a series of former servicemen recollecting their combat experiences and the acts of courage that won them the United States military’s highest laurel, the Medal of Honor.

headline: South Korea: Lone Star May Sell Part of Bank
text: Lone Star Funds, the buyout firm founded by John Grayken, plans to sell a stake in Korea Exchange Bank for as much as $1.1 billion after its move to divest entirely was derailed last year by a legal dispute. Lone Star is offering 73.1 million shares, or 11.3 percent of Korea Exchange, for 13,150 to 13.750 won ($14.19 to $14.84) a share, according to an e-mail message sent to fund managers by the Credit Suisse Group, the investment bank arranging the sale. Shares in Korea Exchange fell 1.7 percent, to 14,600 won, up 14 percent this year. Lone Star, based in Dallas, has struggled for two years to sell the controlling stake it bought in 2003 as Korean prosecutors contend that the firm purchased the shares at an artificially low price. The sale of part of the Seoul-based bank would allow Lone Star to return money to investors while the case is pending and retain a majority stake.

headline: Cheney in Dispute on Oversight of His Office
text: For four years, Vice President Dick Cheney has resisted routine oversight of his office’s handling of classified information, and when the office in charge of overseeing classification in the executive branch objected, the vice president’s office suggested that the oversight office be shut down, according to documents released today by a Democratic congressman.

headline: Still Building a ‘Ladder to the Stars’
text: Robert Roane escorted Gretta Cohen to the senior prom on Thursday night.

headline: City Smokers’ Ranks Drop 19%, Study Says
text: The city’s department of health, citing a combination of high taxes, workplace limits and $10 million in grim television advertising, said yesterday that the number of smokers in New York City had declined by 240,000 in the last five years.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption with a sports article in some copies on Wednesday about the Rockies’ 3-1 victory against the Yankees misstated the score after Kaz Matsui crossed the plate for Colorado in the fifth inning. It was 2-1, not 2-0.

headline: Voucher Use in Washington Wins Praise of Parents
text: Students who participated in the first year of the District of Columbia’s federally financed school voucher program did not show significantly higher math or reading achievement, but their parents were satisfied anyway, viewing the private schools they attended at taxpayer expense as safer and better than public schools, according to an Education Department study released yesterday.

headline: Spain: Explosives Found in Car in South
text: The Civil Guard said it had found a car loaded with explosives in southern Spain. A spokesman said in a telephone interview that the car was found in Ayamonte, a popular tourist area close to the border with Portugal, and that the explosives were apparently in the process of being transported and were not rigged to a detonator. The radio station Cadena Ser put the amount at 220 pounds.
