The paramilitary Basque group ETA formally ended a 15-month cease-fire on June 5 and put Spain on the alert for possible terrorist attacks, particularly in southern areas frequented by tourists.

headline: Theater Listings
text: POTOMAC THEATER PROJECT After 20 years of producing theater in and around Washington, the Potomac Theater Project is hoping to call New York City home again. An earlier incarnation of the group, the New York Theater Studio, was active here from 1977 to 1985.

headline: Track Workers Reminded: Always Look Both Ways
text: Each year Bob Wills teaches hundreds of people who work on the subway tracks how to do their jobs without getting hit by a train — and he likes to tell them that they are going to fail his class.

headline: EBay Is Preparing to Re-enter the China Auction Business
text: STRASBOURG, France, June 21  EBay is on track to rejoin the online auction business in China this summer, with tight restrictions on sellers to clamp down on sales of counterfeit goods, the company’s chief executive said this week.

headline: From Cuba, With a Dream of the Majors
text: Geikel Conyedo may one day play professional baseball. Or he may merely be another high school star whose career stalls in college. Whatever happens, he has already overcome seemingly insurmountable obstacles on his journey to New Jersey from Cuba.

headline: Doping Scandal Puts Dark Cloud Over Coverage of Tour de France
text: The end of the Lance Armstrong era was not fated to be easy for Versus.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Correction: Where It All Started
text: Because of an editing error, an article last Friday about Independence Day celebrations misstated the given name of the British general who surrendered to American forces at Yorktown, Va. He was Charles Cornwallis, not George.

headline: Asking Serious Questions in a Very Quiet Voice
text: KASSEL, Germany, June 16 — Once every five summers the charismatic exhibition called Documenta transforms this ashen industrial city smack in the middle of the country into an international culture center. And even when the show bumps up against other big-deal events — the Venice Biennale and the Münster Sculpture Project both recently opened — it has a mystique of its own.

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: U.S. Envoy Finishes North Korea Talks
text: TOKYO, June 22 — The United States’ chief nuclear negotiator left North Korea today after a surprise visit with assurances that Pyongyang would slow down its main nuclear reactor, a move that would fulfill a commitment made in February and help speed six-nation talks aimed at dismantling North Korea’s nuclear program.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (Sci Fi) STARGATE SG-1 Over and out: Sci Fi’s longest-running original series comes to an end after 10 seasons, leaving the SG-1’s (played by Beau Bridges, Ben Browder, Lou Gossett Jr. and Amanda Tapping, among others) to explore galaxies we earthlings can only imagine. For mourning viewers, two “Stargate SG-1” films are reportedly in the works. Tonight, the Asgard, facing extinction, decide to hand over all their knowledge and technology to the team. But will there be time enough to stop the Ori?

headline: Officials Find Lapses by Trooper Who Drove Corzine in Parkway Accident
text: Law enforcement officials have concluded that the state trooper who was driving Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey during a devastating car accident two months ago was violating policy by speeding and using emergency lights, was not adequately aware of the situation and could have prevented the accident. As a result, the state police superintendent has disciplined the trooper, Robert J. Rasinski, though he declined to specify the punishment.

headline: A Trumpeter in His 80s Feeds the Fires of His Revolution
text: “The new thing, the third great revolution in jazz, has suddenly found its audience.” Whitney Balliett wrote those words in 1965, bestowing a serious subculture with a modicum of approval. By his estimation, jazz’s first two revolutions had been spearheaded respectively by Louis Armstrong and Charlie Parker. The “new thing,” a looser but better term than “the avant-garde,” seemed a bit more surprising in its appeal.

headline: Quartet to Meet on Palestinian Turmoil
text: JERUSALEM, June 22 — Diplomats from the United States, European Union, Russia and the United Nations plan to meet on Tuesday in Jerusalem, a day after the Israeli and Palestinian leaders meet with the leaders of Egypt and Jordan in Sharm el-Sheik, Egypt, said Israeli, Russian and U.N. officials.

headline: Water, Waves, Action
text: DURING the dog days of summer and into early autumn, the competitors and organizers of surfing competitions on the Atlantic and Pacific coasts gaze hopefully toward the south.

headline: Brooklyn: Evidence Turned Over in Case Against Bouncer
text: In their case against a bouncer accused of killing a 24-year-old graduate student, prosecutors yesterday gave defense lawyers four boxes of evidence described as medical reports and hair and fiber analyses. The defendant, Darryl Littlejohn, 42, has been charged with the murder of Imette St. Guillen, a student at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. Ms. St. Guillen’s body was found bound and strangled in a remote part of Brooklyn in February 2006, a day after she had visited a bar in SoHo where Mr. Littlejohn worked. No trial date has been scheduled. Prosecutors in Brooklyn are waiting for their counterparts in Queens to try Mr. Littlejohn first, on separate and unrelated kidnapping charges.

headline: Great Lakes Pollution Suit
text: Eight conservation groups led by the National Wildlife Federation announced plans to sue several shipping companies that operate in the Great Lakes, accusing them of discharging polluted water without the permit required under the federal Clean Water Act. The release of untreated ballast water, water held in the ballast tanks or cargo holds of ships to provide stability, introduces nonnative species that could harm the lakes’ ecosystem, the groups contend.

headline: Nader Weighs Another Run for President
text: Ralph Nader, whose run for president infuriated Democrats in 2000 and made him the object of disdain when he ran again in 2004, said today that he might get into the 2008 race.

headline: Reflections on Baryshnikov’s Latest (Not Last) Legs
text: MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV. Ballet superstar, company director, commissioner of choreography, collaborator, photographer, actor, children’s book author, artistic director of his own cultural center, Carrie Bradshaw’s perfidious boyfriend. But most of all, and most simply, dancer.

headline: Jim Shoulders, a Tenacious Rodeo Champion, Dies at 79
text: Jim Shoulders, a city boy who gained renown as the Babe Ruth of professional rodeo, riding bucking broncos and snorting bulls to a record 16 world-championship titles, died Wednesday in Henryetta, Okla. He was 79.

headline: Giambi Will Cooperate With M.L.B.’s Probe
text: Jason Giambi of the Yankees agreed yesterday to cooperate with George J. Mitchell’s investigation into the use of performance-enhancing drugs in Major League Baseball, apparently becoming the first active player who has consented to speak with Mitchell, the former United States Senator. Mitchell’s investigation is almost 15 months old.

headline: 3 Drug Makers Are Convicted in Reimbursement Overcharges
text: A federal judge ruled yesterday that AstraZeneca, Bristol-Myers Squibb and Schering-Plough must pay damages for overcharging on certain drugs paid for by Medicare, pension funds, insurers and patients.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Wednesday about the success of the New York Athletic Club’s elite women’s running team misstated a team member’s collegiate achievements. Julia Stamps Mallon was named an all-American at Stanford six times, not twice.

headline: A New Commissioner Enters the Fray Against Gridlock
text: IT sounds like a tall order, being asked by a reporter to “dumb down” the hellacious — or is it heaven-sent — concept of congestion pricing and its potentially redemptive role in releasing New York City’s midsection from the pain of gridlock. Congestion pricing is, after all, a very smart product. Ingenious, actually, if Janette Sadik-Khan, the tall (5-foot-8 in her svelte suede kitten heels) new commissioner of the city’s Department of Transportation, is consulted.

headline: Report Rates Hospitals on Their Heart Treatment
text: WASHINGTON, June 21 — The federal government has gingerly stepped back into rating the care delivered by the nation’s hospitals, releasing for the first time in nearly two decades a list of hospitals where heart patients are most likely to die.

headline: Port Authority Tentatively Approves Changes Aimed at Increasing Public Scrutiny
text: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, long a cloistered and opaque agency, took a big step yesterday toward opening itself to greater public scrutiny by tentatively approving changes to overhaul the way it awards contracts, works with lobbyists and makes decisions affecting the airports, bridges, ports and tunnels it operates.

headline: In Virginia, a Blue Ridge Retreat That’s ‘a Little Undiscovered’
text: JOSEPH RADA had been a New Jersey boy his whole life — born in Perth Amboy, grew up in Holmdel, worked in Elizabeth, raised a family in Lincroft. Virginia’s Blue Ridge Mountains were hardly on his mind.

headline: Romney Policy Speech
text: Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential hopeful, called for a “new course” in the battle against global terrorism in a speech to the American Enterprise Institute’s World Forum in Colorado. Mr. Romney urged what he described as “a new type of Marshall Plan” that would deliver economic aid, public health aid and other assistance to Islamic states struggling to resist violent extremists. He also called for the creation of a special military unit that would work with other governments to combat terrorists.

headline: Romancing the Rose in Its Infinite Splendor
text: AS they always have — and absolutely must — during Rose Month at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, fanciers of the queen of flowers will stop, stoop and smell the roses, inhaling the splendor of the Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden throughout the month of June. But this year visitors will discover a 1.04-acre garden that has been redefined. After undergoing a comprehensive, six-month, $2.5 million refurbishing, the rose garden is presenting its largest and most varied collection ever: 3,373 plants in 621 varieties.

headline: Mike ’08? Better Dust Off City’s Charter
text: How does “Mayor Gotbaum” strike your ear? You never know. You just might have to get used to the sound of that.

headline: Jones Is Said to Be Close to a Sale of Barneys
text: The Jones Apparel Group was near a deal late last night to sell Barneys New York, the high-fashion chain, for about $825 million to the investment arm of the Dubai government, people involved in the talks said.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: 2 Companies Drop Pursuit of Dow Jones
text: The General Electric Company and Pearson, the British publisher, have decided not to make an offer for Dow Jones & Company, owner of The Wall Street Journal, G.E. said yesterday, leaving Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation as the only bidder.

headline: Yankees’ Cast in Place, as Sequel Awaits a Finish
text: The Bronx Zoo observed through the impressionable eyes of a teenage bat boy. Such was the original narrative for an eight-part television series on the 1977 Yankees set against the backdrop of New York City in the Summer of Billy, Reggie, George and Sam.

headline: Muslims’ Veils Test Limits of Britain’s Tolerance
text: LONDON, June 16 — Increasingly, Muslim women in Britain take their children to school and run errands covered head to toe in flowing black gowns that allow only a slit for their eyes. On a Sunday afternoon in Hyde Park, groups of black-clad Muslim women relaxed on the green baize lawn among the in-line skaters and badminton players.

headline: Don’t Veto, Don’t Obey
text: President Bush is notorious for issuing statements taking exception to hundreds of bills as he signs them. This week, we learned that in a shocking number of cases, the Bush administration has refused to enact those laws. Congress should use its powers to insist that its laws are obeyed.

headline: Official Says He Told Truth on Dismissals
text: WASHINGTON, June 21  The No. 2 official in the Justice Department said Thursday that he told the truth in February when he testified at a Senate hearing that the White House had limited involvement in the dismissal of federal prosecutors, an assertion that proved incorrect.

headline: As Japan Ages, Universities Struggle to Fill Classrooms
text: DAZAIFU, Japan — When Yasunori Iwanaga was choosing universities three years ago, it was not the academic program, the strong team in judo, his favorite sport, or even the study abroad program in England that swayed him to choose Fukuoka University of Economics.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: CELEBRATING THE FOURTH

headline: A Sad Tale of Fictional S.E.C. Filings
text: When it comes to disclosures, Universal Express is not exactly a model company.

headline: A Course Is Added to the Police Academy Curriculum: How to Become Good Neighbors
text: Concluding that police officers are sometimes too detached from the communities they serve, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced yesterday the start of a new program of intense training in community relations for cadets at the Police Academy.

headline: $4 Billion Price on Bigger Plan for Expansion of Javits Center
text: After a six-month review of the expansion plan for the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, the Spitzer administration is seriously considering a revamped proposal that would include additional exhibition space but cost $4 billion, more than twice the previous estimate.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,526 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Playing in Peoria, Former Top Pick of Padres Hopes to Salvage Career
text: PEORIA, Ariz., June 20 — For a professional baseball player of any acclaim and experience to be in Peoria at this time of year, something has to have gone wrong.

headline: Correction
text: The Keeping Score column on Sunday, about new baseball research into hitting and fielding trends that can help assess the impact of pitchers, referred incorrectly to the status of the journeyman Glendon Rusch. He is recovering from a blood-clot scare last season, and is not pitching now; he is not out of the game because he "appears to have run out of employers to disappoint" with his statistically below-average pitching.

headline: True West
text: Images from the life of a bareback rider.

headline: Lake Living
text: A look at Smith Mountain Lake, a Virginia vacation area with 500 miles of shoreline.

headline: Predictable Gold Cup Final Could Be Anything But
text: In the end, we have the Gold Cup final that everyone expected, those old rivals the United States and Mexico at Soldier Field in Chicago on Sunday.

headline: Rats and Buildings
text: Images from David Macaulay's new exhibition at the National Museum Building in Washington.

headline: The Vatican Library
text: Images from the Vatican Library, which is set to close in July for a three-year renovation.

headline: Browsing at the Renegade Craft Fair
text: More than 200 vendors set up booths in McCarren Park Pool in Brooklyn, peddling their handmade wares to people for whom do-it-yourself is the only label that matters.

headline: A Walk in the Clouds
text: Images from Hiram Bingham's 1911 expedition to Machu Picchu.

headline: A Weekend at War
text: For Dark Angel, a scenario paintball game, 400 players took sides for a 26-hour game of humans against mutant supersoldiers.

headline: How High (or Low) Will Blackstone Go?
text: Just how immune is the Blackstone Group to the slings and arrows of Congress? The next test comes later this morning when its shares begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker “BX.” The $4.1 billion offering generated a flood of interest from all over the world, despite a series of last-minute challenges from United States lawmakers, leading to predictions that the stock would quickly surge about the $31 offer price set late Thursday.

headline: Let’s (Not) Make a Deal
text: Monty Hall would probably be ashamed. Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Legislative leaders were close to agreements on a wide range of issues as the legislative session came to a fractious close on Thursday night. But then it all fell apart, and Mr. Spitzer and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, the state’s top Republican, took to their respective corners of the capitol to assail each other for the failures.

headline: Nimby heartthrob
text: George Clooney has gone from Hollywood heartthrob to neighborhood Nimby. The movie star is protesting a $16 million development that he says will ruin the beauty and serenity of his favorite retreat — Lake Como — where he owns a lakeside villa.

headline: Jefferies Gobbles Up Yet Another Advisory Group
text: The Jefferies Group said it had acquired the Putnam Lovell investment banking business, a provider of merger advice to asset managers and broker dealers, from National Bank Financial Group of Canada. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Wachovia Fined $2 Million for Excessive Fees
text: Wachovia Securities has been fined $2 million and ordered to pay restitution to more than 1,300 customers for charging excessive fees in its fee-based brokerage accounts, regulators said Thursday.

headline: Bell Canada’s Talks With Telus May Spoil Private Equity’s Party
text: Private equity suitors for Bell Canada may soon be headed for the exits as the arrival of Telus creates a clear front-runner in the race for control of Canada’s largest phone company, The Globe and Mail suggested. Bell Canada said Wednesday that it was discussing a possible merger with Telus, the leading phone company in western Canada.

headline: In Battle for CBOT, Tub-Thumping Continues
text: IntercontinentalExchange stepped up its efforts Thursday to acquire the Chicago Board of Trade, appealing to shareholders as the vote nears on a bid from Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings.

headline: Peltz Is Said to Push for Sale of Kraft Brands
text: Nelson Peltz, the activist investor, does not like Fruity Pebbles cereal or Maxwell House coffee. That is what he is preparing to tell Kraft Foods, having quietly acquired a 3 percent stake in the company, according to The New York Times.

headline: How Many Memories Fit In Your Brain?
text: If you were to walk into an unfamiliar room, look around briefly and then close your eyes, how much could you could remember of what you saw? We’ll give you a chance to find out how your visual memory compares with other people’s, but be warned: your memory is probably worse than you imagine.

headline: Plane Freed From a Glacier Sets Out for Britain Again
text: A week ago, the eyes of an anxious world were fixed on Tulsa, Okla., straining for a glimpse of a time-capsule car being unearthed after 50 years under the courthouse lawn — which, despite all the precautions that circa-1957 civic hucksterism thought to take in prepping the car, dashed many a fond hope when it emerged from its vault as only a Plymouth Belvedere-shaped lump of rust. Sniff.

headline: K.K.R. Wins Bidding for Air Canada Division, Report Says
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has won the auction for Air Canada Technical Services in a deal valued at around C$900 million ($840 million), The Globe and Mail reported. In buying the controlling stake in the Air Canada maintenance division, the buyout shop aiming to create a leading Canadian-based aircraft maintenance firm that services airlines around the world

headline: Is Zell’s Tribune Deal Hitting the Rocks?
text: Is Samuel Zell’s complex deal to buy Tribune in trouble?

headline: NYSE Euronext Enters Bidding for Italian Exchange, Report Says
text: NYSE Euronext has joined the bidding fray for Italian markets operator Borsa Italiana, which is currently considering an offer from the London Stock Exchange Group reportedly worth $2 billion, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Madison Dearborn Plans $13 Billion Buyout Fund, Report Says
text: In yet another example of the unprecedented amount of cash flooding the private equity industry, buyout shop Madison Dearborn Partners is planning a sixth fund that could be twice as large as the $6.5 billion to buyout fund it closed last year, The Chicago Tribune reported.

headline: Global Migration
With ABN Amro in Play, Chief of Barclays Capital Savors a New Test
text: Whether Barclays‘ $91 billion bid for ABN Amro succeeds or fails, one of the areas where the impact will be felt most strongly is at the British bank’s investment banking unit. And Robert E. Diamond Jr., head of Barclays Capital, would be crucial to making a merger work, noted The New York Times.

headline: Investors Tune in to Border Media
text: Spanish-language radio station operator Border Media Partners has raised $111 million from a private equity consortium, that includes Vestar Capital Partners, Goldman Sachs Urban Investment Group and Darby Overseas Investments.

headline: Bear Stearns Is Said to Plan $3.2 Billion Bailout of Hedge Fund
text: Seeking to stave off disaster, Bear Stearns plans to take on $3.2 billion of loans to stop creditors from seizing assets of one of its money-losing hedge funds in the biggest fund bailout since 1998, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Mobile Payment Firm Rings Up $9 Million in Funding
text: Danal said Thursday it received $9.5 million in new venture financing. San Jose-based Danal is the U.S. subsidiary of South Korea’s Danal Company, a mobile payment service company. The round was led by Morgenthaler Ventures and the South Korean parent company also contributed to the funding.

headline: For Schumer, New Tax Legislation Demands a Balancing Act
text: Hedge fund managers and private equity titans are not the only ones who find themselves in an awkward position as Congress contemplates legislation that would raise taxes on publicly traded private equity firms.

headline: Alert: Terminal Changes at Rome Airport
text: I did not think Rome’s main airport, Leonardo Da Vinci (a.k.a. Fiumicino) could get more frustrating or disorganised. But it has achieved that feat today: Suddenly, unannounced, as of yesterday, check-in for flights to Paris, Brussels (and a few other Europen cities) are leaving from the Domestic Departures Terminal, Terminal A. Oh, but it’s not that simple: Only flights on Alitalia, KLM and Air France have moved. The rest remain in the European International Departures Terminal, Terminal B.

headline: Jones Is Said to Be Close to a Sale of Barneys
text: The Jones Apparel Group was near a deal late Thursday night to sell Barneys New York, the high-fashion chain, for about $825 million to the investment arm of the Dubai government, The New York Times reported.

headline: Goldman Chief Urges Caution on Buyout Tax Increases
text: Goldman Sachs chief executive Lloyd Blankfein warned Thursday that raising taxes on private equity firms could be “very dangerous,” telling The Financial Times that it might encourage the industry to move to more favorable tax regimes. But Mr. Blankfein, whose firm is extremely active in the buyout business through its private equity arm, also said the issue of private equity taxation deserved a closer look.

headline: A Firefighter’s Death; Bigger Javits; Albany Breakdown; JT Leroy
text: The local headlines today are dominated by the death of Firefighter Daniel F. Pujdak, who fell from the fourth floor of a warehouse in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on Thursday afternoon while fighting a fire that began with a lighted cigarette left on a windowsill.

headline: K.K.R. Wants an I.P.O. of Its Own
text: Reports that Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is preparing its own initial public offering is the latest chapter in the saga of the private equity firm’s rivalry with arch-nemesis the Blackstone Group.

headline: Green Banking
text: This week Friends of the Earth in the Netherlands initiated a campaign called “Not with My Money” in which people were urged not to bank at banks that invest in oil or coal energy.This morning dozens of people cut up their ATM cards in front of one bank and vowed to switch to other institutions.

headline: A Death in the Line of Duty
text: Daniel F. Pujdak, the 23-year-old firefighter who was killed Thursday in a fall at a fire in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, was the first firefighter to die in the line of duty since last August.

headline: Web Aggregator Daylife Raises $8.3 Million
text: Daylife, a news aggregation Web site, raised about $8.3 million in a Series B round of venture funding from investors including the New York Times Company, according to a regulatory filing cited by peHUB.com.

headline: Bear Stearns Said to Withdraw Everquest I.P.O.
text: Everquest Financial, a firm with ties to a troubled hedge fund run by Bear Stearns, has called off its proposed initial public offering, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Blackstone Moves Higher in NYSE Debut
text: Just how immune is the Blackstone Group to the slings and arrows of Congress?

headline: 2008: Obama, Edwards on Government Reforms
text: In New Hampshire this morning, Senator Barack Obama is set to give a speech on trying to “reform” Washington. His campaign released excerpts of the speech, planned for an audience at New Hampshire Community Technical College in Manchester. The reform package, which Mr. Obama pledges to enact on his first day in office, includes a strict provision barring political appointees who leave their position from lobbying the executive branch for the remainder of the administration.

headline: Liberals, Divas and Abusers
Saving Blood Cells from Umbilical Cords
text: Among the more unusual pieces of legislation enacted by the Legislature in the waning days of the session is a law establishing a “public and private umbilical cord blood banking program” in the State Health Department.

headline: Remarks of Senator Barack Obama
text: The following is the prepared text of Senator Obama’s speech on government reform, as provided by his campaign.

headline: A Favorite Swimming Spot in Berlin
text: In Berlin, one good way to beat the heat is by jumping into Ploetzensee, one of the city’s many fine lakes. Ploetzensee is small, understated and central – set back in woods from the busy Seestrasse thoroughfare in Berlin-Wedding about 7 kilometers (4.2 miles) northwest of the Brandenburg Gate. Named after a red-eyed carp called a Ploetze, the lake has been a popular bathing spot with beach and snack bar for more than 150 years.

headline: Two Ritchie Funds File for Bankruptcy Protection
text: Ritchie Capital put two of its Ireland-based funds into bankruptcy protection Thursday, marking the latest setback for the hedge-fund firm founded by A.R. Thane Ritchie, a former college football star. The funds lost more than $700 million investing in life-insurance policies covering wealthy individuals, and Ritchie has sued Coventry First, which sold it some of the policies, over the losses.

headline: 9/11 Simulation Taxes Purdue Servers
text: It’s unusual for an academic computer-science department to brag about its prowess on YouTube, but that’s exactly what happened this month after Purdue University in West Lafayette, Ind., released a study into the causes of the collapse of the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Learning to Walk the Tracks
text: After a series of fatal accidents in the New York City subway, the transit authority has stepped up its safety training. William Neuman of The Times went into an active subway tunnel.

headline: Bloomberg: ‘I’m Not Going to Be President’
text: How many times and ways can the man say it?

headline: Wharton Picks Marketing Man for Dean’s Post
text: The Wharton School has a new dean, and he is well-versed in the art of the pitch.

headline: Live and Let Di
text: I once read a novel – at least I think I did, I can’t recall the title – in which, after a date, a guy returns with a young woman to her apartment. All is well until he gets a look at his date’s bookshelves: they are overflowing with what appears to be Joyce Carol Oates novels and only Joyce Carol Oates novels. Dozens and dozens of them. I forget what his exact response is. But it’s something like: Aiieee!

headline:
Stray Questions For:
Chris Abani
text: Chris Abani’s novels include “GraceLand” and, most recently, “The Virgin of Flames.”What are you working on?

headline: Bloomberg: ‘I’m Not Going to Be President’
text: Sewell Chan at our sib-blog, City Room, has New York Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s latest denial:

headline: Picking Up Where Dean Left Off
text: Hungry for dinner with Senator Barack Obama? A minimum contribution of $5 to his presidential campaign – and, of course, a little dash of luck – was all it took to play along in the latest political gimmick of the 2008 race for the White House.

headline: Why Should A Sale Scare Wall Street?
text: Why is Wall Street so alarmed that a bunch of mortgage securities might be sold?

headline: Freak Amusement Park Accident Severs Girl’s Feet
text: Your stomach falls out at the thought of it: a 13-year-old girl is happily enjoying an amusement-park ride one minute, and is grotesquely injured the next.

headline: Controversy Follows United States Into Gold Cup Final
text: The Unites States men's national team remained on course Thursday to retain the Concacaf Gold Cup with a hard-fought 2-1 win over Canada in their semifinal at Soldier Field in Chicago. The Americans will meet archrival Mexico on Sunday afternoon.

headline: Picking Up Where Dean Left Off
text: In his web column today, Jeff Zeleny writes:

headline: The End of Tom Sawyer-ware
text: Plaxo, which offers a web-based address book service, was an early dot-com high flyer. There was just one wrinkle. The premise of the original service was to persuade your friends to do the heavy lifting and fill in your address book for you. However, by the time most people received their fifth (or tenth) request from Plaxo, they were ready hunt the designers of the service down like rats on the tundra.

headline: Learning to Walk the Tracks
text: After a series of fatal accidents in the New York City subway, the transit authority has stepped up its safety training.

headline: For One Analyst, Facebook Is a Screaming Buy
text: The main thing about Facebook, Pali Research analyst Richard Greenfield wants to make clear, is that it is “not just for college students — if you have not signed up or have not used it lately, you should.” And if you are a big media company, he has another piece of advice: Buy the company.

headline: Petitioners Urge the Mayor to Run
text: A Draft Michael Bloomberg rally on the steps of City Hall this morning drew more journalists than the dozen or so volunteers who are hitting the streets today to collect signatures on unofficial petitions to urge the mayor to run for president. The event started just as Mr. Bloomberg wrapped up his weekly radio call-in program on WABC-AM, in which he told the host, John Gambling, “I’m not going to be president.” (Interestingly, the statewide organizer of the petition drive is a WABC producer, Frank Morano).

headline: 500 Tons of Subway Cars, One Foot Away
text: After two New York City Transit workers were killed in April in separate incidents, the agency’s new president, Howard H. Roberts Jr., on April 29 ordered an immediate suspension of track work. The suspension was lifted on May 4; less than two weeks later, on May 17, the agency announced a series of safety initiatives. Investigations are still continuing.

headline: Bear Stearns Sets $3.2 Billion Rescue for Hedge Fund
text: Moving to placate lenders and stabilize what has become an embarrassing situation for the investment bank, Bear Stearns said Friday that it would provide a secured loan of up to $3.2 billion to one of two troubled hedge funds. Bloomberg News described the loan as the biggest bailout since 1998; The New York Times said it was a tacit acknowledgment that Bear’s portfolio managers “made brash bets on a mortgage market that has been jarred by a rising delinquencies and foreclosures.”

headline: Karjakin, the Youngest Player, Leads Super Strong Tournament
text: A tournament in Foros, Ukraine, a town not far away from Yalta on the Crimean Peninsula, has attracted some of the world’s best players. The tournament, sponsored by Aerosvit Ukrainian Airlines, began June 17 and runs through the end of the month. Among the participants are Peter Svidler of Russia, ranked No. 9 in the world, Vassily Ivanchuk of Ukraine, No. 12, Dmitry Jakovenko of Russia, No. 18, and Alexander Onischuk, tied for 39, who is originally from Ukraine but is now a United States citizen and was the 2006 U.S. champion.

headline: Backing Obama, Without a Blessing
text: Supporters of Senator Barack Obama’s Democratic presidential primary campaign have formed one of the first independent organizations dedicated to supporting a 2008 presidential hopeful, overlooking their candidate’s past criticisms of the legal status of such groups.

headline: Bill Would Raise Taxes on ‘Carried Interest’
text: Congress challenged the private equity industry on a major new front Friday afternoon, when 14 Democrats from the U.S. House of Representatives introduced a bill that would raise taxes on “carried interest.”

headline: Winning the Gingerbread Wars
text: Alison was absolutely right when she identified the three big questions we still needed to answer before we could move forward: How much would this dream home cost? Were there logistical hurdles (like unavailable contractors)? Would our notoriously picky town approve what we wanted to do?

headline: Whose Red Room Is It Anyway?
text: The acrimony between Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno — with each saying the other is to blame for the many failed deals in the waning days of the legislative session — has taken a new turn.

headline: Blackstone’s First-Day Poplet
text: After month’s of hype, hoopla and controversy, reviews of Blackstone Group‘s actual market debut appear to be a little like that Peggy Lee song, “Is That All There Is?” While the offering was clearly a success by most measures — it priced at the high end of the expected range at $31, opened 18 percent higher at $36.55 and recently traded at $35.95 — the relatively modest jump seemed to leave many observers underwhelmed. The stock closed the day at $35.06.

headline: SJP Follow-up: Labor and Costs
text: Of all the topics raised by the Sarah Jessica Parker interview, the one that stirred the most debate was how Steve & Barry’s can deliver Bitten at such low prices, and does this mean the company employs sweat shops and other unethical manufacturing practices. The subject came up during my conversation with SJP at the store — and, according to Parker, she asked similar questions of Steve & Barry’s during her due diligence. But since a lot of people on the blog are concerned about this issue, I decided to explore it further with Howard Schacter, the company’s chief partnership officer, and we spoke this morning.

headline: End of the road for Universal boss?
text: The S.E.C. has asked a federal judge to appoint a receiver to take control of Universal Express, the subject of my column today.

headline: Leaving the Congo
text: I never thought I would be so happy to leave the Congo. Goma never felt right to me; in fact, the more days I spent walking along the dark gray lava-covered ground, being stared at by suspicious and glaring eyes, the more tense and anxious I became. Like Will, I was relieved to return to the oasis of our hotel every night.

headline: Perceivers, Not Deciders
text: Readers respond to David Brooks’s June 22 column, “When Preaching Flops.”

headline: India’s $2,500 Car
text: Let’s talk cheap cars. Very cheap cars. Nissan announced yesterday that it’s thinking of building a $3,000 car for India — which might have sounded inexpensive, if only Tata Motors, an Indian automaker, hadn’t announced plans for a $2,000 car earlier this month.

headline: Wyoming Senator Appointed
text: A Republican state legislator, John Barrasso, is the new United States Senator from Wyoming. The state’s governor, Dave Freudenthal, appointed him to the post today, filling a vacancy created by the death of Senator Craig Thomas earlier this month.

headline: Reports From the Police ‘Shack’
text: Since the early 1990s, New York City has experienced a remarkable overall decline in crime, such that many New Yorkers take public safety almost for granted, pausing, perhaps, only when a particularly gruesome crime grabs newspaper headlines or airtime on the television news. But every day, the New York Police Department issues terse news releases, including reports of homicides; descriptions of suspects wanted for questioning; names and descriptions of missing individuals; and notifications when city employees have been arrested — among other things. We thought we’d share some from the week.These notices — the “sheets” in cop shop jargon — are provided to journalists, including reporters at 1 Police Plaza, the headquarters of the Police Department, who work out of a set of offices known by tradition as “The Shack.”

headline: The Lesser-Known Islands of New York
text: Answers Revealed, noon, June 28

headline: My Boss
text: sent me the link to this video today. I like it.

headline: A Victim of Equity Stripping
text: A Chicago woman who fell behind on her mortgage payments became a victim of a common fraud known as equity stripping.

headline: Win a Trip: A Boat Out of Congo
text: Will Okun, who is traveling with Nicholas D. Kristof in Africa, takes a high-speed ferry as part of his journey to Burundi.

headline: Cinderella Motel
text: Collier Schorr goes inside the arena with rodeo cowboys.

headline: Cheney Rules
Simplicity
text: I’m sitting on a curb along the edge of the parking lot next to the gym with two duffle bags, a ruck sack, the M249 and a 9mm strapped to my leg. It is hard to believe that all of my personal possessions for the next year can be hand carried.

headline: Vows: Hildy and Jarrod
text: For Hildy Kuryk and Jarrod Bernstein, teasing at a political fund-raiser and a shared love of New York City led to romance.

headline: As American as Nachos, Maple Syrup and Sushi
text: What does “Made in America” mean, especially in today’s automobile industry?

headline: Bobby Richardson’s Capper to the ’62 Series
text: Bobby Richardson saw his picture in The New York Times yesterday, and he had to tell the story behind it.

headline: Freedom? We’re Talking Money Here
text: When governments around the world censor the Internet — by which we mean restricting the sites their citizens can visit and the content they can see — it clearly has an impact on freedom of speech and of information.

headline: For Candidates, Fund-Raising Drives the Weekend
text: Most of the leading candidates for president are staying out of the heavily traveled primary states of Iowa and New Hampshire this weekend, and fanning out across the country to court voters and donors.

headline: Baby Hawk’s Distinguished Ancestry Is Now Acknowledged
text: So it turns out that Ziggy, the 7-week-old baby red-tailed hawk that fell from its Seventh Avenue nest and crashed near the Ziegfeld Theater on West 55th Street last week, might be related to Pale Male — one of New York City’s most famous avian residents — after all.

headline: A Wii Bit of Violence in Manhunt 2
text: It’s all very nice that you can use the nifty wireless remote control of Nintendo’s Wii machine to swing a gulf club or a tennis racket. But what do you thing gamers really want to wave around?

headline: Friends Again, Sort of . . .
text: The Boston standoff between Google and eBay appears to be over. The result of the confrontation: only minor scrapes and bruises for Google.

headline: Mules
text: Alice Walker observed, “Black women are the mules of the world.” Traveling across the poor African country of Burundi, we see women doing the majority of the hard fieldwork and, of course, all of the labor in the home.

headline: Waiting for the Punchline
text: See if you spot the humor in all this.

headline: Weekend Project: Build a TV-Lift Cabinet
text: The weekend is about to begin. Get out your power saw and tool belt.

headline: Obama's Volunteer Push
text: Brooklyn supporters of Senator Barack Obama took their enthusiasm to the streets as part of a nationwide effort by the campaign.

headline: Adjust Your Volume
text: “I do television so I can get to New York’’ the English chef Gordon Ramsay told Bill Buford of The New Yorker last fall as he was about to open Gordon Ramsay at the London, his first restaurant in the States. “I prostitute myself so I can have a restaurant here.’’

headline: Mike Wallace: Potter’s Fields, Grand Central, Overlooked Sites
text: Here is the last installment from Mike Wallace, the historian and co-author of “Gotham,” who answered reader questions this week. We would like to extend our thanks to Dr. Wallace for his patience in helping us start up this new feature and also to all the readers who participated. The next person taking questions will be Janette Sadik-Khan, the new city transportation commissioner.

headline: Enterprise 2.0 Agnostic
text: The Enterprise 2.0 bandwagon seems well underway, with the latest sign being a well-sponsored and well-attended three-day conference in Boston this week.

headline: Popular But Poor on Facebook
text: It’s been just a month since Facebook started letting outside programmers add new ‘applications’ to its service, but it’s already hard to imagine the site without them. Thousands of developers have jumped in, lured by the prospect of fun, fame and fortune.

headline: A Long Line for a Shorter Wait
text: For its first stores in Manhattan, Whole Foods, the gourmet supermarket, directs customers to form serpentine single lines that feed into a passel of cash registers.

headline: Chirac Refuses to Testify in French Dirty Tricks Case
text: PARIS, June 23 — Having lost the immunity that protected him from prosecution while in office, Jacques Chirac, the former French president, has refused to testify in a political dirty tricks scandal that sought to discredit Nicolas Sarkozy, the current president.

headline: The Low-Profile Westport River Offers a High Yield of Fish
text: The darkening sky and the damp wind blowing upriver showed no signs of abating. The forecast from the night before promised clearing skies and temperatures in the mid-60s, but the day dawned with mist, fog and a fine, cold drizzle. For an angler in coastal New England, sometimes May and June can be the cruelest months.

headline: Safety Group Proposes 3rd Stairwell in High Rises
text: WASHINGTON, June 22  Skyscraper safety requirements proposed after the World Trade Center attacks on Sept. 11 have been adopted by the pre-eminent building code group. That means tall buildings nationwide could soon be required to be designed with an extra emergency stairwell and more robust fireproofing.

headline: Day of Grief in New Jersey After Violence Claims 3 Lives
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 22 — It was hardly a new path that Thomas Reilly traced from his native Ireland to northern New Jersey, where after two decades of hope and hard work his immigrant aspirations had seemingly been fulfilled. He was a successful business owner. He had married. He had two adorable daughters.

headline: Water Woes in Irish City Are Downside of Growth
text: GALWAY, Ireland  For Breda and Mike Guilfoyle, surveying the containers of boiled water on the kitchen tops of their bed and breakfast inn here, the jokes about polluted drinking water have worn thin. They worry that visitors will stay away from Galway, western Ireland’s premier tourist city, this summer.

headline: C.I.A. Chief Tries Preaching a Culture of More Openness
text: WASHINGTON, June 22  William E. Colby faced an uneasy decision in late 1973 when he took over the Central Intelligence Agency: whether to make public the agency’s internal accounting, then being compiled, of its domestic spying, assassination plots and other misdeeds since its founding nearly three decades earlier.

headline: Baseball’s Japanese Roots Survive Test of Time and Will
text: Chitoshi Akizuki wasn’t sure whether he would travel from San Jose to San Francisco this weekend to watch Hideki Matsui and the Yankees play the San Francisco Giants. But he will be there in spirit.

headline: With Extra Rest, Glavine Breaks His Slump
text: The fans rose in unison as Tom Glavine walked toward the Mets’ dugout. He had thrown 110 pitches through eight brilliant innings, and it was time, they undoubtedly assumed, to salute him for a job well done. Glavine was looking at the ground. He did not acknowledge the applause because he knew something the fans did not. He was not finished yet.

headline: Militants Said to Flee Before U.S. Offensive
text: BAGHDAD, June 22 — The operational commander of troops battling to drive fighters with Al Qaeda from Baquba said Friday that 80 percent of the top Qaeda leaders in the city fled before the American-led offensive began earlier this week. He compared their flight with the escape of Qaeda leaders from Falluja ahead of an American offensive that recaptured that city in 2004.

headline: Rockets Kill 9 in Pakistan Tribal Area
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 23  Nine people were killed in what officials here described as overnight rocket attacks from across the Afghan border in the Shawal area of the North Waziristan tribal region of Pakistan.

headline: Homes Sell. Homes Don’t Sell. Builders Still Build.
text: THE American housing market, as measured by home-building activity, is falling at the most rapid rate in decades, underscoring the pain felt by builders who were far too optimistic about the state of the market.

headline: A Former Prospect on the Court Is Now Much Better at the Table
text: Back in 1979, I coached juniors — teenagers — at a European Bridge League training camp in Ghent, Belgium. Along with bridge, we held sporting events, including a tennis tournament. I was paired with a 14-year-old Dutch boy named Louk Verhees. He was a marvelous player and carried us singlehandedly to victory.

headline: Tugboat Industry Is Experiencing a Revival
text: CLEVELAND, June 22 — The latest sign of America’s tugboat building boom sits on a bank of the Cuyahoga River here. Shaped like a curved silver tongue, the steel hull of the Great Lakes Towing Company’s first tugboat lies upside down in a brand-new factory.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Weekend on June 15 about a deal between the Menier Chocolate Factory theater company in London and the producer Bob Boyett that gives Mr. Boyett first rights to transfer the company’s shows to Broadway referred incompletely to the transfer of the company’s revival of “Sunday in the Park With George” next winter. The Broadway revival will be a Roundabout Theater Company production. Boyett Ostar Productions, Mr. Boyett’s producing partnership, will be an associate producer; it is not bringing over the revival by itself.

headline: Is ‘Made in China’ a Warning Label? (7 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Truck Kills Cyclist in Bronx
text: A bicyclist was killed yesterday in the Baychester section of the Bronx by a truck that fled the scene, the police said.

headline: North Korea ‘Prepared’ to Shut Down Reactor, U.S. Envoy Says
text: SEOUL, South Korea, June 22  The chief American nuclear envoy, returning from the first visit to North Korea by a ranking United States official in five years, said here Friday that Pyongyang had assured him it was ready to shut down its main nuclear reactor and would ultimately disable it.

headline: Space Shuttle Lands in California Desert
text: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 22 — The space shuttle Atlantis glided to a smooth landing on a dry desert lake bed here Friday, ending a two-week mission to the International Space Station that had turned somewhat dramatic after key computers broke down.

headline: Breaking From Tradition in the America’s Cup
text: VALENCIA, Spain, June 22 — It has been an America’s Cup for breaking with convention. For the first time, yachting’s premier competition is being staged in the Mediterranean. For the first time, there is no home team: The defender, Alinghi, picked Valencia as the site because Geneva, its base, was next to a lovely lake, but much too far from the requisite salt water.

headline: A Liberal Explains His Rejection of Same-Sex Marriage
text: Could legalizing same-sex marriage actually strengthen marriage as a social institution? “If I could believe this,” writes David Blankenhorn, “I would support gay marriage without reservation.”

headline: Mr. Spitzer’s First Round
text: New York Gov. Eliot Spitzer marched into the state Capitol in January like a new sheriff ready to clean out the saloon. Six months later, he has emerged from his first legislative session a bit tattered, a bit wiser, but with his high poll numbers intact. Mr. Spitzer may not have won the toughest battles he fought, but he has charted a clear path for where he wants to take the state. There is every reason to believe that if he sticks to it, he will eventually make significant improvements in how the public’s business is done in New York State.

headline: At White House, Renewed Debate on Guantánamo
text: WASHINGTON, June 22 — The Bush administration acknowledged Friday that its top officials were once again actively debating recommendations about how and when to close the detention facilities at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, but officials said they thought it could be weeks or months before a decision was made.

headline: A Need to Reach Out (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Lifeline of Sorts to Newspapers
text: So I went to Chicago this week to see Sam Zell, the billionaire real estate mogul who not all that long ago sold one of his major holdings, Equity Office Properties Trust, to the Blackstone Group for $39 billion.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (Disney) THE SUITE LIFE OF ZACK & CODY The mischievous twins who live in a high-class hotel in Boston with their lounge-singing mother are graduating from middle school in this season premiere. Or perhaps only Cody (Cole Sprouse, above right), will receive a diploma, since Zack (Dylan Sprouse, above left) hears some bad news: summer school. But there’s always the game room, swimming pool, room service and, of course, the candy counter run by Maddie (Ashley Tisdale) to help distract Zack from his troubles.

headline: It’s Anger, Not Nostalgia, at This Antioch Reunion
text: YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, June 22 — The messages have been flying through alumni chat rooms, sometimes 10 a minute, ever since Antioch University announced that it was closing, at least for now, the undergraduate college that once seemed the very symbol of the 1960s.

headline: British High Court Wrestles With Symbol of Premarital Purity
text: LONDON, June 22 — At a time of passionate debate over religious clothing and emblems, a 16-year-old member of an evangelical Christian movement protested in court on Friday because her school has refused to allow her to wear a so-called purity ring, symbolizing her commitment to premarital chastity.

headline: A Homeless Man’s Story (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Brecht’s Take on Chicago: God Among Meatpackers
text: There are costly Manhattan kitchens that have not been designed with a quarter of the efficiency of Lear deBessonet’s production of “St. Joan of the Stockyards.” This infrequently seen Brecht play, now at Performance Space 122, imagines in this incarnation the fights between Christian principles and capitalism, labor and management, rich and poor as back-alley brawls from which there are no easy exits.

headline: In His Memory, the Melodies Linger On
text: There were no fireworks on Wednesday night at the Kaye Playhouse, where the JVC Jazz Festival presented “We Remember Ruby,” a tribute to the trumpeter and cornetist Ruby Braff. They weren’t needed.

headline: Bravura Moves for an Old Crowd Pleaser
text: BECKET, Mass., June 21 — Some ballets, alas, are fragile. Others, alack, are indestructible. I have often wished Petipa’s tutu-Spanish “Don Quixote” were more frail than it is: It’s the kind of ballet-as-circus event that seldom turns into art, but its virtuosity and its music’s razzmatazz are such that you can eliminate the title character and the plot, interleave individual dances from earlier acts into the grand pas de deux from Act III, cram it all onto a small stage to taped music, and still it’s “Don Q,” that whiz-bang crowd-pleaser.

headline: Two Giants, but They Aren’t Twins
text: IT takes more than great technology to make a great technology company. Years after the millennium bubble burst, the lesson is still being learned  the easy way if you own Google and the hard way if your money is in Yahoo.

headline: Damon’s Season Raises Questions and a Few Eyebrows
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 22  When the Yankees signed Johnny Damon to a four-year, $52 million contract after the 2005 season, they did not consider it a risky deal. Damon had never been on the disabled list, and he had recently turned 32 years old.

headline: New Ways to Do It Make Giving Away Books a Bit Less Painful
text: IT has been a long, sometimes painful process, but over the years, I’ve learned to separate from my books.

headline: The Streets Where the Average Age of a Prostitute Is 14
text: For her second documentary under the “Who Cares About Girls?” banner, the globetrotting journalist Lisa Ling takes on child prostitution. “Slave Girls of India,” to be shown on the Oxygen channel tomorrow night, has all the elements you might expect from the combustible combination of Ms. Ling and a story about suffering and injustice: hidden cameras, horrifying statistics and emotional close-ups, many of Ms. Ling herself.

headline: ‘Quartet’ Meeting Set for Jerusalem
text: Diplomats from the United States, the European Union, Russia and the United Nations — what is known as the quartet — will meet Tuesday in Jerusalem, a day after Israeli and Palestinian leaders meet with leaders of Egypt and Jordan at the Egyptian resort of Sharm el Sheik, Russian, Israeli and United Nations officials said. Both meetings are being held to discuss the impact of the seizure of power in the Gaza Strip by Hamas on the region and on the Israeli-Palestinian relationship. At the meeting in Egypt, Israel is expected to offer to release to the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, and his new Fatah-led emergency government much of the Palestinian tax money it refused to pass on to a Hamas-led government.

headline: Illegal Lofts Get New Scrutiny After a Firefighter’s Death
text: The former sewing factory at 83 Meserole Street in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is like hundreds of other buildings in the industrial precincts of Brooklyn — a hulking, century-old brick box lined with big windows, its insides turned into lofts inhabited by designers, musicians and other practitioners of the hipster professions. That the apartment conversions are illegal is usually of little consequence to anyone, including the authorities.

headline: Champions Take Different Path to Finals
text: OMAHA, June 22  The noonday sun in eastern Nebraska bakes the grass and the people this time of year, but Oregon State catcher Mitch Canham walked around Rosenblatt Stadium with a bounce in his step.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts on Thursday about the new Wellcome Collection museum in London referred imprecisely to the work of the Nobel Prize winner James D. Watson, who led the inaugural ceremony. He was a discoverer of the structure of DNA, not of DNA itself.

headline: Sorkin to Broadway
text: Aaron Sorkin, who created the television shows “The West Wing” and “Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip,” will return to Broadway this fall with “The Farnsworth Invention,” Playbill reported. Citing a casting notice, Playbill said that Dodger Theatricals would produce the play, tentatively scheduled to open on Nov. 18, and Des McAnuff would direct. “The Farnsworth Invention” concerns the battle over patent rights to the television set, which pitted the inventor Philo T. Farnsworth against David Sarnoff, who ran the Radio Corporation of America. The play was given a workshop production at the La Jolla Playhouse, in San Diego in February and March. Mr. Sorkin’s play “A Few Good Men” opened on Broadway at the Music Box Theater Nov. 15, 1989.

headline: For Women, a Recipe to Create a Successful Business
text: SAN FRANCISCO  One morning in May, Veronica Salazar stuffed refried beans into sandal-shaped masa cakes, concentrating to block the commotion in a cavernous kitchen here in the Mission District. The chopping of vegetables added to the din as the clang of metal pans against stainless steel equipment competed with background music from a local Spanish-language radio station.

headline: The Fall of Mr. Small’s Empire
text: This week we have gotten a deeply troubling glimpse into the reign of Lawrence Small, who headed up the Smithsonian Institution from 2000 until resigning in March. A stinging new report by an independent review committee concludes that the Smithsonian is in a “governance crisis” largely caused by Mr. Small’s self-isolating and “secretive” management style. The problem does not stop with Mr. Small. The Smithsonian, it says, also suffers from antiquated methods of governance and a Board of Regents that appears to have played a largely ceremonial — and lackadaisical — role.

headline: China Tries to Contain Scandal Over Slave Labor With Arrests and Apology
text: BEIJING, June 22 — Chinese authorities moved to contain a widening slave labor scandal with an apology from a provincial governor for abuses that have shocked the country, and the arrest of two labor officials, state news media said Friday.

headline: ABC and NBC End Race to Interview Paris Hilton
text: After a flurry of accounts this week about financial offers to land the first postprison interview with Paris Hilton, both ABC and NBC said yesterday that they no longer had any interest in securing the interview.

headline: Yoga, Cocoons and Pots, but No Kitchen Sink
text: Perhaps others will be quicker off the mark, but I had to read the title of Donna Scro Gentile Freespace Dance’s “ConTainMeiNiT,” which opened on Thursday night at Dance Theater Workshop, two or three times before I caught on. The simultaneous mawkish cuteness and vagueness of this sentiment were a warning sign.

headline: Stuffing Tortillas and Parkgoers, Dawn to Dusk
text: On the concrete floor of a garage turned kitchen, behind a curtain stamped in lavender and green, was a freezer as tall as a man, as long as a car and as wide as a love seat. Inside was a pile of cardboard boxes stuffed with lettuce, tomatoes and cactus leaf nopales, a Mexican delicacy. The coolers on the opposite end were packed with raw meat: 40 pounds of chicken, 60 pounds of chorizo, 300 pounds of pork, 1,000 pounds of beef.

headline: Delphi and U.A.W. Reach Tentative Deal
text: DETROIT, June 22 — The Delphi Corporation and its largest union reached a tentative wage-cutting agreement on Friday that the auto supplier called a “significant milestone” toward its emergence from bankruptcy protection.

headline: Kindred Spirits, in Country and Beyond
text: Among other things, the current tour by Lyle Lovett and K. D. Lang presents a treatise on the nature of hunger. At Radio City Music Hall on Thursday night, there were songs of lonesome discontent and insatiable desire, along with a cold, straightforward yearning. They came in many forms: as covers and originals, joke songs and deadly serious ones. At one point Mr. Lovett sang “Keep It in Your Pantry,” a lighthearted ode to more than one sort of appetite; Ms. Lang offered “Constant Craving,” one of her biggest hits.

headline: Bonds Belts No. 749, but Yankees Prevail
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 — Before Scott Proctor stared him down in the eighth inning on Friday, 441 pitchers had allowed home runs to Barry Bonds. Proctor, a small right-hander with a big fastball, thrives on a challenge. With a four-run lead on Friday night, this was the perfect time.

headline: Tempers Flare as Discussions on Big Ten Network Heat Up
text: The Big Ten is angry at Comcast. And Comcast is angry at the Big Ten.

headline: S.E.C. Requests Receiver for Universal Express
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission, stating that Universal Express “appears to exist primarily as a vehicle for fraud,” has asked a federal judge to appoint a receiver to take control of it. Universal Express is a penny stock company that has sold billions of unregistered shares to the public.

headline: Marshall D. Shulman, 91, Dies; Expert on Soviet Union
text: Marshall D. Shulman, who devoted his life to understanding the Soviet Union as a leading scholar, a policymaker and a principal builder of Columbia University’s Russian studies program, died on Thursday at his home in Sherman, Conn. He was 91, meaning that he was born before the Soviet Union and outlived it.

headline: Mileage Vote Reveals New Configuration in Senate
text: WASHINGTON, June 22 — Automakers had to know they were in serious trouble when Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, a Maryland Democrat with deep blue-collar roots, announced that she had lost patience with their annual objections to higher gas mileage rules.

headline: Chavez Backs Giambi’s Decision
text: Eric Chavez revered Jason Giambi when they were teammates on the Oakland Athletics. Chavez loved how Giambi respected people, whether he was interacting with an All-Star or a bat boy. Chavez loved how Giambi prepared for games, a dose of intensity mixed with a dash of playfulness.

headline: The Fight Against Malaria (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Architecture, Taken Apart With Pen and Ink
text: WASHINGTON, June 20 — David Macaulay could be called the Mr. Wizard of architectural history. In 23 books over three decades, his arresting pen-and-ink illustrations have explored everything from the construction of ancient pyramids to the subterranean systems that support a modern metropolis.

headline: $3.2 Billion Move by Bear Stearns to Rescue Fund
text: Bear Stearns Companies, the investment bank, pledged up to $3.2 billion in loans yesterday to bail out one of its hedge funds that was collapsing because of bad bets on subprime mortgages.

headline: These Tour Guides Know the History Not Found on Plaques
text: Jennifer Nugent Duffy stood in the middle of Central Park, clutching a clipboard, and talked about what was no longer there.

headline: Footnotes
text: The British band The Cure, featuring the singer Robert Smith, below, announced plans for an American tour, starting on Sept. 13 in Tampa, Fla. The band is finishing work on its first album of new music since 2004, which is to be released this fall. ... With Hollywood in the hunt for the next “Harry Potter”-style franchise, DreamWorks Studios has bought the film rights to the children’s book series “Children of the Lamp,” by P. B. Kerr. The popular series, whose fourth title is due out in September, follows the adventures of a family who pass for human but have the power to grant wishes. ... The New York Philharmonic has received a gift of $5 million from Didi and Oscar S. Schafer in support of the orchestra’s Concerts in the Parks, which take place each July in the metropolitan area. The gift provides $1 million annually over the next five years, with the series to be known as the New York Philharmonic Concerts in the Parks, presented by Didi and Oscar Schafer.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about a warehouse fire that killed nine firefighters in Charleston, S.C., misspelled the surname of a man who was rescued from the building. He is Jonathan Tyrrell III, not Tyrell. (Go to Article)

headline: Masked Man for A’s? Why, It’s Mike Piazza
text: Mike Piazza signed with the Oakland Athletics in the off-season expecting a diminished workload. He was expecting to march to the plate about four times a game, hit the ball and sit down to watch someone else strap on the shin guards and chest protector.

headline: World View Podcast
text: Greg Winter and Jeffrey Gettleman discuss Ethiopia.

headline: Kentucky: Amusement Park Ride Cuts Off Girl’s Feet
text: The Superman Tower of Power ride at Six Flags Kentucky Kingdom outside Louisville malfunctioned Thursday, severing both feet of a 13-year-old girl, state safety officials and a park spokeswoman said. As patrons of the ride hurtled toward the ground at more than 50 miles per hour, a frayed cable snapped and cut off the girl’s feet, said Bill Clary, a spokesman for the Kentucky Division of Regulation and Inspection. The ride was immediately shut down, as were similar rides at three other Six Flags parks, said the Six Flags spokeswoman, Wendy Goldberg. Mr. Clary said inspectors would remain on the scene until they understood what had happened and how to ensure that it not happen again.

headline: Manhunt 2 Too Violent
text: Take-Two Interactive Software said late Thursday that it had suspended plans to release its game Manhunt 2 next month. Earlier this week the British Board of Film Classification refused to issue a rating for the game, citing its extreme violence. That decision made it illegal to sell the game in Britain. In the United States, the Electronic Software Rating Board, an independent industry group, has informed Take-Two that it intends to give the game an Adults Only rating. The game was to be released for Nintendo’s Wii and Sony’s PlayStation 2, but those companies have said that they will not allow Adults Only-rated games on their systems. Major retailers, including Wal-Mart, also refuse to sell games with that rating. Take-Two now must choose whether to scrap the game or to remove some violent content in the hopes of securing a rating of M for Mature. SETH SCHIESEL

headline: Once More With Feeling: A Really Senior Prom
text: Robert Roane escorted Gretta Cohen to the senior prom on Thursday night.

headline: Finding Inspiration in an Unlikely Place
text: A couple of decades ago, opera composers began finding inspiration in newspaper headlines, a trend that opera fans and critics have debated vigorously. It brought the immediacy of current issues to the opera stage, but the transformation into opera sometimes trivialized those issues.

headline: Obama Says New Rules Would Guide His Administration
text: WASHINGTON, June 22  Senator Barack Obama said on Friday that if elected president, he would impose new lobbying restrictions on members of his administration and seek to end a system of no-bid contracts that he says is riddled by abuse.

headline: New Jersey Decides Its Toll Road Plan Still Needs Time
text: For the better part of a year, Gov. Jon S. Corzine has promised to produce a plan to solve some of New Jersey’s fiscal difficulties by raising billions of dollars through the leasing of the state’s biggest toll roads.

headline: Is This the End of Harry, on the Web?
text: A self-proclaimed hacker says that he broke into the computers of the British publisher of the hugely successful Harry Potter series and discovered the feverishly awaited climax to the coming seventh and final installment. But his disclosures were met with skepticism this week.

headline: Wyoming: Senator Named to Fill Vacancy
text: John Barrasso, a Republican state legislator and an orthopedic surgeon, was appointed by Gov. Dave Freudenthal to replace Senator Craig Thomas, who died June 4. Mr. Barrasso, 54, a two-term state senator, was one of three contenders whose names had been submitted to the governor by the Wyoming Republican Party. The governor, a Democrat, was required under Wyoming law to select a candidate from the same party as Mr. Thomas, a Republican. Mr. Barrasso’s appointment takes effect immediately. Although Mr. Thomas’s term was set to end in 2012, Mr. Barrasso will face a special election in 2008 to keep the interim Senate seat. He has indicated that he intends to run.

headline: A Concert for King
text: Stevie Wonder, Aretha Franklin and Carlos Santana said on Thursday that they would participate in a concert to raise money to build a memorial to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on the National Mall in Washington, The Associated Press reported. Quincy Jones, Russell Simmons and Tommy Hilfiger are organizing the so-called Dream Concert, set for Sept. 18 at Radio City Music Hall. Other scheduled performers include Robin Thicke, Bebe Winans, Cece Winans and Jessye Norman, with Al Roker to appear as a presenter. The foundation working to build the memorial has raised $79.5 million of the $100 million needed to complete and maintain it. The memorial will occupy a space on the Tidal Basin between the Lincoln and Jefferson memorials.

headline: Grass to Read in New York
text: Günter Grass, the Nobel Prize-winning German writer, will give his first reading in the United States of his memoir, “Peeling the Onion,” at the 92nd Street Y Unterberg Poetry Center on Monday evening at 8. Mr. Grass, 79, will read passages in German, and the actor Michael Stuhlbarg will read them in English. Afterward, the Israeli writer and journalist Amos Elon will interview Mr. Grass, who came under fire last year for his belated admission that he had served in Hitler’s elite Waffen-SS, despite having long claimed to have been an ordinary soldier. Some critics accused Mr. Grass of making the revelation at that time in hopes that it would increase the sales of his memoir. The English translation of the book is being published in the United States this month.

headline: France: Immigration Ministry Draws Fire
text: More than 3,000 people, among them French and American intellectuals, anthropologists and social scholars, have signed an online petition protesting France’s new Ministry of Immigration, Integration, National Identity and Co-development. The petition, from the Internet-based research center terra.rezo.net, which focuses on issues related to migration, objects to the very idea of the ministry, saying that even its name could foster “governmental xenophobia leading to stigmatize the foreigner as a problem, a risk, and possibly a threat to integrity or national identity.”

headline: Athena Comes Home
text: Athena Comes Home

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The TV Sports column yesterday, about coverage of the Tour de France by the cable network Versus amid the doping scandals in cycling, misstated the surname of a race commentator in some copies. He is Paul Sherwen, not Sherwood.

headline: Signs of Energy
text: The Senate passed an energy bill on Thursday night that could make a constructive, if modest, contribution toward reducing this country’s greenhouse gas emissions and its dependence on foreign oil. Given the resistance of industry and the troubled history of previous energy bills, that is encouraging news. But it’s still only a start.

headline: All-Day Festival of Sounds, From African to Operatic
text: An unsuspecting passerby wandering down Cornelia Street in Greenwich Village on Thursday evening would have been surprised to hear pulsating waves of sound from a large, eclectic orchestra massed in the middle of the street.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Tech Missionary Shifts Focus
text: HIS ideas and opinions aside, nobody has done more than Lawrence Lessig to help people understand the profound effects of technology on the laws governing intellectual property. He is, as Wired magazine called him in 2002, “the Elvis of cyberlaw” (wired.com).

headline: Bear Stearns to Bail Out Troubled Fund
text: Bear Stearns, the investment bank, said today that it would provide a secured loan of up to $3.2 billion to one of two troubled hedge funds operated by its asset-management business, in an effort to placate lenders and investors.

headline: Delphi and U.A.W. Reach Tentative Accord
text: DETROIT, June 22 — The Delphi Corporation, the big auto supplier, reached a tentative agreement today with its unionized workers that will help it emerge from bankruptcy protection by cutting wages and benefits.

headline: Norman Hackerman, 95, Chemist and Former University President, Is Dead
text: Norman Hackerman, a noted chemist and a former president of both the University of Texas at Austin and Rice University, died June 16 in Temple, Tex. He was 95 and lived in Austin.

headline: Second Victim of Flash Flood Is Found in the Catskills
text: COLCHESTER, N.Y., June 22  Emergency workers on Friday found the body of an elderly woman killed in Tuesday’s flash flood, and are still scouring the ravaged banks of a brook that overflowed for two other missing women, the authorities said.

headline: Wimbledon Field Falls Into Place
text: WIMBLEDON, England, June 22 — Witnessing the draw at Wimbledon feels like an hour at the bingo parlor. Blank grids are distributed. Coins with numbers, each representing a player in the field, are drawn from a basket. A man at a microphone calls out the results, and onlookers quietly fill in the blank spots. A screen on the wall tracks it all.

headline: This Land Was My Land
text: MOUNT HOOD, Ore.

headline: A Glamorous Public Debut for Blackstone
text: After months of hype, hoopla and controversy, the Blackstone Group went public yesterday, and with it, lost its “private equity” moniker.

headline: Associated Press Requests Release of Names in Drug Inquiry
text: The Associated Press has become the second news organization in a month to file a motion asking a federal judge to make public the names of baseball players linked to performance-enhancing drugs in government documents.

headline: AT&T Hoping the iPhone Has Coattails
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 — When the iPhone goes on sale next Friday, people are likely to flood AT&T Wireless and Apple stores to check out the new device. But will the curiosity translate into big business for AT&T?

headline: Making Botox Both Medicine and Cosmetic
text: David E. I. Pyott, 53, became president and chief executive of Allergan in 1998 after spending his earlier management career in the nutrition subsidiaries of Novartis and Sandoz. The stock stood at $15.74 and the company was best known for its contact lens care solutions.

headline: Tracing, and Sometimes Reinterpreting, a Pioneer’s Bold Steps
text: NEW HAVEN, June 22 — It seems entirely blasphemous to open a review of America’s oldest dance company by commenting on something other than the choreography. But thank heavens for the Yale School of Music.

headline: Blood Money (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mr. Mayor, the Nader of ’08?
text: A huge ego and a few billion dollars can cause an awful lot of mischief.

headline: Detroit Would Like Higher Numbers but Not This One
text: YAHOO looked to new leadership in its battle against Google. It was a bad week for automakers. Home Depot downsized by a unit, and Wal-Mart introduced products and services for the unbanked.

headline: Space Shuttle Lands in California Desert
text: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 22 — The space shuttle Atlantis glided to a smooth landing on a desert dry lake bed here Friday, ending a two-week mission to the International Space Station that had turned somewhat dramatic after key computers broke down.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,529 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Lowering Flag for War’s Dead Brings a New Rift
text: IRON MOUNTAIN, Mich., June 19 — The Stars and Stripes in front of the Veterans of Foreign Wars lodge here flies at half-staff because Gov. Jennifer M. Granholm issued a statewide order to lower the flag for 24 hours to honor a Michigan soldier killed in Iraq.

headline: A Bach Salute to the Fallen
text: Classical music no longer relevant? Tell it to the families, comrades and friends of the nine firefighters who died in a blaze that swept through a furniture warehouse in Charleston, S.C., on Monday evening. Or, for that matter, to the hundreds of thousands who saw the opening of the memorial service held yesterday in the North Charleston Coliseum on CNN.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Wednesday about a decision by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York to quit the Republican Party  an announcement that further fueled speculation about his plans for a presidential run in 2008  referred imprecisely in some copies to a constitutional requirement for presidential candidates. The Constitution says only that the president must be “a natural-born citizen,”’ not that the president must have been born in the United States. The provision is generally regarded as barring naturalized citizens, not those born elsewhere to American parents.

headline: Guy Vander Jagt, 75, Long a Leader Within House G.O.P., Dies
text: WASHINGTON, June 22 — Guy Vander Jagt, a former congressman from Michigan and prolific fund-raiser and campaigner in nearly two decades as chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, died Friday. He was 75 and lived in Great Falls, Va., outside Washington.

headline: Yet Another Plan for Bell Canada, This One a Recapitalization
text: OTTAWA, June 22  A Toronto-based investment banking firm proposed recapitalizing Bell Canada on Friday as an alternative to the three competing privatization offers and one takeover bid for the company.

headline: From Tibet to New York, a Youth Now Faces a Long Journey to Recovery
text: Gonpo Dorjee, 16, arrived in America on May 26. But he has seen little of his new home, New York City. The sights he sees most often are a small swath of the East River and part of the industrial skyline of Greenpoint, Brooklyn — the view from the window of his room at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan.

headline: At Talks on Europe’s Charter, a Crisis Averted, for Now
text: BRUSSELS, Saturday, June 23 — Europe’s leaders averted a crisis on Saturday after Poland stepped back from a dramatic threat to veto a treaty to replace the European Union’s defunct constitution.

headline: German Officials Report Increased Threat of Terrorist Attacks
text: FRANKFURT, June 22 — Germany faces a heightened threat of terrorist attacks because of its military involvement in Afghanistan, government security officials here said Friday. The danger level, they warned, was comparable to the months before the 9/11 attacks in the United States.

headline: Keeping Early Retirees Afloat
text: What with years of layoffs, employee buyouts and sending jobs offshore, corporate America has helped create a pool of about 800,000 early retirees who now find themselves in a health care bind.

headline: From a Lead Role in a Cage to Freedom and Anomie
text: INCHEON, South Korea

headline: Nominee for a Top Justice Dept. Post Withdraws
