text: WASHINGTON, June 22 — The Bush administration’s nominee to be the Justice Department’s third-highest official withdrew his name from consideration on Friday in advance of a scheduled confirmation hearing on Tuesday.

headline: Skyrocketing Premiums and Drug Prices Going Right Through the Roof
text: Larry Little is among the nation’s early retirees who are barely clinging to their health insurance.

headline: Afghans Say NATO Airstrike Killed at Least 25 Civilians in the South
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 22 — At least 25 civilians, including nine women, three infants and an elderly village mullah, were killed in an airstrike early Friday morning when they were caught in a battle between Taliban and NATO forces in southern Afghanistan, the police chief of Helmand Province said.

headline: Moscow Presses BP to Sell a Big Gas Field to Gazprom
text: MOSCOW, June 22 — Under pressure from the Russian government, BP agreed on Friday to sell one of the world’s largest natural gas fields to Gazprom, the natural gas monopoly, in the latest apparently forced sale that benefited a Russian state company.

headline: Latest Plan From Dow Jones Is Said to Frustrate Murdoch
text: Rupert Murdoch was “surprised and frustrated” yesterday upon seeing a Dow Jones & Company plan to keep him from controlling the content of The Wall Street Journal if the company accepts his $5 billion takeover offer, according to people close to him.

headline: A Mayor Often Ill at Ease, and Usually Muted on Iraq
text: The mayor’s lips are pursed. The tuxedo-and-gown dinner crowd in the Pierre hotel ballroom has fallen still, just a few spoons rattling along the rims of dessert plates. At the very front of the room, the spotlight has settled on Michael R. Bloomberg. Someone is reading an award citation for his work as mayor. Mr. Bloomberg oscillates. He bounces on his toes, nods his head. His eyes appear to be pinned open. Though he has not uttered a word, Mr. Bloomberg’s body seems to all but scream: Get me out of here.

headline: Clooney Protests
text: George Clooney, who owns a villa in the small town of Laglio, on the shores of Lake Como, below, is urging his neighbors to sign a petition against further development there, BBC News reported yesterday. Laglio’s mayor wants to spend $15 million to build a large parking facility and a pontoon bridge that would pass in front of Mr. Clooney’s home. Mr. Clooney is threatening to leave the town, whose population is about 900, if the plans proceed. He came to Laglio in 2002, and since then his presence has attracted an increasing number of tourists to the area. “I don’t want my presence here affecting the local population,” Mr. Clooney said at a meeting of the Laglio protest committee last week. “The building work is only being done because I live here. And unless it stops I’m going to have to move.”

headline: Domestic Worker Rights (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bill Is Offered to Increase Tax on Private Equity
text: Interest on Capitol Hill in raising taxes on private equity and hedge fund managers reached a peak yesterday as leading Democrats introduced a bill that would more than double taxes on most of the income earned by partnerships, including private equity managers, venture capitalists and some hedge funds.

headline: Lessons Learned as Obama Shepherds a Following
text: It was just an organizational meeting for Senator Barack Obama’s New York volunteers, but the gathering this month jammed every pew of a church in the East Village, and the crowd spilled over into not one but two overflow rooms.

headline: Traveling Made a Touch Easier
text: BETWEEN the endless security lines, crowded planes and ever-increasing flight delays, air travel has never seemed more difficult.

headline: A Long Line for a Shorter Wait at the Supermarket
text: Show New Yorkers a checkout line and they’ll tell you whether it’s worth the wait.

headline: U.S. Group Says Pakistan Is Building New Reactor
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 22 — Pakistan is building a third plutonium production reactor at a major nuclear weapons center, a sign of plans to increase the nation’s nuclear arsenal significantly, a Washington group specializing in nuclear issues said Friday.

headline: Reserve Officer Criticizes Process of Identifying ‘Enemy Combatants’ at Guantánamo
text: The military hearings used to decide whether to hold Guantánamo detainees relied on incomplete and outdated information, screened by officers who were under intense pressure from their commanders to conclude that the detainees should be held, a reserve military intelligence officer and lawyer who had a role in the process said in an affidavit filed yesterday in a federal appeals court.

headline: At Odds With Suffolk Leader, Lawmakers Block a Tax Bill
text: ALBANY, June 22  In a rare legislative rebellion on the floor of the State Assembly, a group of black and Hispanic Democratic lawmakers have blocked a sales tax bill that would have provided millions of dollars in revenue to Suffolk County. They called the move a statement against the stringent immigration policies held by the county executive, Steve Levy.

headline: Singing, Dancing, Stamina: The Work of Pop Stardom
text: “Would you love me if I didn’t work out, or I didn’t change my natural hair?” It was Thursday night at Roseland Ballroom, and Stacy Ferguson — the pop star better known as Fergie — was singing those questions to the tune of “Zoom,” the old Commodores slow jam.

headline: Don’t Restrict the Right to Vote (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Influx From Zimbabwe to South Africa Tests Both
text: JOHANNESBURG, June 22  As Zimbabwe’s disintegration gathers potentially unstoppable momentum, a swelling tide of migrants is moving into neighboring South Africa, driven into exile by oppression, unemployment and inflation so relentless that many goods now double in price weekly.

headline: Expensive Art
text: Damien Hirst became, for the moment, the world’s most expensive living artist on Thursday, when Sotheby’s sold his “Lullaby Spring” pill cabinet for £9.6 million ($19.3 million) in London, Reuters reported. The sale came just 24 hours after Lucian Freud had taken the title when his portrait “Bruce Bernard” sold at Christie’s for £7.9 million. The London auctions, which ended yesterday, took in a total expected to be near $1 billion. Christie’s said its auctions set records for 23 artists, including Joan Miró and Mr. Freud. Sotheby’s said it set records for artists including Henri Matisse, Tracey Emin and Frank Auerbach.

headline: Library Repair Causes a Plea to the Pope
text: ROME, June 21 — Normally a sanctuary of scholarly meditation, the Vatican Library has been the scene of unusually hectic activity lately, as word has spread that it will close in July for a three-year renovation.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An entry in the Spare Times for Children listing in Weekend yesterday, about two musicals being performed this weekend by the Our Time Theater Company, misidentified the site. It is the Cherry Lane Theater, at 38 Commerce Street in the West Village  not the Theater Studio on East 24th Street in Manhattan, where the company was originally scheduled to perform.

headline: Leaders in Deal on Europe’s Charter
text: BRUSSELS, Saturday, June 23 — In a deal reached at 4:30 in the morning here, the leaders of the 27 members of the European Union agreed today to negotiate a treaty by the end of this year to replace the defunct constitution.

headline: 8 U.S. Troops Killed in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, June 23 — Eight American servicemen and one British soldier were reported today to have been killed in Iraq, bringing the four-day death toll to at least 25 as insurgents continue to use huge roadside bombs to rip through combat vehicles.

headline: You Will Never Believe Who Goes by Your Name
text: Let’s be honest: We’ve all done it. When no one’s looking, in the privacy of our own home, vanity or curiosity (or a mix of the two) compels us to google ourselves.

headline: ABC and NBC Back Off on Paris Hilton Interview
text: After a flurry of accounts this week about financial offers to land the first post-prison interview with Paris Hilton, both ABC and NBC said today that they no longer had any interest in securing the interview.

headline: Bonds Hits No. 749, and Rodriguez Is There to Cheer
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 — The alliance between Barry Bonds and Alex Rodriguez was forged through shared experiences — home run trots, front-page controversies and lots and lots of booing.

headline: Spitzer Makes His Stand and Things Fall Apart
text: ALBANY, June 22 — This time, Gov. Eliot Spitzer did not blink.

headline: Where Are Our Passports?
text: This week, Hillary Clinton chose a song by a Canadian, Celine Dion, as the theme for her American presidential bid. Ordinary citizens passing back and forth between the two countries are no longer permitted such an easy blurring of national lines.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Thursday about a search for missing people after flash floods in the Catskill town of Colchester gave an incorrect surname from The Associated Press in some copies for a firefighter carrying a child to safety, and it misstated his title in other copies. He is Steve Chesney, not Hecht, and he is the fire chief of Roscoe, N.Y., not an assistant fire chief.

headline: Rookie Laps Her Father in Popularity
text: No one needs to tell John Force, the drag-strip titan, that he needs to step on it. He is languishing in 17th place in the National Hot Rod Association’s funny car standings, and he has already been defeated once this season by an ingénue.

headline: France: Eiffel Ticket Sellers Stole $940,000
text: Fifteen former ticket takers at the Eiffel Tower were given suspended prison sentences and fines for embezzling $940,000 from ticket sales. The company that manages the Eiffel Tower discovered the scam in February 2002 after receiving an anonymous letter from one of 27 employees at the ticket office.

headline: A Group That Lives for Understatement
text: The huge catalog of jazz standards is a cozy, private place for the Keith Jarrett Trio, which returned to Carnegie Hall on Thursday night as part of the JVC Jazz Festival. Mr. Jarrett on piano, Gary Peacock on bass and Jack DeJohnette on drums have been playing together for 24 years, Mr. Jarrett proudly announced onstage. In the concert’s only overstated moment, he added, “Every time we play is a historical event for me, and it should be for you, too.”

headline: Romney Aide Who Is Focus of Inquiries Goes on Leave
text: BOSTON, June 22  The director of operations of Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign will be on a paid leave of absence while the authorities investigate accusations that he impersonated a state trooper in Massachusetts and told a reporter in New Hampshire that he had run the reporter’s license plate, the campaign said Friday.

headline: Recanted Testimony Fails to Overturn Conviction in a 1991 Murder
text: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has denied the appeal of a man convicted of murder in 1992 on the strength of testimony from five eyewitnesses who later recanted under oath.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Thursday about the weekly Billboard album chart misstated last week’s ranking of Paul McCartney’s new album, “Memory Almost Full,” which was No. 3 this week. It was No. 3 last week as well, not the top seller. (The No. 1 album last week was T-Pain’s “Epiphany.”)

headline: Dubai Government Buys Barneys for $825 Million
text: The clothing retailer Barneys New York, a temple to fashion that introduced Americans to Armani and $300 T-shirts, was sold yesterday to the investment arm of the Dubai government for $825 million.

headline: Britain: Biggest Union Backs Israel Boycott
text: Britain’s largest labor union urged “concerted and sustained pressure upon Israel,” including “an economic, cultural, academic and sporting boycott,” to force its withdrawal from Palestinian areas. The union, called Unison and grouping 1.3 million public service employees, also called on the British government to oppose the sale of arms to Israel. The calls were made in a motion approved at Unison’s annual conference in Brighton demanding the creation of a Palestinian state in the West Bank and Gaza with its capital in Jerusalem The resolution followed similar calls for pressure on Israel from British labor unions representing journalists and college teachers. British and American Jewish organizations condemned the latest boycott call.

headline: Jury Finds JT LeRoy Was Fraud
text: JT LeRoy, the authorial “other” whom the writer Laura Albert employed as her alter ego and self-protective proxy in the world, was found yesterday by a jury in Manhattan to be not just a fictional creation, but a fraud.

headline: The Mayor of Jersey City Is Convicted Over a Scuffle
text: BRADLEY BEACH, N.J. June 21  A municipal court judge in this shore town found the mayor of Jersey City guilty of obstructing justice and resisting arrest in a clash with a police officer a little more than a year ago, leading the mayor’s wife, Maureen, to hiss, “It’s a disgrace.”

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about a warehouse fire that killed nine firefighters in Charleston, S.C., misspelled the surname of a man who was rescued from the building. He is Jonathan Tyrrell III, not Tyrell.

headline: Florsheim Shoe Ads
The Last High School Ritual
text: Queen Bond and Cristal Pimentel graduated from high school on Saturday.

headline: Marvelous Menorca
text: Gardens

headline: A Tornado's Aftermath
text: It is unclear whether Greensburg, Kan., can bounce back from being flattened by a violent tornado.

headline: Bloomberg Up Close
text: Diane Cardwell describes Michael R. Bloomberg as a devoted father and avid golfer who takes his work seriously, leads by example and knows how to have fun.

headline: 2008: Gitmo Gets More Attention
text: Even though the White House has announced no timeline for a final decision in the midst of its renewed deliberations about whether to close the detention center at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, some of the Republican presidential candidates are taking the opportunity to remind their base where they stand.

headline: Hong Kong handover 10th anniversary
text: Hong Kong is going to be even busier than usual on July 1, the 10th anniversary of the city’s handover from British to Chinese rule.

headline: How Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg Shames Terry Semel
text: Terry Semel failed as Yahoo’s chief executive more than any other reason, of course, because he didn’t respond properly to the challenge of Google. Mr. Semel passed on many opportunities simply to buy Google. And he was slow to understand Google’s key business strategies—the power of search, the money from search advertising, the enormous value in creating a network that sells ads on other Web sites, and the improbable power of running a big company like a collection of dorm room startups. What’s galling, of course, is that Yahoo was a leader in offering Web search and online advertising years before Google started.

headline: June’s Poli-Book Best-Seller List
text: Former Vice President Al Gore heats up June’s political book list at No. 1 with “The Assault On Reason,” following several weeks traveling nationwide on a high-profile book tour.

headline: baggage handling
text: Page Not Found

headline: Sunday’s Breakfast Menu, June 24
text: With Senate leaders preparing to give the immigration bill a second shot this week, the topic dominates this Sunday’s breakfast menu. ABC’s “This Week with George Stephanopoulos,” for instance has Senator Edward M. Kennedy (as in “McCain-Kennedy”), one of the staunchest proponents of the compromise immigration legislation. Senator Jeff Sessions, an ardent foe of the bill, will also be there.

headline: Obama's Volunteer Push
text: Brooklyn supporters of Senator Barack Obama took their enthusiasm to the streets as part of a nationwide effort by the campaign.

headline: Delights That Linger From Summers Past
text: IT’S one of the enduring early-season rituals of summer: scoping out the business strip of your favorite beach town to see which shops and restaurants have survived the winter. When such places disappear, the culprit is often the turbulent cycles of the real estate market, which have a way of mercilessly washing away links to summers past. But for all the condos and McBeach Houses popping up along the coast, there are still plenty of spots to indulge in nostalgia at the Shore. Here are a few from a recent trip.

headline: Weddings/Celebrations; Charlotte Martin, Mark Smith
text: Charlotte Martin, a daughter of Martha Bacon Martin and David B. H. Martin of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to Mark Powers Smith, a son of Mary Smith Wiatr of Woodbury, Conn., and Wilford A. Smith of Southport, Conn. The Rev. Oran E. Warder performed the ceremony at St. Paul’s Episcopal Church in Alexandria.

headline: A Guide to Summer
text: June 23-24

headline: Correction: AMG: Passcode to Absolute Power in a Mercedes-Benz
text: A chart with a review last Sunday of cars from AMG, the high-performance division of Mercedes-Benz, misstated the size of the V-8 engine in several models. The correct displacement for the E63, CLK63, ML63, CLS63, R63, CL63, S63 and CLK63 is 6.2 liters, not 6.3.

headline: General’s Iraq Progress Report Has Competition
text: WASHINGTON, June 23 — Last month, Congress set a deadline for the American commander in Iraq, declaring that by Sept. 15 he would have to assess progress there before billions more dollars are approved to finance the military effort to stabilize the country. The commander, Gen. David H. Petraeus, said in recent days that his report would be only a snapshot of trends, strongly suggesting he will be asking for more time.

headline: A Critical Need for Medical Marijuana (2 Letters)
text: A Critical Need For Medical Marijuana

headline: Character-Driven Films (but Keep the Kaboom)
text: WHEN they befriended each other in a high school class on French New Wave cinema, Alex Kurtzman and Roberto Orci vowed that some day they would write intimate, character-driven films in the style of Jean-Luc Godard. “We were totally gung-ho to make really revolutionary independent movies,” Mr. Kurtzman said in a recent conversation. “We wanted to throw $50,000 into some movie and just make it.”

text: FILM

headline: Enough About the Whiz Kids. What Happens to Aging Stars?
text: In sports that require athletic skill, an aging star’s decline is easy to understand. In chess, though it can be exhausting, it seems strange to see champions struggle as they age.

headline: A Guide to Summer
text: Hoofing It

headline: Weddings/Celebrations; Gillian Chiong, Nicholas Sahadi
text: Gillian Cirila Chiong and Nicholas Mitchell Sahadi were married yesterday in the Dahlgren Chapel at Georgetown University. The Rev. Walter Lawrence, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. The couple met at Georgetown, from which they graduated.

headline: Let’s Get Lost
text: There’s a moment in “The Motel Life,” Willy Vlautin’s downcast first novel, when the protagonist, dead drunk, is helping his dying brother use the toilet. “This is the greatest feeling I’ve ever had,” the dying brother sighs, and by that point in the story, you believe him. The book is an unapologetic ode to self-defeat, a loose collection of deadpan cataclysms in which the most heartening episode revolves around the rescue of an undernourished dog. Its charm is unassuming, and a little clumsy at the outset, but Vlautin’s novel rewards the patient. At times its appeal is irresistible.

headline: Fears That Nature Performed a Coup de Grâce on Kansas Town
text: GREENSBURG, Kan.

headline: The Mosquito Coast
text: Drive up to Crab Meadow Beach in Northport and you will pass a lovely little salt marsh. It looks pristine, particularly because it lacks phragmites reeds, the common, brutally invasive species whose presence is always a sign of corrupted terrain.

headline: Where the America’s Cup First Set Sail
text: ALUM BAY, England  The fog is rolling in at the Needles, and so are the phantoms.

headline: A Mix of Mass-Market and Couture
text: The Habitats article last Sunday, about the home of two designers in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, misspelled the husband’s name. He is Jan Habraken, not Habranken.

headline: Correction: Endings Without Endings
text: An article last Sunday about the ending of the HBO series “The Sopranos” misidentified the hometown of the Soprano family. It was North Caldwell, N.J., not West Caldwell.

headline: A Critical Need for Medical Marijuana; A Rash Approach to Mosquito Control; Haunted by Children Who Won’t Return (5 Letters)

headline: They’re Partners. They’re Rivals. They’re Both.
text: LET’S try to get this straight: NBC Universal, which is part of General Electric, was until last Thursday taking a hard look at buying Dow Jones in partnership with Pearson, publisher of The Financial Times. Another potential partner in the deal was the Hearst Corporation, which owns Smart Money magazine in conjunction with Dow Jones and some cable channels with NBC.

headline: Weddings/Celebrations; McClain Howarth, Bridger McGaw
text: McClain Livingston Howarth, the daughter of Barbara Livingston Howarth and Robert F. Howarth of Bexley, Ohio, was married yesterday on Martha’s Vineyard to Bridger Edmund McGaw, the son of Eloise See McGaw and Robert E. McGaw of Belmont, Mass. The Rev. Robert D. Edmunds officiated at St. Andrew’s Episcopal Church in Edgartown, Mass.

headline: 6 Proposed School Budgets Pass in Revote
text: SIX of the seven school districts whose proposed budgets were rejected last month had their budgets approved in revotes on Tuesday. The only defeat was in Westbury, which must now decide how much money to cut while it operates on a restricted budget.

headline: Floating a Solution
text: Farmingdale

headline: Poet, Snubbed, Still Every Inch a Laureate
text: Freeport

headline: When the Big Dance Is Over, the Fun Is Just Beginning
text: The first party bus pulled up to Gypsy Tea, a club on West 24th Street, around midnight. Out spilled dozens of teenagers, in jeans and sundresses.

headline: Belles of Bliss
text: The style of dress for bridal parties remains untouched by the caprice of fashion. Dream weddings are played out in endless variations throughout June in city parks and gardens and the center of Times Square.

headline: Questions Your Broker Can’t Answer
text: WHAT kind of people live in this building?”

headline: Mona Xu and Justin Wheatley
text: Xiaomeng Xu, the daughter of Li Yin of Forest Hills, Queens, and Zhiwei Xu of Beijing, is to be married today in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., to Justin West Wheatley, a son of Sharman and Simon Wheatley of Monroe, Conn. Jeanne Stark, a minister of the Universal Ministries, is to officiate at the Poughkeepsie Grand Hotel.

headline: Israeli League Is Ready to Play Ball
text: JERUSALEM, June 23  In the land of milk and honey, it is time for peanuts and hot dogs  the Israel Baseball League makes its debut Sunday night when the Petach Tikva Pioneers play host to the Modi’in Miracle. A high demand for tickets has moved organizers to double the seating capacity at the Yarkon Sports Complex to accommodate a projected 2,000 spectators expected to attend.

headline: Hussein Cousin Gets Death Sentence for Mass Killings
text: BAGHDAD, June 24 — As the judge pronounced five death sentences on him on Sunday, the man Iraqis know as Chemical Ali seemed a shadow of the merciless enforcer who oversaw poison gas attacks that killed thousands of Kurdish villagers in Iraq’s northern uplands nearly 20 years ago.

headline: With Jake Peavy
text: Jake Peavy (9-1), a 26-year-old right-hander for the San Diego Padres, leads the National League with 110 strikeouts and a 1.98 earned run average, and is tied with the Los Angeles Dodgers’ Brad Penny and Philadelphia’s Cole Hamels for the most victories. Peavy, Penny and Hamels are scheduled to pitch today.

headline: A Brave New World for TV? Virtually
text: IF you can find him, Vincent Tibbett is precisely the sort of well-connected cultural liaison any emerging filmmaker should want to know. An employee of the Sundance Channel, he is as easily recognizable for his shaggy haircut and assertively casual attire as he is for the crowds of aspiring artists who follow him around, hoping to chat him up about cinematic trends, get him to evaluate their movies or simply score his e-mail address.

headline: President? Or Kingmaker?
text: MAYOR MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG of New York insisted yet again last week that he did not intend to run for president in 2008, even as he left the Republican Party to become an independent. Then, on Friday, he tweaked his language somewhat, simply saying, “I’m not going to be president.”

headline: 1949: Strawberry Tapioca Flamingo
text: In 1951, 1.5 million pounds of tapioca spilled into the East River when a pier holding a shipment from Brazil collapsed in the early morning hours. (The headline in The Times: “Tapioca à la East River.”)

headline: Saving Coral Reefs Becomes a Tourism Priority
text: GREEN sea turtles, cascades of glittering reef fish, blooming coral pillars — countless travelers have come nose to nose with a thriving undersea universe while on vacation. But increasingly, divers and snorkelers are swimming over bleached hunks of coral devastated by shore runoff or overfishing.

headline: Woody Allen’s Universe, Still Expanding, Is as Absurd as Ever
text: “I keep wondering if there is an afterlife, and if there is will they be able to break a twenty?” Woody Allen memorably wrote in “Without Feathers.” In the same collection, he lamented, “Today I saw a red-and-yellow sunset and thought, How insignificant I am! Of course, I thought that yesterday, too, and it rained.”

Hlafter of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Stuart A. Kenworthy, the rector of Christ Church in Georgetown, performed the ceremony there.

headline: School Officials Black Out Photo of a Gay Student’s Kiss
text: NEWARK, June 23 — It started with a kiss.

headline: When Computers Attack
text: ANYONE who follows technology or military affairs has heard the predictions for more than a decade. Cyberwar is coming. Although the long-announced, long-awaited computer-based conflict has yet to occur, the forecast grows more ominous with every telling: an onslaught is brought by a warring nation, backed by its brains and computing resources; banks and other businesses in the enemy states are destroyed; governments grind to a halt; telephones disconnect; the microchip-controlled Tickle Me Elmos will be transformed into unstoppable killing machines.

headline: All the Race Data Sits in Your Hand
text: IN the last two decades, television coverage of auto racing has developed into a finely tuned presentation. Broadcasts routinely feature multiple camera angles, timing and pit stop information, interviews and even team-to-driver communications.

headline: Weddings/Celebrations; Barri Gordon, Michael Margolis
text: Barri Rachael Gordon, a daughter of Wendy J. Gordon and Maury B. Gordon of East Rockaway, N.Y., was married last evening to Michael Ross Margolis, a son of Cindy Margolis and Jeff Margolis of Manalapan, N.J. Rabbi Uri Goren performed the ceremony at Temple Avodah in Oceanside, N.Y.

headline: Don’t Count on Running Into the Neighbors
text: THE gambrel-roofed Alstede’s Country Market, set alongside rolling farmland on Morris County Route 513 in Chester Township, is more reminiscent of a toy barn than a working farm building. Kurt Alstede, who grows 200 crops on the 500 acres he farms here, ascribes his success to “parents and grandparents who want to give children the experience of picking their own fruits and vegetables.”

headline: My Virginity Went From Choice to Burden
text: Are you pregnant?” Sabrina asked me.

headline: Thou Shalt Not Be a Tailgating Jerk, and Other Holy Thoughts
text: SOMEWHERE ON LIFE’S HIGHWAY

headline: The Ordinary Reader
text: When I was 7, my grandfather recited the first poem I remember hearing, “The Face on the Barroom Floor.” He performed it with verve, winking a little at the figure he cut, his bald forehead gleaming as he circled around the kitchen, doing what he called “the bear dance”: his own brand of performance poetry. He also knew “Casey at the Bat” and many other popular poems. Until I read Joan Shelley Rubin’s “Songs of Ourselves,” I’d always assumed this was a personal quirk, some inborn instinct to literature that belied his orphaned, hardscrabble youth spent working as an itinerant farm laborer and barber in the high plains of western Kansas.

headline: Israel to Transfer Millions to Abbas to Bolster Him
text: JERUSALEM, June 24 — Israel agreed today to transfer of hundreds of millions of dollars of Palestinian tax revenues to the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah, in an effort to support his new emergency government after the Muslim militants of Hamas seized control of Gaza 10 days ago.

headline: Damara Crawley, Kevin Chambers
text: Damara Leanne Crawley and Kevin Andrew Chambers were married yesterday. The Rev. Egbert P. Harvey, a minister of the United Church in Jamaica and the Cayman Islands, officiated at the Ritz-Carlton Golf & Spa Resort, Rose Hall, in Jamaica, with Judge Harry T. Edwards of the Federal Court of Appeals in Washington taking part.

headline: Catholic Lay Group Tests a Strategy Change
text: BOSTON, June 23 — Voice of the Faithful, the lay group formed in response to the sexual abuse scandal in the Roman Catholic Church, is calling for the Vatican to review the requirement that priests be celibate, saying the policy may have played a role in the scandal.

headline: Weddings/Celebrations; Nimet Habachy, Hussein Amin-Salem
text: Nimet Habachy, a former New York radio announcer, and Dr. Hussein Amin-Salem, a professor of gynecology and obstetrics, are to be married today. Judge Deborah A. Batts of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York will officiate in her chambers in Manhattan.

headline: Sexy, Scary and Often Naked: That’s Acting!
text: WITHIN the hothouse atmosphere of last month’s Cannes Film Festival, the Italian actress Asia Argento was a weather system unto herself, creating pockets of turbulence wherever she went. Ms. Argento, whose first name is pronounced “AH-zee-ah,” is one of those rare actors whose mere presence instantly makes a movie less predictable. She had three films in the festival, and in each one, handily conquered scenes that would reduce most performers to nervous wrecks or laughingstocks.

headline: This Summer, It’s Rock Around the Bloc
text: DESPITE recent events hinting at its resuscitation, the Cold War pretty much conked out for good 18 years ago. For music fans in the former Eastern bloc, the demise of the old regime brought about an unexpected benefit: the arrival of rock and techno music festivals on a huge scale previously reserved for May Day celebrations. More recently, Western festivalgoers have begun to take notice of these concerts, drawn not only by the acts, but also by the alluring ticket prices and the unfettered enthusiasm of the audience.

headline: In a Rush Not to Hurry
text: ON an evening in early June, Emmy Rossum, the 20-year-old Hollywood actress, gathered a few friends in a recording studio near Times Square for an advance listen of her coming debut album.

headline: Wright Caps a Perfect Day at the Ballpark
text: Last night’s tense 1-0 Mets victory over the Oakland Athletics at Shea Stadium included the untimely ejection of Paul Lo Duca in a ferocious temper tantrum, excellent pitching by both starters and a game-winning double by David Wright in the bottom of the ninth inning.

text: A graphic last Sunday about sugar in foods and drinks misspelled the name of a cereal. It is Froot Loops, not Fruit Loops.

headline: It Takes a Tough Man to Tell a Bad Joke
text: IN the last few months Brad Paisley and Toby Keith, two of country music’s biggest stars, have returned (if they ever left) to the place they call home: country radio. They have millions of fans and two very different reputations: Mr. Paisley excels at sweet love songs, while Mr. Keith is still best known as a pro-troop rabble-rouser. But neither one can resist a good joke — or, for that matter, a bad one. And this spring both of them came out cracking.

headline: Letters
text: The Savings Gamble

headline: Open Space Rescue
text: Supporters of saving at least some of New Jersey’s dwindling supply of open space and undeveloped land have won an important, but regrettably short-term, victory.

headline: Sonorities of a Tenor Tuba and a Symphonic Saw
text: ODD things come out of the woodwork when you move offices, as The New York Times did recently. Among the items unearthed were a number of unusual, even bizarre CDs: a testament to humankind’s ability to master the unlikeliest of instruments and to carve the classical music audience into the tiniest of niches. Hearing these CDs provided the thrill of listening to fantastically accomplished practitioners of the esoteric. Some are great musicians to boot. Here is a dog’s breakfast of recordings saved from the mover’s purgatory.

headline: Lee Urges Young Players to Carve Out a Niche on the Court
text: As a high school senior, David Lee was a high flyer who, like any teenager, loved the thrill and the theatrics of making highlight-reel dunks. He is now a burgeoning star for the Knicks because of a far more basic skill  rebounding.

headline: A New Culture Takes Hold in an Old Fishing Town
text: IT is midday in Aveiro, a surprisingly cosmopolitan fishing town on northern Portugal's Rota da Luz, the Route of Light. The spring afternoon is sunny and warm, and the canals are filled with bobbing moliceiros, their bright prows upturned like jester's shoes. Tied up to docks for lunch, they are empty of fishermen and tourists; nearby, shopkeepers are itching to close up for siesta. Lining the canals, gorgeous Art Nouveau homes are sleepy in the sun, their half-closed shutters indicating lunch is on the table.

headline: Alinghi’s Crew Begins Where It Left Off
text: VALENCIA, Spain, June 23  For all those New Zealand fans who partied through the night in Port America’s Cup, then woke up hoping that Alinghi’s crew might suffer from rust or the jitters, it turned out to be a disappointing afternoon.

headline: Beating Insects to the Punch
text: A MOSQUITO in the bedroom is usually just a nuisance, but other insects can cause serious damage to the house itself. “Termites are the first thing that comes to mind when you think of wood-destroying bugs,” said Michael F. Potter, a professor of urban entomology at the University of Kentucky.

headline: The Crowd Is Restless, but Maybe That’s a Good Sign
text: INVESTMENT newsletter editors are markedly less optimistic about the stock market now than they were late last year, when the Dow Jones industrial average was a thousand points lower. This suggests that the bull market may run a while longer, according to the market timing theory known as contrarian analysis.

headline: The Stage Shifts to Federer’s Turf in the Battle for Supremacy
text: WIMBLEDON, England, June 23 — It is Roger Federer’s tournament to lose, the expectation that comes with winning Wimbledon four times in a row. A fifth consecutive victory would match Bjorn Borg’s modern men’s record for consistency and put Federer two Wimbledon championships behind the career leaders, including Pete Sampras. It would also give Federer 11 Grand Slam titles, the same as Borg and three short of Sampras’s mark.

headline: The U.S. Attorney Who Roared
text: TRENTON

headline: Whose Orders?
text: In 1997, Saul Friedländer published “The Years of Persecution, 1933-1939,” the first of his projected two-volume history of “Nazi Germany and the Jews.” In the introduction to that volume, he announced his intention of “establishing a historical account of the Holocaust in which the policies of the perpetrators, the attitudes of surrounding society and the world of the victims could be addressed within an integrated framework.” Such a framework has indeed been missing from most historical accounts of this most difficult and challenging of subjects. They have focused either on the processes of decision-making and their implementation or on the world of suffering and death experienced by the victims. Friedländer’s first volume stood out from most other work in this field because it successfully combined both of these aspects. And his second volume does so as well. It now establishes itself as the standard historical work on Nazi Germany’s mass murder of Europe’s Jews.

headline: Subprime Fallout Could Hit Shares
text: THE long-scheduled meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers is a highlight of the calendar this week, but with no change in rates expected, investors may focus instead on subprime mortgages, where rates have been changing for the worse.

text: I FELT someone staring at me.

headline: Eight U.S. Soldiers Are Killed in Iraq Violence
text: BAGHDAD, June 23  Eight American servicemen were reported to have died in Iraq on Saturday, bringing the four-day death toll to at least 23 as insurgents continued to use huge roadside bombs to rip through combat vehicles.

headline: School’s Nearly Out, and Mr. Chips Is Thirsty
text: JUST after 4:30 p.m. on a sunny Friday, Matt Barnes and his friends were impatiently waiting for someone to let them into Moe’s, a neighborhood bar at Lafayette and Portland Avenues in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

headline: Up Front
text: The novelist Thomas McGuane, the author of this week’s cover review, is a talented but reluctant book critic. His last review in these pages appeared way back in 1993, when he assessed Thom Jones’s story collection “The Pugilist at Rest.” (That review began with these two sentences: “Writers as good as Thom Jones appear but rarely. The original poetry of his fictional world is irresistible, and the sense that he knows this world absolutely has cleansed his prose and produced an affectless sheen.”) So why doesn’t McGuane review more often? “I am aware of my responsibility to the author who deserves a fair report, and to the reader who is trying to make up his mind,” he told us in an e-mail message. “The divided mission can make reviewing painful and is probably why I don’t do it more.”

headline: 36 Hours in Bali
text: SAY Bali and most people think paradise. There are stunning sunsets, sculpted rice terraces and a temple on almost every corner. And for less-spiritual seekers, this steamy Indonesian island also has great surfing and a rollicking nightlife. Sure, it's gotten pretty touristy, especially on the pub crawl along Kuta Beach, where beer-swilling Australians rule. And while recent terrorist bombings have rattled Bali's blissful pace (it is a Hindu-majority island in a Muslim-majority nation), they have done little to temper its popularity or discourage super-chic resorts from being built. Paradise, after all, is as close as the nearest temple, finding yourself on your knees with a blue flower pressed between your fingertips, asking for blessings from Brahma or one of the other gods.

headline: Segue From ‘Gigi’ to Geek-Chic Indie Rock
text: WHEN the piano rocker Ben Folds was invited to play the opening night of the Boston Pops this spring, the orchestra managers laid down a few ground rules: No swearing; avoid songs with risqué subject matter; don’t comment on politics. This was supposed to be a gala evening of Champagne and hors d’oeuvres, not beer and groupies. They warned Mr. Folds that he would not be playing to his typical audience. But then, he said with a laugh, “I get up there, and there’s a fistfight.”

headline: Weddings/Celebrations; Sabrina Tanenbaum, Jonathan Strauss
text: Sabrina Gabrielle Tanenbaum, the daughter of Claudie Tanenbaum and Edward Tanenbaum of New York, is to be married this evening to Jonathan Aaron Strauss, the son of Elise I. headline: Correction: Ancient Road, Timeless Trip
text: A picture caption on June 10 with a photograph of a stop along the ancient trade route known as the Silk Road misspelled the name of a town in Tajikistan where mosaics were shown covering Soviet-era buildings. It is Penjikent, not Penjibent.

headline: Trading Partners
text: Creative people want to express that creativity. Meanwhile, they need to make a living — possibly by finding an audience for some buyable form of that creativity. This is an old predicament, but the Internet enables new experiments in resolving it — like the Swap Meat, a project of a Web site called Coudal.com. Coudal Partners is a small firm based in Chicago that does branding and design work for clients and has also created products of its own. Coudal.com is certainly a promotional tool for the firm, but just as certainly a constantly updated trove of interesting links and cleverly entertaining goof-off projects. Which is more or less how the Swap Meat started.

headline: Labor Formally Names Brown as Blair’s Successor
text: LONDON, June 24 — Long heralded and often rancorous, Britain’s transfer of power from Prime Minister Tony Blair entered its final countdown on Sunday when the governing Labor Party anointed Gordon Brown as his successor. It ended an era in which Mr. Blair fought far-flung wars in the Muslim world, brought peace closer to home in Northern Ireland and struggled to reform public services.

headline: A Church and Its Neighbors Grapple Over a Patch of Green
text: AT the corner of 234th Street and 39th Avenue, in the wealthy Douglas Manor section of Douglaston, Queens, a narrow plot of grass abuts a sprawling brick church.

Va., officiated at the home of a brother of the bride, Stephen G. Skinner, and his partner, A. Sinclair Dunlop.

headline: Music That Thinks Outside the Chamber
text: MY epiphany came when I told a friend I was going to a chamber music concert, and she — well-educated, well-heeled, operagoing — made a throwing-up gesture into her hand.

headline: Taming the Runaway Wedding Planner
text: SAYING “I do” to a wedding planner can be the second most important vow a newly engaged couple makes.

headline: What to See and Do in Slovenia, in and Around the Capital
text: This is my first time traveling to Slovenia. Can you give me tips for sightseeing and attractions? And what do you suggest I see in Ljubljana? —Brandy

headline: A Marine Tutorial on Media ‘Spin’
text: IN November 2005, a group of marines killed 24 Iraqi men, women and children after Sunni Arab insurgents detonated a roadside bomb in Haditha that killed one infantryman and wounded two others. Marine officers assumed the Iraqi deaths occurred during combat and were justified, if regrettable.

headline: Marketing All-Star Is Ready to Relax
text: Sonny Vaccaro, the former marketing executive for Nike, Adidas and Reebok, is finally taking a summer vacation. He is closing his ABCD Camp, the signature summer showcase for high school basketball players that he has run since 1984. The move will have a far-reaching impact on college recruiting this summer and beyond.

headline: Can a Co-op Regulate Children’s Playtime?
text: Q My family lives in a co-op at the end of a dead-end street. In the warmer weather, with parental supervision, the children (including my daughter) play outside our building. Some of the other residents in our co-op are unhappy with the noise the children make and are trying to stop them from playing outside the building.

headline: Chirac Spurns Investigators Who Seek His Testimony
text: PARIS, June 23  Having lost the immunity that protected him from prosecution while in office, Jacques Chirac, the former French president, has refused to testify in a political dirty tricks scandal that sought to discredit Nicolas Sarkozy, the current president.

headline: An Overdue Overhaul
text: For nearly 40 years, New York’ s building codes have defied common sense, more nearly resembling a Rube Goldberg vision than a vehicle for regulating building in a hyper-expanding city. Indeed, the important task of overhauling construction standards seemed so daunting that one mayor after another ducked it until Michael Bloomberg took it on.

headline: A Rocky Start for British REITs
text: AFTER much fanfare, legislation creating real estate investment trusts in Britain, one of Europe’s biggest property markets, took effect on Jan. 1. Almost immediately, nine of the country’s largest real estate companies converted to REITs, while five others made the switch soon after and a handful more plan to follow suit by year-end.

headline: Life After a Merger: Learning on Both Sides
text: MERGER planning has a great deal in common with those big premarriage discussions. In both cases, each side needs to be clear-eyed about the other’s strengths and weaknesses, to find areas where the partners can work together and other areas where they could each use some personal space.

headline: With Room to Run
text: WITH their two growing children sharing a bedroom, Asa and Micael Holmstrom decided it was time to look for more space.

headline: In a Lonely Place
text: We imagine we’ve seen this: Trond Sander, an Oslo professional who has recently lost his wife and sister, hopes to cure his loneliness by a plunge into solitude; nothing dramatic, he wants to pension out and make a few changes. Scandinavians differentiate between loneliness and solitude as a matter of course. But Trond, insinuating at times, but colloquial and close to one’s ear, tells a candid story so concretely that the reader has to live it out. “I have been lucky,” he says of his life, while acknowledging that he has always longed to be alone. Has the death of his wife liberated him? He says only, “I lost interest in talking to people.” He will indeed learn to talk, alone, in the middle of a train of thought when “the difference between talking and not talking is slowly wiped out.” Reflecting upon his move to the country, he says, “I had put myself in an impossible situation.” He sleeps poorly because in the quiet, the past presses in upon him and it is disturbing. The millennium is nigh but he expects it to mean nothing. While the fireworks are elsewhere, he will get drunk and listen to Billie Holiday on his record player. We accept that cultivated people turn up in such places, though Americans tend to view them as Edward Dahlberg described the conventional view of Thoreau, “as a kind of cranky male sibyl, a crabbed and catarrhal water sprite of our woodland culture.” Trond is no Thoreau — he’s more like us than other Scandinavian protagonists including Knut Hamsun’s Lt. Glahn or Halldor Laxness’s Bjartur — but his efforts require peace and quiet.

headline: Correction: Ryan Adams Didn’t Die. Now the Work Begins.
text: An article last Sunday about the singer Ryan Adams misstated the sales figures for his most recent album, “29.” It sold 81,000 copies, not 31,000. The article also misstated the location of the concert at which a heckler’s request for a Bryan Adams song prompted Ryan Adams to have a meltdown onstage. It occurred in Nashville, not New York.

headline: Tender Is a Toast to Avatars of the Lost Generation
text: ONE hot July in 1923 Sara Murphy, the model for Nicole Diver in F. Scott Fitzgerald’s “Tender Is the Night,” posed for Picasso on the French Riviera. “Picasso adored her,” reports John Richardson, his biographer. He was not alone.

headline: Couples
text: Here’s the perfect bedside book for an age like our own, when everything is known and nothing is understood. Marriage — especially other people’s — is as fascinating as it is mysterious. But it takes the prism of the past to turn high gossip into cultural insight. In choosing seven “marriages à la mode” in the British literary community between 1910 and the Second World War, Katie Roiphe has hit upon a strategy that allows her to probe the mysteries of marriage with a kind of forensic delicacy. At the end of her book we feel we know these couples as intimately as if we were part of their circle, but the ultimate nature of each relationship is left inviolate in its unknowability.

headline: Weddings/Celebrations; Dana DeGennaro, Joseph Garcia
text: Dana DeGennaro, the daughter of Josephine and Mauro DeGennaro of Secaucus, N.J., was married yesterday to Joseph Anthony Garcia, the son of Lucille and Edelmiro Garcia of Hoboken, N.J. The Rev. Peter J. Palmisano, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Francis Church in Hoboken.

headline: Spaces of Summer
text: THE architecture of summer tends to have a breezy, stick-built feel to it — the band shells, grandstands, boardwalks, theater barns, ball fields, screen porches, hot-dog shacks, lake cottages, beach bungalows and boathouses of a bare-limbed, open-toed season.

headline: Fans of the Concorde Want to See It Fly Again
text: The supersonic Concorde, which had its last commercial flights in 2003, might fly again if a consortium of fans, including two former Concorde pilots, has its way.

text: A Critical Need For Medical Marijuana

headline: The Purloined Manuscript
text: In 1939, while the world lived in dread of war with Hitler’s Germany, Stalin’s Russia was still gripped by the more immediate horror of the knock on the door in the early hours of the morning. It meant arrest, torture, a death sentence or, if you were lucky, “only” years in the labor camps. The danger was indiscriminate, omnipresent and had no other rationale except to intimidate millions into silent submission. Stalin’s hit list included some of Russia’s best writers and poets, whose voices he feared and mistrusted with a dictator’s unerring instinct.

headline: Baerenthal, France:  Hotel K
text: THE BASICS

headline: Where Water and Sunsets Take Top Billing
text: ON Long Island, where summer is nearly synonymous with the water, it is not surprising that many of the restaurants that appeal to us most at this time of year have a view of the shore. Still, with more than 200 miles of coastline, the Island should be awash with sparkling waterfront restaurants. In fact, there are fewer than you might expect, and their food is often so-so.

text: A BRAZILIAN hardwood called ipe is stirring controversy on the Jersey Shore, as two communities consider using it to rebuild boardwalks in coming months.

headline: Counterrevolutionary Road
text: “The more books you read, the more foolish you become,” Mao Zedong declared, initiating a movement that would close schools, send students and teachers to live among peasants and lead to the persecution and death of hundreds of thousands of China’s intellectuals. Yet even when it was most dangerous to do so, many Chinese pursued scholarship and revered the written word.

headline: Carol Browner and Thomas Downey

Justice Peter Fox Cohalan of State Supreme Court in Riverhead, officiated in his chambers. At sunset, Bill Ayres, the executive director of World Hunger Year, led a celebration of the couple’s marriage at the Fire Island Lighthouse at the Fire Island National Seashore.

headline: Saying ‘Small Block’ and Really Meaning It
text: DOWNSIZING may be a chilling concept nearly everywhere, but not in the workshop of George Luhrs, a machinist in Shoreham, N.Y., with an affinity for the very small. Mr Luhrs has built a single-cylinder engine you could lose in a pocketful of nickels and dimes.

headline: Correction: Using Alliance Partner Airlines for Miles and Upgrades
text: The Q&A column on June 10 about ways to use points for upgrades on a trip to New Zealand misstated the option of earning points on a Visa cobranded card with United Airlines and US Airways, both Star Alliance members. Although Star Alliance plans to introduce these upgrade awards across the alliance by the end of the year, the option is now offered only by a small group of airlines in the alliance, which does not include US Airways, United or Air New Zealand.

headline: A Taste of Detroit on Capitol Hill
text: The halls of Congress have been looking like the floor of the Detroit auto show in recent days. All manner of Detroit executives have found their way to Washington to lobby lawmakers on efforts to raise automobile fuel economy standards.

headline: In Tacoma, a Residential Rebirth
text: WHEN Wendy and Michael Dinon decided to buy their first home, they focused on new construction near downtown Tacoma, Wash., where Mr. Dinon works as an index analyst for the Russell Investment Group. Last October, the couple, who have a 2 ½-year-old daughter, Milly, found what they were looking for: an affordable three-bedroom house in the Salishan neighborhood, two miles east of downtown.

headline: Weddings/Celebrations; Jill Gibson and Terrence Johnson
text: IN January last year, Terrence L. Johnson was standing outside the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem when a tall, lithe woman who looked like a runner leapt out of a yellow cab. “I thought, ‘Wow, she’s incredibly gorgeous,’ ” he remembered. “Then I thought, ‘Wait a minute, I think I know her!’ ”

headline: My, Your Car Looks So Delicious
text: SADDLE TAN. I will never forget the name of the color of the Chevrolet my father bought in the 1960s. The name still suggests the Wild West, the television show “Gunsmoke“ and being as cool as James Arness, its star.

headline: Crazy for Theater, Even When It Sizzles
text: THEY’RE big, they’re sleek, they come from La Crosse, Wis., and they’re the reason New York City Center will have its first summer season since Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia designated the former space of the Ancient Order of the Nobles of the Mystic Shrine a performing arts center in 1943. At 350 tons of cooling capacity, the two Trane electric centrifugal chillers newly installed in the basement are part of a $10 million, four-year overhaul that means Patti LuPone and Boyd Gaines can star in “Gypsy” in the previously stifling theater from July 9 through 29.

headline: Jersey Boys Compete in the Heart of the Surfing World
text: IT’S an old surfing story: boys with tousled hair and baggy shorts heading out West to find the perfect wave.

headline: How Many Thimble Islands? Depends on the Tide
text: IT’S easy to drive up the Connecticut coast and never discover the Thimble Islands. Those who do spot an unobtrusive brown sign for them below the large placard for Exit 56 on I-95 probably wonder about the name. Is it meant to imply that they are small and cute, the size of thimbles? Do they look like thimbles, domed and silvery?

headline: Age Gap in Teenage Sex Continues to Stir Debate
text: IN 1999, Jon L. Schoenhorn, a lawyer from Hartford, argued before the state Supreme Court on behalf of a football player from Enfield High School who had been convicted of sexually assaulting the team’s manager.

headline: Meta Physicists
text: As though their knowledge of the quantum secrets came with the power of prophecy, some three dozen of Europe’s best physicists ended their 1932 meeting in Copenhagen with a parody of Goethe’s “Faust.” Just weeks earlier, James Chadwick had discovered neutrons — the bullets of nuclear fission — and before long Enrico Fermi was shooting them at uranium atoms. By the time of the first nuclear explosion a little more than a decade later in New Mexico, the idea of physics as a Faustian bargain was to its makers already a cliché. Robert Oppenheimer, looking for a sound bite, quoted Vishnu instead: “Now I am become Death, the destroyer of worlds.”

headline: Faith Has Role in Politics, Obama Tells Church
text: HARTFORD, June 23  Addressing the 50th anniversary convention of his own denomination, the United Church of Christ, Senator Barack Obama of Illinois said Saturday that the religious right had “hijacked” faith and divided the country by exploiting issues like abortion, same-sex marriage and school prayer.

headline: Still Extra Chunky, Now More Spicy

headline: Who’s Calling That a Peaked Roof?
text: Last fall, employees of the Landmarks Preservation Commission began canvassing the streets of Sunnyside Gardens, a small enclave in western Queens, armed with pens, notepads and cameras. Their goal was to record detailed descriptions of the area’s tidy red-brick 1920s row houses — mostly Art Deco and colonial revival, some with bay windows and peaked roofs — in preparation for a decision on whether to designate the area as a historic district that is set for Tuesday.

headline: Country Refuge, Noise and All: A Love Story
text: WE saw the house for the first time in the middle of winter. We had driven nearly as far as Long Island would allow, to Orient, the last town on the North Fork, then down the long straight road of Peters Neck, beneath tree branches black against the gray sky. Around a bend and over a small bridge and there it was: Our summer cottage, as if I had been here before in some other, more privileged life, with old money and older carpets, and was finally returning after a long trip.

headline: Thai Takeout
text: Who knew that “Bangkok 8” and “Bangkok Tattoo” were just the warm-up acts? As vibrantly as those sizzling thrillers captured the exotic flavor of crime and corruption in Thailand’s capital city, John Burdett’s BANGKOK HAUNTS (Knopf, $24.95) opens up new avenues of awe. Even Sonchai Jitpleecheep, the urbane detective with the Royal Thai Police who narrates the bizarre stories in this series, is struck dumb by the sadistic snuff film that sets the latest gaudy plot in motion.

headline: The High School Kinship of Cristal and Queen
text: The Dominican boys in the back of the freshman English class at the high school in Washington Heights were making fun of the timid African-American girl, Queen Bond. One of the boys got down on one knee in front of her as if he were Romeo — they had been studying “Romeo and Juliet” — and delivered the final crushing insult.

headline: Curling Up With a Bookshelf
text: OFTEN derided as disease-ridden “rats with wings,” pigeons are little loved by many urban dwellers. Sakura Adachi, a furniture designer in Milan, is not among the haters; she admires pigeons for their ability to create private nooks in public spaces. That avian talent inspired her to create a bookshelf called the Cave, which allows readers to curl up in a form-fitting seat, surrounded by their beloved books.

headline: Veronica Seoane, Michael Guariglia II
text: Veronica Seoane and Michael A. Guariglia II were married yesterday at St. Therese of Lisieux, a Roman Catholic church, in Montauk, N.Y. Bishop Peter A. Libasci, an auxilliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Rockville Centre, N.Y., performed the ceremony.

headline: Hamas Overture for Talks Is Rebuffed by Fatah
text: JERUSALEM, June 23 — A top leader of Hamas, which last week routed its rival, Fatah, from Gaza, called today for talks to re-form a power-sharing Palestinian government. But Fatah leaders, looking forward to a Monday regional summit meeting that excludes Hamas, rebuffed the offer.

headline: Top Player Tries to Join Exclusive Company
text: WIMBLEDON, England, June 23  The top-ranked men’s player, Roger Federer, has won Wimbledon four years in a row. If he wins again, he will be the fourth men’s player to win five consecutive titles, joining W. C. Renshaw (1881-86), H. L. Doherty (1902-6) and Bjorn Borg (1976-80). Renshaw and Pete Sampras (1993-95, 1997-2000), each with seven victories, are the only men to win more than five times.

headline: Diminishing Returns
text: During the two years leading up to his diagnosis, my husband, a highly respected physician, struggled to communicate and complete work, left me in doubt about his truthfulness, accumulated debt I was unaware of and wrote a series of notes that I found bizarre and degrading. Yet he often seemed so loving and well. I wondered if the insanity began with me.

headline: Off-Duty Lights Flash at a Popular Cabbie Hub
text: For a decade, the small corner diner at 37th Road and 73rd Street in Jackson Heights has beckoned Queens cabdrivers with the promise of good company and middle-of-the-night curry and spicy tea. So popular was the 24-hour restaurant, known as Kabab King, that yellow cabs were routinely seen circling the block, the drivers waiting for a chance to park and pop in for a quick bite before resuming their cruising.

headline: What the Front Desk Thinks of the Guests
text: Have you ever wondered what the person behind the front desk at your hotel thinks about you when you check in — or maybe weave in — a bit later than you should at night? Now you can find out on Crazy Hotel Workers (community.livejournal.com/hotel_workers/), an upstairs-downstairs type of Web site where mostly anonymous hotel employees let loose on the people they wait on and work with.

headline: Hartford’s Booster in Chief
text: HARTFORD

headline: Piece Process
text: The de facto division of Palestine over the last week into a Hamas-led enclave in Gaza and a Fatah-dominated West Bank marks a new low in the sorry annals of Palestinian affairs. Part of the blame lies with President Mahmoud Abbas, who has proved utterly unable to cope with the challenges of leadership, a fact only underscored by his “firing” of the elected Hamas government that had already in effect fired him. Israel’s wildly unpopular prime minister, Ehud Olmert (a man whose approval rating recently hit 2 percent), played a contributing role by bombing Gaza last summer (in retaliation for the kidnapping of Israeli soldiers), a move that further weakened Abbas and his Fatah party. The Bush administration, too, deserves its share of the blame for openly neglecting the Middle East conflict for its first four years in office. As it turned out, feeling abandoned made ordinary Palestinians despondent about the prospects for peace — which enabled them to cast protest votes for Hamas without worrying that its election would effectively scuttle an already moribund peace process.

headline: All the World’s a Menu
text: Midsummer nights bring free Shakespeare in Central Park, and two productions are under way. The Boomerang Theater Company is staging “All’s Well That Ends Well” on Saturdays and Sundays through July 22 near 69th Street, and the Public Theater’s “Romeo and Juliet” is running nightly through July 8 at the Delacorte Theater, near the Central Park West entrance at 81st Street.

headline: Karzai Calls Coalition ‘Careless’
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 23 — Somber, impatient and angry, President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan on Saturday accused the United States military and its NATO allies of carrying out “careless operations” that lead to civilian casualties, asserting that “Afghan life is not cheap and should not be treated as such.”

headline: Rare Specimens
text: The curious title of Bernd Heinrich’s sprawling memoir, as he discloses straightaway in his preface, is a “direct heist” from an obscure volume published in 1932 in German (“Der Vogel Schnarch”), the chronicle of an Indonesian zoological expedition in quest of an elusive species of jungle rail. Its author was none other than Gerd Heinrich, his “Papa.” Why not call the book an hommage, then? It is ultimately that too, yet the whiff of theft in the air is the first clue that what follows will be no ordinary account of a son following in his father’s footsteps. This particular gene pool turns out to be something of a fever swamp, and thereby hangs a tale of two naturalists that reads like a cross between a Darwinian parable and a Nabokov novel: an absorbing scientific saga rife with uncanny twists and fraught with quandaries over the primordial tussle between nature and nurture.

headline: Correction: Manny and the Socialites: Let’s Roll
text: An article last Sunday about Holly Peterson, the author of the novel “The Manny,” misstated the relationship of her friend Gigi Mortimer to Tinsley Mortimer, who appears in a video promoting the book. Their husbands are cousins; the two women are not sisters-in-law.

headline: White House of Mirrors
text: President Bush has turned the executive branch into a two-way mirror. They get to see everything Americans do: our telephone calls, e-mail, and all manner of personal information. And we get to see nothing about what they do.

headline: Kiss and Make Up
text: As anyone who has read Gregory Maguire’s “Wicked” or seen the subsequent Broadway show can attest, the Wicked Witch of the West was framed. Elphaba, as Maguire calls her, wasn’t really wicked at all. She was a good girl set up by the powers that be (in this case, the Wizard) for, among other things, the green color of her skin. So it goes with the recently unveiled Gospel of Judas, which posits a theory as impertinent as Maguire’s about the wickedest character in Christendom.

headline: Prying Open the Port Authority
text: The Twenties were just starting to roar when New York and New Jersey agreed to quit feuding over their mutual waterway, the one with the Statue of Liberty in its center. The two state governments created what is now called the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The treaty gave each governor the right to appoint half the agency’s board members.

headline: A Weekend Retreat
text: After years of being at the top of the retail heap, denim is finally on the wane. This summer, casual dresses are fashion's new version of jeans and a T-shirt. In knits and weaves, these cool little numbers are flirtier than denim, breezy to reach for and easy to pack. Here are seven great ways to while away a summer weekend.

headline: Mass Arrest of Brooklyn Youths Spotlights Tactics

The teenagers were frisked, forced up against a fence or a wall, or pushed to the asphalt.

headline: Washington Insider
text: As the second of Al Gore’s three daughters, you must get tired of being asked whether your father will enter the 2008 race. So let’s just get that question out of the way: Do you think he’ll run? No, no, no. He calls himself a recovering politician. He says he’s on Step No. 9 and he doesn’t want to risk a relapse.

headline: The Fugitive
text: Best known as a hero of the Underground Railroad, Harriet Tubman has been the subject of hundreds of books for young people. Full-scale biographies, however, have been scarce, though three — by Jean Humez, Catherine Clinton and Kate Clifford Larson — have appeared since the year 2000. “Harriet Tubman,” the novelist Beverly Lowry’s contribution, is labeled a biography, but the subtitle, “Imagining a Life,” qualifies that claim. In an author’s note, Lowry painstakingly explains her decision “to emphasize the visual elements of Harriet’s story — what things looked like, places and clothes, faces, plants, the sky — and to thread information from the sources” listed in her bibliography “in order to come up with one version of what life might have been like for the American hero Harriet Tubman.” She also makes us aware that Tubman was one of the first American celebrities to market her own story for profit, so the first full record of her life contains material that she and her original biographer, Sarah Hopkins Bradford, thought would sell.

headline: Correction: Bosede Gbadegesin and Oreoluwa Adeyemi

headline: Comings and Goings
text: More passport drama: Since the State Department announced that travelers could temporarily fly to Mexico, Canada, the Caribbean and Bermuda without passports, some passengers have been unable to board planes because they did not have the proper documents to enter another country. For a list of required documents, visit www.travel.state.gov and click on “travel information by country.” More recently, the State Department announced that it would give $60 refunds to those who paid for but didn’t receive expedited passport service. Send a written request to: State Department, Passport Services/PPS/Refunds, 2100 Pennsylvania Avenue NW, Washington 20037-3202. Include passport numbers (for renewals), names, dates and places of birth, dates of passport application, addresses and phone number. ... The first meal of the day is often the last opportunity a hotel has to leave an impression. So why shouldn’t hotels perk up the breakfast experience? Hilton Hotels (www.hilton.com) has done so by color-coding its more-than-80-item breakfast buffet with dietary information, as well as offering free breakfast to children 5 and under. And 500 participating Courtyard by Marriott hotels have free breakfast on the weekends —for all ages — through Labor Day (www.Marriott.com/courtyard-summer). ... Hyatt Hotels (www.hyatt.com) is going beyond coffee to embrace the more nocturnal ritual of wine. In partnership with Folio Wine Partners, a subsidiary of the Michael Mondavi family, there is now a Hyatt wine label, Canvas (above). Bottles are $22 to $28.

headline: What’s on Sunday Night
text: 9 P.M. (CMT) UNPLUGGED Last week this Grammy Award-winning concert series, reportedly inspired by Jon Bon Jovi and Richie Sambora’s acoustic performance at the 1989 MTV Video Music Awards, began to cross-pollinate on Viacom networks with airings on MTV and VH1. Tonight it’s CMT’s turn. In this network premiere, Mr. Bon Jovi, Mr. Sambora and their band, Bon Jovi, once again turn off the amps in hits like “Livin’ on a Prayer,” “You Give Love a Bad Name” and “Who Says You Can’t Go Home,” as well as songs from their latest album, “Lost Highway.” LeAnn Rimes, above with Mr. Bon Jovi, sings on the album and is the evening’s special guest.

headline: Satin Frocks and Housing Law
text: DARIO MODON is a burly 64-year-old who stands 6 feet 2 and has painted-on, arched eyebrows and a coy, puckered smile. He marches around the Red Hook projects in Brooklyn, where he lives, with a long More Red cigarette between his fingers. Before retiring, he spent decades working in the fashion industry, designing lingerie and evening wear and helping produce the brief paper dress trend of the late ’60s.

headline: Uniondale Math Results Voided as Cheating Is Cited
text: THE State Department of Education has found evidence of cheating on standardized math tests in Uniondale schools, and it has taken the unusual step of invalidating the 2006 results from math tests in Grades 3 through 8, as well as Regents examinations for math in high school.

headline: Amanda Mayer and Gregory Robbins
text: Amanda Michelle Mayer and Gregory Alexander Robbins were married last evening at Studio 450, an event space in New York. Cantor Bruce L. Ruben officiated.

headline: When Boys of Summer Linger Till Autumn
text: JOHN IVERS, 42, did not want to commit.

headline: Pulp, Packaged
text: Somehow the discovery that your personal heroes are, in fact, everyone’s idols is less comforting than it is traumatic. When you realize that the portable sages whose revelations seemed addressed only to you are the same promiscuous scriveners whose dog-eared manifestoes lurk deep within countless backpacks, lockers, night stands and bedroom closets, you may feel a sense of belonging to something greater, or, more likely, you may feel a pang of betrayal. Where you once feared that these unheralded masters might never be appreciated, now you worry that they will receive their rightful acclaim for all the wrong reasons.

headline: Suspect in 3 Shooting Deaths Surrenders
text: An 18-year-old wanted in the fatal shootings of three young men in front of a Brooklyn apartment building this month surrendered to the police yesterday, the authorities said.

headline: Who Might Escape Bausch Without a Scratch?
text: AS befits the boss of America’s best-known contact lens maker, Ronald L. Zarrella, the chief executive of Bausch & Lomb, has always had a keen eye for the fine print.

headline: A Preservation Handbook in a Few Short Blocks
text: WEST END AVENUE as it labors northward toward 96th Street presents a sort of humdrum tone — not nearly so distinguished as the blocks below 86th Street, with their bursts of Dutch- and Flemish-style architecture. But the stretch from 96th to 105th Streets is a perfect little laboratory of the design, decay and renewal of the apartment house of the 1910s.

headline: Top Official of Hamas Is Rebuffed Over Talks
text: JERUSALEM, June 23  A top leader of Hamas, which last week routed its rival, Fatah, from Gaza, called for talks on Saturday to re-form a power-sharing Palestinian government. But Fatah leaders, looking forward to a meeting of regional leaders on Monday that excludes Hamas, rebuffed the offer.

headline: ‘Doors Open’
text: This week, Chapter 7: For some locals, Doors Open had become as welcome a part of the year as Easter and Christmas.

headline: They’ll Break the Bad News on 9/11
text: BY this late date we should know the fix is in when the White House's top factotums fan out on the Sunday morning talk shows singing the same lyrics, often verbatim, from the same hymnal of spin. The pattern was set way back on Sept. 8, 2002, when in simultaneous appearances three cabinet members and the vice president warned darkly of Saddam's aluminum tubes. "We don't want the smoking gun to be a mushroom cloud," said Condi Rice, in a scripted line. The hard sell of the war in Iraq — the hyping of a (fictional) nuclear threat to America — had officially begun.

headline: Questions Remain on Massacre in Sri Lanka
text: MUTUR, Sri Lanka — The victims had been ordered to lie face down, arms outstretched, all in a row in the front yard of a white bungalow. Two lay next to a parked van, interrupted perhaps in a bid to escape.

headline: Doesn’t Ask, Doesn’t Tell
text: SOME mementos are more momentous than others.

headline: An Ancient Studio for an Even Older Craft
text: FRANCES PALMER is a stay-at-home mom with a full-time career. “I have a 30-second commute,” said Ms. Palmer, a ceramic artist and entrepreneur in Weston, Conn., a historic Fairfield County town with a rural ambience. With a coffee cup of her own design in one hand, she heads through her mudroom (“It’s a mess. Close your eyes!”) out to her studio, where she makes elegantly whimsical pottery that is sold at stores like Neiman Marcus, Barneys and Takashimaya.

headline: The Greenest Thumb
text: IT is late April, and the days are slow for Harri Ramlakhan. He rises early, around 5 or 6 in the morning, and starts to pace around the living room of the apartment in Stapleton, Staten Island, where he lives with one of his five sons. For most of the day, Mr. Ramlakhan wears sweat pants and rubber sandals. Sometimes he wanders into the kitchen to chomp on handfuls of dried chilies and fenugreek seeds.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: COMEDY

headline: Bloomberg Is a Wild Card for the Nation
text: He no longer brags about his dating exploits or shows off his impolitic side. He has largely reined in his temper with reporters and loosened his manner with voters. But Michael R. Bloomberg, New York’s once-improbable mayor, would still be a highly unlikely presidential contender.

headline: Summer Music Festivals Keep Ski Resorts Busy
text: Even nonskiers can enjoy ski resorts in the summer when the focus is not just on the mountains but music as well.

headline: The Capitol Energy Crisis
text: When you watch a baby being born, after a difficult pregnancy, it is so painful and bloody for the mother it is always hard to tell the truth and say, “Gosh, that baby is really ugly.” But that’s how I feel about the energy legislation passed (and not passed) by the Senate last week.

headline: Press the Stop Button
text: For a project on ethnographic research, one of my fellow graduate students wanted to film people in a campus elevator without their knowledge or consent. I think this is an invasion of privacy. He thinks it’s fine because the film is for educational purposes and would never be shown publicly. Who is right? — M.S., Rhode Island

headline: The Mexican Will See You Now
text: SANTA ANA, Calif.

headline: Former-Self Defense
text: One summer evening, years ago, when I was a nice, collegebound high-school senior, my girlfriend and I were wandering around the sidewalks of a closed shopping center along with some other nice, collegebound seniors. But there were also some bad kids there — the kids who were headed for lives of petty crime and repeated misdemeanor citations before finally giving in and becoming policemen. We were on foot. They were driving around slowly in an old Chevy. Thus, you could tell us apart.

headline: Drop in School Test Scores Raises Further Questions in Yonkers
text: LAST year, an investigation by the City of Yonkers concluded that wrong answers had been illicitly corrected on state-mandated English tests in four of the city’s elementary schools. Although no such cheating was found at other schools, stricter security measures were instituted across the district to protect against tampering with test answers this year.

headline: At Lunt-Fontanne, an Impasse Nears a Finale
text: In the theater district, Broadway playhouses are getting pressure from all sides.

headline: When Models Misbehave
text: ALTHOUGH Bear Stearns announced on Friday that it would shore up one of its two faltering hedge funds that are heavily exposed to the subprime mortgage mess, the move did little to instill confidence in an already fearful market.

headline: Watching the Detectives
text: THIS month, a jury convicted Khemwatie Bedessie, a 38-year-old day care worker, of raping and sexually abusing a 4-year-old boy she had been babysitting — crimes she confessed to committing. She faces 25 years in prison.

headline: Larry King Gets Paris Hilton Interview
text: After deals with ABC and NBC fell through last week, Paris Hilton will now give her first post-jail interview to Larry King on CNN on Wednesday night.
