headline: Iran Cracks Down on Dissent
text: Iran is in the throes of one of its most ferocious crackdowns on dissent in years, with the government focusing on labor leaders, universities, the press, women’s rights advocates, a former nuclear negotiator and Iranian-Americans, three of whom have been in prison for more than six weeks.

headline: Robbins Lines and  Brian Gottlock
text: Dr. Jeffrey Robbins Lines, a family medicine practitioner, and Brian Wesley Gottlock, a lawyer, were married yesterday in Montreal. The Rev. Dr. Phyllis Smyth, a minister of the United Church of Canada, performed the ceremony at St. James United Church.

headline: Senators Renew Debate on Immigration Bill
text: Senators renewed their debate over the immigration bill today ahead of the measure’s expected return to the Senate floor this week.

headline: A Troupe That Flies Without Wings, or Wires
text: ANTIGRAVITY Boots sound like equipment for X-Men, and they look that way too, raising the wearer — at rest — 16 inches off the ground on a sleek fiberglass rod that curves like a parenthesis from a “footprint” no larger than that of a high-heeled shoe. The daredevils who wear them charge onstage to a techno beat, rocket 12 to 15 feet skyward and do backflips, landing like high-pressure pistons on concrete and rocketing off again. Just watching can give you an adrenaline rush. More than once the impact has smashed the floor.

headline: Correction: What Does Africa Need Most: Technology or Aid?
text: The Slipstream column last Sunday, about the potential of technology to help African economies, misstated the name of a recent conference held in Tanzania. It was the Technology, Entertainment, Design Global 2007 conference, not the Technology, Education and Design Global 2007.

headline: A Strategy That Deserves a Double Take
text: Once upon a time, in a world we can hardly imagine anymore  an era before steroids, before “Moneyball,” before 12-man pitching staffs  any middle-of-the-lineup batter worth his millions knew that going 3-0 in the count gave him a chance to do real damage.

headline: Sarah Lukash, Robert Berg

Berg of Lynbrook, N.Y. Rabbi Dale Polakoff is to perform the ceremony at the Great Neck Synagogue, with Rabbi Steven Moskowitz taking part.

headline: Serena Wilson Dies at 73; Popularized Belly Dance
text: Serena Wilson, a noted dancer, teacher and choreographer who was widely credited with helping to popularize belly dancing in the United States, died last Sunday in Manhattan. She was 73 and a Manhattan resident.

headline: Lightning Time. Unplug Most Folk Wisdom.

headline: Storm Clouds
text: With each passing year, and each new damaging weather event, it becomes easier and easier to see climate change not just as a looming global problem but as a local problem — a problem touching not only Greenland, coral-speck nations in the South Pacific or misplaced American cities like New Orleans but also the suburbs, right here in Westchester and indeed everywhere within sprawling distance.

headline: Graffiti Secrets
text: Graffiti Secrets

headline: Where Is Washington’s Love for Shareholders?
text: SOMETHING terrible happened last week in terms of legal protections for stockholders. The terrible thing came out of the present administration, and I simply cannot understand how it could have gotten it so wrong, except on the basis of the machinations of one of our favorite subjects, Henry M. Paulson Jr., the Treasury secretary.

headline: Teachers’ Merit Pay: A Good Idea? (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Crossing the Gold Line
text: IF Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan to charge motorists to drive below 86th Street in Manhattan is approved, it may do more than simply reduce traffic, noise and pollution in the Manhattan business districts. Brokers say that it could add an extra sense of exclusivity to what is already some of the most expensive residential real estate in the country.

headline: His Eyes Have Seen the Glory of Rucker Park
text: Ernie Morris was at Rucker Park in the summer of 1957 when a giant named Chamberlain crushed a team of all-stars that included Cal Ramsey, a rugged rebounding machine from New York University who later played for the Knicks.

headline: In Tacoma, Recreating Public Housing
text: WHEN Wendy and Michael Dinon decided to buy their first home, they focused on new construction near downtown Tacoma, Wash., where Mr. Dinon works as an index analyst for the Russell Investment Group. Last October, the couple, who have a 2 ½-year-old daughter, Milly, found what they were looking for: an affordable three-bedroom house in the Salishan neighborhood, two miles east of downtown.

headline: Love and Human Remains
text: Poetry and death have been seen around town for quite some time. Among all the literary musings on death, the most affecting and surprising, it strikes me, are by the poet who daily confronts it. To the fine essays of the poet and undertaker Thomas Lynch must be added this gleaming, humane work by the poet Christine Montross, written during, and about, her first year of medical school. (She matriculated at Brown University when she was 28 and is now a resident in psychiatry there.)

headline: Still More Tales of the City
text: Armistead Maupin’s enormously popular “Tales of the City” series, published between 1978 and 1989, told the story of a disparate group of San Franciscans brought together under the roof of Anna Madrigal, a transsexual lady of a certain age who ran a boarding house on a street called Barbary Lane while growing marijuana on the side. Reviving a 19th-century tradition, Maupin wrote the Tales in the form of a serial, with installments appearing daily in The San Francisco Chronicle. After “Sure of You” came out in 1989, Maupin declared that the series was finished, and went on to write two other novels. He changed his mind, however, and now he brings us “Michael Tolliver Lives,” a sort of coda to the Tales, in which he catches us up on the many characters who populate the earlier books — and in particular on Mike Tolliver himself.

headline: Across Region, a Scramble to Find Lifeguards
text: Wantagh, N.Y.

headline: The Week on Long Island
text: Lawmakers Pass Bill on Affordable Housing

headline: In Homage to Buddha, a Splash of Freedom
text: AS the sun set on Staten Island’s south shore, a Tibetan Buddhist named Gyatso carried a crate of live shellfish down to the harbor. Squatting on a rock, his sneakers perilously close to the water, he submerged the crate, and then tossed the marine snails, one by one, into the sea.

headline: Branded
text: Look around Las Vegas during the 10 days of the Wrangler National Finals Rodeo, and you get the impression that the city belongs to the rodeo and that the rodeo belongs to Wrangler. From the inside of the arena, where the competition takes place against a backdrop of nearly uninterrupted Wrangler signage, to the casino bars filled with the cowboys and buckle bunnies of the rodeo singles scene, there are thousands of backsides stitched with the Wrangler patch. Even the artificial volcano outside the Mirage hotel is tinted pink to match Wrangler’s Tough Enough to Wear Pink campaign to benefit breast-cancer research. Although the corporate headquarters of this billion-dollar denim company are in Greensboro, N.C., this is Wrangler Town, and it appears once a year, a country-western Brigadoon.

headline: United States Wins Fourth Gold Cup
text: The United States retained the CONCACAF Gold Cup in stunning fashion Sunday, by rallying from a 1-0 deficit to defeat Mexico, 2-1, in a pulsating match at Soldier Field in Chicago.

headline: Calendar of Events

headline: Weddings/Celebrations; Sarah Dunn, Peter Stevenson
text: Sarah Dunn and Peter Marshall Stevenson were married last evening at Blue Hill at Stone Barns the restaurant on the Rockefeller family’s Pocantico Hills estate in Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. Paul DeHoff, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

headline: In Pursuit of Perfect TV Color, With L.E.D.’s and Lasers
text: HIGH-DEFINITION television sets grow ever more sophisticated, but the colors on many of the screens are still created the old-time way: with tubes or bulbs that give off white light that is filtered into primary colors and remixed.

headline: Cars for Girls: Dolls Are Included
text: MATTEL, no slouch at marketing, pitched them as “the smallest line of cars introduced at the New York auto show.” The company says that its new Polly Wheels are the first die-cast toy cars aimed at girls — a development that seems to promise progress in smashing stereotypes of boys playing with cars and girls with dolls.

headline: Hard Realities of Soft Power
text: As a senior adviser to the State Department’s Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs, David Denehy is charged with overseeing the distribution of millions of dollars to advance the cause of a more democratic Iran. Affable, charming and approachable, he is bearlike in stature and manner. His voice is pleasantly rumbly; his smile is so wide that it seems to have been drawn onto his face with a crayon. Over the last two years, Denehy has canvassed dozens of pundits, students, journalists, bloggers and activists across the world about how he might best go about his work — what he calls, echoing President Bush, “the freedom agenda.” He has shaken hands with millionaire exiles, dissidents, monarchists, Communists, self-styled Mandelas and would-be Chalabis. He is the public face of “the democracy fund,” as it has come to be known, or simply “the $75 million.”

headline: Small-Screen Sirens; ‘The Sopranos’; Ballerinas’ Farewell
text: SMALL-SCREEN SIRENS

Morosani and John W. Morosani, also of Litchfield. The Rev. Robert L. Ficks III, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Michael’s Episcopal Church, with the Rev. Jennings Matheson, another Episcopal priest, taking part.

text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s congestion pricing proposal to reduce weekday traffic on the busiest streets in Manhattan is a bargain for the New Jersey commuter.

headline: Many Victories for Hendrick, but a Lot of Loss, Too
text: CONCORD, N.C., June 21 — One of the first milestone moments in Rick Hendrick’s storied Nascar career came in 1985, when he was a fledgling racecar owner and was handed a $1 million sponsorship check.

headline: Students Charged in Prank Draw Cheers at Graduation
text: MONTROSE, N.Y., June 22 — The eight seniors were not allowed to wear caps and gowns or to march up to receive their diplomas, but when their photographs were flashed across a screen Friday night at the graduation ceremony, they got the biggest cheers.

headline: Where the Candyman Begins His Journey
text: Last week, Derrick Cruz, a 17-year-old with thick dreadlocks and a droopy backpack, walked into Delma’s Tobacco Company, a cramped candy-and-cigarette wholesaler on Burnside Avenue in the Tremont section of the Bronx. Across the front room, Francisco Ferrer looked up behind a bulletproof window.

text: JAY LENO

headline: In a World on the Move, a Tiny Land Strains to Cope
text: MINDELO, Cape Verde — Virtually every aspect of global migration can be seen in this tiny West African nation, where the number of people who have left approaches the number who remain and almost everyone has a close relative in Europe or America.

headline: Two Loft Conversions, Two Points of View
text: TWO buildings in the process of being converted into residential condominiums — one in TriBeCa, the other in Hell’s Kitchen — are harbingers of what I think is a refreshing return to an aesthetic that celebrates the qualities of loft living.

headline: Effervescence From Bordeaux
text: Sparkling wine from Bordeaux is rare. Jaillance’s nonvintage Cuvée de l’Abbaye, produced there, is a smarter buy than many costly brut Champagnes. A crémant — a French sparkling wine from outside the Champagne region — this dry, white aperitif comes from sémillon grapes.

headline: From Childhood Dreams of Priesthood to a Bishop’s Chair
text: HARTFORD

headline: Famished and Footsore? Stops Along a Road Trip
text: LONG days, soft warm air — the season whispers road trip. Whether the destination is a historic home or a modern outlet center, the drive will probably require a stop for refreshments, and if the atmosphere is pleasant, so much the better. Here are a few suggestions for that midjourney stretch and nibble. Although not as cheap as a food court or a roadside fast-food place, the prices include a view.

headline: What to Expect When Expecting? A Whole Lot of Loot
text: AFTER Claire Varrelmann announced that she was pregnant, she created three registries for her four baby showers.

headline: In 1962, Richardson Had Ball, But No Hat
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 23  Bobby Richardson saw his picture in The New York Times on Thursday and had to tell the story behind it.

headline: The Possessed
text: The stones at Machu Picchu seem almost alive. They may be alive, if you credit the religious beliefs of the ruler Pachacuti Yupanqui, whose subjects in the early 15th century constructed the granite Inca complex, high above a curling river and nestled among jagged green peaks. To honor the spirits that take form as mountains, the Inca stoneworkers carved rock outcrops to replicate their shapes. Doorways and windows of sublimely precise masonry frame exquisite views. But this extraordinary marriage of setting and architecture only partly explains the fame of Machu Picchu today. Just as important is the romantic history, both of the people who built it in this remote place and of the explorer who brought it to the attention of the world. The Inca succumbed to Spanish conquest in the 16th century; and the explorer Hiram Bingham III, whose long life lasted almost as many years as the Inca empire, died in 1956. Like the stones of Machu Picchu, however, the voices of the Inca ruler and the American explorer continue to resonate.

headline: For Filmmaker, ‘Sicko’ Is a Jumping-Off Point for Health Care Change
text: The cameramen shuffled backward through a Capitol Hill corridor, as reporters from Tokyo and Paris strained to capture the campaigner’s every word. An entourage of handlers, with cellphones to their ears, kept the scrum moving toward the door. A van was waiting, its engine running. “Keep moving, people,” one aide barked. “Keep moving. We’ve got to go.”

headline: U.S. Officials Question Ability of Iraqi Troops
text: BAGHDAD, June 24 — Iraq faced more troubles on the military and political fronts on Sunday: American commanders expressed doubts about the ability of Iraqi troops to hold the gains made in areas north of the capital last week, and two Sunni Arab blocs boycotted a Parliament session, demanding the reinstatement of the speaker.

headline: Training for the Twists of Driving a School Bus
text: UNTIL recently, Sandra Castillo, 37, a laid-off factory worker, had never driven anything larger than a car. But now she was at the wheel of a 30-foot-long school bus. She made a tight right turn from a wide avenue into a narrow side street in Brooklyn as smoothly as a veteran bus driver.

headline: Hildy Kuryk, Jarrod Bernstein
text: Hildy Kuryk, the daughter of Judith Frisch Kuryk and David Kuryk, both of New York, is to be married this evening to Jarrod Neal Bernstein, a son of Roberta and Edward Bernstein of Merrick, N.Y. Rabbi Joseph Menashe is to officiate at Sky Studios, a loft in New York.

headline: Outdoor Sculptures Kissed by Nature
text: From where I stand, there is sculpture as far as the eye can see. That’s the beauty and power of art in the natural world. It surrounds you, bonding with the landscape. It gives you a way of looking at nature, and art, in a new way.

headline: Inside the List
text: THE OPRAH THING: Jeffrey Eugenides’s novel “Middlesex,” the winner of a Pulitzer Prize in 2003, is Oprah Winfrey’s first post-Cormac McCarthy pick — but “Middlesex” doesn’t displace McCarthy’s book “The Road” (yet) at the top of the paperback fiction list. It slides in instead at No. 2.

headline: A Diplomat Reflects on Taiwan’s Isolation
text: Taiwan’s small circle of international supporters  countries that have diplomatic relations with the 23 million inhabitants of the island known as the Republic of China instead of the 1.3 billion of the People’s Republic across the Taiwan Strait  got a little bit tighter earlier this month when Costa Rica announced that it was switching its allegiance to China.

headline: Prosecutor Becomes Prosecuted
text: THE misconduct that cost the prosecutor in the Duke lacrosse case his career certainly seemed to call for a severe penalty: he withheld evidence from the defense, misled the court and inflamed the public.

headline: Weddings/Celebrations; Jeana Titre, Clifford Samuel
text: Jeana Titre and Clifford A. Samuel were married yesterday at Pilgrim Church of Brownsville in Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. Hezekiah Farrell, a nondenominational minister, officiated.

headline: Correction: Bolivians in High Dudgeon Over Soccer Ban
text: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Bolivia’s protests of a ban on high-altitude soccer misstated the meaning of the acronym FIFA, the international soccer organization. FIFA stands for the Fédération Internationale de Football Association (International Federation of Association Football), not the Federation of International Football Associations. (“Association football” is an English term for soccer.)

headline: A Bit of Caviar With Those Fries?
text: AT least twice a week, Amy Pines of Westport likes to take her two children out to dinner. Her favorite place to dine? The concession stand at the beach.

headline: When the Diploma Is Just a Dream
text: WHEN he lets his mind drift, Jaime Carrera dreams not of his future but his past.

headline: Internet Video: A Stream Becomes a Virtual Deluge
text: The computer appears to be well on its way toward total entertainment domination in the home. As evidence, look at new data from comScore Inc.: more than 70 percent of Internet users streamed video online in March this year. Television, movies, music and more — it’s all there in that box, awaiting full integration.

headline: Among Venerable Ruins, a Rusty Relic From 1964
text: AT first glance, there is not much in common between a rusty 1964 structure that sits in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park and venerable edifices like the Church of the Holy Nativity in Bethlehem, or Monte Albán, a 2,500-year-old Zapotec ruin on a mountaintop outside Oaxaca, Mexico. This month, though, the New York State Pavilion, a crumbling relic of the 1964 World’s Fair that sits in the park, was named along with the other far-flung sites to the World Monuments Fund’s list of 100 endangered sites, which is released every two years.

headline: Weddings/Celebrations; Jennifer George, Kenneth Heckel
text: Jennifer Sarah George and Major Kenneth George Heckel were married yesterday at the OceanCliff Hotel in Newport, R.I. The Rev. Ara Jizmejian, an Armenian Evangelical minister, officiated.

headline: Oregon State One Win From a Second Title
text: OMAHA, June 23  Every time he approached the third-base line on the way to the mound Saturday night, the Oregon State freshman right-hander Jorge Reyes bounded across the dirt as if it were piled high with hot coals. That is the most obvious of Reyes’s multitude of superstitions, which include tapping seven acupuncture points on his forehead and chest before every inning, and wearing the same shorts on days he pitches.

headline: Former Yankees to Act in a Play
text: Coming to a theater near, well, Yankee Stadium: Darryl Strawberry and Jim Leyritz in “The Boy of Steel,” a one-act play set at the stadium.

headline: Gunman Kills 1 in Harlem, Then Is Shot by the Police
text: A subway conductor was shot and killed and two of his friends were wounded after a dispute outside a fried chicken restaurant in East Harlem early yesterday, the police and witnesses said. The man who shot them continued firing as he ran from the scene and was himself shot and critically wounded by police gunfire, according to the police.

headline: History Intrudes
text: Penelope Lively’s new novel begins as simply as the children’s game from which it takes its title. Her name, his name, an action, the consequences: “They met on a bench in St. James’s Park; it was the 6th of June 1935. Lorna was crying because she had had a violent argument with her mother; Matt was feeding the wildfowl. ... He looked sideways, and was done for.” The novel ends two generations later, as their granddaughter falls in love.

headline: The Human Touch That May Loosen Google’s Grip
text: ONCE upon a time, the most valuable secret formula in American business was Coca-Cola’s. Today, it’s Google’s master algorithm.

headline: Star Search
text: Over three evenings last month, several dozen writers gathered in the airy sanctuary of Hebrew Union College for a bizarre rite of passage: the Jewish book tour casting call. In a combination of “The Gong Show” and speed-dating, they each had two minutes to pitch their books to the Jewish Book Network, 100 cultural programmers from Jewish community centers, or J.C.C.’s, synagogues and libraries nationwide. An M.C. ruthlessly held up a sign when one minute was up and cheerily announced “on deck” to prepare the next speaker.

headline: The Real Villain of New York Baseball
text: Fifty years would be time enough in the national memory to qualify the Dodgers’ departure from Brooklyn as a mythical event, were it not that it actually happened. I know it did; I was one of the kids it happened to.

headline: Summer, and Drinking Is Breezy
text: THAT steady drone of conversation punctuated by the clatter and clink of beer bottles or gusts of laughter sounds familiar, the same way it does when you get off the elevator and home in on which apartment door leads to your friend's party.

headline: A Jug of Wine, a Bag on Wheels and Thou
text: WHEN shopping for a wedding gift it might be more important to know if some couples prefer Sassicaia or Haut-Brion Blanc, rather than if their dinnerware is patterned or plain white. For wine lovers, a special bottle — or a case for that matter — makes a welcome gift. But the wine won’t last forever, so why not include an accouterment that can be used for many bottles and years to come?

headline: Weddings/Celebrations; Erin Walworth, Shawn Reilly
text: Erin Davis Walworth, a daughter of Carla Walworth and the Rev. Geoffrey Walworth of Monroe, Conn., was married yesterday to Shawn Michael Reilly, the son of Elaine and J. Raymond Reilly of Export, Pa. The Rev. George E. Walworth, the bride’s grandfather and a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Inn at Bay Harbor in Michigan.

headline: Autism in the Vaccine Court
text: A federal vaccine court in Washington is confronting the contentious and highly emotional issue of whether early childhood vaccinations might have caused autism in thousands of children. Virtually every major scientific study and organization that has weighed in on the issue has seen no link. But many parents of afflicted children remain unconvinced. Their lawyers will try to prove that some 4,800 children were harmed by the mass vaccination campaigns that protect the nation’s youngsters from potentially devastating childhood illnesses.

headline: No Exit, but No Surrender

The ramp holds a special place in drivers’ hearts. As the first exit above 56th Street, and the last before the notoriously backed-up ramp at 79th Street, it is a kind of navigational sweet spot.

headline: The President’s Man
text: Near the end of his new memoir, Jack Valenti, who died at 85 on April 26, tells how he planned to take an active role in marketing his work. “Spend time with the booksellers,” one friend had counseled him. “If they like you and your book, you’re on your way to the best-seller list.” Valenti did “not intend to ignore” the advice. Fate finally had other plans, but it’s nice to know that the author took his deeply ingrained optimism all the way to the grave. “This Time, This Place” is a cheerful, overwritten double feature, the story of Valenti’s days in Lyndon B. Johnson’s White House — an experience it’s safe to say only he could describe as the “summertime” of a life — and his long subsequent lobbying years as chairman of the Motion Picture Association of America.

Not long after, as she prepared dinner, a golf ball shattered the kitchen window, whistled past her head and crashed through the glass on her oven door. Ms. Weiner retrieved the ball from her oven and stalked outside to confront the golfer who had launched the missile.

headline: Paperback Row
text: REVOLUTIONARY CHARACTERS: What Made the Founders Different, by Gordon S. Wood. (Penguin, $16. ) In a series of biographical sketches, Wood, a Pulitzer Prize-winning historian, looks back on the Revolutionary War era and assesses the achievements of its leaders. For men like Washington, Jefferson and Adams, Wood writes, the “idea of character was the outer life, the public person trying to show the world that he was living up to the values and duties that the best of the culture imposed on him.” Wood situates the founders within the historical and political tumult of their times and argues that the very egalitarian democracy they created all but guarantees that we will “never again replicate” this extraordinary generation. In the Book Review, Jon Meacham called these essays “illuminating.”

headline: Editor’s Choice
text: SUPREME DISCOMFORT: The Divided Soul of Clarence Thomas, by Kevin Merida and Michael A. Fletcher. (Doubleday, $26.95. ) The authors superbly deconstruct Thomas’s multiple narratives of critical events in his life.

headline: ‘Uncommon Arrangements’
text: AUGUST 5, 1914. A few minutes after midnight as Britain was entering the war, an illegitimate baby was born in a conspicuously anonymous redbrick house on the northern coast. His mother, Rebecca West, whose real name, which nobody used, was Cicily Fairfield, held the sleeping bundle in her arms, while her sister and a friend perched on her bed. The baby's father, H. G. Wells, was one hundred miles away, sitting up late in his llama-wool pajamas, in the second-floor study of his large comfortable house in Essex, putting the finishing touches on an essay for the Daily Chronicle, which he was planning to call "The War That Will End War." He poured himself a cup of tea, which he had brewed himself on the small stove nestled in the fireplace, and nibbled a dry biscuit. His wife, Jane, was asleep in the bedroom, her dark blond hair fanned out against the pillow. He loved his wife, and he loved his young mistress. He loved his ivy-covered Georgian house, Easton Glebe, which was a gracious symbol of how far he had come from his hardscrabble origins. Unlike nearly everyone he knew, Wells was feeling optimistic about the war, exhilarated by the possibilities of the world in flux. Through his window he could see the familiar outline of a fig tree in the darkness.

headline: ‘The Snoring Bird’
text: Mamusha is just settling down on her bed to watch the evening news when I arrive. Two cans of Coors, which she has opened with the point of a pair of scissors, are on the table next to her, along with a box of German chocolates. She used to make her own beer, but now, in her mid-eighties, she likes Coors from a can; and because her gnarled hands are too weak, she cannot pull off the tabs. Duke, the huge shepherd-hound that she rescued from the pound, is at her feet, and a one-legged chicken lies cradled in her lap. She is mildly irritated at me for arriving unannounced (I have a tendency either to just show up or to come an hour later than I've promised, which annoys her also), but soon I have placated her and she offers me a beer.

headline: ‘Out Stealing Horses’
text: Early November. It's nine o'clock. The titmice are banging against the window. Sometimes they fly dizzily off after the impact, other times they fall and lie struggling in the new snow until they can take off again. I don't know what they want that I have. I look out the window at the forest. There is a reddish light over the trees by the lake. It is starting to blow. I can see the shape of the wind on the water.

headline: ‘Way Off the Road’

headline: ‘The Archivist’s Story’
text: It is a small matter that brings them together. A story, untitled, unsigned, and by all appearances incomplete, which the arresting officers in their haste have neglected to record in the evidence manifest. A year ago, when the Lubyanka thrummed with activity, when all of Moscow seemed to hold its breath at night and every morning brought a new consignment of confiscated manuscripts to Pavel's desk, such a discovery would have hardly warranted a second look, let alone this face-to-face meeting the archivist frankly dreads. Babel has confessed: One story will not change that, nor will it save him. Still, Kutyrev has insisted the matter be formally resolved, and since Pavel must now answer to the ambitious young lieutenant, the question of authorship is to be settled, if only for the record. Already an empty office upstairs has been reserved for the purpose. In due course the appointed morning comes. Just as the first heavy drops of rain are beginning to fall onto the dreary courtyard below, a guard raps once on the door. Babel enters.

headline: ‘The Motel Life’
text: The night it happened I was drunk, almost passed out, and I swear to God a bird came flying through my motel room window. It was maybe five degrees out and the bird, some sorta duck, was suddenly on my floor surrounded in glass. The window must have killed it. It would have scared me to death if I hadn't been so drunk. All I could do was get up, turn on the light, and throw it back out the window. It fell three stories and landed on the sidewalk below. I turned my electric blanket up to ten, got back in bed, and fell asleep.

headline: Vegas, Baby
text: It’s 4 a.m. and I’ve got the cruise control set to 85 m.p.h. I’m listening to Black Rebel Motorcycle Club, my new favorite band, and swigging Dr. Pepper the way farmers down in Columbia chew on cocoa leaves to wake themselves up. Rolling the window down doesn’t help any, either — the warm breeze coming in is soft as a downy pillow. I’m crossing over the Tehachapi Pass on Highway 58 out of Bakersfield, a windy old road lit only by the headlights of my car. By dawn I’ll be passing through Joshua Tree National Forest, leaving California behind for the bright lights of Las Vegas. Of course, every one of those Vegas light bulbs will be turned off by the time I get there. The remnants of last night’s light will have left the earth’s thin atmosphere and pushed out toward Venus.

headline: Brooklyn: Testimony’s Disclosure May Be Reviewed
text: The chief administrative judge for Brooklyn Supreme Court is considering a motion to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate the disclosure of secret grand jury testimony by the district attorney’s office. The judge, Neil Jon Firetog, is expected to announce his decision at a hearing today. The case concerns Andria Sergio, 27, who has been charged with hindering prosecution and improperly disposing of a body for her role in the death of her sister’s newborn baby, found on the back porch of the family’s home in Bay Ridge in April. Ms. Sergio’s sister Laura Sergio, 25, has been charged with murder. A defense lawyer, Daniel N. Arshack, has argued that a court filing by prosecutors that included a summary of Andria Sergio’s grand jury testimony was improper and was intended to prejudice jurors. The district attorney’s office has said the summary was included to ensure that the testimony would be accepted as evidence at trial.

headline: Giuliani’s Views on Abortion Upset Catholic Leaders

headline: Bedminster: 2 Children Critically Injured in Crash
text: Two children were ejected from a sport utility vehicle on Route 78 in Somerset County yesterday afternoon and were in critical condition. The children, Isaias Rodriguez, 9, and Fernando Tepada, 10, suffered severe head injuries after the driver, Betsy E. Tejeda-Lopez, 34, lost control of the S.U.V., the state police said. She may have fallen asleep as she drove through Bedminster Township about 2:45 p.m. on her way home to Reading, Pa., from New York City, where the group had been visiting relatives, the police said. Isaias, a son of Ms. Tejeda-Lopez, and Fernando, a nephew, did not appear to have been wearing seat belts, the police said. Two other children in the car — Ms. Tejeda-Lopez’s son Eddy J. Rodriguez, 2, who was strapped into a child seat, and Freyla A. Tejeda, 14, the woman’s niece, who was wearing a seat belt — were hospitalized with less serious injuries, the police said. Ms. Tejeda-Lopez, who was wearing a seat belt, had head and chest injuries that were not life-threatening, the police said.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on Tuesday of Lola S. Wasserstein, the mother of the playwright Wendy Wasserstein and the inspiration for several characters in her plays, misstated her influence on the play “Uncommon Women and Others.” She was the model for the mother of the character Holly Kaplan, not for Holly Kaplan herself. The obituary also referred incorrectly to Holly. She complains that her mother  not seen onstage  is pushing her to find a boyfriend. It is not Holly who pushes her daughter to find a boyfriend. (Holly does not have a daughter in the play.) The obituary also omitted a survivor, a son, Abner Wasserstein.

text: BRUSSELS, June 25 —President Nicolas Sarkozy of France blocked a key element of Turkey’s entry negotiations with the European Union today, potentially derailing the country’s efforts to join the bloc.

headline: Fearing Wal-Mart Will Bring Too Much of the Outside In
text: MONSEY, N.Y. — It seems whenever Wal-Mart proposes a new store, controversy sprouts. Across the country, environmentalists, unions, civic associations and churches have objected to the retailer’s plans to drop anchor in their communities, citing concerns about traffic and crime, merchandise and employment policies and the overall quality of life.

headline: A Final, Radiant Juliet, Then Farewell
text: Alessandra Ferri, the fiery dancer-actress, bade farewell to American Ballet Theater on Saturday night as the crowd roared back with something more than appreciation: the kind of fierce love befitting a ballerina whose career enhanced lives with a bold spell of earthy, Italian passion. For years characters like Giselle, Manon and Juliet — reborn in Ms. Ferri’s vivid imagination — have transcended the stage to become flesh and blood. Fittingly, as she took her final bows at the Metropolitan Opera House, where Romeo and Juliet was performed for the final time this season, the relentless twinkle of flashing cameras seemed to transform it into a strobe-filled wonderland.

headline: The Subway Beat
text: It’s nearly always a mistake to think of the subway as a public conveyance. This is a mistake that out-of-towners often make. They overlook the essential privacy of the subway, and by that I don’t mean the young woman at my end of the car who has made up her face in a compact mirror between 86th Street and Times Square. I mean the very fact that this is my end of the car at my end of the train. It’s 7:30 in the morning, and this isn’t just a subway ride. This is going to work. Nearly all the people on this train are in their usual spots, within a few minutes of their usual time, and the ride is not separable from the larger and more complicated rhythms of our private lives. It is possible to be on this train and not yet be in public.

headline: In Baseball, Believing Is Seeing
text: One of the beauties of baseball is that anytime you watch a game, there’s a chance you will see something you have never seen before. Early in the Mets’ 10-2 victory over the Oakland Athletics yesterday at Shea Stadium, José Reyes provided the 50,143 in attendance with something that probably none of them had seen before — not an inside-the-park home run, but definitely an inside-the-park run home.

headline: Study on I.Q. Prompts Debate on Family Dynamics
text: The new evidence that eldest children develop higher I.Q.’s than their siblings has intensified the debate over two of the most stubborn questions in social science: What are the family dynamics that enhance intelligence? And can they  and should they  be changed?

headline: Louisiana Overhauls Defense for the Poor
text: NEW ORLEANS, June 24 — Louisiana moved to overhaul its faltering system for defending indigent suspects on Sunday, passing a bill in the State Senate that centralizes control over the appointment of lawyers for the poor.

headline: Staten Island: Father Charged in Pipe Bomb Case
text: A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday morning and accused of leaving a pipe bomb on the hood of his daughter’s car in Staten Island on Saturday, bringing bomb squad officers to both boroughs before he was found, the police said. The man, identified as Baudelio Rodriguez, 47, was feuding with his wife, who had left their home in Sheepshead Bay and was staying with their daughter, the police said. The daughter saw the pipe bomb on her car and called the police Saturday afternoon. The bomb, filled with explosive powder, was safely removed, its fuse unlighted. The police searched Mr. Rodriguez’s house, on East 29th Street, on Saturday night, but they did not find him or any explosives. Mr. Rodriguez was arrested shortly after 1 a.m. at his brother’s house nearby, the police said. He was charged with reckless endangerment, attempted arson, unlawful dealing with fireworks and violating a court order of protection, the police said.

headline: Sales Chief Is the Latest to Depart From Yahoo
text: Yahoo said Sunday that Wenda Harris Millard, its longtime chief sales officer, is leaving amid a reorganization of Yahoo’s sales team.

headline: Brooklyn: Fatal Shooting in Lobby
text: A Brooklyn man was fatally shot yesterday in the lobby of a building in the Farragut Houses in Vinegar Hill, the police said. The police, who were called to the building just after noon, found the man shot once in the abdomen. He was pronounced dead at the Brooklyn Hospital Center, the police said. Family members identified the victim as Erik Speights, 29, a construction worker and father of two. Daphne Speights, his sister, said the police told her that he was shot in a dispute with strangers that had begun the night before. “Some boys just shot him over a bump and a stare in a store last night,” Ms. Speights said.

headline: Hedge Fund Based in London to Go Public in United States
text: GLG Partners, one of Europe’s largest hedge funds, will go public in the United States through a $3.4 billion merger with an investment company, Freedom Acquisition Holdings, according to people briefed on the transaction.

headline: The Art of Strategic Ducking in Defeating a Small Slam
text: The diagramed deal occurred during the first session of the Cavendish Invitational Pairs in May.

headline: Middle East Summit Supporting Abbas Begins
text: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, June 25 — Leaders from Israel, Egypt and Jordan traveled to this Red Sea resort today to meet with the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah, in a show of support for Mr. Abbas and his new emergency government following the violent takeover of the Gaza Strip 11 days ago by Fatah’s rival, the Hamas faction.

headline: 33 Years, and Good to the Last Pirouette
text: Tears fell on Friday night at the New York State Theater for Kyra Nichols’s farewell after 33 years with New York City Ballet, but there were fewer tears than flowers. Who, watching Ms. Nichols take her final bows with arms round the shoulders of her two young sons, could not be happy? There have been other ballerinas who have managed to have children, enduring marriages and brilliant careers and who have left the stage while showing how much dance juice they still had in them — who have proved that “You can have it all” — but none more wonderfully than Ms. Nichols. It’s only afterward that one sees the gap she leaves; and I write with a lump in my throat.

headline: Rash and Unadvis’d in Verona Seeks Same
text: A battle of the elements is being pitched at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, where “Romeo and Juliet” opened last night in a terrifically exciting new production, starring Lauren Ambrose as a Juliet truly to die for.

headline: Treasury Bill Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about the Senate’s approval of legislation that would require auto makers to produce cars and trucks that get substantially higher gas mileage misstated the final vote. With 92 of 100 senators voting, it was 65 to 27  not 65 to 37.

headline: Rice and French Counterpart Highlight Darfur
text: PARIS, June 24 — France and the United States appeared the best of friends here on Sunday, as Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and France’s new foreign minister, Bernard Kouchner, joined forces to confront the continuing crisis in the Darfur region of Sudan.

headline: National Lampoon Stakes Revival on Making Own Films
text: “Did you say ‘over?’ ” the character played by John Belushi asked in “National Lampoon’s Animal House” in 1978. “Nothing’s over till we decide it is! Was it over when the Germans bombed Pearl Harbor? Hell, no!”

headline: A Big Wi-Fi Aggregator Will Offer Monthly Flat-Rate Service
text: MILAN, June 24 — As Wi-Fi hot spots proliferate, it has become possible to open a laptop and connect to the Internet in just about any major airport as well as in thousands of hotels, restaurants, cafes and bars. Yet logging on can sometimes be onerous, and pricing is likely to be expensive and opaque.

headline: Boy’s Drowning Bolsters a Call for Safer Pools
text: SHIRLEY, N.Y., June 19  When 3-year-old Anthony Muniz drowned in a neighbor’s backyard pool here earlier this month, the tragedy was particularly piercing: Little Anthony had been named for his mother’s teenage brother, who died in his family’s pool years ago.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Foxy Brown Robbed

headline: Murdoch Said to Be Close to Terms on Journal
text: The News Corporation, controlled by Rupert Murdoch, and advisers for Dow Jones and its controlling Bancroft family were close last night to agreeing on terms designed to protect The Wall Street Journal’s newsroom independence if the company accepts a takeover bid from Mr. Murdoch, according to several people briefed on the talks.

headline: Sarkozy Takes Center Stage in Europe
text: BRUSSELS, June 24 — The new French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, has reasserted his country’s traditional role at the diplomatic heart of Europe by emerging as the main force behind a deal that brought the European Union back from the brink of crisis.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: SIGNALS ON THE ECONOMY The main economic news will come out of the two-day meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, beginning on Wednesday. A decision on interest rates will come on Thursday; the Fed is expected to hold rates steady at 5.25 percent.

headline: Hedge Fund Based in London to Go Public in United States
text: GLG Partners, one of Europe’s largest hedge funds, will go public in the United States through a $3.4 billion merger with an investment company, Freedom Acquisition Holdings, the two companies announced Monday.

headline: Pinch-Hitting at Caramoor: Young Pianist and Rachmaninoff
text: KATONAH, N.Y., June 23 — Appropriately, the shortest night of the year ushers in the season of summer festivals, events often conceived as lighter-hearted and briefer than regular-season fare.

headline: Prepare for the SAT Test, or Play With Your iPod? Have It Both Ways
text: High school students cramming for the SAT test have traditionally relied on thick books full of practice exams, sharpened No. 2 pencils and intensive tutoring sessions. But now a traditional test preparation company is offering some options for the iPod generation.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8:30 P.M. (Showtime) SEMPER FI  (2007) When he enlisted in the Marines, Jeff Key, above, already had two strikes against him. At 34, he was slightly above the age limit, which a recruiter overlooked because of Mr. Key’s passion to serve. And he was gay. But because no one asked, Mr. Key didn’t tell when he arrived in Iraq — at first. In this documentary, Vince DePersio traces Mr. Key’s evolution from wide-eyed patriot to disillusioned critic of what he calls an immoral war through interviews with Mr. Key and his family, friends and fellow marines as well as footage taken during his tour of duty and excerpts from his one-man play, “The Eyes of Babylon.”

headline: Please Hold for the Next Available Letdown
text: Whether or not the politics of sending jobs to foreign countries come into play, consumers report greater satisfaction with call centers that they believe are based in the United States, according to CFI Group, a consulting firm.

headline: Gore Galore but a Violent Game Can’t Hold a Gutbucket to the Movies
text: Some people like being grossed out.

headline: Ex-E.P.A. Chief Defends Role in 9/11 Response
text: WASHINGTON, June 25 — Testifying at a Congressional hearing today about the government’s environmental response to the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, Christine Todd Whitman staunchly defended her statements assuring the public that the air in Lower Manhattan was safe in the days immediately after the attack.

headline: Tensions Rise as Kosovo Awaits Word on Its Future
text: PRISTINA, Kosovo, June 22 — Preparations for the party have begun, and the government has even bought fireworks. But eight years after NATO forces effectively bombed Serbian security forces out of Kosovo, the independence that this small ethnic Albanian enclave was fighting for keeps slipping further into the future.

headline: Maine Gets Plenty of Support as Mets Sweep A’s
text: Paul Lo Duca is the Mets’ sieve. Everything from calling pitches to directing infielders to making bold predictions goes through him, and it was after Wednesday night’s game, when he declared that the Mets needed to — check that, that they would — win five of their next seven games to prevent their slump from spiraling out of control.

headline: The Web Site Celebrities Fear
text: LOS ANGELES, June 24 — While the networks tussled over which would land the first interview with Paris Hilton after her release from jail, the upstart Web site TMZ.com was breaking most of the news.

headline: NATO Says Attack Killed Civilians in Pakistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 24 — The NATO force in Afghanistan said Sunday that its soldiers, in pursuing Taliban insurgents on Saturday, had unintentionally chased them across the border into Pakistan, and it confirmed that NATO bombing and helicopter fire caused the deaths of several Pakistani civilians.

headline: Corrections
text: Editors’ Note

headline: Hartford: Reports Required for Missing Guns
text: Gov. M. Jodi Rell has signed a bill to penalize gun owners who fail to inform the police within 72 hours of discovering that a firearm has been lost or stolen. The first offense is an infraction, punishable by a fine of up to $90; subsequent offenses would be felonies. In a statement yesterday, she said the law, which takes effect Oct. 1, will help “stem the tide of stolen guns used in crimes.”

headline: Justices Loosen Restrictions on Campaign Ads
text: WASHINGTON, June 25 — The Supreme Court today loosened the restrictions on what companies and unions can spend on television advertisements just before elections, and in so doing may well have affected the thinking of political strategists for the 2008 elections.

headline: Report on Amaranth Collapse Is to Be Made Public
text: After a nine-month investigation, a bipartisan Senate subcommittee is expected to issue a report today detailing how a single hedge fund, Amaranth Advisors, dominated the North American natural gas market last year, causing high prices and extreme volatility that ultimately led to its stunning collapse.

headline: Raising Taxes on Private Equity
text: So much for the argument often made by managers of hedge funds and mavens of private equity that higher taxes would cripple their business.

headline: Queens: Man Killed at Barbecue
text: A 40-year-old man was fatally shot in the St. Albans section of Queens early yesterday, the police said. The man, identified as Dwayne King of Nashville Boulevard, was shot in the chest about 1:45 a.m. at 176th Street and 110th Avenue, the police said. Relatives said Mr. King was shot at a family barbecue. He was taken to Mary Immaculate Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. There were no arrests yesterday, the police said.

headline: H.I.V. and AIDS: Keep an Eye on Prevention (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Some Errors Defy Fixes: A Typo in Wikipedia’s Logo Fractures the Sanskrit
text: The symbolism is not exactly ideal. Those on the lookout for errors at Wikipedia have flagged a few more — this time, however, they are not examples of vandalism at the user-created site but typographical errors in Wikipedia’s own logo.

headline: High-Tech Titans Strike Out on Immigration Bill
text: WASHINGTON, June 24 — Bill Gates and Steven A. Ballmer of Microsoft have led a parade of high-tech executives to Capitol Hill, urging lawmakers to provide more visas for temporary foreign workers and permanent immigrants who can fill critical jobs.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Thursday of William J. LeMessurier, a structural engineer who repaired a potentially catastrophic flaw in the Citicorp building in Manhattan, misidentified his birthplace in Michigan. It is Pontiac, not Bloomfield Hills.

headline: North Korea Ready to Implement Nuclear Deal
text: SEOUL, June 25 — North Korea said today that its dispute with the United States over $25 million in funds frozen in a bank in the Chinese territory of Macao had been resolved, and that it would begin implementing its much-delayed promise to shut down its main nuclear facility.

headline: Dear Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Hollywood Seeks Ways to Fit Its Content Into the Realm of the iPhone
text: LOS ANGELES, June 24 — The iPhone doesn’t go on sale until Friday, but Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple, is already changing the perception of the mobile phone, from a quick way to call a friend to a hip, media-friendly device. In doing so, he has forced mobile phone and Hollywood executives to react by chasing hungrily after the newest thing or face being left behind.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on June 4 of Ed Yost, considered the father of modern hot-air ballooning, referred incorrectly to his use of hydrogen before air inside a balloon was heated with propane. He used hydrogen, which is lighter than air, to fill balloons  not to heat air that had been fanned into balloons.

headline: Flexible and Fearless, Seeking Rescue Work
text: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., June 21 — It was another perfect day in Disaster City.

headline: A New Job for Tony Blair
text: This page has long argued for naming an authoritative, energetic and internationally known Middle East peace envoy. The Bush administration’s choice for the job, Tony Blair, who steps down as British prime minister this week, has many of the right qualities  and some worrisome flaws.

headline: Art Sales Put London in Catbird Seat (and New York on Notice)
text: LONDON, June 24 — High prices are everywhere in this city, from real estate to restaurants. While most Americans may be daunted by the weak dollar, the international rich, aided by tax advantages, aren’t deterred. On the contrary, they are clamoring for homes here, and shoppers speaking Italian, French, Japanese or Russian are crowding the stores.

headline: Blair Hands Over Leadership of Labor Party
text: LONDON, June 24 — Long heralded and often rancorous, Britain’s transfer of power from Tony Blair entered its final countdown on Sunday when the governing Labor Party anointed Gordon Brown as his successor. It ended an era in which Mr. Blair fought far-flung wars in the Muslim world, brought peace closer to home in Northern Ireland and struggled to reform public services.

headline: Militant Students Capture Masseuses to Make a Point
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 24 — Dressed from head to toe in an all-enveloping black burka, Umm-e-Okasha joined a pack of students from her militant Islamic school on Friday night, and at midnight they drove to a massage parlor here in the Pakistani capital and rang the bell.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on Thursday of Kenneth Franklin, long the top astronomer of the Hayden Planetarium, misstated the definition of a lunation, the unit of time used by a watch he invented for use on the Moon. It is the period it takes the Moon to rotate and revolve around the Earth, not around the Sun.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,532 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans over the weekend:

headline: Standard Lifetime TV Template, Applied to AIDS Awareness Film
text: Welcome to Lifetime Land, a quiet suburban street where the star quarterback is an H.I.V.-positive heroin addict, the girl next door has sex with him because of her slutty-divorced-mom issues, and the cute substitute teacher dresses badly and wears minimal makeup because — you guessed it! — she has H.I.V. too.

headline: Mideast Leaders Show Support for Abbas
text: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, June 25 — The leaders of Egypt, Jordan, Israel and the Palestinian Authority gathered at this Red Sea resort today in a show of support for the emergency government formed by the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah.

headline: U.N. Peacekeepers Vow to Continue in Lebanon After 6 Troops Killed
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 25 — The head of the United Nations peacekeepers in Lebanon said today they will pursue their mission despite the car bombing Sunday in the south of the country which killed six of their troops.

headline: Our Addiction to Energy (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Complex Marriage on Nature’s Path
text: Shim, scumble, saurine, skeg: It’s impossible for readers who delight in such words not to be entranced by the way Annie Dillard chooses — and uses — her arsenal in “The Maytrees.” In the three decades since “Pilgrim at Tinker Creek,” the nonfiction debut in which she introduced a prose style so gorgeously precise that every sentence sang, this poet, essayist and journalist has written nine original volumes powered by spare but brilliant language.

headline: Editors’ Note
text: A front-page article yesterday described a crackdown in Iran that has included the jailing of three Iranian-Americans, repression or intimidation of nongovernment organizations pressing for broader legal rights, warnings to newspaper editors against articles on banned topics, arrests of advocates for women’s rights and of student leaders, and the detention of 150,000 people for wearing clothing considered not Islamic.

headline: Trove of F.B.I. Files on Lawyers Guild Shows Scope of Secret Surveillance
text: One entry, dated April 14, 1954, was about I. F. Stone, who was described as being a writer from New York. Mr. Stone, it was noted, condemned Senator Joseph R. McCarthy’s “persecution of innocent citizens” and likewise the House Committee on Un-American Activities and the Senate’s corresponding committee.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on June 14 by The Associated Press of the movie actress Mala Powers misidentified the B-movie series that included one of her early films, “Tough as They Come.” It was called “Dead End Kids and Little Tough Guys”; the film was not part of the “Bowery Boys” series.

headline: Congestion Pricing Deadline
text: New Yorkers, and anyone else who rides public transportation in and around the city, should mark July 16 on their calendars. By that date, if state lawmakers do their jobs, they will have paved the way to ensuring billions of dollars of new cash to maintain and expand mass transit. If not, the current $2 fare for a bus or subway ride can be expected to increase at least 20 percent and maybe as much as 50 percent. The choice is that stark, and riders, who will pay the price if legislators fail, will know exactly where to direct their pique.

headline: Memories of a Teammate Evoke the Giants of Old
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 — The San Francisco Giants spent Sunday afternoon watching Barry Bonds run the bases, reminiscing about Rod Beck on the mound, and pretending they were all back in 1993.

headline: Two ‘Mightys’ Disappoint at the Weekend Box Office
text: The expensive Noah’s Ark comedy “Evan Almighty” nearly capsized in United States theaters in its premiere weekend, selling just $32 million in tickets.

headline: Waiter, There’s Deer in My Sushi
text: TOKYO, June 24 — Sushi made with deer meat, anyone? How about a slice of raw horse on that rice?

headline: A Cute Little Ad for Wine Pops Up in the Oddest Spot
text: An advertising agency for a California winery recently bought space in a magazine where few (if any) ads have gone before.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on June 8 about legislation in the House aimed at easing restrictions on federal financing of embryonic stem cell research misstated a vote in the Senate in April on similar legislation. With 97 of 100 senators voting, it was 63 to 34  not 63 to 45.

headline: 6 U.N. Peacekeepers Killed in Lebanon
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 24 — A car bombing killed six United Nations peacekeepers in southern Lebanon on Sunday, opening another potentially disastrous fault line in a country held hostage to violence and political deadlock.

headline: What’s Wrong With the Yankees?
text: There was no way the Yankees’ hot streak was going to last, of course. They had won 14 of 17 games since falling a season-worst 14 ½ games behind Boston on May 29, with a 21-29 record.

headline: A Look at Staten Island
text: Vintage photographs and images of Staten Island.

headline: Dusting Off Versailles
text: Images of the Hall of Mirrors after its three-year restoration.

headline: There’s No Place Like Home
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: The Other Iraq
text: Iraqi Kurdistan has enjoyed de facto independence since 1991 and is now enjoying a building boom.

headline: City Lobbyists Stall School Leasing Bill
text: New York City officials managed to stall state legislation last week that would have made it harder for them to lease buildings for school space as part of the city’s five-year capital plan.

headline: An Assemblyman Scores a Personal Victory on Gay Marriage
text: His sister Rosie is the celebrity in the family. (You may have caught her in “A League of Their Own” or on “The View.”) But Daniel J. O’Donnell, a Manhattan assemblyman, got his own dose of fame during the climactic Assembly debate last week over a bill seeking to legalize same-sex marriage.

headline: Air Passengers and Clothing Shoppers Get Relief
text: At least two new pieces of law, should Gov. Eliot Spitzer approve them, are likely to make New Yorkers happy. One is the Airline Passengers’ Bill of Rights, introduced by Assemblyman Michael N. Gianaris of Queens after the nationwide flight delays in February. The bill, sponsored in the Senate by Charles J. Fuschillo Jr. of Long Island, requires that airlines provide water, fresh air, food and clean bathrooms if loaded planes are kept on the ground at New York airports for more than three hours.

headline: Copper Refiner to Buy Smelter Company
text: Norddeutsche Affinerie, the largest European copper refiner, said Sunday that it had agreed to buy Cumerio of Brussels, owner of the biggest copper smelter in southeastern Europe, for 777 million euros, or $1.05 billion.

headline: Vonage and Verizon Head Back to Court
text: Vonage Holdings is scheduled Monday to appear in the United States Court of Appeals in Washington to make what may be a final stand in fighting charges that its online telephone service infringes patents held by Verizon Communications.

headline: Reuters and Thomson May Unload Assets to Win Deal Approval
text: To get their $17.5 billion deal approved by antitrust regulators, Thomson and Reuters may have to sign off on some significant disposals, notes The Deal.com.

headline: Following L.S.E. Deal, Nasdaq Mulls Moves, Report Says
text: Senior executives at Nasdaq spent the weekend locked in discussions over whether they oppose a 1.63 billion euro ($2.2 billion) deal between the London Stock Exchange and Borsa Italiana, according to The Independent.

headline: In Fosun I.P.O., China May Get Its Blackstone Equivalent
text: Fosun International is raising as much as HK$10.85 billion ($1.39 billion) in an initial public offering whose investors include Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing, Bloomberg News reported. The company is offering 1.25 billion shares in Hong Kong at HK$6.48 to HK$8.68 each, according to Bloomberg.

headline: HSBC Buys China Headquarters
text: HSBC Holdings , Europe’s biggest bank, will buy part of a Shanghai office tower to house its China headquarters as it speeds up expansion in the world’s fastest-growing major economy.

headline: Sales Chief Is the Latest to Depart From Yahoo
text: Yahoo said Sunday that Wenda Harris Millard, its longtime chief sales officer, is leaving amid a reorganization of Yahoo’s sales team.

headline: Macy’s Shares Jump Amid Buyout Rumors
text: Shares of Macy’s surged Friday on speculation the company was the target of private equity buyout. In the largest jump since November 2005, Macy’s stock climbed $2.56, or 6.6 percent, to $41.43, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: The iPhone Challenge: Keep It Quiet
text: David Pogue looks at the features of the new iPhone, as furtively as possible.

headline: Visa Takes First Step Toward I.P.O.
text: Visa, the biggest credit card network in the United States, took its first official step Friday toward becoming a public company, outlining to federal regulators how it proposes to restructure and combine its global operations.

headline: Win a Trip: Bringing His Game
text: Will Okun, who's traveling with Nick Kristof in Africa, gets the chance to put his hoop skills to the test in Burundi.

headline: In Hot Ad Deal Environment, Are Big Agencies the Next Target?
text: How far will Google, Microsoft, Yahoo or other Internet powerhouses go in their effort to dominate digital advertising, the fastest-growing part of the marketing business?

headline: Judge Orders Release of Enron Files
text: A federal bankruptcy judge has ordered the Goldman Sachs Group to release to creditors of Enron all documents and materials related to a financial project between the New York investment firm and the company in the latter half of 2001, as Enron spiraled into bankruptcy.

headline: Yet Another Plan for Bell Canada; This Time, a Recapitalization
text: A Toronto-based investment banking firm proposed recapitalizing Bell Canada on Friday as an alternative to the three competing privatization offers and one takeover bid for the company.

headline: Lear Delays Vote on Icahn Deal
text: Lear, the auto parts maker, has delayed a shareholder vote on a $2.9 billion buyout offer from Carl Icahn. The vote was rescheduled to July 12 from June 27 in response to criticism of the bid from shareholders and proxy advisory services. Mr. Icahn made the bid, valued at $36 a share, through his American Real Estate Partners.

headline: A Buyout Fund by Any Other Name…
text: As the private equity industry gets a lot less private, The Financial Times’s Thorold Barker suggests it should be thinking about finding a new name for itself. He brings up one possibility that describes what buyout funds do — long-term capital management — but notes that a certain ill-fated hedge fund seems to have ruined that one for everybody. DealBook visited this question in a column in The New York Times in March, and readers responded with plenty of suggestions, including “adaptive equity,” “enterprise capital” and “constructive finance.”

headline: Barclays Reveals Exposure to Troubled Hedge Fund
text: The British banking giant Barclays said Friday it has some exposure to troubled hedge funds that invested in the subprime mortgage market, but any loss from the exposure would not be material to its overall performance.

headline: Report on Amaranth Collapse Is to Be Made Public
text: After a nine-month investigation, a bipartisan Senate subcommittee is expected to issue a report Monday detailing how a single hedge fund, Amaranth Advisors, dominated the North American natural gas market last year, causing high prices and extreme volatility that ultimately led to the company’s stunning collapse.

headline: In Blackstone I.P.O., Shades of Milken?
text: For some Wall Street veterans, the Blackstone Group‘s debut on the New York Stock Exchange Friday may have sparked flashbacks to the 1980s, notes USA Today. “The publicity is creating a déjà vu all over again,” John C. Coffee, an expert in securities law at Columbia University, told USA Today. “To anyone who was around Wall Street in the ’80s, Blackstone reminds them of the powerful role of Drexel Burnham. They were also masters of the universe.”

headline: Shaw Hooks Up With Alinda for Venture Projects
text: Shaw Group, an engineering services provider, said Friday its Shaw Capital unit and an investment company, Alinda Capital Partners, had agreed to create a joint venture to pursue a variety of projects. The venture, called Shaw Infrastructure Investments, will pursue energy, transportation, infrastructure, water, wastewater and related projects.

headline: F.B.I. Monitoring; a Nazi Artifact; the Weak Dollar; and More
text: And you thought the police surveillance before the 2004 Republican National Convention was intense.

headline: London Hedge Fund GLG to Go Public in U.S.
text: GLG Partners, one of Europe’s largest hedge funds, will go public in the United States through a $3.4 billion merger with an investment company, Freedom Acquisition Holdings, according to The New York Times.

headline: Renewable Energy Panel Named
text: Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson announced the appointment on Sunday of 16 members to the state’s new Renewable Energy Task Force, which by Dec. 1 is supposed to recommend ways to expand the state’s use of alternative fuels and other forms of renewable energy. The task force is scheduled to meet for the first time on Tuesday in Albany.The members are:

headline: A Frothy Magazine Merger
text: This week, Jason Binn’s Niche Media, whose titles include Gotham and Los Angeles Confidential, is expected to announce a merger with Greenspun Media Group of Las Vegas – which publishes Vegas, Wynn and Venetian Style, among other magazines – and the Ocean Drive Media Group, which publishes Ocean Drive and Ocean Drive Español and several other magazines, The New York Times’ David Carr reported.

headline: They’re Partners. They’re Rivals. They’re Both.
text: General Electric‘s NBC Universal with Pearson and Hearst until recently considering partnering for Dow Jones. News Corporation-MySpace-Yahoo. News Corp.-NBC. Universal.

headline: Murdoch Said to Be Close to ‘Integrity Terms’ on Journal
text: The News Corporation, controlled by Rupert Murdoch, and advisers for Dow Jones and its controlling Bancroft family were close Sunday night to agreeing on terms designed to protect The Wall Street Journal’s newsroom independence if the company accepts a takeover bid from Mr. Murdoch, according to The New York Times.

headline: Evolution Is ...
text: "Everybody is interested in pigeons. The book would be reviewed in every journal in the kingdom and would soon be on every library table."- An adviser to Darwin's publisher explaining why Darwin should publish a book on pigeons instead of "The Origin of Species"

headline: Sharing Your Intimate Information Online
text: As people take the idea of user-generated content to ridiculous extremes, an intriguing notion is emerging for applications of user contributed data.

headline: 2008: Giuliani Confronts The Faith Factor
text: In a reprise of the 2004 flap between Senator John F. Kerry and the handful of American bishops who sought to deny him communion because of his support for abortion rights, church leaders are now setting their sights on a 2008 Republican presidential hopeful and lifetime Catholic, Rudolph W. Giuliani.

headline: Battle Looms on Immigration Bill
text: It is do or die – again – for the immigration legislation in the Senate as Congress heads into its final days before the Fourth of July break.

headline: Quarter Pounders of the Soul
text: During the summer of 1999, Stephen King – then recuperating from being hit by a van – read the second and third Harry Potter books and they became, he wrote, “a kind of lifeline for me.”

headline: Life as We Know It
text: NATURAL SELECTION 1858

headline: Congestion Pricing: Has David Bested Goliath?
text: The answer might depend on who you think is the giant.

headline: Will Hedge Fund Bailout Put Bear in Play?
text: Bear Stearns‘s recent hedge-fund troubles could affect more than just the investment bank’s reputation. They could jeopardize its independence as well.

headline: Back to Work for Tony Blair?
text: Over the weekend, signs grew that Prime Minister Tony Blair was getting closer to securing his next job offer, and so did opinions about whether he should get it.

headline: In Search of the Health Care Candidate
Now It’s Spam on Stationery
text: No one is better at using the most obscure features of computer programs than spammers.

headline: The Skim
text: A quick hike through this past Sunday’s book sections.

headline: A Hypothetical Poll for an Improbable Race
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer just took office in January. And Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has shown no interest whatsoever in running for governor.

headline: Blackstone Shares Struggle as Barron’s Sees a Top
text: Though some suggested its opening-day jump wasn’t big enough, especially considering the Hollywood-like atmosphere around the event, the Blackstone Group‘s $4.1 billion initial public offering on Friday was generally seen as a success.

headline: Monday Morning Motorsports
text: In Nascar, Juan Pablo Montoya recovered from an awful qualifying session and gambled on fuel in the closing laps at Infineon Speedway to win his first Nextel Cup (soon to be Sprint Cup) race.

headline:
Talk to the Newsroom:
Digital News Editor Jim Roberts
text: Jim Roberts, editor of digital news, answered reader questions June 25 through 29, 2007.

headline: Reviewing the Raters of ‘Manhunt 2’
text: Echoing concerns “among some veteran game journalists” flagged by Game Politics, a great blog about the video game industry, The New York Times’s reviewer, Seth Schiesel, found the adult rating of Manhunt 2 “entirely reasonable.”

headline: M.T.A. Starts Live Webcasts of Meetings
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority — a bureaucracy long known for being big, opaque and not especially responsive to ordinary people — is letting some sunshine in. Today, the authority began making live Webcasts available of its board’s meetings. The board’s New York City Transit committee is meeting at this moment at the authority’s headquarters, 347 Madison Avenue.In a statement, the authority said it had begun the broadcasts — which include closed captioning for the hearing-impaired — to comply with Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s Executive Order No. 3, which requires all public agencies to broadcast their meetings by July 1.

headline: How to Get on the City Room Blogroll
text: Send your suggested links to jeremyz@nytimes.com and put “City Room Blogroll” in the subject line.

headline: Suffolk Leader, in Immigration Maelstrom, Strikes Back
text: Steve Levy, the Suffolk County executive, is hitting back. Mr. Levy, a Democrat who has gained national attention for his stands in opposition to illegal immigration, has scheduled a noon news conference at the H. Lee Dennison Building in Hauppauge.

headline: Doral to Accept Bear Stearns Group’s Buyout Offer
text: Doral Financial, the Puerto Rico-based bank that is facing bankruptcy, said that it will turn to a buyout offer led by Bear Stearns, after a rival offer from its second-largest shareholder was withdrawn.

headline: Where Are the Doctors?
text: “Can you take me back to the U.S. with you?”

headline: Sea Lions and Bobcats and Bears, Oh My
text: The weekend was rich with news about battles between humankind and various creatures of the wild.

headline: Private Equity Lobby Girds for Tax Fight
text: The private equity industry is not just sitting back and waiting for Congress to raise their taxes. The Private Equity Council, a less-than-year-old trade group representing many large buyout firms in the United States, has hired big guns from the lobbying world to defend their interests in Washington.

headline: C.I.A. Arrest Warrants Strain U.S.-German Ties
text: The arrest warrants German authorities have issued against 10 CIA agents have strained German-American relations. Now, prosecutors in Munich want the agents extradited to Germany so they can stand trial for their alleged roles in the illegal kidnapping of terror suspects.

headline: Theater Briefs
text: The final curtain will fall on the Broadway production of the Disney musical "Tarzan" on July 8 at the Richard Rodgers Theater. At its closing, the show will have played 486 regular performances and 35 previews.

headline: Wild Racing Weekend Outside F1
text: Is wild the word? How can yesterday’s races in Champ Car and Nascar be defined? I did not see the Nascar race, but the race at the Infineon Raceway road course in Sonoma, California does give some food for thought, and I wrote a few words about Juan Pablo Montoya’s first Nascar victory elsewhere.

headline: Postcard from Todd Thomson
text: Todd Thomson, the former head of wealth management at Citigroup and onetime heir apparent to former Citi chief Sandy Weill, is still being a bit secretive about his next move on Wall Street.

headline: Whose Bright Idea? $1 Off a Light Bulb
text: Attention Consolidated Edison customers: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced this morning that all Con Ed customers in the city will receive a $1 coupon in their home electricity bills in August toward the purchase of a GE Energy Smart compact fluorescent light bulb.

headline: The Big Chill
text: We’ve had a run of gorgeous early summer days here in New York – bright, crisp and uncharacteristically dry. It seems like an ideal time for a seasonal warning about drinking white wines too cold.

headline: Prospect Park Scofflaws Caught on Tape
text: Streetsblog and StreetFilms have posted this video by an irate parkgoer in Brooklyn who says drivers routinely enter Prospect Park illegally after the 7 p.m. ban on vehicles goes into effect:

headline: Nano-Sizing Risk
text: Along with creating new strands of DNA, a related strand of engineering also has unknowable, but potentially frightening consequences: nanotechnology–building materials out of very small particles.

headline: Building a Hedge Fund, With No Manager Required
text: The New Yorker’s John Cassidy this week takes a close look at the mystique of hedge funds, and, in a way, sees an industry that would rather not let you look behind its curtain.

headline: Bad Audits And Government Grants
text: An obscure government study of audit quality — in audits that are not regulated by much of anybody — has found that most audits conducted in 2002-’03 were not of sufficient quality to be relied upon.

headline: An Uncanny Avian Resemblance
text: At City Hall this morning, the buzz among reporters — at least those of a certain generation — was, for a change, not about whether Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s presidential aspirations were real, but about how the little cartoon bird (top right) animating the city’s new environmental consumer-education campaign, GreeNYC, had an uncanny resemblance to the logo from “The Partridge Family” (bottom right). It is unclear whether the reference was intentional, since that Mondrian-style school bus the fictional 1970s singing family drove to their pop performances certainly wasn’t a hybrid-electric vehicle.

headline: Hmmm, How Does ‘Senator’ Bloomberg Sound?
text: One might assume that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is getting a bit tired of fending off questions about a possible presidential bid (though it’s also possible he’s loving every second).

headline: Whitman Defends E.P.A.’s 9/11 Work
text: Minutes ago, in forceful and at times emotionally wrought language, Christie Whitman, who was administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency on 9/11, told a House committee that the agency did the best it could to inform rescue workers after environmental hazards in Lower Manhattan after the World Trade Center attack. Ms. Whitman — responding to years of criticism by 9/11 health advocates — adamantly denied that the agency withheld information from the public.

headline: A Familiar Silence After Austin Killing
text: Following a crime in Austin that shocked the nation is a familiar, deafening silence for murder investigators from Toronto to Newark.

headline: Figuring Out Fortress’s Tax Bill
text: Just how much would Congress’s proposed tax increase cost Fortress Investment Group?

headline: Stunning Views, and Safe for Bikes, Too
text: Shore Parkway, which runs along the southern edge of Brooklyn, offers some of the most stunning views of the New York Harbor to be found. Unfortunately, until recently, it was a bumpy, erratic and even dangerous pathway for bicyclists and pedestrians. So deteriorated was the parkway — with a crumbling seawall and open cavities in the bike path — that the city gave the road “emergency status.” Representative Vito J. Fossella, a Republican who represents Staten Island and part of Brooklyn, recalled, “There were craters 15 feet in diameter at certain points where you could literally hide a small vehicle.”

headline: Are the (All) Stars Aligned?
text: One of my first memories of baseball was watching the 1984 All-Star Game at Candlestick Park. I was 3 years old at the time and naturally didn’t remember much from it. But my dad taped it, as he did most baseball All-Star Games when I wasn’t old enough to stay up late to watch them, and a few years later, I would pop the tape into the VCR and watch the player introductions over and over and over. Occasionally, I’d watch a few innings before I got bored and went off to play with Legos or something.

headline: But Can You Insure Against a Wii Injury…
text: Fireman’s Fund Insurance Company last week announced it has begun selling insurance for developers of video games. The policies, which mimic those offered in the movie business, are being marketed by Fireman’s as a way to manage the downside risk of expensive productions and costly “potential eventualities.”

headline: In Suffolk, Warnings of Cuts and Tax Increases
