text: Twenty-six years ago as a Stanford University graduate student and a co-founder of Sun Microsystems, Andreas Bechtolsheim designed a simple but powerful personal computer workstation that would help define the modern technology era.

headline: Upper Deck Goes Hostile in Topps Bid
text: Unable to work out a merger agreement with Topps, its rival baseball card maker, Upper Deck has decided to take its offer directly to shareholders. Upper Deck said late Monday that it would make a tender offer to acquire its rival trading card manufacturer in a deal that values the company at $425 million.

headline: Going Public, SPAC-Style
text: Freedom Acquisition Holdings‘ deal to buy the hedge fund GLG Partners shows how special-purpose acquisition companies can offer a useful way to go public through the backdoor. The Financial Times’s Lex column notes that these kinds of companies, known as SPAC’s, have become extremely popular lately, raising $4 billion in the United States so far this year.

headline: ICE Steps Up Battle Ahead of Exchange Merger Vote
text: IntercontinentalExchange on Monday commenced its proxy battle to block the merger of Chicago Board of Trade Holdings with Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings, urging C.B.O.T. shareholders to vote against the deal.

headline: K.K.R. Applies for Broker-Dealer License, Report Says
text: In a move that would enable it to branch into new businesses and possibly bolster its value should it go public, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts plans to obtain a securities broker-dealer license, according to The Deal.com.

headline: Wall Street Fetes Clinton Amid Tax Debate
text: Hillary Clinton is set to get a cash injection from Wall Street for her presidential campaign coffers Tuesday night at a fundraising event hosted by Warren Buffett and organized by Morgan Stanley’s chief executive, John J. Mack, as well as a slew of other bankers, private equity executives and hedge fund managers, The Financial Times reported.

headline: S.E.C. Is Said to Open Inquiry into Bear Stearns Fund
text: Bear Stearns may have a lot of explaining to do about a big restatement of losses at one of its troubled hedge funds-and not just to its investors. According to BusinessWeek, the Securities and Exchange Commission recently opened a preliminary inquiry into the near-collapse of Bear Stearns’ High-Grade Structured Credit Strategies Enhanced Leveraged Fund.

headline: Bell Canada Bidding Group Said to Lose Members
text: Caisse de dépôt et placement de Québec and the Canadian buyout firm Onex have pulled out of a group bidding for Bell Canada, the Globe and Mail reported. Their withdrawal from the consortium, which is led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, throws into question the group’s ability to muster an offer for Bell Canada.

headline: Barclays Bid Gets Boost from Court Adviser
text: Barclays got a big boost in its takeover battle for ABN Amro when an adviser to the Dutch Supreme Court said that it should allow the Dutch Bank to sell its Chicago-based LaSalle unit to Bank of America.

headline: BlackRock to Buy Fund of Funds for $1.7 Billion
text: The asset management firm BlackRock said it had agreed to acquire the fund of funds business of the Quellos Groupfor up to $1.7 billion to expand its alternative investment operations. Following the acquisition, BlackRock said it would combine its hedge and private equity fund of funds activities to form a business that is expected to have more than $25.4 billion in assets under management.

headline: Buyout Boom Could Slow as Investors Push Back
text: The buyout boom may be about to hit a bump.

headline: Less Hairy, Still Violent
text: Images from “Live Free or Die Hard."

headline: Crowded Subways; 9/11 Dust; Special Education; and More
text: Think your subway car is crowded? Try the entire line. And don’t be surprised if your train is canceled or delayed as a result.

headline: S.E.C. to Face Questions in House Committee
text: All five members of the Securities and Exchange Commission will appear before the House Financial Services Committee on Tuesday, where they are expected to be asked to defend their agency against accusations that it might favor business interests at the expense of protecting investors. The hearing will mark the first time in more than a decade that all S.E.C. commissioners have been called to testify together, the Associated Press reported.

headline: Prevent or Adapt?
text: Catcliffe, England, Tuesday, June 26, 2007. Dave Thompson/AP

headline: Dell Unveiled (Minus the Lovely Assistant)
text: Officially, Dell today unveils its hope for the future. At an event this morning in New York, it plans to show off its new line of laptop computers. They are slim, colorful machines that have a lot riding on them given Dell’s struggles to compete in the consumer market.

headline: Virtual Tennis on a Sunny Saturday
text: Despite the frantic arm-waving involved, it’s hard to get too cutthroat while playing tennis on the Nintendo Wii, the phenomenally popular video game console. After all, you are represented on screen by a little cartoon character with a huge head.

headline: Edwards Tries for a Laugh on Leno
text: John Edwards joked yesterday about his $400 haircut, but he didn’t get the same kind of laughs that the late-night professionals do on the same subject.

headline: Take Two: Paris Hilton Is Released
text: Paris Hilton was freed from jail just after midnight, and once again it was the job of Steve Whitmore, the Los Angeles sheriff’s spokesman, to break the news.

headline: Frugal Traveler: Frequently Asked Questions
text: Do you have a question for Matt? Submit it here and he will answer as many as he can.

headline: ‘Fish Where the Fish Are': City Lures Chinese Tourists
text: Is the Japanese tourist — a stock character (and caricature) of the New York streetscape since the 1980s — being supplanted by the Chinese visitor?

headline: China’s Middle-Class Housing Crisis
More on the 1949 Strike
text: Below are links to stories from The New York Times on the 1949 steelworkers' strike.

headline: Lehman’s Top Power Banker Jumps to UBS
text: Amid expectations of more big deals in the energy sector, James Metcalfe, the head of power mergers and acquisitions at Lehman Brothers, is leaving the firm to become global head of power banking at UBS.

headline: Biovail C.E.O. Sues Former Analyst for Slander
text: The founder of Biovail, the Canadian pharmaceutical company, has filed a $1 million slander suit against a former Banc of America Securities analyst, claiming he was defamed when the analyst called him a “criminal,” The New York Post reported Tuesday. The Biovail founder, Eugene Melnyk, claimed he “suffered serious injury to his personal and professional reputation” as a result of comments made by the former analyst, Jerry Treppel.

headline: 2008: Court Alters Campaign Landscape
text: In a decision likely to have a significant impact on the 2008 election, the Supreme Court issued a ruling on Monday that changes campaign finance laws for corporations and unions. The Times’s Linda Greenhouse and David D. Kirkpatrick report that the court’s decision “has the effect of jettisoning a major part of the McCain-Feingold law, which Congress passed in 2002”:

headline: Blackstone Shares Dip Below Offer Price
text: Stephen A. Schwarzman is quickly learning the downside of being a public company.

headline: Rangel Enters Fray Over West Side Recycling
text: The Bloomberg administration has gained a powerful ally, United States Representative Charles B. Rangel, in its long-running effort to open a waterfront recycling station on the Gansevoort pier, just south of West 14th Street. The plan is the last major element of the Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Plan, a multiyear program that is intended to make each borough handle its fair share of trash and waste.

headline: Fred Thompson Makes the Rounds
text: Although he has not officially declared his presidential intentions, Fred D. Thompson, former senator of Tennessee, kicks off what looks a lot like a campaign in Nashville today, with stops this week in South Carolina and New Hampshire.

headline: Red Light real estate
text: One of the biggest bosses in Amsterdam’s notorious Red Light District may have found a buyer for his extensive property in the neighborhood.

headline: Basell to Buy Rival Huntsman for $5.6 Billion
text: Basell, a division of the billionaire investor Leonard Blavatnik’s Access Industries, said Tuesday it would acquire a rival chemical company, Huntsman for $5.6 billion, or $9.6 billion including debt. The announcement sent Huntsman shares up $5.40, or 29 percent, to $24.30 at the open of trading Tuesday.

headline: Pulp Magician
text: When it comes to Thomas Allen’s remarkable artwork, I’m late to the party. His stuff has appeared in Harper’s, and on the covers of some of James Ellroy’s novels. And last year Chip Kidd splashed his art around the Fall 2006 issue of Zoetrope. Kidd described Allen’s work this way:

headline: Dexter and the Bear
text: Michael Kinsley once wrote about a contest in which the question was: “If you were the author of a book, and could have any words of praise to feature in an ad for it, what would they be?” (One funny entry: “Destroys the philosophical basis of all previous human thought” – Hannah Arendt.)

headline: Alessandra Ferri's Farewell
text: Alessandra Ferri's farewell performance of Romeo & Juliet with  Roberto Bolle.

headline: Rural Ireland in Only Two Days
text: I’ll be visiting my daughter in London either in Sept. or Oct. and would love a trip to Ireland – maybe one but not more than 2 nights. Want to see things ‘other’ than big city life…what do you suggest?

headline: They Aren’t on the Take
text: Few things get a journalist’s back up as quickly as the suggestion that he or she is somehow on the take, being paid by an interested party to influence what appears in the newspaper. So when Gregory Todd, a New York attorney, wrote to ask how New York Times columnists are compensated and whether Nicholas Kristof is receiving money from an African charity or David Brooks is getting paid by Rupert Murdoch, I forwarded the message to Andy Rosenthal, the editorial page editor, with the thought that his response could be quite interesting, as in pyrotechnic. After all, The Times editorial pages under his leadership are aggressive, to say the least.

headline: Injury Sets Back Japan’s Hot Dog Star
text: The showdown anticipated by The Lede and other observers of competitive eating may not happen after all.

headline: Ecumenicalism and the iPhone
text: I’ve heard the iPhone referred to both ways: the Jesusphone and the Godphone. Both reflect the miraculous qualities conferred unto this electronic device by the fervent Apple acolytes.

headline: Lugar Breaks With Bush on Iraq
text: Senator Richard G. Lugar, an Indiana Republican, is far from a publicity seeker. He rarely speaks on the Senate floor, at least in speeches specifically designed to garner big headlines. But when he does, it’s surely worth taking a listen.

headline: Nice Blog, but Is It Journalism? Hamill Says No
text: The geeks here — O.K., that would be me — are finally catching up on a week of podcast listening. A comment from Pete Hamill, the newspaperman and novelist, caught our attention in this June 15 episode of “The Brian Lehrer Show” on WNYC. That was the day we (quietly) went live with City Room. The show had reactions from various bloggers, including Robert Guskind, the former National Journal writer behind Gowanus Lounge, and Louise Crawford of Only the Blog Knows Brooklyn, to Mr. Hamill’s statement:

headline: Examining the Archives: The C.I.A.’s ‘Family Jewels’
text: The New York Times has assembled a panel of intelligence experts and historians to review and comment on documents made public today by the Central Intelligence Agency that describe a series of intelligence operations, mostly involving domestic spying, that first came to light in the 1970s. They also include some discussion of assassination plots against foreign leaders. The C.I.A. account of these activities, running nearly 700 pages, is known as the “Family Jewels.” It consists of responses by C.I.A. officials to a 1973 directive from the Director of Central Intelligence, James Schlesinger, to inform him of any activities that might violate the agency’s charter. Many pages of the material made public today were excised by the agency. Many of the operations were disclosed in press reports in the mid-1970’s beginning with a Dec. 22, 1974 story in The New York Times by Seymour M. Hersh. A commission appointed by President Gerald R. Ford and headed by his Vice President, Nelson A. Rockefeller, investigated the C.I.A. activities, as did a Senate committee, chaired by Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, and a House committee, chaired by Rep. Otis Pike, Democrat of New York. The actual text of the responses to Mr. Schlesinger remained classified and unavailable to the public until today.

headline: As Blackstone’s Shares Fall, Schwarzman’s Payout Grows
text: The Blackstone Group‘s market value may be declining for a second straight day, but Stephen A. Schwarzman’s payout from the firm’s recently completed public offering just went up by another few hundred million.

headline: Philip Taubman
David Robarge
text: Dr. Robarge is the chief historian of the Central Intelligence Agency and has been a member of the agency's history staff since 1996. Before that he worked in the C.I.A. Counterterrorism Center and the Directorate of Intelligence as an analyst on the Palestinian and Iraq accounts. He has published a classified biography of Director of Central Intelligence John McCone, and his articles and book reviews have appeared in the C.I.A.'s in-house journal "Studies in Intelligence," and in "Intelligence and National Security" and the "Journal of Intelligence History." Dr. Robarge holds a Ph.D. in American history from Columbia University, has taught United States intelligence history at George Mason University and has written a biography of Chief Justice John Marshall.

headline: Dow Jones and Murdoch Said to Agree on Journal Protections
text: The board of directors at Dow Jones and the News Corporation have reached a deal on the make up of an editorial board that would oversee Dow Jones’ flagship newspaper, the Wall Street Journal, paving the way for a takeover of the entire company, MarketWatch reported, citing an unnamed source. Reuters, citing two separate sources, said the two “basically agreed” to a structure Monday night, but that several items needed to be discussed.

headline: Trove of C.I.A. Documents Released
text: Note: Updates are being posted at the end of the intro…

headline: About Storing and Backing Up
text: Q. What is the difference between a storage device and a backup system? Can they be used interchangeably?

headline: Newly Released C.I.A. Letter Details Threat on Koch’s Life
text: The Central Intelligence Agency has released a trove of documents, collectively known as “the family jewels,” about covert intelligence operations in the 1960s and 1970s. Tucked within these documents is a two-page letter that sheds light on a 1976 death threat made against Edward I. Koch, then a congressman from Manhattan and later, from 1978 to 1989, mayor of New York City.

headline: Tip of the Week: Undoing Changes in Microsoft Word
text: TIP OF THE WEEK Want to undo a whole bunch of changes in a Microsoft Word document — without having to repeatedly hit Control-Z (Command-Z on the Mac) to back up one change at a time? In most versions of Word, just go to the Standard toolbar — or the Quick Access toolbar in Word 2007 — and find the Undo Typing icon, which looks like an arrow curving down and to the left.

headline: Remember Macintosh?
text: Although it seems that the media can’t write about anything but the iPhone these days, a trickle of intriguing details about Apple’s new Leopard operating system continue to appear. One interesting technology note about the new operating system that was lost in the ten features that Steve Jobs focused on last month at the company’s World Wide Developers Conference, is a quiet deal that Apple made with Sun Microsystems. A bit of software plumbing known as the ZFS File System will appear as an option for Leopard, the next version of the Macintosh OS X, shortly after it is shipped in late October.

headline: $900,000 Homes
text: A five-bedroom house in Ocean Isle Beach, N.C., a three-bedroom condominium in Chicago and a four-bedroom house in Truckee, Calif.

headline: Housing Keeps Sinking
text: The housing market keeps sinking, and what is remarkable about it is how national the slide is. The S.&P. Case-Shiller home price indexes, out today, show year-over-year declines in 14 of 20 major markets. (Those markets are regional areas, with New York’s area stretching from Trenton to New Haven.) That is a record number for that index, but it only goes back to the late 1980s.

headline: Polling Young Adults on a President’s Age
text: What is the optimum age for the president of the United States? It depends who is asked.

headline: The Early Sections of the Documents
text: SECTION 1It is interesting that the first item in the “Family Jewels” was deleted in its entirety — including even the title. Let’s hope there is a leak somewhere along the line — if it was illegal then, it’s illegal now.

headline: Google v. Microsoft, In and Out of Court
text: Google’s jabs at Microsoft came on multiple fronts this week.

headline: The Next Technology Buyout Deals?
text: Private equity firms, on the hunt for new areas of business as dealmakers crowd up the old ones, have been increasingly looking to the technology sector. With that in mind, analysts at UBS have built a model for looking at hypothetical leveraged buyouts of technology companies and ranking potential targets by how profitable they might be.

headline: Bush’s ‘Amnesty’ Gaffe
text: This morning President Bush tried to take on critics of his stance on immigration while casually dropping by (along with a big press contingent that set up long before he arrived) a meeting among his key officials dealing with the issue.

headline: Project Mockingbird: Spying on Reporters
text: The C.I.A. monitoring of journalists in 1963, 1971 and 1972, including wiretapping their phones and setting up observation posts across the street from their offices to track their comings and goings and their visitors, was a practice that the White House itself employed during the Nixon administration.

headline: Looking for the Real Story
text: Readers respond to Bob Herbert’s June 26 column, “Doubting the Police.”

headline: ‘Oceans 13’ Writers Delve Into Hedge-Fund Life
text: Given the recent troubles in the hedge-fund business — a $3.2 billion bailout at Bear Stearns, a 16-month losing streak at Goldman Sachs‘s flagship fund — one cannot help but wonder about the timing of the forthcoming HBO series about hedge-fund managers. Will it turn out to be something akin to, say launching a new series in early 2000 about hotshot venture capitalists?

headline: Bienvenidos and Welcome!
text: Bienvenidos and welcome to the Times soccer blog, which we reactivate today to bring you coverage of the Copa America, the championship of South America. And we do so in the same frenzied, near-hysterical spirit we used for last year’s World Cup, so brace yourself for live play-by-play of matches as they happen and an endless stream of blog posts, some of them actually germane to the tournament.In addition to the 10 nations of South America, this year’s Copa America also features the top two teams from North America: Mexico and the Concacaf champions, the good ol’ USA. We’ll be doing live commentary of the matches involving the US, Mexico, Brazil and Argentina, as well as assorted other games of interest during the tournament — which, for added spice, takes place this year in Venezuela. Muy picante!

headline: Project Mockingbird: Explaining the Many Leaks
text: This was a project where the C.I.A. eavesdropped on two Washington journalists who had quoted from numerous classified documents in their reporting. The bugs were placed on both their home and office phones.

headline: ‘The Cabernet of Rent Checks’
text: On the front page of the Web site Poets.org today, there’s an interesting interview with the poet Tony Hoagland, whose 2003 book “What Narcissism Means to Me” is one I read over and over. Asked how he became a poet, Hoagland replies:

headline: Goldman Asset Management Co-Head to Step Down
text: Eric Schwartz, Goldman Sachs‘ co-head of asset management, will step down from his day-to-day responsibilities this summer after 23 years at the firm, Bloomberg News reported citing an internal memo. Mr. Schwartz, 44, will become a senior director, the memo said, although it did not give a reason for his stepping down.

headline: Comptroller Demands Wal-Mart Documents
text: Opponents have resisted efforts by Wal-Mart to open stores in the Bronx, Staten Island and Queens. So far the Bentonville, Ark., retail behemoth shows no signs of making inroads into the five boroughs. And yet Wal-Mart finds itself a new target of attack today.

headline: Die Hard and Paul Potts
text: Two great online-video stories have turned up lately in — of all places — that ink-on-paper New York Times, and they deserve to be recapped here.

headline: Who’s at the Copa? (Group A)
text: There are three groups of four teams each at the Copa America. The top two from each group will advance, along with the two best third-place teams.

headline: A Plot to Assassinate Castro Was Approved By C.I.A. Director Allen Dulles
text: For years, the public has known that the C.I.A. spent part of the 1960s concocting plans to assassinate Cuban leader Fidel Castro. None of these plots ever succeeded, and many — one explored the feasibility of sending Castro a poison-laced diving suit, another tried to rig exotic exploding seashells — seem ridiculous in retrospect. One of the $64,000 questions from that time is whether these plots were known and authorized by various C.I.A. directors and others outside the agency, including the president. The Senate Select Committee to Study Governmental Operations with Respect to Intelligence Activities, better known as the Church Committee, spent months in 1975 and thousands of pages of testimony examining who knew what, and when. The committee found that the evidence suggested that higher-ups inside and outside the C.I.A .knew about the various assassination plots, but it was not conclusive.

headline: A Good Time to Stay Inside Reading Blogs
text: The city Office of Emergency Management reports that the heat index in New York City will be in the 90s for the next three days. The general advice: stay indoors and avoid strenuous activity, drink fluids and stay in the shade outside. Check on young people and old people and those with special needs. Wear loose-fitting clothes. Take a cool bath or a shower. Use an air-conditioner if you have one.

headline: Bond Fund Manager Sees Debt Jitters Spreading
text: Has Wall Street dodged the subprime bullet? William Gross, who manages the world’s largest bond fund at Pimco, doesn’t think so. In his July investment outlook — which features not one but three Paris Hilton references — Mr. Gross suggests that it is far too early to be breathing a sigh of relief over what he calls the “Bear Stearns/subprime crisis.”

headline: Young Firefighter Is Eulogized in Brooklyn
text: Thousands of firefighters lined the streets of Greenpoint, Brooklyn, this morning to pay their final respects to Daniel F. Pujdak, the 23-year-old firefighter who lost his life last Thursday night when he fell four stories from a Brooklyn building where he was fighting a fire ignited by a cigarette left on a windowsill.“He truly and unselfishly made himself an instrument of peace and safety in the city,” said Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who joined the fire commissioner, Nicholas Scoppetta, and Capt. Jerry Horton of Ladder Company 146, where Firefighter Pujdak was stationed, in eulogizing the young man.

headline: The Animated Life: Paper View
text: In celebration of the Fourth of July, artist Jeff Scher created a confetti of fireworks. Music composed by Shay Lynch. Part of Sightlines, an Op-Ed visual series.

headline: Private Island Welcome for 2008 Honda Accord… in Boston?
text: Car companies love to host junkets. Dubai, the coast of Spain, you name it — where there’s sunshine and a ready supply of shrimp cocktails, there’s a new car introduction going down. After all, why give someone a car to drive on their own grim pothole-ridden roads when you can stoke their happy thoughts at some exotic resort?

headline: Bits and Blogs
text: On a regular basis, people ask my friend John Markoff, the veteran Silicon Valley correspondent for The Times, why he doesn’t start a blog.

headline: Who Doesn’t Remember Afghanistan?
text: Democrats in Congress are fond of calling the fight in Afghanistan the “forgotten war.” Well, The Hill reports that a few on that side of the aisle would like to forget about it permanently:

headline: Keeping Track of All the Redactions
text: ENTIRE CATEGORY OF ACTIVITIES STILL CLASSIFIEDThere appears to be an entire category of activities still classified — the whole section from pages 8 to 10 is redacted. Given all the illegal activities actually listed in this document, the hidden sections are all the more disturbing.

headline: Steven Cohen Gets His House (Almost) at the Beach
text: He may be a hedge fund billionaire, but Steven Cohen still knows how to bargain.

headline: Bear Stearns Won’t Bail Out Second Subprime Fund, Report Says
text: Bear Stearns does not plan to bail out a $1.1 billion struggling fund that invests in repackaged subprime-mortgage securities, Reuters reported Tuesday citing an unnamed source.

headline: Spitzer’s Credo: ‘None of This Is Personal’
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, are at it again. This morning, the governor gave a long PowerPoint presentation at a meeting of the state broadcasters association to outline his accomplishments and unfinished business following the fractious end to the legislative session last week.

headline: ‘Hunt Requests a Lockpicker’
text: So here’s my favorite jewel so far: “Hunt requests a lockpicker.” It’s listed in a memo to the C.I.A.’s deputy director for management and services detailing questionable agency activities.

headline: Who’s at the Copa? (Group B)
text: On now to Group B, which features three strong teams well stocked with veterans from last year’s World Cup — and therefore qualifies it as this tournament’s Group of Death. The integrantes: Brazil, Mexico, Ecuador and Chile.

headline: Frugal Traveler: Tell Matt Where to Go in Kansas and Oklahoma
text: Next week, the Frugal Traveler is driving to Kansas and Oklahoma. He needs your help. Do you know a cheap motel, a great place to eat or a must-see attraction? Share your tips with Matt here.

headline: Herbs Save the Day
text: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, grills sushi-grade tuna with an uncommonly light summer dressing.

headline: The C.I.A. and the Mob
text: In a memo recounting the C.I.A.’s involvement with Mafia figures as the agency plotted to assassinate Fidel Castro, Howard J. Osborn, the agency’s director of security, recalls the qualifications of John Roselli as a potential partner for the C.I.A. It’s difficult to divine from the memo how well C.I.A. officials understood the inner workings, and alliances, of the mob. At one point, Osborn reports that Robert A. Maheu, a Howard Hughes aide who served as an intermediary between the C.I.A. and the mob, knew Roselli slightly but had been told he was a high-ranking member of the “syndicate.” As a further sign of Roselli’s power, Maheu said Roselli controlled all the ice-making machines on the Strip.

headline: New Shots in the Air Wars
text: The campaigns are slowly starting to roll out the big guns, with two of the top Democrats debuting new ads in battleground states today. John Edwards’s latest, for example, isn’t his first of the season (though it is his first spot in New Hampshire), but it does shift from pressuring Washington about the war to asking Americans “to be patriotic about something other than war.”

headline: Queens Neighborhood Is a Landmark; Domino Plant Is Likely to Become One
text: Despite a last-minute protest by a dozen sign-wielding protesters, the city’s Landmarks Preservation Commission voted this morning to designate Sunnyside Gardens in Queens as a historic district. The commission also heard overwhelmingly favorable testimony on a proposal to designate the former Domino sugar processing plant in the Williamsburg, Brooklyn, as a landmark.

headline: The Ad World According to Google
text: For those who are still wondering what all the hoopla surrounding the planned Google-DoubleClick merger is about, Google has chosen to explain. The essay posted on Google’s official blog is, of course, a bit self-serving, as it is a description of how the merger, if it goes through, will benefit everyone from online advertisers to publishers and consumers. In particular, there is no mention of the antitrust concerns raised by some companies, which are currently being reviewed by the Federal Trade Commission, or of the potential privacy pitfalls brought up by some advocacy groups.

headline: A Memo From the Inspector General
text: This is a poignant memo that captures the spirit of the times.

headline: The First 150 Pages
text: I have now been through the first 150 pages of the documents in the C.I.A. Family Jewels archive. They are largely a disappointment. A great deal has been whited out, and many of the disclosures are bureaucratic buckpassing to explain away interagency favors done that might blow back, especially in the United States, by law then and now not the agency’s domain.

headline: The Atmosphere of the Agency
text: Reading through the litany of C.I.A. domestic spying abuses and other questionable activities during the cold war years, including plots to assassinate foreign leaders, it’s hard not to wonder what the men and women of the C.I.A. (mostly men, in those days) were thinking as they wandered far afield from the C.I.A.’s own charter. The 1947 founding document banned the C.I.A. from domestic spying. Assassination plots against Fidel Castro and other foreign leaders, at a minimum, presented tricky legal and ethical issues for anyone involved.

headline: FINAL: Peru 3, Uruguay 0
text: This was a far better game than I’d bargained for, complete with an unlikely result. Which bodes well for the rest of the tournament, no? Join Jeff Z. Klein at 8.45pm for Venezuela-Bolivia.

headline: S.E.C.’s Cox Says an Investment Company Rule Does Not Fit Blackstone
text: Though its stock price has now closed below its initial offer price, the Blackstone Group claimed one piece of good news on Tuesday. At a hearing of the House Financial Services Committee, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said that the private equity firm should not have to register as an investment company.

headline: A Push to Reopen Lady Liberty’s Crown
text: The House of Representatives unanimously approved an appropriations bill for the Department of the Interior this afternoon that contains a provision urging that the Statue of Liberty‘s crown be reopened to the public for the first time since the 9/11 attack.

headline: Bruno Tells Spitzer to ‘Get Over It’
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer said “none of this is personal,” but it sure doesn’t seem like Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, is taking it that way. In an interview with Sandra Endo that is scheduled to air on NY1’s “Inside City Hall” tonight, Mr. Bruno took several swipes at the governor.

headline: Operation Merrimac
text: From February 1967 to November 1971 the C.I.A. recruited several agents and assigned them to penetrate anti-Vietnam War groups in the Washington, D.C. area. The agents were so convincing that the group turned one of the undercover agents over to the FBI for possible arrest.

headline: Redface I
text: In July 1970, the C.I.A. surreptitiously entered an office in Silver Spring, Maryland, of a former defector working under contract to the C.I.A. This involved bypassing a guard and a sonic alarm system, entering a vault and a safe within a vault to determine whether the person had classified material in his possession.

headline: Telus Hangs Up on BCE Pursuit
text: Telus, Canada’s second-largest telephone company, pulled out of the bidding for larger rival BCE at the offer deadline, citing “inadequacies” in the sale process, Bloomberg News reported. BCE shares fell the most in two months.

headline: It’s iPhone Week
text: Don’t know about your business, but in my industry, this is iPhone Week. The iPhone is about all anybody’s talking about.

headline: Answers From the Transportation Commissioner, Part 2
text: The city’s new transportation commissioner, Janette Sadik-Khan, was taking questions from City Room readers through the week. Sorry, we are no longer taking questions for this feature.

headline: Angleton’s Secret Police
text: A rare gem among the family jewels: a pair of detailed reports signed by James J. Angleton, the legendary chief of the C.I.A.’s counterintelligence staff from 1954 to 1974. They describe an aspect of a longstanding worldwide American program to create and exploit foreign police forces, internal security services, and counterterrorism squads overseas.

headline: Restless Youth: Spying on Americans at Home
text: As a card-carrying professor, documents about C.I.A. surveillance of college students tend to get my attention. Here, the family jewels appear to provide more color to the existing portrait. We already know from the bipartisan Church Committee that the C.I.A., the FBI, the Army, and the National Security Agency engaged in deliberate, systematic and long-term programs to spy on Americans during the 1960s and 1970s, with a particular focus on campus protest movements.

headline: Will the iPhone Get Cheaper?
text: The Apple iPhone, at $500 and $600, isn’t cheap. Should you wait to buy it?

headline: FINAL: Venezuela 2, Bolivia 2
text: Fulltime A memorable opening match, at least until the memory is supplanted by tomorrow night’s Mexico-Brazil game. Join us for that, 845 Eastern time, Victor Mather to bring you the live commentary. As for tonight, thanks to all the reader who wrote in with comments — his name is Marcos — and for whoever else followed along. So until next time, amigos, hasta luego!

headline: Pedro Being Pedro
text: Mets PR czar Jay Horwitz just came through the press box to tell reporters that Pedro Martinez, originally scheduled to throw a bullpen session in beautiful Port St. Lucie this afternoon, felt so good that he threw live batting practice instead. This is a small but significant step for him, although don’t go thinking he’s remarkably ahead of schedule or that he’ll be back by the end of July. The Mets will take every precaution with him, and don’t look for a return until mid-August, I’d say.

headline: Of (Marine) Language
text: It’s been over three weeks since my last haircut, and the urge to get it cut again is killing me. I’m accustomed to having longer hair now; that’s not the issue. The problem is that weekly haircuts keep the ends of your hair neatly trimmed to the same length, and the shaggy look of uneven ends bothers me. Everyone else seems to suffer from the same phenomenon of uneven hair, but it’s still a little disconcerting.

headline: The Family Jewels
text: The Times's Tim Weiner discusses the importance of the newly declassified C.I.A. documents known as the "family jewels."

headline: Slip Slidin’ Away
text: That’s the song Charley Steiner played as the intro to our talk on XM radio Tuesday afternoon. Sadly for Yankees fans, it’s appropriate.

headline: Benny Feilhaber — the Man Who Saved America
text: By any measuring stick, Benny Feilhaber’s Gold Cup-winning goal against Mexico on Sunday was perhaps the greatest, the best, the most technically impressive goal scored in the long, long history of soccer in the United States.

headline: New Zealand Rides Gentle Zephyrs to America’s Cup Lead
text: VALENCIA, Spain, June 26 — With light and shifting winds proving unreliable, the crews on Alinghi and Emirates Team New Zealand had to stew for about two hours Tuesday before the third race of the America’s Cup could begin.

headline: Canada: Native Protests Planned for National Day
text: Native groups are threatening to cause major travel disruptions at the start of the forthcoming Canada Day holiday weekend . Shawn Best, a spokesman for the Tyendinaga Mohawk Council, said members would block either Ontario’s main highway near Kingston, Ontario, or the rail line between Montreal and Toronto on Friday to protest poverty and land claims. He said that other native groups had told him they planned similar moves in other parts of the country.

headline: Bob Schieffer Sings Honky Tonk
text: “As a country and western singer,” Tom Brokaw was saying last night, “Bob Schieffer is a great host of ‘Face the Nation.’ ”

headline: Oracle Reports 23% Increase in Earnings
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 — Oracle’s quarterly revenues beat Wall Street’s projections Tuesday as the software company claimed substantial gains over its rivals, SAP and I.B.M.

headline: Jurors Are Expected to Get Conrad Black’s Case Today
text: CHICAGO, June 26 — After nearly 15 weeks in court, lawyers in the trial of the former media baron Conrad M. Black neared the end of their arguments Tuesday, with the jury expected to begin poring over 100 pages of jury instructions starting Wednesday.

headline: Board Approves Smaller Increases in Stabilized Rent
text: Rents for the one million rent-stabilized apartments in New York City can rise by up to 5.75 percent over the next two years, the city’s Rent Guidelines Board voted last night in a meeting that was marred by disruptions, but more orderly than last year’s gathering.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts yesterday about the restoration of the Hall of Mirrors at Versailles misstated the amount of parquet flooring in the hall. It is about 8,460 square feet, not 84,000.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article yesterday about North Korea’s pledge to shut down its main nuclear plant misstated the plant’s location relative to Pyongyang, the capital. The plant, in Yongbyon, is about 60 miles north of Pyongyang, not south.

headline: Dana Bullen, 75, Is Dead; Led Press Freedom Group
text: Dana R. Bullen, a former executive director of the World Press Freedom Committee, died Monday at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 75.

headline: Durant Puts Basketball First, and Second
text: Kevin Durant was 9 when he decided to become an N.B.A. star, and 18 when he decided to get his driver’s license. For short trips, he could always hitch a ride with Mom and Dad, a teammate or a coach. It was the longer journey that consumed him.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption in The Arts yesterday with an article about the handover of nine looted Kenyan wooden statues to the Kenyan government misidentified the official shown at a ceremony at the United Nations. He is Peter Ogego, the Kenyan ambassador to the United States  not Zachary Dominic Muburi-Muita, Kenya’s representative to the United Nations, who also attended.

headline: The iPhone Matches Most of Its Hype
text: Talk about hype. In the last six months, Apple’s iPhone has been the subject of 11,000 print articles, and it turns up about 69 million hits on Google. Cultists are camping out in front of Apple stores; bloggers call it the “Jesus phone.” All of this before a single consumer has even touched the thing.

headline: Giuliani Calls for Increasing American Support for Fatah
text: VIRGINIA BEACH, June 26 — Rudolph W. Giuliani addressed Israeli-Palestinian discord on Tuesday, saying it was pointless for the United States to negotiate with Hamas, the Islamic group that has seized control of the Gaza Strip, and that Washington should work with Egypt and Jordan to bolster Fatah and its control over the West Bank.

headline: Free Will, Held Hostage for Years in a Zealous War on Drugs
text: The war on drugs may have temporarily lost ground to the war on terror, but the rehab drama is here to stay. “Over the G W,” Nick Gaglia’s lean yet harrowing dramatization of his own experiences with drug rehabilitation in the late 1990s, follows a troubled brother and sister (George Gallagher and Kether Donohue) as they are removed from their Bronx home and committed to a New Jersey treatment center by their well-meaning parents.

headline: An Odd Understanding Reached in Israeli Prisons
text: “Hot House,” Shimon Dotan’s absorbing look at Palestinians held in Israeli jails, is full of remarkable interviews. Prisoners talk about how they issue orders to followers on the outside via smuggled cellphones. A former Palestinian newscaster, Ahlam Tamimi, recalls the day she dropped a suicide bomber off at his target, then coolly went on television to report on the resulting bombing.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about opposition to a planned Wal-Mart in the predominantly Hasidic community of Monsey, N.Y., referred incorrectly to the village of Airmont, where another Wal-Mart is located. Airmont is two miles west  not east  of the proposed site in Monsey.

headline: Paris Hilton Rejoins Society
text: Paris Hilton went free yesterday. Ending her three weeks in the women’s jail in Lynwood, Calif., she smiled, waved, embraced her mother and rode away with her parents, The Associated Press reported. “She fulfilled her debt,” said Steve Whitmore, a spokesman for the Los Angeles County Sheriff’s Department. At a daily cost to taxpayers of $1,109.78, more than 10 times the expense of housing inmates in the general population, Ms. Hilton, 26, was confined to a solitary cell in a special needs unit for violation of her probation in an alcohol-related reckless-driving case. She will complete her probation in March 2009 if she keeps her driver’s license current and does not break any laws. The time can be reduced by 12 months with community service that could include a public service announcement, the Los Angeles city attorney’s office said.

headline: Japan’s Tuna Crisis
text: The Times reported the other day that a shortage of tuna is forcing Japanese chefs to start using substitutes in sushi and sashimi  cheaper fish, even avocado rolls. Why are we not sympathetic? The reason is that Japan is merely reaping the whirlwind it and other nations have sowed.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A chart with the Off the Charts column in Business Day on Saturday, about the inventory of homes for sale, referred incorrectly to the number of unsold houses. They were in the thousands, not hundreds. A corrected graphic is online at nytimes.com/business.

headline: Within Days, Share Price of Blackstone Is Below $31
text: At an investor conference in February, Stephen A. Schwarzman of the Blackstone Group called the public markets overrated. After the performance of his firm’s stock over the last two days, he may feel even more strongly about that.

headline: Raid on Top Sunni Official Adds to Iraqi Internal Feuding
text: BAGHDAD, June 26 — Iraqi forces raided the home of Culture Minister Asad al-Hashimi early Tuesday after an arrest warrant accused him of masterminding the 2005 attempted assassination of Mithal al-Alusi, now a member of Parliament who was once a top aide to Ahmad Chalabi.

headline: Newly Released C.I.A. Papers Document Decades of Tricky Legal and Ethical Issues
text: The New York Times has assembled a panel of intelligence experts and historians to review and comment on the Central Intelligence Agency documents. Following are the comments of Philip Taubman, an associate editor of The New York Times who has specialized in intelligence issues and national security affairs. Assessments by the others: washington.blogs.nytimes.com

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Friday about a law passed by the New Jersey Legislature that sets ambitious goals for reducing emissions of greenhouse gases misstated a provision of the bill. It requires that emissions be capped at 20 percent  not 80 percent  of 2006’s levels by 2050.

headline: Stirring Up Sound Waves and Giving Them New Shape
text: Lee Konitz’s alto-saxophone sound grows deeper and darker. He will turn 80 in October, and in the recent stages of his career, playing more slowly and investing swing feeling into floppy, balloonlike notes, his sound has gotten so big and dreamy that it’s all you feel and hear; what he’s playing — names of songs and their pedigree — doesn’t matter much.

headline: Newark: Meetings Promised After Controversy
text: The Newark schools superintendent, Marion A. Bolden, promised yesterday to meet regularly with a task force of the city’s gay and lesbian leaders, according to the head of a New Jersey gay rights group. The promise comes after Ms. Bolden ordered a picture of a graduating senior kissing his boyfriend blacked out of the East Side High School yearbook. After an outcry, the school district said it would reissue the yearbooks with the picture unmarked. Steven Goldstein, of Garden State Equality, said Ms. Bolden made the commitment to meet during a phone call that he described as “heartfelt.” A spokeswoman for Ms. Bolden’s office could not confirm that commitment, but said Ms. Bolden met yesterday with Andre Jackson, the student whose picture was blacked out. The superintendent also apologized in front of Mr. Jackson’s classmates at a graduation rehearsal, the spokeswoman said. Mr. Jackson could not be reached for comment yesterday.

headline: Waiting for the Latest in Wizardry
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 — At the Apple store on Fifth Avenue in New York, the first in line are already camped out. Sightings of the device already in the possession of a privileged few were being reported, even photographed and posted on the Internet. Rumors have it that shipments are arriving in the dark of night, accompanied by armed guards.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article yesterday about North Korea’s pledge to shut down its main nuclear plant misstated the plant’s location relative to Pyongyang, the capital. The plant, in Yongbyon, is about 60 miles north of Pyongyang, not south. (Go to Article)

headline: Nazik al-Malaika, 83, Poet Widely Known in Arab World, Is Dead
text: BAGHDAD, June 26 — Nazik al-Malaika, one of the Arab world’s most famous poets, an early exponent of the free verse movement in Arabic, died last Wednesday in Cairo. She was 83.

headline: Declassified C.I.A. Archives Detail Illegal Activities
text: WASHINGTON, June 26 — Long-secret documents released Tuesday provide new details about how the Central Intelligence Agency illegally spied on Americans decades ago, from trying to bug a Las Vegas hotel room for evidence of infidelity to tracking down an expert lock picker for a Watergate conspirator.

headline: Chapter 1: I Drank the Water
text: IN Mexico City, where I live sometimes, I have a routine. I get out of the gym at about 9:30 and walk across the park to my favorite cantina, where the waiters know to bring me a shot of Herradura blanco tequila and a Victoria beer immediately. I love tequila and I believe that Herradura blanco, fiery and peppery, those first sips going down with the combustion of a space shuttle liftoff, is the great commercial tequila. I like mezcal too. Nothing macho about it: I just like the clean cactus and earth flavors, the warm ebullient high, and that you can drink a number of shots without feeling bloated.

headline: Two Guys Drunk on Ireland, and the Party’s Just Begun
text: “The general atmosphere reeks of talk,” a character in “The Irish Play” says, speaking of the Dublin apartment shared by a would-be playwright and a would-be terrorist who rant and argue about race memory, blood, poetry, ambition, middle-class platitudes and what it means to be Irish.

headline: Rejecting the Usual for a Different Tonic
text: Dissatisfied with the high-fructose corn syrup and artificial ingredients used to make overly sweet commercial tonic water, entrepreneurs are developing their own properly bitter versions.

headline: New York’s Ultra-Open Primary
text: For far too long, New York’s presidential primaries have been an insider’s business, with political bosses from both parties deciding whose names went on the ballot. As recently as 2000, it took a lot of arm-wrestling and public outrage for Republicans to even include Senator John McCain, a strong contender that year.

headline: Schoeneweis a Trivia Answer for Cards’ Ryan
text: Whenever the Mets are playing at home and the number of innings creeps into double digits, Billy Wagner is overcome by an almost mystical feeling that they are going to win. Something about the crowd and the energy, he says. But even if Wagner felt the Mets were headed toward victory last night, the fans surely did not when they saw Scott Schoeneweis jog in from the bullpen.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture with an article on Sunday about the circumstances behind the mass arrests of Brooklyn youths who were on their way to Coney Island for the wake of a slain teenager on May 21 carried an erroneous credit in some copies. The photograph of Asher Callender, 19, one of the arrested teenagers, speaking at a community meeting two weeks after the arrests was by Ramin Talaie for The New York Times — not by Chester Higgins Jr. of The Times.

headline: Paving the Way for Hotels in Hell’s Kitchen
text: The pioneering San Francisco-based Kimpton Hotel and Restaurant Group, which worked its way eastward, is looking west again — this time to Hell’s Kitchen.

headline: Area of Sunnyside, Queens, Is Given Landmark Status
text: The Landmarks Preservation Commission voted unanimously yesterday to give landmark status to Sunnyside Gardens, in Queens, a proposal that had simmered for four years among residents of the area’s neat row houses and courtyards, causing angry divisions among neighbors.

headline: Gitmos Across America
text: Toughness is the watchword in immigration policy these days. When you combine the new toughness with same-old bureaucratic indolence and ineptitude, you get a situation like that described by Nina Bernstein in The Times yesterday. She wrote about how the boom in immigration detention  the nation’s fastest-growing form of incarceration  ensnares people for dubious reasons, denies them access to medicine and lawyers and sometimes holds them until they die.

headline: Tooth May Have Solved Mummy Mystery
text: A single tooth and some DNA clues appear to have solved the mystery of the lost mummy of Hatshepsut, one of the great queens of ancient Egypt, who reigned in the 15th century B.C.

headline: New Report Clears School of Cheating
text: When Philip Nobile reported in 2004 that the assistant principal of the Brooklyn high school where he taught had ordered other teachers to cheat on the scoring of Regents exams, he was embraced by a powerful city investigator as a whistle-blower.

headline: Altria to Expand Cigarette Output in Europe
text: The Altria Group, the cigarette maker, will close a North Carolina factory and increase European production to save $335 million a year by 2011. The shutdown of the plant in Cabarrus County will result in a one-time charge of $325 million in the second quarter, Altria said. The company, which is based in New York, may be preparing to spin off its international unit, analysts and investors said. Factories in Europe will take over production of Marlboros and other cigarettes bound for Japan and the Middle East, which are currently being made in North Carolina. All of Altria’s United States output will be shifted to Richmond, Va. Closing the North Carolina facility, which employs 2,500, will cost about 10 cents a share in the second quarter, Altria said. Expenses will total $670 million by 2011.

headline: If I Worked at the Zoo
text: WHEN I took a job as a zoo keeper one summer in college, I imagined it as a position of considerable, if peculiar, glory.

headline: Checking the Lost and Found of Life
text: The car keys. A brand-new pashmina. Your cellphone — again! A sense of proportion. A sense of decorum. A prosthetic limb.

headline: An Honor for Byron Nelson, Golf’s Patron Saint
text: When Byron Nelson learned shortly before his death at 94 last year that he was about to be voted the Congressional Gold Medal, he told his wife, Peggy, “I never imagined such an honor.” But as much as anything else, his humility was the reason he earned it.

headline: Sentencing Is Epilogue in Corruption Case
text: The end brought no mercy for Paul Siminovsky.

headline: Fuel Rationing in Iran Prompts Protests
text: TEHRAN, June 27 — Angry drivers set fire to at least two gasoline stations in Tehran Tuesday night after the government announced that fuel would be rationed beginning at midnight.

headline: Congress Scolds N.F.L. and Union
text: WASHINGTON, June 26 — With a dozen former players nodding and smiling in the audience, members of a House of Representatives subcommittee hearing testimony on the N.F.L.’s controversial player-disability plan said Tuesday that the system was not adequately serving former players and that the committee would explore legislative means to address it.

headline: France: Teenager Dies on Disneyland Ride
text: The police were investigating the death of a 14-year-old Spanish girl on the fast Rock ’n’ Roller Coaster ride at the Disneyland just outside Paris. A prosecutor said the death appeared to be a result of a pre-existing medical condition rather than a ride malfunction.

headline: Officials to Take Another Look at Decision to Close New Jersey Army Base
text: TRENTON, June 26  At the request of most members of the New Jersey Congressional delegation, the Government Accountability Office says it will look into whether faulty cost and savings estimates played a role in the 2005 decision to close Fort Monmouth by 2011.

headline: Forbidden Pleasure in the Desert
text: WE’D walked together down a road lined with craters. Walked slowly, of course. Looking for wires, animal carcasses, that sort of thing. The telltale signs of hidden bombs. It was a sweltering Iraqi morning, with the mist of the Euphrates infiltrating our lungs.

headline: A Bit of History, Reborn in a Glass
text: LAST October, John Deragon began tinkering with a recipe for Abbott’s bitters, a cocktail ingredient that has beguiled drinks fanatics for years. Over the next two months, Mr. Deragon, the chief technology officer of Waterfront Media, an online health and wellness company in Brooklyn, tweaked the formula drop by drop, using single-spice infusions known as tinctures. After about 18 test runs, he had a version he thought he could work with, and by March he was aging his second batch in a five-gallon rye whiskey barrel purchased from a distillery in upstate New York.

headline: Emirate Eyes Film Eminence
text: A few months after announcing a $1.3 billion deal with France to rent the Louvre’s name and gain access to its collections for a new museum in Abu Dhabi, that oil-rich emirate says it also wants to be the film and television capital of the Arab world. In October it will hold its first Middle East International Film Festival. And today it will announce an agreement with the New York Film Academy, a technical school, to open a branch in Abu Dhabi to train 100 students a year in television and film production. (Tuition at the Manhattan school is $34,000, but the emirate is likely to subsidize a portion of that.) Officials with the Abu Dhabi Authority for Culture and Heritage also said they were soliciting investment in the Persian Gulf region for a sizable fund, to be unveiled later this summer, that would offer financial incentives for film production in Abu Dhabi exceeding those offered by governments in Europe and elsewhere. Sami el-Masri, the authority’s director of strategic planning, said the initiatives were aimed at erecting bridges across cultures in a region accustomed to destroying them: “It’s about looking for common denominators at a time when we only look at differences.” Within the United Arab Emirates, Abu Dhabi has been in something of a footrace to announce cultural and tourist attractions, anticipating a future when the oil wells run dry. Neighboring Dubai is already building a $2.5 billion sports complex and a theme park based on Marvel Entertainment comics, and on Monday a unit of Viacom Inc. said it had signed a deal with a developer in the United Arab Emirates for a $2.5 billion theme park based on its library of films like “Titanic.”

headline: A Match-Point Lob Exceeds the Reach of the 6-10 Karlovic
text: WIMBLEDON, England, June 26  Ivo Karlovic’s aces can be easier to hear than to see.

headline: Recipe: Cold-Brewed Iced Coffee
text: Time: 5 minutes, plus 12 hours’ resting

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,556 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Another Trim in Spending for ’07
text: A LEADING forecaster of advertising spending has again lowered his estimate for growth in the United States this year, joining other experts who have also reduced their predictions.

headline: Dry Dock It’s Not
text: DAVID BERSON is a gallivanting boat captain who runs an electric launch, Glory, out of Greenport, N.Y., on the North Fork of Long Island. Captain Berson has been a deck monkey, a guitar hero and a yellow-cab hack over the years, an instructor of celestial navigation and a fair handler of canvas and rope. He smokes a pipe, is a friend of the masses and counts himself a fan of both Emma Goldman and Blind Willie Johnson. He sails cautiously and well, then pours rum with a heavy hand.

headline: G.M. Shifts 3 Brands to a Single Agency
text: G.M. Shifts 3 Brands

headline: Grant’s Sword Is Sold
text: A sale billed as the biggest auction of Civil War memorabilia ever was conducted Sunday and Monday in Gettysburg, Pa., by Heritage Auction Galleries of Dallas and brought in almost $6.5 million. A silver-, gold- and diamond-encrusted ceremonial sword, above, presented in 1864 to Gen. Ulysses S. Grant by the people of Kentucky, sold for $1.6 million, including buyer’s premium. The buyer plans to exhibit the sword, kept by Grant’s descendants until the 1960s, at the Texas Civil War Museum in Fort Worth. The battle flag of Gen. George A. Custer, sewn for him out of silk by his wife, Libbie, was bought by a private collector for nearly $900,000, including premium. Custer flew the red-and-blue swallowtail flag, showing crossed swords, in battle during the waning days of the Civil War and at Gen. Robert E. Lee’s surrender at Appomattox. He left it at Fort Lincoln, Dakota Territory, before his encounter at Little Big Horn. It remained in the Custer family until the 1950s.

headline: Psychiatrists Top List in Drug Maker Gifts
text: WASHINGTON, June 26 — As states begin to require that drug companies disclose their payments to doctors for lectures and other services, a pattern has emerged: psychiatrists earn more money from drug makers than doctors in any other specialty.

headline: What You Get for...$900,000
text: Chicago

headline: In Food Safety Crackdown, China Closes 180 Plants
text: SHANGHAI, June 27 — After weeks of insisting that food here is largely safe, regulators in China said Tuesday that they had recently closed 180 food plants and that inspectors had uncovered more than 23,000 food safety violations.

headline: Lottery Numbers
History and Homes May Mix at the Brooklyn Waterfront
text: Hulking and dormant on the North Brooklyn waterfront, its floors still sticky from a century’s toil, the former Domino Sugar refinery was the focus of a hearing yesterday to let residents sound off on whether to give it landmark status and allow a developer to transform it into part of an apartment complex.

headline: Manhattan: Mayor’s Grants Announced
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is giving a sixth set of ostensibly anonymous grants, this time worth more than $30 million, to 530 groups through a gift to the Carnegie Corporation. The donations announced yesterday, which range from $10,000 to $150,000, are to benefit a broad cross section of neighborhood-based cultural and social service groups and reflect the mayor’s interest in the arts, education, health and social welfare. Included for the first time are the After Hours Project in Brooklyn, which runs a needle exchange program to help reduce the spread of H.I.V.; the New York Asian Women’s Center, which helps battered women throughout the city; and One Stop Senior Services in Manhattan, which helps the elderly remain in their homes.

headline: Hip-Hop Gangsters on an Isle of Chaos
text: Asger Leth’s “Ghosts of Cité Soleil” offers a tour of a notorious, hellish slum in Port-au-Prince, the capital of Haiti. There, in 2004, when this documentary was shot, gang leaders known as Chimères (the ghosts of the title) fought with one another, and also with opponents of Haiti’s president, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, for control of the streets. Mr. Aristide’s decade-long decline from hero of democracy to belligerent strongman provides a backdrop for Mr. Leth’s focus on two Chimère leaders as they struggle for dominance and survival amid chaos and squalor.

headline: A  White That Is a Friend to Seafood
text: SOME white wines are perfect flying solo, for a sip on a relaxed late summer afternoon. But not spirited, citrusy, herbaceous New Zealand sauvignon blancs.

headline: More on Unions
text: Barry Hirsch, an economist at Trinity University in San Antonio, keeps a wealth of data on labor unions.

headline: Dutch Opinion Lends Support to Barclays Bid for ABN Amro
text: LONDON, June 26  Barclays, the British bank bidding for ABN Amro, won an endorsement Tuesday from a Dutch Supreme Court adviser that could help decide in its favor the next step in the banking takeover battle.

headline: Texas and Oklahoma Hit by Flooding
text: Heavy rains caused flooding in parts of central Texas and Oklahoma today, forcing some residents to climb to the tops of their vehicles, houses and trees to await rescue.

headline: Residents Returning, but Blaze Is Stubborn
text: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., June 26 — As residents began to trickle back to their homes to inspect the damage caused by a weekend wildfire near here, two Forest Service firefighters were trapped for nearly an hour on Tuesday after the stubborn blaze jumped a defensive fire line and threatened two neighborhoods on this town’s western edge.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 9 P.M. (22, 26) PAUL SIMON: THE LIBRARY OF CONGRESS GERSHWIN PRIZE FOR POPULAR SONG Mr. Simon, left, is the first recipient of this new award, created to recognize the impact of pop music on world culture. A gala concert taped at the Warner Theater in Washington features Mr. Simon’s former partner, Art Garfunkel, as well as Marc Anthony, the Dixie Hummingbirds, Alison Krauss, Ladysmith Black Mambazo, Lyle Lovett, Stephen Marley, James Taylor and Buckwheat Zydeco.

headline: Chef Sues Over Intellectual Property (the Menu)
text: Sometimes, Rebecca Charles wishes she were a little less influential.

headline: Iced Coffee? No Sweat
text: BEFORE I go telling everybody that the secret to great iced coffee is already in the kitchen, my friend Keller wants me to confess: I didn’t know from iced coffee until he showed me the light.

headline: Blair Is Appointed Mideast Envoy
text: Tony Blair, who stepped down today as the prime minister of Britain, has been appointed a new senior peace envoy for the Middle East, working on building the framework for a Palestinian state, officials said today.

headline: With Minor Adjustment, Damon Is Back in Place
text: BALTIMORE, June 26 — The fastest way for Johnny Damon to feel better, it seems, is to visit his chiropractor in Orlando, Fla. That is what he did Monday, after an earlier appointment to see a dentist, and the results had him feeling rejuvenated.

headline: From Caveman to Today, All the World’s a (Pompous) Stage
text: “Light me,” orders Robert Honeywell, credited as the writer, director, team leader and imaginer of “Every Play Ever Written,” a gleefully funny faux-lecture that skewers theatrical pomposity as vigorously as Stephen Colbert picks apart political punditry.

headline: Scraping By With a South Dakota Tribe
text: Over the last six weeks, as I’ve steered my old Volvo up and down hills, across plains and through thick forests, I’ve frequently fallen into a hypnotic groove. The right music will come on the iPod — the Rolling Stones, or a plaintive Neko Case lyric, or naïve pop from 1960s Cambodia — and the sun will wring stunning purples out of stone or mysteriously frost the wheat fields at dusk. It’s at these times that the road seems to drive me, the car hugging the curves unbidden, and I want to shut my eyes and hold onto these moments until I careen off the asphalt to my doom.

headline: The Which Blair Project
text: Tony Blair, who leaves office today, deserves to be remembered for far more than the disastrous war in Iraq. In 10 years as prime minister, he transformed Britain in positive ways and revitalized his Labor Party, which makes his failures in Iraq all the more lamentable.

headline: Brooklyn: Cache of Fireworks Seized
text: Five men were arrested on Monday night and charged with fireworks possession after the police seized a large cache of fireworks and $14,000 in cash, the police said yesterday. The men  Lawrence DiAmbrossi, 43, Christopher DiAmbrossi, 46, John Riccardi, 36, and Albert Slavin, 39, all of Brooklyn, and David Melore, 48, of Freehold, N.J. _  _ were charged after the police executed a search warrant about 7 p.m. at 2624 East 27th Street in Sheepshead Bay, the police said.

headline: Recipe: Asian Noodle Soup With Seafood
text: Time: 40 minutes

headline: In a Tough Hearing, Smithsonian Is Urged to Find a New Chief Fast
text: WASHINGTON, June 26 — Citing a harsh report on missteps at the Smithsonian Institution, Senator Dianne Feinstein declared at a hearing on Tuesday that the museum complex should move quickly to replace its ousted top executive rather than take an estimated six months to a year.

headline: In Silicon Valley, Steady but Cautious Growth Returns
text: REDWOOD CITY, Calif. — A glittery blue office tower in downtown San Jose may well be the perfect symbol for Silicon Valley’s resurgence.

headline: Study Finds Whites May Be Overrepresented in Manhattan’s Jury Pools
text: The principle that defendants should be judged by a jury of their peers is a cherished part of the American justice system. But a government watchdog group questions whether that guarantee is being kept in Manhattan.

headline: State Seeks to Sink Old Ships for Big Reef Off Long Island
text: New York State wants to expand its network of artificial reefs in the Atlantic Ocean and add another that would be the largest and deepest off Long Island.

headline: Clean-Energy Obstacle (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: All Is Not Well at Guantánamo (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Arms Flowing Into Lebanon, U.N. Finds
text: UNITED NATIONS, June 26 — The present state of border control is inadequate for preventing the smuggling of arms from Syria into Lebanon, according to a report that a United Nations assessment team submitted to the Security Council on Tuesday.

headline: Calendar
text: Tasting Wine Before the 6:55

headline: The Whole World Is Watching
text: Three years ago, I was catching a plane at Boston’s Logan airport and went to buy some magazines for the flight. As I approached the cash register, a woman coming from another direction got there just behind me — I thought. But when I put my money down to pay, the woman said in a very loud voice: “Excuse me! I was here first!” And then she fixed me with a piercing stare that said: “I know who you are.” I said I was very sorry, but I was clearly there first.

headline: Live Earth Concerts Struggle
text: Less than three weeks after Al Gore, the environmental campaigner and former vice president, visited Istanbul to announce its participation in the round-the-world Live Earth concerts on July 7, organizers announced yesterday that the city had been dropped from the roster of nine sites because of a lack of interest coupled with security concerns in advance of general elections on July 22, Reuters reported. ... In South Africa, organizers seeking to stimulate lagging ticket sales moved the Live Earth concert to the 18,000-seat Coca-Cola Dome in Johannesburg from a site 45 minutes by car from the city, Reuters reported.

headline: Lawmakers Criticize Spitzer on Upstate Restoration Plan
text: BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., June 26  Gov. Eliot Spitzer, born and raised in New York City, made restoring upstate a central campaign theme last year

headline: Scant Drug Benefits Called Costly to Employers
text: Health penny wise, medical pound foolish?

headline: Correction
text: An editorial on Sunday about an autism court case said incorrectly that the vaccine for mumps, measles and rubella contained a mercury preservative. The preservative, thimerasol, was in other vaccines involved in the hearings.

headline: France: Alstom Buys a Wind Energy Company
text: Alstom, a maker of coal-fired power stations, agreed to buy Ecotècnia of Spain to enter the wind energy market. Alstom will pay 350 million euros ($471 million) for Ecotècnia, which also makes solar panels, it said. The purchase will help Alstom, which is based in Paris, expand in the United States and Asia, it said. Buying Ecotècnia strengthens Alstom’s presence in renewable energy as governments seek alternatives to coal, gas and oil. Alstom also sells hydroelectric equipment and worked with Russia’s state nuclear agency in April to develop atomic plants.

headline: W. Learns From Students
text: WASHINGTON

headline: George Kovacs, Innovator in Lighting Fixtures, Dies at 80
text: George Kovacs, a designer, manufacturer and importer of innovative and stylish modern lighting fixtures who introduced the ubiquitous halogen torchiere to the United States, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80.

headline: Outcome of an Ad Contest Starts an Uproar on YouTube
text: Some YouTube users cried foul this week when they saw the winning video in a Malibu Caribbean Rum user-generated advertising contest.

headline: Reflections in an Ice Cube: The Drinks of Memory
text: ON the most bruising summer days it’s hard to imagine ever staring down a stove again. Those are the times when stirring sugar into cold tea feels like all the cooking anyone can handle — and that sweetened drink seems like all the nourishment anyone will ever need. After all, the body can burn spare fat cells for days, but it hits real trouble after a few hours without liquid.

headline: A Taste of Freedom
text: ONCE when I was about 13 years old, my best friend, Renee, and I did that thing where you each tell your parents that you are sleeping over at the other’s house, and they don’t even check. With relative ease, we found ourselves distinctly unchaperoned and hitchhiking the 20 miles to the Trenton, N.J., train station and catching a train to New York City.

headline: Zimbabwe Seeks ‘Indigenous’ Control of Companies
text: JOHANNESBURG, June 26  Zimbabwe’s government has put forward legislation that would require virtually all publicly traded companies to cede controlling interests to “indigenous” citizens, raising the possibility of a sizable redistribution of the country’s remaining wealth at a time when its economy is collapsing.

headline: Baghdad Christians Find New Life in Kurdish North
text: KARA-ULA, Iraq  The 70 houses of this tiny village spring from the treeless, arid plain here in the northern tip of Iraq with the uniformity of an army camp.

headline: Canada’s Policy on Immigrants Brings Backlog
text: TORONTO, June 26  With an advanced degree in business management from a university in India and impeccable English, Salman Kureishy is precisely the type of foreigner that Canada’s merit-based immigration system was designed to attract.

headline: Ex-Governor Says Conviction Was Political
text: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 26 — The convicted former governor of Alabama, Don E. Siegelman, faced prosecutors who urged a long prison sentence here on Tuesday in a federal corruption case that has unexpectedly transcended the confines of this sleepy state capital.

headline: Lindsay Lohan Prolongs Rehab
text: Lindsay Lohan is staying put. Ms. Lohan, who turns 21 on Monday, is “going to be doing extended care” at the Promises rehabilitation center in Malibu, Calif., according to her mother, Dina Lohan, The Associated Press reported. “It was her choice,” Ms. Lohan told The Daily News when she appeared on Monday for a hearing in Nassau Family Court in Mineola, N.Y., where Judge Stacy Bennett ordered her and her estranged husband, Michael Lohan, to attend family therapy to reunite him gradually with his two youngest children. Mr. Lohan left prison recently after serving time for drunken driving and attempted assault. Lindsay Lohan checked into the rehabilitation center after she was arrested on May 26 on suspicion of driving under the influence in Beverly Hills. “She’s doing great,” her mother said.

headline: Ex-Interior Aide Is Sentenced in Lobbying Case
text: WASHINGTON, June 26 — A federal judge on Tuesday sentenced the former second-ranking official of the Interior Department to 10 months in prison for lying to a Senate committee about his ties to Jack Abramoff, the crooked lobbyist who is now in prison.

headline: Russian Says Britain’s MI6 Tried to Recruit Him
text: A Russian citizen has accused Britain’s MI6 foreign intelligence service of trying to recruit him while he was abroad. The accusation was made by the authorities and broadcast on national television. The man was not identified but was described as being in fear of his life. Russian television, which is under tight Kremlin control, has repeatedly accused Britain of spying. The campaign intensified last month when a man accused by British prosecutors of poisoning Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. agent and foe of the Kremlin, said British intelligence had committed the murder.

headline: Thousands Gather in Brooklyn for Firefighter’s Funeral
text: Bagpipes wailed and drums rattled yesterday as thousands of firefighters in dress blues flooded the streets of Greenpoint, Brooklyn, to pay final respects to Daniel F. Pujdak, the 23-year-old firefighter who fell four stories to his death while battling a fire in Brooklyn last Thursday.

headline: Hollywood Scrambles as Strike Looms
text: LOS ANGELES, June 26 — In Hollywood’s upper reaches this week, few are bothering to count past two. As in Adam Sandler has already booked his two “pre-strike” pictures, so let’s try Vince Vaughn.

headline: Recipe: Griddled Butterflied Leg of Lamb With Lemon, Herbs and Garlic
text: Time: About 45 minutes plus 30 minutes for marinating

headline: G.O.P. Senator Splits With Bush Over Iraq Policy
text: WASHINGTON, June 26  Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, the ranking Republican on the Foreign Relations Committee and a steadfast supporter of the president, has conspicuously broken ranks with him on the Iraq war, warning that the United States’ standing in the world could be irreparably eroded if the White House does not change strategy soon.

headline: Study Criticizes Parks Dept. Management
text: The quality of the typical New York City park is determined largely by whether it is in a wealthy or poor neighborhood, according to a study to be released by a private nonprofit group today. The report also indicated that despite budget increases in recent years, the Parks Department is not doing enough strategic planning to manage its parkland properly.

headline: Ex-Senator Returns Home but Is Quiet on Candidacy
text: NASHVILLE, June 26  Dozens of self-proclaimed Fred Heads gathered at the airport here Tuesday to welcome home former Senator Fred D. Thompson of Tennessee, and to nudge him to seek the Republican Party’s nomination for the presidency.

headline: Saudi Arabia: Mobile Phone Assets Acquired in Malaysia
text: The Saudi Telecom Company, the largest phone company in Saudi Arabia, bought a 25 percent stake in Maxis Communications of Malaysia for 11.4 billion riyals ($3 billion) to tap growth in developing markets like India. Saudi Telecom bought the shares from a Malaysian billionaire, T. Ananda Krishnan, who last month offered to buy the 40 percent that he did not already control in Maxis, which is based in Kuala Lumpur and is the country’s largest mobile phone operator. Maxis has 14 million subscribers in Malaysia and India. Under the agreement, Saudi Telecom will also acquire 51 percent stake in PT Natrindo Telepon Selular, the Maxis subsidiary in Indonesia, the company said.

headline: Spike Lee to Try Broadway as Director of ‘Stalag 17’
text: The first revival of “Stalag 17,” the 1951 comedy-drama about American prisoners of war written by two former P.O.W.’s, Donald Bevan and Edmund Trzcinski, is scheduled to arrive on Broadway in late spring next year. And in one of the more surprising combinations in recent Broadway history, the director of the new production will be Spike Lee.

headline: Pope Tightens Voting Rules for Election of Successors
text: ROME, June 26  Pope Benedict XVI has changed the rules for electing a pope by reinstituting the traditional requirement that two-thirds of the cardinals in the conclave agree on a candidate, no matter how long the process takes.

headline: Accord Seen on Oversight of Journal
text: Negotiators reached an agreement in principle yesterday on protecting the editorial independence of The Wall Street Journal, an important step toward a purchase by the News Corporation of The Journal’s owner, Dow Jones & Company, people briefed on the talks said.

headline: Recipe: Sour Cherry Syrup
text: Adapted from Najmieh Batmanglij

headline: Canada: Manulife Acquires a Fund Sales Group
text: The Manulife Financial Corporation, a Canadian life insurance company, said it would buy the Berkshire-TWC Financial Group’s mutual fund and securities dealerships to bolster its Canadian wealth management business. Manulife said the deal would double its number of Canadian wealth management advisers and triple its assets under administration in that business. The deal is part of a plan by Manulife of Toronto to expand its mutual funds unit. The takeover creates a sales force of 1,500 independent advisers and a business with about 19 billion Canadian dollars ($17.7 billion) in assets under administration. The price was not disclosed.

headline: Pointing to Stability, Kurds in Iraq Lure Investors
text: ERBIL, Iraq — It is a measure of soaring Kurdish optimism that government officials here talk seriously about one day challenging Dubai as the Middle East’s main transportation and business hub.

headline: MySpace, Chasing YouTube, Upgrades Its Offerings
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 — Two years ago, millions of MySpace users began adding video clips to their profile pages, helping to give rise to YouTube, which Google bought last October for $1.65 billion.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
