text: The New York Times/CBS News/MTV Poll of young adults is based on telephone interviews conducted June 15 through June 23 with 659 people ages 17 through 29 living in households throughout the United States.

headline: Delay in Buyout Bond Sale
text: US Foodservice, the American unit of the Dutch supermarket Royal Ahold, has postponed its sale of $650 million in bonds that were expected to finance the unit’s equity buyout, people involved in the transition said yesterday.

headline: A Lark Amid the Peacocks
text: YOU can look at the new Landmarc in the Time Warner Center as just another meat-mad, wined-up refueling station for New York’s sputtering masses, a place willing to surrender any intimacy and many niceties in the interests of accommodating serious traffic. With 300 seats, it’s three times the size of the original Landmarc in TriBeCa, whose menu and competent cooking it replicates but whose warmth it largely lacks.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A theater review on Monday about “Romeo and Juliet,” at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, misstated Juliet’s age in the play. She is 13, not 14.

headline: Grass’s Fact and Fiction, Fighting to a Draw
text: In 1945, with the Wehrmacht on the run, a 17-year-old private by the name of Günter Grass cowered in a cellar in eastern Germany. As house-to-house fighting raged in the village outside, his platoon was ordered to mount some bicycles hanging from the ceiling and make a dash for it. Mr. Grass, who had never learned to ride, stayed behind to provide covering fire, then watched as Russian machine guns turned his comrades into a twitching pile of corpses.

headline: U.S. Investigates Saudi Deal for British Arms, Company Says
text: LONDON, June 26 — The United States Justice Department has started a formal corruption investigation into business conducted by BAE Systems, Europe’s biggest weapons maker and a supplier to the Pentagon, the company announced Tuesday.

headline: The End of an Era at Bellevue and a Nearby Church
text: For 17 years, his feet have hit the sidewalk at 5 a.m., always ahead of the first dash of daylight. Then Philip Marani walks the few blocks from his home on East 28th Street to First Avenue, into Bellevue Hospital Center.

headline: Recipe: White Sangria
text: 2 small white nectarines or white peaches

headline: Tentative Accord Reached on Dow Jones Control
text: Negotiators reached an “agreement in principle” today for guarding the editorial independence of The Wall Street Journal if its parent, Dow Jones & Company, is sold to the News Corporation, people briefed on the talks said.

headline: A.F.I. Appoints New Leader
text: The American Film Institute, the country’s leading organization for film history and preservation, yesterday named Bob Gazzale, a film historian and television producer, to be its president and chief executive. He will succeed Jean Picker Firstenberg, who is retiring in the fall after 27 years of heading the institute, which is based in Los Angeles. Mr. Gazzale, 42, becomes just the third person to lead the organization since its creation in 1967. The institute’s board, including its chairman, Howard Stringer, chairman of the Sony Corporation, unanimously voted him in yesterday. He has been with the institute since 1992, mainly serving as the director of A.F.I. Productions. In a statement, Mr. Stringer said, “As we say in the movies, we searched for brain, heart and courage, and found it all in our own backyard.”

headline: The Evolution of Sauvignon Blanc
text: THE sauvignon blanc grape owes a lot to New Zealand. Thirty years or so ago nobody knew much about it at all. Sure, it was a component of white Bordeaux, and yes, it was part of the blend in the great sweet wines of Sauternes. It made wonderful white wines in the Loire Valley, particularly in Sancerre and Pouilly-Fumé, as it still does.

headline: Correction: If Rules Change, Will Camembert Stay the Same?
text: An article last Wednesday about French cheese makers who have stopped making Camembert with raw milk and have withdrawn from the government program that certifies that they use traditional methods misstated some of the standards for that certification, called an Appellation d’Origine Contrôlée. To have an A.O.C., a Camembert from Normandy must be made with unfiltered raw milk, and have a fat content of 38 percent. It is not the milk that has to have a fat content of 38 percent.

headline: BlackRock Spending $1.7 Billion to Get ‘Fund of Funds’ Operation
text: BlackRock, the rapidly growing asset management company, said yesterday that it had acquired the “fund of funds” business of the Quellos Group, a boutique investment firm in Seattle.

headline: Comparing Today’s Tactics With Those Used in the Past
text: WASHINGTON, June 26 — When the Central Intelligence Agency took a nervous look at its past in 1973, one potential illegal act officials identified was the treatment of a K.G.B. officer named Yuri Nosenko. After fleeing to the United States in 1964, Mr. Nosenko was held in a makeshift jail for three years and subjected to tough questioning to determine whether he was a genuine defector or a plant.

headline: Worthy Goal of Flawed Bill: Aiding Unions
text: In the spring of 1949, the men who ran the steelworkers’ union decided to pick a fight over health insurance and pensions.

headline: Renovating Stables in Poland
text: Levis Minford has never bought a house that was finished. Building and renovating have become almost a habit for Mr. Minford, a native of Idaho, and he always has some kind of construction project going on. So it was no surprise that, when he was looking for a house outside Warsaw, he settled on an 18th-century stable that had to be turned into a house.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A theater review on Monday about “Romeo and Juliet,” at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, misstated Juliet’s age in the play. She is 13, not 14.

headline: Workers Split With Bosses on Leave Act, Survey Finds
text: After soliciting 15,000 comments about the Family and Medical Leave Act, the Labor Department will issue a report today concluding that the public likes the law, but corporate America has big problems with it.

headline: Harry Potter Makes Money
text: A first edition of the first Harry Potter adventure worked financial magic yesterday when it was sold at auction in London for $18,000, the BBC reported. The J. K. Rowling novel, issued in Britain in 1997 under the title “Harry Potter and the Philosopher’s Stone,” above (the title in the United States is “Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone”), is a rarity, according to the auction house, Bonhams. The publisher, Bloomsbury, gave it an initial press run of 500 copies. Bonhams sold the book to an anonymous buyer. The seller was an unidentified woman who had bought it originally with book tokens that she had been given as a school prize.

headline: In the Backyard, Fireplaces
text: Steve and Terri Tucker have three fireplaces in their vacation home, but it is the fireplace on the deck that gets the most attention. Even in the summer months, when evening temperatures rarely fall below 60 degrees in the mountain town of Blue Ridge, Ga., Mr. Tucker said, “the outdoor fireplace definitely gets used.” In fact, he said they “light it every single day.”

headline: Tu, at Peak of Career, Moves Into 2nd Round at Wimbledon
text: WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 — People would ask, with increasing frequency, when Meilen Tu would quit playing tennis. It seemed obvious that her best years were past.

headline: Trooper in Near-Fatal Crash Is Driving Corzine Again
text: TRENTON, June 26  He was criticized by a police review panel for not being alert enough to prevent a car accident that almost killed the governor. And he is on the verge of being suspended for several days after violating police procedures for excessive speeding and the use of emergency lights.

headline: Recipe: Long Island Iced Tea
text: Adapted from Gabrielle Hamilton

headline: Senate Issues Subpoenas in Eavesdropping Investigation
text: WASHINGTON, June 27 — The Senate Judiciary Committee today issued subpoenas to the White House, Vice President Dick Cheney’s office and the Justice Department after what the panel’s chairman called "stonewalling of the worst kind" of efforts to investigate the National Security Agency’s policy of wiretapping without warrants.

headline: Brooklyn: Pizzeria Reopens
text: A popular Brooklyn pizzeria reopened on Saturday nearly three weeks after it was cited by the city health department for unsanitary conditions. Di Fara Pizza, at East 15th Street and Avenue J in Midwood, was closed after it failed an inspection on June 4, when inspectors found flies, a mouse infestation and bare-hand contact with food. That was the second time since March that the shop had been closed this year. After a visit last week, Di Fara’s reopened. “We passed the inspection,” Dominick DeMarco, the son of the owner, said last night. “It’s just all bureaucracy. You have to go through the paperwork.”

headline: Family of a Captured Israeli Soldier Gets Word to Hamas, via Norway
text: JERUSALEM, June 26 — Two weeks before Monday’s release of an audiotape of a captured Israeli soldier in Gaza, his father set in motion a request to Hamas, the Islamic militant group holding the soldier, for some sign that the young man was alive.

headline: Oracle’s Revenue Climbs 20%, Helped by Acquisitions
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 — Fourth-quarter revenue at the Oracle Corporation, the software company, beat Wall Street’s projections on Tuesday as it continued to ride its three-year buying spree, leading its executives to claim substantial gains over its competitors.

headline: Evaluating the Evaluators (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: 29 Are Accused of Smuggling Fake Goods Into the U.S.
text: Twenty-nine people were charged yesterday in three federal complaints that described a network of international plots to smuggle nearly $700 million in real and counterfeit goods from China through Kennedy International Airport and seaports in Newark, Houston, Staten Island and Long Beach, Calif.

headline: Files on Illegal Spying Show C.I.A. Skeletons From Cold War
text: WASHINGTON, June 26  Long-secret documents released Tuesday provide new details about how the Central Intelligence Agency illegally spied on Americans decades ago, including trying to bug a Las Vegas hotel room for evidence of infidelity and tracking down an expert lock-picker for a Watergate conspirator.

headline: The Cherries of Persia
text: THE ruby-colored iced drink came in a tall glass set on a painted tray. There were other offerings: ice water, hot tea. But the bright color beckoned.

headline: After Two Days and Four-Plus Hours, Henman Advances
text: WIMBLEDON, England, June 26  Tim Henman arrived Tuesday at Center Court, again, carrying a bag of rackets and the anxiety of a nation. He came to put an end, good or bad, on the most riveting match in Wimbledon’s first 24 hours. Fans and television cameras unblinkingly tracked his every move.

headline: Chinese Company Denies Tire Defect
text: SHANGHAI, June 26  The Chinese manufacturer of 450,000 tires that United States regulators have ordered to be recalled denied Tuesday that they were defective, saying the accusations might be fabricated.

headline: ‘The Queen’ Got It Wrong: No Hands Are Kissed
text: LONDON, June 27 — It had been so often foretold as to seem an anticlimax. But finally — and not quite as in the movie starring Helen Mirren — Gordon Brown got his “Queen moment” today when he took over from Tony Blair as prime minister of Britain.

headline: Half the World Soon to Be in Cities
text: By next year, more than half the world’s population, 3.3 billion people, will for the first time live in towns and cities, a number expected to swell to almost 5 billion by 2030, according to a United Nations Population Fund report released today.

headline: Spain: 3 Suspected Qaeda Recruiters Arrested
text: The police arrested three Moroccan men in Barcelona on suspicion that they had links to the North African terrorist group Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, formerly the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat, and belonged to a terrorist cell that recruits and equips militants. They were detained at the request of the Moroccan authorities.

headline: Japan: Coca-Cola Buys Stake in a Bottler in Tokyo
text: The Coca-Cola Company will buy a 34 percent stake in the Tokyo Coca-Cola Bottling Company to increase sales in Japan after volume declined last year. The Japanese subsidiary of Coca-Cola will buy new shares of the closely held Tokyo-based bottler, the companies said in a statement. The financial terms were not disclosed. The Takanashi family, which founded the bottler 50 years ago, will retain control of about 65 percent of the company, Charlie Sutlive, a Coca-Cola spokesman, said.

headline: With Eye on Future, U.S. Takes Youngsters on Trip to Venezuela
text: Talk about a quick turnaround. Only hours after defeating Mexico in the final of the Concacaf Gold Cup on Sunday in Chicago, Coach Bob Bradley and an ersatz United States national team were preparing to leave for Venezuela. The inexperienced American team, which includes 11 players who have made fewer than five appearances for the senior national team, opens play in Copa América tomorrow against Argentina.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Friday about the Hayward clan of the Mashantucket Pequots of Connecticut, which led the tribe into the casino era but now feels rejected by its current leaders, misstated a comment by John L. Holder, executive assistant to the tribal chairman, about Richard A. Hayward, the tribe’s former leader. He said Mr. Hayward had become rude and undiplomatic as chairman  not undemocratic.

headline: Brown Assumes Power in Britain
text: LONDON, June 27 — On a day of poignant farewells and sober new promises, Gordon Brown took over Wednesday from Tony Blair as prime minister, offering Britain a pledge to “try my utmost” and declaring, “Now, let the work of change begin.”

headline: Zahringer Wins Fifth Ike Championship
text: George Zahringer III of Deepdale Golf Club won the 52nd Metropolitan Golf Association Ike Championship yesterday at Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale by four strokes over Andreas Huber of Garden City Golf Club. Zahringer, 54, won his fifth Ike title and became the oldest champion in tournament history. He shot 75-71 yesterday for a 219 total.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Weekend on Friday about the refurbished Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden at the New York Botanical Garden referred incorrectly to David Rockefeller’s donation in the 1980s for the renovation of an earlier rose garden at the same site. It was in honor of his wife, Peggy, not in memory of her. (She died in 1996.) The article also misstated the name of one kind of rose on display and erroneously listed part of the name as a variety. It is the Rita Levi Montalcini (named after the Nobel Prize winner Rita Levi-Montalcini), not the Rita Levi, and there is no rose called simply the Montalcini.

headline: Senate Republicans Block Bill on Unionizing
text: Senate Republicans yesterday blocked the labor movement’s top legislative priority, a bill that would have made it easier for unions to organize workers.

headline: Con Ed’s Rate Increase a Hard Sell in Council
text: With frustration from last summer’s Queens blackout hanging over the proceedings, City Council members grilled a Consolidated Edison official yesterday over the utility’s proposed electricity rate increase.

headline: Six of the Best and Brightest, Poised to Take the Next Step on the Long Road
text: They are the children of immigrants, or the latest in a long line of siblings to graduate from public schools. These are the valedictorians of New York City. Some will enroll at the City University of New York, others are off to colleges in California and Texas and Maine. They are violin players, dancers, singers and student government leaders. They aspire to be engineers or writers or architects. Many are the first in their family to graduate from high school.

headline: Cheney’s Theory of Government (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Asked for Apology, Japan Plays for Time in Sex Slavery Standoff
text: TOKYO, Wednesday, June 27  Even before a United States Congressional panel overwhelmingly passed a resolution on Tuesday urging Japan to apologize for its wartime sex slavery, the Japanese government said it would have no comment.

headline: Wrestler Killed Wife and Son, Then Himself
text: ATLANTA, June 26 — Chris Benoit, a professional wrestler known as the Canadian Crippler, killed his wife and 7-year-old son in their house in Fayetteville, Ga., over the weekend before taking his own life by hanging himself with a cable from a weight machine in his home gym, investigators said Tuesday.

headline: Carrier From Western Provinces Ends Bell Canada Bid
text: OTTAWA, June 26  Telus, the Western Canadian telephone company, unexpectedly withdrew its bid for its larger rival, Bell Canada, on Tuesday while some partners in one of three separate bids to take the company private also walked away.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage: Parsing the Arguments (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Slaying Suspect Is Questioned in Second Killing
text: A Bronx man who was arrested last week on charges that he killed a man during a botched burglary two years ago is being questioned in the 2003 shooting death of a Hunter College student who was killed after leaving a meeting of peace activists in Harlem.

headline: France: Chirac Faces Corruption Inquiry
text: Former President Jacques Chirac will “very probably” be questioned in the coming months about a corruption scandal involving political no-show jobs when he was mayor of Paris, his lawyer, Jean Veil, told Europe-1 radio. Two years ago, his ally and former prime minister, Alain Juppé, was convicted in the case, which investigators say helped finance Mr. Chirac’s party as it drained millions of dollars from the city’s coffers. Mr. Chirac has refused to testify in two other cases that involve events during his years as president: a political dirty tricks campaign and the mysterious death of a French judge in Djibouti in 1995.

headline: Doubts Emerge About Passage of Immigration Bill
text: WASHINGTON, June 27 — The Senate immigration bill’s chances of passage seemed in doubt late this afternoon as several lawmakers signaled that they were undecided about supporting the legislation.

headline: Manhattan: New Labor Council President
text: The New York City Central Labor Council announced yesterday that Gary La Barbera was elected president at a delegates meeting on Monday night. Mr. La Barbera, 47, is president of a Teamsters local representing 4,000 construction industry drivers and heads the Teamsters’ district council for the New York metropolitan region, representing 100,000 Teamsters. He succeeds Brian M. McLaughlin, who headed the labor council for 11 years before he was indicted in October on charges of obtaining $2.2 million through embezzlement, fraud and bribery. The delegates approved a new constitution that gives Mr. La Barbera less power than Mr. McLaughlin had. The council’s board will have more powers; the president will serve as chairman of the board, sharing responsibilities with an executive director who runs operations day to day.

headline: Mets Prefer Lo Duca Not Delay Suspension
text: There is no way, no how, Paul Lo Duca said, that he intends to miss any of the Mets’ four games this weekend in Philadelphia. But he may not have a choice.

headline: Young Americans Are Leaning Left, New Poll Finds
text: Young Americans are more likely than the general public to favor a government-run universal health care insurance system, an open-door policy on immigration and the legalization of gay marriage, according to a New York Times/CBS News/MTV poll. The poll also found that they are more likely to say the war in Iraq is heading to a successful conclusion.

headline: Bill Giving Illegal Residents Connecticut Tuition Rates Is Vetoed by the Governor
text: HARTFORD, June 26 — Gov. M. Jodi Rell vetoed a bill on Tuesday that would have provided state tuition rates for illegal immigrants at state colleges and universities in Connecticut, saying she did not want to encourage the flouting of federal immigration laws.

headline: Europeans Critical of Romania and Bulgaria
text: Bulgaria and Romania will receive stern rebukes from the European Commission today for failing to root out corruption and organized crime, officials said, adding to concerns that the nations, which became members of the European Union on Jan. 1, were admitted prematurely. According to a draft report on Bulgaria, “contract killings” remain a concern.

headline: Film Portrays Stifling of Speech, but One College’s Struggle Reflects a Nuanced Reality
Expressing Unsteadiness in Lyrics, but a Clear Focus in Delivery
text: “I have no idea how this happens,” Jeff Tweedy sang at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Monday night. “All of my maps have been overthrown.” As his band Wilco chugged soulfully behind him, he continued: “Happenstance has changed my plans/So many times my heart has been outgrown.”

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on June 13 about a more hospitable approach to day laborers taken by the village of Mamaroneck, N.Y., referred imprecisely to the number of hiring sites in the country. According to the National Day Labor Organizing Network, there are approximately 65 formal sites, like the one at the Strait Gate Church in Mamaroneck. But there are hundreds more informal gathering places for day laborers, including street corners and parking lots. (The first nationwide study of day laborers, released in 2006, counted more than 500 sites.)

headline: Our Family Hostage Crisis
text: Fairfax, Va.

headline: Senate Takes Up a Revised Immigration Bill, but Obstacles Remain
text: WASHINGTON, June 26 — By a vote of 64 to 35, the Senate decided on Tuesday to take up a revised version of a comprehensive immigration bill that was pulled from the Senate floor nearly three weeks ago.

headline: Food Stuff
text: New in the Village, the Spices of India

headline: Liz Claiborne, Designer, Dies at 78
text: Liz Claiborne, the designer of indefatigable career clothes for professional women entering the workforce en masse beginning in the 1970s, died Tuesday in Manhattan. She was 78.

headline: Not the Elusive Bluefin, but Just Fine for the Fire
text: BY now, everyone is well convinced that tuna is a fine replacement for steak. And by now, many people have realized that the absolute best tuna — bluefin — has been overfished. The result is that it’s scarce, hard to find, practically unaffordable when available and largely reserved for the classiest Japanese restaurants for use in sushi.

headline: May Your Grill Always Be Smokin’
text: I LEFT the suburbs 24 years ago and never looked back. The one thing I didn’t count on missing was the barbecue, which is what we called it in the olden days, when it was still a tub full of charcoal briquettes topped by a wobbly grate. These days it’s known as the grill, and it can resemble a stainless steel spaceship, a birdhouse or a bungalow.

headline: Ad Forecaster Lowers Estimates
text: A leading forecaster of advertising spending has again reduced his estimate for growth in the United States this year, joining other experts who have also trimmed their predictions.

headline: Welcome at the Border: Thai Fruits, Once Banned
text: FRESH mangosteens and mangoes from Thailand will soon be available in the United States, the Agriculture Department has decided. Those fruits — as well as fresh pineapples, rambutans, litchis and longans — had been barred as imports from Thailand because they could harbor harmful insects, but will be allowed in when irradiated at low doses to kill or sterilize the pests.

headline: Mosquitoes Have the Edge in Singapore’s Dengue War
text: SINGAPORE, June 26  Under the sink, behind the cleaning detergents, Thurainadan Govindarajoo shined his flashlight into the shadows, searching for telltale signs of the enemy.

headline: General Motors to Change Ad Agencies
text: General Motors, once famously loath to change advertising agencies, did so today for the second time in five months — and the third time in a year — by shifting the national creative assignments for the Buick and GMC brands to the agency that creates national campaigns for Pontiac.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A headline on an article in Business Day on Saturday about the efforts of some companies to provide health insurance for retirees too young for Medicare overstated the number of retirees the program might help. Although about 800,000 early retirees are said to be without health insurance, the program’s organizers say the plan would probably help only a fraction of them, not all.

headline: Nascar Continues to Be Strict on Illegal Modifications of Cars
text: Five Nascar teams were severely penalized before the season-opening Daytona 500 to send a message through the Nextel Cup garage. Apparently, that has not stopped other teams from tinkering with racecars and breaking the rules.

headline: Art Critic or Vandal? ‘The Splasher’ Leaves Clues
text: Street artists have speculated for months about the identity of a mysterious figure who has become known as “the Splasher” because he or she hurled colorful blobs of paint at prominent pieces of art on exterior walls in Brooklyn and Lower Manhattan.

headline: Get Out the Lederhosen and Prepare to Oompah
text: BEER + sun + sausage = joy.

headline: ‘Strength in America Is Not Just in the Oval Office,’ Edwards Says
text: This 30-second television advertisement for John Edwards is his campaign’s first big media buy. It will run only in New Hampshire, the first primary state and one where polls show him running behind a number of other Democrats. At the moment, the campaign has no plans to run the advertisement in Iowa, where Mr. Edwards has invested considerable campaigning time and has shown strength in polls.

headline: Letters
text: The Future of a Famous Cheese

headline: They’re More Evolved That Way
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Night Is Steamy, Yankees Are Steamed
text: BALTIMORE, June 26  Andy Pettitte was bothered by his performance Tuesday night, when he walked five Baltimore Orioles and mostly got away with it. But Pettitte sees what is happening around him, and it is almost too much to take.

headline: 2 Oil Firms Are Defiant in Venezuela
text: HOUSTON, June 26 — ConocoPhillips and Exxon Mobil refused on Tuesday to meet Venezuela’s deadline to reach an agreement on ceding control of their major oil production ventures, in what could be their imminent separation from billions of dollars in investments.

headline: How Could There Be Ballet Before the Swans Learned to Dance?
text: It’s hard to imagine what the art of ballet was before “Swan Lake” came along. It classically encapsulates so very much about the whole romance of ballet: the Age of Chivalry; the destiny-laden call to the lakeside and the quest to save the enchanted maiden; the swan-

headline: China’s Leader Vows to Uphold One-Party Rule
text: BEIJING, June 26  President Hu Jintao said attempts to modernize China’s political system must not jeopardize one-party rule, setting a conservative tone before an important Communist Party conclave in the fall.

headline: Oden Is Solid on and Off the Court
text: Greg Oden held a tissue in his left hand, coughed like a truck rumbling through Times Square and graciously extended his right hand.

headline: For a Future That’s Always Rosy
text: HIDDEN within our current tastes and penchants are the persistent and often ignoble residues of our former selves. I call it the Holly Golightly-Lula Mae Principle. Allow me to demonstrate how it works.

headline: Pick Your Poison: Fists or Fireballs
text: The gasping, grunting and oozing hard-body slab that muscles, and sometimes crawls, through "Live Free or Die Hard" sure looks like John McClane. Older if apparently no wiser, the blue-collar super-cop from the "Die Hard" franchise has lost his hair, his foul mouth and apparently his nicotine itch, but he still has the same knack for trouble, the adrenaline-pumping, cheerfully anarchic kind that causes cars to ignite, bodies to fly, eardrums to pop and hearts to race and gladden. He's also lost his sneer, but sneering is cheap, and movies are expensive, especially when your star has pushed past 50 and slid off the power lists.

headline: Differences Remain at Nato-Russia Meeting
text: Russian and NATO leaders meeting in Moscow mitigated confrontational statements but failed to resolve disagreements on a range of issues, including a European arms-reduction treaty and American missile-defense plans, ahead of President Vladimir V. Putin’s meeting with President Bush in Maine next week. Jaap de Hoop Scheffer, the NATO secretary general, advised all sides to “lower the volume.”

headline: Frump-Free Cooking: The Look That Sizzles
text: FLIP through the channels or scan the bookstores and the look is there in all its glory: sort of tight, sort of low-cut, definitely sexy. It’s the new uniform of women who work with food.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Looking Ahead

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about reaction at a reunion of Antioch College alumni to a decision to close the college misstated the number of students who enrolled in 2006. It was 130  not 63, which was the number of new students in 2005.

headline: Styrofoam, Food and Public Schools
text: Public school parents in Brooklyn have started a movement to dump styrofoam tableware in 1,400 city schools.

headline: Frugal Traveler: South Dakota & Nebraska
text: The Frugal Traveler visits a cave in South Dakota, then heads to Nebraska to see Carhenge, a replica of Stonehenge made with cars.

headline: Independent Label, Partisan Vote
text: Michael R. Bloomberg, once a Democrat and then a Republican, rattled the presidential campaign last week with his announcement that he now considers himself to be a political independent. People wondered if it was just the latest calculated step by the billionaire mayor in a quest for the White House.

headline: 36 Hours in Savannah
text: New ideas join the old in the heart of the gracious South.

headline: Asymptote Manhattan
text: Images from the architects' new condo project on Perry Street.

headline: A Brief History of Wooden Sawhorses
text: For decades, wooden sawhorse barriers have been a mainstay at parades and demonstrations in New York City, from the arrival of the Beatles in 1964 to the New Year’s Eve celebrations in Times Square each year.

headline: Bottles, Bottles Everywhere but Nowhere to Recycle
text: Check out the picture of Rome on the front page of Tuesday’s IHT It tells two stories: 1. As the article notes, there is too much drinking on the streets of Rome’s historic center. 2. (And this is more important from our blog’s point of view) There are way too few garbage cans in Rome’s center city and no recycling bins whatsoever. So…in this blistering hot town, people who drink bottled water, soda, beer, booze, whatever, are more or less forced to put bottles and cans into general garbage, or (often) just leave them somewhere street side. There is no way to recycle.

headline: Saudi Telecom Phones In Malaysia Deal
text: Saudi Telecom, the largest phone company in Saudi Arabia, bought a 25 percent stake in Maxis Communications of Malaysia for 11.4 billion riyals ($3 billion) to tap growth in developing markets like India. Saudi Telecom bought the shares from a Malaysian billionaire, T. Ananda Krishnan, who last month offered to buy the 40 percent that he did not already control in Maxis, which is based in Kuala Lumpur and is the country’s largest mobile phone operator.

headline: Coca-Cola Buys Stake in a Bottler in Tokyo
text: Coca-Cola will buy a 34 percent stake in the Tokyo Coca-Cola Bottling Company to increase sales in Japan after volume declined last year. The Japanese subsidiary of Coca-Cola will buy new shares of the closely held Tokyo-based bottler, the companies said in a statement. The financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: Manulife Inks Deal to Boost Wealth Management Business
text: Manulife Financial, a Canadian life insurance company, said it would buy the Berkshire-TWC Financial Group‘s mutual fund and securities dealerships to bolster its Canadian wealth management business. Manulife said the deal would double its number of Canadian wealth management advisers and triple its assets under administration in that business.

headline: Alstom Powers Up Deal for Spanish Wind Company
text: Alstom, a maker of coal-fired power stations, agreed to buy Ecotècnia of Spain to enter the wind energy market. Alstom will pay 350 million euros ($471 million) for Ecotècnia, which also makes solar panels, it said.

headline: U.S. Sues Merrill on Treatment of Muslim Analyst
text: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sued Merrill Lynch on Tuesday over its treatment of an Iranian Muslim, who the commission says was an analyst in the bank’s global markets and investment banking model development group.

headline: 3 Ex-Officers at Countrywide Admit Insider Trading
text: Three former executives of Countrywide Financial, a mortgage lender, have agreed to plead guilty to insider trading in the week prior to the release of a disappointing earnings report, federal prosecutors have said.

headline: An Entrepreneur Makes Death a Business
text: J. Robert Hillier has spent the last 41 years spreading architectural gems across the United States. Now, he is into death and destruction. Why not? Entrepreneurs get to do whatever they want.

headline: Hong Kong’s $2 million dinner backdrop
text: Lisa Lam and Joyce Lau from the IHT’s Hong Kong office weigh in on dining with a view:

headline: Regulators to Examine C.D.O. Investments
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission has a string of potentially overzealous hedge funds in its sights.

headline: Not Yet Legal for the Street, but a Whiz on a Tractor
text: Nicole Snyder doesn't have a driver’s license, but she is in control when it comes to piloting a 7,000-horsepower jet tractor.

headline: The  16-Page Splasher Manifesto
Jurors Are Expected to Get Conrad Black’s Case Today
text: After nearly 15 weeks in court, lawyers in the trial of the former media baron Conrad M. Black neared the end of their arguments Tuesday, with the jury expected to begin poring over 100 pages of instructions starting Wednesday.

headline: The Cyclone's 80th Birthday
text: Stilt walkers entertained crowds, a brass band played, Miss Cyclone made an appearance and a few octogenarians took a ride, all in honor of the Cyclone at Coney Island.

headline: In Silicon Valley Real Estate, Steady but Cautious Growth Returns
text: Silicon Valley’s economy, notorious for its booms and busts as it rode each new wave of technology, is on the upswing again. Led by a variety of industries, including clean energy, biotechnology and new media, the regional economy, this time more sober than speculative, is adding jobs. And Thomson Financial says venture capital investments in Silicon Valley rose to $10.5 billion last year, the highest level since 2001.

headline: Nordstrom to Sell Façonnable to Lebanese Investment Firm, Report Says
text: Nordstrom appears to have reached a deal to sell its Façonnable chain to a Lebanese private equity firm for about $200 million, The New York Post reported. The report said that Façonnable employees received word of the impending sale on Tuesday, along with the potential for some job cuts.

headline: Citigroup in Talks to Buy Automated Trading Desk, Report Says
text: Citigroup is in advanced talks to buy Automated Trading Desk, an electronic trading firm, for about $700 million, The Wall Street Journal reported. The report noted that the deal marks the latest push by the banking giant into the trading of stocks by computerized programs rather than by people.

headline: Blackstone Said to Quit Coles Bidding Group
text: The Blackstone Group has become the latest to pull out of a consortium bidding for the Coles Group, the Australian retailer, Reuters reported, improving the prospects of a rival suitor, Wesfarmers.

headline: Cash in Hand, Hedge Funds Bail on Big Lots
text: Big Lots, the nation’s largest seller of overstocked and discontinued items and whose fare includes organic plant food made from chicken droppings, is losing its novelty for its hedge fund investors, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Quayle Joins in Offering a $500 Million ‘Blank Check’
text: Former Vice President Dan Quayle and the ex-Notre Dame football coach Lou Holtz are joining with the chief executive of the sporting goods maker K2 in a bid to raise as much as $500 million in the second-largest initial public offering of a “blank check” shell company on record.

headline: London’s Candover Lands Stork
text: A London buyout shop, Candover has made an offer valuing Stork, a Dutch conglomerate, at 1.5 billion euros ($2 billion). The companies said Tuesday that Candover will offer 47 euros per share, an 11 percent premium to Stork’s closing price June 18, the day before talks were announced a week ago.

headline: Solar Cell Start-Up Raises $15 Million
text: As solar start-ups continue to attract the eye of venture capital investors, a solar cell developer Stion said it had raised $15 million in a second round of venture capital led by Lightspeed Venture Partners to advance ongoing work in thin-film materials science.

headline: French Director’s Production Company Prices I.P.O.
text: EuropaCorp, the film production company founded by the French director Luc Besson, set a price range on Tuesday for a stock market listing, which it said would raise more than 70 million euros ($94.2 million).

headline: Spitzer Weighs In on Suffolk Dispute — and Aqueduct’s Future
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer said Tuesday, after a speech to the state broadcasters association, that he had talked to the principal players in the dispute between the Suffolk County executive, Steve Levy, and the State Assembly. “Things are at a boiling point; perhaps things can calm down and we can reduce it at best to, at least to a simmer and probably below that,” the governor said.

headline: Carlyle Says Going Public Is an Option
text: The Carlyle Group is apparently evaluating an option to go public, despite speculation  that the private equity industry’s boom may be close to hitting a wall and the news that the Blackstone Group‘s stock closed below its offering price Tuesday.

headline: Youngest Player Wins Old-Timers Tournament
text: Alexander Khalifman, 41, has won a tournament in Bazna, Romania, that ran from June 15 to 26. What made the tournament unusual was that the field was made up almost entirely of great players from the 1970s and 1980s. What Khalifman, who won the World Chess Federation championship in 1999, was doing in the field is anybody’s guess, but he took advantage of his invitation. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the tournament by scrolling down to where it says “Vizualizare.”

headline: Ex-Comverse Chief Relied On Counsel, Lawyers Say
text: Lawyers for Jacob Alexander, the fugitive founder and former chief executive of Comverse Technology who faces 35 criminal counts in the United Sates stemming from backdated options, said Tuesday that he relied on lawyers and accountants when dealing with the securities.

headline: Two Billion-Plus Deals for Bain Capital
text: Bain Capital agreed to buy the Guitar Center, a retailer of musical instruments, for about $1.9 billion in cash. In a separate deal, Bain said it would acquire Germany’s biggest yacht maker, Bavaria Yachtbau, for about 1.3 billion euros ($1.75 billion).

headline: More Buyout Jitters: Bond Offering Is Postponed
text: Investors looking for signs that the buyout boom of the past two years may be hitting a wall have two new ones to ponder. US Foodservice, the American unit of the Dutch supermarket Royal Ahold, has postponed its sale of $650 million in bonds that were expected to finance the unit’s equity buyout. Before the decision, US Foodservice had twice scaled back its debt offering to help finance its $7.1 billion buyout by the equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Clayton Dubilier & Rice.

headline: A Restaurant War, Rising Rents and the Last Day of School
text: Can a restaurant’s distinctive themes — the shade of paint, the selection of chairs and stools, the layout and materials of the bar, not to mention the recipes and choice of salad dressing — be considered intellectual property?

headline: Campaign Cash: Clinton’s Expectations
text: Is Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign about to beat its own fundraising expectations? Or, perhaps, has it been low-balling them?

headline: CommScope to Buy Cable Maker for $2.6 Billion
text: CommScope, a maker of communications equipment, said Wednesday it would buy the Andrew Corporation for $15 per share, or about $2.6 billion. Last year, CommScope offered to buy Andrew, which sells cables and antennas, but quickly withdrew its bid.

headline: Dow Jones Accord In Place, But Incomplete
text: Despite reports that the board of directors at Dow Jones and the News Corporation had reached an agreement in principle yesterday on protecting the editorial independence of The Wall Street Journal, a firm accord between the two parties that would help pave the way for a takeover is not yet a reality, The New York Times noted.

headline: Slide Show: The Cyclone’s 80th Birthday
text: In honor of the Cyclone’s 80th birthday in Coney Island, a brass band played, stilt walkers entertained, Miss Cyclone appeared and a few octogenarians took a ride.

headline: The Alphabet Soup of E-Mail
text: Q. How do I use S.M.T.P. and P.O.P. in setting up e-mail programs?

headline: Tip of the Week: Search Engines
text: TIP OF THE WEEK: Search engines have shortcuts to all kinds of information, like stock quotes and gasoline prices, even song lyrics. In Google or Yahoo, for example, type in phrases like "teaspoons in a pint" and hit the Search button to get unit and measuring information. Both sites can also give you basic currency conversions: Type in "1 USD in GBP" to get a rough idea of the dollar's strength against the British pound sterling. There's more information for using these features at www.google.com/help/features.html and at tools.search.yahoo.com/shortcuts.

headline: Once Upon a Radical Time on the Lower East Side
text: Clayton Patterson — ex-teacher, artist, photojournalist, documentarian, as he describes himself — is a man obsessed. His first anthology, “Captured: A Lower East Side Film/Video History,” published in 2005, took up 586 pages. His latest anthology, “Resistance: A Radical Social and Political History of the Lower East Side,” weighs in at 624 pages.

headline: Forging a Deal on Guantanamo
The iPhone Challenge: Keep It Quiet
text: David Pogue looks at the features of the new iPhone, as furtively as possible.

headline: Pretty in Portugal
text: Exterior

headline: More Than Just Squatting (on Domain Names)
text: UPDATE: My editing on this post added language about the various types of businesses built on domains that does not match the way the industry refers to these practices. I wrote a post to correct and explain here.–Saul Hansell, Bits Editor

headline: 2008: Mrs. Edwards vs. Ann Coulter
text: Elizabeth Edwards, the wife of Democratic presidential candidate John Edwards, keeps making headlines.

headline: No More Money from Murdoch?
text: In Rupert Murdoch’s attempt to buy Dow Jones, the question of price has been on the back burner of late, overshadowed by negotiations over a framework for protecting the editorial independence of the company’s flagship publication, The Wall Street Journal.

headline:
Living With Music:
A Playlist by Kevin Young
text: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for “Living With Music,” a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage. Why? Because books and music, on good days, just seem to go together. And because the “celebrity playlists” on iTunes never get around to asking writers to pitch in.

headline: Poison Ivy, Now With Stronger Poison
text: Summer is back, and so is poison ivy, stronger than ever. The weed is flourishing this year, growing faster and more toxic, and a pair of studies flagged by The Wall Street Journal say an upswing in greenhouse gases is to blame.

headline: Yuri Ivanovich Nosenko
text: A Russian defector held in a secret CIA prison in the U.S. to determine whether he was a legitimate defector or a Russian intelligence plant. Nothing new. The tale has been told in numerous books and articles over the years.

headline: Beyond the Jewels, Unfinished Business
text: Releasing the family jewels is a big step forward for the C.I.A. But don’t revel in the glasnost just yet. There are still troves upon troves of documents that the C.I.A., F.B.I., and other intelligence agencies are keeping locked away. Dirty tricks from the 1960’s and ’70s make for interesting reading. But understanding what went wrong before 9/11 makes for better intelligence.

headline: At AOL, the World’s News Is One Big Blog
text: Blogging and news is in the air here at Bits, so we were interested to note that AOL has restructured its entire news site as a blog.

headline: A Business Opportunity
text: How would you like a business where you have to sell expensive items at low margins in a fast changing business to fickle consumers? And oh yes, Wal-Mart is coming on strong as a competitor.

headline: Who’s at the Copa? (Group C)
text: The third and final quartet features the monsters of the tournament, Argentina, along with a very experimental United States side. Paraguay and Colombia complete Group C, making it very difficult for the American to advance.

headline: Go-Shopping Like Paris Hilton
text: Her name is everywhere.

headline: IRAN GAS RATION
text: Two gas stations were torched early Wednesday in Tehran as angry Iranians protested fuel rationing measures suddenly enforced by the government, while many other Iranians lined up to fill their tanks.

headline: Gas Rationing Prompts Riots in Iran
text: Angry drivers set fire to at least two gas stations overnight in Tehran after the government announced that gasoline rationing would begin.

headline: Lanvin, Soup to Nuts
text: In between packing my party dresses for couture — isn’t that a hoot? — I stopped by to see Alber Elbaz’s early spring clothes for Lanvin. You can never be too early in fashion these days. Elbaz has been broadening Lanvin’s concept, thinking more along the lines of a supermarket spree, something here, something there, and has come out with pajamas (Carole Lombardish), prêt-à-porter wedding dresses (throw on and go to the alter or justice of the peace), T-shirts, travel clothes and mainstay looks that will remain in stock. I especially loved a creamy white shirtdress in double-layered silk inspired by a man’s dress shirt, with a triple-layer navy chiffon minicoat. A super-simple dress made from two asymmetrical squares of black silk showed how Elbaz is such a pragmatic innovator. His other accomplishment is to bring clear design integrity to shapes that appear simple, in fabrics like polyester (yes!), washed silk and organdy, so that the clothes are hard to copy.

headline: They Don’t Make Gallows Humor Like They Used To
text: Patrick Knight, sentenced to death for a double murder in Texas, promised to tell a joke as part of his last words at his execution. After soliciting jokes in a Web campaign dubbed “Dead Man Laughing” and also on CNN, he received over 1,300 submissions. But when the time came last night, his plan crashed and burned, yielding no laughs from what was perhaps the toughest crowd ever.

headline: Of Trabants and a Belvedere
text: If you haven’t read Mark Landler’s article on the Trabant, I recommend checking it out.

headline: It’s Never Too Early to Line Up for That Phone

headline: The Reviews Are In

headline: iPhone Keyboard Secrets
text: As iPhone Week continues here on Pogue’s Posts, here’s a bunch of cool info about the virtual keyboard that nobody–I mean, not Apple, not the bloggers, not the reviewers–has said anything about. headline: Now on the Clock … Tedium
text: The National Basketball Association draft at Madison Square Garden tonight is unlikely to have anything that surpasses Brady Quinn's totem act two months ago. Quinn holds the career record for touchdowns at Notre Dame, won the Sammy Baugh Trophy as college football's best quarterback and is even second cousins with one of the bratty kids from "Home Improvement." But, to this point, the most enduring image of his career involved him sitting at a table and doing nothing.

headline: New York’s Parks: A Tale of Two Cities?
text: “Parks in poorer neighborhoods are more likely to be in worse condition than parks in wealthier neighborhoods.”

headline: Jarring
text: My lasting image of Rwanda, the Democratic Republic of Congo and Burundi will be the children and the jarring contrast between their poverty and their beauty.

headline: What We Can Do to Help
text: One of the most common comments we get goes: “What can I do to help? You guys talk so much about the problems, and now I want to do something.” I don’t like to bring up problems without proposing solutions. In this second-to-last entry, I propose concrete action steps to channel passion and idealism into activism and action.

headline: ‘Paper View’
text: “Paper View” was a film I’d wanted to make for a long time, and July 4th provided me with the perfect excuse.

headline: Blackstone Flipping
text: Shares in Blackstone, the private equity company that went public last week in what looked like a successful initial public offering, declined again this morning. But this is one company that knows how to time an investment.

text: Dealbook reports that the question of price has returned to the front burner in the Wall Street Journal negotiations:

headline: Making Podcast Ads More Nimble
text: Fans of Wired, Epicurious and other Conde Nast outlets download nearly 500,000 podcasts from those titles per month, and Conde Nast says it has just found a way to better make money from those clips.

headline: The Family Jewels
text: The Times's Tim Weiner discusses the importance of the newly declassified C.I.A. documents known as the "family jewels."

headline: Ode to Jersey
text: Almost all states have an official state song. New York, of course, has “I Love New York.” Some states have more than one state song. Connecticut has a state song (“Yankee Doodle”) as well as a state cantata (the ever-catchy “The Nutmeg”). Massachusetts has — and we’re not kidding here — a state song, a state ceremonial march, a state patriotic march, a state glee club song, a state polka, a state ode, as well as a state folk song (Arlo Guthrie’s “Massachusetts”). Only New Jersey has none.

headline: Cuauhtémoc Blanco: Comic Muse
text: There really is no equivalent for Cuauhtémoc Blanco, not anywhere. He is the clown king of Mexican soccer, but with fire, guile, deadly effectiveness and an enormous ego all part of the mix as well. He was left off the 2006 World Cup team — too much of a jerk, supposedly. But now that the national team is run by Hugooolllll Sanchez (no slouch in the ego department himself), Cuauhtémoc is back with El Tri. Which means greater entertainment value for us all.

headline: Toulouse, the Trek
text: In “Moulin Rouge,” John Huston’s 1952 biopic of the French painter and absinthe-bucket Henri Toulouse-Lautrec, Jose Ferrer played the lead – entirely on his knees. The action begins in a Parisian bar, Toulouse-Lautrec sits supping his deathly-green mouthwash – the barman polishes the glasses. Then the painter clambers down off his stool. Suddenly we’re in his point of view, looking up at the great zinc-topped escarpment of the counter; the barman leans over, peers down at us, and speaks the first line of the movie: ‘”So long, Toulouse!”

headline: Things That Go Boom
text: The 4th of July is one week away. Time to start thinking about blowing things up.

headline: WWE Scrambles After Double Murder-Suicide
text: Following a grisly murder scene created by a former champion, World Wrestling Entertainment is trying mightily to cut ties with a deed that echoes a sport that stages brawls between feuding, well-built men.

headline: For Blackstone Co-Founder, YouTube Clip Hits Home
text: Most parents would be elated if their child’s debut novel got a mention in The New Yorker. But Pete Peterson, senior chairman of the Blackstone Group, seems less than thrilled about it.

headline: Hot-Dog Champ Is Coming to Coney Island, Manager Insists
text: Takeru Kobayashi’s debilitating jaw pain has generated widespread speculation in the world of competitive eating that he might not be able to take part in the Nathan’s Famous July 4 International Hot-Dog Eating Contest next week — a competition he has won every year since 2001.

headline: New Wells Chief Charts Stay-at-Home Deal Strategy
text: John Stumpf, the new chief of Wells Fargo, said Wednesday that it is “highly unlikely” that the bank will make any big acquisitions outside its existing geographical markets. He did not rule it out, though, telling Reuters that, while “we don’t want to be big for big’s sake,” Wells Fargo would nevertheless “look at a larger transaction out of market.”

headline: After 3 Years, Adelphia’s Rigases Receive Prison Date
text: A federal judge on Wednesday ordered Adelphia‘s founder and his son to report to prison on Aug. 13, nearly three years after they were convicted in one of the largest corporate frauds in the nation’s history.

headline: Polling Young Americans
text: A 20-year-old student discusses his responses to a CBS/New York Times/MTV poll.

text: And The Lede swings from global warming to one unlikely city breaking out the sleds and parkas.

text: For the last year it has become increasingly clear that the Darfur virus has been infecting and destabilizing Central African Republic to the southwest. Last year’s win-a-trip went there, and since then the situation has gotten worse. In addition, a 27-year-old French woman was just killed there, while working for Doctors Without Borders, and so humanitarian groups are going to have to pull back. Now Amnesty International has a new report on the situation:

text: He led Britain for 10 long years, and on his retirement day … he got a new job.

text: Tonight at 845 Eastern time, we’ll bring you our live play-by-play account of the Mexico-Brazil match. Victor Mather will provide the commentary for this marquee first-round matchup.

text: Some stories you can pretty much write before they happen. But we write them and people read them in a collective act of mutual reassurance that at least some parts of our crazy world is still predictable.

headline: Video: 4 Million Styrofoam Trays a Week
text: Or 850,000 a day. That’s how many pass through the lunch rooms of New York City public schools when classes are in session.

text: Paul and I thought the main floor was working well — except for the kitchen.

headline: Fidelity National Rings Up $1.8 Billion for eFunds
text: Fidelity National Information Services said Wednesday that it would acquire EFD/eFunds, a processor of electronic fund transfers and prepaid card transactions, for $1.8 billion, linking two of the nation’s major financial processors.

headline: Spying on Reporters: Part II
text: The “Family Jewel” documents show in fine detail how the C.I.A., at the direction of high level officials in the Kennedy and Nixon administration, spied on journalists. Top government leaders were infuriated by leaks of classified information to reporters – a view shared by subsequent presidents, including George W. Bush – and instructed the C.I.A. to employ its full arsenal of spy techniques to hunt down the leakers. In some cases, reporters’ phones were wiretapped, journalists were tailed and observation posts were set up near their offices to track their comings and goings and their visitors. All this was done despite a legal ban on C.I.A. domestic spying.

headline: Young Voters on 2008
text: A recent New York Times/CBS News/MTV poll asked young voters about their political views and their opinion, so far, of the candidates and key issues in the 2008 election. The nationwide telephone poll was conducted June 15-23 with 659 young adults ages 17-29. Here are follow-up interviews with some of the respondents.

headline: New Center Has Lots of Clinton Ties
text: A coterie of national security and defense experts from the last Clinton administration have formed a new Washington think tank, the Center for a New American Security, that looks an awful lot like a shadow policy apparatus for Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign.

headline: Styrofoam, Food and Public Schools
text: Public school parents in Brooklyn have started a movement to dump styrofoam tableware in 1,400 city schools.

headline: Sidelined by Inspectors, a Pizza Place Reopens
text: After two weeks on the edge of their seats, pizza lovers have a reason to rejoice. Di Fara Pizza, the much-praised Brooklyn pizzeria, reopened on Saturday after satisfying the city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, which has shut the restaurant down twice this year, once on March 15 and again on June 4, for health-code violations.

headline: Bear Stearns’ Asset Management Chief Takes Charge in Fund Crisis
text: The chief executive of Bear Stearns‘s asset management division, Richard Marin, is taking a stronger role in managing its two troubled hedge funds and appointed the head of the investment bank’s mortgage unit head to save one of the funds, two sources familiar with the decision told Reuters.

Bryson may have been born in Des Moines, but he’s out to save England from its sloppy tendencies. The article’s author, Stefanie March, has a nice dry style:

text: Finding a silver lining in the cloud created by “Bong Hits 4 Jesus”: Writing on The Agitator, his personal blog, Reason senior editor Radley Balko makes the case that Morse v. Frederick “was actually a victory for drug reform advocates, not a setback.”

After that came his banishment from the Argentine national team and from some of the top clubs in Europe.

headline: Answers from the Transportation Commissioner, Part 3
text: The city’s new transportation commissioner, Janette Sadik-Khan, took questions from City Room readers through the week. Sorry, we are no longer taking questions for this feature.

headline: Perspective on the Jewels From the C.I.A.’s Chief Historian
text: For more than 30 years, the Family Jewels have clouded the C.I.A.’s reputation, even though most of their contents have long been known from official reports and ad hoc disclosures. William Colby — who oversaw the compilation of the Jewels while serving as the agency’s operations chief and director-designate — is the source of some durable misconceptions about them. In his memoir, Honorable Men (p. 340), Colby says that the Jewels consist of “693 pages of possible violations of, or at least questionable activities in regard to, the C.I.A.’s legislative charter”; that among the contents are “bizarre and tragic cases wherein the Agency experimented with mind-control drugs”; and that accompanying them was “a separate and even more secret annex” that “summarized a 1967 survey of C.I.A.’s involvement in assassination attempts or plans against Castro, Lumumba and Trujillo.”

headline: The Winning Hand
text: How Peter Homer, an amateur inventor from Maine, bested NASA technology and built a better space glove.

headline: Paulson Criticizes Bills Raising Buyout Taxes
text: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. warned that raising taxes on hedge funds and buyout firms may have “unintended consequences” and said Congress shouldn’t target firms that go public, such as the Blackstone Group, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Our New Look
text: You probably noticed the blog’s new banner. It’s designed by the always funny and far-ranging Gordon Hull. Aside from presiding over his own burger club, Gordie is a founder of Surface to Air, a New York-based company with branches in Paris and Tokyo that provides creative direction for folks like Marc Jacobs, Adidas and Nike. Surface to Air is a little hard to quantify — it also produces books and has its own clothing line and a store in Paris, on rue Charlot. Gordie’s banner looks, I think, suitably couture.

headline: Nested Tug-of-Wars
text: The other day in an interview in The New York Times Magazine, Al Gore’s daughter Kristin revealed that when she was a child, she couldn’t stand to think about wrists. All those veins and tendons. Probably didn’t like to gnaw chicken bones either. Too squeamish.

headline: Edwards-Coulter P.S.
text: During MSNBC’s “Hardball” exchange between Elizabeth Edwards and Ann Coulter yesterday (see earlier post today), Ms. Coulter echoed an audience question: “Yeah, why isn’t John Edwards making this call?”

headline: On YouTube, Candidates Get an Eyeful
text: “Bjorn,” an imposing figure in a two-horned Viking helmet and a thick, black beard – the stick-on kind – wonders how the candidates plan to deal with illegal immigration. Someone else has “a very, very serious question” – about aliens: Will the candidates agree to Congressional hearings on the existence of extraterrestrials?

headline: DealBook: Is LinkedIn Getting Ready for an I.P.O.?
text: Our savvy friends over at DealBook take stock of the reports, including one by VentureBeat, that LinkedIn, the professionals’ social networking site, is about to go public.

headline: Politics, Soccer … or Death!
text: CARACAS — After enjoying last night’s opening ceremonies with Bolivian president Evo Morales and addled Argentine soccer deity Diego Maradona, Venezuelan president Hugo Chávez left the country today for Russia, Belarus and Iran. Chávez may be on a shopping trip for more Russian military equipment, including a couple of submarines, but the main effect will be to switch everyone’s focus from Chavista politics to the Copa América.

headline: The Selling of Coney Island
text: The selling of Coney Island's Astroland Park to developers leaves one last park in the amusement district: Deno's Wonder Wheel Park.

headline: The A.M.A. Gets Under Your Skin
text: On Monday, the delegates to the annual meeting in Chicago of the American Medical Association endorsed what could only be described as a cautious committee report on the role of implanted radio identification tags in patient care. The three recommendations were that doctors make sure that they get informed consent from patients before using such tags, they they not program any medical information into them without making sure it would be as secure as normal medical records, and that they support research into uses of the devices.

headline: FINAL: Mexico 2, Brazil 0
text: Final! Mexican football gets a big shot in the arm with a great win over a Brazilian squad filled with stars. El Tri looked poor in nearly all their Concacaf matches, but this game shows they’re still not far off the world’s elite teams. Let’s see if they can keep it up throughout the tournament! (And I hope some of you bet them to win at 6-1.)

headline: Building a Winner
text: At least a couple of N.B.A. teams hope their pick tonight carries the franchise to a championship. Play general manager: How would you build a winning team, by focusing on the draft or on trades and free agency?

headline: The Other Side of the Desk
text: I will always remember that day in 2004 when I sat on the business side of a Lieutenant Colonel’s desk as he “invited” me to go to Iraq with his battalion. Now, as a company commander in the Utah National Guard, one of my duties has been to send others to fight the war in Iraq.

headline: Cinema Days
text: Editor’s note: An earlier version of this column misquoted a phrase from an episode of “Monty Python’s Flying Circus”; it has since been corrected.

headline: Your Comments on my Climate Change Column
text: My Thursday column is about climate change and its impact on Africa. Please post your comments below.

headline: Answers Are Within, and That May Be the Problem
text: I was sitting here at sweltering Camden Yards on Wednesday night, trying to come up with fresh verbs to describe what we’re watching every night. Slumping, sliding, stumbling, sputtering. They all apply, and many more. The remaining 87 games could test anyone’s vocabulary.

headline: White House Rebuffs Congress in Firings Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON, June 28 — President Bush moved one step closer to a constitutional showdown with Democrats today, as the White House asserted executive privilege in refusing to comply with Congressional subpoenas for documents related to the dismissal of federal prosecutors.

headline: Citigroup Unit in Australia Cleared of Insider Trading
text: SYDNEY, Australia, Thursday, June 28 (Bloomberg News) — Citigroup, the world’s largest financial company, was cleared of insider trading in Australia on Thursday in a case that challenged the way investment banks operate.

headline: A New Genre on Wall St.: Bailout Blog
text: Over the weekend of June 17, executives at Bear Stearns scrambled to avert the collapse of two hedge funds.

headline: Glavine Wins No. 297 in Game With Rain, but Little Thunder
text: Rain delayed the start of last night’s game at Shea Stadium by 54 minutes. The game was called after the top of the sixth inning after a second rain delay of 91 minutes. In between, the Mets squeezed in a 2-0 victory against the St. Louis Cardinals.

headline: The ‘Beerman’ Goes Flat
text: Things are not exactly in a groove for Mark Johnson, the happy-go-lucky Champions Tour player known as “Beerman.” He has played unevenly, often plagued by a string of bogeys during rounds that raise his anxiety level and take him out of contention. If he doesn’t turn around his game, he risks losing easy entry into tournaments in 2008.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 10 P.M. (NBC) STUDIO 60 ON THE SUNSET STRIP Since a penultimate three-part, three-week episode wasn’t enough for Aaron Sorkin to wrap up the loose ends, this series finale should finally resolve the hostage crisis and let us know whether Jordan (Amanda Peet, above with Bradley Whitford) survives childbirth.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An essay in Science Times on Tuesday about the ability to encode information in a genome referred incorrectly to the number of bases, or letters, in the genetic code of a bacterium in which researchers wrote the E=mc2 formula. The bacterium’s genome has about 4.2 million bases, not 400 million.

headline: Learning to Mix Tennis Career and Motherhood
text: WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 — There are times when trying to be both a mother to a 5-year-old and one of the world’s best tennis players does not seem a good match.

headline: Blair to Tackle Economics but Not Peace Efforts, a Task Reserved for Rice
text: WASHINGTON, June 27  In his new role as envoy to the Middle East, Tony Blair will be charged with shoring up Palestinian institutions, but not with trying to nail down a peace deal between Israelis and Palestinians because Condoleezza Rice, the secretary of state, is handling that job herself, administration officials said Wednesday.

headline: Our Gas Guzzlers, Their Lives
text: BUJUMBURA, Burundi

headline: This Is Not la Belle France, but Merrie Olde England?
text: PARIS, June 27 — “My poor man’s ‘Pastoral Symphony,’ ” Frederick Ashton said of his “Fille Mal Gardée,” which the Paris Opera Ballet is performing for the first time, proving once again that this choreographer was entirely too modest. In its enchanting vision of bucolic pleasures and the sensual joys of romantic love; its beautiful Ferdinand Hérold score (adapted and considerably expanded upon by John Lanchbery); and its charming countryside designs by Osbert Lancaster, Ashton’s work is a masterpiece with the lightest of touches. It is as capable of delighting audiences now as it must have been at its Royal Ballet premiere in London in 1960.

headline: 20 Decapitated Bodies Found in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, June 28 — Twenty decapitated bodies were found today in a predominantly Sunni village southeast of Baghdad, Iraqi police said.

headline: A Vanishing Tribe, but Well Dressed for Extinction
text: IT is a transitional time for Valentino — both the man and the institution.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A headline and a report in the “Arts, Briefly” column yesterday about the cancellation of a concert planned for Istanbul, and an effort to stimulate ticket sales for a concert in Johannesburg, misidentified the event whose organizers planned the concerts. It is Live Earth, not Live Aid.

headline: Movie Association Sues 2 Internet Sites
text: The Motion Picture Association of America, a trade organization for Hollywood’s largest film studios, sued two Internet sites, claiming they illegally post copyrighted material.

headline: Israelis Kill 11 Militants Inside Gaza; 2 Civilians Die
text: JERUSALEM, June 27 — At least 11 Palestinian militants and 2 civilians were killed Wednesday during Israeli raids in Gaza in the deadliest day of fighting since the Islamic militant group Hamas took control there nearly two weeks ago.

headline: Senators to Push for Registry of Drug Makers’ Gifts to Doctors
text: WASHINGTON, June 27  In the midst of a Senate hearing about the money and gifts that drug makers routinely provide to doctors, Senator Claire McCaskill mentioned that she had a brother who runs a restaurant.

headline: Pentagon Splits War-Support Contract 3 Ways
text: The Army announced yesterday that it had awarded contracts to feed, fuel and house American troops in the Iraq and Afghanistan wars, breaking the job into three $5 billion deals to separate companies rather than just one.

headline: That Time Again: Make Way for Tomatoes
text: I’VE got a tomato farm growing down in Maryland. About 20 different heirloom varieties, maybe 50 plants and still counting.

headline: Red State Welfare
text: Drive across the empty reaches of the Great Plains, from the lost promise of Valentine, Neb., to the shadowless side roads into Sunray, Tex., and what you see is a land that has lost its purpose. Many of the towns set in this infinity of flat have a listless look, with shuttered main streets and schools given over to the grave.

headline: Building a Winner
text: At least a couple of N.B.A. teams hope their pick tonight carries the franchise to a championship. Play general manager: How would you build a winning team, by focusing on the draft or on trades and free agency?

headline: The N.B.A.’s Dropouts
text: Cincinnati

headline: Abreu Gives It His All, but His All Is Nothing
text: BALTIMORE, June 27 — Bobby Abreu slapped Erik Bedard’s last pitch of the game to first base, then sprinted as if he had a chance to beat out the throw. He did not, but at least he hustled. It was all Abreu had, all the Yankees had on another exasperating evening. It was hardly enough against Bedard.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts yesterday about a Senate committee hearing on problems at the Smithsonian Institution misstated a finding of two reports on the institution last week. They said that the Smithsonian’s Board of Regents had failed to provide adequate oversight, not “inadequate” oversight. Because of another editing error, the article misstated one of the titles of Sheila P. Burke, a Smithsonian official. In addition to deputy secretary, she is chief operating officer, not chief financial officer.

headline: Congress Considers Action to Help Former N.F.L. Players
text: A House of Representatives subcommittee hearing on the N.F.L.’s divisive player-disability plan in Washington on Tuesday afternoon included one particularly ominous exchange.

headline: An iPod Has Global Value. Ask the (Many) Countries That Make It.
text: Who makes the Apple iPod? Here’s a hint: It is not Apple. The company outsources the entire manufacture of the device to a number of Asian enterprises, among them Asustek, Inventec Appliances and Foxconn.

headline: School Ruling Leaves Unanswered Questions
text: The Supreme Court ruling striking down voluntary plans to integrate schools in Seattle and Louisville, Ky., left hundreds of school districts struggling to assess whether they must change their policies using race as a factor in school assignments.

headline: The Sights,  the Sounds,  the Smells of Springtime in the U.S.
text: What do Americans do for sports in the spring? I asked this question, somewhat facetiously, when it worked out that I wouldn’t go overseas this year.

headline: Brief Power Failure Is Long Enough to Unsettle
text: It lasted less than an hour, but a power failure that left big sections of the Upper East Side and the Bronx without electricity yesterday afternoon stirred fears that there may be more dark days ahead this summer for Con Edison and its customers.

headline: A New Low for Clemens and the Yankees
text: BALTIMORE, June 27 — It feels like falling off a cliff, Joe Torre said Wednesday night after another loss, and the metaphor is appropriate. The Yankees had reached a high point before this trip, but suddenly they are plunging to depths never experienced in Torre’s 12 years as manager.

headline: Justices Reject Diversity Plans in Two Districts
text: WASHINGTON, June 28  With competing blocs of justices claiming the mantle of Brown v. Board of Education, a bitterly divided Supreme Court declared today that public school systems cannot seek to achieve or maintain integration through measures that take explicit account of a student’s race.

headline: Union to Help Charter Firm Start School in the Bronx
text: Green Dot Public Schools, a charter school operator from Los Angeles, is seeking to expand into New York with the cooperation of the teachers’ union.

headline: Transcript of the Third Democratic Primary Presidential Debate
text: The following is a transcript of the Democratic primary presidential debate on PBS. The participants were Senator Joseph Biden, Jr. (D-Del.); Senator Hillary Clinton (D-N.Y.); Senator Christopher Dodd (D-Conn.); Former Senator John Edwards (D-S.C.); Former Senator Mike Gravel (D-Ak); Representative Dennis Kucinich (D-Ohio); Senator Barack Obama (D-Ill.); and Gov. Bill Richardson (D-N.M.). The moderator was Tavis Smiley, host of “Tavis Smiley” on PBS. The panelists were Michel Martin, journalist and NPR host; Ruben Navarrette, Jr., nationally syndicated columnist; Dewayne Wickham, USA Today and Gannett News Service columnist. The debate took place at Howard University on Thursday, June 28, 2007. Transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency.

headline: The Spy Who Loved His Mother, Barely
text: The lighter side of espionage has pretty much fallen by the wayside. Something about 9/11, secret C.I.A. prisons and the poisoning of former K.G.B. agents in Europe has cast a pall on spy spoofs.

headline: Updating a House of Tomorrow
text: ATLANTA

headline: As Street Art Goes Commercial, a Resistance Raises a Real Stink
text: The covert campaign targeting street art began about seven months ago, with blobs of paint that appeared overnight, obscuring murals and wheat-pasted art on walls in Brooklyn and Lower Manhattan. Arcane messages were pasted at the sites, but it was difficult to ask for an explanation. The author was never identified.

headline: Brooklyn: Detective Testifies in Killing
text: Testifying yesterday in a murder trial, a retired detective said that the police had failed to build a case against a suspect for 17 years, despite having his name, address and Social Security number. The detective, William Powell, cited his own notes describing the defendant, Craig Sobel, 39, who was charged last year with killing Dominick Masseria, 17, in 1989 on the steps of a church in Dyker Heights. Mr. Sobel’s co-defendant is R. Lindley DeVecchio, a retired F.B.I. supervisor who has been charged with helping a prized informant commit murders on behalf of the mob. Justice Gustin L. Reichbach of State Supreme Court, who is overseeing the case, has told prosecutors to show good cause for delaying prosecution of the case, and has already dismissed the charges against another man, John Sinagra, because of the delay. Prosecutors said they planned to call 11 witnesses to show that their evidence against Mr. DeVecchio was properly obtained.

headline: Study Lauds Police Effort; Commissioner Criticizes Low Starting Pay
text: A police initiative in which narrowly drawn high-crime areas are flooded with rookie officers has played a major role in reducing New York City crime rates since 2003, even as a decade of declines in other large cities have shown signs of reversing, according to a statistical analysis released yesterday.

headline: In Quest for Passport, Patience, Time and Contacts Count
text: WASHINGTON, June 27 — A first-time United States passport applicant is required to pay a $97 fee. But some applicants can testify that the real cost is much higher.

headline: From a Risk of Down Two, a Big Reward
text: In the World Wide Bridge Contest played on June 1, the top finishers from Manhattan were R. Jay Becker and Scott Levine. Playing at Honors Bridge Club, 133 East 58th Street, Manhattan, they finished 8th in the United States and 43rd in the world. (Full details can be found at www.ecatsbridge.com.)

headline: Manhattan: Commuter Train Cocktails
text: Sales of alcohol on the trains and at the stations of the Long Island Rail Road and the Metro-North Railroad will continue. As expected, the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority declined yesterday to act on a proposal to ban alcoholic beverages on the commuter lines. A board committee that studied the issue said it could not find a correlation between alcohol sales and accidents or arrests involving drunken commuters. The authority’s chairman, Peter S. Kalikow, said the board would not take any action on the proposal, made last year by Mitchell H. Pally, a board member from Long Island. Mr. Pally said he would continue to press for a ban. “It is as if we were giving people a license to drink and drive, and that is unacceptable,” he said. The railroads sell beer, wine and hard liquor in some trains and stations.

headline: Giuliani and Abortion (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Brooklyn: Judge Blocks Public Access
text: A judge has declined to make public a motion to dismiss murder charges against a Brooklyn man accused of beating his stepdaughter to death. The motion was submitted on Tuesday to Justice L. Priscilla Hall in State Supreme Court by lawyers for the man, Cesar Rodriguez, 28, who has been charged with killing his stepdaughter, Nixzmary Brown, 7, in January 2006. In court, defense lawyers said that the motion was based on improper grand jury testimony by the victim’s 11-year-old sibling. Clerks for Justice Hall have denied repeated requests by reporters and a lawyer for The New York Times to view the document.
