The court attorney for Justice Hall, Machelle Sweeting, said she was reviewing the motion to determine whether portions that include or refer to grand jury testimony can be disclosed publicly. Prosecutors are scheduled to respond to the motion by July 6. Ms. Sweeting said she would determine whether to release the motion “most expeditiously as possible.”

headline: Wider Use of Latin Mass Likely, Vatican Officials Say
text: Pope Benedict XVI has signed a document that would allow more churches to adopt the old Latin Mass that largely faded from use during the 1960s, when the groundbreaking Second Vatican Council opened the door to worship in the local vernacular, Vatican officials say.

headline: Nielsen Adds to Cellphone Tracking
text: CELLPHONES are rapidly becoming ubiquitous and the Nielsen Company, the longtime monitor of television consumption, wants in.

headline: The Lobbyists Behind the Curtain
text: Senate Republicans need to be reminded of that breast-beating moment last January when they joined in the overwhelming 96-to-2 approval of stringent requirements for sunlight to be shed on the money ties between Congress and the lobbying industry. That worthy bill, and another strong measure the House approved in May, are suddenly hung up by the G.O.P.’s refusal to cooperate in the naming of Senate negotiators to a committee charged with reconciling the two versions of the legislation.

headline: Say ‘Thanks,’ and Smile (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: As Pakistan’s Chief Looks Ahead, Army Holds the Cards
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Speculation has been rife in political circles recently that Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, may not survive his wrangle with the chief justice and hold on to power, but a great silence emanates from the one place that may count the most: the barracks and the mess halls of the armed forces, the other great part of Pakistan’s ruling equation.

headline: A Keyboard Made for Those in Need of a ‘Kill Aliens’ Command
text: Any athlete will tell you that the difference between winning the silver and the gold is often raw talent, but good equipment can give anyone that extra push. That is what Microsoft is hoping to prove with its new Reclusa keyboard, created in collaboration with the gaming company Razer.

headline: Correction: Who, Me Take Running Class?
text: An article last week about dog owners who hire runners to exercise their pets misstated the surname of an owner in one reference and misstated the age of a runner. As noted elsewhere in the article, the dog owner is Richard Shein, not Stein, and Roy Scranton is 30, not 26.

headline: Housing and Hedge Funds
text: There may be a silver lining in the recent hedge fund debacle at Bear Stearns.

headline: China: Playboy to Open Entertainment Complex in Macao
text: Playboy Enterprises will open a 40,000-square-foot entertainment complex, the Playboy Mansion Macao, with dining, entertainment and retail shops, in Macao in late 2009, the chief executive, Christie Hefner, said. The complex will be part of the Macao Studio City complex, with the gambling operations run by a casino operator, Melco International Development, Ms. Hefner, left, said in an interview in Macao. Macao Studio City, a $2 billion joint venture between the Hong Kong-listed ESun Holdings and partners including Silver Point Capital, is next to the Lotus Bridge, which will link Macao and the mainland Chinese city of Zhuhai. It will include a film studio, a million-square-foot shopping mall, and gambling and convention sites.

headline: Reader Responses
text: The following are excerpts from reader responses to David Leonhardt’s June 27 column on labor unions:

headline: Treasury Secretary Announces Broad Review of U.S. Markets
text: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. announced yesterday that the Bush administration would start a formal review of how the United States regulates financial markets and hedge funds amid concerns over competition from overseas trading capitals.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: New York Festival Chooses Opening-Night Film

headline: Often-Asked iPhone Questions
text: With its new iPhone, Apple pulled off two masterful feats: creating the machine and creating the buzz around it.

headline: Young Hopes to Show Others How to Learn From Mistakes
text: ATLANTA, June 27  When someone mentioned to Dmitri Young of the Washington Nationals that he had changed a lot of things about himself lately, his face turned serious and his answer was succinct. “Kind of had to,” he said in a deep voice. “Either that or die.”

headline: A Summer’s Day, Made in the Shade
text: MOST people love sitting in the sun, but they also know the dangers of too much exposure (and leathery, wrinkled skin is the least of them). There are all types of umbrellas, pavilions and tents to provide the necessary shade. Some are portable and sized for an individual; others will cover a crowd.

headline: California Driving
text: Around Pebble Beach, big driving events usually involve Titleists and oversized clubheads. Not so in August, when the Monterey peninsula, California's golf mecca, turns its attention from pars to cars. Classic Car Week, a five-day celebration of vintage and exotic autos, held at various locations in and around Monterey, gets rolling Aug. 16. It's a major show that attracts car lovers from around the world, and PLAY newsletter readers who count themselves among the aficionados might do well to make plans now. It starts with vintage cars making a scenic tour of the peninsula, then picks up speed with races at Mazda Raceway Laguna Seca, featuring historic automobiles. Along the way, there will be vintage car auctions -- Steve McQueen's 1963 Ferrari GT250 will be among the items on the blocks -- and a splashy bash at the Quail Lodge in Carmel Valley, highlighted by Land Rover off-road test-drives and helicopter rides to catch the races at Laguna Seca. Tickets to each happening are sold separately.

headline: Russian Freed From Guantánamo Is Killed by Police Near Chechnya
text: MOSCOW, June 27  A Russian man who had been captured by American forces in Afghanistan and released from the detention center at Guantánamo Bay was killed Wednesday in a police raid near Chechnya, Russia’s intelligence service said.

headline: Flooding Sweeps Central Texas After Record-Breaking Rains
text: DALLAS, June 27  More than a foot and a half of rain flooded broad swaths of Central Texas on Tuesday and Wednesday, and a 13-year-old boy drowned in a Dallas suburb after he was swept away in a creek.

headline: A Latin American Fortune Is Assembled
text: CARLOS SLIM’S EMPIRE

headline: Dozens of Shiites Killed in Baghdad Attacks
text: BAGHDAD, June 28 — A spate of grisly attacks believed carried out by Sunni extremists killed dozens of Shiites around Baghdad over the past two days, just ahead of a planned huge march of devout Shiites through Sunni Arab heartlands to the remnants of a revered Shiite shrine.

headline: Antidepressants Rated Low Risk in Pregnancy
text: Taking an antidepressant like Prozac may increase a pregnant woman’s risk of having a baby with a birth defect, but the chances appear remote and confined to a few rare defects, researchers are reporting today.

headline: Ann Coulter’s Pointed Remarks Draw Edwardses’ Pointed Reply
text: WASHINGTON, June 27 — Never mind Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton. Some days, it seems as if the presidential campaign of John Edwards considers his main rival to be Ann Coulter, the conservative writer.

headline: New Film Studio Planned
text: Two Hollywood veterans announced plans yesterday to form a new independent film company with $200 million in financing secured from a consortium of private investors.

headline: Manhattan: Khat Smuggling Convictions
text: Three men were convicted in Federal District Court on Tuesday of charges related to the large-scale smuggling of khat, an African plant chewed as a stimulant. Prosecutors said that two of the men, Ali Awad, 43, and Abdi Emil Moge, 33, both of Minneapolis, were convicted of conspiracy to import khat, and the third, Abdullahi Hussein, 37, of Portland, Me., was convicted of conspiracy to distribute it. A fourth defendant, Abdi Nur Dahir, 32, of Minneapolis, was acquitted. The prosecutors said Mr. Awad and Mr. Moge were among the leaders of a smuggling group operating in the Horn of Africa, Western Europe and the United States. Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan, said the group used express mail and couriers to smuggle tons of khat into this country. He said that couriers frequently carried the leaves in suitcases on commercial flights.

headline: Corrections
text: An Op-Ed article on Sunday, about Tony Blair, misstated the circumstances of Prime Minister Clement Attlee’s ouster from office. His party did not lose control of Parliament in the 1950 election; it held on until a second election, in 1951. The article also misspelled the prime minister’s surname. It was Attlee, not Atlee.

headline: Lottery Numbers
White House Drops Vice President’s Dual-Role Argument as Moot
text: WASHINGTON, June 27 — The White House has dropped the argument that Vice President Dick Cheney’s dual role as president of the Senate meant that he could deny access to national archivists who oversee the handling of classified data in the executive branch.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Saturday about conflict over whether to lower flags in honor of soldiers who die in combat misstated the policy of New Mexico. Gov. Bill Richardson, a Democrat, orders both the state and federal flags lowered  not just state flags.

headline: Draft Picks Caught in Fast Break of Trade Talks
text: When Georgetown’s Jeff Green was called to Phoenix for a last-minute workout with the Suns on Tuesday, he shrugged, packed a suit for tonight’s N.B.A. draft and prepared for every situation.

headline: 5 Charged in Planting of Devices at School
text: TOTOWA, N.J., June 27  Five teenagers who graduated last week from Wayne Valley High School have been arrested in connection with the discovery of 16 devices with fuses in lockers at the school, forcing the evacuation of 1,400 students on the last full day of classes.

headline: CommScope to Buy Andrew Corporation
text: CommScope, a maker of cable for communications companies, has agreed to buy the Andrew Corporation for about $2.6 billion to bolster sales to mobile phone and wireless Internet companies.

headline: New Campaign Finance Rules Skip Unions
text: The new law would crack down on donations from lobbyists, strictly limit contributions from contractors who do business with the city, and allow developers to give only a fraction of what they once could.

headline: Next Week
text: David Cay Johnston of The Times business desk looks at the practice (often foolish) of using public subsidies for private sports ventures. Also, sailing camps that get right to the tough stuff.

headline: Suggested Reading
text: Last weekend, Ken Griffey Jr. played in Seattle for the first time as a Cincinnati Red, receiving a rousing reception and then delighting the fans with two home runs on Sunday. A spate of injuries in recent years sidetracked him, but this 1994 profile of Griffey reminds us that in the mid-90s, the question was when, not if, he would break baseball’s home run records (while wearing his trademark grin). From PLAY’s suggested reading list:

headline: Unwilling to Retire, a Veteran Looks to Make a Late Statement
text: WIMBLEDON, England, June 27  People would ask, with increasing frequency, when Meilen Tu would quit playing tennis. It seemed obvious that her best years were past.

headline: Bird Lives in the Adulation of a Young Saxophonist
text: The Charlie Parker tribute being held this week at Birdland, the club that bears his nickname, isn’t meant for anyone harboring resentment about the commodification of Parker’s art. Nor is it for anyone who insists that jazz belongs strictly to the Americans, or that it glances backward at its own peril. Presented by the Umbria Jazz Festival, with the help of various Italian cultural organizations, the engagement traffics in nostalgia even as it revels in new talent.

headline: 2 Lawsuits Against Maker of Toy Trains
text: The RC2 Corporation, maker of the Thomas & Friends Wooden Railway toys, was named yesterday as a defendant in two complaints demanding the company provide medical monitoring to children who may have ingested lead paint from its products.

headline: Likely Spread of Deserts to Fertile Land Requires Quick Response, U.N. Report Says
text: ROME, June 27  Enough fertile land could turn into desert within the next generation to create an “environmental crisis of global proportions,” large-scale migrations and political instability in parts of Africa and Central Asia unless current trends are quickly stemmed, a new United Nations report concludes.

headline: After Decade as Premier, Blair Yields to Brown
text: LONDON, June 27 — On a day of poignant farewells and sober new promises, Gordon Brown took over Wednesday from Tony Blair as prime minister, offering Britain a pledge to “try my utmost” and declaring, “Now, let the work of change begin.”

headline: Mommy Is Truly Dearest
text: I TELL her everything.”

headline: New Commitment to Charity by Mexican Phone Tycoon
text: MEXICO CITY, June 27 — Carlos Slim Helú may be the richest man in the world. And in Mexico, where tens of millions of people live in seemingly intractable poverty, that distinction has been drawing some heat.

headline: Democrats Stress Domestic Programs in Debate
text: WASHINGTON, June 28 — For 90 minutes Thursday night, eight Democratic candidates debated before an audience made up largely of one of their party’s most reliable and liberal constituencies — African-American voters — and used the stage to urge a revitalization of domestic programs that they said had faltered under President George W. Bush.

headline: Sex Education (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Protest Raised Over Lowering a Sail, as Alinghi Ties Series
text: VALENCIA, Spain, June 27 — After a wild, wacky ride in Race 3, the America’s Cup, sport’s oldest major competition, returned to more familiar ways and means Wednesday.

headline: In the Berkshires, a Dance Destination Marks an Anniversary by Stretching
text: When Ted Shawn happened upon Jacob’s Pillow in the Berkshire Hills of western Massachusetts in 1930, he didn’t have a grand scheme in mind. He simply pined for a retreat or, as Norton Owen, the Pillow’s director of preservation, put it, a place “to get away from it all.”

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,560 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Not Quite ‘Liz’ and ‘Gordie,’ but Palace Protocol Is Looser
text: LONDON, June 27 — It had been so oft foretold as to seem an anticlimax but, finally — and not quite as in the movie starring Helen Mirren — Gordon Brown got his “queen moment” on Wednesday when he took over from Tony Blair as prime minister.

headline: An African Tragedy, Ignored by the World (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Toxic Waste Fire Linked to Oxygen Generators
text: WASHINGTON, June 27 — A fire in October at a toxic waste transfer station in North Carolina was fueled by the same type of oxygen-generating devices that ignited and brought down a jetliner in the Everglades in 1996, federal investigators reported on Wednesday.

headline: Ms. Bolden’s Black Mark
text: Discrimination is disturbing wherever it shows its face. But it is especially deplorable in public schools, which are supposed to uphold the values of tolerance and basic fairness. Marion Bolden, superintendent of Newark’s schools, seemed to forget that recently when she ordered one high school to blot out a yearbook picture of a gay student and his boyfriend kissing. Ms. Bolden said she thought the picture — which was covered over with black marker — was “suggestive” and “looked fairly illicit.” Photos of heterosexual couples kissing were left untouched.

headline: Poland: Central Bank Raises Benchmark Interest Rate
text: Poland’s central bank unexpectedly raised its benchmark interest rate, for a second time this year, on concern that wage growth will force companies to increase prices. The Monetary Policy Council, which is led by the central bank, lifted the seven-day reference rate a quarter-point, to 4.5 percent. ”It is possible that wage pressure will continue to grow, strengthening inflation pressure,” the council said after the meeting. It said inflation might temporarily slow in the third quarter, helped by the healthy financial standing of companies and growing competition among service providers and goods producers. The inflation rate, at 2.3 percent in May, is nearing the central bank’s mid-range target rate of 2.5 percent.

headline: Israeli President to Resign in Plea Bargain on Sex Charges
text: JERUSALEM, June 28 — The Israeli government has dropped rape charges against President Moshe Katsav in exchange for his agreement to step down and to plead guilty to lesser charges, the attorney general, Menachem Mazuz, announced Thursday.

headline: Jury Begins Deliberations in Black Trial
text: CHICAGO, June 27 — A federal jury began deliberations in the criminal trial of Conrad M. Black, the former media mogul, on Wednesday after more than an hour of instructions from Judge Amy J. St. Eve.

headline: Talks Under Way Over Sunni Official Named in Warrant
text: BAGHDAD, June 27 — The arrest warrant issued for the Iraqi culture minister, Asad al-Hashimi, continued to draw fire from some Sunni Arab leaders on Wednesday, and negotiations with the government were under way to review the investigation.

headline: A State Questions UBS Ties to Hedge Funds
text: UBS, Europe’s largest bank by assets, was accused yesterday by Massachusetts regulators of “dishonest and unethical” practices in dealings with hedge fund advisers.

headline: Gobbling Up Garbage, and Looking Good Doing It
text: YONKERS

headline: A Portable Battery-Powered Charger for Cellphones, Music or Games Can Avert an Energy Crisis
text: Cellphones and other hand-held gadgets always seem to fail near the end of a day that has drained the energy from batteries (and owners).

headline: 2 Iranian Gas Stations Burned Over Rationing
text: TEHRAN, June 27  Angry drivers set fire to at least two gas stations overnight in Tehran after the government announced that gasoline rationing would begin Wednesday just after midnight.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Tuesday with a dance review of the New York International Ballet Competition reversed the identities of the two dancers shown performing “Black Swan.” Kwi Sub Park was on the left and Eun Ji Ha was on the right.

headline: Liz Claiborne, Clothing Designer, Dies at 78
text: Liz Claiborne, the designer of indefatigable career clothes for professional women entering the work force en masse beginning in the 1970s, died Tuesday in Manhattan. She was 78.

headline: Manhattan: Writer Charged With Fraud
text: Three women, including the author of several financial advice books, were indicted on charges of fraud yesterday after prosecutors said they stole $1.6 million from New York area investors. The women — Carla Zimbalist, 62, of Beverly Hills, Calif.; Pam Chanla, 33, of Alhambra, Calif.; and the writer, Jennifer Wilkov, 38, of Brooklyn — were charged with fraud and securities violations, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney. Ms. Wilkov, whose books include “Dating Your Money, for Couples,” pleaded not guilty at her arraignment yesterday in State Supreme Court, prosecutors said. Ms. Zimbalist was in custody in California and Ms. Chanla had not yet been arrested, prosecutors said. Mr. Morgenthau said that the three told 23 investors that Ms. Zimbalist and Ms. Chanla would use the investors’ money to renovate homes in Southern California, but that they did not actually own many of the properties and used much of the money for personal expenses.

headline: Biggest Urban Growth Is in South and West
text: Newark, for four decades a symbol of America’s urban decay, is growing faster than any major city in the Northeast, according to census figures released yesterday.

headline: Switzerland: Massachusetts Challenges U.S. Unit of UBS
text: UBS Securities, the investment-banking division of the Swiss-based UBS, was accused by Massachusetts regulators of dishonest and unethical practices in dealings with hedge-fund advisers. The subsidiary, based in Stamford, Conn., gave hedge-fund managers below-market rent, low-interest personal loans and other benefits to retain and increase business, according to a complaint from the office of William Galvin, the secretary of the commonwealth and its top securities regulator. The complaint also accuses UBS of failing to supervise gifts and gratuities. The action, filed with the state’s Securities Division, seeks a cease-and-desist order, a censure and an undisclosed administrative fine, the statement said. Doug Morris, a UBS spokesman in New York, declined to comment.

headline: New Senators Resist Overhaul of Immigration
text: WASHINGTON, June 27 — In narrowly winning her seat last year, Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri ran hard against what she saw as a flawed approach in Congress to dealing with illegal immigration. Ms. McCaskill, a Democratic newcomer, says she is not about to change her view now.

headline: Opera With Attitude, Guitars, and a Dose of Mayhem
text: PARIS, June 27 — It is no longer thought daring for moviemakers to direct opera. Roman Polanski and William Friedkin first did so some years ago. Anthony Minghella and Michael Haneke tried their hand more recently, and Woody Allen and David Cronenberg will soon have a go. Invariably the idea of opera house managers is to add some screen buzz (and, they hope, draw new audiences) to their standard repertory.

headline: Georgia: No Bond in Habeas Corpus Appeal
text: A judge ruled that a man serving a 10-year prison sentence for having consensual sex with a 15-year-old girl at a party when he was 17 is not eligible for bond while his habeas corpus case is being appealed. The judge, David Emerson, of Superior Court in Douglas County, ruled that Genarlow Wilson, 21, is not eligible for bail because he was convicted of aggravated child molestation, a crime that is considered one of the “seven deadly sins” under Georgia law. The ruling means that Mr. Wilson will probably spend several more months in prison.

headline: U.S. Open Is Looking Younger Than Ever
text: SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., June 27  Alexis Thompson learned to play golf from the seat of a baby stroller, a twist on the Tiger Woods upbringing that included lessons from a high chair.

headline: Teenager Killed on Subway
text: A 19-year-old was fatally shot last night on a subway train in Brooklyn, the police said.

headline: Second Company Bids for Canadian Newspapers
text: OTTAWA, June 27 — A chain of small newspapers that was once among Conrad M. Black’s Canadian holdings became the object of a bidding war on Wednesday.

headline: Long Climb for New President of Health Care Workers’ Union
text: George Gresham, the new president of 1199, New York City’s largest labor union, which represents 300,000 health care workers, has not forgotten what life is like at the bottom.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption yesterday with sports articles about the top two college players expected to be selected in today’s N.B.A. draft misspelled the surname of one player. As the articles noted, he is Kevin Durant, not Durrant, of Texas. (Greg Oden of Ohio State is the other top player.)

headline: Pakistani Underdog Wins Crowd, if Not Game, at Wimbledon
text: WIMBLEDON, England, June 28 — From the balcony overlooking Court No. 18, family and friends, and people he did not know, shouted encouragement in Urdu, his native language.

headline: Immigration Bill Fails to Survive Senate Vote
text: WASHINGTON, June 28 — President Bush’s effort to overhaul the nation’s immigration policy, a cornerstone of his domestic agenda, collapsed in the Senate today, with little hope that it can be revived before Mr. Bush leaves office in January 2009.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the withdrawal from an initial public offering by a company that owned assets of a troubled hedge fund misidentified that fund. It is the Bear Stearns High-Grade Structured Credit Strategies fund  not another fund with a similar name, the High-Grade Structured Credit Enhanced Strategies fund.

headline: Scottish Panel Challenges Lockerbie Conviction
text: LONDON, June 28 — An independent judicial review body ruled Thursday that a former Libyan intelligence official jailed for the 1988 Lockerbie bombing might have been wrongfully convicted and was entitled to appeal the verdict against him.

headline: U.S. Faces More Distrust From World, Poll Shows
text: PARIS, June 27 — Distrust of the United States has intensified across the world, but overall views of America remain very or somewhat favorable among majorities in 25 of 46 countries and the Palestinian territories surveyed in an international poll conducted by the Pew Research Center, in results reported Wednesday.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Tuesday about deaths in immigration detention misstated the year that one immigrant detainee died, and the amount of time that elapsed between then and an announcement this month of a federal investigation into her death. Young Sook Kim, who was detained at a privately run center in Albuquerque, died in 2006, not in 2005; the announcement of the investigation came nearly a year after her death, not nearly two years.

headline: Just Don’t Call Them Inexpensive
text: AS much as I like the word “cheap” and its variations — cheap-jack, cheapskate, el cheapo and the effervescent cheap and cheerful — I seem to have a hard time actually getting the word into a fashion article. “Use ‘inexpensive,’ ” I’m told.

headline: Tentative Dow Jones Sale Pact Said to Give Murdoch Power to Hire and Fire at The Journal
text: A tentative accord on the editorial independence of The Wall Street Journal would leave Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation with the sole power to hire and fire The Journal’s top editors if it succeeds in buying the newspaper’s owner, Dow Jones & Company, people who have been briefed on the agreement said yesterday.

headline: Calendar
text: Furniture Large and Small

headline: Southern Wildfires (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Watching Army Wives Watching ‘Army Wives’
text: FORT DRUM, N.Y. — Poor Denise Sherwood. Her nasty son smacks her around. And she just learned that the Blackhawk helicopter carrying her husband, Maj. Frank Sherwood, was shot down in Iraq. So maybe the real Army wives at this post near Syracuse, watching Denise on TV in the hit Lifetime drama, “Army Wives,” would show her some love, or at least cut her some slack?

headline: The Steamfitter’s Escape
text: THERE are 11,232 parquet-floored apartments in Peter Cooper Village and its sister complex, Stuyvesant Town, east of First Avenue, all built in the 1940s as affordable housing for middle-income tenants, and all remarkably similar in style and layout. Or almost all, anyway: one stands out for its stained-glass windows, its wall of vines and its spiral staircase to nowhere. Step inside, and you’ll never think of mirrors on the ceiling the same way again.

headline: Hot Dog Champ and Upstart Set for July Fourth Face-Off
text: In the world of competitive eating, heads — if not stomachs — were spinning yesterday. In a last-minute development, what observers were expecting to be the Bite of the Century seemed off, then on again.

headline: Study Sees Climate Change Impact on Alaska
text: Many of Alaska’s roads, runways, railroads and water and sewer systems will wear out more quickly and cost more to repair or replace because of climate change, according to a study released yesterday.

headline: Japan: Industrial Production Dropped in May
text: Japan’s industrial production unexpectedly dropped in May for a third month, the longest losing streak in almost two years. Production fell a seasonally adjusted 0.4 percent from a month earlier, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry said. Slower production diminishes hopes that economic growth will accelerate, in contrast with other reports released in the last week, which said that export growth almost doubled to 15.1 percent in May and retail sales gained for the first time in eight months. The Bank of Japan’s governor, Toshihiko Fukui, said this month that the bank needed more evidence of the economy’s strength before it raises the key interest rate from 0.5 percent.

headline: Randolph Will Have Surgery Instead of Coaching in the All-Star Game
text: As a second baseman, Willie Randolph made countless throws to first base. As manager of the Mets, he has made countless calls to the bullpen. All the wear and tear on his right shoulder has taken a toll. Randolph said yesterday that he would have rotator-cuff surgery next month instead of coaching in the All-Star Game.

headline: Church Dissidents Lose Property Appeal
text: Three congregations that broke away from the Episcopal Church over the appointment of a gay bishop are not entitled to property claimed by the Episcopal Diocese of Los Angeles, a California appeals court has ruled.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Friday about government ratings for hospitals misstated the number of hospitals where heart patients are most and least likely to die. The report lists 41 hospitals, not 42, whose death rates are worse than the national average, and 52 hospitals, not 55, whose deaths rates are better than average. A list of the hospitals can be found at www.nytimes.com/health.

headline: The Nets Hope to Keep Triumvirate Together
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 27  The wall above the front desk at the Nets’ practice facility is bare, except for three signed jerseys with names that, for three years, have represented the backbone of the franchise: Jefferson, Kidd, Carter.

headline: Better Protecting the Vulnerable
text: With time running out on the legislative clock, the State of New York is close to enacting three new laws that would set welcome national examples for criminal justice reform. Gov. Eliot Spitzer, the Assembly and the Senate need to work quickly to iron out any differences and ensure these vital reforms are signed into law.

headline: N.B.A. Renews TV Pacts, Adding Links to Digital Use
text: ESPN, ABC and TNT will continue to carry the N.B.A. through the 2015-16 season under eight-year contracts worth $7.4 billion that will let the networks exploit the league’s digital rights more extensively than in the past.

headline: Garden Q.&A.
text: A Strawberry Lawn

headline: Study Finds Many Injuries to Surgeons Go Unreported
text: Nearly all surgeons accidentally stick themselves with needles and sharp instruments while in training. But most fail to report the injuries, risking their health and that of their families and patients to the threat of diseases including AIDS, hepatitis and many other blood-borne illnesses, according to a survey being published today.

headline: Scientists Find Earliest Sign of Cultivated Crops in Americas
text: Scientists exploring the western slopes of the Andes in northern Peru have found seeds of domesticated squash from almost 10,000 years ago, about twice the age of previously discovered cultivated crops in the region.

headline: A Calm, Serene Presence From Islands of Nostalgia
text: In an uptempo song near the end of Cesária Évora’s set on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall, her saxophonist, Totinho, swaggered toward her with arms outstretched, as if inviting her to dance. She gave him one dismissive glance, and he returned to his microphone. Ms. Évora was maintaining the core of her music: a serene, pensive stillness.

headline: Manhattan: Building Code Changes
text: The City Council yesterday approved the first major overhaul of the city’s building code since 1968, greatly expanding fire safety requirements, encouraging environmentally sound construction and simplifying operations at the Department of Buildings. The updated code, which is to be reviewed for possible revision every three years, was approved in a 47-to-0 vote, with one abstention, and will go into effect on July 1, 2008. It adds sprinkler requirements for smaller buildings, raises standards for smoke detectors, strengthens safety regulations for high-rise residential buildings and provides for rebates on permit fees if buildings meet higher environmental design standards and undertake more environmentally friendly practices.

headline: Asia’s Long Road to Recovery
text: BANGKOK, June 23 — As the founder of a petrochemicals business empire that aggressively expanded in refining, plastics, steel and cement, Prachai Leophairatana once ranked among Asia’s wealthiest men.

headline: U.N. Predicts Urban Population Explosion
text: By next year, more than half the world’s population, 3.3 billion people, will for the first time live in towns and cities, and the number is expected to swell to almost five billion by 2030, according to a United Nations Population Fund report released yesterday.

headline: Proposals From Both Sides Fail in Immigration Debate
text: WASHINGTON, June 27 — The Senate on Wednesday killed proposals from the left and the right for major changes in a comprehensive immigration bill, but the outlook for the bill remained in doubt as senators prepared for a crucial vote on whether to end debate and move to final passage.

headline: European Regulator Blocks Ryanair Bid for Aer Lingus
text: BRUSSELS, June 27 — A bid by the low-cost airline Ryanair to buy Aer Lingus, Ireland’s national carrier, was blocked Wednesday as the top European regulator showed a willingness to intervene despite the overturning of past merger prohibitions in court.

headline: Manhattan: Storms Snarl L.I.R.R.
text: Severe storms caused delays of about two hours last night on the Long Island Rail Road after floods caused signal problems at the Jamaica station about 7:30 p.m., affecting service after 8 p.m. to and from Jamaica, according to a railroad spokeswoman. Pennsylvania Station became so crowded at one point that the Long Island Rail Road’s section was shut to new passengers between 8 and 10 p.m., leaving hundreds of passengers stranded outside. As of 10 p.m., service was restored at all but three stations, where trees had fallen on the tracks. Service was expected to be normal this morning.

headline: A Gifted Player Comes Up Short in the Draft
text: Alando Tucker was the Big Ten player of the year. He is an All-American. And some draft analysts project him to go to the Blazers. But not with the first pick, as an old school fan might guess. He’s projected to go to the Blazers in the second round, with the 42nd pick. The rap on him is that he’s a little small to play on the perimeter, and doesn’t shoot well. Thus, one of the top five players in college basketball slips to the second round of the National Basketball Association draft.

headline: Day of Campaigning for a G.O.P. Noncandidate
text: COLUMBIA, S.C., June 27  Former Senator Fred D. Thompson of Tennessee delivered a pep talk to his fellow Republicans here Wednesday, reminding voters in this early primary state about what he called the virtue of conservative ideals.

headline: Judge Rejects Hospitals’ Suit Against Chain in New Jersey
text: A judge in Newark has dismissed a lawsuit claiming that the St. Barnabas Health Care System, which overbilled Medicare by hundreds of millions of dollars, defrauded the federal government so badly that other hospitals were deprived of their fair share of reimbursement.

headline: Edwards on Poverty (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Death Penalty for Delusional Murderer Blocked
text: HOUSTON, June 28 — Enforcing its edict against execution of the insane, a split United States Supreme Court today overturned the death sentence of a delusional Texas murderer who insisted he was being punished for preaching the gospel.

headline: Tu, at Peak of Career, Seeks Last Burst at Wimbledon
text: WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 — People would ask, with increasing frequency, when Meilen Tu would quit playing tennis. It seemed obvious that her best years were past.

headline: A Slipshod Harry Potter and a Challenging Racer
text: Hollywood knows that a movie based on a Harry Potter book must be meticulously made to satisfy the series’ legions of fans. And the video-game industry knows that any game based on a popular movie can make money, no matter how many corners are cut, simply by riding a successful film’s coattails.

headline: U.N. Official Is Expected to Become Chief Prosecutor for War Crimes Tribunal
text: THE HAGUE, June 27  The chief prosecutor at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, Carla Del Ponte, is expected to be succeeded by the United Nations official leading the inquiry into the killing in 2005 of Rafik Hariri, former prime minister of Lebanon, United Nations officials in The Hague and in New York said Wednesday.

headline: Beauty Regimens Reach for the Gold Standard
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.

headline: A Luxury Condo by Arty Architects From the Fringe
text: With so many developers relying on celebrity architects to market condominiums these days, it’s become routine to see names like Richard Meier and Jean Nouvel emblazoned across real estate ads and billboards. But Asymptote? Isn’t that the firm that designed that “steel cloud,” a highly conceptual (read: unbuilt) elevated memorial and park for downtown Los Angeles two decades ago?

headline: Corrections
text: An Op-Ed article on Sunday, about Tony Blair, misstated the circumstances of Prime Minister Clement Attlee’s ouster from office. His party did not lose control of Parliament in the 1950 election; it held on until a second election, in 1951. The article also misspelled the prime minister’s surname. It was Attlee, not Atlee.

headline: Discovery Team Decides on Leader for Tour
text: The Discovery Channel cycling team will start the Tour de France next week with the goal of placing Levi Leipheimer, the winner of the Tour of California this year, among the top three finishers in the three-week race, team officials said yesterday.

headline: Vatican City: Pope Backs ‘Adult’ Stem Cell Research
text: Speaking at the end of his weekly general audience, Pope Benedict XVI endorsed research using so-called adult stem cells, which are isolated from tissue samples taken from adults rather than derived from human embryos, a technique the Vatican still condemns. “Scientific research must be encouraged and promoted, so long as it does not harm other human beings, whose dignity is inviolable from the very first stages of existence,” the pope said, according to the Italian news service ANSA. “Adult” stem cells can grow into a very limited range of body tissues, replenishing dying cells and regenerating damaged tissues; embryonic stem cells can grow into a wide range of body tissues.

headline: Your Briefcase Just Ran Over My Toe
text: DAN RAWLINGS — a sales executive, former football player and guy’s guy — loves his briefcase.

headline: Fidelity National, a Payment Processor, Is Buying eFunds
text: Fidelity National Information Services, the electronic-payment processor, agreed to buy a rival, the eFunds Corporation, for about $1.8 billion in cash to bolster its debit card business.

headline: Corrections
text: An Op-Ed article on Thursday, about presidential elections involving candidates from the same state, inaccurately described the circumstances involving the selection of Warren Harding as the Republican nominee in 1920. Harding’s nomination was not a direct response to the Democrats’ selection of another Ohioan, James Cox; Cox was a compromise nominee who was not chosen until after Harding’s nomination.

headline: Food-Safety Crackdown in China
text: SHANGHAI, June 27 — After weeks of insisting that food here is largely safe, regulators in China said Tuesday that they had recently closed 180 food plants and that inspectors had uncovered more than 23,000 food safety violations.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an obituary on June 2 of Huang Ju, a member of the Politburo Standing Committee, the elite group of nine senior officials who rule China, misidentified the committee member responsible for presiding over reforms to the banking and financial systems. It was Mr. Huang  not Jiang Zemin, the former president with whom Mr. Huang was allied.

headline: Earnings Up 4.2% at Bed Bath & Beyond
text: Bed Bath & Beyond Inc., the home-furnishings retailer, said yesterday that first-quarter profit rose 4.2 percent after customers bought less bedding and curtains as home sales slowed.

headline: Alitalia Seeks Another Suitor After Aeroflot Withdraws
text: MILAN, June 27  The Italian government was dealt a setback on Wednesday in its efforts to find a suitor to rescue Alitalia, the nation’s flagship carrier, after Aeroflot of Russia abandoned its bid to buy the airline.

headline: Building Companies the Women’s Way
text: Karla Lightfoot, 40, a yoga instructor and freelance writer, was meditating one day when the name “compassion couture” just came to her.

headline: While You Were Out, the Post-it Went Home
text: THE romance between Shirley M. Knappe, 83, and Frank Sterling Long, 88, began electronically, with poetic early-morning e-mail messages from Mr. Long to Ms. Knappe, who live in an assisted-living facility in Coral Springs, Fla. But now that they have been married for three years, their day-to-day affairs are tracked on Post-it notes, which Ms. Knappe corrals onto the kitchen cabinets above the toaster oven: her activities in yellow, his in blue.

headline: A Favorite Tune? A Wake-Up Call? A Wireless Alarm Will Blend the Two
text: If you love the music collection stored on your cellphone or computer, why let a little thing like sleep prevent you from hearing it? The iHC5 alarm clock from iHome (www.ihomeaudio.com) can connect wirelessly with any digital device that features Bluetooth technology and stream an audio file to the bedroom.

headline: Looking Like a Billion Bucks
text: MILAN

headline: White House Is Subpoenaed on Wiretapping
text: WASHINGTON, June 27 — The Senate Judiciary Committee on Wednesday issued subpoenas to the White House, Vice President Dick Cheney’s office and the Justice Department after what the panel’s chairman called “stonewalling of the worst kind” of efforts to investigate the National Security Agency’s policy of wiretapping without warrants.

headline: Wells Fargo and Ex-Analyst Are Fined
text: The NASD said yesterday that it had fined Wells Fargo and its former director of research for failing to disclose in a research report that an analyst had taken a job with the company she was recommending.

headline: Religion and the Law (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wells Fargo Gives Next Chief an Early Start
text: The Wells Fargo stagecoach has a new driver.

headline: Storms Delay L.I.R.R. and Shut Down Power
text: Severe storms last night delayed service on the Long Island Rail Road for more than two hours after floods caused signal problems at the Jamaica station about 7:30 p.m. Service to and from Jamaica was affected after 8 p.m., a railroad spokeswoman said.

headline: Italy: Changing of the Guard on the Left
text: Walter Veltroni, the popular mayor of Rome, announced that he would seek the leadership of the new Democratic Party, to be formed in the fall by merging the centrist Christian Democrats and the former communist Democrats of the Left, two main parties in the governing center-left coalition of Prime Minister Romano Prodi. The widely expected announcement officially makes the 51-year old Mr. Veltroni, a former Communist, the new leading figure of Italian center-left politics and a possible future candidate for prime minister.

headline: A Designer Is Virtually Back
text: SOME women, like Natalie Massenet, can’t wait to get a piece of RM.

headline: Even in Agreement, Scalia Puts Roberts to Lash
text: WASHINGTON, June 27 — It’s not every day that one Supreme Court justice, even one as rhetorically unrestrained as Justice Antonin Scalia, characterizes another justice, let alone the chief justice of the United States, as a wimp and a hypocrite.

headline: Wider Sale Is Seen for Toothpaste Tainted in China
text: After federal health officials discovered last month that tainted Chinese toothpaste had entered the United States, they warned that it would most likely be found in discount stores.

headline: Tina Brozman, 54, Former Judge and Bankruptcy Law Innovator, Dies
text: Tina L. Brozman, a former chief judge of the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York, whose work helped change international bankruptcy law, died on Tuesday in New York. She was 54.

headline: Residential Sales
text: Manhattan

headline: Scientists Link Housecats to Wildcat Subspecies
text: Some 10,000 years ago, somewhere in the Near East, an audacious wild cat crept into one of the crude villages of early human settlers, the first to domesticate wheat and barley. There she felt safe from her many predators in the region, such as hyenas and larger cats, and the rodents that infested the settlers’ homes and granaries were sufficient prey for her.

headline: For Education and Fun, It’s Never Too Early to Give a Preschool Child a Starter Computer
text: ClickStart: My First Computer, from Leapfrog, is intended to transform your TV into a computing center for preschoolers. It consists of a wireless keyboard with mouse that can sit in a child’s lap, and an infrared receiving base that plugs into your TV’s audio-video jacks.

headline: Web Browsing Without Windows
text: Q. How do I get the video and animation to work on Web sites when I am not using a computer running Windows or Microsoft’s Internet Explorer browser?

headline: Wells Fargo Fined in Disclosure Case
text: The NASD said today that it had fined Wells Fargo and its former director of research for failing to disclose in a research report that an analyst had taken a job with the company she was recommending.

headline: Patrons’ Sway Leads to Friction in Charter School
text: The Beginning With Children Charter School, housed in a former factory in Brooklyn, landed on the state’s list of high-performing schools this year, thanks to rising English and math test scores among black and Hispanic students.

headline: Bald Eagles No Longer Endangered, U.S. Says
text: SEMINOLE COUNTY, Fla., June 28 — Bald eagles, whose numbers dwindled to historic lows in the early 1960s, are once again flourishing and no longer need the protections of the Endangered Species Act, Interior Secretary Dirk Kempthorne announced today.

headline: Friends and Graduates, Now Victims in a Fiery Crash
text: Their exams, their prom, their graduation ceremony — all the rituals of high school were behind them. So were all the football and basketball games at which they had yelled and jumped from the sidelines as cheerleaders. Now they were on their way to spend a few carefree days in the Finger Lakes before one last round of post-graduation parties.

headline: Not Yet Legal for the Street, but a Whiz on a Tractor
text: TOMAH, Wis., June 24 — It was not just Nicole Snyder’s age, 17, that made her such a hit at the Dairyland Super National Truck and Tractor Pull here Saturday night. And it was more than the fact that her tractor’s two jet engines together produced 7,000 horsepower, enough to fly a troop-carrying helicopter.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of a transmission error, a film review yesterday about “Live Free or Die Hard” misstated the critic’s description of the plot. It should have been described as “logic-defying,” not “logic-defined.”

headline: Paris Hilton Says She Is a Changed Woman
text: Paris Hilton read aloud her prison writings as if she had spent a lifetime on Robben Island, and that was surely the highlight of the heiress/actress’s first television interview since her release from jail.

headline: Bloomberg Had Surgery in 2000
text: Before he was elected mayor in 2001, Michael R. Bloomberg had surgery to have two stents implanted in a coronary artery because of blockage in his heart, a person with knowledge of Mr. Bloomberg’s health said last night.

headline: Free Speech: The Justices Speak (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Brooklyn: Detective Testifies in Killing
text: Testifying yesterday in a murder trial, a retired detective said that the police failed to build a case against a suspect for 17 years, despite having his name, address and Social Security number. The detective, William Powell, cited his own notes describing the defendant, Craig Sobel, 39, who was charged last year with killing Dominick Masseria, 17, in 1989 on the steps of a church in Dyker Heights. Mr. Sobel’s co-defendant is R. Lindley DeVecchio, a retired F.B.I. supervisor who has been charged with helping a prized informant commit murders on behalf of the mob. The judge overseeing the case, Justice Gustin L. Reichbach of State Supreme Court, has told prosecutors to show good cause for delaying prosecution of the case, and has already dismissed the charges against another man, John Sinagra, because of the delay. Prosecutors said they planned to call 11 witnesses to show that their evidence against Mr. DeVecchio had been properly obtained.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Saturday about conflict over whether to lower flags in honor of soldiers who die in combat misstated the policy of New Mexico. Gov. Bill Richardson, a Democrat, orders both the state and federal flags lowered — not just state flags. (Go to Article)

headline: Editor Reveals the Sources of His Unease
text: Back in the summer of 2005 it was no fun being Norman Pearlstine. As editor in chief of Time Inc., he had been battling Patrick J. Fitzgerald, the tenacious special prosecutor investigating the Valerie Wilson case. Mr. Fitzgerald had issued subpoenas to a number of Washington journalists, among them the Time magazine reporter Matthew Cooper, seeking information about their contacts with administration officials who might have been involved in leaking Ms. Wilson’s identity as an undercover intelligence agent. When they refused to comply, both Mr. Cooper and Time Inc. were held in contempt.

headline: Lake Tahoe Fire Hits Year-Round Residents
text: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., June 27 — When word came to evacuate his 12-foot-square shack on Tuesday afternoon, Scott Weise did not have a great deal to pack. He grabbed a few books, some canned goods and his one prized collection: about $1,300 worth of fishing gear, equipment Mr. Weise said he had planned to use — before his evacuation — to take as many crappie and blue gill out of Lake Tahoe as he could.

headline: What kinds of rugs are good for high-traffic areas?
text: Q.  What kinds of rugs are good for high-traffic areas?

headline: In West Bank, Hamas Is Silent but Never Ignored
text: HAWARA, West Bank, June 26 — A new code was born here overnight. No one, it seems, belongs to Hamas in the West Bank anymore. Everyone now is an “Islamist,” a word that neatly, and maybe more safely, shears the religious from party affiliation amid the uncertainty of a Palestinian people newly divided.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A subheading on Monday with a dance review of Alessandra Ferri’s farewell performance with American Ballet Theater misstated the number of years she was with the company. As the review noted, she joined in 1985 and thus was with it for 22 years, not 12.

headline: A Situation Is Brewing, Acoustic and Fierce
text: When the bassist Christian McBride feels good about a groove, he savors it, exults in it. Flashing a million-watt smile, he tosses off frolicsome micro-elaborations: a downward-tumbling triplet run, a jaunt of springy quarter notes on the fifth degree of the scale. This sort of thing happens a lot, especially on his bandstand. It certainly happened on Tuesday night at the Village Vanguard, where he’s headlining this week.

headline: A Gifted Player Comes Up Short In the Draft
text: Alando Tucker was the Big Ten player of the year last season. He was an all-American. Some draft analysts project him to go to the Portland Trail Blazers. Not with the first pick — as his credentials may suggest — but with the 42nd pick. The rap on him is that he is a little small to play on the perimeter and does not shoot well.

headline: Immigration Bill Prompts Some Menacing Responses
text: WASHINGTON, June 27 — The threat came in the weekend mail.

headline: The iPhone Arrives
text: Apple’s iPhone goes on sale Friday. Early reviews of the phone have been mostly positive. The Times’s David Pogue wrote: Even in version 1.0, the iPhone is still the most sophisticated, outlook-changing piece of electronics to come along in years. It does so many things so well, and so pleasurably, that you tend to forgive its foibles.

headline: The Tortured Path for the Immigration Bill
text: May 17, 2007 Senate negotiators from both parties announce an agreement on a comprehensive immigration bill, which would offer legal status to millions of illegal immigrants. Deal follows months of negotiations behind closed doors.

headline: Recent Openings
text: New shows in New York include "Old Acquiantance" and "Gone Missing."

headline: Rolling Briefcases
text: Wheeled briefcases are exploding in number.

headline: The Sights of St. John Valley
text: Standing in the land of the Acadians requires one foot in Canada and one in the U.S.

headline: Letter From the Counsel to the President
text: Following is a letter from Fred F. Fielding, the counsel to the president, relating to a request by Congress for documents related to an investigation into the firings of nine federal prosecutors last year.

headline: Wild Idaho
text: No national parks, but 20 million acres of public land, much of it far from the crowds.

headline: Future Voters of America
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: State Sues UBS Over Hedge-Fund Dealings
text: One hedge-fund hotel is in hot water.

headline: Treasures of the World
text: Images from "Encompassing the Globe: Portugal and the World in the 16th and 17th Centuries" at the Smithsonian's Sackler Gallery in Washington.

headline: Citigroup Unit in Australia Cleared of Insider Trading
text: Citigroup, the world’s largest financial company, was cleared of insider trading in Australia on Thursday in a case that challenged the way investment banks operate.

headline: Second Company Bids for Canadian Newspapers
text: A chain of small newspapers that was once among Conrad M. Black’s Canadian holdings became the object of a bidding war on Wednesday.

headline: The Farmer Needs a Wife
text: The bachelors of La Viñuela, Spain, welcome "women's caravans" to their rural — mostly male — village.

headline: The Keys to Success
text: This film about a brilliant boy pianist fighting to shape his destiny was Switzerland’s entry for the 2006 Oscars, and you can see why. Like most award-seeking crowd-pleasers, it places uncomfortable impulses in opposition — in this case parents’ desire to develop a child’s latent genius, versus the child’s desire to have a “normal” childhood and find his own way — then dramatizes them in the most unchallenging way imaginable.

headline: Sexy Tableaus
text: The notion that French cinema consists mainly of pretentious soft-core pornography is an ignorant cliché, but "One to Another" does little to disprove it. This drama from the directors Jean-Marc Barr and Pascal Arnold aims to be a disturbing account of young love, friendship and murder. But it plays like a remake of Larry Clark's muckraking thriller about youths, "Bully," as directed by Diane Chambers, the intellectual barmaid on "Cheers."

headline: European Regulator Blocks Ryanair Bid for Aer Lingus
text: A bid by the low-cost airline Ryanair to buy Aer Lingus, Ireland’s national carrier, was blocked Wednesday as the top European regulator showed a willingness to intervene despite the overturning of past merger prohibitions in court.

headline: Wells Fargo and Ex-Analyst Are Fined
text: The NASD said Wednesday that it had fined Wells Fargo and its former director of research for failing to disclose in a research report that an analyst had taken a job with the company she was recommending. The analyst, Jennifer Jordan, who is now a corporate vice president in charge of investor relations at the company, Cadence Design Systems, refused to settle the NASD case and will fight it, her lawyer said.

headline: Will Blogging Software Firms Attract Buyers?
text: For the social software side of Enterprise 2.0, there may be a short window of opportunity for M&A, according to the analyst firm The 451 Group, which takes a look at the potential buyers and sellers in the market for wiki and blogging software. Among the potential acquisition targets named in the report are Six Apart and Atlassian Software Systems; 451 Group analyst Kathleen Reidy considers the software giant Oracle to be the most logical buyer of such assets.

headline: Jury Begins Deliberations in Black Trial
text: A federal jury began deliberations in the criminal trial of Conrad M. Black, the former media mogul, on Wednesday after more than an hour of instructions from Judge Amy J. St. Eve. The jury of six women and six men deliberated for about two and a half hours before recessing for the day.

headline: Alitalia Seeks Another Suitor After Aeroflot Withdraws
text: The Italian government was dealt a setback on Wednesday in its efforts to find a suitor to rescue Alitalia, the nation’s flagship carrier, after Aeroflot of Russia abandoned its bid to buy the airline.

headline: New Commitment to Charity by Mexican Phone Tycoon
text: Carlos Slim Helú may be the richest man in the world. And in Mexico, where tens of millions of people live in seemingly intractable poverty, that distinction has been drawing some heat.

headline: In S.E.C.’s Hedge Fund Suit, a Family Affair
text: Federal regulators filed charges against a hedge fund manager, Simpson Capital Management, for allegedly defrauding mutual fund investors of millions of dollars in a late-trading scheme lasting more than three years. And in a twist, the chief of the hedge fund in question had family ties to a fund manager whose alleged market abuses set off an industry-wide investigation in the earlier part of the decade.

headline: Terra Firma Extends EMI Offer
text: Terra Firma Capital Partners, the private equity firm that has offered 2.4 billion pounds ($4.7 billion) for the British music firm EMI Group, extended its takeover bid on Thursday until July 4. As of June 27, Terra Firma had received acceptances representing 3.5 percent of the music company.

headline: Equinix in $482 Million Data Deal
text: A data center services provider, Equinix, said Thursday it is buying IXEurope, a European data center operator, for about $482 million in cash. IXEurope’s shareholders will receive $2.50 for each share held. IXEurope’s operations include 14 data centers throughout Europe, which Equinix plans to fold into its brand.

headline: A Baguette Fit for A President?
text: France has a new president, and a new presidential baguette. This year, Nicolas Sarkozy and his guests at Élysée Palace will have a Renaissance with their meals — the baguette made by Arnaud Delmontel. He won this year’s prize for the best baguette in Paris, awarded by the mayor’s office, which means he’ll be the official supplier to the president.

headline: Fund to Close Doors Following Subprime Losses
text: Fallout from the subprime mortgage market meltdown continued as Caliber Global Investment, a $908 million fund based in Britain and managed by Cambridge Place Investment Management, said it would close after losses on subprime-mortgage debt in the United States.

headline: Sierra Shareholders Approve UnitedHealth Merger
text: Sierra Health Services said Wednesday evening that 99 percent of its shareholders had approved the company’s merger with UnitedHealth Group.

headline: Nuveen Shareholders Sue to Block Madison Dearborn Deal
text: Nuveen Investments, an asset management firm, said in a regulatory filing late Tuesday that two separate lawsuits have been filed by shareholders seeking to block a $5.75 billion buyout of the company.

headline: Texas Pacific Still Interested in Coles Despite Losing Partners
text: The Coles Group, the Australian retailer, said on Thursday that a consortium led by the Texas Pacific Group would not submit a takeover offer for the company by the Sunday deadline but was still interested in making a bid.

headline: Buyout Shops Get Bridge Loan for U.S. Foodservice Deal
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Clayton Dubilier & Rice have decided to finance their $7.1 billion buyout of U.S. Foodservice with a bridge loan after canceling a $650 million bond offering, as investors appeared reluctant to back the financing.

headline: Carlyle Postpones I.P.O. of Mortage Fund
text: The Carlyle Group postponed a $415 million initial public offering of a fund that invests in bonds backed by mortgages after a slump in the subprime market. The buyout shop “is preparing a supplemental offering memorandum that will contain a revised timetable for the global offering,” the Washington-based firm said. The firm had offered investors 18.9 million shares for $20 to $22 each.

headline: Peoples United Inks $1.9 Billion Deal for Chittenden
text: People’s United Financial has agreed to buy Chittenden for $1.9 billion in cash and stock, in a deal that will create the largest locally owned bank in New England, with $21 billion in assets and more than 210 branches.

headline: ProSieben to Acquire SBS Broadcasting
text: The German broadcaster ProSiebenSat.1 Media agreed Wednesday to buy SBS Broadcasting of Luxembourg, creating a pan-European broadcaster that can take on Bertelsmann‘s RTL Group. ProSieben, based in Munich, will pay 3.3 billion euros ($4.4 billion) for SBS and expects a smooth closing next month because the deal does not require the approval of either competition or media watchdogs.

headline: Insight Closes $1.25 Billion Fund
text: Insight Venture Partners wrapped up its latest investment vehicle, Insight Venture Partners VI, with $1.25 billion, a closing that gives the New York firm about $3 billion under management. Founded in 1995, Insight Venture focuses on software and Internet services investments that cover the entire range of private capital investment – from early-stage venture capital deals to buyouts.

headline: Chinese Bloggers on Darfur
text: The campaign to brand the Beijing Olympics as “the Genocide Olympics,” unless China distances itself from Sudan, is unfortunately creating something of a backlash within China. It would be so important to get Chinese bloggers to scold their government for underwriting the Darfur genocide, but in fact the opposite is happening. Nationalist sentiment and a certain defensiveness is leading Chinese netizens to claim that the Darfur movement is just an effort to prevent Chinese oil companies from exploiting Sudanese oil. Here’s a translation of a Chinese blog posting.

headline: PregLem Raises $26 Million in New Funding
text: PregLem, a pharmaceutical company based in Geneva, Switzerland, announced Wednesday that it had raised $26 million in series A funding. The funds will help develop and commercialize compounds for women suffering from infertility.

headline: Former Cendant Unit Affinion Files for I.P.O.
text: Affinion Group Holdings, a marketing-services business that the private equity firm Apollo Management bought from Cendant in 2005, filed to raise as much as $600 million in an initial public offering.

headline: Wells Fargo’s New C.E.O. on Deals and Buffett
text: Analysts said that the sudden promotion of John G. Stumpf, Wells Fargo‘s chief operating officer, to chief executive, signaled that the bank would probably continue to focus on increasing sales in its core markets in the West rather than merging with an East Coast partner like Wachovia or SunTrust, as many on Wall Street have advocated for years.

headline: A Bear Stearns Executive’s Bailout Blog
More Debt Offerings Are Delayed
text: MISC, the world’s biggest owner of liquefied gas tankers, postponed a $750 million bond offering, in the latest sign of the turbulence in the debt markets. The Financial Times’s Lex column suggests the increased resistance “could be the beginning of a serious bondholder revolt.” Separately, an analyst at CreditSights suggested that troubles at two Bear Stearns hedge funds could spread in unexpected ways.

headline: Bloomberg’s Heart; Charter School Control; Blackout Woes; and More
text: A parenthetical sentence in the next issue of Newsweek magazine has become the political talk of the town. In the article, Newsweek notes:

headline: Newark Rises, but Not Like Phoenix
text: Newark, for four decades America’s poster child for urban decay, is growing faster than any major city in the Northeast, according to census figures released this morning. Its population, which has been declining for 50 years, increased by 3.3 percent since 2000, including 0.5 percent in the fiscal year ending last July 1. (New York City, though still the most populous, recorded virtually no growth in the same time period, though city officials dispute that. See below.)

headline: Podcast: ‘Post No Bills’
text: Podcast: Only in New York (mp3)

headline: World Chess Federation Changes Championship Rules, Again
text: Just when it seemed that the World Chess Federation had finally settled on a system for selecting the world champion that had some widespread support, it has rewritten the rules again. In a press release earlier this week that can be found here the federation said that the winner of a grand prix series of tournaments held over a two-year period would play a match against the winner of a mega-tournament called the World Cup. The winner of that match would then play a match against the world champion. The grand prix would begin in 2008.

headline: 2008: The Immigration Debate
text: Senators, who have been arguing for weeks over provisions of the compromise immigration bill, are set to decide today whether to close debate and vote on passage. Whatever happens, the fate of the immigration bill is likely to have consequences for both parties in the 2008 presidential election.

headline: Two Buyout Firms to Buy G.M. Unit for $5.6 Billion
text: After 78 years as part of General Motors, Allison Transmission is switching gears. In a sign of the times, that switch involves some big buyout shops.

headline: The Bouncing Egg
text: Lyndsay and Patrick Mikanowski’s new cookbook, “Egg,” is one I’ll probably never cook out of. It’s crazily conceptual (have a look at the cover, below) and it’s as much an art-thing, a dream book, as a food-thing. Most of the recipes are from avant-gardish, well-known chefs – Ferran Adria, Wylie Dufresne, et al. – and most look like they’d require 8 hours and a battery of sous-chefs to duplicate.

headline: Currents
text: A water purification factory reborn as a hotel and more.

headline: Flout of Office Reply
text: If you can’t defund him, just impeach him: Some opponents of the idea of impeaching President Bush (such as Washington Post columnist Eugene Robinson) base their opposition on the frightening notion of President Dick Cheney. Writing in Slate, conservative heretic Bruce Fein proposes a solution for that problem: Impeach Cheney. Fein, who was associate deputy attorney general and general counsel of the Federal Communications Commission under President Reagan, writes:

headline: Milan’s Latest Trend: Hedge-Fund Chic
text: As menswear designers showcased their latest creations on the runways of Milan this week, many of the shows seemed to have something in common, an animating spirit that reflected today’s culture, today’s time. That phenomenon, according to The New York Times, was best encapsulated by the editor of Departures, American Express’ magazine for the jet set:

headline: When the Workout Brings Out the Crowd
text: EVERYONE loves a free ride, which explains why there are so many gratis sports gatherings during the summertime. Some events in or near Manhattan are well known, such as the Downtown Boathouse’s free access to kayaks and Niketown’s group training runs in Central Park. We scoured the city to cull this insider’s list of 10 lesser-known free (or nearly free) sports happenings. Each regular get-together has added value that puts it over the top compared with similar free events, whether it’s sag wagon support on a 50-mile bike ride or a volleyball court complete with scorekeepers and balls for riverside play. Not to mention that many of the gatherings have regulars whose enthusiasm makes them a riot to row, run and skate with.

headline: Personal Shopper
text: Umbrellas, tents and pavilions guard against too much sun.

headline: Often-Asked iPhone Questions
text: With its new iPhone, Apple pulled off two masterful feats: creating the machine and creating the buzz around it.

headline: Russian Scientists Say the Arctic Is Theirs
text: Toss another stick or two on to that smoldering Cold War fire: There’s renewed talk of expanding the Russian Empire.

headline: A Reclusive Math Star Spotted in Russia
text: A sighting of a celebrated mathematician may not quite be the stuff of Page Six, but it seems perfect for us.

headline: The Hewlett-Packard Nine
text: I don’t know Bryan C. Wagner, but last week the Justice Department contacted me to let me know that I have been designated as a “victim” in his criminal prosecution. Mr. Wagner, an independent private investigator, has the unfortunate distinction of being the person taking the blame in the Hewlett-Packard pretexting scandal.

headline: Often-Asked iPhone Questions
text: With its new iPhone, Apple pulled off two masterful feats: creating the machine and creating the buzz around it.

headline: Video: Outside Two Tents, Looking In
text: The Politicker points to a WNYC video (posted below) of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg at the Crain’s breakfast on Wednesday. Under questioning by Brian Lehrer of the radio station, Mr. Bloomberg provided a sound bite:

headline: A Bill to Help 9/11 Private Paramedics
text: Maybe the third time will be a charm.

headline: Snorkeling Options on Saba
text: How is the snorkeling in the immediate area of Saba? Is there a fairly easy access to the ocean, given the altitude of the living areas? I don’t mind a trek. I would just like the opportunity to take the occasional dip or snorkel without a lengthy boat ride.

headline: Rating the U.S. Players
text: After each US match, Sam’s Army — the fan club/hinchada/torcida that follows the national team — rates the US players on a 1-to-10 scale. Sixty or more fans give their ratings, which are then averaged on the Sam’s Army web site. A consensus then emerges, and under the principle of the wisdom of the market, it provides a quite accurate gauge of how the players really did.

headline: Immigration Bill Blocked
text: Senate supporters of the far-reaching immigration bill failed to muster the 60 votes needed to close off debate today. It was a procedural vote required to move the bill on to final debate and a vote; 46 senators voted to move it on while 53 voted against the motion.

headline: Is the Sun Setting on Investment Bankers?
text: As hedge fund managers inspire fashion trends and TV series, investment bankers have inspired an obituary of sorts from one former member of that profession.

headline: Clinton’s Camp Projects $27M in 2nd Quarter
text: In a memo sent to major donors and supporters this morning, Howard Wolfson, the campaign communications director for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, predicted that the Clinton camp would raise “in the range of $27 million” for the second quarter of 2007, which ends Saturday night.

headline: The Micro-Mini Startup
text: Internet startups seem to be getting smaller and smaller. In the late 1990’s, it wasn’t uncommon for companies to raise tens of millions of dollars and hire many dozens of people, growing to hundreds very quickly. By the time entrepreneurs started rallying around the Web 2.0 banner, the trend was toward companies with less than 10 employees.

headline: Police Recover Stolen Church Reliquary
text: Detectives in Queens have cracked the case of a stolen church reliquary, the police said.

headline: Messi vs. Maradona
text: Most soccer fans must have seen these by now, but with Argentina playing the Americans tonight, it’s work another look anyway.

headline: Drop That iPhone and Wish an A.T.M. ‘Happy Birthday’
text: It seems fitting that a ubiquitous piece of technology that everyone takes for granted celebrated its 40th birthday as people line up for the iPhone, the very height of the mania.

headline: LIVE Tonight: USA vs. Argentina!
text: Group C play at the Copa América begins tonight with two games. First, Paraguay meets Colombia, followed by the match between the United States and the tournament favorites, Argentina. We’ll have the play-by-play of USA-Argentina, Duncan Irving doing the live commentary. Kickoff at the Estadio José Pachencho Romero in Maracaibo is scheduled for 8:45 p.m., Eastern time.

headline: Google Earth Makes Some Officials Nervous
text: The race to map every last square inch of New York City seems well underway, as we noted in a blog post last month. Google’s Street View and Microsoft’s Live Search Maps, which both started in the same week last month, give users bird’s-eye, street-level, 360-degree views of many streets and intersections in Manhattan and in parts of the other boroughs.

headline: Venture Capital Group Hires Lobbyist on Carried Interest
text: The army of lobbying firms hired to battle the effort to increase federal taxes for private-equity managers and venture capitalists continues to grow: A filing made public on Wednesday shows that the law firm Proskauer Rose has signed on to represent the National Venture Capital Association on the matter.

headline: F1 press conference levity continues
text: I think this is the third time I have brought this topic up this year, but it’s a wonderful sign of a change in Formula One, somewhere. The press conference today at Magny-Cours was again an occasion for a little levity, smiles and outright fun laughter.

headline: Oracle’s Deal Spree May Be Paying Off
text: Oracle has its binge of acquisitions to thank for its better-than-expected quarterly profits and sales, according to the software company and some of the analysts who cover it.

headline: Universal Fiction
text: Universal Express, a company that can pay its bills only by illegally selling unregistered shares, has taken out a full-page ad on page C11 of today’s Times. It bills the ad as a response to the “undeveloped articles” I wrote about the company last week. (Here are the column and a follow-up article.)

headline: Dwight, More in Anger than Sorrow
text: Dwight Macdonald’s letters, collected in Michael Wreszin’s anthology, “A Moral Temper,” are blistering reading – rude, funny, alive. You didn’t want to be on the wrong end of a Macdonald thrashing.

headline: Spitzer Says ‘We Need Answers’ From Con Ed
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer declined to criticize Consolidated Edison today when he was asked about the brief power failure that cut electricity to parts of the Bronx and Manhattan on Wednesday afternoon.

headline: Q&A: Ask About iPod Pricing
text: We’ve had quite a bit of discussion on our post about how much to expect Apple to cut the price of the iPhone. And we were very interested to see Hal Varian’s Economic Scene  column today about a study that tries to figure out the source, and cost, of the parts that go into an iPod. (There is a fascinating graph from the study after the jump.) The whole study is here.

headline: Once Bitten, Twice Introduced
text: On May 7, Senator Charles E. Schumer and Representative John Hall held a series of news conferences in the Hudson Valley on dam safety. Sometime during the day, Mr. Schumer felt a sting on his left leg, just above the sock. A couple of days later, he noticed a red bull’s-eye mark in the same spot on his leg — the telltale sign that he had been bitten by a tick carrying Lyme disease. The senator’s spokesman, Joshua Vlasto, says that Mr. Schumer consulted with a doctor who works for Congress and took antibiotics as a precaution, and that the senator did not develop the disease.The tick bite was widely reported, and today, Mr. Schumer’s office announced that he had reintroduced a bill, co-sponsored with Senators Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut and Chuck Hagel of Nebraska, that would provide $100 million over five years for studying, preventing and treating tick-borne illnesses and creating an advisory committee on the matter. Lyme disease cases are up 35 percent in New York City, to 307 known cases in 2006 from 224 in 2003; the record was 399 cases, in 2005.

headline: Google v. Microsoft: What’s the Better Workplace?
text: The perks at Google have long been the talk of Silicon Valley and beyond. But when all is said and done, how do they stack up against the perks at Microsoft? And which is the better workplace?

headline: Family Honor on Smith Point; Animal Houses of Belmar; Other Seaside News
text: Jim Dooley’s father was a lifeguard. His father’s uncle was a lifeguard, too. Now Mr. Dooley himself is chief of the Smith Point lifeguard crew in Long Island.

headline: A Nation of Scaredy-Cats?
text: Digital rudeness is alive and well. More people than ever are yelling into their cell phones, sending text messages in movie houses and reading e-mail on their BlackBerry while you try to talk to them. In one recent indication that etiquette had reached a new low, I was on a tightly packed Bay Area Rapid Transit train during rush hour, and was forced to listen to a fellow passenger conduct a lengthy cell phone conversation with the speaker phone turned on.

headline: Tip: Finding That iPhone
text: Apple is trying to be helpful with a Web page that will tell you what Apple stores have iPhones. It’s binary, yes or no, not how many are left at the store.

headline: Debt Watch: Dollar General, Servicemaster Face Tougher Terms for Offerings
text: In perhaps another sign that buyout boom is slowing down, Dollar General, the national discount chain, has lopped off a potentially risky form of debt from its proposed bond offering, Bloomberg News and Reuters reported Thursday. The retailer has removed $725 million so-called pay-in-kind toggles, or bonds that can be repaid in cash or by the issuing of more debt.

headline: Celebrating the Bridge
text: Joseph Bertolozzi is using a bridge near Poughkeepsie, N.Y., as an instrument and is composing a suite for it.

headline: Accelerade Commercial
text: An ad for Accelerade.

headline: Circle Line Loses Liberty-Ellis Ferry Contract
