text: The Circle Line, which has held the contract to run the ferries to the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island from Lower Manhattan since the 1950s, has lost the contract for that service to a company that runs ferries between San Francisco and Alcatraz.The National Park Service announced today that it had selected Hornblower Cruises and Events to run the ferry service to Liberty and Ellis Islands under a 10-year concession. The contract still needs to be signed by Hornblower and pass a 60-day mandatory Congressional review. Hornblower is expected to take over the ferry service in October.

headline: A List With Personality
text: I’m always on the lookout for great wine lists and I’m thrilled when I find one. Last week I wrote about one kind of great list, at Landmarc in the Time Warner Center, where the prices are extraordinarily low even if the wines are not terribly exciting. Yesterday I found a great list of entirely different sort, at Trestle on Tenth in Chelsea, a lovely little neighborhood restaurant with Swiss and French influences. Here, the wines themselves are exciting and the prices are more than fair. I’ve eaten there enjoyably several times, and here’s a review from my colleague Frank Bruni. But while I’ve always liked the wine list, I think it has improved tremendously in the last few months.

headline: Inside the Mind of Murdoch
text: Today’s unusually late start for reporters was the latest attempt by The Wall Street Journal’s newsroom to protest the expected sale of the paper and Dow Jones, its parent company, to Rupert Murdoch’s media empire, the News Corporation. A passage from this week’s New Yorker may give an indication of just how effective they are likely to be in influencing Mr. Murdoch.

headline: Will Bush Get ‘Saved’ Again?
Hasidic Village Has Led New York State in Growth Since 2000
text: Kiryas Joel, an Orthodox Jewish enclave in southern Orange County, grew faster than any other community in New York State between 2000 and 2006, according to an analysis by The New York Times of Census Bureau data released this morning.Kiryas Joel grew by 51 percent, to 20,071 residents from 13,273, over the six-period period. The village was incorporated in 1977 as an offshoot of a Satmar Hasidic sect in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. As Fernanda Santos reported last August, the community has had a high rate of natural growth, in part because under their religious beliefs, birth control is banned and women get married young and stay in the village.

headline: The Singles Vote
text: The so-called marriage gap, in which single people vote differently from married people, has been evident in the last three presidential campaigns, with married voters tending to support the Republican and unmarrieds supporting the Democrat.

headline: FIFA’s Altitude Ban: Is Sepp Blatter High?
text: Yesterday FIFA announced that it has decided to roll back its proposed ban against international matches played at high altitude from 2,500 meters to 3,000 meters. (For you Americans reading this, that’s from about 8,200 feet to 9,850 feet.) You’ll find FIFA’s announcement buried in the fourth paragraph of this press release.

headline: YouTube Answers Its Critics
text: In response to a deluge of complaints from users, YouTube.com has reinstated features that allow visitors to its site to sort videos by the number of views, rating and other measures in each of its topical categories – “News and Politics,” being one of our favorites.

headline: Council Aide Suspended Over Threats
text: A City Council aide who used the word “assassination” in criticizing a councilman, Leroy G. Comrie Jr., has been suspended without pay for six weeks, the Council’s speaker, Christine C. Quinn, announced this afternoon.

headline: 9,045 Phone Calls During an Hourlong Blackout
text: Consolidated Edison added 50 customer service representatives, for a total of 280, within 30 minutes after the start of the brief power failure on Wednesday that cut power to 385,000 people and disrupted subway and train service and traffic lights.

headline: Competition Is Sometimes Good for You
text: Verizon sent me an e-mail last night to let me know about a “price adjustment” on my DSL service. The price is going up, of course, but I had to check my last bill to see how much: was $29.95, now $31.99.

headline: Now Batting for the Yankees…Joe Torre?
text: Yankees Manager Joe Torre is not the type to bark at his players or flip over a table in the clubhouse to try to motivate them. But Torre admitted he recently thought about taking batting practice with the Yankees “to lighten the mood.”

headline: Readers’ Questions: The Beginnings of Synthetic Life?
text: Are scientists on the brink of creating entirely new forms of life? In a study published this week by the journal Science, a research team led by Dr. J. Craig Venter and Dr. John I. Glass reported that they had managed to replace the genes of one species of bacteria entirely with the genes of another. Dr. Venter and Dr. Glass will be taking readers’ questions about their research and its implications on Friday, and their answers will be posted here. Submit your question below; they will not be able to answer all questions and only those selected will be published. (Editor’s note: questions are no longer being accepted.)

headline: Reading the Ink Blot
text: Well, it took me two weeks to work up the nerve, but I finally read all your comments about my last Hillary Clinton column and see that we have had a pretty major misunderstanding.

text: For Duncan Irving’s live updates of tonight’s Group C match between the United States and Argentina from Maracaibo, click and use the “refresh” or F5 buttons on your browser. Kickoff is at 8:45 p.m. eastern.

headline: Kramnik Leads Dortmund With 3 Rounds to Go
text: Vladimir Kramnik of Russia, the world champion, leads the annual super strong tournament in Dortmund, Germany, with 3 out of 4 points. Called the Sparkassen Chess-Meeting (which almost sounds like a tea social), the tournament is one of the four elite tournaments on the chess calendar (along with Linares, Corus and the M-Tel Masters). The official Web site for the tournament can be found here.

text: Senator Chris Dodd is not Paris Hilton. Tavis Smiley is not Alex Trebek. And both Michelle and Senator Barack Obama are HIV-free.

headline: 5 U.S. Soldiers Killed in Iraq Attack
text: BAGHDAD, June 29 — Five American soldiers were killed and seven more wounded when their patrol in a southern neighborhood of Baghdad was hit by a roadside bomb, the American military said today.

headline: Exploring Vibrant Latin American Sounds
text: “When we think of Argentine composers we think of Piazzolla and now Osvaldo Golijov,” said Michael Barrett, the general director of the Caramoor International Music Festival. “But that’s the tip of one iceberg in one country.” Mr. Barrett and the festival are probing deeper into Latin American music with Sonidos Latinos, a two-year series of concerts that opens tonight.

headline: For the Record
text: An obituary yesterday of Tina L. Brozman, a former New York bankruptcy judge, misstated a holding of Maxwell Communication, on whose 1991 bankruptcy case she worked. It was the parent of The Daily News of New York, not The New York Post.

headline: Stoic Londoners Shrug at Latest Threat
text: LONDON, June 29 — The headline of London’s Evening Standard newspaper today said 1,700 people could have died at “ladies’ night” in the Tiger Tiger night spot. The police gauged the potential death toll as “significant” if the car had exploded.

headline: Even Before Rain, Mets Would Rather Be in Philadelphia
text: Willie Randolph and the Mets were not happy that they were scheduled to play the finale of their four-game series with Cardinals last night. They would have preferred an afternoon game, so they could leisurely make their way to Philadelphia for today’s day-night doubleheader against the Phillies.

headline: Footnotes

The main building of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, normally closed on Mondays, will be open from 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. on Monday in connection with the Independence Day holiday later that week. Other Monday openings will take place on Sept. 3 (Labor Day) and Oct. 8 (Columbus Day). ... Mary Louise Wilson, who won a Tony Award this month for best featured actress for her portrayal of the elderly Big Edie Beale in “Grey Gardens,” will leave the show on July 29. There was no immediate word on a replacement.

Board of Education, a bitterly divided Supreme Court declared Thursday that public school systems cannot seek to achieve or maintain integration through measures that take explicit account of a student’s race.

headline: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article last Friday about the dearth of university students in Japan misstated the reason that the numbers of college-age children of baby boom parents there peaked in 1992, years earlier than the American peak. It was because Japan’s baby boom was concentrated in the years immediately following World War II, while the American boom lasted until 1962. It was not because Japan’s boom started earlier; both started in 1946.

headline: Salvaging a Prudent Name
text: James E. Cayne has a bellyache.

headline: For the Record
text: An obituary yesterday of the fashion designer Liz Claiborne misstated the duration of her working relationship with Arthur Ortenberg, her husband, before the founding of Liz Claiborne Inc. in 1976. Mr. Ortenberg was Ms. Claiborne’s boss for two years, beginning in 1954, not for two decades. The obituary also misidentified the object of the couple’s wildlife conservation efforts in Madagascar. Their foundation sought to rescue the “fish-eagle,” an endangered bird there; they were not trying to save fish and eagles.

headline: Letter to the Editor
text: To the Editor: New York’s second-home owners have broader voting rights than your June 22 article “The Principle of 2nd Home, 2nd Vote” may lead readers to infer.

headline: A Friendly Interstate Battle of Online One-Upmanship
text: BOSTON, June 28 — Sure, they share a river border, but New Hampshire and Vermont have long been the inverse of one another, from politics to shape (flip one upside down and you get the other).

headline: Monster Prices for ‘Frankenstein’
text: Given that the Mel Brooks musical “The Producers” introduced the $480 ticket to Broadway, it’s no wonder that rumors are already spreading about the ticket pricing for “The New Mel Brooks Musical Young Frankenstein,” opening on Nov. 8 at the 1,821-seat Hilton Theater. Well, here’s the official word: On Friday and Saturday evenings and at weekend matinees, you will be able to buy something called a premier seat — roughly, one of the best 100 seats in the theater — for $450. Premium seats, the next-best 120 or so seats, will go for $375. The remaining orchestra and dress circle tickets will be priced at $120 each, and the balcony will be divided between $80 and $60 tickets. Both premium and premier seats will cost $100 less for other performances, and prices for balcony seats will be slightly lower as well. A production spokesman said $25 orchestra seats would be available for most performances, though there are no specific details about those tickets yet. One more thing: “Young Frankenstein” is allotting fewer tickets than normal to groups — 50 at most per weekend performance — to “allow greater single-buyer access,” the spokesman wrote in an e-mail message.

headline: Fund-Raising for Clinton and Obama Nears Records
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign announced yesterday that it would raise “in the range of $27 million” for the second quarter of 2007, which ends Saturday night, and also warned supporters to prepare for a similarly dazzling result by a leading Democratic rival, Senator Barack Obama.

headline: 'E PLURIBUS VENOM'
text: ‘E PLURIBUS VENOM’ The paradox of well-heeled and wealthy art collectors fawning over rebellious street art is apparent everywhere in the art world. The graffiti artist known as Banksy is the toast of London, while Shepard Fairey is approaching cult status in Los Angeles for his posters and stickers of the face of the professional wrestler Andre the Giant with the word “obey” emblazoned across them. Mr. Fairey, 37, is now having his first major New York gallery exhibition, split between the Jonathan LeVine Gallery in Chelsea and a rented 6,600-square-foot warehouse exhibition space in Brooklyn for huge graffiti installations and murals. (Last week’s opening in Brooklyn was disrupted by a man trying to set off an incendiary device.) There are about 80 works between the two sites, together forming a comprehensive, 20-year survey of his artwork in various mediums: screen prints, stencils, stickers, album covers, collage, spray paint and more. Despite the range of mediums and styles, the imagery comes off as generic, combining decorative elements with political metaphors, like an image of a couple cuddling a bomb. (Right is “War for Sale.”) It’s Norman Rockwell crossed with the Dead Kennedys crossed with Communist-era propaganda. References to capitalism and war predominate, especially in the Chelsea show, where many works are neatly framed and ready for sale. It is tempting to see this stuff as just another luxury commodity. (Jonathan LeVine Gallery, 529 West 20th Street, ninth floor, 212-243-3822, jonathanlevinegallery.com, through July 21; 81 Front Street, at Washington Street, Dumbo, Brooklyn, through July 6.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

headline: The Spice Girls, Together Again
text: Like many other disbanded pop groups before them, the Spice Girls have decided to reunite, The Associated Press reported. In London yesterday, the five-member Girl Power group of the 1990s announced plans for their first concerts since breaking up in 2001 and the first with all the members of the original ensemble since Geri Halliwell (Ginger Spice) left to pursue a solo career in 1998. She was on hand with Victoria Beckham (Posh Spice), Melanie Chisholm (Sporty Spice), Emma Bunton (Baby Spice) and Melanie Brown (Scary Spice) to say that they had agreed on 11 concerts around the world in December and January. “Obviously it’s nostalgic,” Ms. Halliwell said. “But equally, if new fans want to come along, that’s fantastic.” The tour will take them to Los Angeles (Dec. 7); Las Vegas (Dec. 8); New York (Dec. 11); London (Dec. 15); Cologne, Germany (Dec. 20); Madrid (Dec. 23); Beijing (Jan. 10); Hong Kong (Jan. 12); Sydney, Australia (Jan. 17); Cape Town (Jan. 20); and Buenos Aires (Jan. 24). Mrs. Beckham, a mother of three sons, said the tour would be arranged to accommodate the members’ children.

headline: Resegregation Now
text: The Supreme Court ruled 53 years ago in Brown v. Board of Education that segregated education is inherently unequal, and it ordered the nation’s schools to integrate. Yesterday, the court switched sides and told two cities that they cannot take modest steps to bring public school students of different races together. It was a sad day for the court and for the ideal of racial equality.

headline: Season of Sounds That Span the Globe
text: The world’s music comes to New York during the summer months. Here is an annotated sampler, in chronological order, of the vast array of such events taking place around town in coming weeks.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about evolution and the soul misstated the views that Nancey Murphy, a philosopher at Fuller Theological Seminary, expresses in her book “Bodies and Souls, or Spirited Bodies?” Dr. Murphy argues that neither humans nor animals have souls, not that both have souls. She cited the ideas of Thomas Aquinas on animal and human souls to contrast with her view, not to support it.

headline: Bondholders Scream Foul as Tyco Splits
text: Bondholders can be the forgotten investors in corporate America. Nobody ever promises to “maximize bondholder value.” Nor should they. Bond investors do not own the company, as shareholders do. They merely have a contractual relationship with it.

headline: 'LE DOULOS'
text: ‘LE DOULOS’ Jean-Pierre Melville’s brutal and subtly brilliant policier “Le Doulos” (shot in 1962, released in 1963) underscores why the French put the name to film noir. Based on the Pierre Lesou novel published by Gallimard in its celebrated Série Noire line, the film follows the parallel fates of two criminals — Jean-Paul Belmondo as Silien, Serge Reggiani as Maurice — bound by an almost mystical sense of masculine loyalty. Mr. Belmondo, below, who had recently worn a priest’s collar for Melville in “Léon Morin, Prêtre” (1961), enters “Le Doulos” in a more familiar Melvillian costume of a belted trench coat and fedora. A stated friend to Maurice as well as to the police, he first appears masked by an enveloping shadow, his silhouette framed in a doorway. He remains a darkly obscured figure for much of the rest of the story, a disturbing question mark for both Maurice (who believes in him) and the audience (who may not). The story eases and lurches, at times mechanistically, but what sticks and sticks hard is the way Melville fashions an entire world out of a threadbare room, a light swinging as if from a gallows, an ominous hat-check number, filigrees of cool jazz, an hourglass figure that melts into the image of a yapping dog and a masterly sense of cinematic space, exemplified by a lengthy interrogation scene. In “Le Doulos” the camera and the actors move in a silent conspiracy, revealing more about the true nature of a man far in advance of any line of dialogue. “Le Doulos” will be shown in a new 35-millimeter print, making it even easier to swoon into its darkness. (Through July 12, Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, west of Avenue of the Americas, South Village, 212-727-8110, filmforum.org; $10.50) MANOHLA DARGIS

headline: For Acadians, History Speaks in Accents Disconsolate
text: DRIVE past the potato fields of the St. John Valley in northernmost Maine, walk into Rosette’s, and a four-inch-high mound of fries hand-cut from regional tubers awaits. So does some half-and-half of a linguistic variety.

headline: Colombian Rebels Blamed for Hostage Deaths
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, June 28 — President Álvaro Uribe of Colombia lashed out at the country’s largest guerrilla group on Thursday, accusing it of killing 11 kidnapped lawmakers after the guerrillas said the hostages died in cross-fire during a military attack this month.

headline: Bush Asserts Executive Privilege on Subpoenas
text: WASHINGTON, June 28 — President Bush moved one step closer to a constitutional showdown with Democrats on Thursday, as the White House asserted executive privilege in refusing to comply with Congressional subpoenas for documents related to the dismissal of federal prosecutors.

headline: Kiichi Miyazawa, Japan Premier in the ’90s, Dies at 87
text: Kiichi Miyazawa, who, as prime minister and holder of many other top government posts, helped guide Japan from postwar ruin to economic superpower, died yesterday at his home in Tokyo. He was 87.

headline: Still Another View of Role of Panel Proposed for Wall St. Journal

headline: Circle Line Loses Pact for Ferries to Liberty Island
text: The National Park Service said yesterday that it planned to have another company replace the Circle Line, which has provided ferry service to the Statue of Liberty for more than half a century.

text: Paris Hilton read aloud her prison writings as if she had spent a lifetime on Robben Island, and that was surely the highlight of this heiress-actress’s first television interview since her release from jail.

text: TRENTON, June 28 — The state trooper driving Gov. Jon S. Corzine during a thunderous crash in April told police officers investigating the accident that he was unaware the vehicle had its emergency lights flashing and was traveling far above the posted speed limit of 65 miles per hour, according to a report released on Thursday by the state police.

headline: FOURTH OF JULY CELEBRATION
text: FOURTH OF JULY CELEBRATION Celebrity sightings are not uncommon in New York; spend enough time in the city, and you can run into the likes of Woody Allen, Spike Lee and Julianne Moore. But residents don’t expect to encounter George Washington and Benjamin Franklin, unless those famous faces happen to be in their wallets.

headline: A Change of Scene for Frick’s Fragonards
text: A CHANGE OF SCENE

headline: Sustained in Death by the Memory of One Great Love
text: At first, second and final glance, Susan Minot’s “Evening,” a claustrophobic 1998 novel about a woman in her 60s remembering the days and few torrid nights of her life while slowly, very slowly dying, doesn’t seem as if it would translate easily to the big screen. It hasn’t. Stuffed with actors of variable talent, burdened with false, labored dialogue and distinguished by a florid visual style better suited to fairy tales and greeting cards, this miscalculation underlines what can happen when certain literary works meet the bottom line of the movies. It also proves that not every book deserves its own film.

headline: Two Car Bombs Are Found in London
text: LONDON, June 29 — Two days after a new government took office under Gordon Brown, London was thrust into a new terrorism alert today when police found two Mercedes Benz cars filled with gasoline, nails and gas canisters parked close together in an area known for packed night-clubs and late-night bars.

headline: DIY Art: Walk on It, Write on It, Stroke It
text: Rudolf Stingel’s show at Daniel Newburg’s SoHo gallery in 1991 has always stuck with me. Mr. Stingel was 35 and newly arrived from Italy, and his American debut pulled no punches. He simply covered the gallery’s entire floor with plush carpet so deeply orange that the white walls acquired a pinkish glow. The effect was profoundly, disturbingly, subversively optical, a Duchampian ready-made in blatant disregard of Duchamp’s injunction against the retinal aspect of art.

headline: If It Quacks, It Could Be Your Tour Bus
text: WHEN James Healy gets behind the wheel of a grumbling 19,000-pound ex-military vehicle called a duck and begins maneuvering it over Boston’s crowded streets, he becomes Cmdr. James Bernard Swampscott, a decorated military officer of his own creation. The commander wears khaki fatigues and displays a knowledge of Beacon Hill, the Common and other landmarks that is nearly as impressive as his driving skills. He also turns social director, leading a chorus of his passengers in a “quack quack” at waving pedestrians on Newbury Street.

headline: At 70, Jazz’s Ubiquitous Free Agent Still Has Miles to Go
text: Long ago, the JVC Jazz Festival started programming its concerts by formula. Perhaps for that reason, Wednesday night’s show at Carnegie Hall, built around the bassist Ron Carter, felt familiar. It was a quadruple-decker, with some of Mr. Carter’s old friends of high repute, as well as his two current bands, and the straw occasion for it was his 70th birthday last month.

headline: The Murdoch Factor
text: In October 2003, the nonpartisan Program on International Policy Attitudes published a study titled “Misperceptions, the media and the Iraq war.” It found that 60 percent of Americans believed at least one of the following: clear evidence had been found of links between Iraq and Al Qaeda; W.M.D. had been found in Iraq; world public opinion favored the U.S. going to war with Iraq.

headline: Chiefs Defend Slow Network for the iPhone
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 28 — On the eve of the Apple iPhone’s sale, the top executives of Apple and AT&T defended their decision to rely upon AT&T’s slow Edge wireless data network, rather than a faster network that is less widely available.

headline: Facing the Nation, Singing Honky-Tonk
text: “As a country and western singer,” Tom Brokaw said on Wednesday night, “Bob Schieffer is a great host of ‘Face the Nation.’ ”

headline: Fuel for Lebanon’s Next War
text: If another war between Lebanon and Israel is to be prevented, the traffic of Hezbollah arms and fighters across the Syrian-Lebanese border must be stopped. That’s been clear since the last round of fighting ended nine months ago and the job of monitoring the border went to the Lebanese Army, backed up by an expanded United Nations force.

headline: It Was Lightning, Con Ed Says, That Caused the Lights to Go Out
text: The cause of Wednesday’s power failure in Manhattan and the Bronx was as improbable as getting struck by lightning, which almost certainly is what happened to a piece of Con Edison’s electrical network, officials of the utility said yesterday.

headline: As Form Holds, Henman Throws Some Barbs at Britain
text: WIMBLEDON, England, June 28 — Through four days, everything is as expected here — the strawberries are perfectly ripe, the clouds have made good on their threats of rain, and the draw has proved to be a fine predictor of the results.

headline: Video of Bryant’s Rant Against Lakers Is Released
text: Kobe Bryant is still a Los Angeles Laker despite a trade request, and his acidic discontent is now being broadcast on the Internet.

headline: Cadbury Bets on Protein to Promote Its New Sports Drink
text: THE competitive — and lucrative — category of sports drinks is getting more crowded as the third-biggest beverage marketer behind Coke and Pepsi introduces a brand to battle Gatorade and Powerade for the hearts and mouths of thirsty athletes and the legions of would-be jocks.

headline: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Wednesday about a lawsuit by Rebecca Charles, a Manhattan chef who has charged a competitor with unfairly copying her restaurant’s concept, design and menu, referred imprecisely to another chef, David Burke, who has also asserted intellectual property rights. Mr. Burke, who received, and later gave up, a trademark for the term “swordfish chop,” also applied for a trademark on the term “salmon pastrami,” according to the United States Patent and Trademark Office. He did not receive a trademark on the term “salmon pastrami.”

headline: Domestic Issues Frame Democratic Debate in a Mostly Minority Setting
text: WASHINGTON, June 28 — For 90 minutes Thursday night, eight Democratic candidates debated before an audience made up largely of one of their party’s most reliable and liberal constituencies, African-American voters, and used the stage to urge a revitalization of domestic programs they said had faltered under President Bush.

headline: For the Record
text: A report in the Inside Art column in Weekend on June 15, about the Japanese artist and curator Takashi Murakami, misspelled the name of the art show he runs. It is Geisai, not Gesai. It also misstated the policy of his company, Kaikai Kiki, on taking a 10 percent agent’s fee for works sold at the show. It does not always take a fee, and in Miami in December it plans to waive it for young artists.

headline: Barriers Held Against Beatlemania, but Not March of Progress
text: They were there when the Beatles came to America, keeping screaming teenage girls from spilling into the street, and when the astronauts of Apollo 11 got a ticker-tape parade up Broadway. Same thing at the Yankees’ championship parades; they kept crowds to the side as the heroes glided by.

headline: NIK BARTSCH'S RONIN
text: NIK BÄRTSCH’S RONIN “Zen-funk” is the term that Nik Bärtsch, a Swiss pianist, uses to describe the music of his five-piece band, Ronin, above. It’s an eminently printable phrase, but it cleanly misses the mark. True, Mr. Bärtsch composed the pieces for his recent album, “Stoa” (ECM), during a six-month residency in Japan. And, yes, at times those pieces do flirt with funkiness, though to draw allusions to James Brown, as some reviewers have, following Mr. Bärtsch’s lead, is a rather dubious stretch. The problem with the term is its connotation of mind-clearing tranquillity, when Ronin proposes something much more heady and premeditated. “Stoa,” for instance, relies on a precision movement of interlocking parts in a manner suggestive of a timepiece. (The Swiss and the Japanese have long had this expertise in common, after all.) Minimalism is a useful frame of reference, in the same way that it is for some hard-to-classify American bands. One track on the album, “Modul 35,” could be considered an acoustic corollary to the music of Battles; elsewhere there’s a vague resemblance to Tortoise. And videotape of Mr. Bärtsch and his colleagues performing “Modul 33” last fall (find it on YouTube, or at nikbaertsch.com) brings to mind the contemporary chamber group So Percussion. Next week’s showcase, which comes on the heels of festival appearances in Vancouver and Montreal, will mark Ronin’s United States debut. If all goes according to plan, Mr. Bärtsch will engage the drummer Kaspar Rast, the percussionist Andi Pupato, the bassist Björn Meyer and the clarinetist Stefan Haslebacher in a tricky yet ethereal interaction that’s more vivid in performance than on record. Maybe it will be meditative, and maybe it will get funky. Whatever the case, the crowd response will surely outdo the sound of one hand clapping. (Tuesday at 7:30 p.m., Joe’s Pub, at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, 212-539-8778, joespub.com; cover, $18, with a two-drink minimum.) NATE CHINEN

headline: A Big, Wide World of Music
text: Music from all over the world floods into New York City year round, but especially in summertime. That’s when outdoor stages supplement clubs and theaters, and free concert series can introduce audiences to music with lower commercial profiles.

headline: Majoring in Snob Studies at Rich Kid U
text: “The Best Years,” a new series on the N network, immerses itself so deeply in the pits of class warfare that its characters might as well be carrying cans of mace.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (TCM) WITNESS FOR THE PROSECUTION (1957) Billy Wilder’s popular whodunit, an adaptation of the Agatha Christie murder mystery, was nominated for six Oscars and boasts a starry cast that includes Marlene Dietrich, Elsa Lanchester, Henry Daniell, Tyrone Power and Charles Laughton, above.

headline: In Texas, Assessing Flood Damage and Preparing for More
text: GRANBURY, Tex., June 28 — The sun emerged Thursday afternoon amid the thunderclouds that have soaked much of Texas in recent weeks, giving residents hope that the floodwaters will continue to recede.

headline: Fed Leaves a Key Rate Unchanged
text: WASHINGTON, June 28 — The Federal Reserve, saying that inflation remains its “predominant policy concern,” left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 5.25 percent on Thursday and signaled that it would keep it at that level for some time.

headline: Summer Rentals: It’s Not Too Late
text: EACH year, Stephen Duffy and a bunch of his friends rent a house in Provincetown, Mass., where they compete in a Labor Day tennis tournament. Finding a rental to accommodate the group in this popular beach town at the tip of Cape Cod usually involves many calls to brokers, vetting of multiple properties, and often simply settling for whatever is available.

headline: William Hutt, Actor, Dies at 87
text: William Hutt, one of the foremost Canadian stage actors of his generation and a founding member of the Stratford Festival of Canada in Ontario, where he appeared in or directed 130 productions, died on Wednesday in a Stratford hospital. He was 87.

headline: Thomas Hits 500th, and the Ball Is Returned
text: MINNEAPOLIS, June 28 — Home run balls hit by the opposition at the Metrodome usually end up thrown back on the field before the player finishes circling the bases. But when the ball Frank Thomas of Toronto hit in the first inning Thursday afternoon for his 500th career home run landed in the stands in left-center field and stayed there, Thomas figured it was bound for eBay or an auction house.

headline: Messier and Stevens Lead 4 Inductees to Hall of Fame
text: Mark Messier was on a cruise with his parents and Scott Stevens was about to clean his kitchen floor yesterday when they received the news that they had been elected to the Hockey Hall of Fame.

headline: Jupp Derwall,  Former Coach of West German Soccer Team, Dies at 80
text: Jupp Derwall, who coached the West German soccer team to victory in the 1980 European Championship and a second-place finish in the 1982 World Cup after a controversy-laden run to the title game, died Tuesday in St. Ingbert, Germany. He was 80.

headline: The Energy Bill (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Revisiting Old Friends Who Write and Fight
text: Two very different roads to the past are being traveled by two very different actresses in the Roundabout Theater Company’s mildly entertaining, maddeningly disjunctive revival of “Old Acquaintance,” John Van Druten’s 1940 comedy of high-heeled and round-heeled sexual mores in literary Manhattan.

headline: Russia: Top Court Backs Ban on ‘Terrorist’ Remains
text: The Constitutional Court lent its support to a government policy of withholding remains of suspected terrorists, a practice causing anguish among families in the Caucasus. Under the policy, bodies are either secretly buried or cremated. Muslim relatives have complained, saying that withholding the dead punishes families, not terrorists, and that no due process determines whether the dead were terrorists at all. Russia calls the practice an effective deterrent. The authorities have withheld remains in several prominent cases, including of leaders in the Chechen separatist movement. After militants briefly besieged the city of Nalchik in 2005, the authorities stacked more than 100 bodies in an unrefrigerated container. It later cremated them all, as relatives begged for their return.

headline: Bald Eagles, Thriving, Settle Into Suburban Life
text: OCALA, Fla., June 28 — Bald eagles, whose numbers dwindled to historic lows in the early 1960s, are again flourishing and no longer need the protections of the Endangered Species Act, Interior Secretary Dirk Kempthorne announced Thursday.

headline: Growing in the Caribbean, Inspiring Artists Over the Centuries
text: If plants and politics seem to be entwined lately, what with genetically modified food, the payment of coffee-bean pickers, deforestation and drugs, a stroll through “Paradise in Print” at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx is a reminder that plants have long played a major role in the human story. This is particularly true in the Caribbean, where, as an exhibition handout puts it, “plants grow at such a quick pace that the gardener’s most useful tool can be a machete.”

headline: For the Record
text: An obituary on Tuesday of J. B. Handelsman, a cartoonist whose work appeared in The New Yorker, included incorrect information from the Web site of The New Yorker for the caption of one of his cartoons for the magazine. The original caption, with a cartoon showing a maitre d’hotel speaking by telephone to a would-be diner, read: “Certainly. A party of four at seven-thirty in the name of Dr. Jennings. May I ask whether that is an actual medical degree or merely a Ph.D.?” The caption in the Web site’s tribute to Mr. Handelsman, which was quoted in the obituary, omitted the word “merely.”

headline: Britain: House Prices Show a Surge
text: British house prices advanced this month at the fastest pace since December, bolstering the case for an interest rate increase by the Bank of England next week. The average cost of a home rose 1.1 percent from May, to £184,070 ($368,000), according to the Nationwide Building Society, the biggest mortgage lender in Britain. “The bounce-back in June is a bit stronger than expected,” said Fionnuala Earley, chief economist at Nationwide. “It looks like the bank will bring forward the decision to increase interest rates, and increase the risk that rates get to 6 percent this year.”

headline: Russia: Gazprom’s Profit Doubled in 2006
text: Gazprom, Russia’s natural gas export monopoly, said 2006 profit doubled, to a record $22.6 billion, beating estimates, as it sold more fuel at higher prices. Net income surged 97 percent, to 613.3 billion rubles, from 311.1 billion rubles a year earlier, the state-run company said. The profit equals $22.6 billion at the average ruble rate for the period and is 8.2 percent higher than the median estimate of six analysts in a Bloomberg survey. Rising prices in Europe, where Gazprom has a quarter of the market, and increased shipments to former Soviet nations drove the gain in earnings, the highest ever reported by a Russian company. Gazprom, based in Moscow, relies entirely on exports for profit because it loses money on sales in Russia, where prices are capped.

headline: Giambi Agrees to Cooperate; So Should Selig
text: Whether or not his lawyers have portrayed his circumstances to him this way, Jason Giambi has entered a plea bargain with Commissioner Bud Selig. Unlike a typical plea bargain, Selig serves as prosecutor and judge, and that’s where Giambi faces a perilous problem with his decision to speak with George J. Mitchell.

headline: Timeless Treasures
text: WHO Siobhan Bonnouvrier, 35, a style director at a fashion magazine, and her husband, David Bonnouvrier, 41, founder and chief executive of a management company, both from Manhattan

headline: Norman Mailer and Günter Grass: Remembrance of Things Past
text: Norman Mailer speaking on Wednesday night at the New York Public Library with the Nobel Prize-winner Günter Grass, said, “This may well be one of the very last times I appear in public; old age is catching up with me.” Still, despite walking with two canes and complaining that he couldn’t hear or see well, Mr. Mailer, 84, was as feisty and funny as ever. He defended Mr. Grass, who has been attacked for what critics say is the belated acknowledgment in his new memoir, “Peeling the Onion,” that he served for a few months in the Waffen-SS as a teenager. Mr. Grass, best known for his novel “The Tin Drum,” has unflinchingly demanded that Germans account for Nazi atrocities. Mr. Mailer said he searched his own life to figure out why Mr. Grass didn’t speak about his experience earlier. “What have I held onto for so long?” he asked, and then answered: stabbing his second wife, Adele, in 1960. “It’s something I’ll probably never write about,” he said. “I’ve never felt ready to write about it.” Unless you can “write something that’s brilliant,” he added, you’re better off not writing about it at all. Mr. Grass, who said his SS experience was publicized in the 1960s, added that he always knew he would write about this period but that “I was going to write about it when I was ready.” PATRICIA COHEN

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article last Friday about nonprofit organizations created by John Edwards that helped keep his political profile alive after the 2004 election referred imprecisely to a donation made to an Edwards campaign committee. Although an individual donor was not identified, the donation was credited to Oak Spring Farms LLC, which listed a New York hotel as its address. The donation was not “anonymous.” The article also misstated the title of one of Mr. Edwards’s campaign advisers. David Ginsberg is a senior adviser for communications; he is not the campaign’s deputy campaign manager, a post currently held by Jonathan Prince.

headline: Text of Fed’s Decision to Hold Rates Steady
text: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Fed’s monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to leave interest rates unchanged.

headline: The Single-Minded Men Who Produced One-of-a-Kind Flowers
text: CORNING, N.Y. — “They must have been single-minded, to put it conservatively,” said David Whitehouse, executive director of the Corning Museum of Glass here.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Editor Steps Down in Los Angeles
text: Douglas Frantz said yesterday that he would leave The Los Angeles Times after less than two years as managing editor, a turbulent period of transition and conflict between the newspaper and its corporate parent, the Tribune Company.

headline: F.D.A. Issues Alert on Chinese Seafood
text: The Food and Drug Administration today issued an alert challenging imports of five major types of farm-raised seafood from China, including shrimp and catfish, because testing found recurrent contamination from carcinogens and antibiotics.

headline: Iraqi Shiite Parties Agree to Try to Unite Moderates
text: BAGHDAD, June 28  In a tacit admission of the troubles between Iraq’s two largest Shiite political parties, their respective leaders signed an agreement this week to work together and back appointments to the cabinet and other posts based on professional experience rather than party allegiances, officials said.

headline: Bonds and Baseball Will Need an Al Downing
text: During an interview on a Boston radio station earlier this month, in anticipation of the San Francisco Giants coming to town, Boston Red Sox pitcher Curt Schilling was asked if Barry Bonds was at home run No. 754 and Schilling was pitching, would he give Bonds a pitch to hit.

headline: Across U.S., a New Look at School Integration Efforts
text: The Supreme Court ruling striking down voluntary programs to integrate schools in Seattle and Louisville, Ky., left hundreds of school districts struggling yesterday to assess whether they must change policies that use race as a factor in school assignments.

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: 62 City Women Agree: The Farmer Needs a Wife
text: LA VIÑUELA, Spain — Ramón Sánchez is not a great believer in the powers of Cupid. But when Mr. Sánchez, a wiry 54-year-old bachelor, heard that dozens of women would be coming to this quiet village for a blind date with the local men, he happily signed up.

headline: Fox Wins Wednesday Ratings Race
text: Fox’s “So You Think You Can Dance” danced circles around its competition on Wednesday, earning the network its 24th consecutive ratings victory on Wednesdays. From 8 to 10 p.m., Fox’s two-hour dance-off attracted 9.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. ABC and NBC fought a close race for second over all in the 18-to- 49 demographic. At 8 ABC’s “Next Best Thing” finished solidly No. 2 in the hour (7.2 million), while NBC’s “Last Comic Standing” (5.8 million) edged ahead of ABC’s “American Inventor” (6.6 million) and CBS’s “Criminal Minds” repeat (6.6 million) to lead the 9 o’clock hour among adults 18 to 49. CBS, which ranked second for the night in total viewers, finished fourth in that demographic. At 10 CBS’s “CSI: NY” (8.1 million) shared the lead in the 18-to-49 set with NBC’s “Dateline” (6.2 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Corzine Heats Up Debate Over Leasing State Assets
text: TRENTON, June 28 — It was supposed to be an orchestrated victory lap on Thursday afternoon as Democratic legislators attended a signing ceremony for New Jersey’s $33.5 billion election-year budget, which will not require a tax increase and will offer $1,000 rebate checks for most homeowners.

headline: Don’t Cry Over rBST Milk
text: Stanford, Calif.

headline: Bill Barber, Who Brought the Tuba to Famed Jazz Sessions, Is Dead at 87
text: Bill Barber, one of the first musicians to play modern jazz on the tuba, died on June 18 in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 87.

headline: Throwing Yourself Against the Wall
text: THE brick wall was only three feet high, but thick, capped by an unforgiving slab of concrete. “So you want to dive headfirst at it,” Cliff Kravit, 27, standing by my side, was explaining, his waist-length hair pulled back in a ponytail. “You have to commit to it. Trust yourself.”

headline: Lower Costs Help Rite Aid to Double Profit
text: Rite Aid, the drugstore chain, said yesterday that quarterly profit more than doubled, helped by lower costs for store closings and labor.

headline: Central Islip: Arson Charge Is Denied
text: A Long Island bar owner pleaded not guilty yesterday to federal arson charges that accuse him of ordering a stationery store on the same block as his bar firebombed. An indictment alleges that the bar owner, Carmine Graziano, 45, hired two men to set fire to the shop, Roseanne’s Cards Galore in New Hyde Park, in August 2003 in retaliation for complaints the owners made about noise and under-age drinking at his bar, Copperfield’s Pub. Mr. Graziano was ordered held without bail yesterday after his arraignment in Federal District Court in Central Islip. Surveillance tapes show two men throwing a rock and then a Molotov cocktail through the store’s front window, prosecutors said. The fire forced the evacuation of several apartments above the store, which was destroyed; there were no serious injuries.

headline: Higher Profile for Bloomberg Heralds Loss of Privacy
text: In pursuing and occupying public office over the past seven years, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has intensely guarded his privacy, bristling at questions he considers prying.

headline: Federal Court Freezes Assets of Hedge Fund in Chicago
text: A federal court froze the assets of Lake Shore Asset Management, a hedge fund firm run by a former chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, after regulators said it overstated its holdings.

headline: Launch the Boat. We’re Going Camping in the Adirondacks.
text: THE Adirondack Mountains have a peaceful quasi-secret that hides in plain sight: some of the best campsites in the Northeast that can be reached only by boat.

headline: Mrs. McCain, Demure in 2000, Is Speaking Up in a Steely Tone
text: PHOENIX, June 26 — Cindy McCain on the presidential campaign trail in 2000 was mostly a cheerful sidekick to her husband, keeping her positions on national policy to herself.

headline: The Same Words, but Differing Views
text: The five opinions that made up yesterday’s decision limiting the use of race in assigning students to public schools referred to Brown v. Board of Education, the landmark 1954 school desegregation case, some 90 times. The justices went so far as to quote from the original briefs in the case and from the oral argument in 1952.

headline: SEUN KUTI & THE EGYPT 80
text: SEUN KUTI & THE EGYPT 80 Competing with a famous father is tough enough, particularly when that father is Fela Anikulapo Kuti, the Nigerian titan of Afrobeat music who before his death from AIDS 10 years ago was one of the world’s most outrageous and electrifying musical figures. But when Seun Kuti (above), 24, Fela’s youngest son, began performing with his father’s band, the Egypt 80, he faced another formidable contender: his older half-brother Femi, who since the late ’80s has earned the respect of critics and Afrobeat fans — not a crowd easily impressed — for his saxophone populism. Luckily or unluckily for both, their father is truly inimitable, and in addition to his music — a deliriously warped reflection of James Brown’s funk — Fela left a tradition of fearless political dissidence. As Seun Kuti told The Observer, the British newspaper, three years ago when graduating from the Liverpool Institute for Performing Arts, his father’s music is a mission that lives on, with room for plenty of inheritors. “Things in Nigeria are even worse now,” he said, “and however hard it is to live up to his legacy, we have to carry on the fight for liberation and consciousness.” He brings his saxophone and his fight to S.O.B.’s on Sunday for his New York debut, and Femi Kuti and his band Positive Force appear at Central Park SummerStage on July 11. (9 p.m., 204 Varick Street, at Houston Street, South Village, 212-243-4940, sobs.com; $30.) BEN SISARIO

headline: Eating the iPhone
text: And what is the iPhone line for? The same as the Harry Potter line. A little magic, a new installment in a familiar story, the hope of being surprised. Perhaps a few of the people queuing on the street or online for this new device really do need a new cellphone or digital music player. But mostly what they need — what we all need — is the new itself, and the intensity of that need is not to be denied.

headline: In Detention, Needing Care (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.N. Development Agency Rebuts U.S. Charges of Wasteful Spending in North Korea
text: UNITED NATIONS, June 28 — The deputy chief of the United Nations Development Program has shot back at American accusations that it had squandered millions of dollars in North Korea, saying the amount far surpassed what the program had at its disposal and questioning the authenticity of documents the American mission provided to back up its claims.

headline: Israel Drops Rape Charges as President Agrees to Quit
text: JERUSALEM, June 28 — The Israeli government has dropped rape charges against President Moshe Katsav in exchange for his agreement to step down and to plead guilty to lesser charges, the attorney general, Menachem Mazuz, announced Thursday.

headline: Fraud Arrests in Case of Lost Girl
text: MADRID, June 28 — The Spanish police on Thursday arrested two people in southern Spain on suspicion that they were trying to defraud the parents of Madeleine McCann, the 4-year-old British girl who disappeared May 3 while the family was on vacation in Portugal.

headline: Ecuador: U.N. Declares Galápagos Endangered
text: The Galápagos Islands have been added to a list of endangered World Heritage sites maintained by the United Nations. The archipelago, home to a array of species that inspired Charles Darwin to form his theory of natural selection, has seen annual tourist visits grow to 120,000 from 40,000 in 1996. Introduced plants now outnumber native plants, according to a report prepared by naturalists for a United Nations committee that keeps track of cultural and natural sites of international significance. Altogether 29 out of 830 heritage sites are listed as “in danger,” a spur to greater conservation efforts, The full list is at whc.unesco.org.

headline: Supreme Court Blocks Execution of Delusional Killer
text: HOUSTON, June 28 — Amplifying its ban against execution of the insane, a closely divided United States Supreme Court on Thursday overturned the death sentence of a delusional Texas murderer who insisted that he was being punished for preaching the Gospel.

headline: In Only Pick, Nets Choose Williams for Athleticism
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 28 — There were no surprises from the Nets’ front office in Thursday night’s N.B.A. draft.

headline: U.S. Reaches Tentative Deal With Europe on Bank Data
text: WASHINGTON, June 28  A new agreement between the Bush administration and the European Union will allow the United States government to continue a once secret program to obtain banking records from a Brussels-based consortium for use in counterterrorism investigations, American and European officials said Thursday.

headline: F.D.A. Curbs Sale of 5 Seafoods Farmed in China
text: In the latest move against Chinese imports, the Food and Drug Administration yesterday effectively blocked the sale of five types of farm-raised seafood from China because of repeated instances of contamination from unapproved animal drugs and food additives.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: A New Face for the Knicks Even With No Lottery Pick
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y., June 28 — Isiah Thomas did not have a lottery pick Thursday night, but he came away with a potential franchise-changing player anyway.

headline: Manhattan: Workers Charged in Gun Sale
text: Three workers for the city’s Bureau of Water Supply have been charged with participating in an illegal gun sale on city property, the Department of Investigation said yesterday. Rose Gill Hearn, the commissioner of investigation, said a supervisor and two subordinates were charged in connection with the supervisor’s purchase of a .45-caliber pistol in the parking lot of a city water facility in the Delaware County hamlet of Grand Gorge. Ms. Gill Hearn said the supervisor, Thomas Ganz, 36 of Grahamsville, N.Y., was charged with criminal possession of a weapon, a misdemeanor. The subordinates, James Geraghty, 38, of Stamford, N.Y., and George Pennell Jr., 39, of Liberty, N.Y., were charged with falsifying business records, the department said. Dianne Struzzi, a department spokeswoman, said Mr. Geraghty, who sold the weapon, and Mr. Pennell falsely claimed that Mr. Pennell, who has a pistol permit, was the buyer. Mr. Ganz does not have a valid permit, she said.

headline: Century-Old Ban Lifted on Minimum Retail Pricing
text: WASHINGTON, June 28 — Striking down an antitrust rule nearly a century old, the Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that it was not automatically unlawful for manufacturers and distributors to agree on minimum retail prices.

headline: Fed Keeps Interest Rates Steady
text: WASHINGTON, June 28 — The Federal Reserve, saying that inflation remains its “predominant policy concern,” left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 5.25 percent on Thursday and signaled that it would keep it at that level for some time.

headline: The Eagle Soars
text: The bald eagle, a symbol of majesty since the earliest days of the republic, was officially removed yesterday from the federal government’s list of endangered and threatened species. This is wonderful news for the bird. It is also a tribute to conservationists who have worked hard for the eagle’s survival and to the Endangered Species Act, which gave the bird the protections it needed. The act has been under assault in Congress and has far fewer friends than it should in the Bush administration.

headline: Correction
text: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about evolution and the soul misstated the views that Nancey Murphy, a philosopher at Fuller Theological Seminary, expresses in her book “Bodies and Souls, or Spirited Bodies?” Dr. Murphy argues that neither humans nor animals have souls, not that both have souls. She cited the ideas of Thomas Aquinas on animal and human souls to contrast with her view, not to support it. (Go to Article)

headline: Humbled by Scandal, Judge Begins Prison Term
text: He was expected by 10:30 yesterday morning, 11 at the latest. The camera crews lay in wait, taking aim at the stairwell on the second floor of the courthouse in Brooklyn. Above them a video screen offered a distraction, something concerning the plight of a famous hotel heiress.

headline: Wie Takes the Crooked Path to Find Her Wayward Ball
text: SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., June 28 — Michelle Wie was standing in the middle of the 14th fairway at Pine Needles on Thursday when she hit her ball so far to the left of the green that it caromed off a grandstand.

headline: A Trade-Off on iPhone Data Speed
text: SAN FRANCISCO, June 28 — On the eve of the Apple iPhone’s debut, the top executives of Apple and AT&T today defended their decision to rely upon AT&T’s slow Edge wireless data network, rather than a faster network that is less widely available.

headline: Art
text: ART

headline: Door Is Open to High-Tech Offerings That Meet Thresholds
text: DAN NYE is perhaps the most publicly accessible chief executive on the planet. Anyone can contact the head of LinkedIn, a social network based in Mountain View, Calif., simply by visiting his personal profile page on the service and sending him a message.

headline: David Cleans Up
text: Already naked, Donatello’s “David” is going to be bathed in public. An 18-month, $270,000 restoration of the 15th-century bronze statue, a landmark of Renaissance sculpture, will be conducted before the eyes of visitors to the National Museum of the Bargello in Florence, Italy, The Guardian of London reported. The statue will not be moved to a laboratory for its first major restoration; instead the restorers have taken lights, cleaning equipment and lasers into the room where the statue is displayed. Television cameras and monitors will furnish spectators with close-ups of the work. “The laser will be used to clean and render visible the gold leaf which we know is in the hair but also probably decorates David’s boots,” said Ludovica Nicolai of the restoration team.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Scientists Transplant Genome of Bacteria
text: Scientists at the institute directed by J. Craig Venter, a pioneer in sequencing the human genome, are reporting that they have successfully transplanted the genome of one species of bacteria into another, an achievement they see as a major step toward creating synthetic forms of life.

headline: Destination Portland: A Big Man, a Small Place
text: Greg Oden is not a destination snob. Without an ounce of hat envy, Oden tugged on a white Portland cap last night, eager for an eco-friendly embrace from thousands of outdoorsy folks who have one indoor vice: the Trail Blazers.

headline: California: Air Resources Board Chairman Resigns
text: The chairman of the California Air Resources Board, Robert Sawyer, resigned just days after Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger expressed displeasure at his board’s delay of an antismog plan. Dr. Sawyer, a prominent air-quality expert and professor emeritus at the University of California, Berkeley, was appointed to the board by the governor 18 months ago. On Friday, however, Mr. Schwarzenegger issued a statement saying he was “deeply disappointed” by a board decision to seek an 11-year delay in enforcement of federal air-quality standards in the San Joaquin Valley, south of Fresno. Mr. Schwarzenegger has made reducing emissions a priority of his second term.

headline: How the Programs Linked to Race Worked in 2 Cities
text: The Supreme Court’s decision on school integration invalidated programs in Seattle and metropolitan Louisville, Ky.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Brooklyn: Arrest in Subway Killing
text: A Brooklyn teenager was arrested yesterday and charged with murder in the fatal shooting of a 19-year-old Brooklyn man on the subway Wednesday evening, the police said. The police said the suspect, Stephen Scott, 17, had had an argument earlier in the day with the victim, Trevell Belton, before he shot Mr. Belton on the Q train at Avenue U. Witnesses led investigators to Mr. Scott, who was also charged with criminal possession of a weapon, the police said.

headline: Two Guys Visit Yankee Stadium: A Tale of Loss and Friendship
text: If seeing is believing, Michael Sayre will see today that he has no better friend than Aiden McGuire.

headline: Justices End 96-Year-Old Ban on Price Floors
text: WASHINGTON, June 28 — Striking down an antitrust rule nearly a century old, the Supreme Court ruled today that it is no longer automatically unlawful for manufacturers and distributors to agree on setting minimum retail prices.

headline: Scottish Panel Challenges Lockerbie Conviction
text: LONDON, June 28 — A Scottish judicial review body ruled Thursday that a former Libyan intelligence official jailed for the 1988 Lockerbie bombing might have been wrongfully convicted and was entitled to appeal the verdict against him.

headline: Tentative Deal on Wall Street Journal Safeguards
text: Under a tentative accord to guard The Wall Street Journal’s editorial integrity in a takeover by Rupert Murdoch, an independent committee could block the hiring and firing of top editors, go to court to enforce the agreement, and conduct internal investigations and publish its findings on The Journal’s editorial page.

headline: On the Web, EMI to Offer More Choices
text: Music blogs and social networking sites like MySpace are playing an increasingly important part in record companies’ marketing plans. Now they will also be able to sell songs from a major label that will play on the iPod from Apple.

headline: Sanitation Workers Honored for Going Beyond Call of Duty
text: Ceremonies to honor firefighters and police officers for saving someone from a burning building, disarming a gunman or other acts of bravery are not uncommon. But for Frank James Perrone, who also works for the city, receiving a similar recognition was a particularly gratifying moment.

headline: Beazer Shares Fall After Executive’s Firing
text: Shares of Beazer Homes USA fell as much as 9.5 percent yesterday, the most since March, after the company fired its chief accounting officer, saying he tried to destroy documents during an F.B.I. investigation.

headline: The Slowness of Motion, and What It May Reveal
text: DURHAM, N.C., June 28 — Few things in the performing arts are more marvelously strange than the way the Japanese-American choreographers and performers Eiko and Koma, having started a slow phrase of movement, take it, and with it a whole work, in dramatic directions you could never have seen coming.

headline: Switzerland: Watchmakers Seek Stricter Content Rules
text: Switzerland’s main watchmaking group urged the government to tighten the rules on what can be called a Swiss watch to stop timepieces with too many foreign parts from reaching the market. Under a proposal by the Federation of the Swiss Watch Industry, at least 80 percent of a mechanical watch or 60 percent of an electronic one would have to be made in Switzerland for it to be called “Swiss made,” the group said. The proposal, approved by 87 percent of the federation’s members, will be sent to the government for consideration. The existing ordinance says at least 50 percent must be Swiss made.

headline: Wanting the War to End Before Seeing It on Film
text: For some reason, a large slice of America is obsessed with how much money Hollywood rakes in every weekend. News organizations lead the way, dutifully recording box-office receipts like diligent accountants. Why this happens escapes us, but it is what it is.

headline: Harry Potter and the Tokyo Fans
text: Daniel Radcliffe showed off his Japanese-language skills yesterday when Harry Potter fans from all corners of Japan converged on Tokyo for the red-carpet premiere of “Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix,” Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Radcliffe, who plays Harry, used Japanese to identify himself, greet the crowd and express admiration for the country. Dozens of the fans who turned out for the fifth film installment of the adventures of the boy wizard were dressed in black capes; some wore wigs. After a gala premiere in London on Tuesday, the film will open around the world on July 11.

headline: Former Alabama Governor Gets 7-Year Sentence in Bribery Case
text: Former Gov. Don E. Siegelman of Alabama was sentenced to seven years and four months in prison yesterday by a federal judge in Montgomery for his part in a bribery scheme connected to his effort to establish a state lottery. Mr. Siegelman was also ordered to pay more than $200,000 in fines and restitution.

headline: Don’t Mourn Brown v. Board of Education
text: Washington

headline: In Sailing, It Comes Down to the Sails
text: VALENCIA, Spain, June 28 — The digital clock on the committee boat had begun the 11-minute countdown to start the fourth race of the America’s Cup. But neither Alinghi nor Emirates Team New Zealand had a headsail up on their yacht.

headline: General Mills Says Its Costs Pinch Its Profit
text: General Mills said yesterday that profit in the fourth quarter rose less than 1 percent, hurt by soaring grain costs, despite a 7 percent increase in sales.

headline: Study Traces Cat’s Ancestry to Middle East
text: Some 10,000 years ago, somewhere in the Near East, an audacious wildcat crept into one of the crude villages of early human settlers, the first to domesticate wheat and barley. There she felt safe from her many predators in the region, such as hyenas and larger cats.

headline: Rights Group Accuses Philippine Army of Abuses Against Leftists
text: MANILA, June 28 — The Philippine military has been waging a “dirty war” against leftists that has resulted in the death or disappearance of hundreds of Filipino activists, Human Rights Watch said Thursday.

text: ART

headline: I.M.F.’s Chief Will Resign 2 Years Early
text: Rodrigo de Rato, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, will quit his post in October, two years before his term ends, the fund said yesterday, citing “personal reasons.”

headline: Prosecutor in Bonds Case Is Set to Leave
text: The second federal prosecutor to oversee the investigation of Barry Bonds will leave the position next month, a spokeswoman for the United States attorney’s office for the Northern District of California said yesterday.

headline: Knicks Trade Francis, Frye for Portland’s Randolph
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y., June 28 – Isiah Thomas did not have a lottery pick Thursday night, but he came away with a potential franchise-changing player anyway.

headline: City May Seek Permit and Insurance for Many Kinds of Public Photography
text: Some tourists, amateur photographers, even would-be filmmakers hoping to make it big on YouTube could soon be forced to obtain a city permit and $1 million in liability insurance before taking pictures or filming on city property, including sidewalks.

headline: Queens: Transfer of Airport ID Checks
text: Transportation Security Administration officers at Kennedy International Airport have begun taking over the task of checking passengers’ identification as they approach the security checkpoint, agency officials said this week. The transfer from private contractors to federal security officers is part of an effort to actively look for false documents or signs that a passenger may be acting suspiciously, Ellen Howe, an agency spokeswoman, said on Tuesday. So far, the document checkers are at only some Kennedy security checkpoints, officials said.

headline: Defeat Worries Employers Who Rely on Immigrants
text: While the defeat of the Senate immigration bill was a dismaying disappointment to illegal immigrants and the groups that support them, it also created major worries for employers across the country who depend on immigrant workers.

headline: Margaret Helfand, Architect, Dies at 59
text: Margaret Helfand, a Manhattan architect and urban planner who served as president of the American Institute of Architects’ New York chapter, died on June 20. She was 59.

headline: Where the Bodies Are Perfect and Not Very Earthbound
text: What is “AntiGravity: The 2007 Tour”? Essentially, it is a tribute to the notion of a human chandelier.

headline: No. 279 From Pakistan: Unseeded but Not Unknown
text: WIMBLEDON, England, June 28 — From the balcony overlooking Court No. 18, family and friends, and people he did not know, shouted encouragement in Urdu, his native language.

headline: Brazil: Airline Agrees to Buy 26 Airbus Planes
text: TAM, Brazil’s largest airline by passengers carried, agreed to purchase 26 Airbus planes for around $5.4 billion to expand its international routes. The airline, based in São Paulo, said it signed a deal to buy 22 Airbus A350 planes and exercised an earlier option to buy 4 A330 models. The company secured an option to buy 10 additional A350s in the future. The A330s will be delivered in 2010 and 2011. TAM operates direct flights to Paris, London, Milan, New York and Miami.

headline: In Münster, a Sculpture Space Odyssey
text: MÜNSTER, Germany — Venice and Kassel and Münster makes three. On the European grand tour of international exhibitions this summer, Sculpture Projects Münster ’07 is the baby: the smallest, youngest, the most modest and, this year especially, the least polished.

headline: Spare Times
text: ON THE STREET

headline: Diamond Deals Were a Fraud, Lawsuit Claims
text: The wholesale diamond district on West 47th Street is reputed to be a closed, secretive world in which millions of dollars in gems are traded based on little more than trust and a handshake.

headline: Pension Advisers’ Roles Questioned
text: WASHINGTON, June 28 (Dow Jones/AP) — Pension plans may have lower investment gains when they use consultants who have undisclosed conflicts of interest, according to a new report by government investigators.

headline: Portugal, Conquering and Also Conquered
text: WASHINGTON, June 22 — A little-known fact: A version of the Internet was invented in Portugal 500 years ago by a bunch of sailors with names like Pedro, Vasco and Bartolomeu. The technology was crude. Links were unstable. Response time was glacial. (A message sent on their network might take a year to land.) They put up with it all. They were hungry to gain access to the world.

headline: Attracting Private Equity Becomes a National Sport in Europe
text: FRANKFURT, June 28 — For most of the last decade, the private equity firms in Germany have argued for preferential tax treatment on the basis of national interest.

headline: Squash Seeds Show Andean Cultivation Is 10,000 Years Old, Twice as Old as Thought
text: Seeds of domesticated squash found by scientists on the western slopes of the Andes in northern Peru are almost 10,000 years old, about twice the age of previously discovered cultivated crops in the region, new, more precise dating techniques have revealed.

headline: In a Room, Police and Youths Talk, and Maybe See Their Similarities
text: WHITE PLAINS, June 27 — Like two tribes, they faced each other. One group wore the uniform of their trade: dark-blue outfits adorned with shields and badges, guns tucked in leather holsters. The other donned what could be defined as the uniform of a generation: oversize pants, loose T-shirts, chains dangling from their necks.

headline: A Long Island Scene So Quiet, You Can Hear the Grapes Grow
text: HEAD out the North Fork of Long Island along Route 25, past vegetable stands, vineyards and farms, by signs offering “Hay for Sale” and farm stands encouraging you to buy fresh strawberries, and by the time you reach Mattituck — the heart of the North Fork — it is clear, this is farm country.

headline: Bronx: Man Is Killed on Bridge
text: Three men were shot, one fatally, yesterday afternoon around the Willis Avenue Bridge in Mott Haven, the police said. According to the police, the victims were chased by an unknown number of young men starting at East 131st Street and Willis Avenue before they were shot. The police said they did not have a motive for the shooting and had not been able to identify the assailants. One victim, a 22-year-old man, was shot in the head on the bridge around 4:15 p.m., and pronounced dead at the scene, the police said. The other two men, a 19-year-old who was shot in the buttocks and the leg and a 17-year-old who was shot in the hip, were taken to Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center and were reported in stable condition. The police did not identify the victims, but at the hospital last night, a family member, Janis Mackey, said the 17-year-old was Edward Steele of Harlem, her grandson. “They don’t know why they were shot,” she said. “They were in the wrong neighborhood.”

headline: Unrest Grows Amid Gas Rationing in Iran
text: TEHRAN, June 28  Unrest spread in Tehran on Thursday, the second day of gasoline rationing in oil-rich Iran, with drivers lining up for miles, gas stations being set on fire and state-run banks and business centers coming under attack.

headline: The Cult of the Amateur
text: Digital utopians have heralded the dawn of an era in which Web 2.0 — distinguished by a new generation of participatory sites like MySpace.com and YouTube.com, which emphasize user-generated content, social networking and interactive sharing — ushers in the democratization of the world: more information, more perspectives, more opinions, more everything, and most of it without filters or fees. Yet as the Silicon Valley entrepreneur Andrew Keen points out in his provocative new book, “The Cult of the Amateur,” Web 2.0 has a dark side as well.

headline: Israel’s President Submits Resignation
text: JERUSALEM, June 29 — Israel’s disgraced president, Moshe Katsav, submitted his resignation to parliament this morning amid fierce public criticism after the state agreed to drop rape charges against him in exchange for an admission of guilt for lesser offenses.

headline: Immigrant Bill Dies in Senate; Defeat for Bush
text: WASHINGTON, June 28 — President Bush’s effort to overhaul the nation’s immigration policy, a cornerstone of his domestic agenda, collapsed Thursday in the Senate, with little prospect that it can be revived before Mr. Bush leaves office in 19 months.

headline: Journal Reporters Protest Over Murdoch Bid
text: Many of The Wall Street Journal’s reporters did not show up for work this morning, to protest the expected sale of the newspaper’s parent, Dow Jones & Company, to Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, and the fact that they do not have a contract.

headline: Love That View? Second-Home Owners Act to Preserve Theirs
text: HOUSING developments, subdivisions and strip malls are not generally considered the most desirable settings for a vacation retreat. So to prevent this sort of growth, many second-home owners are taking an active role in ensuring that their refuge in the country stays sprawl free — and they are getting a tax break in the process.

headline: Long-Awaited iPhone Goes on Sale
text: Apple wanted a spectacle when the iPhone went on sale this evening, and it got just that.

headline: Excerpts From Opinions on the Use of Race in Public School Admission Policies
text: Following are excerpts from opinions by Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and Justice Anthony M. Kennedy in the court’s 5-to-4 decision yesterday that public school systems cannot seek to achieve or maintain integration through measures that take explicit account of a student’s race. Also included are excerpts from the dissent by Justice Stephen G. Breyer.

headline: Over the World’s Infinite Noise, Five Friends Sing Their Songs
text: Dressed in black — like the punk girls they might have been, the widows they might become — the five women who meet at an old teacher’s funeral in the Austrian film “Falling” don’t collapse instantly into one another’s arms. Each circles the other cautiously, sniffing the air. Their eyes and feet shuffle nervously as they take in faces made blurry by age and distant memory. One woman protectively, perhaps too proudly, caresses her hugely pregnant belly, while a second downs a drink and then another a little too quickly. A third dials and redials her cellphone, obviously anxious to be anywhere but here.

headline: Yanks Take New Approach to Season
text: BALTIMORE, June 28 — Jorge Posada’s throw sailed into left field, a wild heave from an exhausted stalwart of the Yankees. Corey Patterson, who was trying to steal third base, trotted home with another run to put the Baltimore Orioles ahead by two in the seventh inning Thursday at Camden Yards.

headline: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about the filing of federal charges against 29 people accused in plots to smuggle nearly $700 million in real and counterfeit goods from China into the United States misstated the given name of one of those charged, an owner of a trucking company. He is Joseph DePaola, not John.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Guantánamo Detainees’ Case
text: The United States Supreme Court reversed course today and agreed to hear claims of Guantanamo detainees that they have a right to challenge their detentions in American federal courts.

headline: President Touches on Cuba After Castro
text: NEWPORT, R.I., June 28  President Bush on Thursday raised the anticipated death of the dictator Fidel Castro as an opportunity to push for democracy in Cuba, which he called the “one nondemocracy in our neighborhood.”

headline: Bush Defends War at Naval College as Senate Republicans Show Increasing Impatience
text: NEWPORT, R.I., June 28  President Bush came to the Naval War College here Thursday to press the case for his military strategy in Iraq, even as his National Security Adviser met with Congressional Republicans who have been expressing dissatisfaction with the approach.

text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, show times and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

headline: Owners Unsure About Europe
text: Some N.F.L. owners want to close the six-team European developmental league because it is losing too much money, said Carl Peterson, the president of the Kansas City Chiefs. N.F.L. Europa, which began operating in its current format in 1995, plays its season from April to June and offers teams an opportunity for young players to gain experience. Peterson said that outweighs the losses, which he said averaged $500,000 for each of the N.F.L.’s 32 clubs.

headline: U.N. Agency and North Korea in Deal
text: North Korea and the United Nations’ nuclear agency have reached an agreement on the logistics of shutting down and sealing that nation’s main nuclear reactor, following up on an offer the North Koreans made to the United States in February.

text: WHAT New residences at an oceanfront resort and residential development.

headline: Cache of Chemicals Found in 2 Spots on Staten Island Prompts Evacuations
text: Dozens of residents were evacuated from their homes on a street on western Staten Island last night as the New York City police and federal law enforcement officials raided a house believed to be involved in the Internet sale of commercial chemicals, including potassium nitrate and sulfur.

headline: On a Summer’s Evening, Strings for the River Wild
text: The Flux Quartet’s name is turning out to be very appropriate. When four string players from the Juilliard School banded together more than 10 years ago as a quartet devoted to challenging contemporary works, they chose the name to convey that music itself is in a constant state of motion and transition.
