headline: Britain Won’t Extradite New York Hotelier in Fraud and Tax Evasion Case
text: After three years of hearings and recriminations, a British judge yesterday refused to extradite the multimillionaire hotelier Stanley S. Tollman to New York, a major setback for prosecutors seeking to bring him to trial on charges relating to a $100 million bank fraud and tax evasion scheme.

headline: The Founding Fathers, Willie and Me
text: THE Fourth of July does not conjure the hallowed ratification of the Declaration of Independence for me. Rather, it’s the apex of summer, a splendidly long day savored with friends, family and fireworks amid smoke wafting from a barbecue, cold beer and even colder watermelons.

headline: With Lofty Expectations, Portland Selects Oden
text: Seven-foot franchise saviors who prompt early comparisons to Bill Russell and David Robinson do not often make their debuts on the Madison Square Garden Theater stage in June.

headline: Explosive Growth Since 2000 in State’s Hasidic Enclaves
text: Kiryas Joel, an Orthodox Jewish enclave in southern Orange County, grew faster than any other community in New York State from 2000 through 2006, according to census data released yesterday.

headline: AFRO-PUNK BLOCK PARTY
text: AFRO-PUNK BLOCK PARTY The block party is as much a New York summer tradition as rides on the Cyclone, concerts in Central Park and — unfortunately — the Mister Softee jingle everywhere. On Sunday, as part of its third annual Afro-Punk festival of film, music and art, the Brooklyn Academy of Music will hold its first Afro-Punk block party, on a Fort Greene street that has been party-bereft for several years. “We really wanted to do something that was drawn from the community,” said Tamara McCaw, the community affairs and audience development manager for the academy, and a party organizer. The area “is really exploding,” she said. “There are these young mom-and-pop shops, and independent artists that live in the neighborhood that have this eclectic, funky edge to them.” In addition to family-friendly activities like sidewalk chalk drawing, face painting and T-shirt-making (“nothing is more punk rock than making your own T-shirts,” Ms. McCaw said), there will be fashion, jewelry and crafts for sale from more than two dozen local designers and artisans, including Adrienne Braxton, a baker and familiar neighborhood presence. (Her peach cobbler is probably the best street-corner dessert you’ll find.) The Dustbin Brothers and the D.J. Rich Medina, above, who’s worked with Fela Kuti, will spin tunes; No Surrender, a Brooklyn electro-hip-hop trio, will perform live. With any luck, they’ll drown out Mister Softee. (Sunday from noon to 5 p.m., Clinton Avenue, between Myrtle Avenue and Willoughby Street, 718-636-4100, bam.org) MELENA RYZIK

headline: Don’t Kick the Inspectors Out of the U.N.
text: TODAY, the United States and Britain will ask the United Nations Security Council to abolish the United Nations Monitoring, Verification and Inspection Commission — the organization it created to oversee the elimination of Iraq’s weapons of mass destruction.

headline: Protests Bog Down Canadian Travelers
text: OTTAWA, June 29 — Canadian travelers faced road and rail shutdowns this morning as they set out for the Canada Day holiday weekend amid nationwide protests by native groups.

headline: Voilà! A Rat for All Seasonings
text: The moral of “Ratatouille” is delivered by a critic: a gaunt, unsmiling fellow named Anton Ego who composes his acidic notices in a coffin-shaped room and who speaks in the parched baritone of Peter O’Toole. “Not everyone can be a great artist,” Mr. Ego muses. “But a great artist can come from anywhere.”

headline: For the Record
text: Schedule information on Wednesday with a theater review of “The Irish Play,” at the Irish Arts Center on West 51st Street in Manhattan, misidentified the Web site that gives complete information and offers online ticket purchases. It is hammandclov.org, not irishartscenter.org.

headline: Mr. Irrelevant Gets a Contract
text: Ramzee Robinson, who earned the title Mr. Irrelevant as the final player selected in the 2007 N.F.L. draft, agreed on a three-year contract with the Detroit Lions, his agent said. Robinson, a cornerback, was the last of 255 players selected in April. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: Those Dodger Blues Just Won’t Go Away
text: The epic villainy of Walter O’Malley for moving the Dodgers west is like a family legend told through baseball generations: Come on and listen to this story of unparalleled baseball greed, my son.

headline: The… Yankees don’t lose!
text: With wins so hard to come by this season, the Yankees will take what they got on Thursday in Baltimore: an 8-6 lead in the eighth inning of a suspended game. The Yankees and the Orioles will resume this game when the Yankees come to town again on July 27.

headline: F.D.A. Curbs Sale of Five Seafoods From China
text: In the latest move against Chinese imports, the Food and Drug Administration on Thursday effectively blocked the sale of five types of farm-raised seafood from China because of repeated instances of contamination from unapproved animal drugs and food additives.

headline: How Many Supers Must a Building Have?
text: Q I am a board member in a co-op with almost 400 units. Is there a New York City requirement that we have two live-in superintendents so that we have full-time coverage, or can the superintendent live nearby and be available 24/7?

headline: Can a Condo Require a Washer to Be Removed?
text: Q I am in the process of buying a condo. Before its conversion in 1978, the building was under rent stabilization, and the apartment I am buying had a washer and dryer in it. They are still there today.

headline: You’re Never Fully Dressed Without
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Architectural Experiment, With Ocean View
text: A meticulous renovation turns back the clock on an ’80s landmark.

headline: Time to Swim
text: New York City’s 52 outdoor swimming pools opened for the summer season, and New Yorkers did not wait long before diving in.

headline: More Than a Country Getaway
text: The mix of rural charm, wine country sophistication and laid-back beach town makes Mattituck, N.Y., an attractive destination.

headline: Pulse | The Dress Designer
text: What I'm wearing now, bottomless totes, pretty in plaid dresses and more.

headline: ‘End of an Era': Police Commissioner Remembers the Wooden Sawhorse
text: Heavy-duty wooden sawhorses, a longtime icon of police crowd control at ticker-tape parades, protests and other large gatherings, are being phased out. The last 3,200 ones owned by the New York Police Department are being relegated to dull duty at street fairs and other low-impact events. Their (functional, if characterless) replacements: the interlocking gray aluminum partitions that the police call “French barriers.”

headline: Beneath the Bubbles
text: A documentary about the famously tingly soap with the famously batty label, "Dr. Bronner's Magic Soapbox" mixes method and madness to chart the evolution of a counterculture phenomenon.

headline: Bank Settles Claims Over Lost Tax Papers
text: Mellon Bank has agreed to pay $16.5 million to the federal government to settle claims that it allowed overwhelmed employees to destroy thousands of federal tax returns and payments in 2001. In turn, the government will not pursue any civil or administrative monetary claims against Mellon, the United States district attorney’s office and Mellon Bank said Thursday.

headline: Federal Court Freezes Assets of Hedge Fund in Chicago
text: A federal court froze the assets of Lake Shore Asset Management, a hedge fund firm run by a former chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, after regulators said it overstated its holdings.

headline: Britain Won’t Extradite New York Hotelier in Fraud and Tax Evasion Case
text: After three years of hearings and recriminations, a British judge on Thursday refused to extradite the multimillionaire hotelier Stanley S. Tollman to New York, a major setback for prosecutors seeking to bring him to trial on charges relating to a $100 million bank fraud and tax evasion scheme.

headline: F.T.C. Could Challenge Genetech’s $914 Million Buy of Tanox
text: With three court filings since March, the Federal Trade Commission has been working overtime to challenge mergers. Next up could be Genentech‘s $914 million purchase of Tanox, which has been under review for nearly six months.

headline: Western Digital to Pay $1 Billion for Komag
text: In a $1 billion cash deal, Western Digital said late Thursday it plans to purchase Komag a San Jose, Calif.-based media manufacturer. Western Digital, a hard drive maker, will pay $32.25 per share through a cash tender offer and also pay down $220 million in debt issued by Komag in March that is due in 2014.

headline: Yamana Gold Looks to Deal Making for Growth
text: With a view to creating a mining behemoth, Canada’s Yamana Gold is eyeing a buyout of two smaller groups for about $4 billion. The move comes during a time when the country’s major mineral companies have fallen prey to buyers from abroad. Both Falconbridge and Inco were swallowed up by foreigners in the last two years.

headline: American Capital Strategies Continues Spending Spree
text: American Capital Strategies continued its buying spree Thursday when it spent about $700 million via two new deals. The publicly traded lender and middle-market buyout sponsor said it had acquired a majority stake in Extream Software for more than $548 million and also committed $100 million of equity to purchase Oceana Media, a movie finance company.

headline: Paracor Raises $44 Million for Pivotal Trial
text: In a Series D funding, Paracor Medical raised $44.35 million to complete a pivotal clinical trial of a device to prevent congestive heart failure, says TheDeal.com.

headline: High-Tech Offerings Make a Comeback
text: The window for public offerings is slowly beginning to open after largely being closed to technology companies since the double whammy of the dot-com downturn and the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, which imposed expensive accounting responsibilities on public companies, The New York Times writes.

headline: Serenex Takes $26 Million Infusion Before I.P.O.
text: Cancer-related drug developer Serenex picked up $26 million in an equity round which could be its last private funding before a public offering. With the round, the Durham, N.C.-based company’s total funding comes to $81 million.

headline: Credit Suisse Strengthens Australian Sales Team
text: In a move to boost its fixed-income sales team, Credit Suisse has hired three new bankers in Australia. Chris Dickman, Clare-Louise Nightingale and Adam Roberts-Thomson have all been recruited to new roles with the firm and will also cover New Zealand.

headline: Deutsche Bahn Buys U.K. Railway Company
text: Germany’s Deutsche Bahn, the state-owned railway company, has acquired the English Welsh and Scottish Railway in a 280 million pound deal. The takeover is expected to take place later this summer subject to regulatory approval, The Guardian wrote.

headline: ABN Amro Fills China Post
text: ABN Amro has appointed 26-year banking veteran Soh Wah Siaw as its head of consumer banking in China. The former HSBC executive will replace Linda Wong, who was promoted to the head of China operations for the investment bank last year.

headline: Activists Keep Pressure on TD Ameritrade
text: Raising the pressure in their campaign to have TD Ameritrade Holding join with another brokerage, hedge funds Jana Partners and SAC Capital sent the brokerage firm a letter Thursday demanding company records and urging Ameritrade to exclude directors appointed by its largest shareholder, Canada’s TD Bank, from merger discussions.

headline: Suitors for Altadis Finish Their Due Diligence
text: Altadis, the maker of Gauloise, Gitane and Ducados cigarettes, is likely to become the subject of a bidding war now that it has revealed that CVC Capital Partners and rival bidder Imperial Tobacco have completed their due diligence work.

headline: All the Latest Frankfurter Developments
text: School’s out, summer’s begun, Independence Day impends — so, naturally, hot dogs are all over the news, one way and another.

headline: Ex-HealthSouth Chief Gets Prison Sentence
text: Former HealthSouth chief executive Richard Scrushy, acquitted two years ago in a major corporate fraud case, and former Alabama Gov. Don Siegelman were both sentenced to prison on Thursday for bribery. A federal judge sentenced Mr. Scrushy to six years and 10 months in prison and Mr. Siegelman to seven years and four months after they were convicted of involvement in a scheme to manipulate hospital building permissions that favored HealthSouth.

headline: A Lightning Strike; New Ferries; Scrutiny of the Mayor; and More
text: Consolidated Edison officials now say it was a rare lightning strike — “a very low-probability event” — that caused the 48-minute power failure in the Bronx and Manhattan on Wednesday, Patrick McGeehan reports. The utility found that a bolt of lightning must have struck a small component at or near a transmission substation in Astoria, Queens, and that no repairs were needed.

headline: Sports Direct May Pack More Punch After Everlast Deal
text: Britain’s Sports Direct has acquired iconic U.S. boxing glove manufacturer Everlastfor 84 million pounds ($168 million), The Telegraph reported Friday. Sports Direct already owns the Sports World chain and the Lillywhites store in Britain, but has been experiencing difficulties as of late.

headline: U.S. Deal-Making Topped $1 Trillion in First Half
text: Slowdown? What slowdown?

headline: British Financial Site Confirms I.P.O. Plans
text: Following rumors earlier this month, Moneysupermarket.com Group has officially announced it will proceed with an initial public offering of its ordinary shares thought to be worth 1 billion pounds ($2 billion). UBS has been appointed as its main adviser.

headline: Intel Capital Takes the Wheel
text: Last year, Intel Capital, the venture capital arm of the giant chipmaker, invested in more U.S. deals than some of the biggest venture firms in Silicon Valley, including Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers and Sequoia Capital.

headline: 3i to Invest in Hedge Fund Administrator
text: 3i, the private equity firm, said Friday that it has invested $57 million in Fulcrum, a hedge fund administrator, through its Growth Capital division. As part of the deal, Akshaya Bhargava of 3i will become Fulcrum’s chief executive. The private equity firm said that its investment will help Fulcrum expand its ability to administer to hedge funds’ back-end operations, as well as broaden its reach to funds in Europe and Asia.

headline: Hamilton-mania at its highest
text: After I walked out of the McLaren Mercedes motor home yesterday and thought about the group interview with Lewis Hamilton that I had just taken part in, it suddenly occurred to me that this must have been a little what it was like with Beatlemania. Pretty much the entire interview dealt with questions concerning how Hamilton was adapting to his new celebrity. Are people recognizing him? (More and more.) Does he like it? (Less and less. Well, not quite, just a matter of a challenge adapting to it.) Is his family happy? (In heaven, more or less.) What does he make of all this press coverage? (Doesn’t really read it, but yes, his family is stocking up on the newspapers.) Etc., etc.

headline: The Other Struggle Over a Top Business Paper
text: As Rupert Murdoch vies for control of Dow Jones and The Wall Street Journal, another newspaper battle is taking place across the Atlantic. Pearson, the British publisher that owns The Financial Times, is considering a sale of French financial daily Les Echos to LVMH, which already owns rival daily La Tribune.

headline: Bear Chief Faces Task of Saving Firm’s Name
text: James E. Cayne has a bellyache. And it is not from the crash diet that has caused Mr. Cayne, the chief executive of Bear Stearns, to shed 20 pounds over the last year.

headline: Europe Considers Stance on Private Equity
text: For most of the last decade, the private equity firms in Germany have argued for preferential tax treatment on the basis of national interest. The breaks are needed, private equity managers said, to help Germany catch up with London and New York, the global centers of the buyout business.

headline: Coastal Splendor
text: Ask Paul Boomsma, executive vice president of the Luxury Portfolio Fine Property Collection, to spotlight an intriguing market and he’ll point to Jávea, a small town on the coast south of Valencia, Spain. Jávea offers the stunning views and picturesque coves of the Costa Blanca without the towers and mass development of the area’s other hot spots, he says. “It’s very non-touristy,” Boomsma said.

headline: Digital Eyewitnesses to the London Car Bomber?
text: Perhaps more than any other major city, London is saturated with closed-circuit video cameras. They watch the lobbies of buildings and sidewalks outside for security; they watch the streets to detect traffic jams and to bill motorists who drive in the city center under London’s “congestion pricing” system (a plan that New York City officials want to emulate), and some of them are there just for fun.

headline: Fear of a ‘Non-White’ School District
text: Writing on his blog, Is That Legal?, North Carolina law professor Eric Muller explains why he thinks Justice Anthony M. Kennedy’s concurrence in the Supreme Court decision about the Seattle and Louisville school systems isn’t as impenetrable as some find it. Kennedy wrote that Seattle “failed to explain why, in a district composed of a diversity of races, with fewer than half of the students categorized as ‘white,’ it has employed the crude categories of ‘white’ and ‘non-white’ as the basis for its assignment decisions.”

headline: Caucus Chatter
text: To Our Readers:

headline: 2008: Democrats Court Minority Voters
text: The war in Iraq and terrorism were front and center at the first two Democratic presidential debates, but yesterday, when all eight candidates appeared on the same stage for the third time during the campaign, they had a chance to go on the record about issues that have received less attention so far.

headline: iPhone Mania
text: Customers eager to buy the cellphone had waited in long lines in front of Apple stores in New York and other cities.

headline: The Hamiltonian Touch
text: Thousands stood hours in a queue in a downpour last Sunday for a chance to meet, greet and get an autograph from new Formula One racing sensation Lewis Hamilton here at the annual Goodwood Festival of Speed in England.

headline: NBC’s Reason for Not Bidding for Dow Jones
text: NBC Universal’s chief executive, Jeff Zucker, on why General Electric decided against bidding with Pearson for Dow Jones: “When you have shareholders who you have to create value for, you have to be fiscally disciplined. When you are the shareholder that matters, you play a different game,” he said, referring to Rupert Murdoch’s controlling stake in the News Corporation.

headline: Answers from the Transportation Commissioner, Part 4
text: The city’s new transportation commissioner, Janette Sadik-Khan, will be taking questions from City Room readers through the week. Here is her fourth set of responses; her first, second and third sets of responses were posted earlier this week. In this round, she focuses on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s congestion pricing proposal. Sorry, we are no longer taking questions for this feature.Commissioner Sadik-Khan: Today I return to questions on congestion pricing. First, there have been some questions about how to get details on the city’s plan. The city’s homepage and DOT’s site have PlaNYC links. Everyone who has participated in this forum should download the transportation chapter of the plan. Page 90 has a good, concise overview of our congestion pricing proposal and there is much more explanation in the plan’s text.

headline: Statement by Britain’s Chief Counterterrorism Police Officer
text: Following is a statement made today by Peter Clarke, Britain’s most senior counterterrorism police officer.

headline: McClatchy Draws Interest From Big Hedge Fund
text: A couple of days after an unusual spike in shares of McClatchy prompted talk — highly speculative talk — that the newspaper chain was a takeover target, there is another intriguing, though inconclusive, development.

headline: Frustrating Lesson for Senate Freshmen
text: Think about it this way: You want a job really, really badly, more than you ever wanted anything. You devote months to pursuing the position, working around the clock, enduring the worst kind of scrutiny and criticism and spending tens of millions of dollars that were excruciatingly hard to come by.

headline: Frustrating Lesson for Senate Freshmen
text: In his web column today, Carl Hulse writes:

headline: Bigger Hearts Than Bank Accounts
text: On the southern tail of the Appalachian Mountains, many people are attached to multiple pets but cannot afford to sterilize or vaccinate them.

headline:
Stray Questions for:
Carl Hiaasen
text: What are you working on?

headline: Breece D’J Pancake at 55
text: I wrote a post last week that mentioned the late short story writer Breece D’J Pancake, and his admirers came out of the woodwork. I got a lot of e-mail about him. So this seems worth saying: today’s his birthday. Pancake was born 55 years ago today, on June 29, 1952, in South Charleston, West Virginia.

headline: He’s Not Defending Con Ed, but…
text: “The last thing I need is another ‘let’s go defend Con Ed’ story, but we all want Con Ed to do a good job and we’ve got to work with them,” Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on his weekly WABC-AM radio appearance this morning in response to a question about the brief power failure this week.

headline: C.E.O. Departure at Commerce Stokes Takeover Talk
text: Shares of Commerce Bancorp, the largest bank in New Jersey, jumped more than 8 percent Friday after the company said its chairman and chief executive, Vernon W. Hill II, was leaving.

headline: Ukrainians, With Home Board Advantage, Win Aerosvit
text: Vassily Ivanchuk of Ukraine has won the Aerosvit tournament in Foros, Ukraine, on the Crimean Peninsula. The tournament ran from June 18 through today. Taking second, a half-point behind, was Sergey Karjakin also of the Ukraine. Games from the tournament, which attracted many of the world’s best players, can be replayed here at the event’s official Web site.

headline: Blackstone Going Public? Who Knew?
text: In lawmaking, as in comedy, timing is everything.

headline: Fight Among Brooklyn Democrats Intensifies
text: The testy fight over a Brooklyn judgeship has become a family affair. Major R. Owens, who served in Congress for 24 years until January, has teamed with his son, Chris, in calling for the resignation of Brooklyn’s Democratic Party leader, Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez.

headline: Sex Trafficking in India
text: After my last visit to India, I wrote in this blog that the approach of some Western philanthropists to work with the brothels in Calcutta seemed to me to have failed. The hope had been that by cooperating with DMSC, nominally a union of prostitutes, it would be possible to reduce forced prostitution and the spread of AIDS by encouraging harm reduction strategies such as condom usage.

headline: Is Bloomberg a Fan of Moore and Gore?
text: Is Michael R. Bloomberg — the ex-Democratic, ex-Republican, now-independent mayor — a follower of the liberal thinkers Michael Moore and Al Gore?

headline: UBS Hires Financial Institutions Banker
text: William A. Houlihan, who most recently was chief financial officer of Sedgwick Claims Management Services, has joined UBS as a managing director in its financial institutions group. He will report to Oliver Sarkozy, joint global head of investment banking. Earlier this year, two bankers from the same UBS group, Joe Jiampietro and Eric Warmstein, left for J.P. Morgan Chase.

headline: Bear Stearns Replaces Asset Management Chief
text: Bear Stearns on Friday replaced the head of its asset management business after two of the investment bank’s hedge funds nearly collapsed because of bad bets on mortgage securities. The turmoil at the funds embarrassed Bear Stearns, widely known for its savvy in handling mortgage risk. The funds were hit by money-losing positions tied to subprime loans, which are made to people with weak credit.

headline: Win a Trip
text: So, win-a-trip 2007 is over, although I still have a couple of final columns I’m tweaking. Here’s a shot of all of us in Congo at a camp for displaced people. Left to right: Will Okun, Leana Wen, me and Naka Nathaniel.

headline: Air Travelers Brace for the Worst
text: Already beleaguered air travelers will probably not get much respite on flights during the coming Fourth of July week, especially since the public holiday falls on a Wednesday. This creates the potential for two sets of long weekends and getaway days.The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which expects flights to be 80 to 90 percent full at the airports this holiday, will have 200 customer service representative on hand at the three main airports to help fliers navigate check-in lines and other bottlenecks.

headline: Love the iPhone, buy Google?
text: So you read the rave reviews the iPhone is getting, and you notice that there are lines outside Apple stores to buy it. Maybe you wonder if you should buy Apple’s stock to cash in on the frenzy.

headline: More Jason Kilar Challenges
text: Just to expand on Saul Hansell’s explanation of the challenges facing Jason Kilar, the former Amazon exec who is slated to head the News Corporation and NBC Universal online video joint venture, consider this: Hitwise reported this week that YouTube’s share of all visits to U.S. Web sites grew by 70 percent between January and May. This is traffic to the YouTube site only, not video streams or views of videos hosted on other sites. The share of visits to 64 other online video sites grew by only 8 percent during the same period, leaving YouTube with 50 percent greater market share than those 64 sites combined.

headline: Ronald Burkle: Wedding Wrecker?
text: Some brides-to-be are upset — “bawling,” according to the New York Post — because Ronald Burkle, head of the private equity firm Yucaipa, bought a $17 million penthouse in downtown New York.

headline: Breather Day 1: Copa News Roundup
text: Today is the first off-day at the Copa América, a good time to take a look around at what’s going on after the first three days of competition.

headline: Q & A: Nicolas Ghesquiere
text: In giving Balenciaga a new silhouette, Nicolas Ghesquiere has created a modern path for fashion. This is the Balenciaga look: lean, seemingly energized with French street cool, relentlessly sharp in its concept. Only 250 people see his shows each season, a fact that has probably contributed to his fashion leadership. Still, he has managed to walk another kind of line. He has made Balenciaga a global brand — through image, accessories, and an imaginative expansion of lower-priced lines such as knits and trousers. Last week, Ghesquiere was in Milan to open a new Balenciaga shop. Another one is set to open later this year in Los Angeles. Yesterday, I sat down with Ghesquiere in the Balenciaga offices in Paris to talk about fashion, multiculturalism, and the influence of designers in a fast-changing world.

headline: Cop Shot
text: What does a fatal shoot-out look like?

headline: Weekend Project: Steve Jobs’s Other Thing
text: I’m not so ambitious this weekend, just too tapped out from all the iPhone folderol this week.

headline: The End of the Bargain Era?
text: The Supreme Court ruling that will give producers more power to dictate retail prices and to restrict the flexibility of discounters is widely seen as bad news for consumers.

headline: Foreign Exchange
text: An all-American family in Wisconsin takes in a foreign exchange student as a way to bolster their geeky son's popularity.

headline: City Pools Are Open for the Summer
text: New York City’s 52 outdoor swimming pools opened today for the summer season. The pools will remain open 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. seven days a week, through Labor Day.

headline: Weekend Gem: Ode to the Nokia Ringtone
text: Critics have suggested that we here at Bits global headquarters need to let our hair down a bit more.

headline: Hot-Dog Champion Is Here. How’s His Bite?
text: UPDATE, 6:05 p.m.

headline: ‘Glacier Girl’ Still Hasn’t Made It to Britain
text: A week ago, you may recall, Glacier Girl, a World War II P-38 fighter lovingly restored to airworthiness after 50 years buried in ice in Greenland, took off from New Jersey in the hope of finally finishing the plane’s interrupted 1942 mission to reach Britain.

headline: Dark Days for Unbiased Journalism
text: Paul Krugman responds to readers’ comments on his June 29 column, “The Murdoch Factor.”

headline: The Lo Duca Imbroglio
text: It was December 2005, a few days after Paul Lo Duca joined the Mets in a trade with the Marlins, and we were sitting in the lobby of a Manhattan hotel. We spent about 45 minutes that morning talking for an article about him that would be published a few days later, and I remember coming away from the interview thinking that he would be a great addition to the clubhouse.

headline: After Bomb Is Defused in London, New York Tightens Security
text: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said he had ordered his department to step up its antiterrorism activities in New York, after the police in London announced that they had defused a car bomb and closed down major thoroughfares across the city.Mr. Kelly said that he had ordered a platoon of extra officers to patrol in the subway system through this evening’s rush and had increased the number of vehicle checkpoints, especially in Manhattan, at least through the weekend. He also ordered special teams of uniformed officers to surge into densely filled and popular places around the city — like Times Square, Herald Square, Columbus Circle and the theater district, in Manhattan, and nightclubs that draw large crowds in the other boroughs.

headline: A Spy’s Lair?
text: A Florida millionaire with alleged (but apparently unproven) ties to the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency is auctioning off his private island in the Bahamas. Known as Leaf Cay, the 15-acre island includes 19 buildings, a desalination plant, a freezer building, an airstrip and, best of all, a radar facility. The opening bid is $12 million (€8.9 million). Read the full story from the Miami Herald here.

headline: Former Top UBS Banker Jumps to Distressed Investing
text: From London, New York Times reporter Julia Werdigier sends word to DealBook on the new venture from UBS‘s former co-head of investment banking.

headline: City Says 83% of Restaurants Have Curbed Trans Fat
text: New York City health officials are beaming about their efforts to get restaurants to stop using oils that contain trans fat, announcing today that as of June 1, 83 percent of the city’s restaurants had eliminated the artery-clogging frying medium.

headline: Win a Trip: Leana's Reflections
text: Leana Wen, who traveled with Nicholas D. Kristof in Africa, looks back on her journey.

headline: Our Builder Speaks Out (Sort of)
text: Alison and I have no problem being criticized for our choices about what our house should look like on the outside (“gigantic and ugly,” Danielle, or how we have chosen to design the interior (“Oh my … your kitchen is full of flaws,” Kimberly Brag said.)

headline: Plugging the U-20s (Updated)
text: It’s not easy being the opening platter in an Argentine goal feast, so let’s avert our eyes and gaze northward instead. Why, you ask? Because the U.S. Under-20 Men’s National Team is competing at the World Youth Championship in Canada.

headline: Ring-Tone Politics
text: Seven different ring tones, and only one cellphone. Oh, to be an Obama supporter!

headline: No Live Commentary Saturday — but Sunday Is Another Matter
text: Well, we did say we’d offer live updates on selected matches, didn’t we?Sadly, lives, wives and offspring need to be nurtured and fed, so we won’t be covering Saturday’s Group A matches (Bolivia-Uruguay and Venezuela-Peru).

headline: So What’s a Little Line Rage Between iPhone Maniacs?
text: By noon today outside the Apple Store at a pleasant outdoor mall in Corte Madera, 20 minutes north of San Francisco, a touch of line rage had already set in. When five big young guys sauntered up to the line where 90 of us had already been standing — some since 6 a.m. yesterday morning — they settled down into camping chairs directly in front of me that had been set up for them earlier by a friend who happened to be an Apple employee.

headline: Let’s Play the Blame Game
Will Subprime Rules Bring Lower Prices?
text: During the Great Depression, Congress and the Federal Reserve imposed rules to limit margin borrowing in the stock market. They thought excessive speculation in the 1920s had led to the crash, and perhaps they were right. By then, however, there was little need for the rules because there was little appetite for speculation.

headline: Answers from the Transportation Commissioner, Part 5
text: The city’s new transportation commissioner, Janette Sadik-Khan, answered questions from City Room readers through the week. Here is her final set of responses; her first, second, third and fourth sets of responses were posted earlier this week. In this round, she focuses on bikes, buses, light rail and one-way streets.Bike Parking

headline: Trans-Atlantic Voyages by Cruise Ship or Freighter
text: Where can I find information on passenger or merchant ships from France, or a neighboring country, to New York in August or early September?

headline: The Dangers of Sitting in Line
text: Waiting for an iPhone isn’t all fun and games. John F. Street, the Philadelphia mayor, according to an Associated Press story, was waiting in line when he was approached by a citizen:

headline: IPhone: It’s Time
text: It’s just after 6 in New York, and just look at that shiny ball and all the confetti… oh wait, wrong event. The latest iPhone updates:

headline: Riddle Me This
text: Update: Pop Quiz Answers

headline: Adu Looking for Some Northern Exposure
text: The Irish writer James Joyce is alleged to have said that “the pun is mightier than the sword.” But even if he did, Joyce could never anticipated that the pun might be mightier than Freddy Adu’s cultured left foot.

headline: Vermont vs. New Hampshire: The Final Score
text: Whenever The Lede is asked whether he prefers Vermont or New Hampshire, he always answers “yes.” But it seems that plenty of other people’s opinions come down strongly on one side of the Connecticut River or the other. And as Katie Zezima of The New York Times wrote in this morning’s paper, New England’s decidedly unidentical twins have been trying in recent weeks to settle once and for all the age-old question of which is the superior quaint, mountainous, vaguely wedge-shaped, lightly populated northeastern state, by means of an Internet straw poll.

headline: Amid iPhone Buzz, AT&T Does a Deal
text: For 1.7 million cellphone users, getting an iPhone just got a little bit easier.

headline: Vows: Alexandra and Jeffrey
text: Alexandra de Suze and Jeffrey Bratcher were introduced by a mutual friend.

headline: Introducing Auto Ego
text: This weekend you’ll find the debut of a new feature in the Automobiles section called Auto Ego. It’s been in the works for a while, and I’m afraid to say that I still don’t have a tidy pitch for what it is. But while reading the comments under my last post, I came across one from Iowagirl that seemed like a fine place to start:

headline: Campaign Cash: Last Call
text: Campaign wordsmiths have been hard at work finding just the right pitch to nudge, cajole and smooth-talk their supporters into sending in a contribution before tomorrow’s midnight fund-raising deadline. In a flurry of e-mails and Web site messages, the campaigns have been trying out increasingly novel pleas.

headline: Paris is Flooding
text: One of the few concessions the Paris men’s collections have offered to spring is the cropped trouser. Otherwise the clothes look wintry. Flood pants appeared at John Galliano (low-slung, often over printed leggings), Comme des Garcons and Junya Watanabe. Shades of Thom Browne? Maybe. Does it matter?

headline: IPhone: It’s Time — West Coast Edition
text: 8:15 p.m. (5:15 local time) John Markoff, Times reporter, reports seeing about 200 in line at the Palo Alto store and about the same number in Emeryville. He is trying to figure out how many iPhones will be sold opening weekend. Before he finishes, he wanders down to the San Francisco Apple store.

headline: One Dancer and 5 Solos in Studies of Character
text: A solo show is a tricky thing, as demonstrated by Tricia Brouk in “Dining Alone,” which features the dancer in five solos “tied together by a narrative feast,” the press material says. (This refers to the show’s cafe setting and insipid interludes performed by four actors.) The program, performed on Thursday night at Dance Theater Workshop and directed by Joe Ricci, is more of a light snack.

headline: A Shakespeare Company Will Grow
text: Shakespeare & Company, the 30-year-old theater company based in Lenox, Mass., announced plans yesterday to transform part of a building on its 33-acre campus into a $5 million arts complex that will include a 150-seat theater, rehearsal spaces and costume and set design shops. The complex, scheduled to be ready by spring 2008, will be used by the company and by other theaters and groups that will be able to rent space. The company, which produces plays like "Antony and Cleopatra," bought 63 acres in 1999 for $3.5 million and sold about half of that property in 2005 for $3.9 million. Plans are still in the works to build a version of the Rose Playhouse, a theater that was active in London during the Renaissance.

headline: Little America
text: Providence, R.I.

headline: Defense and Rivera Get Credit for Saving Yankees
text: In the strange new world these Yankees inhabit, where another defeat always seems around the next bend in the road, even a game with the Oakland Athletics in the dwindling days of June becomes a contest of import.

headline: A Landmark Ruling on Race and the Schools (8 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A 7th-Place Finish Worldwide, Aided by an Educated Guess
text: Jeanne and Joseph Portale of Toms River, N.J., were the leading United States pair in the World Wide Bridge Contest on June 1. They finished seventh in the world with 70.34 percent.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A music review on Tuesday about the alto saxophonist Rudresh Mahanthappa and the pianist Vijay Iyer, at the Rubin Museum in a JVC Jazz Festival concert, misidentified the people for whom Mr. Iyer wrote the ballad “Remembrance,” which was performed. Although Mr. Iyer dedicated the performance to the pianist Andrew Hill, he wrote the piece as a tribute to his grandparents, not for Mr. Hill.

headline: Old Drugs In, New Ones Out
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Can an antipsychotic drug from the 1950s be paired with a 1980s antibiotic to shrink 21st-century tumors? Might an anticlotting drug help a steroid relieve arthritis? How about a cholesterol treatment and a pain reliever teaming up to tame diabetes?

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about BlackRock’s acquisition of the “fund of funds” business of the Quellos Group misstated the total amount of assets that Quellos manages. It is $20 billion, not $200 billion.

headline: In Shift, Justices Agree to Review Detainees’ Case
text: The United States Supreme Court reversed course yesterday and agreed to hear claims of Guantánamo detainees that they had a right to challenge their detention in American courts.

headline: Foxy Brown a No-Show
text: A woman charged with assaulting and robbing the rapper Foxy Brown was released from jail after Ms. Brown failed to appear before a grand jury to testify against her, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Roshawn Anthony, 23, was released from Rikers Island on her own recognizance Thursday but still faces charges of robbery, assault and grand larceny in the alleged attack last Saturday, a spokesman for the Brooklyn district attorney's office said. Police say she and three other people robbed Ms. Brown of a Louis Vuitton bag, $500 in cash and credit cards in the East New York section of Brooklyn. Ms. Anthony, who has denied the charges, is scheduled to return to court on Aug. 9.

headline: Joel Siegel, 63, Movie Critic Who Instructed and Amused, Dies
text: Joel Siegel, the longtime film critic for ABC News whose pithy reviews could capture the essence of a new film in a few words without giving too much away, died yesterday in New York. He was 63.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,563 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the trial of Conrad M. Black misstated the makeup of the jury. It has 11 women and 4 men, not 6 women and 6 men.

headline: Manhattanites Face Driving Fee on the Way Out
text: In promoting his sweeping traffic reduction plan, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his aides have stressed one provision: drivers who enter Manhattan below 86th Street would be charged an $8 fee.

headline: N.F.L. Pulls the Plug on Its League in Europe
text: National Football League officials bet in the early 1990s that the world — or at least North America and Europe — would embrace a brand of football that was of lesser quality than the one the league’s 32 teams play in the United States.

headline: Office That Sought Forbidden Iraqi Weapons Is Shut Down
text: The Security Council voted to shut down the United Nations units that had searched for biological, chemical and nuclear weapons in Iraq thought to have been stockpiled by Saddam Hussein. The last inspectors left Iraq in March 2003, shortly before the United States-led invasion that also ended up discovering no banned weapons in the country. The resolution yesterday directed Secretary General Ban Ki-moon to ensure that delicate proliferation information be kept under strict control and that all unspent money, estimated at $60 million, be transferred to the Iraqi government for its development fund. Zalmay Khalilzad, the American ambassador, said, “There is no longer any reason to believe significant quantities of Saddam-era weapons of mass destruction remain undiscovered in Iraq.”

headline: The Homes May Be Solid, but the Loans Look Shaky
text: AS the American housing market has slowed, innovations in mortgage financing that Wall Street pioneered in recent years have come to the fore, with some indications that the structures are shaky.

headline: Plot Thickens in a Tom Cruise Film, Long Before the Cameras Begin to Roll
text: LOS ANGELES, June 29 — When the director Bryan Singer decided to cast Tom Cruise as Col. Claus Schenk von Stauffenberg, the German Army officer who tried to blow up Hitler toward the end of World War II, he thought he had dealt with all the possible pitfalls.

headline: Nigeria: President Says He’s Worth $5 Million
text: Previous presidents of this vast and often troubled nation are believed to have pocketed billions of dollars from the country’s vast oil wealth. In an effort to turn a page on a reputation for entrenched government corruption, Nigeria’s new president, Umaru Yar’Adua, has taken the unusual step of declaring his net worth as he begins his four-year term. In papers made public yesterday, Mr. Yar’Adua, a former chemistry teacher, said he had about $5 million in assets, most of it inherited from family members. Nigerian law requires that politicians disclose their assets to the government, but they are not required to make the information public. Mr. Yar’Adua said through a spokesman that he hoped to set an example of transparency in his administration.

headline: Some Bloggers Blur Some Lines
text: IF the reaction is anything to go by, the decision by the blog-advertising network Federated Media to deploy its writers to produce marketing copy for Microsoft and Cisco Systems may have set back by a notch or two the efforts of professional bloggers to gain credibility.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption yesterday with a front-page article about a scientific advance in the effort to create synthetic life forms misidentified the scientist pictured. He is J. Craig Venter, who directs the institute that made the breakthrough, not Hamilton Smith, a biologist who worked on the project. The article also misstated the educational affiliation of George Church, a biologist who commented on the research. He is at Harvard Medical School, not M.I.T.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A sports article in some copies yesterday about the Yankees-Orioles game, which was suspended in the eighth inning because of rain after the Yankees had taken an 8-6 lead, referred incorrectly to Major League Baseball’s rule about handling games that are called after the visiting team takes a lead but before the home team has had a chance to bat again. It has been in place since the beginning of the 1980 season; it was not instituted through a rule change before this season. (Yankees Manager Joe Torre mistakenly suggested that his team had benefited because of the recent rule change, but that policy governs the handling of suspended games that are tied.)

headline: Saving Wildlife in Zambia, and Raising Human Prospects
text: MPIKA, Zambia

headline: Ivory Coast Premier Survives Attack on His Plane in a Rebel Area
text: DAKAR, Senegal, June 29 — A plane carrying Ivory Coast’s prime minister came under heavy fire as it landed in the northern rebel stronghold of Bouaké on Friday, witnesses said.

headline: When Is Enough Enough?
text: Chances are you didn’t hear it, but on Thursday night Senator Hillary Clinton said, “If H.I.V./AIDS were the leading cause of death of white women between the ages of 25 and 34, there would be an outraged outcry in this country.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
London Finds Linked Bombs, a Qaeda Tactic
text: LONDON, June 29 — London was gripped by a terrorist threat on Friday when the police found two Mercedes sedans packed with gasoline, nails and gas canisters that had been parked near Piccadilly Circus in the bustling West End entertainment district.

headline: Newark’s Mayor, in Office a Year, Says Major City Job Cuts Are Likely
text: NEWARK, June 29  In a news conference heralding the anniversary of his inauguration on Sunday, Mayor Cory A. Booker warned on Friday that the city’s looming fiscal crisis could lead to substantial layoffs, shaving as many as one in five people from the 5,000-worker municipal payroll this year.

headline: Online Cliffhangers: You Choose the Cliff
text: Last September, just as the mysterious video diarist Lonelygirl15 was absorbing all the attention people could spare for the emerging medium of online video, Brad Winderbaum and Diahnna Nicole Baxter, two struggling show-business entrepreneurs, were peddling their own Web thriller with mixed results.

headline: For an Everyman, a Test of Mettle in Montana
text: RAPELJE, Mont., June 24 — It was after high noon in Montana’s broad, central expanse, and from my vantage point, perched on the seat of a mountain bike, I could see two riders ahead turning from a dusty cow path onto pavement and the final leg of their brutal first lap.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (TMC) DAVE CHAPPELLE’S BLOCK PARTY (2006) “Concert film” hardly begins to describe this movie, directed by Michel Gondry and shot in 2004 on a street in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, above, and in Mr. Chappelle’s hometown in Ohio. It includes appearances by stars like Kanye West, Mos Def, the Roots, Wyclef Jean and Lauryn Hill, along with performances, musical and otherwise, by Mr. Chappelle. Manohla Dargis of The New York Times called it “a tantalizing sketch-portrait of the artist amid an outpouring of hard beats and soul.”

headline: Once Tie Broken, Old Rules in Play
text: Although Yankees Manager Joe Torre might have been confused about the exact parameters of Major League Baseball’s suspended-game policy after Thursday’s game in Baltimore, he praised the new rule before last night’s game.

headline: For President Bush, a Reversal of Fortune on His Political Capital
text: WASHINGTON, June 29 — After a string of Republican defections this week — on Iraq, immigration and domestic eavesdropping — President Bush enters the final 18 months of his presidency in danger of losing control over a party that once marched in lockstep with him.

headline: New Rooms With Views, Some Dark and Chilling
text: “Songs are like rooms,” Rickie Lee Jones said a few tunes into her sold-out show at Fillmore New York (formerly Irving Plaza) on Thursday night. “We all go in and look around, and then we go out again.” She mused a bit longer on the idea, paused, then posed a related question: “So what do you make of this material — are you all right in it?”

headline: Disability, the Insurance That Is Often Sadly Overlooked
text: It took just 17 days for Cindy Wrenn to realize that her disability insurance premium was not just another drain on her checking account. One-third of American workers are likely to be disabled for an extended period, and she became one of them when she had a stroke and brain aneurysm at age 28.

headline: Chief Steps Down, and Commerce Bank Agrees to End Business Deals With His Family
text: At investor meetings just two weeks ago, Vernon W. Hill II seemed upbeat about the prospects for Commerce Bancorp, the company he founded nearly 35 years ago — as well as his own.

headline: Out the Door, but Keeping It Open
text: IN a tight labor market like this one, making sure you handle departing workers well is good for business — and your remaining employees — HR magazine writes.

headline: One-Man Bandwagon Beats Drum for Bloomberg ’08
text: There are no campaign offices or computers or phones. No maps of Iowa and New Hampshire. No donors or interns. And not an ounce of stale coffee — though, in the case of a billionaire candidate, the coffee would probably be fresh and premium blend.

headline: Bear Stearns Shakes Up Funds Unit
text: Bear Stearns moved quickly yesterday to replace a senior executive whose unit ran two hedge funds that nearly collapsed this month because of aggressive bets on mortgage securities.

headline: Columbia Adds an Architect
text: Columbia University said yesterday that it had selected the architectural firm Davis Brody Bond Aedas to work with Renzo Piano Building Workshop (architects of the new headquarters of The New York Times) in the first phase of the university's proposed $7 billion expansion in Manhattanville, also known as West Harlem. The site of the proposed expansion is a 17-acre area just north of Columbia's campus in Morningside Heights. Most of the construction in the first phase will take place in the area bounded by 125th Street, on the south and 130th Street on the north, between 12th Avenue and Broadway, and includes three new buildings: a science center, a graduate school of business and a mixed-use facility. The university's expansion plans, first announced in 2003, are opposed by some in the affected area and are currently under review by the city.

headline: The Break-In That History Forgot
text: Seattle

headline: Neutrality in Expansion at Columbia Is Questioned
text: A state judge has questioned the independence of a state agency that is working with Columbia University to determine whether to condemn private property so that the university can expand.

headline: Abraham Klausner, 92, Dies; Aided Holocaust Survivors
text: Rabbi Abraham J. Klausner, a Jewish chaplain in the United States Army who arrived at the Dachau concentration camp a few days after its liberation in 1945 and a strong voice for thousands of Holocaust survivors who remained in displaced persons camps for years after the war, died on Thursday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 92.

headline: The Grand Collapse
text: The defeat of immigration reform in the Senate this week was appalling, not so much because an ambitious bill died, but because of how stubbornly, to the bitter end, the process remained disconnected from reality. The bill crumpled on the Senate floor on Thursday in a procedural vote, with two-thirds of Republicans swarming to kill it. They shrouded their act with the same rhetorical distortions and ritual incantations  death to amnesty!  that have polluted the debate all along.

headline: Kiwis Falter, With ‘People and Sails Going Everywhere’
text: VALENCIA, Spain, June 29  If the goal Friday was to have another dramatic America’s Cup match, then Alinghi and Emirates Team New Zealand succeeded. Team New Zealand held the early lead, but ended up with a tough loss to the soundtrack of its shredding spinnaker.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about growing urbanization included incorrect information from a report by the United Nations Population Fund for the number of Chinese cities expected to have the largest populations over the next decade. Of the 139 cities that had more than 750,000 residents in 2005, nine are projected to have more than 5 million people in 2015; China will not have, as the report said, 83 cities of more than 750,000 within a decade, with six of those having more than 5 million inhabitants.

headline: Jankovic Advances at Wimbledon
text: WIMBLEDON, England, June 29 — Jelena Jankovic, the world’s third-ranked women’s tennis player, carries little of the distant coolness of No. 1 Justine Henin and none of the socialite aura of No. 2 Maria Sharapova. She seems perfectly minted as a fan-friendly star, with a humble Serbian background and a smile-first personality.

headline: China Vows Food-Safety Changes
text: GUANGZHOU, China, June 29 — A day after regulators in the United States placed a partial ban on imports of certain types of seafood from China, the Chinese government promised Friday to cooperate in tackling its food safety problems but urged a quick resolution.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An art review in Weekend on June 1 about “182nd Annual: An Exhibition of Contemporary American Art,” at the National Academy Museum on Fifth Avenue at 89th Street, referred incompletely to a show at the museum earlier this year, which was cited as an example of shows the academy has been mounting to emphasize its relevance. Although the show, “High Times, Hard Times: New York Painting 1967-1975,” was exhibited at the academy, it was a traveling exhibition organized by Independent Curators International.

headline: Money, Not Race, Fuels New Push to Buoy Schools
text: For several years, two lawyers intent on helping black children do as well in school as white children had a kind of roadshow: Michael A. Rebell would describe the recent successes of state-court litigation, forcing more financing for poor children’s schools, as a matter of basic equity. But James Ryan would argue that integration was the best approach.

headline: May Spending by Consumers Matched Pace Set in April
text: Americans spent less than forecast in May and the Federal Reserve’s preferred inflation gauge cooled, signs that a consumer slowdown is restraining price pressures.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about growing urbanization included incorrect information from a report by the United Nations Population Fund for the number of Chinese cities expected to have the largest populations over the next decade. Of the 139 cities that had more than 750,000 residents in 2005, nine are projected to have more than 5 million people in 2015; China will not have, as the report said, 83 cities of more than 750,000 within a decade, with six of those having more than 5 million inhabitants. (Go to Article)

headline: Farewell, ‘Studio 60’
text: "Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip," the highly anticipated drama from Aaron Sorkin that NBC did not renew for a second season because of disappointing ratings, concluded its run Thursday, attracting 4.2 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. The finale won its 10 p.m. time slot among adults 18 to 49, just ahead of CBS's repeat of "Shark," which drew a larger total audience of 7.9 million viewers. Fox led the night over all and had its sixth consecutive Thursday night victory in the 18-to-49 demographic. Fox's game show "Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?" finished first in the 8 p.m. hour, with 9.1 million viewers, while the one-hour results edition of "So You Think You Can Dance" led at 9 with 9.6 million. NBC and CBS shared second place in the 18-to-49 set, although CBS fared better in total viewers with the help of a "CSI" rerun at 9 (9.8 million). ABC finished fourth over all.

headline: Iranian Leader’s Priorities (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Blake Unable to Advance Past 3rd Round, Again
text: WIMBLEDON, England, June 29 — Roger Federer, the world’s best tennis player, was holding court at Center Court, but gusts of chaos to the Wimbledon brackets were swirling on the courts around him at the All England Club. More than anything, the ups and downs of American tennis were on simultaneous display.

headline: Brooklyn, Your New Floating Swimming Pool Is Almost Ready Now
text: The barge was a buzz of activity. Crews were halfway done with a half-dozen projects. Siding was being put on locker rooms. A checkerboard of paving tiles was being laid out on the deck. Metal panels still had to be hung from the railings. In the center of it all, a large aquamarine pool glimmered, tantalizing everybody on board.

headline: Finding Bliss in a Tub of Fizzy Water
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 25 — Judd K. Roth discovered the naturally fizzy joys of mineral bathing at the precocious age of 12, tagging along with his parents when they came here to see the horse races. The bathhouses had age requirements, but he sneaked in, passing for a teenager, for an early-morning soak.

headline: It’s Summer, and These Moves Are Hot
text: DURHAM, N.C., June 29 — The notion that dance is about both sex and sexiness is a popular one. Certainly these seem the common factors linking all five works on the program presented by the Hubbard Street Dance Chicago at the American Dance Festival here on Thursday night. Each was enthusiastically cheered. Two were performed in various types of underwear. All focused on male-female couplings.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Columbia Adds an Architect

headline: Congestion Pricing (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: British Hunt for Bomb Suspects
text: LONDON, June 30 — As London braced for a weekend of high-profile public events, the British police stepped up foot patrols on Saturday and hunted for suspects linked to what appeared to be a double car-bombing plot modeled on terrorist tactics in Iraq.

headline: Streisand Honored
text: Barbra Streisand received France's highest civilian honor two days after performing her first concert in the country, BBC News reported yesterday. President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, with Ms. Streisand, presented her with the Legion of Honor at the Élysée Palace in Paris. "You are the America that we love," Mr. Sarkozy said. Guests at the ceremony included the veteran singer Charles Aznavour and the actor Alain Delon. Ms. Streisand, 65, was accompanied by her husband, James Brolin, and her son, Jason Gould. She sang at Bercy Stadium in Paris on Tuesday before 10,000 fans, including Mr. Sarkozy's wife, Cecilia. Recent honorary recipients of the Legion of Honor include Clint Eastwood and the Bollywood star Amitabh Bachchan.

headline: China Passes a Sweeping Labor Law
text: BEIJING, June 29 — China’s legislature passed a sweeping new labor law today that strengthens protections for workers across its booming economy, rejecting pleas from foreign investors who argued that the measure would reduce China’s appeal as a low-wage, business-friendly industrial base.

headline: Protests by Native Groups in Canada Close Road and Rail Links
text: OTTAWA, June 29 — Canadian travelers faced road closings and rail shutdowns on Friday as they set out for the Canada Day holiday weekend during nationwide protests by native groups against the Conservative government over several recent disputes about land claims and financing.

headline: Bell Canada Agrees to Buyout Offer
text: OTTAWA, June 30 — Bell Canada’s directors endorsed a privatization offer worth 34.8 billion Canadian dollars ($32.9 billion) from the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan and Providence Equity Partners early today, the company said in a statement. If approved by shareholders, the deal would be Canada’s largest takeover to date, worth about 51.7 billion Canadian dollars after assumption of debt and other factors, and among the largest leveraged buyouts in history.

headline: Subpoena for Advisers on Salaries
text: Towers Perrin, one of the nation’s largest executive pay consulting firms, was subpoenaed yesterday by a House committee after it failed to comply with a request for information about potential conflicts in its compensation consulting business.

headline: Buried Bomb Kills 5 G.I.’s in Baghdad Neighborhood
text: BAGHDAD, June 29 — Five American soldiers were killed when insurgents blew up a huge bomb beneath their convoy and then attacked the soldiers with a hail of gunfire and rocket-propelled grenades, military officials said Friday.

headline: A Mouse’s Grisly Demise
text: The character Farfour, a Mickey Mouse look-alike who preached Islamic domination on "Tomorrow's Pioneers," a Hamas-affiliated children's television show was beaten to death in the final episode Friday, The Associated Press reported. The character was killed by an actor posing as an Israeli official trying to buy Farfour's land. "Farfour was martyred while defending his land," said the show's teenage presenter, adding that the character was murdered "by the killers of children." The show, featuring a giant black-and-white rodent with a high-pitched voice, had attracted attention because the character urged Palestinian children to fight Israel. It was broadcast on Al Aqsa Television, affiliated with Hamas. Israeli officials denounced the show as incendiary and outrageous. It was also opposed by the state-run Palestinian Broadcasting Corporation, which is controlled by Fatah, a rival of Hamas.

headline: Silas H. Rhodes Dies at 91; Built School of Visual Arts
text: Silas H. Rhodes, co-founder of a trade school for cartoonists and illustrators in Manhattan that he built into the School of Visual Arts, one of the nation’s most important colleges for art and design, died on Wednesday at his home in Katonah, N.Y. He was 91.

headline: Smuggling Tunnel Is Found on Arizona-Mexico Border
text: NOGALES, Ariz., June 29 — A smuggling tunnel freshly excavated under the border with Mexico was sealed Friday after a joint raid by United States and Mexican authorities.

headline: Questions About a Governor’s Fall
text: It is extremely disturbing that Don Siegelman, the former governor of Alabama, was hauled off to jail this week. There is reason to believe his prosecution may have been a political hit, intended to take out the state’s most prominent Democrat, a serious charge that has not been adequately investigated. The appeals court that hears his case should demand answers, as should Congress.

headline: Subway Riders Treated Like Cattle? That Would Be an Upgrade
text: In trucks that roll down the great American roads, the ordinary ruminant — that is, your basic cow, sheep or bison — is afforded more space than the average New York subway rider has the faintest prayer of commanding at rush hour. Rhetorical excess? If only. Overcrowding ruins meat, so the industry and federal government have developed standards to reduce stress on the animals, like requiring that they be able to turn freely.

headline: Taliban Spreading, Pakistani President Is Warned
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 28 — The Pakistani president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, was warned this month that Islamic militants and Taliban fighters were rapidly spreading beyond the country’s lawless tribal areas and that without “swift and decisive action,” the growing militancy could engulf the rest of the country.

headline: Failure of Senate Immigration Bill Can Be Lesson for Congress, Experts Say
text: WASHINGTON, June 29 — Congress can learn important lessons from the demise of the Senate immigration bill, and those lessons should inform future efforts to tackle the issue, experts on immigration said on Friday.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A television review on Tuesday about “The Great Inca Rebellion,” on PBS, misidentified the language spoken by a majority of South Americans. While Spanish is more widespread geographically, a small majority of the continent speaks Portuguese  not Spanish  because of Brazil’s large population.

headline: Variations on a Theme: Explore the Differences in What Policies Offer
text: Disability insurance can stave off financial calamity, but policies vary significantly. Here are a few questions to ask about coverage:

headline: Gave Up Sleep and Maybe a First-Born, but at Least I Have an iPhone
text: Apple wanted a spectacle when the iPhone went on sale, and it got just that.

headline: Net Worth Can’t Measure Values
text: I HAVE often wondered what it would be like to be fantastically wealthy.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A review on Page 6 of the Book Review this weekend misstates part of the title of the book by Chris Mooney. As noted in the table of contents and in the bibliographical note, it is “Storm World,” not “Warning.”

headline: East Timor Votes Again, but Democracy Has Not Bred Prosperity
text: DILI, East Timor, June 29 — During the past week, convoys of vans and trucks have wound through the streets of this tiny seaside capital loaded with chanting, cheering men and women. When people threw rocks at them, they ducked.

headline: Splashing the Art World With Anger and Questions
text: Until the pranks turned ugly, it was heartening to follow the dust-up between a bunch of street artists and their nemesis or nemeses, identity unknown. As The New York Times reported this week, for some time works of stenciled graffiti art and wheat-pasted posters slapped onto walls in Brooklyn and Lower Manhattan have been splashed with paint and scrawled with messages of protest.

headline: Mets Sweep Phillies in Doubleheader
text: PHILADELPHIA, June 29 — As if the Mets needed another incentive to defeat the Phillies in this weekend’s four-game series.

headline: iPhone Spin Goes Round and Round
text: By Wednesday morning, the iPhone tom-toms were beating in earnest.

headline: A Big Early Climb Turns Into a Loss
text: Stocks fell yesterday, erasing a 102-point rally in the Dow Jones industrial average, after bomb scares swept London and concern grew that banks face more losses from subprime loans.

headline: Immigrants Work On as Bill Dies and Views Divide
text: SAN DIEGO, June 29 — Ediberto Perez pedaled his bicycle out of a canyon shantytown in this border city’s northern outskirts where he and other migrant workers scratch out a living.

headline: Pool Is Dominant Game During a Stormy Open
text: SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., June 29  When the thunder clapped and the lightning flashed, the 12-year-old Alexis Thompson traded in her golf clubs for a pool cue.

headline: After Hours, in Florence (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Oil Giant Sees Some Strains in the System
text: As chairman and chief executive of ConocoPhillips, James J. Mulva is steering the third-largest American integrated energy company at a time of great profit but also growing concern over global warming and rising gasoline prices and questions as to whether Big Oil is doing enough to cope with either challenge.

headline: Mets Fans Find Their Usual Seats in Philadelphia
text: Philadelphia

headline: Immigrants Work On as Bill Dies and Views Divide
text: SAN DIEGO, June 29 — Ediberto Perez pedaled his bicycle out of a canyon shantytown in this border city’s northern outskirts where he and other migrant workers scratch out a living.

headline: Lebanese Troops Kill 2 Palestinian Protesters and Wound 30
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 29 — Lebanese Army troops opened fire on Friday at Palestinian demonstrators trying to march back to their besieged refugee camp in northern Lebanon, killing two and wounding at least 30 others, Palestinian officials and witnesses said.

headline: Mr. Bush Gets Another Look Into Mr. Putin’s Eyes
text: President Bush’s June 2001 declaration that he had looked Russia’s Vladimir Putin in the eye and “was able to get a sense of his soul” was greeted with bemusement and also relief. The cowboy president wasn’t, after all, going to start another cold war. But that sudden effusiveness wasn’t as sudden as it appeared.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Tuesday about a presentation of New York City’s “congestion pricing” proposal to federal transportation officials in Washington gave an erroneous figure in some copies for the amount of federal money being sought to finance the proposal. It is $536.9 million, not $539 million.

headline: U.S. Account of Afghan Deaths at Odds With Head of Rights Group
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 29 — Four civilians were killed early Friday by American and Afghan forces in eastern Afghanistan, according to the leader of a small human rights group who gave an account of the deaths entirely at odds with that of the United States-led coalition.

headline: Small Schools Are Ahead in Graduation
text: Graduation rates at 47 new small public high schools that have opened since 2002 are substantially higher than the citywide average, an indication that the Bloomberg administration’s decision to break up many large failing high schools has achieved some early success.

headline: Little Odessa? Maybe Not, but Bush-Putin Talks Lend This Resort a Russian Flavor
text: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., June 29 — For the first time in its 39-year history, the Clam Shack has translated its menu of fried clams and lobster rolls into Russian.

headline: Delphi Workers Accept Pay Cuts
text: DETROIT, June 29 — A year ago, members of the United Automobile Workers union who gathered in Las Vegas brashly reaffirmed their fortitude with Bruce Springsteen’s rebellious lyrics, “No retreat, baby, no surrender.”

headline: Backers of the Buyout Boom Seem to Be Backing Out
text: THE private equity business hit bumps. A deal was struck for a possible Dow Jones sale, and the Supreme Court struck down a longstanding rule on product pricing.

headline: Taking the Earnest and Chatty Approach to Strauss and Liszt
text: Not for nothing has the New York Philharmonic placed its Summertime Classics series — now in its fourth year — in Bramwell Tovey’s hands. Part M.C., all enthusiasm, he talks about the music, then plunges into it with the genuine excitement of a small boy attacking a tray of fingerpaints. The orchestra seems vaguely charmed. Much sound and fury results.

headline: Free Agents’ Top Skill: Moving Big Names
text: More than 130 players will spill into the N.B.A.’s free-agent market after the clock strikes midnight tonight. That makes at least 130 new pawns in the N.B.A.’s real off-season game: the hunt for Kevin Garnett.

headline: How a Fan of Comic Books Transformed Himself Into a Hollywood Player
text: LOS ANGELES, June 29 — Drink in hand, attaboys coming at him from every direction, Tom DeSanto was living the fanboy dream.

headline: Red, White and Blue Celebration for an American Born in Berlin
text: Lukas Foss, who turns 85 in August, has in him a little of both the American dream and the American reality. He lived until 15 as a German in Berlin but has since been just about as American as an American can be. Mr. Foss was recognized at the Rose Theater at Lincoln Center on Thursday night. The music was mostly his, with Aaron Copland’s “Old American Songs” added in.

headline: Vanishing of Diamonds and Dealer Roils District
text: A diamond dealer accused by dozens of other dealers in Manhattan’s wholesale diamond district of swindling them out of $3 million worth of stones has fled the country, apparently to Israel, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

headline: Staten Island Man Is Charged in Home Storage of Chemicals
text: A Staten Island man with a conviction for wire fraud was charged yesterday with reckless endangerment after law enforcement authorities found more than 2,000 pounds of chemicals in his home and in a nearby storage locker during a nighttime raid, officials said.

headline: M.T.A. Web Site Went Dark, Too
text: When the power went out in a broad swath of the Upper East Side and the Bronx on Wednesday, a record number of commuters turned to the Internet to learn if their subway lines or commuter trains were running. But the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s Web site provided no help.

headline: Ready or Not (for Many, It’s ‘Not’), New Noise Code Is Taking Effect
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has called it “the first comprehensive overhaul of the New York City Noise Code in 30 years.” But for all the fanfare, it is sneaking up quietly, on a city largely unprepared.

headline: Courage Without the Uniform
text: PORTLAND, Ore.

headline: Israel’s Deal Over Rape Charges Is Criticized as President Resigns
text: JERUSALEM, June 29 — Israel’s disgraced president, Moshe Katsav, submitted his resignation to Parliament on Friday morning amid fierce public criticism over the deal by which rape charges against him were dropped in exchange for an admission of guilt for lesser offenses.

headline: Jankovic Stays Around, but Not Without a Fight
text: WIMBLEDON, England, June 29  Jelena Jankovic, ranked No. 3 in the world, carries little of the distant coolness of the top-ranked Justine Henin and none of the socialite aura of No. 2 Maria Sharapova. She seems perfectly minted as a fan-friendly star, with a humble Serbian background and a smile-first personality.

headline: Knicks Add Randolph and Hope for the Best
text: Zach Randolph will pull on a Knicks jersey, No. 50, on Monday, and will spend every day thereafter getting fitted for a new image under the bright lights of the big city.

headline: Heaven Is Above Manhattan, and the Dress Code Is Relaxed
text: MY flight to the rooftops of Manhattan began on a summery evening when I was denied admission to Hell. Like its Biblical namesake, the place I call Hell is below ground level: you have to take three steps down from the sidewalk to enter. Appointed with red walls and staffed by waitresses in red dresses, the joint literally brims with smoke, fire, alcohol, dance music and other manifestations of sin.

headline: Jeter Sees It’s Time That He Speaks Up
text: Derek Jeter of the Yankees adheres strictly to the baseball code that anything that is said or seen in the clubhouse should stay in the clubhouse. Jeter stresses that he sees no merit in discussing what the Yankees say or do after reporters leave the clubhouse and the doors close.

headline: U.S. Tightens Rules on Subprime Mortgages
text: Federal banking regulators set final rules on subprime mortgages yesterday, turning aside banking industry efforts to weaken them.

headline: Web Space Where Religion and Social Networking Meet
text: Caitlin Todd enjoys making friends on social networking Web sites, but is turned off by content that she believes is inappropriate on a number of popular pages.

headline: Another Argentine Hopes to Win a U.S. Open Title
text: EAST MEADOW, N.Y., June 29  Eduardo Romero stood ready with his driver on the first tee box Friday morning, wearing a smile and bobbing his head to the music coming from a nearby tent.

headline: Commission on Veterans’ Care Recommends Measures to Improve Treatment at Home
text: WASHINGTON, June 29 — The presidential commission investigating problems in health care for military personnel wounded in Iraq and Afghanistan held its final hearing Friday, and focused on problems with moving patients through various stages of aid, from Defense Department hospitals to those run by the Veterans Administration or private health care, to home care and to jobs.

headline: Grand Jury Indicts 4 Accused of Plotting to Blow Up Fuel Tanks at Kennedy
text: A federal grand jury indicted four men yesterday on charges that they plotted to ignite jet fuel tanks and pipelines at Kennedy International Airport.

headline: A World of Scissors and Paper That’s Captured in Photographs
text: Daniel Gordon’s large color photographs, the subject of a solo exhibition at Zach Feuer Gallery in Chelsea, have several things going for them. They operate in the gap between collage and set-up photography, which is a lively place to be at the moment. They benefit from an impressive if not entirely original way with scissors that involves creating figurative tableaus from cut paper and cut-out images that Mr. Gordon then photographs.

headline: As Unrest Rises, China Broadens Workers’ Rights
text: BEIJING, June 29 — China’s legislature passed a sweeping new labor law on Friday that strengthens protections for workers across the booming economy, a response to increasing signs of restiveness among tens of millions of migrant laborers.

headline: Far Beyond Flamenco, a Zest for Rhythms (and Politics)
text: “Resistance with joy.” That’s how Marina Abad described the song “Piedras vs. Tanques” (“Stones Against Tanks”) when Ojos de Brujo played on Thursday at the Highline Ballroom, and the phrase could be this Spanish band’s watchword.

headline: Many Wishes, Many Splashes, and the Fountains at the Met Fill Up
text: Dionysos, standing there in his sandals with his arm over that woman, knows. He spends his days watching everyone in the room and everything they do.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the trial of the former media executive Conrad M. Black misidentified the London paper that Mr. Black’s former company, Hollinger International, once owned. It is The Daily Telegraph, not The Times of London.

headline: Teammates Don’t Mind When Lo Duca Talks the Talk
text: PHILADELPHIA, June 29  The door to Manager Willie Randolph’s office opened at 10:30 a.m., and out stepped catcher Paul Lo Duca, who had just spent nearly 30 minutes speaking about his exasperated outburst the night before.

headline: World View Podcast
text: Greg Winter and Michael Wines discuss Zimbabwe.

headline: Frog-Jumping and Other Ordered Disruptions
text: Andrew Palermo and Taye Diggs became childhood friends at the School of the Arts in Rochester. Mr. Palermo became a modern-dance choreographer and composer; Mr. Diggs went on to act on Broadway and in films and television though he continued to dance. In addition to forming a company, dre.dance, in 2004, the two also teach dance and acting. This is apparently no passing fancy for Mr. Diggs, though he has not given up that other day job.
