headline: For Poor Families, an Added Burden of Too Many Pets
text: SELMER, Tenn. — Phillip Swetman is an accidental owner of 13 dogs. Most, Mr. Swetman said, came from “drive-bys.”

headline: Burial of Suicide Bombers
text: In Afghanistan, a bomber's end comes in a flash of terror and a humble grave.

headline: At Dortmund, Draws All Around, so Kramnik Maintains Lead
text: Vladimir Kramnik of Russia, the world champion, drew his fifth round game against Peter Leko of Hungary and maintained his half-point lead at the Dortmund super tournament with two rounds to play. Trailing him a half-point behind were Viswanathan Anand of India, the world’s top-ranked player, and Evgeny Alekseev of Russia. The official Web site for the tournament is here.

headline: Bell Canada Agrees to Ontario Teachers-Led Buyout
text: Bell Canada‘s directors endorsed a privatization offer worth 35 billion Canadian dollars ($33 billion) from the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan, Providence Equity Partners and Madison Dearborn Partners early Saturday, The New York Times reported.

headline: 2008: McCain’s Campaign Faces Tough Obstacles
text: With this week’s failure of the immigration bill, loathed by many G.O.P. voters and championed by Senator John McCain, talk of trouble for his campaign is picking up volume. Michael Finnegan of The Los Angeles Times examines what one Republican strategist calls a “confluence of forces” working against Mr. McCain:

headline: A worthy cause, and an unsual press conference at Magny-Cours
text: Jean Todt, the Ferrari director, Michael Schumacher, Max Mosley and others have been supporting an interesting medical project for the past several years. Called the Institute for Cerebral and Medullary Disorders, it was founded out of the collaboration of three medical men, Professor Gérard Saillant, an orthopedist and traumatologist and Yves Agid and Olivier Lyon-Caen, neurologists. Saillant has helped heal injured F1 drivers for years, including Schumacher when he broke his leg in 1999 at the British Grand Prix.

headline: Another racing miracle
text: Just three weeks after the most horrendous accident in Formula One in years, when Robert Kubica, escaped injury at the Canadian Grand Prix, the GP2 series support race had its version of a miracle at Magny-Cours on Saturday. On the first lap of the race Ernesto Viso went flying through the air and hit a concrete wall in the car upside down and then spun along the top of the wall for what seemed like forever, before the car landed hard on the other side of the wall and continued its tumble. The race was stopped for an hour as the driver was extracted from his car and sent to hospital. He is reported to be in stable condition, and basically unhurt. Like the accident in Canada, this was another of the kind where it seemed nearly impossible for the driver to have survived. Twice lucky. But it is impossible not to think of Alain Prost’s words before the death of Ayrton Senna in Imola, after Rubens Barrichello had a serious accident on the Friday and Roland Ratzenberger was killed on the Saturday. Prost spoke of his belief in the “law of series.” Thank goodness the sport has never ceased its driver for safety since then.

headline: New Orleans East
text: New York Times reporter Susan Saulny visits the East New Orleans street that her parents hope to come back to by Thanksgiving.

headline: IPhone: Waiting for Ma Bell
text: We are in the first day of the AiP (After iPhone) era. It turns out that Apple had so many iPhones in stock  that there was no reason to wait in line. AT&T stores were not so well stocked, at least according to some accounts.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 1
text: In her news analysis, Sheryl Gay Stolberg, a White House correspondent for The Times, wrote that “a string of Republican defections this week” put the president “in danger of losing control over a party that once marched in lockstep with him.” Each of the defections — on Iraq, immigration and domestic eavesdropping — is featured on this week’s Sunday breakfast menu.

headline: Sad Scenes at an AT&T Wireless Store
text: After spending six hours in line, then another 90 minutes inside the Apple Store in Corte Madera, north of San Francisco, I decided to check out the action at the AT&T Wireless store in nearby San Rafael.

headline: IPhone Good News and Bad News
text: The following video may not be suitable for all viewers. In it, PC World’s correspondent attempts to damage a shiny new iPhone by shaking it in a Ziplock bag full of keys; by keying it deliberately; by dropping it repeatedly onto concrete; and more. Even I was surprised by the results.

headline: A Battery of Questions
text: Joe Nocera, the Saturday columnist for the Times, took Apple to task for designing a cell phone with a battery that cannot be replaced by the consumer.
